name: Reading Terminal Market
categories: Candy Stores, Shopping, Department Stores, Fast Food, Beer, Wine & Spirits, Fruits & Veggies, Chinese, Food, Ice Cream & Frozen Yogurt, Desserts, Seafood, Health Markets, Bagels, Cheese Shops, Shopping Centers, Chocolatiers & Shops, Meat Shops, Public Markets, Food Court, Wineries, Local Flavor, Ethnic Food, Restaurants, Specialty Food, Arts & Entertainment, Juice Bars & Smoothies, Seafood Markets, Farmers Market, Coffee & Tea, Bakeries, Food Stands, Dinner Theater, Sporting Goods, Grocery, Fashion

text: This is such a great place to shop for anything. From antique books to great pastries. There is also a couple quaker stands and one of them, a eat fast diner stand, is great for breakfast...and cheap too!

I love any kind of public market.The French Market in New Orleans, Pike Place Market in Seattle,  Farmer's Market in L.A., I've been to all of them. Reading Market is one of my favorites. It's right in the middle of  Center City, which makes it a very convenient place for tourists to pop into when they're checking out downtown Philly. (There's a broad range of places to eat.)  It's a good example of local color, what with the Amish vendors. And it has some unique features that give it a quirky charm all its own. I liked the old guy who played the piano for tips, for example. And the book stall. And the way market workers wheeled flats of produce right into the middle of the the crowded public areas. (A nice retro touch.) But I especially liked the beer bar set right in the middle of the market. Reading Market is prime people-watching territory, and it was a stroke of genius to put a bar in the middle of it-----the only thing better than people-watching is people-watching while imbibing a tall cold one.

The Reading Terminal Market is absolutely fantastic!!  Pretty much all of your cooking needs can be found here, and it is high quality, fresh, and delicious!  Meats, fish, poultry, spices, cheeses, produce, baked goods, even books - this place has it all.  I always hated grocery shopping, but I love the experience of coming to this market to get all my ingredients.
There are a great variety of places (from crepes to fried clams to Thai to beer) to get breakfast or lunch while you're there as well.  
One of my favorite stands is actually an Amish stand that sells fresh-squeezed juices.  The blends are incredibly tasty without the overly sweetened and processed taste of your usual juices.  I recommend the orange lemonade!

OMG so cool! This was definately one of the highlights.  I much prefer this place to the Ferry Building in SF as things are actually affordable.  Such a great place to stop in and grab almost anything to eat.  The best part was buying jam from the Amish.
My husband and I wandered in here this past fall. Really neat market with a variety of food. Nice atmosphere and friendly people. Check it out!

Oh Reading Terminal Market how I miss you. You can get any kind of food, spice, book and some damn good pancakes from the Amish.
For all of you porkchop eaters out there.........Harry G Ochs Meats is the place to go in the Terminal. They have the BEST stuffed porkchops I have EVER had in my life! The guys at the counter are super friendly, but get there early cause the chops go fast.

Just to bask in the authenticity of this "ode to joy" in downtown Philly is worth the trip. Luckily I get to visit while also seeing my family. We can make it an all day eating affair that borders gastrointestinal danger and delight. The danger is in visiting , buying and eating food from so many different purveyors the delight is also in visiting, buying and eating food from so many purveyors. 
Sausage sandwiches , soul food , Rocco's king of hoagies , seafood, beef, chicken, pork all done in in a rather authentic Philly kinda way.  The Terminal market is one of the gems of the culinary world, blows away the ferry plaza in SF(not for gourmet food but for real food) and delivers great family memories. 
I will never forget the faces that walk by  as I last ate a  sausage sandwich. infact , I will never forget the sausage sandwhich. I heart reading terminal.

I spent many saturdays walking here with my folks to shop and eat breakfast...  I still go every time I'm in Philthy to gets my grub on.

Harry Ochs - Best Butcher in the world

Amish Breakfasts - Ummm scrapple and pancakes

Amish sticky buns - No raisins please, get these at the Amish bakery or at the breakfast stand.  Hands down best baked good in the world - Tartine's morning buns are a distant second

DeNic's - My favorite sammie in the galaxy is the roast pork, all garlicy and nice - with aged provolone and peppers

Birch Beer - Homebrew from the Amish, sweet!

Just about anything at Delilahs...

Down Home Diner and Jack McDavid - Because you made fun of Bobby Flay years before it became fashionable!  

And all the rest of youse there....

I live in San Francisco and visited my boyfriend's family here in Philadelphia for Thanksgiving.  Holy mighty hell, the vegetarian cheese-steak was the most delightful thing ever to cross my lips!
The crowd was sweaty, noisy and rude, but I enjoyed it all.

My favorite spot from my weekend in Philly. Im a complete sweets freak and I got lost in all of my options. We grabbed a quick lunch at the vegetarian stand...i forget the name of it but holy moses was the chicken club excellent. inexpensive as well. Then we headed over to the general store type place where i drooled over their selection of candy/caramel apples. oof! 
Can't wait to come back!

San Francisco tries to tempt me with the uber-posh, 100% organic, nauseatingly yuptastic Ferry Building.  Yet all I want on a Sunday morning is the Reading Terminal.  The Amish pretzels, Termini Bros., the ice cream, the roast pork sandwiches.  This place is what pregnant dreams are made of.  This is my own slice of heaven when I'm in town.  Double oink.

I loved walking around here and being able to have a choice of anything you want to eat!  

Ate breakfast one morning at a diner-esque sorta place with only a counter to the far left side of the place... it was fantastic!  

I can't wait to go back to Philly!

As someone who is befuddled when confronted with seemingly endless choice, lunching in the Terminal is a prospect that seizes me with dread.  At your fingertips you have Japanese, Chinese, Indian, Middle Eastern, Mexican, vegetarian, a huge swathe of delis and of course the Amish (although I heard they might be Menonites) and much much more.  The Terminal is big and mazelike, usually filled to the gills with the geriatric and others with nowhere else to go.  

The stores selling produce pretty much rock and you can get any kind of meat or cheese you want.  On that note, the Terminal is not for squeamish vegetarian or vegan types because its shoppers are subjected to museum-like displays of animal flesh. 

I reccomend 12th Street Cantina, Basic 4 Vegetarian (back from my meatless days) and the Pennsylvania Dutch Eating Place oh and shout out to my store, Blue Mountain Vineyards where you can buy wine from a vineyard in Pennsylvanis (yes, Pennsylvania has vineyard).

Going here makes me feel like a Philadelphian.  This is certainly one of the best things Philly has to offer.

I am in love with RTM.

Wow everyone gave this such great ratings. I thought it was a bt dirty and smelly and whatever you need you can get from better places all around the city.

There were homeless people with coffee wandering around, and some of the food I wouldn't trust. The one reason you should go: Beiler's Bakery (Amish baked goods).

What's all the hoopla about?  Yeah, it has some decent places to eat, but I do not believe that just because you group several decent places under one roof, their rating should go up.    One of the other reviews mentions that it is a good place for tourists because it has a sample of local flavor, and I agree.  But, if you are here for an extended period of time, or live in Philly, I don't see a need to plan a trip to Reading Terminal.  Take your guests here and let them sample a little bit of everything, take yourself to a specific restaurant outside the terminal's borders.

Fantastic market! We didn't expect it to be open on Sunday (and there were fewer merchants operating) but we still managed to get a great breakfast.

Great selection of produce and gourmet items.

I have no tolerance for folks who hate on Reading Terminal Market.

Okay, so you won't have the best meal of your life here. The diner sucks. It's typically crowded. And there's a few pigeons kicking it with you, plus yeah... a rat or ten.

Still, this place truly resonates with the Philly experience. It's so diverse, both in terms of food and in people. I love the Amish juice and the seafood bisque. Around the holidays is my favorite time of year to peruse the aisles with a loved one, and just waste time. Actually, this is my favorite place to kill time, read a book, people watch. I have faith in Philly when I hang here.

In the summer, there's pretty sweet flea markets caddy-cornered on the outside too, Saturdays. If this place wasn't here, I might just pack up and dip for Baltimore or Brooklyn.

There are so many different places to eat in here than it would be difficult to review them all.  Let's put it this way, do you want vegetarian food?  Fresh farm meat?  Eggs?  Cookies?  Cakes?  Cake baked my mennonites?  Thai food?  Falafel?  Ice Cream?  Spices?  Tea?  Coffee?  A burger?  A cheesesteak?  A vegetarian cheesesteak?  Pretzels?  Candy?  Used books?  A public restroom?  Flowers?  Fresh fruit?  Fresh organic fruit?  Fresh vegetables?  Fresh organic vegetables?  Milk?  Soy milk?  Breakfast?  Lunch?  Dinner?  A convenient place to meet a friend?

I think you get the point...

No matter what want in the food department you can get it here!  And if you have a wide diversity of friends who all like to eat different things then bring them here and they'll all find something.

One note: it tends to be very crowded during the lunch hours, as half of downtown comes here for lunch!

My last meal before dying would have to be red curry from the Thai place, freshly blended juice from the juice place, and a piece of cake from the Amish.  If I could figure out when this place isn't packed, that would be my favorite time to go.  However, such a time does not seem to exist.  The crowds of slow-moving cattle make me somewhat homicidal, but Reading is a carnival for the senses, and it's unique charm makes it a gem for natives and tourists alike.  

**Seek out the piano in the back right in front of the shoe shiners.  Local players come on a regular schedule to play for whoever is around.  All of them are talented, of course, but my favorite is a teenaged prodigy who comes with his family on Saturdays.  Damn, can he play.  Brings me to tears.
Homemade cookies. Flowers. Smoothies. Crab cakes. Veggies. Cheeeeeeese. RTM is a great place to spend a Saturday afternoon. I heard they're open on Sundays now too.

Reading Terminal Market is a Philly phenomenon that should be experienced by all at least once. 

I first went there in the dead of a miserably cold winter, and it was such a relief to see people smiling instead of wincing at the chill. Where people had been shuffling through the windy streets with their heads down, here was all chatty brightness. 

Unfortunately for me, this is a place best taken in with a couple pals. And if you're by yourself the first time you come, somehow all of that high spirited conversation and bustle makes you feel the pain of loneliness all the more. 

I had a great hot turnover of some sort from one of the vendors and then a chocolate covered pretzel from another. I wanted to get a slice of pizza too, but there was no place to sit. They have absolutely everything on sale here, it's a great farmer's market. A bit tight through the aisles but a fabulous place.

Show me anywhere else in the US that hosts an annual scrapple fest. Show me a market that has space to spread out tables, build a stage, and host an eclectic crowd of Amish scrapple men, family-owned scrapplers, and a few oddball scrapple enthusiasts wearing scrapple-themed t-shirts.

I'm from New England. We don't eat scrapple there.  On April 21st, I was schooled in scrapple by this crowd of pork-and-cornmeal mush-loving mid-Atlanticals. I watched in wonder as a table of judges assessed the entries in various categories. I tried the turkey scrapple, which I found quite delicious. I did not find the 'wedding cake' made from turkey scrapple to be as appealing.

RTM offers more than just scrapple, of course. For an out-of-towner wanting to eat as many Philly classics in as brief a time as possible, there is no better stop than the market. Don't forget to stop at the Amish pretzel joint - brushed with butter and fresh from the oven, they are a must-eat.

this was a fun place. claustrophobic nightmare. i had a reuben from Hershel's east side deli- tender over load of corned beef, oh so good
there were lots of choices of things to eat and drink. downside of this whole thing was the crowdedness.

It's the mother of all farmer's markets (opened in 1892).

Yes, it's true -- the selection is daunting and the aisles jam-packed with patrons. It's practically a stampede during lunch hour. It feeds the downtown crowd, the convention center, and bus loads of tourists. Everyone's coming because there's too much freaking good stuff! I tried to eat at every stand during my stay in Philly, but couldn't pull it off (got addicted to The Original Turkey). Get a map of the place and plan strategically. Definitely try something new like the Amish breakfast... unless you're Amish yourself... and somehow gotten on yelp.com...

Tips: Explore the market before or after lunch. Save room for Bassetts ice cream. Bring a tote bag if you plan to buy random knick-knacks or produce.

What's not to like about this place?

As usual, I skipped the scrapple and headed for Rick's and for desert, the Apple Dumplings (with heavy cream) in the Amish corner.  It's fun to walk around, take in the energy and watch all the people.  And each repeat visit is a whole new experience!

The RTM is a great place to go for lunch, but it's not exactly the most amazing food that you will find in Philadelphia. Sure there is a lot of it under one roof, but I can name 3 places for crepes that are much better than the stand at the RTM. 

Yes, the Amish stand is good. And Foster's has sweet spatualas. But overall, the place seems grimy, sweaty, and congested. 

Check it out once. That's all you'll need.

The ultimate fun place for bored conventioneers. They have every type of delicacy you can think of, ranging from vegan and vegetarian to meaty heaven and delectable ice cream treats.

A MUST whenever in Philly, and even more so to take a healthy breather from an upstairs convention.

The real life Philadelphia version of Diagon Alley, Reading Terminal market is the place to go for fresh produce, fish, meat... and just about anything. This collection of food vendors is a great place to find whatever you need for your next dinner party. The produce is some of the biggest that I have ever seen. The grapefruits were the size of two fists! Also, the Amish sell freshly baked bread and pastries during the week. Yum! Reading Terminal is also a great place to walk around and just look at all the unique foods and wares for sell.
Good summer produce, fresh from Jersey.  Good spice shop too.

Free wi-fi!!  OMG, how cool is that, given that I can spend hours poking around here.  12th Street Cantina was pretty good- they have prepared Mexican foods, can make something fresh from the menu, and have staples ingredients like posole and quesos that you purchase for home cooking.  yum.  They didn't have horchata- booooo!  Salumeria was celebrating their 25th anniversary and handing out delicious (free) cupcakes.  I bought an incredible 3 year aged cheese that was exactly what I wanted- sharp, calcified, memorable.  Great coffees, fresh juice, etc.  Don't dismiss this as a tourist trap.

A public market that's actually a useful, functioning market and isn't just an overpriced tourist attraction. Intriguing.

Recommentations: 
Grab a totally Amishtacular breakfast, for like 5 bucks you can get gigantic fresh pancakes with the works. They are only there certain days of the week, so call ahead (wait, do the Amish use phones?)

Be prepared to stalk the big crowded seating area to get a table, and mentally prep yourself for a random person sitting down next to you to eat. Much like the state of Pennsylvania and the native Amish population - the terminal is kind of small.

When you eat, be sure to sit near the guy who yells about Pennsylvania cheese. ("Buy my cheese! It's very expensive! But that's because it's the best!"). An honest salesperson. Old skool.

Buy some cheap pies from the Amish. They're very homemade and very reasonably priced.

Hit the farmers produce market. It's also surprisingly inexpensive and definitely "Super" and always "Fresh", unlike the same fare at certain nearby grocery establishments.

The reason I go to Reading Terminal:

There is an Amish Bakery in the way back against the wall.  They sell whoopie pies that are 5" in diameter and 2 1/2" thick.  They are sold for $1.  That's unheard of folks.

Ah, Reading Terminal.  I love this place and don't go there nearly often enough.  It's got everything.  Whatever food you're craving, they have that, plus Amish people, to boot.

Highlights:  Termini Brothers (best cannolis in the city - and they even have vanilla, hard to find elsewhere, but my favorite!), Famous 4th Street Cookie Co. (yum), the Amish rib stand, the falafel place, the French creperie stand, the seafood people, the fresh produce, the fresh flowers...  Actually, everything here is good.  And this list isn't even the tip of the iceberg as far as their selections.  

The only downside is that it's really crowded at lunch time, so it's hard to walk and find a place to eat b/c the tables are usually taken.  But it's worth fighting the crowds for the food.

Coming here makes me wish that I had two stomaches to  be able to sample all the different kinds of food being sold here.  For the LA folks, this place is like the Farmers' Market on La Brea times five.  I loved the variety of foods sold here.  From Amish bbq to cheese steak sandwiches, and Ice cream to cheese purveyors.  This place is guaranteed to make everyone's bellies happy.

One of the places that I worked inside before and have grown to love over the years. I mean face it. There are so many reason why you love and hate this place at the same time.

Why you hate it - it has a bad sushi display,it has a traditional diner that isn't open 24/7 (how does this exist), it's buffet section is kind of seedy, it has a horrible bar inside, Rick's Steaks moving out is going to kind of suck, there are 3 or 4 Chinese style stands and only one of them might be traditional.

Why You love it - incredible market atmosphere overall,The best Amish farmers section that's anywhere outside of Pennsylvania Dutch territory,  plenty of Authentic multicultural cuisines for inexpensive prices, piano music on the way to the bathroom, an incredible cooking book section, one of the best cheese stands ever, the fun events that take place, and the fact that Tony Luke's should be moving in could be amazing. 

No Matter what the good of it always outweighs the bad.

I don't really go here to eat as I live so close by so I'm not drawn to that stuff.  Overall, the restaurants are overpriced in the inside for the food quality you receive.

What I do recommend is the fresh produce.  I go shopping there all the time for that.  Always great produce that is fresh and not gross looking with pesticide film you see in grocery stores. yuck!

I would not recommend getting the seafood here.  You have to be very careful.

FOOD GALORE!  What more can I say!
Foods from all over the world and an amish market place!!
Make sure you are hungry because you are going to want to get a little bit of EVERYTHING!!!
Oh, shit.  What is this place and why doesn't Pittsburgh had one?  You could spend days in here trying to eat your way thru this place.  No lie.  Avoid it, if at all possible.

can i say "Oh My G-d"..... 

if i ever go back to Philly, this is the place I'll go. It has everything. and I mean everything. It's a labyrinth for all six senses. The smells are overwhelming and the selection is astounding. You can go there to grab lunch if only you could make up your mind as to what you want! you'd go there to pick up a fresh steak, seafood, fruits and veggies, or a homemade treat. You could even pick up a gift for somebody's b-day - books, jewelry, kitchen stuff from traditional to funky! 

I'm running out of words. 
I want to go back.

Ever wonder how the Amish at the Amish stand get to Center City?  Where do they park their horses?  I've no idea.  But, I'll take some sticky buns and an apple dumpling with cream on the side to go.

Best fresh squeezed juice.  Again from the Amish.

Best Rotisserie herb chicken.  Again the Amish.  

Sigh.  Only in PA.

I can't even begin to describe how luscious, decadent and wonderful this place is to me. Truly a cross-section of humanity where food is the common denominator. I've been to several farmer's markets around the US, but Philly's is tops in my book. I hadn't seen the Amish since I'd gone to college in this State. It was oddly fascinating to see them so....affable.

I was fortunate enough to pop in here 2 days straight for lunch and breakfast, respectively. How I wish I could make this a regular haunt.

As a side, I will say if you're able to find a table to sit and eat, the people-watching is absolutely choice.

If I ever go back to Philly, I'm heading straight for this place.  Talk about sensory overload - sights, smells, sounds, TASTES.  Good lord.  Go with an appetite and lots of time to spare.  The Amish have the best breads and pastries (Beiler's is my personal favorite, pumpkin bread and gingerbread, gimme gimme gimme).  It can get quite crowded so if you're claustrophobic, be prepared.  The seating area can get pretty disgusting - I know that's because people are pigs and not necessarily the Market's fault, but minus one star for that anyway.

I love this place, but unfortunately I wasn't really hungry and didn't get to try anything spectacular except the Cinnamon ice cream from Basset.

But this place reminds of me Chelsea Market in New York but 5x better.
I guess because they have a lot of things I don't see here in NY.

I would want to come back here again since they were CLOSED for labor day!

*SAD*

I love coming to the Reading Terminal Market for lunch.  My favorite places are the Little Thai Market, where my favorite dish is the salmon with a creamy red curry sauce that is delicious.  I also enjoy the 12th Street cantina, where everything they serve is yummy, but I epecially enjoy the chicken mole soft taco platter with your choice of rice, beans or salad.    

No matter what you are in the mood for, the Reading Terminal probably has it.

I miss this place, since we moved to San Francisco 8 years ago.
Why did law school have to end?
My husb and I used to go here every weekend for lunch.
Miss the nasty crowds of Philly, SEPTA, the cheesesteaks, the Eagles.
One of my favorite lunch places. $5 shrimp pad thai? Can't beat it.

It would be worth the trip to Phillie just to see this place.  And if you can't find something here to suit your fancy something is wrong with you.  I only regret we didn't have more time to spend here so we could taste everything!

This is what shopping for food should be like:  Good fresh produce, cheese shops, hoagies and cheesesteaks.  This is the kind of place where you come hungry and expect to spend a few hours cramming in twice as many meals as you should.  It's not big, but when you see the variety of lunch counters, you will know what I mean.  Not a bad place to be a tourist.  It is reminiscent of Eastern Market in Washington DC if you've ever visited there, but more full featured.  It even has it's own beer garden(which I would only give about two stars on it's own merit - how depressing!).  Why people were so solemn in there I don't know.  They have so much to be happy about.  The Phillies are in the playoffs for the first time in, what, like, fifty years?!  Drink up!

even when i don't really need to buy anything, i absolutely love to come here. i love the wandering, the scents, watching the machinery at the chocolate place, just people watching in general....

when i am here for food, i tend to gravitate toward profi's for savoury crepes, the falafel @ kamal's, spanakopita @ olympic, and golden bowl for noodles of any kind. the husband and offspring dig bassett's like it's going out of style, but i am neither here nor there when it comes to ice cream.

while they wait in line at bassett's, i like to sniff all the flowers at the stand across the walkway. it's a good way to pass the time, even if it does my allergies a disservice.

If you are looking for a good dessert at the market and you happen to love cupcakes then I would really recommend that you try Flying Monkey Patisserie. The cupcakes there are just amazing! I live in NY and I visit philly every few months and always have to pick up some cupcakes from this place.

The frosting is amazing and the cake itself is moist and just delicious. Great combination.

My personal favorite is the Pink Rose, a cupcake that is made with either poundcake or chocolate cake and then topped with raspberry buttercream.

So good!

When I was visiting Philly in September, I fell in love with the Dutch pretzels and the Vegetarian Philly cheesesteak place. It reminded me of the Farmers Market at the Grove in Los Angeles, but with different foods. 
I wish I could have tried all the vendors here... guess I'll have to come back for more!

This is my absolute favorite place in the whole of Philadelphia!!!

I'm the Queen of Fruits & Vegetables and this is my favorite place to do produce shopping. There are two stores selling that and the produce are aplenty, varied, fresh and cheap! And if you show your Student ID, you get a 10% discount - i love student discounts and merchants who offer that! =D

And soooo many kinds of food sold here - lump crab cakes and shrimp pad thai from the Thai store are good. Everything I've had here are good, quality for the money. And I think Reading Terminal Market does such a terrific job at maintaining the market clean and customer-friendly. The bathrooms are clean too. And there are plenty of seats available for people to eat and share their food. Great place to bring your family to. And I really like its location, right in the center of the city and so near Chinatown.

I LOVE Reading Terminal Market!

AWESOME.  We made our way over this past weekend, and although it was sensory overload, it was delicious sensory overload.   I think it will become a regular party of my Philly visits, as there was a whole list of things we wanted to try.  

The things we did try that rocked:
a wheel of brie+figs and toasted almonds... mmmm...
cupcakes at the flying monkey
dark chocolate covered pretzels by mueller

One of if not the oldest food markets in America. This place rocks. If you plan on visiting Philly and you consider yourself a foodie then plan more than one trip here. They have the ubiquitous cheesesteaks and seafood stands and cheese mongers and bakeries and Amish diner and confectioners and on and on and on. You can also see some of Philly's finest here, meaning their police and paramedics having a bite to eat.
Plan carefully as the Amish are only there on Wed. And Thur.
Had the best pretzels here made fresh by Amish girls.

I loved this place. Great produce, cheese, baked goods, food stalls, seafood, butcher shops, flowers and coffee. As well as dry goods and general merchandise some even made by the Amish. My favorites are the bronze statue of Philbert the pig in the heart of the market and the chocolate and peanut butter covered pretzels at Mueller's. The soft pretzels were also pretty awesome, you know it's a good thing when you see local business people coming in and buying paper bag loads of the the stuff. This place is a great testament to Philadelphia and it's heritage.

Definitely stop in this place if you are anywhere near downtown.  Great place for lunch, I'm just bitter every cheese steak place was closed on a Sunday!  They have veggies, honey, crafty things, seafood.  Reminds me of an indoor Pike's Market without all the tourists. (And apparently it's pronounced Redding-why don't they just spell it that way?)
Great general market; third and fourth generation market-stalls for produce, meat, groceries of all kinds. Especially love the Italian bakery Termini Bros.

Oh, the classic. Love, love love. I do my produce shopping here and my fatty self even plans out my walks home from class so as not to pass by here, or I WILL go in. Some people have complaints: it smells, it's crowded, most people don't take credit cards, blah blah. It's stuck in its ways people, and let it be! It's all part of the ambience, and I love it for all it's loud, shouting, ocassionaly smelly, cash-only self. The culture and food are fantastic. Go here if you haven't been, just to experience it.

Great place.

I wish all cities had this type of market.  The way a food court should be, not the corporate chain-restaurant filled schlock they have in the malls these days.  Multiple food stalls.  Variety of every type of food- diner, asian, middle eastern, seafood, etc...and amish.  Also a bunch of non-food stalls.  Great produce also.  I wish I had something like this where I live.  I would never need to cook again.

I had the amish breakfast - pancakes and bacon.  The pancakes were decent but the bacon was TO DIE FOR.  Not the crappy thin stuff but the nice thick slices.  I'm salivating just thinking of it.  After that, I splurged with a soft pretzel.  OMG!!!  Right out of the oven.  So hot and soft.  Finished it even before I got out of the place.  I wanted to try so many other stands but my stomach failed me - too stuffed.

Just a warning.  Great ambience if you like the down-to-earth, in-your-face, about-the-food-only environment (which I love)  Don't expect 4 star dining wait staff.  Most places are take out only.  Others have stools and a counter.  There are communal tables that are open to everyone but be ready to sit next to strangers.

I never thought I'd find a market to rival Pike's Place in Seattle, but this came pretty close. I entered the market from the southeast corner, so I was greeted with the whiff of chocolate chip cookies when I walked in. I wove my way through the aisles and saw such an impressive array of fresh fruits and vegetables, an amazing variety of meats and fish (dare I say, better fish than Pike's Place?!), a huge variety of eateries (sandwiches, crepes, mediterranean, gourmet, vegetarian, Mexican, Chinese, etc.etc.), cheese, flowers.... I could go on and on. Luckily I came on a day when the Pennsylvania Dutch and Amish were here, with loads of fresh dairy products and baked goods. I came first for breakfast, but couldn't really decide, what with so many choices, and ended up with fresh oatmeal from one place, fresh squeezed fruit juice from another place, and coffee from yet another place. I came back in the afternoon wanting a sandwich, but unfortunately both Rick's and DiNic's were so crowded, I just ended up getting a hot apple dumpling from the Dutch Eating Place (http://www.yelp.com/biz/dutch-eating-place-philadelphia). Yum. I also went around and got some gifts for my family, including a bottle of PA wine and a nice big filet of bacalau. If I had had access to some cold storage, I would have loved to get some Amish butter, more baked goods, and more meats. This place is a real treasure; I wish I had a market like this in my city!

i have a love/hate relationship with the terminal. yes, they have amazing food selections. produce, meats, seafood, local, organic, etc. all amazing and affordable. but, its the damn congestion of the place that gets to me. the other shoppers have absolutely no regard for other people. i get barreled into at least 3 or 4 times when i'm there. it makes me leave and not continue my shopping because i get so frustrated. i now have a new method where i only go on a wednesday or thursday morning about an hour after they open. less congestion, more great shopping. awesome place, too many people. good luck on a saturday, i hope you get out alive.

Reading - pronounced "Redding" apparently, as I was corrected quite often.   My savior in Philly.  Want something healthy?  Tasty?  Sinful?  Across the street from my hotel?  
Every lunch I had was spent here - getting freshly carved turkey breast from "The Original Turkey", salad from "Tootsie's salad bar", sushi from "Tokyo Sushi Bar" - this sushi chef was the fastest I've ever seen, and the sushi was amazing.   If I wanted to stay with my healthy eating choices, I'd also stock my hotel fridge with fresh fruit from Iovine Brothers Produce - they also made the BEST fruit salad.  I kid you not.  Ripe, succulent, and juicy.  (Insert dirty joke here)
If I wanted to be naughty, oh it was easy to be downright perverse here.. The cornbread from Delilah's - the best I've ever eaten in my entire life hands down.  Melt in your mouth, buttery goodness..
And the grand finale...Ir-freakin-resistable cookies from The Famous 4th Street Cookie Co.  Oh holy hell.  I had to have one every day, if not only for one bite and then hand it off to one of my friends who cursed me for giving them the additional calories, but silently blessed me for leading them to cookie heaven.  I tried every flavor.. All were delectable.  But if I had to choose?  The peanut butter chocolate chip and the white chocolate macadamia nut.  
Can't we move this to Los Angeles?  Please?

Reading Market could single-handedly convince me to relocate to Philly. Every time I go--which is pretty much every time I visit Philly--I leave there blissed out and I always discover something new. I've eaten at Carmen's (no relation to Carmen's in Bellmawr, N.J., which is a shame because they have the best mixed cheese sub on the planet) which is only passable as far as hoagies go. Rick's Steaks, however, is the culinary equivalent to a mind-blowing one-night stand. You know what you want, you get it, you can't get enough during, and you leave feeling fully sated and definitely sure you'd do it again (even though you shouldn't). There is a Mexican food stall that makes killer nachos, and way in the back this time I discovered a bakery that makes the most delicious little cupcakes that blows away any I've found in D.C. or New York. I'll need to look up the name. They said they do mail order for brownies but not cupcakes--bummer--but make sure you stop by for one.

This is by far the only reason I like Philadelphia; Reading Terminal Market is a cultural oasis in a mundane desert, and possesses a variety of foods, produce, restaurant stands, and products that I love simply looking at-certainly a visiting foodie's paradise.

The reason this place receives four stars is due to the crowds; it takes awhile to find a seat, and even longer to order once you've explored the entirety of the place. 

So far, I have eaten at what I like to call "The Turkey Place;"  you can't miss it. Facing the main seating area, it possesses many freshly roasted gobblers for one's slicing pleasure; I got a cranberry sauce, stuffing, and turkey sandwich, and though it was expensive, it was gut-busting and absolutely delicious. The homestyle sides such as macaroni and cheese and greens, however, are less exciting; stick with the sandwiches. 

There is also a Middle Eastern Joint that serves a variety of specialties, particularly hummus, baba ghannoush, grapes leaves, falafel, etc. This was incredibly expensive, I thought, at $6.17, especially when all I received was hummus, baba, and an eggplant stew which seemed to consist more of peppers than of eggplant; the pita was also quite thin, and lacked the fluffiness that others possess. 

The "stew" and the baba were good, but I could have done without the hummus, which had an odd taste that I can't even describe. I was still hungry, in fact, so I ended up purchasing one of their spinach pies for the road. Unlike spanakopita, the spinach-minus-feta is stuffed inside of a bread-like shell rather than flaky phyllo; it was good but a little plain. This particular place also sells juices; my friend purchased one and really enjoyed it, saying it filled her up. 

The various green grocers have tons of fresh fruits and vegetables, while the fishmongers and butchers have endless varieties of cuts and sea creatures. I've never bought from these guys because I don't live here...and I don't think I should let raw meat sit out for the bus ride home. 

Particularly enticing "stores" are the ones that sell cookbooks, kitchenware, unusual jams/jellies, and spices; definitely give those a try. 

Next time I'm out there, I'll be sure to get Bassett's ice cream, and maybe try an amish kiosk or two; that stuff is so exotic to me-heh.

Oh yeah, just one of the best food markets in the world.  An absolute Philadelphia gem.  If you don't believe me just ask any chef.  This is regional food at it's best and if you want "good" food then you will find regional favorites.  I can't say enough about how special this market is to Philadelphia and everything it represents.  JUST AWESOME!

Everybody talks about Reading as if it's a national treasure but I am sometimes let down by the market.  It's not that it's a good idea to have such a wide breadth of local flavor all in one place it's the execution that's lacking.  

What I mean is that most of the local flavor is represented but it's represented poorly meaning that most of the food is mediocre which is too bad considering you can walk a couple blocks to get the best of (insert food style).  In most cases, it's not who makes the best of a certain type of food but who can afford to pay the rent there.  What would really make the pace special is if they chose the top vendors as opposed to whoever can pay the most rent.  

The other issue, and this is a big one, is the lack of being open on Sunday.  This is really a chicken/egg issue.  Are most businesses closed on Sunday because of lack of business or is there a lack of business because most of them are closed?  All I know is this seems to be an epidemic in what is a city the size of Philadelphia.  In order to attract people into the center of city during the weekend, it has to be open first.  I understand that many of the businesses have religious reasons for not working on the Lord's day but this is akin to Chinatown shutting down one day a week in New York.  This is supposedly a world-class city so why does it feel like I'm in the middle of the midwest when I'm in Center City on a Sunday?
So many reasons to shop here. I don't even know where to start. Hell, there's even like 3 or 4 places that just sell cheese. You're bound to find what you came for.

where does one start when talking about reading terminal? if you're visiting or if you live here, the terminal is a staple in philadelphia. go for lunch, and take 20 minutes to make up your mind what to get. it's huge, is always busy, and fun to just putz around. fresh veggies, meat, fish, and cheese abound!

also the best little candy nook EVER, with candy you haven't seen since you were a kid, and another candy booth where i got the huge swirly lollipops for our wedding. 

also, i still daydream about the whopper flavored ice cream i had here years ago.

LOVED IT!

I can't wait to move to Philly and do my grocery shopping here.

The highlight for me was the apple dumpling drizzled with fresh cream that I procured from one of the Amish vendors.  It was better than any apple pie I have ever had the joy of eating.  

Prices also seemed very reasonable.  Lots of selection, too.

A good ol' fashion market. and its indoors. so, its going to smell like an outdoor market, but inside. 
Great selection of meat, cheese, bread, coffee, candy, more meat, cookies, and a whole lot of shit you only find in markets. Try the sausage place. I picked up some chicken sausage that was absolutely decadent (did I use that word right?). Mmmm....

Let me preface my review by saying that I went to Reading Terminal Market on a Sunday, which I suspect is not the best day to do a fair evaluation of the place.  I think only maybe 1/2 of the stores were even open so I'm guessing this place is much more happening during the week.

From what I did see -- nice variety of food stands, bakeries, pastry shops, butchers, markets and random knick knack shops.  If I lived in Philly, I would probably frequent the place to pick up some meat and seafood, all of which seemed fairly fresh and reasonably priced.  I heard that the Amish don't open their shops on Sundays so I'm a little bummed I missed out on the Amish pretzels that everyone seems to rave about. The food that my gf and I was ok (cheese steaks from Rick's and mac n' cheese from Delilah's) and on par with what I'd expect from essentially a glorified food court.

All in all, I found everything about Reading Terminal Market to be ok.  I would definitely be curious to see what the place is like at lunch on a Thursday.

The good: pretty good food along the whole spectrum of ethnicities as well.  Definitely check it out if you're in the neighborhood and need food served to you quickly (as opposed to fast food restaurants). See the official site for food options.

The bad: it gets really really crowded! Be careful on the weekends and extended hours days due to events in the convention center because that's when the big crowds roll through. Two people I know lost their wallets here, so like I said, just mind your belongings in the crowds.

I consider this the Wal-mart of farmers markets. Everything you want under one roof for a reasonable price. The Amish section of the market is where some of the best food is found. I can't resist the pretzels and cinnamon buns.

the best sandwich ever lives here.  The turkey place, and its like the thanksgiving special or something.  juicy turkey, savory stuffing, sweet cranberry sauce on yummy yummy fresh wheat bread. mmmmmm *drool*  and ps  I don't like turkey but once a year.  but when in philly i eat this sammich!    The reading terminal market is all around awesome.  From the fruit and veggie grocer in the back corner, to the old guy's meat market, to all the Omish stuff... super great.   It's always busy but it's also always good. I haven't visited all the vendors there yet.  but i do recommend the turkey place,  the meat market where the old guy is behind the counter, the fruit grocer in the back, the omish bakery up front  and their pretzel place,  they also have a candy spot that has all the old time favorite candies,  honey-bees, the soft after dinner mints etc...  I'll have to reupdate with the names of places.   A++
The absolute coolest farmer's market in the world.  Makes Pike Place Market look like an touristo indoor shopping mall.

OK so this was my first excursion walking to Center City since I have moved.  I've been to Philly a few times but never actually went in to RTM.  IT's BANANAS!  Literally bananas everywhere for 69 cents a bundle.  I am not sure how busy it is on weekdays, but Saturday was pretty much jam packed I actually got knocked backwards by some lady but it was ok a nice gentleman was immediately behind me to catch my fall.  Pretty much any sort of produce, meat, cheese, fresh fish, bread, sweets, candy you could want is here.  Price vary, I suggest walking the whole place to look around before making too many purchases.  Most places have little lines, but they move very fast and efficiently.  Some good deals are to be had, I bought grapes tomatoes and onions for under a dollar each.  Also adorable tiny cacti were all over one booth.  This is about an hour walk from 44th street but a very enjoyable leisurely one.  I will go again perhaps for sushi or just to buy a bucket of raw whole fish mmmmm...not sure what I would do with them.

I'm a Jersey girl.  My Philadelphia culinary experiences are usually planned and carefully executed and based on some review I read or heard from someone I trust.  Although I appreciate street food and Philadelphia's many informal foodie rituals (cheesesteaks, soft pretzels, etc.), I just experienced the Reading Terminal Market for the very first time.

Yes, of course I'd been there before.  Its in the middle of everything and its hard to miss.  I'm not a complete dork.  But if memory serves, I think the first time I was there I could only manage to find the 4th Street Deli cookie counter and the second time? I met with clients for breakfast and I think I had only some of those homemade Amish granola bars and a lemon square.

Whatever!

My boyfriend, Jon, took me there recently, while waiting for his car to have some detailing finished at High End Stereo at 12th and Vine Streets.  This was a whole new experience: a Saturday afternoon.  Plus, Jon's well-versed in what the Terminal Market has to offer; he works just in the neighborhood.  He knows the Amish schedule (No Monday, Tuesday) and can navigate through the barbecue chicken, ribs, pulled pork and the pastries.  

Everything looked and smelled so good!  I can't imagine working there and having to mingle all day with the sights and smells of food, flowers, art, perfume and people.  Its intoxicating!  I saw fresh seafood.  I saw butchers chopping ribs for the barbecue.  I even saw hot sausage sandwiches with fried onions and peppers getting sweet sauce poured over them, leaving a stream of steam in its wake.  Wow!

It reminded me of when I was a little kid and my mother would load us all in the car at the butt crack of Saturday dawn and drive us to the Englishtown, NJ open-air market (rain or shine, warm or cold) for shopping and eating, but this is much better: no cold and just as great for people watching!

Jon had some barbecue chicken that day and I managed a chicken salad sandwich and homemade lemonade.  Best stuff ever!

Next time?  I'll hit the butcher and the florist and bring some of that goodness home!

This is the kind of place I like to go to when I am traveling. It involves locals and their food (and oh yeah tourists of course).

There is a piano player.
Loved the pretzels and pickles made by the Ammish. 
The veggie restaurant was great with fake tuna and chicken salad.
Bought some chocolate covered pretzels here as presents.

Oh my gawd.  My only regret is that we went here when it was about to close and hardly anything was open.  The fish looked amazing, and so did the chocolates.  We got a cheesesteak which was yummeriffic.  Next time I'm in Philly I'll set aside hours just to wander around here.

I haven't been here in a while so decided to hit it up for lunch.  Finally today worked out for my friend and I and we walked there a few blocks.  Hitting the terminal at noon... uhhh not a good idea.  It was packed.  I wanted everything but couldn't decide on anything.  I could have spent 20 minutes just cruising around the fresh flower stand.  The place is just great.  It was so crowded though and working with an hour for lunch wasn't an ideal situation for what all of my senses were yearning for -- which was in fact everything.

BUT -- I ended up at this "Everyday Gourmet" stand - mostly because there was no line.  I got the most delicious and perfect lunch for what I was craving (it's a monday, folks, I needed vitamins in the veggie form).  The portabello mushroom topped with this cheese and artichoke concoction that looked like a crab cake was stunningly divine.  Heated up and blessed with some fresh spring mix on the side, I was loving it.  It was so tasty.  Even if I did have to eat it while sitting on a wall outside, I was pleased.

My friend and I are going back but only when we have hours to spend amongst the many stands/smells/tastes.  If you haven't been there in a while, it's definitely worth the trip.

I love this place i always have a great experience and there is so much to choose from i love the cheese shop Downtown cheese and deffinatly the produce stands.  LeBus bakery great bread it makes me wanna have a big bowl of pasta and sauce to dip it in.  Old city coffee everytime i go in the fall and winter i gotta have the double mint mocha it so minteeee!  Rick's Steaks always the best place for an oldtime philly steak and whiz.  Tokyo sushi bar is great they make it so fast and right in front of you great if your in a hurry for lunch and want something light.  By George Pizza & Pasta has great sandwiches.  Everything is great here its deffinatly a place to visit in philly on the regular.

Pretty cool, lots of stalls, a great place to go as a group for food because everyone can get their own thing. From barbecue to Chinese this place has everything. Lots of fresh produce and fish/meat stands. Not much more than food, no real crafty things like some markets. Don't leave without getting a cannoli!

This place is flat out awesome.  I'm not sure what the name of the produce place is, but it's perfect.  I think it's only on Sundays but they give student discounts so hold on to that school ID after graduation (all you cheap asses...... like me).

For starters, the terminal discounts the parking if you spend over $10; $3 parking in center city - can you beat that?  Second, go grocery shopping and sit down at almost ANY of the little shops because they're all awesome.

The only reason I'm giving them 4-stars is because of what they're doing to Rick's Steaks.  Not that I'm a huge fan of any cheese steak place other than Delassandro's, but Rick's is a small business that has held up their end of the lease for close to 50 yrs, if not more.  The RTM is kicking them out simply because they want a bigger "cheese steak name vendor."
A hopping place on Saturdays as I finally got to see the wares of the Amish that come here on the weekend.  Rum Raisin ice cream from the Amish stand, is pretty good stuff.

I could not survive without this wonderful establishment in my city.

EVERYONE and I mean everyone can find something they like here. There is everything from mexican and chinese to those wonderful PA dutch folks cranking out some delish soft pretzels and all are available within a few feet of each other under one roof. 

One of my favorite merchants is Kamal's Middle Eastern food stand. The chicken kebob is loaded with lettuce, tomato, cucumber, chunks of tender & spicy chicken with a delish sauce (I have no idea what it is) all wrapped up in a fresh pita. They also have an array of desserts, hummus and pastries for purchase.

To top it all off stop at Bassett's for some Gadzooks ice cream (shout-out to Preston & Steve).

There are also plenty of stalls to purchase cook books, spices and anything else food related. I have also noticed they hold some cooking classes here but have yet to find someone who has participated in them. Anyone!?!

The only thing that really is a downer is if you go at lunch time (which is when I usually end up finding myself there) it can be superrrr crowded.

The Reading Terminal is continuing to disappoint me but for their tasty Gyros, fresh fruits, flowers and more I will continue to give them four hard earned stars.

Minus the annoyance of tourists and gatherings of people on jury duty the terminal can be a fund place to go. The open area seating surrounded by the old man playing the piano is enough to brighten anyone's day..that is until you get to the lines of minions gorging themselves on one of Rick's disgusting steaks topped with a thousand calorie ice cream delight. It's no wonder Americans are so unhealthy.

I for one like to keep to certain sections of the market myself. For those extra hungry days the Amish diner always hits the spot with their home grown, home cooked meals and for those lighter appetite visits there are two smoothie/juice bars [one being at the Middle Eastern market and the other just around the bend which is always run by two very sweet Asian girls]. 

There are several places to get those veggie-vitamins, but the organic market is the best place to find local and pesticide-free fruits and veggies as well as meats and some really great cheeses; Blue Mountain vineyards has a store where you can bring your lunch and enjoy a by-the-glass wine; and there are even some florists and artisans selling merchandise at small carts and inside little stores. There really is something for everyone...just don't expect to be able to actually sit and enjoy it because you might just be disappointed.

This is the coolest place in philly! (food wise). You can find anything here! From the awesome jams that the dutch community sells to the delicious pastries! 
My fave place to eat a philly cheesesteak is at Rick's. (hence the profile pic). I got the phill steak with pepperjack cheese, onions, mushrooms. It was SO delicious. We were even able to go behind the grill and cook some up! The price range is fair, awesome place!
I've eaten at the Flying Monkey, it has sweets like pistachio cupcakes to delicious brownies. this is a must! 

The place itself is amazing, there are so many cultures and it's constantly busy that it's just awesome. You have to go! Bring cash!

I try to control my fat kid tendencies in public, so walking into the Reading Terminal Market was quite an exercise in self control. I think I started hyperventilating as I walked in. I was also kind of ashamed that I was so giddy just being in a place with so many different kinds of food. I didn't even get to really look around as I was there with co-workers, but I spied those apple dumplings on the way out and I'm definitely going back for one. 

I had a sandwich from DeNic's and a lemonade from the Amish Dairy. The sharp provolone was great, I must say. Co-workers got some ribs from Delilah's which also looked really good. Got to go back.

A review on the venue and not so much the stores and shops within:

If you live in the Philadelphia metro area, it would be a crime not to visit at least once.  Super convenient to by public transit especially SEPTA's Market East Regional Rail station.

The variety, the personality, the diversity of culture.  Sociological studies could be done here.  You can't not find something delicious to eat for any mood or diet.

Shining stars include the Pennsylvania Dutch place that serves wings and Termini Bros. Bakery (best cannoli I've ever had).

A MUST during a day trip to downtown Philly!  The Reading Terminal Market has a cornucopia of dining options from Italian to 50's style diner to mediterranean to Japanese to gourmet cheeses and candies.  My personal favorite is the falafel but I am not exactly sure of the name of the stand where I got it from.  The market has a couple small shops but I never had enough time to explore them.  If you're a Philly area resident like me and have out-of-town guests visiting from far away (try California, where I am from originally and have many relatives who still reside there), make it a point to bring them here!

Gee, let's put aaaall of F's consumable temptations underneath one roof & see if she won't go crazy. What the hell was this- a test from Buddha or something?!?!

Good lord, it seriously took me MAD will power to pry myself out of this joint. The spot with the southern food was aaaaight, the BBQ was bangin', the cookies were phenomenal. 

But the cherry on top- the ridiculously low priced sweet goodies the Amish were selling. EVERYTHING made freshly from scratch at great deals. I toootally stocked up on almost everything they had to offer.

*Deal tip: swing on by about an hour before closing, people start to sell their freshly made goods at deeply discounted prices in order to get rid of them.

Amish people are cool--their food is rich and fatty and down home fantastic.  The Terminal is CRAZY during lunch time mostly for jurors and tourists but if you go about 1030 and a bit after 2 you're laughing.   If the Home Show or Flower Show is going on--STAY THE HELL AWAY FROM THIS PLACE.  Merchants will put their prices up during this time.  

There's free wifi too so you can chill out with some food and have great people watching for a couple hours.

You gotta love this place.  The unique selection, the Amish, VietNamese, Asian, Italian and American stands all crammed in together.  Sure it's a bit grimey and can get mobbed at lunchtime, but give me Iovine's Produce, Och's Chicken Breasts, Some Tom Kha Gai from Little Thai Market and a hot fresh macadamia nut cookie from 4th St and I am good to go.

It is a blessing to live nearby.

The breakfast at the diner was delish! 
This place is HUGE and I got lost trying to find the ladies room. You could spend the day there.

Living in parts of Philly, especially Old City, means that getting fresh meat and veggies can be a challenge.  Luckily, RTM is just a quick jump on the El to 11th and Market.  

Martin's meats is our go-to for meats.  OK-Lee veggies are right there, too.  

The prices are fair and the quality is generally quite high.  

We've never actually eaten at the various food stands, but for fresh veggies and meats it's the place to go.

Don't know why it took me so long to write this review but here it goes.
You can't go wrong with the produce here, the veggies/fruits are reliably fresh, really as far as I'm concerned it's the best place for produce. 

Favorite finds include (and this list is derived from vendors): heirloom tomatoes, curry leaves, turkish delights, chorizo, jalapeno jam, crabcake sandwich, and shawermas to name a few. I love this market, can't get enough of it. It's the first stop I make with out of town visitors and usually the last. Good place to get something for the plane ride.

I can be seen here basically 3 times a day.  

First at Le Bus bakery for my 1.25 hazelnut coffee.
Second at Hershel's Deli for my 3.09 ridiculously large in size "small Maztos ball soup.
Third picking up cheese infused with black truffle (SO good) and produce across the way at a stand that offers 10% off for college students.  

If you don't sense my enthusiasm for this market let me make it more clear for you:  I LOVE THIS PLACE.  I can get almost everything I need, and most of the time below grocery store prices.  And when the Dutch come in I think the best smells come out of that place I have ever laid my nose on.

I have said this before, this is about one of the only things I like about this god foresaken city, and bless its food filled heart.

I've loved this place since I was a kid.  You can buy everything you need and lots of things you don't at Reading Terminal.  As a rule, the prices are better than Headhouse Square Farmer's Market and even Clark Park Farmer's Market (both of which I also recommend).  

 Baguettes: Metropolitan Bakery

 Cheese: Salumeria

 *Scrapple: Dutch Eating Place

*If you don't know what scrapple is, it would behoove you to find out, quick!

I worked in the market at metropolitan bakery and I actually enjoyed going into work. The Market has an amazing vibe that is undenialable. The sights and smells have pretty much remained the same throughout my life. I was often brought to the market as a child and the thrill is still there. My top picks:
Bread: metropolitan
Cheese: downtown cheese(andrea is the best)
Sweet treat: termini bros
Produce and dairy: fair food stand
Breakfast: dutch eating place

Try the Market along with your normal weekly shopping, always bring out of town visitors to the market, and continue the tradition with future generations!s

Can you say a whole lot of stuff located in one place? So many things are located in here I just don't know where to start. You can get food, flowers, ice cream, candles, candy and many other things. If you like local markets then you really should check this place out. If you want to come here and eat then get hear around lunch time since that is when most of the places are open. Most places accept credit card but bring cash just in case.

This place is friggin' awesome.    It is a huge market that has a lot of local vendors selling everything from fresh fish to Amish sticky buns to flowers.   I seriously wish there was something unpretentious like this near me...the SF Ferry building wishes it could be like the Reading Terminal Market.  The best thing about the place is walking around looking for "People Love Us on Yelp" stickers :)

awesome
cheesesteaks
coffee
meats
thai
mac and cheese

What's the first thing a yelper does when in a new city?  Well, besides check into my hotel and jump on the bed (my usually ritual when traveling), the answer is -- EAT and DRINK!  And what better place to start such glutenous behavior then at the Reading Terminal Market.

Reading as in the Reading Railroad - monopoly comes to life in the city of Philly!

With over 61 vendors, this place is a virtual yelper's haven. This market was established in 1893 and have everything you want-- booze, cheese-steak from the famous "ricks", fresh farmer's market veggies, honey and honey products, cooking classes, flowers, candles, chocolates, wine tasting, Italian, Greek, bakeries... each place I ate often has locations in other parts of Philly.  So, I will review them individually.  But, collectively, this place is a dream!  (And it was walking distance from my hotel and conference at the Hilton).

A nice place for lunch or to buy some local groceries. It reminded me of the Pikes Peak Market in Seattle. My W bought a Termini Bros. cannoli at the market. The woman took the custard right from the refrigerator and filled it in front of us. I have never seen anything like it. Very impressive! 

If visiting Philadelphia, I wouldn't miss a stop at the Reading Terminal Market. Be sure and check the market hours as they close early.

How does this place not have 5 stars? Shame on you Yelpers ;)

Everything that you need is here: Termini Brothers for your cannoli weakness, Iovine Brothers for groceries, and the Turkey place (shame on me for forgetting the name) for the BEST turkey sandwich you'll have in your life. 

If you are visiting Philadelphia, go there for lunch, you won't regret it!

READING TERMINAL MARKET IS AMAZING!!! Its been there atleast since the early 1900s and you can find EVERYTHING there!! There's chinese places, french places, bakeries, candy shop, meat shops/butcher shops,  I LOVE IT!!! I've only been there once but I'll be going there a lot more in the years to come. 
    i HIGHLY reccommend anyone to go there... as long as you can deal with crowds..

This is one of my absolute favorite places in Philadelphia, possibly in the whole country.  It's like walking into a bygone era, when local producers came into the city daily with fresh meats, produce, cheeses, flowers, breads, spices... except this still happens!  Everyday!  

The maze of independent vendors and the dozens of delicious lunch joints dot this one-of-a-kind experience.  My sister goes to the market several times a week not only because it's one hell of a shopping adventure but their prices are fantastic on the highest quality ingredients.  

This is a landmark establishment and has been part of the fabric of this wonderful city for nearly a century.  It is so heartwarming to see the market bustling with every city resident, young and old, rich and poor, black and white... forget the supermarket, THIS is how city dwellers were MEANT to shop! 

What a true institution.  At the very least grab a cheesesteak or some ice cream when you're in Philly at this place.  Unbelievable!
I stopped in for some quick eats on my weekend trip.  If you haven't been there, you should go. Its' like a open market of restaurants. They have everything.
This place is way cool.  Like the Grand Central Market in LA.  It's directly across from the convention center, so if you're there for a show, definitely plan to lunch here.

Wow. Just wow. This place is a seriously overwhelming on the first visit. There's just so much to gawk at or pick at and/or buy, and I didn't plan it well the first time I came in. I've been here twice already, but I still feel like I didn't check out everything this place has to offer: flowers, fruit, cheese, gifts, and restaurants. 

My main goal was to pick up some fresh fruit to take back to my hotel because I haven't been eating as healthy as I'd like to be while I'm here on business. Not only did I get some fruit, but I also picked up a cupcake, a cookie, a jar of organic apple butter, another cookie, and a brownie (I believe I ate it while shopping around). If I were wee bit closer to this place, I'd go here for lunch or breakfast as often as I could...or if it were open later (closes at 6 PM, I think), I'd grab dinner here. It's the perfect place for healthy and non-healthy eaters alike!

Whatever you want, it's here. It's chaotic and crowded and that's what adds to its wonderfulness. Bustling people mill around, pushing past each other to get at the varied collection of bakeries, eateries (featuring anything from samosas to the best mac 'n cheese (according to Oprah)), and produce stands. It truly feels like a market, and smells like great home-made food. There are tables off to the side, too, so while you can grab stuff to go, you can also sit down, and enjoy your food as you watch the chaos from the sidelines.

recently made my first trip to philly and for a foodie, reading terminal market was at the top of my list of places to visit.
it was super hectic and HUGE (dragged my bf up and down every single aisle), just the way i like my markets. tried the blueberry pancakes at the dutch spot.. chewy, chock-full-of blueberrys, unreal!
if i lived in philly, i would probably have to resist the urge of going to the market everyday. the meats looked incredible, as did the seafood, produce, BAKED GOODS...... drool.
anything you could possibly want to eat all in one place. genius.

Great place with something for everyone. Make sure to check out the Amish booths and the warthog statue (just because it's there). Once in a while, they'll have some sort of fair in there and those are awesome especially when they have FUNNEL CAKE!

I never drive to go to RTM, as I consider driving around there akin to a horrible nightmare, but if you do, park in the garage and get your ticket validated for a discount. It's in walking distance to nearby hotels and very accessible via Septa.

One thing that always annoyed me was when I went there on everyone's lunch break. The lines will be long, the small aisles will be cramped, and it will be painful to find a place to sit. You may be lucky and score one of the picnic tables in the back near the piano but you'll be sharing with others.

If I lived in Philadelphia, I would get fat off of eating too many homemade Pretzels made by the Amish.  Having initially visited on a Saturday and trying this amazing pretzel, I was depressed for at least a good four minutes on Sunday to find their stand was only open Wednesday through Saturdays.

You can find anything from eateries and groceries to homemade dolls here.  At first, walking in feels like you've entered a crazy maze.  Noisy.  Lots of people.  After a while, you find your way.  

Best thing, your money supports local producers.  There certainly is a unique charm about that Reading Terminal Market that is irreplicable anywhere else.  

Loved it!

Can I really say anything that hasn't already been said? Probably not. Reading Terminal Market was everything I wanted it to be and more. It was busy and crowded and it had one of everything. My recommendation is to check out the Amish booths, as they serve wonderful deliciousness such as "Peanut Butter Delite" for EL CHEAPO. Also, half-dill pickles, which are the best. In addition to all the food, there was this totally random guy in the back selling books. So awesome. New favorite place.

Convenient location?  Check!
Large number of selections?  Check!
Indoors so you won't freeze in winter?  Check!
Has obscure amuzing items?  Check!
Affordable prices?  Check!

This may be considered blasphemy, but I think it's better than Seattle's Pike Place.  Oh and this is total blasphemy, but I think it IS better than San Francisco's Ferry Building Farmer's Market.  Okay maybe not.  But if those three markets exist in any one city, I think I would definitely go to Reading a lot more frequently than the other two.

Whenever I am alone in a town other than my own, I like to disappear in obscurity.  I like to blend in with the locals crowd and be as inconspicuous as I possibly can.  This place definitely allows that.  I could walk around for hours and still discover new things.  

I tried one of the Chinese food place, but it was awful.  I can't say for all of the Chinese food in there, but I think if you really want some you should just go to Chinatown a few blocks away.  The Amish places are definitely God-send.  Very, very good hot apple dumplings.  Iovine produce is great because they provided me with reasonably priced healthy snacks and fruits. The fresh juice place is pretty awesome.  And don't forget Old City Coffee, I love the homey feel to it.

I only wish this place opens past 6pm...  Then it would be truly truly mah-velous!

This is just one of many farmers' markets in Philly but has the distinction of having a majority of Amish farmers and products. Whenever I'm visiting my family in New York I love eating this Dutch Potato Bread. I always thought the Dutch reference was to the Netherlands but now I've realised it meant the Amish. Silly me. One advice is if you want any of their product to make sure you get to the market before 3pm-ish because bang on they will pack up and leave. We had a late lunch of a Turkey sandwich and gravy. It literally is a sandwich smothered in gravy. A fun market.

This place is a must-see if you're visiting Philadelphia. Reading Terminal Market is a huge indoor market with every kind of food stand imaginable, as well as produce, and even a restaurant. From Amish to New Orleans, to Indian, to Chinese, to Philly Cheesesteaks, you will be able to find something here. Reasonably priced small food stands with seating areas. Make sure you tour the whole place before settling on one. Or else get a little something from a few! 

You could spend a couple of hours walking around here and exploring. I wouldn't say this is better than Pike's Place in Seattle; it's different. Pike's Place has tons of fresh fish, beautiful flower displays, and is lined by small specialty shops on the outside. Reading Terminal Market has a stand or two for flowers, and has little food places nestled inside. Anyway, bottom line: great stop in Philadelphia...

I love strolling through these markets.

A really cool touch were the multiple posters of other international market locations.

One of them was a poster for Vancouver, where I went not too long ago, but they also had places all over the world there :)

This place is great.  It's like Baltimore's Lexington Market but maybe a little bigger, safer, and a little more in the way of yuppy shopping and food choices.  For example, they had crafts/book shops.  Lexington Market doesn't have that.  

Reading Terminal Market feels really authentic and has a ton of food choices.  I can't wait to go back.  I really liked the falafel shop.

When I think of Philly, I think of Reading Terminal. Anywhere you eat here is GOOD. Like really good. So good you will call someone and tell them all about it. Don't leave without getting a fresh baked pretzel from one of the Amish women. There is a vegetarian place that is yummy too but it's pricey and the servings have gotten smaller over the years.

I absolutely LOVE this place. It just smells sooo good when you walk in. My folks moved to this neck of the woods about 30 years ago when I was in college, but I never actually lived here and didn't know about this market until last year. All those trips to visit over the years and I didn't know about this market?!! I can't believe it! 

Well, I know about it now and have been 3 times in the past year (3 visits to the family). This is now a must-do for me whenever I visit. The food in this place is incredible. The pizza! The ribs! The Italian sandwiches! The delis, Thai and Chinese food! The cannoli (filled when you order them)!! There's so much great food here. There are also some very nice markets for fresh meat, fish, and vegetables. 

Here's the strategy that works for us: When I visit, we go mid-week and get there around 11 AM. Then we walk around for about half an hour to see what gets our taste buds going that day. Then we eat! And eat, and eat! We always have a cooler in the trunk of the car for this trip so we can bring home some of the wonderful looking fresh meats or fish. 

This is a must-do if you visit anywhere near Philly. It's a must-do if you live here. I really wish there was something like Reading Terminal Market where I live.

On a recent work trip to Philly, I chanced to stay at a hotel right in the middle of downtown.  During my trip I had planned to get out see some of the sights (the historic buildings around Independence Hall, the Rocky Statue, and the University of Pennsylvania just to name a few).  Not wanting to have to walk to a fast food joint for lunch, the hotel conceirge recommended taking a short walk to the market down the street.  Keep in mind that this was my first trip to Philly and so I thought this place was nothing more than a corner grocery store.  Oops.

If you have never been to Philly but are looking to make the trip, you absolutely must make this part of your itinerary.  This place will absolutely blow you away.  For the record, this a huge farmers market that serves, well, everything.  Italian subs, cheesesteaks, tacos, sausages, burgers, cajun foods, chinese foods, artisan breads, ice cream and yogurt, seafood, hoagies, fresh produce, specialty cheeses and they even have a full service amish bakery.  And thats barely scratching the surface.

I was only in Philly for five days so there was no way to try out all these places, but I can tell you what I did have was all good.  Carmen's Hoagies were delicious, the Little Thai Market has outstanding chicken dishes, Olympic Gyro had a tremendous Pita sandwich and Beiler's Amish Bakery had an apple dumpling dessert that was out of this world!  In all I think I only had 3 or 4 meals during my trip that didn't come from the market.  For those of you who enjoy farmers markets, this place is the creme de la creme of farmers markets.  

A couple of pieces of information for you if you decide to make the trip.  First, bring cash.  Some of the vendors take debit or credit, but most that I encountered only took cash.  Second, check the Reading Market website for hours for each vendor as they all have different schedules.  Usually a late lunch is a good time to go as the crowds aren't as thick and most of the vendors are still open.  Third and lastly, this is the perfect place if you want to try out true Philly food.  There's other famous spots in town, but if you're crunched for time like I was, this place has all the Philly staples you'd expect.  Pretzels, cheesesteaks, hoagies, you name it.

If you're in Philly and looking to sample some fresh local faire, it doesn't get much better than this.  What Pikes Public Market does for downtown Seattle, this place does for downtown Philly.  A wildly popular local market where people can load up on just about anything.  I don't know when my next trip into Philly will be, but you can bet your bottom dollar on where one of my first stops will be.

Pros: variety of food and lots of it, decent price

Cons: limited space to sit when it is crowded, taste can be hit and miss

I love this place. I could walk in here for hours just trying one thing to another. It has pretty much all the things that make my stomach happy, me being a food enthusiast. The price is decent. I also like how the whole market seems to always be energetic and buzzing with excitement. There is a crepe place, which name escapes me, that I love. I did say the taste can be hit and miss. But I'm giving it 5 stars? Well, because of the variety. When I found out I didn't like something, I knew I had other options, and lots of them.

I would come back here if I'm in town.

The Reading Terminal Market was full of food vendors, craft shops, a bookstore, and an amazing produce market. It certainly was a feast for the eyes, but due to the early closing time on Sunday, my friend and I weren't able to experience any of the food for ourselves. We were disappointed about that, but were pretty excited just walking around for a little while and looking at all of the shops. The thing that really stuck with me about the place was that people were not friendly. We were taken aback when we were kicked out of the market. We were making our way outside at the time, and it was jarring to be yelled at on the way out. Woah.

It's a no brainer.  If you're in Philly, you have to go to Reading Terminal Market.  

We were fortunate to have stayed in a hotel two blocks away, so were went to the market at least one, if not twice, each day.  There are a mix of sit-down and casual restaurants, as well as stands selling local produce, ice cream,  cholocates, pretzels, fresh fish and seafood, honey and preserves, and the list goes on.  

We spent just as much time wandering around looking at the various offerings as we did eating. We tried deli, Greek, hoagies, and more. It was awesome, and a very affordable way to have breakfast or lunch.

My new favorite find in Philly! This place is full of all types of food vendors, bookstores, jewelry and craft shops, fresh local produce, honey and preserves, desserts, ice cream, bread, fresh seafood, and tons more. I wish I could've had more time and tummy space to sample everything!! And I loved how it feels like a real local market right in the middle of downtown.

4 words:
pumpkin loaf with creamcheese!!!!!!







(amish booth pronto)
Love this place! Go there to eat, grab a beer...or just hangout! Really gives you a local vibe of what Philly is all about.

This place is really great. I would have to say it's one of the best markets I've ever been to because of two reasons: Variety and Quality. There is basically any food you can think of, some of the choices include French Crepes, Gyros, Deli style sandwiches, Chicken, Cookies, Baked goods, Chocolates, and so much more. The place is usually very crowded because of it's popularity but the prices are fair with some more expensive things (like $10 for a sandwich). I got a cornbeef sandwich at one of the Deli's and it was delicious, very fresh and good quality. It's fun to just walk around and look at all the things they have there. There is also an amazingly cheap produce area. I got a pack of white grapes for 90 cents! It's the cheapest produce I've found in the city. Near the produce section there is also a variety of dried fruits and trail mixes. The Chocolate peanut butter trail mix is so good. I would recommend this place to anyone who wants to bypass the typical sit down restaurant and spend an afternoon exploring all the different stands this market has to offer. Also to anyone who doesn't mind a big crowd (especially on the weekend).
