One of the top sites to see in Philadelphia, I'd spend a morning here getting some fresh baked goods to eat, or wander in for a lunch at the tasty diner. Pick up chocolate treats, fresh fish, meat, and vegetables, all without too much of a premium.

Come for the Amish donuts (freshly made!), loaves of classic breads, and baked pies, pick up your turkeys here for Thanksgiving, and look for the delicious ribs to the southwest side.  There are plenty of homemade jams and preserves, organic foods, and small restaurants to eat at inside, newly made ice cream, and many many snacks.

Random bookstores and craft shops also here... the only downside is that they close early, around 8 or so most days, sometimes earlier, so make sure you make it there earlier in the day!

Incidentally, the diner to the south - love the sawmill gravy biscuits here.
you have to go if you ever visit philly. they have every type of food vendor you can think of. cheap and just....great.

I go to the Reading Terminal at least once a week to buy my vegetables and eat lunch. I love the options that it has to offer, and the produce prices at Iovine Brothers are nearly unbeatable. Whatever you need in terms of food, you can probably find it here: imported cheeses, fresh seafood (I'd recommend John Yi Fish Market), spices, produce, meat... you name it. Mostly everything is reasonably priced, too. If you're looking for lunch, you'll find Chinese (Shanghai Gourmet is delicious, especially their Hunan Chicken), Thai, pizza, vegetarian options, hoagies, cheesesteaks... pretty much anything your tastebuds could possibly crave. I love the Reading Terminal!
I challenge you to find a better local place with more selection of food and fresh groceries. The prices are fair, too.

As soon as I walked in, I said it reminded me of Essex St. Market in NYC...but as I kept walking, I realized it was just bigger and better (and I love the Essex market). This place blew me away. If you can't find something to eat here, you are going to have to turn in your digestive system. You don't deserve it. 

The smells, the colors, it's completely overwhelming. I saw amazing prices on everything from fish to fruit to beautiful NY strips ($10.99/lb). If I wasn't hopping on a train for an hour back to NYC, I would've stocked up for sure. 

Somehow I got talked into eating an enormous roast pork hero from Dinic's with delicious spicy peppers all over it. For breakfast. And it was phenomenal.

I love markets like this. Only thing is I wish I were her visiting rather than on an assignment. My then bf told me to check this place out when I was in Philly for a project, so I dragged my entire team that's used to doing lunch @ the Palm or somewhere in the vicinity of where the client was located out to Reading. I had a quick walk in the market and was intrigued. I would have wanted to explore the eateries more and try a couple out but the problem with having a client expense budget is.... my colleagues wanted fancy schmancy lunches rather than what was offered at Reading. Bleah, so like I said, right place, wrong time.

We ended up doing lunch at Maggiano's which was just outside Reading. BTW, I bet we could have had a tastier lunch had we decided to eat in Reading instead.

This is one of those places where you learn of it's existence and feel robbed that you missed out beforehand.

Sure, some of the items are trucked in "Dole" boxes of produce and others might be things you may find at the local grocery store but there are gems in this place that make the drive worth it every time.

My personal favorite: The Amish pretzels that you will never have anywhere else.  Perfect buttery delicious pretzels surrounding homecrafted sausage or ham and homemade american cheese.  Yes, the combination is about the best thing on earth and I promise you, nothing else you will find comes close.  I'd drive an hour and a half for one of those.

There are alot of places that I don't ever recall by name like the place that has deep fried scallops and fries, many fresh squeezed orange juice vendors, preserves, produce, meats etc.  

This is a real gem, you owe it to yourself to check it out.  I'll be visiting this weekend in fact!

Love this market!  It's great and has every type of cuisine that one could ever want.  During lunch this place is packed with locals, convention goers and tourists.  It can be difficult to find seating.  However, worth taking the chance. 

Whether you need cheesesteaks, pizza, a hoagie, water ice, vegetarian dishes or dessert; this place has it all.  It is also a great place to pick up fresh produce, baked goods or meat.  It's a shame that more cities don't have places like Reading Terminal market!

Ok ok....Philly can be proud on this market. It is on par with San Francisco's Ferry Building Farmer's Market or Toronto's St. Lawrence Market. Legitmately numerous food options that satisfy the foodie and don't hurt the pocket book. Unfortunately I went on a Monday and the Amish section (based on reviews is great) is only open from Wed-Sat. 
The places that looked busy included Sang Kee Peking House (Chinese), Franks (BBQ), Thai place, Delilah's (Southern) and some Italian specialty place. Hard to decide, but I was hungry and settled on Delilah's (Oprah's favorite mac and cheese). Platter with two sides, $9.75, full meal and tasty. Great place to pursue and grab a tasty lunch with friends. Nothing too fancy and if you're a local, probably a great place to grab some meats and specialty items. Worth the lunch stop when in Philly.

Hungry? Visit here. It has everything from root beer to fish! The best place to grab some fresh veggies and make a wonderful dinner! From crepes' to soul food to drinks to fish to danish it is the best place to go!

We love this place, every time we end up in Philadelphia this is one of the places we go to. The diversity of food, unbelievable, I found even products from my homeland. Now that's for me something to be excited about. But can anybody explain to me what is so Dutch about the Pennsylvania Dutch? 

Last time we visited Philly, we were standing with Al Roker in line for a sandwich and another cool thing to know is that Reading Terminal Market is also highlighted in National Treasure, when Abigail Chase (Diane Kruger) is being chased by a bad guy. 

First thing to do when at 'RTM' is just to stroll around and observe and make note of all the good stuff they sell here. After making a decision what to order, the next objective is to find a area to sit and enjoy the food. (during lunch it is packed!) After finishing the meal, one more round through all the different booths, and maybe a desert to go.

i love love love this place, where else can u go for a one stop shopping for fresh produce, yummy freshly baked goods, real southern cooking and ginormous crepes? it reminds of me a bigger and better Essex Street market in nyc.

It's whackadoodle that I've never reviewed Reading Terminal Market, seeing as how it's one of those places I always encourage visitors to check out when they're in Philly. All kinds of yummy adventures await you inside those walls, the most awesome of which is Beiler's Whoopie Pie. Go early in the day because they sell out often - they're only $1 and are the closest approximation to earthly bliss I've ever experienced. 

Fresh produce, fish, meat, flowers, baked goods (make sure to stop by Flying Monkey Patisserie for some cupcakes to wash down your Whoopie Pie) and more...the choices are outrageous and there's something for everyone. I also love me some Delilah's for Southern food and the Amish food counter for some breakfast delights.  If you have the option of not visiting at lunchtime, I highly suggest you stay far away, as the experience just isn't the same when it's crowded; and trust me, the elbow to boob factor is crazy high during peak hours! If you've gotta be there between 11:30 and 1:30, might I suggest donning some full body armor?

This place is amazing. The fresh variety of foods available here boggles my mind every time. The Amish places are my absolute favorite no doubt. The place way in back next to the bread bakery place is the best for chili! cheap too. GREAT lemonade. Best I've ever had actually. The fruit places are cheap too. I saw blood oranges for 3 a dollar! Those are expensive suckers and that was cheap! White asparagus too! The meats aren't bad either and that old used book store is adorable. It's a wonderful place and I just can't say enough about it. If you're visiting do yourself a favor and go! :)
Every time I am in the city over night I HAVE to stop by the Reading Terminal to pick up something delicious! Whatever you want, they have it here!

I stayed at the Hilton around the corner and snuck away from my group of friends to scope out this place.  I had seen the colorful fruits and veggies from the windows and thought "Hmmm, I'll check this out"

Sensory overload but in SUCH a good way!!!

Later, my friends couldn't decide where to eat and I suggested this place since it has tons of eateries with hundreds of types of different kinds of food.  There are a few Amish booths that have dry goods and delicious treats for sale.  Boy, can the Amish cook!  They have no holds when it comes to cream (HEAVY whipping cream mind you) on top of desserts and prices set so low I feel like I'm ripping THEM off.  $2.80 for a 6" apple pie with ice cream or whipped cream - seriously?!

Brisket, Gyros, Philly Cheesesteaks, chocolate freshly made in front of you, bakeries, Sushi, delis, fish markets, fruit markets, dry goods - it's all here.  It will satiate even the pickiest eater, but the hardest part is just trying to decide what to eat.....

Went here for Sunday afternoon snacks, around 2pm. This place is great and I'm a big fan of marketplaces like Pike Place and Chelsea Market, so I had to go visit. It's located conveniently near the Convention Center, so if you're ever in town for an event there it makes it perfect for grabbing an affordable meal. 

For a Sunday a lot of the vendors were open. It was nice to just walk around and see all the varieties of food available. It seems like they have everything  from Indian to Mexican to Kosher Deli to Crepes. Along with prepared food, there are numerous meat, cheese, produce, bread, bakeries, chocolate, etc vendors. It is a foodie's heaven as any market is.  It was pretty busy around the one entrance we came through as a produce/meat stand was right there. My companion and I setted on some fried chicken from Delilahs which I was told was beat by Bobby Flay during a Macaroni and Cheese smackdown challenge thing. Afterwards we went to Flying Monkey Bakery for brownies and walked around. There is plenty of seating, as most food stands have counter seating and there are tables and chairs located throughout the market. The only downside is that there is one bathroom and it's pretty small so you probably have to wait.  

Aside from food, there are several plant, gift, etc vendors. It's definitely a place you want to check out when you're visiting Philadelphia, especially when you are hungry and indecisive, because I'm pretty sure you'll be able to find something there! If not, then there is something wrong with you.

Very cool market right in the city...both times I have been to Philly, I spent a couple hours wandering around.  A whole lot of things going on, so we had a seat in the beer garden to soak it all in.  Interesting meats, cheeses and other interesting things to look at, I recommend this as an awesome way to kill an afternoon.

Only downside is that it gets extremely crowded, and it closes by about 4pm on a Sunday.

Two bad things about RTM (pronounced "Redding", I believe):  1)  They close too early!  We tried to stop in for dinner on Friday but were rejected.

2)  There's too many choices!  We came in for an early dinner/late lunch Saturday and spent nearly an hour trying to find what each of us wanted.

As a bunch of tourists, my sister, her boyfriend and I were completely surprised by this place as we walked from Chinatown back to our hotel.  There were so many sights, sounds, and smells to take in.  Definitely someplace to stop by in the city.  Oh, and as the place approaches closing, look for bargains on baked goods!  I got a delicious raspberry chocolate cookie for 75 cents!

This is a must-see in the city, I found that it wasn't just a tourist trap. Even many locals make the market a regular stop. I really liked all the food I tried, but what really pushed it over the top for me was getting to stare at all the real Pennsylvania Dutch people who run many of the stalls. Hey, I'm from California, I've never seen them before!

I really wish I could've brought home some of those whoopie pies, they were AMAZING. That was the stand-out item for me. But due to their delicate nature and chocolate coating, they would not have traveled well. I did buy their pecan brittle, and that was very tasty.

The ice cream at L.D. Bassett was good. Not wow, but good. Our sandwich from DiNic's was really good, but I'm glad we split it in half to make room for everything else. I also liked the chocolate peanut butter cupcake from Flying Monkey, very moist and the frosting wasn't overly sweet.

The only disappointment for me were the chocolate chip cookies from the 4th Street Cookie company. Where's the cookie? It's all chocolate. I prefer my cookies to have a nice balance between the chocolate chips and a buttery, brown-sugary dough. But there was hardly any dough, and the dough that was there had a weird fruity sweetness. Do they sweeten with fruit juice or something? I got a really weird after-taste. I guess people like them when they're warm, because the chocolate is melty. But once they cool down, they're just not worth it.

Stopped by here last weekend after a meal in Chinatown.  It was super crowded on a Saturday around noon.  They have a ton of stalls here all with different things - typical farmers market with butchers, produce, cheese shops, eateries, and etc.  I enjoyed the one store called the Spice Terminal.  They had a TON of spices, as well as coffee and tea.  They also had this good cupcake place right outside of the Spice Terminal (but the name escapes me..)

The market is pretty good since I don't know of another farmer's market in the area...I woulda given it a 5, but I expected more from a farmer's market in a city (in comparison to the Allentown Farmer's Market in the Lehigh Valley).  There was nothing really that made me feel like I need to make my way down to the Reading Terminal Market instead of going to the closer (for me) Allentown Farmer's Market.

It is still definitely worth checking out and it's still very fascinating, hectic, and awesome.

Reading Terminal Market is one of Philadelphia's treasures.  There are (?) dozens of stands at the Market-- fresh produce, fish, meat, prepared food, bakeries, Bassetts Ice Cream (called the best commercially available ice cream in the country by the NY Times), killer pastries of every description, Delilah's soul food (her mac and cheese won Oprah's mac and cheese cook off and I'm not quarreling with the results, it's amazing) the list goes on, and on, and on.  In my opinion, the Terminal is  the single best place for lunch in downtown Philadelphia.   The only problem is that you have to choose between Peking duck, falafel, fried oysters,  and barbecue. Leave room for dessert.

I just discovered this hidden treasure last summer.. and I'm telling you!  If you love food, this will be your haven.  You can find Amish bakery and kitchen goods, unique smoothie combinations, french food, desserts, pizza, italian, cheeses, honey items, lots of seafood and fruit (for good prices).. there's a great chocoate dipped cookie place there.... and even philly cheesesteaks.... I haven't even mentioned HALF of what Reading Terminal Market has to offer.  It is simply an energetic and ecclectic environment for food lovers.. just don't take someone there who doesn't like crowds.. they may be a little intimidated!  But it is a MUST for any Philly visitor!

LOVED THIS PLACE! I love farmer's markets and this one is so awesome. My senses went in overload just trying to take in everything I saw. Great food! I seriously wished I had 5 stomachs so I could eat everything I wanted there. Amish bakery and stalls had great honey selections. 

If I go back to Philly, this is a sure place to chow down.

This is one of my favorite things about living in Center City! The market has fresh produce (at ridiculously low prices), Metropolitan Bakery has amazing bread, and Farm Fresh Produce (I think that's what it's called) has fabulous local/organic/yummy/unusual stuff. I try to do as much of my grocery shopping here as I can--usually go weekly after work. There are also a couple of great places to get fresh (local) meat and good fish. Love this place!

I'm not sure why I hadn't gone here before in my year-long (and counting) stay of Philadelphia, especially when its less than 5 minutes by car from work.  I LOVED this place.  Polite workers, bustling "market" feel, fresh produce, bakery, eateries, shops, etc.  Didn't spend a lot of time here, but I will be certain to go back.  I don't think that the 2 mini-tubs of specialty cream cheese (jalapeno and vegetable) in my fridge will do anything for my figure, but honestly, it is really that good.  

My one minor complaint is that the "oyster bar" at the front end (?) of the place only served fried ones!  :(

I usually review this place on a place by place basis, but Reading Terminal is an absolute institution in Philly, a must hit for any visitors, and a god-send when I'm trying to find fresh, local ingredients (particularly during the colder months).

Just next to our hotel we did a walking tour then loaded up with a salad and some cheeses for our room.  Clearly a well earned reputation for a most-see spot in city center.  Lots of local color and foods with a mix of locally grown produce and fruits, plenty of places to eat diner style with counter and stool and a remarkable set of gourmet speciality shops with experts to help you with selections.  Fantastic place to checkout just as all the other reviews said.  Amazing!

Hinter dem Namen Reading Terminal Market konnte ich mir anfangs nicht wirklich vorstellen, was sich dahinter verbarg. Doch die Überraschung war umso größer, als ich herrausfand, dass er ein großer Markt für frisches Gemüse, Fleisch, Meeresfrüchte, Backwaren, Bücher, Kleidung und und und ist.


 Über 80 Verkäufer tummeln sich in diesem Markt. Es ist laut und ein wenig stickig. Vor allem hat sich der Markt darauf spezialisiert frisch zubereitete Gerichte zu verkaufen. Hier bekommt man Amerikanisch, Italienisch, Japanisch, Thai, Chinesisch, Mexikanisch und Speisen und Getränke aus aller Herrenländer.


 Heutzutage sind aber noch nur noch 3 Verkäufer aus Originalfamilien der Gründerzeit des Reading Terminal Market.


 Vor allem Mittags ist hier die Hölle losHier holen sich die Leute ihr Mittagessen aus den umliegenden Büros. Ebenfalls ist der Markt direkt mit dem Marriott Downtown und dem Convention Center verbunden.


 Und für die, die auch mittags weiterarbeiten möchten, gibt es im Reading Terminal Market komplett kostenlos W-Lan.

Lots of variety, lots of fun!

You can find everything here, from a standard salad bar, to fish places, sushi, chinese, middle eastern, Italian, Greek, Jewish, German... It's going to be hard to decide on a place to eat!

Besides the food places, they also have fresh produce, fish, meats, books, crafts, gifts, candy, chocolates, pickles and jams (Amish), ice cream, bakeries, coffee...

Note: about half the places are closed on Sundays, but we found a live band there on Saturday...?!!

This place was great! it had so much personality! so much food so little time! I was just a bit annoyed because my bf and I were getting so confused in here! we were running around in circles trying to get away from the booths we've already passed by. But this place was great! next time i'll make sure to bring more money =P

I love this place! If ever in Philadelphia, this is a *must* stop! 

I loved the fact there were so many people and a foodie's haven. Anything you can think of, they have it here. Not only do the tourists eat here, the locals, too.

Truly is a must stop when in Philly. 

Different varieties of food ranging from Indian to Chinese. Tons of bakeries with cupcakes :) (red velvet in fact!) 
Bassett's ice cream is another good stop here. 

They also have a juice bar, spice shop, souvenir stores...the possibilities are endless! 

A great place to get souvenir...lot to choose from. 
I got a beeswax candle for mom. :)

Wow, this place was a top highlight of our Philly visit. Bakeries, eateries, meat markets, florists, and other cute stores fill this space. I enjoy anything Amish so seeing them in action made me happy. One could easily spend an hour or two checking out this market.

Love, love, love Reading Terminal Market!

Growing up with Pike's Place in Seattle sets a pretty high bar for farmer's market quality.  Reading Terminal does not disappoint -- cheese steaks, Amish pastries, and buskers by the dining tables.  No fish means no weird smells, to boot.

Oh, and everyone pronounces it 'reeding' market, awesome!

I would honestly move to Philly just to be able to eat here regularly.  

It is a foodie's HEAVEN!  

I can't actually say much that hasn't been said before, but this place is amazing.  I loved all the fresh cheeses, honey and jam made by the Amish merchants.

I could easily give this 5 stars, but the day I went here the Amish were not and the continued whispers of "if only the Amish were here" were constant reminders that I am a tourist and that I was missing out on a lot of the charm and flavor they add to this tasty space.

The only other thing missing I felt was a hospital triage to help overeaters restart their hearts after sucking down Delilah's famous Oprah's heart winning mac n cheese or inhaling a Tommy Dinic masterpiece of slow cooked brisket wit provolone and peppers.

The only place i would skip would be the sushi joint...or just go sashimi style as the rice was tasteless and mushy and caused the only frown in the place.

Best visited in the off hours as the lunch rush lines can be too annoying, but it is a city of beautiful people and your chances of meeting a hottie lawyer increase...so just know what you're getting yourself into.

I went with the reviews and  had it on my "must see list"...the first night I was in there a gray baby rat ran across the floor I screamed and left. It took me 2 days to go back. 

Basic 4 Vegetarian Snack Bar is great! Their vegetarian cheese steak is as close as you can get and don't forget to add on the sweet potato fries.
Tried to go to Delilahs but during the lines are insane!
Went to the Crepe spot across from Delilahs but I wasn't impressed with the service. The lady taking the orders left us standing there for 2 minutes. Another customer came and she was quick to ask them for their order, they asked if we ordered already, and she had the audacity to say we already ordered!!! WE NEVER EVEN SPOKE TO HER!!!

In all, its a def a foodies dream come true...def a big variety of foods. Oh and not all places take credit cards.

I've got mixed feelings on RTM.  It's a great place to buy fresh produce for cheeps, plus I love the variety of cheeses, bread, handmade chocolates, and other goodies.   But when it's crowded -- which is basically all weekend --  it's a special piece of hell right here in Philadelphia.  I'll gladly pay the extra couple of $$ at Whole Foods to avoid that mess!

The takeout food is hit or miss.  Basic 4 Vegetarian has pissed me off more times than I can count by being closed during mealtime hours or simply out of whatever menu item I want.  The crepe place is okay, nothing special.  The Indian/ Pakistani place is excellent.  The juice bar is a refreshing treat.  Oh, and in case you are curious and/or drunk:  do not eat the sushi!!

Reading Terminal is one of my favorite places in the world!  Anytime I'm in Philly I must come here.  While it is famous, it's by no means a tourist trap.  Products here are excellent, and if you live nearby you can easily get great meat and produce for not much money.  It's also a great gateway to amish country as there are tons of amish vendors here!  All food stalls that I've been to have been great, and you'll find a huge selection of fresh baked goods, grilled meats, and food from around the world.

It's also home to a Hope's Cookies location, which may be the greatest cookies in the entire world.

eh. i "get it", i just dont like it. too crowded and overwhelming. i like going to smell the smells but ive never had a great experience finding anything i want there. the sushi place inside is the pits. ive tried some other places and havent been impressed. mostly i think bc of the surroundings. but i always go back so it cant be that bad.

mm, this is one of my favorite places in the city! Every time I go I love to stop at The Dutch Eating Place and enjoy a hot turkey sandwich or the chicken pot pie (if you're expecting a crust, the pie isn't for you...it's more of a delicious Chicken and Dumplings, and it is absolutely core-warming) The portions her are huge, and I highly recommend their fries. As a fry lover they are some of the best I've ever eaten.

Whenever we're done we like to go get a cone of Amish ice cream and wander around looking at our favorite shops: The spice shop, the candy store that has chocolate toffee pretzels (best in the world!!), and the honey store to get beeswax candles or honey sticks. It's also very nice to look at the flowers and before we leave to grab a slice of cake from the bakery next to the Dutch Eating Place.

By the time we roll out of here (literally, by this point we've gorged ourselves SOO much walking is no longer an option) we've had a great time that was totally worth the price.

Dear Reading,

Why are you closed on July 4th?  Give me one decent answer as to why one of the biggest draws in the city is closed on the city's biggest holiday.  

Imagine that you are a tourist from somewhere.  You take the plunge and decide that you want to take the family to Philadelphia for the 4th of July celebration.  You have know all about independence hall and the liberty bell but your tourist guide also points out a large market where they have tons of great food.  You and the family walk from indy hall to the market which is no small feat considering they are from the suburbs and walking is alien and weird.  On top of that, they just got the fright of their life as it was a walk through Market East and by the gallery.  But you made it!  And you walk up and find that the market is closed.  How pissed would YOU be?

It's this kind of logic/attitude/work ethic that keeps Philly from being anything but than a could-have-been.  

While we are on that subject, do you not realize that you are above a train station and that people might want to get meat sliced before they head home?  Why is it when I walk in after 5, your meat vendors turn me away because they don't want to get their already cleaned machines dirty nor do they want to stay a minute past 6pm?  

Honestly Reading.  Despite all of your local flavor and great produce, I'm am seriously convinced that you want to fail.

Not bad. Mostly food venues. Corn bread at Franks is good. Original Turkey is not bad. Ice cream at Bassett's is yummy. Famous 4th street cookies are over rated. Good place to go to for desserts, the food is just a-okay. I went on a sunday, a lot of places were closed. Boo.

Beware of the sensory overload when you step into this wonderful haven of delightful, coma-inducing collection of cheesesteaks, hoagies, pulled pork sandwiches, stuffed pretzels, wonderfully thick cookies, moist cupcakes, and other beautiful items of fatty glory. 

Being my first trip there, I was not prepared for what I saw, and then for what I tasted. Every bite of anything I ate was delicious. I wish I could give you specific names of places but all I can give you is various foods and their descriptions. I had a stuffed pretzel stick that had pepperoni, mozzarella, and marinara inside which was excellent. I followed that up with a pulled-pork sandwich which was amazingly juicy and meaty. For dessert, I had a really thick cookie with milk and a slice of carrot cake. I was actually going to go for another cupcake and cheesesteak until my girlfriend halted my obese behavior. I did buy a couple of loaves of some apple cinnamon bread baked by Amish girls for our moms however.

I really have no qualms about the place. They even provide a voucher for free parking in the parking complex next door for two hours which was enough time to walk around the market, stuff my face, actually go outside and enjoy the surrounding area (there's some really cool historic buildings and outdoor plazas nearby), and then come back to buy some ice cream and then go home with 10 minutes to spare. Being from NYC, I thought we had it all. I was proven wrong when I came here and was assaulted by the freshness of their food at such affordable prices. I plan on coming here every time I visit Philly. 

New York needs a Reading Terminal Market!
How can you not like a place that from door to door the smell is yummy.  General Store, Steaks and fresh food ... they are the best

Me and my wife went thru Philly for vacation and This is a GREAT PLACE for lunch near the liberty bell! Has everything from cookies, to fruits and veggies,to soap and spices, to restaurants that are mouthwatering great! We had a cheesesteak and a turkey sandwich and both were great! Did I mention cookies? 
The only part that disappointed us was that some stuff wasnt open on tuesdays but its still great.

You spin my head right round, right round, when you go down, when you go downtown. Yes, I did change the lyrics. How does one justify America's oldest Farmer's Market, the Reading Terminal Market, when writing a review... You don't. 

Your head literally does spin around when you enter for your first time. Once you know the market well and where your favorite purveyors are, I'm sure it's a walk through the park. I had to see it all. 

A portion of the market does have Amish vendors, but you will only find them here Wednesdays through Saturdays, even though the rest of the market is open seven days per week. 

There are over eighty vendors and covers over 1.7 acres. Two descendants of original shops are still there. This market has also been in numerous movies, including Trading Places. 

I walked into aromas of freshly baked chocolate chip cookies and convinced myself, it was too early plus it was only vendor one, even though ten minutes later I was eating some of the best and hot pepperoni pizza I have had. 

There are six bakeries, two of which I purchased baked goods from and one that I have reviewed so far. I was not thrilled with Le Bus http://www.yelp.com/biz/le-bus-bakery-philadelphia-2, but I was very happy with Termini Brothers Bakery, which I will review eventually. 

They have a nice wine shop and beer garden where I noticed a few drinking beer at ten in the morning, a tea shop, coffee, dairy shops and a juice bar, where you can get blended and frozen concoctions. 

A homemade ice cream parlor http://www.yelp.com/biz/bassetts-ice-cream-philadelphia, cheese shops, fresh flowers, organic produce and raw milk. One place that I really loved was Salumeria, what an awesome market filled with Italian groceries, hoagies, salads and international cheese. 

Local produce stands are huge and if you love variety this is your place. All locally grown and talk about a variety of mushrooms! Shops galore for cookbooks, used books, linens, pottery, crafts, handbags, a general store and Amy's Place filled with unique gifts, especially for a house warming gift or a new bride. 

There are a good dozen or more meat, poultry and seafood shops and some will cook it right there for you. I did notice that on each cash counter, they do have posted whether or not they accept credit cards and if they do the minimum amount to charge. 

Now I'm getting hungry, amazing pulled pork and beef brisket http://www.yelp.com/biz/tommy-dinics-philadelphia#hrid:kJ9LwByjlxBcrf_cNZyJUA/src:search/query:Tommy%20DeNic's, pizza, pasta to go or eat there, sandwiches, cheesesteaks http://www.yelp.com/biz/by-george-philadelphia, perogies or crab cakes at Coastal Cave, mac & cheese or fried chicken at Delilah's http://www.yelp.com/biz/delilahs-at-the-terminal-philadelphia-2 

You can sit down in one restaurant and have a wonderful breakfast, which gets packed, there is sushi, a spice shop http://www.yelp.com/biz/spice-terminal-philadelphia, a little Thai market and chocolates galore. 

Originally named the Jersey Market, since most farmers, fisherman and hunters were carrying their goods from the neighboring state to be sold here. After many complaints from the town folks of this non refrigerated outdoor market, it was dismantled and two new markets evolved from this, the Farmer's Market and the Franklin Market. 

This site has been in use as a Farmer's Market since 1860 on High Street, it soon was renamed Market Street and moved indoors in 1892, because of health risks, traffic nuisances and it needed to be controlled. The Reading Railroad built the Reading Terminal Market as part of their use for downtown passengers. 

The hustle and bustles, aromas and excitement fill the air and whenever I have out of town friends or family, who want to tour historic Philadelphia, I am bringing them here. 

The market is closed on certain holidays and they do not keep long evening hours. Parking at several local garages can be validated inside the Terminal and will reduce your $10.00 cost to $4.00, if you are there for two hours or less. 

Many places offer a seven dollar meal deal and have them well posted. From what I noticed they seemed like a good deal.  I am not sure what the story of Philbert is, I do know that he is a pig that was created by Eric Berg and he is surrounded by money. Anyway, he is pretty cool and located at the end of the central cafeteria style dining area. 

I do hope that I did the Terminal some kind of justice, it is too awesome for words! There are out door cafe tables for two & bongos playing outside..

So, as I am walking through the market, everyone was staring at me and I do mean everyone. Finally two police officers approach me and say "you can not wear that t-shirt in here"! As I am looking down to see what in the world I had put on that morning, my daughter said " Oh yes she can, six time Super Bowl champions"! The officers laughed and said, "yeah, I guess she can"!  What was I thinking?!
it's a fun place. we have this type of market in nyc so only 3 stars.
amazing produce.  amazing cold cuts & cheeses.  blueberry and cherry jams with zero sugar or corn syrup.  a beer garden with blue moon on tap.  free wifi.  what's not to like?

I remember wandering through Reading Terminal Market once several years ago, but I don't remember being all that enamored.  I'm pretty sure this was before I turned into a Food Network junkie, before I ever cooked for myself, before I had any kind of appreciation for fresh, quality ingredients, and certainly long before I began Yelping.

What my friends and I thought would be a pretty quick trip turned into a two-hour exploration.  Because it was a Sunday morning, the Amish vendors were closed, but since I have yet to sample their wares, I didn't miss them.  There was plenty to choose from: produce, spices, meat, cheeses, seafood, baked goods...  Maybe it was just the novelty of the place, but I felt inspired to create.

When we had finally filled our shopping bags with various fresh finds, we decided to get something prepared to eat.  We ended up at Kamal's Middle Eastern Specialties, where I tasted my first falafel and lamb shawerma.  Delish!  We ended at Flying Monkey Patisserie where, forced with too many choices, I ordered a brownie to eat at that moment, plus 4 different cupcakes to take home.

Since there are less merchants open on Sundays, RTM was not that crowded during my visit.  I was satisfied with the choices that remained, but am definitely curious enough about what wasn't open to brave what I hear will be a pretty chaotic weekday.

I try to go to Reading Terminal whenever I have a free weekday afternoon.  At first this place can be incredibly overwhelming because it gets so crowded you can barley move.  This is a great place to visit with family because there is something that is bound to satisfy everyones tastes.  I wish they were open later because sometimes I want to stop by for dinner.  Parking near here is a nightmare so don't bother. Certain places aren't open on certain days (I went this past Monday and the Amish dealers were closed). My advice, pick a day later in the week and go when the lunch crowd dies down, making your trip less hectic with more options.

This place was so much fun. There was so much to try. The homemade ice cream was amazing as well as the sample of chicken pot pie soup and lemonade I tried. Oh and the homemade carrot bread. A huge assortment of fresh products. It was fun watching some of the Amish making stuff from scratch. And the thing that shoots out rice cakes. It was packed on a Saturday for an early lunch, but pretty dead when we came back on Sunday for breakfast since the Amish and most of the other vendors were not there. They also had farm animals and music outside when we were there on Saturday. 

I wish I had a place like this closer to home. I will be back next time I'm in Philly!

A Foodie central.  An over-eater's mecca. A chronic snacker's delight.

Reading Terminal satisfies one's every need, but only when it's not packed.  I just can't handle it here when I have to fight my way through the narrow paths between the stalls during busy lunches and mid-afternoons on the weekends.  So go, early on weekends, late afternoons during the week and you'll be (or I will) just fine.

Food from around the globe, whatever your heart desires, it's pretty certain you can get it here.  Pennsylvania Dutch  (Amish) food counters (are the tops and have the best bacon, sausage, meatstuffs what-have-you, jams, honey),  organic/free-roaming butchers, fish/seafood mongers, Specialty cheese shops, spices, gourmet sauces/marinades/oils/vinegars,  plenty of produce, desserts, so many eating stalls - a international variety , flower/plant shops;  they truly have everything.  

Be sure to stop at Dinic's (if you can weather the astronomically long lines) for your traditional roast pork sammie, Amish Lancaster Co. for freshly-squeezed Orange juice and canned goods, Metropolitan or Le Bus Bakery for bread, Old City Coffee for well, coffee; Flying Monkey Pattisserie for cupcakes, Famous 4th Street Cookie for well, cookies (only get them when they're freshly baked right out of the oven, you'll know), Bassett's for ice cream and Termini Brothers Bakery for cannolis.  Almost all the eateries that surround the proud sculptured pig are a sure bet.  Best yet, try it all for yourself - you're guaranteed to find a handful of places that will tantalize your taste buds.

Bring loads of big heavy-duty bags and patience. Get your parking (make sure you park at the lot on 12th at Cuthbert) validated for $4 by any of the vendors and shop, eat at your heart's content.  Menu plan for a few days. Go hungry.

There was a lot about Philly that I didn't care for, all of which was forgotten when I visited the Reading Terminal Market.  I'm from Massachusetts and I heard some tourist in there say, "This is just like Quincy Market".  Yeah...no.

This is the greatest shopping experience for anyone that digs food.  I give HUGE props to Giunta's butcher stand.  Best steak I've ever had and the service was friendly, even busted my balls a little bit.  Prices were excellent.

If Reading Terminal Market were a woman I would have sweet, sweet relations with it.

Huge enclosed market in the heart of Philly with about every kind of food that you could ever want. Definitely check out the groceries, which are definitely worth the walk, especially if you live in the city.

I don't know why I stop visiting the Reading Terminal. I use to visit the Terminal every Sat when I was in college for fruits and vege. I started again last weekend. My husband and I love to go to Martin's to get their homemade sausages and their meat and Iovine for their produce. If we are early, we would head to Dutch Eating Place for their pancakes and turkey bacon. My favorite lunch is going to Hershels for their pastrami sandwhich or Little Thai Market for their $5.50 Thai lunch boxes. The Terminal is a place where you can get a diverse assortment of food and get fresh produce for your home that beats the supermarket prices.

I love Reading Terminal Market!

What's not to love?  I know fast food gets a bad reputation, but not at Reading Terminal Market.  There's a limitless selection of restaurants that provide fast quick eats for a good value.  PLUS if you're not in the mood for ready-made food, try your luck with the numerous vendors of fresh veggies, fruits, and spices.

The atmosphere inside is also something to note.  There is always a constant buzz of people coming and going.  Scents and aromas from the numerous vendors fill the air, I assure any visitors of Reading Terminal that they will come back for more.  Or you can be like me and  try one, two, five establishments per visit.

When I moved to Philly Reading Terminal Market was one of the places I instantly fell in love with, and I still visit religiously for my lunch breaks (I have a personal mission to eat at all the restaurants in the Market, so far 6 down, a million left to go).  Every visitor should stop by!

Made a trip to the RTM last night and it was amazing, as usual.  Walking into the RTM is like taking a step back in time when people actually shopped their local markets.  Although those times have past (in the age of Giant, Acme, Super Fresh, etc) the one thing that holds true is that the quality at the RTM is far superior and full of ethnicity.  10 stars if I could!

First off, if you live in Philly - or if you're just visiting - and you've never been here, you absolutely must go. This is an excellent place to get meat and produce for shopping- especially if you want fresh seafood- and it is an equally excellent place to stroll around, snack, grab a coffee, and browse.   (On that note there is a book store tucked in the back of the market that has an incredible selection especially if you're into esoteric, occult, or off-the-beaten-path type material. Some of it is downright bizarre- I found a book here by The Black Dot that talks about the "hidden Qabbalistic and sacred geometries of hip hop", which veers periodically into unfounded but entertaining rants about sacred Egyptian magicks.) 

Really, there isn't much I can say about the Reading Terminal Market that isn't good, unless if you're agoraphobic. Also, if you go here with friends and don't have a cell phone, expect to spend half of your time trying to figure out where the hell they are.
Hmm... Awesome indoor market - Wander around and make sure to visit Termini's and get a banana (just tell the lady at the counter)

Every time I've visited Philly, I've made it a point to stop here. Everyone should, because it is the best day of food you will experience here or really anywhere. The only bad thing about Reading Terminal is that I haven't yet developed the stomach capacity to eat everything that I want to in one trip. If you live in the area and you haven't tried this place, do so now, but at your own risk--you might be coming back every day and gaining 10 pounds in the process. I know I would. 

Here are my favorite places to check out:

-the amish pretzels (so deliciously buttered)
-Dutch Eating Place (the Amish also make a damn good breakfast)
-Bassett's Ice Cream
-4th Street Cookies

The produce and the flowers are also fresh and beautiful. Basically, this place is paradise.

Rarely do places live up to reviews like this place did.   I visited Philly this past weekend and knew I had to hit up the Market.  It ended up being a block from the hotel and it was AMAZING.  Seriously if you eat (which should be everyone) then this place is for you.  I was thinking about moving to Philly, renting out one of the vendor stalls ,and just living there.  Truly one of the greatest places I have ever been to and I will go back to Philly just because of this Market.

I heart Reading Terminal, it's my home away from home. It's hands down my favorite place in Philly! I'm here pretty much once a week to get my produce. Just walking around & people watching makes me happy!
I'm partial to the produce but they also have great food! (Thai, Deli, Veggie options etc) When I'm in the mood for some really good bread I go right to Metropolitan Bakery. Pretty much everything you need is right here.

The soft pretzel at Reading Terminal Market is the BEST.  You won't be able to eat any other pretzels for a while after tasting the real stuff.  The way they are making it.... soooo great.    I cannot wait to go back there...  Other venders are also really great.  Some produce are rather expensive, but they are all quite worth it.

A great indoor farmers market/specialty food shop/eatery-cafe. Even though I checked it out at the tail end of its hours of operations, it looked like this place had booths of fairly equal proportions to fresh foods to specialty foods to eateries.  If I had an appetite during my visit I would've surely stuffed myself trying to sample all the eatery offerings.  I've fallen in love with Reading Terminal Market and all of Philadelphia it represents.  I must revisit with a group so I can try all that this place has to offer.

The kind of food oasis the concrete desert wanderer dreams about. Just about every kind of fresh food you probably crave in the middle of a workday, and some you didn't know you wanted.

The "street signs" along the aisles are clutch, so pay attention - it's easy to forget where you saw the fresh red snapper or those mozzarella balls, since the sheer visual overload produced by so many juicy vittles is enough to scramble your guidance system.

Decent produce - there's better in the city, but not with the convenience afforded by shopping for your faves and eating them both in the same spot. The variety of cuisine collected in one place is the Terminal Market's main draw; perogies or crepes, you'll likely find some way to get your filling.

Pigs in a blanket from the Amish pretzel place. Do you really need anything else?

Another Philly staple that I've been visiting practically my entire life, but they've been switching things up a bit too much lately. It seems like every time I come home on break, another one of my favorite stands has disappeared or moved...what gives??

As a tourist, I like. It's just the right size without being overwhelming (no, actually, it was overwhelming due to all the meal and dessert choices; definitely arrive on an empty stomach!). Everything is kept clean with accessible, regularly-emptied disposal bins. There is a good mix of vendors providing ready-to-consume food or ingredients to make your own meals at home. Definitely stop by for lunch if you are visiting town!

I could get lost in a place like this and never come out. Sensory overload is almost impossible not to experience, since you're bombarded with foodstuffs from all angles. 

Bonus: penny smashing machine!

Now that I lead food tours, and several of the stops are in Reading Terminal Market, I have even more respect and appreciation for this market. Did you know that all the vendors in here are completely local? They have to be in order to even be allowed to sell their food in here. Also, there really is a complete selection of everything from Dinic's roast pork sandwiches (which make me want to quit being a vegetarian when I look at these overflowing meat sandwiches, complete with greens and cheese on a soft roll, just oozing deliciousness), to the best pretzels EVER at Miller's Twist (pretzels that are dipped in butter and are soft and flavorful) , to fresh cookies at Famous Fourth Street cookies... it's incredible. Fresh produce, fresh cheese, fresh meats, fresh hoagies, fresh cheesesteaks, fresh fresh fresh...and with about 80 vendors total, you have a huge selection of choices of cuisine. Oh, and there's a cute bookstore, too, along with some Amish specialty shops, and the "Spice Terminal," if you want more than just food. 

And! One thing that's really awesome is that Reading Terminal Market has recycling containers for plastic bottles everywhere, so you can bring your bottles here to get recycled. 

I am in love with this place. It can definitely be overwhelming, especially on the weekends around lunchtime, but totally worth it. And the smells are amazing of all the freshly cooked, homemade, local food. Yum.

Sensory overload indeed. It doesn't matter what entrance you choose to come in at, nor does it matter the mood you were in when you got there. This place is huge, has lots of everything, and you will definitely find something you've never seen before somewhere in a corner here. Lots of vendors selling various wares and items litter the conglomeration of shops and the outside ring has food just waiting to be eaten. It's a great place that, with an unlimited supply of funds, one could stay here all weekend.

Prepared foods, produce, fresh meats...the market is a wonderland!  The cheese market is great, the sausage guy has great stuff, and there's a Metropolitan Bakery outpost.  Oh, and Flying Monkey Patisserie.  And the shop that carries Wilbur Buds (drops of chocolate created BEFORE Mr. Hershey introduced his own version nearby, hmm).

Great place for tourists and locals alike. Get a great lunch or some reasonably priced ingredients for dinner at home.  

I also love the fact that you can try different kinds of scrapple at various breakfast joints. They've even got a scrapple festival.

This review started with four stars. But as I wrote the review, I convinced myself that it deserves five.

Any visitor to this fair city absolutely must visit Reading Terminal Market. I have my own little routine, places to go, delicacies to enjoy and I suggest you establish your own if you plan on going regularly. Generally I start with dumpling soup, work my way over to roasted chicken wings, lots in-between before rounding it out with a cannoli. Go forth and enjoy.

Yesterday was my first visit to the Terminal market, and I enjoyed it. I've never been to anything like it. I like that there are so many different types of food in one place: Greek, Indian, Mexican, Cajun, Southern, Italian, and Chinese.

The first thing I had was gator gumbo from Beck's Cajun Cafe. It was their first day open, and although they were missing 1/2 of their menu, what I ordered was it was tasty.
Next, I ate a steak taco from the 12th Street Cantina. I wasn't too impress with the dish or the service.
Last, I stopped at LeBus Bakery for an assortment of pastries. So far, the only thing I've eaten is the dark chocolate chip cookie, and I enjoyed it. I think I'll eat the maple pecan scone next.

Anyway, I enjoyed seeing the fish and meat markets, the chocolate stores, and the natural store that sells raw honey.

I wanted to try the salad bar, but I keep thinking that the tongs are covered in germs (not everyone washes their hands you know).

I'll go back again. Hopefully next time, my parking validation will work. I had to pay $4 to get out of the deck.

I just went last w/e and I forgot how cool this place is. It was a rainy miserable day and the RTM was a great place to go since it is indoors. We ate some sandwichs, bought some seafood and crabcakes for din-din, and bought way more sweet treats then we should have. There is a huge section of all Amish made cakes, pies and breads. They're cheap and so good. I didn't know it but Hope's Cookies from Rosemont even has a store here. They make really, really yummy cookies and other treats. There's a Bassett's ice cream store, too. Pretty much whatever you are in the mood to eat can be found here. This place is a lot of fun and def a must-see for people from out of town or visiting.

I love Reading Terminal and if it were possible to move in, I would. I ate everywhere and everything and loved it all! I couldn't get enough of the awesome breakfast at downtown diner or hot turkey at the dutch diner, seafood, pretzels, cheesesteak, it just couldn't get any better. I LOVE not just Philly but Reading Market!

We're in the World Series with these folks rt now, but I visited Philly over the summer and am just now able to review all the venues. I gotta give 'em their props. All's I can say is WOW... I've been to markets like this in other countries and wondered if it would ever work in the US. You can find more than just food here, soaps, scents, jewelry, trinkets, all made by individual entrepreneurs giving their own spin on things. From raw meats to cooked, produce, cheeses, wines, beer garden, jewelry shop, gourmet to everyday, it's here. Japanese, Indian, Middle Eastern, pierogies, ice cream, cheeses... you name the food, they have it. My sampling consisted of Bassett's ice cream, gourmet cheese, pierogies, heath bar and everything cookie, and bought some $1 tubs o' strawberries for my friends for later.  A unique experience! Go empty bellied and enjoy.

This place is like FOOD HEAVEN! Over 100 years old going strong and its a huge indoor market.  There are food places everywhere you turn in this market.  Everything from fresh made candy, to cooked duck, fresh produce, seafood, ice cream made from scratch, hoagie sandwiches....there is so much!  I grew up going to this place my grandpa would get me the rotisserie chicken wings they are so mouth watering.  Also, the Amish would come all the way from Lancaster on Wednesdays, Thursdays, and Fridays to serve their fresh goods.  If you come to Philly and you have never visited the Reading Terminal, you are truly missing out on the culture.

We were expecting to spend at least half the day here but I think 3 hours tops is good enough to explore the entire market.  It is a few blocks walkable distance from the tiny Chinatown which in turn is about a 10 minute walk from the Liberty Bell & Indepedendence Hall. 

Some places we hit: 
1) Dinic's Roast Pork & Roast Beef Sandwich $7 + $1.20 for 2 toppings (Either cheese & pepper or Cheese & broccoli). We grabbed a seat at the counter and ordered a roast pork sandwich which the waitress said was most popular there. It was very juicy and tender. However noticed that most people ordered the roast beef which looked very appetizing. Note to self: Order roast beef sandwich with broccoli on top next time.  
2) Bassett's Ice Cream: Homemade goodness. $3.50 for 2 scoops : pistachio & peach (loved the peach)
3) Miller's Twist: Cinnamon soft pretzel $2.10. Highly Recommended by me and Adam Richman (MAN V FOOD!).
4) Bee Natural: Honey galore. Bought two bottles of Butter bean ($14.59 for 48 oz) and Blueberry honey ($4.50 for 12 oz). A lady gave us a taste test of this.

Next Trip: Carmen's Cheesesteaks & Hoagies for the hoagies (the line was as long as Dinic's).

This is the market to which all other public markets should be judged. Whether you're shopping for food or looking for a meal this is the spot. It's a total mix of cultures from South Philly guys selling cheesesteaks, to the Asian seafood market, to the Southern Soul Food, to the Amish vendors, and everything in between. The oldest business in the market (and one of the oldest in all of Philly) is Bassett's Ice Cream (in Philly since 1861) they make some of the creamiest ice cream around. Two of my favorite treats here are the Amish pretzels at Miller's Twists and the Apple Dumplings at Dutch Eating Place (just to name a couple). The Terminal Market is a huge clean place and there's always a seat or two to sit and relax or eat, one seating area even has a piano player playing throughout the day. If food isn't your thing there are also a couple shops selling spices, wines, and gifts. If I had to narrow it down I would have to say Reading Terminal is one of the top 3 things to do while in Philly (next to the Art Museum and Eastern State Penn).

Great place for lunch. 5 minute walk from city hall and just 10 min from China town. Whatever you're looking for they have it, everything from Indian, Chinese, Mexican, Greek to Southern food.

They also have great produce, meat and specialty  food stands. Whether your a local a tourist, this is definitely a spot to check out.

Who doesn't love Reading Terminal Market? Its food paradise in the heart of Philadelphia! This is the best place to go to for fresh produce, meats, seafood, dairy items, and baked goods. 

Forget heading over to your local supermarket 'cause you won't find a better deal than here, and these vendors (all LOCAL!) are the best of the best so you know you're getting tasty eats regardless of which particular stand you go to. Its so large that there are always several vendors who offer similar items, so you can do a quick price comparison before buying (which I always do when shopping for seafood), and if one person doesn't have what you're looking for another one is bound to.

This is also a hot lunch spot with a ton of vendors offering anything and everything you can think of: salads, japanese, chinese, middle eastern, crepes, sandwiches of all forms, soups, homestyle cookin', and sweets galore! My favs are the Amish, who have several stalls in one section that you can hit up for baked goods (WHOOPIE! pies are a must), pretzels, candy/confections (mmmm, FUDGE), a pickle or two (or three) straight from the barrel, or a sit down, home cooked meal. If you can't find something here to love, I imagine that you aren't human since you clearly have no reason to eat.

This place is always pretty crowded, but lunch time and the weekends especially are packed. It can get very VERY hard to navigate around lines and tourists who just stop and stare at anything shiny. Plus, unless you've been there as many times as I have, you'll most likely get turned around several times and have no idea what street you're on when you manage to find an exit. But that's just part of the fun of it.

Heaven on earth for a foodie like me!! What can't you find in here?  It's full of tons of yummies!  Doesn't hurt that they've got beautiful flowers for sale either.  The stuffed meats at the Italian places look to die for, so did the cheese rolls wrapped in prosciutto and basil!  I just wish I lived closer so I could've taken more home!!  The dumplings at the dutch place were pretty tasty, though not quite living up to all of the hype, but all of their breads looked amazing!!  Just a little on the pricey, side, unfortunately.  If I had a place like this at home, I would be there all the time!!

I was not prepared for just how amazing this place is. My friend warned me but I expected mostly fresh produce and meat stands like I guess, not the culinary hodgepodge that this place was. This was one of my favorite places in Philly. They have every cuisine imaginable. I wish I had one more day to my trip to eat my way through the market. I unfortunately didn't get to try a whole lot because I couldn't get past the cheese steaks! This place is a true gem and no tourist should miss it. So happy it was across the street from my hotel.

Not exactly sure what to add in this 228th review for a Philly foodie mecca, so I'll just add my favorite finds from last week's journey... "Dollar Hollar" at 4th Street Cookies, as they sell the last cookies of the day for $1 each (we scored the last 2 snickerdoodles!); my favorite espresso blend at Old City Coffee; canollis at Termini; choosing between the fresh fish and local poultry.  And $4 parking at the garage across the street if you spend at least $10... and if you can manage to make it through the market without spending $10, you might be the first!
Really outstanding. As long as you can deal with the weekend and lunchtime crowds, this place has just about everything you need foodwise.

This is one of the best market I have been to in the US. Great stuffs at reasonable price. Choice is what impresses me. For every item there are more than a couple of stalls to choose from. Of course there are a few one of a kind items also. Had the fresh pasta from By George last night. It was good.

Holy. Crizap.

And I thought Portland had badass farmer's markets.

There's not much to say that hasn't already been said. Enormous and full of goodness. Really, really busy. But probably worth it, especially if the notion of a space bubble is foreign to you.

I was in Philadelphia for an extended weekend around 12-12-09. During that time I sampled many cheese steaks from different restaurants. There is no question that the finest sandwich I had was at Carmen's. All other cheese steak makers should sit down and let Carmen show them how. Not only was the sandwich wonderful but the service and conversation was superb.

I go here once a week to get meats and veggies. So much better than any supermarket. Everything is fresher and less expensive. There's also a few good sit down eateries. The pretzels are fantastic. You can watch them make it, so you know it's fresh. Go early because the Amish leave early.

This place is awesome! There are so many places to eat, it will take you about an hour just to figure out what you want. You can get anything from a famous philly cheesteak to mazto ball soup!! There is an amish bakery towards the back that has the best chocolate raspberry cake! The prices are pretty fair too.  It is pretty hectic around lunch time, but if you can find a place to sit, it's fun to watch all that's going on around you.

We got extra awesome food at extra low prices, but I could only put up with the crowded chaos for so long before I needed some fresh air.  Luckily, residents of Philly seem to be much better in crowds than Bostonians - people actually apologized as they ran into you!  

At any rate, I loved coming here as a tourist, but didn't want to spend too terribly long here once I had my groceries in tow.

Holy crap, I live a short train ride away, and I can't believe I waited 29 years before coming here!  This place is pretty much a binge eater's paradise.  There is an absurd variety of food here; I cannot think of a type of food they don't have. My stomach could only fit so much, but the pork sandwich, General Tso chicken, vegetable lo mein, and soft pretzel I had here were top-notch. (And while my heart and taste buds would have loved to finish off with ice cream, my brain said don't even think about it!) It probably wouldn't have been a good mix anyway :)    Well, my visit here was during the week between Christmas & New Years, so I'll keep telling myself that the crowds aren't normally that bad....right???   Anyway, this is definitely a go-to place in center city.  For the variety, prices, and extreme degree of yumminess - the RTM cannot be beat!

Click that little red "X" at the top right hand corner of your screen and go right now.

Good excuses not to go:
Friend or family member will die if I leave right now.
House will burn to the ground (with pets inside)

Bad excuses:
I have to work.
I'm too drunk (Take the train).
I accidentally flushed my keys down the toilet (See above).
I am getting married today.
I have to study for a blood test.
I could go get laid instead.

I love this place. It's just a cool place to walk through. You can find some of the coolest items and best food in the city here. (That's what I'm told anyways)

I'm from the south but then lived in England for a bit. They have markets like this in the UK everywhere so it was a bit nostalgic.

This place is the bomb-diggity! It's one of the coolest places around, and definitely the coolest market I've ever been to! You can get anything there, and I mean, Ah-NEA-THING!! There's over 80 different vendors, selling anything from yummy imported chesses and susages, to home made ice creams and chocolates, to veggie, Indian, Thai, Mesican restaurants, wine shops, butchers and fresh fruit vendors. Get the idea?! I love going here, getting a freshly made pastry and hot chocolate, and just wandering around and taking it all in. It is awesome!!

This is a must for any visit to Philadelphia.  I used to live near by, and I still try to pop in whenever I can just so I can walk in, breathe in all the fabulous food smells emanating from the different stalls, and take in all the colors and characters of the people who fill this place with the spirit of Philadelphia.

Once you walk in, you'll know why this place is constantly featured on the Food Network and the Travel Channel.

Fresh flowers? Check.
Amazing ice cream?  Check.
Award-winning cuisine?  Check.

I'm not sure which days they're there, but the Amish come in from the countryside and make the most amazing "broasted" chicken.  Yum yum.  Licking my lips just thinking about it.  They come in early and leave early, so try to catch them!

Warning: if you bring out-of-towners to Reading Terminal Market, they are sure to show up on your doorstep again asking to go back. Reading Terminal is also known to cause sensory overload. 
This is THE primary choice for lunch when I have friends from out of town visiting. I have yet to eat at the same stand twice and have never been short of pleased by my meals. Be prepared to be a bit overwhelmed with your culinary selections: there is everything from Amish comfort food to Iraqi inspired treats.
The actual market is also worth visiting. Extremely fresh fish, vegetables, and fruits can be found on the side near Market East; a great place to stop on your way home from work (the market is open until 6 pm on week days). Also, the prices are fabulous! 
The best part of Reading Terminal for at-home cooks though would have to be the Spice shop, located near the Beer Garden (yes, there is a beer garden; beer selections are meh though). They have every spice you can think of all for MUCH cheaper than you'll find anywhere else. Note: the spices are packaged in little baggies, so you'll need to have your own containers to transfer them into.
 I will be here soon to stock up on my fresh foods for the week, and cannot wait until another friend visits so I can try yet another stand!

Yes, this place used to be dirty, gross, but they have stepped up hygiene, non-smoking, all vendors have strict guidelines in cleanliness, Love , love the Amish cafe, sit at stool, eat whatever you want, breakfast, huge dutch apples, specials are on board, includes drink dish & side..for usually $4.95 -$6.95 can't beat it!! Wait for seating, but goes pretty quick. Love it there, whatever your heart desires, from Sang Kee , Thai food, Philly cheesesteaks,great places & vendors. Yes, for out-of towners, it can be Overwhelming ..but what a great place!!!

This was probably my favorite thing that I did while in Philly for the weekend. I love markets in general, but this was by far one of the best ones I've been to. SO much great food and amazing smells! And authentic Amish eats! I picked up some things to take to the bf's family's house, including homemade fudge, pickled okra (yep, and it was awesome), rice cakes, homemade jams/jellies among them. For ourselves we picked up a bottle of Pennsylvanian wine for dinner, and snacked on giant pickles when we got there, and later some authentic Amish PRETZELS! Seriously, my mouth is watering just thinking of them. 

There seemed to be a whole separate side where you could actually grab food, sit, and eat. We didn't make it there, but next time I'm in town, I'll carve out enough time to sit there...and eat my body weight in Amish pretzels. :)

As far as must-dos go in Philly, this would be at the top of the list.

Ahhhh one of my favorite places in Philadelphia. 

Whenever I need to escape the office and explore - this is the place I go. Whether I'm in search of food, cooking ingredients, or just something to make me laugh... this is the best place to start. 

I think the most refreshing part about this market is that it reminds me of the traditional shopping experience. The farmers markets! The various vendors each with their own specialty. 

Some of my favorite establishments include:

 - Fair Food Farmstand (organic, local produce)
 - Salumeria (greaaatt italian hoagies. you can also buy gourmet meats and cheeses)
 - 4th Street  Cookies (best cookies in the city! the chocolate chips are usually still melty!)
 - 12th Street Cantina (Mexican - pick up a frequent buyer card... i'm almost at a free meal!)
 - Old City Coffee (so many choices! roasted on premises.)
 - DiNic's (roast beef! brisket!)
 - Down Home Diner (order the bbq burger or the scramblers)

 ... I'm sure I'll have to update this....

The crowds can be overwhelming... but I don't mind. This place reminds me of Europe and I could care less about being swept up in the commotion. It's therapeutic to me.

Besides the wide range of vendors that they have here, they also hold cooking classes in their audience style kitchen. I came here during a free class and learned how to make cheesesteak spring rolls. This kitchen can also be rented out for private events! 

The Reading Terminal... Anything you want you can find it here.

Walk in and inhale, daddy's home! This is my favorite market anywhere in the world. People rave about French markets but I live and shop in them every week and I long to be at Reading Market. You can not beat it for variety and freshness whether you are shopping for goodies to cook at home or looking for a bite to eat. This is a foodie's paradise where you can indulge in food from every corner of the world and buy produce from people who are still passionate about what they make and sell.

This place is so much fun. Just walking in you want to eat and spend spend spend. 
There is a wine store in the very back that is sooo so good. They have a pear wine that is native in the amish area. Everyone there is so nice and you even see a few locals. Not just all us out of towners. I definatly recommend this place as a great stop to introduce you to the city. Not to mention you can walk everywhere.

Raise your hand if you have never purposely gotten lost and wondered aimlessly through this place! I could spend HOURS here just roaming around and taking everything in with full enjoyment. I have only been there enough times to count on one hand, but so far that is enough times for me to be curtain I like it. I am from Cleveland(ish) Ohio and we have NOTHING like this there! I love 4th Street Cookies! Oh man talk about a chocolate overloaded sugar induced coma! So worth it. Try the chocolate chip cookie dipped in chocolate! I have found the best produce there! I also am planning on going back and going on a dry goods binge. I plan on buying crazy pastas, grains, teas and spices next time I venture in!

OoOohh Reading Terminal Market=)

One of my favorite places to go to Philly.  I've made it a habit to stop by here after I've mentally prepared myself from that long ride on the horrible Chinatown Bus around the corner and this place always seems to make the trip worthwhile when visiting my best friend in Philly.

I love walking around seeing the different selections of food...fruit, vegetable, fish, cheese, and bread markets..sooo much more...alll fresshhh all great=) 

I ate cheesesteaks and GREAT THAI food there.  I regret that I have yet to eat at the famous ice cream stand and try the crepes but maybe next time=P

Oh the Reading Terminal Market!  What can I say about you?  I dream of days past when I walked through your stalls and smelled the glorious smells wafting from within.  

Being a Californian I only get there a few times a year but I look forward to it every time.  Its a MUST stop when I am in Philly.  Crepes, cheese steaks, Southern food, Chinese food....the options are endless!!  

Love the Amish people in their nike sneakers!!
Check out helpful tips, reviews, recipes and events in Philadelphia at website www.healthyPHILLY.com

Seems so fun but actually BLOWS. Lots of unique vendors who sell the same food you can get anywhere else in the city, with only 10 times the wait. There are Amish there though (or Mennonites or whatever the hell) if that gets you off.

It's surprisingly delightful when a new route to the office causes me to discover (or in this case, rediscover) places in the city. 

I've been coming to RTM since I was in diapers, when the visit required a trip into the city on the R2. Now that I'm in the city, I go often. Usually to grab a crepe for lunch, pick up produce, a preztel from the Amish folks, Bassetts ice cream and any number of other delicious items. But, I can't remember every having gone into the Market before 9AM. 

But, walking from the eastern edge of the Art Museum area, to Independence Hall this morning, I realized that all of my usual coffee stops were no longer on my way to the office. What to do? Of course, there was an Old City Coffee in RTM - but was RTM open at 8:15am? 

Yes, and I think I knew that, I just never tested it out. 

RTM is an entirely different place in the morning - sleepy, warm, free of all the jostling tourists and hoardes of jury duty-ers. Half of the stands are open or are in the process of opening. People behind the counters look up as you walk by and give you a cheerful smile. There are distinct smells of this or that, not the mix and match you get later in the day. After I picked up my coffee, I walked through the entire place to the last door and the only thing I had to dodge was a guy carrying a crate of produce on his head and an older woman buying fish. 

I think I'll be making a habit of this.

Have a hankering for BBQ? Check. Need a butcher? Take your pick! Fresh produce? There are at least three markets to choose from. Want any cheese you can imagine? Start perusing! Cheesesteak/cheesecake craving? You could get both!! Not to mention there's representation from most ethnic foods - Chinese, Indian, middle eastern, Mexican, Greek. On any given day, there are so many smells wafting toward you once you walk in that it can be very overwhelming. Reading Terminal Market is a Philadelphia tradition where you can satisfy almost any gastronomical craving you might have. 

I personally don't think that the stalls in the Terminal are necessarily the best representatives of the individual cuisines, but it's rare to find one place that can satisfy the palate of everyone in your group. And some items are more expensive here than if you had gone elsewhere. But it's a Philadelphia tradition - no trip to Philadelphia would be complete without a stop here.

Yay, I get to join the long line of people who have written a review of the Reading Terminal Market.  My review will last 2 seconds at the top of the new reviews near you list and then get buried, never to be seen again.  Ah well, better make it count.

Here's my take on it as well as a few things I learned about how to survive.

1.  Come with an appetite.  I ate 3 separate lunches while I was here.  It came out to a meal every hour.  That's how I roll.
2.  Do not come here while there is another event going on...like say a Flower Show.  It's a little disconcerting when all the parking guys are telling you to enjoy the Flower Show.
3.  There are a bunch of pay lots to park in, just shop around for the best deal if you are going to drive in to the city.  If you're taking one of the buses from DC, you pretty much get dropped off right around the corner.
4.  You will get up close and personal with everyone at the market.  If you dress in layers, your body will be less accessible to other people's hands.  If you get claustrophobic, do not go here.
5.  People will think it's appropriate to bring luggage and strollers through the tiny aisles that make up the market.  Hurdle them or tip them over.  Then blame the person next to you.  This applies to old people and small children as well.  Do not be afraid to throw elbows.
6.  If you come alone, you can sneak into all the seating areas that much easier.  There's always that lone seat that no one wants to take.  While that couple is arguing about who should take the seat, you can swoop in and solve that dilemma for them.
7.  Bring cash.  Many of the stalls are cash only.
8.  This is just filler.  I wanted to make the list even.

Reading Market, how convenient you are. All fresh things in one place. All specialty items right there at my fingertips. 

Reading Terminal Market is just like a small Italian or Parisian street with all the stores you need in one place. What makes it so fabulous is every "booth" specializes in one thing or another. Flowers, candy, BBQ, honey, Italian baked goods, sandwiches, crepes, ice cream, pretzels, nuts, organic produces, a butcher...shall I go on? 

I'm a New Yorker, and wish something like this was in my neighborhood. In NYC we have Grand Central Terminal Market, which is good, but this is a bigger scale with more options. Everything looked really fresh and I wanted to try one of everything, but tried to not go crazy and just had a cannoli from Termini Brothers (http://www.yelp.com/biz/termini-brothers-bakery-philadelphia-2#hrid:4LM9uZs4Tv9UdhzaHEc6ZQ/src:self).

If I lived here, this is probably where I would shop. Even the flowers looked amazing and healthy, and each different vendor had many choices of their product. Most vendors were helpful too, I asked questions and the honey bee vendor let me try a few of their products to try and find what I was looking for. 

Go here if you have the opportunity. Even if it is too look around and possibly sample a few things. Totally worth it.

My friend took me here knowing that I would love it. I felt like I was in my element when I am in this place. The fruit, veggies, meat, seafood, pastries, flowers, prepared food and food made to order. The ripe, fresh food draws you to each stand while the smells pull you into many different directions. 

I was impressed with the selection and quality of the food the vendors there were there. I had a crepe for lunch, pastry for dessert, and got a cupcake for later on. If I lived in there area I would have purchased some fish for home but I didn't think it was worth it to freeze something to get it up to Boston. 

The restroom facilities were very clean. There was an attendant in there that checked the stalls after they were used to make sure they were clean and had toilet paper. I was really impressed how they ran the facilities here.

Okay, but certainly not up to the hype it often gets.  The physical environment needs serious work.  People are nice, general vibe is good, lots to pick from...but the place is dirty and in need of help.

Look at Grand Central Market at the Grand Central Terminal in NYC or the Ferry Building in San Francisco, for example.  Philly needs to clean the place up for the shoppers and the vendors.

Suburban Square has a "farmers market" that had a nice tuning up--the food isn't so great in some spots, but the physical market is nice. 

I agree with the people who say venture beyond RTM.  There are plenty of better places to eat all over the city. The food here is not that great.

[I stopped writing this review at this point and got up and went to the market]

I just got back from taking my family down to the market for lunch.
