Everybody spread out and tried a wide variety of  things.  A crepe, which  was "fine but not that great."  A smoothie which was "really good."  Fries from Franks ("frozen fries...they suck.").  Some Pierogi's from Franks ("pretty good").  I had a pulled pork sandwich from DiNic's.  I wouldn't bother getting another one.  It was, amazingly, totally bland.  

Termini Bros., as always, was perfect.

If you're in Philadelphia you just have to come to Reading Terminal Market.  Markets are always great places to wander during a trip, especially when you're looking for a quick breakfast or lunch to get you going through sightseeing, shopping, walking around, etc.  Reading is a very good market.  Comparable to Toronto's St. Lawrence Market, except almost entirely staffed by Amish people.  Look for gigantic baked goods (I saw a slice of angel food cake that was about 1/3 of a cake, I'm not kidding), hot pretzels, and fresh dairy.  

I stopped at Dutch Eating Place for breakfast while making the rounds here and was not disappointed.  The Spice Market was an ambush on the nostrils, but in a pleasant sort of way.  My friend got a pint of fresh organic milk from Lancaster Co. Dairy, and it was nearly a sedative for him.  You can also find plenty of meats, cheese, fish, and produce as you meander the stalls.  Regardless of what you're looking for, or if you're in town visiting, Reading Terminal Market is a worthwhile stop.

This is the single best place in Philadelphia.

I could leave it at that but I'll go a little deeper.

If you are visiting Philly, you have to include Reading Terminal Market. Best to go Wednesday through Saturday when the Pennsylvania Dutch merchants are open. The market is open Sundays but a number of merchants are closed. 

You might think it is a tourist trap. It is to a degree. However, most of the people there are locals. Tourists can't sustain the meat, fish and produce shops that are there. So no shame, none, ever associated with it. Its not like being a New Yorker and going to Times Square for a meal.

The market is closed at 6PM, which is one of the few drawbacks: it has no evening hours. I hope one day that will somehow change.

Also, it can be overwhelming. Lunch rush is intense and finding a seat to enjoy that roast pork sandwich can be a challenge. I went there during lunch rush of the week between Christmas and New Year's and I have never seen it that crazy. So that's not the best time to go because hundreds of suburbanites like myself get the same idea to enjoy Reading Terminal with their day off.

For breakfast the options are limited. There is the Down Home Diner which is decent but I'm not kvelling about it. Some of the stands do breakfast but I haven't really tried them. I finally tried Profi's Creperie and it is pretty good.

My suggestions about food if you're there one time during a Philly visit: If it is Wednesday-Saturday, go to the Hatville Farms deli counter and get a smoked turkey special with iced-tea and potato chips. Hatville Farms is one of the Pennsylvania Dutch merchants and I swear that the smoked turkey special is the best thing in all of Reading Terminal Market. Plus, they have stools at their counter so you don't have to go looking for a seat. 

If it is Sunday-Tuesday, go to DiNic's Roast Pork and Beef. The line will be long but it moves fairly quick. Get the roast pork Italiano with broccoli rabe and sharp provolone. That's a Philly sandwich! 

Reading Terminal Market, you are what makes New Yorkers jealous of Philadelphia!

I have found a cure for claustrophobia. Reading Terminal Market. Crowded and bustling but everywhere you look there is something new to see and you are assaulted by mouth watering smells and temptations every few paces. It makes the volume of people jostling you entirely bearable.

My fave samplings:
Termini Brothers for tasty cheese cannoli, fig bars, sfogliatelle, pignoli cookies and biscotti.
Fisher's for Amish pretzels with butter
Lancaster Co Dairy for fresh squeezed lemonade
Salumeria for gourmet meats and cheese which made for an awesome midnight snack
Dutch Eating Place for food that is similar to Grandma's and a kick ass apple dumpling.

If I lived in Philly I would be in here all the time, the shopping looked incredible, super fresh products of all sorts. So sad to miss DiNic's though, I will have to return at some point. Thanks to Bobby P, Andrew T and Mira V for the suggestion.

There is something about the Reading Terminal market's atmosphere  that I love so much. Everything is at a few steps reach. When I was still living in Philly I would go there every week to get fruits, veggies and meats. I love how natural everything is especially with the  Amish merchants. From them, I usually get ground turkey, it's always fresh and cheap. 

It's a place where you can do your weekly grocery shopping and plus more. Sometimes, temptation gets the best out of you when you smell and see so much bake goods. I always settle with a healthy fruit smoothie. I don't remember what the place is called but it's run by Asian folks and the smoothies are made with 100% fruit with no added sugars. They also have wheat grass shots which can be requested to be put in the smoothies

No matter how much a person describes or tells you the many great things in Reading Terminal market, it's the best to go and see it for yourself.

The major benefit of working from home isnt the free time to come and go as I please, walk around the house in boxers, or sleeping late.  I get to go to the Reading Terminal during OFF hours and not have to deal with flower show freaks or the weekend tourists.  Yeah, that sounds rude but frankly, I dont give a shit.  This place is dirt cheap for produce, either Iovine or the other little place in the center, great fish spots, two great cookie spots, great ice cream, the spice spot is cheap as hell, great thai and Indian spot, and in my opinion some of the best brick oven pizza at George's. Hell, you can even get your shoes shined here which I have done several times. I spent $40 there today and have more than enough food until the next week

You can't miss here...something for everyone and even some cute amish tail running around,  something about those bonnets they wear.  Just kidding.
Looks like everything's been pretty well said. Just adding my 5 stars. I could spend like a week in here, and not get bored ....

Such a cool idea/place. On my second visit to Philly, my friend took me here for breakfast/Lunch it was great because one person wanted a smoothie, and we wanted sandwiches. I got a sandwhich and motza ball soup from Hershels East Side Deli. Check the website for a map if you like. Both ended up being fantastic.
We went back the next day for a late lunch and had cajun @ Beck's Cajun Cafe, which was some of the best Gumbo I have had outside New orleans. They had Abita rootbeer, sooo refreshing. 
This is a great place to shop for fresh produce, meats, flowers and candy! I would recommend a trip here for a tourist or a long time resident. Great for foodies!

The weekend crowd was bananas, but Monday wasn't so bad. I was pretty bummed that they aren't open for dinner. OK yes, technically speaking, they are open for dinner... but only if you're retired and looking for the early bird special. Who eats that early?!

The Pennsylvania Dutch apple dumplings and sticky buns had me drooling, but I wasn't up for the mosh pit I'd have to wade through to get them. They're only at the market Wednesday-Saturday, so I see what the big deal is.

We ate at Olympic Gyro for lunch and Down Home Diner for breakfast another day. Reading Market gave our food budget a break on that trip to Philly, leaving us extra cash for dinner!

This is quite possibly the most amazing place I have ever been. It was almost overwhelming at first. We must have walked around it about 5x before deciding on what we wanted to eat.

It is just an awesome, interesting place to walk around and explore. I wish we had been in Philly longer so that I had more time to eat at more places in the market!

Saturday gets extremely packed but it is still interesting. Sunday was kind of a bummer because many places weren't open.

I love this place! I am not sure what else to say...

They have everything that you can imagine as far as food goes. Well almost everything, and even some things that are really not great as far as nutrition goes (chocolate covered cookie? Win! cheesecake brownie? Hell to the yes!) The only gripe I have about the place is that quite a few of the little stores inside have a fear of credit cards, or they set some high amount as the spending limit when using a credit card. Which is fine if you are planning on buying quite a bit of food, but it can suck when you're just trying to buy some sandwich meat. Have you ever bought $10.00 worth of sandwich meat? It goes a long way. I used to love oven roasted turkey at one point. 

I always find something new when I'm in there. Probably because every time I go in there, it's incredibly busy, so I kind of make my movements through the aisles based on the general mill of the crowd (yes, I am that lazy). I don't mind it though. Part of the joy of walking through RT is just seeing what else I can find; effectively I'm a tourist, which I'm quite fine with.

This regular Saturday morning stop for our family is truly one of the best things about this city. Fruit and Veg, organic meat, dumpling soup, chicken wings, hoagies, cannoli...this place seriously has everything you want and don't want.

The crowds do get a bit crazy, especially around lunchtimes so try early.

If you are a foodie, you've got to go to The Reading Terminal!  It is awesome.  It's basically an indoor farmers market that takes up an entire block in Center City.  My favorite thing at this market is the food products and food stations operated by the Amish.  Consistently delicious!  They also have lots of fresh produce, great butchers, fresh fish, fresh baked goods, and some artisans with various products ranging from jewelry to cooking gadgets to candles.  They also offer cooking classes, but I haven't taken advantage of that yet.

There isn't anything I could say about the Terminal that hasn't been said already. This place is like Six Flags for foodies.

I scanned the reviews and couldn't help but be flabbergasted by the 1 star reviews. To each their own I guess, but it did my soul good to peruse some of the 1 starers other reviews only to find out how bad their tastes are across the board.

Please don't come to Philly without visiting and eating your way through the terminal! Admission is free, but you're gonna need to wear  your comfy pants.

How much do I like Reading Terminal Market? Let me count the ways:

1. Iovine Brothers Produce - Even at the cheapest of supermarkets, I couldn't get a whole bag of the freshest, highest quality vegetables for $5. Same goes to the nuts and snacks on the southern wall, where else can you buy them in such a state of quality at such prices?

2. Godshall's Poultry - Instead of the yellowed, hormoned chicken you get from the supermarket, these are the freshest, tastiest chicken you can find in the city. And fresh chickens do make a difference in taste. Of course, they do have ducks, quails, turkeys and eggs.

3. Martin's and John Yi's is where I get my meat and seafood, Martin's is always a few bucks cheaper and John Yi captures me with their neon signs.

4. 4 Seasons Juice Bar has the tastiest fruit smoothies and blends around. My favorite is Pineapple (for sweetness) + Banana (for texture) + Orange (for taste). Nothing beats a 20oz No.4 in a hot summer day.

5. For your dessert needs, Flying Monkey has the best cupcakes and lemon bars in town. Termini Brothers has a killer chocolate covered banana on a crescent cookie. You can also visit the ladies at Famous 4th for a fresh baked cookie. For something completely evil, you can go to the Amish bakery for a cinnamon roll with nuts AND frosting.

6. Shanghai Gourmet's American Chinese food is as good as any place in Chinatown. Try their fried rice or the Shrimp in Lobster Sauce, it's not on their menu but the jumbo shrimps in the silky luscious sauce is to die for. (gulp)

7. The Spice Terminal will fulfill most of your gourmet needs. Bee Natural has a wide variety of honeys. For cheese and charcuterie, you can visit Salumeria and if not for anything else, go to By George for their pasta sauces, they'll even sell you pizza dough if you want to make something at home. 

It's a vibrant place with lots of other places to discover and it's a great place to walk and browse when you have the time. Just don't stand in the middle of the aisle and block traffic, it can be crowded. Cell phone reception can be on the low side, and it's hard for the working folks to pick up groceries on their way home since most of the shop will close business around 5, but there's the weekend. The Amish generally won't be there from Sundays to Wednesdays but most shops open Mondays to Saturdays and some even open on Sundays.

I LOVE PUBLIC MARKETS!!!!! 

I was a happy girl prancing around sampling, oooohing, Ahhhhhing and just bright eyed with all the possibilities in this place. One of the oldest public markets and I let me tell you it didnt dissapoint. 

The first place we wanted to visit was the Amish bakery and chocolate shop. They were closed and not there that  :( BOO I was so looking forward to yummy baked goods made with homemade everything. 

You know what made up for missing it? MY FIRST REAL CANNOLI !! Can you say happy dance? The Termini Brothers provided the most fresh, authentic and like your face good cannoli ever. I really wish I could have one right now. 

We then had about 3 different kinds of crepes at the Creperie. They were skilled in making some great crepes. Tasty. 

We had such a great time here.

how could you not love this place? They've really turned this large, urban, historic indoor public back around after some down years. It's been thriving with lots of tourists, conventioneers, and locals. Most everything you'll get here is delicious. 

They've previously had a cheesteak venue that was horrible get replaced, which made me feel good because out-of-towners shouldn't have a horrible first cheese steak. Great selection of foods in separated stalls. There's also some diners (Amish one is my fav), produce markets, deserts, fresh meats and cheese shops, some specialty and foreign goods. It's also very close to Chinatown and it's markets. I've seen Food Network special events shot here and culinary exhibitions. 

A few of the shops and diners have small seating areas, mostly at counters. There are also a good number of public tables in the middle with a high turnover rate. This place has people in it all day long but really is packed around lunch time. 

There is some metered street parking and nearby expensive lots, some reasonable a little ways away, but lots of foot traffic here from center city business district, convention center, and hotels. 

You should have no problem finding something delicious to eat or cook here.

Great place to hang out with a group of friends. So many delicious options and you can literally hang out here for hours- eating, browsing around, eating some more and even catch a taping of a Food Network show. Husband thought the cheesesteak @ Carmen's was the best he's ever eaten (although the line was crazy long and they got his order wrong). Sang Kee is always good if you're in the mood for yummy noodle soups. Of course Delilah's is also a place to grab some good food- their mac n cheese is a MUST. Our kids (one of them being a really picky eater) devoured their fried chicken and mac n cheese. I was pretty disappointed with the gyro sandwich @ Kamal's however.  

Sooo many options for dessert too. We tried Flying Monkey for the first time since the Food Network were featuring them for a new show. The cupcakes were just ok although the best one is their signature Flying Monkey cupcake (rich chocolate cake with banana chunks and vanilla and chocolate buttercream). Bassetts ice cream is always a good place to stop by too. I like it that they are very careful in how they serve their ice cream for those with peanut allergies. Overall this is a great place to visit  you like having many delicious options and this is a great place to bring out-of-towners too!

Awesome market.

Nestled away off of 4th street, lies Reading Terminal Market. What looks like a massive grocery store from the front is actually a large market of food places of an assortment of differing kinds of food, ranging from Asian, middle eastern, even to Amish! (there were in fact, a lot of Amish food).

Although the ventilation was horrible in this place, the idea of this market reminded me a lot of Quincy Market of Boston.. just a much larger grander scale. You could easily find breakfast, lunch, and dinner in here, without a problem.

If you're looking for a place where everyone's tastes can be satisified, as well as looking for a hole in the wall place in Philly, definitely go to the Reading Terminal. It's famous- I even spoke to a Food Network show which was filming a segment on the Flying Monkey cupcakes in there.... how cool is that.

I love reading terminal market. (RTM). so many options, so little time. They have great options, they have TONS of options. Great restaurants for eating in, or great places to buy locally (and some not locally) sourced fruits, veggies, and meats- pay attention though, not everything is local, so if that's your goal, just ask around. 

Most of the store owners are friendly and you can usually find exactly what you're looking for. 

As a matter of advice, I would say avoid this place at noon on a weekday- no no, toooooo busy. And avoid it on weekends all together- can you say tourists palooza? I can, i've seen it. But sincerely, I love this place, they have so much variety you really can have whatever you like.

This is another fun place to take out of town people.  A fun experience but I wouldn't necessarily come out of my way.  The groceries from the produce place always look fresh and the prices are pretty good too.  I don't know how I feel about buying my meats from here.... But I like the hustle feel to the place too and it reminds me of a market from back in the day but with modern conveniences.  The rows are tight and it can get busy here on the weekends and during lunch time.  I have to say the bathrooms are some of the nastiest I have seen (including port-o-potties) but other than that Reading Terminal is pretty clean.  We often stop in for Bassetts ice cream.  I don't know why since it tastes the same as any other ice cream but I think it's the novelty of the place.

Only thing in Philly worth seeing. It is amazing and I want one in my town. Has everything, beef, pork, seafood of every kind, chicken, ice cream , veg, fruit, pastries, candy, drinks eating spots, you name it it there. Not in a Wal Mart form either.

Its just a must see in a disappointing town. I was in town for about 4 days and spent a good majority of it at RTM.

what a difference a day makes. 

The amish bring such a different energy and aroma of tasty goodness its worth scheduling your life to be back here the next week to partake in their offerings.

Though the crowds still get a mighty crazy, the people are still not too hurried to show a little courtesy and flash a smile when approached with one. The little surprises around every corner continue to appear and unless you live here 24/7 we are all tourists to a degree and just need to learn to be more open to new opportunities of learning from a larger pool of the population.

This place is great for lunch.  Apparently Man vs Food stopped by over here as well.  

There is always a crowd, especially on the weekends.  

This place is definitely worth it.

Best Place in CC to buy fresh produce. I have yet to be disappointed with Iovines prices or Produce. Great charcuteries and cheese mongers nearby and the butchers are not as good as the italian market but at the same time who always has time to head down ninth street for a cut of lamb

This was by far the highlight of my entire Philly experience. 

Really amazing, fresh food. So many stalls that I could eat here for days..

I'm still a bit partial to my Borough market in London, but this comes a close second in my favorite places to binge eat.

An overwhelming place for an indecisive person but in a good way! So many choices - they have their own streets within the building! It's worth walking around the whole thing to figure out what you want. There's a good variety of options. It's also right next to the Marriott Philadelphia Downtown.

Only con is that they're only open during the day.

I will keep this brief since prior reviews say it all. Reading Terminal Market is a great place to walk around and pig out. There is something for everyone there from roasted Peking duck to freshly made chocolate. Florida, where I now live, does not have places like this and it is really a shame.

Wife & I go here for her "chocolate fix" during a certian time of month (TMI?)....:) 
This place is awesome for the freshness of it's food, the variety and the wholesomeness of the Amish foods. I have to budget myself because one can go broke in here!

My only complaint is trying to find decent parking.

What can one say?- the best Market in the USA! Love love love this place'
Hoagies, gyros, deli sandwiches all compete attention-add fresh flowers, vegies, fruits, meats and seafood!!

My personal faves- middle eastern bakery, the original turkey-amazing sandwiches

i think i could spend all day here, eating, shopping and people watching. really didn't know what to expect when mongo said we'd be going here. what a delightful surprise. he might have regret his decision when he was dragging me out of the exit by my arm. while he wanted to try all the meat and sandwich shops (which there are plenty), i wanted to try out all of the delectable sweet spots (candy, cookies, chocolates). thank goodness for my waistline, we were in a rush and i only got to taste some heavenly cookies. but we definitely plan on going back and getting our fill!

Yay for Reading!  Why is it pronounced "redding" and not "reading."  English is hard.

I get all my produce here, and it's usually super fresh (hey, that's the name of a grocery store) and super cheap (that'll be my grocery that competes with Super Fresh).  I really like the Iovine Brothers and the Lee Produce places.  The one dollar grab bags always crack me up because they're always filled with things that don't go together: carrots with apples, mushrooms and celery, dogs and cats..

I also love the organic food stand that's tucked in the back.  They have a really nice variety of fresh apples.  

As for the Amish, it's so nice to see them making pretzels and other yummy things.  I've had a couple of things from their shops and they're pretty good.  For you sweet tooths out there, they have a ton of amazing desserts- Amish and not.

The only that that really bothers me about the place is that some of the vendors sell really lame knick knacks, but I guess that means I should just avoid them and not say anything.  But I did.  So there.

This is a great place to be a tourist or be a local.  It's a nice attraction and also a place that sells great products.

So what's keeping you at home?  Get on your buggy and make your way out to the Reading Terminal Market.

This place is sick. Just sick. I am a seriously deranged foodie bent on eating the world and this place is my savior and kryptonite all in one. It soothes the savage food beast within but in time would bankrupt me, leaving me unable to feed myself. 

I'm not bothering to go into all the stuff they sell because every other Yelp review can tell you that. I'll just give you an idea of the kind of manic mindset you'll have as a foodie after visiting RTM.

It has everything you could ever want. And it's all so fresh, so delicious, so goddam beautiful to behold. I want to transplant this market right next to my apartment, vacate my apartment and live in a little tent in Beiler's with a summer timeshare at the fudge candy store and a little cottage by the gourmet grocer where the kids can drink blueberry lemonade when they're too hot. And when I die, I want to be buried with 4th St cookies and whoopie pies.

I have been in many markets with the same concept. Usually they are overpriced and the food is mediocre. The Redding Market makes every other market of it's ilk pale in comparison. Not only are the prices absurdly low, the quality, taste and range of offers is exceptional. No matter what you want, I'm sure it can be had here. Yum on!

Where can you go to feel the energy and vibrancy of Philly?  Reading Terminal of course.  So many different variety of food to choose from.  Then there's the fresh produce that are pretty cheap in comparison to some other places.  There are also events like cooking classes, ice scream festival, etc. to look forward to.

We walked around Philly for a few hours and were hungry. Reading Terminal Market better have been worth it, dammit. When we walked into the place, it was kind of cool and perplexing: think an indoor street fair, but well-regulated. In a terminal, go figure.

Unfortunately, the day we came was the day before Memorial Day and a couple of places were closed. Fortunately, it was the day before Memorial Day and the place wasn't engulfed in crows and long lines.

As we circled around the different food vendors, I kept passing by the nondescript Basic 4 Vegetarian Snack stand. It looked so unassuming, kind of sparse, and the nice ladies were walking back and forth albeit not taking orders because there weren't many customers to serve. 

My sister settled for some Cajun food and I grabbed a veggie chili cheeseburger.

Oh my.

I stuffed my face. Because this is the best fake-burger I ever had!!! It was a little steep for a "chili burger," (around $6-$7), but it was huge. And delicious. Two co-occurring adjectives that supersede price. Okay -- that can be read incorrectly if your mind is in the gutter. But that was some good fake-meat.

Love this place. It screams PHILLY! There are so many different kinds of foods here! Parking is always a problem but if u park in the garage across the street and u spend $10.00 at RTM parking will only cast $4.00.  You can spend hours and hours in here.

An incredible place that is a must hit in Philly. Tons of food selections, most of which are very reasonably priced. DiNic's is a MUST try. Going on the weekends is a surefire way to ensure all vendors are open, but be prepared for it to be very crowded and hard to walk around.

Whoa - so much delicious food. Totally overwhelming at first.  Much variety with a favor towards places selling sweet stuff.  Dutch diner type place with amazing apple dumplings with heavy cream for only $3 and a bakery with the most delicious sticky buns for $5.  Saw a place I regret not getting homemade beef jerky from, too.  Wish I lived in Philly so I could capitalize on the seafood and produce stands to cook my own goodness.  Awesome that there are Amish food stands as I feel their goods certainly mean quality, care, and freshness.

Eric B's review and mention of Philly made me HAVE to review this.. esp. since a coworker is about to enter grad school @ UPenn soon... 

Go to this adorable, kickbutt market if ever you're in town to enjoy the sights and history of Philly. Everything that you could possibly think of is here... er, dare I timidly suggest, the Pike Place of the East Coast sans all the fishmongering shows?

One amazing time, trying to thaw by nipping into places intermittently... have gone for a visit to "Brotherly Love" land  in the dead of winter...still, so thoroughly thrilled to have run into the Terminal Market after a visit to the train station (and, of course, to Chinatown!)

Wink; thanks Eric!

I was just in Philly for an event at the Convention Center, and ate at the Reading Terminal Market 3x for lunch.  I read the Yelp reviews and I'm shocked at how excited everyone is over the food at this place.  

Yes, the choices are endless.  And yes, it's awesome to have so many options to grab a quick lunch.  But the quality of the food, while not bad, is pretty much food court fare.  3 lunches from 3 different vendors and it was all just fair at best.  1 just plain disappointing package-tasting corned beef sandwich from an Amish vendor, 1 bready crab cake plate, and 1 hotdog that was worth every penny of $1.50.

Normally I'd be tempted to give this place 3 stars simply for the convenience and variety, Because everyone is raving about how great the food is, I'm gonna attempt to instill a little balance by tossing out a 2.

Since we're visiting Philadelphia, Reading Terminal Market is on my list of places to visit.  I'm giving it 4 stars because there are so many shops I would like visit again.  We got the Reading Terminal Market around 10:45 on Saturday.  The food vendors were not very busy.  We did not have to wait at any of the three places we visited.  

We walked into and saw a lot of fresh produce with really great price.  Since we were hungry, we went to DiNic for the Roasted Pork Sandwich with cheese and green ($8.75) first.  We then found Delilah and got the Southern Fried Chicken, Mac n' Cheese and corn bread ($9.50), finished it off with Peanut Butter Swirl and Butter Pecan ice cream from Bassetts ($3.50).  The portions are pretty big here.  My husband and I shared everything and we were stuffed.

Roasted Pork sandwich from DiNic was good with the Sharp Provolone.  My husband enjoyed the pickled yellow pepper on the counter with his half of the sandwich.  We did not like the food at Delilah at all.    The chicken was juicy, but had no flavor.  The skin was crunchy, but had a slightly burn taste.  The mac n' cheese was soggy and lumpy.  The corn bread was dry.  Ice cream from Bassett's was good, but we didn't think it was really special.  

After we walked around for a bit, we got some nectarine for 99 cents a pound.  It was fresh, sweet and juicy, best thing we had all day.

On Sunday morning, most places are not open.  We went to Down Home Diner for breakfast.  It turned out to be just OK.  But with so many more places to visit and try, I will definitely visit again the next time.

Ever since moving to Philadelphia from the San Francisco area, I have been having farmer's market withdrawal because I used to spend my Saturdays meandering around trying interesting foods and buying super fresh produce.  I was afraid that I would never find a place like that in Philly until I checked out Reading Terminal Market.  

Reading is HUGE with a mind boggling variety of produce, meats, and pre-made food stalls.  The produce is super cheap, and I normally walk out of the corner Iovine Brothers Produce with my week's worth of groceries for around $10.  Of course that's not all I look at or spend because there, I could waste away hours looking at the different ethnic food stands, chocolate shops, bakeries, and desserts (I have a huge sweet tooth!).  

One day I hope to try everything, which I'm sure will take me years since I only visit once a week.  But I'm up for the challenge, and I look forward to every Friday when I get to wander around Reading, relax, try new foods, and buy cheap yet fresh produce.
I agree with most people here. New visitors to Philadelphia.. this is a must stop. Close to subway, close to Chinatown. Open during weekends. What more to ask?

The variety of food here didn't fail to amaze me; it reminded me a lot of my motherland, Thailand where they have fresh food markets, and not a second goes by without it being jammed pack. I LOVE that kind of shock and energy that it brings you.  Right when I walked in, the smell of fresh fish and meat hit me at a special spot.  Of course it naturally invited me to buy groceries, but considering that I was on a trip and Philly is not my hometown, I settled for the hundreds of restaurants that were there. There were different types of cuisines to accomondate any ethnic group which was impressive.  However, the food was just okay. I went with four people and we all got our foods from different stations, but none of them really wowwed me. I think that mine was the best. I got my dish from a Chinese place that had hanging Peking duck. Though tasty, I most definitely had better. The prices here aren't bad at all though.  Fairly reasonable and won't break your wallet.

This place already has so many good reviews. Does it really need another one? Why yes of course, so I can add it to my list! 
Reading Terminal Market is one of my favorite places to visit when I'm in Philly. The market has a large selection of produce, meats, fresh flowers, seafood, fish and cheeses. I love the fresh Amish breads and jams that is sold here and it's a great place to have lunch. To really have a good experience, you need to come here on a weekday because it gets too crowded during the weekend.

The best thing about Philadelphia - I could eat here for a month and still not have tried everything. You can find the best of Philadelphia here - from cheesesteaks to Amish Pretzels (note: The Amish don't come in the beginning of the week though), Chinese food to Perogies. 
Plus side - great food for great prices! Also, lots of produce, flowers, and other speciality food items. 
A must for anyone visiting Philly for the first time!

My parents used to bring my sister and I here when we were little every year around the holidays.  It was a tradition to come here, have a pretzel at the Pennsylvania Dutch pretzel place, get candy, and visit Rick's for a cheesesteak (I know, a great diet!). 

Things have changed some since I was younger.  Now that I live in Philly I consider Reading Terminal to be more of a weekly, rather than yearly, stop.  No more Rick's - it's now located in the Bellevue. 

 I visit the Terminal primarily for produce from Iovine Bros. Produce- reasonable prices and a WIDE selection of fruits and vegetables.  They have things I can never find at the supermarket.  My second stop is usually the Spice Terminal to pick up some coffee beans.  They have a great selection and the coffee is always yum.

Only downfall I can think of is that when there's a conference at the Convention Center, it can be pretty swarmed with badged peeps.  Fight through it!  The crowds are really part of what makes it a Philly institution anyway.

This place is the BEST place to do grocery shopping, have lunch, and bring out of town guests to. I live only a block away and my grocery bills have gone down significantly because (most of) the shops at Reading Terminal are so much cheaper and fresher than a traditional grocery store. Iovine Brothers is great for produce, and they give student discounts of 10% on Wednesday and Sundays. Wan Seafood is great for fish supply. The spice shop right next to Flying Monkey has great spices, marinades, dressings, teas, etc. Not to mention the desserts are great at almost any of the chocolate shops. The beer garden and numerous lunch places (great cheesesteaks, falafels, crab cakes, anything you could want) make this great for groups also.

Amazing.  You can probably eat here every day and never  get bored. 

They have everything.  Literally everything, from flowers to brisket to Minnesota wild rice, all there. 

First time there was a little overwhelming, and I didnt need to buy groceries, so we got some beef jerky (25 per pound) but it was the most amazing beef jerky Ive had in my life.  We also got some Amish pretzels and baked goods, which were delish. 

I also want to note that the place was quite clean, in comparison to Bostons Quincy Market, this place is spotless. 

The place is huge and I would assume that residents of Philadelphia can do their major grocery shopping there.  I will definitely be back.

Anything you could possibly want under one roof. They have some cheap and amazing produce, the best chocolate chip cookies I've ever had, delicious coffee (vanilla-almond!) and, um VEGETARIAN CHEESE STEAK that won't make you miss meat. The only fault I find is that this is not in my hometown.

Who can imagine a Philadelphia without Reading Terminal.  I can't, and I don't want to.

Of course, the crowds are a problem, made up as they are of an uncomfortable mix of locals and tourists/conventioneers.  But such is the price one must expect to pay for having such an indispensable institution... everyone wants to go there, and for good reason.

Some pointers for the uninitiated:

- If driving, park at the garage across 12th Street.  Save your parking ticket, spend $10 or more at any vendor and they will validate, and the parking fee will be a mere $4 instead of the rack rate $26 as long as you check out of the garage within 2 hours of arriving.

- If you find yourself on Philly Jury Duty, walk here for lunch (1 block) and almost every food vendor will grant you a 10% discount.

- Amish and Mennonite-run stands are not open on Sundays.  It used to be the whole market wasn't open on Sundays, but thankfully that changed some years ago.

- The produce vendor Iovine Bros. on the south side of the market (bordering Filbert Street) is awesome.  Huge selection, great prices, and a nice mix of conventional and organically grown stuff.
Awesome!  A disastrous place for an Overeaters Anonymous outing, though.

How could a huge, indoor food-stall market get any better than Reading Terminal Market? I'm not sure it could. 

Full of many different local Pennsylvanian offerings, I could hardly contain my excitement when we walked into the market - especially in the Amish corner! Awesome, awesome place that no one who is even remotely into food should miss when visiting Philadelphia.

Reading Terminal is a staple for anyone visiting Philly or for any indecisive group that wants to eat well. There are so many options, from seafood, to soulfood, to desserts (don't miss the Bassett's Ice Cream- Cinnamon is my favorite!)

I would recommend taking a few hours just to check everything out. Try to get smaller things that way you can try items from a few vendors. I do recommend Delilah's Soul Food!
A Philadelphia institution. Fun place for lunch and a good place to go shopping for fresh and local food. The homemade ice cream is always popular. Worth a visit for locals and visitors alike!

A friend in the area kept raving about this place, so it was nice to be able to stroll in for lunch and see what the fuss was about. And what fuss, there was almost every type of food and drink imaginable in this once-terminal station. Great open air market atmosphere with all types of food to eat.

Lots of different local snacks, desserts, food, beverage, cheese, sweets, gifts... the list goes on and on. Definitely check this out for a big variety of cool market and foodstuff.

You can get an incredible Amish breakfast (complete with a pound of butter and bacon grease), a delicious fruit smoothie, stop off at the butcher for some freshly chopped steak, and grab all the spices you need to marinate it, all within 10 minutes. 

Candy shops, seafood, butchers, spices, drinks, sandwiches, short order breakfast...and dare I say it.......oh I dare...beer. 

This place is also complete with a shoe shine stop and a piano. 

Sure it gets a little crowded, but what do you expect? It's like Disney World for the middle age man...you have women in bonnets cooking breakfast, tons of meat, a guy shining your shoes, some entertainment on the ole upright and a bar. If that ain't livin'...

I'm not too experienced with markets like these but I love this place.  I like farmers markets and I find the one outside of the Penn bookstore on 36th & Walnut or the one in Rittenhouse Square just don't cut it for me.  Reading is open all year-round and even has student discounts on Wednesdays and Sundays (just bring your ID)!  

I've ordered porterhouse and NY strip steaks and ground sirloin (3 lbs for $7.50!) from the butcher shop right near the entrance (Giunta's Prime Shop)--the steaks were awesome even when I pan-cooked them a couple days later b/c I was too lazy to go to the grill.  The whole chickens from Godshall's Poultry LLC are awesome and my sister who roasts whole chickens all the time says these are the best chickens she's ever seen--very little fat and the meat tastes great.  

Four Seasons Juice Bar is off the hook.  The most amazing fruit drinks I've ever had (and I'm not crazy about fruit or juice--Jamba Juice and Smoothies King are ok but this place is really unique).  If you like super sweet drinks/juices or smoothies, this place isn't for you because they are SUPER fresh and I doubt they add any sugar to their blends.  Out front, they have boxes and boxes of fresh fruit and vegetables (peaches, mangoes, strawberries, carrots, broccoli, ginger).  They have crazy blends like carrot, mango and spinach and the like.  For each 16 oz. drink, they mix in 4 whole carrots.  I stick to pineapple, strawberries, and mangoes.  

I get kalamata olives all the time (the best I've found in Philly) from the cheese shop in the middle of the Terminal at the Salumeria (their cheeses aren't so great--tasteless mozzarella for example).  The turkey w/ mashed potatoes, cranberry sauce, etc. from the Original Turkey is surprisingly tasty.  I didn't like the pastrami reuben from Hershels East Side Deli--there was no Russian dressing, just some sauerkraut, tons of fat-laden meat and the bread fell apart immediately (this was definitely no Famous 4th Street or Rachael's Nosheri).  

My default grocery store is Iovine Brothers Produce since they are the biggest and freshest in the Terminal but sometimes I'll go to the smaller produce shops like OK Lee Produce for some greens and basic fruits.  I've gotten tuna steaks, king crab legs, scallops and salmon fillets from John Yi Fish Market and Wan's Seafood.  They are both fine but I'm not a huge seafood person so I can't tell you the nuisances between the two.  The market has an ice cream shop and tons of more restaurants.  It's a great place to browse, grab lunch or do your weekly grocery shopping!

I just bought $50 worth of cheese and cured meats and balsamic vinegar from Downtown Cheese (the owner is also an artist!) so I'll let you know how they are!

Really good selection of tasty eats, fresh produce, dairy, and meats and fish.  All under one roof.  The most impressive was the fish/seafood selection.  There are also several bakeries and some amazing looking cakes.

Not as bad of a tourist trap as I thought it was going to be.  The crowds on the Saturday afternoon I was there was fairly fast-paced and courteous for the most part.  The produce and seafood looked beautifully fresh.  The prepared foods made me wish I had more time in Philly to try all the treats.  We only made one (incredibly delicious) stop at the Miller's Twist for soft pretzel goodness, but trust me, if I had more time, I would have had tried more of the goodies Reading Terminal has to offer. I heard Dinic's is awesome and also recall people swearing by the Pennsylvania Dutch Diner there.

Food good with great diversity. Anything from Dutch pies to Halal shawrma to cheese steaks. Caution, do not remember which cheese steak shop but kind of bland and cheese sauce pretty bad. Other than that great food and grocery shopping area.

Came here for the first time with hubby and out of town guest.  It's nothing like the farmers market I miss from california but its busy and has lots of different foods, meats, cheeses, and baked goods to try.  We enjoyed cupcakes from the flying monkey stand.  Also had an apple dumpling from the amish stand which was ok.  We also bought some tasty specialty honey.  I would come back again. It's also nice to see the diversity of people in the market and families enjoying the food.  If you are walking to the market watch out for the drivers.  More dangerous than nyc drivers.

I absolutely loved this little market. It has everything you could possibly want to buy, food-wise. My husband, father, mother, and I got breakfast there the two days that we were in Philadelphia and could barely decide on what to get! Everything is fresh and homemade, which is refreshing and fun. We chose one of the Amish diner-type booths to eat, and my parents got smoothies from another both; everything was delicious. There are tons of different specialty shops offering everything from candies to spices to kitchen equipment. I honestly could have spent a few hours wandering around, but we had plans, so we only spent 30 minutes or so exploring. I wish I could go back every day!

During my visit I went to:
Beiler's
Flying Monkey
Dutch Eating Place
Miller's Twist
Termini Bros
...and I walked through frequently

All I can say that hasn't been said is that it is without a doubt the best market of its kind that I've yet to visit.  While not as eclectic as the San Francisco Ferry Market and not as large as Baltimore's Lexington Market it is the kind of place where there is something for everyone - down home, organic, simple, artisan, vegetarian, carnivore, local, or tourist.
I've only been here once, but it seems like a great place for lunch, not to mention the Famous Le Bus Brioche Rolls!:-)  My only complaint is that it's "Cash Only".  Who caries cash anymore???
so charming & authentic...must stop on any Philly visit. I'm so glad we're preserving old world gems like this & Pike Place Market in Seattle...

I was MORE than EXCITED to visit let alone chow down on Denics. I saw an episode of Man v. Food and applied myself to what he was praising and backing up with his and his mothers life claiming that Denic's Roast Pork Sandwich is like no other. Instantaneously, my mouth began to water at the meticulous placement of the sharp provolone and the boiling concoction from which the roast pork was being pulled out from. So, I decided to turn off my TV, send the dvd back to netflix, and go purchase two tickets from LA to philly just to try this god sent meat sandwich!

When I got there, the butterflies in my stomach churned quicker and quicker by every mile; my excitement was no exaggeration. As I stepped foot in the heaven bazaar I wasted no time searching for this legendary Denic's! I skim past the array of markets and hustle my way to Denic's. As my cousin and I wait in the never-ending line, we talk amongst ourselves and take pictures to take back home because we definitely cannot take the roast pork with us! As the line pulled us in closer to the cashier, we looked and saw a COCKROACH climbing up the glistening Denic's sign; the sight of that disease ridden insect dismayed my presence. Never-the-less, we order our food; we didn't spend $500 and cover all this road to get stalled by a god damn cockroach! Before I took my first passionate bite, I accustomed myself and made a pledge on the plane ride to not cry at the overload of deliciousness. Again, to my dismay, I bit and was about to GAG! WTF was Adam thinking?! I got exactly what he said! Roast pork sandwich, with sharp provolone and broccoli rabe! Sheer disgust and disappointment is all that rained down my face. Bitter, like biting into handful of Arugula! The only pro about the sandwich would be the barely noticeable presence of the sharp provolone.

All-in-all, it was a very interesting trip. I also visited a few other places that I saw on Man v. Food, however, those did not fail me. Denic's might be a delicious place to eat, but, I guess, my Californian tongue cannot handle the extreme flavors of the east. Judge it for yourself.

A great experience and highly recommended when visiting Philadelphia. Make sure you bring your appetite too. There are great breakfast & lunch spots here! The Crepe place is excellent and Di-Nico's makes a fantastic rendition of the Philly cheese steak but uses pork. I thought it was better than both Pat's & Gino's cheese steaks by far!

Great urban market, I was impressed by the variety, selection and quality of the stalls. Great eat-in places, lively and appetizing. A must see in Philly.

Warning: the Dutch/Amish place is not open on Sundays.

I first want to say that I love food markets.  We stayed at the hotel that is right next to the Reading Terminal,so it was great.  We went on a Sunday, so a lot of the stores were not opened. 

Our first stop (before we started our day) I got a cup of coffee from Old City Coffee and tried the crepes at Profi's Creperie.  We also got a philly cheese steak from Carmen's.  The food was good and we were hungry.

Our second stop (on the way back to the hotel) we stopped and got a pulled pork sandwich from DiNic's, wings from Franks A Lot, and cupcakes from Flying Monkey.  

All in all I really enjoyed walking around in this food market.  It reminds me of Pike Place in Seattle and Borough Market in London.
I love it here so much that I could spend my paycheck AND your paycheck here in a matter of one hour!!!  GO!!  Experience the wonder!!!!  Just bring cash and be ready to spend!

A must-have on any eating tour of Philly.  Get the pork sandwiches from DiNic's, they are some of the best in the city.

And get some cookies at Termini bakery- or even better- GET A CANNOLI.

Or, if you aren't obsessed with Italian food, sit at the counter at Pearls and have some seafood while you people-watch.

I love coming here to eat and check out all of the different vendors.


Its like walking thru a big kitchen with so many things to eat.  The hard part is picking one, the prices are right too.

I'm a huge fan of urban markets no matter what city it is.  I love to explore these places.  I haven't hit up all the vendors yet, but I'm working on it.  I'll admit that I don't live far from the Reading Terminal and didn't start taking advantage of it until recently.  It's a great place to go for breakfast, lunch, or dinner.  They have a little bit of everything.  At least for me, there's always something to satisfy my taste buds.  

The real benefit to me is all the fresh stuff you can find here.  The produce is great and reasonably priced.  I also like the butchered meats and the cheeses that are offered here.  You can't do your grocery shopping here but it's always nice to get stuff from the locals.  Then there are the desserts.  I have a bit of a sweet tooth so I love to indulge when I come here.  

Fun place to always go.  Everyone should experience it at least once.

Lots of great vendors to grab food or shop around from. Try the pastrami sandwiches.

Good enough for me to come back again and sometimes crave.

Price: As every Farmer's market will be, it has its ups and downs. Some places are pricey; others offer a bag of vegetables for a dollar (making avocados a steal.)

Variety: Well, you can get everything from silly home decor (liberty bell christmas ornaments and chocolate phillies logos?) to Carmen's $$ Cheesesteaks, to amish pretzel dogs, seafood, soup, and lebanon bologna. There are your token candy corners and vegetables galore, and it's a great place for jams and jellies, especially those kinds you're not used to seeing in Philly (mint, mulberry...)

I'm from the country and Reading Terminal is a step into the markets at home, with the smell of cheesebox wood and butter and dill pickles and deli meats. You'll get personal service and an assortment of Appalachian to Jersey coast accents :)

I like markets and this is one of the better ones I've been to. So much to see and taste and buy and experience. I start early and make a day out of it.  It's a slow stroll not a dash, so bring a gym bag/backpack, your appetite and plan to take your time and take it all in.

Oh yes, Reading Terminal Market is just about as good as it gets. I'm actually sitting right in the middle of this establishment as I type this and I've been entertained for the last 15 minutes by a wonderful pianist going away at her piano. Even at 10 in the morning, there is a good crowd of people at the Reading Terminal Market and there's a nice sense of hustle and bustle. 

Onto the goods: There's tons and tons of vendors here. From bakery treats to good ol' mac and cheese, there's enough food to make you walk out the door 15 lbs heavier. On top of that, I think if you look hard enough, you could probably find nearly every kind of food here, or at least find damn near all the ingredients to make any kind of food you happen to be craving. 

I thoroughly enjoy their selection of meats, fish and produce but have no fear, candy lovers! Their sugary delights are also ridiculously fantastic. There's a candy vendor right across from my current seat and I can't help but to keep eying up their delectable display of chocolates and other sweet treats. 

All in all, it's reasonably packed on the weekends but definitely a place to walk through, if not shop through when in town!

I'm glad I don't live or work near Reading Terminal Market.  I would gain so much weight.  There are tons of tasty and quick options for breakfast and lunch.  The prices are a little high, it's what you'd expect from a touristy spot like this.  

There are sandwich shops, breakfast joints, cupcake stands, gifts and candles, beeswax stuff, honey, candy and fudge, fish markets, meat markets, greek diners, chocolate, chocolate, chocolate, raw bar, book shop, and (most importantly) one of those penny smooshing machines.

This is a great destination spot for starting a day trip to the Illa. Easy parking (keep in mind it's like 8$ for every 15 minutes. I'm only sort of kidding.) There's a bathroom. Inside this Market it's over- crowded and complete circuitry overload.  Lots of food and restaurant choices. Amish people, Jazz, Candy Apples, Various fruits, vegetables, meats an aroma of all things farmer market waft to your nose and if you're not hungry you wish you were. It all looks amazing. The only down side is that I left feeling like some rube tourist.
We had  blast.  What a wonderful market.  Any kind of food is waiting for you there.  Definitely go on a full stomach otherwise you might tear the place apart.

Tourists-must-go-to place. A lot of different kind of foods, fruits, meats and souvenirs. You can get good crepes, cookies, candies and also sometimes catch a live performance by unknown singer. Them food can be very pricey. If you're a local, just go in and buy stuffs only if other places (like your favorite stores) do not sell it. If you're a tourist, you'll have a good time here. There's always something interesting going on inside. 

It is not that easy to find parking. And if you do find one, it is not that cheap either.

I love walking in this place and smelling all the freshly baked things.. I mean it's like anything you could like is here.. .. they have all types of foods.. from mini produce markets,, where you can pick up your farm share.. to sushi.. to a bakery with delicious treats! 

I ended up here most recently because of JURY DUTY! the best part of that long terrible day was going into the market and finding my favorite; most recently discovered at linvilla orchards; apples.. THAT MADE MY DAY! it's just delightful.. if you have jury duty many vendors will give you a discount.. and they also have cheap lunch specials.. 

The place gets packed.. however they do have so man entrances and exits that things flow decently. 

it's like a gem smack dab in the middle of center city.. you've got to love it!

Step 1: Watch Food Inc. on Netflix
Step 2: Visit the Redding Terminal

Then....absorb how this country has ruined food for us. This place, on the other hand, has fresh meat, veggies, pickles, deli meat, bread, baked goods and more!

Truly an amazing place...its what I miss in NYC, because you can't have this in a big city - they can't handle the traffic.

Philly u did this one right, a gem of a place, and what we should all look at for how we want our food!!

Great place to grab food, snacks and gifts. If you're here a few times, you learn the pattern when crowd starts getting larger and when it dies down. Wish that they would open later, although I find that most places in Philly closes early. 

If you're here for some Amish specialties, they are only at the market from Wednesday to Saturday. The other days, they are just moping at home wondering why they still need to drive to the city with their buggy.

Such a great place to visit!

Like the Ferry Building in San Francisco and North Market in Columbus, OH, this is a place where you can get everything from fresh fruits and vegetables, to varieties of prepared foods and baked goods.  I really have a huge respect for places like these since they showcase some great options that are usually from local farmers and vendors.  One thing that's really unique is that this place is so big...there's so much to see that it really does make for an awesome visiting experience.

Some of the best items at Reading Terminal are Beiler's Bakery and Bassett's Ice Cream.  There are a ton of other prepared foods I'd love to try, but didn't get to...I guess that's just another reason to come back!

I swear, if I lived in Philadelphia, I could eat here every day and never get bored.  I wish Washington, DC had something similar to this place.  It's location, in proximity to the hotel we were staying at, was perfect!  

Tip:  The Down Home diner was very good later in the evening, once the Terminal closed.

There's plenty not to like about Reading Terminal Market. With nearly a hundred merchants selling specialty foods, produce, flowers, books, houseware and so much more, you're bound to find plenty to turn up your nose at.
But even the most closed-minded individual will be able to satisfy their gastronomical cravings in this iconic Philly destination. Hoagies, cheesesteaks, gumbo, jambalaya, ribs, pizza, falafel, salads, soups, sushi, lo mein... I'm not even scratching the surface. 
The best way to learn about all the Market is by taking the guided tour, offered every Wednesday and Saturday. I had a taste of turtle soup during my tour, and learned about who really invented the chocolate kiss.
It's been an important part of Philadelphia for more than a century, and with such rich history and endless variety of sensational cuisines, this place will remain a mainstay as much as a must-see.

Fantastic market to satisfy everyone's likes!!!
I found myself acting like a kid in a candy store..  Food and more food that looks and smells better than the one I just drooled over..  My personal two favorite merchants were the dinic's; gosh their sandwiches are out of this world and the Salumeria, another great hoagies or sandwich whatever place...  
Find some time to explore this place.  Not only there are restaurants in here but also bakeries, flower shop, specialty produce, seafood, etc you get the point..  At one point kinda reminded me of the market in Seattle, WA.  You won't be disappointed to drop by gain a few pounds in here.

If you can't find something you absolutely love here ... well that's impossible so never mind. This place is big, filled with amazing vendors of all kinds, and stuffed with people. 

Why so crowded? 

Because everyone there knows the Reading Terminal Market is a landmark that's worth visiting anytime you're in the city of brotherly love. It would take me a year or two to get through all the vendors in the place, not to say that would stop me from trying!

Reading Terminal Market is one of those places I've never bothered to review because I assume everyone already knows it's awesome.

My favorite time to go is during the week when it's not as crowded.  But us suburbanites normally have to pack in here on the weekends.  It's crowded, loud and confusing.  However, the food is delicious.  So many choices.  When the weather is nice, find a bench or curb outside to escape the crowds while you eat.  Just be prepared to fend off the homeless people asking for change.  That guy isn't stranded and trying to get together money for a train ticket- I assure you.

Who doesn't love RTM? I mean, I guess there are a handful of people who decided to give this place 1-2 stars but they are far outnumbered by those of us who adore this place (yea, that's right 4-5 stars). 

More than the food, it's the vibe that I'm in love with. So this place does get obnoxiously busy on Saturdays and yea, you might wait 10 minutes for your Amish baked goodies on any given day at lunchtime. But its worth it. Where else in the city do you get this kind of variety (and from LOCAL producers)? 

This is the place I take all of my out-of-town friends to and is the only place that everyone enjoys. If you can't find some facet of this place that you enjoy, well, then you might be a mean one, Mr. Grinch.

This is a must do for anyone visiting Philadelphia.  An incredible assortment of food options and just a fun place to be (if you like crowds!)  Our group had a very eclectic array of choices ranging from the Philly Cheese Steak eater, to Chinese, to an incredible Italian sub.  For desert we all picked a selection of candies from Chocolat.  Great fun and perfect for the travelling family that can't agree on a lunch spot!

If you're in Philly, a trip to the Reading Terminal Market is an absolute must.  There are endless food vendors/various markets, and truly something for everyone here.  On the weekends it gets crowded but it's worth the trip that's for sure.  My personal favorites here are Dinic's for roast pork sandwiches and Bassett's for delicious creamy ice cream.  I can't wait to make a trip back here soon.

Where do you start?? This was a problem place for me when I worked in Philly. It was only about 5 blocks from my job...Where else can you get so many different and DELICIOUS types of food!!! I love to go on a Thursday when the Amish stands are open...they truly have the best ribs in the market!! Flavorful and juicy!!!  Just delicious!! DiNics-best roast pork sandwich in the city!!!  Bassets ice cream is to die for!!! Cookies from 4th street cookies are expensive but worth every penny!!!   My boyfriend thought he had died and gone to heaven in this place!!! We had way too many bags when we came out of here because he wanted to eat a little bit of everything!! LOL Absolutely the best there is!!!

2nd time around in Reading Terminal Market...still love it! It's like you see something new each time you go...great place for breakfast and lunch...so many options to choose from.

Examples:
seafood place
coffee
loose tea
chocolates
desserts
books
jewelry

If you are visiting, this is definite a must-stop. Skip the hotel bf if you stay nearby..come on over for yummy coffee and variety of breads/cake! :)

Tip-bits:
If you arrive when the RTM is about to close..the security guards would "chase" you out...:(
Dutch vendors only there from Wed-Sat
Restrooms to the left of the cupcake/bookstore in the middle where Philbert guards! :@

I have been going to the Reading Terminal Market since I was three years old! Throughout my life, different vendors have always remembered me as the little girl who was with her father. 
I send everyone new to Philly to the RTM. It really is a special place, and no one ever is disappointed! 

The quality food you can get here, right in the middle of the city is amazing. It smells amazing, it tastes even better. It's a nice place to go for lunch if you're doing some shopping or work in the area.

I absolutely LOVE this place.  Lots to see and lots to EAT!  My brother and I were in Philly for a wedding and I had to visit this place to eat at DiNIC's!  Seeing this place from Man V Food was my source of finding out about this place and the PORK! O-M-G

So much to see and so much to eat at Reading Terminal, but this review will cover DiNICs.

When we first walked up to the counter we saw mounds of delicious pork behind the window!  You can see perfectly cooked pork just sitting there waiting to be someone's meal!  This was heavenly and awesome...i think i was drooling the whole time in line and I was in some sort of hog trance...lol.  You can see the oven in the back they use to cook the pork and also the awesome dripping from the pork they use as gravy when they dip the pork again when they make that sandwich.  I got mine with the green spinach-type pork sandwich.  That first bite was out of this world.  You don't get this in Texas for sure.  This place definitely made up for Geno's and Pat's.

Philly to me is not known for the philly cheese steak (i think texadephia here in Texas is a thousand time better), but for that awesome pork sandwich at DiNIC's!  I will definitely be back! Enjoy!

On a recent trip to Philly, we decided to do lunch here.  This place is HUGE.  So many options, so, chances are it will have what you are craving.  One of the side effects though, is that the place was also packed.  I got just your typical burger, but had to wait in a line atleast 20 minutes long.

Out of all the reviews I have given, This takes the cake! 

This is seriously my favorite place! I've been to markets all over the world(Quincy,St. Lawrence, Mercado San Miguel, ect) and they have nothing on the reading terminal. Nottthing!  

First off, you have to understand almost all of the best food in Philadelphia is located here. practically everything you order is perfect. This includes candy, Ice cream, fruit smoothies, all kinds of food, flowers, and so much more... 

The Amish shops are what really puts this market over the edge. You know those Anne Ann's pretzels you can get anywhere? Get the Amish version here and you'll never look back! Ribs? Whole chickens? Purple veggies?!?! Yep got them too! 

I could go on all day, but I'd rather you just go and experience it for yourself!

Reading Terminal is incredible! What more could you ask for? Delicious eateries, Amish produce, meats, and pastries, aromatic coffees..... it's heaven in one building!

A word of advice - if you want to avoid the crowds, don't go on Saturday or Sunday afternoon! 

Can't wait to go back!

YARTMR
(Yet Another Reading Terminal Market Review)

I don't get here as much as I used to.  Sure I ride the train back into philly into market east everyday but by the time I arrive, all the shops are closed.  I used to live about 6 blocks away and this place was like my home away from home.  Sure it's touristy but I didn't care.  I could get meat, fish, produce, chocolate, bread, flowers, spices, a cup of coffee and a cookie all in one place.  

Like other Philadelphia institutions, this place is a real gem.  It's a good place to shop every week.  It's a good place to visit for a one off time.  Everything is fresh and it's all got a philly attitude to it.  I believe they have cooking demonstrations on Saturdays (sometimes)

It's fun to be a tourist every now and again.

Indecisive?  Then you'll absolutely hate this place.

Hungry?  Then the Reading Terminal Market will be your seventh heaven.

With a hundred-some-odd businesses and dining destinations in a football field-sized space under a single roof, the RTM is a farmer's market on steroids and the gastronomic heart of Philly.  Housed in a former train shed, the RTM is an amazing slice of Philly culture.

Here's just a sampling of what you can find here:

*cheese shops
*delis
*produce stands
*Chinese food
*Greek food
*Middle Eastern food
*Italian food
*cheesesteaks
*hoagies
*coffee shops
*exotic teas
*ice cream parlors
*Amish food
*diners
*butchers
*bakeries
*fishmongers
*pastry shops
*handmade jewelry
*arts and crafts
*live music

And you know what?  Everything single one is fantastic.  There isn't a single bad apple in the bunch.

(Speaking of which, the apples at the fruit stand near the front-right entrance are superb.)

I brought a dozen-or-so conventioneers here for lunch last weekend.  Everyone went somewhere different, and everyone spent under $10.  And you know what?  Everyone was blown away.  

W I N.

Some people bemoan the RTM as too crowded, too touristy, too claustrophobic.  I think these people are missing the point.  The only thing that the Reading Terminal Market has too much of is charm.

You can never go wrong here.  Cheese steaks good.  Cookies good.  Chocolate good.  Fruit good.  Ice cream good.  Amish food good.  Seriously it really doesn't get better than this.  To date no other markets I've been to compare, and I've even been to some out of the country.  Kudos Philly!

One of my new favorite places to visit in Philly.  Good, cheap eats, more selection than Tyson's Corner Mall, but the quality is muchhhhhhh muchhhhhhh better.

I stopped by Dinic's for a roast pork sandwich (You can't miss this place because it has the longest line out of all the stores in the market)

Had a pretzel at Miller's Twist (very good)

Picked up a loaf of pumpkin bread from Beiler's Bakery (very good indeed).

Just walk around and be random.  Or do a quick Google/Yelp search through your smart phone to see if you can find something that peaks your interest.

This is hardly a 'market' so much as it is a hundred different corporate establishments with satellite locations in one place. If you're looking for a taste of Philly - Reading Terminal Market is the place to be! If you're looking for a farmer's market type experience, you'll most likely be disappointed.

There is something for everyone in this place. It is sensory overload for food, coffee, desserts, veggies, wine, or just browzing. I went in 185lbs, I came out 210lbs. From Soft Philly Pretzels to Amish delights this place has it all. Go hungry, come out bloated! I wanted to eat everything at every stand in the place. The seafood there is insanely fresh. If you are a cheese fanatic you may never leave. Go there!

This market rivals any market in the country. If you come to Philadelphia to visit the historic sites, you will get hungry this is the historic market in Philly.

You can eat here. You sit at their counter or at the seating area in the middle which means you can each eat what you want; hoagies, Chinese Soup, Thai, Middle Eastern, Soul Food and Amish food. 

It is really a market in the international sense. Fishmongers, butchers, produce stands, spices, pastries... and smells. This is food aroma heaven.

How things change! I remember the Reading Terminal Market in the 1970s, when it was dying a slow death. So very far from the vibrant place it is today, one of the most dynamic urban markets you'll find anywhere.

There's something here for everyone: prepared food that will please vegans and porketarians alike; prime ingredients for the most exacting cook; cookbooks; breads; sit-down meals; a food court on steroids with nary a fast food stand or mass-market vendor in sight. There's even a beer garden.

In short, a great place to browse, to visit, and to hang out in.

Love this place, heaven for me. 

I really enjoy visiting farmers market and the like. So this place did not disappoint. I could browse forever in places like these. A variety of eateries: Cajun, Italian pull pork and even sushi. Along with fresh produce stands, butcher shops, and your fish monger. The whole market is enclose inside a building. That's definitely a good thing during the winter. I say this place is better than Seattle's Pike Place. It gets packed on the weekends. So be prepared for long lines at certain places like Tommy DiNic's. 

Crowded and touristy may be. But I think this place is awesome. Worth going.

I could easily spend a whole day here. 

Throughout my food tour of Philadelphia, this was a must-stop for me. I spent about 4 hours here, stopping everywhere from Delilah's for her famous mac n' cheese (or so says Oprah and as seen on Throwdown), the Amish stands, the Jewish deli, bakeries, spice shops, etc. 

I only stopped to eat at a few places, the most notable being Herschel's East Side Deli. Honestly, best hot pastrami I've ever had. Hands down. I live in an area that's laden with Jewish delis, and none of them can surpass Herschel's hot pastrami. I even asked the guy at the counter for the scraps he was cutting off so I can walk around and eat them, they were like candy in meat form.

Of course we stopped at Delilah's for her mac n' cheese. Honestly ---- GREASY. Really greasy. There was nothing creamy and decadent about it. I really wish I liked it, but considering I paid $5 for a small cup, that was a major disappointment. I had a bite, my mom had a bite and into the trash it went. Delilah did, however, lose to Bobby Flay on the Throwdown episode, so go figure... Because Bobby always loses to good competitors. 

Out of all the bakeries I stopped at, I'd have to say I like Flying Monkey the best. I had their red velvet whoopie pie which was DELICIOUS. Try that. They also had some "extreme" cake that was like 72398173981273 layers that looked like a total cake monstrosity, but I guess I'll save trying that for next time I visit, and so long as I bring a small army of people, too. 

I also went through two huge cups of hot cider at Old City Coffee. First when I walked in and I got one before I left. They actually used real unfiltered cider, versus most of the coffee shops these days that use filtered apple cider, which is just a slightly darker apple juice. There's no difference at all. So, of course this made me happy. 

Next time I come to Philly I will definitely be coming back. The one stand I wanted to go was closed, which was one of the Amish stands. I heard their honey is the best  which is what I wanted to take home. Next time.

Love this place. So many things to look at and taste. Each time we go to Philadelphia we have to come here and try something new. Definitely my favorite part of Philadelphia. It can get really crowded, so be prepared during lunch or dinner hours to stand on line at certain stands and hunt for a seat (though you could just stand at eat , but that could be tough depending on what you buy). There are a variety of different foods, such and sandwiches, chinese take out, seafood, bakeries, etc, so definitely something for everyone. 

We don't live in the area, so we don't buy anything at the market section. However, there are a few meat and vegetable and fruit vendors there if you're interested in grabbing some of those items.

Really a solid food experience in Philadelphia.  A good number of butchers and fishmongers that provide enough competition to raise the product quality to a high standard.  Certainly one of the best places in town to shop for meats and fish.  There isn't enough enough competition on the produce front though.  The prepared-food vendors are a bit kitschy, but can satisfy an urge or two if needed.

I have mixed feelings about this place.  I want to support it because this place reminds me of the Essex St. Market.  As I quickly walked past all the local produce and shops, I wanted to support the Amish community.  I feel bad for them, no technology what kind of life is it worth living!?*
But then I saw a sushi place and there was an 8yr old girl sitting at a stool at the counter taking orders.  Isn't that child labor!?  I don't support that.

I think some order needs to be defined.  They should only allow local produce and local stores to resell here.  The Amish people shouldn't be shoved into tiny isles and corners, they should have nice booths setup to display their beautiful produce.  There was hours of hard labor put into growing that Napa cabbage.  It was gigantic and I wanted to buy it to bring home but I'd never finish eating it within a week.

I came in search of lunch and when I smelled the pork from Tony DaNic's, I quickly got into line.  This is not to be missed people.  If you come into this market, you'd better not leave without a hoagie.

*There should be an Amish country reality TV show.  They could bring in outsiders and see how long they survive.  Similar to Survivor, whoever can live w/o technology the longest wins.  If I were a contestant, I would totally corrupt them.  I'd be deemed evil and they'd kick me off the island..I mean the Amish land.

weirdos, children working in booths, cool vendors and awesome produce. i honestly thought the market would be much bigger... however, once you're inside the actual building- it's kind of underwhelming. even with that fact... i still enjoyed coming here!

many booths were closed and i wasn't able to tour everything here. from Italian sandwiches, Gumbo, Gyros, Fish & Chips, Ice Cream, etc... this is a great way to get your chow on!

I love this place. I take everyone who visits me here to eat. So many options and just the atmosphere is great.

Have to get the roast pork sandwich from DaNic's (as seen on man vs food). And the famous 4th st cookies are delicious. There is a beer garden and lots of italian sandwiches that are to die for. 

And then I try to go my fruit and vegetable shopping here - you cant beat the prices!
EVERYTHING IS DELICIOUS HERE.It's like my mouth died and went to heaven. Nothing else to say....

A philly yelper without a review of RTM? Impossible.

RTM equals love, basically. You can find something to satisfy whatever crazy craving you are having at that exact moment and then some.  Always a great place to take visitors too -  total crowd pleaser -plus you get to finally convince your friends that philly IS a cool place to live.

Come in and get lost in the commotion and wafting smells of deliciousness. Here's a short list of some of my favorite merchants:

Iovine Produce: CHEAP, high quality produce.
Downtown Cheese: Expensive but oh man, the appenzeller.
Tommy DiNic's: Best.Sandwich.of.My.Life. No big deal.
Little Thai Market: $5 for a huge portion of chicken, rice and creamy red curry sauce.
Old City Coffee: It's an addiction.

Come here on a weekday, if you can. This place makes me nervous on Saturdays.
Oh, and bring some cash.

Reading Terminal Market is a foodgasm!! The delicious choices are overwhelming. I used to work at 15th and Market and we went to lunch here as often as possible. I want to eat lunch here every day for the rest of my life.

And, the Termini Brothers cannolis ... wow. I know there's a god because he invented beer and cannolis.

Monk's Cafe and Reading Terminal - for me, that's Philadelphia.

This is one of the coolest place to visit in Philly, there is a ton of awesome food and even wine and beer garden for those of you who want to get your drink one.  

Out of towners, please save a lot of room for eating here, there are too many awesome choices, gyro's, dinic's pork sandwich, delilah's mac and cheese, hershel's east side deli pastrami sandwich, i could write stuff all day about this place, really fun!

Like the Liberty Bell, cheesesteaks, and that pesky city wage tax, the Reading Terminal Market is one of those things that makes Philadelphia uniquely Philadelphia.

Yes, it's a historical site, but more importantly, it's full of vendors selling delicious food. There's something for everyone: Amish sellers are there part of the week, and you can pick up groceries or get your grub on if you're in the mood for a cheesesteak, Thai, Indian, ice cream, oysters - you name it.

If the Market was open past 5 PM, I'd be the happiest camper. And poorer, but who's watching my wallet?

PRONOUNCIATION: Remember, it's "Redding", rhymes with sledding. Don't ask me why.

good thing i don't live in philly...otherwise i'd be stuck in reading terminal all the time and spending whatever cash i have in my wallet on the variety of cuisines or really just eat until i need to readjust my waistline.

but then again, with all the greatness and tasty goodness that is crammed into the market, maybe i do want to live in philly :)

can't wait for my next visit...since i already got the liberty bell and rocky steps all taken care of, i can spend all my time in reading terminal eating to my stomach's content.
