Reading Terminal Market? There are no words to adequately describe my love for you. Yes, I stay in Philadelphia for my friends and family, but next to my them, you are the reason I will probably never leave Philadelphia. There are practical places like Iovine's where I can get relatively inexpensive, quality and often unique produce, the Fair Foodstand with locally grown produce and products or wonderful bread bakeries like Le Bus or Metropolitan. Termini's, Flying Monkey, or Chocolate by Mueller where I can satisfy my cravings for sweets. My buddies at Giunta's or Martin's Sausages that provide me with the best meat, especially bacon, in the metropolitan area. The great John Yi Fish market that always provides extremely friendly service and great products.

Of course too are all the great Amish merchants, in particular Haltemann Brothers, Kauffman's and of course my favorite, the Bellier's bakery where you can get the best whoopie pies in the world. Or the independent home cooks that sometimes sell their wares in the center court, from applesauce to kettle corn. 

And without rambling on too much more, there are all the great restaurants...the amazing hoagies from Salumeria (who happens also to have an amazing cheese and olive selection), the fantastic pork sandwiches from Dinics or the duck lo mein from Sang Kee Peking Duck and the places I still haven't gotten to try yet.

So, if you are coming to Philly for anything, you *must* go to Reading Terminal Market. Try any of the places I mentioned...you get my guarantee.

I'm a fan of this market though oddly equipped with amish employees that dresses the part too. I would not pass up the pastrami stand or the the cookie vendor... Those were definitely unforgettable experiences for my palate. :)

I usually stop in here when I'm already in the area for something else, such as the Philadelphia Car Show. If I lived closer I think I'd be here every day. The Reading Terminal Market has a little bit of everything and its all amazing. 

Unfortunately they close early so I can only make it there on weekends. Its always pretty crowded on weekends but very well worth it. 

Parking ( I got this from their website)

You can park for up to 2 hours for just $4.00 in the 12th & Filbert street garage.

Here's How:

    * Park ANYWHERE in the 12th & Filbert garage and receive the parking discount.
    * Bring your parking ticket to the Market with you.
    * Any Market merchant will validate your ticket with your purchase of $10 or more.
    * Upon returning to the garage lobby, you will place the parking ticket into the pay station and your parking rate will be reduced to a flat rate of $4 for up to two hours.
    * After two hours, regular garage rates will apply.
I could spend hours looking around this market.  Great gifts for medical professionals, particularly the chocolate hearts and lungs!   Try the ham too :)

I love coming to the Reading Market. Yes, it's hustle and bustle and a fight sometimes for the food you want. Come early to avoid the crowds...before noon on the weekends. If you want the  breakfast at Amish Eating Place, come when it opens. Don't expect gourmet food here, but expect good, hearty local fare and great fresh produce that is discounted when the market is about to close.

Some notes:

Bassetts--it's not the creamiest artisanal ice cream around,  but hey, it's part of the Philly experience. I had the pomengranate berry chocolate chunk and it satisfied my ice cream craving for the day.

Amish bakery counter-for some reason, the men seem to ignore me when I go to pay. The women are much more customer service oriented. I have tasted many of the pastries--they are cheap and taste it. Too much sugar and too little butter. I usually only get the  breads with glazed toppings. The other goods are nondescript. And what's with all the unhappy children forced to work so early? Child labor??? During Amish week in PA(in July), don't miss the fried doughnuts. They are divine.

Le Bus-this place got some bad reviews from other Yelpers. I've never had a bad bread or bagel here. I love the cherry apple bagels and the olive bread. The day I waas there, they had a low turnout and too much inventory so they were discounting their bread at the end of the day. Whoohooo....

Flying Monkey-the cupcakes are good but just okay for the price.

Metropolitan Bakery-prices are higher;  everything they sell is delectable.

Termini Bros.-how can you sell sweets and be so snotty and rude? Someone should send all the servers to customer service class. Are their pastries good? Sure? But I've walked away from this place at least 3 times when I was ignored. And if you're selling biscotti at $20 a lb, you need to smile.

The chocolatiers Muellers etc....-if you are in to high end gourmet chocolate, take a pass. If you just want  a piece of Philly traditional chocolate, go for it.

Eating area--needs more cleaning people!

Bathrooms-try to find someone else to go. I do!

Oh, and if the crowds dismay you, Chinatown is just around the corner.

I LOVE THIS PLACE!!!

So many selections and all such great food and at great prices.

My friend and I came back here just to visit the Flying Monkey Bakery! YUMMMM

There are tons of seating and it wasn't difficult to find a spot considering there are TONS of people in there. It's packed, but the wait isn't long at any of the stands.

THIS PLACE IS A MUST GO, MUST SEE, MUST EXPERIENCE . . . 

I have moved to Denver, CO, but I am back in Philly visiting family and enjoying the Philadelphia Flower Show. An experience downtown is not complete without a trip to Reading Terminal Market. I would love to find a market like this in Colorado, no luck yet. If any Yelpers have any recommendations I am totally up for the suggestion. 

The Reading Terminal Market has everything you could every want, meat counters, fish counters (shrimp the size of your head - no joke), book stores, gift shops, mexican, thai, chinese, ice cream (yummo), crepes, grocery type stores for fresh produce (prices to die for - so low), chocolate, gourmet little treats and everything else you can imagine. 

This place can be very crowded so if your not into crowds this is not the place for you. If your like me and could spend hours just looking around and finding anything unique or new to try then this is the place to go. 

Take a trip downtown and experience the Market!

How the HECK had I lived in Philly for 19 years and on a visit 11 years later, I make my first trip to Reading Terminal Market? I am very upset at myself for not venturing out here sooner and soaking up all the amazing food, gifts, energy, flowers, clothes etc etc etc.

Now, going on the weekend... prob not the smartest idea as it was PACKED. However, maybe that is part of the experience?

We actually just stopped in for lunch and had a specific destination, DiNics, and it was worth the wait! We also stopped by a cheese shop to take some goodies home. 

There was soooo much more I wanted to check out, I can't wait to go back!!

Push your way through the crowds to find pretty much anything your heart desires in this old train depot. Amish/Mennonite baked goods, meat and salads are not to be missed. Stop by termini's to pick up a fresh cannoli. Sit in the food court and hope someone will sit down at the piano and play.

I love going to markets like this! I worked at Pike Place Market in Seattle so I can greatly appreciate going to see other markets. I love the variety and hustle and bustle that is going all around. Seeing all the fresh produce, meats and quick eats is so exciting. I had a really great time 
wandering around looking at all the vendors. I recommend; Termini Brothers Bakery, Dinic's Roast Pork, and an Amish pretzel.....I tried the egg, bacon and cheese pretzel and it nearly sent me to the moon....WOW that was tasty!

Unfortunately, my first-ever Reading Terminal trip really disappointed me: the food was "okay" at best, the space is very cramped and good luck to you on navigating throughout the market.

Paid visits to Carmen's Famous Cheesesteaks, Creperie & Flying Monkeys --- they're stuck in my mind, but not for any good reasons at all.  I'm very saddened to leave a 2-star review for this market!  Perhaps my expectations were too high.  

The Amish stands are closed on Sunday so if you are looking to get one of those delicious pretzels made by the Amish girls that everyone raves about, don't go on Sundays.

The market  is  an experience. Small stands  offer  unique foods. If you like baked goods try Amish bread and sticky buns the best we have ever had.Unfortunately the crowds can be a little overwhelming

It's best to go on off days/times, but this place is great. They have pretty much anything you could want and can provide a day's entertainment when you don't know what else to do.  We tend to go once every week or two to pick up produce and to wander around the stalls to see if anything catches our eye (honey?  fresh juice in interesting combinations? any type of food imaginable? spices? really, everything).  Just be ready to push your way through crowds and you'll be fine :)

Must see place in Philadelphia even if you don't plan to eat. 
SOO many options of everything!! A lot of tastes (seafood, coffee, sandwich,...). 
I miss we don't have a place like this in the DC area.
We had a cheesesteak sandwich that tasted great but don't expect cheap places over there.  We came back for breakfast the next day and had a great omelet on an "amish style" stand.
I cannot believe how many different vendors are densly packed into this building. Flying Monkey (pastry shop) was awesome.

This market came highly recommended by a few friends who had visited Philly before. 

First impressions is that this market is endless. This is a local/organic food lovers heaven! There are a wide variety of stalls that sell anything from fish to spices to honey. But one thing they all have in common is that the food stuff is high quality. I bought some Cajun spices from the a spice stall and can't wait to use it with some chicken/steak. It can be dangerous to visit this market when you are hungry because you'll probably want to eat everything in sight. No doubt, you'll leave with a full stomach and an empty wallet.

this place is AWESOME.  it is a must-see for those traveling through Philly.  i've only been once, so i was only able to try food from 2 places, but they were both EXCELLENT.  and everything is so cheap!  it is crowded, but it's tolerable and the crowd/commotion kind of adds to the aura and excitement.  i can't wait to come back here and try more food!

i found a guy who was selling sandwiches that were knock offs of rutgers grease trucks.  apparently, after talking with the guy, he told me that his brother used to own one of the grease trucks over 10 years ago and that i was only the second person who ever came through the market knowing about grease trucks.  i was shocked to hear about this random connection to drunk college memories as well as the fact that i was only the second person who put 2 and 2 together.  i got a "fat korean" which consists of fried fish fillet, korean beef BBQ (bulgogi), cheese, lettuce, tomato, french fries, mayo, ketchup and sriracha all squeezed onto a hero.  it's the kind of sandwich that punches you in the gut when you're done, but you still want more, if only it could fit.  i'd take one of these over a cheese steak at pat's or gino's any day.

I love to cook, I love to eat, I love to oggle fresh local produce and cuisines of all kinds... That's what makes Reading Terminal Market such an exciting place to visit. I can't imagine ever tiring of this joint.

 It can be quite a crowded scene at times, and almost overwhelming with so many merchants to check out, so many bites to try, but really that's what gets me kinda intoxicated about the trip- such vast variety and quality. I navigate through, I make the rounds, circling through a couple of times to make a plan before I finally make my purchases.

HIT UP: Tommy DiNic's for roast pork,
Salumeria (hoagies), The Rib Stand (boneless rib sandwich), Dutch Eating Place (Breakfast), Basic Four (Vegetarian), soooo many other places too.

 I particularly LOVE being able to frequent Reading Terminal Market with a bunch of people who don't mind sharing so that we can smorgasbord that mutha.

I always come here thinking that I will find a vendor who has some amazing gluten free bread or cookies or well, anything. I never find it.

The produce selection is great. I wouldn't eat at any of the stands as I am deathly afraid of cross contamination. Too bad.
One of my top spots to bring visitors in Philly, they are rarely disappointed.

Produce, preserves, legumes, wine (small selection), meats, fish, mouthwatering pastries, prepared food, plants.... and books even. Reading Terminal is fairly well-rounded market. Most places inside seem to only take cash, but they have ATMs inside. DiNic's was probably my favorite spot for something warm and delicious to eat. We ordered an italian pulled pork with sharp provolone and sweet and spicy roasted peppers. I normally don't eat this category of food, but wow--it was amazing.

Talk about sensory overload.  The din, the visual assault, the aromas, the throngs of shoppers...I loved it.

There's something, of everything, for anybody, at Reading Terminal Market.  Beautiful produce at affordable prices.  Ready-to-eat world cuisine from India to Japan to Belgium.  Fish markets and butchers.  Bakeries and fromageries.  Pennsylvania Dutch stalls and honey stands.  All-herb stalls and French textiles.  Kitchen gadgets and plants.  RTM has you covered better than any supermarket ever could.

My favorite stalls were:

~The Herbiary with its essential oils, medicinal herbs, and home remedies.
~Kauffman's Lancaster County Produce, which had a dozen flavors of covered pretzels, beet and okra chips, and a zillion other novelties from Dutch country.  Not to mention eminently friendly vendors.
~Amy's Place kitchen wares.  I love a good gadget, and this stall is full of 'em.
~Fair Food Farmstand.  All the produce is local and organic from small-scale farms, with an emphasis on humanely-raised meats and sustainable agriculture.  Yesss!

I'd like to pull a "Career Opportunities" in Reading Market.

I loved exploring all the great little eateries and delis that are housed in this market.  There is such a nice variety of different places including ice creameries, bakeries, BBQ/soul food places, Chinese, sandwiches, Thai, oyster bar, coffee, Amish stands, etc.  It reminds me of the Ferry Building in San Francisco, but with a more comfort food, blue collar vibe.

While we were there we sampled things from Dutch Eating Place (Amish), Bassetts Ice Cream, Dienner's BBQ, Tommy Dinic's, some Chinese place, Flying Monkey Patisserie, and an Amish vendor that sold fresh squeezed juice.  Everything was generous, freshly made, well serviced, clean and fairly pried.  

A definite must see when in Philly.  Hours are Mon-Sat 8-6, Sun 10-5.

One of the stops that I really wanted to check out was the Reading Terminal Market because how can I say no to food?? We came here on a saturday because I read on the yelp reviews that the Amish People don't work on sat and I won't be able to try some of their foods. The place was big and you can compare this market to Quincy Market in Boston, Ferry Building in SF, LA Farmer Market, Essex in NYC(I still need to check this one out). The place was selling anything and everything of foods that you think of....One of thing that i wanted was their seafood but I didn't have anywhere to cook plus driving 2 hrs up to NYC, how fresh will it be so I skip out on that part. It was very crowed and people eating and buying food items. The reasons why I am only giving it a 3 star because honestly the foods is only average. It look nice and fun to be around but i just wish there is more things that stand out. I waited in lines for a roasted pork sandwhich and the line was long as hell but to my disappointed the taste was bland. The only reason I could finish it was the help of their marinated chili they have but the taste was bland!!!
The amish preztel was ok but nothing to brag about, i was going try a few other things but realize after giving them 2 try already, the 3rd will be my bad lol
from corned beef on marble rye to cold Yuengling on draft this place has it all! oh, and they also have FREE wifi

We have gone to Philly just to eat Amish food in the market. We have been to Grand Central Terminal Market in NYC, Union Station in DC http://www.unionstationdc.com/shopping
Pikes Place in Seattle http://www.yelp.com/biz/pike-place-market-seattle#query:Pikes%20place
And several other cities that have  similar markets. This is our favorite due to the Amish food. http://www.yelp.com/biz/dutch-eating-place-philadelphia#hrid:PjeZ1xDZZEsaCkd5_NzYeQ/src:self
There is fresh produce, restaurants , pretzels, ice cream,  and everything you might want to buy as others have already pointed out. Parking is usually pretty easy. 
It is worth a trip from NYC just for the market! 
I have to give it 5 stars for having Amish food since I have not encountered Amish food at other big city markets.

I really hate giving tourist traps five stars. But I can't resist with Reading Terminal Market. There are just too many good things here that I enjoyed.
 
- I had a delicious beef brisket sandwich with broccoli rabe and sharp provolone at Tommy Dinic's. Damn, that was good.
- Picked up some blue corn popcorn at the Amish store to bring back to my nieces and nephew. They loved it. The instant oatmeal was pretty good, too.
- I'm a sucker for soda, and getting imported Mexican Fanta at Flying Monkey was a treat.
- We also enjoyed a cheesesteak from Spataro's (I'm sure there are a ton of better cheesesteak options in Philly, we just didn't have the time to check 'em out).

People were friendly. The food was good. And the food wasn't too expensive.  Just being in the crowd at lunchtime was a memorable experience.

It was very crowded when I was there because it was pouring out so everyone was looking for shelter. I enjoyed it a lot, and there were so many foods to choose from so I got overwhelmed. Will definitely come back here next time.

Fall in love with philly here. You get amish, desserts, pulled pork, cuban plantains, creole po'boy sandwiches, and everything else in between.

There is something magical about indoor market places.. It's such a great community meeting ground, and reading terminal is no different. Every visit to philly should include a stop in.

There are piano players, a beer garden, a central food court, and just about anything else you could imagine.

The Food Court from Heaven, I frequented this market nearly every day during my week's stay in Philadelphia.  Open daily from 8am to 5pm, it's paradise for those who are hungry, enjoy a plethora of eating options, and cash-strapped.  From Amish Dutch bakeries and pretzels to Thai and Chinese to Soul Food and Italian pizza and pasta, you'll find a wide variety of cuisines for breakfast, lunch, and everything in between for under $7.  Oh yes, you can also grocery shop here - produce, meats, and seafood galore.  With over 90 vendors, it's overwhelming if you're hungry because almost everything looks and smells good.  These are some of my favorites and so-so stops:


Bieler's Bakery: Amish bakery with cakes, bread, whoopie pies, and rolls.  You can see the workers bake the various rolls fresh that morning.  Try their famous sticky buns with raisins - deliciously sweet.

By George Pizza: I loved the Spinach, roasted red pepper cheese slice.  They reheat it in their oven for you so it's toasty and cheesy.  

Delilah's Southern Cooking: The corn bread was disappointingly cold and crumbly, but the fried chicken was tender and the mac & cheese was flavorful and rich.     

4th Street Cookie Company: Freshly baked and thick chewy cookie.  I loved my Chocolate Chip with Walnuts.  If you want to combine sweet and sweet, there's the the Chocolate Dipped Chocolate Chip Cookie.

Torini Brothers: yummy baked Italian goods, especially the delectable Amaretto cookies.  At $20 per lb, it's worth every expensive almond flavored bite.  

Dutch Eating Place: A popular Amish brunch spot - the prices are cheap for a hearty breakfast.  The blueberry pancakes are fluffy and decent, and when visiting Philly, try the breakfast "scrapple" to try at least once - crisped ground pork and grits.      

Flying Monkey: Drool-worthy bakery with more whoopie pies than I've ever seen.  In addition to my richly sweet and dense Red Velvet whoopie pie with cream cheese frosting, there are also the flavors of: classic, cookies and cream, snickerdoodle, Elvis, and Lavender & honey.  

Kamal's: Middle eastern fare along with variety of fresh squeezed juice combinations that will give Jamba Juice a run for its money.  The Mint Lemonade hit the spot.

Pearl's Oyster Bar: In addition to trying Malpeque oysters, which tasted quite fresh, I also enjoyed the Lobster and Crab Bisque - creamy and savory with fresh chunks of crab on top.  

The Grill @ Smuckers: Delicious Amish cooked Breakfast Sausage Sandwich.  The egg was fresh, sausage patty juicy and savory, and the melted American cheese with fresh slightly sweet bread roll made a filling and delicious breakfast.  And it's served all day.    

Down Home Diner: Average comfort and diner food, although I found The Country Benny (poached eggs, sausage, buttermilk biscuit, and country gravy) unappetizingly drowning in bland gravy.  

City Coffee: for your morning coffee fix, my iced latte was nothing special, but it still satisfies that caffeine urge.  

Miller's Twist: Creamy and not-too-sweet Strawberry Milkshake comes with a free Amish baked pretzel.  The soft and slightly salted pretzel, with its golden baked surface, is tasty with the cheese dip.     

The Reading Market (Redding) fills up at the popular noon-time lunch rush, especially since it's located smack in City Center with several workers in the area.  It's more spaced out and a comfortable experience earlier in the morning, unless you don't mind squeezing shoulder to shoulder with your fellow Philly friends for some cheap, good eats.

This is a very cool place to check out if you're visiting and love food :)

There are all different types of food from pizza, the famous philly cheesesteak, salad, deli meats, indian food, halal food, amish food, bakeries etc and they sell jewelry and other random things. It's like a flea market food court with cool stuff.

VERY CROWDED during lunch, but a good place to check out when you're there :)

A great place to browse, shop for fresh groceries and eat! Reading Terminal has an vast selection of cuisines, ranging from Mediterranean to Southern homestyle joints. There are also different dessert options to choose from - ice cream, bakery goods, Profi's crepes, and Flying Monkey cup cakes! Oh my..

This place gets packed, especially during the lunch hours and over the weekend. Despite the amount of people, it doesn't stop me from getting my weekly fix of crepes!

If you are parking at the lot on filbert, be sure to get your parking ticket validated for a nice discount. Simply bring it to a vendor of your choice and ask nicely :)

During my three day stint in Philly, I came here twice. I love this market. The food is a little pricey, but I was on my vacation budget, so I was okay spending a few more dollars per meal than usual. They've got everything you want here, including meats, seafood, produce, ice cream, and various desserts. It's also a great place to people watch. I came in during lunch rush and shared a table with random people attending a nearby convention. I even got some tips from local cops on what to order!

Friendly people, and tasty food. What more could you ask for?

It's possible that I spent an afternoon here sampling cheesesteaks, pretzels, Amish baked goods, and ice cream. It's also possible that I was by myself and almost missed a flight back to London while waiting for a fresh batch of cheese-stuffed pretzel bites to come out of the oven. 

Oh, the thin line between pathetic and devoted...

Dining mecca or tourist trap? Ummm... five stars for both! My friend and I came here on a quest for a hangover cure... as we walked in, we were instantly floored by the sweet aroma of freshly baked cinnamon buns and made a mental note to return after we ate substantial food. Only moments later, we found ourselves reaching for a fresh pretzel... unreal! A few free samples later, and we decided that nothing cures a hangover like Thai food. For $5.50 each, we got a generous helping of spicy shrimp curry (amazingly flavorful and spicy!) and veggie pad thai (honestly, the veggie pad thai didn't do it for me - not moist enough). For another $2, we were gulping the very best shrimp tom yum soup. It was partly sticker shock from non-NYC prices and partly the outrageously flavorful food... but I'm hooked on Reading Terminal Market! On the way out, we picked up a whoopie pie and a cinnamon bun from the Amish bakery... both very good, but not quite as surprising as the pretzel. If I lived next door to this place, I'd be a very happy (and fat!) girl. You need a few hours to wander around... and several meals to appreciate the wonders!

i love reading! i always take visitors here, and i never leave empty handed. whether its coming here for groceries or fresh juice or bread, or fresh seafood, i always walk out happily satiated with plenty of goodies to enjoy at home :)

There are lots of really fantastic finds in the Reading Terminal Market.  I was in town for fives day for work and I can't tell you how wonderful it was to get fresh produce and healthy snacks to balance out days of frequently crappy restaurant food.  

There were some amazing stalls that sold teas and herbs and sorts of goods.  If I hadn't had to fly I would have loaded up!   I also wish I could have gotten my hands on some of that amazing looking seafood!  

My only real complaint is that I wish they stayed open a bit later.  At the very least I wish all the stalls stayed open until the market closed.  Unfortunately, many seemed to be closed or closing about an hour before the whole market did.
eclectic mix of food + beer garden + amish people + people watching = good times

Wow!  What an awesome place.  Keep in mind that "market" is a misnomer, as what Reading Terminal is, is an amazing court with a congregation of suprisingly many good food stalls.  It's not a Pike Place market, or a St. Lawrence Market, but it is it's own unique, awesome food paradise.  I don't get why we don't have anything like this in NYC (no, Essex Market doesn't cut it - what a joke).  If I lived in Philly, I would be here every day.

This may not be the place for gourmet diners, because it really is just a bunch of food stalls put together.  It's a place where you can get crepes, pastrami, emu eggs, honeycombs and Amish bread in one place.  You could buy meats and groceries here, but I'm not sure that's the focus here, unless you want Amish meats, which are good quality and cheap.  Bathrooms are not bad - Pike Place bathrooms are worse.

Pro-tip:  anyone can go into the beer garden, even kids, and you can bring food in.  The only rule is one drink per person (which includes sodas).  So instead of paying $1.70 for a fountain drink outside, might as well use pay the same amount at the beer garden and get a table too.

Parking is $28!  If you spend more than two hours there, that is.  And it's easy for a tourist like me, sampling everything, to go beyond the limit.  I spent 3 hours in total here.
You can go insane in here! OMG, from Philly cheesesteaks, to Louisiana style food to some scrumptious Amish sweets. Inexpensive and centrally located, this is a must to visit!

I love this place!  Started going here years ago anytime I was in Philly, but it's been ages since I'd last been here.  Got to stop by a few days ago on my way out of town, and it was just as good as I remembered.  Didn't get a chance to have a full meal as I had just eaten, but I had a few snacks and just enjoyed the smells.  Can't wait to go back and enjoy some fresh seafood next time I'm there.

If you're at Reading Terminal and looking for food, just head straight to DiNic's for a Roast Pork Sandwich with Greens & Provolone.  It's a SUBstantial sized hoogie so unless you're a big eater, do share with a friend and save room for some dessert and treats at the Dutch Eating Place.

It's like the Italian market on the north side... but better! (sorry south philly)

pros!
1. very good selection of fruit and veggies never a bad apple in the bunch, literally. 
2. cheap, well depends on what you're going for. but even if it's expensive its good quality so worth the price!
3. food is good, quick service. ive eaten at several places and the staff is always friendly and helpful. theyre never impatient if you dont know what you want and always have a smile on their faces.
4. it doesnt feel like Philadelphia in here... its like ive died and gone to polite heaven where it smells like sweet sweet baked goods, organic chocolate milk, fresh cheeses and the floors have been swept!
5. tables outside! i love outdoor seating... 
6. theres a wine and spirits near by... can we say wine and cheese date?

cons...
1. during the weekends its always packed with tourists so if u know where you have to go, get there fast and dodge the little children as safely as possible!
2. during lunch time the tables indoors are always packed! you have to hunt them down and wait patiently, get warm food at your caution.. be prepare to have warm soup.
3. during conventions at the hotel right across the street this can be a hard place to get into.. with everyone standing on the sidewalk with nothing to do... i cant stand people who do this in the city. 
4. their hours.. sometimes i wish they were open later but thats why this place is so wonderful i have to plan to get there on time. and even though its not around the corner from me, i love making the trip down there.

SERIOUSLY! SERIOUSLY! I didn't there were European style permanent markets like Europe in America. it was like an American Boqueria! part Farmers Market and part Food Court this place is amazing.
I wondered to myself why doesn't NYC have one of these.

I went in early to get Dinic's Roast Pork and then returned for flowers, eggs and sausage! As wandered the aisles of produce, meats and candies. Also cheese steaks, gyros, Chinese food and even a bar. I found my happy place. It is places like this that make me happy!

This review might not be very helpful, but there is no way I can describe everything great about this place in this little space. If I did have to make a few suggestions, though, DiNic's is always great, you can get some of the best hoagies around at Salumeria (ask for the house dressing on you sandwich as well), and 4th St. Cookies are incredible.

Just go to the Market and you'll understand.

In all seriousness, Reading Terminal makes me very proud to be Philadelphian!  I feel so fortunate to have such a unique place the proverbial hop, skip, and jump away.  I wish I could go there every single day.  

Any food you buy here is amazing - from the produce, to the imported cheeses and meats, to the counter restaurants, anyone can get something from Reading Terminal.  

There's Italian, Chinese, turkey, fresh-made smoothies, baked goods, top-of-the-line produce, cheesesteaks (from people who actually know how to make them - and that would be withOUT that ghastly Cheese Whiz!), and you can even pick up a cookbook or two at the Cook Book Stall.  There' s also a little sports bar tucked inside the Terminal that's pretty cool along with a diner.   

The best part about the Terminal is sitting down to eat in the table area where the people watching is priceless.

Wandering through the labryrinth of the Terminal, as well as the hoardes of people that are there at any given time on any day, is a treat for me.  As someone who was born and raised in the city, I appreciate this treasure trove of food and history and I continue to be amazed at the stuff this place offers every time I go there.

Reading Terminal is a well-run machine that has been going for over a century - and may it continue for another century and beyond!

What an awesome market.

The Reading Terminal Market is an indoor farmer's market with many shops, most focusing on food.  Butchers, fishmongers, florists, grocers, and specialty food stores are plenty, as well as restaurants, deli, and food vendors.  The famous Tommy DiNic's is in the market and their pork sandwiches are must haves.  I'm also a huge fan of Beth's Cajun since Reading Terminal Market was the last place I'd expect to have some bomb cajun food.  Chinese, Japanese, Greek, and Italian, cheesesteaks, and everything can be found here!

There are also plenty of bakeries in there and there's a bakery that'd probably fit your kind of diet.  There's even a Vegan baker here.  As soon as you walk in, the aroma of all sorts of baked goods just punches you in face, in a good way!  Beiler's is a good spot to indulge yourself in the world of buttery goodness.

Old City Cafe has got some bomb coffee and there's even a vendor selling fresh squeezed juices to quench your thirst!

It can get really crowded during lunch, since the convention center is right next door so be prepared to fight through some crowds or stand around to wait for a table.

Definitely take sometime to walk through the whole market.  I was lucky enough to go there for lunch for 3 days during my stay in Philly, but definitely wish that I had an afternoon to explore everything in there!

I hecka LOVE this place!  More than a fat kid loves candy!

Every single day that I was in Philly I made it a mission to come eat here at least once a day, maybe even twice if i found time to sneak away from my work.  I really enjoyed walking around eating bits of food here & there.  It's extremely inexpensive and the portions are huge!  I love the variety and that they sell seafood, poultry, chocolate, candles & everything you possibly can think of!  I wish I could try every single vendor there, but it would take me weeks and my clothes wouldn't be able to handle it!  A few of my favorite places are listed below:

Little Thai Market - you gotta try their Salmon & cream sauce, its da bomb!
Olympic Gyro - huge gyros & so delicious
Beck's Cajun Cafe - I really like the gumbo & their cornbread!
Profi's Creperie - you gotta try their dessert crepes
Spatoro's Cheesesteaks - you cannot go to Philly & not try a cheesesteak
The Grill @ Smuckers - cheap & fast service
Kamal's Middle Eastern Specialities - great selection of meal deals there

This is my favorite place to be in Philly.  I would come back just so i can eat here!

I've said it once, I'll say it again:  I love Philadelphia.  The Reading Terminal Market just made me love it a little more.  It's almost like marrying the woman of your dreams only to find out she loves to play all of the video games that you like to play...sigh.

First off, thanks to Philadelphia tourism for teaching me the right way to say "Reading".  Apparently it is pronounced more like the color Red versus the thing you do with a book when it's open.

For those of you unfamiliar with this place, it is a GIGANTIC open air (but enclosed) market.  I'm not going to list every type of shop and eatery.  If you want that, I'm sure you can go to their website.  What I can tell you is that if you are hungry, but don't know what you want, come wander the Reading Terminal Market for 10 minutes.  I'm sure you'll come across something awesome.

While there, I enjoyed my first falafel from Kamal's, a gigantic calzone from By George!, beer from the Beer Garden, and a cookie from the Famous 4th Street Cookie Company.  All together, a wonderful lunch and awesome experience.

Reading Terminal Market is a must stop when you got to Philly. 

Love at first site and tastes...

There's a couple of places I'd like to try in here, but I get turned off so quickly by how crowded it is I get the heebiejeebies and then I run out. It's always the places I'm not interested in that I can walk right up. Hello ice cream! There's just never a time when I come in here and it's not crowded. It blows my mind. There's all kinds of crazy mofos lurking in that tunnel too.

I must say, the touristy business women are attractive.

Go here for breakfast or lunch!  This covered market has 30+ food vendors and offers everything from crepes to Afghan kabobs, to tasty gyros!  You can also get some fresh produce, a beer at the beer garden, sample some amish cooking or get a Grand Marnier truffle!  Looking for fresh fish or lobster?  They've got it!  Want some fresh lasagna or pulled pork?  Yeah, that's here too.  I went around 11:00am on a Wednesday, it was busy, but not crowded like other reviewers have mentioned.  We were able to find seats easily and enjoyed our lunch while listening to a live piano player.  Gotta check this place out if visiting Philly.  It's just a 7 or 8 block walk from the historic district.
If you only have time to go to one place in Phili, go here.  Seriously.

I wish i could give more stars, 5 are not enough for this gem.
We at the moment are living right across the street.
What can i say?
Fish Markets, check!!
Butchers, check!!
Produce, check!!
Pastries, check!!
Poultry Market, check!!
Diners, check!!
Check, chrck, check!!!!!
AMAZING PLACE!!!!!

I love this place! It opens at 8am on saturdays and has an amish section, great food (new orleans, dinics, and etc), chocolates and desserts, stuff for your kitchen, chinese food and a whole slew of other things. I def recommend hanging out where on the weekend and just trying new food and walking around. Its so close to downtown and old town that when walking from one to the other ther eis no reason not to stop here!

This place was great! Super excited to march around and check it out. Was sad I hit on a day the Amish vendors were not open but otherwise everything looked very tasty. I'm looking forward to going back sometime soon and really diving in.

Pork roast and pancakes, all cheap, oh my!

I don't think we're in Kansas anymore.

We're in Heaven.

Cheers-

In short, this market is incredible! There are dozens, many dozens in fact, of independently owned stalls which feature organic produce, baked goods, artisan cheesees, freshly cut meat, handmade onsite ice cream (Bassetts), gourmet chocolates (Chocolates by Mueller- superb!), even used books and candle/home decor items, but primarily it is a food based market. Come for breakfast or lunch and partake of the many purveyors of prepared foods scattered throughout the market, then plop down at a central seating area and enjoy the bounty of a truly extraordinary market!

If I ever moved far away I would miss the Reading Terminal. It reminds me of an indoor mall focused around food. It's a fat kid's dream to eat here because they have a little bit of everything. From fried chicken to vegetarian, from crepes to muffins, from cheap Amish breakfast to expensive fancy cakes---a tourist would need a big appetite to check it all out. 

Bring your patience because the lines can become gruesome, the bathrooms can be a disaster and the table seats can be all taken up. Still, I love it for its variety and fantastic food.

A true foodie's heaven! You'll want to come here hungry! 

There is absolutely something for everyone here... and then some! 

Chocolates, cheeses, coffees, cookies, cheesesteaks, pizzas, meats, seafood, gelato, pastries, not to mention all the specialty foods 

Everything is extremely fresh & there's no wrong place to start digging in 

Snagged some local cinnamon honey & chocolates.....we got there too late to try the famous Apple Dumplings & they were closed Memorial Day Monday - boo! 

But next time, my pretties.....for sure!! The plan will be to come for breakfast & eat my way through dinner!

This place is great for locals and visitors! When I lived in Philadelphia, I would come here for some fresh produce. As a visitor for a conference, I stopped by here for lunch multiple times. It gets very packed and has very little seating, but there are so many great options! I love the atmosphere of this place. Each eatery has it's own personality and sitting at the bar is a great place to get close to the action!
A must see while in Philly.  Great place to grab some food.  Unique and several choices. Don't miss this!

One of my favorite sites in the whole city.  I come here often for fresh produce and meat, and the prices for those are great.

Prepared food tends to be a little overpriced.  During weekday lunch, this place is overrun with dumb tourists, convention goers, and jury members; all of whom stand around and clog the place up.

But for lunch, grocery shopping, delicous cookies, bulk spices, or just good people watching, Reading Terminal has a lot to offer.

A great place to go and eat lunch, and then shop for meat / seafood / produce / cheese / pasta for dinner!  Some of the prepared food vendors are better than others, so be sure to do your research.  But they have awesome, very well-priced seafood, meat, and produce.

This is another one of Man v Food's spots so while visiting a friend up in Philly, we made it a point to come here to try DiNic's famous roast pork sandwich.  Unfortunately, the line was so dang long that we skipped it and figured that we'd save DiNic's for another visit.

Other than our failed attempt at getting a roast pork sandwich, Reading Terminal is great, although very overwhelming with the amount of people, businesses and food choices.  

Here are some of the spots that I stopped and purchased food at:

L. Halteman Family - great jams especially the blackberry and strawberry flavors; the wildflower honey went especially quick upon bringing it home

AJ Pickle and Patch Salad - they have the biggest pickles I have ever seen; 1 for $1

Sweet as Fudge Candy Shoppe - I could have gone crazy in this store, what with my sweet tooth but just bought dark chocolate covered espresso beans.

Fat Fish Sandwiches - With such inventive names such as "Fat Cajun, Fat Buffalo, Fat Pig, Fat Boy, and Fat Dan" I just ordered the soft shell crab sandwich.  I love soft shell crab, however, it was just tasted too fishy for me.

Lancaster County Dairy and Juices - Great fresh Strawberry Lemonade

Miller's Twist Pretzels and More - Get a fresh pretzel once it comes out of the oven...so soft and buttery

Old City Coffee - They roast their beans on-site.  Pretty good ice coffee.

Kauffman's Lancaster County Produce: sold interesting dehydrated vegetables such as okra and beets (recommended by MacRae O.)  I did buy it because I love both of those vegetable but in dehydration form, is a another story.  I ended up sending it to my dad who enjoyed it more than I ever would.  

Before I left, I ended my food gorging with a cookie to go along with my ice coffee.  I don't remember the name of the shop but you can't miss it as it's near one of the entrances.

This place is the best thing about going to a convention!!!

I wish that every convention center in the world had a market place like this.  What a great place to escape too and have some lunch!!!  The Amish Bakery near Arch Street was making some fantastic smells today.

My favorite place in here is Tommy DiNic's...I had the most amazing sandwich here...go for the Roast Pork...trust me...I did it for 3 days!!!  It was like heaven on Italian Bread!!!

There is also discounted parking across the street on 12th Street...I think you have to spend $20 from a merchant and then they will validate.

Only issue is that during a convention it is always crowded on it...so plan according because there may be a little wait for your food...so schedule your booth time and meetings accordingly!!!

After living in Philadelphia for over 6 years how on God's green earth is this the first time I've ever been to Reading Terminal Market? My only regret is that I didn't find out about this place sooner. Oh how I wish I had known about the wondrous treasures tucked inside this well disguised market full of fabulousness when I worked just 5 blocks away. My taste buds would love me but my backside (and perhaps my husband) might not have enjoyed the consequences of my overindulgence. 

Believe them when they say this place is packed on the weekends.  The little old lady I almost ran over with my stroller can atest to this.  IN true Philly fashion she shot me a dirty look, mouthed some expletives and kept it moving.  Other than that , how could you not love this place? For starters, there are approximately 75 vendors in this locale so even the pickiest of people should be able to find SOMETHING they enjoy (Unless they're from NYC, then all bets are off because you know NYC has thee best of everything *insert eye roll*). The place is cramped, let's just put that out there. They say 100,000 people come through the market per week but honestly it feels more like 100k per day. You're sure to trip over tourists stopping and gawking in the aisles as local people trying to pass by get annoyed (sorry Grandma). Grab yourself a Tenant Directory (from either a bathroom or the market information booth) and it will help guide you to wherever your interests may take you. The directory divides businesses into the following categories: 

*Bakeries 
*Beverages 
*Dairy & Cheese 
*Flowers & Plants (one vendor) 
*Housewares, Books, Crafts, etc. 
*Meats & Poultry 
*Seafood 
*Pennsylvania Dutch 
*Produce 
*Restaurants 
*Specialty Foods 

Be advised that 30% of the tenants are closed on Sunday, this includes ALL of the Dutch Merchants (they only work Wed-Sat).   The market itself is open 8 to 6 from Mon-Sat and 9 to 5 on Sun.  

Treat yourself to a delicious pretzel (and fresh lemonade) at Miller's Twist. 
Get the famous apple dumpling at Dutch Eating Place. 
If you're into the Oprah hype, stop by Delilah's for the "best ever mac & cheese" (I can't attest to that and hell, Oprah looks like she'll eat anything to me so I don't know if she's exactly a qualified food source) 

You'll find Asian cuisine, Soul Food, Ice Cream, baked teats, cheesteaks, and everything you need to get the complete Philadelphia experience. 

Park anywhere in the Parkway Garage at 12th & Filbert Streets and park for $4. 
Bring your parking ticket to the market with you and after making a purchase of $10 or more ANY merchant will validate your ticket (upon request). 
You automatically receive flat rate of $4 for UP TO 2 hours of parking (anything over that and you're subject to the astronomical garage rates). 

If you're not in for a drive just take the train. You can exit either rail line at 13th street, head east towards 12th street and make a left onto 12th. You can't miss the signs and you won't want to miss the food!

Oh my lovely Reading Terminal Market...you kick any NYC markets' ass I am so sorry yet delighted to say. With the Amish markets, DiNics, some kick-ass Cajun food, cookies, whoopie pies, oysters and coffee (in two trips...not one!), it was almost mind blowing how great you are. And you have a beer "garden" where I can sit and eat anything I want...sigh, I will miss you terribly.
We went for the roast pork sandwich with sharp provolone and rabe at DiNics and stayed for all the other yummy things.

Reading Terminal Market is the shit. Seriously, can you think of a better market in any other US city? I can't. This place has it all. From Amish to Thai, to South Philly, to Greek to Chinese, you could spend days eating in the Market (and I have). I plan to give specific reviews for each vendor, so I won't go into too much detail about my favs, but the market itself is a serious Philadelphia highlight and treasure. For those that have never been, the Market is located around 12th and Arch, is indoor, and used to share it's venue with a train station. The market underwent major renovations in the 1990's, and has about 80 shops and stands that sell prepared food, and the raw materials ie. meat, fish, produce, etc.  

Major highlights for me include Termini Brothers for pastries and cannolis, Iovines for produce, Martins for bacon and sausages, the Asian place that does smoothies, Bassetts for ice cream, and the Cajun spot (Beck's?) for gumbo when I get that hankering. Jack's Down home Diner is also a go to if I have had enough, and need a booth to sit down and relax. I am usually in the Market on weekends, and do have to note that many stands are closed on Sundays, especially anything Amish. Saturdays can be, in the words of the Bodes, BANANAS. When I say the place gets packed it can be an understatement, so be prepared for crowds, and watch where you stand. You will be pushed, shoved, bumped, and stepped on if you do not pay attention. There is nothing worse than an obese, fanny packed tourist clogging the narrow aisles declaring "Look kids, its one of those Aim-ish guys!" 

Despite the crowds, there is always something happening in the common spaces, such as live music, or if your lucky, the occasional Philly sports celeb signing autographs. I believe I bought some salsa from Mitch Williams a few years back. Bathrooms are clean, but can be packed. Also the RTM is super close to Chinatown. Parking can be a bit of an issue, but of late I have discovered some great metered spots not too far away that have been pretty empty. I am not giving up those secrets, though. On a closing note- If you are thinking about getting a DiNic's pork sandwich, either get there around opening or closing, or be prepared to wait. I've seen lines with well over 50 people in them. Also, in my opinion, the sandwich is not as good as Paesano's (see my review), so maybe you can keep the dream alive, and hit up the Italian Market, as well.  I've done a double market day only a few times, but have filled my fridge for weeks.  Good luck, grasshopper.

Best. Market. Ever. There's so much ridiculously good stuff here that you forget that one of the places is Tommy DiNic's. I live in Atlanta. I wish that instead of the Kroger or Publix they had a Reading Terminal Market near where I live. If that happened, I would certainly be triple my current body weight and basking in the glory of delicious obesity. It's almost torturous going through Reading and trying to commit to only one place! I only think that by choosing one place, I forgo another place. It's torture I tell you, torture! If you haven't been here, this should be at the top of your list of things to do in Philadelphia. Arm yourself with Tums, Pepcid, and Nexium. And enjoy it. Best. Market. Ever.

Overrated.  About 90% of the things sold here you can get around the corner from your house at the local grocers.  I was there Sat.  Very crowded.  People stepping on each other's toes.
  
Bassetts ice cream is very commercialized and run like the the local Wendy's, and not all it was cracked up to be.  This one of the reasons I chose to visit was because of all the hoopla I heard about Bassett's.  Two baby scoops of ice cream for $5.  Braums ice cream that I used to visit was 10x's better and much cheaper.  Ben and Jerry's tastes even better than this.  
 
Much of the cooked food here is over priced and underseasoned.  It reminded me of an upgraded mall Food Court.  

Parking was $8 for 2 hrs.  Driving around RTM is typical horrendous  hectic downtown driving.   

One of the few places that I did like was Herschels East side deli.  The roast and corned beef were worth the price, very tender and moist.  

At any rate, save yourself the hassle and gas.  Why fight your way thru a crowded food court for chicken, fish or ice cream when you can get that almost hassle free at the local grocers.  However, if you like crowds and ppl watching than this might be your thing.

I have a deep love for Reading Terminal Market. This truly is Philadelphia at it's finest.  There are only 2 issues I have with this smorgsboard of food. The first is that it is almost impossible to decide what to eat. The second is that the amish are not there everyday. Is there anything sadder than when you go to lunch at reading terminal on Monday hoping for some apple dumblings, scrapple, assorted freshly baked breads and fresh deli meats only to find 1/4 of the market is barren and cold? It's at this time when I remember my other options including the turkey cranberry and stuffin' sandwhich special at The Original Turkey and a giant peanut butter cookies at Famous Fourth Street. 

So, try to avoid days when the Amish stands are not open, but if you happen to stumble upon the market even during these off days you are still in for quite a treat. Good luck deciding what you want to eat before your friends have gotten their food and area already half way done.

Market full of treats and foods to eat and try...it seemed like I could have gotten anything there...Asian food and non Asian food...chocolate ears and noses? Hmmm...how strange! But it looked quite interesting....yes, its like a market too-buy eggs, seafood, and poultry too....Hmm....almost reminded me of Chinatown without the Chinese workers....haha.. :)

It is a fun place to go as a tourist.  But, when I do I cannot help but wonder if the city had a rating system what kind of rating it would get.  It really is pretty damn filthy in there.  The food I have had was only ok.  The best was the pizza.

What can I say about Reading that everyone else hasn't said already. There are so many different options for food here that I just laugh when I see my friends drooling over the different options.

Dinic's is one of my favorite spots here for their famous roast pork sandwich. So juicy and succulent that I debate everyday whether to move to Philly just for this sandwich.

If you're around during the weekday, I would highly recommend trying out the Amish market food in here as well!

When you're ready to relax, have a beer or eight at the Beer garden in the middle.

This is arguably the nicest assortment of food you will find inside one place in the downtown area of any major city.  Visiting Philly for the first time, I had a completely different vision.  I thought it would be similar to this big indoor Flea Market with a bunch of people trying to hustle me for a fake gucci bag or some knock off sunglasses.  I was pleasantly surprised to walk over from the Loews hotel to see a bunch of men and women in Pilgrim outfits at different vendors serving, baking and displaying almost anything I wanted to eat.  Cheesesteaks, chocoloates, cookies, pretzels, a produce market, fish market,  bakery . . . . the smell of chocolate cookies and fried onions never smelt so good.

I walked, but parking seemed easy.  I believe if you purchase 10 dollars worth of stuff at the market you get 3 dollar parking on Filbert and 12th, so that is real convenient for those of you driving in.  The place is huge so go in with an open mind and be ready to try an assortment of stuff at your own pace.  The food is delicious.

The only knock I got on this place is the hours of operation.  They close at 6 p.m.  A place like this in the middle of City Center in Philadelphia should be open to atleast 9 p.m. . . . I can only imagine how packed it is on the weekend when people aren't rushing from work trying to make the closing.  Also by me going on a Wednesday morning around 9 a.m. . . . not everything was open.

Overall, if you are visiting from out of town I would say this is a MUST do in Philly . . . anything and everything you thought of eating in Philly is right here and with reasonable prices.  I am very much a fan of this place.  Just don't expect to go here after a long day of touring, because it might not be open.

I love going to the Reading Terminal market during my lunch break. The food for the most part is good, interesting crowds. The only thing I hate is how rude the cleaning staff in the green shirts are. Other than them, the place is awesome.

The Reading Market was a regular shopping spot for me when I lived in Philly.  The food is amazing and the feel of the market is so nice.  People bustling around and trying to buy the freshest veggies.

It's reading terminal. I've been astounded with all the shops in here on a consistent basis. Of note are Iovine brother's produce and giunta's prime shop. It just doesn't get better than this place. My tip - try to get there during the week. It's packed on the weekend.
I wish this place was in Texas.  If you love great food of all types this is the place to go.  This is on the top of my revisit list next time in PA.
Lots of good places to buy from with very fresh produce, meats and fish from.

Reading Terminal is your one-stop shop! It has EVERYTHING. Your first trip here will be overwhelming so allow me to guide you.

FOOD: Hershel's, They have the best pastrami, corned beef, and brisket, all hand cut right in front of you. Served on homemade rye bread. (get mustard and onions and you're set!)

Salumeria: On my top list for Italians. They're great because their products are fresh, delicious, and most of their add's such as Cheese, Roasted red peppers, and hot relish are included in the price. 

SWEETS: 4th St. Cookies. Delicious and affordable, especially if you luck out and get them right out of the oven! 

AMISH: If you want Amish food or goods, be sure to come Wed.-Sat. otherwise you will be sorely diappointed. (Miller's Twist pretzel's are like Auntie Anne's on steroids, yum!). 

PRODUCE: Super fresh, super cheap, mostly locally bought produce. Great selection and really friendly staff. 

COFFEE: Go to Old City Coffee and get an iced coffee. Really good here.

These are listed in a carefully thought out chronological order. Eat 'til you explode, get fresh produce at the end so you don't have to lug it around all day with you, then fight off the food coma with a refreshing iced coffee. Have fun!

P.S. You will get a chance to check out the whole market on your scavenger hunt. Good luck and god speed :)

So much to choose from.  If you don't like eclectic or intl flavors stick with the sandwiches as Dinics, ice cream and Miller Twist pretzels.  If you want to be more adventurous in taste, there are plenty other cultures to choose from.  Make sure to go for breakfast or lunch as they close at 6pm.

If I closed my eyes, I could imagine I was back in one of my favorite places on Earth...Grand Central Market in NYC. A local friend steered me toward this highlight of our visit to Philly. A historic farmer's market in the city center, Reading Terminal Market is crammed with specialty food vendors making it nearly impossible to narrow down a meal. Deciding on dessert, however, was no problem whatsoever...a strawberry, walnut & Nutella crepe from Profi's Creperie. Lecker!!!

Part farmer's market, deli, and specialty food store all rolled into one!  Amish vendors are a bonus.  They are there Wednesday through Saturday and make great pickles.  

Lots of food to try. I was here on business and it is right near the convention center.  It was great to pick some fresh fruit to bring back to the hotel for a healthy snack.  

The ambiance is great.  It does get crowded at lunch time but that is to be expected.  

My only negative is that they use lots of disposable items: utensils and plates and that they don't appear to compost.  Composting would be a natural fit here and could serve community gardens.

Better than Pike Place in Seattle, Granville Island in Vancouver, and Chelsea Market in NYC.  Probably tied with the Ferry Building in San Francisco. 

I've been told this place is for tourists.  Well I guess I love playing a tourist, cause I'm here every frickin' week buying steaks from Martin's, fruit and veggies from Iovine Brothers, and fresh juice from the amish guy near the east end (try the Victory blend).

This is a fun place to visit. There is a good variety of merchants represented here (including Amish vendors). They even have a bar and wine tasting area inside the Market if you need to indulge. The food options are plentiful. You can also buy fresh cuts of meat and fresh fish.
Had some really excellent pumpkin cream cheese cookies from the Amish bakery in the corner.  Delicious!
I absolutely love this place. I wish I lived closer so I could go for shopping more often. They have the best seafood  ever. I highly recommend it to everyone!

Various eateries and businesses. From cheese steaks to wine & cheese to rotisserie chicken to fresh fruit & veggies. A little bit of every thing. Try Herschel's sandwiches, Big enough for two people. Termini Bros. Bakery...delicious!!!
Love it- Great organic products here. The ice cream is a must.

Reading Terminal Market makes NYC's Chelsea Market look like a prison for yuppies. Chelsea Market is small, drab, desolate, crowded, and full of overpriced crap that no one really wants except the few, the proud, and the hipsters.

Reading Terminal, on the other hand, is a colorful, bustling center brimming with food stands. Even on a Sunday, the place was still quite active. There are fresh produce stands (which have delicious goodies!), delis, ethnic stands, and cheesesteak stands. Prices are fair; and vary depending on which stand you go to. Good luck picking a stand, too, the variety is immense.

I even found a machine with free Reese's Pieces!

I wish I lived nearby. If I did, I would come here every day for my fresh groceries!

I love this place... They have just about anything you can think of to eat here. It a perfect place to grab a snack or some lunch.... It's also a good place to people watch. They have lots of seats inside and outside.

It's clean. The prices are reasonable. Service is good from almost all of the vendors. 

Definitely worth a trip to Reading Terminal Market.

Which of the following do you enjoy?
a) markets
b) places that threaten to beat shoplifters to death
c) food
d) crowded places

If you answered any of the above, this place is for you!  I love love LOVE markets like this, and knowing that Flying Monkey Patisserie lives here was even more incentive to stop by!  I enjoyed an almond cupcake and was blown away by the variety of whoopie pies they offered too (snagged me a red velvet). 

I added actual nutrition to my lunch by getting some alligator gumbo that was mighty spicy and satisfying.  You'll find your fill of chocolate, ice cream, Italian food, Cajun, Thai, Chinese, sandwiches, Mediterranean, and candy here! 

What more could you ask for in a market??!

I was overwhelmed with all the stores that were in here! But all was great! We tried Dinick's for their pork and broccoli sandwich - it was ok. Not the greatest, but it was juicy and the slight bitterness of the broccoli rah gave the sandwich a little more umph.
We also tried Salumeria, known for their hoagies. We got the Italian hoagie and I liked it a bit more than the pork/broccoli sandwich. Full of flavor and very filling.
Of course we had to get ice cream and Bassett's! Definitely a lot creamier than other ice cream we've tasted. Most definitely one of my favorites =)
I have to come here again to try all the other things in the market! So many things to do!

Um, how do I even begin? This place is AMAZING.

Firstly - being a CA native, I was in dire need of fresh produce. TJ's? Nope. Superfresh and Whole Foods? Meh. Luckily, someone mentioned Reading Terminal Market as a cool spot to get all my grocery shopping done while grabbing some ready-made eats.

The place can be a little overwhelming/crowded, but just take your time and explore the diff stands. Now that I'm getting more "domesticated," I def love walking around and checking out the various meat/seafood/produce/bread stands. Seafood is the best quality/price I've seen in the area, and produce is ridics cheap.

Will def need to try DiNic's, the Reuben stand and many other spots but this is my go-to shopping spot moving forward.

Quick tip: Student discounts at nearly all of the stands on Sun and Wed!

I don't think there's much else I can add to the Reading Terminal experience, but it was such a charming little spot that I had to write a review on it.

Tips:
1) Come between Wednesday and Saturday, especially this week due to the festival, since that is when the Pennsylvanian Dutch come and fill your hearts content with food. Since I came on a Monday morning, some of the vendors weren't open due to that.
2) Try the fresh fruit smoothies. I got a 20 oz of the refreshing watermelon/cantaloupe/banana for only $4.15 with tax. Made with real, fresh fruit, no preservatives or added sugar - just plain ole goodness.
3) Beer garden in the middle of the day? Sure why not! Average prices of beer on tap. $10 for two Blue Moons and we got our parking validated (:
4) What do you get when you mix seafood, Asian flavors, and Western subs/sandwiches together? You get an Asian fusion, seafoody Fat Korean to pair with that refreshing Blue Moon. (YES they have fat sandwiches at the market!)
5) If you park in the lot across the street, parking can be validated by a vendor once you purchase $10. However, this is only worth it if you spend less than 3 hours in the market. Otherwise it's a flat rate of $28 between 3 and 12 hours.
6) If it's hot out, come to Bassett's early in the morning to beat the rush. There tends to be a line at the counter while people try different flavors and other nonsense. This makes the line unbearably long.

Reading Terminal is such a nice escape from the city, and it's such a large foodie haven. I'm afraid that after frequenting RT, my DC Eastern Market may not be enough for me now...

I love RTM.  My friend and I went the other day and we were both marveling about how unique it is.  I've never seen anything like it in another city.  I don't make it here as often as I would like to, but its a great spot to bring Philly visitors.  They have absolutely everything there including wine.
Love Reading Terminal Market! Come early and grab lunch at Dinic's. Love the roast pork w/ sharp provolone. Reasonable prices and you can find almost anything!
kind of expensive, but the quintessential philadelphia food stop. my favorite attraction in the city. overwhelming with delicious things.
very fun and a lot of selections to choose from.  a must go when visiting philly!
Heaven on earth for foodies. Period. I love this place!!!!
This place is huge, but it doesn't seem very sanitary.  If you're looking to eat lunch here, skip it.  The food places are all tourist traps selling pricey horrible food.

A wonderful place for a casual meal, or to buy meat, baking, produce or preserves.  Many booths are Amish run, and their food is fresh and delicious.  Add in the ethnic spots, and the choices are too many to list.  Not to be missed.

This review is LONG over due. 

I came here after finishing a half marathon and I was craving something sticky, sweet and all around bad for me. 

I walked the market and was overwhelmed with the smells, variety and overall friendly nature of all I met. 

I decided on the crepes stand and ordered the breakfast crepe which was filled with eggs, cheese and some veggies of your choosing. As expected this was light and tasty. The crepe was very savory but not overpowering or dense. Which was PERFECT because I had already selected my dessert; a nutella and banana filled crepe. 

Talk about motivation to workout - this was amazing. Now I should warn you - I could eat Nutella out of the jar on a spoon but warming it up and adding in some banana makes it heavenly. 

Again the crepe was light, fluffy and a bit sweeter this time. They folded in the Nutella and banana slices to make a delectable sandwich. And to show that I am a loving individual I shared my treat with my two co-runners. We all loved it and if it wasn't for our time crunch could have eaten more. 

If you are in the area and want to see and taste a lot head on over.
Great place to try different types of food, deserts, or even grocery shopping.

One of the things I had intention of seeing when moving to the area was the Reading Terminal Market. Think indoor farmers market, amazing looking food vendors, flowers, chocolate, freshly made everything you can think of - cheeses, jam, pickled something, sauces, breads, baked goods, Dutch Pennsylvania invasion - sweet mother of jesus why do I only have one stomach... all under the same roof.

One of the things that thoroughly impressed me was the large amount of vendors of the Pennsylvania Dutch variety. They were legit, down to the garb and beards. Lots of respect there and I definitely plan on patronizing them regularly. There were these amazing looking pies in one booth that had me salivating. I had already had lunch so I skipped on it but next time I know... I am going to have pie, FOR LUNCH. 

It was unfortunately packed and full of tourists (me included) which made navigating a little frustrating and difficult from time to time. Which led to the misfortune of getting my wallet jacked by some pick-pocketing asshats who double teamed by pushing me around in a busy corridor. Beware of crowds near the exits, keep your bags in front of you or stuff your wallet in your underwear, do not take out money at the ATM there cause they will case you... it happened to me. Apparently it is a problem there and I didn't know any better. 

But overall? WOW. It was a cornucopia of culinary eye porn that was a game of "just the tip". I want more. I plan on going back to the crime scene despite my apprehension. No one, not even a wallet stealing prick is gonna keep me from such a killer resource. And next time I am going more prepared: empty belly and an extra sharp eye... more food porn to come.

I could live here. No, really. Last time I went, I spent three hours in here without realizing it. I live less than half a mile from this place and I have to stop myself heading out there every day. I have a feeling that my weighing scale and wallet are both going to be feeling the effects of living so close to RTM before the year is out!

I think the reviewers here have done a more than adequate job of talking about how wonderful this is and where you should go, but I'll add my two cents in anyhow.

OK, so if you do live in the area and come here to shop for groceries, come either in the mornings or after 3pm. Also, if you're a student one of the produce places  (forget which aisle it's in) offers a 10% student discount. Because it's terribly crowded otherwise. Lunch time here is pretty crazy. But, even though I hate crowds, I'd brave even the lunch time crowds for this foodie heaven.

Can't praise the Amish baked goods enough. Their various breads--peach, apple cinnamon etc are YUMMY and they make the best gingerbread I have ever had. Oh and the apple dumplings with heavy cream...I think I'm going to go out right now and get myself one, haha. The international cheese place has a great selection at reasonable rates--it stocked all the English cheeses that I love (Blue Stilton, Wensleydale, Double Gloucester). The Thai place is wonderful too. The red curry was too much for just one meal--I ate it over two. Dinner *and* lunch for just $7!! 

There are SO many places here which I plan on gradually exploring over the coming months...I'll add to this if I come across anything exceptional. But if you're in Philly and haven't been there yet, GO NOW.

I am a sucker for Sunday mornings at the Terminal Market, however I only spend minimal time inside. I like to get there early to get my fruits and vegetables and get out-it becomes too busy and crowded for me! It's pretty great though if you just want to grab a bit to eat during the week or have friends in town who'd like to taste a variety of food in the city.

One of the best and most diverse markets I've been to! 

I'm amazed by all it has to offer and all the options, even for a vegetarian!!

Tons of fresh produce, nuts, cheese, bread, chocolate, pastries, jams, sauces, specialty items, flowers..  the list does not seem to end. 

Huge variety of food, snack and dessert vendors as well from all different regions/ethnic backgrounds. Love that. You could come here everyday every day during a week and get something completely different each time. 

It wasn't overwhelmingly crowded the times that I went, except on Saturday.

If you don't want to break the bank.. several vendors are participating in the $7 meal deal with at least one meal combo on the menu for $7. 

I could easily spend hours here.. makes me so happy :)

Reading Terminal Market...when we will we see each other again... I cannot get over your variety of tastes, color and smell! 1st taste was that famous roast pork sandwich at DiNic's.......after I saw the portly guy from Man vs Food inhale one. What about dessert....dried meats...bread....fresh fruits and veggies...and beer. I can easily spend the whole day here and have all my 6 meals covered, plus grocery too.

Whenever I go to this side of town, I try to plan it around when this market will be open.  It's basically just a large, indoor market where a lot of people working in this part of town will come for lunch and to grab some goodie groceries and a few knick knacks to go.  There's so much though it's easy to get distracted so if you're on a time limit, go in with a plan.  But there are a lot of fresh produce, specialty stands (everything from cheese, chocolates and meats to soaps,) and Bassets ice cream so it has everything I need in life to be happy (and clean).  I think I used to think it was kind of expensive, but after nearly 5 years in CA and shopping SF markets, I don't think so anymore.  

  :')

I can't believe this was my first visit to RTM.  I LOVE food and this market was heaven to me.  I only wish I could have spent the WHOLE day because there are SO many awesome stalls. Prices were reasonable too.  Poor me doesn't live that close but can't wait to go back.

This place reminded me a lot of Grand Central Terminal in NYC but bigger. Every stall looked enticing from food to books to kitchen accessories. Unfortunately we went right after lunch so we weren't hungry. Since we went on a Sunday, we didn't get to check out the Dutch Eating Place. We were also thinking of picking up a sandwich at DiNic's for later but the line was pretty long and we weren't feeling it so next time for sure! Overall, I love the crowd and culture.

Driving from eastern Massachusetts to the Beltway Region(Megalopolis Region ) can be one of the most nauseating experiences in the USA. Not because of the drive but what you see. How many Macys, Walmart, Old Navy, and Kohls do you see ? Probably infinite ! But in reality thats what the northeast corridor feels like. Coming to a place like Reading Terminal Market is a major relief. There are many food, produces, and home made gift outlets throughout this building. All of them are occupied by local bussiness, farmers across the regions, and of course the Amish. I would highly recommend visting any of the concessions owned by the Amish especially if you do not have the time to venture out to Amish Country in Lancaster County PA because it is one of the few places where you can find Amish goods.

everything you'd want in a market. Itialian food, ethnic food, misc crafts, amish goods. I was in town visiting from the west coast and the eggplant parmisean sandwich I had was full of deliciousness and nostalgic goodness.

No trip to Philly is complete without a visit to the Reading Terminal Market.  A foodie's delight with every type of cuisine you can imagine, all under one roof.  

My first trip there, I stumbled upon the Dutch Eating Place and I had their delicious blueberry pancakes.  The next visit, I stopped by a seafood restaurant (the name escapes me) and had the biggest scallops I have ever seen...also delicious.  Another time, I sampled a Philly cheesesteak for lunch.  I've been there at least three times and I still probaby haven't done a complete walk-through, the place is just that massive.  

Be forewarned, it can get crazy crowded at lunch time.  Security is there to make sure you don't form a line in the wrong place, lol.

Welcome to sensory overload. If you're visiting Philadelphia this is an absolute must see and eat attraction. There are many famous vendors in the market place, but also a few gems that aren't as well known. The best part about it is- there is something for everyone. 

The culinary diversity present at Reading Terminal Market is like no other in Philadelphia. If you love good food and cultural experiences you will love it here. 

Make sure you come with an appetite!

So Im def about to rain on everyone's parade here- but after the big hype regarding this place I was really looking forward to raving about it. First impression- hmm, interesting, cluttered, kinda dark and lots of randomness...which i expected from a market. 

Perhaps you have to take your time in a place like this...sampling, looking and observing. I wasn't in a rush and I wasn't taking my time, I strolled along the paths of the unknowns, passed a chocolate boutique that I found interesting and funny, picked up some fried macaroni and cheese from one southern vendor-good, but the pasta and cornbread-not. Sorry, dont remember the name of the place. 

My day in Philly was amazing to say the least, but i just wanted to more from this place. Eastern Market in DC still rules.

I was told to pay a visit here by my friend as I consider myself a bit of a foodie and this place definitely doesn't disappoint.  There are food choices up the wazoo and they all look good from your deli, to your Indian, to your Chinese, to your vegetarian options even.  There are fresh meat and seafood vendors there as well as a relatively large produce selection from two different vendors as well.  In summary, there is pretty much something for everyone here, whatever your craving or taste may be.

Personally, I was able to pay a visit on two separate days, & if I had a larger stomach, I probably would have tried more of the different food options available, but I was only able to sample Hershey's club sandwich and Bassets double scoop (strawberry & mango) in a waffle cone;  both were delicious.

All in all, I believe that Reading Terminal Market is a must stop for when you're in Philly, just because of the general ambiance as well as the selection of very very delicious looking food available.

I LOVE Reading Terminal Market, and we look forward to eating here just about every time we head to the city. But my experience there yesterday has jaded me, possibly forever. Tokyo Sushi was a NIGHTMARE that cost me $67 for a few pieces of the WORST sushi I have EVER tasted. DISGUSTING dumplings that the smirking beast behind the counter had the balls to take out of the microwave, splash with a packet of cheap soy and hand to my husband. I looked at them, smelled them, and threw the $10 pieces of crap in the trash. I want to give the market a 5 star review, but I can't until Tokyo Sushi is gone for good. I am mad, real mad. And real stupid for not Yelping it before I ate there...

I can't add much to what's already been reviewed, but RTM is one of my favorite places in Philly. If I had the time and energy I'd grocery shop here. There is everything from Thai to Cajun food, fresh produce, breads, cheeses, desserts, ice cream, coffee, smoothies, flowers, spices, cookbooks... the list goes on. Go and do not be disappointed.
This place is great! A must-see tourist destination. Great food inside like Dinic's and their pretzels were awesome!

I have been here twice now and every time I always find something different. Its located just outside of Chinatown in a pretty big building. The food selection was HUGE!
