We ate at some appetizers at Sang Kee duck house and liked it so much we went to the actual restaurant. All the food looked so amazing and there were so many variety that you can satisfy any cravings. They also had some really good ice cream, chocolates, sweets, candies, etc. It really does satisfy every cravings. Also, the vendors here are really nice and they have some really cool handmade things that you wouldn't get anywhere else. The veggie and fruit stands have food that were cheaper then the regular store prices. Too bad they dont have this in Washington DC or else i would go here everyday. 

If you are in philly and end up in Chinatown you should definitely stop here. You will find basically everything.

Holy Toledo! There are waaaaay too many food choices here. And when you're belly is grumbling it's hard to choose. There are plenty of tables where you can chill and eat. FYI, some of these restaurants do not accept credit cards. Have a stash of cash just in case. From what I saw:

-Seafood market
-Southern Jambalaya
-Sweets bakery
-Po Boys
-Sushi/Japanese
-Sandwiches
-Ice cream and fruit smoothies

And I'm sure there's more. I walked that thing twice over before I choose jambalaya and friend mac and cheese balls for my dinner. Prices are pretty average. you may be paying $10-$15/person depending on what you choose to eat and drink. 

This market is not the quietest or cleanest I've ever experienced but just having the selection made it enjoyable.

I spent 2 days in Philly for a seminar and made a visit to Reading Terminal Market both days :-D 

I just love the variety of shops you get in here. From spices, baked goods, raw produce and meats to snacks and hot meals! You can find it all inside this market. So far from all the food I've tried from breakfast to desserts it has all tasted above par or better!  

I know I will go back whenever I visit Philly and perhaps one day I'll have tried all the restaurants hahaha!!!

this place was just a wonderful eclectic moshpit of different foods from delis, soul food, chinese places, seafood, cajun, smoothies, icecream, and bakeries.  apparently its also has a lot of amish markets but unfortunately they weren't open on sundays.  it was fun venturing around and just seeing all the different food stands and the actual produce mingled in this shop.

i loved beck's cajun food stand!!!  i was interested in eating the multiple delis and chinese places and the cajun food looked so good in their displays.  My friends and I split the jambalaya, gumbo, alfredo pasta, and shrimp/crawfish pasta and it was just perfect from flavors to texture.  I'm starving for it now.....ahh i'd love to visit reading again when i trek back to philly sometime in the near future.

Dont go to this place hungry... you will walk in circles, soooo many choices! You are likely to over eat, but not like thats a bad thing. Pastrami sandwiches stacked to the ceiling! This place is the real deal for anything fresh! Recommended to all that visit Philadelphia

I found this place by accident! Thank you yelp app for leading me to this market. Probably one of the most interesting places to see in Philly. =)

I could have wandered around this place for hours, but I only had 45 minutes. There is seriously so many vendors selling different specialties and food, I felt like I had found my paradise. Sandwiches, chocolates, seafood, baked goods, smoothies and ice cream!

I happened to wander into a space selling used books too, and I perused the selections before I went off to buy a smoothie, a pork sandwich and a philly cheesesteak. There were so many things that caught  my eye. 

The space is large (I feel like I circled a few times and got lost) and there is a decent amount of seating inside to eat and people watch. I also saw a section that sold fruits and veggies. 

Will totally be back one day if I'm ever in town to sample and enjoy everything else they have here! I love variety!

As overly reviewed as it is i have to say that millers is one of my sole reasons for coming here! I am very much a fan of the market and the crowds it draws makes for great people watching ....

Come here on an empty stomach

Foodie heaven.  Really a four and a half, docking 1/2 star coz no alcohol to be found.  Seafood? Beef? Oysters? Froglegs? Pastries gourmet and homemade?  This place has it.  Glorious place.  If you wanna eat organic or vegitarian this place did not forget about you.  Map it out, make a plan coz this place is dizzying.
Many vendors! Many tastes! How can any foodie resist wandering this market for inspiration and gluttony? It speaks for itself. But MOST DEFINITELY stop here if you're in Philly.

A must if you are in Philly.You can spend the day just roaming around the market. You can find your traditional Philly steak sandwiches to Indian food. What ever you are craving you will find it here and for cheap. There is even a all philly veggie steak sandwich.

My faves at the Reading Terminal Market:
DiNic's (either the roast pork or beef with provolone, and sweat peppers)
I dont know the name of the place buts its the only one that sells roast chicken ( wings, leg quarters, or whole or half chickens)
The Dutch Corner of the Market...

The Dutch Corner closes earlier that the rest of the market. I believe close time is 5pm.

If you go to the Market right before it closes you can find good deals on pastries.

$.75 to $1.00 per cookie vs $10.00per pound (each cookie is pretty heavy)
2 for $3.00 pastries when they normally go for$3 plus.

The only restaurant  I didn't care for was the Cajun restaurant.

This was my favorite place in all of Philly! I'm so glad the concierge at my hotel recommended I stop by to grab something for lunch. There are tons of food counters with anything you can imagine to eat. The lines for the Thai food were really long so I wish I had time to try that... I had a cupcake from Flying Monkey Bakery and a Cheesesteak from Carmen's while I was there and bought some candy from the Amish. I spent a good hour wandering around and wishing I had a kitchen so I could get some of the fresh food and cook!

I am envious of the magnitude and grandeur of all this enclosed market has to offer! We came here for breakfast and nearly stayed for lunch. We sampled a refreshingly simple Amish run breakfast establishment, had steamed chai tea made in single batches, ran into the largest pumpkin on display that I have ever seen, and left our hearts with the uncut, uncured bacon.

The Reading Terminal Market in Philly is pretty amazing.  This place has just about everything...

We visited the following places of note:
1) Tommy DiNic's for some Roast Pork Sandwiches
2) Salumeria to get some Capicola and Mandaroni Provolone Cheese
3) Chocolate by Mueller for some delicious chocolate
4) Old City Coffee for some Kona Coffee

*YUM!*

I love RTM - so many options! Spices, prepared food, produce, meats, gift items. So great! Definitely gets super crowded around lunchtime and on the weekends, so I wouldn't recommend coming with a baby stroller or food cart. But it's fantastic!

This place is straight up amazing and a must if you are visiting Philly. When we visited, the place was packed! Plus, I ate more food than I thought was possible.

Reading Terminal Market has some of the best food vendors, everything was amazing. We even enjoyed some fresh oysters on the half shell- Nom!

If you stop by, you won't go wrong!
The dark chocolate covered pretzels are good and the Amish pickles can't be beat.  Great place to spend a few hours looking and trying food.

Fantastic experience!  I think I visited the Terminal Market every day I was at the Pennsylvania Convention Center (which is adjacent). There are a wide variety of food purveyors and great people watching. 

The only drawback was that several of the shops, particularly those with Amish operators, kept odd hours.

I always saw this place on the travel channel and dreamed of going. I wish I lived in Philly mainly for this freaking market. I wish they had markets this great in LA (if they do PLEASE let me know)

Pros:
-SO MANY EATERIES. You could come here everyday for a month straight and try something new.
-Every place has decent pricing.
-The workers are all friendly

Cons:
-I guess the only thing I can point out is paying for parking. But it's only $4 if you park across the street and get it validated.

I love this place, and it's a definite go to if you visit Philly.

The second I walked in, I knew I would love it.
My family and I went for lunch, and we each ordered something from a different vendor.

My brother got the grilled pork sandwich from DiNic's. The meat was moist and the roasted peppers, definitely made the sandwich even more delicious.

My mom got sausage with homemade saurkraut along with cornbread from Frank's a lot. Good portions.

My cousin got a caramel and apple crepe, which was actually really good, because I expected a mushy apple (like the ones in apple pies), but it was sweet and had a bit of a crunch to it, which was a pleasant surprise!

I got the philly cheesesteak from Spataro's with mushrooms and peppers. It was okay (I personally think the steaks from Pat's or Geno's is better). And I also got coffee from Old City Coffee, strong, but good.

We also went there for lunch the second day and it was just as yummy.
love going to Reading Terminal Market! great food! great shopping! perfect for foodies :)

It's a shame that me and my coworker stopped by this place on our last day in Philly. There were sooo many food options to choose from. Before stopping and eating at the first place that entices you, walk the entire terminal to make your final decision. The terminal is definitely a must.

Great place to people watch, shop for foodstuffs, and eat delicious sandwiches or pastries!

My favorite eatery I've tried in the Reading Terminal Market is Hershel's, though I wouldn't push Dinic's out of bed, either. It really looks like you can't go wrong no matter where you eat, and I love the amazing selection of different (and fairly inexpensive) cuisines.

If you live locally, this seems like a fantastic place to pick up fresh fish, meat, or produce for very reasonable prices. I can't comment on the actual quality of these items but it sure is an eye-feast. And the fish counters all smelled clean as can be.

Why only four stars? The Market is dizzyingly crowded on the weekends, and there isn't nearly enough seating to accommodate the ravenous mobs looking to gobble their purchases. It was so crowded I actually felt anxious and uncomfortable. I much preferred my weekday visits.

I'll admit it, Reading Terminal Market makes me feel a little jealous of Philadelphians. I'll be back on my next visit.

This place is a MUST VISIT in Philly!!  In town for two days but would visit daily if i lived locally.  An eatery for every taste, fresh fruits and vegetables for every chef (and experimental chef) and there are cookies. Lots and lots of cookies and pastries and things covered in chocolate ALL OVER THE PLACE.  Not to mention fried things. Lots of fried things.

I'm from NY - so I may be hard to impress when it comes to deli goods.  The corned beef Reuben at Hershel's was AMAZING!!! For 10 bucks - it was well worth it.  Piled high and the corned beef was tender and fell apart like butter when I bit into this perfect sandwich.  The potato salad at .93 was a perfect accompany to this heavenly experience. Grandma's Sunday special was also corned beef - so the bar is high - you do the math.

Oh..the next day we had sushi from the place next door.  Tokyo Sushi Bar. Philadelphia roll and egg rolls.  Fish was fresh but roll was average and egg roll was sopped in oil .   It  seemed kind of overpriced for what we received but the chef was friendly and appreciated our business. 

Famous 4th Street cookies were closing down, so we purchased a few cookies for a dollar a pop.  The sugar cookies were heavenly but my date ate the rest and didn't share feedback..so get your own and you be the judge...

But what is with DiNic's not being manned but seemingly open on the first day, and messy and one loud non-eating patron sitting at the bar stool on the second day? I know they are working on the new location (across from Hershels) but I was really looking forward to their pork sandwich. The lack of interest by employees (who were non-existent or leaning on something) was a complete turn-off. Good luck with that!

Can't wait to go back with a cooler packed in ice ready for goat cheese and pepper sausages from Martin's!

Love this place.  This is like a mega food court, except better!  The parking does suck, you have to find street parking, otherwise the parking structure is like 6 bucks for half an hour or something ridiculous like that.  When you first walk in, you're overwhelmed where you start, then you just kind of get into a groove or a method.  The only that sucks is that since I probably won't ever be back or at least for years, I wanted to try everything, but I had already had lunch.  So I settled for a cookie and tea.  That would have to do.  I wish there was something like this in LA!

Lots of choices...just wish the seating area was cleaner, less congested and better maintained. Quality...not as high ranking as quantity. But it surely has its place when eating out with a  bunch of people with strong and different tastes. 
Oh and people who work there could try and look happier?!?

As far as food goes.  5 stars just doesn't say enough.

Everything you could possibly want to taste.

I come from Chicago, and only wish there was something here that matches the quality of food at the RTM.  

Yes we have a market too but for real, this one is KING.  

*I had Dinic's but I seriously struggled with all of those choices

Try to go when it is NOT crowded, like a Tuesday at 2:30 for example.

If you haven't visited the Reading Terminal Market, your trip to Philadelphia is not complete. Food for every taste from cheese steaks to corned beef sandwiches worthy of a good NYC deli. Famous Chocolate Chip cookies! Bassets ice cream! Fresh fish, produce, meat, veggies, etc.

I went here on a weekend. The place was slammed, but the selection was lovely. At first it looked like an Amish market, but there were other things that set it apart. It wasn't a strictly Amish market type of place. I noticed Chinese and Middle Eastern offerings as well. The line for the ladies room was ridiculously long and the crowd at the market acts like they just sucked on a bag on rotten lemons, but I digress....the food made all of the hassle worth it.

I feel like this place sums up the Philly food scene pretty well, for me at least.

Due to the fact that I made the trek to Philly, I made sure that I was going to stuff my tummy to new levels of discomfort. I started at Dinic's. The line was long, but went by pretty quick. I settled for a pork sandwich with provolone and broccoli rabe. It was pretty decent, I wouldn't cry to the sky over it, but I liked it. It set me back a little over $9...not the cheapest fast eat sandwich.

There is something about pretzels and Philly that really makes for a happy combo. I picked up a pretzel on my way out of the market...I'll review the pretzel place on its own....along with the Flying Monkey bakery.

Those three spots are some favorites in the market. I could stay there all day and stuff my fact with yummies.

This place is fantastic! So many places to eat and pick up some great take home food. My first stop was at Delilajahs Southern Cooking for some Mac and Cheese. It was good...but not as good as OK Cafe in Atlanta. And I paid $5 for a small taste, which was shocking. My next visit was to Carmes Philly Cheese Steak....awesome cheese steak. I also went to Dinic's....fantastic Italian Beef sandwich. I also picked up some cake and cannoli's from Termini. Fantastic Bakery!! Picked up some cookies from 4th street.

If you are going to Philly, DON'T SKIP THIS! Try the Philly cheesecake, whoa! They have different eateries, diff cuisines, seafoods, fresh veggies, oysters.... muah muah muah, my eyes are getting full just walking around1... cookies, coffee....

Went here on a gorgeous almost Spring-like Monday with my boyfriend at around 2pm... we came hungry as previous Yelp-ers had suggested... :D

We parked at the garage across the street (get parking validated by any merchant with $10 purchase and pay only $4 for up to 2 hours!!!) which was SO convenient. Outside the market there was some emsemble playing music which was cool.

Inside I was immediately in LOVE with all the choices set out before me... Lots of little restaurants and shops. Some have their own counter and stools right in front, but there's also a small cafeteria-like set up in the middle of RTM with a bunch of tables and chairs (this is where we ended up eating... although I was a little displeased with the cleanliness of the tables, eating area, etc bc it wasn't really too crowded but I shrugged it off...)

After wandering around taking everything in... we decided on the Little Thai Market (Red Curry Salmon & Basil Chicken $6 each) everything was great although next time I would ask if they could make it spicy. I got an orange, mango, pineapple smoothie and a piece of baklava ($4 and some change) from a middle eastern shop (can't remember the name-dang it). The baklava was so good we went back for 2 more pieces before we left! 

This place was a great way to spend a few hours getting lost in some great food-Can't wait to go back and try some more places out!!

This was probably the best indoor market I have seen in the US. There is just so  much going on that you just want to try everything. It is local vendor heaven. You have to bring cash it is so much easier and an empty.  It is also really crowd but that make it fun to see what people are in line for and what might be worth the wait.

What a fun place filled with people and great food smells. My friend and I walked nearly all of it and while we didn't dine here, it was such a fun place. There is something for everyone and all ages. Meats, seafood, cheese steaks, ice cream and cookies.
Tourists and locals are welcomed here. I liked the live music too.

I got lost in this place... but didn't care because in every direction I went in I was surrounded by the freshest and most delcious smelling foods whether it was Chinese, Italian, Thai, Fried Chicken, Seafood, Wine.... you name it, it was there!  Think Eataly just 50x the size with a diversity of cusine.  Truly a mall of food!  If ever in Philly, check it out.

If I worked close by, I would be here everyday for lunch. They have everything in this market and plenty of delicious food! Having a lot of options can be a bad thing, but better than not having enough options, right?!

It definitely gets crowded, but rightly so. I mean people congregate to where there's good food...that's a given! If you love good food and people watching, you'll love the market!
I love this place!  Whatever your palate desires, you can find it here.  Even fresh produce.

This place is fantastic! While the various meat counters are pretty gross and off-putting, I was very happy to see so many fresh produce vendors, many of which were specializing in locally-grown and organic produce. I really enjoyed the pianist in the center area and listened to him play while I ate, which was a real treat.

There's only 1 all-veg restaurant, but most restaurants offer at least one or two veg options, so when you combine all the options together, it's a sizeable vegetarian menu. I was particularly impressed that one cheesesteak place had a big photo sign advertising their "100% vegan cheesesteaks", which appeared to be the only vegan item on the menu aside from the fries. Unfortunately, they don't have vegan cheese....yet!

The Chinese places had various fried rice and noodle dishes and the sushi place had several vegan sushi options. While I wasn't particularly impressed with Basic 4, it's nice to have an all-veg restaurant there.

The sign over the door reads "Reading Terminal Market".  However, as one perpetually fighting my waistline, it should read "Abandon hope, all ye who enter here".

Countless food vendors, all offering unique meals.  Roast pork, corned beef specials, kabobs, chicken, sausage...you name it, its all here.  I devoured a number of these infernal temptations and faced spiritual struggle as I realized that something so bad could be...so good.  There are also a number of dessert and pastry vendors, including the ninth level of the abyss, Termini Brothers.

You probably won't have Virgil with you on your descent into dieting hell, but once out there is salvation to be had in the Purgatorio of the gym.

My first stop in Philly after dropping off my bags at the airbnb location I was staying at.

The Reading Terminal is an amazing place jam-packed with all sorts of delicious food stands, ranging from sandwich places to indian cuisine and pastries/icecream. Definitely a great place to spend a couple hours sharing different food with friends.

I stopped at a couple different locations which will have reviews to follow: Tommy Dinic's (Roast Pork Sandwich), Rib Stand (Boneless Rib Sandwich), Bassett's (Icecream).

There is also a nice selection of produce,meats,and seafood. With the seafood selection being the best of the batch. I saw some shrimp that were easily larger than the size of my hands!!

The Reading Terminal is definitely a spot you must check out for both the wide variety of food as well as the experience!

I finally came here for the first time with my boyfriend the other day. I've heard so much about this place, so we were excited to check it out. We got a parking spot right outside of one of the entrances, so we paid $2 for an hour. I saw that you can also get your parking ticket from one of the garages validated to $4 for two hours, if you can't find street parking. It was a Monday afternoon, so it wasn't too busy. An hour was enough for us to roam around the market, get Tommy Dinic's, Hope's Cookies, and some fruit and produce to take home. The market is pretty much like any other market you would go to. You have your various seafood places, some Italian pasta spots, sandwich places, desserts, a few jam/sauce places, and fruit/produce. There is also a couple Asian food spots in there, including Sang Kee's (from Chinatown & UCity), which I found surprising. That's smart of them to have a spot in this popular American market. Reading Terminal is nice, but nothing really special compared to other markets I've been to around the world. I guess it gets all the good reviews because this is pretty much the only big market in Philly.

Had a hoagie that was meh, had a gyro that was very good, had a coffee that was good, it was dry, warm and had everything.....placed directly next to the large Marriott convention center, this place has it all, the crowd, the energy, the food, the bums, the noise, and the essence of Philly boiled down for quick consumption......I loved it!!

I didn't know the Reading Terminal Market was full of fresh produce, restaurants, and local homemade gifts. It was nice walking through seeing different kinds of options they had. The local seafood stands had Stone Crab!!
They also have a beautiful toy train set in the middle of the facility!
One star off for tourist trap. Nice to explore once though!

For foodie tourists (like me) a stroll through Reading Terminal Market is basically baptism by fire. In other words, food porn to the max. Everything you could possibly crave in one (huge) place. I left, silent and stunned, with blood oranges, a block of chocolate shaped like a cheesesteak, herbs, spices, Amish goods, honey, looseleaf tea, I don't even know what else. The sheer number of food vendors, markets, specialty goods-- absolutely blew me away. 

Next time I'm going to be first in line at DiNic's for a pork sandwich. And if anyone beats me to it, I'll trample them.

There are places where you get exactly what you see, and others where the overall experience is better than the sum of its individual parts. Without having actually eaten a meal here, the food/restaurants didn't seem better than a well-selected restaurant outside, but the collective community of restaurants, meat/fish markets, produce markets, bakeries, and miscellaneous stores certainly made me wish I was hungry.

It's a delightful and spacious market that's worth a visit even if you're not looking for something to eat. We ended up with just a single eclair and a bag of apples, more as souvenirs than for actual food value. 

A great change of pace and atmosphere after touring the historical sites of Philly.

Everything looks nice....in a nice location.....food is subpar.  To sum it up?  A nice tourist trap.

This place has tons and tons of different types of restaurants inside (Indian, Middle Eastern, Philly Cheesesteak, gelato, etc).

If you sample anything from here your illusion will disappear...and you'll walk out wondering why you bothered coming.

4.25* for the visual aspects and entertainment.
2* for the food.

Had the Pad Thai with chicken from the Thai food place.  Was pretty good.  Note that the Reading Terminal Market tends to close a little early (about 6pm).

The Reading Terminal Market has a great selection of food and is in a great location relative to many convention area hotels.  The hard part is to figure out which type of food you want out of all the choices!

Oh, why can't this market be in NYC too?

It's all around wonderful.  For produce you have to look around a bit for the best prices.  

The number of food vendors was actually a bit overwhelming at first.  If you're a foodie, plan to spend a while here.  
A bit too overwhelming in my tired mind to detail much but highly rate it as a MUST GO!

A quintessential Philly landmark. Although perpetually busy and overrun with tourists, this is still a place you must experience, especially if you're not from the area. This cavernous space is packed with produce, provisions, and prepared foods from all over the globe... theres literally something for everyone. I would try to avoid the lunch rush and weekends if possible, especially Saturday mornings, only because it can be nearly impossible to move around or get a seat. I would also not recommend coming here for a cheesesteak - much better can be had elsewhere. Parking can be insane - $6 for 30 min "special" in the attached garage. TRUST ME, it will take more than 30 min to do anything there.

Oh Reading Terminal Market! I love you for what you have to offer. I  hate you for what you do to my diet. You have so many vendors, most of whom serve exquisite food. It is so hard to decide exactly what to eat. I wish I could spend a day sampling the fare. Alas, my stomach is only so large. Though last night I did find a place that was only mediocre, I still love you the same. Don't ever change!

This alone (albeit there are many other reasons), is a great reason to live in the Greater Philadelphia area.  A 'foodie' wonderland!

...to be continued...

This is a must-do for visiting Philly. This is a one stop shop for fresh fruit & vegetables, fresh baked breads, meats and fish, coffee, locally grown/raised foods, unique and specialty foods, flowers --you name it. There are also a couple of restaurants as well as tables to eat your "to-go" sandwiches and other treats. Since it is entirely indoors, it is great for a cold day and my son loves running up and down the aisles. We always find some new exotic food item to try. It is also really easy to get here by train ;-) If you drive, the garage is is $4 for 2 hours if you spend $10 or more in the market and get your ticket validated.

Oh goodness, where do I start?

You won't find anything like this. Not in New York, Boston, or anywhere else for that matter. Every venue has something special to offer. No two are alike. 

I forget the name, but you have to try the ice cream. I think I saw on the Travel Channel that the place is the only venue that still exists from the start of the market yearssss ago.

Reading Terminal Market MIGHT, just might, be as good as it gets. 

On a recent trip to Philadelphia I walked in and spent a good two hours walking around. I had to get a refreshment. The sheer variety of everything--bakeries, flowers, fresh meat, seafood, restaurants, Pennsylvania Dutch merchants, coffee shops, dry goods, groceries, etc etc etc--is pretty mind-blowing. 

I ate at Tommy DiNic's (delicious). I got a slice of marbled cheesecake from Termini Brothers Bakery. I sampled some delicious cheese. There was a delightful old woman playing piano in the center of all the hustle, and I bought a hand-knitted hat from Anastasia, who was from Siberia. Hershels East Side Deli, I'll be back for you. 

If you're a tourist in Philadelphia and especially if you're a foodie tourist in Philadelphia, Reading Terminal Market is a must-visit. Come hungry!
The pastrami sandwich I had from the deli here was better than the ones at the Carnegie Deli and Katz's in New York.  That means it was plenty good.
An absolute must-do when you're in Philly. Only challenge is where to eat because everything looks and smells so good.

So yes I was here, January 11th, last week and once I did my thing walking around seeing the Liberty Bell Center and all.  I walked through the chinatown area and made it here to the Terminal Market.  I had not been to Philly for a while so it was nice to finally check this place out.  I did like walking around seeing all these nice food options here.  I got here initially early but was not ready to eat too heavy.  It was my mistake, was not sure when DiNic's or the Reading Terminal Market would close in general but I missed my chance to eat the famous Roast Pork sandwich that I saw on Man Vs Food!!!!

I did eat at the Ice cream place, I was told to check that out and it was worth it (so good).
-Philly I will be back, I need to eat that Roast Pork sandwich.  So now I have something to look forward to in a future visit.

P.S. the Bathrooms looked pretty sad here.  I used it of course because I just had to go but this reminded me of some kind of grade school mishap in the bathroom, where some little kid left shit everywhere on the floor included, well every where except in the toilet.  There was plenty of space to walk around the problem areas and just get to the sink to wash your hands or whatever.

Came back here for the ribs from downhome diner and it was insanely yummy! 

The wait was not too bad, even on a Sunday, the terminal was packed.  A lot of the diner patrons were sit-ins.  I ordered a rack of ribs.
http://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?userid=-Cw2rJx6v8gHgWOBXL3SsA

I also went to Dinic's to try another type of sandwich besides their famous pork sandwich.  I tried the pulled-pork and beef.  It was alright.  Their famous sandwich was more tastier with the brocolli rabe.  But man, the line was around the corner!!  It took like 1/2 hour to order the food.

In any case, the Reading Terminal is one of my fave places to visit while out in Philly.  It is vibrant and sooo much fun!  Love all the shops!

If a giant space filled with food can make a foodie have eating anxiety, this place is unbelievable.  My brother toured us around to his favorite spots, and I noted a trip to Bassett's at the end was required, regardless of the 20 degree snowy weather outside.

He pointed out some of his favorite spots, and then Eric R. grabbed a table and sent us off to eat.  I wandered and wandered and could not figure out what I wanted, though I noted a seafood vendor had soft shell crab sandwiches.  I swapped with Eric and he went off to get something while I held the table.  My brother came back with a sandwich from Salumeria and Eric R. returned with schwarma.  Then I went around again and found a Tea shop and got jasmine iced tea, but waiting in line at a few places I got shoved around and remembered why I don't live in the East Coast.

I sat down again and by then, the guys were almost done eating.  They insisted I try to find something and I set off again.  I decided my brother's sandwich had looked pretty good so I finally went to the Salumeria and got a small (but it is really huge!) turkey with the works.  It was pretty darn amazing.  We did end up at Bassett's for ice cream and then set off into the cold.  This place is wild.

My family and I go to Reading Terminal Market just about every week. Sure it's about 50 miles away from where we live, but it's that good! The Market is the absolute must-go-to destination for foodies in town and there is a never-ending array of things to try. Do make sure you visit the Market between Wednesday and Friday when the Amish merchants are there, and if you're going on a Saturday, try to get there early, especially if there is a big convention across the street like the Auto Show or the Flower Show because it does tend to get crowded. And don't show up at 4 PM because a lot of merchants will be shutting down soon and may be out of what you want. 

My favorites at the Market include the pancakes at the Dutch Eating Place, the roast pork sandwich with greens and provolone at DiNic's, peanut butter chocolate covered pretzels at Mueller's, soft pretzels at Miller's Twist, cinnamon buns, fritters, and muffins from Beiler's, and peanut butter or mint chocolate chip ice cream from Bassett's. And a big-assed turkey leg from the Original Turkey during the festivals that RTM has.

I really like this place.  Want ice cream? check.  Want gumbo? check.  How about a vegetarian cheesesteak sandwich? check!  The Reading is a great place to take out-of-town guests, but it's also fun for townies to come for lunch or just to ppl watch.  When I'm in a rush for an ingredient, I'll sometimes stop in here at the spice market for it.  There's also an international food store - sure, they're a little pricier than Whole Foods, but hey - when ur in the midst of awaiting your dough to rise, sometimes you just don't have time to drive to the supermarket.

Some of my favorite places are: the Amish bakery on the NW corner of the market.  They make really good Raisin Bread (you can also watch them making cinnamon rolls), Iovine Brothers Produce (students get a 10% discount on Wed and Sun), OK Lee Produce (students get 10% discount everyday), the Basic Vegetarian (again, vegetarian cheesesteak), Beck's Cajun Cafe (beignets on Wed, also have really good gumbo and jambalaya), and Dinic's (the line is always around the corner for their sandwiches).

Some places take cash only, so it's better if you come with some.  If not, there are ATMs throughout the market.  

Besides food, there are stands that sell jewelry, cookbooks, kitchenwares, candles, lotions, souvenirs - just come check it out if you haven't already - there's usually something for everyone.

Reading Terminal is in an former Train Terminal - with gorgeous architecture not to mention some of the best local fare Philly has to offer. 12th street cantina mole burritos and homemade guacamole are a favorite, as are the myriad of spice, chocolate, amish and other stores.

Reading Terminal Market is one of the great places to go in Philadelphia.  It's vibrant, energetic and a sensory overload - in a good way.  You have many choices of places to eat and to shop for fresh meats, fish, deli items and odds-n-ends you don't find in many places.
To get the best feel of what Philly has to offer, this place is a winner for sure!!

What a cool place!! Tons to see and to try, but it gets very crowded and it is hard to navigate your way around (almost the reason why I was going to give it 4 stars.)

A good place to go to get food for a party or a present for the hostess of a party.  You can come here every day for months and you'll probably never taste everything you can.  

A must for locals and tourists alike.

Overall, this is an amazing place with so much to see and try.

The #1 downside is that it gets extremely crowded...crowded to the point that you won't be able to walk or even move. 

Many people come here for their lunch break, so if you are stopping in for lunch, be prepared to wait in line for a LONG TIME.

It's nearly impossible to find a seat, so be prepared to eat standing up.

The variety of shops/eateries is amazing. Every kind of food you could crave. Definitely worth stopping in the next time you are in Philly!

Great assortment of markets, breakfast/lunch/dinner/treat spots, and other various stores. Where else can you get soul food, crepes, cheesesteaks, ice cream, chinese, seafood, and pumplecake (pies baked into a two layer cake - visit the Flying Monkey)? Almost every type of food you can think of is here, which makes it great for groups, tourists, and out of town friends. What doesn't make it group friendly is how crowded it can get during peak times. Seating is limited, and much of it is reserved for patrons of a particular shop. They do put some tables outside when it's warm, so try to snag one of those and escape the craziness.

Some things are overpriced, but some of ridiculously cheap. You just have to know where to go. Iovine Bros produce is one of the cheaper ones, with most of it's offering hovering around $1/lb. If you're looking for a deal, come right before closing when the vendors are packing up. Places like Famous 4th St cookies offer 'dollar holler" where all cookies are $1 towards the end of the day.

It might be easier to ponder what the Reading Terminal Market is missing rather than highlighting the many, many great things about it.

1) Does it lack a great selection of vendors... no, it certainly has that covered
2) So are they all just crap... no, not only is there quantity but quality as well
3) Does it smell like, eh, Philly... nope, the fresh smells of deliciousness is a pleasant change from the streets of Fhiladelphia.
4) Well then how about celebrates, there is no way it has those... does Adam Richman (Man vs. Food) count? He marked his second trip there today!
5) Ok well, does it have a coat check...

Damn, I managed to find something the Reading Terminal is missing, coat check!  

So unless coat check is a deal breaker, I recommend you manage to carve out some time to check out the market.  Bring a date and explore or just go on an empty stomach...

This was one of my favorite places in Philadelphia.  As a local, it was a great place to come and get fresh produce, cheese, and meat in the mornings before the crowds arrive.  There are all kinds of places to get a quick meal, but my favorite for breakfast is the Dutch Eating Place.  They always have wonderful pancakes and sausage and you can get a homemade apple dumpling to take home for later.  If you are a fan of people watching, you can certainly see a lot here between the locals, the tourists, and the people in town for a convention.  Finish off your visit with homemade ice cream in a pretzel cone and you have a perfect day!

Now that I've moved to New York, I still haven't found any place that quite replaces Reading Terminal Market.

Reading Terminal Market is a dream come true for me (and was a nightmare for my wife). 

I like options, and RTM had plenty. I like places that specialize in things. RTM had places that specialized in chocolates, ice cream, wine, pickles, and jerky. I like unhealthy food. RTM had virtually anything you can think of.

My wife doesn't like crowds. RTM has them. My wife doesn't like cramped quarters. RTM is as cramped as can be. My wife didn't like the giant cockroach she saw scurrying on the floor at one of the produce vendors.

Well, I guess you can't fault her for that.

Not much else to say besides beware of crowds and move deftly.  Don't wander around looking at everything or else you'll piss the rest of us off who are trying to get some crawfish etoufee as fast as possible.  DiNic's just remodeled and are still the kings of hot sangwiches in the market, as far as I'm concerned.  Basset's is the best Ice Cream in creation, and I've never seen a straight up Bassets bar like that anywhere else.  Many Saturdays they'll have live music in the center, which can range in genre, but is always awesome.

Endless options! There's so much to choose from, yet the two times I've been there for lunch to eat, I went to the same place, Profi's Creperie. It was pretty good! I also got Mocha Chip ice cream from Bassetts Ice Cream. They give you generous portions. In fact, after all that ice cream, I kind of wished they had given me less. I had originally been scoping out a fruit tart, but there wasn't a single one in sight. That was a letdown. My cousin also tried clam chowder from Pearl's Oyster Bar. That was a disappointment, too. Nevertheless, I'll be back!

Have it a 4, for diversity of products available there ranging from chocolates, coffees, sit in food court, Veggie, fruit, meat, etc sold here! I did avoid the crowds by being there for breakfast at 8ish in a Sunday morning as it was a nearby breakfast place. Def worth worth checking out.

This is a great spot for lunch in Philly.  The hustle and bustle of the market is energizing and there are countless food options, some better than others.  I live in DC, and this is like a bigger version of Eastern Market.  Some places are specialty shops that look like they've been there for years because they turn out a high quality product.  Other vendors look no better than a typical mall food court operator, so pick your lunch spot carefully.  Still, it's a cool experience.

Two words: over stimulation (but in a good way)

Reading Terminal Market is a farmers market and specialty market with ready to order food places/restaurants, and coffee places. Did I miss something? I probably did, just b/c there's so many things happening in this market. You'll love this place if you like options and can handle crowds. As for me, I give this place a 4 star despite being over stimulated and unsure of what to eat, drink, or buy. I think this is definitely one of those places that you have to visit when you are in Philly. It reminds me of those open markets in Asia... or like Eastern Market in DC, but definitely way more packed with people and food.

Great! A wonderful selections of meats, produce, cheeses, seafood and just about everything in between. Sure it's touristy but what a place if you're a local. So much great foods under one roof with relatively reasonable prices. I'm game.

This is my second favorite place in all of Philly. It's the second place I take anyone that has never been down here before and it never fails to disappoint. The beauty of this place is the selection that it contains. No matter what your searching for, your gonna find it when it comes to food. All that diversity in one area is so convenient and stupendous. My favorites gotta be miller's twist, dinic's, carmen's and the ice cream place.
If you are in Philadelphia, stopping here is a must! Cheeses, meats, and baked goods as far as the eye can see..

Stopped in here during a day trip to Philly.  I only wish I had picked up some homemade fudge during this stop!

First off, I stopped at Spartan's for a yup, Philly Cheesesteak with the Whiz & fried onions.  OMG!  Soooooo damn goood!!!!!!  Wish I could have eaten another one or at least....bring one home!

Walked around & saw tons wonderful things.

Ended up stopping at Tea Leaf for a wonderful cuppa Bourbon Vanilla tea.  Made to perfection by the wonderful lady who greeted us.  And I treated myself to a mug with a strainer here.  

Before leaving, we stopped at Bassett's for ice cream.
I scream
You scream
We all scream 
for ice cream!!!

I can highly recommend the Butterscotch Vanilla.  Yummy!!!

I wish I had a place like this here in NY.  It was a great market!  Lots going on.  Definitely very crowded, but everyone was really nice.  I got bumped several times & people apologized.  Wow!  Definitely not NY!

The original and supposedly the oldest market that sells fresh meat and vegetable on one side and on-the-spot cooked ethnic cuisines and delicious sweets the other side. Mario Batali and Todd English, come and see how a real market is run so you can take some back to your fancy copycats in New York!

As a life long Philadelphian and a former Saturday employee at the Market I have to say there is no other place like it in the city. From Shopping to noshing all of your needs can be met.  Yes it get crowded especially on the weekends but its always fun. When I worked here it was breakfast from the Amish, lunch at Dinic's and shopping for my meats, seafood and fresh fruits and vegetables. Most of my pay was funneled directly back to the merchants but we ate well all week. You never know who you will run into here as well. From politicians to former players, it's a great place for people watching.

What do you say about an amazing place that already has over 600 reviews?  I know; put the ten (10) most important things you need to know all in one place.  So, especially if you are a 1st timer, read on.

1. Be prepared to embrace the crowds.  It's part of the Reading Terminal experience.  Think about it.  All those folks are there because the place is so amazing!

2. Don't visit on Sunday, Monday, or Tuesday.  Why you ask?  There are over a dozen Pennsylvania Dutch (Amish) vendors that are definitely worth visiting.  They have special hours and don't open on these days.  It would be a mistake not to see them.

3. If you want the very best deals make sure you end your visit during the last hour of each day.  That would be between 5:00 and 6:00 PM Monday -Saturday and 4:00 to 5:00 PM on Sunday.

4. If you are a foodie be prepared to be overwhelmed, stunned, amazed, and generally blown away.  You won't be able to do it justice in two (2) hours.  Think three (3) or more.

5. Speaking of two (2) hours, it will cost you $4 for that amount of time at the 12th & Filbert garage.  All you need to do is spend $10 and any vendor will validate your ticket.  Even better is to not park at all and take public transportation.  

6. Check the website for cool events especially to see the live music schedule.  http://www.readingterminalmarket.org/events/

7. Some folks say the place is touristy and they are partially correct.  That's true of some of the vendors but anyone with half a brain can spot them in a second.  If that's not your thing just walk on by.

8. If you want to stay in the market and have an adult libation, check out Molly Malloy's.  It's a great place for a beer.

9. If you are thinking about lunch at prime time (11:30-1:00), please think again.  And then think again and again.  Trust me; it's complete and utter craziness.  Eat early or eat late.

10. Last but not least let's talk Tommy DiNic's as this legendary emporium deserves special mention.  I know, I know, you saw Man vs. Food and you want "The Sandwich."  Is it worth it?  Yeah, it is.  Stroll the market and stop back occasionally to check on the length of the line.  If you see it below twenty five (25) folks, go for it.  It really is an amazing sandwich.

As just about everyone says this place is a must for a Philly visitor.

Just about any food, grocery, ice cream  item you can think of and this place has it. Packed with people but thats the fun part. I've had creole, ice cream, greek, philly cheese steaks, and sushi in here. all are bomb!

Very eclectic selection of food and crafts.  Got to try Shoo fly pie but it's the Miller's Twist Pretzels that I'm still dreaming about!  Picked up some unique crafts too, e.g., a pen set that had a fork, spoon and knife attached as tops so you can eat and work at the same time, LOL.

Oh my GOSH!!!  THis city and it's market's are amazing!!  Puts the French Market in Chicago to shame, same with the Milwaukee Public.  This place is off the charts....I was stressed out at how much I could stuff in just being in Philly for the weekend.  Skip the cheese steak rivals and come here, food is amazing!  Had the pork at        Di nicks and the oyster po boy at the Cajan place, both were off the charts good!!!
P.s-it is open on Sunday but soooo many vendors are closed.  :(

ANother place I like to stop in when I'm in Philly :). Love buying the Beef Jerky its amazing! The Teriyaki and Spicy are so yummy! Beware though the spicy is really hot! I also by the homade Pepper Jam! Sooooooo gooood!! LOVE THIS PLACE

You can find whatever food you want in the freshest quality in huge portions with reasonable prices. lunch, early dinner, breakfast, brunch, dessert, bread, coffee, groceries, meat, etc etc. I LOVE this palce and I think everyone has to visit at least once. Everytime I have a visitor come over, Reading is a MUST TO GO place on my list for them. and I 've never disappointed anyone. GOOOOOO check it out!
SOme of my favorites are: Pastramis sandwich from Hershels, Beiler's bakery's bagels, Old City cafe, Termini Borther's pecan bar, Iovine Brothers Produce, Deliah's fried chicken and cabbage.

Reading Terminal Market is very uniquely Philadelphia.

A market 97% entirely devoted to food from Amish pretzels, sweets, cheese steaks, ice cream, chocolates, fresh produce to Thai, Indian, huge jumbo shrimp, etc.  The size is huge as one needs a huge stomach to intake all the food with all reasonable prices.  The aromatic smell and flavor will entice patrons for a food crawl and continuous grub for more.

Imagine one of the best food courts you've ever been to and you got the Reading Terminal. We came here in search of a sandwich we saw on the Food Network and tried not to get carried away with all of the mouth watering foods. 

I saw some of the biggest prawns I've ever seen, great looking "salads and sides" had some amazing desserts and of course we ate the sandwich we were looking for (review to come). We also stopped at Molly Malone's for a pint with our sandwich. 

My question is if you had the opportunity to come here every day, what would you choose? It all looks fantastic. 

The one thing we really missed out on was the Pennsylvania Dutch (Amish) vendors since we came here on a Monday and they were closed. We even tried back on Tuesday to no avail, so if you are headed to Reading - make sure to come Wednesday thru Saturday to make sure you get to try it all.

fun+food=great mix!
you can really choose any type of cuisine and enjoy in a casual atmosphere
nice to bring any visitors first time in philly and eat ur heart out!
also they have a nice some market for fruits and veggies at the corner that are not overpriced.
DO NOT GO HERE FOR THE CHEESESTEAKS unless you want to pay over $10 for a 4" roll. If you don't believe me, check it out for yourself. The amish section is as good as any you will ever visit.
This was my first time here and I was impressed.  There are sooo many different eateries and little shops.  This reminds me of the farmer's market at the Grove in Los Angeles.

From organic meats and fruits and vegetables, to chocolate, to gyros, to roasted duck, to pizza, to ice cream, to fresh fish and seafood, to homemade bakery awesomeness, the Reading Terminal Market is a one-stop shopping food mega mart.  They also have flowers, cooking utensils, handmade soaps, cookbooks, and other stuff in this huge facility.

If there is a large convention next door at the Convention Center, be prepared for huge crowds inside, but it is worth the effort to get through the throngs to whatever you're looking for.  The Amish are not there Sunday through Tuesday, and they are a big part of the Market.

Simply just one of the best places to go in any city anywhere.  Delis, restaurants, book stores, ice cream, bakeries, butchers, fish  monger, sandwich shops, diners, produce, Amish merchants; all in one place...and all of them great.  Whatever you need, you will find.  The worst part of the Terminal is that there are too many choices and great options.

This place was my favorite thing about Philadelphia. It had so much GREAT stuff.  As a Clevelander, I'm loyal to the West Side Market, but I have to say I had a glorious fling with the Reading Terminal Market while I was in town.  We saw this place on the food network, and decided we'd hunt it down once we got to Philly.  We were delighted to realize it was right next to our hotel.  The biggest problem?  There were so many great places to choose from that I felt like I missed out on a ton!  You'll deal with crowds when you are there for a convention, but there's lots of seating and lots of choices.  While I had several rushed experiences for breakfasts and lunches during the conference, I came in for a more leisurely walk through on Saturday morning, and enjoyed it so much.  What a great mixture of a fantastic food court and a fantastic market.  Loved it.  Can't wait to head back to Philly just to come back here.  My recommendations would be to try coming during off hours if you hate crowds, there are definitely times of day when it's more quiet, and you have your pick of lineless vendors.

So many great shops and restaurants. If you can't find something you like here then just give up. The Mexican restaurant, the one bakery (monkey something? - maybe), and the Bassats ice cream are a personal favorite.
Omg how can anyone decide what to eat or buy here! The choices are endless! It reminds me of Lexington Market in Baltimore

Reading Terminal Market is a must visit. There's so much variety of everything here - fruit, meat, cheese, flower shops.. they have all types of food to choose from as well - southern, pizza, chinese, sandwiches, desserts. You'll be a bit overwhelmed once you enter through the doors, but I assure you, you'll walk out of here with a satisfied palette and a few extra somethings for later.

Thanks to Yelp Philly, we decided to stop here and check it out. Wow! What an awesome place. It's like a food court/farmer's market on steroids. 

We walked through the entire place to check it out and decide where we wanted to eat. We decided on Olympia Gyros (for the guys) and the falafel place (for me). I got my meal quickly, a falafel platter with falafel, salad, pita, hummus, and tabboulah. I also got a tropical smoothie. All of this for about $12. One thing that confused me is that you get your food and eat, THEN pay. I wanted to carry mine away so I could eat with the people I was with, so I asked for the bill and then headed out.

Everything was fresh and tasty. I especially appreciated the smoothie - they were juicing the fruits right there. The guys liked their gyros and fries too. The lady working there was nice as she let me sit and eat even though I hadn't bought my food there, and even cleared my trash for me.

The amounts of meat and seafood here were crazy. I have never seen so much. Lots of produce - I can imagine even more when the summer comes around. Some standout booths were:

- a shop dedicated entirely to cookbooks. Cookbooks unlike I've ever seen before, for everything under the mood and more. 

- A honey shop, with products made from honey, plus several varieties to buy

- COOKIES. PLEASE, Yelp Philly, help me out here. We bought cookies from a place that had very unique flavors, like caramel and raspberry chocolate. Some of them were available halfway dipped in chocolate. They were the best cookies I've ever tasted. I can't remember the name of the shop, and wanted to see if they are online for me to order. I checked the webpage but none of the bakeries ring a bell. I think they sold more than cookies. I'm desperate! Please PM me! 

We spent more than enough to get our parking ticket validated. $4 for 2 hours was a great deal, seeing the prices of parking if you didn't have it validated. Wow.. now I know why there are such parking issues there that they shoot "Parking Wars" in the city! I sort of wished that I was going to run into a PPA employee so I could mention it.. hehe. But I digress...

This place rocked... and I'd go back in a heartbeat!

This is a great place to go, especially with good Friends.  Stop by any of the food stands and expect to receive a good meal.

This place gets insane on the weekend so if you can go on a weekday.

Wow.... A little bit of everything, fresh produce, desserts & the food was amazing. Plenty of places to browse if your looking to grab something to eat. We waited in line for a half hour to get Frank's Chicken & Perogies It was good but I can't believe it took that long to get our food.  I Really couldn't believe how few tables there are to sit at, We had to put 3 of us at one table and 3 at a different table. I would recommend getting there either before Noon or after 1. There was a sea of people, even seen a lady flipping out yelling at a cop because some lady stole her seat. I really enjoyed walking around and checking out all the different markets, but My favorite part was the Pretzels the Amish made stuffed with cheese filled Weenies.

I adore this place. It is like a HUGE farmer's market. I like the fact that I can get fresh organic produce while sipping Old City Coffee (my addiction). In addition, the food stands have something for EVERYONE.  I don't recommend going on the weekend unless you go about two huors before closing.
ice cream and cheese, and an old guy selling expensive organic apples..

Tips:

Looking for fresh produce? Go to the produce stand in the middle by the food court. They have great .99cent bags and if you have a student ID you get 10% off, and they have a great selection of items. 

Looking for eggs? Smuckers not only has a great grill to get lunch, but they have farm fresh eggs for $2.65/dozen. They also have LevelUp

Looking for natural/GLUTEN FREE baking and cooking items? There is a little convenient store with various kitchen food necessities and have very decent prices (compared to Whole Foods) and it is again toward the middle of RTM. 

Looking for an adult beverage? Maggie Malloys just opened and I hear great things! 

Looking for natural tea and health cures? Herbiary (right around the corner from the diner) has a great selection of teas and natural products and cures. I believe they also take LevelUp.

Looking for wine? You have options, there is a local wine store in reading terminal and a block away on 12th headed toward market is a PA liquor store with a great wine selection. Beer is not sold here however. :(

The best thing about this place isn't the food; it's the sense of hominess you feel when you walk in. The diversity of the stands is amazing, and you feel welcome in any corner of the marketplace. Unlike other food courts I've been to, the Reading Terminal community actually feels unique. Each stand is a treasure; it feels personal and welcoming, unlike the Panda Expresses and Subways or the snobby "upscale" food courts with celebrity chefs in NYC.

That being said, I don't want to play down the food, which was really delicious. Beck's Cajun Cafe was my favorite. DiNic's was good too. The variety can be overwhelming though and I did stand around for a good 5-10 minutes figuring out what to get. If I ever find myself in Philly again, I will definitely be back.

This is a food heaven, and you could easily get food coma here.  This place is just as good as the farmer's market by the SF pier, the Quincy Market in Boston, and/or the farmer's market nearby the Grove in LA.  Yet, the feel is unique and different from all the markets mentioned above. 

This place is extremely busy when we ate lunch here on a Tuesday.   There's a convention center nearby.  Needless to say, there were a lot of people from the convention center.  Luckily, they put a lot more seating than last time I came (in April 2011).  Still, it took me a while to look for a table, and while I was waiting for my husband to buy food, I was asked way too many times if they could sit at my table.  If you decide to eat here during the week, be prepare to wait online for food and to wait for a table for your party.

Also, since it's right in the middle of Philadelphia, it's very difficult to find parking outside of the market during the work week.  And the traffic is terrible like any other city.

Great variety, great food, and a "local" atmosphere in the middle of downtown district.  A must visit place for lunch.  

I usually go for the Philly Cheese Steak place and they were wonderful...  I once loaded up 8 of them (at about $10 a piece) and took it back home for the family and extended family members... man, I was a popular guy for a brief min.   Everyone loved it.

Oh my god, this place is so effing amazing.

For my fellow Milwaukeeans, you may think our Public Market is pretty cool. NOPE, SORRY, IT IS A SAD, SAD, MEDIOCRE STRIP MALL OF SAD.

The Reading Terminal Market...wow. Just effing wow. This place is like a stadium filled with every frigging thing you can think of. Total sensory overload as I tried to pick just one thing to try. Every ethnicity you can imagine is represented here, and not just food-wise.

If I lived in Philly, I'd be here everyday.
Fun to visit, tons of food, some of it not as cheap as I expected, but still very affordable. Not always easy to get a table. Great to just walk around and see everything.

Sonntag morgen  auf der Suche nach einem Frühstück außerhalb des HotelsViele Cafés etc. haben geschlossen  und so entdecken wir den Reading Terminal Market. Hinter der alten Fassade verbirgt sich ein ganzes Labyrinth an tollen Ständen und Shops, die alles mögliche feilbieten  von Fisch, Sushi, Fleisch, Wurst, Gemüse, Obst und und und. Auch der Frühstückshungrige bleibt nicht lange hungrig  sei es nun ein Crepe, ein French Toast oder eine Eierspeise, für jeden Geschmack ist etwas dabei!!! Wären wir nicht vom Frühstück so satt gewesen, wären wir schon zum Mittagessen wieder da gewesen.

Reading Terminal Market - with "Reading" pronounced as, "redding."

After walking inside, I totally wanted to grab some stuff for a picnic but I couldn't decide what to get. It was lunchtime and I was immediately jealous of everyone who worked nearby. You could easily spend half a year of lunches here without having to order the same thing twice.

My dearest lumberjack got major urges to cook with all the fresh ingredients and my eyes ate up way more than my stomach ever could. 

Come with a plan and come hungry.

Well in Seattle we have a Pike Place Public Market - which is comparable in size and scope.  However we have hippies selling tyedye clothes and really crappy"hipster" art.  OMG, not another Beaded POS. 

Reading TM, has Pennsylvania Dutch (PD) who seem polite, and while plain, they seem to have a knack for good food to eat.  I haven't tried the Scapple though.  This sounds gross yet so tempting!   

I know that i kept slamming Philly for not having a good coffee - but honestly, i go to starbucks in seattle more than anything, so what should i expect??  I should have just gone to starbucks in philly too.  Old Town coffee, nothing special.

Anyways, go to Reading TM, it's nice, there's places to sit and eat your "whatever"  Not horribly crowded.

If you like food -- there is no better place than Reading Terminal.  EVERYTHING you could possibly want is there.  Walk in & you're overwhelmed by aromas abound &  a seizure of food imaginary.

Fresh baked goods, cheesesteak, delis, chinese food, fresh seafood, produce, candy shops, custom chocolates, amazing cookies, homemade ice creams.  You'll be tempted to buy and try everything.  Good thing or bad thing?!?!  My tummy says yes but my wallet says no.  =)

Reading Terminal Market, you are just like my own North Market is Columbus, Ohio. What an absolute treat when being away from home!

With my hotel being right next door it was a blast taking fresh produce back to my room for a yummy and healthy snack after walking all day. 

This is a nice gem, but man does this place getting insane-crazy come noon and after. 

Come early--especially if you've never been and want to get a look around at all of the vendors, because once the clock strikes noon, the herds of human cattle come shuffling in, which can make waiting in lines and acrobatic and annoying experience. I recommend coming around 11, because most of the Vendors will have their delicious smells wafting through the air, and chances are, there won't be a major wait to get food. 

Our stop was the infamous Dinic's. You know, Man vs. Food? Yeah, I know we're total Posers, but it was wonderful and we are still craving one of his signature sandwiches. We also stopped at a produce stand ran by some Asian ladies, and at an Amish place in the far corner serving up cobblers, and bread puddings. YUM!

All senses are inspired here; the smells, the sights, the sounds, but most importantly the tastes. 

Happy adventures and happy eating!

Wish they sold little rooms in the Reading Terminal Market that you could just rent out for a month, and come back as a healthier version of yourself.

This review is for those who haven't visited the Reading Terminal Market yet.

If you've already been there... you'd know..

You walk inside the market expecting to find what you're looking for and exit. But as you stepped in, you've just embarked on an amazing journey to a magical land... Okay maybe I'm getting off topic. But it's only because I genuinely love this place.

The Reading Terminal Market has been my inspiration to get back to my Persian roots, by cooking some delicious Iranian cuisine. You can literally find any ingredient you're looking for, AND I MEAN ANYTHING, and it is the freshest!! (To all the Iranians out there, this place is fantastic to find ingredients for Ghormeh Sabzi  .)

Aside from the fact that you can find the tastiest organic product from any vegetables and herbs, to meats and fish, the energy in there is really remarkable. Friendly faces all around greeting you to try free samples, or even some times learn more about what they have to offer.

If I lived in Philly, I'd be living in the RTM!!! Yup, LIVING there! I was that fascinated. I love love love small vendors cooking up incredible, delectable bites. The croissant at Market Bakery was sooo good! It was flaky, buttery, delicious! I was a little sad that I had to share one with my boyfriend. Capuccino at Old City Coffee, yep, definitely 5 stars. It was strong, rich, foamy and piping hot. I struggle with this temperature issue at lots of coffee joints, including Starbucks. I want my coffee to be hot when it is served. I can adjust it to be less hot, if I want. I can't go the other way!
I digress. 
The cajun shrimp and crab pasta salad was good but I couldn't find any crab in it. The cheesesteak at Carmen's, DELISH! We got ours with roasted hot pepper and mushrooms. The heat was a definite plus!
Finally, Bassett's icecream was a good way to end brunch. 
Definitely coming back here when I visit Philly again!
Nice lil spot for an afternoon hangout, its kinda similar to Chelsea Market in NYC but much bigger and the food options are plenty..a must see when in Philly!

The Reading terminal is a lot like the Milwaukee Public Market but on crack.  

If you're from out of town, definitely plan to go at a non peak time or else you run the risk of being engulfed by the masses and carried away into a sea of schwarma.  

Don't miss: amish pretzels, grabbing a drink at the bar and people watching, or an authentic philly cheese steak

I also really wanted a miniature rhubarb pie that was being sold by one of the amish vendors, but never got back to it.   

The only thing I was really disappointed by was the miserable organic selection at the grocery section, despite a huge banner that says "organic"

Foodies version of the Pearly Gates

If you're in Philly and you bypass this place, your making one HELL of a mistake! I loved this place so much that I'm flying across the Pacific ocean and the continent just to sit in this marketplace to enjoy an amazing Dutch breakfast prepared by an Amish family, have an amazing roast pork with broccoli rabe sandwich for lunch from Dinnick's, and go crazy with trying to figure out where to have your final meal of the day from the plethora of food booths before they close the market for the day.

...And yes Lisa, you were right. It's St. Peter, not St. Gabriel, that guards the gates into heaven. Forgive me.

I love markets and this one has to be one of my favorites!  It has some great fruit and veggie options that remind me of Granville Island in my city of Vancouver, but with way more cooked food options!  Your head is almost spinning as you see the famous Tommy DiNics, baked goods, Indian food, crepes, smoked meat sandwiches, cheese, pretzels, and more!  Definitely budget a few hours here.  Bring your cash, an empty stomach, and have fun!

Conveniently located near transit and the convention center.

Like many of my review, I was in town for business and saw that my hotel was near the Reading Terminal Market.  I love places like this!

I only wished my wife was with me, we enjoy traveling and enjoy walking through big open markets like this.  

The Reading Terminal Market is exactly like the markets in Toronto, Cleveland and other cities across the world.  It's full of local vendors selling fish, meta, sausage, fruit, veggies, unique local fair and peppered with eateries.

Being in Philadelphia, I had a cheese steak of course.  The sandwich was good but being from Chicago and being familiar with a similar sandwich it was hard to compare to a good Italian Beef.  However, the sheese steak was good and the experience was awesome.

You're lucky to have a such place if you live in Philly, and if you don;t and you're in town for business or to watch your local NFL team beat the Eagles (DA'BEARS!), make the stop for lunch.  It's worth it.

Love this place! I visited Philadelphia with my sister and we ended up coming here everyday we were in town. 

There are many vendors and the Amish are there to sell their products on Saturdays. If you go on a Sunday, only about half the vendors are opened.

You can find everything from all sorts of food, bakery, dessert items to gift shops, beauty supply, etc. They're all local vendors and everything tastes amazing. We definitely enjoyed the soft pretzels, especially the stuffed breakfast pretzels.

Hey, everyone outside. Come in here and lets walk up and down the isles as slowly as possible. Grrrr. 

I love markets but they are hard to review because they are created of so many components. Let me just write whats on my mind and you decide.

Easy to find, i walked here from the Convention Center. The second i walked in it was packed out with people walking without a purpose. I get people browsing, cool, but i was starving an in a rush to find something.

Variety, its got it. You can get all types of food here from Sushi to Chocolate and Deli meats. I chose to eat at By George (no good) check out my review on it.

After i battled the crowd and got my food i sat at one of the public tables. It had food all over it and the ground. The area was generally dingy and gross. Also i noticed a few homeless (or so they looked) roaming around inside. I sympathize for the situation but i felt generally uncomfortable at some points. 

I am not shutting this place out because of the size and options. I'll try it again for sure but just seems a bit dirty and crowded for my liking.

Reading Terminal Market is a piece of the city's historical fabric.  Thousands of visitors pass through daily to hit up the variety of food stands, buy produce, pick up a cake from Termini Bros., check out the wine selection at Blue Mountain Vinyards, and pick-up some knick-nacks from a variety of sundries stalls. There are many storied names in the market (Iovine Brothers produce, Delilah's, Miller's Twists, Bassett's Ice Cream, the list goes on).  The place is great to visit if you know what you want, but it's so crowded at times and there are so many aisles that visitors from out-of-town will get lost if they do not have a plan.  If you live in Center City, you will come here on at least a monthly basis for food and produce. 

The bottom line: It gets crowded, it's sometimes difficult to remember where things are, but you have to go to Reading Terminal market at least once for the experience. You'll have to keep going back to deeply appreciate and understand it.
Great market...good place to stroll through on a Saturday to buy some choice items

What a neat place.

Tip: Don't bother going on Sunday!!!
Tip: Don't get sucked in to ridiculous prices for everyday things. Try to make purchased of items you would not usually get. 

My favorite booths were hosted by Amish families and were closed on Sunday as well as many others for what I image would be religious reasons. They really add a nice touch to the market. We only grabbed quick sandwiches from two stands, both were great. The cookies at the North West corner were also great, warm and chewy as they were fresh from the oven. We also picked up some rolls to bring home with us. 

This is a great please to grab some items to go and eat in one of Phillise' many wonderful parks.

Gotta love open air markets that sell you incredibly fresh produce and has a list of endless, mouth watering vendors. Out of all the times I've been to Philly, I couldn't recall the details of Reading Terminal. Bf and I came here for weekend and we decided to come here for lunch on a Sunday. Sadly, Sunday means that the most notable vendor, Dutch Landing Co is closed (this is the Amish place every talks about). We talked by their booth and saw a delicious menu featuring chicken pot pie, blueberry pancakes, and that type of thing. 

We tried to eat as much as we could.  The famous sandwich shop here is the Pork place (sorry I don't know the actual name)- this is the one that serves the Italian bread hoagies with pulled pork, roast pork with broccoli rabe (which my bf got, with roasted sweet peppers), and beef..brisket? I don't really eat pork so I had a tiny bit. It seems watery and lean; the rabe was very crunchy and yummy. My bf loved it. It was some $11 with a drink. 

I went to Frank's chicken to get a side of homemade mac and cheese (yummy, very cheesy but not crunchy as I'd like) and 2 pieces of BBQ grilled chicken (not too sweet, but more like a rotisserie chicken- very yummy but nothing I hadn't had before- hot, with crispy skin and juicy), I wanted two homemade pierogis but they'd just ran out. Came to some $7. 

We walked around and sampled the jambalaya at the Cajun place, which was really spicy and yummy- I would have ordered from here again. Typical long lines included the pretzels and cheesesteaks. (We had pretzels from the same place that does chocolate covered stuff in the corner.. but sadly it was too stale. I'd get the famous pretzels off the street somewhere) 

 There is also that famous chocolate shop (another) that features pictures of Andrew Zimmerman (funnily) eating a chocolate covered onion (and not liking it). Instead, we sweet-ed it up with a big gooey chocolate chip cookie with walnuts from the 4th St Baking Company (cookie place near the entrance). 

While my travels have taken me to wonderful markets like Pike Place in Seattle and Granville in Vancouver..I've overlooked this wonderful little place close-by in Philly.

The Reading Terminal Market is so cool.  It basically has everything you need (food court wise) in one spot.  My husband got the TOmmy DiNic's cheesesteak sandwich with the broccoli rabe where I got lost and confused with all the goodness surrounding me and went for the Jambalaya and Gumbo.  (Although a bit salty, this review is strictly for the Terminal Market).

We were so in awe with the hussle and bustle of everything.  And everything looked scrumptious.  My bff got a pound of Amish chicken wings.  Fried to goodness.  Her daughter (less than 2 loved em).

We finished it off with Bassets Ice Cream on a sugar  cone.  

DO: Make sure you stalk then grab a table quickly.  We had to wipe ours down a couple of times from the previous patrons but it fit all of us so we were good.
DO: Make a round or two of the whole place before you decide where to go.
DO: The ice cream.  It's really delicous and rich on a nice humid hot day.

DON'T: Get lost.  It's a big place and you can easily find yourself all in circles.
DON'T: Get the gumbo.  It was pretty salty.

LOVED THIS PLACE!

As a former Washingtonian, I have high standards when it comes to markets - Pike's Place really set that bar high....so let me tell you - Reading Terminal Market, well it definitely holds its own!

The market is set up in blocks / gridded districts, as depicted in a map you can view in the center seating area. We walked each corridor and took in the sights of many amazing items - from juices and smoothies, to breads and baked goods - local honey to fresh produce, seafood, meats....sensory overload, as MacRae posted in a previous review - in the best of ways!

Definitely make a trip here!!
Very interesting to visit a whole block of stalls with cuisines from all over the world. I enjoyed the bakeries, ice cream and coffee the most..

this is like a farmers market held indoors! many different food options from dutch to cajun to bakeries and coffees to pretzels and ice creams.  theres a mini produce market in the back as well.
lots of people and lots of see, eat, and do.

i can eat breakfast here everyday!
This was a great spot in the middle of downtown Philly that is just a variety of different foods, vendors, different cultures are put together I had breakfast and lunch here everyday I was here.

This place is overrated.  There are better indoor markets elsewhere with higher quality food and more variety - e.g., SF Ferry Building, Boston Quincy Market, Seattle Pike Place Market.  We got an okay cheesesteak from Spataro, a warm apple dumpling from a PA Dutch place, and a cone from the ice cream shop.

This market has tons of eats. From seafood to meat. Free wi-fi tons of seating and was visited by famous eats celebrity andrew zimmerman. For 3 days in philly, I ate various food and wish I had time to try everything. This place is always crowded and busy so there is no off-hours where you can stroll unless opening time.

Never disappointed in the products, just the rudeness of people.  So many places to shop for fresh veg and fruit, keep your eye out for the lowest prices.  Smoked meats and beef jerky are a must have!  Very fresh fish at John Yi, always super nice staff there!

This place is food heaven. If you love cooking and food, this place is the place to be. You can buy anything to cook for dinner here. I love, love, love the Amish Pretzel place (i can never say no to the jalapeño stuffed hot dog pretzels). You MUST try the following: Louisiana cajun place (crocodile gumbo), 45th street cookies (OMG macadamia nuts with white chocolate), sang kee (wonton duck noodle soup), the fried chicken place (can't remember the name), DiNics roast pork sandwich (sometimes 30 min to 1 hr+ line-- make sure you order it with sharp provolone, long hots and broccoli rabe), and Hershel's Farm (pastrami sandwich). ALL deliciousssssssss. 

I also love buying fresh groceries and meats here.

love this place My fave eateries here are
Beck's Cajun Cafe= fried mac and cheese, cajun alfredo pasta and whiskey bread pudding
Creperie place
vegetarian place- i forgot the name
next time i'll try the by geoge

Easily my favorite place nearby to buy produce and proteins.  Turkey bacon is super reasonably priced, as is the steak at most of the vendors.  The seafood selection is pretty good, and the prices reasonable.  It is a great place to have lunch and do a week's worth of shopping on the weekend.
I love philly and this market. Amazing foods and pastries there. Oh and I almost forgot  about Bassets ice cream!? SO GOOD! :)

A friend told me about this place, and I love it!
