It's a fabulous place for local food, gifts, daily items, etc. It's like an indoor open-air market, with fresh produce and homemade treats, as well as honey, candles, prepared foods, groceries, etc., etc., etc. Not on the typical tourist track, which is a great thing! Taste local, go here!

The second I opened the door and glanced inside I already knew I loved this place!  It is a market centered around food, not so much on knick knacks.  But everything looks ridiculously good!  The placed was packed on a Monday afternoon.  Our first stop was the Famous 4th Street Cookie Company, we opted for one that was covered in chocolate which had the texture of frosting, the cookie itself was so soft and delicious!  For lunch I could not decide what to eat, I ended up having the artichoke, spinach, mozzarella sandwich at the Mezze, it was ok, not too much flavor and lots of bread, but still enjoyable.  My husband had a cheesesteak sandwich which he enjoyed, I tried a bite and it was tasty, warm and spicy!  I wanted to try Bassett's Ice cream, it looked so wonderful and tons of unique flavors but I already had plans to visit The Franklin Fountain while in Philly.  Must visit even for a quick stop if you are in the area!

Can't find a market like this anywhere else! I'm a Philadelphia native, and I can't get enough. I've lived in other cities, but nothing compares.  No matter what kind of food you're looking for, there's a place in this market. There's also tons of local specialties, and even places to get good gifts for friends or relatives!

Can I give six stars? Ten? Two thumbs-up, five stars, and whatever other maxed-out rating system is what this place gets!

This is food Heaven, and no there's no Peter at the gate to ask you questions. Fresh produce, locally sourced honey and jams, bakeries, ice cream shops, fresh seafood stands (w/ amazing prices btw), a bar, awesome food stands (DiNic's!), people watching...AHHHH, I wish this was in Denver. I don't anticipate moving to Philly anytime soon, but I would live there just for this place.

If you live nearby and don't go here, shame on you. If you're in town visiting, come here at least once. Ugh...writing this review makes me sad that I can't go there right now. Every major city in America should have something just like this.

A must see if you're visiting Philly, and a vibrant place for anyone else. My favorites are the Market Bakery, whose cookies, breads and sandwiches beat Metropolitan Bakery by a mile; Beck's Cajun Cafe, whose po-boy sandwiches you'll be craving until the next time you visit. The Amish stands are best for ripe tomatoes. The market has live music during the lunch hours and vendors are pretty friendly, if a little expensive at times. Go in with a plan; otherwise it can be a little overwhelming.

I was in Philly for a wedding. I went to Chinatown, and it was...Chinatown.  The food sucked.  Why would any Asian want to go there?  I thought I would be stuck without anywhere to go or do.   Then the recommendation for the Reading Terminal started coming in.  Boy am I glad they did.  This place was awesome.  Food everywhere!!  After going to Pat's several years ago, I swore that I would never buy another one.  I kept to my word.  I had the leftovers of what my wife couldn't finish.  It was so good!  I got into the longest line that I could find, and later found out that I was standing in the line at DiNic's.  I got their famous pork sandwich, and it was good.  The wife also gave me some of her leftover shrimp Po boy sandwich.  Awesome place.  Too bad, I will probably never go to Philly again.

My favorite place to eat in Philadelphia! Who couldn't love it with all it's options. You can get mexican, vegetarian, philly steak, hamburgers, pub food, bakery items--you name it they have it! 

I have several places that you will have to try...

1. Basic 4 Vegetarian Snack Bar: amazing. I recommend their Classic Veggie Burger. You may also try the Class BLT with soy bacon. I loved this bacon. At first I was nervous not having tried many soy products but it tasted so similar to the real thing minus all the yucky fat. With either grab a cup of lemonade and grab the nearest seat you can find! 

2. 12th St. Cantina. I used to eat here all the time before I stopped eating red meats and chicken. Plus, they offer their own seating so you don't have to fight for a table. Although, it's not the same!

3. Ice cream from Bassett's. 

4. Metropolitan Bakery and Old City Coffee for your grab and go!

You have completed my essential reading terminal guide.

Now all you have to do is get lost in the crowd and find the next best thing!

I do not recommend the vegetable gyro from Olympic Gyro. I just didn't take to it.

If you don't like crowds you won't like this place but keep an open mind and explore because the Reading Terminal is A LOT of fun!

Definitely one of my favorite markets. So many shops compacted in block and there's anything from sandwiches to sushi to sweets to meats to seafood. It's pretty much endless and they also have fresh produce. You can get almost everything here. It's fresh and the foods are cooked on the spot. Lots of locals come here and tourists also, you would be missing out if you didn't stop by here when visiting Philly.

They have seating areas around the market so you'll have to scout around for that. Some of my personal favorites would be - DiNic's (delicious roast pork sandwich, get it with provolone and broccoli rab), Beck's Cajun Cafe (amazing gator gumbo, full of spice and chunks of gator sausage), Kamal's Middle Eastern Specialties (stop by for a refreshing Lemon Na-na, aka mint lemonade with rose water and also the baklava - so good!).

A little note - if you can help it, don't come on a Sunday because a lot of shops are closed. Best day would be Saturday!

Lines, long lines, nothing but lines. Keep in mind this was a Sunday afternoon. Every place we tried to eat...there was a line. The worst part was that it appeared the eatery employees did not seem motivated, at all, to try to move the people. They moved at a snail's pace and the line just kep on growing. Maybe they thought it was cool to have a crowd in front of their establishment.
For what this is and where it's at....this place is awesome. Tons of prepared and fresh food vendors all under one roof in center city.

I came here on a nice Sunday afternoon. My friends have been there before and it was my first time. It reminds me of being in Chelsea Market, but with a much better section of produce and places to eat. I was sad to see that most of the shops were closed on Sundays or opened at a later time. 

From fresh produce, meats and seafood. You have lots of choices. If you are craving something good to eat. You have choices of Chinese, Mexican, Cajan and even Middle Eastern Food at this place. It's cooked right in front of you and you can sit right there and relax. It's definitely worth going to again whenever i'm back in town.

Not impressed with this gourmet market. Definitely a TON of choices and lots of fresh options (e.g. juice, baked goods, sushi, etc.). Truly a meat lovers paradise + some vegetarian options. Extremely crowded & difficult to navigate; I'm sure it's not so bad during weekdays when it's less touristy. I would've liked to have seen more healthy options; the two juice bars I stopped at wouldn't even do a custom juice blend as they told me everything was carrot based?! Disappointing.

Why cant all cities have affordable, year-round farmers markets that sell food? Its such a great idea to have so many small businesses and farmers come together to sell fresh wholesome food- -- at DECENT prices!

This was a great stop on our way back from Dorney Park we stopped here thanks to Adam (Man Vs Food) Richman If I lived in this area this would be a great place to go everyday. It's for locals and tourist alike the only set back is parking but this goes for any stop in any big city,so sit back enjoy the food or read a book from the used book section and relax...

Despite the good stuff, you probably don't want to visit if you're claustrophobic.

I spent a lot of Saturdays going to Termini Brothers for a cannoli early in the morning.  Today, since I'm not living here, I launched myself from the motel a bit late.  I didn't even bother to see if Termini Brothers were there since it was afternoon and I'd already eaten.

The place was so crowded that I was uncomfortable.  Of course, all of the produce looked good, and there were multiple Asian lunch counters and the Amish were there as well.  The meats and cheeses looked amazing.  If I could just take them all home with me until I can move back here, I would.

One thing that seemed odd were people taking large dogs through the entrance on Filbert St.  If there isn't some pet care inside, would you want to eat with dogs around you?  I wouldn't, and I've had dogs.

Everything you need to satisfy your hunger in one bustling building. Yes it's crowded and yes it can get hot but boy your taste buds will be enlightened to new levels after you get out of this market! Pulled pork sandwiches, fruit-ades, pickles, whoopie pies, cookies and fudge, oh my! 

Good luck navigating around but getting lost in here is a treat itself. Have fun!!

Love love love this market! Being from Hawaii I was just in foody awe at what this place had to offer on a REGULAR basis to the Philly population. Lucky dogs! I think I walked a mile in this bustling mecca of delights and wanted to buy everything! 

Right after I gorged myself on the wonderful pretzels at Miller's Twist, we walk around the corner and it's cookies, bakery heaven! Id' really have to exhibit          
self-control if I lived here. Good thing we were just visting LOL!  I bought a lot and definitely ate everything my little pig heart desired! I can't wait to come back!

This place is ridiculous!  At the awesome level :-)

Such fantastic energy with the myriad of businesses and people all clustered inside.  A plethora of food choices (think Austin's food truck lots but inside) with a main sitting area in the center to enjoy.  Rather quickly moving lines for the number of people, and the cost at is the regular work-lunch level (~$7).

It is precisely what it sets out to be, and that's fantastic.

The smells alone are worth coming here, but don't just settle for that.  Go with a group and order a bunch of different things so as to get the full RTM experience or just be greedy and gorge yourself on all the treats.  There is a reason that travel/food/cooking shows come here - it is part of the identity of Philadelphia even more so than the cheesesteak itself.

There are so many reviews that it is hard to add to the conversation without repeating myself, so I will just stick to the sweet stuff.  Flying Monkey Bakery is one of my faves and has boozey desserts, which let's be honest, is one of the best combo's around.  Bassett's ice cream is some of the better icecream this city has to offer- plus with their local inspired flavors (WHYY Experience, Gadzooks, etc) you know that they are as integrated in this town as RTM itself. Hope's Cookies are chewy goodness.  There are also a bunch of old timey candy vendors and hand made chocolates.  See that is the thing with RTM, for as many times as I have been there, it is hard for me to get to all the vendors.  They need a punch card so you know which ones you have tried and which are still on the list.

This was conveniently located one block from my fabulous hotel. It was nice to be able to walk to it. I was told it's one of the oldest markets and it had everything there. We walked in from the chocolate pretzel section the delightful baked goods looked so appealing, then the sections opened to a variety of areas for fresh produce, seafood, philly cheese steaks, chinese food, juice bar, coffee, cookies, delicatessens, Amish selling fresh poultry, bologna sticks and very good bacon. The highlight was a young man playing jazz on his portable piano it was fantastic! My two favorite stores were Hershel's East Side Deli and a store selling kitchen knick knacks. At Hershel's East Side Deli there was a line of people waiting for sandwiches the beautiful pieces of pastrami,briskets and corned beef. The meats were heavenly! I was tempted to buy a whole pound of briskets but I couldn't destroy my 95% vegetable diet at the moment. As for the knick knacks - I found a floating duck tea infuser haha!! And we bought some flat kabob grill skewers like the ones usually used by the authentic middle eastern restaurants, these with nice handles.

I enjoyed my trip to Philly especially discovering the Reading Terminal Market!

Lots of great food!, fun shops! great place for lunch, and for taking people from out of town to show them around Philly!

They have a food court style area with tons of delis and restaurants. Options range from Indian to Italian and everything in between.

They have candy stores, cookie stores and smoothies.

The shopping consists of book stores, soap, jewelry, some aprons and shawls,  wine and kitchen ware.

There is a candy shop that sells a novelty chocolate covered onion and has pictures of this guy eatting it. Its pretty funny.

Also they have this great fresh juicing places where it is all fresh! and no sugar added.

I like bringing out of town guests here to show them a little slice of Philly living.

I have personally eaten at "Hershels" see my review for details.

Like going to the circus? Well imagine if the circus was all food, that's the best way I can describe RTM.. I loved it at RTM and hope one day my city will become cultured enough to appreciate a market like this too..

What a cool place.  The kind of downtown food and shopping market that I can only dream of Charlotte having.  We're trying with the 7th Street Public Market but, it's not even a fair comparison.

So much to choose from that it literally is mind boggling.  I feel like I would spend part of every weekend here buying seafood, meat, produce, snagging lunch at one of the huge variety of eateries contained within.  I only got to Tommy DiNic's for the roast pork, sharp provolone and broccoli rabe sandwich on this visit and it was awesome but I just wanted to try so many other places.

Nice job Philadelphia!

If you in Philly, you have to put this place in the top of our list to see.  I would almost put it first.  And plan on going back and spending plenty of time while you are there.  I probably could have eaten lunch here every day if i could have.
There is so many food stands to see and check out.  It made choosing super hard.  We split up our group and got things from all different stands and everything was excellent.  

Go here and go often.  I want one of these in my town.

I love this place! It gets pretty crowded and it is often hard to find seats but it is all worth it.  This is my favorite part of living in Philly(I am such a fat girl).  My favorite spots are:

L. Haltemen- I get all of my meats here. Always fresh and taste great.
Beilers Bakery- Everything here is good! Stay away if you are on a diet.
Franks A Lot- The best baked chicken wings with a bbq glaze. You must try them! The cornbread is also good.
Coastal Cave Trading Co.- Great seafood sandwiches!
Salumeria- Best Italian Hoagies!
Hatville Deli- Best cold cuts.

There are so many other great places to try here other than the places I have listed, I get so stuck on these places that I don't get a chance to try something new.

This place is always busy.  Great variety great food must visit.. Gotta visit Dinics the sandwhichs are great. If your lucky ull get a seat .  Make sure you know what you want or they get pissed. And no they dont have lettuce or tomato lol

OK I'm a fan of markets, I'm used to the open air market of good ole Rochester NY, but if you want to shop come here and if you want to eat come here. I tried to "check in" to too many spots on yelp while I was there that they like blocked me---fie! Yelp I'm so good to you and you deny me! Bastards! Anyway we were supposed to get to the Italian market but came here instead, tomorrow Viva Italia! Very busy but friendly crowd. We were on a sandwich quest. This is a lie I was on a sandwich quest, I'm just lucky to travel with people who will go on the adventures I like to go on, that or the  I'll probably fork you under the table look gets it done. Either way I am lucky that they participate. The variety of items to eat is very good, if you can't find anything you are a block from China town. Our three sandwiches, apple fritter and fruity beverage are all rated in other posts, keep reading and visit the markets! Ground cherries, one stall had them, Montreal had them last week, is this a new phenom? Pretty tasty I'd recommend giving them a try kind of a fig texture, no pit, honey tones.

I absolutely love this place and every city should "try" to imitate Reading Terminal, if they could.  We went there all three days of our trip, ate at several restaurants, bought food any many of the vendors.  Bread from the dutch bakery, sausage from one of the meat vendors.  The place is great, crowded and full of things to see, try and do.  Nice having validated parking if you spend $10, that helps.  this is a must see for anyone that likes food and is visiting Philly.

Can you say WOW! A Foodies paradise! Made me want to move to Philly with all the fresh seafood vendors and meat markets all in one spot! It has offers of wonderful smelling foods and so much to see and take in. Jammed pack both times we visited. Experience it if you're in the area.

granted, I visited a little after 9 am on a Friday, but a lot of the stalls were closed :(

somehow, i imagined this place to be bigger. pike place in seattle seems to have a ton more vendors. this place looked just like a mall food court. 

my friend wanted to try a cheese-steak, but the one we got here was not good. the gator gumbo at Beck's Cajun Cafe was good, but the po-boys were 90% bread (cold, and stale).

Reading Terminal is like a classier version of the Pennsauken Mart. There is a myriad of shops and foods and what not to explore. I was there for 2 reasons recently; 1) to take the Philadelphia Chocolate Walking Tour and 2) to eat a pork sandwich at Dinics because it was on Man vs Food. The chocolate tour was meh, ok....different chocolate samplings around the city. The misses is the chocoholic, so it was more for her than me. There was a gelato place at the end of the tour that was pretty awesome.....damn...I can't remember the name. (I shall update after I use my google-fu), The sandwich was actually pretty good even though I should have went with spinach instead of broccoli rabe. Lesson learned. Variety is the spice of life so if youre looking for a little spice, check out Reading Terminal. Oh, and they validate parking if you park in the lot across the street. Pretty damn sweet in Philadelphia any time you can get that.
Olympic Greek Restaurant was great! The Gyro's were fresh and fantastic. Reasonably priced. Would eat there again!!

Amazing selection of food and other products! Whether you want to grab something already made or you're buying fresh meats, produce, etc to make later, there's going to be something for everyone here. 

Expect big crowds and long lines during most times, but it's more than worth it in the end. Also, if you're hoping to get something from the PA Dutch vendors don't come on Sundays because their stands will be closed!

This is a fun place to go and get something to eat, though it does get crazy busy during meal hours. I came here several times the last time I was in philly and stopped by with some coworkers for lunch during a conference this most recent time. It was extremely crowded. We first staked out a place to sit and we had one of us reserve the spot while the rest of us got food. I got cheesesteak (which you have to do when your in philly) with american chess, peppers & onions. The line was very long but they were efficient. Food was delicious which be due (partially) to the delicious bread. The sandwich was also huge! If I had a fridge I would definitely take half back for dinner.
Great place!

This Center City (midtown) gem is the reason I moved to Washington Square West.  Not only do I go for my weekly groceries, but I go for the End-Of-Day cookie sales.  Take a stroll and just look at all the selections available.  30 types of jerky, shrimp the size of a baby's forearm, fudge to die for, etc.

I love you reading terminal, marry me?

This is a great place. I live in NNJ, about 2 1/2 hours away and try to get here 3 or 4 times a year. My excuse is the Franklin Institute or Please Touch Museum for the kids, but the Terminal Market is my favorite lunch spot. Great burgers, chicken, Chinese Food and oysters, so much left to try. Great produce, coffee and fish to take home. Be sure to visit their website and check out the subsidized 2 hour parking for $4; otherwise it's $12 for 2 hours. Enjoy.

If you are hungry and not sure what you want to eat, this is the place to visit. There are so many food stands to choose from it is hard to make a choice! Our group opted for the homemade PA Dutch Chicken Pot Pie, Sausaage, Peppers, and Onions Sandwiches, and Beef Jerky. We went on a Saturday and we had a small problem of trying to find somewhere to sit to enjoy or food. There was seating, but not enough to handle the large crowd.

The Cheesesteak counter and the pulled pork counter were by far the busiest in the whole building. The lines wrapped around the aisle and snaked to the next. 

They have it all...hot, cold, fresh, and dried! So much to see and smell! Taking a shopping bag would be helpful if you would like to take some tasty treats home. 

This would be a fun place to take the train downtown to visit!

Make sure to go hungry!

WOW, you must experience this cornucopia of food at least once during a trip to Philly. Its impossible to truly take it In during one visit. We made three separate trips and found something new each time. Desserts, meats, fish, Amish all sandwiched together and all seem to make money here. Dinics roast beef w/provolone was good but a bit dry, Martins Sausage stand we bought home ribs, ground beef and stew meat which were a good prices. Even got an insulated bag from them to get the meats home in good condition.Bassetts Ice cream had good ice cream and Flying Monkey bakery had good cupcakes. Overall great experience well worth a visit.
It is very busy during lunch time hours 11am-2pm so be prepared or come later in the day. Some stall close earlier Tuesday and Wednesdays (Amish mostly) You cant walk out of here empty handed.

OMG Amish jerky. 
Seriously one of the best markets in the US despite the touristas.

"You can have whatever you like..." literally. 

Italin.Greek.Sushi.IceCream.Cookies.Beer.Fruit.Juice.Crepes.Body Oils. Accessories. Oysters.Coffee. Sweets. Pastries. & of course..."Best Sandwich in 'Merica." 

A Must-Do while visiting Philly!!

I freaking love this place. I'm big on variety and there is a little of everything here. I've eaten a multiple stations in here and no one has disappointed me yet. My fav is Hershals deli corn beef sandwich and the famous something (forgot exact name) cookies. Their chocolate chip with walnuts is huge and really yummy. I usually get one to share during the day and keep other one for late night need something after going out in my belly to soak up some of the fun from that night:)

This place is especially good if you have picky eaters with you. Something for everyone.

What an interesting gem of food. Everything is here...sandwiches, ice cream, cakes, pretzels and beer.

I was drawn here by Di Nics but ended up getting ice cream as well.

Be sure to stop by everyday to try something new!

This market is reminiscent of Pike's Place Market in Seattle, only better because it's indoors (so in case of rain) and has more food versus flowers and other local stuff like candles. I love all the food stalls - I just want to try them all (so many choices!)! They must be good because as I was searching yelp reviews, most of the individual places are rated four stars. 

I am not sure what the parking situation is like, since I stayed at the Hilton Garden Inn around the corner. It seemed street parking is VERY limited, so parking in a garage is probably best. I don't know the hourly cost ($33/day), but the same parking garage I used for the hotel can be used for the market (entrance is off of 11th or Arch streets). Apparently there is a deal right now that you can now park up to two hours nearby in a garage (not sure which one) for $4 with vendor validation. Perhaps this is a way to gain more business, but it seemed people were in full force either buying food at the grocery stalls or sitting down to eat. 

I noticed there are some places only open in the morning versus not open in the afternoon for lunch, so be forewarned! Your best bet is to use the Yelp app as a tool to figure out the operation hours of the different places. Good luck!

This place is awesome! It has pretty much any kind of food you want. I've been here several times and have come away happy and full each time. Fresh cooked salmon with spinach and rice, pork spareribs with roasted potatoes, delicious baked goods....the list goes on and on. It also has Bassett's ice cream, which I haven't yet had but have been told it's the best ice cream around. I'd definitely make it a point to visit this place if you are ever in Philly.

Sehr viele Händler mit Großer Auswahl an Gemüse, fisch, fleisch, Obst und selbst erzeugten Lebensmitteln. Die amish people verkaufen auch hier ihre erzeugten Waren. Hier kann man richtig gutes echtes und originales Philly-cheese-steak Essen. Es gibt jedoch auch reichlich andere speisen in dem Markt zu finden. Man findet schon was. Zu empfehlen

Oh my God. Why can't DC have something like this?!?!? Reading Terminal Market is a must stop when you are in Philly. It has just about every type of food you can think of, all delicious and all at a very decent price. It tends to be crowded on the weekends (and now especially since Dinic's won "best sandwich in America"), but it's totally worth it. Every meal I've had here has been good. It convienently located right in the center of the touristy part of the city, so if you are visiting Philly YOU HAVE TO GO. There's also spices and breads and any food you can think of for sale besides the eating places. Every time I go to Philly, I make it a point to stop here. Best place in Philly, hands down.

I love this place! I was at the convention center for a few days for a conference and was ecstatic to find out that the convention center was next to the Reading Terminal Market.  I pretty much spent all of my time between conference sessions wandering the stalls at Reading and looking at or eating a variety of all things food-related.  I was excited about the cookbook stall which had a decent selection of mainstream cookbooks, but the books were all so pristinely displayed that I was hesitant to thumb through them.  I was inappropriately enamored with the Amish food stalls, as I consider that type of thing to be "exotic" coming from California.  I wish I had had an opportunity to make good use of the produce, meats, fish, and cheese sold in the various markets. Overall, this is a great place to immerse yourself if you love food.
Nice place to visit while in Philly. Dutch Eating Place ( great b'fast ), Beck's Cajun Cafe ( alligator ), Dinics ( awesome roast pork/broccoli rabe hero )...

This place is like a dream come true. I think yes, maybe other places I've been had some kind of a similar market where goods were sold and delicious, delightful, amazing foods were offered, but it seems like almost every business in this market is a hit.

We tried the famous Tommy Dinic's and even met the owner who was so friendly he threw in extras for us. We tried the original turkey sandwich, which was the most delicious, and largest sandwich I have had that was FRESHLY carved ... ever! And the cookies and pretzels and ice cream delights. 

The only thing that was sort of sucky is that not all of the businesses here are open all of the days that the market is open so we were not able to try out the deliciousness of Dutch Eating Place, but perhaps we were saved according to Steve T. as it literally was an abandonment of hope of eating less once you enter. 

If you come to Philly and you don't come here, you really have missed out on a LOT. Not just one, but many, many restaurants, vendors, and delights that you would be hard pressed to find elsewhere.

Less mentioned, this place also sells produce, seafood, fresh cheeses and other grocery related items that are fantastic. I was nomming for days in here, even a fellow visitor noticed me everywhere in the Market and said "you're still here! eating!" ... hah guilty!
Love this place. A must see if you are visiting Philly. Excellent food. Great service.

I wish I could have had a couple hours to walk around this place and soak up everything it had to offer. We got coffee, cookies, and later lunch here. There are options for every cuisine, taste, and diet here. I really would have liked to try some of the Amish fare - maybe next time. It was pretty crazy busy on the weekend, I imagine it is better during the week.

I've gone here twice now for the market portion (I've never tried any of the vendor/restaurant-style food places).  Both times, I was just stopping in for some fresh veggies and cheese.  While the selection is decent, the price seemed about comparable to the big chain grocery stores (maybe a little cheaper on certain items).  The downside is the CROWD.  There are times when you literally can't move, it gets so crowded.  I have nothing against tourism (I love to travel!), but fighting a crowd of people who are stopping every 5 feet to take pictures is not the ideal grocery shopping experience for me.
On the plus side, a lot of places here take LevelUp as a form of payment, so if you bike/walk over with nothing but your phone in your back pocket, you're still set for success.

A real gem.  Unlike Faneuil Hall in Boston and Harbor Place in Baltimore, locals actually can shop here for fresh foods to cook at home.  Food is a bit more affordable than those venues- had a great order of dumplings for under $5.  

I'm not into this cuisine, but for those that like Pennsylvania Dutch cooking and baked goods make sure you don't go Sunday as those stands (20% of the stands probably) are closed for the Sabbath.

I love this place.  So much incredible food it is hard to choose what/where to eat. This visit I decided on a Turkey Special at Original Turkey. It was outrageous.  Dessert at Terminis.  It does, understandably, get crowded.
Lots &  LOTS of good food here.  Just about something for everyone.  You definitely want to go hungry.

a little bit of everything in 1 spot! Yay!
One of the cool spots in Philly!

Reading Terminal Market makes a trip to Philadelphia worth it. 

Think... Seattle's Pike's Place Market, Los Angeles' Grand Central Market, New York City's Chelsea Market.

But I personally would rather go here than the other places mentioned above.

It's like Disney World for your mouth. I am so, so upset that I didn't have time to really explore the place properly, but what I did try was fantastic. Beck's Cajun Cafe had delicious gumbo- if you had ever told me I could get decent Cajun food from a stall in PA I would have called you a filthy liar. I don't even like beef jerky but the fresh jerky made by....whoever makes it here, was actually good. Regrettably I didn't have half an hour to wait on line for a pulled pork sandwich :(  The fresh produce, the meat, the baked goods...I'm going to have to come back here at some point and just fill my friends trunk full of goodies. It's a shame we don't have anything like this in NY, I think what comes closest is Chelsea Market and that's a laughable comparison. I'd KILL to have this place in my backyard.

So cute.  I thoroughly enjoy coming here and boyfriend was right when he said we would probably be here every weekend if we lived in this place.  It can be very crowded and slow paced (probably partly due to tourists like us) but is a great experience.

Don't exactly remember all the specific names, but here are some great places to try out:

-Shwarma place: amazing shwarma and they also have delicious berry smoothies here that are so refreshing!

-Nut/Olive Oil places:  these are right by each other near the back and have great products.  The olive oil place, Tubby Olive, offers samples of a bunch of its oils/viniagrettes and the majority of them are just spectacular.  Too bad they are expensive.. very difficult to select which to buy because they are all so good.  My recommendation is to try the White Cranberry and the Mushroom&Sage.

-Fish!  There are several places with fresh fish, including sashimi grade fish, giant shrimps as big as your head, crab legs and some really fresh looking other things.  Very attractive displays.

-Beef Jerky!  Cheese!  These stores are near each other too and have great unique selections and also offer up free samples.  The beef jerky place is especially interesting.

There are tons of other things in here: fresh produce, Japanese restaurant, Italian restaurant, several places offering deli meats, coffees, teas, kitchen supplies, hippie products, candy!  Amish people.  You can spend a good two hours just winding around here looking at things and the time just flies.

I find myself back here every time I am in Philadelphia and just burst with excitement every time I see those Christmas lights and the cow sign.  Such a fun place and I love it!
Great selection of different foods. If your in the Philadelpia area you most check out the Reading Termianl Market. My favorite there is Tony Dinics!

What can I say that hasn't already been said?

This has to be the best market on Earth.  Anything you want is in here, and it's probably excellent.

Do not leave without getting Bassetts ice cream!!

Now this is my kind of place! While I generally dislike Philadelphia, and most of its sports loving constituency, I have a deep and profound respect for their culinary scene. If you are looking for the foundation of the foodie scene, Reading terminal market is probably the best place to start. 
A vast smorgasbord of everything edible as well as non edible.  Amish food stands serving up pretzel wrapped hot dogs, chicken and sausage. Behemoth fish and meat counters that purvey some of the freshest morsels from the sea and land. And then there is Dinic's!
Dinic's is the reason I came here. For those of you not in the know, Dinic's is quite possibly the best Roast Pork and Broccoli Rabe sandwich on the planet. I am not embellishing here. This sandwich transcends mortal cuisine. Since this review is about the Market, I will limit my laud for Dinic's here, and you can read my Yelp review of Dinic's for a more detailed and introspective account of this landmark.
For a great taste of the Philadeplhia scene, drop by the Reading Terminal market and peruse thier wares. You won't be disappointed.

Love this place. Can find all sorts of fantastic food here. It's all kinda expensive, but definitely worth checking out. I forget the names now, but there is some amazing ice cream, bbq ribs, fried chicken, and Dutch apple pies and such here. Definitely miss coming here with friends on weekends.

The Reading Terminal a MUST whether you're visiting Philadelphia or have lived here your entire life. You want Chinese? Boom! they have it. In the mood for a delicious roast pork sandwich? Well you're in luck considering Dinic's has one of the best in the country. Or maybe you want an Amish pretzel, a half rack of ribs and a delicious ice cream cone for desert. What do you know, its all here too. Jokes aside, this place has everything you could want to eat as well as a produce market and small knick knack shops. Make sure you come hungry because you'll leave satisifed and, believe me, you'll want to come back again and again to try everything it has to offer.

Amish breakfast was very tasty they run a counter service.  Around the corner from the Amish place you can find Very good creamy ice cream.  Not quite the same as I remember, but it is worth a trip if in the area.

I once dreamt that I entered a food paradise, where I was surrounded by a palatial assortment of yummy eats and sweet delights.  That in this same place I could get a steaming order of Shanghai soup dumplings, and just as easily turn around and get an Amish-made hand-rolled pretzel, or even some Mediterranean food.  Perhaps instead of the pretzel, I could go for some luxury chocolates or world famous cookies or ice cream.  I dreamt that I'd be in the same place that once found Bizarre Foods host, Andrew Zimmern eating a whole chocolate-dipped, yellow onion.  

In this dreamland of food, I would enjoy the most incredible key lime pudding while sitting in a comfortable little cafeteria, all the while taking in the lovely sounds of a live pianist playing the tune to "Memories" from the Broadway show, Cats.  

All was well with this place.  One wound find produce galore, from jumbo, tiger shrimp at least 4 inches long, to all types of sweet delicacies (Turkish delight, and an exotic pastry called "Burma"), to savory local favorites (Philly cheesesteaks, pulled pork sandwiches), and even some household goods, flowers and jewelry.  

The New Yorker in me wished that this glorious place would be a perfect hybrid cross between Essex Market and Chelsea Markets, boasting of high quality offerings at affordable prices.  How amazing would this be, how glorious would this look.  How swell then, that when I came to my senses, I discovered this was no dream at all, only all this wishful thinking led me to discover Philly's Reading Terminal Market.  

Yes, this food paradise does exist.  And in this magical place, I only had to pay $1.50 for THE most amazing chocolate whoopie pie the size of my outstretched palm (BEILER'S BAKERY, FOR THE WIN).  Just, wow.  

If you're planning a trip to Philly, don't miss out on RTM.  It's a straight forward, down-to-earth food-lovers oasis.
This place is great!!! The variety at Reading Terminal can't be beat. I go here for produce, specialty foods, lunch...you name it, they've got it! If you are a tourist visiting Philly, it's a must
Super busy place with tons of food choices.  Many venders with everything from cheese to meat, ethnic food, bread, coffee, and cookies.  I think this is a must see when visiting Philly.

LOVE everything about this place.

I do groceries here a lot and there is a student discount on ( I think ) Sundays and Wednesdays.

The Amish guy with the fresh juices is great.

CANNOLLIS.

Also did the cooking class here and it was really fun.

Great place to bring people who are visiting!

I hate crowds, I hate people, and I hate lines. But despite that, basically, this is one of my favorite places in the world. As many times as I've been here I still feel like there's always still so much to discover, taste and experience. Some of my favorites are the L. Halteman Family meat and cheese stand, the 4th Street Cookie Company, the honey stand that keeps me in giant vats of honey... The list goes on.
Everything but rutabega exists here.  That means it has everything you would need for a full shopping trip or a quick bite.  Beware of crowds -- it being packed is a good sign though.
I love this place so much. I can buy fresh fruit, cofee, backery here. the most important thing is that the quality is good and price is reasonable.

Many Options
-Great for any tourists to visit or non-tourists
-Varieties of Food
-Great Atmosphere

I love this place!  The dutch pickle place in the far corner makes the best spicy pickles.  The Dutch Eating Place is a great for breakfast, and the Turkey sandwich stand makes a turkey, cranberry, and stuffing sandwich (Thanksgiving on a roll, to Jersey-ites) that is amazing.  There are crafts, and lots of knick-knacks to browse.  If you're a "cheese-head", like I am, stop at Downtown Cheese.

Iovine Brothers is as cheap as grocery gets!

Best thai food
Baked good you can spend a whole month on
Bassetts!
Famous Dinics Sandwich [i dont like it though]
Italian food at George's
and endless Meat, cheese and fish
Live piano music

Just go. You can take me with you too if you like. This is my Friday rehab after work.
The best spot foodie spot in Philly. A fun experience with an abundance of extra delicious and well-priced food.

I love going to food markets, such as this one because I feel there are so many hidden gems in every corner. Back in NY, I really adore Essex Street Market and Chelsea Market, but this one was even better! There were so many vendors and different foods to choose from. The different aroma from fresh seafood to pizza to brisket sandwiches just filled the air and left me salivating each time I turned the corner.

This market was pretty packed on a weekend, yet still very spacious. I loved how there's many seating areas throughout the market. The New Yorker in me wished this market would stay open around dinner time and open on Sundays as well. Nonetheless, I know I will return!

Every city should have a reading terminal... but it will never be as good as Philly's. 

GO -- get lost in Reading Terminal... Graze on bites from this stand or that. I love that you can get Amish beef jerky, delectable Thai or Shawarma, sweet treats by the piece or by the pound... and one of a kind goods. 

Don't forget about the shoe shine by the restrooms... best shine for the price I've ever had. And fast.

I love this indoor Farmer's market!

It's filled with an eclectic medley of food from all over the world (and all very tasty!), fresh veggies, fruit, meat, seafood and kitchen gadgets.  In the mood for a full on Thanksgiving dinner?  You got it!  An infamous D'Nics pork sammie that almost always sell out before closing?  Yup, you can find that here.  How about a chocolate covered raw onion?  They have that too.

You get the gist.  You name it, they have it!

Just a FYI: everything Amish is closed on Sundays due to holiday.

Once again, thank you 'Redding' Terminal Market. Hurricane Sandy forced me to stay in a hotel around the corner, and only you offered fresh eats on the fly. The Mezze mediterranean lasagna was hearty and flavorful, but their salmon a bit overcooked. I also picked up a lb of super chewy cookies from one of their bakeries (ugh, can't remember the name and am too lazy to walk over to the table to look at their bag). That's what happens when you can't decide, stuck in a long line, and a baby strapped to your chest. So far, I've had the pumpkin, the turtle, and starting my way into the macadamia nut...mmm.

Reading Terminal Market is a nice spot in Philadelphia to take your family when you just want to get away. I live in Trenton NJ and there is no place like Reading Terminal Market anywhere near here. I love the Terminal but I wish they would expand their walking space because Saturday traffic in the Terminal is bumper to bumper.

I didn't try EVERYTHING inside, but I definitely ate as much as I could. I stopped by Dinic's Roast Beef and Pork. Asked the waitress what was most popular and had at it! Finished off with some desert at Basset's, had some Banana flavored ice cream which I absolutely loved, but the heat outside made it impossible to eat all of that heavy cream. I'm sure Philly natives would say they're bored with this place as I would say of Times Square, but it was/is new to me and I can't wait to go back!

This place is basically an awesome indoor farmers market. You literally have everything you could possibly want in one place. 

It has a very old style feel while also having that edgy vibe that only Philly can give you. They have fresh seafood, sandwiches, Thai food and whatever else you can possible think of. I went to the coffee shop in and sat at a table with my GF, while enjoying the sights of the market and all it had to offer.

This place is pretty awesome for either having a meal in a market atmosphere or simply doing some shopping in a place where you have literally every option you can think of. Definitely will be making it a point to come here more often when I'm in Philly.

Love Reading Terminal Market.  A lot of variety to choose from at decent prices.  Farmer's Market, Dutch Amish baked goods/ pretzels, Crepes, Greek, chocolate/cookies, wine, take your pick, they probably have it!  Go, get lost in it and you'll find something you love.  

FYI, if you park in the lot at 12th and Filbert, take your parking ticket in and have it validated at a vendor and you'll get $4 for 2 hrs in the parking garage!

Has pretty much everything you could ask for.

Gyros ... roast pork sandwiches (yes yes Dinic's ... thanks Adam Richman) ... cookies ... chocolate ... produce ... Chinese food ... ice cream ... everything is pretty much here! 

The only downside and the reason it doesn't get a 5 star review? All the tourists that manage to simply stop in the middle of the crammed walkways ... either go into the stall or move on please!

Seriously, what's NOT to love about this place? The food choices are endless and authentic. Sweet, savory, cheesy, meaty, vegetarian... you name it, it's there. If I'm ever in Philly again, I will definitely be going back.
Shop. Market. Eat. The best! It's NOT just for tourists. Hotspur

There are so many things to eat and see and buy here. I like taking out-of-town friends to this location, setting them free, and telling them to buy food until they burst. The only thing that I always forget to take into account is the hours--it's best to go around lunchtime or the afternoon, because the Terminal closes at dinnertime. In addition, it can get a little crowded, as space is at a premium here. Be prepared to maneuver delicately.

Must stop at: the Asian smoothie place near Bassett's (another must-stop). The Termini Brothers satellite shop and the Fourth Street cookie place. Also at DiNic's (obviously). Oh, and there is a great Middle Eastern place called Kamal's, as well as a fantastic creperie a few aisles away. Finally, the Lancaster merchants always have amazing baked goods (like cinnamon buns!).
Can't think of a better place to get produce and meat !!! So Fresh, Great Variety and well priced...

My husband and I wanted more of a nontraditional wedding venue, with amazing food, and room to dance the night away.  That is exactly what we got at Reading Terminal Market.  Planning with Stormy was easy and laid back.  She was a treat to work with, and was always available to answer my questions.  

No words can describe the experience that my husband and I had on our wedding day!!! The staff was so incredibly kind and helpful, and everyone from vendors to waitstaff seemed happy to be there.  It was amazing to see the market transform into the wedding of our dreams in just an hour!  Every detail that I asked for was perfectly executed.  It was amazing to see my vision come to life.

Our guests had an amazing time too.  I really think they appreciated a change from the normal wedding venue.  They were in awe of the markets transformation and everyone raved about the food!!! My only complaint is that my husband and I didn't eat a thing!  We were too busy celebrating!  Luckily Stormy sent us home with a doggie bag!

Cheers to RTM!!
I love this place! It's always so vibrant and full of neat things to see, buy, and eat. Pro tip: I like to go pick up some spices and fresh produce before splurging on an ice cream cone.
This place is uh-mazing. I want to eat all the things.

A 2lb Steamed Lobster with drawn butter for $15! 

Hell Yea!

Business meeting at the hotel across the street, came here twice. The seafood counters mostly sell to take home, but ask and ye shall receive. Ordered my lobster and 15 minutes later chowed it down at the dine in table opposite the merchant.
Carmen's Cheesesteaks are amazing.  They are located inside of Redding Terminal and Michelle is very friendly and welcoming.

Reminds me of the Lexington Market in Baltimore... but so much cleaner! I love this place. I wish I could find a little back room and set up a little apartment. I'd eat here all the time. You'll find all your quick fast foods here (but healthier and tastier). Lots of ethnic foods as well as various American favorites. You can also find some Amish stores in the back of the market and pastries that will beckon you. Every time I come to Philadelphia, I must make a stop by here! It does get a little crowded and forget about finding seating during lunch time, but most of these places have ample seating during non rush hour! My favorite places are Amy's in the back where you can buy great kitchen supplies, the fresh produce, the "peking" duck section where you can buy Chinese BBQ pork and roast duck. My favorite! They also have a great crepe place and ice cream parlor. Well worth the trip! No parking here. You must walk or take the train.

Overwhelming and packed with people.  Yet, the huge variety of great fresh made food make up for it.  We had food from the pretzel place, the dutch market, and the crepe place.  The cheesesteak pretzel was amazing.

Go for the sassy cookie girls at The Famous 4th Street Cookie Company, stay for the claustrophobia and panic attacks (they're character building, don't let anyone ever tell you differently.)

If you're really trying to impress someone, and you are, treat them to the hot wings at Frank's. Anyone willing to navigate those gigantic meat monsters in front of you is a keeper. 

Oh, and Olde City Coffee once let a frazzled, cash-strapped friend pay them on I.O.U. which was really nice. My friend paid the next day, but she remained frazzled. That's neither here nor there.

If you're not into slow-walkers, avoid. Unless you get an hour-long lunch. In which case, where you work, boo?

Great place but I really have to be in the mood. Cramped, crowed, touristy gourmet, over priced foods. Some good deals here and there but I think it's the name and history that sells it. Fresh and organic items everywhere!!  Love the Home Diner!! A trendy traveler's or urban socialite's dream come true!

Whenever I visit Philadelphia, I run as fast as possible to this market.  I dream of it.  I wish it was in NYC.

I don't think I've ever had a bad meal here.  My favorites are Franks-A-Lot, The Original Turkey, Little Thai Market, Famous 4th Street Cookie Co, Termini Bros, The Dutch Eating Place and Beiler's Bakery.  Of all of them, don't miss the Amish stalls surrounding Dutch Eating Place and Beiler's.

I wish I could be at Reading Market all the time.  What others have said about the crowds is right.  This place is standing room only, mosh pit crazy, rush hour subway ride crowded and it's not an over statement.  So hold on to all your patience and jump into the scene.

I love getting lost in the market. It is so much fun just to wander up and down the aisles and see what catches your eye. Sometimes it can be a bit overwhelming, but I love doing it. Famous 4th Street cookie right at the front is famous for a reason so stop by. However, there are some days when the Amish stores are not open so you may have to make a second trip on a day they are. 

I recommend a visit.

I liked Reading Terminal Market, but if you don't know what you're looking for, it can be a bit overwhelming.  Case in point...all I wanted was a quick meal, but food is scattered through the market and I really couldn't tell what was good...I think I was too hungry to wander through and really decide what I wanted.  

I stopped for some crab cakes, which were good, but I wish I would have had more time to explore!

Definitely worth a walk through, but give yourself more than 30 min total (including eating!)

One of the best parts of living in Philadelphia. Local, fresh, handmade- It's all here. RTM is a genuine marketplace, vibrant and alive. Get to see your city first hand bumping into each other and jostling your way around a buzzing market. Turn shopping into an adventure, support your local vendors and try something new. Reading Terminal is amazing.

Reading Terminal Market is an integral part of Philadelphia's culture and history.  You will find wonderful restaurants and vendors throughout the market and a truly unique atmosphere.  If you are in town for even one day, come check it out around lunch time; you won't be disappointed.  For those of you whining on Yelp about it being crowded, please stop embarrassing yourself.  Its a 150 + year old market in the middle of one of the largest cities in the USA; it's supposed to be busy.

This place is a double whammy for me. I'm a huge foodie and I'm into trains. I could have eaten myself into bankruptcy and a coma here. The historical tidbits on the wall were interesting for my train nerd side, but the food...OMG.

I agree with the recent reviewer who wishes this place were in New York - then I could frequent it more often. It really reminds me of the exhibition buildings at the Big E (the New England equivalent of a State Fair) with all the delicious food.

Wander, try everything. Don't eat yourself into a food coma!

Love this place. Best times to go are off times. Had one of the best breakfasts at the Dutch Eating Place last week around 10:30 (on break from jury duty a block away). Today, had a cheesesteak at Carmen's -- still a wait for the food, but there was seating and time for banter with the staff.
Nice Variety of Food!!!

This is a must visit for locals and tourists a like.  It's a great spot for lunch, to purchase meat and produce or crafts.  They are open every day; but the best days to go are later in the week as that is when the entire place is open.  There is a great sections with Amish farmers that prepare homemade pretzels and great sandwhiches.
Like my review is gonna make a difference ;) Outstanding and delicious.

If you haven't been to the market yet, get there! It's got everything you could possibly need/want. Fish, meat, produce, wine, chocolate, sushi, smoothies, ice creams, salads, cheesesteaks, pizza, Amish stuff, honey store, kitchen store, Cajun, Chinese, turkey-centered, cookies, baked goods, whew- the list is truly endless. 

If you want to go to be seen and fight the crowds, go at lunch time. There's also a piano player in the center and group table seating open to all. 

If you want to save a few bucks, use your Level Up! Lots of the vendors participate in it within the market.

If you are going for the Amish baked goods, they're closed on Monday. Otherwise, go early and try their apple fritters- yum! The donuts are pretty good, too. The cakes and pies are just meh. 

Tootsie's Salad Express is pretty decent for a pay-by-weight salad bar with way more than just salads (think Chinese food). 

There is also a great little spice store in here that is great and also has a fantastic coffee bean selection. The people who work here are super helpful, too. 

There's also a bar in there, so if you're in mixed company and someone would rather have a beer than fight the crowd, well, there' truly is something for everyone!

THE place to go in Philly for foodies and for high-quality ingredients.  All kinds of shops and food vendors in this place; if there's something that you want food-wise, it's likely that you'll be able to find it all under this one roof.  The location is really cool, too; it's an old train station that has been turned into this awesome foodie paradise.  If you love food and are visiting/live in Philly, this is a must-go place!

Hungry?

One must head here if in the area.  We walked over from The Walnut for lunch.  There's something for every taste.  Oh, how I wish this is something that was more readily available to us!

I have a love/hate relationship with Reading Terminal Market...more specifically... i hate the crowds and everyone else knowing how amazing it is. It has every option you could possibly want for lunch. From cheesesteaks, greek, thai food, mexican, and a salad bar. 

Fair warning: Fridays the terminal is insanely crowded. If you are not a tourist, I'd avoid it unless you love crowds and people walking around aimlessly with no clue where they are going!
I love Reading Terminal at the Holidays.  What a great day today shopping for food and gifts for my family and friends.

Got their at 345pm and DaNics was already closed and I really wanted to try the pork rabe. So I went next door to Hershel and had the reuben special. OMG it was so good and I was stuffed until the next morning. Paid about $9 for food, drink and tip. Great place and lots of other neat shops in this place. Next time I fly to Philly I'll go back and maybe get there in time for the pork rabe!

Four stars only because of its closing time (6pm).  It takes a bit too long to get there unless you really work next door.  The alternative is wading through the weekend crowd.  So even a half hour extra (6:30) would make a huge difference.

Otherwise, it's just perfect.

Reading terminal market is FULL of FOOD. (A lot of great food and a lot of average food).
Great produce. Delicious sandwiches. Hershels!!! mmm.
Great chocolate! at Chocolate by Mueller! A little overwhelming at first and can be crowded, but amazing. Plenty of seating.
Everytime I bring my ass to Philly, to see the fam, I roll by Reading Terminal. I love this place. It be cheap here too!

This is one of the many places you HAVE to visit if you are touring Philadelphia. Old world charm in a high tempo retail/food service environment. Delicious prepared foods, fruits and veggies, baked goods, and Dutch-Amish staple products.

There is literally everything one could want here.

Always a staple for when friends or relatives from out of town come for a visit. Good cheesesteaks, coffee, flowers, meats and cheeses. Can't stay too long, or my claustrophobia-introvert freaks out a little (i.e. it gets really crowded on weekends).

I could spend hours walkin through this mega market if it weren't for the hords of people in my way.  But, seriously, this is a great foodie mecca.  Do try the pork sandwich at Dinic's and a fresh filled cannoli from Termini Bros. There are a number of tempting other spots, including fresh pies, fudge stands, ice cream, crepes and lots of other delights.  Try to go with someone else to split the job of hunting a table while the other person stays on line.  While lines may look long, they do move rather quickly.
I get the appeal - this place is awesome! Just about every type of food with delectable Dutch-Amish shops!

Who doesn't love Reading Terminal Market? I worked there for 2 years and also lead a food tour through this location learning about the history, past and present.

Not only are all the vendors local but they are required to serve everything fresh. I worked at Hershel's and they literally cook their meat for 14 hours before serving it and slicing it up fresh in the market. There are tons of Philly gems here including DiNIcs, Carmen's, Bassetts, Famous 4th Street Cookies, Flying Monkey and Delilahs'.

The produce there is fresh and often times cheaper than if you were to get it in a supermarket. The seafood and fresh meats that you can purchase at the market are unbelievably fresh and at moderate prices. It's one of the only places I can go to as a one-stop shop for preparing a meal.

I try to go to Reading Terminal during the week as it gets PACKED during the weekends. The Amish vendors are there from Wednesday through Saturday. As a Lancaster County girl, I'd definitely recommend trying out some of their food if you can get them (especially the Rib Stand).

I honestly can't rave enough about this place. Just come with patience. It's tourist central, and for good reason.

Who does not love this place? Every corner is filled with food and things to drool over. I've been here a couple of times and each time you end up trying something new. Sometimes I wish I lived nearby so that I could take advantage of all their fresh produce. 

I highly recommend Bassetts. DiNic's was pretty good too. The Spice/tea/coffee shop near the bookstore is really of great value!

Wow! Never seen such a stunning place! Its awesome and breathtaking! Im a tourist coming up from Germany and I never saw something like that in Europe...  we are saying  "Da bleiben keine Wünsche offen!"

The culinary heartbeat of Philadelphia. If I could only eat under one roof for the rest of my life, it would be here. The selection is overwhelming, the energy is high, and the competition for your dollar is cut-throat.

A wonderful market right next to the Market East train stop. Lots of wonderful vendors with many types of food. Asian, Middle Eastern, American, Bakeries, Coffee, and lots more. It is always crowded and difficult to find seating, but totally worth it. I also enjoy browsing the store-type vendors such as books, spices, and hand-made gifts. I have never went wrong with anything I have bought/eaten here. Yum, yum yum!!

So I came here for DiNic's and left here feeling like I wished I had planned a whole day here. Being someone that loves to eat, I could see myself slipping into a pair of sweatpants and spending an entire day here eating. 

You name it, you've got it. That is pretty much the best way to explain the Reading Terminal Market. You can come here for groceries as they have what looked to be an extensive produce section, or you can get meats, seafood, or just about anything else you would need to make a top notch dinner at home. Now there are also restaurants here where you can order food and then eat in one of the seating areas located in the market. There is such a diverse choice of ethnic foods here and I would like to try all of them. Some of them I noticed on my quick trip here were an Indian, Japanese, Chinese, Middle Eastern, and Cajun. There is also a bar, if you prefer to drink your meals.  I was not prepared for all the places located in this market, so I was a little overwhelmed as I saw all the different places to choose from.  

I think I might just have to plan a day trip to the Reading Terminal Market and see if I can eat my way out of here!

Food lovers paradise. This place is incredible, unlike any other place I've frequented in the US. They have everything foodie related here, whether you want a quick bite to eat, full meal or something to cure your sweet tooth they have a ton of options here. There is this dutch diner, can't remember the name but if you have the patience to wait I think you should go. While I didn't get to go because I was pressed for time if the lines were any indication of how good the food is then you should definitely check it out! I did get to eat at DiNic's and I loved it so much that I came here the following day!

Oh Reading Terminal. How you make me wish I was a better foodie and could handle myself better in crowds. 

Reading Terminal is the only place I must take out of town visitors when they're in Philly. No, not the liberty bell. Not the Rocky statue. Not Pats or Genos. This place.

Something about being able to say "I'm going to the market" and coming home with freshly butchered meat, local produce, artisan cheeses, fresh bread, and a bouquet of flowers makes me feel like I'm in a different time and a different country.

Oh and that little kitchen gaget shop? Gets me for at least $15 every time...

Can't get any better when it comes to a great variety of food. Also, great for produce and meat/poultry/seafood shopping - so convenient if you live in Center City and aren't near a grocery store! Only slight problem is how crowded it can get around lunch time, and around times when the Convention Center has a big event.

We LOVE Reading Terminal Market! We shop Iovine Brothers for all of our produce...Giunta's for local, good quality meats...The Head But for spices and coffee...you name it, you can probably get it here!  A fantastic alternative to Big Box Stores!!! A great place four tourists and locals alike.  It's always packed but that's the beauty of it.  A true community vibe. Great for lunch, a snack, or a treat! I hope it's still around for me to take my kids to some day!

With 799 reviews already, does the Yelp world really need an 800th review of Reading Terminal Market? Sorry, but I couldn't resist.

There's so much going on in here, so block out a couple of hours of your day to explore up and down the numerous aisles of assorted goods. Word of advice: if you don't want to eat here, don't show up hungry. Not one bit! You'll never make it. There are too many vendors selling everything from fruits and vegetables, to chocolate and cookies, to meat and beer. Notice how it just gets better and better? And that doesn't even include the actual, sit-down sandwich and food places.

If you work your way through the entire market maze and found you haven't purchased a thing, even to take home, then you're a liar. That's also impossible. So just accept it, have fun, people watch and leave with a lighter wallet. Don't worry, everybody's doing it.

My wife and I ate at the Reading Terminal Market twice. The first time, we ate at aand Amish spot run by a Mr. Smucker. The pot roast sandwich was delicious.

The second time we ate at Pearl's Oyster Bar. My wife had a crab cake sandwich and I had an oyster po' boy. Both were good, but not great.

We also shared an ice cream cone from Basset's: quite good.

My wife and I went to Philadelphia for a tour with reading terminal market being our first stop. It also ended up being our last stop. When we first arrived around 10am and looked around. We were astounded by what was inside. Everything you can think of could be found in here. We have nothing remotely close to this from where we live so this was a welcome surprise. We did some shopping before/during the tour and since we parked really close by we knew we were going to come back. We ended up coming back after a late lunch and shopped some more. We even stopped by the bar for a drink or two. The place was wonderful and I can't wait until we can get back there.

There are some excellent choices here at Reading Terminal Market-- but be wise as to which place you decide to eat at. Some eateries are just sloppy fast good on the go, and others are good eats. Check out the plates around you-- there are so many choices!
I love everything about the reading terminal, but I love the diversity of the food the most, This market is a must for tourist!

Pricey, Good, but not great.  A must try as an institution.  Solid food, Try DiNic's.  Its good, but not the best.  As an institution you must try it.  Def check out the wine store in there, and all the sweets shops.  There is motorcycle parking nearby, but if you park on the sidewalk near a bike rack, they won't ticket you.
Awesome place, ive only been here once but i must say i loved it! Great food, nice people and lots of things to try....the only thing that sucks is how crowded it is!

Haven't you figured it out by now?  

Any place that has over 800 reviews, and is able to maintain 4 1/2 stars with all of those reviewers, is worth going to.  In fact, I'm shocked that anyone in their right mind would give this place only 4 stars.  

No, seriously, stop reading these reviews and just get your ass over there.  You'll thank us later!  

Because if you can't find something you want to eat at Reading Terminal Market, then you just don't like food.  Really, give it up and just go on a liquid diet or something.
By far the best destination for great eats in Philadelphia. Inexpensive casual and best of all local!

I haven't been here in awhile whereas I used to go weekly to shop. Well, now i would like to go weekly again. They have added new tenants and updated the bathrooms. I love a lot of the vendors and if you go with a bunch of people , they have something for everyone. weekends is packed, so, if you have to go then, my advise is early. I went during the week after 8am. I could even get breakfast at some places. Not all vendors are open early or on Sundays, but, it's worth a trip whenever you go.....prepare to be overwhelmed. This is a cool place for shopping....

This place is crowd, noisy, aromatic, and I just love it. So many food to pick, and everything is so worth it. I think I can spend the whole day here but then my stomach would not be very happy with me, neither would my wallet.

How could you not give this place 5 stars?

It's freakin' awesome! 

Having lived in Memphis for many years, it took me a minute to get into the flow. This place is busy, and people move with purpose. I had to shift into "East Coast" mode---which means I sharpened my elbows, quickened my pace, and stopped getting flustered when the little Asian girls walk under my elbows in their quest to buy pretzels.

There's no time to mess around, so get your order in place before you get to the front of the lines. 

You can get anything you want in here. Hundreds of food stands means thousands of choices. I opted for the icons----soft pretzels and a Cheesesteak. They were delicious.

If I lived around this market, I would be here every day. Fresh Seafood, Meat, Sausages, Cheeses, Produce, and Vegetables would make your cooking as fresh as you could afford. 

Whether you want to sit down and join in the fun, or carry some food out the door, this market will be fun for everyone.

Love this place.  Great place to pick up produce, meat, baked goods, or a fully-cooked meal.  I like the variety, quality, and price of produce and meat here.  And while you're there, grab a meal from any of the amazing restaurants.  The crowds of gawking tourists can be pretty annoying at lunchtime.  I prefer to go at the end of the day, when it's less crowded.
Even though it's becoming a prepared food tourist attraction, the Amish & few old standbys still make it a worthwhile stop...

The Amish stands on their own are worth a trip - unfortunately these stands are only open wed-sat so plan your trip accordingly - specifically to miller's twist for a soft and buttery pretzel - yummy yummy!!
Had a cheesesteak that was awesome. Also went to George's where the tortellini was also terrific. Village of food. There is definitely something to find to eat for even the pickiest of eaters.

The Reading Terminal Market is awesome. I have been at a conference at the conference center above the market all week. I've had a number of meals there, and they have all been great. The ingredients are fresh, the preparation is good...  What's not to love. If you're in Philly, you should certainly stop by.

The lioness and I love this place.  If we ever moved to Philly I would recommend living in this market.  You just need to fabricate a bed somewhere and use the public restrooms for showering.  This place has everything you can ever dream of.  It was so amazing we ate here two days in a row.  I hate repeating places to eat while on vacation but this place had so many things to try.  I wish the Ferry Building in SF could be as cool as this place.

From hot meals to handmade ice cream, fresh pastries to local fruits and vegetables, ethnic cuisine to cookies and chocolate -- Philly's famed Reading Terminal Market brings together food from around the world. It's a veritable garage sale, featuring a million things from a million different cultures as well as delicious locally-sourced foods, ranging from Italian truffle oil to German sausages to local Whoopie Pies. One could spend an entire day just exploring the whole place. If you're feeling daring, try one of their famous chocolate-covered onions!

RTM's fame as a city landmark is undoubtedly well-deserved. But beneath its bustling facade lies a much more sinister truth -- that a surprising proportion of its shops and stalls hawk low-quality wares, catering to the daily hordes of brainless tourists who grace its halls. Buyer beware; Kamal's Middle Eastern is abominable. Market Bloom's flowers are rarely fresh. Items that could be found at a grocery store tend to be of equal or lesser quality, and horribly overpriced to boot. Meat by the pound? Don't even think about it.

That said, RTM is a must-see for out-of-town-ers. Just be cautious, and make sure you've got an empty stomach!
Good quality food, bakery, coffee and other stuff. LOVE this place!

This place is awesome. I literally spent 3 days here and kept finding new things! I also spent those same 3 days eating here every meal and barely made a dent in all the places you could eat. What a shame. I can't wait to come back here with a cooler so I can transport all sorts of good things back to Virginia with me! This place was best described by another reviewer as the "Disneyland/world for foodies." Spot on.

If I'm ever wondering what to get for lunch in Philly and I'm close to Reading Terminal Market, I head here. There are so many options, and regardless of what I've chosen, I've never been disappointed. One of my favorite things that I've found here is homemade ginger lemonade. It's so delicious!

LOVE this place!!! 

What's not to love about?? You can find EVERYTHING you need, and everything you don't!!! 

The worst part about this place is trying to narrow down what you're going to eat because there are so many great options - save room for a Fluffernutter cupcake from Flying Monkey Bakery! 

Asian food, ice cream, Philly Cheesesteaks, Beer, Wine, Olive Oil, fresh produce, salami, cheese, Amish people, hippy stuff, smoothies...Why haven't you been here yet?!? 

Best tip I can offer (other than aforementioned Fluffernutter cupcake) is to try to avoid peak eating times (like noon - 1pm and 4-5pm)

It's fun to walk around Reading Terminal Market to view all the restaurants and food markets.  If you work in the area it's a fun diversion to go over at lunch-time to walk around and choose lunch from one of the many vendors.  I also enjoy taking visitors to Philly here.

Wow.  OINK!  Foodie heaven baby!  I've been here only twice, but can't wait to go back and explore more.  I was introduced to this wonderland by my partner who is from Philly.  It's a fresh market and food court with anything & everything and then some.

Delilah's - I was sad to hear of their closing.  Fried chicken was huge, crispy & juicy.  Greens were damn good, mac & cheese okay and the catfish super tender.

Termini Bros Bakery - We've picked up several cakes from them.  It's good but I"m not a dessert foodie.

A.J. Pickle Patch - Just wanted to try something from them while browsing.  The pickles are good!  All kinds of varieties.  

Tommy DiNiC's is on my radar, courtesy of course of Triple D.  Hopefully in September when we're back again!

I'm not saying anything that hasn't been said a hundred times before, but this place is awesome.  I just wish it was open later so I could eat dinner there too when I'm in town because there are so many options.  This is a must anytime I am in the area.

It can get crowded at lunch, so be prepared to wait in line for some of the best stuff.

So if you know me, you know I'm always bitching about food in America, specifically groceries in America. I think our grocery stores are depressing at best. I want to cry when I walk into certain grocery stores (*cough* SuperFresh) and pay way too much for limp "veggies" I wouldn't feed my llama and grey "meat" I wouldn't feed my dog, or that over processed crap that looks and tastes like a sawdust/toilet paper hybrid. I also don't enjoy paying $6 for an apple, WHOLE FOODS. UGH.

This is why I love Reading Terminal. In most other countries in the world, you buy FRESH, LOCAL food from MARKETS. And you don't spend your whole paycheck on it!!! This place is our answer to that. 

Reading Terminal is a brilliant indoor market in a really cool, historic building, just blocks from Chinatown, Old City, the Convention Center, and Center City. It's my go-to place to buy veggies (from Iovine's), lunch meat (from Reihl's Deli), and various meat and fish from the butchers scattered throughout. 

The prices are cheap. The produce is  fresh. What's not to love?! 

OH!!!!! And did I mention, it's like a giant food court, with plenty of vendors selling everything from sushi, Thai, and Chinese, to Middle Eastern pastries, Cajun, and Italian (that pizza place across from Iovine's makes the best meat balls and mediterranean pizza! HUGE lunch for $6.)?? There are several bakeries, including an Amish bakery and Le Bus. I worked 2 blocks away for a year, and I would almost always get lunch or breakfast in Reading Terminal. Whatever you're in the mood for, you can find it here!! 

A lot of the places in there are Amish owned and operated so you get some great, homecooked food and local produce without driving down to Lancaster. There are also cool little shops like the honey store and the wine shop that sell various trinkets.
Love this place. Great variety. Book store is awesome. Try a cheesesteak or roast pork at Dominics

Reading Terminal is good with tons of different foods to choose from! I do  think it is over priced & hard to find a place to eat during lunch times. Vegan options are limited. However, everyone in Philly needs to go here a few times. Watch out for the numerous pan handlers though!

Five stars for the amazing stands it has, the great produce, and how fun it can be to go there. Not every stand is five stars (or even close, really), but in the end, it is one of the best in-door markets in any city in the entire United States. It's not just a tourist attraction, if you ask me. My favorite stand is DeNic's.

Whenever we are in Philly this is a must stop. We always go to Dinic's which has hands down the best sandwiches I have ever had in my life and we also have Bassets Ice cream. Oh lord fatty ice cream heaven. If you get your parking ticket stamped by any vender in the terminal you only pay $2 for 2 hours. Great deal! Love this place!

This is one of my most favorite places in Philly- if you haven't been you need to drop everything and go now. From fresh cheap produce, deli and seafood counters and spice shops for the chef in you, to some of the best food I've ever had in my life.

The Original Turkey place provides real off the bone thanksgiving-esque turkey from meals w your fav home style sides like Mac n cheese, greens or mashed tators, homemade turkey soup, turkey salad to the classic turkey sandwich on a variety of fresh breads w tons of great toppings to chose from. Did I mention you can get a 1/2 sandwich, which is huge, chips and a drunk for under $7? It's unreal!

The Amish stands are a huge treat but are closed Sundays and Mondays- from pretzels 10xs better than Philly pretzel or auntie Anne's, a bakery with fresh sticky buns, whoopie pies and cakes, and then their sit down diner style restaurant with chicken and waffles, great burgers and the best chicken corn soup! 

If your into sweets The Flying Monkey delivers but don't forget crepes, dipped cookies, fresh made chocolate, and the Italian bakery w the best carrot cake I've over had-sorry I don't know all the proper names--- you can't go wrong here. My only negative and it's not even bad but Dinnicks roast pork is not my favorite- drive to tony Luke's and skip the cheesesteak and go right for their roast pork w sharp Provo and broc rain!

Also the garage on 12th offers a $4 parking special if you have a business in the Terminal validate your ticket!

Awesome, wonderful place.  There is something here for everyone. If you are in the mood for anything from Thai curry to chocolate covered onions, it is sold somewhere in this Market.  I would suggest Sang Kee Peking Duck Wonton Soup, Dutch Eating Place, Bassetts Ice Cream, and DiNic's Roast Pork Sand which (featured on Man vs. Food).
