The building itself offers restrooms and three separate seating areas to enjoy your goodies (FYI, they get filled very quickly).

Also, be sure to hit the Market on a Tuesday - Saturday because the Amish stores are closed on Sunday and Monday and they are definitely a must-try!

Let me start off by saying, if you have grown up in the tri state area, or more specifically in south jersey and other philly suburbs and you havent been to the reading terminal market, i must tell you that you are missing out on one of the most classic philly staples that has been or will ever be.   I could go on for days listing the stalls and vendors that need go be hit from fresh fruit and veg to the best bacon and meats in this whole area, but i won't.  I will simply tell you about the one sandwich that actually changed the way in approach my weekends.   

Dinic's stand at the terminal market is one of those spots that you need to know when to hit it.  If you hi at the wrong time, you could be waiting for a bit and your hunger will grow exponentially as you see the roast pork with gravy and beatiful garlicky greens being slathered between the best bread in town.  If you were me, you would be getting there around 10 AM to avoid the craziest traffic and you would be getting the non Roast Pork Sandwich, The Brisket of Beef with long hots which i can say, hands down the best sandwich in this market and prpbly in the top 3 in the entire city including Johns Roast Pork and Paesanos.    

Just go to the reading terminal market, be nice to the vendors and someone will definately validate your parking taking it from 20 to a measly 4 dollars.  Go, explore, and go again, you could never taste and see it all.  I beseech you, go. Its worth the trip.

If you are particular about your food and knowing where it comes from, or that it's of good quality, I can't imagine you will like this place.  It's basically an indoor market with purveyors of produce, meat and fish (I saw no evidence of anything being organic, free-range, antibiotic-free etc.) with the majority of places there selling what is essentially fast food (even though the names of the prepared food vendors are not readily recognizable like Pizza Hut, Wendy's etc., it still has that fast-food feel.  Blech.)

If you ever knew Haymarket in Boston back in the 80s/90s, or if you know Essex Street Market in Manhattan today, that's essentially what this place is like.   I was not about to buy anything at this place.  It felt depressed, gross and dirty.

The open-seating dining area felt like something you might find at an old baseball stadium....mainly people just stuffing their faces with food, but not SAVORING the food like people who appreciate find cuisine would do.  All in all, not a nice environment for foodies.  If you like going to street carnivals, sporting events, and eating the cotton candy, hot dogs, fried dough etc., I'm sure you'll like this place just fine.  ;-)

Awesome market with a lot of good spots for food!  

If you're ever in Philly, you should definitely visit.

A place that needs no reviewing, it has been an integral part of Philadelphia since the city's founding.  

For produce I recommend Iovine's, everything is so fresh and affordable!  Coming here is a true highlight of my week and it makes every meal a little better

Termini has the best cannolis, I like the vanilla with chocolate chips.

Go to Beck's Cajun Cafe if you're really hungry and enjoy the best hoagie you will ever have the "train-wreck po boy" with Andouille Sausage, Steak meat, Salami, Onions, and Cheese!  It's like a cheese-steak for champions!

Reading Terminal Market should definitely be on your to-do list if you're visiting Philly!  Everything you can think of is here...all different kinds of food from sandwiches to meat to sushi to pasta to crepes to everything!! Very good candy shops too!!

Nice place to buy food but I find it to be more of a tourist trap. I prefer other areas of Philly for my Italian food. Defiantly a must stop for people visiting Philly but not what I would recommend for the locals. Great crapes for breakfast.

If you're hungry but not sure what you're craving, and you want to also grab some produce on the run, go here.

If your elbows are sharp and you're ready for a crowd, go during the weekday lunch rush.

A definite Philly staple, no matter how you look at it.

If you are from Philly or out of town...tough to beat such a condensed bunch of winners.

Hershels, Beck's, Dinics, 4th St Cookie, Rib Stand (Most underrated sandwich in Philly), Milller's Twist, By George, Chocolates by Mueller, Termini Bros, Ochs, Godshalls, Iovine Produce....All straight up winners.  

You could go to the terminal everyday for a year and never eat the same meal twice.  Most for under $10.

Great place for a non foodie to learn and appreciate different styles, and get familiar with classics.

Every city should be so lucky....now if the City of Phila would only imvest in Market East and make that neighborhood shine!

name of the game: Variety.

i like this place because you can get just about anything you want...if you have picky friends and can't decide on a restaurant, just bring them here. 
highlights: 4th st. cookie (huge cookies...you're bound to break out after having ONE), ice cream....they give you so much...so make sure you share, amish pretzels, rib stand...

Admittedly, my standard for city markets is pretty high, using Seattle's Pike Place Market as the benchmark against which all others will be compared.  Philly's Reading Terminal Market holds its own against this lofty standard.  While not nearly as large as Pike Place Market, it still holds a solid variety of vendors, from butcher shops to fishmongers to fresh produce and other vendors that make it an actual working market not a tourist trap with a bunch of kiosks selling souvenirs and other Made in China crap.  Of note, the Sunday early afternoon crowd definitely seemed to be made up with a lot more tourists compared to the Monday crowd, as it was considerably less crowded and chaotic on a regular workday.  Reading Terminal Market also offers a numerous food counters serving a wide array of regional and international cuisines from which you can sample.  It can get very congested with customers/tourists especially around lunchtime in large part due the place being packed with vendor stalls and narrow aisles between them.  However, it's worth your time to check it out.

Quick and simple- reading terminal is finally upgrading, bringing in new amenities, and they have some great new storefronts and eateries. The good places are even getting better. I can't wait to see what else they have in store for 2013!

Without any doubt the "Reading Terminal Market" presents all different variety of traditional Philadelphia Food and a reminder of old Philadelphia's "food market place".

Although this is not the first and only food market place in Philadelphia but it is very popular.

I am a fan of this place and I like it especially the food is great!

This is my personal experience.

Please share your personal experience that you had with every business at reading terminal market, especially if the person who was serving you or the business owner was not very respectful or was very kind or even the food's quality so they can correct and improve their services.

Reading Terminal Market is packed with culture:  great food, great music and fantastic people.  It's pretty incredible to walk in here and see lines and lines of people waiting at almost every counter.  It's only a few minutes away from the city center and is a great place to try a little bit of everything!

Ice cream and the Philly Cheese Steak... thats why I went and it was awesome!

As some people have said, you can come here for lunch everyday for the whole year and never eat the same meal twice.  It's accurate! 

You'll love the live music -- it's definitely so refreshing!

On a recent trip to Philly we visited Reading Market and I immediately feel in love with this place! This is a must for anyone interested in trying out different cuisines as well as a great market place for picking up fresh cuts of meats/fish, veggies/fruits, cheeses, sweets, and well I could go on and on! Reading Market is definitely a must do!
great place for food.only problem is its too big..u get filled up by the time u find what u want, i guess thats a good problem. dinics the best spot in there tho

They have many different food places, where you can eat or snack. Check 
out the nice bakery that serves different kinds of very delicious bagels
 right next to the smoothie place, which isn't bad either.
Whenever I've been there usually in the morning during the week, I've also seen Amish-dressed people selling their goods. 
On
 the weekends around lunch time, it gets very crowded and you have to 
expect to wait in line for some minutes until you can make your order.

They have many different food places, where you can eat or snack. Check out the nice bakery that serves different kinds of very delicious bagels right next to the smoothie place, which isn't bad either.
Whenever I've been there usually in the morning during the week, I've also seen "Amish-dressed" people selling their goods.
On the weekends around lunch time, it gets very crowded and you have to expect to wait in line for some minutes until you can make your order.

One of the best places in Philadelphia to eat in my opinion! I don't want to repeat what everyone else has already said, because my view on it is mimicked to a lot of the other reviews, but I will say that there is quite a large variety of different foods ranging from French crêpes, to delicious Bassett's ice cream. The only thing I dislike about the place is the parking. The only place you can seem to find to park are $25 parking garages, but I guess that's just being in a large city. Other than that, I'd recommend this to anyone visiting the city!

Reading Terminal Market is amazing.  Whatever you are looking for, it is probably here.  I wish that I worked nearby so I could go to lunch here every day.  The Amish market was closed because it was sunday, but it was still amazing.  There were more cuisines than I can remember including Greek, Middle Eastern, German meats, local cheeses, Chinese, noodle bars, salad bars, sushi, Thai, crepes, seafood, spice market, all sorts of bakeries and desserts...  I don't know, everything.  

There is not much seating around, and it is jammed in there.  I would enjoy eating there for a quick meal, but a lot of this is more useful to take home with you.  

I even found purple sweet potatoes, which I have been looking for months.
The reading terminal market is really cool. This place has something for everyone. It is definitely one of the main attraction of our great city! I suggest you come take a look for yourself.

Home of the Best Sandwich in America. Somewhat touristy but it's a must-see for out of towners and definitely a place that locals should make a point to stop into every once in a while.

10% off any restaurant inside when you have Jury duty.

Possibly my favorite thing about living in the city.  I like to cook from scratch and make use of every piece of meat or produce that I buy.  Consistent quality meats, local produce and plenty of snack options.  I love bringing visiting friends there and it's a great date place in the sense that you can walk around, talk and feel less pressure than sitting across a table with someone and it potentially be awkward.  There is something for everyone and I'm there every Wednesday and Sunday!
Love this place, first time their it was crowded but it was lunch time. I love the fact the place caters to everyone needs. Wish they had one in New York

I just love this market. I'd likely stop in nearly every day if I lived in the area. There hasn't been a single time I've walked in and walked out without buying something from one of the merchants. Yesterday, a lunch at Olympic Gyro followed by some Amish cakes was just a great start to the day.

Plus, there's always interesting characters floating around outside.

HOW TO VISIT RTM RIGHT/HOW TO TAKE OUT OF TOWNERS TO RTM in 11 easy steps

1. Do you/your friends hate crowds? Forget it. Just don't even try. I brought extended family here and they got so overwhelmed we left and they decided it would be a good idea to go to Field House for cheesesteaks. A part of me died that day.

2. Is it Sunday or Monday? Go home. That's where the Amish are, and you don't want to miss them.

3. Now that you/your normal friends are psyched for the experience, enter, be amazed, and maybe take a lap or two around to work up an appetite. 

4. Stop at DiNic's for the Best Sandwich in America talk about how this was on Man vs Food. (Roast pork, broccoli rabe, sharp provolone.) It's worth the line. Split it between at least two people. You're gonna need to save room. (Maybe let other friends get what they spotted/are in the mood for, too, if they're being good. I hear the Rib place, Meltkraft is great fancy grilled cheeses, and Hershel's is always good for some giant deli brisket/pastrami/corned beef sandwiches.)

5. Go to Termini Brothers. Get a cannoli. Look across the aisle at the other chocolate place. Talk about how weird chocolate covered onions are and how awesome chocolate cheesesteaks are (once you realize there's no cheese or steak in there).

6. Go to Bassett's. Get ice cream from oldest ice cream company in America.

7. Hit up 4th Street Cookie Company. Get cookies.

8. Go to Amish guy. Try juice samples. Buy some juice.

9. Go to Tubby Olive, try lots and lots of olive oils and vinegars. Buy a little bottle for whoever is the unlucky person who did not take this trip to Philadelphia with your friends.

10. Get some cheese from some cheese counters for later. Ask them what type of cheese to get.

11. Get some produce from Iovine's for later. If it's Wednesday (or Sunday, but it shouldn't be: See #2), use your student ID for a discount.

ENJOY PHILLY!

If you live in or visit Philly, you have to go to Reading Terminal.

- David Rounick
This place was great! So many different things to choose from...cookies, meats, chocolates, honey, candles...just about everything! When in Philadelphia check this out!

This place is awesome! There are rows and rows of food vendors. You can get hot dogs, ribs, sandwiches, cookies, ice cream, and so much more. There are also a few storefronts to shop at for books, flowers, coffee, and spices. It gets really crowded though and it's definitely a little overwhelming. My friends and I had to walk around a few times before we could pick what to eat!

Ahh reading terminal market. One of Phillys staples. SO MANY CHOICES. haha. you can get any type of food you want - for any meal. From produce to brunch to crepes to japanese to greek to ice cream to cupcakes and coffee. Everything your heart desires in one place. It does get crowded on the weekends and hours vary certain days. but def worth the visit. 
Any type of food you want - if you have a group who cant decide what better place to go.
i guess worth checking out just to have checked it out, but this place is like a freaking zoo, complete with overpriced junk food.

Obsessedddddd!  This place is amazing, I now go once a week for all my fruits and veggies.  It is a bit packed some days, but for the amount I save I can handle the crowd.  Great fresh food, various vendors  serving anything you want or desire to eat!

This market is great all except for the tacky food art hanging in center court. I'm guessing its some type of children's project? I really have no idea. All I know is I wanted to hold an event there and was told they could not be removed. 

Seriously? Good luck selling any parties in the near future with that eye sore..

A great place to find cafes, shoppes, bakeries, fish markets, everything. I love it! Great place to find gifts, eat on the go, or just browse the fresh meats, veggies, confectionery goodies, and just about anything you want to eat. :) A must do for a trip to the Friendly City! Just take a cab, walk, or bus, don't try to park anywhere in Philly...

Great great great selection and a fun place to spend a little time browsing for trinkets, housewares, hand-made artisan soaps or tablecloths or even dinner ingredients!

I was disappointed to have missed many businesses that are only open Wed - Sun. 
but one would have to KNOW that information to plan a visit. The left most wing of the market was dark. 
I'm sure, when all merchants are there and open, it's even more fun!

BEWARE OF PARKING SCAMS IN THIS AREA........I pulled into a lot across the street that advertised parking for  $17, little did I know it was $17 per 10 MINUTES!!!!  Even though I immediately pulled out I had to pay the $17 and that set the mood for most of the day.  We ended up parking several blocks away at a meter that had an hour limit; by the time we walked the distance to the market we could only stay about 15 minutes before we had to leave for the long walk back to the meter.  From what we saw of the market it is a place we'd love to further explore although the crowd was overwhelming.   I truly believe if you cannot safely maneuver a stroller you shouldn't be in an area with such a concentrated crowd. 

 Come hungry!  We left in a mouthwatering state from the array of food smells but too long of lines to actually order anything.  If anyone has any suggestions for parking on a budget and manageable distance I'd love to hear about it!
This place is a foodie's paradise!  It makes French Market in Chicago look like a hot dog stand.  My coworkers and I ate here every day for lunch while we were in town.  Do not miss this local gem!

want ice cream??

BASSETS is where its at!! so yummy!!!

tubby olive is so neat! deffinatly a different place to try out and experience different balsamics and oils!!

I went to this market specifically for DiNiC's roast pork sandwich, and it was worth every minute in line. It's fun to walk around the entire market and look at all the vendors, selling everything from fresh produce to meat to baked goods to fresh juice drinks. There's something for everyone and most likely, you'll find 5 things you want so go hungry. My favorites include the roast pork sandwich, whoopie pies from Flying Monkey, and a mocha from Old City Coffee. There's a juice bar that's pretty good too and Bassetts Ice Cream is supposed to be great. Sadly, I have never tried to ice cream because I'm lactose intolerant, but it sure looks good!

Me:  
Damnit, Washington DC, get your shit together.  You don't have a good IMAX, you don't have a namesake food, and you don't have anything as good as Reading Terminal Market. 

DC:   
I have Eastern Market..... isn't that like it?

Me:    
ha ha ha, no.  Eastern Market is terrible and more importantly, it is a flea market. There is no Denic's at Eastern.  I don't remember seeing any whoopie pies, good coffee shops, unspoiled produce, or Amish people rocking their dresses, bonnet thingies and hairy legs while hocking Amish grub. . . . Nice try, DC, get away from me!

DC: *sigh*



Translation: Reading Terminal Market is freakin awesome. Go eat everything. Also, parking sucks, you'll probably have to walk a bunch.

Keepin it real
~M
2nd trip back to Philly. You have to go to Reading Terminal Market. Have yet to have a bad meal

I love this place.  If you can't find it at the Terminal Market you can't find it!
Food is delicious and varied. Candy shop is the best, kitchen store has a bunch of "what did I ever do w/out this".  Great for out of guest of the city and locals.

What can't you get at 'Reading Terminal Market'? 

This was my work lunch spot for a couple years. It never fails to deliver. This place can be overwhelming with the selections and sometimes it can be difficult to find seating but it's definitely a great place to go if your group can't all decide on what you want for lunch.

I go to Reading Terminal every week to grocery shop, mostly at Fair Food Farmstand and The Herbiary. My husband and I absolutely love the selection of local foods, including all the goodies and fresh produce the Amish have to offer! When friends from out of town are visiting, we are always sure to bring them here to show off all of the wonderful things it has to offer, including some great places to sit down and grab a bite. Metropolitan Bakery, Market Blooms, the spice shop, and kitchen store are also favorites of ours. 
Whether you live in the city, or are visiting, you should make it a point to check out this historic and awesome spot!

I love markets like this, so I tend to visit them everywhere I go.  Reading is definitely one of the better ones I've been to.  So many food options, so many shopping options, and a really fun vibe for out of town guests.  Good for your weekly shopping or a touristy outing.

Who doesn't love the Reading Terminal Market?  It's big, crowded, noisy, and full of variety.  It could do with more seating and I'm sure that not every vendor is perfect, but this place is an amazing resource for the city and for anyone working next door at the convention center.

Herschel's - pastrami sandwich.
4th st. Cookie Co. - chocolate dipped chocolate chip cookie.
Dutch Eating Place - hangover breakfast(but get there early to avoid the lines).
John Yi Fish Market - Get sushi grade salmon for that tartare that you're going to make later.
Jonathan Best - For groceries and spices such as pink peppercorns.
This could go on forever but I really don't feel like overdoing this review. The Reading Terminal is so, so great.

Tolle Markthalle! Auf jeden Fall ein MUSS, wenn man in Philadelphia ist. Egal ob frisches Fleisch, Gemüse, Obst usw. alles ist da. Sehr ansprechend präsentiert in großer Vielfalt und Auswahl.
Jede nur erdenkliche Nationalität auch bei den warmen Speisen. Die alte Halle hat ihren ganz eigenen Charme. Dadurch, dass viele Stände von Armish People betrieben werden, hat man auch ein bisschen das Gefühl einer Zeitreise. Spannende Mischung in dieser Halle. 
Man kann gar nicht soviel Essen, wie man probieren möchte. Die Preise finde ich normal. Die Speisen sind sehr leckern. 
Ich kann sie als Punkt auf der Sightseeing List für Philadelphia absolut empfehlen. Werde dort auf jeden Fall immer wieder hin gehen, wenn ich wieder in Philli bin.
Excellent experience for visitors and locals. Be prepared to be overwhelmed by lots of people.

Dinic's pork sandwich is good.  Bassette cookies and cream is good too.  We got plain noodle soup at Peking Duck for our son for $3 and it was alot of food, I end up eating most of it.  I really want to try Cajun Jambalaya, but too full.  Overall, great experiences and very diverse in term of food.  There are grocery, spices, live seafood as well.  Great place to visit.

I go to the Terminal quite often, and I love it.  Good eats, good selection, many faves, and always a treat!

For lunch go do:
- Diennier's Rotisserie Chicken: go ahead and get that half chicken or pound of wings.  YUM
- Beck's Cajun: I love it and you will too if you like spicy--and they let you sample!
- 420 (?) Smoothies! (the one next to/near Bassett's Ice Cream and across from a bread place) they have the freshest and best smoothies, and they do wheatgrass and bubble tea tapioca stuff for you affectionados that like that health kick to your drinks
- Thai Food: the grilled salmon is OMG good and a huge serving of salmon; the spring rolls are delish, and the chicken kabobs/skewers are awesome by themselves w the yummy sauce (note: extra sauce is extra, but if you like sauce, do it!)

For dinner treat do:
- Keven Parker's Soul Food Cafe: new and yummy and same owner as Ms. Tootsie's on South Street, but pricey! Treat Yourself to this one
- Thai Food (I get the salmon all the darn time, Yelpitos, it doesn't disappoint me ever!)

For Dessert Treat do:
- The two cookie spots (I don't know their names, so bad, but after 4 pm on the Basset's Ice Cream side you can grab cookies for $1 and the other one is near the wine spot on the Arch Street Side closer to 11th Street) and the "oh i have a sweet tooth" for the Flying Monkey (love everything I have tried there) 
- and Termini's mini bakery ... cheesecake and lemon curd and ... I could go on!

For just a treat do:
- The pretzel twist!  fresh hot Philly pretzels that beat Aunt Anne's in my book

For food shopping:
- The Amish Stands are the best! Fresh bakery! Fresh Cheeses! Wholesome salads and desserts! After 4 pm everything is $2
- The Ok Produce Stand: $1 bags of fresh fruits and veggies
- Godshall's Poultry: the only place I get Turkey Scrapple from
- Seafood: shop around, almost always a sale somewhere for lump crab meat 

For crafts and other stuff:
- I usually shop around, but I love the bee hive for honey.

This is a must-visit for anyone traveling to Philly. It's packed full of interesting, fun food options. I went here with my wife to grab lunch and the atmosphere is exciting. There are rows and rows of markets, restaurants, bars, shops. I would be shocked if you could not find something you liked here.

My wife got a chicken schnitzel sandwich and an apple soda. I got a grilled cheese with chips. Afterwards, we grabbed some nice fresh produce at a market. We both enjoyed our meals and had a great time wandering around taking it all in. 5 stars for sure

I hate to admit that I only just discovered the joy that is Reading Terminal within the last year, and on one hand I feel like I've missed out big time, on the other, my grad school wallet is grateful... 
There is SO much here, every time I stop in for lunch I end up leaving with something else as well from the to die for candy from the Amish stands (which also make good presents) to some fun infused oil, to fresh produce or cheese... You can't go wrong wondering around the Market filling your bags. 
The food itself is with out question a highlight of the city. My favorites include the obvious famous DiNic's, a the chicken cutlet sandwich, any of the cheesesteak places, Bassets Ice Cream, OK so EVERYTHING is good, and the Market is a Philly MUST. Just come, walk around, make your choices and enjoy!
Awesome selection of everything.  Long-ass lines for the more popular places and a litany of vendors.  This is a must-see/eat in Philly.
if you've never been here, make time! Iconic Philly attraction.

Awsome place to go when you dont know what your in the mood for. Many vendors to choose from. Went here during Jury duty and i got a nice discount. They have some stands where there are lines wrapped around the place. Everything from Pizza, Chinese, Thai, American, Italian, Sushi, Desserts, Candy and Specialty Coffees. I dont get to come here often but i would definitly like to go try this Thai Food stand that everyone tells me about.

not sure why you would ever go to  whole foods in philadelphia. you really can't beat iovines prices for produce, and between giunta's prime shop and godshall's you have a mountain of high quality and reasonably priced meats and poultry to choose from. did I mention martin's? another great butcher with a huge selection of freshly made sausage including legit english style bangers, usual italian varieties, and more. Salumeria is your stop for cheeses and cured meats like pancetta, or a mouthwatering hoagie. Fair Food Farmstand is generally pretty overpriced (13.99 a lb for garlic? I don't care if its organic that is outrageous) but I don't know where else to get raw milk and I refuse to drink pasteurized if I can help it. Head Nut is pretty awesome, a small fairly new bulk spice and nut shop that has quite a bit of variety. Love that you can buy very small amounts of spices (whole or preground) here as they have quantity/price stages, and the best part is that it's CHEAP. Don't be suckered into buying one of those tiny 8 dollar spice grinders from Jonathan Best; go to Head Nut. Thai Kitchen has a lot of asian ingredients for sale like holy basil and fish sauce, and their cheap thai curries aren't too bad either.

There are of course many food stands, which range from okay to good, but those can be a bit tourist trappy and expensive. Places definitely not to miss: DiNic's (overpriced but still a damn great roast pork sandwich, go early though they have a tendency to run out of broccoli rabe), the Rib Stand, Smucker's Grill (absolute best breakfast sandwiches right here, get the scrapple egg and cheese, you'll thank me later. Or walk to the other side of the counter and buy some scrapple to take home, seriously, it's the best scrapple I've ever had.), Miller's Twist (sorry philly pretzels, you just got your ass kicked), Beck's for delicious po'boys, get the fried oyster, Herschel's for an awesome (but expensive) reuben or pastrami special on challah.

I would not reccomend down home diner, not sure why people seem to love it, the couple times ive eaten there the food was just sloppy and in one case I got regular (frozen) fries instead of the sweet potato fries that were supposed to come with my sandwich. Seriously just go to midtown II on 11th and sansom if you want a diner experience that badly. The Dutch Eating Place does a pretty tasty burger, but the fries were really disappointing. Fresh cut but soggy and oily, not crispy at all. 

Personally I don't go to many of the restaurants any more, I'm reviewing RTM as a place to get your grocery shopping done, and on those terms you really can't beat it for the price and quality in center city.

One side note and why i knock off a star, the fishmongers don't appear that great to me in terms of freshness and price. Maybe their fish is fresher in the mornings, but I'd rather go down to Ippolito's for cheaper seafood that I KNOW is fresh. this just an observation based on sight I have not bought any fish from RTM so maybe I am wrong.

Overall it's a great place to do grocery shopping or grab a bite to eat if you don't mind the overpriced-ness of the food stands, stop going to Whole Paycheck, go to the Reading Terminal Market.

I have been here once and had a very positive experience. The vastness of the market and the sheer number of vendors is fairly overwhelming. However, that is also part of the fun. There are sweets, baked goods, dairy, jams, jellies, seafood, meat, prepared foods like sandwiches etc. If you can name it, it is at reading terminal. I ended up getting a Italian sub, several spicy pickles, chocolate covered bacon, and hot pepper jelly. Obviously service and quality varies vendor to vendor, but overall my experience was fun and delicious. This iconic Philly spot deserves a visit.

I don't even know where to begin.  This place left me literally speechless.  I could probably write a 5 page review, but I'll spare you and give you the highlights.

*Parking is a pain, almost $30.00 for two hours... unless you get it validated!   GET IT VALIDATED!
*Tommy DiNic's... best sandwich ever!
*Termini Bro's Bakery... yummy cannoli, do yourself a favor and get one!
*The Head Nut... teas and spices, and snacks galore!!
*The Famous 4th Street Cookie Co... I recommend the White Chocolate Chip Macadamia Nut.
*Four Seasons Juice Bar... Good Lord I wish we had one of these near me!  

Those are all the places we hit in my short 2 hours here.  I feel like I could take another trip to Philly and spend at least a week in Reading Terminal Market and just eat my way through.  The people who work and live near here are so lucky!

I've reviewed each of the above places individually too... check em' out!

everything you could ever need or dream of, they have it here. busy at lunch time during the week and weekend so it's tough to fit into the normal lunch-break, good people watching spot.  definitely a cool spot to take visitors from out of town.

I love going to Reading Terminal. My only complaint is that it can get very crowded and/or loud. But everything else is awesome. If you are touring Philly, you have to stop here to try some famous Bassett's ice cream and Amish pretzels. So much to do here, even if you just want to people watch. It is the epitome of a melting pot.
I try to go every time i visit my sister. we walked around, and had lots of fun.

Agreed that getting parking validated is a pain, but I love this spot as a local bus-ride away.

Countless options, awesome food, huge pieces of meat and crab.  A great place to swing by whenever you're prepping for a dinner party.  

A bit overwhelming on the first trip but it's okay, you'll keep going back :)

This market is one of the most successful blends of "tourist trap" meets "where the locals do their food shopping" that I have ever encountered.  

It's the place to be if you want to buy Thai food, spices, coffee, tea, cupcakes, a rutabaga, honey, Middle Eastern food, baklava, roasted turkey, fresh turkey, baby spinach, an awesome sandwich, a single chicken breast, 100lbs of chicken wings, steaks, milk, cheese, bread . . .  The list goes on and on.  As long as you avoid Tokyo Sushi, you literally cannot go too wrong with any of the classic or newer vendors. 
 
If you are a local trying to food shop, weekday mornings are the quietest and weekend mornings (before 10) are usually manageable.  Expect a big crowd at lunch time and on the weekends, especially if there is anything sizable going on at The Convention Center.  Avoid at all costs during The Flower Show.  If you are a tourist . . . well then . . . just get on in there and be prepared to throw a few elbows as you make your way through the crowds getting a feel for Philly at its finest.  Just please don't come to a dead stop to look around and take pictures in the middle of the aisles.  Thanks!

I love love love the RTM. Italian Hoagie from Salumeria. Boneless Rib Sandwich from the Rib Stand. Cookies from Hope's. Grilled Salmon from Little Thai Market. Sang Kee, The Original Turkey... omg the list goes on.  Working across the street I was there all the time! I was so spoiled with food. And now I have a new job in the middle of nowhere. Sigh...

Reading Terminal is a defining location of Philly--so how could I not like it? With everything from charming Amish farmers to trendy food artisans to good ol' blue collar cheese steaks,  Reading Terminal fully encompasses what defines Philly cuisine. (Just, please, don't go on the weekends).

I haven't written a review in so long but this place is so great that it deserves one.  I came down from NYC a few weeks ago just to see what Philly had to offer.  The city was about what I expected (not bad) but this place was a real gem.  It's pretty convenient, right in the middle of town near city hall.  It has just about every type of food stand you can imagine.  There was so much good food that I came back 3 times before going home!  Tommy Dinic's seemed to be the crowd favorite but unfortunately it was so crowded that I never got to try it.  My favorite ended up being the pastrami sandwhich at Hershel's East Side Deli.  I'd trade Eataly AND Chelsea Market to move this place to NYC!
Iovine brothers, the Amish corner, it's all great.  Only downside is that it gets packed with tourists every weekend.

What a great find in Philly. The market had so much stuff to try and everything looked great. We ended up picking Tommy DiNic's due to it's fame and we're glad we did. If I lived in Philly, I'd definitely come here often.
fresh vegetables, reasonable prices. great tasting baked goods (especially the donuts). great place to spend an hour every weekend

My only complain with this place is that it closes so early!  You can get some of the best deals just before closing though.  If you want to eat, come two hours before it shuts down or most of the vendors will have already started packing up their delicious foods.

You're going to want to make a point to stop at DiNic's, Bassette's, and the Creperie.  Also stop in for Amish weekend or head over to AJ's Picklepatch for fresh preserves!

RTM is a regular stop for us during weekend shopping trips.  Last week, we finally discovered the new cheese shop, Valley Shepherd Creamery, in the newly refurbished back avenue of RTM.  What a spectacular addition to an already spectacular market.  We tried numerous cheeses, including their amazing made-on-the-premises mozzarella.  This is a much more flavorful version of fresh mozz and we both loved it.  We left with two hard cheeses for later that day but then went back - when we got hungry after much shopping - to have one of their toasted cheese sandwiches.  OMG, simply the best!  Go!  Try it!
Best place in Philly for lunch or food to go. Been coming here over 35 years.

One of my Philly favorites!!! 4 Seasons, Olde City Coffee, 4th Street Cookies 12th Street Cantina and the place where they make the fresh donuts are the places I frequent.

In a pinch, I go to Mezze and the rotisserie chicken place on the Arch Street side.

I absolutely love going to the Reading Terminal Market.  There are so many different things to check out and different foods to try.  The market has ended up being one of my go-to places when I have visitors in town.  The only downside is that it can get insanely busy so if you don't do well in crowds you might want to avoid this place during meal times!

This place is so much fun for food freaks!  So many options available in a huge facility.  I always have fun wandering around here and having too much to eat : )  You can try so many types of cuisines that I can't even list them.  Plus you can buy farm fresh ingredients, preserves and the like from the local Pennsylvania Dutch.  It's like a food Mecca here!

Do you want to find chocolate in the shape of a brain?  Do you want to find local wine or sangria?  Do you want prickly pear honey?  Do you want sushi grade fish?  What is your wacky food fetish (you bad, bad boy)? Almost every quircky to completely blaze food item can be found at Reading Terminal Market.  As soon as you walk in the door, you are overwhelmed with the sights and smells of food.  Even times where I went that I wasn't hungry, I had the incredible urge to gain twenty pounds munching on the gigantic sandwhiches and pasta dishes arranged so beautifully by the vendors.  It is a little overwhelming for those looking for the first time, but I suggest strolling through the whole place first and then going back through to sample and grab some items you will be sure to love.

Herschel's deli is by far my favorite food stop here.  I don't even like pastrami sandwhiches normally.  But even thinking about the smokey, melt-in-your-mouth pastrami from here has me drooling on the keyboard.
Excellent selection of food. I love the Mezze Mediterranean place, the creperie, Dutch fried chicken and apple pies. If you are craving it they have it!

I went to the Reading terminal with a few friends. We went on a Friday about 11am. We got our lunch almost right away. I ordered from Franks. I got a cheeseburger and fries and a soda. I asked for well done and the burger was med but it was good. the fries were great and there was a lot of them. Then we walked around. Our trip to RTM was good.

RTM covers it all.

Best sandwich spot (dinic's)-check
Great ice cream spot (bassets)-check
Great Coffee spot (Old City Coffee)-check
Great pastry spot (Termini Bros)-Check
Great Cupcake spot (Flying Monkey Bakery)-check

And these are all just in view when you enter from 12th st.

Remember that you can park in the garage across the street.  Now, to save some cash, and by some, I mean a lot, spend $10 anywhere in the market and get your parking ticket punched.  Up to 2hrs will then only cost you $4 instead of the usual $20.

Love this place...all the sights, sounds, and yummy treats.  LUV the dark chocolate pretzels from the Chocolate by Mueller...breakfast of champions!  I had bad luck with John Yi Fish Market.  After reading some reviews, I thought it was a safe bet and ordered a cooked lobster to go.  They told me it would take 20 minutes, but I thought it was because I was in a queue.  I didn't realize that they were going to bake it for 20 minutes.  Seriously, it was the toughest lobster I have ever had.  The claws were tough and dry like cardboard and I am not exaggerating.  What a $21 disappointment!  The raw fish looks good, so I think the only issue is their lobster abuse.

I know I'm going to catch some flack for this, but I don't looooove RTM. I much prefer the Italian Market for most produce and meat items. RTM pricing seems a tad higher and much more touristy.  I will say that beef cheeks are nearly impossible to find in the city, and I checked with all the butchers in the Italian Market - one pointed me to RTM! I need to go check it out.
DiNick's Brisket sandwich with spinach is the best sandwich I have ever had.

When people review books they sometimes employ a simple system of "buy, borrow, bypass". For a place like Reading, which can feel like it houses just about everything under its roof, we might think in similar terms... let's try "frequent, few and forego"

now, despite having gone to Reading at least once a week for nearly a year now, I have to admit I haven't given a thorough tour of every shop represented, so the following are just selected from what I have been able to consider:

Frequent:

Dutch Eating Place - I would use any excuse whatever to stop here. 

Godshall's Poutry - I've never been disappointed by the meat I get here. Of course if you drop into Asian markets down the road, you'll notice the price difference. 

Iovine's Brothers and OK Lee tend to have competitive prices on most of their staples, but their grab bags generally cover different territory. If you're fishing for inspiration, it never hurts to swing by both shops

John Yi Fish Market - I've never actually stopped by Golden Fish, I guess it simply happened out of chance. I've had cooked and raw food from Wan's and I was never impressed. John Yi does the job for me.

Few

12th St Cantina - they sell guacamole, salsas, and a variety of tortillas to go, which is convenient since they are generally freshly made and great quality. They also have pre-made foods that are kept cold that would make for a convenient meal at home. 

Bassett's Ice Cream - Few if you can restrain yourself! The WHYY is fantastic, and not only because I love Terry Gross. 

Bee Natural - Love the raw honey. Candles are not my thing so I've never shopped for more than honey.

By George! Pizza - love the pizzas I've tried, and they have a variety of pre-made side dishes that will kick up the variety to dinner without the added time investment. 

L. Halteman - I've had bought their meat before and was satisfied with the freshness and quality. What I primarily come here for, however, is their smoked dog bone, which my dog is absolutely addicted to. I haven't really seen this offered anywhere else and my dog doesn't really go for rawhide so this helps me control her plaque and spoil her rotten.

Martin's Quality Meats and Sausages - They have 20+ varieties freshly made sausages that they have out everyday. Decent selection of meats otherwise. The reason why I don't come here for all my meats is because they don't cut their pieces for you. Meaning, the last two times I've come here for a pound of something, I walked away with anywhere from a quarter to nearly half a pound extra. This makes it harder to portion for meals, so I tend to only drop it when I know I wouldn't mind the difference.

Metropolitan Bakery - I don't eat bread much but I've enjoyed the few I've picked up from here. They also sell their bread for 50% off if you stop in late enough, though the selection dwindles the later the day as is expected.
 
Forego

Blue Mountain Vineyards Cellars - sells a lot of things that have nothing to do with wine. Wines are overpriced. 

The Down Home Diner - Food was pretty disgusting.

Giunta's Prime Shop - nothing wrong with their meats, just a $10 card minimum that bugs. As someone who doesn't like to carry cash and does buy groceries as needed each day, I tend to skop Giunta's altogether.

Jonathan's Best - GENERALLY forego, use in emergencies. 

The Tubby Olive - a bit gimmicky in my opinion. I like to go with a good olive oil and simply infuse on the shelf or on the stove. I can't really see the necessity for treated "gourmet" oils. 

For whatever else residing in Reading, I haven't experienced quite enough of them to merit a review. The rest will have to wait for a review update!

Incredible collection of eats. Since Basic 4 closed, the vegetarian selection has hurt a bit. Nevertheless, there are multiple stands that can be called "Best in Philly" - 4th Street Cookies, The Original Turkey, Dinic's, etc. Come here for incredible food and don't be surprised to get some light live music with your lunch.

I love Reading Terminal Market! Its a great place to go on a Saturday morning to look around and enjoy the food and atmosphere. This is a great place to get the famous pork sandwich from Dinic's and maybe a soft pretzel from the Amish Market. The Reading Terminal Market is definitely a spot to hit when you are in the city!

If you haven't been in a while , 2 new things to try!  Beiler Donuts.  They are worth every single calorie.  After these no other donut will be worth the effort!!!!   Valley Shepherd for all things cheese and things that go with cheese. Grilled cheese then donut for dessert.  You can't go wrong.
Excellent shopping but you have to be ready to fight tourists who laze about and get in the way for fun.
This is such a unique place to grab a meal and get a feel for a true Philadelphia icon.  There are very few places in the country as diverse and is a must visit if you are in Philly.

I absolutely love the reading terminal market.
When I bring friends to visit Philadelphia I bring them here whether they have any interest or not.
I burn about 3 hours getting lost in this wonderland.  It's full of delicious food, my goal in life is to try food from each and every stand. Not a hard feat because so far everything I've tried is mouthwatering. I would recommend a certain stand to go to but it would just be unfair to pinpoint the "best" stand. All of them are exceptional in taste, quality, and service.
The prices here are a bit pricier, but you certainly get what you pay for.
The variety is great and the experience of walking down aisles upon aisles of fresh unique food is incredible. However, the lines are long and the prices of prepared food can be high. Worth a trip.

Ate: "The Famous" from Dinic's, lemon tart from Termini Bros

Drank: A raspberry and pineapple smoothie from one of the vendors.

Liked: Lots of food and interesting things to eat.

Disliked: Crowded!  And I went on a calm day.  Some dude cut in front of me in Dinic's and pretended that I didn't see him.  The audacity!

Chicken: Yes.  I had some chicken wings but can't remember from where. They were acceptable.

Would mom like it?: Yeah, big crowds are mom's natural habitat.  She knows how to sidestep and maneuver in ways I could only dream of.

Would I go back: Sure, next time I'm in Philly.

Recommend:  I'd like to try the pulled pork from Dinic's next time.  That looked really good!
Interesting market - similar to Boston's Quincy market - but more condensed, large crowds but great little shops.

A must go if you're visiting in Philly or live there.  I was lucky enough to live a few blocks from there for a few years.  There is every thing good to eat.  I must admit that a highlight for me was on of the candy shops with turkish delight during the summer.  Good noodles, amish people selling cakes and breads.  Fresh produce.   It's crowded and bustling in a good way.

Had oyster po boy at Pearl oyster house for lunch. What a ripoff, a measly 3 over fried, over salted oysters on a huge doughy hoagy roll with lettuce & tomato - for $8.50 plus tax. Not eating here again.

Great market. I love the availability of local honey, whole chicken, raw milk, etc. if you like food this is a must stop- a lot of variety of quick eats. Wish I had something like this close to home. I visited as a tourist and would be interested to know if local like it too.

I really like this place, but they lose two stars because they close ridiculously early. 5pm? REALLY?  This place gets third-world crowded, so if you go, make it on a weekday.  The RTM is losing a LOT of my business because they close so early.

Love the Reading Terminal.

Quality food and houseware stalls in one location. Love it! What I don't love is the spacing. It's always crowded here which gives an indication of the popularity of the products but you can feel a bit overwhelmed by the crowds. Always disheartened when I see school-aged kids here during the week, DURING school time. Any truant officers in Phila. at all?

My favs are Flying Monkey, any and all of the Amish food stalls, Hershel's, Iovine's (freshest fruit and veg) and so many more.

This is a good people spot and I've always met nice folks here...workers and patrons like me.

4 well deserved stars.

A must for anyone visiting Philly! This is the city's main farmer's market, which is hosted within an old train shed. Its history is absolutely fascinating, and when it first opened WAY back when it held almost 400 vendors - can you imagine!

My first visit here was apparently on a "quiet" day, which basically means I had some breathing room in what was still an absolutely packed space. 

But there's a reason this place is always packed: it's fantastic. You can find EVERYTHING here if you look long enough. Breakfast food, sandwiches, gyros, sushi, bakeries, desserts, beads, an entire stand dedicated to selling flavored honey and beeswax, and of course, Philly cheesesteaks - and that's just to name a small number of the stands and types of food you can find in here; it's an absolutely amazing place to just get lost in. 

Bring your adventuring spirit and appetite when you head in here for sure, because you will get a heaping plate of food no matter where you go to eat! And give yourself pleeeenty of time to explore and enjoy the place!

One of my favorite places on earth! This place is spectacular for so many reasons. You can explore on your own and experience marvelous artisan items, like fresh bread, pastries, jams and jellies, candies, produce, and dairy items. However, you can also come here with a large group and please everyone with their cuisine of choice!

I've been here twice. The first time I was with just a friend, and we really enjoyed the shopping experience. The second time I was chaperoning an eighth grade field trip, and it was the first time the whole week that nobody complained about food because everyone was able to get what they wanted. (Unfortunately, I made the poor choice of going to Tokyo Sushi....avoid at all costs!). There are even vegetarian and vegan options at most locations. You can find something for everyone, and then you can all eat together in one of the several seating areas and enjoy the vibrant ambiance of the market!

This place was amazing. so many different places to try. It was like a swap meet of restaurants. each aisle was labeled as a street and there was enough room to walk around. I wish i had more time to try out all the different kinds of food. From philly cheesesteaks to chinese food to mexican food this place had it all. The hard part about this area was you werent able to yelp all the restaurants through nearby search so to find out ratings on certain restaurants, you'll need to type each individual place's name or you could go in blind and make it an adventure!  I would suggest the second option. If I had a reason to come back to philly, it would be for this one market place.

A little torn here -while this was a really cool place, it was a bit chaotic for me. It's like a big, crazy grocery store -and then you continue walking and there are other shops too. For those in my hometown in Chicago, it is like the 26th Street Discount Mall -but higher quality goods and a lot more food.I did find a cool stand that sold all natural body lotions -it was called Herbiary. I think the chaos distracted us a bit from really looking around and taking advantage of everything it had to offer. I'm sure the beers the night before didn't help ;0).  So my advice would be to hit this place up early before it gets super crowded.  If we had not been as tired / hungry, this would have been a cool place to really do some shopping. I think we were just not prepared for how busy it was!

A true Philly icon.  You have all kinds of amazing eateries - go to Dinic's for the Roast Pork w/ Sharp Provolone and Broccoli Rabe if you are a first time, to fascinating little shop (think farmer's market type of places), Reading Terminal Market is always bustling with activity.  The biggest drawback if you eat there is it is very hard to find a seat at lunchtime and if you don't live or work nearby, it's very difficult to find nearby parking (and if you do, it is usually at an outrageous price.)

There is a Philadelphia food tour service that is anchored in Reading Terminal Market and that is a great way to experience it for the first time.

I am from pittsburgh and this reminds me of a sampling of our strip district. you have to walk around it a few times to take it all in.  

The Ice cream is magical is all i can say and the baked goods are great too. Not a big fan of the coffee though...

I do like this place a lot although its not somewhere I needed to go more than once.  If I worked in the area, I think it would be a good lunch spot to take advantage of the variety of places under one roof.  Its not cheap but there are a lot of quality food places and vendors selling goods from their places of origin.  I think the prices are high to take advantage of tourists, considering the seating is so-so.

Talk about variety! The Reading Terminal Market is a great time. Especially if you have friends or visitors from out of town, it is a great tourist attraction. A great place to people watch, walk around and get phenomenal food and treats. 4th Street Cookies are phenomenal!

So many good places to eat. DeNic's roast pork is my favorite but the lines can be crazy long around lunch time. The farmer's Markets are cool for fresh local produce. the Amish place is awesome for breakfast, they give you like a pound of butter. I wish the whole place was open later.

Can be horribly crowded on weekends and it's a bit pricey if you're doing serious shopping here.  But, it makes for a pretty fun, cheap date activity.  Check out the chocolate covered onion at Chocolate by Mueller, nab some cheese samples, get a toasty cookie from 4th street cookie company.  

Also, this place taught my how to say Reading correctly.  So next time I'm playing monopoly with friends, I can snootishly correct their pronunciation.

this place is mediocre at best, as far as "markets" go. there are better/cleaner/cheaper markets all over major cities in the US. but -- RTM does have some iconic establishments - dinic's for one, is a favorite. it's a tourist [trap], but i suppose it must be visited on any first-timer's trip to philly!
cool place.

Wow, check it out, another 5 star Reading Terminal Market review.

If you're in Philly, this should be on your must-go-to list for at least a meal.

The food here is great.  If you can't find what you're looking for, you're too picky.  From Wed-Sat most of the Amish folks will be here and I HIGHLY recommend getting breakfast at the Dutch Eating place which is nested toward the back of the market.  Their blueberry pancakes are perfect and their homemade apply turnovers are so worth it, if anything get one to go.

Most of the market is what I would classify as the United Nations snack fest.  Everything from falafels to pulled pork sandwiches, Asian cuisine, just everything.  

Termini Bros has a shop in here, don't pass on the canolis, they are renowned for their pastries.

I would not recommend Down Home Diner - they have a dining time limit.  I understand they're busy, but really?

Love the Reading Terminal, even when it gets super crowded. Such delicious food all over the place. I make sure to take all out of town guests here for the experience. Just wish it was open later during the week so I could get there after work more regularly.

Seriously, what is not to love about this place?! You can get anything and everything you want. Stop in for lunch, sity down or grab it and run back to work. Even relax with a drink at Molly's. And then dessert on your way out.

My favs: DiNic's roast pork and beef, Hershel's, Terminis, Bassett's, Hatville deli, Beiler's..

Open everyday, year round. A MUST stop in for tourists and locals.

I always enjoy coming here. The local meats and dairy are really cool. There are some great prepared food items to try here to. Hershel's pastrami is a real hidden gem that you should check out on your next visit.
five stars--my wife and I could spend the whole day here eating great food and people watching.
Absolutely love the market. the environment is bustling and the food is so diverse. From cheese steaks to seafood, its all in this market. I suggest bringing cash but there is an ATM inside.

While the Terminal Market doesn't boast the best food or the best prices in the city, it does have the best selection, and many of the options are good. My favorite part of going here is walking in and being hit by the incredible combination of wonderful smells. This is a truly special place.
Great place to eat and such diverse cultural experiences. No way you don't.love this place. Try a Amish breakfast

This place is just too much fun! Flowers, fresh veggies and meat, candy and more places to eat with different types of food than you can shake a stick at.  They don't stay open late (the diner does I think) and they are best to visit for breakfast and lunch.  It can and does get crowded in there.

Can't recall the name of the place but we had breakfast sandwiches on a pretzel that was just too tasty.  And the Amish pastries - OH M GEE!!!!  If you are in Philly you have to go visit this place and enjoy yourself.
A must visit, don't miss Dinic's!! Best pork sandwich ever! The entire market rocks! Free parking across the street!
What's to say that hasn't already been said. This is truly an American treasure.

Oh Holy hell, I was SO excited to find this place! more reviews of what's inside to come, but just the variety of what's available inside is enough to keep going back! Plenty of seating, great food and other stuff to peruse/buy, and bathrooms close at hand if you happen to be there for too long, as we were. If I were a local, I'd be there every day for breakfast. As we're only here for three days, it will just have to be three days in a row.

amazing, That's all I can say. This place is a pregnant woman's dream. I've never been pregnant but when I do and I have food cravings, I'll just go here and eat from ever vendor! The amish pretzels are the best
Really a melting pot of culinary delights!  My favorites are Becks Cajun Cafe and of course DiNics Roast Pork, doesnt get any bettter than those two locations.

Love this place!! Everything you need under one roof. Come in for breakfast, do all your grocery shopping, produce, meats, cheeses, sweets & stay for lunch. I haven't been to one place I haven't liked

I love Reading Terminal Market.  It's totally worth pushing your way through the tourists to get some unbelievably cheap groceries.  My favorite spots are Iovine Brothers for cheap produce, Martins for amazing and inexpensive fresh meat, Metropolitan Bakery for sliced bread, The Amish baked goods stand for rolls and pies, and The Amish cheese stand for cheap, good quality cheeses.  I get most of my groceries from Reading Terminal and always bring famiyl and friends whoa re visiting for ice cream and a cheesesteak.
This is a great place to get a "Taste of Philadelphia". Fresh food, plenty of choices and even a beer garden!
My favorite place in Philadelphia. I go here at least twice a week. Heaven. No matter what you're in the mood for, RTM has it.

A nice market with Philly cheese steak, Amish apple sauce, Italian food items, and deli. Can be overwhelming if it's your first time. Certain stands are really busy. But you'll catch on. I always stop by the Amish stand, it is the most peculiar and unique part of the market.

One of the coolest places on earth. You can find anything you can think of to eat here. Plenty of "Pennsylvania" food here as well as international fare too. If you are visiting Philly, you must visit the Reading Terminal.
the best place to shop in philly. the food is fresh i love it

This is my grocery store and I am incredibly thankful for it every time I make the trek.  Not only can you get meat, eggs, veggies, bread and cheese, but also cooking gear, a beer, awesome breakfast, crepes, Italian cookies for business meetings and chocolates to take back home as gifts. Love it.  It's so Philly (though you do have to pay attention and avoid when there's a conference in town).

Reading Terminal Market gathers a variety food and people together. Big restaurants and bakeries have their small shops inside. You can find all sorts of things from ethnic foods to books and flowers. The diversity is great. One of my issues is the crowded-ness and navigating the area. It does remind me of places in Asia, packed and noisy. But it is a neat place that adds to the uniqueness of Philadelphia.

Man I wish more cities had places like this. Anything you can think of is in this place. From restaurants to grocery stands. I ate at Tommy Dinic's. I had the roast pork, sharp provolone and broccoli de rabe. Damn good sandwich. I need to go back again. Either way, if you're in Philly, make sure you stop here. Give yourself some time too. Make sure you have the munchies...
There is something for everyone here.  Mexican, vegetarian, chinese, bakeries, greek...anything your heart desires all in one place!

You know that you're in a real city when you can pop into a place like the Reading Terminal Market. Centrally located near our hotel, it was a great option for lunch on our arrival day into Philly. There are almost too many choices to choose from at this place. The wife and I opted for the German place with the curry wurst and the potato pancakes and both were great and filling. 
The curry wurst alone could have fed a small family of 4. It was loaded with German sausage, fries and a curry flavored ketchup. It was kind of the German version of poutine, but either way it was tasty. The potato pancakes were fluffy and not really greasy, which was nice.
The place was packed with us being there at lunch hour, but service was quick. Plenty of sandwich places, an oyster bar and many other ethnic food options, as well as butchers, cheese mongers, fish mongers and grocery.
I suspect a return visit before we leave Philly.

I loveeeeeeeeee this place!

When I get there, I never want to leave.  It makes me sad that I can't buy certain things because I am just visiting, but all the meat, produce and seafood look so fresh and delicious.

There is such a variety of food in there.. it is hard to choose what you want to eat.  But it's great to know you have so many choices to choose from.  Definite go-to spot is Tommy's Dinic's.  Roast pork, broccoli rabe, and sharp provolone.  Better than a Philly cheesesteak!

Was here on a Monday night around 5 and a lot of shops were already closed.  Including DiNic's. - insert sad face here-
Love Reading Terminal Market for lunch. A must try spot when in Philadelphia. There is something to munch on for everyone and they have an excellent farmers' market too.

Love the variety here.... there is everything you could ever want. Restaurants and meat/fish markets. But closes pretty early, 6 I believe. 

I've been to one of the 
- Little restaurant for Gyros which were tasty. 
- Little Thai restaurant in the back right was also very tasty.  (If looking at the complex from the front) 
- Pakistani food was delicious and your able to get free samples. 
- Beef Jerky store makes me laugh and reminds me of home, but is incredibly expensive. 
- Ice Cream is tasty in the front. Something that starts with a B. 
- Donuts on the far left front are also delicious but incredibly expensive. $11/dozen. (If looking at the complex from the front) 

We plan on coming back every week just to try something for lunch. 

It's just fun to walk around and look at everything that they have to offer.

Loved it.  I walked over from the sheraton four points which was super close. Inexpensive food options galore.  Had breakfast at dutch eating place and got super full so I didn't have room for the great looking donuts at one of the other stores. I walked around the marketplace and bought a natural beeswax candle for $6. I wish there was more space to sit and eat. The freshly baked bread looked yummy.

I feel fortunate to live a few blocks away! Unbelievable variety; you can literally eat anything you want in this very building. Would even be good for a group of indecisve diners for lunch. 
Oh, but the shopping! Meat, poultry, seafood, cheese, olive oil, bakery, and the best goddamn produce market in the city.  A necessity for anyone that loves to browse and food shop as much as I do.
I love it here. You can walk around and try different things from different parts of the world. The food is always good and the staff is always nice. Only, sometimes it gets too crowded.

Great place to go to if you don't know what you're in the mood to eat.  Walking throughout Reading Terminal, you'll be sure to land upon a place that suits your appetite.  There are lots of different venues to peruse through.  Also, a great place to people watch.

This place is awesome! So many foods to try.

What I had:

Tony Dinic's - roast pork with provolone and broccoli rabe and roast beef with provolone and broccoli rabe. This was okay, prefer roast pork over the roast beef though.

Beiler's donut - strawberry filled and apple fritters - pretty okay, better than the donut chains.

Kamal's peach, strawberry, and guava - very refreshing!

Miller's Twist, sausage in a pretzel and cheesesteak in a pretzel - Not a fan of the sausage in a pretzel. I would say the cheesesteak pretzel was one of my favorite's at the Market. 

Bassett's Ice Cream - Pistachio and green tea were so fresh! 

I will certainly be back to try everything else.

Love the variety here.... there is everything you could ever want. Restaurants and meat/fish markets. Anything you have a taste for Reading Terminal market has it. Its like a maze in there smelling different smells and seeing a lot of diversity. It's kinda big you could get lost.
My Idea of Willy Wonka's Factory.  Every conceivable food known to man under one roof!!  Just wish it didnt get so packed around lunch.  Oh well.

The Reading Terminal Market is kind of one of those things about Philly that appeals to both tourists and locals. If you're a foodie, you'll love it here. Just beware, the crowds can get pretty intense, especially on the weekends and especially around lunch.

So the market is kind of half actual market where you can buy meat, seafood, cheese, produce, canned and packaged goods, etc., and take it home, and then the rest of the stands in the market are all kinds of varieties of lunch counters, basically. There's sushi. There's Greek. There's Thai. There's cheesesteaks (well, duh... but if you really want a great steak, go to Pat's in South Philly or at least Jim's on South Street). Some places actually have counters where you can sit. Otherwise, there are communal seating areas with tables and such for people who want to sit and eat. It's a great place to taste and explore but bring some patience and a kind attitude with you.

Two cautions:
1. Many of the lunch places especially are cash only. There is an ATM in the building but you'd be better off to come packing with some cash.
2. The parking rates around the market are atrocious and the parking meter people are Nazis. If you are lucky enough to snag a street spot, make SURE you are parked in a spot that is for cars (some are for motorcycles only) and that you note how much time you have. Some of the spots are really tricky and are only like 15 minute spaces. You can also try nearby Chinatown -- it's only about a three block walk -- but parking there can be dicey, too. If you cannot find street parking, there are two nearby decks that have a deal with the market. Park in the deck, spend $10+ with a market merchant, have them validate your receipt, and your parking will only be $4. 2 hour limit, but that's plenty of time to get in, look around and get out. Info here: http://www.readingterminalmarket.org/about/parking/
This place is the cornucopia of foodie-land. Never a letdown because whatever you are hungry for they got it. Nuff said!
The produce selection is great and a good price, plus lots of lunch counters,etc. wish I lived just a wee bit closer

Great place to eat almost anything, but terrible seating.  Favorite is Greek near the west wall. and ice cream along the wall.  Amish Breakfast cool.  Lots of ethnic cow and pig choices.   Maybe with embedded Sushi Roll.

Need to put clones of this along the Turnpike.

Don't expect gourmet food here, but it's worth a stop just for the experience. Noisy with big crowds, and slightly overpriced, but it's a great place for lots of tasty treats. I highly recommend Basset's ice cream (the Gadzooks Blanc flavor is my favorite).

What's there not to love about Reading Terminal Market?! It's essentially got everything anyone expects at a market - ice cream shop, cheese vendor, deli stands, and even one that's owned by an Amish group (correct me if I'm wrong...sorry!). So many different selections there, and it's always such a hard decision coming here with a limited budget. 

Even better, Chinatown is essentially right next doors. Go for a nice bubble tea or authentic Szechuan cuisine just one block down! Plus, Dim Sum Garden always has amazing food! The Gallery is right by the market, too; so if you're not in the mood for Chinese Food, maybe you're in the mood to do some shopping. 

I'm not rating it 5 stars for two reasons: Reading Terminal Market is great, but unfortunately, being in the center of the city, it is a bit small. I hope one day, the Market will go through an underground renovation and add a basement! Also, I wish there were an easy exit/entrance by 11th street. I've discovered a sketchy exit onto Arch/11th, but it's used for trucks to load and unload. Regardless, it saves me time and effort, and lets me zoom through the market whenever I make a trip to Chinatown!
It doesn't get better than the salmon at the Little Thai market. And try to keep track of when the Penn Dutch Fair is in the terminal. The amish donuts are TO DIE FOR

Great and varied selection, but does get pretty crowded .... well pretty much all the time from 11-3pm. If you can look past the crowds (especially doe eyed tourists) you can find basically anything and everything you could want for breakfast, lunch or dinner.

Besides the crowds its the best place to get a taste of the city.  From cheesesteaks to roast pork to amish desserts.  The hours of most establishments are designed for lunch. 

Definitely check out Bassetts Ice Cream for a cold taste of philly or Terminis for South Philly Italian dessert goodness. 

DaNic's is the way to go for a sandwich.

This place is a little piece of heaven, Philly heaven!!!  I got cheese steaks, pumpkin bread, watermelon candy, fruit cocktail, yogurt pretzels, and drinks. And I can easily say this was one of my favorite places in Philadelphia to visit.  There's just so much to see and smell and touch!  It's similar to Seattle's Pike's Place Market but almost grander...almost...I have to say you tie. hehehe

Regardless, of all the places I could have gone, I spent the most time in the Market.  It was awesome!

This is one of those loves, that will never fade with time.. until I get diabetes and die. 

Reading Terminal, you are superfluous with food galore! The only downside I've ever experienced are the ridiculous crowds of tourists, and the feeling of being overwhelmed because there is SO MUCH FOOD, so many options!

My favorites include the classic Roast Pork with provolone and broccoli rabe at Dinics, and the Salmon lunch special at Little Thai restuarant. 

my suggestion: GO WITH AN EMPTY STOMACH, full wallet (cash only at a lot of spots), and just wander up and down the aisels. Try what you want, walk by what you don't. You will leave extremely happy, full, and probably waddling like a penguin :) 

ALSO they have yellow watermelon in the summer... TRY IT. or don't. leave more for meeeee

If your in downtown Philly this is a must. Super fun and cool indoor market. I recommend walking around trying a little of everything if possible. They have an array of different cuisine and some fun local beers. Bring cash and walk around. I will be back.

Border Springs Farms Lamb is a new spot at Reading Terminal Market or at least I have never seen it before. I was so excited when I passed by and saw they have lamb burgers. I had to take a double take and never moved beyond the cashier until I ordered.

I have been searching for a mouthwatering lamb burger for sometime. The few places that I had ordered the lamb burgers from in southern Jersey & Philly left me disappointed. They were often overcooked, bland or the toppings did not adequately compliment the burger. Well, I need look no further because this place has won over my tastebuds. So much so that I came here 2 days in a row just to order the lamb burger.

I know you asking so Michelle what makes their burgers so good. Why, THANK YOU for asking.. I think I will let these adjectives do the talking: moist, juicy, succulent, flavorful, hearty, lip smacking & finger licking good. I think that sums it up. It wasn't just the burger but the wheat roll/bun, arugula and the sauce that worked harmoniously to make such a powerful impact in taste.

So, my recommendation is if you want a good lamb burger try this place, you will not be disappointed.
I wish the prices were a bit lower, but the food is great!

a philadelphia staple... 
there is a variety of food from many cultures. the amish come to philly bringing their buttery baked deliciousness! if you are a tourist, THIS is the place to go to try some of the areas little treasures. and if you are a resident, the local markets are pretty reasonably priced. HOWEVER, on the weekends it is super crowded! holidays = super crowded!! so you'll need to be prepared for that.
my favorite lunch is the fried chicken salad from the country diner.

What a gem of a place. Reading Terminal Market is such a fun and valuable resource. This is a great place to grab lunch or people watch, and an amazing place to get local, organic produce, dairy, and eggs. The L. Halteman Family's Tub Butter is heaven on earth.

I love Reading Terminal. I go here almost every weekend to pick up fresh veggies, meat, fish, and a pound of freshly roasted Old City Blend coffee from Old City Coffee Company. I always try to hit the market on Sunday, Iovine Brothers Produce has a student discount and the market is much less crowded. The only downside to shopping on Sunday? All of the Amish stands are closed. Saturdays are insane, almost not worth going. There are just wall to wall tourists and you'll have to fight for the perfect piece of fruit at the produce stands. 

Favorite shops: 

Iovine Brothers Produce (fantastic fruit and veggies)

Giunta's Prime Shop (I always pick up a few chicken breast, ground turkey, and maybe some pork shoulder or steaks)

Ok Lee Produce (not as fresh as Iovine, but if you're going to eat what you buy the same day, the prices can't be beat)

Downtown Cheese (I looooove this shop. They force feed you a cheese while you're shopping. Also they carry Claudio's fresh mozzarella from Italian Market, delicious!)

The Head Nut (replaced the Spice Terminal with a larger, more navigable selection of spices, nuts, beans, candies, etc. )
I like reading terminal for great fruits and veggies and fresh spices, but I'm not a fan of the crowds. Go during the week or when there isn't a convention in town.

It's going on 23 years that I've been a regular here, so I've been coming here long enough to see vendors come and go. Doesn't matter; I can always find a new favorite among my standard go-tos. First, what's now called Olympia Gyro has THE BEST gyros in the area!!! You have to drive 40 miles to even get close to its runner-up (Olympia Restaurant in Vineland, NJ). Bassett's Raspberry Truffle Ice Cream is a-ma-ZING! The Dutch Eating Place is a great place for a quick breakfast pig out. Take-home fresh pastas from George's or fresh produce from Iovine's. Munch on chocolate chip with walnuts cookies from Famous 4th Street Cookie Co. or chocolate covered pretzels from Chocolate by Mueller. Create your own salad with too-many-good-choices-to choose-from at Tootsie's Salad Express or fill up on falafel, shawerma, or kebabs at Kamal's Middle Eastern Specialties. 

Ignore the crowds; the Market's location across from the Convention center guarantees crowds - but that's GOOD! That means the market will be around for a very long time - and that's GOOD!

Reading Terminal Market... what can I say. One of Philadelphia's finest landmarks and tourist attractions (rightfully so), it really can take up an entire day to go, walk around, people watch, and take in the sights and smells of a vibrant Philly foodie culture. It's a really hard place to describe - one really needs to go and spend an hour or two just walking around in order to really take it all in.

From Lancaster farmers to beeswax candles to wineries, this place has it all. Some of my highlights include: Bee Natural, The Original Turkey, and the Famous 4th Street Cookie Company, amongst others.

But in any case, whether you're looking to go buy some fresh produce or even go for a leisurely stroll, the RTM experience is one that you're surely not going to forget that easily.
I know a lot of people love the Reading Terminal Market but when I went I thought it was to crowded and crazy!

Reading Terminal is walking distance from my house and I love that it is. Its such a great place to go to when you're cooking dinner for someone and you need adventurous supplies or when you're hungry, but not for anything specific. Their produce stands are priced well and they have every type of food that you could think of that you can take out or eat in. Definitely worth a walk around to check out its many offerings.

This place is really cool. There are a bunch of sandwich shops, an Amish corner that has breakfast, lunch, and dinner foods, a bakery, and a sweet shop, a large fresh produce section, olive oil & vinegar shop, several coffee shops/bakeries, as well as some cultural food like Indian, creole, Thai, and Chinese.

It's fun just to walk around and in general, things are very reasonably priced. Yelp reviews say this is $$, but I'd actually say at a lot of places you can get a sandwich and drink for just about $10. 

Even though it may seem overwhelming at first (& somewhat easy to get lost in), I'd suggest walking around first to get an idea of your options before choosing a spot to eat. Dicnic's roast pork sandwich is really good. I am not from Philly, so I wanted to try the traditional roast pork w/provolone & broccoli rabe, but I was not a huge fan. Next time, I'd get the roast pork w/provolone & roasted peppers. The broccoli rabe is more bitter than I expected and did not taste like broccoli at all. 

Tip - try to walk here or take the train & walk because parking is only street parking & it's difficult to find
