You can get any and every kind of food here, ranging from Philly cheese-steaks (3 different stalls, all amazing!) to stalls with authentic Indian and Chinese food.  The place has a very "farmer's market" feel to it on the inside, as there are fresh vegetables, meat and fish being sold.  There are great desert places as well.  This is a great place to take the family for a fun meal, especially if your tastes differ.

The drawback:  CASH ONLY.
This place is awesome! So much amazing food. We ended up getting an Amish breakfast with scrapple and blueberry pancakes. Too many great things from which to choose!

Great spot to take out of town guests - give them a taste of everything Philly.
We took our kids to the Creperie inside the market and it was a huge hit!  How can you go wrong with banana, nutella and powdered sugar.  Sugar High.  Cheesteak line was huge and from what I hear so so cheesesteaks.

Reading Terminal Market has a ton of different choices from breakfast to desserts, so if you're unsure of what's in the area or if you want something quick, try any of the little shops here. Have a good look around before deciding on anything. 

Most places take credit cards. 

Definitely stop at the donut shop in the morning. Warm just-made donuts!!!!! WHAT!

There's a great spice shop that carries every spice under the sun - amazing to peruse.
Such a nice variety of food!

So much to pick from, I go on a weekly bases :) If you are going for the first time give yourself time to look around because they have almost every type of food to offer. One of the best places to eat in the city whether you are all by yourself or with friends or family. There is something for everyone there. And the food is always amazing!

Reading Terminal has some of my favorite places to eat (4th St. Cookies, the turkey sandwhich place, Bassets, Flying Monkey, the Middle Eastern place, etc.) and is something I always recommend to people visiting the city. Definitely worth the visit!
Everything you could ever want! Local veggies, good food, fresh cheese, and much more
love this market great food vendors love the donuts there best ever from the mennonites from lancaster county rocks, the new orleans restraunt rocks too love this place clean too

SO MUCH FOOD AND SO LITTLE TIME! You can literally find ANYTHING and EVERYTHING here! I come here to buy bulks of candy/chocolate for my little cousins, and the stop by for a quick lunch. It's a bit fast-paced and rowdy but definitely worth pushing through crowds for.

Reading Terminal is one of a kind.  Its rare for indoor markets to be this large and contain such a VARIETY of ethnic booths and food...in fact, it can be delightfully overwhelming at times.  You can ALWAYS find something you want at RT and i dont care who you are or what you like.  Support the friendly businesses tho, alot of rude lazy people at some of them.
Love the Amish place for breakfast, Apple dumpling with ice cream cannot be beat!  Also Rick's cheese steaks are the bomb!

This market was easily my favorite spot we visited on a recent trip to Philly. I am pretty sure we could have eaten almost every meal of our trip here and been content.

They have every kind of food you can think of here, from Mediterranean to Indian to Mexican to Philly cheese steaks. They have a lot of stands devoted to fresh fruits and vegetables, meat and fish. They have a number of bakeries with cookies, cupcakes, cakes and donuts. They have spice shops, bookstores, honey shops and souvenir shops.

I personally really liked the Amish breakfast spot with the sandwiches. My husband had the pork roll sandwich and really enjoyed it. I also loved the red velvet whoopie pie from the Flying Fish bakery. We ate lunch here and got the philly cheese steaks at Carmen's. I could have eaten at a lot of the other shops too though!

This is a really fun place to walk around and try a variety of Philly foods. The prices are generally reasonable and there is plenty of seating available to sit down and have a meal. Many places are cash-only and the market can get very crowded on the weekends. I only wish they were open for dinner too!

A must-visit in Philly!

Pros: you can find almost any kinda farmers food here. Meats seafood candies wine you name it. Some are cheap like the Dutch breakfast area, some are expensive like little amounts of whatever delicacy they make.

Cons: smells funny, looks weird and crowded, you can get lost, no areas to sit to eat, you can lose your stuff here

I went to Reading Terminal Market just to get sheep milk for my puppies. I'm not a big fan of overcrowded - pricey market. I don't know whats special about this place.. maybe I need to spend more time there...

I'm always a big fan of Reading Terminal. What's not to love? Dozens of food vendors, hundreds of food choices. We always bring people here when they're visiting us from out of town. There's something for everyone...kids, chocolate lovers, vegans, big eaters, picky eaters....you will not go hungry! 

Avoid on a Saturday, if possible. Also avoid during the Flower Show. The crowd becomes so thick it's hard to see the different food options avaiable.

I used to intern right over on 12th and race which is a block from reading terminal, so I've eaten here plenty of times.  I have to admit that it's stressful walking into this place because I am extremely indecisive! So many choices! My favorite spot here is the Thai food stand all the way in the back! It's delicious!  I would avoid the all-you-can-eat soul food buffet, the food was dry and over priced.  The chicken wings when you first walk in are a good hit as well! If you're looking for amazing coffee stop at the coffee shop right at the entrance, they make a mean mocha!

This is a Philly institution that I make a point of visiting every time I'm in town.

Farm fresh produce, great meat/fish/poultry selection, lots of great goods from the Penn Dutch folks and great food stalls = heaven.  Too bad I can't really buy a lot of groceries to bring back to NYC in the summer but I do try to grab food here and bring back a few Amish pies when I can.  Beiler's bakery makes a damn good shoofly pie!

Folks here are friendly, the food is great and most importantly, I just love the atmosphere of the entire place.  It's always great grabbing an apple dumpling to go and eating it right by the casual piano players who pop by and play a few nice tunes.  It's just a nice, friendly and relaxing place to pass the time and get some shopping (and eating) done.

I hope this place never goes away.  I'd really miss those apple dumplings and killer pies

You can find a plethora of goods at Reading Terminal Market. In one outing, you can have breakfast, lunch, and dinner, as well as get your grocery shopping done. I have not had one disappointing meal from the Market, and would highly recommend it during a trip in Philadelphia.
If its food related... you will find it here. I love this place. Take food home or eat there for an awesome people watching experience.

I've been to Reading Terminal Market dozens of times and always have a pretty standard routine, which I'm starting to believe that most people have a routine or atleast a set of Reading Terminal Market guidelines which is completely individualistic. What I mean is. I always have to start RTM with a vitamin B12 and wheatgrass shot from the middle eastern fresh juice place, then I wonder around looking for food, I always have to stop at the chocolate place and look at the hideous chocolate covered onion which I have tried by the way, end up eating either crepes, a hoagie, a collection of small treats really whatever tickles your taste buds that day.I pretty much end RTM by hitting up bassets. Thats my routine in a nutshell and I know everyone has thier own. 

Its the best part of RTM there is literally something for everyone. my reco is when you go with a group of friends just leave and do your own thing (unless you're doing the dinics thing) then don't be an ass and make your friends wait in line while you explore the glory of the market, wait with them, talk about the last night and how reckless it was. 

Sorry I got on a tangent, I actually feel like this whole review is a tangent. 

Go to Reading Terminal Market! eat lots of food and enjoy life because this is as good as it gets.
So much fun! You can eat your way through this Market and still get lost with all the options! This is a great place to hang out or bring out-of-town guests.
Excellent! Fresh fruit, veggies and delicious baked goods.

As a local to Philly, I'm pretty embarrassed to say this was only my second trip to the Reading Terminal Market. Wow. Just wow. I'm glad I didn't come hungry or I would have been quite overwhelmed. I was meeting my girlfriends for the start of a big day of eating. One of my friends suggested Reading terminal and based on what I've heard about the variety, it was the perfect pick,

We did a lap of the building before anyone purchased a thing. I wish I took notes to make my next trip easier. Things that stood out included the sushi, DiNic's, a stand with bacon, a fresh fish stand, a juice/smoothie place and the list goes on. 

We were able to grab a table with 5 seats and took turns getting our lunch. I love the variety at the table- sesame chicken, a turkey sand which, char grilled eggplant sandwich and a falafel. Since I was fresh off brunch, I decided to just have some ice cream. I was intrigued by the abundance of Amish vendors so picked Miller's Twist. After sample a few flavors, I decided on a small cup of banana ice cream. Perfect! Creamy and delicious.

If this wasn't the start of the day out, I'd probably go on a produce shopping spree. I can't wait to return hungry and ready to bring any purchases promptly to a fridge!

Great market, full of life and colors. You can find fresh fruits and vegetables as well as great restaurants and bakeries. Is a must go in Philadelphia.
Most of the places (restaurants) are close on Sunday. Check the webpage before going
Great place to goto if you have a group with many tastes. My wife and I went several times she like things I do not get into.

This place is just....paradise.

I've been here a few times over the years, and it is so jammed packed you can barely move. Now, I don't know if it was because of the heat, but this past Friday afternoon and Sunday early afternoon, it was oddly empty! I could easily just sit down somewhere if I wanted to. 

They have every kind of food imaginable there (I bought some BBQ from the Amish merchants and it was RIDIC, it was so good).  Plus, you can do your grocery shopping (meats, veggies/fruits, seasonings). It's in a really good location as well.

Heaven on Earth for hungry people...you better have self control or you could be eating cookies, ice cream, and candy for lunch ! everything fresh and priced right. HAVE THE BASSET ICE CREAM- just arm yourself with napkins- you will need them . Had Thai soup one day, rib dinner the next. So fun to browse and people watch. You gotta go !!

Reading is an adventure for your stomach. It's just got so many options, you can't possibly see everything in one trip. You can find pretty much everything here, and it's always fresh and delicious. You can buy loose leaf tea, sauerkraut, pickles, fish, cheese, meats, bread, cookies, candies, spices, flowers, anything! You can watch cheese be made, watch chocolate be molded, watch meat be butchered. It's an experience you have to have for yourself.

theres so many good stores here and almost all of them have gotten level up, the new way to pay with your phone! its (Finally!)completely free and totally safe to use. you just hook your card up to your phone and pay through an encrypted bar code. no one ever gets your info so youre safe from identity theft. Plus level up acts as a loyalty club so as you you spend money at the places you normally shop you get money back. the philly pretzel factory offers $5 back on every $30 spent! if you havent gotten level up yet use this code to get a bonus $5 global credit to use at any level up carrying location!!! 9WHRC2 and no worries the code never expires! come enjoy philly with a few extra bucks!!! ^.^
Everything you could ever want! Local veggies, great variety of food, and a bar!

I've heard a lot of great things about this market and that it's basically a Foodie Central. Reading Terminal Market reminds me of Chelsea Market very much, except with more variety of shops and food. It's quite busy here and busy with customers and tourists

So many shops condensed into one block and there's different foods to choose from.From fresh produce to seafood to meats to sandwiches to sushi to sweets and a lot more.  You have choices of Chinese, Mexican, Japanese, Cajun and a lot more. Everything here is fresh and the foods are cooked on the spot. The food is cooked right on the spot.

They have seating areas around the market. There seems to be a lot of locals that come here and tourists. If you come to Philadelphia, Reading Terminal Market has to be one of the places you visit on your list.  I highly recommend all foodies to check out the Reading Terminal Market because there is tons of food and places!

Note: A couple of the shops are closed on Sundays, so your best bet is to go on other days.

This is the greatest indoor food market in North America.  The colors, the sounds, the smells, the tastes, and the cool feel - every sense is used in a visit to the Reading Terminal Market.  Fortunately it retains its tradition and old look despite its modern infrastructure.  It's the best place in Philly to food shop and one of the best spots to eat.  There are too many culinary highpoints here to single one out.  But one thing I can tell you to def do is to put a coin in the nose of the pig statue in the center of the market, make a wish, and then rub the snout for good luck.  Now you're a real Philadelphian!

This place is an absolute gem. I'd say it's underrated, but it's pretty hard not to get into a giant selection of takeout, groceries, and specialty foods. Although it feels a bit like a post-apocalyptic market because of the labyrinth-like setup/crowded lanes/exposed ceiling, I think it adds to the charm and I wouldn't change a thing.

I was so excited about all the food I saw, but unfortunately this place CLOSES SO EARLY!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!! After being a tourist and sightseeing, by the time I got there at 5 or 6, things started closing. the hours of operation is definitely the biggest CON EVER!!!

I like that I have many choices, so I generally get entrée & dessert from different places. I enjoy the Amish food when they're open, very filling. Great for a quick bite, a relaxed lunch or even to get some fresh meats & veggies.

Reading terminal is a place one MUST visit when in Philly! It's super fantastic! Anything you want is at your disposal....snacks, treats, sweets, market value groceries & high gravity brew. 

It's a gem! Words just can't describe. Make sure you go earlier in the day or before sightseeing, it closes at 6pm on Friday:/ 

Anywho...grateful recommendation for us & passing it on to yelpers. #visitphilly

Happy everything!

This market is great to try out various food items.  There's so much to take in and try.  We got a pretzel to snack on..buttery goodness, soft and fluffy with a touch of salt.  The dipping cheese puts it over the top, highly recommend!   The sandwich from Dinic was great as well, juicy and full of meat.

It's hard to find anything bad to say about Reading Terminal Market. 

When I first moved to Philadelphia a few years ago, it was the first place I wanted to visit because of it's appearance on the Food Network several times. I was expecting something much less than what I actually found. This place is huge, and has a selection that rivals any market I have seen in the U.S. as well as abroad. 

The selections range from the famous DiNiC's Roast Pork to the incredible and authentic Cajun cuisine by Beck's Cafe. You can also find a beer garden, freshly made ice cream, fruits, vegetables, and so much more. Candy shoppes, bakeries, incredible coffee and diners, it's almost too much to be included in just one Yelp review.

The entire place is labeled with street names, making it fairly easy to navigate despite the intimidating size for first-time visitors. In addition to shops and restaurants, there is ample seating in the middle for you to enjoy whatever delicacies you try during your visit. 

It's also always expanding. Over the past two years alone I have seen several new shops appear, as well as renovations to older members of the Reading Terminal Market family. 

The only downside - DiNiC's has been known to sell out well before closing, so make sure if you're visiting and want to try their famous Roast Pork sandwich that you get there early and try to avoid the lunchtime rush.

As a native Philadelphian I have found memories of the Reading Terminal Market, the food here is excellent and there is always something interesting and delicious to try. Many people I know shop here habitually for their groceries and I get the vibe that the shop owners are loyal to their customers which they show through providing high quality products for reasonable prices. 

If you're throwing a gathering you can find all your exotic cheeses, dips, and breads here.  If you're preparing a dinner you can find all the essential spices an ingredients you will need to prepare almost every dish you can fathom. You can also find other interesting items at the Reading Terminal Market; besides food you can buy books, candles, and holistic body products as well.

A fantastic place to visit whether you're a local or a tourist. Fresh foods from the farmer's market stands, eclectic gourmet baked goods from local vendors, and some of the best regional food you can find in the city. If you like roast pork sandwiches, or cheesesteaks, or Amish food, this is a great one-stop shop

This is a food paradise, as being a life long San Franciscan all my life, I find this haven is hard to beat! The minute I walk in, I was shock n' awe by the area and variety of food emporium this is. 

Tourist and locals mingle among the market place and there is something for everybody. You will not walk away hungry and just for this one day....Forget the diet! Better yet, get some fresh fruit & produce, wolfs and lambs can walk together here.

what is there not to love about delicious, authentic, diversified food at your finger tips?  I will say if you are going to go - try going after lunch instead so there is more wiggle room to gawk at all the food your belly will be aching to sample!

If you are in the mood for a pork sammy - please go to Dinicks! Best sammy I have ever had in my life! Either wait for an open bar stool to order from the waitress or get in the To GO line. It usually moves pretty fast. 

Oh and the Donut shop---hand rolled donuts. I wanted one but ended up getting a half dozen b/c they were oh so good!

But really what can't you get here? It is a def MUST do for visitors.
Super place! Very bucolic - soothng atmosphere. Excellent food and service.

If you are visiting Philadelphia and are not sure of what to eat, Reading Terminal Market is easily the best place to start! My uncle suggested I go there and I could not be more grateful! 

Lots of shops for touristy things to buy, t-shirts, small kitchen items, etc. Lots of choices for food to eat and food to use in your own cooking. It really is the largest and most unique market I've ever seen! If only supermarkets would go away and be replaced by thousands of Reading Terminal Markets (although it would lose a little bit of its appeal.)

My favorite spots were Famous 4th Street Cookie Company, Beiler's Bakery, Dutch Eating Place, Sweet as Fudge Candy Shoppe, Lancaster County Dairy, Bee Natural, 12th Street Cantina, Dienner's Bar-B-Q, and Kamal's Middle Eastern Specialities.

The Amish merchants are without a doubt some of the best foods I have ever eaten and what makes the market so special. I ended up buying 2 pounds of various chocolate fudges from Sweet as Fudge, 2 dozen doughnuts from Beiler's, an open faced turkey sandwich from Dutch Eating Place, a Strawberry Orange Lemonade from Lancaster County Dairy, and 3 chocolate chip cookies from Famous 4th Street Cookie Company. 

If you are driving in, make sure to get your parking validated when you spend at least $10 and can park in the garage on Filbert Street for just $4 up to 2 hours. You won't find a better deal for parking anywhere else in the city. When you don't have anything else planned, you can easily spend an entire day here and you'll love every minute of it!
Seattle has the pike place market , philly has the reading terminal market which is nicer then the pike place market and with out the urine smell.
Love the variety! A bit overcrowded on the weekends, be prepared!
Great variety and fresh choices. If you go on Sunday be ware of tons of people, which makes food shopping a lot less fun! Best place to get fresh fruits and vegetables in the city for a great price!

Can be tough to find seating if you're grabbing a bite to eat while you're there, but the eclectic mix of food and goods makes it worth the trip. Also, I'm obsessed with the chapstick from Bee Natural. Better than Burt's Bees.
Amazing place. Adore Iovine's for fresh fruits and veggies. The Head Nut is fantastic for spices, flour, sugar, etc.
great ice cream, sushi, kabobs, and a fun enviroment!
Love this place! It gets a bit crowded, so bring your patience or wait for a non-peak time.
I absolutely adore Reading Terminal Market!
It's an experience, to say the least!  Not as many good vegan options since Basic 4 left, but it is still a neat place and a good place to get breads, jams, produce, and other delicious things.
Great for looking and snacking . Despite raves, lunch food is rather ordinary and uninspired with the exception of Sang Kee duck noodle stand.

RTM is one of the coolest places to visit in Philly.  It's a great melting pot of cuisines and people all smashed into a large building.  Lots of local purveyors and vendors with anything from sweet to savory for your to try and enjoy.  There's even a bar in the back to grab a beer and/or watch a game.  Some of the best cookies I've had (Hopes) are from Reading Terminal.  The (Pennsylvania Dutch) pastries and food are all excellent from various pickles to the great salads (seek out Turkey Salad.. AMAZING) to their fabolous baked goods; just be sure to go Tuesday through Saturday since they're not on premises Sunday/Monday.

Oh man! This was the very first place I visited while in Philadelphia and I have to say I really, really, really, really loved it. I mean, this place has everything! Cheesesteaks, check; donuts, check; breakfast, check; fresh meats, check; fresh produce, check, check, check!! 

It reminded me of a mixture of Chelsea Market and Eataly in NYC. I tried a few of the food places there and I wasn't disappointed. This is definitely one of the places I enjoyed the most from my visit to Philadelphia.

Super cool market! You can eat any and everything here and it all looks amazing. Only tried DiNic's here, but next time I visit Philly I will have to try more! I cam here around 9am on a Saturday morning and this place wasn't super packed at all. All the stands were open and everything looked superfresh. Definitely a place to visit if you love food and specialty items!

As a tourist, I have to say I was underwhelmed.  The market was crazy crowded.  There was no place to sit. You had to wait in super long lines for food.  It was hard to find anything.

Yes, there's a lot of variety.  Yes, the food I had was great and I found some knick-knacks in the shops, but it was a stressful visit and I felt very claustrophobic.

Had I gone without kids, I think it might've been slightly better.

This place is Amazeballs! I kid you not!

There is no way to go wrong at Reading Terminal. They have som many food options. So many good options. So many really really good, in fact great, in face Amazeballs options.

The biggest drawback on the Reading Terminal is that it closes at 6pm. Dude, this is way too early for such a great place. I mean, how are we supposed to have time to eat dinner there. I have to do a drive by at 5:30pm, and hope places still have good options, to get me some grub for dinner. Booty!

But seriously, if you have not been, you must go here. Do your homework on the spots inside too. Some are the bomb. Some are okay. And, you'll have to make a tough choice.

I love this place! You can get anything from Chinese food to Philly cheesesteaks. 

Also, you can get souvenirs, handmade crafts, and other knick knacks.

If you go during the Pennsylvania Dutch Festival (early August), they'll have homemade pastries and ice cream. I got some ice cream, and it was delicious. It was definitely worth the $3. 

This place is good for lunch, but keep in mind that it might be hard to find a place to sit. I wouldn't try going here for dinner, unless you like eating dinner extremely early, because it closes at 6 pm.

Once of my favorite places in the world! It has such a great vibe and the combination of all the great lunch places with all the great produce and fish. Was a longtime fan of the 12th Street Cantina -- how more partial to Beck's Cajun. Love the flower place as well.

When I think of Philadelphia I instantly think two things. Philly Cheesesteaks, of course, and Reading Terminal Market.

This Market really has some wonderful food merchants. And it was absolutely fantastic how close it was to our hotel!!! It was actually creepy how close it was...like not even 1/10 of a mile!


Though I didn't make it to every spot I had on my list to try, I did try out quite a few.
I first had a mixed single cup of cinnamon and dark chocolate ice cream from Bassetts. Creamy!
We then went to Chocolate by Mueller for chocolate peanut butter pretzels. Yum.
Next, I bought an anise biscotti and a chocolate chip cannoli from Termini Bros. Insane.
And our last stop was The Famous 4th St Cookie Company where we got their chocolate macadamia nut, double chocolate chip, and oatmeal raisin cookies. OMG.


Next on my list for Reading Terminal is a roast pork sandwich from Tommy DiNic's. I'm also hoping to go there between a Tuesday-Saturday, so that I can experience some of the Pennsylvania Dutch Vendors (amish...) like the Dutch Eating Place, Miller's Twist...

LOVE Reading Terminal!!!

I traveled with 7 hungry teenagers here and they were all able to find different food they liked from sushi to burgers to barbeque to southern to Philly cheesesteak, the variety was amazing. There was also a bakery, a chocolatier, florist, tablecloth and blanket boutique, an amazing assortment of booths and stores! Everyone was happy and the historical flavor and melding of people was really fun!

It feels slightly unfair to lump all of the different vendors into one category, and for places I've been I'll try to be a bit more specific. But I'm still rather impressed at the immense variety of shops spread out throughout the region. Sure, there might be a dud once in a while, but there are countless grocers, each who carry things you don't typically see in your typical supermarket. It can get pricey in a hurry, but there is a great selection and the things I've gotten have been high quality.

It's a very cool place. You can find pretty much anything you want here and more. There's always something interesting.  It's a family tradition to go here around Easter to get Cannoli and pork sandwiches, then again in Christmas for real Amish style cheesecake  (can't be beat!).

You haven't experienced Philadelphia if you haven't been to Reading Terminal. It is one of my favorite places in the city. With a myriad of ethnic food options, meat, baked goods, produce, spices and more, Reading Terminal probably has anything and everything you'd ever want food-wise. It is also a great place to people watch, whether from a table in the center of the market or at one of the many food counters. No Yelp review can do this establishment justice. It's a wonderful place and truly Philadelphia. Go if you can make it!

I'm a HUGE fan- I just don't make it there often because it's in CC and always crowded and I usually cart two small children around with me. 

We stopped by for Dutch Fest 8/9/13 and there was a small petting zoo and pony and buggy rides on Arch and it was a TON of fun for my little guys. There's always great food inside and various wares both Amish and local. 
 
They have some of the best cookies in the area at 4th street bakery and tons of butchers and even a beer garden. 

Since people stop and browse (read: block the foot path) I wouldn't be upset if they took out a row of vendors and made the aisles wider though...;-)

An easy walk, busy, but navigable. A nice place that felt like a pavilion in county fairs. All indoors and all contained to a single building, lots of Quakers selling different goods. There is a restroom toward the middle edge  of the building.
Fresh produce.  Fresh fish.  Coffee.  Desserts.  Steak sandwiches.  Teas.  Knick-nacks.  A diner.  Under one roof.

I love Reading for their fresh local produce! But it's also a must anytime I have friends from out of town visiting. So many options to choose from and so much fun energy. It's always a little crazy, especially on the weekends but it's worth it and adds to the experience. I'm a huge fan of the crepes, ribs, smoothies, spice shop, cheese shop, and fresh baked cookies!

My first time there and at first it was very overwhelming but don't despair!!!  I suggest walking the market before purchasing anything.  This place has almost everything your belly would ever want.  The Roasted veggie focaccia at Metropolitan Bakery was perfect with my bbq chicken skewer from Little Thai Market (the Thai BBQ sauce is pure crack.  I wish they sold a bottle of it).  Desert was cookies from The Famous 4th Street Cookie Company.  Those cookies are slap your mama good!!! Try the cinnamon oatmeal raisin cookie it's just so good.
Great place... but when you're here you feel like you're gonna buy everything here, its so tempting lol

A must-see for both tourists and locals alike, with dozens of stands selling fresh produce and seafood, plus many others selling prepared food from a variety of cuisines. There's something for everybody, whether gourmet cheeses, Asian or Middle Eastern cuisine, cheesesteaks, or whoopie pies. 

Service at most stands is usually fast enough to accommodate the large crowds, and there's usually enough communal seating spread throughout the establishment so that you can enjoy a bite on the go. It's open early in the morning but does close fairly early (usually around 5-6pm), so come here for a smorgasbord brunch or lunch affair, or to pick up stuff to take home.
Love this place! You can get anything here and everything is so fresh. I had a crawfish broil with the crawfish i got at the fish market. delicious!

It's the perfect place to bring out-of-towners. Try for a weekday so it's not so packed you can hardly move. Keeping track of a group on a weekend is really tough here, not to mention finding a place to eat together.

I suggest killing time during the prime lunch hour at Field House across the street. Delay your hunger with a beer and catch up with your friends, then forge a path through the diminished crowds to your favourite food destinations.

Highlights: Sang Kee Peking Duck (I always get the duck fried rice), Salumeria for killer hoagies, DiNics for roast pork, Miller's Twist for pretzels and milkshakes, Beiler's for doughnuts, Fair Food Farm Stand and Iovine's for dinner fixin's.

I really wish it was easier for me to get here during the week because I have major crowd-related claustrophobia issues and it's just too intense on the weekends.
Been coming here all my life the atmosphere is wonderful and all the food is great.

Oh no another review of Reading Terminal Market, but it is that good. I know its a tourist trap, and that it is crowded and so forth. But surprisingly compared to most "root shopping market", I'm looking at you Fisherman's Pier. Its really still true to the roots, and still has all the good food and things that Philly natives like. 

Not just from a eating perspective but also shopping perspective as well. They have a great selection of great meant vendors specializing in the off beaten track fares, as well as the good old fashion sources of protein. All fresh, tasty, and at a fair price.

Then the restaurants inside Reading Terminal is actually really good. From the buck a shuck oysters, to the artisanal lamb specialty stores, and all the way to the classic Johnny DicNic pork. 

That old say, do as the local do? Well Reading Terminal Market is as the locals do!

Go to Bassetts for ice cream and the juice bar for fresh squeezed juice. Everything else was mediocre. They do have a nice Christmas village display complete with awesome looking trains during the winter holiday. In my opinion, that's the best part.
It needs a  personality treatment and major renovations. Historic doesn't and shouldn't mean horrific.

There is so much in this market and everyday my wife and I walked through it we noticed  something new. 

If you are there for the Apple Dumplings make sure you don't go on Sunday as the Dutch side of the market is not open on Sunday's. 

I tried Tommy Dicnic's and I must say it was a great sandwich. We got there for lunch and the beef brisket was not in stock. I must say, do a little research on how to order your sandwich. This helped us be able to order quickly and feel comfortable about what we ordered.

The pork sandwich, wet, with broccoli rabi and cheese was a HIT! It was large enough for two of us to split it as a snack. We decided to try multiple things around the market.... Don't let the long lines scare you..

DICNIC'S TIP: If you find a seat at Dicnic's sit down and you won't have to wait in line!!!!

Overall, there is so much in this market it is hard to explore in one day. Take an appetite and try a little bit of everything! You won't be upset!

Absolutely love this place. Whenever I have friends visiting I always take them to this Philly staple. So many different options to chose from. I tend to stick with the Mediterranean options and am always impressed. I also always stop by for some fresh produce or fruit. 

Of course it's necessary to end the trip with Bassett's Ice Cream or a 4th Street cookie.
Love it here. The bakery is amazing and they have a delicious gluten free granola.

I can't believe I haven't already written a review for Reading Terminal. Now is the time. I'm probably in the minority of people in the City who love but don't Love RTM. 

I think this place is great for finding those oddball foods that I might otherwise have to look for on Amazon, or for snagging a bite to eat when I'm in the City for lunch-hour. This is also a great place to come for cheaper-than-store prices on produce and finding tasty, local, gourmet products like Metropolitan Bakery, DiNics Roast Beef, Flying Monkey Bakery, etc.... along with all of the cheese stands and butcheries. If you have a favorite cheese or meat, and you can't find it most places in Philadelphia, this is the place to look! 

However, the crowds here, the smells of rotting fish, the often-closed back half of the Market, and difficulty in finding seats to enjoy the lunchtime delicacies, make me a little less appeased by RTM. 

Overall, I return again and again, and there's always something new in store. If you're a visitor to Philadelphia, you can't pass this up.
I don't recommend going here for a cheesesteak. Saltiest fries on the planet at By George. However many, many other food choices and cool place overall.
I've been coming here my whole life. They offer a wide variety of prepared food, baked goods, and produce. It can get quite packed on the weekends, but it's worth braving the crowd.

Reading Railroad was always my favorite Monopoly property. I liked all of the railroads, but especially that one. Unfortunately, most of my family members knew this so they'd force me to mortgage it all to claim it. Reading Terminal? Just as cool.
 
This is a place where you can shop, eat, explore, indulge, pamper, and lose yourself for an afternoon in the aisles of restaurants and shops. 

Among the highlights:
1. Vegetarian cheesesteak sandwiches.
2. Beeswax candles and lotions, with live bees you can watch behind glass.
3. Purple roses.
4. Live piano music while you eat your lunch.
5. Fruit fry-pies. It's fried pie with fresh fruit fillings, enough said.
6. Donut vendor making donuts right in front of you. Giant vats of custard. *Cue Homer Simpson voice: Mmmm, donuts!*
7. Pig statue in the middle of it all, to remind you to pig out.
8. Handmade paper mâché food garland decorations.
9. Dutch cafe making apple puffs with fresh whipped cream.
10. Vintage bookstore. 
11. Cinnamon ice cream on top of Guatemalan chocolate coffee ice cream.
12. Fresh homegrown vegetables.
13. Cutesy culinary decorations/appliances: aprons, teapots.
14. Philadelphia tourist stuff: magnets, travel books.
15. Chocolate covered onions. Didn't try this. That just sounds gross.
16. Pay by the lb vintage candy store, run by an Amish guy in costume. Suspenders and all.
17. Free samples at many food vendors.
18. Fresh pretzels being rolled and twisted on the countertop.
19. Herbal remedies store. Awesome hand lotions.
20. Sights. Sounds. Tastes. Smells. Aisles and aisles of it. 

Skip the board games, go to the Reading Terminal.

I really don't think I'm gonna write anything you couldn't have read in the past 1,000+ reviews. I'll explain what I ate though.
Apple Dumplings.....Buy the 3 for $7 instead of 1 for $3.50. For a apple pie lover this is probably the best thing I've ever had in the realm of apple pie.
I do not remember what stand I got my Beef Jerky from but for $27 a pound I was kinda on edge....till I tasted it. I got Sweet and Spicy and it was exactly that. AMAZING JERKY!
Rocky Road Fudge - BOOM!
Split a Cheesesteak from some unknown stand before I realized there was a really popular place with a line around it. It was good, but I'm still yet to have a Philly steak in Philly that's better then my go-to spot in NJ
Pork sandwich from The Rib Stand - Pretty good size for the price with REALY good sauce they give you on the side. (Sweet OR Spicy) 
My girlfriend got Ice Cream from the really popular place and said it was good but I was stuffed at that point.

I know I know....I didn't try DiNics. By the time we got there EVERYTHING was sold out. I don't like Broccoli Raab anyway.

I did bring home some Habanero Cheese that rocks, and a more mild Chipotle cheese that I put out for guests.

I would have loved to come home with some of those $20/lbs Lobster tails the size of Popeye's Forearm, but I had a full night in Philly ahead of me and no way to keep them cool. 

I will return.

Reading Terminal is the best place in Philadelphia.  It IS Philadelphia.  All local purveyors, tons of history and just all around awesome!  Great shopping, great people watching and where all of the city intersects.  Go explore the market over and over again.  It is ever changing and always entertaining.

We come here regularly to satisfy our curious-must-try-new-cuisine belly. I absolutely love Reading Terminal. I'm a foodie and this place offers so much choices, it'll make your head spin. My favorites (for now, since I've been here in Philly for only 5 months):

Salmon Belly from Little Thai Market
Dinic's sandwiches
Bassetts ice cream
Famous 4th st Cookie
Mezze Mediterranean Food
Termini Bros Bakery
By George Pizza, Pasta & Cheesesteak
4 Season's Juicebar

The farmer's market is awesome to, fresh fruits and vegetables. Oh heaven, every time I'm there. Except when it's swarming with people then that's another story.

If I ever left Philadelphia, this is one of the places I would miss most. Its the ultimate one-stop-shop. I take all visitors and new Philadelphians here. From Termini's to the Dutch Eating Place it's really the best place to eat and people watch. So why only four stars? What happened to The Basic Four vegetarian place?! I ache over its closing...
everything you can think of. lots of good quality food and local organinc produce

This place has a lot of great food.  It's a cult phenom too - as people will travel here.  There's also a sub-place that has a broccoli raab-cheesesteak that was featured on Diner's Drive-Ins and Dive's.  A great visit if you visit the city.

Whether you are visiting Philadelphia, live in town or in the burbs, this is a must see. Whatever type of food you are craving, you will find here. A Philadelphia institution.  Mornings and afternoons are the bet bet since the market closes at the end of the workday.
I LOOOOVVEE this place, so many options to choose from just go hungry and you won't be disappointed!

I love going to the Reading Terminal Market. Lots to see, do and taste. There is not much I don't like about this place. Maybe when it's very crowded. The fresh foods are awesome. The Amish foods are great. The cheese places are great and love the different flavors they have to offer.

Reading is an nice place to go with a variety of restaurants, snack foods and other items.   Just a little pricey because it is in "Center City" and a tourist site.    Being from Philly it is A-OK for me but for the average tourist it is a great place to visit.

This is a fun place to bring anyone who visits Philly for the first time.  A lot of great variety with some classic Pennsylvania/Philly foods like several Pretzel stands and Amish food stores.  The ambiance is great too since it's indoors but all of the stands are not separated by walls.

While a technically a "working" market ,Reading Terminal Market is really just a cleverly designed tourist Mecca.....here's how I know. Try finding any visible information on how to take advantage of the $6.00 for 3 hours of parking for market shoppers at the parking facility across the street....without knowing that your ticket has to be punched by a market vendor you'll end up paying $30.00+ plus for the same time.
That being said I really love this place,crowded,raucous,exciting,and absolutely filled with all kinds of great eats, We availed our-selves of the rather disappointing Italian pulled pork and beef sandwiches with Broccoli rabe at Tommy di Nics and some excellent stuffed pretzels at the Amish.
There are so many little nooks and cranny's to explore in this rather small venue and I can't wait to try some more of what Reading has to offer....just watch the parking.

Over priced and over-hyped tourist trap.  The glory days of the Terminal are long done.  The people who manage it now are catering to higher end customers.  by giving them less quality and higher prices.  Used to be the best place to shop for everything and anything you could think of.  Most of the best eateries have been chased out by high rents.  RIP Terminal--we knew you when,

Reading Terminal Market does have a few hidden gems, but overall it's not a huge stand out to me. I LOVE Hope's Cookies and the Amish Market (their BBQ is AWESOME). I haven't really been wow-ed by the other vendors in RTM. The produce is hit or miss. Flying Monkey has NEVER had red velvet cupcakes when I stopped by. You'd think for such a popular flavor, they would make a larger quantity per day. The other food vendors are okay, but nothing worth going out of your way for. Avoid RTM at lunch time since that's when it's plagued with tourists and convention goers. So in short, when you hit up RTM, stream line for Amish BBQ followed by Hope's Cookies and you won't be disappointed.

Prices are higher then normal but, center of Philly. Convenience is the factor here all these places in one spot. Every place is pretty solid, it's a great choice if your with a bunch of people who want different stuff. Touristy, yes... But in a good way.

I want to give it 5 Stars but I can't. My 4 Star rating has nothing to do with the taste of the Food. However it does have everything to do with the crowd. But before I get to that let me tell you that if you walk in here and can't find something that you absolutely LOVE than there is something wrong with you. Ladies and Gentlemen there are no bad meals here. And trust me you won't have to walk far to find a completely different genre of food if you don't like the one you stop at...no worries just turn left or right and you are bound to find something to cure your cravings. Now back to the crowd issue. Good luck if you are a person who doesn't deal well with feeling cramped up and like you can't move. The worst hours to go in my opinion are the typical lunch hour of between 11:30 and 12:30. Oh yea and if you plan on sitting down somewhere inside to eat...forget about it.

Oh my god! I love this place! So many food choices. I could live here! This marketplace would be the reason I move to Philly. I would get an apartment right above and eat every meal at the Reading Market Terminal. From Cajun to Philly Cheesesteaks, cookies to cheese cakes, it doesn't get much better than this place in Philly. Its a few blocks from Historical Philly, so if you are in the neighborhood, drop by and get some grub.

Had my first date with my now husband here! SO MANY great foods to choose from! The market is always bustling with great energy. It can get a bit crowded so beware but the food makes it worth it! There's a little something for everyone's tastes from carved sandwiches to ice cream to crepes and falafel to cupcakes and fresh fruit! 

We even did our engagement photos here and they were awesome!

Well, with over 1000 reviews and still carrying a 4.5 star rating, (a tough feat to accomplish on Yelp) there isn't anything I can say differently that would convince you to visit this market. 

This is the ultimate foodies' paradise in the Philly area and deserves all the accolades.

Just go and enjoy!
If you eat food, you'll love it here.  Wander the halls of food, and you can have whatever your little heart desires

Okay, if you're in Philly, you have to check out Reading Terminal Market. Although the place is a bit of a madhouse because of how busy it is and seating can be hard to find, the sheer number of great eateries here makes it a place that you have to go to for lunch or an early dinner.
I love the variety at Reading Terminal Market! They have everything you could ever want to eat there!
Love this place.  They have something for everyone and a great atmosphere.  Get some overpriced fudge dipped cookies (definitely worth it) and  a pork sandwich from  Dinic's.
A must see when visiting Philly. Everything I have had in this place is great, except for the sushi. Worst sushi ever.
Love it here! I do my usual run for my grocers and for lunch stop my di nics for a corn beef excellent!! Fantastic atmosphere and people are quick with their service pricing is the best!!

Loved this place! So glad we found it on our vacation. So nice that we went both days. This place was fun to explore and had everything you could want as a tourist. If I'm ever back in Philly you can rest assured that I'll be here again. The lines go fast so don't let that deter you from trying whatever you want. The lines mean the food is worth it!
So many choices! Great for a visitor coming into town. A lot of places only take cash so keep that in mind. Love Smuckers for breakfast.

I have no words. This place is beyond wonderful. If you are in Philly- do not miss this gem. A few personal faves: alligator sausage and chix&corn soup from Cajun place. ALL the pretzels from Millers pretzels. Kale salad from tootsie something.  And if the fish market has fresh soft shell crab- EAT IT!!!
So many options, don't go too hungry.  Best place is the Valley Shepherd Creamery!

Love Love this place. Always a treat every time I go. I usually buy my groceries from there because its maybe 20 cents cheaper than conventional super markets. This place is awesome to just hang out with some friends sampling all kinds of foods. They're open super early and closes around 6pm.

Amish people, fresh baked goods, fresh seafood, fresh veggies, variety of different cultures and cuisines, pickles and beef jerky for days. This place has everything and is so unique from anything we have down here in Texas including Amish people, yes. I come here and I don't even know what to eat or what to pick up. Homemade pickles and jerky from the Amish is a must. I go to those two places first. Then I'm craving Indian food, Thai Food, Chinese Food, Soul Food, Mediterranean food. So I end up walking around for half an hour, making a round through the entire market TWICE and still can't figure out what to eat.  

A lot of places is cash only but there are ATM machines scattered throughout the market. I usually just take the subway here and walk to avoid parking because parking in the city? Forget about it. Don't do it, don't even think about it. Just don't.

Love love loveeee The Reading Terminal! There's so much diversity and so many different foods to try. From Bassetts Icecream, hamburgers and fries to Chinese food. Something is bound to catch your eye and it's a great place to explore!

The food choices here are very good BUT every single thing is served in plastic or styrofoam :( EVERYTHING!!! There are NO "here" cups/plates/utensils. It's absolutely ridiculous!! Even when eating at a counter there, the only choice/s are styrofoam plates - not even paper!! 

When I mentioned this to the workers and patrons most did not care one bit. When I explained that every piece of plastic or styrofoam will eventually end up in the stomach of a sea animal they made fun of me and called me a hippie.

I find it interesting that if someone cares about the environment and the wildlife and not themselves, they are the "bad guy". I should be more narcissistic like them? It's a sad commentary on our society if you ask me - not that anyone is asking me...

Hershel's East Side Deli has great food, it's where I ate the most. The people who work there are really nice and agreed with me re: the plastic and styrofoam. There is also a freshly squeezed juice bar but sadly if you order a large (32 ounces) they give it to you in a styrofoam cup which kept me from returning.

Overall I'd have to say I wouldn't go back to the Reading Terminal Market - the environment is just too important to this altruistic tree hugging hippie.

The "must do" thing in Philly. The Reading Terminal Market is as much Philly as the Cheese Steak or Roast Pork Sandwich. Be sure to get some cookies at 4th Street and Bassets is really yummy. Dinic's roast pork is the best in the world and from Wednesday through Saturday the Amish are there selling their goodies and wares. 

It does get VERY crowded but a total genuine Philly experience.

I love the fact that this place has a lot of food choices and is generally inexpensive. There's always something to eat for whatever I'm feeling like. I especially appreciate the Amish foods on Thursdays. My only reservation is the crowd at lunchtime - be prepared to be bumped and possibly shoved and occasionally miss out on a table...it's all worth it though. Everyone who visits Philly has to stop by here... :)

Oh man. I love this place. What more could you want? Everything from bakery foods, produce, cheese, meats, fish, fresh pre-made foods, local favorites, pastries, coffee shops, local winery area, a beer garden, and other artsy shops. I could only shop/eat food from here and I'd be totally happy.


Only down sides- it can get seriously crowded! Also, some of the places might be a bit more expensive than a traditional stores, or locations outside this area. Still...not reasons to not go. Its amazing there!

Mostly I love RTM for Iovine's and L. Halteman's meat selection.

I would give five stars if every food stand was amazing, but unfortunately most are ok-to-good. The Down Home Diner is a decent spot for breakfast, you can never go wrong with the Dutch Eating Counter, and Dinic's roast pork sandwich is pretty amazing. The cookbook store is always worth a stop if you enjoy cooking, and be sure to get yourself a 4th Street Cookie, a Beiler's donut, and some Bassett's for dessert. You piggy, you.

If you're planning a trip to Philadelphia, I highly recommend a visit here. I especially like going there for lunch. It does get crowded, so get there early. Then you can sit, enjoy your lunch and watch the flood of people...great people watching.

This place is the most wonderful and most dangerous place ever. It's literally a mall of food. You can do your grocery shopping here (produce is usually pretty cheap), get a fantastic bread and cheese pairing, and some crazy good (and good quality) meats and go home and make a great dinner for yourself. 

Be wary though, you will want to buy everything because everything in this place is wonderful--keep your wallet in the hands of another. I recommend the reuben sandwich at Hershel's (I get it with pastrami), also some local Amish dessert breads, and there's a great cheese selection.

Why would it be less than 5 stars? I guess it's crowded but that's because it offers so much and I take that as a good sign, obviously. We mostly go here for the lovely selection of raw milk and meats from the Fair Food Farmstand but we've eaten lunch at a few of the stalls and bought some very tasty cookies here before, too. It's a great place and we are grateful to have it in philadelphia. We drive an hour to get here! I guess my only beef is that a validated ticket only gets you a $2 discount in the parking garage... mostly in other places, validation gets you free parking (we spend 60-100 bucks here sometimes!) but such is life. Now we've taken to dropping one of us off and circling the area until we get our goodies lol!
Great variety of food for tourists! The flying monkey and hopes cookies are great dessert spots!!! I suggest for people to come visit here if ure from out of state!

I love this market.  I do the majority of my grocery shopping here and love the quality and variety of fresh fruits and vegetables, seafood, meats, and cheeses.  On Sundays and Wednesdays, students can get 10% off at some places.  However, if shopping on Sunday, beware that a number of stalls will be closed.  It does get very crowded on the weekends, but if you go in the morning you can beat the lunchtime rush.  There are several diner-type stalls that cook up a fantastic breakfast!
Always something new, different, and exciting. This place is like a cross-section of the Philadelphia gastronomic experience. Do not miss it!

200+ reviews later, finally writing this jawns up. That's what we say in Philly, right?

I ain't gonna lie to you, kid. I usually only come here when people are in town visiting because it's made for indecisive people like me! Sure I want to take my out of towners to my favy restaurants, but at the same time I'm like "well hmmm, this person only eats vegetarian, and this chick has a gluten allergy, and this assh%le only eats steak..." etc etc so it can be like a nightmare coming up with a place where we can all be happy. Hence Reading Terminal where I don't have to dictate anything, I can just point you to what you're craving and we can all meet up by the tables by the piano (real, not electric today!). Great! 

The festive thing about this place is that it's not just food. They've got flowers, they've got cookbooks, they've got jewelry, they've got kitchen gadgets... So it's a great place to wander around too, which is perfect when you're sick of taking everybody to see the bell for the 100th time. And hey, I needed olive oil and a bag of green beans... and viola! I can grab those things here too. So wonderfully efficient, one stop shopping like Target but like, less evil. I think. 

The only uncomfortable thing which also makes me laugh dorkily to myself is the waiting-for-the-tables nightmare. When it's crowded and you've hit like everybody with your ginormous roast pork sandwich trying to hustle to find a table you then have to STALK the various areas and watch people eat, counting how many minutes it'll take them to finish based on their current consumption rate/conversation. I like to find the quiet people. They leave faster. But it's so awkward swooping down and crowding them when they're just trying to relax and enjoy their Amish food. But it's gotta be done. No way around you feeling my beady-eyed stare at the back of your head as you try to finish your fried mac and cheese ball. Sigh.

Do it. Come here. It's quintessential philly, baby.
good variety. easy access.

I buy all of our meats in bulk from Giunta's and Godshall's and save a lot on good,  quality meats...  Plus, 4th street cookie, flying monkey, pork sammies, fried oysters, Iovine's, bassetts.... Yes, yes yes.

Any trip to the city of brotherly love can't be considered complete without a trip to the market. Whether your a foodie, organic lover, craft queen, etc there is definitely something for you. All of the vendors are super nice and more than willing to answer questions you have about their products. If you are a foodie and are in reasonable driving distance bring a cooler for the leftovers/fresh meats and seafood.

This place is a hot mess.  But I love every single thing about it. 

It's loud and hectic but full of just about anything you might be looking for- fresh produce, counter after counter of meats, cheeses, and baked goods.  Oh the baked goods!

We spent well over an hour wandering around and finally settled on a Boneless Rib Sandwich from The Rib Stand (http://www.yelp.com/biz/the-rib-stand-philadelphia#hrid:mN-jilQ6AgwBRYEDz6PO9g) and several snacks from Beiler's Bakery (http://www.yelp.com/biz/beilers-bakery-philadelphia#hrid:2FZHu1jUHxo8Y4oXKGVQfQ).  So good!  Can't wait for another visit. 

Other notes:
- It's set up like a grid which is nice, and there are several exits.
- Some of the food stands have places to sit inside, but there are a handful of large seating areas in the middle of the market.  
- There are also a bunch of tables/chairs outside along 12th Street.
- The bathrooms were surprisingly really clean and stocked.

Though I've heard a lot about this place and this one is the closest to my office. I would still say, they are not worth the money.

Not good options for veggies and the place is too crowded.

If you're in Philly, you HAVE to pass by the Reading Terminal Market and make sure you have an empty stomach when you do. They're open Mon thru Sat from 8 AM to 6 PM and Sun from 9 AM to 5 PM and they're closed on the major holidays.

I'll get to the food in a second but they also have/sell Flowers, Plants, Seafood, Organic/Specialty Foods, Housewares, Books, Crafts, and Produce. Now onto food, they have BBQ, Mexican, Delis, Greek, Chinese, Cheesesteaks, Cajun, Thai, Pizza, and the list goes on. Even though not all of the places will have their own seating, there is a common seating area somewhere towards the middle. 

I'll def be returning here next time I'm in Philly!

A Boston native, I went here by recommendation, hearing it was similar to Faneuil Hall. It is so much better than that! There are more vendors and stands than you can imagine packed into that space. Any foodie could stay here for hours. 

I personally enjoyed the $1 blackberries, and huge create your own salad bar, with everything from chickpeas to chicken wings. I enjoyed the local fruit and vegetable stands as well as the variety of ethnic foods. Be sure to grab a chocolate dessert on the way out!

If you are looking to avoid your typical chain restaurants while visiting Philly, this is your place to go to.

The place has a wide variety of everything you could imagine. If I worked in Center City, I would come here almost every day (wallet permitting).

In my opinion, every food is slightly over priced except for the actual supermarket. The pasta is freshly made and I made a delicious pasta dinner that night with fresh vegetables as well. 

It is certainly worth it to come here to experience every culinary delight you can think of
If you can't find what you are looking for here then you don't know what you are looking for.  Absolutely best eats from all over the Philadelphia area!

I wish I had a market like this close to where I live because I would be here a few times a week to shop and eat.  It was packed on a Saturday but that didn't stop us from checking out all the places.  We tried a few things here and they were all good to excellent.  The only downside was not being able to try everything.

This place is honestly a foodie's heaven. Any type of food you want, restaurants, take-out, and markets, and all reasonably priced. The Tubby Olive has amazing Olive Oils and Balsamic Vinegars (the best is the dark chocolate balsamic vinegar). There is a donut place towards the back (I can't remember the name) that has the most amazing PB&J donut. All I can say is that when you are in Philly, make sure you don't miss this stop!!!

Heard about this place from a friend on a visit before officially moving out and loved it! Have only tried 1 or 2 of the food stands, but good. A little pricey, but it is definitely a tourist spot. The donut place, don't know what it's called, but seriously, amazing! And not a bad price when the regular donuts cost the same amount as the fancier kind.

And I can't give enough props to The Chubby Olive. A great olive oil/vinegar booth inside. Was one of the only places open on our first visit (we didn't realize how early it closed) and when we told the guy we were visiting from out of state, he gave us a 15% discount, which was so generous. We only bought a small sample pack (had to get it home on the plane somehow without checking our luggage) but seriously so good.
Lots of fun. Plenty of places to shop and eat including a winery. Biggest problem is the parking which is scarce and expensive

Love this place! So much to see, eat, and do.

My favorites are the juice bar, the tea place, and the place with all of the natural soaps!

Spend the afternoon here, grab some treats, enjoy yourself!
You can find basically anything you want or need here. Candles, honey, snacks, meat, breakfast, lunch, dinner.
It's busy, but totally worth it. They also started validating for parking from what I know.

Food nirvana is the best way to describe this place. Everything from matzo balls to the best grilled cheese sandwiches you'll ever have to fresh produce and seafood and the pot to cook it in.  On Sundays several of the vendors close up shop, so to get the full experience plan for another day.  A couple of hours is good to wander through the market and take everything in. The cheesemaker in the back is beyond belief (Valley Shepherd Creamery?). If you love cheese, this place has your number.  And the sandwiches from Melt Kraft? Absurdly delicious. Dessert can be had at the Flying Monkey Bakery, or a huge, fresh baked cookie from the Philadelphia General Store.  

Come here with an appetite and someone to help carry everything back to the car!
Make sure you get some chocolate chip cookies when they are HOT and don't forget the candy shop right next to it.  The cookies are right at the front door. The best ever!

OMG. Have I died and gone to food heaven???

Jessica White states it perfectly in her article "Best of Reading Terminal Market":

"History junkies have the Liberty Bell and Independence Hall, art enthusiasts have the Philadelphia Museum of Art and animal lovers have America's first zoo. Food connoisseurs, who eat as a pastime and not just for sustenance, have Reading Terminal Market, Philadelphia's historic and iconic food hall. Boasting over 80 merchants selling Amish specialties, fresh produce, charcuterie, cheese, confections, etc. (the list is endless), this bustling market overwhelms even the most adept food shopper. Street scoped out the extensive offerings, feasting on the best grub -- from the gourmet to the greasy. Whether you have 30 minutes or three hours, check out the best of Reading Terminal Market."

The best lunch location in the city! You can get just about anything under the sun! Ice cream, cookies, smoothies, sandwiches, beer, you name it, they have it! Our favorites include DiNic's, Basset's Ice Cream, and the Dutch Eating Place.
What can you say about the Reading Terminal? Whatever your heart desires is at the Reading Terminal, meats, deserts, spices, breads. You name it, they have it.

For groups of people who have no idea what they feel like having or can't come to a compromise on the same restaurant - just go here, split up, and meet back at a table.  It covers absolutely anything you'd want - great thai, greek, roast beef, indian, brisket, middle eastern, cannolis, ice cream, coffee, you name it.

I stumbled on this wonderful market.  I was just trying to find the Dutch Eating Place for breakfast and didn't know it was part of the Reading Terminal Market.  What an extraordinarily wonderful market.  The pork sandwich at DeNics is the best I've ever had and the Cannoli at Termini's Bakery is to die for.

This is probably my favorite place to go in all of philly.  And a must see stop for tourists visiting. My only complaint is that during peak times - between 11am and 3pm, especially on weekends,  it becomes claustrophobic and virtually impossible to navigate within the massive crowds.  My advice is arrive close to opening and bring an appetite, even most of the lunch places open early...Roast Pork from DiNic's at 10am - sounds perfect :-)

Reading terminal market, are you a foodie haven or a tourist trap? I think that you are a foodie haven that moonlights as a tourist trap. The tourists own this place, along with convention goers and business type people. My favorite place here is DiNics roast pork. There are several other places that I have bookmarked (Beck's, Termini Bros, Flying Monkey, etc) and I was able to check off The Dutch Eating Place from my bookmarks this visit. I'd like to think that you'd be able to get almost anything you need here, the exception being anything hard to find or extremely specific specialty items. The Amish donuts are amazing, but only worth eating while they are hot and fresh. I have Bassett's Ice cream near  the top of my list of must trys. 

Expect large crowds, and larger lines during lunchtime throughout the week, surprisingly enough, the crowds were light on Saturday around 10am.
I was here once during the Car show. It (the market in general) was overly crowded and had a dirty feel to it. We ended up at the Down Home Diner. Food was ehhh ok. Staff was really nice though.

I don't get it, how is this the biggest tourist attraction in Philly? Reading Terminal Market reminded me of the Farmer's Market at The Grove upon entering, only completely indoors and much more cramped. While I found the various Amish vendors complete with workers who looked and dressed the part to be quite interesting and a novel sight, none of the food actually looked very appealing. 

Not sure if I'm just not appreciative of the culture or what, but I honestly don't get the draw of this marketplace.

Great Local place to come to on the weekend. There is so much to offer here; between the different types of food to the many ethnic backgrounds that walk around. It's really enjoyable to come here with friends or family and the experience makes for a wonderful adventure!
Don't know what you want to eat? Have a diverse crowd to feed? Head to the Terminal. Vendors selling anything you can imagine.
Awesome, a foodie's dream, paradise, outstanding food, excellent quality and you don't have to break the bank, I cannot wait to be back in Philly!!!

**Five Stars**

I literally died and gone to food heaven once I stepped in here!  A definite place to put on your list if you are in the area.

If you don't know what to eat, come here - whether you have dietary restrictions, on a budget or just plain picky - there is something for everyone! From your typical Philly Cheese Steak, hoagie, Soul Food, Greek, Amish foods and breads, seafood, various fresh fruits, hot and fresh cookies, specialty donuts, homemade ice cream...the list goes on...literally something for everyone.

While some can compare the Reading Terminal to "The Grove" in Southern Cali, I would somewhat agree.  The Terminal however, seems to have such a historical significance and different feel once you step in.  

My only gripe is that it would be great if they were open longer. Busy peak times are during lunch, some vendors start cleaning up and closing shop at around 3:30ish and the entire market closes at 6pm.

Overall, highly recommended, you will not be disappointed.

It's like a foodie wonderland!  I love places that always surprise me, and that is just what Reading Terminal does.  One of my favorite stops is always the Fair Food Farmstand to pick up some raw milk or feta or some local, seasonable veggies.  The staff are great and you can pay with level up.

I also still love Tootsie's salad bar which always offers a light snack option.  If I am in need of coffee, there are plenty of shops selling brewed drinks or the beans to take home.  And cheese!  Fabulous cheese offerings towards the middle of the space. The newer additions include a spices and candies store, back by the restroom area.  And an oil and vinegar shop.  There is also another cheese store near these, so it is an easy walk down the line for all your artisanal goods.  I 

Definitely take a look at the maps on the wall when you visit.  It can be crowded at peak meal times and it is easy to lose your orientation with plentiful distractions around.  Some seating is available throughout if you wish to sit, when it is not as busy. I recommend making this a stop on your itinerary if you are in Philly and leaving yourself time to explore if you can.  One of my fav parts of center city!

This Market is Philadelphia! if you can only visit one place in Philadelphia, this is it.
Shop, eat, browse and gaze in wonder.
I have been coming here since i can remember and i am going to start Medicare in May, it has been my favorite place my entire life.

This place is absolutely bananas!  They have every possible type of vendor you can imagine and plus it's in the heart of the city.  A true Philly institution!  If you have never been to Philly or just visit every so often, the Reading Terminal Market is a MUST STOP!

So many choices, so many choices! Where do I even begin?!? Came here for the first time ever during Jury duty (even though I've been living here for ages!!! lol) and was completely overwhelmed. They have everything that you can think of...asian, italian, sweets, american, etc etc etc. You have to go here if you ever visit Philly. If you are a huge fan of food like myself, you would want to purchase everything! You probably have to go back everyday you're in town (and even if you did, you wouldn't have been able to still try everything)

Going back this weekend for the festival (yes..they always have stuff going on here)
Love the terminal..tons of varieties of fresh food, and plenty to eat. 5 stars
Great place to bring tourists, lots of good, high quality food, but it's just so crowded and I'm not sure you can get anything here that you can't get at DiBruno Brothers.
Love this place!!! The market is the place to be for good good food. Its a must go when visiting philadelphia. From fresh cheese to fresh produce and meats. You can find almost anything.

A Philadelphia landmark that fills locals and tourists...and jurors, oh can't forget the random convention people all craving good eats. If you're afraid of fairly large crowds, then this place isn't for you during the weekday lunch rush hour. If you want fresh produce or a cheesesteak or just cheese, this is your place! Tuesday through Saturday I think are the best days to go since the Amish vendors are there with their comfort food and sweets. There's something for everyone here!

Don't know what kind of "mood" you're in? Just take a stroll through this classic Philadelphia market. Japanese, BBQ, Amish, Jewish Deli, American, Indian... you can't possibly leave here unsatisfied. 

This is one of the go-to places I like to take guests from outside of the city, there's really something for any taste pallet!

Wow is all i can say!  This place is awesome!  This place is a HUGE station that has tons and tons of small stations set up for food and groceries and more food!  There's a small area to sit and eat and people watch.  Just walk around, pick a direction and go and smell the food!  

Really - it's really awesome.

Amazing foot market and a must if you are in Philly.  Can be crowded on weekends but it's well worth it.  We got a little food from a few different markets. From amazing Chicken wings to a nice pastrami sandwich.

vendors I like the most:

iovine brother produce
dutch eating place
Beller;s donut

Walking around Reading Terminal Market is a great way to spend a rainy day. They have so many booths with different kinds of food and knick knacks that you can spend hours meandering and never get bored. There's also an excellent fresh produce section on the back. It can get crowded around lunchtime, so be prepared to find a quiet corner to sit and eat and people-watch.

New Yorkers: Think "Chelsea Market", but about 7,634,699,734,876,921 more raucous. 

Hot DAMN. 

This amazing conglomeration of foods and gifts is delightfully overwhelming. Pick up homemade fudge, market fresh veggies, Amish-made pretzels, and sinfully greasy cheesesteaks all within a 20 foot radius. 

A suggestion, for the tourists: it gets packed like a can of sardines in there. If you are carrying bags or luggage, drop it all off at your hotel first or be prepared to be "that person" that drags their loaded stuff through the tight crowds. (Ummmmm...sorry, folks. Ha!)

One stop shop for everything; fresh produce, French pastries, cheese, meat, seafood and some wonderful dining choices all under one roof. It is a city by itself and a great place to shop and walk around. It is lively and bustling and is unbelievable that everything is going on inside one huge umbrella.

Love this place! Any day! Any time! Always interesting vendors and people watching. I love the Tubby Olive for vinegar tasting! My favorite vinegar is the fig - great in almost anything from roasted mushrooms to drizzling on pears and blue cheese. Yummy!

One of the must sees in downtown Philadelphia is the Reading Terminal Market. I didn't know exactly what this place was until I actually ventured here on a Friday after sightseeing in the historical district. The Reading Terminal Market is basically a larger than life indoor Farmer's Market that mingles like a Chinatown as well. There's plenty of vendors and food choices that will make your head spin. I probably spent a good hour here and buying a few things before heading back to the hotel on Walnut Street.  Pretty much anything and everything food wise you can get is here. 

Located on 12th Street, the Reading Terminal Market  is centrally located in downtown Philadelphia. Many bus routes converge here and it's very walkable from all points in downtown. It's quite busy here and it  tends to be loaded with a lot of people surfing for good deals on anything and everything. It reminds me of a indoor Chinatown in a way, where all the vendors line up tightly and it's more or less a mom and pop operation for each vendor that's represented. Good deals can be had here and I took advantage of it.

Prices here can be wholesale and retail at the same time, depending on what you are looking for. There is even a shoe shinning operation at the back of the market. I'm not sure why tripadvisor told me that this is really a must do, but it wasn't as good of a visit that I thought it would be. While it was cool to get deals and see how the locals and tourist folk do their business in some crazy fashion, I have no doubt that the Reading Terminal Market is as popular as they say it is. Overall, I would recommend this place for shopping and something to do.

Support local!

B

I'm not too experienced when it comes to markets (I have been to St. Lawrence Market in Toronto, but only twice), but this place just seems to be such a dive. It's so big and there's so much variety in terms of food available.

One thing you have to remember is that these markets are mostly family owned and have local ingredients. Sure, they may be slightly more expensive, but you're supporting the local economy, local families, and most importantly you get food in return!

As a tourist in Philadelphia, I highly recommend this place. Grab a philly cheesesteak, because it's just one thing you have to do when you're there.

I absolutely love this place!!! This place is so unique that everyone who comes to Philly should at least visit reading terminal. I go here for lunch almost every other day. Some of the food stands can get kind of expensive but its totally worth it! Don't forget to go to Dinics and get some Ice cream at Bassetts!

If you come to Philly and skip this place and are a foodie, your trip was not complete. 
I hate to say it but you messed up. This place has so much going on and so much variety and culture it almost over whelms you. 

There is a reason why this place has such a great review from our fellow yelpers. They have a little bit of everything, I recommend if you come in a group everyone go to a different spot and grab something and meet back up and split so you can try a little of everything. 

It can be tough to find a place to sit but just be patient. This place is worth a visit for Tommy DiNic's (which is why I came) but it had so much more than I expected. Seriously don't sleep on this place. If you are looking for a cold one hit the bar that is in the back by the restrooms. CHEERS!!!
Great food, great people, decent amount of seating. If you're in Philadelphia you MUST check this place out.

So much stuff!  There's gooseberries in the produce section. The thing about the produce section is that it is so expensive.  for example, I just got starfruit at Trader Joes for $0.99 each, but was $1.99 and also about half the size here.  

Somewhere in Reading Terminal there's a stand with rose lassi and pomegranate lassi!  It's unhelpful that I forgot to make note of the name.  

I never go to Reading Terminal without getting gator gumbo at Beck's.
What a great market!  Far better than Grand Central Terminal market in NYC!  Anything and everything can be found here...my favorite part of the market is the Amish section...

I walked in and was wow'ed. Not my first time at a food court but somehow Reading Terminal is better and is a bit more than your typical food court. There are a lot of homemade goods and freshly made food. I loved all the Amish stalls. The prices for the most part are pretty decent. My favorite stall is the fresh donut stall from Beiller's. if you are visiting Philly, this is a must see place.

Have lived in Philly for 4 years and only just visited Reading Terminal Market yesterday. I was missing out! I've been to similar markets in Boston, DC, and in my most recent visits to Barcelona and Madrid and RTM is just as awesome and its right in my backyard!

Boyfriend and I went in on a Saturday and though it was bustling with activity it wasn't too difficult to meander our way through and find a table once we chose our respective dishes. (I picked Meltkraft (?) he chose a crepe place). The number of options was great as 1. we can never agree on where to eat because we both always want different items, this satisfied us, and 2. you can go here 100 times and not get the same thing twice.
