So many different options of food and goods. The employees were great with helping us find something we would like, even when they didn't work for that other booth -- it has a great community feel. I suggest asking the other workers what they recommend if you're looking for the best [insert delicious food here] as they work and eat there daily so they have some great recommendations. 

I will definitely be returning to RTM in the future, though they do close early, so perhaps only on the weekends!

LOVE reading terminal. Love Iovine's produce, the butchers and fish markets. I come here for all of the grocery items I can get. The amish bakeries are amazing and the diner inside is phenomenal. Worth the trip.

Okay, it is a tourist magnet but if I were local, I'd still go there once a week.  It blows away similar food halls in other cities.  The Amish presence adds a nice touch and we had breakfast at the counter of the Amish Kitchen and it was killer.  Went back for lunch as the variety is overwhelming and yet the quality is consistent from rib joint, to sushi to the oyster bar.  Just outrageous.  Needless to say I stopped there on my way to the airport to load up on food for the ride and the fresh turkey sandwich rocked.
It's a good thing I don't live there, between the Amish donut place and the big bakery (pumpkin donuts?), I'd be on Biggest Loser.

Pretty awesome, especially in the middle of the city.  You can find anything you want.  Candles, fresh produce, fresh seafood, hoagies, wine,  beer, Italian food...the list goes on & on.  

There are several cheesesteak places....of course this is Philly.  

There are pictures of the Philly skyline & hand made stationary available.   Most of the fresh seafood shops/stalls offer to cook your purchases for you.  There are several cheese shops & Mediterranean shops. 

Everything looks very appetizing.   The Italian shops smelled wonderful.   Some things had reasonable prices (produce) while others seemed a little high (the seafood).

Was just strolling around my hotel and by accident landed in this little piece of heaven. One mouthwatering food stall after another. If you love food more than people, as one of my special friends tends to say, then this is Shangri La.
I bet half of the stalls here would make it on my yelp list.

I wish I lived in Philly just to go to Reading Terminal Market regularly! Baltimore has 6 public markets and though I've only been to 3 of them, I'm going to overgeneralize and say this one is better than them ALL (debate is welcome lol)! There's so much to taste and see you need at least a couple weeks daily visits to try it all. I love that there's ample seating to enjoy the goodies you buy.

This was my first visit! I got breakfast from the Dutch Eating Place and baked goods from the adjacent bakery. Everything was delicious from the fresh churned butter on my french toast to the thick cut turkey bacon. I took home wheat and oatmeal bagels, cinnamon rolls, sticky buns, and crumb cake for less than $10! I love the Amish!

I'm with my fellow yelpers, if you're in Philly and don't stop here you're totally missing out. I CANNOT wait to go back!

Decisions decisions! So hard to choose a spot. There is a little of everything here. I saw Philly cheesesteaks, pork sandwiches, delis, local produce, hot pretzels, ice cream and so much more!! I tried the pork sandwich with provolone and sweet peppers at dinicks. It was a melt in your mouth kind of sandwich. Very impressed by the way the meat was done. The bread was fresh and had just the right texture... not too hard and not too soft. Be prepared to get messy, as this sandwich has ALOT of (tasty) juices that run. The sandwich totaled to $10 tax included. A little pricey if you ask me, but worth it. I also had Bassets ice cream. The flavors I got were coffee, chocolate, and moose tracks. Three scoops in a cup totaled $5 tax included. Decadent ice cream and so thick! Definitely satisfied my sweet tooth. I also had a hot pretzel... Forgot what the name was, but it was the only place serving hot pretzels. They were alright. Nothing special. A pretzel totaled $2.25 I believe. My reason for 4 stars and not 5 is that this place is SUPER crowded at rush hours. Hardly any place to move. It's an "on the go" kind of scene so don't expect to find restaurant kind of seating.
Lots of fun eateries!! Inexpensive yummy local famous food. Also have many dessert choices. It's indoor,so it's a perfect hang out/lunch spot especially during hot summer days!

Absolutely love this place.....great variety of food....kinda crowded on Saturday afternoons.....I personally do not like crowds especially how tight people are in there....My best place is the produce corner....has everything you would need and the prices are fair.....A little upset when the spice store closed in the back...A must to go to when downtown Philly....pick up some cheese, wine and sweets....

My girlfriend frequently shops here and I have been a few times... you can't really beat this place in the city for selection and price, although personally for me it's too crowded. But if you can get over that part of it, it's probably the best place to go for fruits, veggies, etc.

This place is ridiculous!  I've been wanting to check out Reading Terminal Market for a long time since seeing it featured on an episode of Man v. Food.  So much good stuff in there that it's way too much to cover in one visit.  A lot of the best stuff that Philadelphia has to offer can be found here:  Scrapple, BBQ, Grilled Cheese Sandwiches, Roast Pork, Seafood, and yes, even Cheesesteaks.  It was a sure treat to spend time over here.

Definite must stops are DiNic's and Dutch Eating Place.  But then again those were pretty much all I was able to visit due to my limited stomach capacity.  I'll have to come back again to try everything else.  I will definitely return!!

Best place to go if your group can't decide on what type of food to eat. There's everything from Chinese to cheesesteaks to fried chicken. During the weekday, it's best to go after the lunch hour. Because it's downtown, it's ridiculously busy between 11:30 AM and 1:30 AM. 
Great tourist spot to hit if you've never visited the city before.
I love Reading Terminal Market! It has everything! I love Tommy DiNic's!

One of my favorite places in Philly. 

Reading Terminal is a 2 block walk from my office and about 4 block walk from where I currently live. I pass by it everyday on the way to work around 8:30am to 9am and it's already packed with people. You can find anything and everything here from gourmet food to diner breakfasts to fresh made bread or even home made cheese. It really is the melting pot of Philadelphia. I could spend hours in there roaming around, eating all kinds of different foods.

Saturdays the busiest but you may also want to avoid lunch traffic on weekdays as it is frequented by everyone and their moms which means you'll have to fight for a table to eat your food or spend all of your lunch break waiting in line for a meal. They close early on weeknights.

I do 90% of all of my grocery shopping here.  There is something here for everyone!  From the fresh produce, numerous fish mongers, 4 or 5 butcher shops.  There are also a large number restaurants within.  Head here for the best Reuben of your life!  Wonderful new place that sells fresh mozzarella made on site.  I could go on for days about Reading Terminal Market.  Do yourself a favor and check this place out!  For foodie folks in from out of town this is  a must!
One of the best places to go for fresh cuts and random food adventures! Too bad I only get to visit about once a month or so ... :)

I went to Philadelphia for a quick work trip, and figuring I wouldn't have time, I didn't do any research in advance. I am SO happy I stumbled upon the Reading Terminal Market.

I only went to the market in the morning during the week and it was not crowded at all. I was able to walk through the aisles, look at menus, talk to the folks who worked there, and easily find a seat to eat at. I can't even imagine what this place is like during the weekend, and honestly, I'm happy not to find out! 

The market is a mix of small restaurant types and market stalls. The produce, fish and meat all seemed very fresh and the place was just clean all around. I found all of the people working there to be very friendly and helpful, but again, I imagine it's not so nice on the weekends. Such an awesome indoor market -- would love something like this for the Boston winters!

Philadelphia staple. Enough to choose from to please everyone.  Good to eat-in or shop for - well, pretty much anything food related. Try to avoid the lunchtime rush, its easier to wander around and take it all in during off-peak hours.

To echo the words of Jason C., "a nice tourist trap".  But there are a lot of locals that eat here too so what gives?  It seems like the regulars use the tables for lunches brought from home and maybe a dessert purchased within the market?

The only items worth purchasing will be made by anyone that looks like they're Amish.  The best items will come from those that are actually Amish.  You should probably check out my list aptly titled "Philadelphia" for more information.

Buyer beware...

Thanks to DJ M. for reminding me about the great things in Reading Terminal Market. As I described it to someone back home, "it's like Pike Place Market in Seattle, but older, and without the flying fish!"

Locals can get fresh produce, fish, artisan cheeses and more to take home. Lucky them! 

Lucky everyone- we can all enjoy the great food vendors like Tommy DiNic's (roast pork w/provolone and broccoli rabe like a local), Flying Monkey whoopee pies, and on and on!

I also liked the knick knack vendors, and they range from souvenirs to one of a kind artisan items. I bought my nephew a table runner chalkboard from the vendor who has the colorful Mexican bags. She was super helpful, and let me know I can get the chalk "markers" to go with it from any craft store, even though she was selling them too.

There's a nice Information Booth here as well, that has tour information for Philadelphia, and a map of the Market! There are relatively clean bathrooms here, good to remember if you're in the area and gottagorightnow. All in all, I loved this Market!

gotta love reading terminal
beillers pickel place is a must visit
dinics is a must visit
termini's is a must visit
So much to do there! And great food & produce! I have went to 2 cooking classes there at La Cucina. Wonderful experiences! Definitely will go there any chance I get when I am in Philly. :)
Good variety. Great produce.  Love the salad bar at Tootsie's.

Glad i asked my tour guide where I should eat while in Philly. She recommended Reading Terminal and I was a little unsure about it at first but boy was I pleasantly surprised. They have some many options for food it is close to impossible to decide. Look around before you make a final choice. For desert have Bassett's ice cream it's the BEST!!!!

A mist the throngs of tourists, and limited seating, is a gold mine filled with culinary variety. A delight to witness in person. All of the aromas permeating the air as you walk up one aisle and down the next, is invigorating fellow foodies. A treasure to behold, housed in an old,once active train station dating back tot he mid 1800s. A must see for anyone visiting or residing in or near Philadelphia. They offer discount4ed two hour parking with proof of food purchaser at a lot across the street on 12 th. Just be prepared for varying size crowds and limited seating aviliability.

This is a favorite place for us to visit as often as we can. You never leave hungry and without bags of something. Neat neat one stop shopping stop whether its yummy cupcakes, cheesesteaks, fresh fruit, candy, or lots of other goodies. 
Just go, it's an adventure.....

Good place for good food. As a result, the place is always packed to the gills with tourists and yuppie foodie assholes on weekends, so you gotta either come early, or come on a weekday. If you want to get high quality and (relatively) cheap produce, make sure you drop by Iovine Brothers.

The Reading Terminal Market was right across the street from our hotel, so it was incredibly convenient place to grab a meal.  The market it clean and has a zillion choices, but its more like a fancy, well designed food court than a real food market, like Cleveland's West Side Market.  Other than that, I am a definate fan!

Cool place. So many options! Actually, so many options that I couldn't decide and ended up not being able to get anything because everything started closing for the night. 

I am not going to repeat what they have to offer, other reviewers did that already. It's definitely a must-visit Philly destination though.

So I will just say that this place shuts down early. As in 6pm. Don't make my mistake and GO EARLY. It's probably a sh*tshow during lunchtime so maybe not thaaat early.
Nice little fresh produce area for quick shopping. Tons of eatery stands that I'll need to try later! I'll definitely be back to explore some more!

If you're in Philadelphia you must stop at Reading Terminal Market. It has become my Saturday tradition and there's something for everyone here! At Profi's Creperie, I highly recommend the Nutella and Banana crepe, but they also make a great breakfast sandwich with fresh croissant.  The Famous 4th Street Cookie Company sells cookies by the pound and it's easy to get carried away with the warm gooey goodness. The authentic amish donuts at Beiler's Donuts and Salads are ridiculously fantastic, seriously. The line is always super long. BEWARE they are closed on Sundays. The Cheesesteaks from Carmen's are just OK. The roast pork sandwhich at DiNic's is great! Wursthaus Schmitz also does an awesome bratwurst and potato pancakes.

Next up on the to-eat list:
The Original Turkey
Rib Stand
Soul Food Cafe
Dienner's Bar-B-Q

I really wish NOVA had something, anything, even remotely of close to Reading Terminal Market. 

It's so massive and everything looks so yummy it's easy to stand in the middle of the aisle mouth agape trying to figure out where to even start. For me the staples to hit are DiNic's, Flying Monkey Bakery (make sure to take home some whoopie pies!), Bassetts Ice Cream, and Blue Mountain Vineyards Cellars. 

Also worth mentioning is the Golden Fish Market that has every type of fish imaginable and Kauffman's Lancaster County Produce that has every type of jelly known to man.

One of my favorite places in Philadelphia! As the individual vendors all have individual reviews, I will be reviewing the venue itself instead of the plethora of vendors in the market. 

RTM is very chaotic and it's real easy to get lost in, but it only adds to its charm. There is really something for everybody here, from sushi to dessert factories. If you were to show someone Philadelphia, RTM is a great place to start.

This is a must stop every time you are either passing through or staying in Philly for any amount of time.

No matter what your mood, there is always something here for you, with endless options for sweet and savory foods.

For the best savory bite, you should head over to Tommy DiNic's for the Roast Pork Sandwich with broccoli rabe and provolone. Featured on Man vs. Food as well as his show on the Best Sandwiches in America, it really is an amazing sandwich and worth the sometimes huge line in this chaotic market.

My favorite sweet things include The Famous 4th Street Cookie Company right by the entrance, serving hot, freshly baked excellent cookies, and the Apple Dumpling from Dutch Eating Place, which is so sweet it will make you shake. Don't forget to try Hope's Cookies also though - located all the way in the back, they have some really amazing cookies and tons of other chocolates and sweets.

Whether you want some authentic Philly eats, or you are one of those Chinese families that must eat Chinese food no matter where you are, or you want an overload of excellent dessert options, Reading Market's got you covered.

I love this place. They have a bit of everything from Amish stores, to eaters, to Candy stores, to bakeries, to fish markets. Literally, you can find a bit of everything here. I recommend terminis bro bakery, the creperie, franks, and beilers bakery. The terminal also offers nice and fresh fruit and vegetable stands!! Definetly worth the visit!!
Esp. Nonna's kitchen. Real home food Pakistani-style. AND don't leave w/out the rose lassi!

Reading Terminal is one of those places that you go into thinking it's going to be the best thing ever, and then inevitably leave mildly disappointed.  The entire market is eye-candy and it can be an adventure just choosing what you want to eat.  However, for the most part, the restaurants in the market are overpriced and not that good.  If you go during the lunch hour, good luck being able to move around at all.  Save your money and go to chinatown.  This all being said, going into Reading Terminal is a cool experience, and there are some gems, such as Herschel's (though again, overpriced).  Where you can make at well is on the non-prepared foods like produce and the fish and meat markets - these are all more reasonably priced and of generally high quality.

The Reading Terminal Market is a great place to visit while in Philly.  The variety and quality of vendors was fantastic.  I had never been to the market, so my plan of action was to wander through aisle by aisle and check things out, then make my decision about what I wanted to purchase and eat.  We arrived at the market a little after 11:00 on a Saturday.  It was busy but not overwhelming.  We saw delis, cheese shops, a dairy and restaurants/food stands that sold everything from oysters to sushi and even french crepes.  And, of course, a huge amount of vendors offering cheese steaks.  

By shortly after noon, it was unbearably crowded.  You could not move unless you were pushing yourself through.  Do yourself a favor and go early in the morning or later in the day after the lunch rush.  

Highlights for me were the orange strawberry lemonade from Lancaster County Dairy (a bonus, they offer free samples), an ice cream cone from Bassett's ice cream, and jerky from Smucker's Quality Meats & Grill.  I wanted a sandwich from DiNic's, but the line was waaaaaay too long.  

It was an overall fantastic experience.  I know it isn't feasible, but I wish the walkways were wider and that there were more areas for seating.

I love the variety of foods here. They even have indian food in here! I haven't tried everything yet but there is so much food here and something for everyone. A place where you can try everything from different places. Not to mention they have that grocery right in there where you can pick up fresh fruits and veggies! Also a place to chill and sit and eat there too somewhere towards the mid and back of this complex. Public restroom in the back and if I'm not mistaken: a shoeshiner in the back somewhere?! oh and fresh juices and this Cajun and kabob place also looked great! I keep finding new things to wanna come back to try. I really didn't know what to try first sometimes! Oh did I also mention a buffet in there too?! lol.

RTM is a destination that has something for everyone. From comfort food at the Dutch Eating Place, bakery goods at Terminis, Lamb Tacos, Chinese soups at Sang Kee, and fresh produce and meats galore Reading terminal is an eating and shopping mecca that gives a Center City resident an alternative to the supermarket.  Always remember the Amish merchants are not there every day. Sundays and Mondays they are usually closed, though some may not be there on Tuesdays either. Lately there has been a lot of movement in the market, and new merchants have moved in, so its worth revisiting if you have not been there in a while.

I won't repeat what I'm sure a lot of other people have written. I'll just say that this place was a lot of fun, but you'll want to mind that most vendors close rather early especially on Saturday, and of course the Pennsylvania Dutch vendors are not open on Sundays. Therefore anything you want to buy, make sure you don't wait until last minute to do so! I had a lot of things I wanted to buy on Saturday afternoon, but didn't want to lug around all day, by the time we got back to the market around 4:30(ish) the vendors I had wanted to purchase from were closed.
I really like this place when I go into philly... there are so many different vendors to choose from and all the food is great! I do wish there were more places to sit down! it gets very crowded!

Can't live without Miller's Twist pretzels (with the sweet mustard sauce), Grill at Smuckers breakfast wraps, Martin's steaks and sausages, and Profi's breakfast crepes. So much variety it's the best place to bring friends from out of town when you can't agree on something for breakfast or lunch because there really is something for everyone and it's always quality food.
The only thing that could make this place better would be for them to stay open a little later for people to pop in after work.

I haven't been here in a while to shop for food, however, my mom often goes here to pick up spices. The food here is great and pretty diverse -- you can basically get anything here, from pastry to cheesesteak. It's kind of like an flee market, only with granite counters and cashiers.
I loved this place! There's simply not enough time in one's life to enjoy all of the different food/shops. It's a great spot in Philly.

Love visiting this place whenever we have an event to go to in the city.  So many places to eat under one roof, but we always go to Dinic's for our usual Brisket sandwich.  No one makes it better than this place!

Love it here!!!! Drove from NY to get some cheesesteaks and decided to walk around here amd open our appetite.  WTH were we thinking.  We left full lol...We sampled everything and it's a must to try the FRIED MAC & CHEESE BALLS FROM THE CAJUN SPOT. (I forgot the name, sorry) just walk around you'll find it. Head to 2nd ave (every aisle has an ave name) and try the cookies from FAMOUS  4TH ST COOKIES, its AMAZING. SOFT,WARM ,DELICIOUS & FAMOUS ;)

favorite place to go play and bring out of town guests.  Something for everyone.  High dollar to low dollar; useful to flightful fancy love this place.  Prefer to drive in but the train experience is great for the grandkids they love it.

There are a lot of positives about RTM:

There is an abundance of food options. If you're in the neighborhood and want something fast and tasty, this is a good place to go. You can choose to sit down and eat (like at Molly Malloy's) or you can grab something fast and walk around with it (Olympia Gyro).

I am also particularly fond of the home made chocolate retailers. Yum!

The main reason that we go to RTM, though, is for the humanely raised and organic meats. There are several Amish stands that specialize in selling *real* meat (not genetically modified, hormone-injected, tortured animals). You should check them out!

Parking can be a real bitch, though, so you're better off taking public transportation if you're not going to have too many bags to carry. There are also hordes and hordes of people, so if you've got social anxiety, this is NOT the place for you.

I have definitely reviewed Reading Terminal Market before but my review has disappeared :(

Regardless, this is a great market.  They have odd hours so make sure you get there early.  There are TONS of food places to shop around.  There is a huge assortment of cheese, meat, and candy.  I'm a fan of the Amish shops because they always have the best fudge and yogurt covered pretzels.  The only reason I had to knock off a star is because it gets very crowded in here, which in turn makes the place very warm and sometimes uncomfortable.  Still a great place to visit whenever you're in Philly.

I love food markets and this one didn't disappoint. The minute you walk in you are in food heaven. The aroma in this place is unbelievable, all of your senses will be working overtime. If you are foodie like myself then you must come here. I got to try some Cajun food, roast pork sandwich, cookies, candy apple and olive oils. I was pretty full by the time I saw the Amish place and the fresh donuts so I couldn't try them but I will next time I'm in town.

Crazy busy indoor farmers market akin to Pike's Place in Seattle Washington. Lots of different fare and food and a good place to waste a few hours but if you are not into crowds and higher prices then beware this place is a nightmare! You should go at least once though and check it all out.

This historic market is one of my favorite places in Philadelphia. I bring all my friends who visit me here. This place is just oozing with culture and what it really means to be a Philadelphian. It's a great place for locals to shop, eat, visit, and hang out. For visitors/tourists, you cannot visit Philadelphia and skip out on Reading Terminal Market. You will not regret your time here.

Great place, but is pretty crowded. The pastry shop just inside the door, where they sell the small cakes and such, they have bad customer service. None of their cakes or muffins are labeled as to what they are. One lady asked if I needed something, I was just in awe at the cakes and said I was just looking, to which she rolled her eyes and walked off. There are nicer pastry shops around. All because it was my first time at the Terminal and was trying to take it all in. Nonetheless, it's a unique experience and plan to go back many more times!
As someone not from the area, Reading Terminal Market was a really cool place to go to. Cheesesteaks? To die for. Ice cream? Out of this world. Definitely go check this place out!

This was my/our third trip to the RTM in 20 years with consistently great experiences.  The RTM features a collection of places to eat, shop for food (fresh markets) or just to shop.  Ethnic experiences from Amish to Italian to Soul to Philadelphian are feet apart.  Some have been written up on your favorite cable food/travel channels...many have not.  But...overall: it's a blast.  Go with a small group and graze: order something, share and move on to the next establishment...repeat for a few hours.  You'll be surrounded by a lot of people in a unique environment that buzzes with energy.

Downside: it can get crowded, especially on a weekend.  The seating is ridiculously limited.  But, I'll go again the next time I'm in town.

AMAZING food quality, taste, variety. Friendly people, lots of energy, people having fun and laughing over great food in a historic location just a stones throw from where the forefathers created our nation. Just the smell and feel of this place makes me dream that when I die I'll get to heaven and there will be a RTM there! One of the best food experiences anyone can ever have, hands down, bar none.

I thought this place was in Reading PA !! I can't use any electronic devices or the authorities can traingulate where I am, so I couldn't get directions. I drove all the way out to Reading, PA and when I got there I asked around, no one helped except this one guy Carlos said "yea follow me aound this corner it's over here", next thing I know I woke up in the bushes in some park with no pants or shoes, wallet gone, and a huge bump on the back of my head. I spent a week in a state hospital, my friends felt bad and afterward took me to the real RTM and guess what, no club to the head! Just great food and people, and...em...um, wait what was I saying, Hmm not sure who I am right now, I'll call you later.

If I was a local, I would know what time to come here on what day. Instead, I was visiting Philly on a Saturday.... soooo crowded. I didn't eat anything... which is shameful. Instead we just grabbed a beer at the bar. I will figure this place out in the future, and I am sure it will be awesome.

Tons of delicious options, hours are weird but if you can work it out its worth it. Also the parking garage beside it will give you discounted parking if you show a receipt from the market, just keep it in mind because parking on the street is rough.

I wish every city had this market in it! It is fantastic for selection of products and the quality of prepared foods especially Amish - Mennonite selections.  I tend to find myself at the Dutch Eating Place enjoying wholesome favorites like the turkey sand which with gravy and a side of coleslaw and cranberry dressing.  Any of their hot sandwiches are divine! 
Right by that vendor is a splendid chicken wing place where the wings are rotisserie . So good!  There are a few fantastic bakeries in this place also.  If I had one in my city, I would shop there every week and find a way to do lunch here all the time too!

Cute market in a central location. It's not as cool as Seattle's Pike's Place but it's probably on par with LA's Grand Central Market.

We sampled food from a few food stalls and I enjoyed walking through the market. Definitely a fun place to check out.
RTM has something for every foodie. Dinic's is always packed, and they run out early (especially the brisket). RTM is a don't miss, must-stop.

This was right across from our hotel which I thought was cool. It is fairly large compared to most markets in the south. It is definitely a hipster and tourist filled blob. I'm guessing it's almost always busy? Lot of cool vendors/food stalls. I would probably go back if it wasn't super crazy-maybe during a weekday? Definitely a place to visit and buy some cutesy little things.

Reading Terminal Market has a great selection of different kinds of food to eat,. So far I've been to Dinic's for their pork and broccoli rabe sandwich (must try!) and Smucker's for a breakfast sandwich which is probably a weird thing to rave about but it was actually really very good and reasonably priced. I definitely plan on checking out their grilled cheese place the next time I'm in the area.

It's also a great spot to walk around and check out the fresh produce (the last time I was there I got some huge artichokes!), baked goods, jams, jellies, baking mixes, gifts, etc. The only downside is that there isn't a lot of seating and it tends to get pretty crowded in there. During the warmer months they have some outdoor seating but not nearly enough to accommodate the amount of people that are coming in and out of there. It's definitely still worth checking out and grabbing a bite to eat!
How can you not love this place?  They've got DeNic's!!!

you really cannot lose with Reading Terminal.  the options are vast; everyone can find anything.  my personal faves are: the Thai spot for their salmon &get the sesame ginger glaze instead of the traditional sauce.  you're welcome *wink wink*  .. shanghai gourmet makes the best rice noodle soup.  veggies always fresh &delicious.  brilliant broth !! .. kevin parker's spot is a little above average.  expensive as all get out, but it's always nice to have a good downhome soulfood option on site..   the amish are fantastic, no matter what you order, but make sure you go on the right day to catch them. i like the amish diner.  their turkey burgers are not the biggest but are thee most delicious.. gotta love termini bros and their canolis. simply YUM !!.. there's a chinese place that's located in the 2nd or 3rd isle if you are entering from the 12th st side, and they make wonderful chicken dumplings.. and i'll end it w/ franks-a-lot (i think that's the name).  anywayz, i dont eat franks, but their bbq chicken wings are fabulous.  charcoaled to perfection.  grab a cornbread too -- DEELISH !!

If you live in Philadelphia, and you've never been to the Reading Terminal Market, shame on you! The market is a cultural icon to our region.  There is so much diversity of stalls, products and eating establishments, it would take 20 trips to Reading Terminal to hit 'em all and try something from each, (unless you can mix completely divergent food types - I can't).

If you are a tourist visiting Philadelphia, you should absolutely take a few hours to tour the market and get something to eat while you're there.  Off the top of my head, I would say check out the crepe place (forget the name), and get one of the fresh fruit filled crepes.  Absolutely delicious!  Or if you want to sample some unusual beer, as well as some delicious sandwiches, try Molly Malloy's.

I've been to the Grand Central Market in LA, and it's OK, but not nearly as diversified in it's products and stands as Reading Terminal Market right in my own backyard.  You should go.
I'm not sure how I can sum up Reading Terminal in a review, but to keep it simple here you go: reading Terminal is Philly in a nutshell. Really. There is something for everyone

I really enjoyed this terminal market! It was one of the most amazing experiences ever. I got to witness the Amish community and different foods from other cultures. I had my first homemade pecan sticky bun from the Amish shop, Beilers and had a roasted pork sandwich from Tommy Dinics! They have the best slow roasted pork meat I've ever had! Soo juicy and tender. Overall the market was great! Lots of food to try. I just wish the seating was wider and better

I can't add more but 5 stars, but 5 is not enough. This is one place I would love to have close to my work.  I would be in this place everyday for lunch. I wouldn't get tired of going because there are so many and different type of food places to choose from. If you're in Philly, this is a must see and eat.

This place is awesome! Every kind of food to tempt you, nice little stalls, very diverse and fun. The only down side was how busy the place is. But I would definitely come back here every time I go to Philadelphia. Definitely try the Amish doughnuts, they are amazing. I was only able to eat a few things, but I want to come back and try more.

What a place. The variety of food stuffs is unbelievable. 

If your hungry and want it, they probably have it!

Just be ready for crowds. The amount of people was crazy.

If you like the amish items , go later in the week, they aren't there on certain days.

It gets really crowded at lunch time and on the weekends, but it is well worth pushing through the crowds!  There are a lot of really great places to visit.  Make sure you hit the 4th street Cookie Company. Their cookies are seriously delicious. Whenever I get jury duty I always go to Reading Terminal Market. However, be warned, not every place is great; you really have to try wherever and figure out what you like!
Love coming here. It's always a happening and all the different foods are delicious and stalls are unique. This is truly a treasure in Philadelphia.

This place is amazing. I lived in Philly for 1 month and ate here more than 5 times. Right across from the convention center. Always busy and full of tourists. Ive eaten the pot roast sandwich at the Amish stand which is awesome. The gyro stand is good. The mexican burrito spot is alright, though I'd try something different. The Asian noodle bowl spot isn't worth it, theres better places. There was a smoothy spot that was delicious. Its not too expensive in any of these places. On one side theres fresh fruits and stuff to buy grocery too. Definitely a worthwhile trip for anyone visiting Philly.
This is a must stop attraction for anyone visiting Philadelphia.  You will find some of the best food on earth here.

One place I have to stop at whenever I visit Philly - just the vast amounts of crazy variety in one place - wheatgrass shots at one end, pork rolls at the other, Metropolitan bread mixed in - I'm in heaven :) Bathrooms are nasty though - don't use them!

I wish I'd have had more time to explore this place during my trip. It's a huge building full of more vendors and food than you can possibly imagine. All of my friends were raving about the things they'd eaten from the various vendors they tried. Don't go to Philadelphia without checking this place out!

Something tells me that I don't have a lot to add here.I have come here for years.It is one of the best markets out there ,not necessarily my favorite but a good one.You can buy all kinds of food , prepared and raw.You can buy books , goods , knickknacks.When it's not too crowded , it is fun just to walk around.Although it is often very crowded.If you haven't gone , you should.

Reading Terminal Market is a fantastic place to go to for food. I'm personally very partial to the Dutch Eating Place (their Grilled Reuben is an American Treasure), which means I don't like going here on Sundays (when the Amish stands are closed).

There are a lot of other good things here, and it makes for a great bustling experience where you go with a bunch of friends and all get something different to eat.

A haiku for Reading Terminal Market:

Senses tingle here
Fresh food and wares call your name
Buy and taste delights
Nice, a must see place for everyone. I stay nearby and I go here to get my groceries every week. A large variety of good food and good service. It's overcrowded during the weekends, just enjoy it,

Everything here is amazing.  But do yourselves a favor, skip the line at DiNic's and go to Border Springs Farm.  Get the lamb shoulder sandwich (although everything is amazing).  Feel free to send me a thank you afterwards :)

Reading Terminal Market is truly one of a kind. Every stall here is worth a visit. I'd even consider moving to Center City just to be able to shop for groceries here on a regular basis more conveniently. Not to mention, it is one of the best lunch spots in the city.

Really cute market that is worth a visit!  Huge variety of prepared food to choose from, including Chinese, Indian, Middle Eastern, Italian, and deli foods, plus multiple dessert options and a grocery.  Reasonable prices and lots of seating area, although we went during an off time when it wasn't too crowded.

A gem in the heart of Philadelphia! Find everything, from organic produce, local honey, Amish poultry or eggs, the freshest seafood and fish, superb meats. And that's only for the market part; you find such varied foods that you travel instantly to far away lands, or stay home with the best Philly cheese steaks! Sweet tooth no problem! Even wine tasting with real baguette and stinky cheese is possible, like in Paris!  There is also some craft for unique presents.
The Reading Terminal is my food mecca. Fresh and local produce, poultry and meats, not to mention all of the vendors selling delicious sandwiches and snacks. And local honey?!?!?! Yes, please.
Such an awesome place. If you are attending a dinner party you can find something to bring here

If you are in Philly...Go!  There is such a great variety of shops inside.  Enjoy the great food.  DiNic's, Old City Coffee, and Beiler's are my favorites.  Try everyone else too.  You can also get great ideas from the restaurants and then walk the market and pick up all of the freshest produce, meats, cheeses and fish to make nearly anything.

Whenever I have visitors, I take them here. There is something for everybody, and it is always a great time. It's super busy, so get comfortable with people standing really close to you.  We love Dinics, the spice/candy shop, every dessert area, and the jerky/meat stick vendor.  I can't go in without buying something I don't need, but definitely want.

For those who have visited Pike Place in Seattle or the Ferry Building in San Francisco, this is Philadelphia's version of an indoor market place in/near the city's downtown area. Having said that, it is quite touristy. 

Visited Sunday and Monday and several shops that we read about on yelp were not open. :/ Not sure if the winter storm had to do with the closures on those days but was a little disappointing.

Parking garage across the street is $4 for two hours if you buy something over $10 at Reading Terminal. Probably the cheapest garage in Philadelphia's city center.
I got the roasted pork with broccoli rabe!! Out of this world!!

Great market with a variety of different deli and ethnic foods, vegetables, fruits, cheeses and a variety of other items.  A lot of the popular places to eat have long lines so be prepared to wait a bit but overall the lines move fairly quickly.  A lot of tourists and the market makes for some great pictures.  Within walking distance to other Philly tourist attractions.  This was the primary reason for my visit to Philly but it turned out to be one of many sights to see in the area.

I love this place.  it's my grocery store, and my favorite lunch spot.  People of every race and social class go there to do their shopping.  It's Philadelphia at its best. Just don't go on Saturday or, if you can help it, when a convention is in town.  It is a tourist destination, and i'm ok with that.  I just have to plan ahead to avoid the worst times when people have to move single file through the aisles.  Monday morning is the best for grocery shopping, unless you want to go to the Amish stands.  They are open only later in the week and never on Sunday.  This may disappoint tourists, but they have to understand why the Amish stands are closed -- they have a life, and it's not all commerce, all the time.

We tried Creperies, karen Parkers soul food and Carmen's Cheesesteak.  All were delicious.  Creperies, we tried the cheesecake with berries crepe.  A taste of heaven.  I would highly recommend.  Karen Parker's soul food.  Her Mac and cheese was divine.  I had to keep my husband out of my plate.  I also had fried chicken and okra.  All was so good.   Carmen's was recommended.  Our cheesesteak was great.  Loved the vibe of the market. Bi wish we had this in SA
Best place to pick up vegetation and baked goods. Yum yum.

Super delish. I was sad to miss the Amish family that does home baked goods and food. I guess they only show up from 8am until 12pm unless they are sold out, which happens often. At 1pm we missed them. Maybe next time! so many great delish choices and everyone was very helpful and friendly. We tried three or four different stands and left happy!

This is the greatest food place in the world, bar none. It's like a Whole Foods version of a mall food court. 

Dinics lives up to the hype. Beiler's donuts are out of this world. Chocolates are delicious. Ribs and fried chicken mmmmm. The Thanksgiving Turkey joint. 

Other than the sushi place, which you should avoid at ALL COSTS (seriously look up Tokyo Sushi, how many places manage an overall 1-star rating on yelp?) you really can't go wrong in this market. 

Avoid the sushi.

Eat anything else.

Pure Bliss for the little fat person inside of you ... my little fat girl inside were dancing like a ballerina on crack from pure ecstasy. I simply wanted to hug every ounce of bacon that gallantly paraded behind the shelves simply teasing me. The notes of baritone, falsetto and soprano glided rose higher and higher as I fancied all the beautiful cheeses propped next to salamis and olives and all the beautiful things that makes one kick ass brunch or a sandwich or Hors d'oeuvre or just simply a beautiful.life.dammit. You can make it rain here! Rain chocolates that is! It 's so full of delicious goodness, it is uh-mazing!! 

and oh, Andrew Zimmerman was here and if you are anyone who loves food, you should definitely stop by here :D

One of my favorite places in Philadelphia.  I am here almost every weekend. Great place to buy fresh produce and meat or have lunch at one of the many food options. Also, the 4th Street Cookie Company is addictive!

The only bad thing that I can say about Reading Terminal is that as someone who lives a short walk away I certainly do not go enough.  Every time I do go I kick myself for not going more.  I love the lamb gyro platter at Olympia and the produce market is just awesome.  There are lots of affordable options here that would be pleasing to even the most discernible palate. If you have not been here GO!

Love this place. It is all about the food: fresh produce, seafood, meats, and tons of places to eat. There are all cuisine to dine at in the Reading Terminal Market. It was really busy during the lunch time, so seating may be difficult.
Amazing place with so many choices. Hard to go wrong with so many great foods, from Dinic's pork roll, cheeses from Valley Shephard and cheesecake from Termini's. Stroll and enjoy!

This is probably my favorite place in the world. Everything you could want under one roof. It's a foodies dream. You can get a delicious pork sandwich, walk around the corner and get the best Pennsylvania Dutch pretzel you will ever eat. I would live here if I could, like a rat

I love this place. I always make it a point to eat lunch at the Market whenever I'm in the neighborhood. There are so many delicious choices from cheesesteaks to deli sandwiches to gumbo to oysters....  just so many choices!

Besides the prepared food vendors, there are also many shops selling produce, meats, fish, and specialty goods. If I lived closer, I would definitely do some of my grocery shopping here. 

Some of the highlights for me are DiNic's Roast Pork, Beck's Cajun Cafe, and of course, Termini Bros. Bakery, where I absolutely must get a fresh canolli whenever I'm in the Market. 

Leave whatever you wish, but take the canolli. Trust me!

If variety is the spice of life, Reading Terminal has got to be the Mecca, at least in Philadelphia. Delicious eats from tons of places. In this humble reviewer's opinion it starts and ends with DiNic's delicious Roast Pork - worth the wait!

Went to Dinic's for roast beef and italian pulled pork sandwiches. I don't if it was because I was starving or it was just that good. I went halfsies with a friend and I thought the pulled pork was better. I'd still eat either sandwich any time of the day.

Foodie heaven. If your ever in Philly you must go to this place. You can spend the whole day walking around stuffing your face with delicious, freshly prepared food. Some establishments are  pricey so don't get fooled.

It is hard to go wrong when you go to the Redding Terminal. First of all, many of the locals shop and eat here so you know it has to be good. The terminal itself has been around for many years and so have many of the businesses that rent space inside of it. 

Whether you want Cheese steaks or Indian food, you will find it here. My only complaint is that there are too many choices. I know there are individual Yelp reviews for many of the restaurants and businesses inside the terminal. Our family sat down to eat meals from 5 different restaurants and they were all tasty. We capped off the meal with a visit to Bassett's ice cream which is one of the oldest businesses in the terminal and the ice cream was fantastic.

A visit to Philadelphia is not complete without checking this place out. It is sure to be a crowd pleaser.
So many choices. So many people. So few tables. I love the vibe and atmosphere of this market. I am not a fan of busier days when people are hovering above you to snag your table. Eh well.

I really liked this place. A little hard to enjoy as it was INSANELY PACKED, but I guess you can't blame other people for wanting to do the exact same thing as me. And I went on a Saturday. I definitely want to come here during the week to enjoy it a little further. But great selection of food, produce, sweets, etc. Quite the experience. But it was seriously so packed I do have to give it three stars.

I love this place. I have been going here since my first summer job back in the 80s. There is always quality food. I have never had a bad meal here.

If you going for lunch - head over a little early to beat the crowds but even when its mobbed thing move pretty quickly.

A great Philly experience. There are office workers mingling with tourists and families in town for the afternoon. Everyone comes for the huge portions at unheard of bargain prices. Everything is fresh and made from scratch. Outstanding bread, produce, fish and meat also.

Awesome place a, definite to visit. Great smoked pork, philly steaks, choclates even cajun. Two great seafood markets aswell as meat markets. My boy picked up four giant porterhouses and they were delishous. They have organic produce to cheese and even candle making. Heck just visit it if your in Philly you will not be disappointed.

Every trip to Philly requires a trip to the Terminal Market. There are so many delights, it's a food lovers paradise. Some of my favorites:

M-F, 4-6pm $1 oysters
Ice Cream
The Fair Farm Stand in the corner has the most awesome cheese counter
The Amish breakfast sandwich place

The cheese counter is my absolute favorite... All the cheeses are from local farms in Pennsylvania and a few in New Jersey. My favorite one from the most recent visit was an ash-covered soft goat cheese that was creamy and a little sour.

There's more lunch choices than a week business trip or a vacation can exhaust. I still have to try some beef jerky and cannoli's. Not to mention the cajun food and Philly cheesesteaks.

What's not to love?  Good, traditional food from all over the globe and many local favorites as well.. Sometimes there is live music... I even saw a few couples getting married there on Valentines day.... Wonderful place to be

Everything you could want from a market standpoint with lots of energy & local flavor. Great location. Across the street from the Market East train station. Especially recommend Metropolitan Bakery for breads & Molly Malloy's for lunch.

This is the real deal. When I lived in Chinatown I used to come here every week to buy fresh produce, meats and eggs. Iovine is awesome. Always fresh and always affordable. The dollar bags in the back are a steal. Also Godshalls has quality poultry and the guys that work the stand are super friendly. A rather new favorite of mine, is Guintas for both poultry and red meat. The smoked turkey and pig parts are fresh and taste great in soups. Perfect place to shop for groceries and ready to eat food. Highly reccomended - but be prepared for the crowds on the weekends.
Can't go wrong...Sang Kee, DiNics, Hershel's, Termini's...as well as some very good butchers and fish mongers.
Must go! Food everywhere. DiNic's sandwich in the back was really good and quick even with a line.
duh. This place is amazing! Every sort of person in here. Cheap produce. Nice fish. Cheap fish. fancy fish. good coffee. They have it all. And the people watching is amazing. Just the best!

I like coming here because there's an eclectic vibe to it and there's a lot of things to buy here. Lots of flowers, candies, food, etc. On the other hand, it is very touristy and very crowded. Difficult to get seats in here if you want to eat here, and it's extremely hectic and loud. However if you're new to the area or just stopping by, I highly recommend coming here at least once to check it out and get something to eat! There's a great place in here that serves delicious crepes. Check them out.

My favorite spot in Philadelphia. Wander, munch, people-watch... it doesn't get better than that. I mean, you only have to go two feet to get an A+ cheesesteak from Carmen's and ice cream from Basset's. Also nice is the parking validation.
So many choices that you can't be disappointed. When I visited, I had a warm apple fritter from Beiler's Bakery and it was delicious.

You can't go wrong at the terminal. Working right across the street is probably one of the best (worst for my waistline) things that have ever happened to me. 

There are so many different places to eat here, which I'm sure each have their own Yelp reviews, but overall, 5 stars. There are a lot of really yummy places. Some of my favorites are the tomato pie slice at ByGeorge, the salmon from the thai place, Hershels, Beilers (OMG THE BEST DONUTS I HAVE EVER EATEN IN MY ENTIRE LIFE), the cannoli at Terminis... The list goes on. I guarantee that you'll find something you'll like.

This place is AWESOME. My friend (who lives in Philly) suggested I go check it out my first night in town visiting for a work trip, so I figured I'd learn about using public transportation and get myself there. I went inside and it was about 3 p.m. - and just about everybody was getting ready for the post-work rush (read: not much was happening). So I walked outside and through the streets out to see Independence Square and some of the historic buildings, which were just a few blocks up the road from it. I returned closer to 5 p.m. and it was hustling and bustling. Whether you are grabbing fresh produce or a few staples for dinner, or planning to sit down and eat dinner, Terminal Market offers an extremely impressive selection of foods, both locally and from around the world. I stopped at the German place and had a schnitzel sammie for dinner, plus bought some genuine German cookies to bring back home. There is a bar on site and plenty of places to grab food and a seat. Very cool experience that I'm glad I did!

Wow! Such variety and atmosphere. Good prices, good quality.

It would rival Melbourne's Queen Vic Market except that there's no place for entertainment or dedicated organic section or wine tastings. And it's all indoors, but given the climate, you couldn't have it otherwise

Whether you're a local or a tourist, great place to saunter and sample local fare.
great market...usually a bit crowded.

Love the variety!  Found Comice pears!!!  The cheese shop is amazing!  Roast pork sandwiches were killer!  As were the the brisket sandwiches.  Used to love the Dutch Eating Place but not so much.  Ok, so much for individual details, overall RTM is a great place to spend a good chunk of time discovering great foods.
When i came here in June "13", this was like a food paradise. All kinds of foods here with crowds of people.
Foodie? This is a Philly landmark, some of the food vendors are one-of-a-kind, some are very touristy, go for the experience, not the food.

This is an absolute must. I will skip a few of the usual obligatory superlatives and say...

1. Skip the hotel or fast food breakfast and come here. There are places to buy a cup of coffee, a pastry, or have a sit down breakfast in the market.
2. Bring cash. Most places take credit, but there are some small treats (like Beiler's donuts) that work best with cash.
3. There is a good balance here of local and tourist feel. On one hand, there's plenty of fresh fish, sausage, and produce, while on the other, sweets, specialty items from local vendors, and restaurants.
4. Be mindful of Sunday. Many vendors are not open on Sunday.
5. There are loads of lunch choices. You can eat sushi, Mexican, or bratwurst here, as well as plenty of other choices.

Reading Terminal is a Philadelphia experience. If you are visiting want a real pretzel the Amish bakeries inside cannot be beat (and as a visitor you can see some real Amish.. oh lala).

 If you are a local, there is no where better to get fresh produce, meat and fish. And for everyone there is a wide selection of different foods to cater to every pallet. Reading Terminal is fun, delicious and a cultural experience.

This is one of Philadelphia best attractions whether you are a local or a tourist. This market is a foodies paradise, filled with many different styles and flavors of cuisine. Even if you do not want to eat it's fun just to look around. However good luck not craving something yummy while your experiencing all those smells in there! 

There is everything from gourmet food, to fast food. Bakeries, cheese shops, seafood shops, dan which shops , dinners, it has everything! 

While this place is made up of many different buissness, i found most places to be on the slightly expensive side. But I guess with all the foot traffic the businesses get paid well. You can fine places in here with decent prices, you just got to look around the whole market first before you actually spend money (that is if you are being money conscience). 

Also know that it gets VERY crowded in there! The isles in between the different restaurants are small, so prepare for traffic and hold on to your kids . Please do not be THAT tourist walking in there with suitcases!

One of my favorite places in Philly, hands down!

There's almost nothing that I love more than a great farmers market. The Reading Terminal Market has something for everyone. You'll find some of the best food and coffee here and the place is always full of tourist and Philly residents alike.

Some of the best dates I've had in this city started out with a trip to this fabulous place for brunch! I'm in love with the energy and food selection of this place -- there's always something new to explore and I'm never disappointed.
selection is great, love the bustle and variety, has afforadable options.

There is absolutely nothing in this place that won't blow your mind. RTM was founded in the 1890's, and has never closed since. About a third of the shops and eateries, bakeries, etc are owned and operated by Amish people. 

Three of the businesses at Reading Terminal Market have been run by the same families since the 1890's when the market originally opened. 

The Market used to be closed on Sundays (I assume) because of the Amish people, but a few years ago they decided to keep it open. So, you can go on Sundays, just expect about 1/3 of the businesses to be closed. 

Reading Terminal Market is where you go when you want to have a food experience that you can't have anywhere else other than Philly. As a local I can tell you this is where I take people just about every time if they have never been to my city. I take them to Cosmi's or John's Roast Pork later, once their RTM induced food coma has worn off.

I won't make any specific recommendations because EVERYTHING you can eat here is worthy of 5 stars. That's why it's great. You can walk around and sample all of this amazing food from all over the world and at the same time experience the TRUE definition of what it means to enjoy Philly's best. Locals come here daily to experience what they know to be one of the best spots on earth for amazing food (yes, earth).

Enjoy!

How could you give this place less than five stars. This is one of the best markets I have been to aside from my beloved Eastern Market. Of course it is going to be crowded and full of tourists, but there's nothing you can do about it except have some good eats!

Right off the bat a good tip is to go at an off time (and avoid Saturday all together if possible).  RTM is much more pleasant when you can browse through your options without constantly being in someone's way!

Though it may be a popular tourist attraction, it is also a favorite of people like myself that live here in Philly.  The following are some of my favorite spots at RTM:

- Dinic's (of course) 
- Hope's cookies (some very inventive flavors and every single one I have tried has been soft and chewy.  In my opinion, MUCH better than Famous 4th St. cookies which are also sold at RTM.  I recommend the english toffee bar cookie)
- Amish juice and milk stand by one of the exits (not sure of the name).  They sell delicious fruit juices and my all time favorite is the starberry orange lemonade.  There is even a huge jug at the stand where you can sample the lemonade.  I make sure to stop here every time.

If you're into great food and want to buy great local, farm-fresh produce, meat, and eggs, this is the place. 

It's literally the best place to buy food in the city. 

There are great places to eat (bakery, amish bakery, chocolate shops, sandwhich places, italian places, middle eastern, sushi, etc)

Fair Trade Food Stand sells fresh off the farm produce, meat, etc. 

If you live near the terminal and shop at the supermarket, shame on you.

its like .. christmas in july. 

everything you want and need, in one spot. plus, olde city coffee is AMAZING. oooommmggggggggg. chug a lug. shits all dope! 

good pricing, quick lines.! good smells all over the place

Thanks to TripAdvisor and my gf's predilection for getting the '#1' of places we went here. I was expecting another crowded tourist trap selling overpriced stuff that I'm sure locals would get for cheaper at a farmer's market. Well, yes and no and I was happily surprised. Yes, there are crowds, yes there are some pretty touristy things but there's a lot of good food and deals to be found. Despite the push of the holiday crowd it was a pretty good experience and walked away with some good eats and finds. The cider and the cheap donuts makes it good, Smucker's beef jerk and bacon make it great.

The grilled reuben sandwich we had here at the sit-down diner was probably one of the best meals we had in Philly... period! 

Loved the cheapo slim jims too. This place is great to explore in the comfort of air conditioning ;)

Love this place! They have everything you could need at the highest quality with great prices. One our favorite Sat/Sunday morning spots! Advice--Saturdays are better to go because there are a lot of Amish vendors that are closed on Sunday.

Unbelievable experience . So much going on from doughnuts being made right in front of you to chocolate covered every thing.The largest non commercialized Food Court.
/ farmers market / seafood / poultry / Beef / Sausages. You name it..
This place is so big! I want to find the flying monkey brownies.  the places we went to were ok - I liked the one cookie place a lot.  I would like to go back and take some more time to explore.

This is probably as close at it gets to those open markets you can usually find anywhere else in the world with a decent climate.  The best is just to walk around the labyrinth of stalls, sampling different foods and drink.  It is a good thing this place closes early, because I would imagine late night inebriated people would have a heyday at the terminal. 
There are a lot of Amish products sold here.  Definitely try the desserts and baked goods sold at Amish stalls. (I am sort of curious about how the whole Amish interaction with the bustling modern urban market works out.)
  This place could definitely be featured on an episode of Portlandia, as everything seems to be organic, environmentally-conscious, and a niche product.  But it is a great place to hang out in the afternoon, see a wealth of interesting tourists and locals, and sample the local grub.  Nothing is really that cheap here, it's like "Whole Foods pricing," but the quality is premium and with Philly flavor.  If you splurge a couple of dollars for a quarter pound of artesianal cheese, it's worth it for the atmosphere, and the feeling you get of buying fancy locally-made dairy products.
I just love market for its vibe!

Love this place. If you are in Center City, Philadelphia and don't know what you are in the mood for, or are looking for something fresh, there is no better place than this. There are so many options! The fresh produce and meats, to the unique little gems you find here; I feel like there is something for everyone. It is usually buzzing with a crowd so finding a place to sit is a trick. I try my best to get my things to go and find somewhere else to sit down to enjoy. If you do nothing else in Philadelphia, you have to see this place to believe such a thing exists! Just remember, the place does close a little early compared to the rest of the city so make sure you get there before 4pm or you could miss a few vendors.

This was a nice change from our past visits to Philly where we spend most of our time and meals in Chinatown.  We've been visiting more frequently while DD is checking out options for college.  Her top two are both in Philly so I wanted her to soak up the Philly experience to help her visualize herself there.  Luckily it is only two hours away!

So, we've walked through RTM before but not as a planned destination- this time was a designated stop in our itinerary.  I was afraid parking would be a problem as I could tell from signs that there was an event taking place but lucked out and found something on the street a block away.  It was nice and early and not quite the lunch rush.  I saw a couple with suitcases and just smiled as other reviews I had read suggest not to be "that guy" :)

We browsed our way through the aisles making sure to criss cross and scope it all out before committing.  Opted for some roasted spare ribs from Sang Kee Peking Duck, baked ziti from By George and a sushi roll from Tokyo Sushi Bar.  None of it was anything special to write home about, but it was fun and lots to check out next time.  I do regret not picking up some sweets, but there's always next time!  The kids had a great time but were too famished to appreciate it fully.  They just wanted me to hurry up and get something.  You can't rush an experience!

Valley Shepard Creamery has wonderful fresh mozzarella and roasted tomato sandwiches. I swear there was a pound of cheese on my sammy. This place is just wonderful. We went on a Sunday, and although some places were indeed closed, there was still more than enough going on to slightly overwhelm me.  The high star rating this place has is well deserved.
I love it! Every time I step into Reading Terminal, the memories flood back to me. I try to get there once a month at least. Love the energy and the food!

I don't know if there is much more to say than this is the best place ever. Any kind of food item you could ever possibly want from fresh pressed juices to a 10 pound whole fish! Every place is as good as the one before it and everything is incredibly fresh. The people are extremely friendly as well. Beware that it gets INSANE crowds over the weekends and crazy lines during lunch, but it's well worth the wait!

This is a great place for tourists and locals alike! I come here all the time to buy produce, bread, and cheese at many of the different food stands. It's a great place to shop because if you can't find something at one shop, you're bound to find it a few steps away at another one. They also have a great selection of lunch options -- Chinese, Greek, Indian, and of course cheesesteaks. I always bring friends and family who are visiting Philly here, and it never disappoints.

Places not to be missed:
Beiler's Bakery
Le Bus Bakery
Iovine Brother's Produce
Bassetts Ice Cream

Obvi 5 stars (one of the best places to go in the city) but really each shop should have its own review. Most are 5 stars anyway though. Everything I've had in here has been excellent and very cost effective. Maybe quit looking at reviews and just stuff your big fat face! Don't complain about the crowds either, that's what happens when ish is this good.

LOVE this place. This place reminds me of a cross between Seattle's Pike Place and NYC's Chelsea Market. We came around 11am on a Saturday and as time passed it definitely got more and more crowded but i didn't mind the crowds. Old City Coffee has a nice menu but I wasn't blown away by the coffee or overly sweet latte. Our bbq lunch hit the spot though not the best food Philly. Love coming here for cheap fresh groceries (basil, bananas, etc) in the center and then a few other quality items towards the side of the market (arugula, portobello mushroom, heirloom tomatoes). Love the maple bacon that we had for breakfast at home today and getting ready to slice up some more yummy tuna and salmon sashimi that we got from here.

Restaurants have been kinda underwhelming except Hershel's which makes a really good pastrami sandwich.

We validated our parking when we bought our groceries which came out to $4 for the 1-1.5h of  parking. I'm used to suburbia where parking is free or at least meter parking is cheap/bountiful so this was the only part that  bothered me a bit but it was fast and stress-free --so very worth it I'm learning =]

I cant wait to go back and eat more samples. I've heard that the amish bakery sells things for $1 after 3pm Saturday since they remain closed til Tuesday.

I have a love / hate relationship with the market. While I love that it's right there at Mark East with wonderful selections for lunch and farm fresh shopping, I think it is also a victim of its own popularity. At lunch time it is often so crowded that you can't even move down an isle. People often just stand around and have no awareness that they are creating a human traffic jam. Thus, I try to avoid RTM like the plaque between 11:30 and 1:00 PM on weekdays, but sometimes the call of Dinic's roast pork or beef overrides my aversion to crowds.
The diner - the egg creams and grilled cheese sandwiches are not for the faint of heart ( or those with cholesterol issues) but O M G are they YUMMY :-)
Amazing market for find everything good about the food. You can find Cheese, charcuterie, bakery food, Chinese and so on. All small thing from everywhere. You can eat here too and enjoy your dishes.

I cannot say more than enough. It has every kind of food you can imagine. Park across the street at the parking garage and with a receipt its free. Dinic's won the best sandwich in America on Food Network and well deserved- but you'll wait for that pork sandwich ( and you should). The chocolate place has a chocolate shaped like an ear in homage to Tyson but the truffles are a do not miss. Ice cream in the front is great- love the coconut & pumpkin. Even the cookies in the front are so good ( i only buy 2 or I'd eat a while dozen). We have eaten all kinds of food-- make sure you starve yourself all day and eat your way through....

1. The spice shop in the northeast corner
2. The kitchen tools shop in almost northeast corner
3. The dutch diner
4. The donut shop in northwest corner
5. Tom's diner right in the center

If you know your orientations, I gave you the address to most amazing shops in RTM. Enjoy :)
My favorite place in the city- really authetic and there's something for everyone!

What's not to love. Not exactly a take-a-date kind of place but definately worthy of taking a date to Bassets! Best homeade icecream EVER. Only good,quality stuff at the market. Of course you could find thing cheaper but not fresher or better. Love this place for the nuts and ice cream. The chocolates are fantastic too. Oh and the donuts...what can I say? We do go here from time to time just for the occassional treat but we've had lunch here too and it's just so darn good. A must see if you're just passing by...worth the time to browse around.

There is little I can add to 1400+ reviews. This place is a top destination for Philly. It reminds me distinctly of Pike Place Market in Seattle. It's a fine place to check out. Sometimes it has super good deals on produce. Otherwise, it's just never been my kind of thing. I prefer less crowded farmers' markets.

This place has it all. On my most recent visit to  Philly I ate Amish cookies & donuts and enjoyed the crab cakes at the Pearl.  Previous visits have found me worshipping at the altar of Dutch Eating Place's apple dumpling.  I will be back, oh I will be back.
I eat there from time to time, there are plenty of food selections. I would suggest visiting the Reading Terminal Market.

REading Terminal.

This place is amazing.  There is SO MUCH good food within this giant space it will make you dizzy.   I don't know if i can ever drive through filly again without making a pit stop here for some good grub.  #lifechanger

Reading Terminal Market has so many food options that it's impressive. I could literally spend all day walking around, just looking at everything there is to see. Whenever I have friends visiting from out of town, I always bring them here because it's such a great experience.

Reading Terminal has everything you could ever need. I love to buy fresh produce, fruits, and meat from here and the prices are generally reasonable. But the variety of options makes shopping here so great. Plus, although there is often a large group of people, it never feels crowded and most of the lines move really fast.

If you are looking for something fun to do or want to try some interesting choices of food, you should definitely go to Reading Terminal!
Whether its the fresh produce, butcher cut meats, or huge cheese options I always find what I need.

This is a great place for a quick stop pick-up and it's very close to most hotels in Center City. We originally visited the area to pick up some snacks for the hotel but there's a variety of stands for freshly cooked meals and raw ingredients as well if you want to whip up a meal with your own personal touch. I think they do close a little early for me  but that's just because I function more at night and do most of my errands late. We shopped around as they also had some local art and jewelries for sale.

Often quite crowded, and to be honest some places are not that good, and everything is a bit pricey.   General tip do not bother getting any Asian food here, go to Chinatown which is on Arch and Race Streets between 12 and 9th.  Some of the same places but will be cheaper  The jewish deli is good as with a cajun place.  Stay away from the English pub, the food there is not good and overpriced.

Reading Market has everything. Definitely a hotspot for good eats and interesting folks. People watching is great here as well as the variety of different foods you can get. The crepes are A-MA-ZING and completely worth going down there just to try one.
Great place. Lots of interesting vendors and food. A bit tough to find seating place, so grab one when you can.
Excellent food market that has maintained its authenticity.

I've had an out-of-towner describe it as "food Disney".  For me, it's a great selection of oretty much whatever you'd want from incredible bakery items to cheese made on site.  It seems to bee one of the few places both tourists and locals enjoy.

This place has it all everything from fine cheeses, meats, seafoods, fresh veggies, cookies you name it! I love the variety and most of the quality of the foods all under one roof! They have some of the best fast sandwiches (D'nicks) and other quality fast food in the city. However be prepared most of the time this place is PACKED!!! and when there is a food tour around my love for reading terminal becomes a love hate relationship especially when they take the last black and white cookie from 4th street cookie!! which is why I rate reading terminal 4 stars instead of 5!

Apple Dumplings!!! (Thurs-Sat) Filbert St Entrance
Amish rotisserie chicken (Thurs-Sat)  Filbert St Entrance
Fresh fruits
Fresh veggies
Fresh Flowers
Fresh Fish/Meats
Awesome! Everything.

I absolutely love Reading Terminal. It's a foodie's heaven and you can literally satisfy any craving you're having. Great prices and selection for produce and other goods like fish and cheese. A plethora of stands selling pre-made foods that you can eat there or take to go.  They have a fabulous selection of Amish foods that I grew up with back home. It's always pretty crowded and therefore hard to find a seat to actually eat your meal there which is a bummer. You must go to Beiler's Bakery (best sticky buns, pie, donuts and whoopie pies, oh my!) and Famous 4th St Cookies if you enjoy sweets!!! Prepare for long lines during lunch and weekends--especially at the most popular stands (DiNics, thai place, etc). Stands will validate your parking ticket for the garage across the street if you spend over $10 (i think it's $10) so you pay less for parking. All in all this place is a gem in the city and somewhere locals and tourists must go.

Although the Reading Terminal Market had been described to me, I was in no way prepared for what actually awaited me.

Options. Millions of options, as far as the eye could see. In my two visits here I saw an oyster bar, Indian food, sushi, Greek food, an Amish baker.... I could go on.

The first time I went, I chose a New Orleans's themed booth and had what I thought was the best sandwich EVER. That is, until I went back the next day to Meltkraft where I definitely had the BEST. SANDWICH. EVER!

It gets crazy packed in here, and waiting for your order often means standing right in the middle of a crowded walkway. Not good for the agoraphobic or claustrophobic, but so worth it if you can get past the insanity.
This place is awesome and so much fun! On the weekends it's busy but all the booths are open and has a great vibe. Great place to go for lunch or grocery shopping.
Real nice the last time I was their I was working up there the crowd was cool ,but if you looking for food this the place to go too.

This place is great! It's a true Philadelphia experience. I don't come here as much as I would like, because I don't always want to brave the huge crowds.  Nonetheless, this is a fantastic place to pick up lunch of any kind, and do your shopping.  I go for the fresh seafood stands, with everything you can imagine.  I also pick up fresh olives, pasta, cheeses, and Amish delicacies.  They have a stand for everything. It's like an old-fashioned European Market, but located inside. Check it out!

I work near RTM and go here way too much. Here's my quick guide on the highlights of where to eat: 

Breakfast
Beiler's donuts - Ranked by Fodor's as America's 20 best desserts spots. They do donuts well. Apple fritter and Dutch crumb are my favs. 
Beiler's bakery - You'll need to share the blueberry loaf of bread. Honorable mention for the sticky bun, but it's not served warm.
Metropolitan bakery - They do typical baked goods well. I love the almond croissant and various muffins. 
Dutch Eating Place - Breakfast done well. Love the pancakes.

Lunch
Little Thai Market - Their grilled salmon dish (comes with rice and broccoli) is good and affordable ($7 and some change). You can get extra curry sauce and/or shrimp if you pay a little extra. This dish is popular with the locals and you can see a line at lunch time. If there's a long line, I would skip unless you really want to eat seafood.

Sandwiches
Hatville Deli - Corned beef special
Dinic's - Featured on Man vs. Food. Get the roast pork, get it with provolone.
Herschel's Deli - Pastrami sandwich preferably reuben. The corned beef is also good. 
The Original Turkey - thick slices of turkey, cooked perfectly.

Snack -
Miller's Twist - The pretzels are way better than Auntie Annie's. 
Iovine Brothers Produce - eat healthy and get some fruits or nuts for the road.

Dessert
4th Street Cookie Company - My favorite is the chocolate chip with walnut
Basset's Ice Cream
Termini Brothers - Get the cannoli 
Beck's Cajun Cafe - The beignets are amazing, but only served on certain days.
Beiler's Bakery - The shoofly pie and whoopie pie are good and very unique to this culture.
Dutch Eating Place - Hot apple dumpling, the PA Dutch version of an apple pie.
Flying monkey - Get your dessert fix here if you're vegan.

Beverages
Old City Coffee - This hits the spot after all the food you've eaten. Goes great with dessert.

I love going here! I always make a trip before a party when I want to get some interesting snacks for a party. I can find cheeses, nuts, candies: all perfect snacks! It's a fun place to check out, and I'll go back for more whenever I can.
If you don't get a roast pork sandwich at DeNic's, you're doing Philadelphia wrong.

There is really nothing more to add about the Reading Terminal that hasn't already been written. The place is extraordinary and if you visit Philadelphia this is a must. It's always packed because the food is outstanding and there is something for everyone. The crowds can be a bit disorienting and overwhelming at times so if you hate crowds try to hit it around 2pm just to get the lay of the land. Once you get a handle of it return for breakfast, lunch, or dinner and take it all in. Enjoy!
