Good food and selection of restaurants. I love visiting so many stores here. It is really one stop shopping, and has a store for most of your needs. Parking is pretty much all around the area. I try to circle around the perimeter, until I find an empty spot, because the parking lots can be a bit expensive.

Is this review even necessary?  Yelp feed keeps prompting me, so I'm officially declaring my love for RT with the written word.

Cheap, quality produce.  Get those seasonal goods at Iovine or O.K.  I love the random farmy or foreign things you wouldn't find at your typical grocer.  Like extra local mushrooms, aloe stems, and elephant garlic.  Those heads are like woa.

Hmm what else do I like here.  I usually stop by Flying Monkey on my rounds and gawk at the fantastic creative concoctions, like vegan pumpkin whoopie pies and Guinness cupcakes.   The pumpple cake always gets a good stare from me too (apple pie in vanilla cake, atop pumpkin pie in chocolate cake, all nested in rich buttercream).  Or I watch the staff make stuff.   I probably creep them out.

Oh. and Tootsie's salad bar!! They use produce from Iovine and other market purveyors.  I load up on quality grilled chicken and greens, sampling the Southern comfort foods if I'm intrigued.

Then I might bop over to the Cajun cafe or whatever it's called.  You know the place.  They are always passing out samples and everyone is like NOM ME.

Oh and I get my candles at the Bee's wax and honey spot.  Perfect for gifts and personal olfactory pleasure. 

Then of course Four Season's juice joint.  The fruits and veggies of your choosing, blended with ice.  No sugar! yippee.

Welp.  That about wraps up this brain train.  Enjoy, tourists!

Sometimes I find myself lost in the RTM. The colors and smells drifting in the store take me to another place, another world. As an aspiring creative chef and food writer, this place gives me alot of inspiration. But yeah, ok enough of me.

The fresh produce for one, is great. Any type of fruit, mushroom, herbs that you can imagine can probably be found here. Every time I come here, something new is to be found. There's always a variety of many many things from baked goods to Thai to delis to vegan desserts. Seriously, I cannot come here enough!

I love how unique the East Coast is, and that you can get Amish made products here.  

Go to Beiler's Bakery and get a cream-filled glazed donut.  They're made fresh, right in front of you..I think they're around $0.90?  Enough said.  I could eat about 10 of them in one sitting.

If you reside in the city, or if you're just visiting, you'll definitely enjoy the market. I live just a couple block from RTM and I'm here a couple times a week. I do 95% of my grocery shopping here because its very fairly priced and everything is always fresh. I also stop in here for lunch regularly because again, its fairly priced, and 9 times out of 10, its a great meal. Some of my favorite places in here are: 

Iovines for produce, Giuntas, for chicken and steak, Martins for ground beef and their finger link breakfast sausages, literally the best in the city, Bielers for my fat girl doughnut obsession, and the wings at the Amish Market are literally the most amazing thing you will ever eat. I get them packed to go, and throw them in the oven for 30 minutes to make them crispy when I get home, the smoked wings are the best, by the way. I also regularly go to Fair Food for Little Baby's Ice Cream, pricey but worth it, Muellers for any type of gift for coworkers, because everyone loves chocolate, and my favorite stop for brunch on saturdays and sundays in Pearl's oyster bar, they have awesome french toast and eggs benedict that will blow you away. The market is defiantly worth stopping by, especially if you live in the area for groceries!
Great place to visit if you want to sample a lot of different cuisines and equally great if you want to do some unconventional grocery shopping.  I recommend it if you have some free time!

If I lived in this city I would eat here often.  Such a great selection!

I had to get a cheesesteak.  Made just how I like it.  And boy was I happy...for hours.... 

I was there in a snowstorm and most of the stands were closed.  But I could have spent hours looking at each booth.

Love it here - the vibe is boisterous and alive.

Can't decide on what to eat?  Then get your bum here right away.  Everyone has been here at least once.  If not, then go.  Even if your not hungry,  the smell and sights of the food will delight you.  Plus there are also nice shops within the market.  I recently discovered Meltkraf in here, grilled cheese heaven.  The fruit shake place tastes fresh and refreshing.  The cheese shop employees are very helpful and they had quince paste.  I love that there are now numerous places to sit and eat.  They do keep the place cleaner than before.
There is nothing more to say.. this place is amazing.. cheepest groceries in Philly (outside Italian Market).  Amish sections are closed on Sunday, so beware.

I simply cannot describe the magic that is Reading Terminal Market. If you are visiting Philadelphia, do not miss this quintessential, bustling locale. Whatever you seek can be found beneath the roof of this 19th century train station packed from wall to wall with restaurants and vendors. What's best is to wander the aisles until something unexpected catches your eye. I especially recommend Kevin Parker's Soul Food and Hershel's East Side Deli. Do not miss this place.

5 Stars, but due to the overwhelming crowdedness it needs to drop to 4. This place is a foodies freakin' dream! I didn't know what to expect really. Upon entering my eyes shifted all over, food stands galore, long lines and lots and lots of people. Everything looked so good. I wish I could have tried a bunch of different stands, but ended up at The Rib Stand. I wouldn't recommend this place because the Mac and Cheese wasn't good and neither were the Green Beans. The Meat was good though. They also sell random items throughout the market like groceries, soap, books, etc.
Love the RTM. A true slice of Philadelphia and something for everyone.
Great place to sample a variety of food AND drink.

I love the variety Reading Terminal Market has to offer. You can find delicious foods as well as nice gifts for a dinner party here. If you can avoid going on the weekend, it will be a much more enjoyable experience as it tends to get crowded with tourists.

I love this place.  It can get crowded at times, but there are a lot of vendors in here that make it worth the crowd, and the lines.  Whatever you're craving, there's most likely someone there selling it.  And don't shy away from the long lines... chances are good tha they have the best food!

There really isn't a bad thing you could say about, basically, an upscale food court. You can find literally anything and everything in this place from amazing cheesesteaks to locally grown beets. It's definitely a place that takes a few minutes to get used to if you've never been, as it can be a bit hectic and anxiety-provoking, but you'll get over it once you see all the amazing food and other items for sale. I'm pretty sure there are black market sales going on in back rooms, that's how many things they sell. Who knows?
If you're visiting the city, it's a great place to go, especially if you have no idea where to eat. It's pretty accessible and has a parking garage that the market will validate for 3 hours maybe?

Carmen's Famous Italian Hoagies & Cheesesteaks is a must. Amazing...everything. The cheesesteaks are phenomenal and the cooks are super nice, unlike other cooks at some cheesesteak places around the city...

Bottom line: You won't regret going here, even if it's just to walk around and look at everything.
Get a DiNiC's pork sandwhich with broccoli rabe. So good! It's a popular place at lunch time so look for the long line.

Every time we go to Philly we check out the market.  Dinic's cheese steaks in the middle is the best cheese steak we've ever had! 

Everything is fresh; seafood, produce, baked treats!   

Every shop gives out samples so you can try before you buy!
It's a nice place to visit during the week, but on weekends can be a bit crowded. The food is always fresh.
Great place to get a lot of different things.  Has all the Philadelphia staples.  Take advantage of the parking by making a $10 purchase and having the store validate your ticket.
Great place to have a variety and tasty food! My wife and i love love this place...given it is so popular always crowded though

This market is so awesome. It was my first spot after checking into my hotel and I spent almost two hours exploring this amazing place. Upon entering the market, I was overcome by all the various shops. In every direction, it seemed never-ending. There was soul food, Chinese food, donuts, bakeries, fresh produce, fresh seafood, hoagies, cheesesteaks, crepes, etc. The list goes on! I had the intention of going to Tommy DiNic's for lunch. They're famous for their roast pork sandwich with broccoli rabé. The line wrapped around the entire counter and to the soul food seating area. Many other shops had long lines as well, with eager and hungry folks waiting for a bite to eat. 

There is something for everyone at this market. It's a blend of Farmers Markets with fresh fruits, vegetables, seafood, and meats to various shops that offer food to eat right there and then. It's enormous and often packed, especially on the weekends. If you wanted to, you could spend all day or all of your vacation at Reading Terminal Market. There's just so much to see and do. Absolutely recommend coming to Reading Market, if not for a bite to eat, at least to see it for yourself.

Great first timer!  This is Foodie heaven!  Came down on a Sun around 2pm and the place was already jammed packed.   Thanks for the tips from fellow Yelpers, we tried the famous Dinic's sandwiches (provolone with roast pork) and they were quite good.  I was the 50th one in line but it was well worth the wait.  Washed it down with a blueberry, pineapple, banana smoothie from four Seasons Juice bar.   For dessert, had the famous 4th Street double chocolate chip cookie and it was soft and really tasty!  yum!  We missed the Amish stores as they were closed on Sunday.  Tons of food and things to buy but will have to trek back on a weekday (less crowded).   Only peeves: 1) the cleaners didn't clean the tables in a timely manner and empty water bottles and napkins littered all over the floor.   2) Parking is a pain though (can't find those special lots they keep advertising $4 for 2 hours on their site will try to find it next time around.    Tip:  I found large parking lot on 9th (between Market/Filbert) connects to the Gallery at East Market and it was like 3 hrs for $10.

Awesome! Can get very crowded but usually worth it once you find your meal spot. 
Great fresh fish meats and poultry.

Places I've tried and highly recommend!!!

DiNic's: Get the hand carved beef brisket, I really think it tastes better than the roast pork, which kind of lacks flavor

Hershel's Deli: CORN BEEF sandwich!

Bee Natural: Really love their Honey in the Raw

Bassetts Ice Cream: I recently tried their Pralines and Cream... wow!!!

Dutch Eating Place: Unfortunately only open Wednesday-Saturdays, but this place is always my top choice. Their Amish breakfast is the bomb if you don't want to travel all the way to Amish country!

Reading Terminal Market is one of the best establishments of its kind left in the country. Sadly, markets are becoming more and more rare, as people tend to do more shopping at megastores and eat crappy prepared food in food courts or strip malls.

This market has an excellent array of food stalls, pantry items, and fresh produce. In my opinion, the best establishments in the market are Iovine's produce market, The Head Nut (which has bulk food, spices, coffee, etc), John Yi Fish Market, and Beiler's Hand Rolled Doughnuts. These business are exceptional and some of the best of their kind in the city.

In addition to those listed above, there's a smattering of other very good food stalls. Some places are definitely overpriced, and others are just not very good at all.

But, there's something for every taste here, and it is definitely an experience to go. If you're only in Philadelphia for a day, it's worth it to go to Reading Terminal Market so you can have the experience once. 

I am lucky enough to live just under a 20 minute walk away, so I try to make a trip once every 10-14 days to stock up on certain food items for my pantry/kitchen since it has some of the best produce (at Iovine's) and fish (at John Yi's) in particular.

Sure, it's not like some of the bigger and better markets if you compare it to other cities in the world. But, guess what? Philadelphia isn't Tokyo or Dehli or Mexico City or any of those places with better market situations. Considering the plight of the America market, Reading Terminal market is certainly one of the best in this region of the United States.
Love this place! Hatville is our go to for corned beef special.

OMG so much food! I wouldn't do it justice in any length of a review. Just know you can't miss this if you're in Philly. Check out Yelp for individual recommendations on the storefronts within. I definitely wished we had checked this out sooner and gone here for more than one meal. After much deliberation and a bit of anxiety we decided on the juice bar, pork sandwich and a baked good.

NOTE: the Amish stores are, obviously, closed on Sundays!

Prepare to be overwhelmed by choices.  I feel like I can eat here everyday and be satisfied with my trip. Torture is being full but seeing all these goodies to eat. I found a way to stuff down a cookie from Hope's cookies and it was well worth it. I ordered the caramel pecan and they guy asked if I wanted the one that was dipped in chocolate?  Who says no to anything dipped in chocolate?  

Come around 4-5 PM if possible (after checking the closing time of the places you want to go of course) to avoid the huge crowds.  There were still mini lines everywhere but it was manageable.

This place is great! Lots of great Philly food vendors, seafood, Greek, chocolatiers, coffee and other great vendors located in an old Philly building reused for the permanent market. Tons of great food choices for those looking for Philly food or not. Been there a couple of times and keep finding new places to eat. Parking is tough in the immediate area but near downtown makes a great stop passing through Philly.
This place is just awesome. So many options under one roof and everything I've had so far has been really good. If I worked in close by, I'm sure this place would be my go to lunch spot every day.

We had a chance to visit this food and craft building while on an overnight visit to Philly.    On a recommendation from our hotel desk mgr, we ventured off to find the 'famous' Philly Cheese Steak.   The market place houses many 'amish' vendors selling breads, baked goods, home made jams, kettle corn, and almost everything that you can pickle.   The rest of the market place is home to many food vendors and other crafty type goods.    Note:  be sure to check the hours(opening/closing).   On a Sunday, a lot of the places don't open until past 9am and some places are not even open on Sunday.

Oh boy,..I don't have room on this page to tell you about all the wonderful treasures in The Reading Terminal. My favorite spots to go is Godshalls Poultry where I buy all my Turkey Products, they have fresh meats. Another is Jovine Brothers Produce where I get all my fresh vegetables for really cheap prices. The Golden Fish Market for fresh fish and shrimp! Plenty eateries to pop in an have lunch, my latest place Hatville Deli where they slice the meat fresh onto the bread...yumm. Oh and don't forget about the Amish fresh baked donuts...I could go on and on about the Reading Terminal just go an take plenty money you won't be disappointed.

Reading Terminal Market is a great place to browse and to enjoy the bustling atmosphere. I wish I had more time (and appetite) to truly enjoy this market and EVERYTHING they have to market. Come here for a huuuuuge variety of food, types of cuisine, and dessert options. 

Of all the things we could have bought, we decided to try the grilled cheese shop, due to its popularity before $8 you get an ooey-gooey cheesey sandwich with a side of refreshing and salty dill chips. Deliciousness. We don't often eat that much cheese, so we were glad to share this one sandwich. Trust me, it's rich enough. And even though it was perhaps a bit too rich for the both of us, it was totally worth it. Sooo good. 

Surprisingly, this place has a variety of grilled cheese options. It can get a bit overwhelmed, but I recommend just going for the classic. We added tomato and bacon- also a nice touch. 

Remember to event cash- not all shops accept credit cards. While there are several ATM, it's nice to bring cash ahead of time to avoid the fee.

I love this place.  I won't go into too much detail as I think everyone who lives in Philly needs to come here.  Personally, I like being here in the early morning as it's not as crowded and you get the freshest portions.  But the weekend crowd is cool because you get that bustling market feel.  That is if you don't mind standing shoulder-to-shoulder with people, especially if there's a convention center event that day.

must go, must see.  i go almost every time i am in the city. lots of fun treats and huge variety of food, plus great people watching and stuff to see.  i highly recommend the pickles. no, seriously. the amish know what sup.
Two words: Foodie Heaven!  This place is amazing, and is home to such diverse offerings that there is sure to be something for everyone!  Don't miss it if you are in the city.

This place is a food lovers mecca !!!  When you walk in the door, I swear you hear Angels singing and life just gets 1000X better.  There is more food choices than one can fathom and ALL of them delicious. Just walk around and take it in, this place is amazing.  Im making a super sad face right now because I went there to get the FAMOUS DiNics roasted pork, broccoli rabe & provolone sandwich and, when I got to the booth they were SOLD OUT !!!  I almost collapsed in the aisle; a did tear up though.  That being said, I got a fantastic Greek Lamb Dinner Platter.  Great price and a great savory and satisfying choice.  Ill be back tomorrow, to get my pork sandwich at DiNic's.  ill be sure to get there before 3pm.

I could hands down eat here everyday. From the selection of amazing meats and cheeses to each vendor, I am in love with these place. The owners are ridiculously nice and helpful, and genuinely love their food. I love it when people are passionate about their craft and you could spend all day talking to these people about the dishes they are so proud of. Make sure to get some doughnuts from here and the crepes are also out of this world! Basically, you can never go wrong by going here. I make it a point to take anyone who has not experienced the amazingness that is this little foodie heaven.
Loved this market, we there were one here in Hawaii lol Love the variety of foods, from the restaurants to the produce! Must place visit for the visitors!
Loved this market, especially trader joes.  many other great shops

Best place to visit when you have a terrible hangover. Many would disagree and say it gets way to crowded if your not feeling up to par in the morning. Great selection of greasy fat sat food varieties that make your hangover go away. Pastrami sandwich or my hangover fix favorite chili cheese dog with the works. Yep sounds gross right but it works every time. Sometimes you need a over flow of extra fatty goodness to sop up the alcohol still swooshing around in your gut from the night before. Trust me it works and this is the place to get a variety of tasty treats to easy the pain away.

If you live in Philly or are visiting, GO HERE!  Every type of food you can imagine.  If you can, avoid on Saturday mornings or weekdays during lunch, because it can get crowded.  If you can't find something to eat here, you're crazy!

This place is a Philadelphia institution but unlike Pat's and Geno's this institution is well worth the visit.  They have everything you could ever want.  

Downside:
Unless you love an insane amount of people I'd stay away on Sundays.
Great place to eat or shop because of the wide selection of vendors. A must-do in Philly.

I've always enjoyed trips to Reading Terminal, since I was a little girl.  Before transitioning to a vegan diet, I would purchase rotisserie chicken from the Amish station along the north-most wall.  There is also a really tasty breakfast place inside and a cheesesteak spot I loved ( both run by Amish).  As you can see, I like the Amish :)... These days, I just order from the Mediterranean & Indian places. 

A lot of the shops are extremely cool as well! I usually visit the shops with homemade candles, natural health & beauty products, and African cultural items/accessories.  There is definitely something for everyone at Reading Terminal!

Good luck finding anywhere to sit in the main dining area, during lunch.  Also, parking down there throughout the day can be a major headache.  I'd suggest public transit or taxi service.

Reading Terminal Markets offers so many delicious things to eat and purchase.  I love coming on the weekends for lunch and having my choice of gyros, roast pork, breakfast sandwiches, and some of the most delightful donuts in this city.  It is true that on the weekends the crowds can be crazy and it can be hard to walk through the aisles and browse, but if you know where you're going you can go in one of the exterior doors nearest your destination and cut out some of the hassle.  

Olympic Gyro makes awesome gyros (go for the platter and you get a heaping Greek salad on the side!), Beiler's Donuts are cream-filled gluttony (the banana is an old standard, and don't miss the banana ice cream at Bassett's-best banana ice cream EVER).  DiNic's is a classic and draws huge crowds of tourists and locals alike but I tend to skip the lines in favor of Olympic because you can pretty much always get a seat right away. 

 Also the Amish diner counter slings breakfast foods insanely fast- you've barely finished ordering and they already are putting plates down in front of you!  Very standard fare but worth it in a time crunch.

Also The Tubby Olive, a little shop that sells flavored olive oils and vinegars, is a great place to get a hostess/mom gift and they have tons of different styles and flavors that you can try in the shop.  A little pricey for olive oil and vinegar but a fun gift idea for someone who likes to cook/make salads.  

Also Reading Terminal Market is super conveniently located in Center City so it's perfect in the middle of a day on the town.  Watch out on Sundays though because many of the Amish shops are closed and you can't have any donuts :(.

I like this place. Not sure how I'm supposed to write a review for this place there's lots of places to eat here. I guess if it's the entire market I'll say that that front left area is nice, feels more authentic. The back seating area has too many neon I feel. It's not so crowded like you see in the movies and it doesn't feel really like a market-market either because its not really a bunch of open shops. It's a food joint as far as I'm concerned and they've got a good selection. The Rib Stand is pretty good. I tried the the Spataro Cheesesteak too which isn't bad. I tried going here late but they close way too early as far as I'm concerned. Looks like a lot of places close down early here in Philly. But I like this place, like I said. Plenty of food to pick from.

If you're a foodie, this is the place to go.  All different kinds of food are available from chicken to Cajun.  There's fresh fruit and veggies, bakeries, seafood and meats.  My fave place to eat is Dinics roast pork.  They have the best pork and beef sandwiches in Philly!  There's parking for $4 at 12th & Arch with validation from a vendor.  The General store has cute Philadelphia souvenirs as well as local candy and cookies.  This place is fun for locals and tourists!
Best part of reading terminal market?  The food.  The worst part?  The people.  It's also the cheapest place for produce.

I love the "Ok Produce" market here at reading terminal. I make the trip every single weekend just to go there. I can spend $10-$15 there and come back with enough produce, Fresh fruits and vegetables to last me for WEEKS. It would cost me 3X that much at the grocery store. Plus the people are super friendly. 

The other places in the terminal are great too. Awesome bakery shops and candy shops, excellent ice cream shops plus the Amish are there on certain days and they have the BEST goods and products. Overall, i love coming here with any out of towers and they also leave feeling satisfied.

I love this place, from Iovine Bros Market (great produce and vegetables at excellent prices) to Martin's Meat (great quality, selection and prices) to all the great food vendors (Sandwiches!) and of course the real, honest to goodness Amish!
I love the Reading Terminal because of its variety but it can be very crowded on weekends.  Try to hit it on a weekday and get some of the Amish goods.

Reading Terminal Market provides much-needed character to the city. There are options for just about any type of cuisine and bounteous local items. There is no question it is worth your visit and no advanced planning is needed, though it will be busy on the weekends (and the hours during the week are not accommodating).

This place is a must-visit for any out-of-town visitors to Philadelphia.  But if you can, try to avoid it during the weekends.  It gets pretty crazy and packed in there.

But for Philadelphians, I would recommend that you check this place out as an actual market.  There is great produce and meats/poultry/seafood to be found within the stalls in the market.  The prices are actually pretty good, and I prefer coming here to shop for cuts of meat and seafood that you can't get at a place like Trader Joe's and are of higher quality than some other grocery stores in the area.

Reading Terminal Market is Awesome & a MUST for Foodies!  It's like SF Ferry Bldg and Emeryville Food Stalls 10x bigger & food stalls everywhere.  They even had street names inside.

I only got to check out a few things because of limited time & stomach.

Tommy DiNic's - Must try their Roast Pork w/ Extra Broccoli Rabe & Provolone Cheese $8.50 & $2 (rabe & cheese) - can CHARGE IT.

Bassetts Ice Cream - President Obama likes the Mint Chocolate Chip Ice Cream there.

B. got a Gumbo dish from Train Wreck - he liked it.

I got a couple cookies from Hope's Cookies - Tasted ok not that special.

GO!!
I love this place. You can find any kind of food you want and some more stuff. What can I say that already hasn't been said. Been coming here since I was a kid and I'll keep on going.

This is a pretty good shopping place in Center City.
Its got variety and its busy.
I think it has gotten pretty pricey ($$$) if you plan to sit and eat, but if you want to shop produce, the prices are very reasonable ($$) and the quality is good.

For me, as a self-declared food glutton, and fan of local goods, i can honestly say my life in philadelphia would not be as bright if it weren't for reading. I work across the street so the obvious choice for me is to pop in and grab pretty much whatever is making my mouth water that day. Then, in the evenings as i leave work, i consider what i would like to cook that night for dinner. A couple texts between my fiancé  and I and voila! we have decided what delicious, local and fresh dish. 

Some locals might claim this is just a tourist spot but to this philadelphian, it's a very dear part of the philly that I love so much.

I would be okay being imprisoned in this place.

Between Dinic's sandwiches and Beiler's hand-rolled doughnuts . . . WOW!

The food options here are incredible.  Thai, deli, bakery, produce, Mexican, Italian, sushi, sweets, produce . . . 

A MUST-VISIT for anybody's Philly itinerary.
Just wander and have fun and spend money on all the cool stuff, most so much cheaper than anywhere else.

I have been to Philly many times and confused as to why I've never been here. Anyway....This place is like a foodie heaven. They have everything to eat here. And it's fresh and good. 

They have fresh fruit, vegetables and meats also. 

I bought lunch meat and fresh bread. Some ribs. Smoked wings. Wanted Chinese food but didn't get it. Kevin Parker has a soul food stand in here. Picked up the specialty tea and a soul food dinner. 

I also had orange strawberry lemonade samples which led me to purchase some.

I tried gator gumbo which was delicious.  I had some pistachio ice cream from the ice cream place.

Trust me when I say this place is foodie heaven i mean it.  I have to go back on a Sunday so i can get the beignets from the cajun stand.

Food Heaven.  I love it here!

This is one great food mall. I saw about 2 vendors selling trinkets but this place is really just a great food market with Cajun, Pakistani, Indian, Italian, and of course Philly cuisine. Yes, hoagies and steaks are a cuisine lol So if you want diversity in your lunch, dinner or dessert, then this inexpensive food market is the place to visit.
Definitely a fun place to stop for unique foods you may not find anywhere else, but sometimes it is overly crowded and touristy.

RTM is probably one of the coolest places in the city.  I go weekly for produce and fresh meat, as well as amazing lunches and fresh juice.  The variety of things you can find is incredible! The only downside is that when there are conventions or events in center city, it's packed, but I guess that's part of the experience :)
Pro tip -- you can park at the garage across the street (at 12th & cuthbert) and have your parking ticket validated at the produce stands if you spend over $10, so that you only have to pay $4 :)
Love A OK produce stand (I think that's what it's called).  The small on in the middle.  Their produce is cheap and great freshness.  You can't go wrong here anywhere.

I wish there was a 6th star for this place. Reading Terminal Market is unlike any food/shopping experience you have had in the past. With almost 100 different vendors, it is the perfect spot to grab lunch, or a very early dinner (it closes around 6) with those picky eaters you might be friends with. The market also has a great history surrounding it- it opened in 1892 and occupies the Reading Railroad's basement. You know the Monopoly Railroad card you always fought over? Now you can take part of the action in real life.

The market has an eclectic array of restaurants serving up dishes like roasted pork sandwiches, crepes, sushi, Mexican, traditional Amish chicken/donuts/breakfast, peking duck, ice cream, cookies, cakes and homemade candies. You can also find vendors that sell Italian sausage, fish, fresh meats, produce and so much more. It is the one stop shop for lunch, dinner and dessert.

Some suggestions:
If you want a traditional Philly style "hoagie" (what we call sandwiches), that tops the traditional Philly cheesesteak, head over to Dinic's. They feature a roasted pork sandwich with provolone, sweet/hot peppers and broccoli rabe. Messy and drool worthy all at once.
Martin's Quality Meat and Sausage has great pork sausages, chicken sausages, and Italian sausage. This place is a perfect spot to pick up tonight's Italian dinner. You will impress everyone around you, not only with your cooking skills but with your ability to decide on which type of sausage you want. This place seriously has everything....
If you have a sweet tooth, definitely hit up Basset's Ice Cream- every single flavor you could imagine in cones and cups, dishes and sundaes, milkshakes and packed pints. A great family establishment with tasty ice cream to boot.

You can't go wrong at Reading Terminal (unless you decide NOT to get anything, and then that is just sacrilegious and an insult to Philly), just make sure you bring cash for CASH only hot spots and try not to become too overwhelmed. Don't worry, it happens to the best of us; being indecisive is a gift.
A true Philadelphia experience.  A must if you are in the city of Brotherly love!  They have everything, from the Amish to Zapoli's.

A perfect spot on a day when the weather is not ideal outside and you want to kill a couple hours snacking, dining, drinking, shopping in a cool marketplace atmosphere.  I enjoyed my time there during my trip to Philly last week.

I love German food and there is a stall toward the back of the market where they cook up a nice pork schnitzel, potato pancake, and german potato salad.  It would not compete with the best German restaurants I have visited, but it is very passable for a fan of that style of food.  I enjoyed it.

Then just step across the way and have a beer (I forget the name of the place....but it is directly across from the German spot)

This is one of our favorite places in the world to eat and buy fresh food, and has been there for years and years. From the broccoli raab at DeNics to the ice cream at Bassets, there is nothing bad to say about this gem. Go if it's not crowded; go if it's crowded - it's all worth it. The Amish merchants are closed on Sunday (duh) but there is plenty of other choices to make up for that. If you're visiting Philly, and are short in time, skip the broken bell and have yourself an awesome feast at RTM instead - you won't be sorry. If you drive, there is discount parking at the lot across the street - two hours for something like $4 or $5 if you get your ticket validated at one of the shops. If you take the train,  Market East station is next door. The Convention Center is upstairs. Do you get the idea? Go now!
There is nothing in the world like this place (at least in my limited experience of the world). I'm going to keep this review short & sweet. Just go!

Being a foodie this place is like walking in food heaven! Lots of different cuisines under one roof. What more could I ask for?! I have tried the crepe place (there is only one so you'll know)--it was good but I've had better, Dinics roast pork sandwich would have to be my top go to place here though (about $10). Just try it and thank me later. If you are craving for something sweet, there is this amish place that sells donuts (the only one there too!). It was so yummy, not too sweet but melts in your mouth! You can't go wrong with reading terminal market.
excellent market with a huge selection of reasonably priced stands. Roast pork with brocolli rabe, yum!

The place I return to time after time. Since childhood when you could order snapper soup and get a bottle of sherry with it to today where pretty much everything is available. It is a little sad though that it has become more and more like a food court and less farmer and ingredient type places. I like going here to be inspired to cook at home but most places have prepared foods these days and they are not all of great quality. Still gotta love the place!

I love coming here, but I prefer going alone since it's so noisy and packed! There are merchants selling anything you could think of! I love the Head Nut, I buy loose tea there frequently and there is such a large selection, at a good price! Iovine bros is great for a fresh selection of produce. The breakfast wraps at Smuckers are delicious! I love it all!

Please do not miss out on this gem. We wandered around for over an hour and could have stayed longer. The food options were endless. If you want a foodie experience in Philly look no further. Highly recommended. Will be going back very soon!
You kidding me?!  Philly's Best!  If they had beds, I'd wouldn't leave for a week.

LOVE this place! Any time we're in Philadelphia, this is a MUST-DO thanks to the sheer number of food options available. You could spend an entire day getting lost in here....make sure you go when you're not on a time constraint so you can really take in everything there is to see, experience and eat here!

Cons: It's ALWAYS jam packed and crowded, so stay away if you're claustrophobic at all.
Who doesn't love reading term??? I mean, really? They have so much in here that it's not hard to find something you'll love about it.

Could be my favourite place in the world!  I went for the famous roast pork sandwich I'd seen on man vs food - and what a sandwich it was.  I think the three in front and behind me had ordered the exact same thing - roast pork, provolone, rabe.  It was amazing.  Loved every bite, the moist bread, the cheese.  Delicious.

I also had my first whoopie pie from flying monkeys - again delicious!  

I then spent the afternoon shopping on walnut and chestnut and everywhere in between - before heading back to my hotel I dropped by the market again to pick up soon for dinner.  It was about 5.30 and most places were closed by this time.  I managed to grab the last boneless rib sandwich from The Rib Stop - I'm glad I did as it was also delicious, the awesome dry rub rib taste letting the meat be the hero rather than the sauce.  Just simply delicious.

I think you could go here for lunch and dinner in a month - eating somewhere different each time - and never visit the same place.  Really fantastic - need to figure out how to work another trip here into the rest if my vacation!!

I love this place. We come every time we go to Philly. Our first stop is always DiNic's and then we wander. The place is crowded and noisy. Just push your way through. Also, the lines are deceiving at most places. They tend to move quickly. Also, any of the Amish stalls will be closed on Sunday.

The best grocery shopping in the city.  Iovine Brothers for Produce, Martins for meat, the place across from martins for seafood, the creamery for cheese.   And Reidels for lunch meat.  Love love love!

Our first stop on Philly was not for Pat's or Geno's or any other cheesesteak place. It was DiNic's for their roast pork, broccoli rabe and cheese sandwich. I've been craving this for years after catching a couple of glimpses from the Food Network. The line was pretty much wrapped around the place. 

Verdict? It was pretty awesome. Not as what I expected or hoped for, but it was still pretty damn good. For some reason or another the roast beef was much more juicy and flavorful than the famous pork. But hey, why not get them both and try for yourselves. 

Reading Terminal market is basically where both the locals and tourists go. Chocolate dipped bacon, chocolate dipped pretzel with bacon, a great donut shop which offers a variety of donuts including maple bacon, triple chocolate, coconut cream, mocha cream, etc...

You can probably spend a good 2 hours here before your clothes stink like seafood, fried batter and cheesesteaks. 

Really enjoyed the visit. Thanks Philly.
Just wish there were more veg-friendly spots. Nonetheless, awesome place!

Definitely a must when in Center City!! The food is amazing!  Atmosphere is one if a kind!  A few of our favorites are: Bassett's Ice Cream, the Tubby Olive, Spataro's-Cheesesteaks, Olympia Gryo, & Beiler's Bakery. Go there hungry...you will not be disappointed!!
This place is busy most of the time, but whether you're window shopping, looking to graze a bit, or just picking up some steaks for dinner, this is always a treat to go to!

Absolutely LOVE Reading Terminal. I have been going to Reading Terminal Market for as long as I can remember. And there has never been a day that I haven't been disappointed. I bring visitors of Philly here as well. 

I usually go to buy meat and produce and spices. I love how I can always find what I am looking for. And a lot of times I leave with everything I needed and a lot of awesome things I found and could not live with out. 

I warn you all it gets crowded because it is a great lunch spot in the city. So if you go and want to shop then come early. Make you sure you get what you want. Then stay for the ambiance and bustle for tourists and regulars getting food and meeting up with friends.

Reading Terminal Market is my favorite public market in the world!!!  Whenever we visit Philly, this is the first place I want to visit!  This indoor public market houses so many of my favorite places!  It is simply amazing that to have them all in one location.

"Today the Reading Terminal Market is one of the nation's most successful public markets with more than 75 independent small businesses that offer an array of fresh and prepared foods, lunch counters, and places to eat and shop."

These are my "Must Go To" spots at Reading Terminal Market:

1)  DiNic's  (for the best sandwich ever!!!)

2)  Bassetts Ice Cream  (the oldest ice cream company in the U.S.)

3)  Famous 4th Street Cookie Company  

4)  Flying Monkey Bakery

These four places are my absolute favorite "5 Star" places that I have visited here so far!  

I can't wait to go back to Philadelphia and Reading Terminal Market!

There are still many other places that I have yet to try here!  

Reading Terminal Market......you are a dream come true to me!!!  ;)

First time we set foot on Reading terminal market, we were overwhelmed. We came at lunch time, 1pm. We were starving from our 2hr nonstop drive to Philly from NYC.

It seems as tho you can easily get lost in this place. It looked huge at first glance but once you get your footing steady, it isn't as big as I initially thought it was. Just one run around and we knew where everything was.

This place is a must-visit if you're new to Philly or in the City Hall/Market Street area and want a fun "local favorite" lunch option.  However, be warned - if you go on a weekend afternoon (of during the lunch rush during the week), it WILL be packed and it WILL be frustrating to move around the place.  But it's packed because it really just is that awesome and trust me, it's worth it.  No matter what you're craving, this place will have something to satisfy you and it will be delicious and reasonably priced.

How do you even rate this place? So many different food options, plus other vendors. Go find the little book store in the back! Definitely worth a visit if you're coming to the city. Watch out for the lunch rush though.

This is one of my favorite spots in Philadelphia. Though it gets extremely crowded, you'll find some amazing food and dessert spots here (my favorite dessert is Termini Bros!). There's something for everyone, and even if you're not in the mood to eat or spend money, it's a ton of fun to just walk around and observe the crowds and food stands and establishments. Worth the trip, definitely!

A Must stop when in Philadelphia. They have everything! it is a blast just to walk around and try different things: soft pretzels, roast pork sandwiches (di nic's), donuts, cookies, ice cream, mexican, sushi,...ok you get the idea. they have produce market, spice market, sea food market, anything-you-can-think-of market. you could spend hours here. 

it can get a little crowded, and some of the line get long but they move along and most line are well worth the wait. i wouldn't recommend coming in with a stroller unless it is fairly empty. my wife and i did it once...yeah that wont happen again.
Think Pike's Market but replace the coffee and flying salmon with Amish donuts and Italian sandwiches.  It is massive and worth visiting on a lazy weekend afternoon.  Bring your appetite.

Reading Terminal Market saved us on a rainy Saturday in Philadelphia.  Heck, this would also be a great place to go in the middle of the summer if you wanted to escape the heat.  In other words this is a great place to go anytime of the year.

Being that I currently live on the west coast I would have to say that this market reminds me a lot of Pike Place Market in Seattle.  This market happens to be entirely indoors, but it is the same concept more or less.

You want meat?  Come to Reading Terminal Market.  You need linens?  Come to Reading Terminal Market.  You want killer pretzels or handmade donuts?  Come to Reading Terminal Market.  We ended up getting both of the latter and both were just about great.

You can spend hours going through all the nooks and crannies of this building.  It was highly enjoyable and I wish that I had something like this where I live.  Actually maybe not.  I'd probably spend all of my money there.

I work a few blocks away from RTM, and I wish I had an unlimited amount of money, so I could eat lunch there every day.  
Iovine Brother's produce -- the cashier gave me the student discount on Wednesday (thanks to my youthful appearance)! Produce is fresh and reasonably priced.
Miller's Twist has delicious pretzels. 
The Amish stands have great homemade peanut butters, jams, etc. 
Always tons of great lunch options-- can't go wrong with sandwiches anywhere, really. Love the Four Seasons juice bar. There's Thai, Chinese, sushi, mediterranean.
4th St. cookies are the bomb as is the dessert places right next to it (can't remember the name).  
This place is a must-go for travelers and city-dwellers.

One of the very best public markets anywhere. 

Lots of great options for breakfast, lunch, casual dinner or just food to take with you.

I love this place. It is one of the best markets I've ever been too. I'm both happy and sad that I gave up sugar otherwise I could have easily put on ten pounds from indulging in all of the delicious looking baked goods and sweet shops I saw. The Amish breakfast spot was great. Basic hot breakfast at a great price.

We ate a place called pearls oysters for breakfast. Super delicious! I had the breakfast special. Veggie benidects. Toast topped with eggs, spinach, avocado slices served with home fries. My co-worker ordered the grits. They were the best and I don't eat grits often cause everyone can't cook them right. The service was also very good. Can't wait to return to Philly just to eat here.

I love this place! There is so much variety! I especially love the Amish pastries & donuts. This place can be overwhelming if you're trying to find people to meet up, but luckily there is a center aisle for seating and eating. This place is great for local products, and I like to support the locals because it is their livelihood. Plus they put passion into making their food and that is what counts nowadays! Definitely, if I come back to Philly, I would stop by multiple times just for the pastries. Yum!
Absolute great place for a food-centric stroll.

i go here every time i go downtown,i try to avoid lunch hour since that time is immensely crowded and cant sit anywhere,but i like variety of food and other things that make it what it is ,there is actually just one place in the entire market that i dont like that is a bar type atmosphere,my out of town friend wanted to go there ,we sat down and they told us we had to order a drink a piece,i dont drink and they told me i had to leave,so after she created a scene we left,but other than that i do like the market.

Reading Terminal Market may very well be my favorite part of going into the city.  It is a must-do on any city visitor's list and a do-veryoften on the list of anyone who calls themselves a Philadelphian.

I have too many favorite vendors to list them here, but I think the most important thing to say is that you need to just experience the market!  Don't try to get in and out as quickly as possible.  See the sights, smell the smells, hear the noises - it is just an amazing part of city life that we don't get to experience when we are going through the Starbucks drive-thru, picking up milk at Wawa, and rolling into the parking lot at the Acme in the suburbs.  

Wander through the market and pick 3 or 4 different vendors that you would like and then decide on one and go back.  Even better, go with 3-4 friends and try a little bit of everything.

I have only ever gotten prepared foods here, but I know many friends that do their raw foods shopping here and I understand the butchers and fishmongers are amazing and have unique items that you can not find elsewhere.  

Finding a seat can be a contact sport and don't be afraid to ask to share a table with a fellow Market shopper - it is part of the experience.  

Lastly, don't forget to get your parking validated - it is only $4 for 2 hours if your spend $10.

Seriously?! One of the best places in the country. Get anything you want to eat here. Really a fun place to visit and spend some time, eat some food, see some people. 

Check out more here:

http://www.cnn.com/2012/06/22/travel/smackdown-detroit-philadelphia-philly/
Beautiful place, many shops, good prices (if you know where to look).

SO AWESOME!!!!!!

It totally reminded me of the pike place market in Seattle, which means it's CRAZY AMAZY!!!

There are so many cool knick-knacks you can buy as gifts, (as I did), and you can splurge on taste-bud dancing, spine-tingling food, (as I did).

Everything there is great, but the two places you MUST go is DiNics and the beilers donut shop. SO GOOD!!!!
Something for everyone! Whether you're looking for fresh fruits & veggies, or a greasy spoon lunch, you will not be disappointed with a trip thru the market.

I love reading terminal market. I go there for groceries and lunch all the time. The produce is ridiculously cheap and the food stands are all so delicious and are from every genre of food you can imagine. I would highly reccomend the DiNics Roast Pork sandwich with greens and cheese.

There is everything in here: good food, grocery, butchers, coffee, snacks, pastry, kitchen utensil, local veggies, and even beer. I lived in Center City years ago, and I was here almost on a daily basis. When we moved away from the city, we missed it dearly and thank goodness, we are now close enough to come here almost every month. We'd come here to get lunch (if not too crowded), afterward buy a pound of chocolate covered pretzels from Chocolate by Mueller, turn around and get a slice or two of cakes from Termini Bros, then head over to a butcher to get steaks or fish vendor to get seafood, and on the way out to the train station, pick up some veggies and a cup of joe. This reminds me of the street markets in Hong Kong, except this is indoors, smells much better and is a lot cleaner. I am so glad they expanded recently to accommodation more vendors and added more sitting areas. I've lived in many different cities, and Philly is my favorite (yes, even better than SF and Los Angeles, take that California) and Reading Terminal Market contributes to Philly's unique character.

I am not going to recommend any specific place, because everyone has his favorite places. The only thing I don't like in here is cheesesteak. We were at the Terminal this morning and were just talking how none of the cheesesteak places measures up. If you want good cheesesteak, you'd have to walk or cab it to 4th and Market to Sonny's. Most people rate Sonny's secondary, but we've eaten around town and like the balance of greasy cheese, bread, and meat there the best. Personal preference.
So many great little restaurants all in one place. Authentic food from tons of different cultures and styles. Highly recommend.

I love this place. I spend almost every Saturday at Reading. It's great for grocery shopping. The produce and meat markets have literally anything you could ever one. The food option are incredible as well. Whether you are looking for baked chicken, cajun cafe's, or a great roast beef sandwich...Reading has it ALL.

This is a good place to check out once while in the city. There are an inordinate # of places to it. It may not be for everyone, though, because it is extremely crowded and hard to find a place to sit. I'd say it's worth seeing if you don't mind big crowds...
Love coming here. Always have a large selection for the things I need and it just always a good time walking around. Can't beat the cheap produce at Iovine's either!

quality products to be found everywhere...from produce to hot food and products they have everything.  The added historical nature if the building also gives it a kind of energy that is felt the first moment you walk in. This place is a must for anyone visiting Philly, and even though I am local I still love to go there for lunch every now and then.
There are no words to describe this Philadelphia treasure! Support the local and independent vendors as often as you can!

Super fun place to go just because of all the culture--definitely a Philly thing to do. 

I walk around the whole place about 3-4 times deciding what I finally want to eat because everything looks so good! There's mediterranan, sushi, Chinese, sandwiches, and cheesesteaks, and more! 

It's also a kinda interactive date place..but definitely not a first date!

Cheap, yummy eats!
We went here for breakfast!! YUMMY! Oh boy! It was a bit of a wait, but those pancakes and eggs were well worth it!

I probably go here once every month. Which I never intended to. Because I live in New Jersey, and it's quite far.

But my boyfriend and I can't seem to stay away. Not with Tommy DiNic's and that roast pork sandwich. I've also grown quite fond of the Flying Monkey Bakery with their s'mores bar and butter cakes.

It's always a wonderful, worthwhile, and fattening experience at Reading Terminal.

Just another 5 star rating, I mean what more could I add that hasn't been said already? My gf and I were staying across the street at the Marriott and if we were staying in philly for more than a day we would have gone to reading terminal market every day. It's that good. We walked in at around 1pm on a saturday afternoon to scope out our dinner options since we just had lunch. We wanted to try Tommy DiNic's cause of all the hype over their roast pork sandwich and brisket, but the line was long so we figured we would come back closer to dinner time. This was a BIG MISTAKE.. and i'll tell you why in a second. When we came back at 4:30pm they were sold out... of everything. yep everything and the market closes at 6 on a saturday. We were both disappointed so we settled for Beiler's Donuts, Bassetts Ice Cream, and Miller's Twist Pretzels to comfort us. Beiler's donuts did the trick. We got the maple bacon, banana creme, harvest apple 2x, pumpkin, and blueberry fritter. They were all delicious, fresh, and omg i'm dreaming of those donuts as I'm writing this review. My favorite was definitely the maple bacon. The donuts are cheap for what they are $5.25 for half a dozen. Bassetts was also good, their ice cream is very creamy. I had green tea and cookies and cream, but the ice cream here is pricey. Miller's twist was the last thing we tried and they make their pretzels really well, not overly salted and reasonably priced ($2.25 for a regular pretzel.) So glad I don't live near Beiler's cause I would get fatttttttt.
Lots of food, to choose form on Wend, Thurs, Fri and Saturday.
Always fun to bring friends here - can be really crowded sometimes but that is part of the experience!  From raw honey to donuts to grilled cheeses you can find everything here!

This place is crazy crowded on the weekends. But I love it anyway.

You can get everything from duck eggs, to fresh honey, fresh meat, corn tortillas ... anything!  I like to come here for a quick meal (though I can never choose!)  Molly Malloy's is also pretty legit.

I love the Amish Bakery. Pro Tip: Saturday afternoons everything is half off at their baking counter!
Awesome delicasies of every variety - including goodies for a vegan like me!

Loved this place!! Saw it on Food Network, and wandered past it today, so I stopped in for a quick light lunch. 

the 8 oz. serving of lobster bisque had more lobster than some lobster rolls I've had in my home state of MA!! Will be trying the lobster roll touted on TV ASAP

Is it crowded? Yes.

Is it worth it?  ABSOLUTELY.

Even if you're introverted, and aren't the biggest fan of crowds, I'd urge you to find some time (perhaps an off-peak hour?) to walk through and explore this market.  They have a little bit of everything for everybody.  I don't know if there's another place in this city quite like it.

We went here on our vacation and I loved it! It's crowded so maybe not the place for small children. We got small servings of all sorts and then sat and had a feast. If you're visiting Philadelphia and love food or culture this is definitely for you!

This place was really cool but crazy crowded!! It's definitely a tourist spot.  It has so many good places to eat.  It was cool to walk around and see the different shops.  I came for the cookies.  4th street famous cookies.  They were delicious!!  Wish I was hungry to try other places but we ate before we came here.

Great energy (be prepared for the lunch and weekend crowds!) and variety of food and restaurants.  My favorite place to eat there is the Thai booth that serves huge filets of grilled salmon with rice and broccoli.  They also have Pad Thai and curry but I always get the salmon.  You can find anything and everything foodwise in the market.
Still retains the flavor of the old farmer's market, and now with an added assortment of gourmet foods and lunch places from many cultures.

First I want to say or ask why are the Amish missing in action on mondays, thus always saddens my heart, I love their breakfast, when I'm handling my business in town, I always stop by there to get their enormous pancakes, cheese eggs,  grits, and home fries, and freshly squeezed O.J. (it's a killer breakfast) :-) The staff is so nice, most women, pretty and natural, and so sweet, feel like I'm on the set of little house on the praire, and I also love the meat market area, always grab a steak or two to cook later, super fresh ! Hey I will keep this short, stop by there and show them some love ! Peace

Really, really happy about this place. In town for a convention, and I've been eating here every day. Pretty sure I could be here for a month and still eat new stuff every day. Every place I've been so far has been solid, which is impressive. Definitely worth a look!

I'm a big fan of this place. As others have said, it can definitely be crowded but it's worth it in my opinion. You can get just about any type of food here. I love the fact that you can come here to sit and eat for lunch or buy food to cook for dinner. They really have it all and there's so many different types of food from traditional American cuisine to Greek. You really can't go wrong. The hardest part might be trying to decide on one place. Reading Terminal Market is a must stop if you're visiting Philly.

Tourist?  Local? Day Tripper?  Reading Terminal hits the spot! If you're here to see the sites of Philly, you'll be pleasantly surprised by this downtown mix of restaurants, shops and local flavor...including a piano player on weekends.  If you're a local, why shop for veggies anywhere but here?  They are the freshest and so much cheaper!  I KNOW the owners get up at the crack of dawn to get the best produce the ports have to offer.  Yes, the PORTS.  These guys go to the docks to pick out their produce.  And they are the first there.  Day Trippers, where else can you get a warm turkey sandwich smothered in coleslaw on rye that'll last till you arrive back home?
If someone from out of town asks you where they should visit during their time in Philly, this place should be #1 on your list. Start here.

The Terminal is as good as it gets in terms of varieties of great food carefully prepared by independent venders!  I've been eating lunch here on and off for over 30 years.  (At the start a cone at Bassett's Ice Cream was $.95!!)  My favorites at this time are the Down Home Diner and Dinic's Roast Pork.  You can also do all you grocery shopping here for fresh, local, often organic meats, fish and seafood, produce and breads, as well as coffee, tea, spices, other baked goods, etc.   Lunch at the Terminal if you are visiting Philly is a MUST.
One of the best indoor markets around. You can easily get lost in the place - but you loosing a friend is gaining random treasures.

We stayed next door at the hilton for a week for a convention across the street, so I was at this market at least once every day. My first trip on a Saturday afternoon was really overwhelming and I felt like I couldn't stop to check out the food vendors or shops without getting trampled by people who seemed to know exactly what that wanted. There are plenty of food and drink options in the market, so even the pickiest of eaters won't go hungry. My favorites were the metropolitan bakery, the donut shop, old city coffee and the matzo soup served at the deli. Come on a weekday if you can where the lines and crowds are far less intense and you can take your time walking around without a fear of being run over by determined pedestrians.

Love love love the Reading Terminal Market.  Whether friends and family are coming to town, going for a bite at lunchtime or shopping for groceries, the Terminal cannot be beat.  


Some of my favorite stalls are:
Godshall's Poultry (Turkey steaks!)
Martin's (all the different sausage flavors are awesome)
Iovine's Produce (always carrying what's fresh so you should eat it soon after purchase, so much produce for excellent prices)
Miller's Twist (butter anyone?)
Market Blooms (these are the longest lasting blooms in Center City with artists for arrangers)
The Head Nut (Coffee at reasonable prices)
Metropolitan Bakery (their baguette cannot be beat)
Dinic's (roast pork is worth the wait in line)

I could keep going, but that's the beauty of the market.  Lots of variety and more to try and explore.

This is a must for anyone who is a resident or visiting Philly.  They have an eclectic blend of vendors. All the vendors are really very thankful that you are doing business with them.  Even if they have a line around their booth.  I always make sure that whenever I'm in Philly that I go to Reading Terminal Market.   

It may be crowded, but the Amish sticky buns make it all so worth while.  Heavenly good.  I bought some for family, but doubt it'll make it to them. 

It's also a great place to grab a soda and people watch.  Such a great mix of people.  I could of stayed there for hours taking in the sights and the most curious thing for me was when I saw this big brass pig that was sitting on a clear box and people would come up to it and put money in the box and they would either get their picture taken with it or have their kids kiss it.   I was a bit lost on that one, but hey made for interesting watching.

All in all a good time and an experience, but be prepared there a lot of people that go to it and most are nice you do run across the occasional a** hole.

Man, this place is awesome.  A true Philadelphia must-see.  Amish foods, the oldest ice-creamery in the country, delicious meats and sandwiches, great breads, awesome German food, and plenty of other great finds.  It's in a convenient location for much of the city, too.

Love this place, I would eat here everyday If I could. So much variety in this market you can enjoy eating virtually every type of cuisine you can think off. Also you can purchase  fresh produce, dairy products, exotic meats and seafood, freshly cut flowers and much more.

Sure the tourists are here, but the tourists should be here--there's something for everyone. I go for blueberry pancakes with my husband but also the seasonal train show and cider donuts with my nieces and nephews. Where else can you eat, get a lil history, and buy a lavendar candle, cumin and jar of honey in the rain?

When you get a free day to walk and explore a single building in downtown Philly, come with some cash and an empty stomach. You won't want to miss out on some of the great eats inside Reading Terminal and be a part of the hustle and bustle of the marketplace.

Some things that really sucked about coming here, the parking was ridiculous. I went on an off-day and it was still super busy and the structure (where I ended up parking) was pretty expensive. I felt really rushed to eat my food then get out. Next time, I'll have to try really hard to find street parking or maybe even a paid lot which is cheaper than the structure. Also, inside, you pretty much have to fight for a seat and hold down the fort while your friends order and bring the food because even though there's a lot of seating, there's a lot more people.

If you can walk down here and park further away and don't mind searching for a table/seats then this is a really cool place to check out.

Parking: Structure across the street $6/30mins or limited 2-hour street parking

Reading Terminal is a great place to spend a few hours. Whether you're a Philly native or visitor, there's something for anything you'd want to do, see, or learn. While it does have tourist trap prices, it's just one of those magical things that's part of Philly.

reading terminal market is bustling with locals and tourists all trying to get a bite or two of philadelphia's best grub. from soul food to gyros, an oyster bar to cheesesteaks, doughnuts, roast beef, falafel, gourmet cookies, crepes, etc. etc. etc.... 

lots of choices. you'll want to bring some tasty local treats home, so make reading terminal market one of your last stops if you're visiting. trust me, you'll want to come hungry. and bring friends so you can share lots of dishes from all over the indoor market.

the prices are great, and there's something for everyone's tastes. also, it's not all food (well, it's mostly food)... there's a great florist and various little shops for locally made goods and crafts, too!

seriously though, you'll eat til you're stuffed and then eat some more.

tip: if you have the choice, don't come on a Sunday. many of the stands are closed on sundays (including beiler's doughnuts, which are incredibly delish). boo.

The Reading Terminal Market is classic Philadelphia. Featuring some of the city's best food, from DiNic's sumptuous roast pork and roast beef, to Termini's incredible Italian pastries, the market offers a dizzying array of foods to eat or take home.

Come for the food, stay for the experience. It's like stepping back in time.

But the pork juice on your fingers will remind you why you're here.
One the nation's oldest farmer's markets is a "must see" in Philadelphia.  Be sure to try the Amish bakery's cinnamon rolls!

Tried Karen Parker for the first time and the fish was outstanding!!! But lawd the Mac & cheese was thee absolute worse I've ever tasted!! No taste, bland, salt & pepper did no justice. I would come back but for the fish only.
The workers customer service was fantastic!!

Lots of great stuff here. If you have claustrophobia, panic disorder, any type of anxiety, etc. etc. avoid from 12pm-2pm. Avoid if there is a convention going on. There are literal swarms of human beings during this time and seating can be difficult to find.

Tips:
Iovine is the greatest, cheapest spot for produce and weird fruits.
Termini Bros has the best italian cookies. 
By George has banginnn pizza. Big slices.

I think this place is overrated.  There are a ton of places to get food but I think the seating situation is terrible.  Outside of a few places I have really been let down on the food I've gotten here.

It's a Philly institution for a reason. it's great for lunch and also for picking up your fresh produce. If you're there to eat you've got to visit Dinic's, my favourite is the brisket with provolone, but you'll see most people ordering the pork. It's pretty great too. We could spend hours, and we sometimes do, wandering the small shops and buying products from the small artisan producers.
SO many options for food I especially love DINICS Brisket sandwich and Millers pretzels.  It can be cramped with people HOWEVER i have never had a situation where I waited in line for very long!

As a newbie to Philly, this was a great way to meet the city. Tons and tons of things to see and perfect for the overly hot day we were walking around in (since its indoors and cool).
Excellent place to shop for produce, meats and fish, while also grabbing an egg, cheese and scrapple breakfast sandwich.
Go to DiNics!!! OMG AMAZING! Then go to the Amish donut shop, every donut is worth the calories! Everything in this place deserves to be put on a pedestal and worshiped!

There really isn't much I can add to the Reading Terminal Market so I will just review my personal experience. It will most likely be repetitive of other reviews for it, but oh well. 

First, we waited until Sunday to go, which I now wish we wouldn't have done since some of the PA Dutch vendors were closed. It was a rainy morning though, so venturing to the Reading Terminal Market was a timely idea since it is all inside. 

It was sort of like an indoor farmer's market, much like the sheltered waterfront market in Seattle. Different vendors selling all kinds of food items, many having a dine-in option, or at least counter service. You truly should come hungry. There are lots of items to choose from to sample, and buy to take with you. We actually came in the morning, and grabbed enough fruit, peanuts, and cheese that we just ate what we bought as we walked around all day so it was a really great option. We also bought some jams, cheese, and vegetables to take home with us. 

The only negative (but not worth a reduction of stars), because of it's location, there are some homeless people and scammers who know that tourists are there and ready to pounce on so there is that. We did have a few homeless people ask us for money, and another guy who tried to tell us that he had a kidney transplant and needed money to get back home, but we didn't let that damper our experience. We've been taken by this kind of things many times in the past. It has sort of become standard of our experiences nowadays.

Not a spot for the indecisive. You will walk around wanting something from every stand. This is a great spot for locals and tourists. Also, a unique spot to bring a date, would definitely impress me. Everything is reasonable and its always an experience. Great people watching!

Things you can't miss: the Amish's homemade donuts (go with the banana cream), the savory crepes, Dinic's pulled pork sandwich with broccoli rabe, and termini brothers canolis to name a few!

For the full experience avoid this spot on Sundays. You will miss all of the Amish treats.

Reading Terminal Market, I'm certain, embodies a certain time in Philadelphia's history. Imagine a bustling street full of vendors of all sorts and origins. 

There's a joyous business in reading terminal market. It's similar to what I imagine a candy store to a kid is, for an adult. Whether it's a rush for lunch, a hang out with friends, a visit as a tourist, or just a lunchtime stroll, there's something for everyone at Reading Terminal Market. Many times, I don't even spend anything there, but rather just walk around and see the myriad varieties of food. Of course, if I had more money with me, I would just love to try out every store, Amish pastry, or organic ____. Definitely a gem of Philly.

This is one of my favorite places to visit in Philadelphia.   Other cities have markets in their downtowns, but this is the gold standard.   Like other markets, there are a lot of food vendors here.   However, unlike other markets, it's HUGE and there are so many grocers here that you could actually do your weekly shopping here.

Well It's full of tourist's and a bit pricey, But the selection is pretty great and I live within a 2 minute walking distance so It's very convenient. Big fan of going early to get the fresh amish offering and another reason why buying a bread box, yeah I said bread box, on groupon was an awesome idea.

Love the Reading Terminal Market...one of Philly's true food treasures. Located in the heart of Center City, this place is as much for tourists as locals. I know when I work across the street, office mates and I end up here for lunch quite often. If you haven't been, it's literally dozens (50 - 75?) of individual vendors all set up in a football field sized marketplace. There is seating integrated throughout, but it is sometimes too busy to grab a seat (M-F, 12 - 2). The vendors ranged from fresh fish and vegetable purveyors, to cheesesteak joints, Amish bakeries...you name it. There's lots of great sandwich places...and even a handful of places that do a great job with Mediterranean, vegetarian, etc. It's such a diverse place in fact, that when I lived close by, I used to visit the Market on Saturday mornings and use it as a fresh farmers market. Certainly worth the trip...and due to it's wide selection, the kind of place you'll want to visit on a semi-regular basis.

If I hadn't taken my adderal prior to experiencing Reading Terminal Market, I may have imploded. It's like Disney Land for foodies. 

In one corner, you can pick up a sheepskin rug, sheered from a farm in Virginia. 
In another, you can gorge on black and white cookies.
The variety is never ending, and each vendor is better than the next.

Personally, this is as big of  TO DO for tourists as the Rocky Stairs.
It just comes down to this: I can always find something at Reading Terminal and mostly likely it will be at a decent price and taste delicious.

This is just plain outstanding.  It's a wonderfully lively, bustling large space with stands/restaurants covering all types of food -- American, Middle Eastern, Indian, Chinese, and Korean, seafood, vegetarian, coffee, desserts, etc. -- as well as shops hawking fresh meat, seafood, and vegetables, plus general wares including flowers, jewelry, candles, souvenirs (of course), housewares, and on and on.  There are loads of sights, sounds, smells, and (especially) tastes to take in.  The prices vary widely from shop to shop, but they are generally very good.  If you don't like crowds though, time your visit carefully...if there is such a time when the market is actually calm.
A food fanatic's paradise. They have nearly every type of food you may think about: Amish, Indian, Mexican, Cookies, German, Italian... you will eat very well here.

Food inside Reading Terminal is great, especially Tony Dinic's sandwiches (which have the best provolone cheese I have ever had in them). Would highly recommend to anyone looking for a casual lunch with pretty much any type of food they can think of.

The perfect market for center city Philly.  A good balance of fresh ingredients and prepared foods to fit every cools needs and budget.  Saturday is usually the day of full isles with locals and tons of visitors.  Great place for lunch, shopping and people watching.

As a tourist, I could spend all day in this place. As a foodie, I wanted to spend all week trying the delicacies of each booth! From cookies to cheese to sandwiches, you will definitely find something worth your tastebud's while. 

Tips:
Sunday is not a great day to go - many of the traditional booths are not open for business. 

Bring cash!
great palce to visit for a variety of goods. I defiantly recommend the coffe

This place is always great! The crowds, vibe, & the selection of food, markets, & goods make it a wonderful place to check out. I always get lots of food shopping here, while enjoying the different food vendors. The only thing that's a bummer is it closes early & the surrounding PPA parking is hourly until 4pm. So if you can take public transportation here or walk, so you don't get a ticket or feel rushed. This is a must on a to do list! A must every season to checkout the new goods! Bring out of towners here or direct them to come here.

Great place to try out different foods every week. Really great selection.
Hershels Deli do a stoncher of a pastrami Reuben.
Wursthaus Schmitz has amazing sandwiches and the Hungarian sausage sandwich is the balls.

So this one time I was at Reading Terminal Market and as I was salivating at all the amazing food options, this hobo-esque woman asked if I could spare any food. I decided to give her my just-made-that-morning ham and egg sandwich. She turned me down and said she did not eat pork and asked for money instead. WOW WELCOME TO PHILLY. 

Despite that odd experience, RTM has more than enough cheesy, meaty, savory, melt-in-your-mouth, cheat day goodness to warrant a re-visit (if I ever return to Philly).

Omg! I wish we had this in DC area! So many food options to choose from, fresh market to go grocery shopping, and even inexpensive beautiful flowers. Came here on a Friday during lunch time and it was a busy place. 

Enjoyed Tommy DiNic's for lunch! Amazing food - definitely try that out. Took awhile to find a table because it was packed. But I'd love to come back here. 

If you park in the garage across from the market - make sure to bring your parking ticket inside and get it validated for a LOT cheaper with a minimum market purchase of $10.

I love the RTM.  The place is always bustling with buyers, tourists, and vendors.  I particularly like the seafood at Jonny Yi, the sausages and deli meats at the Wurst Haus, and the confections of the Flying Monkey.  Every visit should include excellent coffee, espresso drinks, tea or chai from Olde City Coffee as well.   It's a great place for breakfast at the Down Home Diner, lunch at La Cantina a bowl of noodles from Sangkee Duck House, or of course Breyers Ice Cream.  Go, see, shop, and eat--you'll love it too.

Sooo jealous of the locals who are able to have lunch here or visit on the regular! Such a fresh VARIETY of food, with everything from gluten-free healthy to toothache diabetes sweet! Absolutely loved it! The smells walking through the aisles alone can stimulate your senses enough so that you'll be able to return to work with no problem. A straight uppercut to the beloved Pike Place of Seattle.

It has a variety of food available. One could go there and practically get anything that you may be craving. There is Italian, Mediteranean, Asian, German etc. If you feel like eating healthy there is a sald bar, if you want some coffee they got it, they even have FRESHLY made doughnuts for 0.95 and they are to die for!!! The only bummer is that it closes pretty early so if you're like me and like to take your time in the day be sure that you give yourself enough time to get ready and check out the awesomeness that is Reading Terminal Market.

This is a great place to eat just about anything you can imagine. My favorite store is The Tubby Olive. The lady let us buy a baguette from the bakery and go around tasting all of the oils and vinegars. Amazing!

I live in the Suburbs of Philadelphia and make it my business to frequent the Reading Terminal for Five reasons. The variety of Amish Fresh Meat, Bassett's Ice Cream, DiNic's, Hope's Cookies and Le Bus Bakery. If you love lots of choices in Flowers, Food, Candy, Produce, Fresh Meats and Fish, Some of the best Amish Baked Goods and a reason to visit the terminal then these are just a few "Great but Valid" Reasons. You cannot visit the city without stopping at the Reading Terminal for both the experience and what it has to offer (Which is A LOT!!!) 
Bon Appetite & Enjoy!!!

How awesome is this place? Very awesome! 

You can really get lost in here - so many great things to See, Eat, and Shop. This is a huge market with lots of different foods from all over. You really have to come here and experience it for yourself.

We went here this past weekend and everyone (children included) had a great time. Wish I lived closer so we could shop here more often.
