Went here once. Got the Bassett's ice cream and that was awesome! We also ate somewhere else, but I can't remember where. But that was good too. Very crowded but worth all the trouble.

This was one of the first places I ever went in Philly and its still one of my favorite places in America. You can try food from all over the world and America in one convenient place at affordable prices and then buy very reasonably priced groceries to bring home.

We actually did a food tour that is offered on Wednesdays and Saturdays and it was a blast. The tour took us through the market with various food samples such as Apple cake, ice cream, snapping turtle soup, scrapple, and chocolate. We also went outside of the building to have a look at what used to be the Reading Terminal, which is now part of the convention center. It was a great way to get a history of the place and well as be introduced to some foods that I never knew about (scrapple!) and get pointed in the direction of all the best places to try and learn the proper way of ordering a cheesesteak. 

We also went all around and tried various samples that were put out on the stalls. They have the best cheese I've had, anywhere. MOST of the cheese I tried were absolutely wonderful and some of the cheese spreads were also amazing and super affordable.

Last but not least, I also did some grocery shopping. Got some sausages from Martin's, and some fish and mussels from the shop across from Martins. The fish was great, but the mussels were a bit funky even when I bought them. I made the mistake of trying to cook them the next day and they really started to reek at that point, so I just threw them out. The one sausage that I have tried so far, the merguez, has been excellent.

Probably have been to this place more than I would like to admit considering I am not a tourist!
If you live nearby its great for produce from Iovine's
Grab a delicious thick and creamy ice cream from Bassett's
A sinfully delicious baked good from the Amish bakery on the end
or my favorite, a no non-sense gyro from the greek vendor in the center

This is also my go-to place for buying cakes for co-workers etc as they are very reasonable in price and super decadent and rich (I think Paid maybe $15-18 for a giant cake which would have set me back at least $35-40 at my local bakery)

I would say my last visit was not the same as it was 10 years ago, it seems to be predominantly food vendors whereas before there was a mix of food and other storefronts
ie a kitchen place (they have a replacement one now but its not like Foster's!!), spices, a dog toy place 
There was just a lot of options for unique gifts and now I only see a few of the original stores still standing

Anyways if you are not a fan of crowds or enjoy sitting to eat a meal
DO NOT VISIT ON A WEEKEND 
period
its controlled chaos

I love early morning before work and midday when we decide to take a PTO day at work, those are the best times to really enjoy yourself but I'm also not a fan of large crowds

I would also say people compare this a lot to SF Ferry Building or Boston's Fanueil Hall or Chelsea Market
I have lived and visited nearby all and I still have a soft spot for this place as its very affordable and down to earth, but maybe that's why after living all around the country I decided to finally plant firm roots here!

PS--Bring Cash! most places take card but it just makes life easier for some of the smaller shop vendors

A Philly landmark.  A tourist must-see.  Yet nothing is overhyped or overpriced about Reading Terminal.  I tend to waste too much time looking at all the options - the trick is you can't make a wrong choice and everything is priced around the same point.

One of the most interesting places to go to on a day off, desire for unique and foods full of flavor! You can find foods that contain the most sweets, salts, sour and etc. at this market. It becomes really, really packed most days and makes it tough to sit down and REALLY enjoy your food, but it's very possible to do so. I have a few favorite shops, like the place in the middle of the market that is famous for their pork roll sandwiches, my goodness so unbelievably good. There are many Amish stores in this market that sell foods that really make me feel at home, especially the cinnamon buns.

Went here back in July of 2013.  A verylarge selection of diverse food.  I got the Samosas.  Very light and very tasty.  
I noticed that all of the prices in the Terminal were very reasonable.  There is also a very popular area with Amish baked goods.

I remember going to this be-all, end-all of food courts about five years ago, indulging in an oyster po' boy.

I was a po' boy on my porcelain throne for the 36 hours that followed that adventure, but the food was absolutely delicious. I chalk it up to this weak strain of AIDS I have finally trying to catch up with me. Yeah, nice try, HIV! You're going to have to do a whole lot better than a little diarrhea and nausea to keep this Sherman tank from running roughshod!

Since I can't remember the names of many of the places, my broad rules would be to avoid anything "Cajun" there & just get eyeball-deep into the ice cream. It's truly that amazing.

Oh, and believe the hype about DiNic's! You won't want to smack your mama, because you love her and that's cruel, masculinist garbage that we should've left in the Bronze Age. You will want a second sandwich, though, and that's as good a sign as anything.

Best bets: go during the fall or winter on a weekday in order to beat the throngs of tourists, and don't be a jerk. Watch what everyone else is doing, do that, and you'll be just fine. Matter of fact, you'll probably enjoy yourself twice as much as you would if you were Ol' Uncle PushyPants!

And hey! If you see me there and you don't look like some sort of terror, I'll even let you get a lick or two off of my cone. Trust me, you'll love that!

C'mon down and have a great time with us! Very few of us are mean! We have some snobs, but not too many meanies and grumps!
I love Reading Terminal But just a word of advice "Get there early". I don't like crowds.

The Reading Terminal Market was founded in 1893 and has evolved into a major dining destination.  It is a food Mecca where you can taste just about any type of food you desire.  The Reading Market has something for everyone.  Every type of food to enjoy and ravish.  Prices are reasonable, but flavour and choices are abundant.  The Reading Market also offers something for FREE.  If you are like me, and addicted to your iPhone....your battery is always hot.  At the Reading Market they offer a service to charge your cell phone for free.  It is a locker that you can leave your phone locked up while you grab a bite to eat.  How cool is that?

I love reading terminal!! Wish it was not so crowded on weekends but what can you do? Its a great place!

I can get relatively cheap produce, meat, seafood, grab lunch or a drink with friends, etc. It is a nice day out and a nice alternative to going to a grocery store. The only problem is is narrowing down where to eat!! So many good options. I also really enjoy that they have a bar so you can grab a drink if you need a break from shopping.

Just pay attention to the hours. I believe it closes early on Sundays.

This place is awesome! Such a classic building that used to be the train station and now houses all these great food vendors of Philadelphia. Such an amazing selection of so many ethnic foods. I love this place, every time I come to the city I must eat lunch here. Not open late, though.

Love this place. Easy to get to by SEPTA and has lots of stuff going on. Really nice coffee and cookies (yes, I believe there is a reason why these two are next to each other). Delicious ice cream (coffee and mint choco chip). Definitely a touristy spot if you have visitors who are into lung or nose shaped chocolate OR chocolate frosted raw onions (yes, RAW onions, the whole thing).

My go-to spot for coffee and cookie if I happen to be around the area. Won't recommend going at lunch time because it will be crowded.

This place is amazing. It's the large scale version of my favorite Cincy market. If I lived in Philly, I'd go here all the time. It does get crowded around lunch times and I'm sure weekends, though I was not there on a weekend. 

The market has everything you can imagine- it's foodie heaven! There are even gluten free options (my sister in law really appreciated that). Cookies, donuts, sandwiches, produce, cheese, cookbooks, flowers...  just go. I'd be there to try a new stand a day if I could!

A foodie's paradise. A foodie photographer's paradise. A person who has a hard time making decisions would drown in this place. And I consider that a fantastic thing.

Even if you're not a foodie, go at least once when you have a bit of time so you can peruse through all the shops. The experience is unlike any other restaurant market place in Philly.

I ordered house fried noodles from Sang Kee, but I would recommend getting something a little more novel since you can get the full Sang Kee experience at their main restaurant a couple of blocks down. I'm looking to go back enough times to pick out my favorites from each shop. Don't worry, I'll be sharing it on my yelp reviews!
Fresh food and grocery, some nice fun little things too. A bit expensive, but it's a fun place to go.

Tons of choices under one roof! I found alcohol-free food flavorings here and the shopkeeper was nice enough to write down things I would like to see at his store in the future.  The place is buzzing with variety and excitement and the fresh produce is beautiful..... If you're in Philly and haven't been here yet, GO TODAY!
An amazing place to explore! Super yummy food and fresh produce :) Kinda expensive, but worth it.

RTM is the kind of place that makes you wish you had an infinite stomach so you could eat all the things. 

All the things to eat:
DiNic's roast pork sandwich with broccoli rabe. This is the true Philly sandwich.
Hershel's brisket sandwich. 
The Fair Food Farmstand has amazing local products, like heirloom apples and ethically raised meat.
Termini Brothers for your Italian sweet tooth. 
Bassets for ice cream.

It is a must visit if you are in town, but try and avoid the well known places in the middle and venture to the back and sides. Some hidden gems include and olive oil store "The Tubby Olive." It is an adult candy store with free samples of delicious oils and balsamics. 

Beck's Cajun Cafe has some great Po Boy sandwiches and let's you order half of two types --  it is worth trying the oyster. And of course they put Chicory in their coffee. 

The Amish donut stand makes them hot and almost to order. Bacon and Maple is my favorite. And, yes, it is worth every calorie. But they aren't there on Sunday.

Generally worth getting to the Terminal around 10. Lets your venture freely without crowds.
Fun place to visit!  Provides a wide variety of food choices and other interesting things to buy.

i love reading terminal market so much. i could spend an entire morning here just browsing through all of the different stalls. it's like a playground for adults who love food and the amish. it's heaven for people who get a thrill out of buying what is likely the best produce in the city and checking out 30 different types of honey and fruit butter.
Not to be missed!  All kinds of wonderful food, fun to just look even if you don't want to eat - a true Philly staple.  Especially if you're visiting make sure to check it out.
Love it here! Sensory overload, some of the best sights, sounds, and flavors the city has to offer.

Awesome! What a great find in Philly!! It is a bit crowded but well worth it, everything we tried was amazing!!
I loved the Indian food and our son tried his first alligator here. 
Even if you don't have cash they have an ATM. 
I would strongly recommend touring the whole market first so you can then choose your favorites and enjoy!
Fresh meats -Fish and great cooked food....loveeee this place!

I honestly don't even know where to start. If you don't consider yourself a foodie, I garuntee you will be after your first few minutes walking through this place. To simply put it, the Reading Terminal Market is heaven. I'm surpised they don't have a Golden gate and angels at the entrance. There is every kind of cusine you can think of and it is all authentic and as fresh as can be. A few of the restaurants in there have been featured on food network tv shows. And many of the places are Zagat rated. For you sweets lovers, they have a whole aisle of just that and if you don't see what you're looking for on display, there's a few places that can make any dessert/ cake you body/ mind desires. This place is so amazing, I can't even say what my favorite restaurant is. There's just waaaay too many! To add to that, they also have amazing coffee, book stores, a nut stand, Amish stand, ice cream stands, cookie stands, an oyester bar, exotic grill chees stand, bee wax product stand, fresh bread stands, a few vegetable and seafood stands with unbeatable prices and products, just to name a few. They occasionally events/ shows around the food court which makes it almost too much to handle. Annnd difficult to navigate. Speaking of navigating, that's my only complaint about this place. It gets super, ridiculously, unbelievably crowded on the weekends. But that's only because it's clearly one of the best things that Philly has to offer. Simply put, if the Reading Terminal Market was the only place I could eat for the rest of my life and the next life, I would be perfectly ok with that. So do yourself a favor and treat your taste buds to total euphoric pleasure.
-You're welcome ;-)

An essential Philly Mecca of markets meshed together in one spot. Hershel's East, Franks a Lot, Keven Parker Soul Food, Down Home Diner, Dutch Eating Place, Termini...even a bar/restaurant (Molly Malloy's!) are all here. Whew. I'm heading over there just thinking of all these wonderful spots.  See ya.
a nice little place but so far of the places that i have tried it didn't make me want to head back there unless i have to do something at the convention center...

As a Center City resident, I actually shop for my groceries at the Reading Terminal - Iovine's, Giunta's, Metropolitan Bakery, and the Fair Food stand are my four regular stops.  I don't mind the tourists milling around because, hey, who wouldn't want to see what the RTM is like?  I just wish they wouldn't stand around in large clumps when I am trying to get through with my bags of goodies, but that's the price we pay.  Love the place!

The market is a great place for a quick bite to eat, purchase groceries, or shop for specialty items ranging from soaps to baked goods to cookbooks.  There is a lot of variety, so it's pretty easy to find something for everyone.  Just be mindful about the days and times you want to go.  The market can be overwhelmingly crowded on the weekend.  So unless you want to fight the crowds, I would try to go during the week.
Not the best quality but has variety of food.

Excellent food market with a wide diversity of quality offerings. Home of Dinic's, awarded "best sandwich in America". Baked goods are excellent here. At the produce corner you can find fresh squeezed orange juice for half the price of what you would pay in the burbs. This place truly has something for everyone.
Love the hustle and bustle of the Market.  Good food and great atmosphere.

As much as I would love to give this location five stars for the amazing variety of high-quality food, the one thing that always irks me is that there isn't more seating.  Seating can be hard to come by during busy periods like the weekend.  If you're looking to take stuff home with you, you can't beat this place.
This is a great place to browse and eat lunch!  We loved The Tubby Olive for the balsamic vinegars.  We had lunch at the Middle Eastern stall with a bar, and loved the falafel and dolmas.
I enjoy going, especially with visitors and on weekends, when the Amish boothes are open.

This place is a mad house, a million stalls, a million smells and food all over the place. Some of it looks like run down food court options, but some of them look amazing. I saw a butcher that was selling different types of sausages that sounded so good I wished I was a local and could buy them and grill them up.

Its a little frantic and hectic in here but finding a table for 5 to sit and eat didn't seem very difficult which was really nice. Over all clean place thats great to dive in for a random selection of eats.

This place makes having no real major grocery store in Center City bearable.  I came here expecting to be able to find all the great fresh meats, seafood, produce, etc. that I was missing and had resigned myself to the idea that I'd just have to suck it up and pay a pretty steep price to get it, but RTM has blown my mind!

Frequented both by tourists and locals alike, this place has everything! I'd say the majority of the shops are food stalls designed for you to order something and eat there (sandwiches, bakeries, etc.) but there's also quite a number of seafood, meat, poultry, and produce places.  Overall, I found the prices of the seafood to be comparable to my local grocery store (but sooo much fresher looking), and the prices of the meat/poultry to be about on par with grocery store prices, if not just a tad more expensive.  If you look closely, you can even find some deals (like ground lamb for $4.95/lb?! I usually pay $7.99-$8.99!)

Come early, avoid weekends if possible, and try to avoid being in the background shots of as many tourists' photos as possible :)

Wide variety of cuisines to select from the numerous stores here. Its really what you call the melting pot of food in Philly. From amazing ice creams at Bassets to the amazing rib sandwiches at Rib Stand and the yummy kebob roles at Kamal's..this place has it all.

I love Reading Terminal Market!  It reminds me of the Mercado San Miguel in Madrid. Upon entering the market, my senses immediately came alive from the wonderful smells, and all of the different foods. The only difficult part is deciding where to eat. My daughter and I enjoyed a gyro at Olympia Gyro and it was certainly among the best gyro I have had!
This place is unreal.  So many many options,  definitely something for everyone.  Even if you aren't eating its worth stopping by just to check it out.

Foodies paradise.  They have everything in there.  My faves are Beiller's, Hope's cookies in the Pennsylvania gen store, Bassetts Ice cream, Dutch eating place and tommy dinics.

Sad that the Smuckers place was closed on the sunday we went bc my hubby really wanted to take home some since we don't live in Philly anymore.  

I do think that some stuff can be a little overpriced, but the Amish food is the best buy esp for the type of food and price.  Their doughnuts are amazing and only 95 cents.

Also a little disappointed that there weren't a lot of fruits in the produce stores.  we were hoping to get some honeycrisp apples.  We did get champagne mangoes though.

Overall, I highly recommend this place even if you don't want food.  they have candles, books, houseware stuff.

A veritable moving feast for the senses, and in my humble opinion, the best public market in the country.  All of the stalls feature something unique and delicious.  The Amish contingent are a wonderful part of the market, they have a few amazing shops and are always friendly and helpful.  The butchers are all great, and you can't beat the produce prices/quality.  Nothing needs to be said regarding the superlative D'Nics, which is one of a slew of great eateries within the market.  The four dollar parking garage is another great feature as well.
Wow!  So much to see, do, and eat!  A lovely way to spend an afternoon~  Great place for a date :D

I can't even begin to explain to you how completely EPIC this place is.
It's a foodie's DREAM and if I lived in Philly, I would be there every. single. day.

I am going back to philly just to go here (and to Monks Cafe!). It's a 4 hour drive, but the market is incredible. What a way to enjoy a weekend!  Everything foodie under one huge roof - price range from insanely cheap to kind-of-high-but-worth-it.   Highly recommend the German cafe and deli (Wurzhaus Schmitz), the Tubby Olive balsamic vinegar store, Giuntas meats and the 4th Street Cookie Company. All amazing!  Foodies heaven!

Don't ignore this foodie landmark - the Market has basically everything - from local fresh produce to ice cream and sandwiches. 
A bit crazy in there, though, so don't expect to have a  ceremonious meal.

reading terminal is where the city goes to eat together. the range of people is amazing. and the camaraderie is undeniable.  Sometimes I wish the food was better but at least there are many choices. Some favorites: Metropolitan Bakery, one of the best around. The music at lunchtime. The coffee and tea places. And the improved beer garden.

When I wrote my review for Reading Terminal Market in 2010 I called it "the single best place in Philadelphia."

A lot changes in 4 years. The market has a little bit but I have changed a lot more.

In that time I have converted to a vegan diet. The market has some new stalls but its overall vibe (meat and fish heavy unhealthy Philly fare) has not. 

I still enjoy a stroll through the market (so long as my gaze avoids the meat and seafood stalls) but those walks are just nostalgia for my first years in Philadelphia when my wife and I were first dating. Way back then (the ancient era of 2004-2005) she and I would go to the market for a the special at the Hatfield Farms deli counter. Back then whenever I had time to kill, I would do it at Reading Terminal Market.

As my tastes have changed the Market has barely budged. It feels stuck in a past where people ate like they did not give a damn. Maybe I'm being too hard here. It could just be my age. I loved the market in my 20s. In my 30s, I usually only order something from the Four Seasons veggie juice bar. 

I recently sat at a table at the Market to grade some student work before I met up with some friends. As I was sitting with my Four Seasons juice I was asked to take part in a survey by a woman researching for Reading Terminal Market. My overall feedback to her: "this could be such a great place and I would recommend it to friends if only it had some vegan take-out!"

To be fair: Reading Terminal Market has the vegan cupcake at Flying Monkey (quite good) and Molly Malloy's which is not a bad place to hang out. And of course Four Seasons for some really good cheap veggie juice.

Aside from that and coffee I don't spend money there. Its managers should take a walk on South Street and enjoy some of its vegan take-out. Imagine what Reading Terminal Market could be if it included some of that!

Everything you could imagine is here! Affordable prices for great meals from different places around the world, unfortunately I always miss the Amish area, because I always go on Sundays. I highly recommend to bring cash; not all the places receive credit cards.
A mandatory site visit on your next visit to Philadelphia if you love food. We made several culinary discoveries and have been tasted delicious products.

A great market, anything you can think of to eat fresh and tasty. 
 Tom M. In the reviews is a dumb ass just because you turned idiot, I mean vegan sorry I get the two confused you shouldn't 3 star a place because of your stupid thinking.
The Reading Terminal never disappoints! There are so many delicious options, you can't go wrong. However, I would avoid at all costs on Saturday and Sunday afternoons as it gets very packed.
Great assortment of businesses and venders. one of my fav spots to shop when I go into the city

Lots of fresh food and unique ingredients at an easy convenient place! 
Try the cannolis and fresh jam!
If you want a taste of Philadelphia, this is the place to come. Termini Bros Bakery, Dinic's Roast Pork Sandwich, Amish soft pretzels, Bassett's ice cream - Reading Terminal has it all!!

love love love The Reading Terminal!!!! So many vendors to choose from Fresh everything!!! The Amish vendors are my favorite besides Martin's. The sit down and eat vendors have some great food also. Pack your patience it can get very crowded in the Reading Terminal but the wait is worth it!!! Enjoy!!

I lived in l loft less than 1 block away from 03-06 when I was single, just so I could come here everyday. I prob spent thousands a month from the Amish cartel to sang kee, pearls oysters and the down home diner. I'm not even counting all the $$$ I spent on fresh squeezed oj, which was $10 every other day. Great place but going everyday and doing my shopping there almost led me to become one of the homeless that inhabit the corners. From what I understand these unlucky souls used to be attorneys and doctors before succumbing to the delicious addiction that is contained inside the old reading railroad station.

What a melting pot of cultures and influences under one roof! Amish selling wares (except on Sundays), halal middle eastern cuisine, fresh juices, soul food, burgers ... The list goes on :)

What I was really looking for was the raw milk ... But having gone in a Sunday the Lancaster Foods stall was closed :(
Nice if you can handle the crushing amount of tourists.  I haven't really explored the whole thing because of this reason.
Great place to people watch and get some great food!  It can be a little overwhelming and I found out that a lot of the places close earlier than 6pm but I'm just sad that I'm so far away.

This place is amazing!!!  You can easily spend hours exploring everything in there and sampling all the food.  The meat and produce are also priced very cheap.  They even have products that you can't easily find in other markets.
So much variety and culture! So many options! So many great smells! Eat there then order other things for later, and while you're at it do some of your grocery shopping. Not to be missed.

Reading terminal is an awesome place.  The restaurants and take out counters are great and there is something for everyone.  The Produce sections are unbeatable when it comes to price in center city.  The only reason it is getting 4 stars instead of 5 is it's a little tough to navigate until you get the hang of it.
Great market overall. The German deli, the Cajun restaurant, the Amish restaurant are especially great. Also, the sushi bar, produce market and cheese counters make the trip worthwhile, too.

A heaven on earth for foodies like me.

Reading Terminal has something for everyone. Salads, sandwiches, wraps, pizzas, gyros, and crepes are just a handful of the many types of food offered here. I go to the Termini Bakery and Meltkraft Grilled Cheese when I want to indulge, and to Tootsie's when I am feeling healthy.

When it comes to food, you can find anything here.  Wait, let me rephrase.  You won't food anything average or bad here.  It's almost like all the food vendors wants to show off who has the biggest muscles here.  Everything was awesome from the roast pork subs, hand made pretzels to the fresh donuts.  I highly recommend taking a tour to get the history behind this market as well.  It completes the experience.

Reading Terminal is the quaintest, most awesome place in Philly, as far as food goes. I hate that my favorite places inside don't take credit, but I guess that comes with the quaintness. Scallops, kale, and sweet potato drizzled in honey from Pearl's is something I get at least once a week when I walk to the Terminal on my break at work. The lamb hash from Border Springs Farm is incredible for breakfast. And don't get me started on the produce, I could go on forever !

If you've never been... this food emporium is as good as it gets.. From the fabulous sandwiches at DeNic's, the apple turnovers at the Dutch Eatery, the baked goods, the ice cream and the other great ethnic foods..you have a hard time going wrong at any stand here..
I love Reading Terminal Market! It is a place for foodies, the market has all sorts of food from ice cream to awesome pub food. Also the place where you can find DiNic's roast pork sandwiches!

I visited the other day and was amazed by the variety.  However, it was overwhelming because of all the options and all the confused people walking around making walk ways narrow.  With that said, I left with amazing chocolate covered pretzels.  It's safe to say that I enjoyed the variety of sweets offered.  

But, as a visitor from NJ I don't think that I'd come back just for the market.  Still, that doesn't take away from the chill atmosphere Philadelphia constantly provides.

Cool historic place to grab some lunch.  Was excited to know that this used to be a terminal for the Reading Railroad (I couldn't help but immediately think of all the good times I had playing Monopoly and picking the card that said "Take a ride on the Reading Railroad"..... now I wanna go play Monopoly).Fun spot to check out if you're visiting Philly. Be sure to bring cash- not all places within the market take cards.

Al-Qaeda believes that heaven has the promise of 7 virgins.  I now know that they are wrong.... Heaven is located right here in the walls of this building!

I am currently updating my resume so I can move to Philly to frequent this place on a daily basis.  

My goal would be to start in the Dutch Bakeries and eventually eat and drink my way to the Italian Sausages.

Until then I still have the memories of that wonderful day at the Philly Farmers Market     

Philadelphians you are so lucky!

Lots of good variety, and very reasonable prices for fresh fruits/vegetables.  It's hard finding good produce in the city, at least at a reasonable price.  Very crowded, but that's because everyone else loves it as much as I do.  Going on a Sunday before it closes isn't worth it: a lot of the vendors aren't there on Sundays and it's packed.

I'm so in love with Reading Terminal Market! It reminds me of Marche Jean-Talon in Montreal, but with way more food and less groceries/farmer's market (both are indoor structures, by the way). Vendors are separated by stalls/sections and there is even a map so you don't get lost. You just have to see it. So amazing. I wanted to try everything but I only have one stomach so I opted for the ones that had the highest Yelp reviews. Best decision ever.

Reading Terminal Market is now on my list of favorite places in Philly and dare I say it, overall, in my travel adventures (but theme parks - you'll always be #1). Don't miss out! You won't be disappointed with anything inside.

Amazing place to soak in all the diversity that philly has to offer. Great place to have breakfast or lunch while visiting philly. Great place to get produce and fish.  In the heart of center city so very accessible a MUSt do for anyone visiting philly.

ok I must say I was warned about this place!! A must stop market in Philly that has everything from cheesesteaks to fresh produce. After browsing for 30  minutes I wanted To try one of the pulled pork sandwiches. The line was so long that I settled on eating at one of the food counters that served New Orleans inspired cuisine. My shrimp poboy wrap was tasty and inexpensive.
Picked up some fresh fruit and nuts and few caramel cookies that were divine. I will be back today.... And probably tomorrow!!

Need to shop for some produce or seafood or meat? Hungry at the same time?

Well, Reading Terminal Market has it all! Everything from a Pennsylvania Dutch bakery to fresh seafood can be found at the market. Not only is it easily accessible via the metro, it's a fun place to go and experience life.

But, be warned! It's a popular place and the weekends can get quite crowded, making it hard to find a spot to sit and eat. And yet, when I overheard someone exclaim "There's too many people in here!" I almost yelled back, "I guess you haven't been to Asia!"
umm what more can you say but WOW!! TOTAL food heaven. Fresh foods, cooked foods from all type of cuisines, a bar, several deli's and cheese shops, bakeries etc. go. just go.

Believe everything you've heard about Reading Terminal Market and then some. RTM features a dizzying selection of specialty foods, ethnic foods, and wonderful eats - from sweet to savory - to satisfy any appetite. It's a foodies wet dream. 

Most people have heard of RTM and check them about because of the fanfare that Dinic's Roast Pork sandwich has received from the Travel Channel. I might take some heat for this - the sandwich is really good but a bit overrated IMO - but you do yourself a disservice if you have the opportunity to try one and don't. But you also do yourself a disservice if you go to RTM, eat at DiNic's, and don't explore or try anything else. 

The wife and I took the complimentary ride from our hotel to RTM, arrived at about 10:30AM, and spent about 90 minutes or so there. We started at Old City Coffee before heading over to DiNic's, and we also tried Miller's Twist (my favorite) and Flying Monkey Bakery (Whoopie Pies FTW!) We explored The Head Nut (insert joke here) and my wife enjoyed reliving her childhood while exploring Wursthaus Schmitz.

A few tips for the RTM n00b:

1. Read the review of my new Yelp Elite friend and Philly local Steven B. He covers many of the basics. Definitely make sure you go on a day where the Amish vendors are open!

2. If your mission is to try the famed Dinic's Roast Pork, plan strategically. The wife and I were in Philly Friday and Saturday, and we decided to come early Friday morning, guessing that would be the least crowded. We were right. We got to DiNic's about 10:45AM or so, and were lucky to get two seats that hat just opened up. 

3. The place gets crowded FAST. Be prepared for crowds. It wasn't crowded at all when we arrived, but by lunch time the market was packed with local workers on lunch break.

4. Plan ahead if you are a tourist and you want to purchase items to take out with you. This was our mistake. I planned to explore the market, but DiNic's was my main mission, so we came early and planned to go do the touristy stuff (Independence Hall, etc.) after. Unfortunately, this did not allow us to buy any product except what we stuffed in our bellies. Next time we visit Philly, we are considering staying at a nearby hotel to alleviate this issue.

Anyone who loves food and dares to call themselves a "foodie" will love this place. If you don't love Reading Terminal Market, you have no soul.

This place is something else!! I've been passing by it for at least 3 days without investigating. I finally pop up in here today and what do I find?? I find a city within a building that has international as well as domestic restaurants at my disposal. It's a flea market for food basically and is basically humongous!! 

I even found a cajun stand with nothing but Louisiana foods prepared from gator gumbo to sausage and chicken gumbo. They gave me a sample of the jambalaya, the chicken and sausage gumbo and I was heavily enthused!! Being from Louisiana myself, I had no complaints as to the taste because it had everything that was needed. 

You can find fresh fish, oysters, gyros, chinese, or anything you have your heart set upon in this place. Some places in here cook your seafood, lobsters, or what you want while you wait. Some of them are to go only as it pertains to Seafood or fish. What one place don't do, the other will for you!!! THIS IS ONE HELL OF A PLACE TO VISIT!! As I have 2 more full days here, I will be spending some time in this place.

It is an amazing place where you may find a wide range of cuisine. There are not only common cheese steaks but also French crepes, Vietnamese soups and a lot of sweets and fruits. After a trip, when you don't know what to eat, reading market is worth to visit. If is a magic spot with delicious plates, not so much expensive.

LOVE THIS PLACE.
Definitely my favorite part of Philly (Mainly in part because they have Beiler's donuts -- the most amazing thing I have ever eaten). There was so much to do here!

Basically, it's an area filled with restaurants - all with their own specialties whether it's seafood, philly cheesesteaks, grilled cheese, baked goods, ice cream, etc - as well as little shops for basically anything you could want. They have a garden store with flowers and seeds to plant, as well as olive oil shops, candy shops, and many produce, fresh meats, and cheese shops.

This place is a food-lover's dream, and I would highly recommend it to anyone. I wasn't a huge fan of Philly, but RTM was the BOMB.

This place is a foodie's paradise.
Rows of incredible top notch food choices and food product.. You need more than one (and a hearty appetite ) to fully appreciate it

What can I say about this place that hasn't already been said?! This is the go to spot for all things delicious! Had some roasted pork, ate a giant Amish pickle and potato salad and killed some doughnuts. This place is top notch and i'd highly recommend.

Market was not as big as I originally thought. There is a good variety of food, including 2 Peking duck places, as wells as several cheesesteak ones (you know which ones are popular by the lines that snake around the stall). Tommy DiNic's looked good too, but the queue was too long for me.
Great food, great variety! Great for people watching! Kraftwork (?) grilled cheeses in Valley Dairy was great, try Valley Thunder with Brisket and Mac & Cheese!

Love this place. Some many choices. Now it is really busy must of the times I have been here. If you are in a group the best thing to do is walk around and get an idea of what you want then divide and concur. Make sure one of you is looking for a place to sit if you your staying. This is a must stop when you are in town.

We arrived on Sunday afternoon as the vendors were closing. We were able to purchase some fresh fruits and veggies. My biggest regret is not bringing any cash (most of the vendors only accept cash). We will be going back to Philly in a few weeks, so I'll update this review then.

Crowded, Expensive but such a wide variety of things to buy. Unfortunately we went on a Sunday when all of the Amish stores were closed. A ton of helpful informed store employees. So many things to see, taste, and do too much for a one day trip I can't wait to go back again. Just not on a Sunday!
I've always heard about the Reading Terminal Market, and a few short weeks ago I was finally able to experience it. This place has such variety and I cannot wait to go back and discover more things.

I love the market! It's a must-visit for out of town guests, and I frequently stop by for my grocery needs as a regular ol' Philadelphian. When you go, check out Beiler's Doughnuts, ruining healthy diets since whenever they were established. Those 95 cent apple fritter's will be the death of me! And I'll die happily!

Love the fact that EVERYTHING and ANYTHIG you want is there.
Plenty of parking options...easy access with pulic transportation too.
Great VIBE

Personally, this place is both an irresistible draw and a great source of confusion. The latter due largely to it's sheer size and the incredible level of variety available here. 

Upon arriving, I always find myself doing laps just taking in all the visuals and aromas of the wealth of foods around me. I have to admit, I've been here numerous times and I can still get lost inside. I walk, stare at stuff, dodge people, read menus, walk some more, dodge a few more people, stare at more stuff. 

I've barely scratched the surface in terms of how many vendors within the RTM I've patronized. I've bought treats from the Amish and I've been to Pearl's & DiNic's - all were good experiences.

I can see why some might call it a tourist trap, but I personally would not characterize it as such. I think aside from it's practicality and usefulness, it's part of the rich history of the city and a throw back to markets of old. It's certainly a great asset to have here.

When it's time to leave I just walk straight until I find an exterior wall which will ultimately lead to an exit. Depending on what street I'm facing and my intended course, I adjust as necessary. 

There's nothing quite like it. Worth a visit.

Reading Terminal is a lot of fun to get lost in and people watch. There is some excellent fast food options along with a few sit down places and some really funky (in a good way) food stores. I love the duck place that's on the edge near the ice cream place, not to be too vague or anything! It does get very crowded during lunch time and on weekends so only go if you have enough time!

Oh yea I have NO IDEA what else to tell you guys that 1700+ already hasn't been said.  I can talk about the cluster , or a gathering of cultures under one roof that will overwhelm you. I can talk about the endless options of food to satisfy anyones cravings. I can mention also that there is a minature supermarket located inside.  I really don't know what else there is to mention other than this is a foodies paradise.  

Reading Terminal is by far the best option for anyone who wants a taste of everything , from the simple to the exotic. I know I just used the word exotic , but its true, when you step inside its like a whole different world. You don't know where to go to first pretty much, they have everything you could possibly imagine. 

A combination of cultures ready to hit you with an endless amounts of delights. If it isn't the Amish with their sinful donuts, pastries, cakes and pies, its their BBQ pit. Forget what you saw on TV about the Amish Mafia ,(If anyone ever saw it) these guys set up a "Front" in Reading where there is a line as  wrapping around the corner. All just to try their product, which by the way is on point. I do reccommend you go during the end of the week, these guys aren't set up on the weekends.(Sundays and Mondays)   I am still baffled by this.... the Amish, who knew they could attract so much attention. 

 A little side note~ To the Amish, I am now a loyal patron to your pastries, you made an offer I couldn't refuse.

Where else can you go for shopping, tasting, exploring, eating, all under one roof in the city. I am sure there is 1 or 2 spots, maybe , but do they have a bar inside? Yea I said it a bar, you can break away from the shuffling of on goers. All  trying to get that last slice of cheese or get that  fresh baked French bread. Slide on in at Mollys and take a breather, enjoy a few libations, recharge the system for rounds 2 or 3 maybe 4. I mean they do also have coffee stations along the way if you need a little pick me up , even they get blown out .  

Reading Terminal is pretty much the United Nations of cultures with American to European, to Asian, even Middle Eastern cultures trying to win you over.  This gives you  another reason why for you to return, endless options that can't be conquered in one day. 

 Plus they have cook books, a library basically of food preparations for every ethnic backgrounds  available. Reading even has a GINORMOUS section where you can buy key ingredients in spices and herbs,  where it would not be easy to find anywhere else.     

I am still trying here people to figure what to tell you that hasn't been said, so if I sound like I am repeating its not my fault.  I will tell you this though, the city did try to shut this spot down. In the mid to late '90s the city of Philadelphia came close to putting an end to Reading Terminal. I guess the power and the voice of the people pretty much told the city who their daddy was.  

Pretty much if I were to try to sum it up  Reading Terminal is a MUST. You'll definitely leave either with a full belly, or bags of goodies to peruse later. Now get in there and get a chocolate dipped onion to munch on as you enjoy the festivities of Reading Terminal.
Probably one of my favorite places in Philly! All the desserts there are worth your time and money!

can't get enough of this place.
everything's fucking phenomenal. visually a downgrade from nyc, but experience wise - wow. amazing food. 

foodie's paradise.

Salumaria is in my top 3 of hoagie places. Beiler's has delicious dirt pudding, spicy pickles, broccoli slaw and smackaroni(which is potato salad and macaroni salad combined. I get the bulk of my produce from Iovine, but am mindful to only buy organic, I've found that almost every fruit or veg that wasn't organic has spoiled within a day of purchasing. Several meat markets to choose from which all offer meat packages - open to change to your liking for the kosher or halal eater. My biggest pet peeve is the lack of seating, or even reliable seating, as a lot of the tables are wobbly and the chairs tend to be broken. Great place for ice cream too!!

I loved this place for the six years when I lived in Philly and missed it when I moved west for four years. Now we're back and it's gotten even better. More variety, lots of new places to eat, excellent fresh meat, cheeses, fish and produce. Wonderful sweets and ethnic foods too. Great bustle and energy.

Reading Terminal overall is awesome.  It's the mecca for all things food.

It does get confusing going around the market but every twist and turn has something for you to check out.
Possibly the most eclectic collection of really good food in the region. So many vendors under one roof it is mind boggling. Walk the aisles, smell the aromas, choose what you love!

Imagine Grand Central Market (LA) + Pike's Market (Seattle) 

*I think what drew me the most is the place for all the Amish desserts. Philly is actually very close to an amish community and every single Saturday they have 1/2 off desserts cause they all go back to Amish country on Sunday so they have to hawk all the desserts

**Awesome spot and I wish you could put it like 20 feet from my house so I could get fresh fruit, great amish desserts, and awesome food all day bro. 

JY
They have everything here. You can't go wrong with all the choices of food. The Salumeria is one of my favorite fooderies but Mezzi, Dinics, Border Springs and Flying Monkey are all great vendors.
Very cool place to visit with about 100 different food stalls. Something for everyone's lunch, and well priced produce. A must visit (albeit a bit of a tourist trap)!
If you dont mind doing your grocery shopping in an extremely crowded place but with tremendous fresh and amaaazing options - this is the place to be!

If you can't find something here that suits your appetite then you should stop looking. Can be a bit of a tourist trap - best on weekdays when there is no convention in town. Great produce from Iovine's, DeNic's Roast Pork was rated best sandwich in America, Termini Brothers Cannoli..but my personal favorite: The Herschel's Special - House-made pastrami on rye with coleslaw and thousand island. Actually, I am done writing this. My mouth is literally watering and I am headed to get one. You should too.

I loved it! Thinking of all the variety of foods to choose from and all the yummy food staring you in the face makes my heart skip a beat! We walked here from the historic district, and it was a little bit of a hike, especially for my 76 year old mom. If Philly had taxis available like NYC does, we definitely would have taken one for my mom's sake, at least. It was very crowded though and loud. And it was a little hard to find a table to sit at to eat. But all of these cons will not keep me away the next time I find myself in Philly!

Reading Terminal Market is probably the first place I would bring family or friends when they visit Philadelphia.  It is a fun experience, and pretty accessible via the train system.  There are dining and shopping options for just about everyone.  There are Amish bakeries and butchers, candy shops, a great roast pork spot, foods of every ethnicity, produce shops, cheese shops, a book shop, and much more.  
Being a New Orleans native, I was surprised to find a New Orleans stall with fairly legitimate food (I am quite picky about that).  
You can get almost the entire Philly food experience in one go at Reading.  Dinic's offers a great roast pork sandwich, you can enjoy Amish cheeses or baked goods, and there is a tourist-like shop in the back with local items.  If you are in Philadelphia for a conference, this is a good way to get the experience quickly.
The market will be crowded almost around the clock, so be prepared for that if you have small children.  Kids will love the candy shops and the Bassett's Ice Cream.  One candy shop has chocolate-covered onions for the most daring.
Best variety! Love Iovine's Produce, Lancaster County Dairy, L. Halteman Family Country Foods for my grocery needs!
Returned here while on jury duty a few weeks ago, still a great unique place with so many choices. It's pretty crowded in the summer, but you can handle it.

Since I moved to the area, I've visited Reading Terminal Market many, many times! Every time I try to buy something new but I always find myself going back to Bassett's Ice Cream for dessert! I've never actually had a bad experience coming here, though it can be very crowded most of the time and I wish it closed later in the evening.

What could be bad? No matter what you like you WILL find something that you like here. My favorite places are Miller's twist (cinnamon sugar is my favorite), 12th street cantina (great mexican food), down home diner (for breakfast), Sang Kee (try the pork), and Bassets (best ice cream in Philadelphia). The reason for the 4 star review is that the market gets extremely crowded.

This is one of my favorite places in the city.   It has more eating places than food stands, but thats OK.    I usually go on a Saturday morning before it gets too crowded or sold out.  Perfect time.

I love Martin's Meats for the sausage.  Tons of variety and fresh.  

The produce my Iovine is inexpensive and local, which is a plus.  Some of the fruit can't sit too long, so make sure to consume soon after buying. 

I love the Amish stands and there are a few.  Beilers Bakery is one of the best Amish Bakeries, definitely don't pass up a donut!

Lots of good cheese from Valley Shepard Creamery and be sure to try a grill cheese.

The best gyro I have had in the city is at Olympia Gyro.  

I could go on and on.  

It definitely gets touristy, but once you get past that and get used to it, it makes dealing with the crowds a lot easier.  Also, if there is a convention in town on the weekends, it will be super packed.

Love this place! You have a range of food options as well as grocery items to choose from. 

No words to describe how much I love Reading Terminal Market.
Everything you want to eat is here. So many options. Everyone will be satisfied. There may be crowds and long lines for some of the vendors, but isn't that a sign that this is the real deal?

A must go! A great place to just walk around or get a good meal. We went the first time on a Friday and it was very easy to walk around. We went back on a Sunday and it was very packed but still fun to walk around. We ended up buying some fresh meats to take home with us.

This market was awesome. I came in here looking for a good, authentic Philly Cheesesteak and found just the thing i was looking for. Carmens inside the Reading Terminal market was awesome. Friendly staff and an amzing cheesesteak! Highly recommended.

This was our first time here and I love this place! It was a little overwhelming at first, with so much to see and eat. You should definitely try the Brisket at Tommy DiNic's, Pastrami at Hershel's, and a desert  from Termini Bros.

One of the first places I recommend for any out of town visitor who likes to eat.

It's only gotten better in recent months with the addition of Valley Shepherd Creamery, Beiler's doughnuts and Border Springs Lamb.

Even though I've moved out of walking distance, it's at least a weekly stop for me to pick up produce at Iovine Brothers, who do great (and very well-priced) fruit and vegetable trays.

I am very partial to Pike's Market, which, of all the markets I have been to, is the most colossal and impressive of its kind. For perspective, I have also been to the French Market in New Orleans, Findlay Market in Cincinnati, City Market in Charleston, and Faneuil Hall Marketplace in Boston, among other notable markets. 

Reading (pronounced "redding") Terminal Market is definitely unique to Philadelphia and worth a visit. It's like Pike's Market, but on a smaller scale. It's a very large warehouse space has offers aisles upon aisles of specialty foods vendors. They also have a farmer's market section in one corner of the market. They also house a fresh seafood market and several delis. There's 1 florist shop in Reading Market and 2 sit down restaurants inside the market. Most other food vendors either do not offer seats or just have limited bar seating. 

Some things I like about Reading Terminal Market include the large sitting area in near the middle of the market. Furthermore, they have complimentary cell phone charging lockers. That's right lockers. You can lock your mobile devices up and shop around while it charges.
Was there the other day.  I had been there before, yet not for years.  Was totally overwhelmed by the amount of different types of food and the crowds.  Yet had a good time.

I fell in love with this market place immediately!  Since I recently visited Seattle, it reminds me of Pike Place Market.  

When you walk in, you'll become overwhelmed by the amount of people congregated around different vendors combined with the scents of amazing food sold here.  There are many varieties of food to choose from.  Not to mention the assortment of desserts appealing to anyone's taste buds.  

There are many vendors selling cute crafts to Philly souvenirs.  You'll notice the strong Amish presence at many of the sites.  Fresh baked breads and delicious fudge are ready to purchase and devour.  Yum.  

I would highly suggest stopping here whether you are just visiting or a local.
Best food in philly all in one place! so many food vendors and not enough tummy space to sample them all! It was crowded but every place i went was worth the wait. This is a must see/do in Philly!

Came in after hours for the eTail East event. Got to sample food from a variety of vendors and walked around when it wasn't busy. A great experience.

Best part was that we got to sample the philly cheese steak so many different ways.
The turkey samich place is mmmm....drool worthy!

Put Reading Terminal Market on your to-do list if you are visiting Philadelphia! This is a place that offers all kinds of food and good and despite being a tourist-friendly location, the pricing is reasonable and the quality is superb!

While you are looking for hot food eats like Philly Cheesesteak or desserts like ice cream, Reading Terminal Market has it all! The Market also has shops that sell meats, produce, and seafood and it seems like even locals like to shop here. Heck, if I were a local, I would come here often too! My mom, who is a health freak, insisted that we needed fruit for our meals so she brought apples from a local produce stand in the market. Our family was surprised at the cheap price, and was even more surprised at how fresh and delicious the apples were. I haven't had an apple this great for a while!

Don't miss out this awesome marketplace! If a tourist attraction is also a possible local favorite, then you know this is the real deal.

Absolutely amazing selection of vendors surrounded by amazing history. I recommend getting a roast pork sandwich from DiNic's. We did the food tour, which was really interesting and resulted in many samples from the market including snapper soup (it's turtle, and delicious).

My wife's cousin who lives in Philly took us there yesterday. I have to admit that is is a great place to experience. I wish I lived closer so I could shop here often but we live in New Jersey. So I will have to be content with just visiting on occasion. The variety of food is astounding. So fresh and inviting. It is a great place, with the history of the train terminal as well. We definitely will come back if we are in the neighborhood.

We have been to markets in Morocco, Italy, Tunisia,
France, England, I could go on...RTM can compare
favorably with all of them.  It is very much like the 
markets in Italy in look and feel.  Huge variety of
edibles and tchochkes, something for every taste.
Yes, Tom of Glenside, if one wants vegan, the 
offerings are somewhat limited.  Check out Tootsie's
at the back, lots of veg there.  Best:  the kale salad
with citrus dressing and cranberries.

A food lovers paradise!  Walk around and take in the sights, sounds and smells.  There is something here to please every palate.  I've tried quite a few of the stands over the years and have never been the least bit disappointed.  Philadelphia is steeped in American history,  and if you're going to take in everything that the city has to offer, definitely try to make this market one of your stops.

Love love love this place!  It is amazing and anyone who visit Philly must come visit this Market on an empty stomach!  And I mean it!  Once you walk in, you'll feel like you will get lost with so much going on under one roof.  One corner you see people showing for produce and the next corner you see a meat market.  Throughout the entire market there are different eateries, bakeries, desserts, ice cream and a bunch of goodies that you're wishing you had a third stomach just so you can try everything!  

Take some times to look around!  My friend and I have already decided the next time we visit, it will be on an empty stomach and trying a little bit of everything at each station.

We tried several restaurants at the Reading Terminal. Some were a bit disappointing. Our expensive pork sandwiches were so dry... Philly cheesesteaks, not so great. 
But over the course of 3 days, we found our favorites. The blueberry and apple fritters at the doughnut shop. The handcarved pastrami sandwiches at Hershels were the winners. We even went back to get some more sandwiches to take on the plane for dinner and doughnuts to bring home to share. Long lines but well worth it for those 2 favorites.

I always come here when I have a layover. They've got something for everyone! This is a great place for eating with a group since you can grab whatever you feel like from one of the many many eateries.

Some of my faves:

Flying Monkey Bakery- Whoopie pies. Especially the pumpkin chai in the fall.

Dutch Eating Place- Apple dumplings!

Iovine Bros. Produce- Cheap produce and some random finds. I have a recipe that calls for Spanish onions, and I get them here because I can't find them back home. Might not mean a lot to some people but it's a treat when I get to bring home produce from the east coast.

Fair Food Farmstand- Yummy finds like honey infused with asian pear or blueberry. My favorite find was the Trinidad Scorpion peppers.

Tommy Dinic's- Roasted pork sammich. Get it!

Beilers Bakery- Apple fritters and blueberry fritters!! Delish!

So, basically, you're gonna leave here 10lbs heavier.
Ditto on all the other reviews! Great fun and interesting activity. If you can't find something here to try, well, I just don't know what to tell you.

Very cute place!  I loved all the variety of foods and all the little stalls whether it was crafts, desserts, drinks or foods!   I think this location is perfect and there is something to offer everyone!   The positive is that they have tables (although I can envision it getting super crowded during lunch and hard to find a seat) and big bathrooms!  I was surprised the bathrooms were relatively clean too!   

Beware, the amish close early.  I think at 4.  We wanted to try their foods and were disappointed they closed.  Reading Terminal Market is easily walkable from Chinatown and the Rittenshouse Square area.   As for parking, I am not sure since I parked at my hotel and walked over.   I came after the lunch hours so I don't know how busy it gets during peak time.   This is a must if you are coming to philly to visit or even if you are a regular and looking for something to eat.
Must visit when in Philly, simple as that! Too many great spots to review, just go and enjoy.

I love coming here for fresh veg and fruit (Iovine Brothers) and shopping here at Reading Terminal is something everyone should experience. 

Although you probably don't want to bring small children during lunch, it gets more than a little crowded.

I have to give this place five stars. Not only is it uniquely Philadelphian, it is also yummy 99% of the time! As much as I enjoy the sloppy Joes at the Amish diner, I still recommend that you skip the Amish fare (they use saturated fats and favor unhealthy shortenings over butter - for shelf life) and go for the uniqely Philadelphian and international cuisines. I love every stand. The Thai place has a salmon dish that is amazing and every stand there has a speciality, just ask the people in line for which items are the stand's signature dish(es).

Best place in Philly for local's and tourist alike. Great experience, amazing, unique atmosphere and some of the best food in the city. Roast Pork at Dinic's with provolone, broccoli raab and long hots is the best sandwich in Philly and is more Philadelphia then the cheese steak, yeah I said it. If you haven't been its a must and when I have friends or family from out of town this is my first stop and I love it every time.

Lots of variety but way too crowded and a bit overpriced for what the vendors are selling. The best time to come here is during the weekdays around mid-morning. I'm not really into touristy things so if you enjoy going off the beaten path it is best to skip this place. I only come here when my work takes me downtown.....Lunchtime is insane and the weekends are even worse.

Take a stroll through Philaldelphia's historic Reading Terminal Market and take in all of the bright sites and tantalizing smells wafting through the air. This place is a mecca of Philly's Phinest eats.  You can make a day of exploring the market, and it is an especially great location for a date. Go for lunch, dinner, or to sample a little bit from a variety of vendors, and pick out some beautiful flowers for your sweetie while you're there!  Whatever path you choose, you won't want to miss the DiNic's roast pork sandwich with broccoli rabe and sharp provolone!
I could probably come here regularly and still never try everything. This place is amazing. No matter what you're craving you can most likely find it here. It can get crowded around the lunch hours.

I was really fascinated with this market place in Philly. My friend took me here and I had a great time! It has everything from grocery stores, meat markets, fruit markets, Indian restaurants, Chinese restaurants, gyros, bbq, herb stores and a Bee Natural store (natural body products store). 

I really liked Herbiary. I picked up a tangerine lime shea butter which smelled divine and the tester sample was very moisturizing. 

I also liked this one grocer (I cannot remember their name) where I picked up this freshly made raspberry lemonade which was very good! I wish I had purchased more bottles. It definitely had the homemade taste with the raspberry seeds that had sunken to the bottom of the bottle. 

I wanted a gyro but didn't know which one to try and I hadn't consulted yelp before heading out. 

I wanted some Chinese but out of the three we saw: 1) the first one- no one was at this restaurant's counter and they seemed sketchy especially with the "No refunds allowed" policy they had posted, 2) the second one- this restaurant was closed, and 3) the third one- didn't seem appetizing from the pictures. We ordered some smoothies from Kamal's and we were sourly disappointed because the smoothies were rather watery and they had an artificial, almost chalky taste. However, Kamal's validates. 

Apparently there is free wifi but I was unable to connect.
Sensory Overload! You can pretty much find anything you could need here.... Just be aware that there is always going to be a crowd.

Collectively, I can get my groceries (mainly fresh vegetables and meats) for much cheaper price than I can get at my local supermarket.  Plus, everything is fresher, I'm contributing to local businesses, and it's more likely that the food is locally sourced here.  And still a one stop shop!  Don't forget to get $4 parking across the street when they validate your parking (which is just a strategically placed hole in your parking ticket).

Definitely a good place to visit if you're touring Philly with the fun local stands.  The produce market has great student prices, and caters to locals. 

I like the roast duck at Sang Kee's stand.  The soft pretzels.  Any of the Amish meat.  The ice cream.  Actually, I've never had bad food here.

I had some time to kill before my bus left to head back to DC, so I decided to explore Reading Terminal Market. Many people had told me about it, but I didn't really know what to expect when I went there. There were so many options when I walked in, that I wasn't sure where to begin. I ended up just walking around for a while, just to see what was available. You could do a great deal of shopping here or even just stop in for a bite to eat. Not everything was open when I was there on a Sunday, but there was enough for it to be enjoyable. It wasn't overly crowded either, which I'm sure is rare. Yea there were a lot of people walking around, but very few places had unbearably long lines. I definitely want to spend more time here, so I can't wait to come back!

Do you wish to have sensory overload? If so, head to Reading Terminal Market, right quick!

The colors, the smells, the hustle-and-bustle of the people who are looking for good eats, and then the good eats... Oh. My. Gosh. It is just an amazing place to...exist. They have seafood, Amish donuts, great chicken, roast pork sandwiches and other deli sandwiches, the country's oldest continuously operated ice cream parlor, and the list goes on and on.

We had very little time to spend in Philadelphia, but our visit here is most definitely one of my most favorite things that we have done. I will be back, and when I do, I will make sure I am truly famished. There are just too many things I want to eat from this place!
This place is incredible. Its like Disneyland for foodies.

Awesome place to see a mix of Philly food and people culture ! Love all the options  and would have been a 5 star but very uncomfortable walking out being  hounded by addicts as you walk in and out of the entrances . Little too cramped and crowded at times .

This place is awesome. This is equivalent to Seattle's Pike Place, SF's Ferry building, Boston's Quincy Market LA's Grand Central Market, etc. It's a place of culture and food and history. There's butchers, bakeries, candy, fruit, oysters, ice cream, beer, samosas, cheesesteaks, cookies, sausages, crepes, fried chicken, peking duck...... 70+ vendors of food and gift items. You might as well prepare yourself to stay for breakfast, lunch and dinner (an early dinner because it closes at 6 PM). Many of the vendors appear to be family owned and operated, so you feel good supporting these small businesses.

I had it bookmarked before I got to Philly, but it was right across the street from the convention center where I had my conference, so I would've bumped into it anyway. When I walked in, 10 different wonderful smells pulled me in different directions. I merged into the flow of traffic and began to survey my options. Over the course of a few days of meals I tried the roast pork from Tommy DiNics, apple dumpling from Dutch eating place, corned beef from Hershel's, and ice cream from Bassett's (America's oldest ice cream company!). Nothing disappointed! The biggest problem? Deciding what to eat.

The most important thing to know is DON'T COME ON SUNDAYS! Many of the vendors are closed on Sundays and you will not get the full experience and miss out on some of the best reading terminal has to offer.
Love this place. So much to eat and buy. Brought home pounds of bacon from the Amish

Reading Terminal is a very large indoor market, with lots of restaurants stands, grocery stands, and stands selling a variety of other things. There's a reason it's popular with locals and tourists alike: this place is full of delicious food. It can get busy on weekends, and it's easy to get lost, but the food is worth it. Some of my favorite places are Beck's Cajun Cafe (great if you like spicy food) and Beiler's donuts, but nearly every place has great food. It's definitely not the cheapest, most meals will run you $8-11. However, this is definitely a must-do for anyone visiting Philly.

You will never find another place as awesome as this.  This is a huge food market.  There are people from all cultures and backgrounds here making food and selling goods.  It doesn't matter what you want to eat you will find it here and it will be amazing.  There were foods and cultures from places all over the world.  Not only the food but there are so many people from different cultures from the area that come here to eat.  It's truly a really awesome place to be.  There is paid street parking and there always seems to be a spot because people are constantly coming and going.  I went to a creole place and had an alligator po boy with creole mustard.  So tasty and sweet you wouldn't even know you were eating alligator unless you were told.  I also had some alligator gumbo which was a bit spicy but it was so awesome there.  I would suggest people go here or even the market in general and eat at all of the little places because each one was more interesting then the next.

Spoiled with choices.  I prefer the Dutch Eating Place for their extra large scrapple serving that comes as a side with a delicious pancake breakfast.  Afterwards, in true fat kid fashion, a stop at Beiler's for tasty doughnuts is a great way to pack on some additional calories.

I love this place!! A food lovers paradise. Hungry??  Want to eat?? You will hurt yourself trying to figure out which of the dozens of places here to try. Of course, there are plenty of places to buy food to cook at home as well. Seafood, fruits, vegetables, meats, cheese, it's all here in one giant madhouse!!  
       Of course, it's always good to come at times that aren't as busy.  Craving dessert?? Termini's, Beilers, Bassets Ice Cream. For the love of God, if you weren't diabetic when you came in, you will be by the time you leave!!!  Keep in mind that while Sundays seem a little quieter, that's because all the Amish vendors aren't here!!  I wouldn't recommend missing Beilers and their amazing baked goods!!  
      If there is one downside, it's the parking. As in most of Philly, parking is an abomination!! your best bet may be to find the closest lot and park there. This way you can take your time inside without worrying about rushing out for the time limit on the street parking.

There is NOTHING better than this market for foodies in the tri state area. Its a huge market warehouse filled with restaurants, food stands, produce, bakeries, fresh butcher stands, fish markets, bbq, fresh juice stands, even retail stores selling food related products!!
Theres no shortage of places to eat, or variety!! You can have Amish, Greek, Italian, Chinese, Vietnamese, Thai... theres even a bar restaurant towards the back for sports.
My favorite is Becks (creole/cajun), Dinics roast pork w broccoli rabe and sharp provolone sandwich (amazing!!) The fresh squeezed juice guy in the side corner, and the Amish stands with their incredible bbq ribs and their fresh bakery. Amazing dinner yeast rolls.
When my husband and I come we park right across the street, gather a few items at different vendors, then sit and eat lunch. After that? I grocery shop and bring alot of the food home. Bags and bags, hence the close parking spot lol
They have several dining areas and some of the restaurants have their own seating but do not come at lunchtime or during conventions or events ( convention center right next door) you will be standing or eating very closely w patrons!!
Great place, I will never stop coming here, I love it!!

There is not a single thing wrong with this place. Variety, quality, and quantity! If I lived closer I would come here weekly. When in Philly this market is a must! Go hungry and leave happy! It can get pretty crowded and some places have lines but don't be discouraged, it's worth the wait!

Such a wonderful place! Every time we go we find something new to try, although DiNic's will always be our favorite! From shopping for groceries, produce, and fresh spices (Head Nut!) to grabbing a great lunch, to being undecided for dessert because there are just so many options.... Reading Terminal is always an amazing trip.

The best food market that I have visited in the US hitherto. There are so many stalls. RTM is a must visit while you're visiting Philly. I suggest visiting around noon or later so that all of the vendors have a chance to fully prepare. 

I've purchased from about a dozen of the three dozen or so vendors, and I continue to find awesome new merchants each time I visit!

Unquestionably, RTM is one of America's must stops for food enthusiasts!

I've been to Philly a number of times and only now that I discover that this place existed.  I'm still pretty upset I've only discovered Reading Terminal this summer. It's pretty amazing! The closest thing I can compare it to is Pike Place Market in Seattle (without it being on the water).  If you've ever been to Pike Place, you'll know what I'm talking about.  

Located right in the middle of Philly, Reading Market has so many different stalls with a variety of merchants, ranging from small food stands. bakeries, ice cream shops, coffee shops, local crafts, fish market, butcher, salumeria, cheese shop, flower shop, fruits/vegetable stands, winestore, etc. OMG, my mouth is watering just thinking about it!

Word to the wise: come here on an empty stomach. There's so much to try and choose from, you will want to try everything.  Everything looks appetizing. Unfortunately, I only had enough space to try some ridiculously amazing Macadamia Nut cookies (drool) and a Kibbeh.  

Next time I come back to Philly, I'm coming back here gain, but hungry of course.

I go here for all my fruit and veggie needs at iovine brothers. For fresh produce their prices are reasonable and they have student discounts on Tuesdays and Sundays I think. Will confirm next time I'm there. I am now a regular. Plus if you don't mind they have a small offshoot somewhere towards the middle that sells anything that was close to going bad for even cheaper. You have to be careful but may find a few good things left

Big indoor market with tons of delicious vendors! I just love the energy and variety, and I've never gotten anything that was less than delicious. I take everyone who visits Philly here and it's always a good time. Highly recommend for an interesting lunch experience!
my favorite place in Philadelphia.  I visit at least once a week to do my grocery shopping.

1800 reviews can't lie right!!

I love this place. Being a foodie (aren't we all) this place was heaven. A huge variety of foods from any genre imaginable. You have everything from bakeries to delis to asians serving peking duck (hanging in the windows just like you would find in Chinatown).

We went there on a Sunday afternoon and though parking is a bit of a pain, there are some meters closeby that charge $3 per hour and a maximum time of 2 hours. I only stayed there for about an hour, but I am sure you can "refill" the car without penalty.

They also advertise discount parking rates at two closeby garages for $4 for up to two hours with a valid $10 purchase at the market, which I think is great for business.

I wish I was in Philadelphia for longer than one day. I was able to pick up some fresh veggies from the market, a few cookies from 4th Street Cookies and a Brisket Rueben from Hershel's Deli. Everything was great. I would have loved to try DiNic's as per the food channel, but the line was longer and I was craving a Rueben. 

There are some tables in common areas to sit and eat as well.

Seafood selection there is also amazing. I witnessed the biggest shrimp I have ever seen at $28.99/lb. 

Definitely a must in Philly.
Wonderful place for quick bites, snacks, groceries, produce and food. Something for everyone! Definitely go there.
really great stuff. not cheap. DON'T go at lunch time it's a mad house.

I have visited the Reading Market perhaps hundreds of times over the past 25 years. As a vegan, I would expect more fresh vegetables but am always sadly disappointed. In fact, the quantity of butchered meat on display and the smell of blood can make for a very unpleasant experience. A great vegetarian restaurant in the Market, "Basic 4," recently closed and now houses a shop that only sells lamb! Today, I spotted entrails and baby octopus on ice -- stomach-turning. This said, Iovine Brothers is 1 of only 3 reliable produce stalls in the market. Easily, 85% of the vendors are butchers or meat-pushers ... but DO seek out the fresh food farmstand or Iovine brothers if you care about suffering on the planet and if you care about your own health and longevity. Added bonus: The Flying Monkey bakery has vegan cupcakes and cookies! This market is extremely over-rated, and be prepared to dodge/ignore beggars who stalk neighboring sidewalks for tourists.
Phenomenal! Some of the best food in the world. It'll get a little expensive (8$ for 3 perogies?!) but I guess you get what you pay for.

I really like the Terminal Market. It's definitely worth a visit when in Philadelphia with so many different places to eat and try, everyone can get what they want. The only cons I can think of are that it can get crowded and loud and finding a seat can, at times, be difficult. I wouldn't ever let the crowd scare me away though, lines move fast and the food is good.

For my 400th review, I'm dedicating all of this little white space to the Reading Terminal Market.

Go to Philly.

Find your niche.

Raw, pure honey. Check.

Quality, local wines.  Check.

Home-style wings.  Check.

Donuts.  Doughnuts.  Check.

Pulled pork.  Check.

This place will appeal to any and every sense.

Global cuisines.  American eats.  Local crafts.  Wild herbs.  Fresh. Fresh. Fresh.

I am a Libra.  I cannot choose.  Variety anxiety.  That's a new one I just made up.

Self-diagnosis.

Sigh.

I'll be back in a few months.
Wow what a place! Foodies paradise, you can even eat inside, great place to find good Italian food, meats, vegetables and fruits and pastries.

If you go early on a Saturday, it's nice, as soon as it gets crowded it's ridiculous trying to move around. Some of the stands serve slop that is no better than a cafeteria, but they have added some nice food-retail options the last few years. I can't quite understand the huge line for the Amish Eating Place or whatever it's called, the food is sub-par - must be the tourists. Of course, it's ALL tourists. Personally, I have my own places I like to go, so just taking a spin around the aisles is enough. I'm not hugely enthusiastic about it, but I do enjoy going there sometimes.

If you're hungry in Center City and no one can agree on what to eat, the RTM is perfect, they've got cuisines A-Z for everyone.

Great collection of restaurants and produce stands. My favorites are Iovine Brothers produce and Hershel's East Side Deli. Can't beat Iovine's prices and variety. You can't go wrong with a corn beef sandwich.
