This place was a foodie's paradise. Each stall was better than the next. From spices to deserts to corned beef, butchers, fish mongers etc etc. For me the best find of the day was the Pennsylvania Dutch stand selling juices and milk. Best juice I've ever had barring those I've pressed myself. Every stall I visited the employees were happy, knowledgeable and friendly and it really made walking through the bustling lunch crowd worth it. Bought as much as I could carry..and left planning my next trip.  4 stars..would have been 5 if my parking wasn't 29$. I got validated.. But I stayed 15 minutes passed 3 hours. So instead of 16$ parking I got banged for 29$. I'll know better next time..and now so will you!;) ( parked in the garage across from the convention center. ) Also I visited on a Thursday early afternoon. If the lunch crowd was an indicator of how it would be on a weekend.. I'd stay away Saturday and Sunday. Other than that..its worth the trip.

Great variety and the place is huge so you can try so many things! They have enough places to sit when you order food. Tried Carmen's cheesesteak which was pretty good and the apple dumpling from the Dutch eating place which was also good. Would not get the pumpple (pie baked in cake) again though.

Awesome place to kill a few hours and stuff your face full!

My faves were denics (?) and the handmade fresh donuts. Everything was awesome though.

This place gets really crowded around noon time and its crazy hard to move around. In some ways its part of the experience of being there. I prefer to go when it is less crowded and I can take my time and see all the sellers. There is pretty much something for everyone here. I personally love the cookies sold by Metropolitan Bakery.  I've also found the produce sold at Iovine Bros to be fresh and delicious. RTM will certainly not disappoint if you don't mind the crowds.
The first time I walked in, it just blew me away. It's hard to know where to start. Rows and rows of beautiful, fresh, delicious food. I come every chance I get.

Ah, the market. You're like a long-term, committed relationship. In the way of Scrubs' Dr. Cox. 

On the outside, you seem a tad rough around the edges. And by rough, I mean ragged. During your peak times, you are most certainly a violation of fire codes and human rights, with we consumers packed into the avenues as cattle being led-not to the slaughter but the feeding trough. I've been touched in ways I haven't been since grad school-er, I mean, my last visit to NYC. 

But, when I get a tad closer, unravel the mystery behind your crazy busy-ness, I see the soft, delicious, sentimental center. I love finding your produce bargains, munching on burritos or brisket, pasta or pancakes, chowder or chicken, you-name-it-they've-got-it. I love finding lavender oil for my home fountain, a Flying Monkey cupcake on those hard-to-function workdays, and just maybe SUPER rib-sticking grilled cheese sammie during those delightful winter months. 

So, continue on in your wonderful ways, Reading Terminal. I'll come back week, after week, after week. Just find an Arrested-Development-Style prison guard that can yell "NO TOUCHING" ironically from time to time, and you'll be the perfect Dr. Cox, the gruff mentor with a heart of gold.

I love Reading Terminal!
There is a small wine shop where I like to get wine.
There is an Amish restaurant called Smuckers where you should DEFINITELY get their Roast pork sandwich OMNOMNOM
There are also many places to get produce!

It all depends on what you're looking for.  There is a LOT of variety here, but it can get very crowded, especially during lunch time.  It's still a good place to go, though.  Want middle eastern food?  Check!  BBQ?  Check!  Seafood?  Check!  Wanna pick up some veggies and fruit?  Check!  Got a sweet tooth?  Check!  Want to take home some baked goods?  Check!  It can be a little overwhelming, especially if you don't know the layout.  I've only been here a few times, and keep making a mental note to go when it's not as busy.  Also, it can be a little pricey, but not much more than other places in the area.  Again, it all depends...

As a first time visitor to Philly, my sister had to take me to Reading Terminal Market because I'm a fan of these market/specialty shops places like Chelsea Market in New York City and the Ferry Building in San Francisco. This place is awesome. There is so much going on, and you can get so many types of food! They have Middle Eastern kabobs to Chinese to rubens and cheesesteaks. My sister and I had already gotten lunch, but she did suggest I try donuts from Beilers. I got a regular glazed one and a cinnamon sugar one. Yum, I inhaled them both within five minutes. No shame. They were awesome. I wish I got more to make me feel better about the Philly heat! Next time, I'm coming back here for a full meal and some grocery shopping! I eyed some really fresh seafood and meats and cold cuts.

When my wife and I went to visit Philly we marked the Reading Terminal Market for a visit but didn't expect much since we thought this would be another version of a tourist distraction such as the South street seaport in New York, Fanueil Hall in Boston or Navy Pier in Chicago, etc...

Boy were we wrong and instead were treated to a really well run market with delicious food left and right and priced very reasonably.  You kind of realize that it's a serious market and not a tourist trap because there are tons of locals and even New Jerseyans from just across the bridge doing their everyday shopping.

There are great fresh baked goods, sandwich shops, seafood, butcher shops, restaurants, food stalls, artisans, dessert shops, wine stores and produce, etc.. A lot of the vendors there are Pennsylvania Dutch Quakers who also operate their shops in their traditional garb and really just produce excellent clean, fresh farm fresh food at great values.  Everything is affordably priced, fresh and delicious so you really can't go wrong.

The first thing you have to learn about Reading Terminal is No1: Its the best place in Philly to go for high quality specialty food. You literally can get anything you want like a one-stop shop. HOWEVER do not go around lunch time or right after work and NOT expect to stand in line for a long while at any place you go.  
No2: Take a day and just explore the darn place, you'll always miss a cool store, wine shop to new business if you don't take your time at least once.
No#: I demand you to get dessert from the farmers market there or have breakfast brunch at the amish diner thats there. Period. Good luck.

All of my friends recommended this place for when i'm in philly and I was so glad I went. 

So many great places to eat!
I've only tried Dinic's (roast pork sandwich) and Bassetts (ice cream) so far, but I definitely want to come back to try other places.

It's definitely hard to find a table to eat at... but I found that you have to look for people almost done eating and then swoop in once they're done. 

It's also a nice place to get some air conditioning from the hot weather outside. It was 94 degrees when I was in philly.

Over 100 restaurants inside.  This is the place to visit while in Philly.  You will be in food heaven!  Philly cheesesteaks, donuts, truffles, all kinds of sweets, oysters, lobsters, Chinese food, Indian food, Pakistani food, you name it, it's all here!  I can stay here for days!!!

Foodie paradise!

Roasting pork. A store filled with cheese. Fresh fish lined up for display. Tea, tea, tea. A tower of fruits and vegetables. Is that a waft of sweet fudge? YES. YES IT IS. And it's all within walking distance. 

I honestly don't know how I didn't A) spend more time here and B) spend more money here. Guess I have some self-control after all. I say, don't believe all the hype about some of the more popular joints in here (ehem Dinic's) and go check out some smaller shops. I had a blast at one of the Amish candy places and bought some stellar fudge (and take it from me, I used to work as a candy maker!). The cheese booths kept calling my name, but my wallet kept me from purchasing multiple cheese wheels (CRY). 

I love options and I love food, so if you love being overwhelmed by awesomeness, this is the right place for you. I could see tourists and locals alike coming here for a fun afternoon or a quick bite. Yum yums!
Great please to eat. For the best cookies anywhere go to the PA General Store.

Fun, vibrant energy. It is just that people are so pushy and rude walking right through out in the crowded walkways between the vendors. I wish it was a little more spread out. Feels crammed but the food options are diverse and delicious.
Love this place it's a foodies dream! It can get a bit overwhelming because of all the choices of food and the weekend crowd. This is always a must whenever I come to Philadelphia
Great place to walk around and get treats! It gets REAL crowded on the weekends so I suggest you go during the weekday BEFORE rush hour.

Reading Terminal is my connection to the city. This market represents everything Philly means to me. I've been coming here since I was about 5 years old and I don't think I'll ever stop. Reading is unparalleled in the amount and diversity of food they have here, you can find pretty much any cuisine you could ever imagine. The amount of specialty shops is literally amazing. To buy food, check out Guinta's for meats, Downtown Cheese for, well, cheese, Johnny Yi for seafood, and Iovine for produce; just to name a few of my favorites. The Head Nut isn't what the Spice Terminal was, but its getting there. To eat food, go to Sang Kee, Beck's, by George, Nani's, Kamal's, and the crepe place (emphasis on Sang Kee). I've had many friends move away from the city only to say that their local markets pale in comparison to what Reading is. Unless you absolutely must, avoid going on the weekend! Park in the garage on 12th and get your ticket validated for cheap (relatively speaking) parking, that is, if it actually works...
There are some great vendors here and there are some that only survive because it's always packed with tourists. Watch your pockets, it's shoulder to shoulder in there.

It's a great place to go if you want to buy quality meats, seafood, produce, bread, spices, kitchen gadgets and other wonderful things in one building. Reading Terminal is lively and fun to walk around and look at things.

It's also a convenient place to grab lunch as there's a wide variety of cuisines and options. Sometimes it's tricky to find seatings, but you walk around and find something somewhere.

Although I can no longer indulge in cookies due to wheat allergy, I used to love cookies from Famous 4th Street Cookie Company. Their cookies are one of the most wonderful gifts from Reading Terminal. Bassett's Ice Cream is decent, too.

The only drawback is the parking situation. Street parking isn't always easy to find and it's 1 hour max.

Also, it's busy during the week, but tolerable. I'd never come here on the weekend when it's crazy packed unless I don't have a choice.
Good location. Very friendly staff. Horrible wifi. Kicks you off every 5 minutes.

This place is a foodie paradise! A food mecca! A venerable feast for all your senses! You can find just about everything. I tried: 

1) Roast Pork Sandwich with greens & provolone from Tommy DiNic's: this is probably the obligatory must-eat thing for tourists. So lines are really long and wrap around. Personally, I thought it was average...bland even. 

2) Juice from Four Seasons Juice Bar: You can choose one of their selected combinations or you can take destiny in your hands and make your own juice. Improvise, don't be scurred. 

2) Doughnuts from Beiler's: Lines are long but since there're no Amish where I live, so I wasn't about to miss a chance  to try out Amish baked goods. And they're even dressed in their cute little Pennsylvania Dutch outfits hehe.

Even if you don't eat at Reading Terminal Market... it's a great atmosphere.  A great place to check things out.  They have great options and all different kinds of food and baked goods.  It's a great landmark in Philly and if you go to Philly and don't stop in Reading Terminal Market for at least a walk-through, then you've missed out.  But I've been there many times and they have some really good food spots.  I really like the Lamb spot that sells sandwiches.

Place gets crazy at lunchtime, but I would always make it a point to have lunch here at least once a week when traveling for business.  DiNic's has an amazing Italian sausage, also love Beiler's donuts & 4th Street Cookies.

This made me extremely jealous not to have a market like this in Salt Lake City. Reading Terminal Market to me is the equivalent of the Boqueria in Barcelona. Fantastic market with top notch, down to earth local eats.
Everything about the market is great.  It's truly something you have to experience on your own to understand.

YESSSSSSSS!! So believe it or not... i've lived in Philly for 20 years and i've never been here until 2 weeks ago LOL. it has EVERYTHING you can imagine. it gets crowded, but who cares! it's worth it. the food i've tried here is amazing and you won't be let down. it's a must if you're ever in the Philly area.

Loved it! Wide variety of food to choose from. The place was very clean my favorite was the ice cream and the soul food place.
I cant remember the name of the ice cream place but it was near the entrance.
I am such a foodie i will defintely be back to try other vendors.
This place is a hoot. Gets a little too crowded for my taste but I've found amazing cheeses and out of the world pickles (check out the amish pickle stand)

First time back here in ~20 yrs.  Good to see many familiar vendors and lots of new stuff too.  No matter what your individual taste, there is something to please just about anyone.  For me, it was sampling some German for lunch (Bavarian sausage sandwich), since for the most part, that it not easy to find where I currently live.

Of course, at peak lunch hour, finding open seating can be tough, though generally no worse than in any urban market in any major city I've visited.  The staff seems to make a really good effort to keep the Market clean, despite the volume of patrons.

Our group browsed around for a while, sampling some 'Old City Coffee' and of course a few sweets.  The dark chocolate pretzels were the perfect dessert for me!

Great Variety.... Crowded Weekends.

Wow what a selection of different foods!! Great place, great atmosphere. It can and is usually crowded, especially at lunchtime and on weekends, and with it being in the heart of center city definitely helps with this. All in all the crowds are well worth it.... Awesome place, Great, great foods!!!

Excelente calidad y variedad de comidas (dulces y saladas, grandes puestos de panadería). Degustaciones en varios puestos, y atención personalizada y muy atenta. No pueden irse sin probar el Philly Cheese Steak, típico de la ciudad y presente en cada uno de los puestos.
Evitar en horario de almuerzo porque hay mucha gente y la espera se vuelve un poco pesada, mucho más difícil es conseguir donde sentarse en ese horario.
Se puede comprar para llevar, o comer allí. Lunes a sábados de 8am a 6pm y domingos de 9am a 5pm. Si consumen algo por más de U$S10, pidan la validación y tiene 2 horas de parking a U$S4 (1th & Arch Streets ó 12th & Filbert Streets).
I love, love, LOVED, Loved the variety of ethnic foods and goods available here. Must go.  This market has anything and everything.  So fresh and so inviting.  GO GO GO HERE!!

This was a fantastic place to start our morning touring Philly. It was great since we were in a group and there something for everybody. Excellent food, cheeses, spices and an eclectic of people and products.
Thank god for RTM! I can find almost anything here- good produce, great spices, tasty treats, honey, such a variety of spreads and jams, dried fruits and chocolate. I love this place.

Foodie paradise. You can spend the whole day eating your way through this food mall. It gets crowded so if you see a place to sit, go for it! Work as a team with your significant other and cover twice as much territory. This is a tourist's delight located right at the heart of Philly.

Great market to go to when you're around philly. Pretty much any kind of food can be found here. The grocery in the market seems to sell good quality meat and produce. This place is definitely not a bad option to look around for breakfast. The Omish donuts are well known here and shouldn't disappoint any donut lovers.

WONDERFUL!! 

Everything from perfectly fresh meats, fish and vegetables to authentic asian cuisine is under one roof.  The prices are reasonable (for the quality), and they have virtually anything you want.  It is a great place to take any visitors or family from out of town, but it is also perfect for weekly shopping.

In my dreams, I can shop exclusively at Reading.

Great place for locals and tourists.  We took some out of time family visiting the city and stopped for ice cream.  Wish more shops were open on Sunday but that's only because it seems a bit empty with half the place closed.  Still worth a visit!

This may be my favorite place in the whole wide world! 

If you visit Philly, and you only have time for one lunch, this is where you go! Great coffee, Chinese food, Amish desserts, chocolate, soul food, ice cream, crapes, Thanksgiving dinner, and of course...Tommy DiNics. 

I cannot overhype The Reading Terminal Market. It's that good and better.
It is touristy as hell but there are a ton of good food options. Great to bring out of town friends there, you can see some Amish folk with out being dragged out yet again to Lancaster County.

Be ready to spend a good few hours or even half a day here...

WARNING: DO NOT COME HERE when you're SUPER HUNGRY...because you'll literally want to buy and EAT EVERYTHING!! 
The BEST advise is to come here with 4-5 other fiends, so you guys can each other something different and try LOTS of different food!

When I first came here, I was amazed, awed, and fascinated by the HUGE variety of food they could offer. Honestly, anything you could name or could not name! Chinese, Italian, Indian, Japanese, African, South American, Spanish....seriously, it was like a cultural food paradise! So many flavors, colors, aromas. Plus, many places let us sample the food first! It was truly amazing especially since there aren't many markets in the area that's like this. 

Besides delicious main courses-entrees, they also have desserts, such as chocolates, ice creams, and fresh-cut fruits! It's a very fun, exciting and adventurous place! 
WATCH OUT for the people though! It can get very crowded and packed at times, so be aware and don't lose your friends! Another pro is that they have lots of seating.
Very crowded. They have maps, which is helpful, because it's almost impossible to find your way through the sea of people. Couldn't find anything vegan though, other than produce.
Great place to experince different cultural foods.
Food heaven.  Whatever you want to eat now or whatever ingredient you need, you can get it here.

This place is amazing for foodies.  There are types of foods for every palate during every time of day.  I have taken family members every time they have come to visit to experience what is Reading Terminal Market.  Some times there are long lines but usually well worth it.  My wife loves the pickles and honey that we pick up while at the market to take home.

You have to love the Reading Terminal! It has everything that any food that anyone wants in their Philadelphia experience all condensed into one market downtown. I recommend buying one of the Amish soft pretzels  (perfectly buttered and salted) and one of the homemade lemonades or strawberry lemonades. The terminal also features stands with fresh produce, deli meats, and fruits, as well as tables with paintings and nick-nacks all over. This is a must-visit if you are visiting Philadelphia!

Almost every big city has a market like Reading Terminal. It's great because as a visitor to the city, you can explore a variety of cuisines in one location.

The market is located very close to the convention center, which makes it very convenient for breakfast, lunch or a quick snack. Although it is extremely crowded at lunchtime, The vendors seem to know how to get people through the line and moving. There is a decent sized seating area, but during the lunch hour it may be challenging to find a seat for more than one person.

All sorts of food can be found here from Dutch to Italian, Chinese, Korean and Mediterranean. There are cheesesteak vendors, along with stands offering fresh produce, baked goods, and meat. The famous roast pork sandwich at DiNic's and Bassett's delicious ice cream are both located here as well.

This market is great for groups as the variety of offerings will surely appease even the pickiest eaters and the price points are rather reasonable.
Great venue to try all kinds of foods.  It would take a week to try all the great places.

I'm biased... nothing can touch Pike Place market but this place is pretty awesome. I loved the produce shop in the back. They had great prices and the best part was the shelf full of bags of mixed produce that were all only $1!

A place where you can eat and shop at the same time. When we were here last weekend, there was a string ensemble playing at the food court area. There are many restaurants that you need to try, so come hungry! Must have the Bassett ice cream! The terminal is located near Chinatown and the City Center where you can walk off your meals after.

I loved this place! At first, I was somewhat overwhelmed with all of the different food vendors. I did not know where to start! Once I got passed that initial shock, I realized I was pretty much in food heaven. I ended up trying Dinic's Roast Pork and Beef, Dutch eating place, and the Beiler's (donuts). I was not disappointed at all. I plan on coming back and trying new places once I visit again

As a newcomer to Philly, it was slightly overwhelming to stop here with a local friend for breakfast. I slightly regretted that we only stopped for a quick breakfast. I wish we had budgeted AT LEAST an hour for me to wander around. Although it was probably better we didn't because I was hungry at the time and probably would have stuffed my face and emptied my wallet. I ended up getting crepes with fresh fruit and nutella (at least the fruit was healthy).  I was surprised at the variety of food available. We just happened to be there during the Philadelphia ComicCon and it is right by the convention center so it may have been more packed than usual. However it didn't take long to get our food and we still found seating at the counter.
awesome place!  Got the best grilled cheese I ever had at the little cheese shop in the back of the market...same one that sells awesome olives!

I used to live near Pike's Place Market in Seattle so I'm a tad biased here, but I'll try to put that aside. 

Positives: nice markety vibe while still being pretty clean, good prices on produce, cool things to look at, and great location in the middle of the city.

Negatives: not quite the variety of quick dining options that you would expect at a market in a large city.  I know we're in Philly, but everywhere I looked there were sandwiches. The Amish country food looked pretty good, but other than that and an Indian place, I didn't see many a myriad of options. 

Seafood selection is sparse and on the expensive side. Worth going to to pick up your fruits and veggies for the week, but not worth bringing your friends here when they visit.

You could go to the market every day for a week and discover something new.  You can get every meal any time of day, get your groceries, and even do some shopping for friends and family.  Tourists and locals alike can share this place and have their needs met.  A quiet spot to read and enjoy a glass of wine?  They've got it.  Local snacks to bring home from a weekend trip in Philly?  This is the place to go.  Meeting up with a colleague for lunch?  Plenty of options.  I'm definitely going back next time I'm in Philly!
Amazing place.  Can be very overwhelming if it is your first time here but there is always someoen around to direct you to the best food spots.
One of THE BEST places in the whole city.  Lots of great food and options.  A little crazy when a convention is in town or for lunch during the week, but always worth the time.

I'm in love! This was the perfect rainy Saturday morning activity on our visit. Reading Terminal Market is just wonderful. The size of this market is overwhelming, but they offer so much under one roof; crafts, organic goods, fresh produce, seafood, fresh meats, authentic German sausages, wine, cheeses, baked goods, places to stop and grab a snack - the list goes on and on. It gets busy and crowded. Be prepared to wait in line at the more popular stops. Also note the Amish vendors are closed Sunday and Monday. A visit to Philadelphia is not complete without stopping here!

Very fun place, especially for visitors.  If you like crowds, come on the weekend.  All the shops are open and there are some great options for food.  If you don't like crowds, try another day of the week.  I know some of the shops are closed on certain days, so be sure to check ahead of time.
Simply the best indoor market in Philadelphia. Whatever you're looking for you can find it at the Reading Terminal Market.

This is SUCH AN AWESOME PLACE to walk around and just explore! It can get a bit packed during lunch hour so try to come off-peak times. The market is set up so it's pretty easy to navigate because it's in a grid form. There are maps around area so it's easy to find your way. There's also a couple of small seating areas and some restaurants have their own seating area. 

There is just an abundance of good here! All sorts of food: Chinese, Indian, Seafood, Philly cheese steaks, Southern, bbq ribs, donuts, pastries and dessert, and more! There are also some other types of vendors: bookstore, honey store, salami and cheese, groceries, and farmer's market? 

The only thing is that the popular places may have a long line so it may be a bit of a wait, but it's such a cool place to just visit and walk around in!
This place is heaven! I come to Philly every year in October and visit this market thru out my entire weekend stay. The cookies, cakes, sandwiches and everything else is jus amazing!!!!!
Tons of variety! You really can't go wrong, but I love Beck's Cajun Cafe and Wan's Seafood. Go explore yourself and find a place to fall in love with! :-)

It was our second visit to Philadelphia and second visit to the market as well. We went to the Carmen's to get our favorite philly cheesesteak and Bassett's to get our favorite ice cream. We tried the "Philly's #1 Pecking Duck" from one of their Chinese places but it wasn't #1 honestly, there was fire alarm keep going on and off and at one point everyone was little confused but we were told by the information center's lady that we don't have to worry about it and if anything happens that she will be leaving. haha. Such a cute market that is actually serving a role as a market (not like a chelsea market, which became the place for tourists only).

Great place to grab breakfast /lunch whatever. Make some great sandwiches. However sometimes some of the vendors can provide you with some pretty lame cuts of beef (ruebens/cornbeef, ets) call them out if they do. I cant give specifics cuz i dont recall the exact vendors. There is some phenomenal food/groceries/baked goods within this market.

Great selection of vendors. A foodie's taste of heaven. Visited DiNics, Chocolate by Mueller and Termini's on a Monday (Columbus Day) and they were busy. 

If in town, would definitely be back.
love reading terminal market. great meat & produce selection

If you leave this place hungry, you have failed!

Favorites (in no particular order)
Olympia Gyro (used to be Olympic, but thanks to the IOC they had to change their name)

Valley Shepherd Creamery & Meltkraft Grilled Cheese - just go to their instagram @meltkraft ; pictures tell truths and their food will not disappoint....unless you dislike cheese or are lactose intolerant.

Smucker's Quality Meats & Grill - Amish people making food with butter....objections?  Bacon, Egg, and Cheese and the eggs are cooked in front of you.

Beck's Cajun Cafe - Fried Mac and Cheese Balls :) and the Trainwreck.  Neither are really that Cajun but they are delicious and they have a great menu.

This is the kind of place that no matter how long you have lived in Philadelphia you still go to, its a consumer staple.  I'll recommend this place to anyone that likes to eat.  But if you find eating to be a chore....not the place for you

Parking Tip - park at 12th and Cuthbert lot....you can get it validated by any of the vendors and it will be a little bit cheaper, NOT free!

We visited philly for a day and I gotta say, this place is a must stop. There's a huge variety of food in this market ranging from American, Indian, Asian, Mediterranean, donuts, fudge, oysters and anything you can think of.  We opted to try Dinic's for their pork sandwich since they were all over the travel channel.  I wanted to try Bassett's as well since I've seen them on TV also but didn't want to ruin my appetite for dinner at Morimotos! So I'll definitely have to try that next time.  There's a Reading Terminal Market parking garage. It's $4 for two hours if you purchase $10 worth from a single vendor.  Make sure you bring your parking ticket so you can get it validated at the discounted rate!

barely made it in before closing at 6! co-worker and I were in town and this place was highly recommended by others..I love international food markets. too bad it was so early to eat at 5:30. we forced ourselves to eat. the place is huge.
A great place to eat with a variety of good food. My personal favorites are The Original Turkey for a healthy sandwich, smoothies from Kamal's, and pretzels from Miller's Twist.

Came by here just to walk around, having just had brunch nearby.  Place is pretty interesting; LOTS of food options.  Just got some cookies and coffee and walked around seeing the vendors --- the stand with all the different honey was probably the most interesting.

Didnt get a DiNic's sandwich this time, but by all means, if you're here and hungry that should be your first stop.
Best place to eat lunch, shop for dinner, and buy local gifts. Been a patron there since the mid-80s. Go there!!!

If you can't find something you like here, there's something wrong.

The market is an interesting combination of hot/prepared foods meant to be consumed immediately and grocery-type specialty meats and produce. 

The market is extremely crowded on Saturdays and sometimes Sundays, but you will still be able to move.  Highlights for me are DiNic's Roast Pork and the Flying Monkey, but everyone has a favorite once they've been a few times. My close friend is partial to the Turkey place where you can get Thanksgiving dinner year-round.

There's always something interesting to see/smell/hear.

Reading Terminal Market is one of Philadelphia's many gems! There are so many stands that sell various products. I love checking out the stand that sells products made of honey! Everything is so natural and the prices are wonderful for the caliber of their goods! There are many food places to try and enjoy various cuisines! The candy stand is full of fun, colorful items that will have you stopping before you even set your eyes on all of the products. This market is indoor and is so spacious, which makes for a comfortable visit no matter what time you go! It is never too busy and you can enjoy yourself whether you are sitting indulging in some wonderful ethnic eats or walking around exploring. I recommend this market to everyone and anyone who loves to try various products from food items to flowers and bath and body products! This place has a little bit of everything that will keep you coming back for more!

best place to go shopping in the city! Fresh fish at Wan's, produce at Iovine's and meat and poultry at the Haltemans. I go there twice a week for years now. Also the experiance is fantastic, walking around, seeing everything in their glass cases; getting to choose exactly what you want. I highly recommend it!
All I have to say is this place is FOOD HEAVEN. It's probably one of the top 5 tourists "hot spots" in Philly. I can't point out any specific vendor and food stand because it's all DA BOMB!!

Sadly, DiNic's was (unsurprisingly) not open on Sunday morning when I came, but I was able to get a fresh banana + pineapple + orange smoothie from 4 Seasons Juice Bar, a salmon benedict from Fair Food Farmstand, and a scoop of the Whyy Experience + a scoop of Irish Coffee from Bassetts Ice Cream. 

4 Seasons Juice Bar has a wide selection of fresh fruits and supplements like wheat grass to choose from and I thought their prices were reasonable (comparable to Jamba Juice).

The salmon benedict was tasty from Fair Food Farmstand, although I wouldn't say that it was particularly amazing. The portions are quite generous though; my friend got the breakfast burrito from the Fair Food Farmstand and it was HUGE - as big as a Chipotle burrito.

Apparently, Bassetts Ice Cream has a rotating menu of different ice cream flavors. Irish Coffee tasted just like Bailey's and the Whyy Experience was the perfect complement. I snuck a bite of my friend's Mango ice cream, and it was probably one of the best Mango ice creams I've ever had!

I also stopped by The Tubby Olive on the recommendation of some of my friends. They have a wide selection of different infused olive oils and balsamic vinaigrettes. I mixed the Blood Orange Olive Oil with the Dark Chocolate Balsamic Vinaigrette for a flavor that was similar to those orange chocolate candies you can get at World Market! Ultimately, we ended up buying 2 bottles of the Tuscan Olive Oil, which tastes similar to the seasoning you can find at Carrabba's.

I wish I had been able to stop by The Tea Leaf! Sadly, it too was also closed on Sunday morning. Next time I'm in the Philly area, I'm definitely stopping by again!

Reading Terminal compared to other city indoor farmer markets, this one is much smaller but at least some or most of the vendors open on Sundays.  Food sell out fast for certain famous places on weekends so better grab the food first (even you were not hungry) then eat them later; they generally still tasted very good :)  Most of the food I tried, none disappointed me except the apple dumpling. It was too sweet, too saggy; the crust was soaked, I ate it when it was still warm.  It was the only one thing I didn't save it for later.

This is where suburbanites come to eat when they visit Philly so they can avoid those scary hipsters. Basically a glorified mall food court. Bland overpriced food everywhere, crowded, welcome to Disneyland.

A huge city block sized indoor market place with dozens of vendors.  
A must stop while in Philly, but you'll find that you keep coming back, we did. So much to see and several choices for breakfast and lunch.  Opens at 8:00 am with lines forming at the doors and closes at six pm so don't get there too late.  For breakfast we liked the Dutch Eatery, the Creperie,  the Old town coffee and brasserie donuts.    We also liked the honey shop and the olive oil shop.  You can find some great local (not touristy) gift ideas here.  We didn't get to try and fresh baked breads but they looked and smelled fabulous.  If you are lucky to be staying nearby you'll be able to visit frequently.   But Just the sights and smells make it a great stop on your trip to Philly.

This place is great!!! There is everything for everyone. The market is filled from bbq to cajun to philly cheesesteaks to seafood to donuts to candy to flowers and housewares!!! The food is delicious and the staff is super friendly. I've had the chance to try Spataro's cheesesteaks, Beck's Cajun Cafe, Beiler's bakery, and Sweet as Fudge Candy Shoppe. All great places and delicious food. The portions are great and the market is huge. Definitely come with an appetite.

Philadelphia staple. If you go in the morning you can avoid some crowds, but it's almost always jam packed. Great vendors for food, produce, groceries, and gifts. Most of the places are very inexpensive so you can save lots of money if you brave the crowds.
One of the most unique places I've ever been. Every city should have one of these! We ate there three times in a weekend. Must see in Philly!

You could lose your mind here (and your waistline) plowing through the variety of great food -- from ribs to peanut butter to cookies to huge prawns.  Only tried the cinnamon oatmeal cookies at 4th street cookie company which were yummy.  Fun place to walk through on the way to Independence Hall.
Tons of great places to eat authentic food!

Are you kidding me? Does the Reading Terminal need any reviews? Or are you here for the recommendations? That's the only reason why you should be looking up reviews for the Reading Terminal.

Bomb dot com. I haven't tried everything in the market, and that would be a pretty ambitious goal, but I've tried enough things to say this is one of my favorite things about Philly. Food so good, you'll end up going back to the same place over and over and over and just delay achieving your goal to try everything.

At least that is what is happening to me.

DiNic's is a must. Be sure to add either broccoli rabe or spniach AND the sharp provolone! Boy, is it SHARP!

And then Bassett's for dessert. If you're there on any day, but Sunday, don't forget to check out the Dutch Corner!!! Because you will crave it on Sundays when it's closed!
I frequent this place on a weekly basis, it has a lively and colorful atmosphere. It has a great array of food choices for breakfast and lunch. It's a definate must see if your visiting.
I love everything about this place, the variety of foods, but most importantly the QUALITY of foods. It makes me jealous of Philadelphians - I wish I lived nearer.
Yep, it is as good as it gets.  We eat here whenever we are in the area.  Be sure to try Carmens for a hoagie and check out Beilers for donuts.

If I could put together a perfect market that includes every single cuisine I love in one place, it would be Reading Market! Everything from Mexican, Greek, ice cream, books, produce, meats, Chinese, etc. Only drawbacks is that it can get crowded and there isn't much seating.
I would highly recommend getting an Italian sub from Salumeria. High quality meats, great ratio of all ingredients for a good price. 
Explore and enjoy!
I visited this place while in Philly last January. It's a place that's worth checking out if you go. They offer a variety of food and gifts. Also good to just people watch...

Philadelphia and Philadelphians are extremely lucky to have such an amazing place.  It reminds me of similar style markets in Europe.  You can find just about anything under the sun, in the food world, at Reading Terminal Market.  Whatever your favorite cuisine, you can find it here.  Whether you're hungry and looking for something prepared now or looking to stock the fridge at home with meats, cheeses, and veggies, this is the spot.  Check it out.  You won't be disappointed.
What can I say? Go-to place for food, fun, fellowship where people of all walks of life mingle in Philadelphia :)

This is a haven for people who love ethnic food. May be the best place in Philly for its variety and potential for one-stop shopping. There must be at least 50 booths here, and virtually every ethnic group is represented here. There are numerous fruit and vegetable stands supplying any veggie fruit, nut, several fish mongers, a terrific  spice shop, delicious pastry and bread booths,  a kitchen gadget shop,  sandwich places, e.g.  Most of the food is fresh and house-made. The used book stand is somewhat pricey, but the books are interesting and unusual. There is even a booth that sells only cook books.  I found that a good time to shop is on Monday morning before lunchtime. You can usually get a seat if you wish to sit down with your food and the isles are not as crowded. Try to allow a few hours there, as it will take you that long to explore all the Market has to offer. Have fun!

I couldn't buy anything perishable because I was travelling, but if I lived in Philly I wouldn't go grocery shopping anywhere else!...Assuming I had a more generous budget for the high-quality, market-fresh food they were selling. Those lamb chops and sausages are so enticing, and the produce was a great selection. There were so many food stalls I couldn't remember them all even after two trips around. I know it's become increasingly touristy over the years, but there's a reason some secrets aren't well-kept!

Reading Terminal Market is amazing at least. Parking is not bad considering that you are in the heart of Philadelphia. The food is Diverse as it gets from chocolate covered onions :P  haha to Juicy BBQ ribs.  A must go if your visiting Philadelphia. You might also see the Amish with they're Delicious Baking and other Amish goodies.

I love Reading Terminal Market!  It literally has anything and everything you are looking for.  I sometimes go just to look around, and I probably go there every weekend.  I love the falafel place and Bee Natural , which has honey chapstick, candles, soap, and regular honey.  So many surprises like really cheap produce and a used bookstore.

Absolutely the best place on Earth. Truly something for everyone. The Iovine's fresh produce, Godshall's poultry and Martin's meats and sausages to name just a few. Dinic's sandwiches, Olympus pork souvlaki and the Dutch Eating Place for amazing creamed chipped beef on home fries. Miller's Twist is a must too.

Everyone should go here.  It's a bizarre and fantastic market.  It's basically perfect.  

Tommy DiNicks (spelling?) has awesome pork sandwiches.  Old City Coffee has bangin coffee.  The produce market has some things at a good price.  The spice shop is great but I think it might have closed so...it WAS great, if that's the case.  The bakery is great, they have every kind of ethnic food possible, prepared and also ready for sale for home cooking.  It's probably the best place to take a group of folks for lunch because there's no way in hell someone will walk away unsatisfied.  

It's just awesome to walk around this place even if you don't buy anything!  It's like a zoo for gourmet food.  Take the kids!  They'll be attracted to all of the beautiful everything sold on site.
Great place to purchase fresh groceries at a cheap price!!!

Convenient location downtown with tons of options. You can buy fresh conventional and organic produce, chocolates, baked goods, meats, fish, olives, soaps, olive oil, balsamic vinegar, and other goods. Additionally, there are plenty of ready to order items such as Indian, Italian, and soul. For the vegan, I even saw a few desserts marked as vegan! Prices are decent, some really great. Artisan goods are on the higher end, but I found organic romaine lettuce for 99 cents!

I'm a Philadelphia native, and I'm amazed at the variety and vitality every time I come down here. I haven't yet tried everything, but I'm working on it, and I know I like DiNic's roast pork. Adam Richman was spot on!

OMG my school went here on a class trip in middle school!  It was the first and last time I've been to the Market.  I wandered around with a few classmates and we ate Chinese food for lunch and matriculated throughout the place until I felt like I found out what it would be like to be an ant in an ant farm.  There was even a news story going on and we tried to be in the background but the chick who was the reporter shooed us away.  This was one of many fun class trips to Philly that serve as reminders of why I love New Jersey.
Love this place and all the options.  The amish stands are great.  One of the best places in Philly to visit!

If you are in Philly, even if only for an hour or two, you MUST come here.  I've been coming here for years and I haven't had a single thing that I didn't love.  
Favorites: Olympia Gyro gyro, Hershel's corned beef reuben, Termini Bros cannoli, everything Amish

Love it. A real taste of Philly. Termini Bros for Italian pastry, Basset's chocolate Ice cream, those gross Philly cheese steaks, deli, wine, New Orleans food, Miller's pretzels, Amish baked goods, fresh produce, etc. A must for any foodie who visits Philly. It's an indoor food flea market. The Marriott is right next door as a landmark
Love it Here! The food is great and the Little shops have something for everyone! a Must if visiting Philly downtown!
This place has everything. And it's not just variety--you're talking high quality stuff for the old school and the nouveau foodie alike.
Whoa. This place is full of choices. I certainly don't think you can make a wrong one. If you're in town traveling stop by each day and try something new.

This place is a must visit if you come to Philly.  I could have spent hours in here if I had the time just walking around checking out shops- its huge!  They have clusters of tables in the middle where you can sit and eat.  Where we sat a little old lady was playing the keyboard and she was so cute!  I bet there is a place you can get any type of food you want- but you must go to the Amish bakery towards the front.  Their baked goods are incredible!
I'm a huge fan of going here for breakfast or lunch.  Crepes, cheesesteaks, pork sandwiches, Amish bread.  So so good!
Oh my god, this was fun!  Pick your flavor, they have it.  If I lived nearby I would never cook.
There's no place like it! It's an incredible way to get all of Philly's most iconic foods in one place! Great crowd of foodies!
Many choices. Need a long time to chose. Most of them taste good.

Reading Terminal Market = Disney World for foodies

If anyone asks me the question "I'm coming to Philly, what is there to see and do?" My number one answer would be Reading Terminal Market!

It is the perfect place for families, friends, couples, etc because you will be able to find something for everyone - even the pickiest eaters.

There are tons of places and kinds of foods to eat, in addition to a beer garden that allows takeout for those who are interested.

My favorite place to eat here is Meltkraft. I love the Melter Skelter, a grilled cheese with BBQ chips as one of its delicious ingredients. 

You can go here countless times and try something completely new and different each time. I also do groceries here as you can find fresh produce, meats, and more. 

The best part is, this is all indoors so as the weather turns cold, its the perfect place to spend a day eating and people-watching.

Just the best food in all the land. 3 important stops on the list. Beiler's bakery:pick up glazed donuts and blueberry fritters. Dinics: Get a brisket sandwich with provolone (dont worry, the huge line goes very fast). Millers twists: ANY pretzle, hot dog or stuffed pretzle. SO good.

This is a great spot for fresh local foods, candies to taste there or buy produce and meats to take home. Great farm to table market place! I wish I lived closer so I could have brought some of them home! I had a Dinics sandwich and some great candies from local companies.

Going to Reading Terminal Market is like an event in and of itself. There are so many amazing sights, scents and tastes! This place is one of the many things I love about Philadelphia. Anything you want, you can get it here. There's even a bar!

Not only can you get any kind of food you want from a number of sit-down places, you can also pick up fresh seafood and produce--why would anyone shop at the regular grocery store? The prices here are great. 

And the Amish bakeries..OOH the Amish bakeries..Make sure you get there before those booths close, because you do not want to miss out on all the varieties of breads, pastries and pies. My friend introduced me to Shoo Fly Pie from one of those places, and I will never be the same again. Shoo Fly Pie is basically sugar and molasses and butter in a yummy pie crust, and not much else. But when you think about it..what else do you need?

I'm very lucky I work close to this place. Or..maybe, not so lucky, since I am tempted to spend most of the money I make here.

This is the best market in Philadelphia. Forget Whole Foods and Trader Joes. This place has all of the fresh veggies, candy, butcher stalls, fish markets, and PA Dutch food you could imagine. And the people watching is pretty great too. Bonus points if you check our Herschel's corned beef special. Yum!
So much fun to visit and so many amazing food choices. It is a must visit if you've never been to Philly.

A great way to visit the Amish without having to drive to Lancaster.

The riffraff on Filbert Street is mostly harmless and can actually be entertaining at times

Amazing place for grocery shopping, a quick snack, or an interesting way to kill 20 minutes walking around or people watching. Every conceivable type of food, often farm fresh and prepared in front of you. For a tourist, definitely a stop you should make. This one helped rename "Market Street" in honor of the open air markets that crowded it, and Reading Terminal opened as a closed air market in the mid 19th century. Cool place. The Penn. Dutch usually aren't there every day, so don't be surprised.

Great place.  It's a great tourist and resident spot.  It's quite possibly the only place in Philly where you can get a taste of EVERYTHING available from a food standpoint: Chinese, Soul Food, Baked Goods, Fresh Meats, Ice Cream, Cheese Steaks.  It has it all...

I can get really really crowded, but if you can navigate it, it's worth the hustle and bustle...

If you live in the city and plan on cooking it's a great place to pick up some fresh ingredients for your meal.  A lot of the food vendors located there in my opinion have started to go down hill when it comes to quality / quantity vs price.  I remember when the hoagies and steak sandwiches were stuffed with meat and toppings of your choice.. now you get one slice of meat an pay 1.00 for every additional topping you choose.  Some of the favorites are still there.. Hershel's, Denics Pork, and a great homemade doughnut place when you first walk in at the corner of Arch and 9th.  Not a big fan of any of the new comers I think for the prices you get better food and service at some of the local restaurants... and at least you can sit.  This place is for tourists and quick meal if your at the convention with no time to venture off.
I LOVE this place and the variety of wonderful foods, friendly merchants and festive environment.

Awesome place for anyone that loves food or people watching...but only if you don't mind a crowd! I've been here various times over the years and it's always bustling.

Dinic's roast pork sandwich with broccoli rabe is a must, but if the line is too long, any of the other food stands offer great, quick grub.

Wonderful place for produce, meats, olives, even wine. The seafood stand is one of my favorites - large selection, fresh, fairly reasonable prices.
An institution in our city; almost sensory overload with so many people and so many choices where to eat.

There are so many different vendors here that I basically go to RTM to look around like a tourist. From sweet to savory to inedible, RTM has it all. I recommend going to the Harvest Festival, which I thought was very fun.

Great place to shop for food that is fresh, delicious and quick service. Desserts of all kinds from baklava to home made chocolates, wonderful, wonderful, wonderful. 
Parking is a problem. Wish they were open till 9 pm.

Awesome experience...It took me 40 mins to decide to figure out what to order ... Place is a perfect outing on a Saturday afternoon where you'll eat a nice lunch and wrap up direct from the farmers groceries! Loved it ...highly recommend!

Absolutely love this place and have been going since I was a kid.  Lunchtime is pretty hectic but they have such a variety of vendors that you don't mind the crowds.

I started a tradition with my granddaughter and she and I travel down the day before Thanksgiving, pick up some baked goods, have lunch and then hop back on the train.  I love when family comes to Philly to visit because this is a place they always want to stop at.

I love the atmosphere of this place, it has just about anything you may be looking for and targets just about everyone. Looking for fresh produce to a specialty from another country? Looking for the worlds oldest operating ice cream parlor, take a visit to the Reading Terminal Market, they have it all!

Reading terminal market I Love. It is a little crowded but There use to some of these in NJ but they have gone away. 
There is something for everyone. Somethings are pricey but there are good local deal to be found. All types of foods are here. there is something for everyone. 
If you are in Philly this is a MUST Visit.

So many awesome shops, from Amish bakeries,  to spice shops,  youre guaranteed to spend your money here. When you're done your shopping stop by Dinic's roast pork for a roast pork sandwich with long hots. Way better than a cheesesteak!  Always end up spending hours here, so plan your day accordingly!
Lots of different kinds of food and drink.  Can get really crowded - lots of tourists as well as locals.

Good for foodies. Lots of different options. (not too many vegan choices, but still fun to check it out).  Super dense, which makes it a great place for tourist short on time but who to get a taste of everything!

Fabulous place. I got to work here for a week shooting all the photography for the foods. 

I got some awesome donuts and sticky buns at Beillers. 
Really great nuts from Iovines. 
Ate at Becks nearly every day. 
Wonderful loaves of bread from Metropolitan bakery. 
And there was an Amish stall that make really good pretzels and ice cream that I can't remember the name of.
Can find anything from Italian delis, gourmet coffee, seafood, cheeses, fresh produce, restaurants, etc. Can be difficult to walk around, but is worth it.

AWESOME OLD SCHOOL MARKET......  For foodies and people who like the freshest fish meat and breads etc.  If you rate this any lower than 4 stars you obviously don't get out much.  This is one of the oldest market in the US.  There is a variety for everyone and I do mean everyone. I have always had a great experience here. Some of the vendors had been here for many many years. This market is made up of small business owners. So spend your money here, there are no big box stores at this location.

Hi to everyone who's reading this. Before I start I should mention that I'm only a customer of Little Basil restaurant and I don't know anyone personally in that restaurant.
I've read Brad A.'s  unfair comment about the little basil restaurant and I didn't appreciate the way he talked about the employees /owner of this restaurant.I have been buying food from this restaurant for over 30 years and yet, I've never had or heard any complains about the food or especially of the employees. To my understanding Brad was looking to get something for free.First of all according to him,the ad (If there was one) says if you purchase $20 or more you'll get something for free. Well, he spent $19.58 and that's not $20 .Also, he says that he does not believe they're losing a customer over 47 cents. My question for Brad is , apparently he likes the food that he orders it from there,then why he's losing his relationship with them over 47 Cents. Also, he laid about the owner telling him that it was a new deal. She never said such thing to him. To my understanding this thing has been going on for quite a while and he manages to get free things by threatening to cancel his order if they don't give him something for free. Since they wanted to keep him as a "customer" happy, they gave him something for free. Unfortunately, Brad got greedy and kept asking for more freebies. Brad ,you should be ashamed of yourself to bother these hard working people who work at lease 14 hours a day to serve people like you and I .You don't like their food /customer service then I suggest you find someone else to put up with your non sense.Have some dignity and be a man and leave them alone and don't ruin their reputations for your cheapness and selfishness. I'm surprise why didn't Little basil management didn't take legal action against this "man".
Fred D

If you're ever in Philadelphia and want to visit a landmark, skip the liberty bell and come here and then maybe go back to the liberty for a walk once you're full. Seriously, this place makes me all kinds of excited, happy, nervous, anxious, in love and many many more emotions. Yes it may be completely overwhelming with the amount of people and vendors in this place but please make your way around the place! I like to make a complete circle around the entire place then work my way to the middle. There's cheese shops, Philly's famous cheesesteaks and roast pork sandwiches, fresh produce, fresh meat and fish markets, Indian food, Amish food, Chinese food, southern soul food, a florist, a book store, a delicious creamery, a bakery, oh and the list continues. If this has not made you get off your butt from where you are and head to philly, I don't know what will! Come to the Reading Terminal and all your food dreams will come true, at least mine has. (:

It is the magical hidden gem in Center city. You can find pretty much all the fresh grocery, meat, seafood, wine, coffee, desserts, prepared food, etc. that you need. Great place for a lunch stop. Unfortunately the market closes too soon and the Amish stores are not open on Sundays. So if you are especially interested in the Amish stores plan your trip accordingly.

Probably the best indoor market in the country.  You'll find every culinary group in SE PA represented here: Amish, German, Italian, Vietnamese.  Seating can be almost impossible, especially during lunch hour, if you're hoping to eat here.

Cool place. A taste of everything cuisine wise. A little pricey but i think its worth it for what this place offers. Only downside is this place becomes a mad house once noon hits. The crowds can be just as overwhelming as the choices of food. Food is worth it as well.

OH BOY!  Foodie fun!   I enjoyed the place a lot and I purposely stayed in a hotel right nearby so I could breeze over there morning noon and before closing. I cant say night as they aren't open at night. 

    You can find all sorts of food!  Plenty to eat!  Would be great to have a place like this next door!    

    Helpful hint at one door on Race Street they have a holder of maps. GET ONE. I had some coupons for some of the businesses and it was hard to find them!  Its crowded and you have a hard time seeing signs through the crowds. That map was certainly helpful.  I'll post a pic of the map too!

    I cant give the place 5 stars though because of one major drawback. Crowds.  They need more space. I don't know whats upstairs but someone sometime back should have found a way to make another floor up there. They have maybe 100? 150? seats in central areas but those are only a small fraction of the demand. If you go with a family or group and you want to sit and eat together you have to go off hour or you can forget that idea!  Mid day Sat is a madhouse.  Individual vendors often have seats at their counters too but often just 5,6 or 7 chairs. Again if theres many of you you can forget that!

   Prices are not low either, but you can hunt for bargains. You will find some marking down items in the last hour or two. Especially bakeries that bag it all for a flat price, and put it on top of the counter. They want the counter bare when they go home.

   The actual fruit and vegetable vendors left are only a few, so not much there or major interest.  Lots of sweets, candy, honey, meats, cold cuts, sandwiches, turkey, ice cream etc. 
  
    Bassetts is the oldest ice cream in the USA. I had a coupon there but no way was I going to try and carry it and eat with such a crowd.

     Its fun though to walk through and maybe grab a few things to go and then find yourself a place where you can sit and enjoy it later.

The Reading Terminal Market is an absolute must-see attraction in Philly. There's a whole world of food in there, with enough nooks and crannies to just about get lost and keep stumbling upon new things you didn't notice before. I love to get hot cookies and Amish taffies, and the last time I went, I had a delicious kielbasa. There's good people-watching here, too. It's interesting to be able to see a young Amish woman on her lunch break. You can see a lot of things in New York City, but not that.

It is a crowded market place. I had some super delicious bbq ribs, mac n cheese from this Amish food place  in there. They have delicate chocolates, cookies, ice cream but, also carry a variety of food styles under one roof. It was a different experience for me.

Reading Terminal is the best thing that has ever happened to mankind, aside from the discovery of fire, the wheel, and Emma Watson.  If you like putting food into your body, Reading Terminal is ground zero for stuffing your face full of delicious treats.  I've lived here for years, I go there not uncommonly, and I still find it to be an emotional experience to watch pastrami and corned beef being cut at Hershel's or watching sandwiches get put together at DiNic's.  You could eat at Reading for every meal for a month, start over again, and not get tired of the place.  From Wednesay through Saturday you also have the extra company of the Amish, who during that week have managed to bake like a million pies, cakes, and fruit breads with frosting on them.  FROSTING ON THEM.  ARE YOU KIDDING ME!?!?  

I CAN'T GO ON I'M GETTING TOO EMOTIONAL

This Place is in a word... Amazing. Point to a place on a globe and there is probably food from that country. This place is good for grocery shopping, wine/cheese/olive shopping, international gourmet foods, specialty butchers (lamb.turkey, beef, pork, and chicken) and many many restaurants. Its better to come very early on a weekday, it gets PACKED. Most of the places are cash only, there are a couple of ATM's inside. You can park in the parking garage right above the market for 4 hours. A must visit if you come to philly.

Make sure you park in the lot which gives one a much lower rate. Di Nic's has the best roast pork. Bassett's has the best ice cream. Metropolitan has the best chocolate chips.Then walk to Chinatown and buy a peking duck to take home.
This place is amazing. As good as it gets in Philly; from Dinic's Roast Pork to Beiler's Doughnuts - you cannot go wrong visiting Reading Terminal.

I love Reading Terminal Market! It's got an amazing amount of options for food and goods. There's almost nothing you can't find here, and the atmosphere is filled with gastronomical excitement. Be aware that the lines can be long sometimes, and the market can be crowded.

The reading terminal market is fantastic.The market itself has a variety of things and food for purchase. You can find some of the more obscure items at the market. As far as food there are many options with most of them being really good. My only complaint would be it can get crowded which makes it hard to move around in some areas.
So many options to choose from, between fruit and vegetables, meat, fish, baked goods.  Perhaps not the prettiest place, but everything I've ever bought has been great and reasonably priced.

As someone who grew up in DE and who has traveled through Philly to visit the fam for the past six years, I can't fathom why I wasn't aware of RTM until less than a year ago, and why I never visited until the day before yesterday!  Although there is a public market in PGH, where I live now, it pales in comparison to RTM--a more appropriate comparison would be to the entire neighborhood that the public market is located in (the Strip District).  What I'd like to know is, how does Philly manage to fit most of the offerings of the Strip into one building?!?

Anyway, I wanted to make the most of my first visit to RTM, so I did my research, and hit the following places for the following goods, all of which cost me about $25:

DiNic's: Roast pork sandwich w/ sharp provolone and broccoli rabe
Miller's Twist: Pretzel w/ honey mustard sauce
Lancaster County Dairy: Orange strawberry lemonade
Bassett's Ice Cream: Peanut butter swirl sugar cone
Beiler's Bakery: Half dozen donuts

Because I came here directly off the train from Pittsburgh, which was running late and hadn't made the usual stop in Harrisburg for lunch, all I'd eaten all day was a bagel at 7am and an apple at 1pm.  So, needless to say, when I arrived here around 3:30pm, I was ravenously hungry, and ate everything listed above with the exception of the donuts, which I brought home for my family.  I was surprised at how many vendors were open when I visited, but one of them explained that they were open later than usual due to the proximity to Thanksgiving.  How lucky for me, since I wasn't expecting to be able to patronize Miller's or Beiler's, given that they're not usually open at this time!

I'll leave the details of each foodstuff I tried to reviews of the individual vendors (forthcoming), but suffice it to say that everything, with one exception, was supremely delicious!  I left RTM stuffed and happy--a good thing, since I had an hour-long ride on SEPTA to DE to look forward to.  I walked out of there wondering why I'd never been to RTM before, and thinking that I need to get back here ASAP to sample more of the offerings.  In fact, I'm planning to talk the fam into taking me back here for brunch at Dutch Eating Place on Sat. before my train back to PGH leaves on Sat.

Long story short, this place is awesome!!!  If you're a visitor to Philly, you need to see this place before you leave.  If you're a local and you haven't visited, crawl out from under that rock you're living under and get here ASAP!
Amazing selection, and personable staff as I experienced. Must try for a visit to Philadelphia.

So glad I was able to stop at Reading Terminal Market on a recent day trip to Philly. It was especially packed as it was the weekend of the Philly Marathon, but it was worth braving the crowds for some great food. Although our lunch sandwich left something to be desired, we had good luck finding great meat and our thanksgiving turkey at one of the butchers. We also took home some great oils, pickles, and middle eastern snacks. It was difficult to find a spot to sit down and eat, but if you are patient and keep looking, one will open up eventually. Parking was surprisingly easy at the garage across the street... just remember to get your ticket validated and it will knock the price down quite a bit. I am excited for my next trip to Philly so I can try some new stands inside the market.
It's the closest thing to Seattle's Pike Place Market.

Took a day trip to Philly and had to stop by the market from reading all the reviews on Yelp. Reading Terminal Market definitely did not disappoint! Came here today which is the Saturday after Black Friday, was a bit crowded for our liking but it wasn't unexpected. We had parked near and visited the Liberty Bell and Independence Hall first then walked over for lunch. 

I would definitely grab a map to get a good lay out of the place. It can be overwhelming with so many stands! Food wise we ended up with:
- duck lo mein from Sang Kee Peking Duck 
- Philly cheesesteaks from Spataro's
- rib plate with mac and green beans from The Rib Stand
- strawberry lemonade from Jonathan Best Gourmet Grocer
- chocolate covered pretzels and strawberries from Chocolate by Mueller
- cheesecake from Termini Brothers Bakery
- whoopi pies from Flying Monkey Bakery

Wish we could have tried more things! This place reminds me of Pike's Place in Seattle a lil bit.

This place has it all from ice cream to cheesesteaks, and everything in between! You want marmite? They got it. You need some co-op produce? Check! Seriously, it's great for tourists and Philadelphians alike. Also a great place to go looking for gifts!

Took a weekend trip to Philly and decided that this was a good decision for lunch. The weather didn't hold out for us so being inside was nice. Due to the cold rain, it was tough to find a spot to sit and eat but the selection is unbelievable!

We walked the entire market and then made decisions on what to eat. Grab a map at the little kiosk or do what I did and print a pamphlet ahead of time from the website. It was very helpful.

We can't wait to go back and try more another weekend!

So good to be home! 
LOVE a good Amish breakfast and pan fried scrapple with maple syrup !!!
As good as life gets!

This place is awesome!!! History, Good Food, great people watching and an amazing cross section of Philly.  
The Reading Terminal Market has been my market for the last 10 years-  we moved into the neighborhood ten years ago and I was thrilled to find a world class market two blocks away.  We always got to Iovine for our produce and Giuntas for our Meats- John Yi is the only place we will buy seafood.
The Amish Corner has amazing deli, candy, bakery, pickles and dairy-  Go to the Dutch Eating place for Breakfast-  it is worth the wait! 
Get there early on the weekends otherwise you will have to wade through a sea of tourists and avoid the market between 11:00 AM and 2:00 PM during the week.

I have been doing my grocery shopping from Iovine Brothers produce market. 
L Halteman shop is the best for meat and cheese (in entire Philly in my opinion). Jonathan place is kind of expensive, I can get same stuff from trader's joe at much cheaper price though. If you are a tourist, there are lot of choices for restaurants.  I get chocolates from PA general store . Best chocolates(if you like chocolates without much sweet stuff) and cookies. Very crowded ALL THE TIME :)
Too much deliciousness in one building...was completely overwhelmed with all the choices!!! Yum!!

I want to eat all of the things here!!!  I would come here every weekend if I could.  It was a touch bit crowded for me, and if you know me I avoid crowds at all cost, but this place is worth braving the masses for.  And that's saying something coming from me.  I'd suggest grabbing lunch at one of the counters because it is tough to find a seat in the general seating area.  There are so many great little places to check out.  If you're into different olive oils and balsamic vinegars, you have to try out The Tubby Olive.  Awesome!  Can't wait for the next day trip to Philly.

Do:
- Get fresh fruits, veggies, meats, fish, cheese, baked goods. I couldn't believe how fresh and cheap the produce was. I wish we had come here at the end of our trip so I could take stuff home with me.
- Eat lunch here. So...much...food.
- Check out the display in the back with info about all of the other major markets in the country/world. Super neat. Shout out to Eastern Market in DC.
- Be adventurous and buy something you wouldn't usually. In the back corner there's a store with all kinds of dried herb/spice/rub mixes and dried fruit/nuts/candies.
- Bring Tylenol if you get headaches when people bring small children in strollers to crowded places.

Don't:
- Buy from the first counter you see. There are multiple shops selling everything, find the best deal or best looking chocolate/apple/sausage/whatever.
- Be in a hurry. There will be tons of people on a weekend. That's part of the experience. Allocate time accordingly.
- Start impulse buying until after you've had lunch or at least a snack.
An amazing Philadelphia experience! A must see if you're new to the area, or even if you're a local. Can't beat it!

The Reading Terminal Market's one of my all-time favorite spots to shop for holiday meal treats, fresh produce, delightful gifts for new home buyers. Fun place to catch up with friends & clients. Can't wait to take the family for our annual visit to see the Holiday Train Exhibit.

LOVE this place.  Tons of options, culture and good food. Whenever I have visitors, I take them here.  Only criticism is that it can be very crowded at times, to the point where it is difficult to get around.  Long lines tend to go quickly though, so still worth it - just try to find a down time.

The food mecca of Philly. While not condusive to the kosher minded,the amounts and types of hot food available will fit anyone.TThe stalls seling ingrdients from flour to spices is mind blowing.here is even one that sells their hot food by the pound and offers dozens of choices.Just make sure your eyes aren't bigger than your wallet.If you hit Philly,putting the Terminal is a must add to your tour of the city

Reading Terminal Market is like a cross between an (indoor) outdoor market and a food court. It's one of the top tourist attractions in Philadelphia, and you should probably experience it at least once during your visit.

With that said, you should know that it's a little overwhelming. I would give it closer to 4 stars on weekdays, but definitely three stars on the weekend. EVERYONE goes to this market. Seriously. I couldn't handle the crowd!

But once you can come to terms with the sheer volume of people, you can focus on the food. I personally found it to be a little repetitive. I mean I like sandwiches as much as the next person, but there are like a half dozen delis in there! There are stands run by Amish vendors, and those have special hours. I can at least tell you the places I tried:

Hatville Deli (sandwich)
Mezze (sandwich)
The Famous 4th Street Cookie Company (cookies)
Sweet As Fudge Candy Shoppe (candy)
Chocolate by Mueller (candy)
Market Blooms (flowers)
Iovine Brothers Produce (fruit)

So, you should go. Be in an adventurous mood. It's at least an experience. You *will* find something you like here. (And if you can swing by the Sweet as Fudge Candy Shoppe & pick me up some lime fruit slices, that'd be great.) Just be prepared to dodge the crowd!

Food paradise with some many unique food dishes from Philly like their famous Philly cheesesteak, I believe there are at least 4 places in here, lots of cheese and chocolate places, this place was rammed to the max, everything stand is a line up, even the chinese food stands

We tried our first Philly cheesesteak at by George, got the cheese steak with american cheese and it was soooooooo filling and good, one sandwich feeds 2 people, also tried a cookie place that was so soft and gooey....this is truly a food market, one of the best in the country in my opinion is better than Chelsea market in NYC

This place has keep its originality and I wish I could have tried other foods like the donut place seemed to very popular but that Philly cheese destroyed me

A must visit whenever in philly

I'm from New York but I might consider staying in Philly because this place is just so AWESOME. 

Everything Amish made tastes amazing. I haven't been able to try all the market has to offer but I will. This place gets really busy on the weekends. Try going sometime in the afternoon, Tuesday thru Thursday would be the best days to go. It will just give you a better opportunity to take it all in. 

If you want local, freshly grown vegetables cheaper than what they charge you at trader joes or whole foods, this is the place to be. 

The only thing that disappointed me was Sang Kee. Their roasted pork just didn't taste authentic. Trust me... I've tried a lot of different "cha su" pork, I even went to Hong Kong just to eat it. Sang Kee wasn't up to par, but other than that, this market is just everything anyone can ask for.

Take your largest grocery bags, tuck a bunch of cash in your pocket (forget the purse, it'll just get in your way), and go mildly hungry, at about 10 am.

I always aim for the Lancaster County bakers and butchers and greengrocers (sticky buns; gorgeous chicken, pork sausages, and scrapple; fabulous celery or tomatoes depending upon the season), AND The Spice Corner (which may no longer be its name, but,. hey, they're the BEST whatever their name is).

For mid-morning snack, shop carefully, because you'll want to sample goodies from the multitude of ethnic delicacies available.  Do not expect to need lunch.
It's ok. Farmer's market and Amish folks have good stuff. Not wow in general .

Great selection of food, shops, bakeries...but it can be unbelievably crowded and packed with people. Try to find an off hour to visit the market, or else it's just not as enjoyable. All of the long lines for food are typically worth the wait, so grab a snack and enjoy the scene.
Its a pretty neat market, but definitely a little over-rated in my opinion. Try going on a weekday when it is less packed so you can try more!

I don't know why i just don't go here first when i come to Philly to work.  The food is really the best - i love the baba ganoush platter - the parsley said is so refreshing and the baba ganoush is the best i have ever had.  That mint / rose water lemonade is flipping fantastic!

A must see in Philadelphia. This market has something for everyone, including DiNic's (pork and beef), Wursthaus Schmitz (German), a deli, seafood, bakeries, coffee, ice cream, cheesesteaks, cajun, produce and more! The market is very popular and becomes crowded during lunch hours and on weekends, but it is definitely worth a visit. 

There are numerous seating areas but sometimes you must be patient if you are in a larger group that wants to sit together.

The ambiance is lively and if you are lucky, there will be someone playing live music.

Best Advice to Navigate: Start from one side and work your way down each aisle. Many offer samples. After you've seen everything - pick your favorites. Flying Monkey was a standout with their pie IN cake. The Grilled Cheese place (MeltKraft) was so very very very very good - and unfortunately, the Elvis donut at Beiler's Donuts (banana, bacon!) I didn't get a chance to try because we had to leave for the train and the line was wrapped around the shop! I'll get it next trip. If you see something you want and the line is short, better get it while you can!

Ummm, I don't know that I really need to tell you why this place is great.  There are just too many reasons, most of which are obvious.

However, I will say that you MUST go to L. Halteman Family for all of your butchery needs.  They have been my go to for years now and never let me down.

They recently started carrying wagyu (ribeyes, flanks, etc.) and their scrapple is the BEST I've ever had.  Any time I want to wow my family or friends, I grab some tasty beef or poultry from them.
Somewhat overwhelming at first, but take a your time, a few deep breaths and you'll find you way. There's something for everyone.

I really loved Skillets, it was nice to sit outside, and the staff was really friendly..we came to eat just after noon on a saturday. This was a slightly slow time, as I think we were in between times..The food was tasty, the service was good and friendly, and I would definitely take my hubby here for a nice breakfast. you can even bring fido, and they give them water etc...
 I like to patronize the local eateries when ever I can, as its good for the community...
Yummmm, everything u can think of here besides what u find in whole foods is great. Love the atmosphere and enormous selection. Will come back for new things every time :} love it :}
