This place is great when you've got food or book needs and you're stuck between stops at the train station. Just wonderful. There is probably nothing else like it in Philly a beautiful station with plenty to do. Love it.
Amazing place to buy everything! I recommended to everyone.

This is a must see in Philadelphia.  So many great foodie options that have individual reviews on Yelp.  Reading Terminal Market is a destination not only for tourists but also for locals as well.  Always busy and always a good time, and gives a one stop shop for not only food, but also many other Farmers Market like items (i.e., crafts).

Reading Terminal Market is a great place to shop and EAT!!! They have tons of different foods and baked goods.  My favorite spots are Ms. Tootsies Soul Food and The Amish BBQ chicken from Diner's BBQ chicken.  Even though I am born and raised in Philly I have yet to discover all that Reading Terminal has to offer, because there are so many different things inside.  All very reasonable prices.  A good place to stop and look around on a day off or even just to stop by just to grab a bite to eat for lunch.

I always drop in whenever I'm near there.

This is Philly's heart and soul, and of course, stomach.  It's fun to wander up and down the aisles to browse and get hungry before you eat. Grab a buttery fresh Amish pretzel (eat your heart out Auntie Anne's -- this is the REAL fresh buttered pretzel!) while you wander.  Try De Nic's roast pork with brocolli rabe and provolone -- I think it was voted Best Sandwich Ever, Anywhere --- or something like that.  Or Salumeria.  Or canolli at Termini's.  Or buy a baguette at Metropolitan Bakery, and some cheese at one of the amazing cheeseries -- triple brie maybe?  Spices at the Head Nut?  Fresh fish (with head on OF COURSE)?  Oh I could just eat here the entire day.  One tip:  don't go to the big produce market the Monday, Tuesday or Wedsnesday before Thanksgiving -- it's INSANE!

This place is a foodie + Farmer's Market haven!! It has delicious baked goods, sandwiches, BBQ, cheeses, hobby shops, souvenirs, books, and more! My BF and I came here on a Saturday and were immediately overwhelmed. We picked up a map because we already knew which stores we wanted to try.

Top 3 businesses worth stopping by:

1. Tommy DiNic's-- delicious roast pork sub w/ sharp provolone and broccoli rabe
2. Basset's Ice Cream-- creamy texture plus delicious ice cream with so many different flavors to choose from!
3. Beiler's Bakery-- so many cheap, freshly baked goodies!!.. I picked up so many it was hard to narrow down!

We also stopped by Flying Monkey Bakery for their infamous "pumple" (apple pie in a vanilla cake atop a pumpkin pie in a chocolate cake) and the Dutch bakery for their apple dumplings, yum! 
Definitely want to try the Wursthaus Schmitz deli and check out other spots next time when we have more time.
Even though I live in Denver now, I never miss an opportunity to visit RTM when I'm home in Philly. It's one of my favorite places in the city - if only there was one here!
My favorite spot in Philly ... Hands down. Great food and the employees are great.

Great but touristy and elbow to elbow at peak times.
I like the hustle and bustle but not to the point of bas aisle management and alot of stands get overlooked becaise of snaking lines for popular ones (like donuts & bbq).I am based in NJ and can get pretty much the same quality `Amish` at any of 5 places within the same drive so I pretty much only go when vibing something different.I dislike the parking situation but I get it,its `urban`. I enjoy the slection at the organic co-op style stall up front,really neat stuff and nice staff. Alot of baked goods along the way..For variety A+, for the packed nature A-..The pixxa place near the door across from produce had the driest grossest looking things in the hot buffet. Termini Bros gave us Iced Tea when asked for Iced coffee.Would we return? Yes,but not as a destination like we made it,we would have to be doing sometihng nearby. Hershels Deli looked like good pastrami being thrown down,but we were so full and already had eaten so we passed.
Love the Reading Terminal Market. So much to choose from and what a variety. I can spend hours in here and love it. It's a mecca of melting pot

Reading Terminal...How I love you...let me count the ways. 

The first piece of advice I can offer is to take a lap around the market before commiting yourself to the first delicious treat that you stumble actoss. There's a lot of real estate to cover, you're best bet is to window shop first and commit later. From savory sandwiches to sweet treats from antique trains to novelty goods you're sure to find something for everyone here. 

If you have a need for Amish goods you have several options but be mindful of the hours. The Amish vendors tend to leave earlier than others and do not open on Sunday. It's well worth working around the time restraints; the pretzels, donuts and butcher offerings are my top recommendations. 

Stop for breakfast, stay for lunch and buy fresh ingredients for dinner. You're welcome.
Too crowded, overpriced and shady with the homeless.  Prefer Italian Market.

Oh Reading what would have I done without you! I came to Philly on business and RTM was my savior. I got a chance to visit 3 times and each time I tried different foods and goodies.

Reading is similar to Pikes Market in Seattle but everything is indoor and is on one floor. Lots to look at and the Market get super packed on weekends. There are tours that come through so be mindful that some of the food items or goodies may have a long line or may have sold out. 

Check the hours also because some of the shops are closed on certain days, or they may close early due to them selling out of their products. Also, some of the shops offer deals at the end of the day (e.g. 2 for 1). 

Cool place to hang out for an hour or so and only a block walking distance from my hotel, Lowes.

I love it there!

I mean...I'm from boston and quincy market is the same type of place but this was better...seriously BETTER

Ihad all the foods....ok I tried to have all the foods but I was only there two days
i stayed literally across the street from RM at the Marriott and it was just a short walk over..so over I went

and over
and over
and over

I had so many of the things

foodie paradise in philly....who knew?
You cannot beat this place. Just such variety and all of it is wonderful. If you are ever on jury duty, just skip on over and have some wonderful food.

love love love!!!  How could you not enjoy this smorgasbord of amazing vendors and foods all under one roof.  Bring your appetite and your wallet (it's not cheap)....oh and wear those comfy jeans one size too big.  You will thank me later.

There is no place like it every thing is delicious and fresh. If you haven't been go and don't be overwhelmed by the crowd just go with the flow and who knows what gem you will stumble upon. One of my favorites is Dieners bbq and the juice stand right across from it. The only reason it's not 5 stars is because they closed the beer garden. It was the perfect place to go after collecting all of your delicious treats to sit, get a cold pitcher of black and tan and eat. It was a place for locals our private little nook.

You need what?  Oh, Reading Terminal Market has it.  Seafood, produce, meat, Mexican, Amish, Japanese, bagels, Cajun, roast pork and broccoli rabe.  Everything!  My biggest complaint is that they aren't open past 6 pm, which makes it very difficult to get there during the week; otherwise I would do most of my shopping there.  It can also be a lot for some people due to how busy it gets during lunch hours and on the weekends, but bring out your inner South Phillian and push through those mobs of people!

I adore this place! It's a go to every time we can't agree on where to eat or if we have friends in town and want to take them somewhere unique to eat.

I have still yet to even try a quarter of the places in RTM - but Flying Monkey Bakery, Dutch Eating Place, Beiler's Donuts, and Olympia Gyro are a few I've tried. 

I also love the fresh produce stands and the fact that the Amish are represented really well here - you can't go wrong at any of their food, bakery or meat stands.

In addition to the wide variety of tasty food - I like the layout, it makes it really easy to navigate. RTM is set up on a grid and each row is labeled a 'street name' which makes it simple to find a person or place fairly fast.

Perfect spot for a quick and inexpensive spot. Came visiting to philly and staying in a hotel nearby so this was perfect balance of yummy options and inexpensive prices. Wished there were more samples but probably a good thing there aren't for my waistline's sake
Fun place to go, eat  and shop. Can purchase all kinds of food and treats. They  really cleaned it up from years ago. More bathrooms would be nice.
Amazing place for food and groceries.  I love the Amish farmers who sell their goods.

"DiNicks is a must"  "It won national awards for the pork sandwich"

In all honesty, yes they are good sandwiches but they are not "knock your socks off and send them down the street" good.  

A place called Riddle Ale House in media, or Nicks roastbeef in Springfield definitely have better roast beef, and pork sandwiches.

Again, good but not great or worth the drive, finding parking, waiting in line.

IMO, Philadelphia as a city doesn't have much going for it, but this place is truly special. Anytime a friend mentions a trip they are going to take to Philly, I unfailingly mention this place  for a visit.  There's quite a number of good eats all under one roof, not unlike Midtown Market in Minneapolis.  There's a soul food place here that's a favorite of Oprah Winfrey.  You will get FOMO (Fear of Missing Out) syndrome inside this place.  Lots of variety and you really can't go wrong.  The location is really close to the center of the city, if not in Center City, so it's quite easy to get to.

This is my favorite place to go & make up a meal to cook as I go.
Fresh meats, breads,fruits & veggies and cheese galore.

It's pretty much always busy so be ready for a crowd, but so worth it! A Philly treasure!
fun to go with visitors from out of town. like the variety of food, baked goods, and groceries.

I really like the atmosphere here.  Recently I was here and had a great cup of soup and sandwich but it is pretty pricey and you can eat the same food at the actual restaurants represented in the market for much less money without the crown.  

Although expensive, if you have a lot of indecisive people or people who can not agree on what to eat, this is where to go, you can get anything you want and everyone can have a different type of food!  Great shops and specialty places are also here.
I don't think there is another spot in Philly that makes me more proud to be a Philadelphia. This place has everything delicious you'd ever want and a charming crowded market feel.

Wow, what a an amazing place. I only had one day in Philly, so this was one of the must-stops. My bro and I decided to have some lunch here but we were having a very hard time deciding, as there were way too many tempting choices! We had to systematically go up and down all the aisles to make sure we saw all the vendors to make the best informed choice. In addition to all the prepared foods there were purveyors of all kinds of other goods, such as produce, meats, seafood, and crafty items. And all along the perimeter of the market were restaurants too--most of them chain restaurants, it looked like, but if that's more your speed it's nice to have that option. After perusing ALL our options, we finally decided to get lunch at the Wursthaus Schmitz (separate review). It's pretty hectic and crowded, as you may well imagine, but it wasn't too bad, and kind of added to the atmosphere. Fortunately they have lots of seating. 

STEPH JUDGEMENT: A sensory overload--in a good way!

Ive been visiting Philly for years now and never stopped into the Reading Terminal Market before, what time I have wasted! the aroma of all the different foods and candies and coffee here is worth the trip. A crowded little market filled with everything from unique restaurants to a raw oyster bar to bees wax candles. Wish I had more time to stop in and really explore everything that was inside!

One of my favorite places to eat and shop in the City!  The fair trade organic produce market is a favorite of mine, in addition to the Dutch shops, tea and coffee stores.  They seriously have the best produce (greens) I have ever tasted.  They also carry grass fed organic milk in glass bottles at fair prices.
Solid food options here that address all tastes.  You really can't go wrong -- definitely worth a visit for lunch if you are staying nearby.

I went to the market for the second time. There are lots of places to eat and purchase fresh fruit and produce. It is crowded especially during the holiday seasons. overall, I like reading terminal market and will come back when I back to philly.
Wide array of food! Can't go wrong with a dinics roast pork or an Amish breakfast. The wait in line is worth it so don't get frustrated.

This is my second visit here and I think I could cheerfully spend a whole day here, aside from the crowds! What an amazing selection of wonderful food! We started with breakfast at Pearl's which even has real maple syrup. We stocked up on sausages, cheeses and baked goods and drooled over coffees, crepes and beautiful mountains of fresh produce. I love this place!
Always a stop for us when in Philly.   Wide variety of different types of food.  Have some time to spend and enjoy.

This place is amazing!!! Its a foodie heaven. It combines a flea Market like experience with a food court and farmers market feel. So many choices for things to eat. Seafood, deli meats, asian cuisine, pastries.  Take your pick and come hungry.

A Philadelphia icon.  If you can't find something you love here, then you have no business eating out.  Tommy DiNic's roast pork, in my opinion, is the best in the city.  And yes, I've had the roast pork at John's, which in my opinion is second to Tommy's.  We also had oysters at Pearl's, which in my opinion, was nothing special.  The charm about Reading Terminal, though, is the overall variety of greatness.

We live in Philly and get produce from Iovine Bros. every weekend.  The market is always crowded, but you can't beat the prices and variety.  Overall this is a really fun Philly spot - if you're visiting even for a few hours, it's worth checking out.
Still a great place after all these years.  Plenty of vendors and plenty of variety.  Definitely a Philadelphia institution and a good place to stop for a fast lunch or great groceries.

We love the wide variety of places to eat and bakeries to choose from.  It is very crowded here, but worth it.  This is our second visit to the Reading Terminal Market (RTM) and the only surprising experience we had was someone approached us asking for money.  My husband gave him some money, but then before leaving RTM, we were approached again by the same guy.  My husband reminded him that he had all ready asked us for money.  Otherwise, we enjoy eating and buying from the many markets that are at RTM.

Yay for touristy things! We did a random day trip and just had to stop at the market for some food and Amish items. Very clean place with wonderfully intoxicating fragrances everywhere.  If it's your first time, walk around first to decide what to eat before committing to just one place and regretting not trying all the other varieties.  You can get jams, coffees, jerky, sandwiches, beer, poboys, and even butcher cuts.  Try as much as you can!

Great tourist place, but definitely not a place I go as a city dweller. I would take visitors here, but there are no great food places inside (it's all standard!). 
If you are from New York and know the Chelsea Market- this is NOTHING like it and not nearly as cool. 
If you are from the UK and love the Borough Market- again, nothing in the same ballpark,. 
Reading Terminal has a mix of chinese food, greek food, ice cream, lots of Amish stands. You can't even get good priced flowers here. 
It's cool to visit once, then you're done.

I feel sooo lucky that such a service exists. Since I'm moving, between laundry back up and time, Got Laundry saved the day! I had the pleasure of meeting Ray, what a nice and professional guy. I actually ENJOY the the fact of having done business and supported a family business instead of Big Box business. It just proves there are still caring businesses and people around. I'm just sorry I'll only be a 1 time customer since I'm moving out of state. Got Laundry? sets the bar high for other businesses to follow. Thank you sooooooo much Ray/family. Money can always be replaced some how, but time is something you'll never get back. Got Laundry? has saved that precious time. I would recommend this business over and over.

This place was amazing! We went here twice while spending a week in Philly and it did not disappoint. I wish I had more time to visit every place and that there was more room. Due to the small space, it can become overwhelming. DiNic's pork sandwich was great and Carmen's had the best Philly cheese steak I've ever had! Make sure to stop by Famous 4th Street Cookie Co. for some delicious treats!

The best food for any occasion.  From amazing pork sandwiches at DiNics to some of the freshest Seafood and Meat for fair prices in the city. Its where I go for a good meal, any variety, and general food shopping  when trying to avoid the overpriced supermarkets of center city.

Awesome place to get something to eat. So many great choices; allows everyone to get something different. Horribly crowded during the holiday season, but a place you MUST go if you live in the Philly area.
Great place...too many choices. Seating is the challenge but absolute must if visiting Philly.

Absolutely love this place! Mind - blown.

It's a huge market with so much to experience and offer, from restaurants to wine to food-to-go, and then some. I went to an Amish restaurant for breakfast, and it was so damn good! Seemed like THE place to eat and be at. We were so full afterwards that I couldn't look at any more food nor overwhelm my senses further, so I didn't explore much else, but from what I did see, I could definitely say this isn't your average, annoying tourist trap and well-worth the visit.

Way too crowded for my tastes.  There's nothing worse than fighting your way through the crowds to find some interesting, unusual, good food, but then having no where to eat it!  Avoid this place at lunch time.

Let's start by saying this is the place to go if u are hungry.  

There are many varieties of food there from Chinese Thai, soul food, burgers, cheesesteaks, pastrami or corned beef sandwiches.  And everything here is fresh and made to order.  I went into this looking for a pastrami sandwich. And Hershel's deli did not disappoint.  The pastrami was cut and served right in front of ur eyes and it was juicy and delicious!!!! 

And if u have a sweet tooth. They have a chocolate spot and a homemade donut shop.  They make the donuts right there. And wow are they to die for.  My favorite donut was the salted caramel and blueberry fritter.   But there were many more flavors to choose from.  

They also have a produce section and also a fresh seafood and butcher as well.   I'm From jersey and would definitely come back to try some other things.

love love love this place! Diverse selection of places to eat at, and they always have fresh seafood produce, meats. the Dutch section of restaruants is great as well. The Dutch eating place rocks! Go there for breakfast and get their pancakes, they are huge and the size of the plate!

I absolutely loved this place. So many great things to eat that it makes me sad I can't stay in Philadelphia and go here every day. Check out the Dutch breakfast place for fresh, home cooked food and friendly service.

Love this place!  Need a fresh cut of meat and want to talk directly to the butcher?  Want a whole fish for dinner, but don't know exactly what you're looking for?  Go to the Reading Terminal Market!  It's a fun way to spend a Sunday morning, strolling thru the stands, sampling the merch.  For breakfast, try the Dutch Eating Place (long lines, limited seating, but it moves fast) get the blueberry pancakes and turkey bacon-bit of a splurge, may want to walk home and skip the sub or taxi :)

Love going to Reading Terminal Market whether it is to pick up some fresh produce from Iovine's produce or to grab a quick, gourmet bite. Love eating breakfast at the Dutch eating place (blueberry pancakes are the best and the apple dumplings are amazing).

When I arrived in Philly, I had no idea that such a place as magical and wondrous as the Reading Terminal Market existed. Going off a tip from a friend on Facebook, a quick Google search showed my hotel was only a couple of blocks away, so off I went in search of something new. When I arrived and stepped inside, I couldn't believe my eyes.

I was instantly transported from a dreary cold and rainy day to a vibrant market full of shops and people milling about. I entered by the fresh produce and thought, "it's like a farmers market". Wrong. This place is a little bit of everything. Farmers Market. Grocery Store. Restaurant. Fish Market. Bookstore. Winery. Lancaster County Amish goods. Cakes. Pies. It's a you-name-it, they have it kind of place.

All of the shops are fairly small but packed. For those of you in Indy, imagine City Market sized businesses, but picture 150-175 of them on a single floor about three times the Indy City Market. Picture lines of people 30 people deep waiting for hand rolled donuts from Beiler's Bakery. Picture small restaurants with seating for only 10 or so people turning out every type of food you can imagine from all over the country. Picture me walking around trying to absorb every piece of this that I could, all the while wondering why Indianapolis doesn't have something so amazingly awesome. 

Philly, you've won my heart and you've won my stomach. Places like this make me want to come back every weekend just to find another shop that I didn't know existed, but am better for knowing that it does.

OMG! I could spend days in here.... We did spend days in here and I went back once. There are a ton of places to eat and tons of little shops. I highly suggest picking a hotel within walking distance if you are in the area vacationing. It was the best place to walk to for breakfast, lunch, or dinner. Can't wait to get back!

Was only here for a weekend but came twice. There are a lot of food options here and a couple little shops. Similar to Chelsea market in nyc except all the stores are open layout. We bought some cake from the Terminal Brothers, and wanted to get donuts from Buellers(?) but were stuffed and they were closed on Sunday because they're amish. There are significant lines at Dinic's and the ice cream shop but we managed to get a seat at the bar for some sandwiches. There's also a cute stand for natural honey and bees wax candles which makes for good souvenirs!
love the energy and the variety. Peking duck and Sang Kee is a fav.
I'm kind of obsessed with this place. The Dutch Eating Place had the most delicious homemade apple dumplings. I'm drooling just thinking about it!
they close early, but that can be expected from a market setting.  Love it

One of the city's gems, Reading Terminal is the best place to go for a lot of things and I will list all of the ones that I go there for. Ice cream is always a good one and the food in general that you can get is awesome, the Greek and Sang Kee counters are probably my favorites other than DiNic's of course. If you get there pretty early you can just walk right up to DiNic's and get a roast beef and to me it's totally ok to have one at 9 am. I only go to Smucker's now for meat and bacon (sometimes I cheat on them with Kensington Quarters now). The bacon prices are the same or cheaper than the supermarket and the quality of what you are getting is miles better. For seafood there is no better place than John Yi's seafood, they consistently have the best and freshest selection of seafood and everyone who works there is super friendly and helpful. All in all there isn't a better place in the city where you can get everything you might need in one spot. Iovine Brothers produce is also a nice little gem in there, this place makes me happy to live in Philadelphia.

If you need a touristy activity to take friends to, especially if it's a cold or rainy day, this place works great. Without being as stuffy and expensive as NYC's Eately, it's a fun experience with lots of great food options. There are some Amish shops that are fun to look through, and they do a great job around the holidays.

Oh my goodness. This place is unbelievable. You absolutely have to go here if you are visiting Philly, ideally for lunch or an afternoon snack. Even if you're not even hungry, this is a place to see - it is that impressive. 

My understanding is that this is an old train terminal now transformed into a gigantic marketplace. From Indian and Chinese food to baked goods and even a small bookstore, this place has so many unique items. 

There's tables in the middle where you can bring your food and eat. Definitely have to experience firsthand as words do not do this place justice!

If you love food (and, to a lesser extent, crowds) you will love RTM. It offers nearly every category of food you could want, multiple fresh food grocers, a beer garden, a diner, butchers, seafood stands, snack shops, candy stores, and even authentic Pennsylvania dutch (on weekends) selling cakes, pies, breads, etc. It makes everything extremely accessible, too, by being located within the same building.

It does get very crowded, especially on weekends but, to me, that adds to the charm, making it an excellent place to people watch in Philadelphia (while staying warm and VERY well fed).

For the tourist, it's a MUST SEE. For the Philadelphian, it's the mecca for great, inexpensive, different foods.

Have you been to Eataly in NYC? Have you been to Faniuel Hall in Boston? It has a very very similar vibe. Walking through the maze of the market is an experience itself, even if you don't stop to buy anything. It is a marvelous, glorious, hectic, loud, smelly, annoying experience. But it is so city and I loved it! It has hundreds of different food options, all classic Philly meals (donuts, pretzles and philly cheese steaks) as well as hundreds of other options. It is busy and crazy, but the food selection is like no other. THey also have a market, with hundreds of fruits/vegetables that looked so good! They had many butchers with meats and fish that also looked very fresh. This would be a great place to get fresh food if you live in this part o the city... or go to any of the hundreds of venues for pre-made food! I also loved that they had a corner of  "country store" type stuff with candles, jams, memorabilia, small candy stores.

It is genius, having it all together in the same building. Even if you aren't hungry, even if you don't like crowds or smells, it is a "tourist experience" to check this place out! It is magical, it is perfect... it is a necessity! 

I am OBSESSED!
I love this place - Nanee's Kitchen (in the back) makes the best Chai tea! Only thing is the market is always so packed with people - I never sit down in there for that reason.

A well lite, spacious and clean indoor market offering a  wide selection of vendors ranging from eatery, arts and craft, florist, fashion and grocery.  Locals and tourists (that would be moi) alike crowded this place daily!  Upon the first day of my first visit to this lovely city, my tour guide took me there and we walked through alleys of delicious goodness!  I had breakfast, coffee, cookies, flowers and yummy philly cheese steak!  On busy days the line for philly cheese could take 30 mins!  Well worth the wait!  I devoured my quickly and told my tour guide i need to be back for more soon!

Lots to choose from at the RTM - it is crowded so be prepared. There are some seats in open areas if you can grab some food and then find a seat or if your like me go to the restaurants like Molly Malloy's which also has great food and enjoy your stay. The best sandwich as shown on t.v. is here at RTM, if you like slow roasted pork! Check out DiNic's in the middle of the market.
Most of us Phila. residents have been coming here all of our life!
Great food, great atmosphere, can get crowded on weekends but still one of Philly's best locations. Don't miss the heavenly Bassetts ice cream.

Place was great, plenty of culture for our day tip to Philly. I would recommend going in the morning when their is lots going on. I think it closes around 3pm. 

We got pretzels from the stand in their and they were great! This is coming from a amateur pretzel eater.
Love this place. Whenever I'm there, the pleasant memory of childhood'd come back to me. The trains, the smell of grandma's cooks, the Christmasy decorations... Oh I wish my family were here with me.

Wow, where to start. I grew up going to the Terminal and frequent it now with my family. It is perhaps the most fun place in the city to grab lunch or breakfast. You can get anything you want to eat -- our favorites are the huge blueberry pancakes at the Amish counter in the back, the Mexican foot at the Cantina, and the new grilled cheese stand. The Terminal is such a Philly experience that it shouldn't be missed by residents or visitors to Philly. 

A visit wouldn't be complete without dessert from either Fourth Street Cookies, a hand thrown soft pretzel dipped in butter from another Amish stand, or Bassetts Ice Cream. 

This place is Philly's own slice of heaven.

I absolutely love this place. Always something delicious to try and new people to meet. 

Giving it a 4 mostly because it can be a little pricey.

The reading terminal market is one of my go-to spots in philly. It is perfect for lunch with friends because you can all get something different. They have everything from desserts to cheesesteaks to gyros- you can even do your grocery shopping here!
 
Every time I go, I try to go somewhere different. There are too many great options to choose from. 

The only downside is there is limited/crowded seating, but that is expected at such a busy place. Big plus for the restaurants that offer their own seating. 

Definitely a great spot for visitors and locals!
A must-see in Philly! Lunch hour is craaaaaazy crowded, but that's part of the fun if you're up for it.

Great place to buy groceries, especially fresh vegetables and fruit., best time to go is in the morning.
There are so many stores with a nice selection. I personally think that the place is a little bit overrated and overpriced excluding the iovine brothers store.
If you just visit it is a fun place to see. Great deserts and decent prepared food.
This market reminded me of Quincy market in Boston or Fisherman's Wharf in SF. I like these old school style of tradition. I was very happy to find out the most yummy whoopie pies I ever had.
Great place to eat. I went on a weekday and there was a lot of locals, which is always a good sign.

I love the reading terminal!! There's truly something for everyone! Bakeries, produce stands, cheese steaks, gyros, Chinese food, a grilled cheese place, pizza, a crepe place... And that's truly just to name a few! Besides being crowded around lunch time and probably dinner too, it is a fun place that everyone should visit.

Went to check out the market on a Saturday and really loved the experience.

Make sure you come here hungry, there is so much deliciousness to try!

There are many vendors here, selling everything from Amish cheeses, to fresh seafood, to local chocolate.

I had fun picking up various items to take back home and try including freshly made peanut butter with honey, Amish butter cheese, and Soy Vey marinade.

Can't wait to return the next time I visit Philly!

It doesn't get much better than Reading Terminal.  You name it (food wise), they've got it.  From fresh produce, to meats and cheeses, to desserts, to fresh made sandwiches... this place has pretty much everything.

Of course with those sort of options, this place can be busy... especially on weekends or holidays.

In addition, parking is a little sparse so your best bet is to park in the garage across street and walk over.  You can even get that parking validated if you spend some money at the market.
Love Reading Terminal, to bad I no longer live down town, i would go several times a week.

This place is awesome and definitely should be the first place you should go to in Philadelphia. There's so many different foods you can try out and so many small markets inside, you can easily waste a lot of time wondering what you want to eat.

I went to Frank's to get their BBQ Chicken Sandwich and fries. While the sandwich was a bit bland, the amount of fries we got was humongous. I mean, we got a big bucket full of them. I couldn't finish it all and had to give some to my friends. A friend of mine tried out a Thai place there and thought it was okay.  I would try out more places next time since it was only a stop for us in Philly.

Reading Terminal reminded me of the outdoor markets and bazaars you'd see on a travel documentary, although we lacked the voiceover narration of Rick Steves, Andrew Zimmern, or Anthony Bourdain. still, it's a lot of fun.

jam-packed with stalls filled with trinkets, donuts, books, sandwiches, coffee, spices, incense, and more, there's something for everyone. seating is haphazardly strewn about; consider yourself lucky to find a seat anywhere.

the best plan is to grab something and keep walking. or, run into your friends - completely unplanned, since they live in Connecticut these days - and find out that they have a big table with their family. the donuts they got were superb - I don't know which vendor, but I had a super-dense chocolate donut that was as big as a car tire. okay, I exaggerate, but it was epic and delicious, unlike what you'd get at Dunkin (or, perish the thought, Starbucks).

worth a stop if you're in Philly.

The best food, the best place to get lunch, snacks, cheese, flowers, bread, fresh fish and meats, Amish and other ethnic specialties.  RTM is a treasure no visitor to Philadelphia should skip.
Cheap parking at the garage on Filbert St. - just make sure to have your parking stub validated at one of the market businesses.
-Little known fact - the RTM sells gift certificates - great for your Philly friends and relatives.
Love Reading Terminal, to bad I no longer live down town, i would go several times a week.

The only problem with this place is that you can never make a legitimate choice on where to eat in a decent time frame. Too many places! It's too much to take in at one time! Also the place is rather small and get's crowded easily. I wouldn't go there during any event at the Convention Center because that's where everyone goes to eat.

I will keep this super short and sweet.... 

Reading Terminal Market is one of the oldest and largest enclosed public markets in America. It is located directly across from the Philadelphia Convention Center (Corner of 12th & Arch Streets) in downtown Philadelphia.  This market offers everything from  handmade crafts--to fresh produce -- to fresh flowers-- to meats-- to seafood-- to fresh flowers-- and a plethora of dining options of every type of worldly cuisine. Make sure you bring your appetite and allow yourself plenty of time to wander through the enormous food bazaar. 

I ate at the 'DUTCH EATING PLACE' on my last visit.  I truly enjoyed their homestyle cooking. Everyone raves over their apple dumpling and breakfast fare. They can be found in the "Amish Corner" of the market and they're their perfect spot to sample classic Pennsylvania Dutch deliciousness. Again, there are plenty of options to choose from and you defiantly won't leave here empty handed or hungry.  

Final Verdict: This is a MUST VISIT if you're visiting Philadelphia.

OH WOW!!! I have always heard great things about this place and now I can finally attest to all the amazing reviews! 

A little about the experience:  First, the place itself; walking in is a treat within itself and so easy with all the entrances that are available. The air is filled with aromas from all different foods and cultures that just seem to blend so perfectly well together. The bustling from all the locals and out-of-town"ers" makes you feel like a true city folk. All the vendors are nice and knowledgeable of the area; which sure helps a first timer like myself when trying to navigate the market innards. However this wouldn't be needed if a directory was put up somewhere which was my only complaint about the whole place. My first thought was oh this place is going to have a couple of little places to eat inside, to my delightful surprise it also contained fresh looking meat markets and fresh vegetable stands located inside, it was quite a treat to see. In addition to all the food YOU CAN EVER WANT they also offer little stores filled with knick-knacks so you can leave with two types of souvenirs one to eat and a one to keep. Not to mention if you ever seem to be a little short on cash no worries you can find ATM's scattered throughout.

Now a yelp-ers favorite part of the review: the food. I personally went to Herchel's, Dinics and the famous Beiler's Bakery. Lucky for me when I first entered, the bakery was staring me right in the eye holes tempting all my taste buds with their aesthetically pleasing cakes, muffins, pastries of all sorts and the ever so tantalizing Beiler's Doughnuts which I had to part-take in. Unfortunately by the time I had gotten there all the Boston Creme doughnuts (which happen to be my favorite doughnut were all out (sad face)). So I went in without a plan and was not totally disappointed. I went with a Red Velvet doughnut which to my pleasure was quite the pallet pleaser, it had the red velvet taste down to a "t", Other doughnuts included a Salted Caramel apple, Gingersnap and "The Elvis".

Dinic's is located more towards the middle of the Terminal market taking up quite a bit more real estate than others. They offered delectable sandwich choices and the staff was pleasant and knowledgeable of their product. 

I knew I couldn't leave without trying Hershel's deli.The menu looked delicious so I couldn't say no to grabbing one of their scrumptious sandwiches. So i then found myself standing in line. They offer your run of the mill delicatessen sandwiches, however I wouldn't be wrong to say that they do them a little better than most, in my honest opinion. 

All-in-all this place is must-go if you ever find yourself in the City of Philadelphia; with its wide variety of stores and fresh produce as well as meats, you can't go wrong with a trip to Reading terminal market!! To quote the famous actor and Governor of California Arnold Schwarzenegger "I'll be back".
Great place to grab lunch and do some shopping in Center City.
love bringing visitors here for the experience. lots to try, a lot of great specialty stores and a fun way to spend a saturday morning.
best place to go for the atmosphere.  It's Philly in a nutshell.  Plan to eat and browse.  It will be crowded during the holidays, but that is part of the beauty.

Wahhhh there's so much to choose from I don't know where to start!!

Busted out my Yelp app to see what's worth my time since I'm only in Philly for the day.  Dinic's was definitely at the top of the list.  I also got to try the infamous whoopee pies.  The lines move pretty quickly in general so long line didn't necessarily equal to long wait. 

Restrooms were also surprisingly clean for such a busy place.  Kudos to that!

One of my favorites. I love to go there to get my cheeses for the holidays. The kids love that we can all go in different directions to get what we each want. Favorites are the pork sandwiches, two deli style cheese places and the bakery. Can't go wrong- awesome food and fun atmosphere!

The Historical Reading Terminal is the Epic Center for the ultimate dinning or food shopping experience.

There's a restaurant to suit every taste bud!!!

This Market has everything you need. There's Tasty pastries and mouth watering sandwiches. Candy, chocolates and fresh flowers for all occasions. 

There is a large selection of: meats, poultry, turkey, cold cuts and large varieties of cheeses. 

Everything is fresh and good. You have a nice selection of produce, nuts and gourmet coffee. 

A great place to have breakfast!!!!The Terminal is the blue print! A staple in Philadelphia's history!! Enjoy!

Beilers Donuts and Becks Cajun Café with Alligator Gumbo, oh my I've died and gone to heaven. Tons of great vendors. Parking is a pain for at least its discounted it you buy something, which we always do.

It's a Philly favorite & a Must stop for visitors to the area.  Featuring many local Philly favorite foods, a variety of restaurants and a few small gift shops.  Also a great fresh produce spot.  DiNics pork is a must as is a Termini Bros Cannoli.
Talk about a smorgasbord of GOOD EATS! From fresh seafood, to classic philly cheesesteaks, ice cream made in-house, and dangerously fresh cookies, there is no way you will leave hungry!

I really have to say I'm a big fan of Reading Terminal. As a quick stop to get one of your favorite foods, or just as a place to meander around, and find something delectable to your taste buds, this place seems to have it all. The best time to go are during the week from 2pm to 6pm to avoid the lunch rush, and then after 4pm on weekends. Parking is only $4 in many of the surrounding parking garages, just remember to get your tickets validated. Street parking is also available. 

I strongly recommend the Original Turkey, Herschel's Deli, or any of the Amish foods.
Lot's of great food and groceries!  Some of it better than others, so everyone will have a different experience.

There is something for everyone at Reading Terminal Market. This is the perfect place to bring guests you are hosting who are visiting Philadelphia. It is in a great location that is near other attractions and each person in your party can choose what stand they want to visit. It can become crowded - especially during typical lunch times so if it is nice outside I suggest walking around, getting your food to go and then eating outside. Be sure to take pictures - all of the vibrant colors can lead to some really great shots! I highly recommend the fudge from the "Sweet as Fudge Candy Shoppe"
Very nice place! I would recomment the pulled pork sandwich at Dinic's.

I love this place!!!  Everytime I come here it is a feast. There's a shop for anything you want to eat here. I usually start by getting an array of awesome olives at one place and a few pieces of cheese at another for appetizers.  I follow that up with some oysters and sometimes a lobster,  which they will prepare for you on the spot. For main course,  I love the lamb sandwich or the Amish spot has great barbecue. Or there are plenty of places to grab awesome Chinese,  Greek or some traditional Philadelphia sandwiches. End it off with out of this world cheesecake or canolis and a world class expresso. Whole I'm eating dessert,  I usually have one of the friendly girls put together a flower arrangement at the flower shop with the most beautiful and healthiest flowers in town. This place is AWESOME!!!

This place is heaven to my nose.
They have everything you need under one roof. Makes me wish I lived in Philadelphia.

There are so many great dining options here. My personal favorites:

The Train Wreck Po Boy at Beck's Cajun Cafe

The apple filled doughnuts at Beiler's Bakery

The Valley Thunder grilled cheese sandwich at Meltkraft

The apple dumplings at Dutch Eating Place

What can I say that hasn't been said. I lived in Philly for a year and Reading Terminal market was easily my favorite place to be. In fact, I may go as far as to say that it is my favorite place... PERIOD. Obviously there is a nostalgia factor, however, this place lives up to the hype. 
Reading Terminal is situated right in the heart of center city and is located above what is now the Jefferson Station (used to be Market St Station). The market has various vendors where you can buy your high quality meat, cheese, fish, and produce. Not to mention Ivarone brothers, which has the most affordable high quality produce that I've ever encountered living on the east coast. Reading terminal also has vendors selling cuisines from all over the world. These are your must go places: Amish market area, Tommy Dinic's (roast pork sandwich), Ivarone Brothers, and Hope's cookies. The Amish area is only open I believe Wed. or Thurs. through Saturday. They have an Amish diner which is incredible (check out the baked apples). They also sell hot dogs wrapped in crispy homemade pretzels and cheese which are to die for. The Amish bakery must also not be missed and you honestly can't go wrong with pie by the slice or any of the various other traditional baked confections they offer. Tommy Dinic's is a must too. Adam Richman (Host of Man v. Food on Travel Channel) coined their Roast Pork Sandwich the best sandwich in the country. Lastly, you CAN'T miss Hope's cookies. They also sell fudge, but you need to get those cookies. Everyone heads to 4th St Cookie Co (also in Reading Terminal), which has great cookies, but nothing compared to Hope's! They have unique gooey flavors like Heath Bar, caramel pecan, and my personal favorite, Wilbur's peanut butter (PB cup chunks and chocolate chunks). 
Whenever you or anyone you know ever enters the city of Philadelphia, you must forget what your doing for a good hour and head to Reading Terminal Market!

I love coming here. There are so many different food options and stands to get gourmet, meats, cheese, etc. I could get lost in here for hours just walking around and checking out the different things each stand has. If you're with a group of people that's not sure what they want to eat, this is a great place to bring them. There are so many options, that everyone is bound to find something. Even if you're not hungry, this is just a place worth coming to for the experience. It's almost always crowded, but even when it's not it'll feel tight because there are so many stands. Even with that, I love Reading Terminal and I can't wait to come back!

The trout amandine was the very best we've had (and we're from Manhattan!!). The steak frites, on the other hand, was well reviewed on these pages, but didn't woo-hoo us. Festive ambiance and friendly wait staff. You'll have fun.

If you're looking for a variety of foods prepared fresh daily for a reasonable price, look no further!! Gems found in this market whether it is eating brunch/lunch/dinner, buying fresh seafood, meats, coffee, flowers, ect., or grabbing some amazing desserts!
Cute market in the heart of Philadelphia, but didn't see anything special there that I haven't found in other cities.

You're not human if you don't enjoy Reading Terminal Market!! 

They have everything you could want/need! However, I always tend to drift around the Amish because literally everything is amazing! 

If I lived closer I would visit more than 5 times a year, but everytime I do visit I leave with 10 bags

One of my favorite parts of Philly! 

Reading Terminal Market has something for everyone! There are so many speciality vendors there and local shops that produces goods. I will admit that sometimes I get overwhelmed coming here, but in a good way! 

I haven't had the chance to try as many food places in here, but the ones I've had are nothing short of delicious. They have every type of food here. Craving something? You can probably find it here. I have nothing but good things to say about this place. A definite must when in Philly!

Philadelphia landmark and treasure!  As a local I get all of my produce and fresh meat here for reasonable prices downtown.  Plus it has so many unique and interesting shops that you can always find something spectacular.  Can get a bit crowded with tourists, but that's its general appeal and why we should be proud to share it.  Beiler's Donuts are UNBELIEVABLE, it is a must stop shop!

I only gave it 3 stars because it was my first time and it was packed. We couldn't get any food due to the lines everywhere. It was crazy. I'll return when we don't have the kids to eat my way through that place. The sights, the smells. It was new to me. I wouldn't go on a Sunday when its packed, when there is an event across the street.. will try to go when its not a peak time. My fault. But everything looked awesome.

Variety is the key! If you are a visitor to Philadelphia you will see so many styles different cuisines under one roof - all of them respectable to fantastic. 

If you are a native of the city and haven't yet visited - get there!
Always a fun place to stop and look around! Great food!
Best place in the city for a meal, produce or dessert.
Love Reading Terminal.  Great food options, especially Iovine, Thai Food and Molly Malloys!

This place has so much to offer! You walk in and there are people everywhere. Good luck finding somewhere to sit because the eating area is packed but it is well worth the search to find a seat! 
 There is one place that serves Curry salmon over white rice and broccoli and its delicious! the salmon is cooked so delicately that it breaks the moment you touch it with your fork. The sauce on the salmon seeps onto the rice on the bottom that gives it a smoked taste.  
 This market has clothes, trinkets, food you name it. You could spend hours in here just lurking around at it all. If you want some fresh produce definitely check out Iovine Brothers!

Fun!

So many beautiful and delicious foods packed under one roof. I definitely recommend the grilled cheese stand but do a lap around the market before you make any decisions because there's so much good stuff and you can prioritize after you see all of the choices.

If I lived in Philadelphia...I mean Philly cause that's what I would call it if I lived there right? So if I did live in Philly, I would be at Reading Terminal Market every day. I would also be 100 lbs heavier because I would be eating a dozen Beiler's donuts, a couple of cannolis from Termini Brothers, Philly cheesesteaks galore, ice cream at Bassetts...

You can find everything here. Not just food but other goods as well. It does get super busy though so try to find non-peak times. But if you want to soak in all the food goodness that is Philadelphia, just go here. You'll find everything!

One of my favorite places in Philly, full of amazing food stalls, fresh produce, specialty items such as aged olive oils and herbs.

Yes, it is typically very packed but the hustle and bustle is worth it for the vast array of items available all in one place. I love its proximity to the Convention Center means a lot of out-of-towners get to experience this amazing piece of Philadelphia.

I can't wait for the City Kitchen to get going in full swing as I would love to take some cooking classes!
Great variety of vendors and product selection. A nice outing for any afternoon to grab lunch.

I would guess that locals all have their own favorites and habits at the Terminal. I know which veggie stand to go for which items, I know to get to the Thai place early to avoid the lunch rush (salmon curry!). I know you can't beat Beiler's doughnuts and coffee special, or that Miller's Twise pretzels stuffed with egg and your choice of meat are the perfect handheld breakfast item. 4 Seasons Juice Bar is always phenomenal (although they run out of some staple fruits too often - how this is possible for a place located in the Terminal is mind-boggling) but the Middle Eastern eatery has a great banana-honey smoothie. There are things I'd never do in the Terminal - like buy a cheesesteak or pizza. But the sandwiches at Hatville Deli are incredible. At the Terminal, you have to deal with some price inflation (read: avoid the flower stand) but all in all, it's a fantastic place with something for everyone.

Reading Terminal Market, I confess my love for you! 

I remember the first time I came to the market. It was overwhelming and honestly one of the most exciting food experiences in Philly! The options are endless! I couldn't decide on one thing to eat and the beautiful part was that I didn't have to choose just one spot for lunch. You can have Greek food with Indian side dishes, Italian food with German accents! The options are actually endless. I still haven't worked my way through all of the stands, though this is a challenge I gladly accept. 

One thing to note is that the Pennsylvania Dutch run stands are closed on Sundays (I know it's heartbreaking.... Don't show up on Sunday expecting to have a big Dutch Eating Place breakfast with pancakes, french toast, and ahhhhhh my mouth is watering just thinking about it). 

The real tragedy is that I live in Washington, D.C.... However, I'm up in Philly almost every other weekend and you bet that I go to Reading Terminal at least once per weekend. If you live in Philadelphia and don't go to the market then you, my friend, are missing out!
Whatever you want. Meat, seafood, vedge, sweet, savory. Breakfast lunch dinner. Greek, Indian, Italian...ahhh I could go on....
So many choices, it makes it fun just to walk around and people watch! Love Iovine's!

The crowds, the crush, the noise .. it's all worth it to visit Reading Terminal Market, an indoor nirvana for both blue and white collar food lovers, with many of Philadelphia's Best under one roof. There's more than one (or two or three) incredible bakeries, multiple seafood vendors, a couple of butchers, a poulterer, three produce/grocery meccas (well, one mecca and two side chapels). The quality of food at all of them is terrific, and the prices are reasonable considering the quality. There's a honey place, a tea store and an herb vendor. Pennsylvania Dutch farmer's sell homemade pies, donuts, sandwiches, meats, cheese, etc. I get my Thanksgiving feast food here -- the poulterer is tremendous.

And the restaurants! Coffee, donuts, ice cream, several vendors for delectable cold cuts and spreads, sandwich places up the yahoo, two Asian places, one German, one Greek, a creperie, and more. There's a large community eating section in the middle of the Market and individual vendors have seating as well. Restrooms are available that are clean and well maintained.

Non-food vendors include a cookbook niche and a Philly-themed gift shop.

RTM appeared in the movie Trading Places, and it dresses up for the holidays with a huge miniature train set up, which is appropriate since this building is the former Reading RR (as in Monopoly) train shed.

The Market is open seven days a week but the Pennsylvania Dutch vendors are not there on Sundays or Mondays (and maybe Tuesdays?).

On 12th Street between Arch and Filbert, this fascinating indoor public market is near the convention center, not far from City Hall, and on Chinatown's doorstep, convenient to Market St. and many bus routes, and very close to the Chinatown bus depot.

Founded in 1892, it's a great place to bring visitors. Go there for the history, then stay for lunch! It's not nearly as crowded in the mornings before 11 and in late afternoon, even on weekends. Other times it is crushingly crowded with lines everywhere. Still worthwhile, but not as pleasant! The vendors are almost universally cheery and helpful.

There are multiple entrances. At the 12th and Filbert door you'll find maps of the Market and there are sometimes walking tours.

It can be very overwhelming visiting the RTM so I recommend checking out there website to make a plan of action. I have eaten here and there but not familiar enough to name drop just yet. It is a really great market where you can purchase breakfast/lunch, grab fresh produce, and grab a drink. The only down side is how crowded it can get. I read reviews about avoiding this place with a stroller and should have listened but we were at the car show and holding a toddler the entire time would have been back breaking. We tried getting a seat at Molly Malloy and when that proved impossible we drove back on our side of the bridge and hit up PJ's. 

Also can someone tell me what is in those donuts! The line was wrapped around the entire market. 

We haven't given up on you yet RTM. I will be back!

This is my favorite thing about this city. The terminal market has everything you would ever need. It's a place in which you can dabble in all your guilty pleasures. 

This market has everything from homemade pickles to cheeses to fudges to pancakes to fresh bread to gyros to cheese steaks. If you want to eat it, this market has it. 

The lines are long but the people watching is endless so time flys by faster than you expect even in some of the longest lines you will probably stand in. This is one of my all time favorite markets. 

Beiler's donuts is a must. It's one of the most spongy and bouncy donuts you will eat. They make the donuts right in front of you! Try the apple fritters!!! This place has a line that passes Dutch eating place and the fudge shop. 

This market has bee wax candles to little gift shops. It pays to stop by this market to pick up some little gifts and keepsakes. 

Another place you have to try is the Dutch eating place. The restaurant has great specials. Get their Ruben sandwich. This place is a must for breakfast.

One place I do not recommend is tommy dinic's. This place makes me angry cause I waited in line for so long just to get a low quality sandwich. I was expecting their sandwich to be delicious because of all the hype. I was a bit confused as to why people were so excited about this place. I really was so confused and I am still confused by it. I also feel like I will forever be confused as to why people are so infatuated by this place. It's really not worth the wait nor is the hype real. They don't have a huge depth of flavor profiles in their sandwich. I give dinic's two stars. But their service is quick and very friendly. 

Overall, this market is a must when in the city. It's worth your time and all the extra pounds you will most definitely gain.
They literally have everything! Little tip: all the Amish run shops are closed on Sunday. Best donuts I've had in a while. Get the peanut butter creme! Banana honey walnut crepe was amazing too!
Dear Philadelphia, you can keep your Liberty Bell.  Just give me your Reading Terminal Market and I'll leave quietly.

If you're visiting Philly, you MUST check this place out! This is one of my favorite places in Philly and I always end up taking my friends and family here when they visit. There's so many different types of vendors here, it's the perfect place to satisfy any type of craving you may have. My favorite is Beiler's Bakery, they sell Amish donuts that are DELICIOUS. There's Dutch food, Asian choices, Cajun options, Polish pierogis, coffee beans, cookbooks, ice cream, an oyster bar, and so much more! 

It may get overwhelming at first with the huge crowds and long lines, but it's not all that bad! With all the food options in front of you, it will all be worth it!
This place is wonderful! Just dont be stupid like me and go on a Saturday at 4 during the car show, haha. Great food, great prices on groceries!

Food: many small shops, mostly chinese take out food (at least 10) or Phili cheese steak, some bakeries, chocolate shops, farmers market, ice cream, oyster bar. Tried the cheese steak at "#3 in the market" since #1 and 2 were closed that day, for a 30min line it was very average, perhaps better than cafeteria phili cheese but nothing too amazing. Tried some baked goods, plain and pretty expensive ($5.50 for a scone). Obama ice cream was pretty good. 

Location: can't miss it, big building lots of entrances. Does have places to sit, but gets pretty packed on weekends. A lot of people ends up eating standing up. 

Service: does not exist. The cheese steak places are too busy to greet you, just yells for you to move forward. Clean after yourself. Place is not dirty but definitely not the most clean, esp the places you can sit.

There's only one bad thing about the Reading Terminal Market- and that is the crowd it pulls in! But that isn't necessarily a bad thing.

There are so many amazing places to eat in here!

There's a stand that sells homemade lemonade - the orange lemonade is the BEST!

I love Wurhaus Schmitz- led their by my favorite Philly bar- Brauhaus Schmitz. Potato pancakes to go or to eat there!

D'nicks roast park is another favorite stop... the best sandwich ever!

Fourth Street cookie has the biggest and best cookies ever!

The chocolate store in the one corner makes crazy chocolate shapes. They once had a chocolate covered tastykake and it was the best thing I ever had!

Basessts' Icecream is another one of my favorites.

You really can't go wrong with going here! Plenty of seats to sit at and eat in the middle of the market.
Lots of selections.  try out the Thai food place and get the salmon dish.  Good price and tastes amazing.  Nothing like grille salmon with coconut sauce.d
Definitely a place I want to avoid around any holiday or on the weekend BUT it serves a purpose and I'll always go back for the donuts and falafel!

Best place to go to in Philly. Come on an empty stomach. They have everything from every desert you can dream of, various cuisines for lunch and dinner, cute little trinkets, and deli and produce section. My favorite and what I always go to is Beiler's donuts - the most delicious thing I've ever eaten ever.

This place is awesome! You can buy really good and really cheap produce here (Iovine Brothers, OK produce (the name is definitely a misnomer)), and also get really good food! Di Nic's sandwiches are some of the best sandwiches you will eat in the northeast. Afterwards, you can cool off with ice cream from one of the oldest vendors in America, Basset's. Reading termninal also houses good fresh meat and seafood shops, although I have personally not shopped for meat there. All in all, a great shopping environment, with a lot of treats to offer.
awesome food...great shopping...I love it here...it gets really croweded and that's a kill but that one con is outweighed by the pros
I love going to Reading Terminal! It has a large variety of places to eat and none disappoint.

I love the Market! Every kind of food you can want, all in one place - from prepared meals and sandwiches. to fresh fruit and veggies. I just moved to Philly, and have been told that many locals do in fact shop here for their groceries. Great people watching at lunch, and definitely not touristy like you might expect from such a popular place :)
Loved visiting the Reading Terminal Market on a day trip to Philadelphia. It is indeed a food lover's paradise. You name it, they probably have it. Most places only accept cash.
Staple...Try Valley Shepard Creamery, Tommy DiNics and Oysters
what an amazing place.  Just be aware of parking hardships and crowds on weekends

A visit to Reading Termimal Market is always necessary for us when we're in Philly. You have a variety of options to eat.  Just be ready to brave the crowds of people here, especially on weekends. 

Highly recommend DiNic's, Herschel's, Bassetts, Keven Parker's Soul Food Café and Famous 4th Street Cookie. 

DiNic's - My default order is the pulled pork w sharp provolone. It's very juicy and lots of flavor. I've tried the roast pork but I definitely prefer the pulled pork.

Herschel's - I've only tried their pastrami sandwich and it has to be one of the best pastrami's I've ever had. Very meaty and tender and not fatty at all. 

Keven Parker's Soul Food Café - if you're in the mood for soul food, come try this place. I've tried their fried chicken & mac and cheese. 

Then, go get dessert at Bassetts or Famous 4th Street Cookie! 

Park at one of the parking garages. We usually park on 12th and Filbert St and walk across. But don't forget to get your ticket validated at one of the vendor's (with a minimum purchase of $10) - you'll only pay $4 for upto 2 hours.
So many selections! So much yummy food to try. Always a good choice if you wanna pick up a sandwich or a snack or something exotic.

Very fun. There's a lot going on here - lots of options, lots of people, lots of temptations. We came here for a stroll and then for lunch, and ended up enjoying both greatly. One of the hardest things was just deciding what to eat among so many delicious-looking options.

Great location in the center of the city.

Wish there were a little more seating and water fountains, and a little less crowding.

One of the best indoor markets I've been to, Reading Terminal is both a local delight and a tourist attraction. It is a foodie's haven, but also has other quirky shops that'll capture your attention for quite some time. 

Notes:
* Must try the places with long lines because they're obviously good. 
* Dutch Eating Place and Tommy DiNic's have those long lines.
* Don't even try looking for spaces in the general seating area unless you fight for them.
* Save room for dessert - Termini Bros Bakery, Chocolate by Mueller, and Famous 4th Street Cookie Company.
* Sometimes, it's worth being extra cold even in the winter - Bassett's Ice Cream.

Awesome mix of small food outlets and grocery.  You'll come to get the famous Dinic's roast pork with broccoli rabe and provolone.  But when you see how long the line is try the falafel place.  It's fantastic and fast.

This place is ALL about food. So come with a serious appetite. Intensely crowded place. Long waits for food during lunch time, no matter what day of the week it is.

Save room for Bassetts ice cream!

Just be aware that this is primarily a place for tourists. And people who work nearby (for lunch).
Noisy, Crowded, but whenever I'm in town I go there for the Corned Beef Special and the Cannoli's at Termini's.

Very fun. There's a lot going on here - lots of options, lots of people, lots of temptations. We came here for a stroll and then for lunch, and ended up enjoying both greatly. One of the hardest things was just deciding what to eat among so many delicious-looking options.  Great location in the center of the city.

Wish there were a little more seating and water fountains, and a little less crowding.

Boasting a rich historical legacy and connection to our region, the Reading Terminal offers a unique atmosphere, endless freshly-prepared food options, and an "out of the box" experience, making it one the most desired event spaces in Philadelphia. An ideal option for a non-traditional wedding, corporate or social celebration!

Lots of good food here.
I cant help it, I'm a big fan of DiNic's roast pork sandwich.
Some friends were in town and we drove into Center City to prove to them why
 "Man vs. Food" voted them the best sandwich in America!

I love this place!! I am a huge fan of markets and this place a variety of stalls and small shops and bakeries. It was my first time coming here and I would definitely come here again. There are a lot of hidden food spots that I feel I've yet to discover. 

Reading Terminal Market is a mixture of a farmers market and a supermarket. There are flower shops, bakeries, grocery stalls, food stalls, drinks, and other knick knacks. I actually came here to meet up with some old high-school friends and it was the perfect spot. We came here around 3:00pm on a Friday afternoon; I saw high school students, college students, couples, kids and parents...this place is great for everyone! My friends and I were able to walk around and enjoy the different stores, get a drink, buy food,  sit down and eat, shop, etc. Reading Market is definitely a nice tourist spot and there are some very interesting things to see...and taste! For example, there is one stall that sells chocolate-covered onions. Not that its my sort of taste, but it isn't something you see everyday at your typical supermarket.

I'm sure there are a lot of people during noon time and dinner time, but it was not very crowded when I went during mid-afternoon. Definitely recommend coming here - whether to hang out or to visit as a tourist spot!

Man... it's not until you move away from a place when you ever regret taking it for granted.  I stopped in on my most recent pilgrimage back to Philly, and maybe I appreciated it more for what it is, but it was even more wonderful than I remember.  Although at the same time, it was exactly the same.

Fresh fruit and vegetables, termini brothers, denics, chocolatiers, books, linens, just everything you could want - and it's ALL good stuff.

I'm sorry Reading Terminal Market for taking you for granted when I lived in Philly and always going to Whole Foods.  You are the superior being.

One of my favorite places in Philly. I come here to buy my veggies, deli meats, bread and sweet treats. The amish have the bakeries on lock and make some of the most wonderful donuts, pies, and cakes! Their cheese and deli meats are always a million times better than anything you can get in a store and their prepared foods are great too! The 4 Seasons juice bar is amazing as well! Be careful coming around lunch time though-- this place gets mobbed!! Way too many people to enjoy your time-- you're better off coming mid morning or after lunch.

I can't believe this place.  This is foodie HEAVEN.

So basically, this is a huge terminal filled with different food vendors.  It ranges in everything from Thai food to Amish food to donuts to a bar to Cajun food to a candy shop to a butcher to a winery to ice cream to...well, you get the point.

If you are a food lover (and I suspect you are if you are on Yelp) and you are in the PA area this is a must do.  Yes, it was extremely crowded, but it was worth it.  There are so many delicacies to try and there is something for everyone here.

If you haven't been here and you're a Tourist you didn't visit Philadelphia
If you haven't been here an you LIVE in Philadelphia, you're a tourist!
Amazing food at every turn. Highly recommend Dinic's Roast Pork Sandwich!

You know it must be good when you drive two hours just to come here for lunch! Took the drive from Jersey just to go to Tommy Dinic's for their delicious pork, cheese, and broccoli rabe sandwich. It's a must when visiting!!! Went to BEILER's Donuts for dessert. These spongey, warm, delicious doughnuts will change your perspective on doughnuts. Expect a line that moves fast (don't be discouraged). It sure is worth it. Got a whole dozen to take home. Another yelper quoted this place as a foodie heaven. I'd have to second that!!

Uh excuse me why are you reading reviews? Do you really need to see the 100+ reviews stating this place is glorious? Because it really is glorious. Food on top of food on top of food. Delicious cakes, mouthwatering cuisine, awesome grocery items ranging from gigantic shrimp to produce, and just ... amazing. You can't go here and NOT buy at least something. I wish this place was closer but, alas ... it's a trip to go here. Not to mention it's CROWDED but this place is POPULAR so to be expected.

Do yourself a favor and hit this place up. You're not going to be disappointed. Well, you might be disappointed when you realize you can't buy every damn thing in the store but that will eventually fade.

Awesome! We hit the crepe place three days in a row and for breakfast crepes or dessert crepes they are amazing.  My husband and son had 3 plates or oysters and could not have been happier and the service was amazing.
We had so much fun here! Highly recommend food lovers sign up and take the tour. We learned a lot about the history of the market and got to sample some of the food as well!
Great indoor market for seafood, groceries, and meat.  Also have good food stands.....

Wicked cool!
What can I say that other reviewers have not?

This wonderful foodie landmark offers more options for a meal, grocery, and knick knacks than most small towns! Am I exaggerating? Come here and find out!

The market may be crowded, as I came here during lunchtime on a Sunday, but the bustle can be perceived to augment the atmospheric energy and excitement. 

I will be sure to come back on a Saturday instead, as more food vendors (particularly in the Pennsylvania Dutch section) are open. I have yet to find out what this "Apple Dumpling" is all about! ..Till next time - 5 stars!
There are too many good places inside to name.  Just go, sample a bunch, and be satisfied!  You won't be disapointed.

So many things to choose from!!!  I'm an indecisive person this place was great for me, I asked around for about an hour before deciding! (Don't judge)...this is my second time being here even tho I've lived in Philly my while life and I think this place just gets better and better every time. I ate at a place where the name escapes me at the moment but it was like a little soul food buffet and they weight it and ya pay, the fried chicken is amaze ballz!!!

I love this place. So many options. It has as many positives as it does negative. If you drive, just plan to park. Avoid Saturdays and Sundays if you can. Prepare for the amish to be closed whenever they want. BUT man, molly malloys, iovines, the fresh smoothie place, millers twists, flying monkey, all are worth the time and effort!

Everything you want in one place. Literally, a plethora of food and products all in one location. It is a great place to hangout with friends and for a meal. I haven't had a bad experience yet, except for looking for seating, but everything there is great.

I love Reading Market! I've worked close by and always enjoy dropping by. They have pretty much everything you can imagine here, though it can get a little confusing and overwhelming to navigate the stalls, especially on weekends when there's a large crowd. 
I especially like the selection of fruits and vegetables (although it's a little pricier than at the supermarket) - you can find some unusual selections to experiment with at home, which is great. Boiler's Donuts is great too - definitely try out their selection of homemade donuts, they're delicious!
What's really lovely about the Market is that even after being here several times, you can still wander around and discover new things every time. I'd recommend coming here just to browse around for a while, you'll be surprised by what you find!
This is the coolest part of Philly, especially when it's really cold out and you want to see a bunch of things indoors...i dont like being outside when the wind hurts my face.

Excellent cluster-bomb of a place with a little of everything for every taste.  The quality of the establishments here is pretty high.  It's a fantastic place to come and watch people while enjoying some good food.

I'm already looking forward to spring so that I can walk over and enjoy lunch here!

Great place to go. Have an idea of what you are in the mood for because making a decision on what to eat can be very over whelming. Have a solid game plan when entering. But always stop for a cookie from 4th st famous cookies.
love yourself and get a roast pork from dinic's and a donut (or 12) from beiler's. you will not be disappointed and you can thank me later.

WE go here when me and my friends go to the philly car show. This place is always packed. There are so many choices when it comes to food, from cold sandwiches, cheesesteaks, BBQ to tons of desserts. The market always seems to be pretty clean despite how many people are walking around. Seating is a huge issue, there is definitely not enough seating although some places inside do have private seating areas. I've had meals from a few different places in there which honestly I can't remember, the one place Dinic's stands out to me. They have a nice beef brisket, we get that a lot however, if you get there before 11am they will not serve you the brisket. We got their at 10:50 one day and they refused to take any orders for the brisket lol. All in all always enjoy going to there and trying something different, but not guaranteed to be able to sit and enjoy it lol.
Great place to grab a bite and and a pint! Got some real nice mozzarella cheese too!

Wow this place has a lot going on. There are so many shops to choose from and tons of options if you're hungry! Everything looked & smelled delicious. I tried the roast pork from dinic's and it was amazing! Grabbed some produce from Iovine's and it was all a great price. Also, I definitely recommend the cheesecake brownie from The Flying Monkey. It was so moist and yummy! The possibilities are endless here & there's something to please everyone. The center has the most traffic and can get a bit chaotic but the outside aisles were pretty easy to move through. You can't go wrong at Reading Terminal Market.
...I am absolutely obsessed with the Reading Terminal experience. I dare you to go in there for one or two things and not leave with 25 things!!

Overall I love reading. They have great groceries, amazing desserts, and random little stalls that offer everything from earrings to honey chapstick. I'll break this down more

Groceries: I go to reading terminal for groceries as much as I can. I've been able to find everything, and for cheaper/fresher, except for milk and pasta. I always get my fruits and vegetables from "ok produce." They generally sell berries for $.99 to $1.99, and small bags of eggplant, apples, mushrooms, cauliflower, etc. for the same price ($1-$2). I'll get two full bags of fruits and vegetables and spend less than $10. Produce is always a good buy as well. Whether I need mussels, oxtail, or chicken I'm always guaranteed to get a good buy (and with multiple fish and meat markets you can take your pick). 
There's also a spice/dry goods store that I LOVE. I buy loose leaf tea, spices, and lentils/other grains all the time. Again, super cheap and very varied.

Food: The food is just ok. It's cool that they have pretty much any type of food you might want, but it's definitely not the best quality. The Indian food is underwhelming and the flavors are never on point, Japanese food is American Japanese and again not that great, but the soul food is pretty good. I wouldn't go to reading for the soul food alone, but if I have to eat there that's usually what I'll get. I'd recommend getting groceries and snacks in reading, and then eating in chinatown. 

Snacks/dessert: Beilers donuts are fresh rolled and amazing, reading terminal has addictive cannolis, and any of the bakeries has great croissants and other baked goods. I come to reading purely for the cannolis when i get cravings

Variety in foods all over this place is great. Bakery bread good. I do like this place and have only found one place inside i dont like which is one of the chinese places which gave me the crappiest duck meat i have ever seen.
Great place to grab a bite to eat.  So many food choices!!! The only hard part is finding a place to sit!

My only complaint about Reading Terminal Market is that I can never decide where to eat, particularly when I'm really hungry (which, let's be real, is all the time). 

Is it a tourist trap? Maybe. Is it a fat kid's heaven? Yep. 

I've probably only sampled about a quarter of the total merchants within RTM, but I'm never disappointed. Not gonna lie though, some places are just average food-wise, but the charm of this place really makes up for average food in my mind. My personal recommendations are:
