Profi's Creperie
12th St Cantina
Dutch Eating Place 
The Original Turkey
Bassets Ice Cream

Also, the fresh produce/meats/cheeses/bakery products/flowers available for purchase here are all incredible. Definitely leave yourself enough time to wander the place after you've stuffed your face to full capacity.

I'm just going to be echoing what MANY other Yelpers have already said about this place, but I think it's worth a walk through if you happen to find yourself in Philadelphia. It's right in the heart of the city and there are so many food options here, you're bound to find something to please everybody here.

So far, I've tried doughnuts, ice cream, a sandwich, coffee, chocolate, and pretzels from here, and I've barely scratched the surface with that. I've never been to Pike Place Market out in Seattle, but I imagine this is like that (and both markets remind me of Chelsea Market Place in NYC).
I love this place.  We came bye after lunch and hit up the bakery counters.  Bought way to much and ate it all. Look forward to coming back.
Great place, A ton of things to do. Love going on rainy days.

This place is a foodie heaven! If you go...go hungry and carve out a couple of hours so you can meandor around and experience it all! I started at the far right side of the market where I got a directory and worked my way through. There are cheesesteaks (of course), seafood, pastries, soul food, Chinese, Cajun, Italian, Greek, cookies, fresh produce, flowers, fresh meat, and so much more.  There are several stands that cater to organic produce and dairy products as well. They also have stands that sell hand crafted soaps, chapsticks, specialty German items and everything in between. There probably isn't anything you can't find here. TIP!!! Parking in the city is not easy nor is it inexpensive. Park for $4.00 in one of these conveniently located garages:
11th & Arch Streets (Expert Parking)

12th & Filbert Streets (Parkway Garage)

With $10 purchase and merchant validation. Limit 2 hours. BE SURE TO GET YOUR PARKING TICKET AND RECEIPTS VALIDATED BEFORE YOU LEAVE THE MARKET!!! THE DISCOUNT IS NOT HONORED WITHOUT THE VALIDATION. 
If you find yourself in Phialdelphia, it is worth a trip to this market. If just for the history alone (this market has been around since 1892.)

I could spend hours in here! Very cool place with lots of interesting vendors. Mostly prepared foods, made to order foods, delis, specialty foods etc. So. much. food. 
The place was packed on a snowy Saturday so it made it hard to really wander and look at things. But we enjoyed Amish hot dogs and then wine at the winery!

Definitely need to come here if you are visiting Philly! It can be a little overwhelming, so if you're coming for lunch make sure you have an idea of what you want or you will be walking around for awhile.  I come here a lot to get groceries, really cheap produce.
Tons of options. I could eat here every day for the rest of my life and die a happy man.

A must see on any visit to Philly.  Abundance of food choices from Asian, to French, to Mexican and more.  Awesome corned beef sandwiches.  Candy. Cheese.  Ice cream!    If you are at 30th street or Suburban, it just just a 5min train - they are running every 5-10mins.   Don't miss!

Ashton Apartments on Wilshire has great service.  We actually never moved in, but the help we received from Alexandra Trudeau was incredible.  She answered all our questions and provided anything we asked for promptly.  She was friendly and so accommodating.  I highly recommend speaking to her if you are in the market for a luxurious place to live.

One word. LOVE. This is my happy place. You can't go wrong with so many of the gems housed under one roof. Everyone loves DeNics. No doubt. Roast Pork is amazing and they get the hype, but you can't go wrong with Martin's for meat, the Amish counter for breakfast. Molly's for a beer. I could go one and on.

Reading Terminal has every food you can possibly think of I'm not sure how you couldn't like it. If you are looking to try foods from other cultures or just plain old comfort food you will be right at home. The best place to go to get a feel for the Philadelphia culture and a nice place for yourself or the whole family.
Great selection of Amish sweets! I esp love the ice cream and cookies. Another must go is the Cajun counter. Their bread pudding is to die for!

WOW!!! this place has it all foods from all over the place true Cajun foods with gator meat and whole ducks and produce and shopping why go anywhere else when all the fun is here at Reeding? the gals and I has a blast shopping and tasting all kinds of yummy foods. there was one down fall a few of the vendors only took cash so there was an atm there to extract cash but of course there was a fee... I could have gotten my sweets with that fee and the other down fall was the one place I went to try a philly cheese steak was awful and there was no extras like pickles there was a little entertainment there when we went on Feb 21-22 and that was neat but steer clear of the attitudes some of the vendors have all in all a fun place to spend a day

It doesn't get better than having hundreds of merchants across a variety of cuisines that include restaurants, bakeries, confectioneries and produce stores, all under one roof. Expect to get everything from fresh produce, meats, fish, artisan cheese, groceries, ice cream, flowers, grilled cheese, baked goods, crafts, books, clothing, and specialty and ethnic foods. 

Fun fact: According to Wikipedia, three of the vendors today are descendants of original market merchants from 1859.

Reading Terminal Market can draw large crowds during the weekends, so avoid the lunch hour and other busy times. 

This place is like an endless maze with a new surprise at every corner. My favorite is  Beiler's Donuts that always has a long line, but it moves fast and you get to see them make the donuts from scratch while you wait.

I am certainly repeating what other have said about this place, but I will share my experience. We love the terminal. It's a great place to bring people who are new to Philly and get an exciting and bustling experience. Lots to see. LOTS to eat. 

We have eaten at many of the vendors. You really can't go wrong with any. We loved the Amish doughnuts. Overall, fun place to swing through on your tour of downtown Philly. Eat it!

The Reading Terminal Market is by far the best spot for any food geek. Especially if you're a yelper this is spot to go. 

They have so much of the best and top quality food around. From, donuts to hoagies, cheesesteaks, coffee, seafood, name it they have it, 

If are a local or not. When you are down in the city. Take time to come hear. You will walk out with something for left overs and happy you came. Always try to leave with a cup of coffee from any coffee shop in the terminal is good and strong. And leave out with half dozen Donuts, you will never want to eat another donut esle where after you try them at the Reading Terminal. 

Tommy Dinic's for roast pork, Carmen's if you want alsome cheese steak. Hershels if you're looking to get a good pastrami sandwich,  Beiler's Bakery for the Donuts, Dutch eating place are you looking for some good breakfast, 

Just make sure when you come here you come with an empty stomach cuz you're going to need it!!! 

And the best of luck trying to find that one spot you want to eat at because it's tough to just choose one place!!

Despite the tourists looking for terrible diners to eat at, this place is pretty amazing.

This is the best place to grocery shop in the city. Period.
 My "go to" places:

Produce: Iovines
Meats: Giuntas Prime Shop is my favorite, but Lancaster County Meats has a great selection (sometimes better) and Martin's meats is where to go for flank steaks or whole hams and turkeys.
Food: Herschel's East Side Deli (pastrami) OR Hatville Deli (corned beef)
Donuts and Pickles - Beilers. for Salted caramel donuts and horseradish dill pickles.

Can we talk about food heaven?

It doesn't get better than the RED-ing Terminal. Yes, spelled reading, pronounced reding. This place has just about everything you can imagine. From produce, to bakeries, to seafood. If you want it, the Reading Terminal probably had it. When I visited Philadelphia I tried to eat here as many times as I possibly could. The only downfall is that it gets insanely packed. One time I visited was a Saturday around 3pm and I could hardly move around. I chose the place closest to me to eat because I could not stand being around so many people. Other than that, this place is amazing and I highly recommend it.
This is an awesome place to explore, especially for foodies. Seems like a simple place but you'll spend a minimum of an hour to navigate through.

Who needs those fancy "bulk up fast" products when you can just spend 30 minutes in Reading Terminal! I came out nearly 6 pounds heavier. If I can see these kinds of results, anyone can!

Believe in yourself.

I love the Reading Terminal! It's too bad I'm not a local because I would eat there every day if I lived in Philly. How do I even describe this place? It's like an indoor farmer's market-ish place. Everything you could ever want food-wise can be found here. My mother-in-law took me to buy produce and deli meats, but we also ended up stopping by for some awesome sandwiches, Italian food and hoagies. (We were abnormally hungry that day, apparently.)

There are literally so many food options, you'll have a tough time deciding because everything is displayed right in front of you and the smells are absolutely incredible. Before we left, we bought some homemade pastries made by the Amish (which were way better than anything I've ever baked in my life).

Such a cool experience. People milling around everywhere. Vibe is busy and fun. People were playing live music. Excellent place to go for tourists and locals alike.
This is something that I will miss very much, when I return to Miami. This was like being in the nineteenth century. Found great original restaurant and a fantastic coffee place.
Amazing variety of high-quality, fresh, delicious food. I always bring my out of town friends here.

Wonderful hub for a diverse array of tasty eats. With a scene like this it's not just the food, it's the ambience and the experience that leave a mark. Depending upon time of day, it can be suffocating and a little too much for some. There's always an opportunity to meet other people from different walks of life and make a new friend, as this is a great forum to ask others for their favorites.

I recommend coming early in the day and or at an odd meal hour with family or a friend who can appreciate the fun of shopping around and picking the highlights that catch your eye on a given day. Too many delicious things to pick from, definitely a frequent visit for me and a memorable pit stop in the city.

Wow this place is amazing!!  If you visit Philly this place is a must.  The variety and quality of food will blow your mind. My wife and I have visited two day in a row and will probably go back tomorrow:)
I'm born and raised in Philly and Reading Terminal is by far the best place to experience all the taste in Pennsylvania  and food from all over the world...

Absolutely ANYTHING you can think of is here. Want some fresh ice cream? Got it. How about Thanksgiving dinner? Check. Homemade honey? Yep. Even a book to read while lunching? They even have a little book store.
I grew up in Philly so I'm used to Reading Term but I never realized how cool it actually is until friends not from here ask me to take them on a tour here. So I guess I'm a lucky duck for knowing this place inside and out.
I love reading terminal market! I always bring guests here when they visit Philly! I just wish they were open later.
It's like all 5 continents under one roof- simply amazing!

This is a great location to go to experience a little bit of everything. From delicious bakeries to meat markets reading terminal has a fantastic selection. There are tables available  to sit and eat or just enjoy the passerby-ers. They not only have a wide food selection but also a other nick-knacks and shops.

How can you not love the Reading Terminal Market?  The sights, the smells, the people, the goodies.  I've been coming here since I was a teen in the early 80's.  It has changed quite a bit since then but the vibe is still the same.  
I love it!

Neat place with a dingy feel. I bring friends here for the experience (much like Quincy Market in Boston), but I don't go often myself. I don't care for the atmosphere (always overly crowded and wayyy to many competing smells) but when I do go, the Soul Food spot never disappoints. Huge portions, delicious menu, friendly staff.
So worth the long lines. Go early to avoid them. They seek everything and the fruit is really cheap.

I love it here....truly a local jewel in our crown. It is crowded, large, at times overwhelming, but still perfect. The people watching is great, it always seems to have a great combo of tourists and locals. But the food....there is something for everyone. I could wander around here for hours on end. We are lucky to have this place!

Yup, came as a tourist and loved it. I love markets like this. My only gripe is that it's tight and you can get lost....lol I would have loved a map of all of the stalls and restaurants. But in any case, the food is fresh and the selection of eateries is pretty astonishing. I'm sure their is some historical significance mumbojumbo, but really it's just a large market with great food and also some random gifts/goods too.

It's pretty touristy sometimes, but it has great things in it, like the Flying Monkey Bakery that makes super delicious desserts, the Amish juice shop that has great natural juices (including Victory Thirst Clincher), the Amish rib place that'll give you a super rib sandwich/potato wedges/mac n' cheese and soda combo for under $10 that's usually my meal of choice from this place...and some places like Dinic's that have gotten national attention for how good they are.  It's a pretty neat place, def a place to visit if you're not from around Philly.

This is in an indoor market place with many variety. From bakeries, seafood, Italian food, and much much more!! Reading market can be extremely crowded during lunch time. Very popular place for tourist and locals to buy food and other grocery produce.

This place was heaven. So many variety of food in such a compact area. The only problem is that there are so many people here during lunch hours. That and the fact that it closes early than I'm used to. There is such a diverse range of food that I'm pretty sure you can find what you want just by walking around for 15 minutes. Chinese, cajun, soul food, BBQ, dessert, breakfast, candy, groceries, there is just so much to this little terminal. There is also a seating area that had a piano and live music. It was very cute.

I think Reading Terminal is great, as long as you are prepared for what's in store. Long lines and huge crowds! The food I have tried is always worth the wait and I love the mini market in there, fresh vegetables for reasonable prices! Must see for tourists!
So many good places to either eat or buy food. DeNic's has the best Pork and Roast Beef Sandwiches. Martin's Meats is by far the best for home Sausage! No one in the City comes close!

It's the jackpot of food and drink!

Juices, fresh made Philly pretzels, pizzas, ice cream, smoothies, cupcakes, whoopie pies, cookies, bread, candy, beef jerky, a Garden of Eden of fruits and vegetables, pasta, fresh fish and shell fish,Philly cheese steaks, gyros, Mexican food, any ethnic food you can think of, teas, coffees, grocery staples, cheese, gourmet foods, a soul food cafeteria, Amish food, it just goes on and on.    

The building used to be the Reading Train terminal.  It's close to 80,000 square feet jam packed with hundreds of vendors.

We were there on Saturday, it was overflowing with customers. 

What a cool place.

It is always a pleasure to go there. Tons of colors, flavors, aromas. Best espresso, bread and soft pretzels in town, among many other "bests". It is difficult to sit, especially groups, but the waiting time is minimal. Then you have the history of the place itself, right below a former iconic train station. A must see and experience in Philly.

Love this place. A true Philadelphia original. I've been going to this market since I was a child in the sixties, and it still has that wonderful charm. How many places can say that today? From the best in baked goods and confections, to the freshest meat, fish, and produce, you can hardly go wrong shopping here. Also a great lunch spot!

I love this place. I was in Philly for a conference across the street at the Convention Center and I literally ate breakfast and lunch here for three days straight. It was so convenient to just cross the street and grab a quick bite to eat. There's also SO MANY options to choose from. You can have Chinese, Italian, Mexican, Cajun, American, and so much more! 

My favorite places were the Dutch Eating Place and Smucker's. Their portion sizes are so big that you almost can't even finish it all! 

I also love all the Amish stands in the Market - their breads and candies are so good that I brought some to bring back to NYC with me. Everything is super affordable too!

I love all the variety you can find here. However, it is ALWAYS so crowded that it diminishes my enjoyment. I end up feeling overwhelmed and like I just need to make a choice, quick. Finding seating to eat, especially if you aren't alone, kinda sucks.

You can find just about anything to eat in this place. From Amish products to fried onion rings! 

They had so much I tried nothing lol. I felt a bit overwhelmed and being in a diet doesn't help! They had some yummy looking donuts that I wanted to buy :( but didn't. The bad part about this place is the parking and sitting! 

Oh boy, it's a race to get a table with chair. This place is on the middle of China town and the penn station. 

It's a must stop in your tour of Philly!

Although it can get crowded, it's a good one-stop grocery shopping for me.  I much rather support these vendors than the big corps.  If you're going on the weekend, just make sure to get there early for the best picks, plus it isn't as crowded.  The lot across the street is a good place to park, just make sure you get your ticket validated by one of the vendors.

Without a doubt one of my favorite places in Philly. Real food, sold by real people. We do most of our weekly grocery shopping  here, which has freed us from nasty mainstream supermarket chains. In addition, it's a terrific breakfast and lunch place; I'm lucky enough to work within walking distance, so I can come several times per week and never have the same thing twice. The vendors are super-friendly and helpful. If you're a foodie, this is your natural home.

Talk about busy!!!  A group of us went to the Flower Show, and ventured across the street for lunch.  We could barely walk, it was so crowded.  After finally depening on a place to eat, (DiNic's), we got in line, and it didn't take long to find seats and order.  Fast, good, enjoyable, with great atmosphere.  Don't go if you want quiet ambiance!

My boyfriend was raving about this place and we finally took the trip to Philadelphia and check this place out. It was a food haven for foodies. I was overwhelmed with all the options of deliciousness. We had a roasted pork sandwich with provolone and broccoli rabe which was just amazing and a burger with roasted mushroom, onion in the delicious sauce with a side of lobster macaroni and cheese. So amazing. Don't forget to stop and get some chocolate covered Oreos and chocolate covered strawberries.

Overall, I love this place! It's packed with a HUGE variety of places to eat and drink and has pretty good food-although I wouldn't come here to get my philly cheesesteak.  The downsides to Reading Terminal Market are: 1) how packed it can get--it can feel a little overwhelming when you just want to go in and grab a grilled cheese sandwich and sit down when there are throngs of people trying to do the same thing; 2) how rude some of the employees can be--it feels like they assume that everyone who is a customer sucks because they are probably a tourist and it's annoying to have to explain to customers where to stand/etc. However, it's still a great place to grab a cup of coffee or lunch and there are a LOT of options.
just a great place to tease your hunger. everything is good.

Great place, but if you're in a hurry to get lunch avoid getting there sometime between 11 and 1. I love the atmosphere and almost everything I've tried there, but I especially love the ice cream and doughnuts.

GO! I dream about the pretzels and donuts
I ate here while in the city visiting my sister. What I would give for one of those pretzels right now!!

Also, we saw Usher walking around the market while we were there! Such a Fun spot.

this place is heaven on earth , you can literally find everything you need here.
if you love food , you should make it a point to go there.
Great food and selection. The reasons for a 3-star rating are the overly expensive parking and the crowds! Wow, too crowded for my taste. Will not return any time soon.
Where to start? There are so many things to chose from. My favorite is Herschel's. Some of the best corned beef and pastrami around.
A wide variety of food that will literally cure any and every craving!
Great food options and many different vendors to look at. Donut line gets crowded though!

This place is around the corner from where we are staying in Philly.  You can find pretty much anything here...mediterranean, indian, mexican, burgers, and MUCH more!  It's perfect for traveling with 2 kids because we can all get what we want :)  I wasn't so impressed with my salad from Hunger Burger, but I guess that's what I get for ordering a salad from a burger joint...it was pretty soggy and didn't have alot of tang, like most mediterranean salads do.  The grilled cheese sandwiches from MeltKraft were super scrumptious though...you can even add bacon to them, yum!

Ok spot for the area. Always something to try to catch the experience of while it town but avoid the main food times; breakfast, luch, dinner hours. Try to go off the main clock hours as it can be a very busy, crowded place and much overwhelming if you have never been. 

Plenty to choose from bit some spots that are listed with great ratings of course have lines you will need to be prepared to wait it.  They do tend to move quickly and the staff at each place is well adapted to the crowds and rush. All 4 places we visited were pleasant,  quick and the food was good.  Seating is scarce but there is some places that have counter seating. And there is a larger area that has multiple tables but again just not really a sitting type place due to the crowd.  An order and go place.
It's worth it just to get the Basset's ice cream.  Go early on a Saturday and you will have the place to yourself (almost).
My favorite place to by foodstuffs in Philly. Go during off hours (weekdays not during lunch) for the best experience.

I have a like dislike relationship with RTM. 
The like part all the vendors under one roof. It's a one stop shop for most of your food needs. The diversity is great. The friendly service.
My dislikes the messiness of the place, it's a major turn off for me to stay & eat there.  I usually take my food to go.  It's a major tourist trap especially on weekends. I avoid it then too many crowds & it looks like a tornado hit the place.
I do think you should go at least once and experience the place.  If cleanliness is a problem for you too just take your stuff to go. I go about once a year and that's enough for me, usually it's b/c we have company that wants to check it out.

Reading Terminal Market is an amazing destination in Philly.  There are tons of vendors, something for everyone.

Be prepared for crowds.  

A place to return again, and again, and again.  Definitely a must-see location if visiting the convention center, or Center City Philadelphia.
I love this awesome place. you can easily find something that suits your appetite. Especially try Philly Cheesesteaks which is identified with Philly.
Always an adventure...whether you want a meal, or flowers, or great pastries!  This is a must experience.

I've been to a lot of public markets - Pikes in Seattle, Fishermans Wharf in SF, Fanieul Hall in Boston; but the Reading Terminal Market is the best. 

Huge, diverse, overloading your senses with sights, sounds, crowds, smells and the atmosphere of dynamic human engagement. 

It's a combination of food courts/restaurant, food vendors of all types - fishmongers, picklers, chocolates; and assorted bric a brac. 

It's fun and lively. Good place to take the family. Lots of locals there mixed with the tourists. 

Highly recommend it!

Now, how can you not love the Reading Terminal Market? I work as a tour guide in city, and love bringing tourists to this Philadelphia gem. They are always overwhelmed by the sights, sounds and above all the smells as soon as they walk in (I always bring them in through the Amish bakery section by the northwest door for full effect). The food and goods are all local-not a national chain store in the place. Whether you're visiting Philadelphia, or or a long time resident as I am, do NOT miss the Reading Terminal Market experience.

This is such a fantastic place--I love going here!  Smucker's for their sandwiches, the Dutch Eating Place for pancakes, the candy shop which also sells dried fruit, even the bookstore at Reading Terminal is worth visiting... Wear comfortable shoes and get ready for crowds-- however--unless you visit during off-hours.

This was my first time there and I came here with my husband. It is truly a wonderful place for foodies. Hands-down they have everything you could ever dream of. We started off at:

-Tommy diNic's - pulled pork sub with Sharp provolone and broccoli Rabe. One sub sandwich feeds two people. Trust me!

-Beilers Bakery - apple fritters hot out of the oven and made with love. A little too sweet for me. Wasn't our favorite. 

-Termini Brothers - cheese cake - imho, too heavy. Don't waste your $ on this one. 

-Beck's Cajun Cafe - their gumbo was peppery spicy and it's not due to the sausage or anything. Disappointed. 

-Flying Monkey Bakery - Whoopie Pie. This was truly worth the wait! They use real cream.

-Old City Coffee - now that's good to the last drop! Needed a coffee fix and refused to have my coffee anywhere else thanks to my many fellow yelpers advice. 

Will definitely return. I want to try Millers Twist, Molly Malloy's, Famous 4th Street Cookie Co., & my coffee place: Old City Coffee.

A must see in Philly. The markets inside are so fun to go through, the food is awesome, such a huge variety. The amish donuts are out of this world, always hot and fresh!! I can't wait to go back, we go once a day while we're visiting, and grab all the fresh fruits and veggies we can before we go back to NYC!

I love public markets and so Reading Terminal Market was a must-do on my visit to Philadelphia. RTM is a huge public market with a lot of vendors - there are an overwhelming amount of options! From fresh produce, to seafood, to meat, to cheese, you can get almost anything here! You can get pastries, coffee, tea, ice cream,  Pennsylvania Dutch, Chinese, Thai, Mexican, Cajun, burgers, cheesesteaks, and more! There's even an oyster bar inside. Great variety! 

Stopped in at lunchtime on a weekday and the place was just packed with people everywhere. No surprise that it's a popular stop for locals and tourists to get some lunch. The line at Beiler's Donuts was the longest, as was the line for Hershel's East Side Deli. There are communal seating areas, but at lunchtime the tables were filled. I came back the next day early in the morning and while not everything was open, there were definitely less people and less chaotic. 

What I was most interested in was the Pennsylvania Dutch businesses. There's a sign by the Dutch Eating Place that says the hours for the Pennsylvania Dutch merchants being Tuesday or Wednesday through Saturday, closing up at 3PM on Tuesdays and Wednesdays and closing up at 5PM Thursdays, Fridays, and Saturdays. But I was there on a Monday and Beiler's was definitely in operation, though Dutch Eating Place was closed. Aside from Beiler's and the Dutch Eating Place, there's also Miller Twist that has soft pretzels and ice cream, and Riehl's which has cheeses, and Smuckers which supposedly is famous for their pot roast sandwiches. Other Pennsylvania Dutch vendors sell crafts and jams and honey. I returned the following day on a Tuesday to eat at Dutch Eating Place (separate review). 

Overall, RTM is a fun place to visit and a great option if you're not sure what you want to eat - there's bound to be something you're craving if you walk around long enough. I tried tea from the Tea Leaf, tea from Old City Coffee, ice cream from Bassetts, jambalaya from Beck's Cajun Cafe, a donut from Beiler's, a soft pretzel from Miller's Twist, and breakfast from Dutch Eating Place. Wish I stayed in Philly longer, so I could've tried even more stuff!

I love this place! It's a great indoor shopping area with tons of little shops and food places to go to. Can be crowded on the weekends and during lunchtime so seating is difficult to find sometimes.

My favorites: The ice cream shop with Bassett's ice cream is to die for, and I love to get my produce at Iovine bros. There is also a honey shop with raw honey that might be the best honey I have ever tasted. Check out the Amish store for amazing dairy products.

DiNic's and Spataros are a couple of great hoagie places if you are in the mood for a substantial lunch. Definitely check this place out whether you live in the city or are just passing through.

There were sooooo many options and I had the hungry burger and it was DELICIOUSSS! And I show a donut shop that had the most appetizing donuts I've ever seen! Like maple bacon and there were many other options of food as well! So I definitely recommend, was a bit crowdy but it was worth it!

One of my favorite places. Discounted parking with validation in specific parking ramps - make sure you keep the receipts from locations you stop at. I will say this place can get really cramped/busy especially weekends. I love Hershel's Deli, Beliers Pickle patch, donuts and Baked goods. My husband loves Carmine's cheese steaks and DiNics pork sandwiches.  They have some sit down restaurants I haven't tried.
Just a really incredible experience with food, but very crowded!
There is no place like Reading Terminal Market! It's where you can go to find anything you could possibly want to eat. Not to mention delicious doughnuts!

This place is certainly hustling and bustling! Expect lines at peak hours for sure.

There are so many vendors here. You want fresh bread? Someone has it? Meats? Sweets? Check and double check. Produce and fish? As you wish!

Honestly if you are visiting Philly or live there, you owe it to yourself to check out this market.

Way too crowded with vendors and in a mostly disorganized fashion.  Not the cleanest/sanitary place to be.  Hunger Burger had terrible service.  Cheesesteaks at By George were good and the service was good.  Pike Street Market in Seattle is quite a bit more comfortable and interesting.  Quincy Market in Boston way outshines both.
probably getting a little too touristy and expensive but still great hopefully will not get back to the way it was

Truly a hustling, bustling foodie heaven! A must-see if you are visiting Philly. I really love the energy and overall vibe here. With that said, there are so many promising eateries with crazy long lines, it's easy to get overwhelmed when you walk in. 

Best method is to 1) come with equally eager companions 2) divide and conquer. 

Have your friends/family stand in different lines and buy a little bit of something from multiple places so that you can maximize the foods you try :) Don't forget to bring cash!

Beck's Cajun Café: 
* Bourbon St. Breakfast is red beans & rice, fried egg, cheese, and grilled corn bread. This is a working man's breakfast providing you with the carbs and protein to get you through the morning until lunch. The sausage and eggs were just the perfect breakfast and the rest just reminded me of New Orleans. Rating: 5/5
* Breakfast Po Boy is a French baguette with choice of fried eggs, melted cheese, andouille sausage, turkey sausage, or ham. These were the perfect sandwiches with just the right amount of bread to fillings. The turkey sausage had a light texture but flavorful. The Andouille sausage reminded me of a Hawaiian Portuguese sausage and eggs breakfast. I was in heaven! Rating: 5/5
* Beignets (served on Sundays and Wednesdays) are French doughnuts/fritters served hot and topped with confectioners' sugar. Beck's makes the most authentic beignets outside of Louisiana. They have a beautiful golden brown crust and just the right consistency inside, not too dense and not too fluffy. If you've eaten beignets at Café du Monde in New Orleans, you will absolutely love these! Rating: 5/5
* Chicken and Andouille Gumbo is something my mom had to try. She loves gumbo and is certain this gumbo was made with love. The color is dark with the vegetables cooked down to their essence to flavor the gumbo base. The chicken and sausage add the meaty texture and flavor to the mix. Rating: 4.5/5
* The Alligator Sausage Po Boy is topped with caramelized onion, peppers, and creole mustard. The alligator sausage is mild and lends itself well to the sweet flavor of the peppers and onions and the robust creole mustard. Rating: 4.5/5
* Fried Oyster Platter is served with corn bread and choice of red beans & rice, white rice, or Cajun fries. The oysters were meaty and fried to a perfect golden brown with crispy outside and slightly briny and creamy on the inside. The red beans & rice was fantastic with nice pieces of sausage. Rating: 5/5
* Muffaletta is salami, ham, mortadella, sharp provolone, and olive salad served on Italian bread. My husband and I used to make this sandwich every day at Café Orleans in Disneyland. Beck's version was much better as there is more meat and cheese and they sandwich the olive salad between the meats which keeps the bread from getting soggy. We took these with us to the airport to enjoy before our return flight. The flavors of the different meats is just amazing and the olive salad had just the right amount of acidity to bring the sandwich together. The bread was very rustic with crunchy outside and tender yet chewy inside. Rating: 5/5

Beiler's Bakery: 
* Apple Snitz Fry Pie is reminiscent of the Hostess handheld pies but tastes more homemade with a buttery crust and slow-cooked apple pie filling. They only make them on certain days so if you see them, buy a bunch. We missed our chance to load up before we headed back home. Rating: 5/5
* Chocolate Whoopie Pie looks like a mini flying saucer with chocolate cake on the outside with frosting in the middle. The chocolate cake was marvelous with rich chocolate flavor and soft, spongy texture. The frosting in the middle was fluffy, creamy, and not overly sweet. They were so good, we brought a dozen home with us. Rating: 5/5

Salumeria: They had beautiful French pates, cheeses, and meats. We picked up some imported prosciutto, capicola, Swiss, and provolone to make picnic sandwiches in the hotel room for lunch. The prosciutto had a grassy essence blended with the aroma of aged cheese. The closest taste and texture comparison upon eating some is that it's like butter with a salty porkiness and almost obscene. Unfortunately, my work day had not yet ended or I would have enjoyed a glass of Rosé to complete the food experience. Rating: 5/5

Dutch Eating Place is a diner of sorts serving breakfast and lunch next to Beiler's Bakery. Since seeing Andrew Zimmern making and tasting scrapple, I had to have some. Dutch Eating Place served a Scrapple and Egg breakfast. I was so excited to finally try it and it was wonderful! If you like pork and liver, you'll love this. It is pork scraps mixed with cornmeal, wheat flour, and spices, like a savory pork cake. It fries up really well with a crispy outside and almost pate-like texture inside. Every meat vendor in Reading Terminal Market sold variations with pork, beef, and even turkey. Again, I wish I had a refrigerator in my room so I could have brought some back with us. Rating: 5/5

Miller's Twist serves up hand-rolled Amish-style hot buttered pretzels. Man vs. Food's Adam Richman stopped by during his visit of Reading Terminal Market. You can watch as they roll and artfully twist pretzels. They also wind these beautiful pretzels around full size and mini hot dogs. The pretzel is golden brown with a beautiful glaze on the outside. The interior is chewy and works well with the hot dog. The mini dogs are two-biter and perfect to share as a snack. Rating: 5/5

THIS PLACE IS AMAZING!!! I loved being a tourist here, and just walking around discovering all the places inside. Foodie heaven! Loved the Amish bakeries, freshly mad donuts and cookies, and sandwiches. Wish I lived close so I could do my weekly shopping here! 

It is literally everything you could want in an indoor market. I went there 2 days in a row and left still feeling like I needed at least a few more days to experience more meals. Only tried it for lunch, and wish we had tried breakfast too!
Something for everyone! Check out the maps and reviews in advance so you don't get overwhelmed. You can easily walk by some amazing food and vendors!

finally made it to this place!!! my friend and i had a pho date in chinatown and passed by on our ways back to my car...slight detour...but omg i love this place! too bad my friend and i were stuffed because there were so many delicious options. i DID walk out with some great produce for cheap and beautiful handmade soaps during this trip though. i will def be going back soon to try all the other wonderful goodies!!!

parking is tough so def recommend public transportation. it's a fun place tho so have fun!!!
Fun place to be, all the commotion gives you a nice philly feel and the food options here are amazing. It is hard to pick from just one place

This is the heaven of every food lover. You can find anything you crave. The prices at the restaurants are very reasonable and the wait lines aren't bad and the service is always quick. Make sure you try some of the deserts as well.

This place is freaking awesome. I only wish there is something like this in New  York. The lines move quickly. It is crowed. But how convenient to have good food all in one location. Many, many options to choose from. My favorite was the pork and broccoli rabe sandwich from danic's. and Bassett's ice cream. There are many booths for grocery shopping aside from cooked food.

This is a great place for a goodie, lots of food stuffed into a small space. If you are in Philly you will definitely want to stop by and check it out. Every type of food and produce market. This place is always busy so there is no special time that would be best, just go when you are hungry

Fun stop for lunch. Hop off the bus here. We, two people, ate at 4 different places consuming a Philly cheese steak (we got the wrong order but somehow it was still OK), a savory crepe, fresh squeezed juice and ice cream. Lunch was great! I think that even locals like choosing this place for the lunch but do be aware that there's nowhere without a 15 minutes line. I mean the lines move but still you're going to be in the line for a while. It's a great place to sample some real Philadelphia food.

Donuts, beer jerky, breakfast, lunch, sea food anybody? This place has it all.  Came here in the morning and started of with a great eggs and pancakes breakfast. Waited in line for fresh Beriler's donuts which were delicious. Walked around some more and found probably the best beef jerky ive ever had sold by the amish.  Its like a mall of all kinds of different food. Really cool place and cant wait to come back.
Reading terminal is great. I love a good indoor market with tons of shops carrying specialty items, and baked goods to eat while you walk around.

This little piggy went to market,
This little piggy definitely didn't stay home,
This little piggy had roast beef and a bunch of other crap to,
This little piggy had none (what an idiot),
And this little piggy cried wee wee wee all the way home because they were full as shit after eating non-stop for over an hour.

This place is seriously dope.  It reminds me of faneuil hall marketplace in Boston except it is a legit market with local vendors where you can get everything from produce to baked goods as opposed to just being a giant food court. I mean they have that too but at least they can legitimately call themselves a market.

My biggest advice is buy stuff from anyone who looks remotely amish.  Their baked goods are incredible.  Sticky buns and pecan pie that I had there has me salivating right now thinking about it.

Also 2 hour parking for $4 with validation from a vendor here.  Go to the website for specifics.  But how awesome is that?

Downside?  Crowded as all hell.  Be prepared to throw elbows, shoulders, and dropkicks or be really quick on your feet in order to get a table to sit at.

Reading Terminal Market really is such a fun place to check out and definitely worth visiting when in the city of Brotherly Love. I loved its convenient location and proximity to so many other city attractions (including the Greyhound bus station for those just here for the day) and with about 100 different vendors all under one roof, it's difficult to get bored. 

Looking to get your ice cream fix? Look no further than America's oldest ice cream company, Bassetts (I still dream about their strawberry ice cream). Wanna get the whoopie pie crowned the best of Philly? Flying Monkey is your stop. Have a craving for Thai food? Little Thai Market is what you're looking for. And the list goes on! 

Everyone that I met there was so friendly and helpful and coming from NYC, the land of the overpriced, I was often shocked by just how affordable things were. The one downside is that it closed so early (at 6pm) and I think it definitely is a place that would still be packed late into the evening. 

It is truly a haven for all things cooking, food, crafting, and so much more! So next time you're in Philly, definitely make sure you give this place a visit, you definitely won't be disappointed.

So hard to come here and not want to eat everything!!! Should probably come with a friend or two, so you can try every stall and split everything. Absolutely insanity with the line-ups to the popular spots (ie. Dinic's) during Saturday lunch hour...or maybe even all day? 

If you have an entire day to eat, you should probably come here.

Very cool place with an assortment of stores and restaurants. Some of the things you can do... buy groceries or fresh produce, eat fried chicken or Chinese food or blueberry pancakes, buy chocolates and candies, get coffee and cookies. It didn't take too long to walk around the entirety of RT, so if you have some time to spare (15~20 min) check it out and buy some goodies.

For starters, this place is overwhelming.  With that being said, you need a plan of attack before purchasing any food.  Please take this as a warning that if you buy something to eat at the first place you come across, you will be upset because the next place you come across will be even better than the first and it's an endless cycle.  My advice: Do a dry run of the places so you know where you would like to dine.  I started out with an roasted pork sandwich for Dinics.  The line wrapped around the counter, but it was worth it.  The sandwich was HUGE!  I then saw people walking around with ice cream and knew that was what I had to head to next.  We stopped at Lancaster County Dairy.  I had one of their specialty ice creams which was coffee ice cream with peanut butter cups in it.  Mmm!  Seating is kind of scarce, but people didn't seem to hang around for too long after eating, so you will eventually find a place to sit down and enjoy whatever you purchased.
Fun place for a tourist to visit for lunch or a snack.  My kids loved the donuts at Beiler's bakery.
Great selection and good variety of different foods and flavors. Highly recommend if you are in the center city area.
Great place to eat and shop.  Just beware of busy times.  It totaly sucks when its overcrowded.  Check that local activitys befor making the trip.
Amazed at the selection and high quality throughout..  I have travelled to other areas that claim to have great market food courts but none is better than here in Philadelphia's Terminal Market

I LOVE it there!!! So hard to make food decisions here!

Beck's Cajun Cafe - Po Boys, Jambalaya, and Fried Mac and Cheese Balls

The Original Turkey - grilled turkey Ruben sandwich

Whoopie Pies from Flying Monkey

Grilled Cheese from Melt Kraft

Lemonades from the Amish Stands

Cookies from Termini Brothers

LOVE EVERYTHING!!!

It definitely gets crowded here during holidays, lunch time, and weekends so plan accordingly and be patient!

Fantastic! Huge variety of foods and artisan wares to get! I went on a Saturday afternoon around 4 or 5pm and this place was bustling but not too crowded. As most people do, I waited on the pretty fast line to try a roast pork sandwich from Dinic's since their hand carved Italian pulled pork was gone. That was delicious and I will be writing a separate review on their own yelp account. Like I said, there were so many choices and delicious looking and smelling dessert/bake shops to try from. Finding seats was not difficult even for the group of 6 we were.

What could I possibly say that hasn't already been said? This place is an institution - a gem - a must. There are too many choices - smells that are enticing to your senses - visual displays of foods and people so colorful I found myself just wanting to stand still in the middle of it all and take it in - but the crowd doesn't allow for pauses - you have to roll with it. If you take too long trying to decide what you want it's almost certain something else will catch your eye and you'll be on to the next thing.

Enjoy this place - it's special.
If you're visiting Philly and you'd like to see/eat/visit someplace awesome and local, come here! It gets crowded at times but it's worth the trip. A Philadelphia institution indeed.
Excellent market for all things foodie and beyond. Had breakfast in the diner inside. Felt I had to try "scrapple" - worst thing I ever tasted, but I guess you have to try everything once!

My favorite place to eat in Philly when visiting my girlfriend.

1) Pretzels from Miller's Twist are a must. Don't forget the spicy mustard!

2) Iced and green tea from the leaf tea stand is amazing

3) DiNic's is ovverrated, it's good but don't expect anything extraordinary...certainly not the "best sandwich in America"

4) Still looking for a good pizza place though.....

I love this place! On both of my trips to NYC from the west coast, I had to take the 2-hour bus ride to Philly to visit Reading Terminal Market. There is so much to eat, buy, and see here.

During the winter, there's not much to do outdoors. After visiting Love Park, my friends and I spent a couple hours at the market. It's warm inside and there is so much to explore. During the fall, there's much more to do and see outdoors, but I still spent at least 2 hours here. It's a great place to find things to take home with you - everything in one place.

I highly recommend trying the hand-rolled donuts!!! I should have bought 5 dozens when I was there...no joke. Sang Kee Duck House is also delicious.

I know there is EVIL in this world because this place is too close to my job!!  I want to eat breakfast and lunch here -DAILY - luckily have restraint - so I try to keep my visits to once a week.  I LOVE the choices that are offered here when I eat lunch or I shop for items for home cooking.  When I have visitors from out of town, I bring them here to sample the Amish Cuisine and all the other speciality restaurants.  At times choices can prove to be pricey, but if you are a Yelper - you should know which places have the best deals...Some of my Fav Place are Dieners Chicken (reviewed), Smucker's, Beck's NOLA Cuisine (reviewed), Godshall's & Martins Markets, Hunger Burger (reviewed), Nick's Roast Beef and I few others that names don't come to mind. 

Do your best to avoid during BIG conventions, but if you are here during a convention and want to check it out - do us locals a favor - don't stand in the middle of the aisle - try to be kind and enjoy the EXPERIENCE!!

This place is massive. Tons of things to see, booths to check out and you will never, ever starve to death here. All kinds of ethnic treats, local staples and everything in between. Also are stalls of goods and sundries as well. We were there on a Saturday evening, probably half an hour before they closed. Packed to the gills, even then. This place is pretty much an entire city block, so be sure to give yourself plenty of time to look around and decide carefully what you REALLY want to sink your teeth into. Otherwise you may experience doughnut envy or sandwich regret. And no one, no one, deserves that.

Fantastic spot similar to the Pike Place Market in Seattle!

Inside you'll find lots of hot food eateries for breakfast or lunch. A huge section was closed today because it's Sunday, and there are tons of Amish-run businesses.

There is a creperie (we went to Profi's), Keven Parker's famous fried chicken soul food joint, chocolatiers, bakeries (we went to Metropolitan) and tons of places to get super fresh seafood including sushi grade tuna, Scottish salmon, the biggest shrimp ever, crawfish, clams, oysters, etc., freshly made sausage, a cheese vendor, ice cream vendor, fun jewelry vendors.

There aren't lots of farmer vendors inside but there's a grocer there that has fresh veggies and fruits.

It's directly across from the Philadelphia Convention Center, so next time a conference brings you to town, you can come here daily for lunch and get something different each time.
In my opinion of the 10 top places to visit when In Philly. The variety of ethnic food you can get her is amazing. I come to buy the produce and to buy Amish made apple dumplings. Yummo!

I absolutely loved Reading Terminal! There were rows and rows of different ethnic foods and even more dessert options, how can you not fall in love with Reading. 

When you first enter the building, you'll be greeted with the sweet and savory aroma coming from all of the eateries. Your mind and stomach will be overwhelmed with all the goodness. 

Reading is a great place for breakfast, lunch, or dinner. If you are craving a snack during the day, you'll have more than enough options to select from. Reading offers Thai, Mexican, Greek, American, and Indian food, just to name a few. For someone who has a sweet tooth you'll get to choose from fresh made cannolis, doughnuts, cakes, chocolate, and cookies. 

Not only are there restaurants and stores in Reading, they also have stands that sell produce. I have also never seen any fresher poultry (chicken, lamb, beef) at a market. They even have a great selection of seafood (lobster tails, crawfish, clams, mussels, shrimps, crabs). There's even a stop for fresh cheeses and deli meats. 

During my short stay in Philly, I managed to come to Reading at least once every day. I came to either enjoy a meal or buy produce/poultry to cook a nice home cooked meal. 

I will definitely be paying Reading another visit whenever I come back to Philly. 

Tip: Some locations only accept CASH.

LOVE this place for everything from produce, to meat from the butcher, fish from the monger, treats, coffee and local produce and meat.  Eating here is one stop shopping.  Wish it was open for longer hours on weekdays tho!

everything you need - and i mean EVERYTHING - all in one spot!  

just avoid it like the PLAGUE during the week of the Flower Show!
Great place for breakfast, brunch, or lunch!  Wish we would have known about this on our first day of our long weekend instead of our last day!

I have yet to come across a place like this. Truly - RTM is one of a kind. From Pork hoagies, fresh chocolates, organic teas, to herbal health remedies, RTM serves people from all walks and wants of life.

Take the stroll - be mindful of others - try to avoid the lunchtime rush if you can
:)

I almost skipped this because some places I had read about are closed on Sundays. It's so huge that I didn't even notice what was closed. This place is AMAZING and I was sad I only had one meal here. I think the only thing that would make it better is if the vendors would sell smaller portions so you can try more things. We split sandwiches at Dinic's and Meltkraft. Bought some goodies from The Tubby Olive and tried desserts from the Flying Monkey and Termini Bros. Everything was SO good. Pick up a map when you come in if there is any where specific you want to go otherwise you'll get completely distracted...not that it's a bad thing here.
Hit and miss. Stay away from some dodgy Asian food dealers. Great fruit and veg. Very touristy. Watch out for pickpockets. -- Hotspur

Great selection. Immediately on coming in you see all the produce you would expect from Farmers market but then there are tons of little restaurant counters. Got a pizza slice from one place and carrot-banana smoothie from other. Good quality for affordable price and had a place to sit and eat.

This is foodie heaven. 

An overwhelming amount of food vendors, ranging in all kinda of cuisines!!

Explore, bring your appetites, and enjoy!

Simply put, you can find anything you want here - and all at great prices!! But no matter how distracted you get by the tempting smells and delicious food, don't leave without a Beilers Donut!!! It'll easily be the best $0.95 you've spent in a long time!
One of the best places in the City of Philadelphia. While admittadly it is a little touristy, it is still worth going for all the food, ambiance and meats/cheeses.
Best Philly Cheesesteak sandwiches in the world are prepared and served right here!
Iconic Philadelphia site that both visitors and locals love and patronize. Eat, shop, socialize.

First off why is this listed as a sporting goods store?

I lived near Philly for ten formative childhood years. Reading Terminal was a fond but insubstantial memory - a blur of smells and associations more than any single event.

As an adult, it does not disappoint. In three days we came twice, feasting on cheesesteaks, buying cookies and coffee and generally seeing everything this food wonderland has to offer. 

What does Reading Terminal offer? Fresh produce, fresh seafood, cheese, meat, coffee, honey, jams, baked goods, chocolate galore, ice cream, pretzels, ethnic products, hippie dippie bath products, wine, clothes, and so much food ranging from Indian to Italian to Amish, scrapple to shawarma. 

Love it.

I want some food in bed with a little bit of everything....I went there when i was visiting Philly and had a great time.... we took the car around town...... Anyway we found food right when we step inside... had soft pretzels from the Amish stand...had a Philly cheese steak...bought some sub sandwiches...and had some ice cream.... it was fun walking around and seeing the little areas inside and having some snacks here and there...sadly there's no parking....and the area is really hard to find parking...place is really over crowed... Be aware every food stand has a line! waited about 45 minutes each time! which was pretty aggravating..

The market is amazing and jam packed with diverse offerings of food and goods of all kinds. I loved it and the only reason I didn't mark it a 5 star was that it was hot as Hades in there!!! I imagine it would be a difficult to cool, but I found it difficult to remain in there long enough to do much shopping. It was like being in hell, but with nice people and cool stuff.

Everything and anything you could ever want from a farmers market.  I would highly recommend going on a weekday for your everyday grocery needs, but if you want a great breakfast, brunch, or Saturday lunch definitely going to Molly Malloy's for a great burger and stout or the Down Home Diner for large filling portions and bottomless coffee just like at gradma's house.

If you are looking to get the full Reading Terminal Market experience, go on a Saturday morning, by 8AM.  You will be able to smell all the meats being roasted, hear the sounds of the market, and taste one of Beiler's Bakery famous dutch donuts (I'm PA Dutch AKA German, and these are the real deal!).  Beiler's is not open on Sundays so be sure to make it there early on Saturday to get your donut fix, before the long line begins.

Also, Olympic Gyro is one of my favorite spots located in the middle of the Market, near the front.  It is family owned and the grandmother still makes their delicious Spanakopita, which is heavenly.  No matter when I go to Reading Terminal Market, I always get a slice of spanakopita from Olympic Gyro.

A must-see for visitors to Philadelphia. Lots of great restaurants including award-winners and Philly classics like Dinic's, Bassett's Ice Cream, and Termini Bros, as well as year-round farm stands featuring local produce.
Love this place! I used to live near by off of 13th and race but since moving to Fishtown I miss coming to Reading for Amish Donuts and the Juice bar!

This place is without peer.  The varied food choices are dizzying and it's smart to go in a group to maximise your choices! While many will (justifiably) mention De Nic's broccoli rahb sandwich I prefer their meatball sub (a hidden gem). I never miss an Italian hoagie at Salumaria's (with extra hots and artichoke). All washed down with a 4th street cookie and some bassetts ice cream!
great place for shopping and grab agreat lunch.... many options , great atmosphere

So I gained three pounds over two days.

Not only are there forever food options, most of the food or snacks you try are just fantastic and made with serious thought and consideration for your darling taste buds. 

I feel deep sadness and regret for the people I see going into the Wawa nearby. Why?! Why would you deny yourself the magnificent oral and olfactory adventure that is the terminal. This place is especially awesome if you and your friend(s) don't want the same thing. Break for 10 minutes while you surveil the area and pick a meeting location for your subsequent feast. Try it at least once.

Awesome. Doesn't get better. Go hungry because you will want to (and should) try everything you pass by. Cannoli at Termini are a must for a sweet tooth. Tons of amazing Amish foods (made the old fashioned way). YUM. A Philly institution.

The food. So. Many. Options. Foodie's heaven.

So many things to recommend: Bassett's Ice Cream, Beck's Cajun Cafe, Hunger Burger, Jonathan Best Gourmet Grocer, Famous 4th Street Cookie, Flying Monkey Bakery. And so many more left to try. As always! Will add more as I go.
So many options to choose from. I recommend 12th St Cantina if you like Spanish food. You can find practically anything here!

I wandered around RTM a few times during my stay because it was nearby and interesting. I bought some decent cookies from a bakery and had some freaking marvelous ice cream from Bassett's. Everything there looks and smells good. The whole market is busy and hectic and colorful. I only wish that Dinic's hadn't run out of food when I went there. I also wouldn't mind trying the famous chicken wings one day.

This place is a plethora of food.  I love it! So much quality food to try, so you won't be disappointed.  I say come early on the weekends because it gets packed and difficult to walk through (hence, the 4 stars).  Other than that, I think it's a great place to bring family and friends that are hungry and don't want to pay high prices at a sit down restaurant.

Awesome Place

Where to begin?  This marketplace has a myriad of stands inside what kind of looks like Quincy Market in Boston, but let me tell you 100 times better.  You literally could eat at every stand for lunch and eat something different for 2 months, it's that large and diverse.  

All fresh food stands, you can do some food shopping as well.  The smells that reviberate inside this place are intoxicating.  I can see why anyone would eat at a crappy fast food place nearby, with this gem sitting in front of them.  

Whatever cuisine your in the mood for, they are bound to have it.  If your in Philly this is a must stop.  You could take an hour just to walk through and check out the entire place.

Check out the website:
http://www.readingterminalmarket.org/merchants

I will never miss it again when I visit Philly, awesome!

Thanks
OK place.  Not that great.  Fairly clean for a city that is not. Tourists drawn there.  Some locals seem to frequent it.  You can find plenty to eat but no where to sit.
One of my favorite places in Philadelphia. I go every week for fresh vegetables and hormone free meat. The prepared food can be a bit expensive but worth it for a treat.

I guess this Philadelphia's version of Chelsea Market, perhaps it's a bit smaller but it still offers the same variety of eats, sweets, treats and delcious snacks to satisfy anyone.  Fresh pressed olive oil, Amish baked treats, fresh seafood-pizza-pasta and handmade fresh mozzarella cheese...the list goes on and on.  This is a really nice place near the historic district to come in on a Saturday morning to have a delicious hearty breakfast, fresh brewed coffee,fresh squeezed juices and find some savory and sweet treats in between as well.  Wasn't able to try all the various dessert booths but they all seemed busy and as good as the next one. Nice find!!
Unbelievable! The food, the atmosphere, the selection.  I have nothing but great things to say about this Market which I stumbled across completely by accident while in Philly for a day.

A permanent farmer's market, except additionally with delicious variety of every kind of cuisine you can imagine. Highly recommend you come here on a Saturday afternoon, and browse the huge selections of cheeses, meat, seafood, vegetables, trinkets, and dairy products...and then also make a meal out of the New Orleans, southern, chinese, mexican, indian, european....etc...fare. A heaven for foodies who love grocery shopping!

Is this foodie heaven?  So many choices here, that it is an indecisive persons nightmare.  Comparable to an amusement park where you line up to wait to get on the ride, the ride here being the food.  I had to try 2 spots in here on my first visit, and that was Beiler's donuts and DiNic's pork sandwich.  

Can't wait to come back and try more things.

Had dinner on Friday evening. Nice night to sit outside. I've always been a fan since Diving Horse opened years ago but it seems as though the portions have gotten smaller and prices have gotten higher. It's lost a little of its uniqueness over the past two years. I love the atmosphere but was hungry about an hour later. For the prices they charge I shouldn't be hungry till breakfast the next morning.

A must see if you're visiting - great foods and produce (di nick's roast beef obviously, ice cream and the pickle patch!) - cool atmosphere 

otherwise (if you live in philly) try to avoid this place during high traffic because it can be a nightmare.

I'm in love with this place! It was my first time today and it was wonderful it's lie a little village on the inside. It's really crowded though so be careful button the upside it has a little so helping you find the shops you're looking for. Definitely get some pickles while you're there!!
Lots of great places inside. 12th Cantina and DiNic's are a MUST!

Let me be frank; I absolutely love the Reading Terminal Market. LOVE IT. It's without a doubt my favorite place to go on the weekends. It can be overwhelming being there are so many choices to eat, to shop, etc. If you can't find something you like here then there's something wrong with you.

Not only is it a great place to eat but to shop too; there are vendors that sell products other than food. 

A warning; it can get extremely crowded on weekends. Crowded as in shoulder to shoulder (the lines for the vendors can get very long, Beiler's Donuts being one of them). If you're a tad claustrophobic, like myself, it can be a little overwhelming. But worth a trip!

This place was so much fun. I wish I could eat more! Had the best grilled cheese here and the ice cream from Bassetts was so creamy. The philly cheesesteak from George's wasn't that great because of the bread they used. I've only been to Philly once but maybe best to try a cheesesteak outside of the Terminal Market? Also, I can't believe I missed that this market has the best Fried Chicken according to Food Network at Keven Parker Soul Food. Gotta try it next time I am in town!
It is great What can I say. I stop here every time I come to Philadelphia. Great food at great prices. And always an adventure.

SUCH a fun place. I lived in Philly for years and would come here at least weekly to do my grocery shopping but it's also fun just to walk around and look at things.  The produce is fresh and so cheap.  The restaurant stalls are good.  The Pennsylvania Dutch goods are also yummy.  My favorite places are the iovine brothers, the butcher's right next to it, Flying Monkey makes beautiful cakes, the cheese shops are yummy and will give you samples.  There's a great spice shop/kitchen supplies shop

Great place. Large. I stop there for fresh produce from time to time. During my last visit I stumbled up an herbal shop with plenty of cool teas. You can find coffee and much else here as well. Only 4 stars because some places and items are pricey.
Always a pleasure to walk around those aisles and grab something in all of that different places. Great to eat and to shop.
Tons of food options and even cheap groceries (OK Grocery, in the center), what more do you want?

What a cute Market! We came here while waiting to check into our hotel. For breakfast we ate at The Dutch Eating Place. We tried the blueberry pancakes and the Apple Cinnamon French Toast. So soft and fluffy. I also have to mention the slab of butter they put on it...definitely not the place to go if your on a diet. Lol. Next time I want to try the apple dumplings. 

The market has various restaurants, produce, dessert, and meat stands. Great place to roam around.
This place has every type of food you could ever want.  Without question, the best place to go for a quick bite in Philadelphia..  maybe even the world!

THE spot to take visitors to in Philadelphia. No, not the Independence Hall, or the Museum of Art, or even to get a cheese steak. If you really want to celebrate freedom, give yourself the freedom to do a Rocky Run through the aisles of RTM, picking out and putting in your stomach any and everything delicious that comes to mind. Tons of choices, from amish baked goods to chinese food to soul food to crepes to gyros to amish baked goods to actual groceries. Did I mention amish baked goods? It may seem chaotic when you visit. Good. Embrace it. It is the Pennsylvania Madhouse Farmer's Market from Hell, and you'll enjoy your visit. Here are some Go-To Spots.

Beiler's Bakery: Amish Donuts. Get a dozen of them. Regret Nothing
Hatville Deli: Corned Beef Special Sandwich
Termini Bros. Bakery: Cannolis

Next to chinatown, so you can get your fill of fantastic food from both sectors and then take a nap by Independence Hall, like the Sons of Liberty did. At least...I'm pretty sure that's what they did.

It can really be hit or miss depending on the vendor, but there's an excellent selection. My favorite is the specialty olive oil and balsamic vinegar stand, I have yet to find a decent regular butcher there. If you're looking for interesting soaps and incense, you'll be right at home here. Avoid the prepared foods sections, you can find those in any other food court in Philly. Also here, Amish means quality! Get those pickles, folks. They sure are tasty.

The place has some staples that you cant get anywhere else in philly... but its a mad house in there.  with that being said there are only a few places in the market worth the hassle.  but you're going to have to figure that out on your own... that's really the fun of this place though.  the discovery.  but after you've discovered what's good you basically don't go back until you've succumbed to your urges lest you wait in those unforgiving lines.

I was blown away on my first visit to this market, there is so much to see inside, tons of  eateries and shops, I had a very hard time choosing where to go, what to see and what to eat !! Foodie heaven !
Head right to the Thai place in the middle of the market.  CHEAP!  Great Food!  Long line moves fast.  Excellent Tom  Kai Gai soup, Salmon Salad.  GO

Many restaurants to choose from here! Several chocolate stores which also had sugar free options thankfully. Bakeries with yummy bread and a super market to boot. Wish the hours were longer that's all.

So many delicious options, it's hard to decide what to get. I decided on the Baby back ribs in the corner of the market in the Amish section. The ribs meat literally fell of the bone and the rub was just right.
Come hungry because the amount of good food is insane! Cool Amish ambience too! Unexpected fun times!
Fun place to go to get food, lots of options.  It was very crowded though.  Definitely a place to go to if you are visiting Philadelphia

Is it possible to dislike this place, aside from the occasional crowds and long lines during peak hours? Everything you could possibly want is waiting for you, and the bright neon signs will guide you to exactly where you need to go. Coffee, ice cream, chicken, donuts, cheese steaks, fresh juices... 

If there's something you're in the mood for, you'll find it at Reading Terminal! Dinic's for pork sandwiches, Beiler's for donuts, Old City coffee, flower shops... the list goes on! And the workers are almost always cordial and friendly. It's a must visit in Philadelphia! I've only lived here for 3 weeks, and I know it has already become a favorite spot!
First time at the terminal.  Been living in Philadelphia for 14 yrs and never been inside.. Has great vendors that offers so many things! Can't wait to go back!

I am a huge fan of the RTM. There are so many wonderful, authentic, and eclectic places to eat inside this establishment. Even if you are just going to grocery shop (I recommend Iovine Brothers) it is always an experience. I've enjoyed seafood from Wan's and thought that the people working there was extremely friendly. Terralyn is a nice little boutique with handcrafted soaps and other beautiful gifts. There are always fresh flowers for purchase at the market, delicious crepes to be eaten, and hundreds of friendly faces. Don't miss out on the roast pork sandwich from Di Nics- it is worth the wait! 

Whether you're looking for a quick bite, a few groceries, a gift for a unique or artistic friend, or a fun place to go for a daytime activity, the RTM is always a good choice.

Everyone who visits Philly needs to make time for Reading Terminal. It is a cross-section of Pennsylvania, with delicious Italian food, Asian grocers, amazing baked goods from the Amish, and local produce and dairy products. We would all be better off if we did our grocery shopping here. 

I also love Molly Malloy's, because sometimes you want a beer and a sandwich in the middle of the day.
This is the place to get any delicious goodie you want to eat all under one roof.  A Philly must experience.

Been one of my favorites for many years...you can get anything you want at RTM. Over my latest 2 day visit, we had red beans and rice, cheesesteaks, PA Dutch breakfast, shoo fly pie, coffee, wine, and more. If you are in the area or attending something at the PA Convention Center, it's a must do.

Based on selection and quality of food alone, I'd rate this place as close to a 5 as it can get without jumping in front of me during the climactic gun fight with Lo Pan and the Decepticons.

In terms of actual experience going there, I'd rate it a 3.5, if I'm being generous.

This all averages out to a solid 4.

The only reason the experience can be kind of stressful is that it's always packed. Like, Asian night market packed. Like, gambling den on 4 v 4 cockfight night packed. You get the picture. Whether you just want a container of takeaway, or some quality meats, cheese, or artisan whatever, you will be waiting in line, likely for 15-20 minutes. I've yet to come here at a time of day when it wasn't filled up like 25 cent drink night at Paddy McRegretfuls.

That said, you have to go here, and you have to try everything. They have what you like, I guarantee it - except Vietnamese cuisine, I haven't seen that there.

This is pretty much the best place in the world, & I don't know what else I can say about it that 2,000 other reviewers haven't already said. It's magical, bustling, full of every kind of food you could possible imagine, from ready-to-eat to grocery. What do you want for lunch? Reading Terminal Market has it. 

Highlights, for me, are the large Pennsylvania dutch offerings, Meltkraft Grilled Cheese, the old-fashioned candy shop (homemade fudge!), & the pierogi place that I can never remember the name of - but seriously, probably anything you get here is going to be delicious.Other bonuses: Reading Terminal Market is committed to supporting purveyors of local & regional produce, & though it's easily accessible by public transportation, parking is only $4.

Planning to eat in? You may have trouble finding seating, as there's certainly not enough of it within the market. On nice days, find seating outdoors & people watch as you consume whatever delicacy you've just acquired inside.

Wow! The Reading Market is amazing! Here you will find the finest cuisine of Philadelphia, all in one place. Whatever you desire... It is here.  I would give it ten stars if yelp would let me. This is a foodie paradise. If you do nothing else while in philly, visit Reading market. If you are on a diet, save up your carbs and calories and spend them here. What the heck, its so worth it.  Double xtra super highly recommend!
Awesome market! You can get many different types of authentic ethnic food from many of the best restaurants in the city. Must check this place out!
Awesome place to shop especially if your a foodie but I wish the prices where more reasonable and not priced for the tourist.

My favorite place in Philly! There are so many options. I don't know where to start. The icecream is good, the Peking Deck sandwich is good.. The seafood is fresh. The soul fried chicken is good as well! Everything is great here!

Took my mom and brother (visiting from out of town).  Amazing options available, and the food was awesome with reasonable prices.  One star taken away because general cleanliness of the overall facilities was a tad lacking.

I've been here a couple times and there is no place quite like it. From the outside it almost looks like a run of the mill deli or average supermarket but once you are inside you know that is not the case. Reading Terminal is basically a warehouse filled with small food stands and shops, think mall food court just infinitely better. No matter what you are in the mood for they will have something for you. Some of my favorites are Beiler's Donuts, where Amish bakers make AMAZING donuts like the Elvis which is a jelly donut with peanut butter frosting and bacon. Then there is DiNics, where they make giant slabs of roast pork, slice it, throw it in some jus, put it on a bun and top it with broccoli rabe and provolone.

There are so, so many more places. You have to go there if you are in Philly.

Tourist trap with some good stuff for locals. City coffee roasts their own coffee right there and they have the best prices in the city. Good produce and seafood. Large variety of foods to choose from.
Pretty much any type of food you'd want!! I stayed across the street and popped over several times during my visit. They have the Amish market on the weekends as well.

I had a vegetable crepe that was excellent, but it was hard to enjoy because of the noise and the difficulty I had in finding a table. I would recommend this only if you would enjoy a hectic and crowded market.

Philly is worth one whole point higher in a 1-10 scale because if this fantastic destination. No matter your tastes there is something for everyone that will exceed their expectations. 

This is probably the number one destination for anyone visiting the city. This type of gathering of independent businesses (no chains) is a model for all cities and towns to emulate. 

Nothing exceptional comes from a chain restaurant.

Reading Terminal Market was exactly how I pictured it. I've seen it many times on television but never visited until recently. There are dozens of vendors and also provides a good amount of table seating for a market of this size. The only downside of coming here was the parking. The parking lots around the area were a bit expensive and street parking looked very limited. We drove over to Chinatown and got lucky with spot. It's about a 5 minutes walk from Chinatown which isn't bad at all.

Places that I've visited and tried.

1. Bassetts Ice cream is a must!
2. Molly Malloy's Chicken pot pie had a bad crust but overall was still good.
3. Beck's Cajun Cafe was dynamite with their Gator Gumbo.
4. Tommy DiNic's roast pork sandwiches were great. They're not greasy like cheesesteaks.

We peeked at other vendors but were too full to try anything else. I will definitely come back to Reading Terminal next time I visit Philly and try other things. As for now, I highly recommend the Gator Gumbo from Beck's and Ice cream and shakes from Bassetts. Those were my two top picks during this visit.

Reading Terminal Market is a food lovers dream! I would venture to say, this puts Quincy Market to shame. Do not leave Philly without stopping here for a meal. It can be a very overwhelming place, but I find it helps to go in with a plan or at least some idea of the places you want to try. I did some research and decided to go with:

- DiNic's for the classic roast pork sandwich. This was excellent! You can go with or without the rabe... I might go without next time because it can be a bit overpowering and mask some of the more subtle flavors of the pork and provolone. 

-Termini Bros Cannoli - Really good! A nice crisp shell, that somehow had a lightness to it. The cream was mild, with a very subtle tang and a hint of cinnamon throughout. It was not too sweet and you could actually taste the ricotta. which I appreciated. 

- Famous 4th St. Cookies - This was the only disappointing place to me. The cookie I tasted reminded me too much of Pepperidge Farms.

- The Dutch Eating Place - This was pretty good. Everyone seems to order the Hot Turkey, which I would love to try next time. We got the sloppy joe, just for the sake of nostalgia! I also tried  shoo fly pie for the first time. This came from Pennsylvania Dutch next door. 

Also consider trying the Peking Duck place. It had great reviews, but we just couldn't eat another thing. Reading Terminal is also a Farmer's Market, so you can purchase grocery items and homemade treats to bring home with you.

Enjoy!
