I love that there is so much fresh. local food and such a huge variety. It's really awesome that it is so close to the train station, so I can stop on my way home. Knocked off one star from perfect - could use some more organic options..and later hours - i make it by the skin of my teeth every time .
Great experience and lunch when touring historic Philadelphia. Dinic's Italian Beef was amazing.
I love coming here! They have great coffee, fresh produce, amazing pastries and vendors. I never get bored!

Cool place to grab lunch. Best thing to get is the pastrami sandwich at Hershel's. You can also get a beer to go at Molly Malones. Definitely prepare for a crowd on weekends -- had much better luck with finding a table on Monday. Biggest complaint being the people who take their laptop and work. There aren't enough tables for them to be doing that shit!
Really crowded on weekends. Too many sweets to choose from. You have to get the roast or pulled pork.

If you ever end up in Philly, you can't NOT check this place out!

It's a huge indoor market - they sell everything from candles, linens, & numerous gift items, to donuts, fresh cannollis, beef jerky, pizza, and pretty much any type of food you can think of or imagine!

The place is clean, cool looking, and if I lived in this area, I would be here oh-so-regularly.  You won't ever starve or run out of choices!

Some of the vendors there are:  

12th Street Cantina
Beck's Cajun Cafe
By George! Pizza, Pasta & Cheesesteaks
Carmen's Famous Italian Hoagies & Cheesesteaks
Dienner's Bar-B-Q Chicken
DiNic's
Down Home Diner
Dutch Eating Place
Franks A Lot
Golden Bowl
Hatville Deli
Hershel's East Side Deli
Hunger Burger
Kamal's Middle Eastern Specialties
Keven Parker's Soul Food Cafe
Little Thai Market

That list isn't even half of what is there!

Our only fault was that we came at an odd brunch time, and already made reservations to eat lunch elsewhere, so we ended up getting beef jerky and donuts to go (& ate a couple of them while we were there.) If we didn't already have plans, we would have definitely tried Dinic's - "Home of the famous roast pork and broccoli rabe sandwich, crowned the best sandwich in America by the Travel Channel." Their line was crazy long each time we walked by, so you know they sell some GOOD stuff! 

I already know that we will definitely return the next time we're in town. Don't miss out; this place is foodie heaven!
Awesome, and you can't beat the parking deal $4 in the garage across the street with validation.

I was overwhelmed by the plethora of different store shops and eating stalls.  I felt like I was back in Tokyo with the crush of people running around.  What a great place to sample food from around the world while never leaving Philadelphia!
Great for tourists! Though new competition is pending from new Market East development. -- Hotspur.

I had heard so much about the reading terminal market, and I was quite excited to visit it for the first time with some friends the other day. One step inside and our senses were blasted with an almost overwhelming sense of busyness inside. The chattering of people around us, the wafting smells of food from the nearby stalls, the brisk pace of the regulars, it was all quite exciting. There were just too many things to choose from, but the overall experience was amazing and I can't wait to go back. The only downside is that they close before dinner time, but looking forward to going back again.

If this is not the best of Philly, I don't know what is. 
love to drop by here whenever possible, to try the cheesecake, the ice cream, the beer, everything , like farmer's market, plus the food.  Will try cheesesteak next time.

This place is the best! All sorts of food from all walks of life. When can find snacks, meals, gifts, groceries. The biggest problem is that it can be quite crowded and noisy. It is a convenient walk from most Center City locations. Don't expect to find a seat to eat your lunch. If you find one it will be crowded and probably dirty.  It deserves five stars however because you can find anything and it's all wonderful.

What a vibrant fun place for a morning coffee or lunch. Philadelphia was wise to save this city jewel and check out the convention center above the Hard Rock Cafe - it was formerly the reading railroad terminal. Another great save by the community.
Amazing- So may options and so much beautiful food. Best donuts i've ever had!
This place is great, a little crowded but well worth it.  Lots of good food choices , fresh produce and more.

Oh yeah, I'm  coming back!!!  When I come back to Philly, this will definitely be on the list of places of places to go first.  The enormous offering of food offerings is staggering.  I might browse first, then start all over to choose.   Don't go there starving, or you won't make past Hershel's deli.  A fun place. Had an authentic feel.  Highly recommend

I worked in the Terminal for a little while so I have a non-glossy view of this consortium of businesses. For anyone confused, this is nothing like a farmers market. There are a few meat places and an occasional veggie stand but it's mostly a bunch of tourist traps. 

Most of the restaurants are sub-par and have a large markup because tourists flock here. That doesn't go to say there aren't a few great eats here. I would definitely recommend Sang-Kee, DiNiCs and Pearls. You can't really go wrong with anything on those menus.

A big plus to the market is the Amish side toward Arch Street. Bailer's Doughnuts will put you into a sugary food coma and the wait at the Dutch Eating Place is well worth the wait (Don't miss out on the apple dumplings). 

Just a note. If you are new to the city and are looking to save a little cash while eating fresh produce, go to Iovines. This is still a family run business, the produce is usually great quality and the prices are great. Usually lower than big grocery stores. You can regularly find berries for $.99 a container on special in the front.

There are definitely some great spots at the terminal but overall it's for tourists and the shops are generally more expensive than the equivalents anywhere else.

I recently hosted my sister's baby shower at Satis Bistro.  It was an adorable venue, with delicious food and marvelous service!  The waiters were so kind, and even assisted with carrying the gifts from my car to the restaurant and back again.  I would host another event here if I lived in Jersey City.

I have never been let down by a visit to Reading Terminal Market. I had a strawberry and nutella crepe for breakfast that was very good, the fresh produce is so cheap I have filled my back pack many times for less than $20. We once got a lamb shoulder from the butcher in the middle that was really good, I would buy meat from him again. Cheese shop right near the butcher had some of the best cheeses I have had in America and the guy was very informed and offered many samples, which was nice. And the Termini bros stand is not to be missed for a perfect cannoli! I only wish it was open later than 6 pm weekdays so it would be possible to stop by after work sometimes.

My goodness where do I start. 

No literally, where do I start. Upon walking in and finding this not-so-secret market, I was immediately in sensory overload, so many lights, people, SO MANY SMELLS. It'd take me literally a week to try every stand in this market. 

So we came in at about 4:45pm and many stands were closing already. Tried Dinic's roasted pork sandwich and it was just average. not that moist and peppers didn't add much to the flavor. 

Also tried the last donuts at Beiler's and they were okay. Wish I could've stayed longer to try the other places but so far it looks like the restaurants in the greater Philly metro might be better. This place is mostly touristy hype.
There's lots of great food and a wide variety of souvenirs at Reading Terminal Market. The crepes - every morning.
This place is so yummy and has food for everyone.  The market is enjoyed by tourists and locals alike.

If you don't know what to do, Reading Terminal Market is the best place to shop and eat. From food to grocery shopping, there are numerous things to do in this market. It is endless. I have been there a few times and I haven't even finish exploring, :D

Let the journey begin !

I love this place so much! RTM is a great place to spend an afternoon just wandering around, grabbing food and shopping for knick-knacks. 

A personal favorite would have to be the used books corner. Always something fun in there.

Man 
I can't say enough about the Reading Terminal Market!
I have lived in Philadelphia all my life..except like most, if I may vacation at the JERSEY Shore..Wildwood..
I have to insist that if you are around Center City Philadelphia...you most definitely bring your appetite and any extra money for food , that you might want to whip into a sensational meal, like Lasagna with handmade Sausage and 
Country fresh from the Amish, a beautiful salad and flower arrangement of such beauty that you steal the show .
And almost like Disney world, you might not be able to get everything done in a day..
So if fortunate enough to have at least lunch with a friend and a homemade smoothie kale and all.. homemade one at a time veggie burgers and the line can get long as it's well worth the wait! 
Hit the Reading Terminal cheese shop.
Turn around and grab some cannoli ! 
Or a butter slathered homemade Amish pretzel, served to you by the real Pa Amish country , originals who drive and commute towards the end of THE week...
And hustle from the break off day, till the sun hides away for yet another day...
Do not be left out! 
Don't leave Philadelphia, and say, oh GOD we didn't have a chance to see"the Philadelphia Mayor eating a pulled pork, or even a 50yr+ recipe for a crab cake to die for! 
The Reading Terminal Market is not a landmark to be missed! 
Philly girl "Maggie Razzi"

Love this place, my only complaint is that I wish they had more maps because it's easy to get lost .. also I find myself buying produce then walking around and finding a better place 10 minutes later! Still what a great space though.. if you can find parking!

I absolutely love this place. Always something delicious to try and new people to meet. 

Giving it a 4 mostly because it can be a little pricey.
Everything here is amazing. The atmosphere and all of the choices of food are so diverse it is almost impossible to chose!

Redding terminal market is a great place for lunch, knick-knacks, and real grocery shopping.  For groceries, Iovine's market is a fantastic place to buy produce.  They have great quality and the prices are incredibly cheap.  There are also several butchers and fish shops, and one or two great cheese shops with very knowledgable staff.

This is one of my go-to places in Philly for a quick lunch or cup of coffee. The variety of cuisine can satisfy most cravings. I usually grab a Philly cheese steak - hey, when you are in Philly, you need  a cheese steak!
AMAZINGGGGGGGGG Next time I'm going to get all the makings for sushi.
Love love love this place! A true Pennsylvania experience. Give yourself lots of time to explore this Philly gem!
Reading Terminal has a great selection and has great prices, however it is always crowded - so be prepared.

This is a MUST VISIT for anyone visiting Philadelphia. As a native of Philly I've been here many times and now that I reside out of state I always return and bring friends who have never been. Go early in the am when they open if possible to avoid the massive crowds and lines. Dinic's, Miller's, Termini's and Beilers are a few favorites.

Fun place. It's packed with people, so you have to like that kind of thing. I only had time to stop at one place and got a Philly cheesesteak, so I will be back to grab some produce, ice cream, donuts, pretzels...

This is one of my favorite spots in Philly! The huge variety of foods to be found are amazing. And there are just lots of fun places tucked away here. Definitely need to take the time to explore this little treasure if you have not done so already!
If there is a food quart in heaven this it! Olympia Gyro is amazing! Plan on eating several times!
Excellent stands, big fan of Herschel's deli, Martin's Meats, Downtown Cheese, Iovine Bro's produce and Metropolitan Bakery.  Insanely croweded at lunch time, though, so go early.
We took a stroll here before running Philadelphia's marathon! You can find everything here! Awesome market with great vibe! Everyone should explore this place when in Philadelphia!

Simply put Reading Terminal Market is one of the reasons I continue to live in Philadelphia. The fresh produce and meats, the amazing restaurants, and the exquisite desserts are heavenly. Not everything it the market is an absolute winner, but that's only because you can walk 2 ft over to another booth and get something mind-blowing. Essentially when walking the market you can never go wrong, just miss out on the actual best roast pork, grilled reuben, or chocolate chip cookie.
This place is a bit overwhelming but wow!  So many things to choose from.  A bustling place with some good food and interesting little shops!

This place is THE ultimate foodie paradise. I can (and have) easily spent hours here, browsing the endless rows of food stands. I come here from NYC because unfortunately there is nothing in the city that even remotely compares to this place (admittedly, it has crossed my mind to move to Philadelphia just to have this place near me). 

A few of my favorite things: jerky, San Kee duck noodle soup and Amish donuts. 

Pure amazingness indeed!
Get the oysters! If I lived inside this market for a week, just maybe I would cover a fourth of what I wanted to try.

If I could give this place ten stars, I would. This is a foodie's heaven - I would honestly consider moving to Philly just for this place!

My friend and I only budgeted two and a half hours for this place, and since having nine stomachs is not a reality for human beings, we decided to hit up only a few, select places (yes, this was a strategic operation).

Brunch at Dinic's- got the Italian pulled pork sub, which was great (not too salty), but heard the roast pork was even better, so maybe next time I'll try that.

We snagged a taste of some deli meats at the stand next to Carmen's, and I was half-tempted to pretend being a hobbit and have a second lunch...

Bassett's icecream is a must-have dessert. Amish icecream - can't pass up the creaminess that's actually not heavy but quite refreshing. :)

We also had pretzels from Miller's. Do yourself a favor and get one when it's piping hot...I feel like the Amish have the hand of Midas, figuratively-speaking. Everything they touch tastes so much more amazing than your average food items!

There are two cookie stands. Both are good, but I personally go against the grain and say the ones from Famous 4th Street's are better than Hope's. At least, if you're going for less decadent and less butter. If you like the sweet, heavy, buttery goodness, go with Hope's. (Or do what I did and get both and compare).

You can get fun souvenirs at Chocollate by Mueller - anatomically correct hearts, lungs, pancreas, etc. and chocolate-covered...onions. I was too weirded out to get that, but it would make a great passive aggressive gift. ;)

Finally, swing back in the late afternoon - all the produce prices drop to ONE DOLLAR. I got an entire cantaloupe for $1, and strawberries by the pound for $1. Such a steal...and don't forget the fresh milk and yoghurt - these are as local as you can get!

Dinner: Carmen's Philly cheese, hands down. No whiz though - whiz looks narsty (and I know I'll likely get crucified for saying that, but go for the provolone). President Obama came here! I can trust that recommendation haha.
Lots of great selection here!  Easy to get just about any type of food, including fantastic deserts. I recommend a visit here for anyone visiting Philadelphia.

Wow! If you go in here a lunchtime, your head will spin! So many options! So many people! So much fun! Once you start navigating through the river of humankind you begin to grasp the possibilities. Sandwiches, salads, ice cream, fruits, veggies... the list goes on. Once settled in, you see the people. Workers squeezing in a lunch, locals for produce, tourists for the experience and that list goes on too. So, what are you waiting for?

This place was incredible. A must visit place in Philly. We tried numerous items at several places. A food lovers paradise. My wife and I walked through the entire market one time, saw what they had and immediately I started drooling.  My favorite  was Dinic's, I had the brisket sandwich with spinach. KILLER!!!

My favorite place to go to market! I absolutely love the crepes, Beiler's doughnuts, the flying monkey and old city coffee! I love the atmosphere of the market and the variety of things they have to choose from! I bought squid ink noodles from one of the vendors and they were excellent! Absolutely love this place and is a must go every time I go to Philadelphia!

This is how you do an urban market! In Baltimore we have Lexington Market, which is like the Capitol building for Heroin City, U.S.A. While that can be a sight to see, I'd gladly give up Lexington's junkies hocking pills for Reading's sprawling venue filled with vendors who have been perfecting their crafts for years. Must stop on a Philly visit!

You will be overwhelmed, you will be very overwhelmed.  In a good way though!  It's like we took spanish tapas markets like the botequin and the san miguel market and americanized them.  Little shops sell their specialties and everything is SO fresh.  Goods are also sold here (doorbells, nick nacks).  Reading terminal is very close to the bus terminal and city center, so this is a convenient location at the beginning, middle or end of your trips.  I went to the Dutch Eating Place, which is amazing and affordable.  However, there were lines to dine at many other places so I would look around and choose wisely!

Great food and wonderful atmosphere all around.  The reading terminal market is reminiscent of a nice indoor farmers market you'd find in Lancaster Pennsylvania.  The old tradition. of quaint farmers markets  in Pennsylvania is alive and well.
The ultimate tourist trap.  But I love it though.  If you want to get a quick overview of Philly, especially food-wise, you have to stop here.
Love the Reading Terminal. They have something for everyone. Great Food of all kinds. Can be a little bit pricey and a little too crowded
Too crowded. The food at Tootsis was alright I guess. There was nowhere to sit! And a bunch of kids playing hooky were bothering me and my friend while we were having lunch

How can you hate this place? It's a foodie's heaven that's open all season! Cheap good eats from ice cream, to doughnuts, to chinese, to soul food. You can't go wrong in this place if you want to try an array of dishes from different cultures. It' a market so don't expect it be fancy.
What an amazing place!  You can find anything you want here from the best hoagies to obscure game meats. Great variety, good prices, awesome people.

I love this place... and you will too.  It is fat kid heaven.  You can have whatever you like... so "treat yo self" to a day in a food utopia.  The only thing I can say they are missing that I need in my life... is korean food.  They are lucky everything else is so good... that I am gonna leave that extra star.

Love shopping for groceries here. I can always find the veggies I want. 
Nice fish and seafood and meat too!
Like the deli counters

A food lovers dream paradise! Get here early to avoid the lines and come hungry. Have your mind made up as you will find yourself in a wanderlust if you are not careful. Although that is an awesome way to kill a day.
Love this place for all my fresh meats and produce! I particularly go to the Amish, since the taste in their meats are fresh and without hormones and GMOs.
Been there many times, we usually go to Spataro's for a great Cheese Steak or a hoagie. They have the best sandwiches in the Reading Terminal Market.
Fun place to explore a ton of different food options.  Almost too much to choose from!  It was very busy so a bit of a challenge with a toddler in a stroller.  Would love to go back and just shop.
Love it!!! A great adventure for date night. So many choices . Friendly and very clean for a market.

Well, duh.  Reading Terminal is great.  Dutch Eating Place should just serve breakfast 24/7 -- you can tell when it's not breakfast time, they empty out.

The ribs place is great.  Iovine's has good prices on some produce.  And it's all in a tiny area -- what is there not to love?

This place is awesome.  I loved the variety of food options and shopping fun.  I would have spent two days here.  the convention center is just across the street and is a perfect location for attendees.  Everyone needs to visit.  This place made my Philly stay PERFECT.

The Reading market is fine and certainly a place for tourists to visit if they've never been in town before. But, its a racket. it isn't the best food in the city and its not as fabulous as it used to be in the 80s and 90s but there 's a good selection of prepared foods. The Meninite stands are one of the best.

Very very busy and claustrophobic but if you can get past that this is one of the best farmer's markets in the Philadelphia/Greater Philadelphia area! They literally offer every shop of every kind under the sun (vegan cakes, meat, cheese, burgers, gourmet chocolate, etc). Definitely check it out if you're ever in the area!
I could have spent all day eating a wide variety of delicious foods. Sampled the Flying Monkey's Elvis Cake quite tasty.

PLACE To walk by, it reminds me a taste of Barcelona for the market part. If you're hUngry tRy to know where you want to go before being there! The multiple foods turn your mind and you don't know where to head! And every thing looks good, from oysters to ice cream, shawarma sandwiches and beers....

Although some of the places were closed, the market was crowded, obviously (it was July 5th). I really wanted to try some of the cheeses and cold meats with bread, as well as the freshly cut fruits and juices but did not get a chance. I'd really like to come back with more time in order to try some of the food there. That would be my advice: come with time, preferably during the week and think in advance about what you would like to try in order not to be overwhelmed by too much choice.

I went to Keven Parkers at RTM! I cannot say enough about how delicious and plentiful the food was. The little side seating area could use a spruce up. The beverages are delicious! I was satisfied with my meal!

Love Reading Terminal.  Great place to get fresh produce, flowers, and more.  If we go to the Convention Center we always stop at the Reading Terminal for lunch but so does everyone else.  It is vey crowded at lunch because of all the options.  There is always police there/in the area so I feel safe.  You definitely have to go once for the experience and you'll want to keep going back.  Make sure to try a DeNics Pork sandwich and Bassett's ice cream - yummy!

Neverending array of crafts, meats, veggies, cheeses, fruits, restaurants, gifts, and anything else you can imagine.
Highlights for us were By George cheesesteaks, Herbiary herbs, the fish market next to By George, and the cool coffee place around the corner from there.
Wish we had half a day!
Terrific place to enjoy a good meal - the variety was great and the local feel even better!
I buy all my meat, seafood and poultry here!  Everything is great.  It's my Saturday hangout.

So much under one roof. From cookies and desserts, to cheeses, to fried chicken! I did not get a chance to sample enough vendors. It was early on a Sunday and I was tired. Not my best performance. But overal, this is a great space. It is well organized, and had more than enough available seating. I was surprised at how clean it was and that fact that there was no lingering nasty food smells! Looking forward to paying it another visit when I am back in Philadelphia.

The BEST of Philly all in one place! First market of it's kind in the country. Get a Hershel's pastrami Reuben or a roast pork sandwich from DiNics. Italian hoagies from Salumeria are also excellent. The Rib Stand has a great rib sandwich and the turkey at The Original Turkey is to die for. Hatville Deli has an excellent corned beef special. Beiler's donuts are awesome but they have lots of hydrogenated oil/trans fat so don't overdoes on these.

This market reminded me of Quincy market in Boston or Fisherman's Wharf in SF. I like these old school style of tradition. I was very happy to find out the most yummy whoopie pies I ever had. It had a long history.

ALL of the food is a bit overpriced but if you visit Philadelphia it is a quintessential experience. As a resident, all that I ask is that you not be the millionth tourist to stand in the middle of the isle, no doubt in a circle, with a stroller, at noon so that no one get can past you.

Reading Terminal Market is the place to go in Philadelphia for one stop eats. You will find everything from cheesesteaks to different desserts. It's so many food places inside of the market for customers. It's probably best to make more than one trip to check out everything at Reading Terminal Market. The atmosphere was very lively. Some lines were wrapped around the corner. Hours at Reading Terminal Market is odd, so be sure to check the website. I definitely will stop by Reading Terminal Market every time I'm visiting Philadelphia.

Aside from the fact that this is an awesome place to take out-of-town visitors, don't forget to take advantage of the awesome market. The vegetables are always fresh and you can't beat the deal on meat and seafood. If you live in the city The prices are lower and the quality is better than most supermarket. 

In terms of where to eat:
Hershel's - brisket Reuben and matzoh ball soup
Beilers donuts - worth the wait; get a variety
Beilers bakery - 1/2 cina buns & pie slices
Becks Cajun - sausage chicken gumbo
Olympia gyro - gyro combo
4th street cookies - black & white, snicker doodles 
Termini bros - cannoli 

Tip1: since DiNic's is famous (overrated in my opinion), The line is always very long. However that line does not include the wait for the seat at the bar surrounding the booth. Wait for a seat to open up and skip the line- they will serve you directly & chances are you're going to end up anyways 

Tip2: The Pennsylvania Dutch booths are not open every day so make sure you check the website before getting your hopes up for some awesome food

Huge, huge selection of small businesses and high-quality products. It would take days to sample all the food here. The Bassett's location and the candy shop make me so, so happy. 

The only valid complaint I have is that the crowd is massive during peak hours...
They have a great selection of fresh food. The place gets way to busy on the weekends and other than eating a quick meal. I wouldn't recommend spending your time here.

So I've probably been here like 10+ times. I always try to get a cheesesteak from here. I love the icecream as well. 

There are so many choices for what you can get. Also, this place is packed. You can think of it as like a mini shopping plaza indoors. 

Great place to show people new to philly.

So, I like Reading terminal.  Don't get me wrong.  It has lots of stuff, and when it's not jam-packed crowded it's a really great place to wander around.  An amazing destination for cheap produce (ah, Iovine!), gorgeous fresh flowers, Amish meats I will never ever try, fish that I don't buy, a wide selection of honey...  It's great!  It is.  Buuuut....it *is* a bit overpriced for lunch - I mean, I have no idea what the rent is on those little stalls, but it must be pretty high.  And I wouldn't get a cupcake there unless  really needed a cupcake.  And it is just so full of tourists and people who don't know how to walk.  It's just not a relaxing, chill place - it's a hustle and bustle place.  But you should totally go check it out.

Can't imagine saying anything bad about RTM.  If you want to avoid tourists, the best times to go are on weekday mornings.  My husband and I love coming here for before-work breakfast dates.  Sometimes, we stop at Schmucker's to get gluten-free breakfast sandwiches (Moses and his wife are amazing people).  Then, we get our coffee from Flying Monkey in the next aisle.  You also can't go wrong with Downhome Diner.

I also love RTM for groceries.  Iovine's is great for produce.  I also love Fair Food--they host the Lancaster Farm Fresh CSA, but also have a nice market (Weckerly's ice cream sandwiches = so, so good) and very lovely staff.

I'm only giving a 4 just for how crazy busy it is and how hard it is to find a place to sit and eat during the busy times - agree with others that weekday mornings are your best bet if you can make it then. What else can I say? It has everything and in both quantity and quality.

We all went to Philly to see the USS John F Kennedy, now retired and rusting in the shipyards... as that's where it all began for my husband over 22 years ago. After checking into the Ritz Carlton (which I HIGHLY recommend), we headed to Reading Terminal Market for some nosh. After reading a few reviews on Dinics, we tried their pork sammies with broccoli rabe... and regretted it almost immediately. Something was just "off" about the taste and smell, and the pork had very little (if any) spices. Nobody finished their sandwich, but wandering about the market was fun, and some of the other food vendors looked like they held great promise. We returned the next morning when my husband had an egg n sausage sandwich and I had a bagel with cream cheese and lox from Hershel's East Side Deli and it was fresh and oh so yummy. Funny story: the young guy behind the counter said "Do you want wudder in a cup or wuhdder in a bottle?" BAHAAAAA... so CUTE! I just LOVE that Philly accent!

I love Reading Terminal Market! It can be pretty crazy the first time you go, and a little overwhelming! I would recommend the Dutch place that has burgers, pulled pork, etc. The burger is delicious, can't go wrong there! But...the pulled pork is AMAZING! I would highly recommend this! The fries are also really good, you can watch them cut the potatoes and drop them in the fryer...so good!

When I have an afternoon free and i'm HUNGRY (or if friends are in town and I want to take them someplace cool) we head to RTM. I always get onse of those pretzel hotdog from the Amish stand. Then i walk around and graze on whatever is looking good. Oh, grab a treat from Flying Monkey Bakery - you wont regret it!

walked a mile just to get a donut
and It was worth it

If you want everything in one place when it comes to food I suggest going to Reading Terminal. It's very touristy so if you're into that sort of thing plan out a couple of hours so you can look at everything they have. There is a greasy atmostphere to the place but it gives it character. They have everything from their famous pulled pork, donuts, chocolates, indian food, burgers, hoagies, drinks, and tons more. My cousin bought some candles. I had some Indian food which was really good.

Wow, this is probably the best food market I've been to. Not only are there myriad food outlets but the prices are quite reasonable. If I lived in Philadelphia anywhere near this place, here is where you'd find me.

The grocery store is as good as many stand-alone stores you find. Tubby's olive oil place is great for gifts. LeBus bakery sells divine biscuits and croissants. Gourmet and specialty food items available, too. The breakfast place has to be good because half of Philadelphia was either sitting there or queued up. And many others.

I'm sure the market gets crowded but at 8 AM on a Saturday it wasn't at all. We spent about an hour and the aisles were still navigable when we left.
Great prices on fresh vegetables n fruits.  Great place to find whatever you enjoy eating.
This is an absolute must if you are in Philadelphia. There are many great places to eat as well as go shopping for cheeses and meats. There also is a bar in the back to grab a quick beer.
Terrible farmers market, rude and obnoxious local crowds, mediocre food, super dirty market. Stay away. Instead go to Seattle's Pike Place market or Atlanta's Underground (that's crowded too).
Get Blue Mountain wine and mozzorella wrapped in pruischutto.

The only thing I dislike about Reading Terminal is that it is so far from my house. I really only get to go every so often when I have friends visiting from out of town! Perfect place for tourists and locals, alike. I usually have a divide and conquer routine when I walk through the doors. This way, you save on time, hit all the spots, and when you find a seat, you can each try a little bit of everything! The stands I always hit are: Dinic's (roast pork), Herschel's (pastrami), and Meltkraft (grilled cheese). For dessert, Basset's (ice cream) and Beilers (donuts). Everyone raves about the fritters at Beilers, but theyre much too sweet and oily for my liking. On the other hand, the plain glazed and powdered cream donuts are life changing. I'm hoping to branch out and maybe check out the Dutch Eating Place or maybe some of the seafood stands soon!

Tip: if you're bringing a car, you can park in the garages marked for reading terminal, grab a voucher, and get it validated by any vendor in the market when you spend over $10. 2 hour parking for $4!

I was just looking for a good sandwich for lunch when I stumbled into this market hall. Immediately it hit me and I was in love with this place. The stands, the variety ... the everything! Seriously, if I ever was left in this place alone over night I would die from overeating. Everything here looks as I want to try it. If you're hungry and in the area: go here!

I am writing this review of Slack's Hoagie Shack in the Shoprite Shopping Center on Ark Road in Mt. Laurel.

I have not eaten a hoagie in YEARS.  On an impulse, I decided to stop in today.  What a reward!  I got a "Godfather" hoagie.  Prosciutto, capicola, salami.  The meat was thinly sliced, rich, and tasty.  The bread was fresh and chewy and the seeds on the roll added to nicely to the taste!  I loved this sandwhich.  Every calorie was well worth it!

We come out to Philly every year for a tattoo convention and this market is right across the street. I wait all year for Dutch corner omg! Best pretzels ever and I buy all their dried beans and jams and candies.
This place is a boon to conference goers housed nearby...a variety of food stalls as well as artisanal products and fruit. Slightly cramped and bustling but it all adds to the fun.
A must see and experience when in Philadelphia. Hustling and bustling food frenzy.  Something for everyone but good luck finding a table to sit while enjoying your epicurean delights.

Ive been to reading terminal about a dozen times since moving to Philly and its always a good time. I like how busy it gets with people shoulder to shoulder. Theres always something different to try and I love the pretzel place and the produce market - they have fresh squeezed orange juice for sale!

Despite the constant weaving through throngs of tourists, I love Reading Terminal. It's become one of my weekend rituals: grab a juice and a bite to eat, get lost in the aisles finding cool stuff, spend so little and get so much at Iovine Brothers, then wheel my granny cart full of fresh produce all the way home. 

Also, being that it's great for tourists, if I have friends visiting for the weekend, Reading Terminal is a great 2-for-1: show my friends something cool & touristy, but still get my weekend routine shopping done. Win win.

I don't have anything bad to say about Reading Terminal Market.  I would recommend that you get here pretty early to avoid crowds.  Iovine's is pretty great for produce and I haven't had a bad experience with any of the butchers or fishomngers, though I do prefer (if time allows) Ippolito's and Esposito's

Many businesses only take cash, so be prepared. A very wide variety of prepared foods, but limited seating. This is a cultural mecca of all sorts of foods and is a great place to browse and experience the sights and smells of a large, indoor market. If you don't like large crowds, you may get grumpy. A Philly highlight.

My first stop is always Iovine Brothers where I can usually get a ton of produce for under $20, then I go to Old City Coffee to get my Beans for the week and the wine cellar for my vino for that night's dinner. I take the trolley from West Philly after work and it drops me right there. I love this Philly landmark.

Went here on Sunday so i missed out on all the amish goods, but otherwise they have everything you'd want. I got some ice cream from Bassets and it was awesome. Definitely worth checking out while in philly

I really wish more cities had something similar to Reading Terminal Market. You can go in there and find just about any type of food you could want, and just about all of it is amazing!

Aside from great restaurants, there is a humongous selection of fresh produce, meats, seafood, cheeses, which could easily lead to hours of walking around in awe of your surroundings.

Definitely a must-visit when in Philly!

There are very few places I've visited that seem more like a writer's description of a marketplace come to life than here.  For a domestic sort of awe, this counts amongst the most impressive and inspiring indoor markets I've ever visited.

Having had many opportunities to entertain out of towners or simply enjoy a donut in the afternoon, Reading Terminal never disappoints.
A very delightful place with local foods that will please any and everyone palates!! If you're in Philadelphia, this is one of our staples! You must visit!
Best place in town to get food! Especially if your with other people that want to eat something different than you!! For travelers and tourists this is a Philly must do!!

I can't get enough of this place! If you're visiting the city, Reading Terminal Market is a must-see. There's something for everyone, from the biggest foodies to the pickiest eaters. Even if you're not there to chow down (but really, what else would you be doing there?) the market is always bustling and everyone should experience its fun atmosphere.
This is a place where no matter what food you are looking for you'll find! A great Philadelphia experience! So many choices and locally grown veggies! Amish food galore!

In a city that has delusions of being "world class" ( if you've ventured out into the world you know what I mean) Reading Terminal IS world class. Not as big as the indoor market in Warsaw, Poland or as quaint as the one in Oxford, England - I always feel proud  no matter where I am that Philadelphia's Reading Terminal is one of the greatest markets of its kind anywhere. Besides the wonderful Amish presence, the variety of foods and crafts, the friendly pub - no matter how crowded it is I always manage to find a seat.

Great place to take my friend visiting from out of town. Seating can be tough when packed but its all a part of the experience. I am hooked on millers twist soft pretzels and dienner's rottiserie chicken is amazing!!
I think I'm going to be able to get a new one for me and you, but I don't think I'm going to get my nails done with this new version of the best thing ever.

I love the Reading Terminal. It reminds me of European markets because it has so much to offer. You could come here with picky friends and you would all find something that suits you.  It gets pretty busy, so if you don't like being around a lot of people, you probably wouldn't enjoy this.

busy busy busy!

lots of stuff and vendors to look at and purchase

you have to stop by just to experience it.

Almost like the Ferry Building in SF, Chelsea Market in NYC but way way way more packed and busy than both
Really fun place to stroll around, grab a great lunch and some nice produce.

You'll never find such a diverse, unbelievably great, mass group of eateries in one place! No one will leave this place hungry or dissatisfied if they give this place a chance. You name it they have it, Cajun, Italian, Dutch, Asian, Greek, sandwiches, turkey, pasta, gyros, ice cream, and much more!! Fresh meats, seafood, vegetables, and bakeries! It truly is a wonderful place to visit and experience!

My absolute favorite market in America.

This is because of the cheeses sold by the Mennonites, who are so nice that they provide samples of everything. And the prices...let's not forget how cheap they are!

You can find a steak and onion cheese, which is to die for! YUMMMMM!

And everything else in that market is too good for words. Even the butchers, who sell prime cuts that are ready to cook.

The mennonites sure know how to make hearty delicious food so go have anything they are selling.

Even the baked good are so cheap! I once got a red velvet cake here for $8.

I LOVE THIS MARKET SO MUCH! Go on a Saturday or Friday and not a Sunday when the Mennonites are not there. You need them.
Tons of great food. Love the Cajun food stand best gumbo in town and the gator was actually good. If you can't find something there then you never will.

As a local, I usually just buy groceries at Iovine Bros. and the Head Nut here, but for the guilty pleasures, here's my list:

DiNic's Roast Pork - it's in the name
Beiler's Doughnuts - Apple Fritter is the way to go, don't be seduced by anything else (unless it's the Blueberry Fritter)!
Metropolitan Bakery - the sour cherry choc chip cookie w/sea salt

Always popping with energy and full of diverse options and delicious food.  Oh how much I appreciate the delicious fresh juice and veggie drinks, produce, and myriads of options.

This place exemplifies Philly and I would argue is the heart of Philly.

I love coming here even with the crowds. I would recommend to go on a Wednesday or Sunday because the fruit market gives students a discount. Who doesn't love a nice discount?

The food is also really good I always go to grab chicken samosas and something from one of the MANY bakeries. I have never had a bad experience with any of the places that I've eaten at. I love how everything is fresh and ready for purchase. 

Always a treat to be at Reading Terminal!

A must visit place when you are in Philly. A wonderful mixture of prepared food and fresh ingredients for those who want to pick up that special cheese, meat or even produce. 

Stop in here and have a cold beer while wandering through the spectacle.

This is a historic landmark and has been open since 1892 when the Reading Railroad built a terminal that was going to displace the outdoor markets on Market Street. A compromise was reached and the old markets agreed to new space under the railroad station and tracks. A new convention center nearly pushed the market out in the 1980s but merchants and preservationists were able to get the market renewed and it has remained as a vital market, busier then ever. Fresh baked cookies at the entrance, Philadelphia made ice cream from Bassets down one aisle and fresh bread and poultry down another. It's an amazing conglomeration of food and wine and candy and people that can be seen no where else.

Definitely a place to visit!

I've been here thrice during my one month visit. 

For the cheesesteak, I've tried Carmen's and By George! And I honestly like By George!'s better. A tip - Spataro and By George! Are closed on Sundays (among other stores) so the line at Carmen's get really long. I recommend going on other days to be able to visit all the shops. 

Bassett's Ice Cream is really good too! More on the creamier side. 

The donuts from Beiler's Bakery (closed on Sundays) are really good too! They run out really fast also. I tried the one with colored cereal on it and it was awesome. 

The chocolates from Mueller's are good as well! Even their sugar free options.

We went in search of Tom Dinick's famous pork with broccoli rabe sandwiches and he did not disappoint.  The line was long but moved quickly and there were bar stools around the stand inside the market.  We shared a sandwich and it was plenty big and filling, finger licking good.  To put it in perspective, we also sought out the famous Philly Cheesesteak at Pat's and it didn't hold a candle to this juicy treat.  Oh, almost forgot, there's just one ice cream place in there and it's the old fashioned creamy kind, enjoyed some delicious Moosetracks!

I love the food here and the energy. I would shop here more often for meat, fish, and produce if I lived closer. The one thing I cannot get over, that drives me nuts, is how crowded it gets. I know it cannot be helped, but I cannot stand pushing my way through endless crowds.

This place is awesome - hands down! Can't to visit the market again when I am in town! The "Old City" coffee was reasonably priced and the taste was great! Also visit the doughnut  please and ate the best doughnut I ever tasted and DeNik's - just excellent!!!
Cant go wrong with most of the vendors here for food.  Get a pork or beef from Dinics and a cookie from Fourth Street Cookies!

I do love this place. The ambience (history!), variety and quality of food are all, if not unique, very rare. I see negative reviews from drinkers, but if you are serious  about drinking, If you want to drink good beer go to Monks or get take out from the Foodery. 
Yes, the prices have gone a bit bistro, but this is the big city. Tasty fun for all ages!
Awesome place to visit in Philly. Tons of little shops makes for a very wide selection -- something for everyone.

I love coming here. Great fresh produce. Great pizza place. The diner is delicious. The chardonnay at the Blue Mountain Vineyard is one of my favorite chardonnays on the market. But my favorite thing about RTM? APPLE. DUMPLINGS.
This place is a must go if your a tourist. They have amazing food, produce, and etc.

There's something for everyone in reading terminal!

Grocery shopping for produce is spectacular. It is a little more expensive than the Italian Market but the produce is a better quality and lasts much longer.

Count yourself very lucky to work close for a top notch lunch spot. It can be crazy busy and a little disorienting for your first few times. Totally worth it, once you get the lay of the land. You really cannot go wrong with places to eat here. 

Here are my favorite 3:
Valley Shepherd Creamery & Meltkraft Grilled Cheese: Rivals Dibruno's for a cheese spot. Grilled cheese sandwiches are the best I've had. Valley Thunder (cheddar, brisket, mac n cheeese) is sooo good and try the Melter Skelter

DiNic's: Maybe the most popular draw in the entire place and is wildly busy during lunch. Expect a big wait but it is a must try for their famous Roast pork (close 2nd to John's Roast pork) and roast beef. The place has a ton of hype and deservedly so, the wait can be much. 

Wursthaus Schmitz: Part of Brauhaus, this place is definitely worth a try. Do yourself a favor and get some sausage and schnitzel in your life!

I know that it can be a tourist trap but it is a great place for a meal. Over the years, they have really expanded the variety of food options here. If you want BBQ, Chinese, Indian, Italian, Cheesesteak, or Crepes then you can find it here. Metropolitan bakery has a branch here. Some of the best cookies in Philadelphia are sold here through the 4th Street Cookie Company. You can also do all of your grocery shopping here. They have butchers, fish mongers, and specialty cheese shops galore. There is a monthly cooking class that I'm still trying to attend.  You can also get baked goods from the Amish and Mennonites of Pennsylvania. They have a stall that makes fresh donuts and the line is rarely short. Have a great time.

Liberty Bell Diner is my favorite place to go for breakfast, lunch or dinner and is open 24 hours. Mostly I go there for lunch and dinner and everything on the menu is delicious. There's early bird specials, businessman's special, and special menu for seniors, all at a great price. There's no alcohol served, like some other restaurants but you won't need to drink when you come here. I like how you feel like family and when you hear "Everyone, may I have your attention, someone's having a Birthday so let's sing "Happy Birthday"...how nice that they make you feel special like that. Such nice people and the food is great especially for the price. I'll tell you what I like, first, it's the chicken parm which covers the whole plate (delish). Also, the chicken and beef pot pie is yummy. I keep getting the shrimp scampi over white rice....out of this world delish.
Amazing.  Anything you can think of is there. Its a bit overwhelming, but once you decide what you want, its worth the wait.

If you're in Philadelphia, you must check out Reading Terminal Market! It appears to be a very hip and cool place to go walk around and buy and try some food. They have everything from meat, to ice cream, to cheesesteak and to even a local bookstore. 

Unfortunately, the day my boyfriend and I came there was a street fair going on and the Terminal was MOBBED. You couldn't move one inch without running into someone. This was a disappointment since I wish we could have experienced it more since it seems like such a cool place. We made the most of it though and did buy a cheesesteak from a local vendor. I'm sure that they usually aren't this crowded and most people will get a better experience then we did. 

Come here hungry and check out at least one or two places before you leave. Definitely worth it!! I'd give them another try the next time I'm ever in Philly. 

Cheers!
So much variety. Best thing I've had was a cheesesteak from Carmen's
Love the variety of stores and atmosphere! Great place for fresh produce.

Ive only eaten at a handful of places, in the RTM, but theres DiNics , which is good enough on its own to warrant a visit there, other than that to be honest, theres so many damn places I cant remember the name of them all .  I know thm as "that cookie place"..etc. 

Right across the street from the hotel where the valet stole my phone, hard to get to in terms of parking unless you're going to park in a lot, or at the Radisson downtown ... where your phone will disappear like David friggin Copperfield if you aren't careful 

If you're near City hall in Center city Philly you really cant miss, they have everything in there .
Try the Indian place. They have a spicy baked salmon. Pair it with spinach and vegetable rice.

This is great place to visit when you're a tourist in Philadelphia. If you're a local and haven't been there - get moving! 
There are great places to eat and terrific little shops. The Amish places are always great and some of Philly's finest can be found there. Check out Termini's for cannoli and the farmers market produce stalls.
This place is like heaven. some of the best food all in one place. A produce section and a lot of specialty grocery items.
Always love stopping by the Reading Terminal Market.  Check out the yummy German food kiosk:)
Literally the best place on earth. There is nothing like the Reading Terminal anywhere else in the country. You can entertain, grocery shop, and/or stuff your face. Seriously, you need to go here.
Love the reading terminal market! Can't get away from the Reubens!
Reading Terminal is a great spot to be an active eater.  Go enjoy some food and take in the sights.
Huge selection of ethnic foods all over the place ; shopping stands ; mini farmers markets selling fresh produce for really cheap! Love this place because you can wander around it for hours.

What a place-I was actually surprised that it wasn't that enormous of a place, but that's good!  Prices at most places weren't bad at all, and it's well run, and very clean!

Walk around and experience the sights and smells of what is an eclectic and diverse food city.  From all of the treat shops to the produce market, it's tough to resist buying a few of everything.

The world's largest (debatable I'm sure) food court is how we described this to our boys, who are semi-adventurous for their ages.   One had a fish sandwich at Wan's, the other a cheesesteak and fries from By George, where to me the prepared Italian dishes looked quite appetizing.  Frank's has good ribs, cornbread...but their mac and cheese was the highlight.

Amazing! I really enjoyed coming here and sampling a bunch of different vendors (Beilers for donuts, old city coffee, melt Kraft for amazing grilled cheese, the big ice cream place with the blue and white logo). Gets very crowded on weekends though, and wish it was open later. Tip- if you go like 20-30 minutes before closing some places are trying to get rid of products and will sell it at a heavily discounted price!!

I would love to get back to the Reading Terminal Market more, though I will advise that Sunday isn't the best day to go. I recently visited on a Sunday and discovered that a number of the vendors were closed for the day - and for what it's worth, Wikipedia notes "The Pennsylvania Dutch merchants (a small but significant minority) generally do not operate Sunday through Tuesday". I say this because my cousin and her husband had heard from friends about the Pennsylvania Dutch merchants, so they were a bit bummed that the timing didn't work out to visit their location during our time at the market. 

All told though, this enclosed market offers a nice variety of coffee, dessert, and food options (if I lived in the area, I'd be going here all the time to buy fresh produce). There are also a variety of florist-type places and the like that add a great brightness to the market. I grabbed a coffee early in our stop at the market and enjoyed the experience of wandering through the place and taking in all the smells and sights around me. 

Prices with most vendors are reasonable, though also know that some portions of the market can get very congested (and very quickly) as the day goes on. This last time, I think we all arrived around 11am (and we managed to grab parking on the street right outside the market), but we were there about 20 minutes and the market really started to fill up. The place serving crepes, for example, had SO MANY people around it. 

TL;DR  Would certainly visit again, but I'd pick a different day of the week (Wednesday or Thursday, maybe?) and get there earlier in the day. Enjoyable experience though.

We stopped here for breakfast.  There were so many places that I forgot where we ate.  We got some breakfast sandwiches and breakfast sides that were great.  I have never seen so many vendors in one place.  It was truly a unique experience.
A great place to shop, dine and people watch!
I enjoyed reading Terminal Market. so much to see so much food. I sampled the Cajun food and it was very good. so I will be going again
This is a great indoor market.  The restaurants in the market are delicious.  I really liked all of the other booths too.

RTM can be overwhelming if you on the weekend but it's a gem during the week.  There are numerous stalls with any kind of food you can imagine as well as wonderful gifts.  Some of the best stalls are closed on Sunday or Monday so plan your visit accordingly.

This place!!!!! I don't even know where to start! The smell, the taste, the people, the concept itself is amazing.  I'm so greedy, I had an amazing grilled cheese sandwich made from cheddar, brisket and mayonnaise, cheesecake, donuts, cheese steak, cookies, cream soda...I didn't eat it all at once, instead i just kept filling my shopping bag and I took it all home! 

It's easy to walk and navigate thru.

If you live near it, there are some great produce and fish market stalls that you can visit at times it is not jammed with people.  If you are going as a tourist, be prepared for crowds, particularly during lunchtime when finding seating can be a challenge.  It has a wide variety of food stalls (the cheesestak places will have long lines during lunch and tourist seasons) except for the Thai place which was sub-par.  Nice to visit but if you hate crowds, be prepared.....

You can't get better.  The atmosphere, the food, the drinks, the shops, the people, the location....you need to go here. Now. And get a pork sandwich from DeNic's. 

Now.
Always enjoy spending time here. Between the arts and crafts to all the wonderful eateries to shopping for dinner this place serves up a little of everything!
Simply put, it's food heaven. I would gain 50 pounds if I lived in Philadelphia!

Nice place to go for lunch. Lots of options, all kinds of food. We had the doughnut...to die for! Also the pull pork sandwich very good. Everything look delish. 

Must stop if your visiting.

4th Street Bakery was AWESOME!!!  Workers were super friendly and helpful.  Bassett's Ice Cream was crowded but they had a system and kept the line FAST, and they had SORBET, which was wonderful since I can't eat dairy.  Flying Monkey Bakery guy was chill and explained all their products and how best to refrigerate & didn't rush me.

I have been to the Reading Terminal Market once and it was chaotic. I am not a fan of places like that. The food was good though. One of my co-workers has a 2nd job near there and he does occasionally buy me excellent cannolis. That I would highly recommend if you like that type of stuff!
Best cannolis! Awesome flowers for good prices! Fresh meat! And if you have time, eat a grilled cheese!

This place is great.  You can get just about whatever you want served fresh here daily.  It's great for groups with different eating preferences because there is something for everyone.  

A few of my favorites were: Meltkraft (grilled cheese), Cookie Co , Dinics Sandwiches.  I haven't worked myself through the entire market, but I'd go back to Philly just for Reading Terminal Market

sorry I know this place is a Philly icon
It's so dirty- walk by at night and it's like Templeton after the fair in Charlotte's Web
GROSS

One of my go-to places in Philly. An absolute haven for all foodies, or anyone just looking for a great meal! There are so many food choices that it can actually be overwhelming! 
I always opt for DiNic's, and then stroll around for some desserts. I love the Amish bakery stands, everything is always fresh, delicious, and ALWAYS without that chemical taste. The donut stand is out of this world, the Elvis donut being my favorite. I can honestly say there isn't a single stand in the market that I don't enjoy, it's an amazing place!!

Obviously the Redding Terminal Market is a must. This place caters to every type of person. Everyone can find something that they love here. My favorite places are Hope's Cookies and the Amish Bakery. YUMM.

A trip to the convention center means a trip to RTM. Love love LOVE all the options for eating. I always take home a bag full of goodies from the Hatfield Deli, and or Flying Monkey. The slow cooked pot roast sandwich is my go to 99% of the time at Smucker's Quality Meats and Grill. The Indian place and Cajun place are awesome too.

As someone who lives in the suburbs, I used to come here just for lunch while in the city. Now that I work nearby, I do a lot of my regular grocery shopping here. I am never disappointed by the freshness or quality of the products I buy. Iovine's produce is a cheap and plentiful stop for all your fruits, veggies, and herbs. If you want the best sausage, go to Martin's.  Riehl's cheese is the best. I especially enjoy when I know that I am going to have company, so I have a reason to get a nice cake at Termini Bros or a dozen cookies from 4th Street Cookie Co. or the PA General Store. 
For lunch though, I enjoy Beck's Cajun jambalaya, pierogies from Franks A Lot, or chicken tikka masala from Nanee's Kitchen. No day is complete without an ice cream from Bassett's or donut from Beiler's Bakery.
I love that I always find something new here.
Pro Tip: Go on a weekday in the morning, or just before they close. Avoid during the Flower Show.

There is never a time when Reading Terminal Market isn't crowded. Of course, holidays and weekends are the most chaotic. It's also really hard to find a place to sit.

Even still, I will never let a friend visit me in Philly without checking out Reading. So many awesome and diverse food options. It truly is a smorgasbord of the very best Philadelphia cuisine. My most recent delicious discovery is the Singapore style noodles at Golden Bowl. Spicy, delicious, and plentiful. Also, you shouldn't walk out without 6-12 Beiler's donuts to go. Yum!

wit..witout ?   save yourself  ,  get here for the best PORK or BEEF sandwiches  
sweet or hot peppers , shaved & aged Provolone  a great way to power thru lunch .
Superb & consistent
Visiting Philly? A must-see on your tour list!

Walking into this humble abode, I call this foodie haven! Literally, it's just wall-to-wall of savory goodness from every diverse part of the world. As the City of Brotherly Love should continue to pride its rich and diverse offerings, Reading Terminal Market does that! Today I had Tommy Dominics for their roast pork sandwich (f**kin DELISH) followed by Beller's Donuts for a couple incredible donuts (Maple Bacon and Elvis's Delight - both had bacon!). I'm gonna have to come back again if I want to savor more of its fine offerings!
What a great experience I had at the Terminal Market.  Anything you could possibly want is there.  What is really nice is that it is indoors on those cold winter days.

I can't say enough about RTM. I made my way here last year while on vacation and my eyes nearly popped out of my head drooling at all the goodies. I had to return this year. Where do I begin? I grabbed a dozen donuts from Beiler's, fudge, butter mints, fresh made fruit juices, a Brielle grilled cheese sandwich from Meltkraft, and the icing on top was the Tikka chicken, rice and chick pea and spinach samosa. It's authentic Indian food and its to die for. I will definitely be back again next year. I haven't tried anything at RTM that I didn't like. There is an old man that sits close to one of the entrances(near the 4th St cookie company. He's old, crass and downright rude. Don't ask him to tell you where something is located. He'll belittle you for asking. I didn't take any points away for that because people are just people-some nice some not. I ignored him and went about my business and found everything I was looking for.

Love this place, plus the cheap validated parking across the street or the ride in from Septa make it easy to go! DiNics, Termini Bros, Carmens Cheese Steaks, Dutch Eating place and oh so much more, the hardest thing is deciding where to go and what to get. No matter your choice or preference there is a very good chance it will be very good if not amazing, But you must choose wisely!
I fell in the love the second I walked in. This was our very first stop when we arrived to Philly. This market has everything which is awesome!
Everything you can imagine. Best to go in the off season and better tues-sat when the omish are there.

I absolutely love markets like the Reading Terminal Market.  I mean, you can't go wrong with the abundance of food deliciousness at this place.  I'm not from Philly so this was my first visit but certainly won't be my last.  I will travel for food, specifically veggie food. I don't recall all of the veg options but RTM has so much to offer.  We were only seeking breakfast and grabbed a few orders of hotcakes from the Dutch Eating Place; those babies were huge.  My last stop before departing was the Herbiary.  I didn't get to explore as much as I would have liked so more reason to come back.

This is my second visit to Philadelphia, and my second visit to the Reading Terminal Market. Decided to branch out from cheesesteaks and try MeltKraft grilled cheese -- so glad I did! The sandwiches are delish, and the staff were incredibly friendly. They even pointed me to various other foodie places around town. Five stars in general for the market, and especially for MeltKraft!

Nothing like Reading Terminal to give you a unique experience of the Amish markets, fresh  farm grown produce, squeezed juice, and a plethora of cultural cuisines. My favorites are the crepe place, Olympia Gyro, 4th street famous cookies (woww), Termini Bros Bakery (Cheesecake!!), DiNic's roast pork, Bassetts Ice Cream. It's a struggle to find seats and maneuver through the crowds, so be prepared !

So this place is awesome.  It's right next to the convention center.  I was looking for a vegetarian option and there were enough options for me to choose from.

They have a donut place here that people are raving about.  I will come back to try that another time!
fresh seafood and produce. fresh breads, cheese wheels spices and great restaurants for lunch

I live nearby and have purchased flowers, caulk, paint,etc. They are always helpful and they sell mostly everything.
Recently I bought a replacement screen for my patio door and had  no way of getting it home. Tony offered to follow me home with the screen  in his van then as if that were not enough he volunteered to carry it upstairs to my deck!
This is hometown service!  I feel grateful to live close to this store!

Judy C

This place is amazing. They have every and anything you can possible need when it comes food. From Greek, to Asian cuisine, you will be able to find it here. I have never found such diversity in one building before. The vastness is what makes this as impressive as it is. The good food, sounds and smells all contribute to make this a place worth visiting. If you can't find anything that peeks your interest, I would truly be shocked.
I don't need to explain this. Some of the best food in Philly is in here and if you're a foodie you most likely know this. Go now and try everything (especially DiNics).
I love this place. Donuts, cheese, coffee, vinegar, sausages...what else is there in life?

Love, love, love this place!!!  Highly recommend it for everything between a quick shopping experience to grabbing a cup of Joe, flowers, ice cream, candies, fresh juice to a hearty breakfast, lunch or dinner. I would go here everyday if I lived in Philly.

This is a food MECCA. Just go. Go lots of times! Try the butter cake at the Flying Monkey! Beck's Creole Cafe gives samples of their deliciousness, and don't miss Beiler's - the Deli and the donuts are a must.

Wow, this spot literally blew my mind. If you're looking for something to do, something to eat or just plain whatever. Make your way here and watch the hours melt away.

Once you walk in, you are literally greeted by mom and pop shops all over the place. Grocery shops, food stalls and dry good items. Heck yea!! It's like sensory overload!! From fresh fish to meat to cheese to produce I will guarantee that you're gonna have a hard time keeping the money in your wallet. Trust me, you will spend on something here.

Today, we came to eat,,, and it's not hard to find something to fancy as well. Everything from Mediterranean to Chinese to hoagies to burgers, you'll find them here. I haven't tried all of the stalls here, we had Tommy Dinics, but I can bet you they're all pretty good. You fancy making your own food? Buy yourself some fresh fish, some produce and a bag of potatoes, go home and cook yourself a kick ass meal. Don't feel like turning on the stove?? Fine,, buy a box of crackers, there's some cured meats and cheeses and create yourself a charcuterie board.

I could go on and on about this place and how awesome it is, but wouldn't you rather be experiencing it first hand??

Life is short, go experience awesome things.

Weeeeeeeee!!!
I have lived in Philadelphia for 6 years and this is my favorite place to go. Dinic's roast pork sandwich with provi and broccoli rabe is a must have.

WARNING:: Sensory overload will be imminent if entering this establishment. 

The sights will amaze you. You won't be able to decide what to eat. There are so many fantastic restaurants, you can't really make a wrong decision. If I may though, I highly suggest Tommy Di Nic's and Country Breakfast. 

The smells will fill your nostrils with more pleasure than that crazy night back in your sophomore year of college. Use your sense of smell to guide you to your dream meal. 

The tastes will blow you away. Nothing like a Tommy Di Nic's roast pork sandwich with broccoli rabe, hot peppers, and provolone. Your taste buds are not ready. 

Unfortunately your sense of sound and touch might not be as pleased. You will feel cramped. Slow moving people, ogling everything in sight. You will hear loud crowds. This is a place to be, thus there will be noise. If there is one thing you'll hear often, it'll be "That was delicious".  

Trust me though, you'll gladly sacrifice those two for the other three. This is a must stop if you're visiting the city.

I really don't know how to asses this place with stars. There are so many vendors, the conditions vary based on time of day, upcoming holidays, and even what trade shows are going on across the street. 

In general, I really like the market. Giunta's Meats is a favorite of mine. I'm also a big fan of DiNic's Roast Pork and Beef, as well as Hershel's Deli. The market has really gotten better over time, but it's also getting increasingly crowded.

You have to be alert while walking, and stopping in the middle of an aisle to gawk is frowned upon (yes, even by me). Seating can be very difficult, especially during lunch. If you love the hubbub of a bustling market, this is your place. If you want a quick, convenient, calm, easy option, this is not your place. 

Dear tourists: When you come to our market, chose seating that matches the number in your party. That is, do not take up an eight person table, and three extra chairs for your bags just to seat four people. Additionally, if you are going to stop and gawk at one of the vendors, move out of the aisle. This is like stopping in the middle of a highway, because you saw a cute bird on the side of the road. It's disruptive and arrogant.
Such a great selection of interesting food. Can't wait to come back I only wish it stayed open later!
Love the selection of great foods here. Beck's Cajun Cafe, Dutch Eating Place and By George's are my go-to places!

Reading Terminal Market is a cool place to walk around in, but that's it, you're much better off just walking and looking rather than trying any of the food that is offered there. The restauranteurs do a good job of presenting some of the food items, but that is where the buck stops. The food just doesn't taste as good as it looks. Basically, Reading Terminal is a huge TOURIST TRAP. Go there, try something if you really have to, and then leave and never look back. There are many, more cleanly,less crowed, better quality, though albeit less well known places to dine in the city of brotherly love.

En tant qu'Européenne le Reading Terminal Market me fait penser au marché couvert de Barcelone, La Boqueria ! Des produits locaux, frais, typique et atypique, en somme un lieu qui vaut le détour ! J'ai pu y goûter les fameux cheese steack, spécialité de Philadelphie, et y rencontrer des Amish et leur produits 'homemade'. Je conseille fortement à tous les touristes, expatriés, ou étudiants comme moi d'y faire un tour. Seul bémol : énormément de monde au moment du déjeuné et peu de place pour s'assoir.

Words can't describe how much I love this place.

From onion chocolates, homemade honey to duck fried rice, the oldest ice cream place in the  and apple dumplings, The Reading Terminal is by far the best touristic place in Philly and best place for foodie travelers.

Throughout my week in Philly, I went back to The Reading Terminal 4 times. Kinda crazy right? I mean... They literally have everything there. I kinda feel embarrassed to say this but I wish I had spent more days to just try everything there...

Prices are decent depending on what you buy but if you eat, you will most likely spend the same amount of money.

Things I try or bought or recommend:

1. Dinics - great pork hoggies
2. Homemade Honey from Delaware: blueberry, orange, raspberry flavors
3. Apple dumplings
4. Bassetts - oldest ice cream place in the world
5. Duck Lo Mein
6. Buy fresh ahi tuna and mozzarella cheese

I'll be back Philly. I promise.

This place is great!  
Here you can find the BEST donuts (Beiler's), some delicious PA Dutch foods of other kinds, plus about any kind of ethnic food you might want, and lots of knick knacks and gift items, as well as fresh fish (sushi grade, if you're into that kind of thing, which I am), fresh veggies (not really your typical farmer's market options though -- I think they're mostly shipped in from Mexico/California/wherever most grocery store veggies come from) and lots of other local mainstays.  
HOWEVER, this place is often mobbed by people from conventions, and things can be overpriced.  
If you are a guest from out of town, you will find few better places for fun, tasty foods and some local flavor, and if you live within walking distance, it's worth coming here for certain things, but it doesn't rank in my top 10 places for food in the city, not even close!

I love this place and its on my places of must stops whenever I visit Philly. Think of it and it's in here. I can't remember the names of some of the vendors I've frequented but I know the Creole food spot is banging. Also the ice cream place by the exit. Last but not least there is a diner which serves excellent breakfast fare.
Great food. Not enough seating at times. Tough with kids because of crowds.

So many food options, surely you can find something you'd like.  I got a whoopie pie for $1.50, fresh whipped cream.  Also, I had breakfast at a diner I can't remember the name of.  Service was quick which I appreciated as I was very hungry.
Mind blowing variety of food! Philly cheese steak! Pastries! Name it! They've got it!

Great historical landmark in Philadelphia! Buy fresh Bronzino from a fish monger, incredible meats from the Amish farmers, and the best fruit in town at Iovine's. The list goes on and on. You can eat breakfast, lunch, and dinner here all weekend from every type of ethnic restaurant imaginable. What a blast!

I love it! Everything you could possibly want is all in  one place. From the crepes to the meats to the produce not one thing has ever been less than wonderful for me. I highly recommend it for a quick lunch spot, or a place to buy produce or dinner. So impressed.
Bustling atmosphere, great place to shop whole fish, fudge, honey, and tons of places to eat!
Bielers donuts are amazing!! The panini place is quite good if you have time to wait a bit! Really haven't had any negative experiences at any of the vendors!
Greatest selection of originial Philly food in the city!

I wish I had more time to explore this place! There was SO much going on, but it seemed to have everything you could ever want. It's a foodie playground, and I can see why people love it so much. I had my eyes set on the produce area, which was slammed, so maybe I'll come back another time to get some goodies.  

It's only a four for me. I did love the concept and everything they had. It was exciting, but personally, it was almost impossible to move around (which is why I'm rarely in the city). 

I suggest coming here when you aren't pressed for time! There's to much to see to rush through it!

A melting pot of flavors and different cuisines.
It is impossible to eat your way here in a day..more like a week. Places worth a visit are:
FOUR SEASONS JUICE SHOP; incredible edible fruits all processed into amazing vitamin packed juices. Anytime juice good as a meal or as a liquid snack.
MARKET BAKERY; artisanal breads, muffins, and coffee.
SWEET AS FUDGE CANDY SHOP; gotta a sweet tooth?
Best gummy bears i always get the green apple, blue rasberry,  pinneapple and coca cola..
Dont forget the lemom drops..get it all by the pound...LOL. if you worry about sugar they have sugar free items as well.
BASSETS ICE CREAM; home made creamy ice cream in very delicus flavors. I like coffee and chocolate bit the flavors can really get complicated.  
FAMOUS 4TH STREET COOKIE COMPANY; the best cookie in town, no questions asked just get in line brinf some cash and wait for the cookies to come out the oven.  My favorite are the chocolate, ginger snaps and snicker doodle. Yum..exponentially!
THE RIB STAND; come hungry and be ready to eat with your eyes. Ribs to die for with great bbq sauce. They too have pulled pork and other items but the ribs are awesome tender and well seasoned.
LOBINE BROTHERS PRODUCE; you can pick up fruit and veggies directly from local producers around the area.
KEVIN PARKERS SOUL CAFE; great mac and cheese and fried chicken with collar greens 
This market is amazing, you can live in this place.
I think i have been coming to this market since 2010 and every year it gets better!
An experience! Very crowded but has truly everything. A create mixture of a variety of different local and exotic foods as well as crafts and shops.

This place is amazing - a foodie paradise on earth.. Hot pretzels .. Amish jerky amazing desserts chocolate
wine Chinese food ... We were in town 2 days and went twice!

Interesting market with a really great range of groceries, fruit preserves, meat, cheese and wine just to name a few. It's noted as a must see local, historic attraction on Philadelphia's tourism website. 

Nice food court with lots of tables and seating. Ending up getting ice-cream from Bassett's and wine from Blue Mountain Wine.

If you're a tourist in Philly, you should definitely stop by.

Reading Terminal is awesome. I go on average twice a week for veggies and fresh fruits for smoothies. Right around the corner from Iovinne Brothers is the cheese place where the guys are extremely helpful and informative. They turned me on to Labne kefir cheese, which is now a favorite.
Alive with people and jam packed with amazing eats. Foodies heaven! Bring cash as some places don't take debit/credit. Limited seating. Best cheesesteaks and haogies at Carmen's.

How can you not LOVE the Reading Terminal Market?  It's a taste of everything Philly in one location.  Is it crowded? Yes.  Can parking be a pain?  Yes.  But will you have a culinary experience liken one other? Yes.  

For a full experience don't go on a Sunday, the Amish stands are closed (I think they're closed Monday's, too), so you'll miss out on some delicious treats and what feels like 1/4 of the market will be closed.  

The Market has changed a lot recently- a few new stands and brand new bathrooms.  It feels cleaner and more customer friendly.  We always stop by The Original Turkey - it's the best!!!

This is just one of those very unique places in Philly that you must experience. If you are a foodie, prepare to spend some time here. They've got locally grown produce, Amish specialties, fresh flowers, meats, cheeses, desserts, and other foods you've been missing out on all your life. Reading terminal is rich in its' history as well as in its' food. 

Prepare to be over stimulated, it is usually filled with tourists and locals. Also, some of the places are CASH ONLY. Some of my favorite places to go are for their sweets. You must try Bassett's ice cream, Beiler's donuts, and Termini Bros (esp for their cannoli with choco chip cream cheese filling or cream cheese carrot cake!!)

FYI- there is $4 parking for 2 hours at 2 garages nearby if you spend $10 at the market (with merchant validation)

Will continue to shop/eat here!
