If you live in Philadelphia or are visiting, you have to check out Reading Terminal Market.  The market has literally everything you could possibly want.  DiNic's roast pork is my personal favorite.  The only thing keeping this from 5 stars is seating can be hard to come by.  If you visit during the week and are looking for seating from 12:15 - 1:30, good luck.  But the variety and uniqueness can't be beat.
Love it!  Never leave there hungry but the choices are way too many-I end up spending too much and bringing it home.

I absolutely loved this clusterfxck of food vendors jampacked into these tight quarters. I may even have been more excited about coming here than my visit downtown.  There are tons of people, super noisy which I think just adds to the appeal of this Philly staple.

This is a foodie's paradise. No joke. There are vendors everywhere selling every palatable whoozits and whatzitz imaginable.  cheesesteaks, pizza, pastries, cheese, meats, seafood, they have everything here. There's a lot of scattered tables for sitting and you can literally eat your way through the market if your belly and wallet allowed. 

Some shops are cash only, but most take credit cards.  Parking can be found in the neighboring areas for a small fee. 

In my one hour here, we managed to get a half dozen donuts, a cheesesteak, and pizza.  That didn't include much browsing time though.  Make sure you give yourself enough time to truly enjoy walking around and soaking up the atmosphere.

Ooops. Apparently I attached this review for the incorrect reading terminal market link.
-----------------------------------------------

I absolutely loved this clusterfxck of food vendors jampacked into these tight quarters. I may even have been more excited about coming here than my visit downtown.  There are tons of people, super noisy which I think just adds to the appeal of this Philly staple.

This is a foodie's paradise. No joke. There are vendors everywhere selling every palatable whoozits and whatzitz imaginable.  cheesesteaks, pizza, pastries, cheese, meats, seafood, they have everything here. There's a lot of scattered tables for sitting and you can literally eat your way through the market if your belly and wallet allowed. 

Some shops are cash only, but most take credit cards.  Parking can be found in the neighboring areas for a small fee. 

In my one hour here, we managed to get a half dozen donuts, a cheesesteak, and pizza.  That didn't include much browsing time though.  Make sure you give yourself enough time to truly enjoy walking around and soaking up the atmosphere.
Diverse, tasty and a little bit of peace in a crazy city!

Love them! Check out Valley Shepherd Cheeses  - best grilled cheese in town and the Produce place (there are two, both great but the corner one is dynamite!). Love love love. I suggest for both locals and tourists!

This is one of my new favorite spots in Philly! It has been around forever, but I never gave it a fair shot. I went there with a grocery bag, and an empty stomach, and wow was I impressed! There are so many options, and it wasn't too over crowded for  Sunday early afternoon. It so unique and having a market indoors is awesome, as I can head and hang there day or night!
This place is so fun and the food is excellent!  I had a great almond croissant and a Philly cheesesteak!!!
This place is awesome! Anything and everything you could want from fresh fish to aged cheeses! I so wish this place was near me!

Great place to visit while in Philadelphia. So many options for fresh food. It is so hard to decide. We also had the opportunity to attend a private, after hours, party where we sampled many different food options, oysters, shrimp, Philly cheesesteak, falafel and more!

gotta grab a pastrami reuben at Hershel's!

shout out to Beck's Cajun too :)

Meltkraft - I'd say not worth the hype..

Reading Terminal is the perfect place to meet friends & hang out, while grabbing a great bite to eat, or do some food shopping.

There is a vast array of food selection of eateries: seafood, Rotisserie, sandwhich shops, burger places, Thai cuisine, soul food, cajun. food, & a myriad of bakeries where you can get: pastries, cakes, fresh baked bread,  cookies, ice cream and other authentic desserts. 

Reading Terminal is located in the heart of center city Philadelphia. Don't fear trying to find parking, for there is a park lot across the street which provides discount parking to Reading Terminal patrons. This is a  place  you must visit if you are in the Philadelphia vicinity.

Awesome big food market with everything you want. Food court, shopping, desserts, everything from around the world.
Would definitely come back!!!

I want to live inside this market. There's every kind of food you could want, with a range of prices. It's a bit overwhelming and it took me a few laps to settle on something to eat, but that's what's great about it. Theres a general seating area that had plenty of room on a Friday afternoon so,you can sit and eat meals from vendors without counter service.

Oh how I loved this place! I've been longing for it since we left Philadelphia. So much good food here. Definitely a must! Spend three days at the hotel upstairs and had all of our food needs met here. Recommend the Dutch Eating Place!

Holy moly!!! This market is huge! My eyes lit up in every direction I turned to.  It has everything you can imagine.  All types of fresh meats and seafood, desserts and pastries, burgers, pizza, sandwiches, cheese, crepes, fresh smoothies and juices, Chinese German Indian Pakistani & Middle Eastern food.  This place is just foodie heaven! They even have an oyster bar and a regular bar with TVs.  I wished I had more time to spend here to try all the different food options.  A must visit place in Philly for sure.

this was one of highlights during my trip to philly. it's a market with such a huge variety of food. i tried dinics, the amish donuts, and a pastrimi place and all of them were super yummy. a must-see-eat-visit place when in philly

Foodie paradise.  Immaculate. I only wish we had been a bit hungrier when we went.  We had pretzels from an Amish stand, peirogies from a deli stand, and ice cream from Bassetts. All superb.  The meats and produce looked super fresh, with reasonable prices.  Wonderful selection of jams and jellies, nuts, olives, cheeses, oils, flowers.  The most delicious looking donuts that they make in front of you, in so many flavors.  Can't wait to visit again!

Almost everything here is top notch.  I love the atmosphere and the free music.  The only vender that was disappointing was the Thai restaurant.  I love Thai food but thought they just "slopped" it together.  
The hardest part is deciding what to eat.

I probably eat here at least once a week. Great selections and decent prices. You have to be careful with what time you go because it can get very busy with tourists and folks at the convention center.

Good food options.  The ice cream joint located near the front is just ok.  The cookie place across from the ice cream place is great. I also like the different sandwich shops and the fresh food markets.  I would give the place 4 stars if they power washed the floors on a regular basis.

I bring all my out-of-towners here. I (we) love it every time. It's packed but it's definitely worth going. Plus they deliver on instacart !!!

Beiler's has the best donuts I've ever had and the oysters at the Oyster Bar are always fresh.
Reading Terminal Market is an incredible place, to eat, shop, and hang out. I buy all of my produce there and the student discounts are awesome!

The Mecca of deliciousness and diversity. I'm from
Chicago and I wouldn't dare come to philly and not visit this place at least once a day. If not more. Could easily come for a week, eat delicious and different  everyday here and spend under 150/200 dollars for the entire week. EASILY.

This is a staple place to bring out of towners for lunch or simply grab something when you can't make up your mind and need a lot of choices. Best days to go are when the Amish are there for more variety. It's really a unique place where everyone can find something, whether it's indulging in a cheesesteak, some Asian food or finding healthy choices like salads and sushi. My personal favorite is Diener's chicken wings. Rotisserie, flavored goodness that is not greasy and never disappoints.

Reading Terminal Market reminds me of Chelsea Market in NYC, only it's way bigger, has a much larger selection of food stalls, produce, and shops. I found it bustling, but low key, with plenty of seating, not that much waiting around and I liked the layout a lot better because it takes up a whole square block and there are multiples to come in and out of the building.

Tried Di'nics roast pork sandwich with extra sharp provolone and roasted sweet peppers. I highly recommend it - the roast pork is so succulent and juicy, and the combination of the roasted peppers with the sharp provolone kept the sandwich interesting, so you kept waiting to eat more and more of it. On top of it, the soft italian roll would soak in the juices with each bite, and it just got more delicious at the end.

Really, really good.

RTM is awesome when you are looking for unique bits to eat and even specialized ingredients. The only downfall is it can be quite pricey. For instance Iovine's Grocery carries many fresh produce items like the Italian Market, but can be 3X more expensive. The other downfall is that it is a huge tourist attraction, so if you are a local avoid the weekends and opt for a mid week shopping trip.

I can't seem to get past Beiler's Donuts every time I go to Reading Terminal!!!  A vanilla creme donut is my all time favorite just in general.. but I have to get that and the apple fritter every time I pass Beiler's.  Everyone must try this apple fritter.  Trust me...
Yes.. Reading Terminal is usually crowded with people and could be daunting to those that don't know where they are going.  It seems that everyone around you does!  But have no fear, once you get used to the rush and the 'panic' of people rushing around you to get to where they want to go.. you start to fit right into the traffic patterns like the 'regulars'.
Go to the Dutch Eating Place (line is always is long, but wait isn't that bad), Sweet as Fudge Candy Shop, Hatville Deli for lunch meats and fresh bacon, scrapple, Dienner's BBQ chicken for great rotisserie chicken, 4 seasons Juice Bar  and of course Beiler's. DUH.
I'll get to the rest of Reading terminal at some point! (I've walked it many times.. but always return to that corner of the world for some odd reason!) Will definitely come back to Reading Terminal...

This is the first place anyone visiting Philadelphia should hit up. Yes, its packed with tourist all the time but there is a reason why so many choose to come here. If you get there early definitely get breakfast at the Dutch Eating Place (open tuesday-saturday). Dutch Eating Place is the perfect place for a simple good breakfast- my favorites are the omelets and pancakes. DiNics is a must for their roast pork sandwiches, the lines are worth it. And if you are local or new to the area, this is the best place to get your fresh meats and produce. Iovine Brothers has the freshest and cheapest produce around.
Love this place. So many options. Seems like locals come here as well which is nice. Highlights were the ribs and mac and cheese balls. Oh yeah, the cannolis!

Came in on the Sunday of Labor Day Weekend (2015) and this place was so full of life! Lots of places to eat and shop and a live band playing in the middle of the seating area. It was so hard to choose where to eat because all of them offered something that looked and smelled absolutely delicious! The only downside was more than a few places were closed, probably because it was Sunday. We ended up grabbing a sandwich from Tommy DiNic's that did NOT disappoint. This is definitely a must see if you're in Philadelphia.

a crowded gem, local color, great food, crazy non-food items.
One of the places that makes Philly Philly. Don't miss Denic"s pork & provelone sandwich

Absolute Favorite! We take all of our out of town guests here as soon as we can. It's a great place bc they can get a feel for the charismatic Philly atmosphere and get classic Philly dish while I get whatever the heck I want! Of course we always end our visit with some ice cream from Bassetts
i love this place! mmm... my go to spot is the amish rib stand. sucks that they are closed on monday and tuesday.

Every time i go to Philly i need to stop by here. There are about 100 different vendors and so many awesome options to try a great variety of foods. 

I still need to try all the spots but i recommend going with a big group of people and trying as many things as you can! Fun time as well

--- Short Synopsis ---
 
This place seems like a food haven and a foodie's (aka Yelper's) dream! There are so many delicious smells, tastes, and sights here at the Reading Terminal Market. I also like how it's simply organized into "streets" and blocks. It feels like there is something here to cater to many tastes!

Tommy DiNic's (or just DiNic's) and Beiler's Donuts were divine!
 
--- Detailed Review ---
 
Seeing how this place had the 2nd most Yelp reviews in Philly (2nd only to Pats Steaks) AND 4.5 stars, I had to come here to check this place out when I flew to Philly en route to a place a few hours south. I am glad I did!
 
Driving and parking here was a tad hectic, but I eventually found my way. The parking garage next door is $4 for two hours if you make a purchase of $10 or more from a Reading Terminal Market vendor. Just make sure to get your parking ticket validated. I would suggest walking and/or public transportation. I am going to do that next time.

As for the actual market, I was initially a little lost where I was, so I began wandering around. I eventually stumbled across a map near the restroom. This help me orient myself and explore the market. There are so many vendors, but they all relate to food, which is awesome!! Most of the vendors sell ready to eat foods like sandwiches, burgers, and pastries, but they are others that sell raw food like produce and seafood! 

From exploring, I noticed Beiler's Donut/Bakery corner had a long line and previous Yelp research led me to Tommy DiNic's. I had both and instantly fell in love with both! They were amazing!

For Tommy DiNic's, the roast pork sandwich with provolone and their broccoli rabe was such an amazing combination. The strong, but not overpowering, cheese complemented the succulent pork. The broccoli rabe provided that nice chewy texture. The bread's texture and taste was excellent along with containing all the extra juices of its delicious interior items. I also enjoyed putting the peppers they provided along the counters. It adds another depth of flavor along with a crunchy texture.

Just a heads up, Tommy DiNic's is also referred as just DiNic's on the map.

For Beiler's Donuts, I tried the harvest apple and blueberry fritter. They were both amazing, but I liked the blueberry fritter more. Each bite was like a blueberry muffin that had been perfectly deep fried with that amazing crisp edge to it, along with being coated in a sweet, succulent glaze!!

For any Yelper, even those just using Yelp to find places, this is a must stop destination in Philly! There are just so many options in this market!!
Don't wanna go there anymore!   I'd rather go to China town.  Cheesesteak was so so. Don't really like it. Fried chicken,  not good.  Crepe,  no!
I always love this place when we come to town. The vendors are thoughtful and all about customer service.  The food is delicious. The entire place oozes character.

I really enjoy going to the reading terminal to shop for my regular groceries which i had not considered until recently.  The Iovine produce is perfect, come early to avoid the crowds and if you are driving park in the lots for $4 with a confirmation stamp.  Excellent for all food items and especially cheese and produce.
Awesome food, great shopping, and unique finds!  The selection of food, especially on the days when the Amish are there, is second to none!

When I pop into Reading, I primarily stick to one corner, which has Iovine Brothers Produce and Giunta's Prime Shop.  These two stores can supply about 80% of my grocery needs each week for prices that continue to surprise me ("Really? $11 for this whole bag of produce??").  Overall, I'm happy to frequent these sellers for the great prices, awesome selection, and helpful, nice employees.  

However, the hours can be a bust:  closing at 6pm means I'm rushing in from the trolley stop after work and doing a mad dash for those one or two extra necessities for my dinner recipe. I think it's usually worth it though.  The yellow plums I got last week were divine.

I like this place despite it being a tourist trap, it's always crazy busy, but the food is worth it. There is a ton of variety when you come here, Indian, Greek, Thai, Italian and of course Amish. The Amish are the best bakers in the world and their cakes and pastries are the best, they're fresh and fairly cheap. If you're a cook, there is a ton of food you can find here for your recipes, fresh produce, fish, meats and hard to find ingredients and cheeses. The sights, sounds and smells are enough to visit here even if you're just passing through and the bathrooms here are very clean and big enough to handle the crowds you'll see here.

Loved the ambience of the food market. There were plenty of food stalls but I did find that it lacked some foreign / ethnic foods. Great cheesecakes from Beiler, cajun fare from Becky's. It isnt easy to hrab a table n chair so try to beat the crowd at peak hours.
There are SO many options and if you can't find it at Reading Terminal, that's your problem! j/k But for real, it's awesome! So many options! Go! Go now!
Lots of good eclectic eateries here.    Really is a must see in a culinary tour of unique Philly spots.

This place has a mecca of food. Some places are better than others, but I love the plethora of options here. you can get Roast Pork/Brisket at DiNics, Roasted and Carved Turkey like Thanksgiving, Chinese Food, Thai, Fried Chicken, Burgers, Sushi, Bassett's Ice Cream, Donuts and bakery items by the Pennsylvania Dutch and fresh produce as well!

It's great to try a bunch of different places each time. The prices are also incredibly reasonable too. Just avoid coming during peak times as it can be very crowded and the lines get long.

Working in philly allows me to stop into reading several times a week, which I happily do.
Everything from produce, butchers, cheesesteaks and dessert is offered. Not to mention a florist, organic skin care and even clothing. Seriously, there's so much offered here.

One I first started to come to reading I was overwhelmed with all the food options, what to eat, what do drink, who offers a better special, who makes a better sandwich, ugh, so many options.
But I mean, who can really complain about having to many options?! NO ONE! 
All the spots I have tried here are great! Food is good and staff is good.

Seating is limited but what do you expect? This place is always packed and has hundreds of people at any given time. They always have piano player during the lunch hours which is really cute. 

Come on an empty stomach, be open to trying something new and walk around the whole place! Look at all your options! Enjoy!!!

Best place ever.  From the pretzel stands to the diner, everything is just amazing, fresh, delicious.  If you're a tourist, it's a must for lunch!  Skip those overpriced restaurants and get a bite to go and sit at the park or in the terminal's own indoor seating area.  You can also get lots of local goodies, pastries, cheeses, meats, dairy, etc.  It's the bomb.  Great for the family as well, fun for everyone since there is someting for everybody!
Love this place! Amazing selection, run by pros with all different specialties. One of the best things about Philadelphia, hands down.
Love coming here just to try the different cuisines.  Especially love to come on the weekends sometimes for brunch and eat the Amish diner. Their pancakes are great!
If you are in Philadelphia this is a must see market. Could not stop taking pictures and sampling all the different foods.

My wife recently had some furniture reupholstered at  Ms Bak's Upholstery.
The work is done on premises.  She found the workmanship to be excellent.
It was completed when they said it would. They have material to choose from or you could purchase your own. They have pick up and delivery .She is so glad she
found this business.

I've been to the dope-ass markets in Madrid, Barcelona, Venice, Portugal...and this is the only American venue that comes close to the variety of deliciousness of those world-renowned markets.

My homegirl attended college in Philly so when I would visit her, we would frequent this savory/sweet/uber-yummy market, often.

It has the following, and more:  sweets stands (chocolates, cookies, macarons, cupcakes, cakes, ice cream), Asian food stands (Japanese, Thai, Chinese), meat stands, cheese stands, fresh fruits and vegetable stands, diners, pizza stands, cheese steak stands...and...Tommy DiNic's (you gotta hit this stand up).
 
This spot kicks ass...I need to return, ASAFP.
It's so great there and very unique. So many choices, so many good places to eat and buy fresh fruits, vegetables, etc. A real experience to see.
Great place to spend an afternoon.  The produce stands are my favorite -- easy to spend a day here picking up little presents for yourself and other people.
So many options and so much good food! I love that there is a large produce market as well as fresh seafood too.
Great place has a large variety of food that will fit everyone the down home diner is excellent

Such a neat indoor farmer's market setup! Unfortunately, the Dutch Eating Place was closed both times I went, and DiNic's was sold out of the pulled pork sandwiches...but I was successfully able to buy some artisan truffle boxes at Chocolates by Mueller, a Philly soft pretzel and other goodies at the PA General Store, a few scoops of Bassetts Ice Cream, and wished I could still have room for Flying Monkey Bakery or Old City Coffee. Pearl's Oyster Bar looked pretty enticing as well. I could've spent all day here if I didn't have business to do. Very impressed by the array of fresh meats, seafood, cheeses, nuts, produce, baked goods, even olive oil! They even already had t-shirts commemorating the Papal Visit as of early August 2015. Surprisingly, I didn't try any of the cheesesteak places here (By George, Spataro's), just didn't have enough time to explore all of it. Too bad the Wednesday and Saturday morning Taste of Philadelphia Market Tours fell during times I wasn't in the area!

Everything looks nice and is nice, but to sum it up it is a tourist trap. I found this place a little over rated for what it is. After my friends talking it up who are local -- I found it unfortunate to not be somewhere I might myself to usually roam. Essentially what it is a huge market inside a terminal with lot of different specialty shops and eateries. 

In Washington DC where I reside in one of the suburbs -- there is a place on a smaller scale that is similar to this that sort of has spoiled it for me to no really enjoy these kinds of places and has saturated it for me. I like Reading Terminal for what it is, but I don't know if I'd consider it a 'must see' in Philly unless you're into this sort of thing. I like it for its historical significance, but the food choices were a little less than exciting.

I will probably give it a second shot at my next return simply to say that I did get the grand experience, but like I said -- it is a huge food and flea market gathered in one confined space. Don't expect to find parking around this very easily unless you get lucky like I managed to do.
Nice place; plenty of eats! Good prices. A bit crowded at lunch with tourists and PHL natives.

I miss living in Center City for only a handful of reasons and the big one is Reading Terminal Market.  It does get a little crowded, especially around lunch time, but there are some amazing deals to be had on great food and fun trinkets.

Great Place!
Large selection of meats, cheeses and fruits.

Such a large selection of food! Much of the food is simply excellent. But beware of high prices.

My favorite stop in here is the Creperie. Sweet and savory crepes with fair amount of food stuck inside.
A little bit of everything for everyone.  Word of the wise, don't fill up on one thing so you can visit multiple stores and have a true Philly experience.
They have so many different options for food. They have the best crepe place and donut shop!!
Just one word.: yum! Go to the Amish spot for breakfast! You won't regret it.

best cheesesteak I've ever had was from here!
great cookies, too!
really fun to walk around and check out all the vendors.
only downfall was it was very crowded and HOT.
Reading terminal is a place where there is something for everyone...  Overall it's a nice place and atmosphere most times of the day. I believe their prices are a bit high, but the location is prime.

A must see & experience in Philly. Numerous food vendors and unique stands including candy shops, Amish bakeries, organic fresh foods, cheese & meat counters, & more under one busy roof! If you can't find something you love here, you have issues ;)

Lots of great food available here. I ate the ribs from The Rib Stand (Pennsylvania Dutch), which were so tasty and tender. I had 5 baby back ribs, nac and cheese, and a container of bbq sauce for about $13. We also had a roast beef sandwich from Dinic's, which was very good.

It is a charming marketplace, I would have come here again during my trip if I had more time. All the stores are neatly laid out and easy to find with the maps provided. Overall a good experience. There is paid street parking nearby and a parking garage that validates your parking ticket for 2 hours if you spend a certain amount in the market.

No matter where you're from, what you eat, how old you are, etc. You are bound to find something you would like here. This is one of my favorite places in Philadelphia. 
You can find fresh oysters, delicious crepes, cajun food, nuts, kitchen gadgets, etc. You name it! I like trying different things at once so this is the perfect place for me. 
I can get an appetizer at one place, then go to multiple other places to share a dish, and then have ice cream, cookies, or any dessert I'd like. They also have a fresh produce section, deli meats, seafood, and other stores that sells raw material for cooking. 
I have been to markets all over the world, and I would say this is one of the best ones in America and will tie with markets in Barcelona and Venice. It has Philadelphia culture and paints a perfect picture of America's melting pot.  
I would recommend you to not go at the busy hours because it will be hustle, bustling. Some stores close at a certain day and time of the week. So be aware.

When I go to Philadelphia I always visit this place at least 3 times per visit. The choices for food are a wide variety. I am more impressed with the people watching you can do. From the fish fish to the aroma therapy you can purchase I could literally spend hours in this place. The cookie place at the front make awesome black and white cookies. Good tip at 5:00 when they get ready to close all cookies go on sales for $1 each. Get there early as they go fast.  This is also a great place for breakfast. Long lines start early but it goes fast and is worth the trip. Looking forward to my next trip in a month. I will definitely be there wandering the aisles. Go ahead and give it a visit you will not be disappointed!!!!
Pretty cool market with lots of different food options. Would definitely come back here. So much to see and try!
This market is always an overload of sites, sounds, smells, and delicious food.  Love the discount parking at the indoor lot next door.  However, could use a better local artisan bread bakery;)
Great indoor market with any kind of food you can think of. Crowded but fun and if you spend money there you get a big discount on your parking. Awesome place and a must see in Philly.

THE iconic food market of Philadelphia, you simply can't go wrong if you choose to eat here! A foodie haven, you can find everything from ice cream, chocolates, cookies, meats & cheeses, fresh seafood, vegan & veggie food and plenty more. There is a vast array of options to choose from.

If you have a strong aversion towards crowds, going here during the weekends maybe be frustrating as the lines are long and finding a place to sit maybe be difficult. But these are just small inconveniences in my opinion! 

Tip: Carry cash with you as some places are cash only!

I'm not sure what there is to say that hasn't already been said.  If you are visiting from out of town, this experience is a Philadelphia must.  Aside from weathering crowds, there is nothing not to like.

Reading Terminal is reputable for their marks in Philadelphia history. Reading Terminal has a variety of things from delicious diverse food cuisines to beautiful flowers in the season and different fabrics/textiles. Also a notable thing about this place is the multi-cultural exchnge as they allow different groups to perform from time to time. A definite must-see for any tourists or philly-native alike.
Oh yeah, I'm  coming back!   Be prepared to spend time checking out the amazing variety of food selection stores, all under one roof !
A must go! A lively indoor market with endless food opportunities. The diversity is is very fitting for this city of neighborhoods. Check out DiNic's for a roast pork sandwich

I love Iovine Produce and OK Produce, I usually stop by every couple of weeks. Fresh, cheap produce and wonderful customer service! 

I started looking around Philly for cheap produce markets and this hits the spot! I've been to several places where the produce was cheap but rotted a day or two later, this place is NOT like that at all. I love coming here because I can eat healthy without breaking the bank.

Reading Terminal Market has everything anyone could ever want! Restaurants and shops of all different types of food. I've tried a handful of restaurants and all of them have been delicious. I also go here every week to get my produce because it's cheap and fresh! If you are in Philly, you must stop by here to grab a meal!
Amazing variety, so if you and your friends can't agree on a place to eat, this would be a fantastic place to go.  Most of everything is delicious!

Variety is the spice of life. If you're into food, and not sure what you want, definitely come here. It's hard to choose from all of the eateries in this one location. The only issue here is having too many options!

Every city should have a place like Reading Terminal Market! Talk about one stop shopping. We traveled to Philadelphia on what we call our siblings trip. I have 3 brothers and a sister. They all have a spouse or significant other. We even have some nieces and nephews now. So we take a trip every other year and this trip was to Philly. We absolutely love Reading Terminal Market. If you can't find what you need here, you won't find it anywhere. They have a ton of food places, butchers, bakers and probably candle stick makers. We went here every day whether we were looking to buy fresh fruit or cheese or just to eat. We all tried different foods and different venders.One place that we all agree was our favorite was the homemade pretzels. There is something about a Philadelphia pretzel that is unlike any other pretzel you will ever have. I know if we ever get back to Philadelphia again, I am going here to eat some pretzels.
Never disappointed !! Absolutely love love love coming here for my produce and whatever else I happen to bump into!! It's obviously a tourist attraction but even that crowd makes it worth the visit.

No trip to Philly would be complete without stopping in Reading Terminal Market at least once while you are there. This historic indoor market is home to so many different merchants offering up everything from cheesesteaks, ice cream, jerky, Cajun cuisine, pastries and all sorts of fresh food and produce (just to name a few).

In past visits I've had the chance to try the famous roast pork sandwich at DiNic's, sampled some delicious locally made cheeses from Valley Shepherd Creamery and picked up a tasty set of homemade chocolate truffles from Mueller Chocolate Co. Not to mention I've also been really impressed with the amount of fresh fruits, veggies, seafood and meats that are available for purchase throughout the market.

The only downsides I can think of when it comes to this place are that when it's really busy there can be good size lines that build up when ordering food (Carmen's, DiNic's, Beilers, etc..) and the market closes relatively early (I believe 6pm) each day so definitely try to get there earlier in the day if possible. Reading Market is a Philly icon / tourist destination that should be on your list of places to visit when you are in the city.

I love the reading terminal market, especially during the week when it isn't as busy!  Its a great place to buy little things, oils and balsamic, groceries, and a great place for breakfast and lunch!  All around a great market in Philadelphia and one of the best overall.

The oldest indoor market in the centre of town, close to Chinatown. It's heaven for foodies with great options, although very touristy. Try the sampling from the cheese shops as you inhale the smell of cheesesteaks around you. There is even a brewery inside. The prices are not cheap for produce.
Value 3/5
Atmosphere 4/5
Service 4/5
Quality 3/5
14/20

This is a must! A friend brought me here because I am visiting. It's a little bit of everything. Booths with chocolates, fresh meat, vegetables & delicious things to sit and eat. Oh & the cheesesteak they have a pretty good cheesesteak!

LOL @ people calling this a tourist trap, overrated, not worth the time... It is downtown and within walking distance to every major location center city Philadelphia has to offer... OF COURSE tourists will come here.

This place is pretty awesome...tourist or not. It has a little or a lot of everything, and there is a good chance if you're in the mood for something... you'll find it here.

This place will be here forever... no Yelp review is going to change that lol.

Great place to visit on an empty stomach! Try all the 'thanksgiving' sanwhiches. Bring empty bahs BC you will want to fill them with delicious treats. NOT stroller friendly. It tends to get very crowded. People are also ruthless and very pushy! They will cut you in line or take your seat! Bring your 'game face'.

This place can be described as foodie heaven. There's a lot to choose from and so much to see. Reading Terminal houses foods from all over. There's Cajun, Chinese, Thai, Indian, Italian, Soul food, Philly favorites, bakeries, fresh produce, the deli, even a bar! The best time to go is during the week. The convention center is right across the street so it can be a bit overwhelming on the weekend with all the tourists.

I would recommend this place to a friend! I am under 25 years old with not so good credit but  the salesman "Sean" was really helpful and I was able to drive off the lot for just a dollar down and a one year warranty. He was really patient and friendly with me. He even helped me get auto insurance which is mandatory to drive off the lot. The one critique I would add is that it was a all day process mainly because they don't tell you the prices of the car upfront because they have to go by your income so every time you pick a car your interested in they have to submit the information to the financial counselor who is off site and that's takes up to 30 mins each time. I only took me two days to find something that was in my price range and that was reliable and convenient.

I wish there was  seven stars like in the luxury hotels system!! This place is magical, I have been may times and it never a seises to amaze me. This time was particularly memorable because of the visit of my dad. He loves food and groceries stores!! I have never seen him so happy and I'm awe like today. This place not only made us happy but it gave us such beautiful memories together that wi will cherish for life and will share with my family.  

There is absolutely nothing wrong with this place except for that fact that you want to come every day I I will only get fatter!! I absolutely love LOVE the terminal and every tourist and local should come as often as possible to enjoy it and but good quality everything. :)

Miss the more local appeal of being a place for residents....It has become more of a place for tourists and lost some of the rawness which was both good and bad.  Sort of lost its magic and now is like a food court at a mall.

What is not to like here? I gravitate toward farmer's markets when I travel and I think that Philly has a solid thing going. The air is saturated with deliciousness. There are great representatives of the food of this region.  There is also a nice variety of international selections. You get authenticity with a dash of hipness here and there. Iovine's is the best place to buy produce in the city. If you don't like crowds definitely avoid lunchtime. Try everything. Right now I am craving the salmon from Little Thai Market with an apple dumpling from the amish stand for dessert.

I was visiting my fiance who is new to the area. We decided to go check out Reading Terminal for lunch. We were walking around a lot trying to figure out what to eat. We ended up at the cajun place (can't remember the name). The lady working there was quite rude and seemed really annoyed that we were eating there lol. The food was good but I wouldn't say amazing and it's not cheap either. Next time I visit, I want to try other places in the market.
Amazing amazing amazing! Best coffee, donuts, pancakes, etc all within one incredible establishment. Just wish it were open a little earlier / later.
So much to choose from. I really enjoy the variety that is offered. Super busy at times and hard to find a place to sit and eat.
Fantastic magical place. Love it!  The creperie is the bomb!

This place is so amazing that recently I've made sure to book my hotels far AWAY from it because I cannot control myself inside the market! Seriously! The food is just okay, but the dessert places are heaven on earth. Love the strawberry cheesecake from the amish place, the chocolate chip cannoli on the other side of the market, the chocolate chip cookie brownie in the way other corner...omg I can't even walk out of this place with just one food item! Only reason it's not a five star is because I wish it were open later. Go here for dessert, you'll thank me later.

Giving a review of Reading Terminal Market is absurd. People aren't going there because of yelp reviews, they are there because they are at the convention center, they are local, or they want a highly specific ingredient. 

Regardless of which one applies to you, you will get what you're looking for. Great place with many options (truly close to everything) for lunch; cheap place to pick up groceries with a short shelf life; place that has every ingredient I've ever looked for (and I like to cook). 

This feels like reviewing the liberty bell. Does my onion matter? Does it sway you? You're either coming here anyway, a regular already, or this opinion is meaningless.
So many choices, so little time!

Reading Terminal Market is a wonderful place to visit for people who love food.  There is something for everyone, locals & tourists. You can eat there, or take your finds home. It's fresh because it's local. And oh so good!

The atmosphere is terrific and the prices are competitive towards what you might find in a regular market.  Depending on the time that you go though I am a little concerned about the increased presence of the homeless constantly begging as my wife has been there along with our daughter several times and they have gotten a little too close to her for my taste when we go as a family though we do enjoy the experience

very cool place- anything you want-it's all there
felt safe and comfortable
decent food
Numerous options here it's a little pricy but you can get almost anything you want. Go before lunch hour in order to avoid the crowds and lines.

Still the best! ------I'd give it 5 stars if it weren't for all the tourist traffic. Stick to weekdays to avoid the ridiculous and obnoxious tourists.

-Iovine Brothers Produce
-Amish pickle barrels
-Molly's - Gotta love grabbing a shot and beer while grocery shopping!
-Dinic's
-Jonny Yee's seafood is the best in the city!

The list goes on and on.

I love RTM! So many great things to eat, all served with a side of great people watching. My favorite spots include the Fair Food Farmstand, Valley Shepherd Creamery, the Cookbook Stall and Beiler's but there are so many other fantastic spots. You can usually find exactly what you're in the mood to eat. 

Reading Terminal Market is a wonderful Philly tradition.
I walk there almost daily. I enjoy quality products at reasonable prices

In Philadelphia to host an exhibit at the Convention Center and had no idea how lucky I was to have access to the market every day for breakfast and lunch. I never had a bad meal. Favorites were the Miller Time pretzels, Beiler's donuts (I will dream about the PB cream donut for the rest of my life) and Carmen's for cheesesteak. You can't go wrong with any of your options though.

As a market this is a place where you can get just about anything.  Need a custom cut of meat, no problem.  Need an unusual spice, you can get it.  The quality of the food and produce is excellent and there are many choices so don't go to the fist purveyor you see.  Cheese, seafood, soul food, Asian cuisine galore, Cajun, southern, German beer garden, Amish produce and bakery, everything!
There are lunch counters with every delicacy you can imagine.  You can also arrange for catering or take out.  There is ample parking nearby and the market offers validation if you shop there.  
A word of caution if there is a convention or if go to the market on a Saturday.  Go early; this place is can be a zoo.

Reading Terminal Market is a great way to get any type of food you want in one location. It is great for groups that want different things. Their is plenty of affordable food with such a variety that is hard to match. I recommend Dutch Bros Company for breakfast which the best seasonal Pumpkin pancakes.

It's always a joy to shop at RTM. Great choices, lot's of incredible cheeses, wonderful sandwiches, but my most favorite thing is the merchants themselves.
My wife and I have been shopping here for years, and it's nice to have a smile, a hello, a thank you for coming back, stop again.
touristy and often too crowded but still a great city market in a great city.
When in Philadelphia you must check this market out. Everything you can think of is sold here. Fresh breads, fish, meats, desserts. It's quite an experience

After seeing this place featured on several food network shows and in the movie National Treasure, we were pumped to try it out and it has not let us down. There are a TON of vendor restaurants on the inside each with their own special foods. For a awhile we only got pork sandwiches from Danics because they are so amazing. Then we just recently tried a pastrami sandwich from Hersels. Amazing!! Does not disappoint!!

Avoid if you have even mild anxiety about being trampled by cheesemongers, charcutiers, and/or tourists

Was able to buy an apple quickly and run out of exit #52

Fantastic public market featuring cuisines from all around the world. Plenty of local and fresh options available too.  I got a great pretzel wrapped hoagie from Millers and picked up some local chocolate from another store. 

It's a little cramped and crowded, but to me, that's part of the charm. Definitely a must-see if you're visiting the area.
This is a must visit site when your in the Philadelphia area, they have the market, small famers and vendors to visit as well as many small places to enjoy lunch and good amish supplies.
I like Reading terminal market it has a lot of different varieties of food and markets. It can get very busy. The prices are outrageous. Beiler's bakery has great pickles.

There is no doubt that this is a Philly landmark and it offers something for everyone and is good for hanging out with friends. But, it is overly crowded, taste is mediocre, and prices are high. This place is jack of all trades but master of none.

By far, one of the Top 10 places in Philadelphia you must visit. My favorite places are: Iovine Brothers (produce), Hershel's (for sandwiches), Flying Monkey(for sweets), Little Thai Market (for Thai food) and for breakfast Dutch Eating Place. 

Whatever you are looking for: the market has it. For first time visitors, grab a map, cause the places are side by side and lunch time and after work "4-6PM" It crazy packed. Especially Saturdays. Have a game plan before heading in.

The SO spent a week up in Philly a few months ago and when she asked her host for a place closeby to get some food she suggested the Reading Terminal Market.

You should really prepare before you hit this place.  Bring some money, perhaps a shopping bag, and be sure to wear stretchy pants.  Sweat pants are probably best!

The variety here is really just stunning, especially as we had no idea what this place was other than "a place to get something to eat" before we arrived.

This building is huge and is a wall-to-wall patchwork of different food vendors, and I'm not talking about the same old fast food franchises you're used to seeing.  I mean row after row of independent vendors selling any exotic food you can imagine.  It was really amazing.  I defy you to show up to this place and NOT find any kind of food you're looking for.

Yes, it's crowded.  Yes, it's full of tourists.  Yes, you're going to have to wait.  And oh my god is the food good!

I have recently given up meat, but was almost in tears as I saw the incredible pastrami sandwiches and gyros they were serving.  I ended up having an amazing vegetarian Indian dish from one of the stalls.  We also picked up some freshly made and freshly sliced sour dough bread from one of the bakeries.

This place is definitely worth a visit.  You should probably starve yourself before you go.

This place is amazing. Love a good market in a city, and this place has everything one would need: produce, cheese, meats, pickled stuff, fish, bakery, doughnuts, and much more. There is always something to see and I love the vibe. It is always fun to just walk around and browse the market.

Its ok, I've lived in Philly for the majority of my life but I honestly don't get the hype of Reading Terminal. You can go in there and a variety of things like cake, cookies, candies, cheesesteak, Chinese food, soul food, groceries just to name a few things. Its always over crowded and seating can be limited depending on the time of day. My favorite spots here are the Famous 4th street cookie company Keven Parker's soul food café and Bassetts Ice Cream.

I love going to Reading Terminal market! Its really convention to get any groceries since its in one building! Absolutely love smelling the chocolates! And i always stop by and get crepes! However i dont like how a bit small it is to walk through it! But by far the best place to get some lunch.

Best place in Philadelphia. Wonderful for taking a stroll around and grabbing food on the weekend. If you're looking for something fresh that has the variety to feed an indecisive appetite, you won't be failed by RTM.
This place is awesome!  So much choice!  It is the best food court I've ever been too.  So many fresh and delicious options.

I had to leave and take a break after about an hour... it was sensory overload. So many delicious smells and sights and flavors! When I came back, I was a bit better acclimated. It's not as large or as expansive as the Mercato Centrale in Florence, but it's pretty big!
One of the mainstays there is DiNic's, which makes a revered roast pork sandwich comprised of three ingredients: Roast pork, sharp provolone and broccoli rabe. The cheese provides a tanginess and prevents the pork juice from soaking through the roll; the pork is slow-roasted and delicious, while the broccoli rabe provides some crunch and offsets the sweetness of the pork. Justifiably loved by many.
The many Amish stores there are also worth checking out; there's a fresh-made doughnut shop that's excellent and a country-style diner that serves breakfast fit for powering field hands.
I had a great time there and would urge anyone to spend time there, especially on your first trip to Philly.
Love the whole experience!!! I could absolutely spend all day there. I think I love the fresh AMish pretzels the best!!!!

This place is an iconic, amazing, foodie paradise.  I've lost count as to how many stands they have, but they have quite the variety, from very local to sort of local (Lancaster County).  They have a million options for lunch and dinner.  I always try to find a new place to try every time I go there.  From turkey dinner to vegan cupcakes and the freshest raw seafood, they have it all!
Must visit amazing foods thruout the place cannot complain left with Bellys full and two bags of goodies
It's a nice place to grab lunch, don't go on a Saturday during tourist season unless you want to feel like a sardine!

Love the Reading Terminal Market! Lots of choices, something for everyone! Whether you're visiting for breakfast, lunch or dinner, you will find something yummy to eat.  Also many great fresh produce and meats to take home. Shop, eat and snacks all in one place.  Every trip includes a stop to bring home cannolis from Termini Bros! Yum!
My first time at Redding Terminal Market.  It truly exceeded my high expectations.  A huge selection of high quality food stands.  A must for any trip to Philly.
So many choices and everything is great! You also get a discount if you visit while on jury duty!

Here once a week.  Cons: They deal with tourists all day, so sometimes you may not get great service, at some of the spots there.  But overall, I buy all my chicken, fish and alot of coffee there.  
Its a fun trip.  Better than going to the supermarket.
Love the Reading Terminal! Whether shopping for fish heads or just picking up a hoagie, a Philly must.

This is a pretty fun market, especially if it is your first or second time coming. There are a lot of different vendors all under one roof, with lots of gourmet options. Some of the produce is the same and a little more expensive than some Chinese supermarkets just down the street in Chinatown. However, the convenience of one stop shopping under the guise of being "down town at the markets" is very fun. Be sure to bring plenty of money and an empty stomach to snack as you shop!

The variety of food here is unmatched anywhere in the city, let alone the tri-state area. My favorite by far is The Original Turkey where you can get hot turkey on a long roll topped with stuffing and cranberry sauce. Finish that off with an ice cream cone from Basset's Ice Cream and you'll be a happy camper for sure.

I stayed in Philly for the weekend and my hotel was (unintentionally) super close the the Terminal Market. Score! I was so excited that I could walk through the Market and browse all the different foods this place has to offer...Sooo much variety (wear stretchy pants lol) It was so PACKED but that didn't stop me from stopping by every day while I was in Philly. I would definitely  recommend you have cash, although most of the vendors accept credit most of the vendors are very fast paced and it was a lot easier for to pay cash instead of charging everything. I know this review is kinda vague so I will sum it up like this...if you're in the downtown convention center area take some time and visit Reading Terminal Market... It's awesome!
Great variety of food and other items to purchase.  Enough places to sit. A fun place to go and browse, or just to grab a bite from many food venues.

In addition to being a tourist attraction, it is a wonderful place for locals.  All kinds of food at reasonable prices.  They work hard to keep it from being another food court, but the lunch restaurants they have are great.  The Down Home  Diner is excellent and fun.  And the new donut place is out of sight.  Not to be missed.
The only thing bad about this place is there are too many places to eat. I gain 10 pounds because of this place. I will defiantly stop back in when I am in Philly.

This place is literally FOOD HEAVEN! It is a massive food mall and ANYTHING you want you can literally have. From dessert to soul food. From salad to gyros. From Chinese to Cajun or Mexican or Italiam. You can even buy fresh produce and meats. 

Great experience!!!

No way is this the Reading Terminal of yesteryear. I used to regularly go in from the suburbs.  It seems many of the old favorites like Spice Terminal have been bumped out and replaced with Food Court style vendors. Prices are becoming exorbitant, geared towards the tourist types. It's hard to negotiate in the afternoon with all the beige types gawking but not buying. Avoid at all costs during anything like the Flower Show. The fact that many of the Amish vendors take a day off on Mondays makes a great deal of the market dark on that day.  I have a perfectly well stocked Wegmans and Trader Joe's in my vicinity which makes a trip to Reading Terminal lame at best.

Reading Terminal Market is a Philadelphia landmark and is a must-see place containing lots of eateries, butcheries and produce vendors.  I don't particularly find the prices appealing but it is cool to check out from time-to-time.  The Market is under new management and they are constantly trying to upgrade the vendors and services, so things look promising.  Avoid this place at all costs if you have a hangover - the zig-zagging of people will make you crazy!

#unpopularopinion but I HATE reading terminal market. It is a complete tourist trap. Lines are long, food is subpar and seating is a nightmare. Be prepared to fight off overweight suburban moms and their hoards of unwashed kiddies. If you need your fix of one of the shops in reading terminal, I recommend getting it and getting out.

This place is great! You can pretty much get anything you want! There are pastries, meats, sea food, produce, Mexican food, sandwiches, wine, candy, grilled cheese, coffee, etc - you name it, they most likely have it! It's a melting pot in the middle of the city. Beware: it gets VERY crowded at lunch time!!! Also, they validate parking for 2 local parking garages, making it only $4 to park! Check it out :)
This is an amazing place. I never have enough time here to see everything. It can get pretty packed here, but it's a very unique experience.

Took my mom to Pearls for clam chowder and crab mac and cheese. Fantastic!  She loved them both, and had cookies from 4 st Bakery.
Perfect end of the day.
 I love the terminal's food court. Its a wonderful treat as they have everything that my picky family can enjoy as we all want something different. 
The bonus is everything is fresh. A great place to stop and enjoy a meal during any Center City travels.

Great place to find a place to eat or buy fresh food and treats. The variety is fantastic it it has a great feel of a place that has been around a long time. It is very busy with people and sometimes hard to find a seat to enjoy your food. Great opportunity to meet new friends.
So many great things under one roof. Where to begin. Numerous food vendors, meat markets, seafood and cheese. Flowers, chocolate and everything Amish. A must when you come to Philadelphia.

This is my absolute favorite part of philly! I would go there everyday if I lived there!!! So many varieties of food, very clean, lots of space, great for all meals, breakfast, brunch, lunch, dinner, or a snack!
One of my favorite places in the whole world. Period!

Noisy. Crowded. Busy. It's great! All kinds of fresh ethnic and local foods, cooked or uncooked. If you want to shop or eat in a bustling, casual atmosphere, this is it. Even if you are not planning to buy anything, it is just a great place to walk through as a tourist. It is close to the historic area of Philadelphia and to Chinatown (great eating and shops there also). If you have the time, definitely go there and "Don't forget the Cannoli" at Termini's Bakery in the market or down on 9th St. in South Philly. I'll have a Ricotta filled one. No powdered sugar on top; makes them soggy.

As a local, Reading Terminal is one of my favorite places to go in the city. I love doing my grocery shopping here cause I can get a lot for almost nothing. 

When you come here park in the parking lot that is on 12th street right across from the 12th St market entrance. If you park here you get 2 hrs of parking for $4 with a $10 purchase at the market. Just make sure to get it validated inside - you'll definitely spend $10.

OK Produce, located right in the center of RTM (next to DiNics) is a great place for a college student on a budget to grab produce. They mostly sell dollar bags of produce that you then can slap the 10% student discount on. This place might not have the most quality produce but you get a bang for your buck. Iovine Brothers has nicer produce but you definitely pay for it. 

The Amish are not usually there Sunday-Tuesday so if you go then you are playing your luck to get some of their tasty treats. They run a lot of shops with Reading Terminal and you are honestly missing out if you don't get something from Beiler's Bakery. Some of the best donuts in town. I also like their Mac n Cheese from the Rib Shack. Definitely worth trying! Also, I recommend going early the day before Thanksgiving and grabbing a pie from the Amish.

All the way in the back is the Nut Shop *or something along those lines* that sells coffee, rice, snacks, and tea in bulk. You pick out what you want and drag the bin to the front and ask the nice people behind the counter to weigh it out for you. It's definitely a good deal on a bunch of staple things. Plus they have some snacks that I used to get in my Naturebox *which I have now unsubscribed to*. It's definitely a good place to check out. 

The final place I want to mention is Meltkraft. If you are a lover of Grilled Cheese, you gotta check it out. This is one of the most satisfying meals in the market and they are always have a specialty sandwich. Plus, each order comes with homemade chips. yum. 

All and all, I am a huge Reading Terminal fan. I recommend going in the morning during the week cause the place is empty.

Love this market! Definitely check out the RAW milk!!! And also the grilled cheese place :) 
I do wish there were more organic options, but it's a really fun place to look around, and great food!

Tourist trap or not, this place is worth a visit.

+ Beiler's Donuts = HEAVEN.
+ Free food demo in the back left on the day we went (hello, turdurken!)
+ Lots of food choices from dumplings to pizza to cheesesteaks
+ Some specialty shops (shoutout to Bee Natural)
+ Public restrooms

The only downside is it gets very crowded and hard to find a seat. But be vigilant in your quest and be flexible with your experience... I enjoyed it all. :)
Lots of tiny shops to explore.  Every nook and cranny smells wonderful from the food establishments to the herbiary.  A must see place in Philadelphia.

What is there NOT to like about this amazing, vast and treat-filled space? Maybe that's there's too many choices. Boo hoo for me. Beautifully conceived, designed, layed out. Bright, cheerful and full of wonderous sights and smells. It would be amazing to go here when I'm in no rush at all... We even decided to stop here for lunch at our way back out of town only to find out they were closed on weeekdns.. much to our dissapointment...

It's a great place for lunch, TONS to choose from. There's a sandwich shop right in the center that I like, and the sweet shop near the entrance. The folks from Lancaster are always very friendly, too. (And if you ever get selected for Jury Duty, this is where you'll be going for lunch; probably the only good thing about that!)

Every time I go to Philly I have to go to Reading Terminal.  Anything and everything you could possibly want can be found there.  I always go to Dinics for a brisket sandwhich with sharp provolone and greens.  There are many other great places.   Anything Amish is great!

This is a great place to go if you are with a group that is hungry, but everyone wants something different. Tons of tasty food options to pick from and a few boutique shops to peruse. Great people watching too!

So much to see and eat in here!! I wish it was open late and did not close at 5. Beliers doughnuts are a must. The line gets long but its worth the wait. Carmen's has the best cheesesteaks. We even tried a Chinese place the was good. They also have cookies, fudge, juices, gifts, soaps, and lots more.

Pretty good for a market. Have lots of options and all good ones. Was so confused as to, which food stall to pick.
Options to buy produce and meat and spices and such as well. If I were living nearby, this would have been my regular hangout spot.

This is my favorite one stop food place. It's good for breakfast or lunch and great for groups because everybody can pick what the want and then sit together.The gyros are amazing, the cheesesteaks are great, and don't forget to get dessert at Beiler's donuts!

Reading Terminal Market has a huge variety of vendors selling different kinds of food. Some food is good, others are not so great. One of my standards: apple dumplings from Dutch Eating Place. 

Be warned that it can get very crowded. If you buy food to eat, it might take a while to find a free table, especially on weekends.
Amazing market. Great environment and energy. Something for everyone!
Has a huge variety of vendors and variety of food. Seating place is hard to find, so take it to go.  I would highly recommend this place
Fun for a day out in town. Good food vendors and merchants. Very casual. Often crowded.

Just as great as everyone else says! Despite the crowds on weekends and the children running around unleashed, this place is worth it!

Definitely recommend Miller's Twists, my all time favorite pretzel place. Also, Molly Malloy's is a safe haven in the middle of all the chaos with seating and delicious food to share. From Molly Malloy's I recommend the brussel sprout satay, butternut squash croquettes, and goatcheese flatbread. Perfection.

While spending 4 days in Philly we had to stop in here on two of them.  This place is fantastic!!!  I loved strolling through all the different aisles of goodies.  There's a grocery area surrounded by different chocolatiers, bakerys, deli cases and food stands.  We went on a Monday morning and while it wasn't total chaos it was definitely busy and crowded but that didn't deter us from taking our time and trying as much as we could.  
We started with a pork sandwich from Tommy DiNics that was delicious, sat at Hershel's counter and split a pastrami sandwich that was equally great.  On our way out I nabbed a tasty mint chocolate ice cream cone from Bassett's.  On our second visit we got cheesesteaks from Spataros, another gem.  My only regret is not having had more sweets, there are some crazy looking doughnuts that I must try next time!

Located centrally in downtown Philly it's easy to get to. I've visited on multiple occasions, it's great for large groups because there's something to eat for everyone. My favorite stops are Dinic's for their better than any cheesesteak pork sandwiches, Beiler's Bakery for Pennsylvania dutch specialties, and Smucker's Quality Meats for grabbing hand cut bacon for breakfast the next day(scrapple fans can also get their fix). The market can be an absolute mad house on weekends and during peak dining times, making it cramped and hard to find a table. Lines at Dinic's can reach epic proportions but the sandwiches are worth the wait. Parking in the area is outrageously expensive so take public transport if that's an option. Chinatown is in close proximity for a quick visit as well.
I love the food stands, I love the fresh cheeses and meats, I love the Amish pretzels.  I adore Termini's everything.  Don't go here. It's mine, mine I tell you!
Sorry, I'm from Philly also. I feel like I'd be eating in the Broad Street Subway. Never even tried the food, probably good but like I said I don't want to eat in the Subway

I ate lunch here while I was on a business trip and loved it so much I went back the next day. Great variety, good prices, and excellent quality. The first day I went to Spartaro's Cheesesteaks. Now, I'm not from Philly so I don't have a lot to compare it to, but it was phenomenal. The next day I went to Molly Malloy's, which I believe is the only place there with waitstaff service--everything else you order from the counters. I got the bacon, lettuce, avocado and tomato sandwich and it was to die for.

This is a great place you must visit in Philadelphia. Many organic foods you can find here. We usually buy our honey and olive oils from here because the quality is just amazing.
One star off because of no free parking.

I love this place! It's the hodge podge, classy flea market paid buffet style type of place. There are so many vendors and stalls of different cuisines and other crafts sprinkled in with tables. You can eat a whole meal from one place or try multiple cuisines from multiple venues.. it's really up to you the patron.  Strolling through the isles you will find your own adventure and be met with friendly smiles and hellos.

Love this place! Ended up here this afternoon because the Christmas Village was a let down. Never a sad thing when you end up here though.
The crowd was moderate when we arrived...about 1. But got busier as the day went on. For being just two days before thanksgiving the crowd was exceptionally friendly. 

Beilers bakery was BOOMING with people buying pies and pastries of the sort. Happily the donuts line was not as long as a Saturday so we took advantage and jumped in line for a half dozen. Really excited to try as we never have! They had their pumpkin donuts so I'm pumped to give them a try! 

We ate pizza and a sandwich. Totally forgot the named the place but it's all the way in the back.  Pizza was yummy and my boyfriend said his sandwich was okay. He said it would have been better if it was warmer. But overall, good experience for lunch as we were able to find a place to sit! Everyone at the tables were so nice and chatty. (And commenting on the cuteness of our little one!) 

We got some delicious sausages from the Country Food vendor and we can't wait to eat them as the last time we had them they were so good!

This place is always a pleasure to visit. 

And for the record to anyone heading here...check out Becks! It's super yummy New Orleans food! And if they have the alligator-GET IT!!
Wrong posting...redacted. I actually love Reading Terminal Market

One of the essential stops for a tourist visiting Philadelphia. From the eclectic mix of Amish baked goods, locally sourced coffee shops, and misplaced confectionery shops, Reading Terminal Market is an experience comparable to that of Seattle's Pike Place Market. 

Only one major problem; the entire thing is indoors. If you're like me and enjoy just a tiny bit of space, this definitely detracts from the vendors.

Whereas Pike Place has the benefit of being an open air market, Reading Terminal forces you into rudimentary queues akin to a rush hour NYC subway car.

4 stars because it's a unique and excellent form of quick immersion in Southeastern Pennsylvanian culture.

Docking one star because the mass herds make me feel like I'm at a state fair/flea market.
Wonderful food experience.  A must see if visiting philly.  Beilers donuts are off the chain!!

I have visited the terminal about a half dozen times at this point... And every time their is something to catch my attention. Whether it's a mouth watering roast beef sandwich at Dienicks or a baked vegan treat at the Flying Monkey, their is truly something for everyone. This is a staple location in Center City. Make sure to stop by!!
So much delicious food here! Only downside is it's a victim of its own success - huge crowds make it a kind of stressful experience, unfortunately.

Had a few communication/scheduling issues with sales team but overall I am very satisfied with the work that was done by Jason, Zachary, John, and Brady. There was a lot of work to be done and they did it flawlessly, efficiently, and neatly. Reviewed the system and answered all of my questions.

I am confident in the work done and am ready to remodel my basement.

This is a great place to grab a quick breakfast or lunch. So much variety! I visited twice around 8-10 am and the dutch breakfast place with apple dumplings seemed super popular. Fresh donuts, a million types of cheese steaks, gyros, Amish goods, honey products, candies -- the list goes on. 

The market is like 95% food though. Was hoping that there would be a few more non food local products.

Dropping my daughter off at bus station today - Looking to grab a quick breakfast and found this gem. Everything you could possibly want is here! Wow! So much to choose from wish I could eat more. Take home is a must.

This place is a SIX STAR!  We traveled north on the recommendation of pretty much everyone from Philadelphia and the multi hour drive was well worth it.  As we arrived late we didn't have much time, but we ordered a pretzel, a felafel, some chocolate and bought a few sausages for the road as well.  All of it: A+.

Pretzel beat out the NYC street pretzel, which surprised me (though it's far lower profile) - lower salt and more substantial.  The felafel was awesome, though I'm sure you can get a good one everywhere these days.  That one was particularly delicious - lots of greens.  

Great on price, super high quality.  Great environment with must be hundreds of different establishes.  I'd say this is the strong equivalent of Fanheuill Hall in Boston, Mass and that it probably has no equivalent on the East Coast.  To me worth a trip from wherever

Minor quibble.  We were there at closing and the custodians truly shove you out the door.  So be sure to get everything done with some time to spare.  Everyone's nice until closing time, don't expect to beat the clock and make out big because...they really push you out. Literally.

I'm in love with Reading Terminal! I had seen in numerous times on various TV shows and I was finally able to go! Amazing food! Anything you want they have it and more! 

Tip: Make sure to take a lap before settling into a certain vendor when it comes to getting food so you see all the amazing options.

Great place to browse, eat, and shop!! Cool and touristy, I always bring family and friends who visit. It gets really crowded on Saturdays though, so be sure to visit from Sunday-Friday to avoid the cramped feeling.

Heard a lot of good things about this place, read a lot of good reviews. I had to try it out for myself. WOW! This place is well worth the trip and the money! The obeisance is awesome, very well price food! Highly recommend trying this place!

The greatest part of philly! you have to go there once to try all the great food vendors. I recommend the amish diner and herschels pastrami. I've been there dozens of times and still have not tried all the different offerings, this place is awesome! wish there was one in every major city!
Everyone who visits Philadelphia should have a stroll through the market and grab a bite, it has something for everyone.

This place is amazing! I would frequent Reading Terminal Market when I lived in Center City, Philadelphia. Whether it was for a delicious bite to eat, or to shop for ingredients, I found just what I was looking for & more! 

It's a interesting place to stroll, I would definitely recommend visiting!
Absolutely the best place to go in Philadelphia. Could spend an entire day there trying to decide what I want to eat!

This place is a life SAVER... if you're like me "an artist on a budget" THIS IS THE PLACE!!!! Dollar grab bags will get you through the week, the Amish always have reasonable baked goods, that are sooooo yummy! Thank life for the reading!!!

I love this place! There are SO many options for food of any variety -- you will not leave hungry. You can also get produce and meats/seafood here too. I loved Sweet as Fudge (the Amish candy store, with lots of homemade chocolate candies), Beiler's Donuts (fresh hand-made donuts daily!), Dinic's (awesome roast pork sandwich). There's Mediterranean food, burgers, seafood, dessert stands, Asian cuisine, New Orleans cuisine, cheesesteaks, smoothies, and so much more. I thought the prices were also fairly reasonable! Plan to spend some time here at least during your initial visit just taking in all the sights and delicious smells! It can get crowded though, and sometimes there are big tour groups or school groups. I would recommend coming here earlier in the morning or later in the afternoon when it's not as busy.

This place is so amazing. I'd you have someone visiting this should be at the top of the list for Philly attractions. 

My favorite is the Reuben from Hershel's. Holy cow.

The donut shop is also out of this world. Im not a donut person at all but was blown away by the Amish bakers

Great place. 

1) Tons of options. 
2) Atmosphere is amazing. 
3) Foodie heaven.
4) Must visit.

Love this place! Anything you could want, you can pretty much get it here.  Really cheap and diverse produce in the back right corner.  If you can't find what you're looking for, ask one of the people who work there and they'll help you find it or give you a good alternative.  They're pretty knowledgeable.  The only downside of this place is it gets crowded on weekends and at lunch time.  It's pretty difficult to find a table if you're trying to eat lunch there.  Definitely worth checking out though!
Really crowded but some awesome small businesses. Especially bakeries. Produce area is great too. Good prices.
Have had many delicious meals and key ingredients from here.  A great fresh market. Flowers, food, veggies, and desserts.

Love going here. The cheeses are phenomenal (Riehl's), the breads amazing, great ice cream and chocolates!! Don't settle down until you've walked through the entire place and had an opportunity to decide what to try, there are so many delicious choices! Once you've decided and ordered, sit and enjoy in the food area in the center at the back. Don't leave without going to the bakery and getting donuts for later! For me the drawbacks are the crowds (but, hey, it's a popular place!) and I wish there were more vendors of "craft" type items and not so much just food.
Crazy amounts of variety. Great, local atmosphere. Food lovers guaranteed to love it.

I've been here several times. I have not even made a dent in trying to taste everything this place has to offer. But everything I've had so far to date has been very good. There is an enormous selection of food and deserts and more. The atmosphere is bustling and it's so lively. There are a lot of tables and seats but you'll want to try to grab a spot as soon as you see one because they tend to get snatched up pretty quickly. It's definitely a place to visit if you've never been to Philly before.

Have been in college in philly for three years now and finally made it there! Suuuuper crowded and hard to move around and see everything. From what I hear it's busy pretty much every day and all the time. There was a Latin band playing outside the day I went, so it was a really festive environment.

This market is a must if you're in Philly! There are so many good shops and places to eat at in here like Beilers Bakery, (Best donuts in the world.), Riehl's Cheese Shop, (Best cheeses in the world.), Meltkraft, (Best grilled cheese sandwiches in the world.), Mueller's Chocolate Co., DiNic's, Keven Parker's Soul Food and so many others I forgot the names of. They also have fresh fruits, meat, seafood, vegetables and juices. I got this really good fresh berry juice for $2.99 but I don't even remember where I got it from. If there's anything that's related to food you can get it here. If you want to eat good food come eat lunch here because there are so many choices: Indian food, cheesesteaks, gyros, pizza, crepes, beef jerky, sandwiches, fried chicken I felt so overwhelmed! I finally decided on a grilled cheese from Meltkraft and it was the best decision I made all day. If you love food and you love to eat this is the place to be! TIP: If you're visiting COME DURING THE WEEK IF YOU CAN. THE WEEKENDS ARE TOO PACKED and you can't even take your time and look at anything in peace.

This place is great!  All kinds of food choices for everybody.  Parking can be tough and it can get a little crowded. If you're walking around the area it's an excellent place to stop and have a quick bite to eat with a huge selection.  But every time I go there I end up walking around looking at all the awesomeness.  Parking sucks

While the overall market is colorful, varied, and a good place to people watch, I have been finding the quality of food from the vendors slipping. Greasy burgers, fatty pork, boney duck, underwhelming sloppy joes from four different venues in the past few weeks.
What's not to love!  Crowded, sure, but great food, drinks, coffee, everything.  A must see and enjoy place when in Philly.

I love this place! I just want to spend the whole day going from one stand to another tasting everything. After I'm done doing that I want to buy one of everything I liked to bring home!
Local grown, home made, and just plain delicious. Cheese and sweets, snacks and drinks. You're sure to find something to enjoy. 
You just need to go. I was there for the Philly Marathon. I didn't get to spend as much time at the market as I wanted. I hope I will return some day. I'll take lots of pictures!
My new favorite place to shop for fresh produce and hang out for lunch!So many choices to eat and for some sweet treats.
Great choices. The doughnuts are freshly made and simply out of the world. The stall with the cheese sandwiches was amazing.
We loved this experience!!!! Especially Hershel's inside! AMAZING Pastrami Reuben!!!

I am going to get the bad part out of the way immediately because the experience of the Reading Market is absolutely superb. The one exception to that is parking. There is ABSOLUTELY no easy way to pull up and go in inexpensively or conveniently. There is parking across the street in multilevel parking lots which are often full & expensive. Aside from that fact, which I think can be improved on if they put their minds to it, the multitude of food aisles to walk up & down are exciting & delicious. You can go in for a snack or you can eat an entire meal or bring home groceries for a week. It is fresh and creative and flavorful at every single turn. You can grab fresh meats, fresh fish, prepared foods of any desired sort, desserts galore, and many beers & wine in their beer garden. It is a gastro-experience of gargantuan levels.
