I personally have been going here for over 30 years regularly. There are also many non food vendors such as gifts and crafts of a very nice quality, spice shops, & floral shops. There is a whole 1950s looking counter that goes along the entire front which serves Philly's famous & notable sandwiches & food fare. You have soul food, Italian foods, Mexican, Japanese, Chinese, regular sandwiches, English pub fare, and on and on and on. There is a large seating area whereby you seat yourself. It is relatively maintained but can get a little messy at busier times. You also have bathroom facilities which are monitored and kept up. It is located directly in the center of Philadelphia's downtown and directly across the street from the Philadelphia Convention Center.
Amazing place! There's a cacophony of sights, scents and sounds, cool merch, great atmosphere and some of the best food you can find in the city.
It has the best and freshest meats, eggs and produce. Also features some things from Lancaster, Pa.
This place is the best.  Anything you could want, they have.  Don't bother going on Sundays as all of the Amish/Dutch places are closed, and they have some of the best booths in the building.

Awesome selection of delicious foods. One of my faves is the chocolate dipped cookie at the Famous 4th Street Cookie Company! And there's farm fresh produce at Iovine Brothers (they give student discounts on select days too).
This place is extremely over whelming because there's just sooo many options but you really can't go wrong with whichever place you choose.

Every shop in the RTM is great. Each place has their own specialties. Buying some cooking products can be pricey, but the quality is unmatchable in Philadelphia. If you're in a rush get there early in the morning as to not get caught up in the lunch rush.
Place is awesome. Something for everyone. Dinic's Roast pork sandwich is my favorite!
The Reading Terminal Market is like a Mecca for food. If you are a bipedal omnivore you must visit this place, and consume.

They have almost any food you could want at a fair price. Especialy the Amish / PA dutch food.

The only part that sucks is the cafeteria space is kinda dirty/dumpy, and all the tourists every time there's a convention - can of sardines.

I made a beeline for L. Halteman Family (the Amish fresh meat counter) for a selection of their turkey sausages and smoked maple turkey bacon. Afterwards, I had to make a pit stop at the crowded amish bakery stand in the back of the terminal, for a slice of their lemon pound cake. With so many delectable selections, it is always a tough call to make.
Redding Terminal is the largest market with the most varieties that I have seen in the U.S. They have something for everyone and I promise that you will leave very satisfied.

What can I say
Iovine brothers
Little Thai Market
Martins
La Davisi
Keven Parker
Termini Bros
Metropolitan Bakery
Herschels



I'm trying to make a purchase from every vendor in the market by this time next year
I grocery shop at the Terminal all of the time!! I buy my meats from the Amish people, they have the best babyback ribs ever! I'm very selective about my lunch meats, the Terminal is the place to go!
Huge variety...fresh food choices....produce, seafood, vegetarian/vegan, "ethnic" options

A great place with a lot of great food. And with a great price. You can get coffee, bakeries, Chinese food, American, Italy, etc. Try the ice cream on the winter, And donuts with coffee. Buy some snacks or vegetables, You can do a lot of things inside. Only its hard to find parking lots on weekend and the place gonna be too crowded. Better go on weekdays
Best place for lunch in the city!  Anything you want!  Sang Kee is particularly good!  Duck!  Roast Pork!

Very busy Saturday pearls oyster bar  great waffle and of corse oysters ! What a combo fun place to go you can get almost any food you can think of including of course Philadelphia cheesesteaks walk around and just get the feeling of old Philadelphia where at one time this was really the place to buy your produce and meats

I don't think there are enough words to describe Reading Terminal Market and it's an impossibility to review every single vendor in there! The market is big, usually crowded (especially on weekends) and there are food options as far as the eye can see. Whatever you want to eat, they have it and more!

When we came on a Saturday afternoon at about 12:30pm, the market was bustling. It felt like every tourist in Philly was here. From the moment we walked in, our stomachs began growling from the smell and sights of all of the food. There were so many delectable places to eat from our heads were spinning. However, with that said, I did have a few key observations, specifically about the vendors:

Pearl's Oyster Bar - From reading reviews, this is probably one of the most popular spots to eat at because they serve seafood and apparently very good seafood! When I passed by, the place was packed, although they had one of the largest seating areas of any vendor. 

Beiler's Bakery and Belier's Donuts - By far, the most popular desserts/pastry vendor in the market. The line for the donuts was the longest line I saw for any vendor and for a good reason as the donuts looked ridiculously amazing! We ordered a  1/2 dozen for ourselves and are still feeling the effects of how good the donuts were!

Molly Malloy's - They serve tavern/gastropub type food. We ordered the Chicken Pot Pie from here as recommended by many online blogs. The Pot Pie was good, but not great. Although filling, it could've used a bit more flavor.

Beck's Cajun Café - The employees were handing out samples of their soups and Jambalaya, which made it all the more difficult to pass it up after trying out their food. As the name indicates, they serve Cajun, Louisiana style foods --- gator meat, po boys, Jambalaya, Gumbo, etc.

Basset's - The only ice cream vendor in the market and, not only is it rich in history, but rich in many flavors! The employees here were extremely generous with the scoops of ice cream they gave on the cones we got. They were some of the biggest ice cream scoops I had ever seen.

DiNic's Roast Pork - According to the hype, they have arguably the best Roast Pork sandwich in Philly. Unfortunately, we didn't have the stomach space to store the sandwich, but it's on my to go list. The line for the sandwiches was pretty deep too.

There were so many vendors and so many places to eat, I could go on and on about the vendors. If you come here on a weekend, just be prepared for the crowds. It will get hectic and, although there are tables towards the back, its a first come first serve. Trying to find an open table during peak hours can become an issue so many customers actually walk and eat as they go. It's all part of the fun of coming here and exploring the different types of foods served here. It's a must visit if you're in Philly!

This is an eclectic market filled with amazing smell of food and spices.  Just a wonderful place to be around, explore and taste.  It does have limits on their sitting, and it gets real busy, but a great place in philly to visit!

The most visited attraction in Philadelphia and for good reason.

There is a decent variety of food to be found here: French, Vietnamese, Halal, Indian and your typical American steaks and burgers.

This may exist already, but it would useful to have a map of the facility. Sometimes it's difficult to find the exact place you're looking for.

I go here to buy food products, not for the restaurant scene, which is lively, varied and packed - nice to see as I hit my choices for produce, meat and cheese. 

Downtown Cheese has to be the best cheese shop in Philly, with rich choices and rational pricing. The place is staffed by people who actually know cheese, and can work with you to assemble a tasting menu or address whatever other "cheese issues" you might have.

I vary my produce purchases by checking the freshness and pricing.... always find what I need... and the various "farm to market" stands provide ease of access to fresh stuff.

Only challenge is the shopping on the weekends can become gridlock, especially during car show and flower show events, at which point, I make a determined effort to arrive as early as possible.  Will never forget being spied by two librarians from Ohio attending a conference.. who noted to each other that "the natives really shop here..."....

If heaven existed on Earth, it would be inside this building. The market is my absolute first stop to go to every time I come into Philly. It's where I want to be buried when I finally have to kick the bucket. 
     Hours and hours of my day can be spent here tasting all the delicious meats, pastries, cheeses, sandwiches, and beers.  My favorite sandwich EVER is inside this market. I wish they could pick up and move to Atlanta. I would be here every single weekend if I could. 
      Do yourself a favor, if you are a foodie and visiting or local, go here. It gets packed on the weekends, so if you can make it in here during the weekday, shoot for that. Was in there by 8:30am this morning and had a fantastic Amish breakfast. 

5 stars isn't enough, where are 10 when you want to give them?

A must see, a unique experience unlike any other of so many local establishments of all sorts crammed into a miniature city. However I found it more difficult than expected to locate various vegetarian options and the density of pedestrian traffic is a little overwhelming sometimes.
The best place to eat in Philly!!! Reading Terminal Market has something for everyone.
Tried French Cannolis there. They were sooooooo good!!! So regretful that I didn't get more. Definitely will miss it.

A very impressive place! I have never seen so many different food options in one convenient location. It's also a great place if you are looking for gifts/souvenirs. There really is something for everyone. If I visit Philly again, I will definitely come back to the Reading Market.
Really cool place with lots of options. The pork sandwiches from Dinics are awesome. If I lived in Philly I would shop here regularly for groceries. Can get pretty crowded.

Man..  If I only lived closer, I'd shop here for all my meats and seafood needs..  This place has everything under the sun, from fruits and veggies, candy and cakes, coffee, Chinese Food, Indian, Sandwich shops, meats, seafood, beef jerky, ice cream, grilled cheese restaurant, etc....  You can really spend a day here and it's a MUST visit when you come to Philly...

This is a quirky "food court" with lots and lots of places to choose from.  In fact, it's too popular, as the crowds descend on the place at 1130 and it's PACKED from that point on.  It's hard to find seating, though some places have carved out little areas of their own.  There are many, many wonderful choices, including Philly Cheese steak (Sabatoro's) which was average -- double provolone with fried onions and jalapeños.  Melt Kraft, where my daughter got a really good grilled cheese and bacon - the bacon was crispy and the bread was big - so that the Gruyere and Cheddar didn't overwhelm.  Again seating is problematic, and it gets a bit wearisome, otherwise I'd have rated it a 5, as I love the quirky and nooks and crannies.

Pretty awesome place the other reviews did a great job of summing it up. It's a huge market with food, groceries and other cool stuff. It's pretty easy to get lost so if you see a place that you like and want to come back to it later because first you want to look around, I suggest you just eat there first because you're probably not going to find it. Or it will take you some time. A long time. Reading Terminal Market is definitely a must see attraction in Philadelphia. It's pretty amazing. However, if you're someone like me you can get pretty over whelmed with the plethora of options and lose your appetite or simply get fustrated and go to Panera down the street. My best advice to the indecisive people like me is to know what you want before you get in there. Seriously. Before you enter decided on what you want to eat. Do you want American or Chinese ? Sweet or salty? Trust me. I'm helping you out. Also make sure you have CASH! It's just a lot more convenient. Happy feasting

What a mad house with crowd!! But I have to say I dig places like this that gives you the one-stop-shop for food, sweets and meat! Unfortunately, it was so crowded with few seating area and many places had very long lines or sold out items :( I guess we should have come in early to beat the crowd. We did get a grilled cheese sammy from Valley Shepherd and it was delicious, short line but 15minutes wait for cook time. 

Even if you are not eating here, be sure to swing by to check it out. It's always fun to look around.
Love the variety of stalls in this place.  My favorites are Termini Bakery and Metropolitan has the best bread.  Always great places to find lunch.  Don't forget Bassett's Ice Cream on your way out!

Tons of food places! Quite touristy. We got there around 1:30 pm and it was still packed with lookie lookers. Lots more offerings than the Marketing in my home town. Fresh made  donuts, Greek stops, of course the Philly cheesesteaks! The gal at the help desk was very polite.

Ranked as one of the top 5 things to do in Philly, so I went.  Glad I did.  This is a colorful, bustling place with fresh produce multiple eateries, candy shops, bakeries etc.  find your favorite.  I found super cheesesteaks and awesome donuts but much more to see....

This is a great place for visitors to Philly and locals, too. It's a unique, very large indoor market. Plenty of food options, both to dine in and to take out. All kinds of meats, cheeses, desserts, pastries, coffee, tea. Amish food stands. It's an experience, but be ready for long lines and a lot of people. This is a popular spot. Note that there's a parking garage to the west of the market.

This place is a must when we have friends in town...and we recently moved to Philly and have lots of visitors.  Dinic's for roast pork, prov, and broccoli rabe...forget pat or Gino's cheesesteaks...THIS is the quintessential Philly sammie.  Also love the turkey place for a stick to your ribs carved turkey dinner with all the fixins.
Get there before the lunch crowd!  Lots of choices, all of them good.  Steak sandwiches, roast pork or vegetarian dishes...all great!  And the dessert...oh my!

I love the Terminal. I've been going there since i was a kid. The only draw backs are the large crowds in such a crammed place; But you can find fresh garden veggies at inexpensive prices & it's a great place to go for lunch or an early dinner.

This place is not to be believed. It is like 100 (more?) small restaurants got together in one building offering food from all over the world. Beyond the awesome choices of what to eat there or take with you, there is this great energy. Many of the stands have their own places for you to sit and eat but there is also a central area with lots of tables. We could always find a seat. It's literally right across from the convention center and is definitely worth the 100' walk to check it out, even if you aren't hungry.

There are so many different little vendors! Don't go unless you have an hour to walk around and see everyone! Chocolate shops with amazing truffles and delights, hot fresh Thai food, 20 types of jerky, head cheese, scrapple, ice cream, and hundreds of cheeses. It's a foodies paradise. The only sad thing is that you are limited by the size of your stomach!  :)

It's a tourist staple, but for good reason.  Reading Terminal Market seriously has some of the best food in the game.  If you're looking for a wide array of food (seriously, anything from vegan food to donuts to southern food, and of course, cheesesteaks), you've got to check it out.

My personal favorite spot in the market is Tootsie's, in the back of the building.  It's a build-your-own salad bar and build-your-own hot bar/soul food.  The staff is always super nice and the food options are plentiful, good quality, and a reasonable price (it's priced by weight, so you control how much it is).  

Just a fair warning, though, it's the Reading Terminal Market.  It's popular.  It gets PACKED on the weekends and during the peak of lunch time.

Very cool venue, there are a lot of options so there's something for everyone. I got a boneless rib sandwich from the rib stand, and it was DELICIOUS! It comes with a hot or mild bbq sauce (I opted for the hot and stand by my decision) and the sauce definitely adds to the sandwich. I have to say me and my friend liked my sandwich more than the cheesesteak he got, I highly recommend it! 

There are also a large variety of sweets shops, including a chocolatier that is known for onion truffles, and another stall that has chocolate covered bacon! Needless to say it's a must see.

Only thing is a lot of the stalls close early, we arrived at about 3-4 and many were closing. If you intend on trying a lot of different stalls I recommend getting there early. Also, park farther away and walk, your chances of finding parking nearby are slim to none unless you want to pay an arm and a leg.

I think this place is ok.  It is very busy and I am not sure just how clean each place is here.  Lots of variety.  Whatever you want you eat you can find it here. Parking the car was a real hassle. Expect to pay $20.00 to $30.00 to park your for a few hours.  The food is not too expensive for the most part.
Great selection of local favorites.  Don't leave without trying DiNics roast pork sandwich. Fuggethabot cheese steaks--this is the real deal in Philly.

There's something for everyone here. I went in on New Year's Eve day, and it was super crowded so we did not stop to eat or drink. It was fun walkong through the isles of delicious foods and patiseries.
Very interesting diversion, if you are in the convention hall area.  I would not make the trip just for this, but it is a nice add on to any other attractions in the area.

Cool place to go if you're a foodie and want to try a large variety of sandwiches and snacks. The place gets very crowded and seating for all the delicious food tastings is at a minimal. I recommend the cheese shop. They make some killer grilled cheese concoctions. Not good for little kids, don't be the asshole trying to maneuver a stroller around.

A tourist must-see, but a bit crowded and overwhelming to visit too often as a local. Husband and I went on a great food tour which culminated in the market. Highly recommend one of those. Tips: smoothies, Thai food, organic veg market, old city coffee, and a grocery stand with all kinds of British delights (tea, marmite).

I always love this place.  And I give it the rare, for me, 5 stars.  Is every place 5 stars? No, but should every one have an exceptional experience there? Yes!

- I really like the gourmet burger place's mac and cheese.  And this Indian Food Place was solid.  Everyone should check out a Cheese Steak and Amish Pretzel while they are there (I personally think the ones here are better than Pat's or Geno's).

Here are some tips -- if you don't like crowds, don't go.

Plan to spends some time there - 1.5 to 2.5 hours, minimum.  I can't think of a food part they don't have covered.

I have reviews for other places individually.

This place is way too crowded. The food is good but not great, I don't get why it's so crowded all the time. There are many other places in Philly that have better food than places in Reading.    Come here if you have nothing else to do but this place is not worth is if you are on a busy agenda.
Awesome place to grab lunch over the weekends and grocery shop. There are so many different kinds of food options, you really can't go wrong. It's like the best of Philly all in one place.

My ultimate favorite place in Philly! This place has everything in one location. I love that I can eat all types of foods. 

This place is always packed weekday or weekend! But it's worth the experience. 

Here is a quick list of some of my favorite stops:
Bassetts ice cream
Beiler's donuts
Dinic's
Sang Kee Peking Duck

LOVE PEARLS OYSTER BAR. I've had breakfast and the seafood dishes and what a delight. This counter spot on the 12th Street side of the terminal is putting out dishes that not only look like fine dining but taste just as delicious! If there is such a thing as fine dining breakfast, it's here too!

Reading terminal has a lotta great options. It really depends on what you want. The wait can be really long depending on the time that you are going. Reading terminal has everything from cheese steak to cheese cake.

This is a nice indoor market and a city staple. The best day to go is Saturday, because the Amish merchants are all in. I absolutely love the produce stand in the middle of the store - they have such fantastic deals on produce! There are many cute shops, but mostly pretty expensive. The prevalent odor of seafood is also a bit bothersome.

Love the RTM, its a great place to just go in and grab a quick bite to eat or grab some goods to take back home. Needless to say this place can be deadly on the wallet especially if you like a lot of items in there like I do. Come hungry and then shop because trust me you will want to purchase everything in site.

Fantastic place to purchase your fresh foods and to try unique, local selections.  I find that the market offers affordable fruits, vegetables, and hot food, but if you want the more unique sauces, baked goods, and groceries, you will pay more here.  This is a must visit market for visitors and locals alike.  

Favorite outlets include Beilers Donuts, Iovine Brothers Produce, and Martin's Specialty Sausage.
A smashing of different shops and vendors, Reading Terminal Market is a hustle of smells, flavours, and people.

This is a must see in a trip to Philly. I loved everything I purchased here, and they had such a variety of local food. The quality was amazing from bagels with house made cream cheese to Amish pretzels. Donuts were epic and I took a dozen back on the plane!
What could I possibly say that hasn't already been said?  There aren't many places in the world like it.  And if there are, they're copying off of Reading Terminal Market.

Really busy, but also really fun with great food. The Cajun food place was amazing, maybe a little salty, and Beiler's donuts was also incredible. 

It's fun to just walk through the whole building too, if it's not too busy.

A Philadelphia treasure. Great place to walk around and shop for just about any food thing you could want. It gets pretty crowded but it adds to the ambulance. Every tasty delectable treat you could possibly want is housed in here. Check it out. I can pick up dumplings for lunch, shop for my grocers and get fresh sea food, then get a ice cream cone for my walk home.
I love this place! The donuts are the best you gotta try it! Next up is the crepe place!

Must-visit if you're in the area or living here. Foodie's paradise, with tons of items you won't find (or be hard-pressed to find) elsewhere in the city. A lot of old, locally famous/traditional vendors that go way back, lots of Amish vendors, etc. Great place to take in the culture and food of Philadelphia. And a lot of the produce is cheap.

Breakfast, lunch and dinner!

I had the good fortune of working across the street from the Market for the few months that I worked on a project in Philly.

This was my go to breakfast and lunch spot.  I rarely ate dinner here because they close at 6pm.

The selection and diversity of food will blow your mind.  While over half of the vendors are Amish, there is just about any type of food you can imagine here.

The prices are cheap but the quality and taste are excellent.  Just thinking about this place makes me happy!
A must-see in Philly! Lunch hour is craaaaaazy crowded, but that's part of the fun if you're up for it.
Very cool place. Lots to see and eat. Many different varieties and stores. Would definitely need to go again on a day where i can take my time exploring.

The hustle and bustle here is definitely something you have to get used to but when you do you'll be in love.. There's food everywhere, sweets, fresh meat, fresh fruits and veggies, coffee beans, even aromatherapy shops. It's the perfect place to grab lunch and walk around to all the booths and meet some amazing people

Reading Terminal Market was the last place my parents and I checked out before heading back to NYC.

We walked in here for some breakfast without really knowing what we were getting ourselves into!! 

Walked out with a tummy filled with a nice sausage egg and cheese sandwich, a nice cup of joe, a bag filled with sticky buns, pumpkin roll with cream cheese frosting, bags and bags of candy and a donut. 

My parents and I were set as far as "snacks for the trip back" was concerned.

The Terminal is basically a Philly landmark that everyone should be required to take their out of town friends to at least once... it's a no-brainer. If you don't you're a shitty host.

Too much stuff here to go into specific details, but this is THE definitive Philadelphia bazaar.

You want it? Reading Terminal probably has it. Beyond having amazing and sometimes hard to find foods, there are all kinds of fabulous restaurants that will make food for you. I wish I could pick a favorite, but I think it may be impossible. Make sure you take a day (and an appetite) and go explore!

Being from Hawaii, I had only heard of the Reading Terminal from playing the Parker Brothers game, Monopoly.  Hey, little did I know or realize that these railways (Reading, Pennsylvania, Short Line and B & O (Baltimore & Ohio)) actually existed!  Not only did they exist, the Parker Brothers strategically chose these railroads for their board game because of their routes and destinations.  Well, I've gotten over my ignorance as my business travels have taken me to the great city of Philadelphia many times.

During my first visit, which I think was the most memorable, my taxi driver was kind enough to point out the Reading Terminal Market just as he drove into the porte cochère of the Marriott hotel that I would stay at for a week.  The history and touristy draw of this market didn't dawn on me until I got into my room, began to read about it (and other Philadelphia "hot spots") and found that my room overlooked the market.  I was really excited about going to check it out right away but, having just come off an eleven plus hour flight, I, instead, opted for a short nap.

When I awoke, I quickly jogged my way into the market.  This historic landmark is divided into 3 structures:  1- Reading Terminal Headhouse, 2-Reading Terminal Train shed and 3- Reading Terminal Market.  I found out that the Reading Terminal Market is located BENEATH the Train shed.  The architecture of the terminal is beautiful and was designed in the Italian Renaissance-style.  In parts of the market, you can see the engineering and construction details it took to build these immense structures.  Back in the day, it was an open-air Farmer's market.  This is a huge Farmer's Market that has been in operation since 1892.

It was dazzling to see so many vendors from various ethnicities or cultures ranging from bakeries, flower markets, fresh produce, ice cream and restaurants--All Under ONE Roof!  This market is a melting pot of The aromas, colors and sounds started to drive me wild.  I immediately started eating my way through market starting from the famed Bassett's Ice Cream (America's OLDEST ice cream company) to Termini Bros (Italian bakery - got my FIRST cannoli) and onto DiNic's (for an Italian roast pork, Provolone and broccoli rabe sandwich).   

This was a day of FIRSTS for me... I got to see and experience a bit of Americana, hear the local cultural excitement within this huge market and  smell and taste culturally diverse Pennsylvanian cuisine. Geez, I thought to myself that since I'd be in Philadelphia for a week and hadn't really scheduled any other dining plans, THIS was going to be my life-saver!  I had to try the Pennsylvania Dutch specialty, scrapple.  Ah, if you have to ask what it is, I'm not telling...it was just tasty!  Alas, I ended up dining at other noted Philly restaurants and only got to return to the RTM 3 more times to get myself to more cannoli, amaretti, biscotti, and those Italian roast pork sandwiches.

Granted, the RTM may be more tourist-oriented but it sure was conveniently located to the Pennsylvania Convention Center which is in the Market East section.  I did return to shop and dine here on subsequent trips to Philadelphia.

Oh, just in case you're wondering... The reason why the Parker Brothers chose the Pennsylvania, Reading and Short Line (Shore Fast Line) railroads for the ORIGINAL U.S. Edition of Monopoly board game was because of their routes led directly to Atlantic City.  A side note:  B & O Railroad also operated on the East Coast but did NOT serve Atlantic City. 

#514

Having traveled regularly to Philadelphia and never going into the Reading Terminal Market, i'm really disappointed in myself for wasting all those years.  I enjoy just walking through the market, eating at the various food stands is a bonus.
One of my favorite spots in Philly. Always bring out of town friends here. Amazing variety and quality. Can't beat the environment.
I love the market and all of the wonders it has to offer. I forget how much is there!

The Reading Terminal has everything one could need for shopping from fresh fruits and veggies, meats/seafood, desserts, and everything else in between.  If you go during peak lunch time 12-2pm, it will be very crowded do be prepared to wait in lines.  It's a good tourist spot and natives to the city love it as well.  Breakfast, lunch, or dinner, one can't go wrong eating there!!!

Oh my gosh!!!! As a foodie - I have wasted too much of my life having never been here!  My husband and 9 month old decided to stop in before we started our 7 hour trip home to NC and man oh man I was literally like a kid in a toy store!  I don't even know where we stopped for food, snacks, chocolate, donuts, a mufalatta, Boylan cream soda out of the fountain but everything was awesome!  I actually almost cried because this market made me so happy!!(yeah, I know I sound crazy) Seriously though - if you enjoy good, amazing food and are in Philly - this is a must stop!!!

Pretty much used to live here and got to explore every vendor there. 
Mullers=best chocolate ever.
Bassetts=excellent turkey sandwiches. Try the #2 with sourdough.
Kang Se duck. Try their soup. The best; wonton noodle soup with sliced pork!!
Thai place...(the name of the establishment eludes me at this time) has the best basil chicken and bamboo shrimp!
I could spend days in the RTM.....great spot!

Reading (pronounced "redding") Terminal is fantastic, lots of wonderful yummy things. However, there's also a bunch of people, so if you're not into crowds, do your research and figure out what time might be best to go (early morning? not weekends?). I particularly like getting the fresh squeezed/blended juices and smoothies. There are places to get produce, cheese, meats/fish, chocolates, gifts, coffee, pastries, and so much more! The prices are not particularly cheap, but it's not exorbitantly priced either. If nothing else, it's a great place to people watch. 

It's also ideally located for me, since it's right next to Chinatown, where I do my weekly grocery shopping.

This is a great experience for anyone who likes markets and is a foodie. There is a market for fruits, veggies, meats, deli, and sweets. It's a great first date activity, or just a nice way to spend the afternoon. Be prepared to spend lots of money on food and have a good time stuffing your face after you make a serious decision on what to eat!

A "must-see" to get the full Philly experience.  A market teeming with local vendors, you will have your pick of the litter when it comes to food options. Sandwiches, soups, baked goods, cheeses, fresh meats and seafood, produce, nuts, canned goods,  etc. There are places to sit and eat or you could just grab something to go.

Pretty cool selections of joints from which to choose; but, lines way to long!!  Don't go there with a bunch of little kids, there is nowhere for little ones to sit, no boosters, high-chairs fahgettaboudit.  Looks like a fun place to take visiting guests and people with time on their hands.  The burger place across the street is pretty decent, there was no wait at lunchtime last time we tried to eat at RTM.

Ive only been here once. The one time I went it was a seriously phenomenal visit. The donuts were amazing and literally melted in my mouth alone with this fresh bread with cream infused in it. I am going back again this week for lunch, super excited!

My first time going to Reading Terminal Market and it will not be my last. There's so much stuff to see and so many different foods to try, you literally can spend hours there. I had one of the best black and white cookies of my life. It's nice to walk around and people watch but obviously the best thing is the food. It was actually quite clean including the bathrooms.

I absolute love anything resembling a farmers or flea market, so of course fell in love with this place. I stuffed my face with Amish donuts and bought some herbal tea from this organic shop. I doesn't over an hour going up and down the aisles. I probably shouldn't of went hungry. They had everything to eat you could ever want. Food coma!
amazing counter service and fresh food... one market is greater than the next

If you want a truly Philly experience you have to make a stop at the market. Butcher's, Fish Mongers, Amish, fresh local produce, variety of cuisines and most importantly fresh baked cookies. Ok that last one may be my thing but damn it, it should be everyone's. I love it here. The atmosphere alone is not to be missed.
Best place in Philly to shop for food and eat. . . This is the place the "real" Philly cheesesteaks are made

The epic metropolitan market for social, and edible satisfaction in Philadelphia. As crowded as the terminal can be, everyone is there to get what they want.  I knew I wanted a delicious home cooked meal. For me, it was The Original Turkey. I get the Original sandwich. It has succulent, savory turkey, crisp sweet lettuce, and lustful, crimson tomato. It fits. It makes my stomach howl. During the summer, I got to sit outside of the terminal with the rush of the city around me and this delicious treat in my hands. You see places like Sang Kee Peking Duck, Spataro's Cheese steaks, and Dutch Eating Place, you find your taste, you always want to return, and might find a solid conversation.

If your a foodie, this is the place for you. They have everything from fresh baked specialty doughnuts to the best sausage shop in town. We stop and had chocolate covered graham crackers and butter crunch cookies from the chocolate shop. Went to the meat shop and had a meat sampler of roast beef, corn beef and pastrami. Nothing that I had was not great. I purchased some garlic white wine sausage and the hard to find andouille sausage. We also had garlic wings which were cooked perfectly with amazing cornbread.

Foodie Paradise!!
If you are in town and anywhere near the Reading Terminal - go check it out!! The foodie in you will thank you! Anything your little heart desires can be found here when it comes to food. The place is always packed and always delivers. We love going here with a group as everyone can get what they crave and then all meet up in the middle and eat together. Everything is in stand/kiosk format but there are a lot of tables in the middle and throughout where you can sit once you figure out what you want at this magical place. You can also do a little shopping like veggies, fruit, coffee, chocolate, meats, bread.... YUMMY! 

NOTE - there is also a bar to get drinks at.... great success ha!

This market is awesome! A little pricey, but you get what you pay for. Foods are fresh and tasty. You can also shop for everything from small souvenir magnets to handmade crafts and textiles from other countries!

This place is amazing and living one block away means that I go everyday. From fresh local produce, cheese stands, chocolate shops to a variety of food offers. Only thing is on the weekends around lunch time it can be very crowded!
Great. Has groceries and cool restaurants in a market-type setting.... cheap.

Holy jamoly! This place is local food chaos like I've never seen before.

My advice to you- if you're looking to experience it without having to come up for air every few minutes, try to avoid showing up at 12:30 on a Saturday afternoon like we did. I love a good food shit show but I also wanted to explore all of the booths without being pushed along by the masses. It's super-exciting to see the locals and tourists get behind this historical institution. 

When you do decide to visit (because you can't miss it!!), make a beeline for Miller's Twist and order a traditional pretzel. It will blow your mind. Trust me, wouldya? Plus it will only cost $3 at most.

Next up? Well, that's up to you- there's cheese, fresh juice, hot pork roast, Szechwan, fresh flowers, baked goods, hot apple dumplings and plenty of food  souvineers. My only regret is that we didn't have more room in our stomachs for the Yelp-adored apple dumplings. What a fun mix of people, sights and smells under one roof.

If you don't like Reading Terminal Market, you're a communist and I don't trust you. 

This place has pretty much everything you could ever want to eat. As a matter of fact, if there is no version of Reading Terminal Market in Heaven, then I'm going to be extremely surprised.

There's so much diversity in deliciousness here. Cheesesteaks, brisket, roast pork, chinese, thai, pizza, ice cream, mac & cheese, crepes, burgers, gyros, soul food, roasted turkey, cookies, pretzels, cakes...ah darnit, now I want to go there.

If a friend is in Philadelphia for a visit and you don't take them here, you have failed. As a matter of fact, this might be considered a betrayal. 

As a (tiny) negative, it can get crowded and sometimes difficult to find places to sit. Also, food apparently has calories (sp?) which make you fat if you consume too many...and you will want to eat everything here. 

If you're reading this review and have never been here, drop everything and go right now. Unless it's your phone. Don't drop your phone. You'll need it give this place another five-star review.

Best best best as it gets. Even if you're only visiting this city for an hour, must visit any of the stands at Reading. Cookies discount at end of day. Favorite roasters at Old City Coffee, my go-to is Sumatra and Six-Bean Espresso. Griggstown Farm Chicken Pot Pie (frozen) at the Fair Food Farmstand is a winner. The Head Nut is a good weekly shopping place for your dried foods/spices.
SO many great vendors here, especially love the Herbiary and Beck's Cajun Cafe.

Amazing! Unique! But be warned: it can get overwhelming

First time here? 
Must try: Herschel's for corned beef, Beiler's Donuts for donuts, of course!

Been here?
Great finds: Iovine brothers for awesome deals on literally every type of produce; Head Nut for an ASTOUNDING assortment of herbs, spices, flours, candies, you name it (some of my faves they offer: lavender, nutritional yeast, 00 flour!)
SOOO many counters for meat, fish, cheese, chocolate

COME HUNGRY! You'll be back :)

I always end up planning trip itineraries around food and alcohol. I recently paid my first visit to Philadelphia and we were looking for a light breakfast so my husband suggested stopping by the Reading Terminal Market. Boy am I so glad that we did. I would be in absolute heaven if we had a place like this at home. This market has literally everything to offer. You can eat Mexican, American, Indian, Chinese, Oysters, Thai, etc.. etc.. etc... There's the oldest ice creamery in the country, the best coffee I've ever sipped on and some Amish donuts that will change the way you think about donuts! We got crepes, we shopped for fresh produce, we visited with local artists, we browsed an herbiary. Seriously, you can't go to Philly without visiting this place!

I love Reading Terminal Market. I like that you can get all sorts of great food, prepared and raw. I love that there is a piano. I love that there are tourists and locals alike all enjoying the atmosphere. I love that there are cannolis next to shrimp.

The only real problem with Reading Terminal is totally unavoidable. On a day/weekend with the convention center is in use it can be very difficult to get anything. So much of the fun of Reading Terminal is wandering around, and on a day when its overly crowded, it ruins probably my favorite part of the experience. On an Empty day 5 stars.

This place has it all.  What ever you want to eat, they probably have it.  If you are in a group of people who are all picky on where they want to eat, these are the kind of places to stop.  They even have the Amish making up tasty treats.  Can advise anyone on where to go here because there are so many choices, it is over a hundred vendors packed in one huge building.

What a delightful gem!!!  My father often took me to Reading Terminal when I was a child. Bassetts ice cream was always a special treat when I was a child - and still is!  The market has morphed from a real "working man's" market to a culinary delight for today's obsession and interest in food with local and fresh ingredients.   We always take visitors to Philly to the market and they always want to go back for more.  Many times we've had visitors say that the Reading Terminal market was the best part of their trip to Philly.  Such an abundance of really great food, fresh flowers, spices, meat, seafood, cheese and a really great cookbook stall.  We are so lucky to have such a great place in Philly.  The atmosphere is exciting, especially when there is a conference in town and the Market is buzzing with people who are in awe of one of our best Philadelphia assets.
Don't forget that market businesses will validate your parking ticket for a drastically reduced cost at specific parking lots.

I love to hang out here. There are countless choices for food and coffee. Sometimes it gets a little noisy/crowded, but that's part of the charm, and a few minutes spend on looking for a seat is part of the experience.
A cornucopia of gastronomical delights, with special shoutouts to Miller's Twist, Original Turkey, and Beiler's Donuts. Good luck finding a place to sit between 11am and 2pm.

I love the terminal. The food. The cookies. The coffee. Everything about it is great. Tons of unique businesses and lots of great smells when you walk in you can smell an aroma of different scents. I love old city coffee in there and I also love the cookie. They have a great cook book place that I would recommend going to.

Love the many vendors and types of food available...prepared and raw...seafood, port, red meat, etc...baked goods, drinks from Lancaster...and the ethnic jewelry vendors as well as the fresh produce and too many others to tell.  Never disappointed nor food that was not optimally fresh.  You will not regret purchases from her for a meal at your leisure  and home...Enjoy!  I certainly do...and travel regularly from NJ to patronize.  I was so excited 2 days before Christmas to be able to purchase some smoked turkey for my collard greens as all market and meat stores in Jersey were sold out!  Reading terminal meat vendor came through with flying colors!!!!  No regrets...ever!

Seriously, what's not to love about RTM? There is something here for absolutely everyone!

If any friends or family members come to visit Philadelphia, this is one of the first places I'll take them. I think it does a tremendous job of showcasing the diversity of people found in this wonderful city.

Some of my favorite spots include:
--Miller's Twist
--The Rib Stand
--12th Street Cantina
--Kamal's Middle Eastern Specialties
--Terralyn: Bath, Body, Spirit

The prices can be a little bit expensive, but it is nearly always worth it for the quality of ingredients and customer service. This is a place you definitely cannot miss if you're staying in the area! It's tradition.

Reading Terminal Market is absolutely amazing!! There is all sorts of food--colorful produce, fresh-baked breads, fat sandwiches, bomb ice cream flavors. There's so much to see and eat; the hard part is deciding...and probably finding a seat. I'd definitely recommend checking this place out!
What can i say?  A must visit, even in town for one day.  Brevity is the soul of wit.

Must stop spot in Philly.  You will always find something you can eat.  Come here hungry and try a little something at each of the stands.  Very busy business lunch so be prepared to wait and be cramped for seating.

I love that reading terminal is in Philadelphia and that its so close to my office. The head nut, little Thai, metropolitan and Salumeria, are my go to spots. I also like the sandwich offerings at by George. People watching and the random piano player are definite reasons to make the terminal a regular lunchtime haunt. Stay away during conventions-the place gets mobbed (also during the flower and auto show weeks).

If you love to eat, you will love it here. Come hungry, but not hangry. You could probably spend days here and still not finish all the stuff that you want to try. 

The best strategy is to come as a team. These are the roles of each teammate. Without them, you will not have the best experience that you possibly can have:

1. The hunter of seats - must be strong and able to hold their ground. You may have multiple members on this team. Their main lines are, "You can't sit with us" or "Sorry, this seat is taken, and that one too" 
2. The hunter of food - must be a wise decision maker and have great rationing skills as you will be the ones gathering and feeding the troops. Again, you may have multiple members in this team if you want to take down all targets of food in the building.
3. The hunter of dessert - must be fast, but not too fast (you gotta make it back to the fort before everyone finishes their food because you can't get full on dessert only. Bonus if you can get everything back unmelted. 
4. The time manager - if you drove here, more than likely, you're parked at a paid meter. Your job is to make sure all teams complete their tasks in a timely manner and you return to your vehicle before the time runs out.
*This role may be combined with any roles above. 

If you master all these roles, you will have a successful meal. May the odds be ever in your favor, tributes. Let the games begin!
A great way to spend a day of shopping ad eating with some amazing Restraunt ,  butchers and bakery's there is somethings there for everyone
Great place to stop and have lunch, when entertaining out of town guests.

I love the vegi and fruit store when you first walk in. They have great prices for what I spent $10 there I would of spent double or more at Walmart. Some places can be a hit or miss that's why I didn't give 5 stars. I got Cod fish from one of the market and it was no good it had a bad smell to it, I didn't notice till I got home.

I love this market, I have been there 10 or 15 times, every time I go there is a new shop I am always surprised. You can go to buy fresh produce, aged cheese, or even dinner. There are fancy chocolate stores, bakeries and an iced cream. You can get just about anything and its all home made.
Tourist trap. Don't see what is so great about it.  Go spend your time at the Mutter Museum or the Art Museum.
expensive of course cause of the tourist trap but fresh food and love the cookie place.   take out a loan for a few cookies cause you will pay but its so worth it
So many good places to eat.  So many places to shop.  It's not just for tourists.  I worked near there and ate there at least once a week for many years. I always stop by when I'm in the area.

This place is a mecca of all foods.  You can find anything your heart desires. The juice place was somewhere I stopped frequently for breakfast (fantastic way to start the day).  I would recommend the savory crepes along with the famous donut place with a bunch of funky delicious flavors.

You can't go wrong any where here!

I'm still making my way through to eat from every food stand in the Market (each visit makes me wish I could eat more!), but nothing has disappointed. 

There are more than enough reviews here, so I'm keeping this short.  Try everything, or if you're a tourist and not here often, don't be afraid to try something that's not hyped--you might still find something amazing.  Let yourself wander.   It's really about the experience.

Some favorite items:
-Blueberry/apple fritters, maple bacon donuts from Beiler's-- doughy, warm, fresh, sugary goodness.
-FRESH mozzarella from Meltkraft.   I literally eat it plain with fork and knife.
-Flying Monkey's woopie pies.
-$1 closeout cookies around 5pm from Famous 4th Street [on a slow day]
-Peking duck, easily accessible without going to Chinatown.
-Apple dumplingw/ heayv cream from the amish diner (foodies--this was featured on Food Network)

I stayed in Philly for a weekend and was told that Reading Terminal Market was the place to go for a quick delicious breakfast. I sooo wish there was a place like this in Rochester, NY. As soon as I walked in my heart soared with delight. 

Reading Market provides a warm environment (literally and figuratively). There are countless mini markets in this indoor market. I was curious to see what I could find that I walked through the entire place before ordering anything. There's bakeries, meat/fish markets, souvenir shops, cafe's, and bread companies to name a few. The prices are low and competitive, which made my breakfast experience a little more challenging than I had hoped for.

I purchased a baguette breakfast sandwich at a New Orleans style market. The sandwich only cost $4.75 and it could easily feed 2 people. I was shocked at the portion size when they handed it to me. 

I bought whoopie pies for my family at a cute little vegan bakeshop as well. When I returned home with them, they gave rave reviews. 

It wasn't very busy for a Sunday, which made the experience even better. I would like to check it out on a Saturday when more stores are open.
Wonderful variety of delicious food, beverages, and cool gadgets. Excellent people watching also!
What great choices!! A bit of everything. I love going there for lunch when I am in Philly at the Convention Center
Food out the wazoo! Great prepared food for immediate consumption, or fine meats, vegetables, & ingredients for the most outrageous of recipes.  Fun to eat and stroll, people watching as you go.

The signs of a great market are as follows: local produce (and flavorful), good bazaar (and fun), and really (really) delicious food (and famous!). When there's more than 250 food dealers and countless of tempting (not so calorie-conscious), as well as few healthy choices under one roof, from Hershel's reuben, Beck's mac n' cheese fried balls, to Beiler's maple bacon doughnut, I bet you can't stop eating at just one stall. Luckily, you can always come back for more.  P.S: Don't forget your Tums

What a tourist might pick:
- DiNic's: Roast Beef and Pork. ( Winner of best sandwich in America'12)
- The Original Turkey: The Stuffin' Cranberry. ( All-year-round Thanksgiving)
- Beck's Cajun Café: Train Wreck.

What a local might pick:
- Flying Monkey Bakery: Pumpple. (2 pies in 1: a pumpkin pie and an apple pie)
- Dutch Eating Place: Scrapple breakfast sandwich.
- The Famous 4th Street Cookie Company. ( $1 cookie holler before closing )

What I might pick:
- Meltkraft:  Valley Thunder Grilled Cheese.
- Beck's Cajun Café: Shrimp & Chicken Gumbo. 
- Kamal's Middle Eastern Specialties: Chicken Shawarma. 
- Iovine Brothers Produce: Local fruits & vegetables. (10% discount on Wed. and Sun. for all students and Jefferson ID employees) 


Pro tips:
1/ Take your kids, they'll love Philbert the pig: Reading Terminal Market's mascot. 
2/ Get $4 parking validation with a purchase of $10: Two hours limit, and valid only for two assigned garages: 11th & Arch Streets (Expert Parking), 12th & Filbert Streets (Parkway Garage). 
3/ Amish vendors aren't at RTM on Sundays.
4/ Free WiFi access.

Five Yelps.

LOVE LOVE LOVE this place. So much food, so many options. It has EVERYTHING. Beiler's donuts, Bassett's ice cream, Dutch Eating Place's hot apple dumpling, Metropolitan Bakery's cookies, and many many more... Amish food here is amazingggg, so rich, decadent, sweet, and pure. Two words: food orgasm. 

I don't really come here for entrees. I'm not interested in real food -- I want desserts and other sweets!! I had tried Tommy DiNic's roasted pork and pulled pork sandwiches; they were great but didn't really stand out to me. I also had a hoagie at one shop (forgot the name), and it didn't stand out to me either. I think while the entrees here are good, there are plenty of other (and less crowded) places that have similar, and equally delicious, entrees. Plus, there are tons of food trucks in Philly that specialize in hoagies and sandwiches, and they're equally delicious and far cheaper! So, I mainly come to Reading Terminal Market for Amish sweets and non-Amish sweets. 

The place is always packed full of people, so that's one con, but it's also full of delicious food. A must-go for everyone, tourist and local. I would go everyday if I could.

The market can get so crowded that it's not for the faint of heart. Don't lose track of the people you come in with! Pretty much anything you want to eat--either on the spot or to take home--is here. Somewhere. And most of it is very good. Some specialty items can be very pricey, but if this is the only place you can find them and it's what you want, it's worth it. I've taken out of town guests there just to share the experience with them. It's an adventure even if you're not hungry or interested in shopping. When I have time to kill before catching a train, I always pop in to see what's happening. There's always something different that I hadn't noticed before.
There's something for everyone at Reading Terminal Market. My boyfriend and I love to shop here for ingredients to make a nice meal.
Classic Philadelphia spot!  This place is amazing, prices great, and there is so much variety in the places you can order from.

This market has a wonderful variety of prepared food items, produce, meats, specialty foods, places to eat and a few non-food shops. I love the atmosphere,

Some of the best was, i had roast beef and roast pork sandwiches from DiNic's, one of my favorites. This is a counter service place in the center of the Market, with delicious sandwiches with moist meats on crusty rolls that you can customize, with choices of sauteed spinach or broccoli rabe, roasted or hot peppers, sharp provolone, etc. Pepperoncini peppers and horseradish are on the counters. Don't worry if there are no seats, wait and ones will open soon. Take out counter is to the right.

Tips - 
Parking in the garage across the street is reduced cost if validated with a purchase.
Come hungry or you'll be sorry!
If you have never been you need to experience RTM. Great place to get some great food, meet some locals, and enjoy the environment of the market!
There's a lot to choose from at the Market, but to guarantee a 5-star experience, have a Beiler's apple or blueberry fritter.

There's nothing bad to say about Reading. Try the salmon platter from the thai place. It's a lot of food for $7 plus you get shirmp, don't skip the curry/crack sauce, it's poppin. The cookies at the cookie stand are also bomb as fuck but I wish they had gluten free options.

A little bit of everything for everyone! I love spending an afternoon here sampling odds and ends at various establishments. It's huge and has a little bit of everything for even picky eaters. It's a great indoor market, but it does tend to get loud.
Great variety of food which tastes good just a little pricey and it stays pretty crowded.
So many awesome stands in here. A great salad place, a great produce place, cheesteaks, beeswax, juice bars, wine, something for everyone.
Who doesn't love Reading Terminal Market!  So many things under one roof, and you need a whole day to just explore.  Have breakfast, lunch, and an early dinner here.  It's worth the visit!

It was love at first sight once I stepped foot inside. This is heaven to any food lover! There's so many choices that you'll have to keep coming back before you can even try them all. I highly recommend getting portions of your meal (appetizer, entree, drink, dessert, etc) at different stands in order to try as many as you can during one trip. There's also a grocery market on one side!
Should be made a National Landmark. This is what a big city can afford that smaller ones just can't.
One can never go wrong at the reading terminal. A Philly institution that just gets better with age. Try the gyros,at Olympia they are very tasty

I love this place. Definitely more pros than cons. It truly represents the culture of Philadelphia. They have a version of any good food sold in Philly, cooked or fresh. They're open nice and early so you can visit before work. The hot and fresh donuts are to die for. Very diverse. It's just a great place to visit. Because of that, there are a few things for which you must pack your patience. There's just not enough dining space. It's definitely not a relaxing atmosphere. There's so much to see that you're bound to get stuck walking behind someone who behaves like a tourist although they probably live here in the city. You want to go to the terminal when you're in the MOOD for open market shopping. It's a great experience.

Always super crowded, don't get your hope up on finding somewhere to sit. They will be e pensive but all of the food is great. There's even a small produce spot in there and several a meat/seafood vendors.
Try the pork sandwich, and the cookies, and the ice cream... really everything is great there!
Amazing place. Very Philly. Bustling food court with fresh and diverse options. Foodie haven for sure.

Suffers from commericaliazation, don't even bother to come here on the weekends if you are not willing to wade through the tsunami of tourists and looky-loos. The worst comments come from people who seem to think they discovered something new, when in reality its been the same forever(at least the 10+years Ive been going); dont complain about lines/crowds if your a tourist who hasn't lived in the area or visited the market regularly. Puhlease....just save everyone the trouble and stay in your burb market area, we appreciate not having to wait for you to make up your mind while standing in front of the cashier(s).

RTM is a local essential that keeps getting infiltrated by tourists.  Yes,  the apple fritters from Beilers, the roast pork and provolone with broccoli rabe, cannoli from Termini Bros, and ice cream from Basset's is worth the wait,  but could if you could wait in an orderly queue that doesn't block me from getting trimmed to order pork shoulder from Giunta's, or raw milk from Lancaster Dairy, or wonton roast duck at Sang Kee, I would be rather grateful.

If you can't find somewhere to eat here, then you're not doing something right.  This place is AMAZING!!  I always request working the Philadelphia Auto Show, just so I can come into town and frequently visit the Reading Terminal.  I also make peace with the fact that I will be spending a lot of money because it's just too god to not take advantage of. So many delicious options!  You're sure to find something you like, definitely something you love and probably something you'll want to try again.  One of the best places on Earth for sure!
Terrific.  Authentic and fun.  Can get VVEERRRYYY crowded at lunch, filled with jurors fro the nearby courthouse, office workers and tourists.  You WILL find something delicious to eat here.

It is an amazing place to eat, buy fresh food. It is fun, there is a great atmosphere. I like to go here with my family to grab a quick lunch or share a breakfast. 

****

C'est un lieu fantastique où vous pouvez manger et faire vos courses. J'adore y aller avec ma famille pour partager un petit déjeuner ou manger sur le pouce.

It's touristy, crowded and loud and always seems to have a different foul odor every time you turn the corner, but somewhere in that indoor maze is a place called OK Produce that sells produce that are literally just that - okay (as in overly ripe and a little funky) for super cheap. I left with two brown bags filled to the brim for a mere 8 bucks. Don't know what I'm going to do with 5 lbs of poblano peppers so now it's time to get creative in the kitchen.
This place is amazing and a must stop every time we visit Philly.
Gitta live this place.  Still has vendors selling raw food and a nice mix of those and prepared food vendors  Dont go there hungry if you are shopping for groceries

Definitely a must stop for all visitors! It's filled with amazingness! All kinds of food vendors and small craft stores. Just so much to explore each time. There's a big public dining area. You kinda have to fight for seats. It's close to public transportation but parking is a nightmare especially there's events at the convention center. I love the diversity Reading is able to bring together.

This place is neat! It has everything! A lot of great places to eat inside! It can easily get crowded. We ate at Tommy DiNic's which has scrumptious cheesesteaks. I was looking forward to trying Miller's Twist's soft pretzels but they were closed on Sunday. Boo! We tried Bassetts Ice Cream and it was really good! They can make milkshakes too. I didn't see much souvenir shops like I've seen at similar markets in other cities. Maybe I missed it?? We still enjoyed visiting this place and we recommend checking it out!
Awesome market. They have almost every type of food here. It's amazing. The donuts here are so good.

This place is a feast for the eyes and mouth.  You can find pretty much anything to eat here at the Reading Terminal Market, as there's aisles and aisles of food, from cooked food to consume now, to raw food to prepare at home, to sweet desserts and candies to give to someone special.

This place reminded me of the Granville Market in Vancouver, Canada, or the Grand Central Market in Los Angeles, and to some extent Pike Place in Seattle.  I'm sure like those markets, this market changed over the years.  You can get breakfast or lunch here by walking up to the food kiosk and plop yourself on an open stool, chat with the guy next to you, and then grab something from the bakery as you head out.

Even though its semi touristy, the prices are not completely outrageous.  At one of the deli counters, their shaved meats were about $4 a pound.  A supermarket in California charged $7.99 a pound for roast beef, so this was quite a bargain.

You can spend hours here, but if you're a tourist without a car, hauling your goods can be a problem.  I did stop at Flying Monkey Bakery and picked up 4 bars of the Butter Cake, which were amazingly good (but messy!).  

It is definitely a must stop if you're in the Philadelphia area.

A must-go if you are in Philadelphia! Reading Terminal offers something for everyone! The variety of food seems almost endless. It's always very crowded with tourists, but locals still love to come here. I buy my produce and meats here every week. I prefer to go in the mornings before it gets very crowded. The lines for the donuts at Beiler's can get very long, but so worth it. There is ample seating provided in the center areas for you to enjoy the food. Just about anything food related can be purchased here, including spices, canned foods, special ingredients, etc. You can also get your parking validated here for a discounted rate at nearby garages.
Best place to shop.Has everything you need in one spot.And the Amish women are beautiful.

The Market is a collection of vendors selling everything from dinner, cookies, fresh veggies and meats to souvenirs. It is loud, sometimes crowded on weekends (very crowded, hence 4 stars and not 5) and very fun. This is one of those places that a tourist should not miss, come to have lunch and by a few things to bring home.  Don't forget to try a hot, fresh pretzel.

Been to Reading Market a few times in the summer, but I have never seen it more packed than last Saturday (rightfully so, as it was one of the coldest days in the last few years). You can eat to your heart's content and there are grocers and knickknack vendors sprinkled throughout. Like other tourists, we went to DiNic's for a pork sandwich, Beiler's for donuts, Miller's for pretzels, and Sweet as Fudge for chocolate and nuts. More hype than what the line was worth, but a great way to spend a couple of hours on a cold winter day.

Love this place. Go here with an appetite. You can have breakfast, brunch, lunch, snacks and more meals here. It has a mixture from candy to donuts to seafood and greek food. Every cuisine is there. 

It gets pretty warm in there. On the weekend it is crowded. The place closes at 5pm so get there before then.

There are certain places where the lines are insane but they go by fast.

What's there not to like about the Reading Terminal?! 

Swing by the Tubby Olive and taste test olive oil and balsamic vinegar. Walk out with five bottles of the most delicious olive oils that are great as dips and on salads! 

Drop by for lunch and there's endless options. 

Swing by for a beer and hang out! 

Walk around and taste all the delicious desserts! 

Love cheese and fresh cut meat? The Amish do it right! 

Definite go to spot while you're in center city.
What's not to love about Reading Terminal? Basset's ice cream, DiNic's roast pork, Termini Brothers cannolis, heaven.
We love the Reading Terminal!!  We had a great experience shopping and a super lunch at Molly Molloy's.  Always fresh and yummy

This place is the BOOM.COM... I love  farmers markets & the one is a rare gem... There is no two stands a like & prices are super fair... I love you can buy books, china & then sushi all in the same building. It has been feature many times on different travel programs..

It's a must go to in the Philly area...

Love this place. So many great eateries to choose from. Seating can be rough at peak times, but you can't go wrong with the food. Love the candy shop- I am forgetting the name- they are so kind and the candy is amazing!
Everything here is fantastic. Spices, PA Dutch foods, fresh produce, chocolate, honey, and snazzy lunchies everywhere. Also great place for dates

Best food hall on the East Coast. Something for everyone and a slice of local Philly culture. I'm a Philly ExPat and I try to stop in there on each trip. There is food for every taste and a fantastic selection of fresh meat, fish and vegetables. Fantastic baked goods as well. You can't go wrong.
This was our first stop in Philadelphia, and it did not disappoint!  I'm just sad we didn't get to try more things.  That just means we have to keep coming back until we've tried them all.
it's obnoxious, crowded, and full of tourist traps...but also awesome and full of delicious goodies.  you just need to figure out what the good stuff is!  start with bassett's ice cream.  yum!

Enjoy doing my weekly shopping here, though it's typically PACKED (emphasized for a reason) Good quality produce to be found, good meats, and other trinkets from the PA Dutch like Peanut Butter and Preserves. Organic/raw Honey. Pastry and chocolates, cheese and bread. Coffee and loose tea to be had as well. Some of it is overpriced, as the place is a tourist trap but at the end if you're a regular shopper you know where to go and where to avoid. All in all pretty high quality stuff at reasonable prices. 

Bike parking can be tight, so if you're a rider be prepared for that.

Again, the joint is a cattle car on the weekend, so be prepared for that.
I was just blown away by this market.  So much great food, wonderful people, cool setting and great vibe.  It is a must visit when coming to Philadelphia.
Food is pretty good however it can be pricey depending on the type of meal that you choose but it is well worth it on an occasional basis.
Typical Farmers Market and Food Court. Avoid this place around lunch and on weekends...

I love this place! I came here as a visitor first. Promised to myself I will be back the next chance I get. I moved here for a job and still love coming here! Hershel's deli is my go to sandwich - corned beef pastrami reuben. Possibly the best sandwich. Ever. I still come here once every 1-2months. It's just worth it. I bring all my visitors here too. You have to go and just explore. Definitely worth your time even as a visitor or a resident of Philadelphia.

This place makes me miss philly !  You really experience the culture and food philly has to offer by walking around the market and exploring all the different stores .   This should be your first destination upon arrival and after go say hello to rocky he's not far !
So much great food, so little time. No trip to Philly is complete without a stop here for lunch. I also highly recommend the Bloody Mary's at Molly Malloy's, they just may be the best in the city.

This is one of my happy places in Philly. As I'm sure it is for lots of locals and tourists alike.

Some of my fave stops: Termini for cannoli, Beiler's for doughnuts and cookies, Kamal's for Middle Eastern food and smoothies, Salumeria for some of the best hoagies in town, Fair Food Farmstand for quality (though pricey) local produce, DiNic's for roast pork sandwiches, and several great butchers and seafood vendors. 

Wish I had a bottomless belly to hit up all these places at once!

Really really good lunch and shopping place if you are wanting to grab some things to make dinner.  Very good selections of produce, butchers and seafood.  I would suggest going with a crew so you can try a few different things. I try not to eat sweets much anymore but damn this place. Termini's best cannoli, sfogliatelle and the banana thing...Criminal!!!  So try not to eat sweets was appropriate to say this day .... The f'ing donuts are another problem.  The prices here are also very reasonable 

As far as food is concerned the Thai place was very crowded but gets good reviews and the gyro and Dinics were both very very good.  

The only problem is Philly is a little seedy, other than that hurry here if you haven't been.

it's a fun place with many vendors,
it was crowded every single time we went there (on almost a dozen occasions)
I highly recommend the Beiler's Bakery, and several of their eateries. 
Reading terminal is also the only place I know of that offers chocolate covered onion (as a gag present)
a definite must see in philly

What a lovely place to get lost in. I admit, I first heard of Reading Terminal Market from National Treasure. Stop laughing. I'm a huge Diane Kruger fan.

Ate so many good things. Bought some cookies to-go. Drank some coffee. Perused some shops. Amaze.

This is one of the best places in Philly to eat if you're not exactly sure what you want. With a large variety of foods from different regions and cultures, you could pick any shop to eat at and you won't be disappointed. There's also a couple delis and a market if you need to do some grocery shopping.  If you name it, it's probably there (Except the sushi place that is no longer here.) 

It is a tourist spot so some of the places can be a little pricey, but overall it's a good place to get a quick bite to eat. Because it's a tourist spot it can also get very crowded and loud when it's busy. 

Whenever I'm here I usually get a roast pork sandwich from Dinic's.
love it, definitely gets a little too crowded and touristy for my taste but other than that great place.
Anything and everything is here!  Well mostly anyway.  I love coming here for lunch and buying organic meats and produce at a ridiculously cheap price.  Great place to people watch.
Great place to visit for both residents and tourists.  This is an important part of Philadelphia's culture; delicious food, great variety, vibrant atmosphere, and a great pace to pass time.

What's bad to say about this place? Whether you're craving freshly baked cookies that are literally just coming out of the oven or clams on the half shell, you are sure to find it all here. This place is my go to if I have time early in the morning and want to indulge is a fresh donut. This place is ALWAYS packed on the weekends. FYI - a lot of the Amish stands aren't open on Sundays.. The produce stand (Iovine Bros.) is nice and always clean and well organized. This market is always buzzing with patrons. They sometimes play live music in the designated "seating area" which is in the middle of the market. Local produce, in-house made chocolates and cakes, spicy Indo/Pak food, Jamaican delights and so much more are all housed under the same roof. Come hungry because you will definitely leave happy!
this place is the best on a Sunday AM!  Try the Amish breakfast place :)

What's not to like. It the single place I always tell out of towners to visit in Philly. U can get what you want for reasonable pricing. I love browsing the book store, grabbing a beer in the tavern, and of course all the Food vendors from Spataros HUGE sandwiches to the Amish style baked goods. YUMM!

This place is a lot of fun! Great atmosphere, hustle bustle, so much to look at - kitchen shop, candy shops, flowers, meat, fish, cheese, produce, lots of food stalls. Our group of 5 split up to each find what we wanted to eat for lunch, then got a table in the center area. Some of the food lines were pretty long, but I found a short line at Beck's Cajun and was very happy with my etouffee.

This place is definitely one of Philly's treasures. If you don't know what to eat, stop in here! It's a great mix of produce stands, baked goods, fresh meats, and tons of different types of foods and restaurants. HIGHLY recommend the Amish bakery for donuts and fritters and Meltcraft for one seriously amazing grilled cheese sandwich. Be aware that it's crowded on the weekends (and any time there's a major event in the convention center), but aside from the crowds, Reading Terminal has great variety and a lovely atmosphere. Definitely a must-see (and eat) when you're in town.

This place is insane. So crowded and hectic so be prepared. I would advise to go on off-peak hours so you can enjoy walking around and looking at things. I went an hour before they closed on a Saturday and it was still crazy. 

However, they do have some great looking food. I wish I could of tried it all! Getting our food took so long and we only had about 15-20 minutes before closing (6pm) and vendors were already closing up shop.

You can park in the parking structure for 2 hours for $4 if you spend $10 and get it validated!

I can't come to Philadelphia without coming to the market. I don't think there is anything you could not find here. From fresh produce to all kinds of ethnic foods and amazing bakeries and confections. This is the place to shop and eat.

First time I came here, it was love at first sight. The amount of food available is truly staggering. For sweets lovers, it's paradise. For someone in Philly at lunch time, it's the best place to go. The PA Dutch girls are an integral part of the atmosphere. They show you a part of Pennsylvania culture which cannot be found anywhere else in the world. The hardest part about the Market is choosing what you want because everything looks delicious.
One of the best places to visit in Philly if you love food. Some places only take cash. The Dutch eating place is phenomenal. Fresh food and great service. Best pancakes I've eaten in my life.

THE BEST!!! OMG - ask questions the people are so nice, I bought a few goodies... Sticky buns, peanut butter, chocolate fudge and had a very nice thanksgiving! I ordered the turkey and mash, I don't recall the name, but I was some good cookin! Lol!! They have options for all!! It is a must in Philly!! The only thing... It was so busy!!! But that's a good problem to have! Be ready to navigate through the crowds... And please walk fast!

MUST CHECK OUT!!
definitely a must do while in Philly. Bring plenty of delicious food home lots of cool spots. I love the selection of choices at this convenient location. Yoy Won't Regret eating or coming here.
Pretty good if you're hungry or an Amish food fan. Prices are pretty steep there, but a fun time.

So many people that it takes away any good this place might have. 
Either prepare yourself or don't go.

One of Philly's absolute must-go spots. Whether it's for fresh produce/meat/fish/herbs or for an amazing quick meal or treat from one of the many food vendors, it has something to satisfy everyone. Anytime family or friends are visiting from out of town, I always take them for a lunch at Reading Terminal Market and it never disappoints. One of my favorite things/places of the city!

The market has a huge selection of food outlets and it's always busy. Personally I find it a bit overwhelming on weekends and around lunch, so I'd recommend not visiting during those times. However, if you like a bit of bustle and loads of dining options, you'd struggle to find anywhere better in Philadelphia.

I really want to love Reading Terminal Market for all it's variety and chaos but it's too chaotic. Every time I walk in there, hundreds of people are rushing past you, bumping into you, and you feel rushed to hurry, get your food and get out!

I have tried a few of the stands there but my favorite will always be Bassett Ice Cream shop!

You can't visit Philly without going here. Reading terminal is the epitome of Philadelphia life, such a great melting pot with everything you want. Be sure to check out Beilers, the best homemade donuts in the city. Also great hidden treasures like Molly Malloys and Pearls Oyster Bar. The possibilities are nearly endless! Also make sure to stop my meltkraft, the best grilled cheese in the city by far!! Either way, you'll always have a good meal at reading terminal.
Love making this one of my stops when I'm in center city.

Simply writing a review for Reading Terminal Market does not do it justice. For those unfamiliar, RTM is a large building consisting of many small businesses and stands ranging from groceries to eateries to miscellaneous goods. Only the listing on their website or a visit in person can give an accurate feel of the scope. 

Overall, the place is clean and you're able to find just about anything food-related you might have a craving for. Be prepared for an overload of options and  to spend a good deal of time here- even a simple walkaround can take an hour or two. Most businesses and eateries have their own review pages and websites for those curious. 

Two important things to note: 1) The Pennsylvania Dutch retail section is not open the same hours as the entire market due to their beliefs and scheduling. This section is normally only open Wednesday to Saturday. 10+ of the stands are qualified as PA Dutch, Amish, or Mennonite and as such missing them is a significant chunk of the market.

and 2) Parking is generally done in garages near to the market, though it can get expensive quickly. Even locals are sometimes unaware that if you do end up making a purchase, ask the vendor to validate your parking ticket for a significant reduction on 2 hrs of parking. (Though still not free)
