LOVE THIS PLACE! It is a mad house at lunch time so go early. You can get all your food needs HERE! Seafood, produce, soul food, blueberry pancakes, fresh jam, hoagies, and infused olives. Any picky eater can find food. Honestly, Reading is an experience even if you don't eat.

Interesting assortment of stores, food, and merchandise.  Some good food places in there.  The place is old but seems a bit on the grungy side.  Way too crowded to really enjoy.  You can almost forget about getting a quick bite to eat, as it's usually a long wait in lines to purchase food.

Range of vendors from groceries to prepared foods.
Eating options abound from around the world. Baked goods, International foods..
Amish stands only open Thu.- Sat.  The best bacon is at Halteman's.
Don't go on Saturdays unless you're not afraid of a crowd.
Iovine Bros. produce has student discount days on Sun., and Wed. need ID.
Need to bring cash as some vendors have a credit limit.
Get the best and freshest seafood at Jon Yi's.  Definitely worth the price.

The best place to buy groceries in the city.
Every type of honey imaginable at Bee Natural
Reihl's deli and cheese shop sells huge smoked bones for dogs at a great price
Molly Malloy's has a great beer selection and is a nice place to take a rest.
Ice Cream at Bassett's is amazing!
Need to stop by Miller's Twists for the best pretzels.
Arch St.  Has a parking garage.  Any vendor can validate your ticket to make it $4
Landmark in Philadelphia.

My first trip to The Reading Terminal Market was back in 1952 when I was four. My mother took me there for my first Bassett's ice cream cone, and from then on, there was no turning back. I've had a long term love affair with the Reading Terminal ever since. 
Naturally, I also have hundreds of wonderful things to say about the Market, but I hardly know where to begin. Well, let's try this... The Amish part of the Market is always a real treat! Talk about some good old fashion cookin'! Wowee!  And then there's... Scrapple sandwiches, maple bacon donuts, FAB Philly pretzels, and at DiNic's, there's their famous Roast Beef and Pork sandwich, the winner of best sandwich in America!!!  
Seriously, if the angels made sandwiches, they would taste like this one at DiNic's.
So... if you come into the city for a visit, or you work in Center City, take the time to make The Reading Terminal Market a part of your day in Philly.  
It's more than just an indoor market and eatery - it's an Experience! 
Ya gotta go.

This major tourist trap is nothing more than a mall food court.  You can do much better for a cheese steak almost anywhere in Philly; and why not join the debate about Jim's or Pat's or Gino's.  You can also get oysters and shellfish elsewhere.  The best options here are the ample amounts of cookies, pastries, chocolate, and desserts.

the greatest place for lunch in downtown philly. 

about a zillion food places housed in the old Reading Railroad train shed at 12th & market--yes, the same Reading that is in Monopoly, as in "take a ride on the Reading".  

For many years now, a great food joint.  

a great dessert joint.  bassett's ice cream and many coffee places.

you can buy fresh fish octopus or squid here.  meats & veggies.  many odd spices and foods.

the coup de grace is they connect to the convention center above, to the suburban east commuter station below, to market east mall to the east, to city hall to the west, and to the Marrriott across the street.  

a superb philly tradition!
An incredible selection of eat in and takeout along with farmers market for produce, meats and bakery items

Best Spots & Menu Item: Millers Twist for a salted pretzel (see my review), DiNic's for a roast pork hoagie with sharp provolone and long hots, Bieler's Donuts for a maple bacon donut. 

A must see and eat in Philadelphia. This is one reason why I am happy to be a resident of this great city. Although I have listed my favorites, you can't go wrong here. Prices are fair and everyone accepts cards. The ambiance feels vibrant, local, family run, fresh, clean, and just fun. Come here just to walk around, but my recommendation is to arrive hungry!

Hot tip: Let your friend order for you while you look for a seat. It is a daunting task to find a seat with all your delicious goodies in tote.

Preface: I went to Reading Terminal Market on a Saturday at noon during the weekend of the international flower show (which was down the road) AND St. Patrick's day. It goes without saying that this triple whammy made for a very crowded and chaotic experience. There was barely room to move and navigating between stalls may have involved the tactful use of elbows. 

Now, aside from the crowds, Reading Terminal is AMAZING. Craving something? Reading Terminal probably has it. There's an incredible selection and most things are very well priced so come hungry! We were only able to hit three places before getting full. 

12th Street Cantina- Veggie Quesadilla with chips and guacamole. The veggie quesadilla was great and the guacamole was sublime. You can tell that it is made fresh. Don't forget the napkins because eating this can get messy! Overall, I was very happy with my selection. 

Indian place that starts with an N (totally forgot the name)- only grabbed a potato samosa here but they have many of your typical Indian food options. The samosa was bland and disappointing. It was also wrapped in puff pastry vs the usual samosa shell which would've been okay had the filling been more flavorful. 

Meltkraft- I love grilled cheese. Meltkraft has sooo many options from the filling to what fat to grill your sandwich in (duck fat? Truffle oil? Garlic rub?) We decided to get the basic grilled cheese with added jalapeños. The cheese itself was very very good but after grilling the sandwich was a bit oily. I also would've liked more jalapeños in the grilled cheese. Almost an entire half of my sandwich was jalapeño-less. But the cheese was on fleek

Awesome atmosphere. Crazy ton of food options for lunch or breakfast or treats to take home. Not horribly priced at all for being such a tourist spot. Bring cash! Some places to eat are cash only; not all, but some. Definitely a must go to spot while in Philly!

Interesting market with fresh vegetables, fruits, fish, candies, desserts, and many other things. We even bought a bag of blueberries back to NJ. Love this place~ Hope there could be a shop to sell some small  plants or flowers~
Great for grabbing stuff to make for dinner, also fun to show your tourists. I love Dinic's and tried the Flying Monkey this past weekend. Big fan!
Various local food and they are all good. So many stores to choose from and so crowded for reason.
I love going to The Reading Terminal anytime I go to Philly. You have so many food and produce options that it's worth it. Highly recommend
best priced (and fresh!) produce in the city

SHOP 543 - excellent food, friendly service , and incredible views of the ships while dining. Yes, you pay a little bit more because you get so much more in the quality of the cuisine. I am not talking huge portions (portion size is fine) but definitely not the 'ordinary' lunch choices when you dine here. But, for the 'ordinary' lunchers, you will make out fine here as well.
The most overrated place in Philadelphia.  WAAAAAY too crowded.  I hope you don't like moving.

Loved this place! So many places to eat & check out! And it was packed with people on a Monday at noon. That says something. We stopped & got the most amazingly fresh cookies & a pot roast sandwich...it was to die for! I wish my stomach could have fit more so I could try tons of others eateries. So glad we came here!

I went on a Sunday and kept reading that the lines get crazy as this was true, in my opinion the lines move so fast that it doesn't feel like a bother. They have stations set up that will prevent getting lost. There are a lot of eateries and I am def coming back to try more. Only thing is next time I will bring wet wipes because it can messy. I was fortunate to try 3 different places here. I got the Olympia Gyro's, Basset's Ice Cream and than to finish the food coma I got some cookies from The General Store. 

Olympia Gyro's- They were so good, soft warm pita bread with freshly sliced lamb. The Gyro sauce compliments the wrap nicely. Nothing over powers another its just the right blend you want.

Bassets Ice Cream- Massive scoops. I bought some for my sister and she was amazed when she seen her cone. I got the Butterscotch Vanilla in a waffle cone. It was both creamy and sweet and the waffle cone was satisfying. It was a big cone.

PA General Store- I got Top 3 best cookie I ever had in my damn life. I got the Lemon and White chocolate, The Turtle, and the Original Chocolate Chip Cookie. I would def shop by the pound next time. Don't make the mistake and not bring back extra for home.

Can't go wrong love this place! Anything your hearts desire is waiting for you there. You are truly only limited by your imagination. Light, decadent, refreshing, wholesome, pure, organic, heavy, sinful, what is your pleasure? It's almost like the Hotel California. You can check in, but won't want to check out!

Came on a Saturday that an event was happening at the Convention Center and it was PACKED!! Unfortunately that forced me to get in and get out but I was very pleased to see the selection of vendors the market houses! I got some delishhh Mexican food and some sweets from Flying Monkey! All in all its a cool shopping place. I will be back!
I just love going in this place the food is so fresh so eye appealing I don't mind paying for top quality food so much variety never disappointed

I came here with my bf on a weekend trip to Philadelphia. I love markets and after looking into some things to do in the area I decided that we had to stop by. My review will be a mix of us going initially on a Saturday (when it was crazy busy) then returning the next day where I actually got to experience the food. 

 Y'all.....we must have gone on the worst day possible! Our first time visiting was on a Saturday and there was a volleyball tournament going on at the convention center across the street which meant that 2 billion people were at this market! Ok...maybe not 2 billion but a lot. This made it difficult to walk around to all of the vendors/restaurants. 

*Location- It's a busy area and we parked in the garage right across the street for $4 (2 hour max with $10 validation). 

*Food- SOOO much food!!! I was initially overwhelmed by the amount of food there was around me. (Note: this is not a bad thing.) After settling in we tried fresh blueberry and strawberry lemonade from a stand (sorry can't remember the name). It was amazing! We even brought extra to take home. Next, we ate at Pearl's Oyster bar for brunch on Sunday. I had the chicken and waffles benedict. *Le sigh* I really wanted to like this but I just didn't. The eggs were over cooked, the waffle was bland, and I don't think you can call that chicken breast (they more like crumbs of chicken breast). Next, my boyfriend tried a chocolate chip cookie from a stand across from Pearl's which he loved. We really wanted to try a few other places but some were closed I'm guessing because it was Sunday. Booo....

*Overall Experience- I loved that there are amazing vendors and there was no way for us to try all of the greatness that was around us. On my next visit I plan to try some of the famous foods that were closed. If you're visiting the area you should definitely stop by. It's a busy place but well worth the trip. 

*Tips- Beware that many vendors are closed on Sundays. Also, there are restrooms and free wifi. Come hungry!

I grew up coming here, so I never remember to review it. Seeing as I was just there on Saturday, I feel like I should throw in my 2 cents.

This is a MUST SEE in Philadelphia. You are experiencing a melting pot of culture, history, and of course, food, when you come to Reading Terminal. It is an experience that will transport you.

Like previous reviewers explained, it is CROWDED on the weekends. Check your anxiety at the door and just go with it. It is fun to get lost in all of the aisles and discover new things. 

My favorite places: DiNics, Terminis (incredibly authentic Italian desserts), Iovine brothers (for fresh, cheap produce), Beilers donuts, Beiler's bakery (very underrated pies!), Pearl's oyster bar (for clam chowder), Kamal's Middle Eastern Specialties (I have fallen for their falafel), Martins for delicious sausages, Salumeria, and The Original Turkey, for when I need to recreate Thanksgiving in March.

There are so many amazing places here, you cant go wrong no matter what. Start a tradition with your family to come every now and then, they will never forget it.

SO MUCH FOOOOOOD!!!!!!!!!!!!!!
It's a bit overwhelming trying to make a choice of what to eat!
I didnt really see anything special about this place.
A must see when visiting Philly. The Amish doughnuts can't be beat, so don't even try! Great food and great prices. No complaints.
A cool place to bring guests - but a little overwhelming, personally.  They do have a little bit of everything as far as food variety goes - and the Dutch food is delish!

LOVE, LOVE, LOVE the Reading Terminal Market. If we are picking up fresh food & vegggies for dinner or almost EVERY THING Beidlers makes ...... Its great!  Beidlers ( Amish near the front of RTM .... )  Has incredible puddings & fresh donuts.  MMMmmmmmm The best!  & Worth every penny!

Must check out when in Philadelphia!! There are so many food options throughout the whole place that you don't know what to choose. Definitely make a point to walk around and look at everything. There's great places for fresh seafood, cheese, sweets, donuts, and even coffee. There are maps so it will be easy to find what you need. There are several sitting areas to enjoy after picking up your food.

Some places can be hit or miss, but the good ones make up for it. Beiler's (donuts), Bassett's (ice cream), Hunger Burger, and the Thai stand with the $7.50 salmon (toward the back) are all amazing. Honestly, the donuts are the best I've had anywhere and the salmon is huge. Great place to eat and explore!
Always love coming to the market! It's an experience! Everything offered at the market is DELISH! Be ready to stand in line but it's worth the wait!

Reading Terminal Market is a busy hub of activity; a quirky biosphere of tourists, locals and vendors buying, sighing [at the long lines] and plying.  While I appreciate the history, tenacity and in some cases brusque moxie of the RTM and its denizens, my first visit became a Dickensian experience as I sifted through retail debris to find hidden gems.  

The building retains remnants of bygone eras; bits of stone and architectural features hinting at the days of steam engines, horse-drawn carts, and the hubris of the 1920's.  It also reflects elements of social decay and the unfiltered byproducts of congested city living; patches of graffiti, cardboard condo residents (some verbally aggressive) and filth. 

Inside you are met by a cacophony of sounds, colors, and aromas.  Determined to "carpe diem" the hell outta the place, my SO and I forged-ahead through the crush of people and visited almost every shop, stall and huckster.  Some of the highlights:

- Iovine Brothers Produce.  Decent selection, many fresh options, reasonable prices and among other things, cold-pressed juice.  Had I been putting together a meal, much of my shopping could have been done here.

- Fair Food Farmstand.  A small but quality selection of organic and/or local edibles. Stinging nettles and kombucha both found a place in my shopping bag.

- Paprika Letterpress + Design.  A delightful proprietress using a century old printing press to create unique paper products for every occasion.  From modern to vintage, joyous to satirical, there is something to grab your attention. 

- Market Blooms.  Little can beat the beauty of fresh flowers.  Nature is the ultimate artist.

- Beiler's Donuts.  Ubiquitous.  Everywhere you turned someone was holding a box of donuts with Beiler's printed boldly on the top.  When we finally found the source there was a line that looped around their space and extended beyond. It looked like it would take an hour to get a donut, so we moved on.  They looked and smelled fantastic.


Final Verdict:  Quantity over quality.  Dozens of mediocre shops selling pedestrian food, blah produce and uninspired crafts. Enough sugar and bad-coffee to leave the cities population sleepless for weeks.  However there are some business worth visiting and supporting - just be prepared to wait.
So many different options with incredible food. Definitely worth visiting while you're in Philly.

Gonna miss this place now that I'm leaving for MD. Great seafood sellers! DiNic's roast pork is an institution! The Amish diner in the back is great for breakfast/brunch! It's usually crowded, so be ready to deal with that.
DiNic's roast pork and beef is fantastic.  Asian places are all good.  The fresh fruit, veggies and butcher shops are incrediblel.  Must go!!
Would love to come back.  Every food you want to eat is here and inexpensive.   Garage parking across the market is expensive though.  Cost me a hefty $30 for only 3 hours of parking.

Any trip to Philadelphia without visiting Reading Terminal Market is an incomplete one. The market itself is a sort of cultural epicenter of Philadelphia with its robust mix of locals and tourists alike. After an all too brief (two hour) sojourn here early in the morning I can reliably conclude that it is virtually impossible to top Reading Terminal Market if you enjoy food markets and consider yourself at least somewhat of a "foodie."

Upon entering, one can be forgiven for feeling a bit disconcerted by the sheer number of pungent aromas that greet you as you open the door. The market has an almost overwhelming amount of vendors packed into a relatively small space, which I feel only adds to the vibrant, bustling energy of the establishment. I don't think you can go wrong with any single vendor, but my favorites would have to be Hershel's East Side for serving one of the tastiest sandwiches I've ever eaten (Pastrami Special) and Beiler's Bakery for indulging my serious sweet tooth with their celestial baked cakes/brownies and rightfully well-renowned donuts.

One of the best places and markets that I've been to a while. I've traveled across the world and food markets are always my top pick, and I have to say THIS ONE is probably the best. Yes, there're a lot of lines, but they go fast. It's an experience you won't forget!

Amazing atmosphere. An absolute feast for the senses. So hard to pick where to eat as everything looks and smells delicious. A must stop when in Philadelphia. We went for early lunch at Dinics and bought some cookies that were amazing and ended up returning for dinner before returning to New York! Amazing!!
So many different stalls, so much to see, try, eat and admire! Yummy all round

Amazing selection of vendors, food being made and eaten every square foot. The smell and the atmosphere alone makes it worth it to take a peek inside. I will probably be coming back here next chance I'm free in Philadelphia.

The area around the market is a bit iffy, with things typical of cities, such as busy traffic, rude drivers, homeless people, offensive odors, etc.

Once inside, you'll feel more comfortable as you wander up and down the aisles making the difficult decision of what to eat.  (Although most of the stands are counter service food establishments, there are stands for things like cookbooks, local produce, a butcher shop, and the like.)

Different stands make different impressions.  Some seem clean, streamlined, and "professional"; others seem rougher, as if the owner didn't give a hoot about presentation, relying instead on the quality of the food.

On two visits, we enjoyed our meals which included baked mac & cheese, perogies, cornbread, banana cornbread, samosas, and beer-battered onion rings.  Both times we went, the seating areas were dirty.

Certainly recommended for the food choices, though.

This is a food mecca of all things Philadelphia does great.There are a wide variety of amazing places to eat as well as some of the freshest quality produce. I personally recommend DiNic's, Beck's Cajun Cafe, Hershel's, Wurst Haus Shmitz, and Molly Malloy's. Go Early morning or late afternoon because the lunch rush is a mad house! Saturdays and Holidays are the same but it is a great experience.
Heaven. You can find absolutely anything and everything you could possibly want or crave. Definitely a must do when in Philadelphia.

Gorgeous on the inside and much bigger than other markets in the same still. Really wonderful choices. It gets very busy but there are some many options that if you are really in a pinch, you can get any food you want.

Neat stuff here! Every imaginable cuisine, all kinds of quirky shops, inexpensive parking. Super crowded on a Saturday afternoon, so there was a little stress and a lot of bumping elbows. A unique experience that no visit to Philly should be without.

Decoration goes with the ambiance. Cost of items are a little high specially when side orders are not included with the sandwiches. Side orders are charged extra. Sandwich portions are small. Metered parking only.

Vibrant, energetic space with diverse offerings of great food. Really clean and inviting. Located next to convention hall and bus terminal, it's been either my first or last destination each time I've visited Philly. This weekend I happened to get off the bus at noon on Friday and go in for lunch. It was maddeningly, outrageously crowded (bus loads of students on 8th grade or senior class Spring Break trips?) but still worth it.

Suburban people are there on the weekend and it's a mob scene. Keep it for the week days. The Dutch counter is a personal fave for a great breakfast that is quick and cheap. Termini Brothers for a Cannoli. !! ! But I love this philly staple

Reading Terminal is a smorgasbord of anything you could possibly want to eat crammed into this wondrous place.  I've been many times and personally love to get an ice cream and a crepe or grab some cheap fruit at Iovine's - though you have to use it pretty quickly because everything is fresh!

My only gripe with this place is that it can get overwhelmingly congested.  Weekdays are the best.
There's a lot so it's overwhelming. The food is fantastic everywhere, and the groceries are so fresh and cheap! Wish it was open longer.

Visiting from NYC, definitely enjoyed the vibe and ethnic variety of this super busy gourmet food market. All your food craves can basically be satisfied at this one stop shop and it's conveniently located just a block from our Loews Hotel. Would love to come back.

carlucios
northfield, nj
Love this market and I take all my guests to lunch here. Everyone is happy with the variety of food and if you have out of towners, they love the shops and people watching.
What's not to love!!?? I love everything about this place. Great food and good people. My only suggestion would be to have some patience.  This place is often crowded.
It is an amazing place with a collection of restaurants and foods from around the world! It is a must go to if you are in Center City
If you struggle making decisions, then this is not the place for you. We wanted cheesesteaks and decided on Spataro's. The line moved quickly and worth the wait. There's something for everyone here.

The donuts are good (not quite the same as the ones you get when going apple picking), they are sweet and thin. The oreo donut was really good. The frosting taste like oreo's. 

Had a brisket sandwich from the market, it was okay.
a little of everything, in a truly philly way. a must-stop to eat place... too many options to choose from. my only caution is to be careful around closing time. shops will close up to an hour early

I LOVE the concept and wish we had something like this in Northern Virginia. We were lucky enough that the reading terminal was right next to our hotel & we swung by before it got busy. It's amazing how many restaurants and little booths they fit in here! Although I probably wouldn't eat at most of these places, it was an awesome experience and the few places I did eat at, I loved so I would definitely come back one day but I don't think it's a necessity.

This is my second visit to this great city and I can't believe I missed the Reading Terminal Market on my first visit. This is a must visit - right after the liberty bell.  OK - for get the bell come here first.  This place is crammed with food venders serving some of the best food ever. I stopped at Hershel's East Side for a pastrami Rubin  -  there must have been a pound of meat on this baby.  So good, I should have a stopped but I didn't.  Next stop will be Di Niks for the Italian pork sandwich.  I'll be back for that.  My wife said and I quote "we should move here".  Are you  kidding me, I'm a New Yorker by birth ... That would be sacrilege ... But I'll be back for the food.

DISCLAIMER: I visited the Market around noon (on a Thursday).  Being there during the busy lunch hour likely impacted my experience.  That stated - I didn't like the place at all.  My biggest issue: I couldn't find a seat!

Yelp reviews inspired me to buy a pretzel (and a drink) from Miller's Twist.  With hands full I walked around the Market for twenty minutes looking for a place where I could sit down and eat.  I never found that spot in the general seating areas (inside or out) so I snuck into the seating section of some vendor I can't remember.  By then my pretzel was cold.  It didn't taste very good anyway.
If you're at the convention center or find yourself walking around the city, make sure you visit. Great food, drinks, dessert and lots of great specialty shops.

A great place to shop and browse. The veggie section is a must.

Only negative is bookshop in the back sells the vile anti Semitic and anti American rag "The Final Call" the propaganda organ of hatemonger Louis Farrakhan's Nation of Islam.

Definitely letting everyone know. In for SI/EI LOF. Oil was left dripping all over the place, the oil cap was missing. As usual the tires were NOT rotated. They even went as far as NOT to fill out the inspection stickers. Awesome job on my brand new truck. Really living up-to there reputation. Way to go guys!
Excellent food and shopping right in Center City. It is one of my favorite spots to go to for lunch.

After hanging out downtown that morning, we decided to stop by the Reading Terminal for lunch.  We were there on a holiday weekend and there was also a Volleyball Tournament of some sorts going on at the Convention Center, so the lunch crowd was extremely chaotic.   It was rather challenging to keep up in a group of four where three of us had never experienced Reading Terminal before.  However, as expected, we lost each other a couple times while looking for a restaurant that didn't have a line completely wrapped around the corner.  This wasn't upsetting because this is a world famous spot.  I totally understood why it was so crowded.  Didn't upset me at all.  I found it rather exciting and adventurous.  I was also grateful they had street signs on the corners which helped us locate each other.  The maps were useful, too.

There were so many restaurants to choose from, but figuring out how to order your food while faced with crowds of people and ridiculous long lines was indeed a challenge.  Thankfully, everyone we encountered was quite friendly and the locals I spoke to were willing to explain the process.  No one seemed irritated by my questions.  I felt welcomed here.  

We fell right into place and found a restaurant that didn't have a long line that we could all agree upon.  We also walked around the entire facility and peeked at every shop.    
We were all very pleased with our meals from the Thai Food Market.  We look forward to returning and trying out foods from other restaurants.  

Notes:  Crowd control is a must!  Line indicators/markers/signage would help tremendously.  More seating for patrons to eat their food would also be helpful.

Such a fun place to go if you want to try multiple different types of food in one day! Reading terminal reminds me greatly of the Chelsea market in NYC. There are tons of different desserts, Delis, ice cream shops, and even Amish owned shops! (Just be aware that Amish owned shops are not opened everyday! They do not work on weekends!) there is live music on some days, a vegetable shop that provides a discount to students on Thursdays, and so much more. Definitely a place to go if you're visiting Philly or if you're hungry and want to try lots of different food!

So we were lucky to stay nearby this place that had so many choices for food.  Their Philly Cheesesteak spot was not good and they charge you for lettuce/tomatoes if you don't want a dry sandwich.  On the weekend they have musical guests by the area where all of the tables are at which was really cool.  Yes, it was crowded on a weekend but we still found seats and pleasant people to sit around and chat/eat with.  The Ice cream place was also awesome,.
Amazing place for a big appetite. There are plenty of places to choose from, but one of my favorites is the Thai spot with the Curry Salmon. Try it and you won't be disappointed!

The Reading Terminal Market is a famous enclosed public market in Philadelphia that was first established in 1892. The urban farmer's market is located on 12th & Arch Streets and is a foodie haven. There is a very wide variety restaurants, fresh and local produce, meats, seafood, diary, baked goods, confections, fresh flowers, coffee, Amish specialities...anything! The selection is incredible and it is fun to explore more than 80 vendors which are mostly family-owned. The market is a very popular spot at lunchtime where you can grab a quick lunch. There are some areas in the market where you can sit and eat. Sometimes the lines can be long but it is always worth the wait. www.readingterminalmarket.org
A must-visit place in Philly. Tons of food options and great shops to buy unique knick knacks. You have to go more than once because there's just too much to choose from.

Not sure how to rate the whole market, all the vendors differ. It a must stop if you're visiting philly for its variety but it is slightly overpriced being a tourism attraction. Hershels deli is a definitive stand out as is the ice cream place.
You can find anything you want here! Love getting fresh chicken breast from the Amish vendors, you won't regret it.  Fresh mozzarella cheese is a must also!

Crowded but the best thing conferences can do it what they did when I recently attended a conference in the Marriott on Market:  give attendees a gift card to the Reading Terminal Market and let them pick their own meals.  The variety ranges from grilled cheese to Philly cheese steaks to pasta to barbeque to donuts to salads to cookies to oysters.  Seriously.  Whatever your people want to eat can be found  The only downside was the limited seating.

Doing Philly with Danis! Philadelphia Museum of Art (Pop), DiNic's (Italian pulled pork with broccoli rob & hot longs!, Beiler's (berry pie & sticky buns), washed down at Molly Malloy's with an Evil Eye IPA (Philly), Perpetual IPA (Hersey) & Hard Cider
Simply the best representation of the variety of food Philadelphia has to offer. Great for locals and tourists alike.
The atmosphere and display is a 4-5 however the actual food is on average a 3. The sweets and produce though are 4-5.

What is not to love about this place!? They have every type of food imaginable. It is all high quality and there is something there for everyone. This is a must stop for food when in the City of Brotherly Love!

Who doesn't love local city markets? They have a little bit of everything, amazing energy, and some of the best eats in the city! If you feel overwhelmed by choosing, look for the place with long lines... that's usually a sure sign it's got something worth trying. I would say this place has an equal mix of ready made foods, desserts, groceries, and other goods like kitchen supplies, soaps and pantry items. I'm pretty sure anyone could find something they're looking for here, and you can also usually find seating outside near the doors.

This might honestly be the BEST market I have been to in a very long time.  I've gone to the West End Market in Cleveland.  The Lexington Market in Baltimore, and really, none of these compare.  This had everything you could possibly hope for and need.  Very crowded but why wouldn't it be?  It's the best.  

From bars, donuts, flowers, groceries, and Philly Loving souvenirs, I wish this was in every city I visited.  It made everything so easy food wise, entertainment wise, and it was clean and comfortable to be in.

Better than the best lunch truck festival. Anything you could possibly want to eat cooked fresh and authentic. I was there during a big convention time so it was pretty crowded. That made getting around a challenge but the wait times were not long and there was plenty of room to sit and enjoy. I'll go back on a less crowded day to spend more time sampling.

Recently visiting the Reading Terminal Market in Philly while visiting for the weekend. 

It's a cool place, and there's a lot going on. They had a bunch of fresh food, meats (that I know nothing about), cheeses, desserts, and sweets. I was pleasantly surprised at the wide variety of cuisines that were available. 

We had some food from one of the deli's, a greek place, a chocolate maker, and a baker. A cool way to kill a few hours.

The BEST market in my opinion. The Amish have a restaurant that is VERY good. The service is quick, and the selections that I have had are fresh, and cooked to perfection. I recommend the Terminal to anyone!!

Best market I have been to in my US travels.

It was like holy food heaven when I walked in.

Reading can be hard to navigate so make sure you look at the map so you do not get lost.

Very very crowded. So be ready to bump your way through to where you want to go.

Remember cash is almost a must when you go to any market!

Great for food and groceries! Advice, go to Chinatown for souvenirs.
Love going to the terminal. Always fine what i need for good prices and the fresh meats n veggies are exacy what i need. Can be crowded on wknds but still worth it.

Amazing Amish dinner pancakes bigger than the plate omelets and the candy and cakes out of this world
Don't forget the ice cream just trust me

BRING YOUR WALLET!!!

Some of the BEST meat cutters and pastries, bread bakers, cheese shops and (OYSTERS!) fishmongers in Philadelphia.... mostly because they're almost ALL from Lancaster County.  This used to be exclusively Amish and Italian (I've been going there for 60 years!) and it HAS gone downhill in quality a little in that time, but the overall quality of available products is still far and away superior to just about any shops in the tri-state area, except for specialty food stores.  Not even Weaver's Way in Germantown can beat them, but:

It comes with a price.  A steep price.   You'll find lamb is 20-25%more expensive than imported New Zealand meat, but SO much nicer and fresher.   Fish are clear-eyed and firm, no slimy scales and can be filleted as you like, while you wait.  Pastries/baked goods are fresh, tender and delicious, albeit each carries a hidden five pound penalty... It's worth it!

DO visit if you have the chance, and bring a refrigerated or a "cold bag" with you for the meat and fish.

Your tummy will love you!
This place is a foodie's heaven. I just wish they were open later into the night.

Favorite lunch spot in Philadelphia.  They have over 100 food vendors so a plethora of options for everyone.  From cheese steaks, gourmet cookies, Amish stands, multiple coffee stands, etc the Reading Terminal Market has something for all hungry travelers.
Unusual place.  Anything you want to eat is here.  Parking is impossible. Have to take public transportation or an expensive cab.  It is very loud, but worthwhile visiting just to experience.

An absolute treasure!  It's iconic, it's full of great food, it's a tourist mecca - you simply have to go there if you visit Philly.  Though it's open on Sundays (when we went), about 25% of the stores are closed (in particular the Penn-Dutch stores, but some others as well).  An absolutely wonderful place to shop for fresh meat, fish, vegetables, and OMG the CHEESE stores are amazing. There is plenty of cooked food available to eat on the spot too - pork sandwiches, cheesesteaks, vegetarian Indian, Chinese, soul food, crepes, and a load more. Yummy Bassett's ice cream too! Parking downtown can be super expensive - about $14 for an hour in the lot across the street, so take public transport or shop around!
Awesome place!  I am from Boston and this is even better than Faneuil Hall!!!

I'm from Seattle with Pike Place Market and I must admit that Reading Terminal Market is better (in a big way for food selection and space overall). 

If you are visiting Philly, add this to your "MUST do list".

Try to beat the lunch rush, it is completely jam-packed during lunch hours and opens during business hours on weekdays.

Great place. All kinds of good food. Amish market and sea food, all kinds of other varieties. Downfall it's crowded and expensive. Amish make great food. Definitely worth the trip down there. I go once a month at least.

Big market place! It has many vendors from aged meat, seafood, fresh bread, coffee, asian fast food, sandwiches and much more.

It was really crowded and I'm talking about shoulder to shoulder crowded. If you decide to get something to eat the seats are very limited and there is definitely not enough seating. You might as well stand and eat.

Best Market in Town! Tons of places to explore and get local fresh produce, cheeses, meats, totally love the fresh sausage places.

Some places are expensive, so browse around and you can find good deals. The vendors are super friendly. Not the cleanest place in the common eating area, but it gets a ton of traffic. 

The Spices/Nut shop is the BOMB for loose by the pound spices. I will never pay full grovery store price for spices again. I got a HUGE handful of bay leaves for $1. Compare that to 10 leaves for $6.99 and it doesnt take a rocket scientist to figure out where to go in the future for spices! 

Must stops are the Beiber's donut place, and the Olive Oil/Balasmic Vinegar vendor. So many gems in there. 

Closes earlier -- not open late at night!

I was looking for somewhere to eat while running errands downtown.  I got a sandwich from Herschel's East Side deli.  I forgot how thick the sandwich was.  I ate it down with a fork to make it easier.

It was loud and touristy, but I was expecting that.  Whatever you order get it "to go" as finding a seat is not fast, even if you have someone scouting ahead for you.

As senior Philadelphian, I started going to the Reading Terminal when I was a kid, and that was 70+ years ago.  Nothing much has changed except the signs have gotten more modern and the food better and multicultural. You visitors to the Convention Center, forget the fancy resaurants.  Walk accross the street and roll up your sleeves.  A lot cheaper too!

I try to do most of my food shopping here. Every 2 weeks I go to John Yi for my fish. Although they are expensive, the fish here is incredibly fresh. I splurge and get the wild king salmon which is about 20.00 a pound. They give me a 2 pound slab and take off the skin and it looks so beautiful. I think it is sushi grade. When I am ready to cook it, I slice off what I need and just grill it. It is better then bad sex!! I get at least 5 meals out of it. The salmon is so fresh that I can keep it in the refrigerator for about a week.
Then it is off to Godshall's for my fresh chicken. I always get a chicken breast not split. When I bake this the chicken comes out juicy and fresh. It is good for 2 meals.
A great place!!

Great place for all types of food whether your looking for a light lunch or dinner.  It also has a great variety of desert foods such as Termini's Bakery.  The size of the aisles are lacking though and usually full of many ignorant tourists.
Wonderful food and selection, but if you are not one for crowds, I would avoid this place on the weekends.

So many options!!! From Molly Malloys to Dinic's roast pork, you can't go wrong at Reading Terminal.

For desert, try the Cheesecake at Termini's bakery.

I'm also a big fan of basset' ice cream.

I wish they were open later on weekdays, but I have no complaints about the eateries. A standard Philadelphia gem :-)

It's noisy, crowded, hard to park at, and worth enduring all the inconveniences as there is just so much awesome to choose from!  Sure, it's touristy, but unlike most things geared towards out of towers, this place is so unique and authentic, it's a must visit.  If you can't find something here to enjoy, you're likely unappeasable.
Always lively, people everywhere and being surrounded by a plethora of food options! Food heaven.

I love Reading Terminal Market. There are so many options to choose from. DiNics (roast pork) and Herschels (pastrami) are where I go to for good sandwiches. Iovine Brothers have great fruits and vegetables. I tried the duck lo-mein at Sang Kee Peking Duck and it was delicious. You can't go wrong with anything in the Terminal.

As a law, when someone in Philadelphia is introducing themselves they have to say, "hi. my name is ____ and I live in Philadelphia - home of Reading Terminal Market". 
That should be a law. I come to Philadelphia fairly often for work (I'm a pro baseball player) and why is it that I'm just learning about this place. It's dizzyingly large. 
Crêpes
Cheese
Salami
Lox on a bialy 
Creole
Chocolates
Espresso 
Coffee
Oysters 
Coffee
Espresso
Pastrami
Peking duck
Baked goods
Produce
Seafood

God bless you.

The Reading Terminal Market is one of Philadelphia's gems. If you're indecisive (like me) it can be both a dream come true and a nightmare. I found myself in Philly today and thought I stop by to brainstorm on dinner. I found some good cuts of meats, walked around and came up with some side items to go with the entree. There are so many choices that it took me entirely too long to decide but having too many options is hardly a problem (or it is a quintessential first world problem). I grabbed some coffee and lunch while I was there, browsed around a bit more and left satisfied. You can count on finding high quality goods here with prices that rival any supermarket and restaurant, bakery, etc. 

When I left this morning I thought I don't take advantage of the fact that this amazing place is so close to me often enough. It was then that I made a promise to myself to come back soon (and often).

Holy moly. A parthenon of food. So many choices, whether you're going there to eat already prepared food, or buying for cooking later, this place has everything. Docked it one star down because the crowds. When it gets crowded, it can be overwhelming. Overall, worth it though.

A Philadelphia institution essential to visit for anyone who enjoys food! Not much you can't find under this roof. An ideal, budget friendly place to bring a family with various tastes or levels of adventurous eating. Avoid on Saturdays and during big conventions if you don't enjoy a bit of elbows and body checking through the aisles as part of your shopping experience. There are some less worth it spots (all "American" style diner, cheesesteaks, the bad choices are, I think, obvious to to pick out) but they are far, far outweighed by the Philly roast pork, po boys, Pakistani kebobs,  pastrami, and middle eastern pastries that abound. Not to mention the cheese counters of various specialities, produce and juice options galore.
Golden Bowl  Fabulous The Absolute Best  Do Not Miss  friendly owners absolutely incredible Asian food. You will go back again & again!!!! Great Find !

Whatever you're in the mood for, from Chinese to a simple smoothie or nice breakfast, this place has it all! I'm a huge fan or Pearl's and Down Home Diner for a morning pick me up! The bacon stuffed french toast at Pearl's is to die for, be prepared to roll out of that place not walk.
Go there hungry with patience. Everyone enjoying the onolicious food there

This place has everything you craving from, roast port sandwiches, cheesesteaks, donuts, jerky, candy, Chinese, Thai, beers, pastries, cookies, spices, fresh fish, pastrami, corn beef, fresh oysters, beers, and whatever else. If you can't find something to eat here then you don't belong! I traveled all the way from Maui, HI for Tommy Dinics roast pork sandwich and believe me, that shit was the f'n bomb man, if I lived here I would be a 300 pound happiest fatass alive.

Love Reading Terminal! A must visit when in Philly!! I recommend going early.It gets very crowded which can be frustrating, but still worth the visit.Nothing better then a pastrami sandwich at 10:00am, Clearly, Philadelphia is the absolute best city for delicious sandwiches and Reading Terminal is one stop shopping. The best Pastrami sandwich in the world at Hershels East Side Deli which beats anything in NYC. A pork sandwich with sharp provolone and greens at da nics, mouth watering. .We always get one sandwich from each place so we can sample and share.
Besides sandwiches there are tons of other restaurants, shops etc....

The only reason I didn't give this 5 stars is because it does get very crowded but crowds aside, this is 6 star!!

One of a kind market with anything you could possibly want from Amish food, cheesesteaks, Roast pork from Dinics or salad from Ms. Tootsie's. Also I don't know the name of the Amish place but they sell great beef sticks. The place to go if no one knows what they want to eAt. Also Termini Bros Bakery is the best- separate review for them

Just expect huge crowds of people! Lots of choices for food, I certainly have my favorites but I won't list them since it is really dependent on what you want to eat.  When I used to live down in Philly (and still when I am visiting on an all day trip) I tend to stop into the market to pick up some goodies to take home.  

Best time to go is first thing before the lunch crowd, or after 3pm.

Please forgive me I am a Philadelphian not overly fond of the Reading Terminal Market. We stopped there last week to have a quick bite and maybe it's the sound of the people, or crowds whatever but my turkey sandwhich wasnt worth the headache or price...
The bathrooms are clean..good thing

OMG, if you have food on your mind, this is the place to go.  You can find ANYTING here and I mean ANYTHING.  The variety is overwhelming and it seems to never end....you can eat your way in and out,.  Fresh produce, jerky any kind, fish, meats, cheese, gourmet selections, breakfast, lunch, dinner, cheesesteaks, cookies, doughnuts, drinks both non alcohol and alcohol, you name it, I am sure you can find it here.

This is an amazing place to experience if visiting, we had the best breakfast in Philly here and a great cheesesteak as well.  The cheese selection we found was out of this world from fresh cow, to sheep to goat and the staff will give you samples to help you decide.  

I did not find anyone here who was not warm and friendly from workers to shoppers, all we very cool.  If we had more time or if we make it back to Philly in the future, this will definitely be a stop on our list to try some of the amazing items we saw but did not try this trip.

We did not find a lot of organic items especially in the produce stand but it all looked really good.  If you are in Philly and have the time, you have to put this on your list of places to experience at least once.
This place is bomb. I got the donuts from the Amish stand in the one corner and WHOA. Real tasty.

The best place for someone who's indecisive... or just like to eat!  One of the oldest markets in the US, it's been around since 1892.  We were there on a Saturday morning around 10:30am and it wasn't too packed.  We got a brisket sandwich from Dinic's (pretty good), duck wonton soup from Sang Kee, fried mac n cheese ball from Beck's Cajun Cafe and butter cake & whoopie pies from The Flying Monkey bakery.  The sweets at the Flying Monkey are amazing! The butter cake has a really interesting crunch gooey texture.  My husband loved the whoopie pie.  

Great spot to grab a bite!

God, this place is overwhelming. Also, probably don't come here hungover, it's going to REALLY overwhelm you. Most places take only cash. They literally have EVERYTHING here but it's just too much. Also, why is it only indoors? Let's take this party outside. After walking around for 15 minutes unclear what to do, I finally just closed my eyes and picked a Rueben place. Sloppy Rueben with a side of potato salad. My bf closed his eyes and picked a cheesesteak place. Subpar cheesesteak with a bag of chips. It is what it is. Don't come here with expectations. Don't come here trying to find a SPECIFIC place either. People are everywhere, bumping into you, stepping on the back of your feet, crowding you. Just close your eyes, pick a place, and get the hell out of there.
Great destination for locals for fresh and artisan foods. CAn be a little crazy on weekends, so try to go during the week.

Who doesn't love reading terminal? They have everything you could possibly want, and since extending their hours a couple years ago, it's made it easier to get these things. 
I regularly go there for produce, seafood and local raw milk.
It's a must see for visitors so bring all of your guests! 
Absolutely go there for lunch some time, but try to go on an off hour, not right at noon, because it gets super busy.
The Dutch eating place is the best for breakfast and although they are usually pretty busy, they keep things moving.
LOVE this place! They have so many great food spots that it will satisfy everyone! If you're visiting Philly it's a must.

Definitely worth checking out. This market has a wide variety of things from food, desserts to books. My go-to places are dinics, bassetts ice cream and beilers bakery and donuts. I recommend spending at least 2 hours just getting lost in here to see what Reading terminal market has to offer!

Can't really review single store front. I have been to most over past four years and I would say biggest suggestion is just go do a walk around and then let ur belly and nose decide for you. Everything is great and you will find something! Enjoy a true philly gem!

Wonderful selection of culinary delights, sweets and treats from from favorite cupcakes at the Flying Monkey to the delicious Amish chicken wings at Dienner's.  Peruse used books, have a glass of wine, buy kitchen gadgets or just sit and people watch - the Reading Terminal is a cool place to be in the midst of Center City.
Pretty overrated.  If you like sweets, you'll be in heaven.  It's crowded & uncomfortable seating.

My first time in Philly meant that I had to make a trip to the famous Reading Terminal market.. And I was not disappointed. In fact I loved the vibe of this place so much that I came here twice on my 2 day weekend trip.

We tried the cheesesteak at Spataro's which was not as flavorful and greesy as I had hoped for a cheesesteak to be (hence a star less). The coffee from Old City Coffee was a great change from my usual go-to, with a nice full bodied medium roast coffee. I loved it's old school vibe and servers making sure to give you the coffee exactly how you want it. 

On my second time here I stopped at the Pearls Oyster Bar right at the entrance for a hearty diner-style fare. My husband got the eggs Benedict which he really enjoyed and I got the berry compote french toast which was perfectly sweet and just what I needed. And they have unlimited coffee refills!! *gasp* 
We got a chocolate milkshake from L.D. Bassetts which was really nice but a little too rich for me. Unfortunately, after all the food and the I couldn't  try their ice cream for which it is famous. Until next time! 
I walked around the market and wished that my stomach and appetite were large enough so I could try everything here (which is a HUGE selection of various cuisines) since everything looked and smelled de-lish. Next time I am coming back to try the dutch breakfast place and get an assortment or their local cheeses and groceries.

Donuts! Amish pulled pork!! Sausage stuffed pretzels!!! chocolate chip cookies dipped in freaking chocolate!!! Fresh fricking roasted coffee!!!! Mutha freaking overstuffed pastrami sanwiches!!!!! Brick freakin oven freakin pizza!!!!
Warning!!  It is always packed,  I'm a local Philadelphian and this is still one of my favorite places. Eclectic, with a wide variety of shops.

Where to start...head over to Down Home Diner for breakfast and a Banana-Pineapple-Orange smoothie at Kamal's and grab a box of donuts at Beilers.  Run around the block at least 10x to shed the calories.  Head back in for lunch - DiNic's for pulled pork or Spataro for a cheesesteak and fries, 12 St Cantina for loaded nachos, pearl's oyster bar for some shellfish and osyters ...grab a cannoli from Termini's and a bag of cookies at Famous 4th Street.. leave and go home and take a nap...and then go out and buy bigger clothes to fit in...worth it.
Being from Boston this indoor market is nothing new. I have been to a few in my life but this was the best. Massive with the best shops I have ever seen. The smell of food will make you very hungry.
I can always find anything from fresh meat to fresh produce here. Great meals at the various food vendors. Please check out Blue Mountain Winery. Awesome vino!
Excellent choices available of all types of foods!! Problem is that it's very crowded and not enough seating
This is an absolute must for visitors and Indigenous folks. Lots of wonderful food, Wonderful Coffee, wonderful produce, beautiful women , and a mixture of multiple cultures .
There is a variety of deliciousness available in different price ranges. I love the Amish bread & cinnamon rolls. It's also very close to the Masonic Temple which is a must for anyone visiting.
Philly at its finest. If you visit, you can't leave without a stop here for a cheese steak at whatever stall you end up choosing. You really can't miss.
A Philly landmark. RIDICULOUSLY AMAZING! What's not to like. You can find anything & everything here.

Love this market. I've been to the market in DC and another in Boston but I think Philly has the best variety and down home flava.

The Amish walking around doing their thing is a riot to watch. You just have to wonder what these people are really like.

Secret: Skip the uber-trendy and annoying brunch spots all around philly and go this market. In the back corner is a great Amish diner that has the best hot cakes around! Let me know if you agree!!

First time there last week.  Way too crowded and loud.  Every single person was so nice except for the cook at Spataros.  He was so rude, barking at everybody. He screamed at me for asking if the cheese I ordered was on the sandwich, standing there in his stained undershirt. YUCK.. Will NEVER go to this establishment again. The other servers were nice and helpful.  The chocolates were out of control delish! Parking was a pain. There was some other stands that I would have liked to have sampled and some of the produce and other stuffs looked great but it was a bit much to deal with.

I love this place .The food choices are outstanding .Start with the fresh produces and work your way around the baked goods, chicken,chocolates,coffee,prezels Chinese food ,Southern cooking ,juice bar,fresh turkeys,beer and cocktails .You want a decent fair priced meal with food on your plate you need to come here.OBTW if you don't like noises and crowds please avoid this place, But the noise and the crowds  is also part of the charm

Love this place!  I always have an idea of what I might eat before I go--turkey platter?  crepes?  If I don't have some idea before I go, I walk around hungry but undecided for a good hour!  For anyone visiting Philly, the Reading Terminal Market is a must see!   And go hungry--you will be glad you did!  My favorites stops are the fresh turkey dinner with mashed potatoes and gravy, or the true French crepes, sweet or savory.  I'm not stuck in a rut, I just can't resist these two spots!

I loved this place bc I love variety and food. I ate from DiNic's [Italian pulled pork sandwich - I think it was $9/11?] and Bassetts Ice Cream [$5 for 2 scoops of featured ice cream in a cup] -- I recommend!

There were stores for food, kitchen tools, soap, tea, books, flowers, etc. So many things to see and feel and smell.

Everything you need is right here.  The Amish and other locals bring their best here, so lots of fresh meat, fish, seafood, vegetables plus lots of great little places to eat.  Had the best turkey sandwich of my life here.  Plus there's pretzels and donuts and ice cream and Cajun and roast beef and wines and chocolates.  This place is heaven on earth, I just wish I lived closer.

This is my second visit to this great city and I can't believe I missed the Reading Terminal Market on my first visit. This is a must visit - right after the liberty bell.  OK - for get the bell come here first.  This place is crammed with food venders serving some of the best food ever. I stopped at Hershel's East Side for a pastrami Rubin  -  there must have been a pound of meat on this baby.  So good, I should have a stopped but I didn't.  Next stop will be Di Niks for the Italian pork sandwich.  I'll be back for that.  My wife said and I quote "we should move here".  Are you  kidding me, I'm a New Yorker by birth ... That would be sacrilege ... But I'll be back for the food.
Reading Terminal market is the best place in Philly to buy produce. Their prices are a little high, but you can find ANYTHING you can think of there.Would have given 5 stars if not for the prices

This place has ranked high on my East Coast foodie bucket list. I wish I could have had time to try every vendor in there, but I was only in town for a short weekend, and you can only eat so much in the span of 48 hrs. 

We arrived at about 10:30 on a Sunday. Traffic wasn't bad at all and it was pretty easy to locate the parking lot, directly across from the market. Bring your ticket with you for validation from a market vendor. Parking is normally $29 for 2 hours, but if you spend $10, you can have your parking validated and it will only be $4 for 2 hours. Very reasonable.

I forgot the Amish area of the market was closed on Sunday's, they are only open Tuesday - Saturday. Shame we missed those shops, I hear they have some very yummy stuff. Oh well.

We made a couple rounds through the market, trying to decided what we wanted.

We first got a cheesesteak with whiz from Spataros. Not bad but not my favorite cheesesteak in the city. Pass.

We wanted to try Wursthaus Schmitz but they weren't open quite yet.

We got two cannolis from Termini Bros, very yummy!

And then tried the Ave. D from Milkcraft Grilled cheese. You can add bacon, tomatoes or have the sandwich grilled in duck fat. We chose the last option. It was dripping in grease, so I don't know if I would have gone with the duck fat, but it was still so decadent and amazing. Honestly I would go back for Milkcraft alone. Amazing stuff. 

I was worried we were going over our two hour parking window, but we got back to hour car with 30 mins to spare. 

Very cool place, highly recommend coming here. Just wish I had had more time to try everything!
so much different food to try, unfortunately many of the places are closed in Sunday, will have to come back again!
Love this place.  If you can't find it here, you won't find it anywhere.  So many delicious options, it's nearly impossible to decide where to start.  Highly recommended.

This place is awesome. It is crowded however with a lot of people, but if you are a foodie then this is the place to go. They have almost every kind of food possible to man kind except for Japanese and Korean.  You go here to also get ice cream, honey some fresh meat like fish and meat.  They gave awesome donuts as well. This place has hard places to get seating as well. If you are lucky there are some restaurants that have seating.  Overall a great place to go.

A great local market with tons of options across the board. I wondered upon DiNic's and am glad I did! I thought it was a little pricey, but that's probably just my mentality coming from the Midwest to the East Coast. The roast pork sandwich with cheese had great flavor, but was super sloppy and rendered the 2 small napkins they gave me useless. I also tried out the wings and mac and cheese from Keven Parker's Soul Food stand. Again-- solid choice! The wings were great, the mac was fair. I've definitely had better. I was surprised to learn after visiting that these two stands are two of the highest-rated there. I was impressed by both but would love to try some other places out next time.

This place really reminds me of Pike Place Market in Seattle & Essex/Chelsea Market in NYC. For anyone visiting Philly, this is a must visit!

To me, the reading terminal market was food heaven. There was so many food stalls. With too much choices, time constraint, and limited stomach space, I only ended up eating from 2 stalls: 1) Wursthaus Schmitz (german foods), and 2) Beiler's Bakery.

For anyone that likes a delicious bratwurst & schnitzel sandwich, and potato pancakes - Wursthaus Schmitz is a must visit. Super delicious! The donuts from Beiler's Bakery was another notable mention, as it was delicious as well. 

Street parking is difficult around this area. However, there are 2 parking lots near the market, and it is $4 for 2 hours. After 2 hours, it is $10. After 2 hours there is another charge (forgot what it is). Just make sure to have your card stamped by a food stall to get this parking discount, and remember you need to spend at least $10 to get this stamp.

There are many tables on the back area of the market, where you can sit and eat there.
Iconic Philadelphia food landmark. Something for everyone. Sang Kee Peking Duck is a personal favorite. Make sure to try the steamed dumplings.

THIS PLACE IS AWESOME!

I spent over 2 hours just walking around looking at everything for the first time. I couldn't decide what to do or buy or eat, but I wanted ALL THE THINGS. The ambiance is fantastic here.

The people cooking, serving, and preparing dishes all make each of their offerings look delicious. The vendors each do their utmost to present the best goods, most quality selections, and excellent standards to their very popular market.

I was there not only during the week, but at an off-peak time during a regular work day and the place was still packed. They offer so much: cheesesteaks (obviously), ice-cream, Asian food, Greek food, Indian food, a vegetable market, a bar (or two), a florist, breakfast, lunch, and dinner options, as well as candy, snacks, goodies, tasty treats of all kinds, and even butchers!

If you're new to Philly or plan to travel here, just go on and save at least 1/2 a day on your trip to check out Reading Terminal Market. Totally worth every second there.

I just can't say enough about how much I loved this market. My husband and I visited Philadelphia for a week in May and stayed about a block from Reading Terminal. This made it easy for us to visit during the week days, when the market is much less crowded. I think we had some sort of food from nearly every stall. 

Some of the best food in Philadelphia (and probably the country) lurks behind the colorful and brightly lit counters that line the aisles of the market. Not only is the food incredible, but every time we went there (every day, sometimes twice a day), I was pleasantly surprised by the kindness and pride that the vendors exuded. You can tell the people here take their food seriously. This place was my spirit animal, if locations can be spirit animals.

Best things we ate while there: the salted caramel doughnut from Beiler's; the corned beef rueben from Hershel's Deli; ANY grilled cheese from MeltKraft (we tried three); cannoli from Termini Bros; roast pork w/broccoli rabe from Tony DiNic's; gator gumbo from Beck's Cajun Cafe; shrimp & grits Benedict from Pearl's Oyster Bar. Plus, you can grab an adult beverage from Molly Malloy's and walk around the market with it - because what doesn't taste even better after a few cold ones?
Fresh fish, fresh veg, ... you'll make a great meal based on what you buy here... except... you'll be full cause you'll also stop for lunch and eat too much great already cooked food.... ahh well.

Always super busy on the weekends! I would recommend getting there as soon as they open. Otherwise the options are out of this world. My favorite is Dinic's - They have some of the best slow roasted pork. I always go with the sharp provo and broccoli rabe. Stop by and check it out if you are ever in Philly. Lot to choose from!
Definite "must-do" in philly.  I love it and go back all the time.  There are so many things.  Saturdays are better than Sundays.

人山人海，包括中国炒面在内的世界各地美食汇总在一起。周末的时候一家老小都会来此饕餮聚餐，实在是瘦身族人伤心地。
可惜吃饱了墨西哥玉米饼过来的...从独立宫步行也就五分钟到了这里...尽量选择非餐点过来，否则座位实在难找咯

Food lovers paradise.  We ate at probably 10 stands and everything was great.  You can't miss the caramel pecan cookies and the amish doughnuts in the morning.  Don't come here if you're on a diet, but if you do, the grocery store area has some delicious pressed juices.  All of the vendors seem to love being here, and that fun vibe bounces onto the customers.
Very eclectic market, arrive early for best selection and to avoid the crowds.
As far as touristy things go, eh it's okay. Great place to wander in and out of if you are close. VERY crowded most of the time, but many many options to choose from.
Place has everything you want. Got lunch from a different place everyday for five days. I'd come back to the city just to revisit this place.

All State Van LInes moved us from Pennsylvania to Massachusetts.  It went very well, our belongings were delivered in good condition within the guaranteed time frame.  I will use them if I ever move again. They contract out the jobs to other companies and contractors.

In this case the hype is all true.
This market is as indescribable as it is awesome. Wifey and I spent only 3 hours eating and exploring but I think several all day visits are required to do justice to the Market. If you hate crowds you had better go elsewhere. But if you love fresh meat/seafood/candy/beer/vegetables/ice cream/cookies, etc. all served by friendly, helpful folks of all backgrounds and ethnic persuasions, you will be pleasantly overwhelmed. Wifey and I can't wait to go back. Only this time we won't eat for two days in advance but I fear we still won't have enough room for all we want to consume!

Everything you can possibly want is here.  Amish food awaits you.  Great food and friendly service and staff. One can easily spend breakfast, lunch, dinner and desert at this one location.  Plus happy hour.
Not only is it a classic tourist destination,  but the food is great!  Check out the Cajun place.

Oh my gosh, so many good things to say about Reading Terminal Market.  Their variety of food is top notch and you always can find something new when you are there!  We are obsessed with 4th Street cookies.  They also do private events at this place, which I had no idea.  Would be really cool for a wedding - wish we had known about it!

The choices are endless. Every time I go inside I am overwhelmed about where to look and what to eat. My favorite choice is Beck's Cajun Cafe. I love their cajun chicken poboy and cajun fries. I also love Bassett's Ice Cream. They have so many delicious flavors, it's the best way to end a trip to Reading Terminal Market.

Very hectic and busy but usually an overall good experience. This is another "tourisy" thing to do in Philadelphia. Many popular businesses displaying their goods. It is a pretty big market so allocate an hour or more to walk around and have a few tastes.

Absolutely loved this market! Everything from cajun food, to bagels, ice cream, fresh produce and retail shops. All of the stand employees were extremely friendly and helpful. This place makes me wish I lived in Philly :)

This place is great. Its a strictly in door market that houses a LOT of restaurants and small shops a little bit of everything is available to you including some of the absolute best in Philadelphia like Carmens and Tommy Dinics.

This place is great. There is something for everyone here. We were able to get a taste of Philly here for lunch and dessert. Oh, and, maybe we were sheltered by where we were staying (Home 2 Suites) across the street and waking between our hotel, downtown and Independence Mall, and South street for cheesesteaks but the people of Philly are great. Yeah it's like other urban areas but everyone has been friendly and helpful. One On vacation just has to put things in perspective. Don't be a hindrance to those on their way to work. We are on vacation and they are not in a rush so we don't get in the way. I like the city of Brotherly Love and this their treasure the Market is awesome. It is a must visit at least to see where National Treasure was filmed.

For fellow New Yorkers visiting Philadelphia, this is your Chelsea Market meets ubiquitous farmers market.  Inside this huge expanse, you'll find aisles and aisles of prepared foods/meals mixed in with local produce, pastries, meats, and seafood you can bring back and prep yourself.  Prices are extremely fair and you'd be hard-pressed to walk through without finding something to buy and/or eat while you're here!

This is the real thing! Not a tourist place like Faneuil Hall in Boston with its national chain stores like Sunglass hut, but a larger, 100% local, fantastic food experience in the Reading Train Shed (think the original Monopoly game).  REAL PHILADELPHIANS use this place, too. It's not just for tourists. And, its right next to a fantastic Chinatown.

Of course, tourists should also cross over to the west side of Center City, walk around Rittenhouse and Fitler Square, and along the Schuylkill River, but this is still a great place.
I like just walking around there.  Great way to spend time between downtown appointments or events
Big city market with lots of shopping and food. Great place to grab lunch away from the middle school tour groups. Was a perfect stop on our Philly trip for cheesesteaks.

I love everything about this place except the prices and business hours. go alone or meet up with friends, either way you'll find something delicious to eat or something interesting to see. one of Philadelphia's great jewels!
So many options! I love this place. Anything from fresh produce to a shoe shine. The eateries are wonderful, especially Herschel's deli

This is a "do not miss" attraction in Philadelphia. Particularly if you are in the Convention Center as you are right next to it. So many wonderful cuisines, fresh produce/meats, kitchen specialty items, and unusal spices all local. The Amish are there through Saturday, not on Sunday. Their baked goods are too die for. I have gotten hard to find spices from The Head Nut, special cuts of meat from the butchers, fresh flowers and the best chocolate chip cookies you can find. Great prices too. I live close so I am able to shop periodically, lucky me!

If you have never been here then you have to visit. Whether you live in Philadelphia or are visiting, it is a one of a kind experience. There is such a variety of food that you will never be dissapointed. There are even gift shops and a used book store! It is very diverse and all inclusive. Even if you are a little claustrophobic and don't like busy places crammed with people, you should fight through it and get out of your comfort zone and go try it!

5Star because the place is huge so you can find something you're down for that's really good, no sweat. That being said, outside of some of the crowd favorites that are basic and satisfying, some restaurants specifically are better or worse than others objectively. By grouping Reading Terminal Market as just the market instead of allowing each restaurant to be represented and in turn individually rated and reviewed by the community.

Reading Terminal Market is a wonderful place both for the transport element and the massively diverse cultural food market filled with wondrous smells. The floors stay pretty clean, bathrooms are a toss up but what can you get its Philly. Place stays well protected and cops are abundant; often you'll find a group of blue vested men just sitting at a table enjoying their gyros and pork ribs armed to the teeth and still laid back. At the same time, police will always be on patrol for any dangerous activity or suspicious individuals. 

I enjoy the place, what can I say.
Loved it here. Wish my tummy had more space to to more food and drinks. Would definitely come back and recommend to others visiting the area

Choices.  Thousands of choices to delight any foodie.  We love shopping here and eating here.  Parking in the garage across the street is the way to go.  Get your parking ticket validated and it's only $4.00.  The Mennonite/Amish places have different hours than the rest of the RTM, so check before you rush down to get a Beiler's doughnut on a Monday.  This is one of my favorite places in the city and it's constantly evolving and changing for the better.

I love Reading Terminal Market!  You can find a little of everything here!  The food is delicious and you can get all kinds of yummy eats there.  They even have a couple of awesome fruit stands where you can get really inexpensive fruit.  I  love this place! I would have given a 5 star but it gets crazy packed and that is a con for me.
Unique food market.  Packed with all different types of eats!  Great variety and good quality.  The area was a little congested and it could have been a little cleaner.  Worth visiting!

Great place for a fresh food market, homemade sweets, and a Philly cheesesteak. Head to the middle and you have found the best cheesesteak ever. It was so good we went back the next day. Forget about going to the tourist places to try one. 

Walking distance to several hotels. Go early as it tends to shutdown earlier than we were ready to be done for the night.
Was hoping to hit up Beilars but the line was really long in the early AM. Went to this diner ouster bar area for some breakfast. Very cool space and lots of diverse places to eat, drink and shop in.

This place, on the first floor of the Reading Train Shed (a National Historic Landmark), is the largest tourist attraction in the city--beats the Liberty Bell. But it has fresh food merchants as well as a diner, and take out counters of almost any type of food. Cheesesteaks? got it!  Pennsylvania Dutch food? you bet! I love Reading Terminal Market for what it is, the place that sees everyone;  those that use food stamps (the highest number in the state); City Hall workers; convention goers, and residents hungry for lunch or dinner.
So many varieties of food from all over the world!! All of them made within a homemade touch and simply amazing! A tour of the world's finest cuisines without leaving center city!

I love coming to the reading terminal. It's like a fat boy dream. You have all types of food and desserts. When I get there I usually go for Dini's roast pork it's so good. Also melt Kraft is pretty good.they have Beilers donuts omg it's go good I bought a dozen one time and thought I was going to share with co- workers but ended up eating the whole thing. They also have termini and Basset ice cream there. I swear if I worked around there I would probably be 1000 pound and have a show on TLC.

It's my favorite place to eat in Philadelphia. Tootsies kale salad is so good. Bassetts Ice Cream is so good. Bielers Donuts, so good. Every food stall is so good. Get the roasted chicken from one of the Amish stalls. Ok Produce has good deals on ripe, ready to eat/cook fruits and veggies. Iovine Brothers is fresher and has more selection. I absolute adore Reading Terminal Market!!

Eh. I feel Andrew Zimmern betrayed me. As much work as it took me to get here, I was expecting more. I like the set up and the variety of eateries but it was quite crowded. I know it was a weekend but I was hoping everyone would be at the beach. The highlights of this trip was the validated parking and Mariah Carey playing on the tv at Kevin Parker's Soul Food stand. I may give it another try on a weekday if I am in the area but driving 1 1/2 is too much for me.
Best place for food in Philly, anything and everything.

The only thing that keeps this from a 5 star rating is the fact that it closes by 6PM. Great food, wonderful variety. Especially like the pretzels from the Amish stand, but there's load  of good stuff. It gets very crowded, and finding a place to sit can be a challenge, but still a favorite place in Center City.

This place is awesome in that there are so many places and spots to eat. 
However, the problem is that it's so packed that there is little seating areas to actually relax and dine. Also, feels a bit hectic inside. The tables also got a little gross because of all the other diners and not enough people cleaning or wiping them down. Each time, I ended up just eating at the restaurants inside because I didn't want to fight for food or wait on long lines at the different stalls.

Most incredible open market I never seen. Every type of food you can possibly imagine they have. If you're ever in downtown Philadelphia it's definitely one you need to put on the bucket list of things to do.
Excellent market and restaurants. It can be a bit crowded during lunch time, but otherwise has reasonable crowds.

Amazing selection of meat, fish, cheese, honey, and crafts. I'd suggest going on weekdays instead of weekends due to high foot traffic. Also, try going earlier rather than later for the freshest foods and less crowds.

This really deserves high praise.  I would not normally say this but anything below 3 stars is insulting.  I loved Philadelphia, I prefer it to NYC, and it's up there w Chicago.  This market is one of those places that make Philly truly great.  You want the best baked goods, fish, coffee, meat, lunch, dinner, etc, etc. this is the place.  We went each day and it was great, a must visit.
I looove the Terminal!!! I buy my lunch meats, seafood, poultry and variety of meats from the Amish people. I'm always there, I'll never shop no other place for my meats

Hi Reading Terminal Market, this place is awesome and I would say this is Philly's food heaven!  Parking may be an issue if you come here during peak eating hours, but you may be lucky with some street parking, or just suck it up and park at a deck!

Anyways, this market does have some fresh food stands, similar to a farmer's market style if you have some grocery shopping to do, but I feel the best part of this place are the massive amount of food stands inside.  Beware if you come here on an empty stomach, you will want to try so many things that I am sure you will get full quick... and buy too much!

Over the years Reading Terminal Market has allowed people to try many various types of food.  Whether you are looking for a good sandwich, cheesesteak, Asian food, soul food, pastries, ice cream, donuts... it is all here!
