NOTE: The general hours of Reading Terminal do not apply to ALL the food stands.  Some close earlier on specific days and a few (the Amish establishments) are not even open are Sundays.  Take a look at the operating hours of specific food stands you want to check out before you come here or else you may be disappointed that it is closed!

Some of my favorite stands:

Bassetts Ice Cream - Ice Cream!
Beck's Cajun Cafe - Gumbo!
Beiler's Bakery - Doughnuts!
Carmen's Famous - Cheesesteaks!
Flying Monkey Bakery - Whoopie Pies!
Hershel's - Brisket, Corned Beef, and/or Pastrami Sandwich! 
Meltkraft - Grilled Cheese Sandwich!
Sang Kee Peking Duck - Duck noodle soup!
Tommy DiNiC's - Roast Pork Sandwich!

There are still other stands I have yet to try.  So yes, I HAVE to come back again!  It is just so hard to try new things when many of these dishes are already very satisfying :)
Like you died and went to food heaven. Go! This is Philadelphia all the way. The people watching the variety it is a must.
Never disappoints...delicious baked goods, oysters, dinics, and bassetti's ice cream.  We always find something special to take home and the whole family loves it.

Like a going on a field trip! So many wonderful sights and smells. Food of all kinds to try out. Plenty of places to sit down to eat. 
Sandwiches....home made pastry....home made soft pretzels.....chocolates in all shapes and sizes.! ....the biggest fish I have ever seen for sale.

A great adventure and place to enjoy lunch, dinner or snack!

Our driver dropped us off here after we checked into our hotel. After grabbing some cheesesteaks we strolled around this market.

There are so many great eating establishments for every type of craving. There's even a nice craft beer bar that serves pretty good beers.

Recommend visiting this place.

Literally there is no way someone can walk out of here upset. Young and old there is something for everyone. An absolute philly classic. My favorites are 4th street cookies, Beilers, Dinic's, and the roasted turkey place (can't miss it). Of course Bassets and Termini's are classics and you can't go wrong with anything Amish. As a local for Fred veggies and meats or as a tourists to visit a philly classic, it's a must do.

Always wanted to get in here. Wasn't sure what to expect. Inside are a bunch of little stores with food, produce, and other little shops. Got a cheesesteak at one of the places and it was terrific. Great place for lunch and a cool place to stop into.

How can anyone give this place less than 5 stars.  You can buy some vegetables, have a beer, pick up spice to make dinner,grab some candy, and get some take out.  This place is always a stop you need to make if you are visiting Philadelphia.

If you are looking to buy a MINI, whether you live in the Washington D.C. area or not, I recommend that you contact BLAKE DACOSTA of Passport MINI in Alexandria, VA.  I live in Delaware but I worked with Blake online to find the perfect car as a birthday present for my wife.  Blake was responsive, informative, courteous and always helpful.  When it came time to pick up the MINI, Blake had all of the paperwork ready, provided me with some additional advice and made the entire process smooth and transparent.  If you want to buy a MINI from an honest and knowledgeable sales associate, in my opinion, you won't find a better choice than BLAKE DACOSTA.

How could anyone not love this place!  It is a food heaven filled with anything your heart could desire.  I'm pretty sure I stopped by twice a day each time in Philly since it was conveniently located right across from my hotel.  There are vendors offering a wide variety of foods such as oysters, doughnuts, duck, pork and steak sandwiches, candies, produce, really anything and it was all amazing.  I really could spend all of my time and money and time in here and not care one single bit!  I only wish it was open late at night to satisfy my post bar hunger!

So So.

This is a really big food court.   If you enjoy exploring a food court with better than average offerings this is it.  My style for the same price is a restaurant to be taken care of.   There are some places in here that need some help with quality.   Hershel's East was good.  The Dutch place needed improvement.  

For me, overall a waste of time and energy when there are better places around for a nice meal at the same price.

I love Reading Terminal Market! So much variety and a lot of tasty options. From Dinic's cheesesteaks to Bassett's ice cream( get the frequent licker card, you get a free one after 10 buys) , the market is magical. There are so many places I have yet to try but all in all, bring an empty stomach and your wallet!

Dinic's for the pork & broccoli rabe sandwich 
Oyster Bay breakfast of chicken & waffles eggs Benedict- YUM!! Also the shrimp & grits my boyfriend loved!
All the produce is super fresh
Love beef jerky? 5 cases of it!

Great place to pick up fresh fish and meat. If I lived in Philadelphia, I'd be here weekly!
It's an awesome place to visit. Great food, cheese, olive oil and a variety of items. Only problem is parking.

You can be a tourist in your own city if you stop by RTM. What a fun place to go with your family, friends, or a cute city date!! There are so many fun and unique vendors to check out. For lunch, I love the corned beef special at the Hatville Deli. I get that with some cold apple cider. It's one of my favorite sandwiches. It has cole slaw, russian dressing, and a nice portion of corned beef  on rye (you can also get it with pastrami). 

They have chocolates, wine, kitchen stuff, farmer's and locally farmed foods. Check out the fair food farmstand vendor! They have lots of cool veggies and cheeses. 

There is a vendor that sells bee products-honey, candles made from bees wax, and lip balms. The Tubby Olive is a fun place to go and try different olive oils and vinegars on tap. It's pricey but you don't have to buy anything to get some samples :)

You can't live in Philly and not have been to this place. It has something for everyone. Saturday is the worst day to go because it gets super crowded. Once, I got out of jury duty early on a weekday and it was ghost town. The court also gave me some vouchers and coupons to use at RTM since it was only a block away. 

This establishment is right by Chinatown. I recommend taking a day to explore the area, there's that much to see!

Love it so much - great for every day, great to take guests for a BIG slice of Philly culture, and one of the only places I can reliably find (fresh when in season) Halibut - being from So. California, this is a favorite fish. I'm not a fan and have not adopted the E. Coast Talapia - yuck! Anyway, Reading Market has been and continues to be a favorite of locals and tourists alike for a reason - because its awesome.

This is a must visit in Philly -for the sheer versatility of it. Anything and everything you want is here. This is similar to Quincy Market in Boston. Some recommendations are oysters, Rueben (from Hershel's East Side), Gator Gumbo, and fried mac n' cheese (From Beck's Cajun Cafe).

Hard to find seating.

No Big surprise here. I love it as much as others. I strolled in after having lunch in Chinatown. That didn't stop me from eating so much more here. I had the roast pork sandwhich from dinics with sharp provolone. It's was good. A little dry for my taste but it was good. I think I'm going back to try the pulled pork tomorrow. I then had bassets vanilla ice cream. The best vanilla I have ever had. I then had an all beef pretzel wrapped dog and took a salted pretzel to go. Delicious. I bough a couple of gifts at the Pennsylvania General Store. Decent prices and the chocolate converted prezels will be a pretty neat gift for family. 

I went on a Friday afternoon. Crowded but moving. Vendors are fast. People are nice. A lot to see. Give yourself time to walk through the entire place. This can definitely be a stop for breakfast, lunch and snacking.

I love Reading Terminal Market.  There are always numerous vendors each housing their own specialty good.  There are soaps shaped like seashells and halal chicken curry and produce and samples of Dutch country handmade candies and herbs for wholistic healing.  Almost every kind of store is there and it's a great place to go on a big day or when your friends or family are visiting from out of town.  The only thing is that it can get a bit crowded, so maybe go when you're in the mood for a bit of hustle and bustle.
Definitely a lot of different variety of food and good for tourist in one place.

If you like food, and you happen to be in Philadelphia, take yourself to the Reading Terminal Market.

Food: all the delicious American foods are available. Shout out to MeltKraft grilled cheese.

Size: enormous. To walk around it takes a good half an hour. 

Location: easy to get there by bus, taxi or uber.
Lots of amazing places to eat! It's a huge tourist attraction so be prepared to fight the crowds, but definitely worth the visit!

This spot is a foodie's haven. They seriously have every type of food imaginable to man (almost everything). I've only been to Philadelphia twice, but I believe this is a go to spot for food. The atmosphere is so lively and full of life, and as a people watcher, I thrive on feeling people's energy, so this is just a good place to feel alive and eat some good food! They also sell fresh produce in addition to grab and go, plus sit down foods. I've only eaten ice-cream from here and had brunch at one of the breakfast restaurants, but all the food around me looks so good! I'll have to dedicate some time when I visit again to sample more of their options.

Variety: cheap things, expensive things, all types of food...you can get anything you want
Beiler's Donuts are especially good!
The terminal is a good spot, De Nic's is a favorite, and the Amish donut place is amazing. One of the go to spots for food in Philadelphia!
I love all of the choices offered but you have to be ready for loud controlled chaos. Finding a seat is always difficult too.

Although the RTM draws comparisons to Seattle's Pike Place, Philadelphia's Reading Terminal Market is far less gungho and far more clean. The RTM is more of a large indoors food court, with a labyrinth of a layout and lots of wonderful vendors to check out. A small handful of shops were closed on the Monday we visited, and the hours aren't spectacularly accommodating, but it's a nice place to grab a bite.

At least one Saturday a month, my family comes into Center City to enjoy breakfast and shopping at the Reading Terminal.

The Dutch Eating Kitchen is the absolute BEST breakfast, and well worth the minimal cost. 

The Fair Food Farmstand has great organic vegetables, sauces and honeys. 

Amazulu has eclectic, authentic African jewelry, clothes, home goods, accessories and body treatments fro all over the globe! 

Monday-Friday, after 5pm, The PA general Store has happy hour where all the homeade cookies are $1 EACH!!!! There are nearly 30 varieties of cookies!

Hershel's East Side Deli has mouth watering Pastrami, cornbeef, egg salad and turkey sandwiches! Did I say MOUTH-WATERING???

Beck's Cajun has the best BREAD PUDDING with WHISKY SAUCE! YES...WHISKY! 

Finally, grilled cheese becomes an adult classic when you create one at Valley Shepherd Creamery & Meltkraft Grilled Cheese! Move over chil'rin...let the adults sit down!

This place has EXTREMELY CLEAN BATHROOMS! My only complaint is the cleanliness of the seating areas. People do NOT clean after themselves! Yes, the janitorial staff works HARD, but customers feel like they do NOT have to throw their trash out. Disgusting.

Great market when you are looking fresh vegetable and fantastic meats. Only one problem, the crowds of tourist just milling around lost. 
Love Iovines for fresh fruits and Veggies. And Martine for the best chicken and turkey products.

Amazing market, wish I lived near something like this.  So many options for food!  Great seafood options including some of the biggest shrimp I've ever seen.  Awesome meat and cheese shops.  Plenty of already made take home options.  And a doughnut shop that I've never been to, but must be awesome from looking at the line.  Highly recommended, but be ready for touristy crowd and long lines for certain items.
A little overpriced, but still quality.  Loved by tourists and locals alike.  Great vibes, difficult to find seating.

This is a must for good food in Philadelphia. Different and very good options. 
Go there hungry and be prepared to have great food, good prices and an amazing atmosphere.
Prices are reasonable.

A great place to just walk around and browse, find good deals, or find rare, hard-to-find foods. It's awesome, and you can truly find anything. I'm a huge fan of the cheese stands, as they have great selections of fine, local cheeses. 

Word of warning, don't come here at lunch. It's absolutely nuts, which tells you how good the food is in there, but it's an absolute madhouse.
Diverse / Versatile place.  Great organic food!  Breakfast and shopping are the best times, lunch is usually a mad house but fantastic none the less.

I didn't know what I had when I lived in pa, and now I wish there is a reading terminal next to me especially those Amish stands. One of them sells beef jerky, don't miss it if you are there. It's probably the best beef jerky I have ever had, and I have had a lot of them. From Internet to local stores and restaurants, from east coast to west coast, from Asia to America, this is hands down the best. I recently went to one of the local rated best beef jerky in OC CA, and it can't even get close to what the Amish has in RT.
Literally has everything. Pad Thai at the Thai food stand is the best around and Beilers when the line isn't crazy is heaven. Beilers does donuts, and do yourself a favor and try them

Amazing place.  Food stands covering pretty much everything and a zillion ethnic styles available.  Meat, fish, pastries, deli, all under one roof.  Prices looked on the high side but not bad.  They also have a bar to sit down and have a cold one after walking around.  Wish I had seen this place before eating or I would definitely have gotten something.  A must see when back in Philly.

Many different places to eat, from all sorts of cultures. My family decided at the end to eat some Mexican food and it was just wonderful and the portions were huge too. We went twice, once Saturday around 2-3pm just to look around and we could barely move around because there were tons of people, and again Sunday around the same time and there was a lot less people. Just be mindful of when you want to visit.

A true taste of what Philly is all about (pun intended).  It is best to go during non-peak hours; I recommend mid-afternoon.  While there are a ton of vendors, DiNic's is definitely the crown jewl of the market.  Also be sure to try the Amish vendors who sell desserts; you can't get the quality anywhere else.  A full tour of China Town's delights (Dim Sum Garden) + Reading Terminal Market is a true treat for the tongue.
everything there is amazing . its the heart of south phillys melting pot.
Very cool location with a bunch of different places to eat at.  Only negative was there not being a lot of space to sit and eat but it was lunch time.

One of my favorite places to go to in Philly, and I take every one of my visiting friends here! This place has a lot of yummy stores and awesome stores ( recommended: the grilled cheese place at Meltkraft Grilled Cheese, the donuts at Beilers, 4 Seasons Juice Bar, Muellar's Chocolate Co., icecream from Bassetts, and local honey from Bee Natural). I love coming here, and even though it can get really crowded during lunch hours on the weekends, it's still worth it.

dkhfgkldshjfgkldsjhfg
dfglkdjfjjff fjfjfjflskdfjgh sdflkgjhdsfg  ghgjflkjdsfg dkfgjhd fgjj
this place is too crowded makes me feel icky sticky. and so expensive! i got some icecream for almost $5. what the HECK! i would rather stay home
Packed, stressful, not enough seating, food is mediocre. Go early or pass it up if you've been to something similar!

Im not sure... why they have so many good reviews... I mean, the place is all right. nothing too special about it. Bunch of food/shops things you can eat at. They also sell fresh fruit, veggies, fish, seafood. The whole place is relatively clean, but not the most shiny place either. If you are around the area, you can check it out, but dont expect too much - maybe your experience would be better than mine :)

This is a must do in Philly.  It gets super crowded but for a reason.  Some really great food at this place.  It can be hard to find a table but I think thats expected with a place this well-known.  It's definately a Philly institution.
SUPER fun! A must for any tourist or new resident to the city.

La Fourno trattoria  this restaurant is a find for us.  We really never go to south street.  But who would believe 636 south street would have a hidden treasure.  We had one of the best Italian dinners the four of us ever had in 
Philly.  The Shoenfeld's and Weintraub's who love to try good restaurants downtown in philly and NYC.  Found a gem tonight.  The service was superb, the meal extraordinary.  The salmon was sone perfect and generous, the veal parmigiana was the best we ever ate.  Special salad was great and dessert outstanding. We highly recommend you trying this Italian gem.

Cant say enough great things. I drive from Wilmington every weekend for the produce on its own!! Super cheap, place is clean but super busy. Huge savings on parking too in the two garages around it....check website for address, but parking goes from up to $35 to $4 if u spend over $10 at a vendor. They have restaurant for literally every kind of food you can imagine as well. This place would make living in Philly totally worth it!
Literally everything in this place is amazing. It can get way too crowded and it's very expensive...but the food is fantastic.

A Philadelphia institution and must see for all tourist. Yes when all is said and done the old reliable Terminal Market is still the best breakfast and lunch spot in Philly, as long as you can deal with the constant over crowding and fighting for a seat etc. Particularly good are the Amish restaurants and take out home grown veggies and farm raised chickens. Really to die for! Wonderful other choices , like Dinic's, Salumeria for sandwiches. Various Bakeries are excellent as well, and they even have a wine cellar there?!  Soul food and middle eastern, Asian eateries are wonderful,, really everything (except the Down Home Diner , avoid at all cost) But even arguably better than the restaurants are the various fresh fish, produce, outlets sprinkled thru out the terminal. The best fresh fish fruits and veggies produce money can buy Again if you are visiting Philly, I highly recommend you stop by and visit the ONE and only Reading Terminal Market, a unique Philly Staple that you just wont find anywhere else.

This place literally has something for everyone. Went grocery shopping at Iovine Brothers (extensive selection of fruits, veggies, everything in between, nuts, and organic food) then got the maple syrup yogurt from another shop. Amazing when frozen! Heard the juices, cheesesteaks, and ice cream are amazing too so will need to be back!!
Must see spot in Center City. Plan to get something to eat (meal, snack, dessert) as there are many options to choose from.
Every tourist should visit the Reading Terminal Market!

Awesome place for everything Philly. Great local food spots, chocolates, breads, pastries, cool peeps. If you only have a day or two in Philly I would hit this place for an hour for lunch or something.

Yiu just have to know which stands are gimmicks and which are legit down home food and treats.

always get the donuts...

This is an indoor heaven market....

Once u step inside is like a whole different world !!!
There's a raw oyster bar ! 
Pecking ducks 
Middle Eastern food
Greek food
Soul food
Of course PHILLY CHEESE STEAKS!!!
There's also skin care products! 
Organic honey !
Varieties of desserts like a brownie stand  but be careful is weight by the pound and u will easily spend $40 getting brownies---  but what is that keeps me coming here !!!
The freshly baked donuts made by the Amish people - the line by far is the longest line in the market -  I just had to try it and I don't even like donuts like that ....

All I have to say is if Beilers donuts were in NJ- Dunkin Donuts would be out of business! I honestly drove one afternoon to Philly just for the donuts I kid u not !!!

I can't even describe it -it's so good u will never buy donuts from any other place!!!

Now what I don't like is that there are not many seating areas but I guess u could eat standing up ?

Tons of great eateries.  Can't miss this place when in Philadelphia. The Flying Monkey makes a great butter cake, Termini Bros made a mean buttercream stuffed cupcake, and Wursthaus Schmitz Fried Bologna sammich is worth a  stop.

If you are visiting Philly, this place is a MUST GO for a meal! Come on an empty stomach though- there are TONS of options, Yelpers. While some lines may look long, don't be intimidated! They move fast.

(to the tune of "Pieces of Me" by Ashlee Simpson)

On a Monday, there's less waiting.
Tuesday, lines are fading
But most weekdays, crowds at lunch.
And on weekends, check those long lines
There's no ending, but I feel fine
'cause I come right after brunch.

Crowds, I hate those crowds so much....
But the produce and the meats, they're all so CLUTCH!

Ooooooh
It seems like I can finally find the things I really need
From fresh fish to sunflower seeds
Ooooooohhhh
It's as if this place has really got something for everyone
And to people watch, so fun.
All the people, people, people they feed.
All the people, people, people they feeeeed.

Reading Terminal, once a destination for me before I moved to the city, has quickly transformed to a spot I frequent for weekly groceries, specialty items, or even a little treat now and then. I've got my tried-and-true favs (Iovine Produce, Martin's for meats, Hatville Deli) and my favorite spots to bring out-of-towners (Beilers! Dinic's! Flying Monkey! Dutch Eating Place!) There's no better way to WOW a party than offering to bring desserts, and just making a platter of RTM goodies. From whoopie pies to canoli, black and white cookies to chocolate in the shape of nearly ANYTHING, this place is a goldmine. 

Weekends make things a little tougher, and, honestly, a lot of weekday lunchtimes. Tourists will stop in the middle of aisles, or (dressed in their comic-con finery), ogle menus and take pictures, halting progress. But that's kind of a part of the whole thing, isn't it? We are lucky enough to call this amazing city home, and RTM is definitely a Philly gem I'm proud to share with anyone who's just coming to visit.

Prices are great, convenience is greater, and I'll brave the crowds when the quality is that good.

Oh my God! Where to begin? This place was overwhelming! I needed several days to eat my way through here! I will be back. The smoked and rotisserie chicken wings along with their rotisserie carrots were fantastic at Dienner's BBQ. It is tucked away in the back of the Amish corner. Go there! Also if you like soft pretzels, you must to go to Miller's twist pretzels and more! The best I've ever had! Be sure to get there honey mustard dipping sauce if you like honey mustard. I can't wait to come back to the market.

This place is overwhelming but there is no shortage of choices for dining options.  Anyone can find something to eat here.  I had a Thanksgiving dinner sandwich, which was exactly what it says - Thanksgiving dinner on a sandwich, complete with stuffing, mashed potatoes, cranberry sauce, and turkey.  It was delicious though too much bread and not enough potatoes.  My wife had a cheesesteak from Carmen's.  The meat was very dry and had no flavor.  Beyond dining options, there are several shops selling anything from soaps to olive oil to wool goods.  It is easy to get lost here and you could honestly spend a couple of hours wandering from stall to stall.  Overall, an excellent Philly experience.

Had a great time there!! I took my three daughters down there over spring break in April, 2015. It was definitely worth the trip.  

Enjoyed seeing all of the local favorites and seeing what the excitement was all about.  It's not as big a place as the open-air market in Baltimore, but it's still a great deal of fun.  The ice-cream place down in front is wonderful. They do a local blueberry ice cream that is to die for.

Make this a definite place to stop (after seeing the Wannamaker organ) when you're in Philadelphia. You won't regret it.
Amazing selection of food, groceries, and desserts. Brokers, Bassets, and Terminis were excellent.

Super crowded, super chaotic, but it adds to the charm of this place. My group and I used the divide and conquer method. We each had one food assignment to purchase, while one of us scouted a table. We loved Denic's roast pork with broccoli rabe and sharp provoline, it's so different from a traditional Philly Cheese! Beiler's donuts are amazing, but very rich and heavy...you have been warned! Termini Brother's cannoli was nice but a little overhyped. Becks' Cajun fried mac n cheese balls were pretty good. We had THE BEST samples of different flavored turkey sausages at Haltman (sp?) Family Country Foods. We came back the next day to buy a bunch to take home but unfortunately, they close on Sundays. The Amish really know how to do meat right! We ended up at Martin's Meats and they also have a vast selection so we bough turkey andoille, turkey chorizo (the best!), turkey hot provolone, red wine and garlic, and more. Downtown cheese had an AMAZING truffle cheese that was around $50/lb. but we couldn't resist and purchased a sliver to take home. We used it on a homemade grilled mushroom pizza with a truffle cream white sauce...!! Many other food stalls we didn't get to try. Good luck finding a seat!
A fun place to check out when visiting Philly! Lots of fresh food, varied prices. I spent about $10 on a pulled pork sandwich for lunch. It is very crowded and seating is limited so.
Great atmosphere coupled with delicious food - something that you can't miss if you're a foodie in Philly.

We really enjoyed the different vendors and the food we selected was really good. Two of us ate at a booth specializing in roasted turkey and one of us had a burger.  The best part was Bassett's Ice Cream - it was absolutely delicious. BIGGEST problem is that we went there on a Friday night for dinner but the place closes at 6 p.m., not a great plan for dinner.
Love this place, there is something for everyone. This is a must stop for a foodie visiting Philly or for someone looking for something different for lunch.

Here you will find some of the best lunch food in the city... and some of the most annoying tourists standing in the middle of the "aisles."

Reading Terminal houses Tommy DiNic's Roast Pork & Beef, named the best sandwich in the country by some guy on the food network. I can concur, the brisket and the Italian-style pulled pork are some of the best sandwiches in Philadelphia. You will also find Miller's Twist, ranked third on some other guy's list of best soft pretzels in Philadelphia, and a variety of Amish vendors with more reasonable prices than Whole Foods and that pretentious mini-supermarket on Walnut Street.

Reading Terminal Market tops everyone's list of tourist destinations, but don't let that fool you. Some of the best food in the city is here. Though you should avoid RTM from 11:30a-3pm on most days, especially weekends, if you wish to not have hundreds of tourists standing in your way talking about how New York has better food because they chose a cheesesteak over a pork sandwich.

Love coming to the market whenever I visit Philadelphia.  They have anything and everything you could imagine.  This is where people come for their fresh produce, meats, dairy products who live downtown in a high rise.

I love all the restaurants in the market as well, I always love getting a cheese steak sandwich from Karmens when I visit Philadelphia.

Always alive.  Some favorites are the New York style deli, the veggies at the food market and the little shops.  I could go on and on, but if you are not familiar with it, just put it onto your agenda.  It's a slice of Phila like nothing else...anywhere.

I remember when this was a railroad terminal.  Hard to tell now.

This place is amazing if you are at all a foodie, or just like to experience and taste a city! This place has something for everyone here! My suggestion is bring your wallet, appetite, and make sure you have plenty of time! To many places to try and cram in a hurry!
Love this market, it was my first time,  a lot of great food and even candles and honey. The famous dinics is here, the best roast pork sandwich. My friends and I brought a lot of stuff.

it becomes a crush that feels claustrophobic at times: try to go to this great place when it's not the rush hour - you will find it difficult to get seating there. Perhaps take out the food. The Dutch Eating Place is go to.

The terminal has the best produce, Amish donuts, tomato pie, meat, honey, fresh juice, coffee, fish, cheese, spices, candy, and kebabs on the East Coast. Did I forget anything? If it I did, it is also the best of the best because nothing being sold at Reading Terminal Market is less than superb. Forget Whole Foods, this is the legit healthy (or not) shopping experience. Just don't go during the lunch hour if you dislike crowded places - this is a very crowded space and that can be irritating. If you do one thing in Philadelphia go here. The liberty bell is way less fun and tastes much worse.

Love it there.  So many food offerings and places to shop!  I went to have lunch with a good friend, and I ran right into a spice shop that had the spice that I had been looking for over a long period of time at a very good price.  I will definitely go back to shop as well as eat!

Love the Reading Terminal, but try to avoid going during 12-2 as much as possible. That is the absolute worst time if you're in a hurry and can't afford to be lost in the crowd. Other than that, it's definitely an experience.
There is literally something for everyone here. Huge variety of foods and drinks. It is pretty crowded and like most of these types of markets not much seating to really enjoy what you get to eat.

If you've never been, it's a must.  Delicious and varied food.  

If you work nearby like I do, it's a great option to include in your lunch hour weekly rotation.

If you have sensory issues or anxiety in crowds, try avoiding lunch hour and definitely avoid days when Philadelphia is playing host to a national convention or a worldwide clerical leader.

Some, but not all, entrances are wheelchair/stroller accessible.

I have been coming here FOREVER! I am 53, and my GRANDFATHER brought me here as a child, as did my mother. I am NOW visiting with my husband. We live in Cape May, NJ, but make it a point to come here several times per year. We stock up! I LOVE the cheese place in the back. LOVE Iacovine Brothers produce, fresh juices, dried CRANBERRIES, and snacks!
And, of course there is Herschels BRISKET, and HOT PASTRAMI! But then...there is METROPOLITAN BAKERY...BUY ANYTHING, you won't be sorry! LOVE this place, the re-do was VERY beautifully done, love the events and entertainment, ESPECIALLY at Christmas...SO festive! I DO, however, miss the VERY period bathroom stalls, and the PINK marble...they should have kept that! And the shoeshine guy is fantastic, I always wear my Dr. Martens when I go, for that reason! Parking is extremely convenient, and I appreciate the discounted ticket for shoppers!

Awesome selection of foods, desserts, groceries, and everything else.
A must visit for those visiting Philadelphia and a good place to get not-as-standard souveniors/gifts. 

I really like the jambalaya here :)
I probably tried all of the dessert places and they're all quite good.
If you are in Philly, you have to go to Reading Terminal Market. I visit this place at least twice a week. Lunch time can get crazy busy, but it's every second worth spend.
When I first moved to the city this was one of my first spots to eat. So many cool places to get a bite and the cookies at famous 4th street are the bestttttt!!!
Awesome! Just good old fashioned home cooked Philly food at its greatest! So ethnic and sooooo goood!!!! A part of our history and culture here,

I LOVE reading terminal my boyfriend and I go there but have a hard time deciding what we want to eat because we're extremely indecisive and I'm allergic to peanuts and IT IS NOT PEANUT ALLERGY FRIENDLY. Most of the restaurants there use peanut oil in their food and it's quite annoying. I went to this place called Charlie's the service sucked but their food was pretty mediocre

This place has a great, authentic market feel. It is a must do experience once in Philly. You can find all kinds of street food under one, historic, roof. It is definitely an must-have experience while in Philly.

My new favorite place! Wish we lived closer!!
So many to choose from; definitely something for everybody! 
Bring cash as some places don't take cards- 
We also parked in the garage across the street and there's a discount if you have your card validated from one of the stores.
Reading Terminal is amazing people watching and even better eating. There are tons of amazing places to try but be prepared for crowds especially at lunch time and on the weekends.

Such a great market to check out.  Everything you need is there under one roof.    Even if you don't buy a thing, just the atmosphere and all the different places with all the choices  is just insane.  Check it out and you won't be disappointed. 

All the best,
Tod

Hands down my FAVORITE PLACE IN PHILLY!!!!! Had the chance to experience the market during the AACC Clinical Lab Expo and I'm OBSESSED. Returned severally times over 2 days and it was worth every visit. DeNics is a MUST for the roast pork sandwich with broc rabe and provolone. I'm bringing some sandwiches back to Jersey tonight!

Good spot...
Bring cash...
Tough parking
Overall decent

Love this place! It's good for breakfast, lunch and even to pick up something for dinner. I am giving it 4 stars rather than 5 because I wish they would open up a little earlier than 8. Not all people start work at 9, so it makes getting breakfast there a little tough since I start work early.

LOVE this place. There is something for every palate here. Easy to reach via subway or car and worth getting to. A delicious break from sight-seeing. You can grab and go or take advantage of limited seating. Always my last stop before leaving town to avoid the pain of searching for road food.

Top Philadelphia attraction. If you can't find it at Reading Terminal, it's not available. I love this. They have such a variety of eateries, including DiNic's Roast Pork. We get our olive oils from here too. They also have a bar in case you just need to get off your feet. Don't skip out on the fountain drinks and cookies either.

I also went here for a wedding reception which was a wonderful change of pace.

This place is a food lover's paradise!  I go mainly for Beiler's Bakery and their amazing donuts and baked goods.  You can get a smoothie, beef sandwich, dessert, and a beer all in one spot!  The lines move pretty quickly in most places, and most places also take credit card. There is always someone at the netrance to direct you to what you're looking for.

Talk about a cultural melting pot of food, shopping and people watching, RTM has it all. I still haven't eaten at every establishment in there, but trust me, I'm working on it!

If you like to eat, do a little shopping a people watch, this is the place to be!
This place is AMAZING!!! Whatever you are in the mood to eat, you can find it here. The portions are outstanding and the service is fast. I have not been to a place in here that I did not like.

This market offers something for everyone. Coffee, tons of food options, groceries, cute souvenirs and housewares, an insight into Amish farming, and you can even get a decent Philly cheesesteak. It gets busy but still is manageable even during the lunch rush. Best part, as a tourist, is that they have free wifi! So you can start off your day at the market with some delicious food, and plan out the rest of your day while you eat.

If you are in center city Philadelphia make sure you go to the reading terminal market. This is the site of the old Reading railroad closed down many years ago for train service.
Its crowded, fun, food delights. In the corner is a small restaurant. Get scrapple, eggs and fried potatoes and you will be a true Philadelphian. The cost is low too, this place is like a small diner.
Pennsylvania dutch people come down from Lancaster County and sell boneless chickens (also known as eggs :) and cheese, baked goods, dressed in their traditional clothing. Its the real thing folks. Local people buy vegetables, fruit, meat, seafood, everything you would want for a home cooked meal. Tourists can try everything, you buy something and take it to one of dozens of tables all over the place.  Share a table with other tourists or locals.  Pennsylvania had a state liquor board system with state stores so you can only buy beer to go and there is a bar for full service cocktails, wine and beer.  All the stuff is good, repeat good, you won't be disappointed from a cheese steak wit onions, or to a hoagie with everything. anybody putting mayonnaise or ketchup on a cheese steak should be tossed into the Delaware River. And no lettuce or tomato either. Its meat, onion, hot or sweet peppers and a roll from Amorosos.

We came here during the Democratic national convention. It was packed with reporters and people this was on a weekday even then it wasn't too bad there was lots to see and lots to do plenty of room to walk around tables to sit and eat were hard to come by but we managed a family of four. I would recommend coming here without any type of bags or things to carry as you will just hit people walking past them lots of the stalls here take credit card as well as cash. There is plenty to eat and plenty to see and buy. You can buy fresh food fresh meat to cook, you can buy premade food, you can buy ice cream, fresh made donuts, Amish food, pretty much anything. Lots of the stalls offer goods that are you the handmade or Amish or of the Pennsylvania Dutch style. They do have some restaurants that are available to eat in. Things like an Amish diner I believe as well as other sitdown restaurants with bar stool type seating. A great place to come if you have a few hours to kill and you need fresh produce, groceries, meats, etc.
Always fun, good for people watching, and hasn't been turned in to a corpratized tourist trap... real local businesses are what makes this place great.
I like walking through the aisles to see the different stalls. Spending some time at Reading Terminal is a neat way to experience Philadelphia. Groceries are very inexpensive at the market.

At Bassett's had a double-decker of their glorious ice cream on a sugar cone (the best way) during the week of the DNC.  For five dollars it seemed as though I received almost a pint of the most delicious peach and mint chocolate chip.  In comparison, I had just eaten two of the tiniest scoops of ice cream at a farmers' market for almost the same price.

Been eating there at Bassett's since I was a kid (back in the Dark Ages), they are still the best.

Great place to eat and shop. They have produce at affordable prices and so many food options. I was able to find quite a few vegetarian options. Try Kamal's falafels! Old City coffee is great. And the cookies at 4th street famous cookies are such a nice treat.  loved this market!

The biggest trouble that I have with the RTM is the variety. I usually have to walk around at least twice before I can settle on something to eat. A must see for locals and visitors. Bring your appetite. This isn't your average place to go.

I'm going against the group here. 3 stars for Reading Terminal Market. This used to be an old railroad station. Reading Railroad(bonus points for Monopoly nostalgia). If you're not hungry, at least go in to check it out for historical purposes.

After closing the train service, what better thing to replace it with than food? All of the food! I think you should at least visit this place once, but other than that... don't waste your time with multiple visits. 

When you walk in, it can be overwhelming. Tons of people. If there's one thing that's dangerous.. it's hungry people all in one place around dozens of food options. Options include: Asian, ribs, desserts, tacos, oyster bar, a buffet, burgers, sandwiches, produce, seafood, and that's barely touching the surface of all you can order here. 

I ended up ordering a beef brisket sandwich(with green peppers and provolone). I also had a tamale. The tamale was delicious. The brisket sandwich was mediocre. It was tasty, but overall the brisket was dry. It did help that they put sweet or hot sauce on it(your choice), but even with that it was still too dry. Don't try to cover up your dry meat with sauce and then be conservative with the sauce. 

This was one of the first places we visited. As we explored Philly over the coming weekend, every new place we went I became more annoyed that we went to Reading Terminal. With tons of places in Philly to eat, the Reading Terminal is mediocre.

A must visit for out of town guests and many options to pick from!  Everything you could possibly want to try under one roof.  Termini Bakery and Beiler's donuts for desert are a must try!  Beware on Saturday and Sundays, lines are long, the space is crowded, and seating is limited.  Bring cash as many vendors do not take credit cards.
It's a wonderful place to shop, stroll and meet people from EVERYWHERE. There are older markets in Europe but nothing more wonderful in the US of A.

I have lived in the Philadelphia area for six years now and this is still one of my favorite places to visit. The variety of food you can get in here is ridiculous. You have to visit the usuals....like Dinics who has the best roast pork sandwiches. Also grab a dozen (or two) donuts from Beilers. I promise you it'll be the best donuts you've ever had. If they have any available....get the blueberry ones!! Come hungry so you can leave happy because you will want to try everything! !

Great atmosphere, every ethnic food you can think of, which enables you to taste a small portion before you head to a local ethnic restaurant and are overwhelmed by the various selections. I'm not a rib person, but the small Amish rib joint has the best beef/pork ribs I've ever had. Whenever we have visitors from another city or country for that matter, always agree this place has the epitome when it comes to ribs. In fact, we had family in from PR and they loved so much, they took home 2 racks!!

Blocks away from the center of town you must go here and walk around and try the mounds of food selections. I mean it makes Chelsea market look like a closet. The closest thing to this place is the Lexington market in Baltimore. tons of options, place is packed so be prepared and seating is hard to get when you want to eat but its there.

this is a staple of the philadelphia community... im biased a bit because ive grown up around this place. i will say however there is a good amount of food that can not be replicated by any other place in philadelphia... try going on weekdays when it is not too busy.
All the YES to the Reading Terminal Market! One of my [modest] life goals is to try every food stand in this place.

Where do I start? Foremost I shop here for all of my meats every other Saturday morningI always go to the same great reliable purveyors-For Poultry, no one but Godshall, for Fish-John Yi and LHalteman's for everything else
The big surprise of this place is that the meats cost no more than a good quality supermarket except the quality and freshness is much better here.
Great place to people watch and take in the sights if you are a tourist. Hands down one of the best "farmers"  markets in the country

This market is one of a kind. The myriad of food and drinks is incredible. If you are looking for a place to take a friend from out of town this is it. 

I would recommend going during the week to avoid the ridiculous crowds which hoard the market on the weekend.

This is probably my favorite place to eat in Philly. They have every type of cuisine. I've only ever gone during lunch time so it's always ridiculously crowded, but well worth it. I pretty much always get the 4 cheese white pizza and gnocchi at By George. I've never had to wait more than 5 minutes. I love Head Nut which sells every kind of nut, candy, etc, and the candy and chocolate shops are all amazing!

This was our first stop after we arrived in Philly after 10-11 hours in a car and we were FAMISHED. Our Airbnb host suggested RTM, particularly because it was early-mid-afternoon and probably one of the 'less busy' times to visit (comparatively....it is *always* busy).

We walked over to the terminal and were immediately overwhelmed! So many people! So many lights! Smells! Options! CHOICES! 

The fourth star in this review is simply for the initial impact the place makes as a first impression!
The food options and locations within are impressive, but unfortunately what I got did not live up to expectations, therefore no fifth star.

If you are a Philly tourist, go here for the experience and the excitement! If you are hungry but don't know exactly what you want, go here because you will find something that catches your eye.

The Reading Terminal is a must do item for almost anyone visiting Philly. If you're in town for a convention it's a convenient choice for a wide array of lunch options. If you're a tourist there's great people watching and shopping. If you're a Monopoly fan you can stop a take a photo. (It's the terminal, or end, of the real Reading Railroad!)

On my trip I stopped in for a quick beer while killing some time and had a great conversation with a local who was in for lunch. I will say beware of pick pockets and thieves as the woman next to me had her purse taken right of the back of her chair!!

Hershel's pastrami on rye is better than katz's in NYC. 9 dollars cheaper too. Born and raised in philly and have had both in the past week. Hershel's is far superior. Could not taste the mustard on Katz's. Also noticed that Hershel's cuts pastrami portion then cuts it into thirds and stacks it so that you get a little bit of end fat with the leaner middle of the slice in every bite. Hershel's also throws it on the panini grill which gives it some texture and keeps it from falling apart on you, which happened to me on the flimsy katz's bread.

What an amazing selection at this market! Food and goods from local businesses all in one spot. Perfect place to eat with picky friends or family because there is something for everyone. Avoid the chaos of prime lunch hour or if eating there, take turns grabbing food while someone snags a table in the seating area. 

Check out the map or website ahead of time to look at reviews and items you want, otherwise you could end up with a dud or annoyed locals if you don't know what you want. :-) The only bathrooms are way in the back by the seating area. Please note that they lock doors at 6 PM, so don't plan on spending time here after your 9-5 job or after a day of tourist exploration. 

Variety and some really unique and/or homemade food or products make this place a winner!

Probably one of my favorite places in the world. Seemingly hidden in a warehouse in center city Philly lies one of the best food experiences you'll ever have. Filled with professional looking stalls from every cuisine, each and every one of them is an institution in their own right. From the Ditch Eating Place to DiNic's, to Hershel's East Side Deli to Kamal's, you'll find anything you'd ever want to your heart's desire. Too bad it's not open much later during the day for a later dinner. I always try to stop by when I'm in Philly.

This sandwich is everything. The pastrami is tender, well seasoned not salty and taste great. I would recommend you stop past this location the next time you're at the reading terminal. The prices are a little steep for a sandwich.

Great place to dine out for various foods, desserts, etc...You can't go wrong coming here. The place is always packed, but still cooler inside then the hot asphalt. There are tables outside, but it's hot and smells like urine.

Amazing place!
Whether you are looking for cheese, veggies or meat at a good price & high quality ...
Or you are trying to have a nice meal after a day in Philly center-city ...
Or just in for a treat of frozen yogurt ...
You are at the right place :)

There's a lot to eat and see. If you're going for the doughnuts at Beiler's prepare for a wait as that line builds up quickly. Go find the little old Greek ladies and get their Dolmades (grape leaves).

Amazing selection of food vendors. This is definitely a must for any person stopping by in Philly. I stopped by on a weekday and the marketplace was still pretty busy. It seemed like a mix of regulars who worked around the area as well as tourists. There are plenty of seats throughout the market, so I wouldn't be too worried about that.

If anything, come to see the Amish at work. It's so authentic and cool (not even trying to be creepy).

Anyhow, I ended up going to the BBQ Stand and got some ribs but I was pretty torn because there were about 1 million other restaurants I wanted to eat at. I will be back whenever I'm in Philly.

Loved this place! For lunch I grabbed a roast pork sandwich with sharp provolone from Dinics which was great! But the main reason I'm writing this review is Bc I came in off the hot philly street desiring something refreshing. Not only was I greeted by a number of friendly good looking men... But they proceeded to make me one of the most delicious drinks I've ever tasted. "THE LEMONANA".  Never have I ever been so enamored by a beverage in my life. I would pay an exorbitant amount of money to have a personal tap of this in my house. When I first got this drink it was served in one of their medium sized cups .... I drank that down in about 5seconds. So I went back and requested that they make me "THE LEMONANA" in the biggest cylindrical container they had, to which they happily obliged. 
It's located right under the big neon sign reading "fresh juices smoothies" across from golden bowl and next to market bloom. If you love lemonade or are interested in tasting the most delicious drink on this planet you should make the trip to the market and find this place !
Very cool food market with pretty much anything you can imagine.  Lots of people walking around.  Philly Cheese steaks, seafood, chocolates, flowers...

Cute place. They have food stalls where you can grab a casual bite to eat or an ice cream and sit down and relax. Also a produce market inside. They close early however so don't expect to go for dinner, unless it's early dinner! Closed by 6p and I notice many places close even earlier. I think it's more of a casual lunch place. It's definitely worth a stop by if you are in the area.

Whether it's your first time or twentieth time, you have to go to the Reading Terminal Market.  It's Historic and has many vendors, including American or International food, meats and seafood, produce.  They even give you a parking voucher to lot across the street. It's located across the street from the Convention Center.
Consistently good food, but very crowded around peak meal times. Discounted parking in the garage next door with a ticket validated at the market.
great selection of food here. wish i had more time to eat!

This place is awesome! Only found out about it just last year (even though I made several trips out to Philly beforehand). 

The selection of food here is insane in a good way. Though, I must admit, I only go to a few spots here: Beiler's, Flying Monkey and Wursthaus.

last visit was day before Thanksgiving 2015 heeheehee.  Very crowded, but I love this place.  I'm a meanderer and a lover of food in general, so I enjoy visiting here. Its a potpourri of offerings, good, bad & ugly, depending on your perception, but never boring.  Plan a few hours there , like a day trip, and see what YOU discover.

Came here for the first time and it was fun! Avoid the lunch time rush though, it gets really crowded. Come with an empty stomach and fill it with lots of yummy food. We had some homemade chocolates, a Philly cheesesteak, I bought some spices, kale salad, some honey to go, and got some fruit for the road.

This is one of my favorite places to buy produce and watch people.  The proximity to the convention center promises that the Reading Terminal Market will always be filled with interesting people and great food.
so much to see and do-- I always pick up vanilla hazelnut coffee at Old City Market and a wine tasting at blue market is a nice retreat. It can get a little crowded, but definitely worth it.

This is a fantastic food hall, containing stalls that sell fresh produce, meat, prepared items, non-food items, and baked goods.  There are also a wide variety of restaurants preparing food fresh, either to eat there or take away.  I was so happy to see the variety, as it could have been nothing more than pretzels, ice cream and cheesesteaks, but there is so much more!  

While not all food vendors are of the same quality there were a few that stood out to me - Dutch Eating Place, Sang Kee Peking Duck, Termini Brothers Bakery, DiNics.  Once place I really wanted to try but was not able to was the Soul Food Cafe.  The fried chicken looked so good.  

it's worth taking a lap or two to check out what's what.  Prices were reasonable, the portions leaned towards generous, and the quality was pretty high.  While seating may be an issue during periods of high density I didn't have much of an issue during multiple visits.

It's worth a visit, at least once, during a visit to Philly.   Note that the Amish owned businesses have limited hours (they are posted at the market entrances).  Some places take credit cards but I'm not aware if all do.  I did see at least one ATM inside.  This market is located above the Jefferson Station  and is fairly close to the historic sites and Chinatown.
Amazing local city market. Best to go on weekdays, however, anytime but at lunch as it is very very popular.

AWESOME PLACE TO VISIT!

Tons of great food. 

Must visit when in Philly. 

Well worth the wait for food.

Must stop while you are in Philly. Tons of amazing vendors all in one place. Definitely stop by DiNic's for the roast pork with broccoli rabe. Beiler's deserves all it's fame and glory, too. Every donut is incredible. These shops won't disappoint!
I love this place! Doesn't take me long to get there and the food is great!

I love this place.  So much better now than when I was a kid.  I remember it smelling very raunchy back then, but there probably wasn't any air conditioning in the Middle Ages!  

There's always something fascinating about the Farmers' Market, and I love to see the colorful fruits and veggies set out.  It's never quiet or empty - a lot of hustle and bustle is part of the experience, but the lines move quickly and the service is efficient.  The vendors know a lot of us snuck out of work to pick up groceries or grab lunch, so they don't waste time, but you can chat with them if you have time.

Felt like Grand Central Market in LA, but WAY BETTER.

Lots of selection for food, meats and bakeries!

Every place I checked out was reasonably priced, it was difficult to choose a place to grub from. Most definitely check out Bielers for donuts..99 cents is all you need to know. The line was quite long but it moved quick!

Some of the places close in mid-afternoon so be sure to double check if you want to visit. There's Amish people. So cool. Never seen them before. 

I wanted to ask so many questions..I wonder if they will ever read this review?

One of the most amazing places in the country for foodies!! Hands down this market which I have been to 4 times now and have sampled many of the different restaurants within the market, and can confidently say they are all amazing! The level of authenticity and pure love for fresh produce and ingredients pours through the market. Cultures of every corner of the world are on display here, and the tastes go from exotic to comfort foods with just a few steps. Try everything here and go broke, it will be worth it, trust me.
If you can't find something you love here you must have no taste buds! tons of options for any taste with Denic's being the best of them all!

They say the heart of a city is found where it's culture lies, and we all trace our culture back to the food we eat. This holds true for Reading Terminal Market.

This market is the heart of downtown Philly. Make sure you check out Dutch Eating Place. Best Apple Butter in Philly!!!
Awesome place where you can find everything you want. Also great to meet up with friends or have a quick lunch!

Can't say much more than what's already been said. Must see if you're visiting Philly. Awesome experience, lots of fantastic vendors. Hershel's makes a killer Pastrami Reuben, and that's only one of a million options!

Plain and simple. Do you like amazing food? You'll love it here.
You can get practically any food item your heart could desire here. There are so many amazing places it would be silly to try and list them all. Hershel's though is probably my favorite for a real great corned beef sandwich outside of NYC.

The reading terminal market is so amazing! There are so many food vendors to choose from. From smoked turkey legs to delicious Amish donuts that are made fresh on the spot and they are so amazing. The line can be pretty long but def worth the wait. I'm looking to head there from NY just to get some donuts!
I would consider moving to Philadelphia just so I could come to the market often. Especially if Beiler's Donuts was open (that is, on every day except Sunday and Monday).

Reminds me of home. In Milwaukee we have the Milwaukee Public Market. They are very similar. Here in Philly I got a taste of what its like to eat, drink and shop like a Philidelphian. Which was cool.

I found out what scrapple is... not that i'd eat it but at least I can say that I know.

I like to support the local business and economy. The Terminal Market was a cool trip.

I love everything about this place from the baked goods to the seasoning the fresh meats. The Dutch have the freshest products. And if you get your parking pass stamped it's only about $4 to park. Once I was done shopping for home goods I sat down for lunch before leaving

Fantastic produce market, flower market, and a slew of amazing food and goods vendors! The Amish and Dutch spots are always spot on with their food and baked goods. Beiler's is amazing - their blueberry fritter is a must have. Can be crazy in there during the tourist times (spring/summer lunchtime and weekends). Downside is the tight schedule that keeps people from utilizing it if they work a 9-5 without much flex in their schedule.
A lovely place to hang out! A lot of restaurants, great food, great drinks and really great place. We enjoyed this place very much and we recommend everybody to go there!
We shared one of the best pastrami Reuben sandwiches we have ever had.  Then, we picked up a Pineapple Upside Down pound cake, which we took home; it was amazingly good.

This has to be a must see on any trip to Philly.  I've been to Philly a lot in the past 3 years and I normally get there at around lunch time. There is no better place to start than reading Market. They have everything you can imagine all under one roof.  Want to try a cheese steak, there's  Spataro's Cheesesteaks.  Want what's is becoming Philly's signature sandwich, go to  DiNic's for one of their Slow cooked Italian roast pork, broccoli rabe sandwichs, with thick chunks of Sharpe provolone. You have a sweet tooth there are 7 bakeries and 4 candy booths. There is a clam bar and for those that like there lunches wet, there's Molly Malloy's. Now I'm not saying that this is all that Philly has to offer, far from it but it is worth spending at least an hour in.
A little disappointed with the grilled cheese sandwich. It wasn't as i was expected. I think they've cut down on the cheese. Not quite sure. But anyway, the cookies are delicious and puffy.
Some good places to eat, some not, I'd say it's overstated, the down home diner really kills it for me, really bad food.

The Reading Terminal Market is quintessential Philly.  If you are a tourist, don't miss it.  If you are local, don't miss out!! My first year I avoided RTM because I felt so overwhelmed by the crowds, but then I happened to wander in on an off time & discovered the magic of feeling like the place is all yours for the taking! My favorite shops include Iovine's Produce, 12th St Cantina, La Divisa Meats, DiNIc's, & Beiler's Donuts [do not miss out on these, whatever you do!].  Philadelphia is lucky to have a gem like RTM; I always look forward to the weekend events they put on, for example, today is Bacon Fest if I remember correctly!

The Reading Terminal has most of the best foods Philly has to offer under one roof. Looking for a REAL Philly cheesesteak? You can get one here. Looking for some fruits and vegetables fresh from a farmer in Lancaster? Right here. Looking for a quick lunch that's healthy and fun to eat? Right here. Termini's, one of the best bakeries in Philly? Get their to die for cannoli right here! You can't go wrong at the Reading Terminal.
I love this place. If you don't see what you want?  Just look harder. There are soooooo many food selections.  So much to see.  So many people to watch. An epicurean delight and fun too!!!!

This market is one of the most impressive examples of how diverse the United States really are. Wandering in from the bustling center city Philly one is greeted with many languages, foods and people. This market not only has great selections of produce, Halal food, Chinese food, Philly cheesesteaks etc. it also boasts Dinics steak and pork stand where the some of the best sandwiches in Philly are made.

You can find whatever you want here, from a great Philly cheese steak to various ethnic foods to a roast pork sandwich which was named the best sandwich in America by Adam Richmond of the Travel Channel.  While there, you can buy fresh produce, meats, seafood, etc.  One of the coolest places in Philly!

This market was right across the street from our hotel.  It was our morning destination each day!    Might I suggest the following:

Spataro's (Philly Cheesesteak Breakfast Sandwich)
Molly Malloy's (Spicy Hash, yogurt and granola, steel ground oatmeal)
Market Bakery (Fantastic bagels and croissants)
Old City Coffee (Great locally roasted coffee!!!)
Kamal's  (for daily smoothies)
Beller's Donuts (Every kind of flavor you could possibly want)
Termini Bros (Grab the Cannoli!)

Besides foods, there are bookstores, a French linen stall, herbs, teas, etc.
Obsessed. The cookie place has these amazing chocolate dipped lemon drop cookies. And my go-to is the falafel pita from the Greek stand. Really... All of it's good.
This place is a food lovers paradise. I am going to make a trip to Philly once again just to eat here and i'm not kidding :)
love the salmon and rice....just wish you could get a seat

This is a Philly must. It has an amazing array of places to eat as well as many places to buy great food and cooking ingredients. The olive oil shop at the back is an interesting place even if you're not interested in buying anything I'd recommend going there just to taste the various combinations of olive oil and balsamic vinegars - odds are you'll end up buying something. 

While many places are really good, if you like your meat you have to try out Hershel's Deli. Go to the sitting area in the middle of the market and you'll see it. It has an absolutely amazing set of sandwiches with perfectly made meat that'll send you straight into a food coma. Enjoy.
Awesome to go for great food. Every time someone comes to visit me in Philly I have to take them here and they love it!!! So many amazing options to choose from that its almost overwhelming!

LOVE THIS PLACE

It is truly a foodie heaven with everything from baked goods to cheesesteaks to gyros in sight and walking distance. Tried the Boston Cream donut from Beiler's and a cheesesteak from Carments. Both had the longest lines (lunch hour rush) but were worth the wait.

One word:  DiNic's.  Get the roast pork sandwich.  Seafood mongers have the freshest fish in the city and its the only place I know of where you can get a variety of fresh fish roe for frying (not the sushi stuff like Salmon and Flying Fish, think any female fish carrying an egg sac.)

Reading Terminal Market is one of my favorite places in Philadelphia. The Market has an incredibly diverse selection of food stands housed inside an old warehouse. For people that haven't been to Reading Terminal Market before I describe it as a small city of food stands. In addition, there's also a nice fresh grocery area if you're local and need to do some grocery shopping, and some other shops with things like soap and candles.

However be warned, Reading Terminal Market is always very crowded. 
Consult the map to find what you want, otherwise you may spend a long time wandering, gawking at the choices, and standing in a traffic jam of people who are doing the same thing. Seating is also unfortunately very limited because of volume of people. But this place is worth it!
Got everything foodwise there.  Just not so good on the Cheesesteaks.  DiNic's is a plus....

In my opinion, Reading Terminal Market lives up to the hype. It's worth checking out if you are visiting Philly. It's pretty overwhelming (but in a good way). There is so much to check out. The indoor market has a wide variety of vendors and food stations. 

In terms of food stations, my favorite one is the Cajun Po'Boy one. Also, whenever I go to Reading Terminal Market, I always visit the Amish vendors and check out their jellies and honeys. 

You can also eat inside the market. There are a number of tables, but seating can be hard to find during busy times of the day. 

I highly recommend Reading Terminal Market! Go check it out when you are in Philly.

Fantastic stop while in Philly. Food galore. A must-do while in the city.  Great stop for breakfast or lunch.  We ate at Molly & Malloys, splitting the deviled eggs and a philly cheese steak. Both were deee-lish.  Also picked up some chocolates, cheese, a baguette loaf (which was warm and crispy) and some ice cream. Great end to our first sightseeing day in the city.

Super cute market! 

Tip: Come super early or later in the afternoon to beat the lunch rush.

Metered street parking available- we were able to snag a spot around 2p Sunday. Parking spots seemed to turn over quickly. 

This place is poppin' and lovely for a weekend stroll. Your biggest challenge is probably navigating the crowds and finding a table to eat at, depending on your lunch choice.  

Our stops:
Termini Brothers Bakery: delish ameretti and horseshoe cookies. Always a pleasure to see fresh cannolis that are filled right in front of you once upon order. Love the idea- keeps that cannoli crust from getting soggy :)

Tommy Dinic's Roast Pork and Beef: Our fav lunch spot. Come early before they sell out of the beef brisket. Since we arrived later in the afternoon, we had to "settle" for their pulled pork which was still phenomenal!! We ordered one sandwich to share (they're ginormous). Each sandwich comes with the option to add toppings- we chose broccoli w/ cheese and it was perfect. We were content and satiated after inhaling our half sandwiches. TIP: If you "eat in" at the bar, you can skip the entire line! And their service is super nice and friendly. We left happy with our experience. 

There are also a lot of healthier options too (we are just total pigs)...and ultimately decided to leave with a smoothie/green drink from the juice bar to feel better about ourselves. lol 

Service was all around really friendly. You'll see a nice mix of college students and families here on a nice weekend. I'd definitely be back! :)

By far, this was the most overwhelming indoor market I've been to - the choices were literally endless. So if you're REALLY ambitious, have time to walk around, and are with a group, you could each get food from a different vendor and share, Smorgasburg style. But warning: lines are LONG. 

After walking around the entire market (and getting lost) for 30-45 minutes, I finally settled on Dinic's Roast Pork and Beef - I got the Roast Pork ($8.75). Tbh I wasn't a huge fan.. the meat was tender and moist, but it didn't have much flavor, so I thought it was pretty mediocre for something so highly raved. 

The market, while stimulating way too many senses at once, is still pretty incredible and a must-visit!

An awesome market. So many food vendors, most of which are really cool and unique. I liked their dutch eating place, though I've had better french toast. Still, it's pretty tight and I've heard the donuts are amazing.

Definitely worth the crowd ! This place is an amazing indoor market with so many choices to eat, I would've stayed there all day if I was left to my own devices. Yes, it is packed ... Yes, there are a lot of tourists .. But it is sooo worth it. There is literally anything and everything you could ever want under one roof. This place absolutely has something for everyone..gluten free options, desert bars, gyros, cheesesteaks, po boys, fresh fish, live lobsters in a tank .. I could go on and on ..its ridiculous . If you are adventurous , I suggest you spend a couple hours here trying out the different food options.. You will not be disappointed .

This is a MUST when visiting Philadelphia! It is a little chaotic, noisy and crowded but you just have to deal with it. The food is fantastic! I've only eaten one thing that I haven't fully enjoyed and I've tried a lot of stuff! This is seriously my favorite place in Philadelphia besides Iim's for a cheesesteak!

This is s great market to get lost in especially on a rainy day. There is a melange of different eateries: fresh meat, fish and wonderful produce.
It's best to come with a hearty appetite to sample all the great food.
The highlight was the produce department which displayed a fresh assortment of eggplants, sweet peppers, corn etc
This really puts NY Chelsea Market to shame
Highly recommend visiting when you visit Philly

I honestly don't know what else can be said about Reading Terminal that hasn't already been said.
There is a reason why this place is frequented by locals, celebrities, even the president himself comes here when he's in Philly. I could tell you about the Dutch place, cheese, fudge,produce, baked goods, donuts that people line up and wait willingly for, but this is something that you truly must see and experience for yourself. Be prepared to spend a good amount of time here, especially if you are a serious foodie.

Reading Terminal Market is awesome. You have a wide variety selection of anything to get to eat while there, to-go or grocery shopping for later. There are endless top notch food places here. It's great for people watching as well. A nice place for "tourists" to check out or anyone who works in the area for a good lunch. Could even have a super cute date night here. But, be prepared for crowds, lines and be comfortable with being uncomfortably close to people lol - many tourists flock to this place and do not know their way around, just a warning. The crowds/lines are well worth it though!

This is a great spot to take any visiting friends, and a great spot to grab lunch, or to go to if you are with a big group and can't decide what to eat. 

For desserts - 4th st Cookie (get the chocolate dipped chocolate chip!), and Flying Monkey are great choices. 

Sang Kee is delicious, as is the Crepe place.

The veggies and farmer's market items tend to be a bit over-priced - but to find those options in the middle of the city is a great resource!

I just want to keep going back until I've tried every single stall! This is a haven for someone that loves all types of food and is very adventurous. On the other hand, if you're indecisive and stumble with too many choices, you may end up being there all day. Either way, you'll have fun! I went to RTM every chance I could get while in Philly and will go there again when I return!
Omg I have never seen so many food choices in one place!  there were options that catered to anyone and everyone literally so many options wow!

Ate here almost everyday during the Democratic National Convention, and I'm glad I did! I'm from Los Angeles, so I as attracted to the market atmosphere and the variety of food it offers. The place is huuuuge and has something for everyone. I had my first Philly Cheesesteak every here & it was so delicious. When I return to Philly, this is definitely a place I'm visiting again!
SO many options. every kind of food you could think of, including a deli and butchered meats/seafood. If you're ever looking for a bite in the city, please check this place out for your own good!!!

My son told us this was a go-to place to find Philly atmosphere and good food.  We didn't find that to be our experience.  The place consists of a lot (!) of retail enterprises set up adjacent to each other and separated by aisles.  The food places serve a variety of what I would call grill-food...do not look for cloth napkins. It did seem to be popular as a business lunch destination, being quite busy the day we visited at about noon.  Our challenge was sorting out where and what to eat since the crowd had filled-up many of the sparse-seating-available sections....come to think of it, that may have been what caused us to end up less happy with what we had to eat....in any event, the food was quite expensive given portion sizes and counter seating arrangements. Glad we went.  Would go again on a day we had more time to spend looking over options.  The activity was interesting and the employees friendly and in some cases colorful.

We came to reading terminal market for lunch. There are many options for eating and I got pretty overwhelmed! But, since it was Sunday, a good portion of the market was closed. Carmens was really crowded so we opted out. My parents got the sang kee roasted pork and duck rice special. They loved it! I got a savory turkey breast crepe with veggies and cheese. It was pretty good, a bit too salty though. My favorite part however, was the BASSETTS ICE CREAM! It's amazing. I got vanilla and even the most simple flavor was perfect. I hope to be back!

Perfect place to grab lunch. Dozens of choices to please any picky eater. Whether you're here to quench your thirst or hunger, you'll definitely find something that'll please you! Just be careful to not stand in the middle of all the hustle and bustle so that you don't get run over by wandering tourists lol.

Pretty cool place to stroll through! Plenty to see and taste! Prices are on the higher side but I guess that comes with the territory. You can find so much here and definatly something for everyone here. All sorts of food snacks desserts and grocieries that u can find here! Definatly worth the trip! Must visit!

A true gem and a must-see stop for anyone lucky enough to be in Philadelphia. What a genius move to have this place next door to the Convention Center. I cannot say enough good things about the convenience of going to ONE stop and having food options for days. The delis and Mennonite restaurants are the real winners here, but just don't go on Sundays when all the Mennonite/Amish businesses are closed.

Everyone told me this was a must-see place during my visit to Philadelphia. I went there twice during the lunch hour, once on a weekday and once on Sunday. I found it to be extremely chaotic, noisy, barbaric, and disgusting. If you like being crammed alongside wall to wall aggressive people who like to queue up to the trough to wolf down food, this is the place for you. Not my idea of dining. On my first visit, I was so overwhelmed that I left within five minutes. On Sunday I sat at a counter. It was 10 minutes before anyone offered to take my order. When I said I'd like it to go, I was told I had to go to the other side and stand in line. I ended up going to a different vendor to get a sandwich. It was acceptable, nothing outstanding.
I love this place. Lots of specialty stuff in the terminal. If you like cookies checkout Famous 4th Street Cookies.

Reading terminal offers a taste of all the flavors of Philly, in one convenient spot.  For anyone visiting Philadelphia it is a must see.  Although, it has its drawbacks. For a typical lunch spot the meals are usually a minimum $10 and the place is full to the brim with tourists throughout the year. Quality of food is always pretty high throughout the market. You can park in a nearby garage for $4 or be a true Philadelphian and take the subway here, it's only a 2 minute walk away from 13th or 11th Street stations. Come here and wander through the stalls and experience the hustle and bustle.

Here are some highlights for the non-tourist:

Iovine Brothers offers a wide variety of decent produce at a good price 
Tootsies eatery allows you to build your own meal from it hot and cold buffet, you can get a decent size salad for about $7, and it has cheaper desserts compared to the rest of the terminal.
Beilers fritters are a must. 
Dinics is a classic and Old City Coffee is great.

My review for this place is LONG overdue, and I know it is only going to be a drop in the sea of the 3,240 reviews this place already has. *Note that this place is called the READING terminal market, yet it is pronounce REDDING. 

This Market is nestled between 11th & 12th Ave and Arch Street. There are several entry and exit points, one being right by the Hilton. 

This place is a foodie lovers paradise and overload!!! There is virtually something for EVERY palate. Want something fresh, hot, sweet, creamy, chocolate ears, something loaded with carbs to indulge your senses...they've got you covered here!!!

They have a LARGE produce section filled with an array of healthy options, I didn't spend much time in this section but everything appeared to be in peak freshness/ripeness. 

There is a LARGE selection of fresh meats (steaks, roasts, ribs etc) and what seems to be an even larger selection of mouth watering deli meats to choose from. We are talking stacks of piled high meats ready to be consumed in between two slices of bread, topped on a cracker with a cheese spread (that they have plenty of) or to just snack on a lone. 

If you do not want to make your own sandwich, they got you covered as well. You can walk over to another vendor that sells gut busting sandwiches such as: chicken Caesar, fresh mozzarella, chicken caprese, Pompeii etc. The sandwiches can either be purchase on loaves (better have a big appetite) or a more hand held option like ciabatta. A few steps over and you can purchase one of their ridiculously HUUUUUUUGE philly cheesesteaks, where they prepare the food in front of you. They also put on a show while they make it, which is kind of cool.
