Don't feel limited to just a traditional cheesesteak, you can get a chicken cheesesteak, pizza cheesesteak, broccoli rabe, BLT cheesesteak and on. You can also choose the cheese, be it provolone, American, or the east coats favorite cheese sauce. 

Next to the philly cheesesteak counter, they have pasta sheets that they will cut to your preference, while you wait for your food. You can pay at the same register. The pasta we purchased was seasonal, Pumpkin Pasta and it was terrific. 

If you meander to the left of the cheesesteak counter, they have a variety of comfort foods ranging from lasagna, spaghetti, Stromboli's, chicken parmigiana, and meatballs. 

Once you have quelled your hunger pangs, head over to their bakery section. There you can load up with cannoli's (filled to order), cheesecakes, torts, individual sliced cakes. Ever wonder what a chocolate shaped foot with almond toes, or Van Gogh's ear tasted like??? The also have a variety of caramel apples, plain, dipped in chocolate AND caramel or overloaded with chocolate chunks, marshmallows and drizzled in peanut butter. 

There are plenty of other delectable delights in this jam packed market, too many to list. Come hungry and with plenty of ambition. You could easily spend hours, if not a whole day here. Lines can be long at times, and some counters require you to take a number. It is worth the wait and weight ;)
I love this market! There is truly no place like it. You can find a little of everything. This place is great in quantity and diversity as well as quality.

Great variety of food and market options. I was in town for work and stopped here for most of my dinners. Bustling with people shopping and dining. Very cool spot. They do close at 6 and I found that even shortly after 5 some of the food stalls were already closed up. Just something to be aware of if you're planning to stop in for dinner.
Great place for all kinds of food; produce is especially fresh

This place is amazing.  Busy indoor marketplace located right in the center of the city that has every type of cuisine and all types of little shops.  Most of the places offer fast service since it's a hot spot for people to go on their lunch break.  

Reminds me a lot of Pike Place market in Seattle and puts grand central market in NYC to shame. Definitely put this on your list of places to checkout if you're visiting from out of town.

I love this place. I love the variety of the vendors, and everything I've eaten  here has been finger-lickin' good. 
My faves: 
-cannoli from termini bros 
-doughnut from beilers
-coffee from old city
-cheesesteak from Tony Dinics

The Reading Terminal is great! They have everything you could ask for, and then some! Many grocery/produce options, and eating places. They definitely have something for everyone including Asian food, desserts, Mediterranean food, pizza, etc. You name it, and they got it! I always look forward to coming to the terminal each time I'm in Philly.

Didn't know what to expect, more like Quincy market in Boston but I couldn't be more wrong. What an amazing place. It was so hard to make a decision on where to eat and then what to have as a treat. Hope to visit the area again so I can go back

Great place full of a variety of restaurants/vendors. I do enjoy it and it reminds me of a tinier version of New York's Chelsea Market. If I lived closer I would probably find myself eating at a different restaurant everyday! Great place to find fresh seafood and small gifts (food wise) for friends and family.
This was so amazing. The best of all Philadelphia has to offer food wise under one roof!

What an incredible market. So many places to choose from. The New Orleans eatery is authentic with red beans and rice etc. Amish food delicious. Go there often because soooo much to choose from. Diet before you go!
What's not to love?! One stop shop ftw! Do yourself a favor and pass by the Metropolitan Bakery. Thank me later

It's Nirvana.  I'm Philly born and bred, so I have seen the evolution of the market over the years- opening on Sunday, all the wonderful cooked food vendors, make it a Mecca for visitors. Great offerings in a soulful spot. 
Proud of my city!

This place has an amazing selection of food.  You could literally eat there every day for a month and try something different each time.  It must be great for people that work close by.  If I did, I'd be eating there every day.

This is a cool place and definitely somewhere to take someone who isn't from the area. At first it seems HUGE but then you realize it's not quite that big. There's lots of food options, many of them decadent that you can bring home....like the amazing doughnuts from beilers....but there's only so much you can eat while you're there. Fun place...definitely check it out!
Had so much fun getting little bites from different vendors. There were so many options. Love it here!

Fun place to visit, whether I will actually shop here is a different question. Like any other market, watch out for the tourist traps, have fun but be judicious. I agree with other reviewers saying that it is a much better market than Grand Central in NYC. A must-visit if you are in Philly for a visit, and even if you live there.

The Reading Terminal Market is right by 12th and Market and behind the gallery old market east station and now Jefferson Station. . They have a other of stuff and variously from meats to pastries even restaurants.  Has been around for over half a century. It is a diamond in the rough for those of us from and raised in Philadelphia. I highly recommend this place to any tourist.

Such a great Philly spot! I was able to go a few years ago for lunch and on my most recent trip stayed right next door. The place is always filled with people and the offerings are very diverse. We had ice cream, french fries, oysters, grilled cheese, cookies, craft beers, and a smoothie over the course of our trip. The great thing about the market is being able to find pretty much everything and anything you are looking for food-wise.

The shopping items are a little more limited, but still made for great browsing.

Only thing to be wary of - it is a very busy place. I saw a few parents with strollers looking like they were having a hard time and it took us quite a while to sit down to eat (there were three of us). It seems like during the day it is a pretty consistent level of busy, so be prepared for that!

This place is a foodies dream come true! There are tons of different restaurants, boutiques, mini grocers, bakery shops, and more. It's a shame that they don't have a market like this where I live. 

One of my favorite places to visit every time I come to philly!
Yasss, easily the best option if you want to 'eat your way around Philly' without worrying about actually leaving one place.

Love, love, love going here! Sooooooooooooooooooo many choices of soooooooooooooooooooooo many food places! From soup to nuts, to the Best Gyros, to cookies! The Amish Bakery is to-die-for! Wouldn't miss stopping at Reading Terminal when I'm in the area!

This is a great spot to go to if you are a tourist or a local. My little cousins who are 7 and 9 call the market "The Mall of Food!!" They love coming here. I come and get my groceries here with my boyfriend often. We try out different restaurants for lunch and usually get something sweet before we leave from a bakery shop or candy shop. This place has a little bit of everything so I'm never disappointed. (I also enjoy people watching here, it's a great place to do it.)

Great selection! There's truly something for everyone at RTM. Some personal favorites? The cinnamon raisin bagel with black raspberry cream cheese at the market bakery, the chocolate peanutbutter ice cream in a pretzel cone at the amish pretzel shop, and pretty much any grilled cheese at MeltKraft. Ugh, you really can't go wrong, but these 3 places get my business time and time again.

Amazing fine vendors. My favorites are the Fair Trade stand, Iovine produce, the local-product meat stand, Schmidt's German deli, a couple of cheese stands, Metropolitan Bakery, Old City Coffee...but all are worth checking out. 
Besides the cheese steak vendors ( I hate them all), the most popular lunch stand is the Asian vendor in the south-central section. You can tell by the long lines.

Would love to start and end every day of my Philly trip here! Many different vendors and a lot of locally sourced ingredients in a whole variety of food options. Some market type vendors, and many other options for prepared food. Love it.
I love the Reading Terminal.  There are so many great places to eat.  It's a lot of fun!

The selection of food here is absolutely amazing.  It is always a fun time even if you just walk around to soak in the sight, sounds, and smells of all the different food stands.  Also has fresh produce which is a plus.  It may not all be healthfood but you will certainly find something delicious to eat.

I love this place! I can stay in this market for hours. I came here for to peruse and came across Keren Parker Soul Food Cafe.
Now, this IS the BEST soul food I've had in my days on this earth. I ordered the chicken wings with mac n cheese and another order of candied yams. The entrees come with one side. Also the tropical ice tea with the slice of watermelon was icing on the cake.
It was so good, I ate there everyday during my visit to Philly. I also visited the Amish bakery which is to die for. Tip: They close on Sundays.
Another Tip: Go with an empty stomach, this isn't for the faint of heart/stomach.

Was so excited to visit this spot when me and Eric went to Philly this weekend. We got there around 4pm and almost every single vendor was already closed. It said 6pm on the website and we were highly disappointed.. I wanted a roast pork sandwich from Dinics and a pretzel from Millers Twist and both were closed down. The only things that were open were the bar and The Flying Monkey Bakery. We got a Pumple cake which is pumpkin pie inside of a chocolate cake inside an apple pie inside a yellow cake. It was ok. Kinda stale but the cashier was so nice and friendly. It reminded me of the old Farmers Market in Bethpage that i used to hit up as a child. We looked around a bit and was just so let down that i couldn't buy anything i came for. We were leaving Philly that night so never had the chance to go back. Sad.

This is an amazing terminal. So many good eats and cool merchants to choose from. Fresh fruit and veggies and cheese and pastries and treats!!!! I loved it! I live in north Jersey and sometimes consider driving to Philly for the day just to visit this terminal!
AWESOME! Literally anything you would ever want is at Reading Terminal. Stop what you're doing and go. Right meow.

If you want to die of a food coma you come here.

Everything from cheese steaks, burgers, and pastries are sold here.  The cheesesteaks are huge, greasy, and packed to the point it's overflowing. Literally a heart attack in a bun.  The market also acts as a grocery store and you can buy a lot of fresh fruits and meat. Really has something for everyone.

It's extremely crowded during the weekend with people walking up and down the isles and seating space is so limited. You really have to walk with a purpose and get lucky with the seating. It's very overwhelming just the amount of people in such a congested space.

As for the food, I went to Flying Monkey to get dessert, you can't miss their stand as the stands awning is huge. I got the Elvis cupcake and the cookie dough brownie. Extremely good, especially the brownie. The brownie is great for anyone with a sweet tooth. The price wasn't bad as the cupcake was about 3 bucks and the brownie was about 4 bucks.

I like this market more then other markets such as such as Eataly in New York and Quincy Market in Boston. Eataly is all Italian related and Quincy Market just isn't as big.

It's been over a month since I've made it home, and I'm still having dreams about his spectacular market. Everything in Reading (pronounced Redding) Terminal is fantastic. I wish I had a market like this close to home. How many markets are there where multiple establishments make the food network and travel channel?

From breakfast to lunch to dinner, you could barely tear me away from this place when I was at a conference in downtown Philly. I may sell everything I own and just take up a warm spot next to the doors. People would bring me their leftovers, right? What more could I ever need?
Reading terminal has an abundance of choices. Fresh produce is quality and dirt cheap. The seafood and PA Dutch spots are always a tasty choice. It can get a little crowded but it is well worth it.

So many food choices! I was in heaven when I visited here. Lived in Philly all my life and just made it here recently. There's something for everyone here whether you want seafood so something sweet. There's take out food or you can eat in if you can find a seat. You can also shop here which is cool because mostly everything is local and fresh!
This place is the best for foodies. Tons of restaurants inside it. If you're visiting Philadelphia, this is a must visit. You won't be disappointed. Nice place to hang out on any day.
Visiting Philly looking for great eats best prices check out the market. From land to sea it's all here for your indulgence. Eat-up. Cheers
So fun! Everything I've ever had has been delicious. Little busy esp. on weekends but it's worth it.

A must when in philly. This place is always extremely crowded, which can be a pain...but well worth the visit. We come here to pick up coffee, veggies, and chicken for the week. I don't eat here often because I can't stand the lines (especially the donut lines), but there's clearly a reason why the lines are so long.... the food is delicious!!
Yum. So much food here, I cried a little on the inside. Some things worth getting. The Rotisserie chicken wings and the donuts. You will definitely leave happy after eating here.
A friend recommended me this place. The food options are spectacular. You'll find a organic fresh produce market, and various food stands ranging from Asian cuisine our soul food!
Lots of options for lunch.  I will bring a cooler next time for meat and seafood to bring home.
Very nice place to Visit. There are many nice shops here. We especially like the Amish market.
Great amount of choices. Great food. Regular folks of all ethnicities getting along famously. As it should be.

Love the hustle and bustle and the old world feel of so many vendors under one roof. The smells, the people watching, the variety of products and of course the amazing food make this an ideal place for lunch or to pick up some ingredients for a fresh dinner
What's not to love about this place. Many vendors, great produce, unique dining choices.

This market was pretty fun. There was a convention in town so the place was hella packed.  There wasn't as much stuff to buy as there was just food to eat, not a bad thing, just don't have too much expectations if you're looking to shop.  The lines were crazy long for anything remotely like a cheesesteak probably because this place is a bit of a tourist trap.  Anyway, I still enjoyed myself so 4 stars for sure.
This place has everything you could think of to eat.  All the stands are high quality and tasty.  I dont get there enough.

Very cool place. Went at not a great time (2pm) so it was pretty packed. Not many places to sit and felt like I was always in the way. But loved the assortment of places, would definitely like it more at a less busy time.

This place is amazing! We went to following:

Tootsie's Salad Express: Had the fried fish, fried chicken, mac and cheese and some potatoes. I thought the fish had the best taste, everything else was a little bland. Not my favorite in the market.

Flying Monkey: The plain whoopies pies were delicious! The pumpkin was a little too sweet for me. Also, lemon bars were yummy!

Mueller Chocolate Co.: My only regret is that I didn't get more chocolate. Had the almond bark and milk chocolate coconut, SO GOOD!!!

Yum! This massive food market is located conveniently near the Greyhound station, so it was quite easy to visit during my weekend trip to Philly. Tons of food, both prepared and not, there's something here for everyone - you just have to be willing to find (and wait) for it.

Seems like almost everything is solid, but I had to do some research anyways and ended up getting:
- Snickerdoodle cookie from 4th Street Cookie Company: So huge! I didn't like the rather crisp edges on the outside (prefer a nice, gooey cookie myself), but the middle was delicious.
- Smoked chicken wing from Dienner's: Love that they let me order just one, even though the guy looked at me weirdly. The wing was piping hot, and the meat juicy and tender with some delicious smokiness. Skin, as always, was the best part.
- Roast pork sandwich from DiNic's: After seeing all the hype over this sandwich, I have to say I was let down. Not that it wasn't good, just that it wasn't revelatory, which I'd expected. Definitely get the greens and provolone, lest you end up with just a pile of meat on bread (not that there's anything wrong with that...)
- Cannoli from Termini Bros: Oh my. I used to work in an Italian bakery that I'd thought had the best cannolis until I tasted this. Fresh to order so the shell stays crisp, and the filling is not too sweet.

Tips:
- Some vendors are cash only.
- A lot of places aren't open on Sundays (Dutch Eating Place, Beiler's, and Dienner's, to name a few). Definitely want to try the chicken pot pie and a Beiler's donut next time around.
- Place is super crowded, but we still had no problem getting a table at lunchtime on a weekend.
- Take a picture of the map located next to every entrance!
If you are heading to Philly, you have to check out Reading Terminal Market. Really cool experience!

This is foodie haven. I came here the day before the my Rock N Roll half marathon so my sister and I could "carb up". We started with Chinese food and ended with french crepes. Its foodie heaven, but often packed to the nines. Its best to come with a very small group and just accept the fact that you will probably have to share tables with someone. 

Overall, if you are looking to eat soul food, go there. Or if you just can't decide if you want ice cream or whoopie pies.

I don't know if this place deserves more than 3 or 4 stars. It's got a lot to pick from: food, souvenirs, and shopping - but it's crowded, loud and full of pushy and overzealous people. There was nowhere to sit after getting food (a small food court that was crowded and a pure trash infested wasteland) and it was confusing to maneuver around. There was no clear map anywhere and it was difficult remembering where we parked. Oh, and the parking. It would have been nice if it was clear in the parking deck how to get your parking validated. We had to go back inside the market after leaving to get the receipt validated by the merchant I bought a $15 coffee mug from. As a foodie and earthly tourist who has traveled all over, I can't say this is something I'd do again.

It's okay, many places to eat but not a lot of good one.. I really love the Hershel Pastrami sandwich and the Greek pork gyro, the sauce on the Greek gyro was amazing.. the halal wasn't so great, meat was very dry and the nunn was burnt.. overall it's a good place to begin in the morning since they close early then slow work your way outside of the city into China town and everywhere around it..

Bright Now Dental in Newtown PA scams you if you sign up for financing.  I've been scammed.  They damaged a tooth so I stopped using their services and they continued to take money out of my account after the services were paid in full.

This place is so cool. I love the variety and all the options. I got an iced mocha from Old City Coffee. I wish I had studied the menu just a bit longer before ordering because while they were making my drink I noticed a Hot Apple Cider on the menu. I also got a black and white cookie from Famous 4th Street Cookie Co. The ladies working there couldn't have been nicer. And that cookie was one of the best black and white cookies I've ever had. There is also plenty of seating if you get a meal. I grabbed a tuna sandwich from Hershel's East Side Deli. It was packed with tuna! O.K. Produce had plenty to offer, however I found it kind of funny that they were selling Driscoll berries (Californian berries aren't exactly local, but still pretty delicious). Blue Mountain Vineyard and Cellars provides wines for pretty much everyone's taste buds. They even offered me a couple sips of different wines before I made my choice and took a bottle home.
Unbelievable! I could spend hours there. Truly heaven for foodies and connoisseurs! I'll be back with a big bag and lots of money in my pocket.....

If you visiting Philly, go here. If you are a native of Philly go back. If you are stuck in jury duty, walk a few blocks and use your jury duty discount here. There are too many favorites to list, but I would not miss 1) Miller's soft pretzels. Watch them being made, get one hot, dab it with a little mustard. Nothing anywhere else compares, nothing even close. You will never buy a street pretzel or go to a chain pretzel place again. 2) Dinic's pork sandwich with greens. Beats a cheesesteak any day. 3) A chicken pot pie at the Dutch Eating Place. You won't have to travel to Lancaster County to get your Amish dining experience. If you are local shopping for a dinner party, I like Godshall's poultry, Downtown Cheese, and John Yi's fish market. This is a don't miss destination, one of the great urban markets in the U.S.

My wife and I visited Philly over the weekend and had a blast.  The one place we absolutely had to go to was the Reading Terminal Market.  We told our friends who we were visiting to take us there and give us the tour.  My friend is a mega foodie, so he knows exactly what to eat and when to go.  He made sure he told us it closed at 4pm, so that when I was inevitably running behind, he admitted it was actually closed at 6PM on Saturday...

There are a lot of people in this market, but its not so much where you cant comfortably move around.  There is action on every corner.  From restaurants, to bakeries, to candy stores...they have it all!  We made sure we had a delicious sandwich and we also had some famous donuts from a bakery who's line wrapped around multiple stores.

The only couple of things that bothered me, which are the reasons its not a 5 star is the prices are very high and it can be a battle to find a seat.  If you go alone or with another person your okay.  If you go as a group of 4, you may find it challenging.

I highly recommend coming here to anyone who goes to Philly!
Great selection, friendly people.  Fresh food at a good price!

I love this place; in fact, it is my favorite place to go in Philly! I love seeing all the different fruits, vegetables, meats, oils, spices, and more in raw form. You can find just about anything here, and the atmosphere is always fun! Most recently, we had breakfast at Molly Malloy's and it was absolutely delicious. The fun part about it (besides the location) was the restaurant used ingredients and products from surrounding vendors. For example, the bacon that I had came from Halteman's which was located adjacent to Molly Malloy's. I love indulging in all the candies, chocolates, cookies, and cakes! Bring the whole family as it is a fun-filled, tight marketplace where you can find just about anything.

It's extremely crowded but a fun experience.  You can find almost anything here.  I recommend breakfast at the Dutch Eatery and a cookie from the 4th street cookie co.  You can also get fresh produce, meat, cheese, spices, etc.
Such a rad place. For tourists and non- tourists, alike. I usually try 10 different things and have just a few bites of each! I come here each and every Philly trip-- well worth your time and money.
Great place for good food, there's great cheesesteaks, burgers, penn dutch, among others. highly recommended.

Add this to your Philly bucket list.  This place is AMAZING!!!  On my next trip I'm renting a hotel near this place so I can get there more easily.  The Reading Terminal Market is filled with foods of every variety.  Some awesome cheese steaks, fresh seafood, donuts, ice cream, candy and so much more.  Everything we ate was delicious.  

My only advice, come hungry.  Come very very hungry.

Foodie heaven. Walking into the market is highly overwhelming, as any foodie market tends to be. However, as a tourist this is an ideal place to go and explore.

No matter what food stand we went to, the lines were crazy long but they moved fairly quickly. We went to George's where they offered a variety of options for cheese steak lovers. One order of the sandwich with some additional toppings was about $11, not bad.

As we continued to explore I came across an all gluten free Indian/Pakistani Stand. I am not allergic to gluten but lately I've started to do some research and inform myself of what it means to become gluten free. So when I saw this stand I was so excited! It was so cool to see a such a unique option available. I went for the chicken wrap with mild sauce (sauce is not gluten free, but they were nice enough to notify me when I requested it). The wrap was about $8 and so delicious! It did not leave me extremely full but at the same time I wasn't left hungry, it was the perfect portion. 

Lastly, I had to have some dessert and went to Bassette's Ice Cream. I chose their cookies and cream shake which was yum! Other people had ordered shakes before me and had extravagant orders (with whipped cream, chocolate syrup etc), whereas mine was a simple shake. Nevertheless it was delicious. If you are ever in Philly make sure to stop here! There are so many options to choose from and you will not be disappointed.

I would be off the charts in giving stars! LOVE this place. Seriously. The amount of choices are insane - favorites are Termini Bros. for italian pastries that are to die for. Also DiNick's - the roasted pork sandwich is HUGE, a good price and tasty. I like sitting at the counter and eating amongst everyone else. Coffee...the seafood...smells....just an amazing must see experience!

An integral part of Philly - for tourists and residents alike. I love the fresh produce at the grocer and the Amish donuts! The stand w/ the beeswax candles and lip balm is also very reasonable w/ great products.

I love this place!  Definitely a go-to for visitors with it's convenient location next to Jefferson Station.  Even though it is typically crowded, the people and lines keep moving, making it less over-whelming.  I've tried a few places in the markt, including Hunger Burger's sausage, egg and cheese breakfast sandwich (top notch), Weckerly's ice cream sandwiches, Beyer's donuts, and one of the coffee joints.  Meltkraft is next on my list!

The Reading Terminal is like no other place you'll experience, not even in New York. While New York does have the Chelsea market, the two places couldn't be more different. The Chelsea market is filled with the pop-up shops, toy business ventures for rich people to throw money at that will charge you $4 for a salty donut. 

The Reading Terminal is cramped - so take your backpack off - and full of worldly delights. Want to go to the Far East? Go to Shanghai Gourmet. Want to go to the Lower East Side in the early 1900s? Go to Hershels - the Reuben and pastrami sandwiches are to die for (and better than Katz in NYC)! Want some donuts made fresh (most likely while you're waiting in hour-long line)? Go to Beilers! Want a godly pork sandwich? Go to DiNics! Once you taste it, you'll never think of pork the same way again. 

Come hungry and be prepared to wait for your food, but I promise you it is well worth the wait.
this place is a wanderlust for a variety foodie like myself.

My best advice that I could give anyone visiting the Reading Terminal Market would be to get there as early as possible, if not when the door are opening in order to truly be able to enjoy your experience here without feeling like a sardine in a can. 

I would say this is a must stop for anyone traveling to Philly and looking for some great food. There are so many pallet pleasing experiences here that even the pickiest eaters will be absolutely satisfied. 

I saw everything from freshly stuffed donuts, smoothie bars, crispy whole fried ducks (heads on), falafel stands, deli counters, grilled cheese storefronts, roast pork sandwiches, seafood stands, Mexican taco counter, chocolates and cakes made in every flavor imaginable you name it chances are the most likely have it. They also have an array of so many different ingredient stands from spices to meat and seafood stands they literally have everything.

My only complaint about the Reading Terminal Market is how cramped it gets in here so quickly and is almost chaotic not to mention the lack of seating to accommodate the hungry customer who I saw leaning over garbage cans at time for a surface to lean on and scarf down their food. They could use some more staff here in order to keep the eating areas tidy for the customers. I found myself wiping down my own table due to it being dirty from the previous people eating.
Fun shopping and a great selection of food choices from wonderful pastries, cookies and donuts to lunch and dinner fare. Best early.

Great place to go grocery shopping for produce. Quality is great and it is so much cheaper compared to the grocery/convenience stores around me. The fifteen minute walk from my apartment is definitely worth it. Not to mention they have meats, cheeses, chocolate, coffee. Good place to go for lunch. A lot of the lunch vendors have seating at their counters, plus there are several large areas with tables for eating. There is an ATM on premise, but if I'm not mistaken- all the vendors I've been to accept credit cards. There is always live music outdoors. The only drawback is that is it very crowded. I've definitely seen field trips come through. It is significantly less crowded right before it closes, but by this time a lot of the vendors have closed, so you just have to know that going in. Great place to go for those that have never been to a large market before.
A tad overwhelming for the visitor to philly. I imagine it can be a fun place if you have your favorites. Extremely busy at lunch as expected. Wish I had recommendations
This place is dank.  The only drawback is that it's too dank and gets a bit too crowded.   Any type of food,  drink, all with an authentic Philly as duck vibe.

I've been lucky enough to visit Reading Terminal Market for breakfast and lunch the last 4 days. It has the best variety of everything I've craved while my visit to Philly. It got really crowded in the market, but the different restaurants were super quick and kept their meals delicious.

So busy. So many choices. But it's a must experience when visiting Philly! I only had time to try one place - I don't remember the name but it was BBQ chicken. The chicken was pretty good and mac and cheese was even better! Entree + 2 sides was $9.75 comparable to most meals at Reading Terminal. 

Reading Terminal Market also has groceries, fresh fruits and veggies, deli meats, fish, cheese, etc. It gets super crowded during prime lunch time ~noon. The first time I ate lunch here was around 2-3 PM so it wasn't that crowded. I went the following day (Friday) around noon and the lines were soooo long. Didn't have time to wait so I couldn't try another booth :(

RTM definitely is a foodie paradise with dozens of stalls that are crowded at each instance I went. I could easily see New York's Chelsea Market and Essex Street Market or LA's Grand Central Market compared to this because of the vast array of food items. Because of its central location near Chinatown, the bus station, several SEPTA stations, the convention center, and many downtown attractions, it's very highly trafficked. But its vast size and sheer amount of options is dizzying. 

I definitely like the organization that it has. The market is divided by "avenues" and "streets," much like a New York street grid. It definitely helps to locate something if you know where to go. But for someone like me who has "food court dilemma," I could easily spend a half hour trying to navigate the market's different roads backed up by crowds and unsure what to get.

There's anything you can imagine. You can get fresh and raw honey, cheesesteaks, Chinese, Middle Eastern, bread, Pennsylvanian Dutch, deli meats, Mexican, etc. It's a true gem for dining around the world. Allow yourself some time to navigate and get acquainted with the market's layout.

There's also a live band that plays occasionally. Pretty cool!
Must see in philly. Lots of different food vendors mixed with a farmers market. Must try the Amish donuts!

There's sooooo many options here. It is like paradise. Come hungry, leave happy. Literally. This is a great tourist spot that my friend had taken me too. Side note: parking can be a little tough at times since it's a busy area. 

They have a variety of different foods and even desserts for you to fill yourself up on. It's a great experience so make sure to come with lots of money and an empty stomach. I didn't get to try everything here, but just know that there is something for everyone here! Definitely worth the trip if you're in the area !

There are 2 reasons why I fly to Philadelphia International Airport versus Newark Airport when going back East.

1. Cost: Savings of up to $100-200 per ticket 
2. Reading Terminal Market:

Definitely not one of the largest markets in the nation, but sometimes less is more. There are some "hot spots" that were featured on Man vs Food and the Travel Channel's named DiNic's Roast Pork and Beef "Best Sandwich in America" and Beiler's Bakery are my absolute favorite to dine at.

I can see why DiNic's sandwiches was honored that award. I had the roast beef with peppers, provolone, and broccoli rabe that was an excellent sandwich. This sandwich used simple ingredients with the right balance of flavor and the freshness that you can taste and see.

This market definitely made my criteria as one of my all time favorite markets to visit. Don't let the size fool you. It may be small but the cultural diversity of merchants, activities offered (check their calendar), and location in downtown Philadelphia puts this on top of my list. Chinatown is ONLY a walking distance away!

TIP: $4 parking fee for 2 hrs with $10 purchase and validation for a quick bite.
The Amish have the best wings ever! Craft beer is great too!

On my brief visit to Philadelphia this weekend, Reading Market was my homebase. It was my reference point when my internal compass failed, my shelter for when it was just too cold to walk and explore outside, and most importantly, my treasure cove of an incredible variety and expanse of more foods than my little brain could fathom. You can find anything and everything: the proclaimed best sandwich of the country, the freshest squeezed juices from locally grown fruits and vegetables, and amazing handmade donuts and other baked goods from the Pennsylvania Dutch (beware that their shops are closed on Sundays).  I think I discovered a new shop each time I visited in a corner I hadn't yet explored. Saturday was definitely the busiest and super packed of both locals and tourists; lots of human funnels in most, if not all the walkways between the maze of shops.  No words really are able to fully capture the unique experience of the Reading Market, and it's a great excuse to visit the city of Philadelphia, if the cheesesteaks do not convince you enough.

I know markets. I live in Cleveland and we have the West Side Market, for goodness sake!

Are there any Clevelanders reading this?  ::Looks around::  okay good. I am pained to say that the Reading Terminal Market BLOWS away the West Side Market and furthermore, any other market I've ever visited.

Now that I have that off my chest, let me tell you I was a kid in a candy store (Yes, don't worry they have a candy store). Any kind of product or food you could want is enclosed in this indoor market with over 100 vendors. High-quality, respected vendors in a beautiful space.

I didn't get to spend as much time here as I would have liked, but this is a must see for me in Philadelphia. It gets a little crowded, so plan accordingly and be patient, but it's so worth taking the time to navigate through the aisles to check everything out.

Yesss. All the foods.
So many choices that you can't show up here and not find something you want to eat. 
Not at all as pricey as all the high end food malls like we have in NYC.
Definitely a must visit while in town!
If you are looking an awesome food experience, this is a must visit when you are in Philly!  Once you go, you will want to return again and again.
Reading terminal has everything... best cheesesteaks in town, best espresso in town, best breakfast in town, produce, baked goods, Amish market, one of my favorite places to eat.
You can get whatever you're craving, and you can be pretty confident that it will be delicious. Definately worth a visit.

This place is a food lover's paradise. Coffee and chai (they make it with fresh spices and Assam tea)from Old Street Coffee was awesome. 
Belier doughnut had an unbelievable queue so they must be good. The Dutch place was super crowded and was quite cheap for the serving size (pancakes for $8 or so from memory). The cookies from 45th at cookie company were great too. 
I could just roam around and look at food stalls here all day haha. 
Apart from food, you can buy fresh produce, jewelry, kitchen stuff,  flowers and cookbooks. Street side parking said $4 for two hours.

Was so looking forward to coming here, but disappointed to see the scaffolding blocking the main sign. Weak! :(

Overall, it was just too crowded...
Love this place. Be sure to check out the spice shop in the back. The doughnuts are to die for.

Always a fan of big marketplaces--especially those all under one roof. I was there on a Sunday, so don't think it was as bustling, since not all stands were open. We sampled a tea stand and purveyors of cookies --got a black and white/ night and day (?) cookie that was awesome, as well as a little German type market that had lots of marzipan options, as well as many other items you won't find at most shops.There was one part of the market that appeared to be filled with locals, gathering raw items for some home-made recipe. There were a few chocolate stands. The bathrooms were clean.
A must visit for tourists and locals alike.  Top on my list of things to do for visitors.

They say Disneyland is the happiest place on earth, They would be wrong. RTM is the happiest place on earth, everything we tried was the best we've ever had. From the pizza to the ice cream to the sandwiches, everything was excellent. I foresee myself visiting there from Indiana a few times a year now that I have tried it.

This is a fun place to walk around, but it's way too many people when I came here. There are lines for most of the restaurants and no seats. There are so many restaurants that it's so hard to choose one (or two) because all foods look so good.
It's worth a visit if you haven't been here yet.

First time in Philly & our hotel was right across the street. The 1st thing we did after we checked in was to head to the market for late lunch/early dinner. 

It was definitely crowded - Black Friday at 4pm. Duh! But we were able to safely navigate with a 7&8 year old in tow. 

The variety is out of this world. I wish we had more time & stomach room to be here longer. As it was, we were there 4 days & ate there 3 of them! Seating is definitely an issue, but since our hotel was right there we took our food to go.

So much food! The sub shop has a special spread for their Italian subs that is amazing. The different meats you can buy here are great. Whenever I leave I usually take a load of cheeses and racks of ribs with me. It's always a treat when I can get here.

One of my favorite places in the city. Beiler's donuts are excellent and even if the line is long, it moves fast. I also love Dinic's for the roast pork sandwhich, always worth the trip. In general, one of the best places in the city to get a great lunch. Only downside is on the weekends it is crowded, but I've always found it was worth dealing with the crowd

What can you say about a place where you can get just about anything your heart desires (ok, except World Peace, but I'm sure this place comes close to it).

Come here for lunch.  Come here for dinner.  Pop in for some eggs before heading back home on SEPTA.  This place has everything.

Not my first time here, but finally got a review in.  Have had lunch.  Have had dinner.  Have eaten in as well as taken carry out.  It has my farm fresh cage free eggs as well as donuts.

Need I say more?

Love love love coming over here.  I have my go-to spots, which I will specifically write about, but this place as a whole: food extravaganza!  Oysters, burgers, chocolate, bread, fried scrapple, halel food, Greek food......everything.  

It is a little clausterphobic and crowded in here, seating is atrocious, and it is a little tiny bit touristy (that's being generous), but that won't stop me from meandering over here to catch a bite for lunch.  Come early though.....some of the best spots close at 3.
Love this place... crowded but so cool. And the smells and food are to die for! A must stop when in the city.

This is one of my favorite places of any city in the world! The concentration of such supreme food in one place is awesomely overwhelming. K. Parker has one of the best chicken wings in Philly. DiNic's roast pork is probably the best sandwich in the US. Peking Duck has a dumpling soup that will change your life. And Beiler's has the best donut you'll ever eat. And these spots are only a few in a massive market of top quality choices. Whenever I get visitors, I bring them to Reading Terminal and it just blows their minds.

A food flea market/farmers market which never loses its intrigue!
A must experience and return again and again.
So cool!! Has many small food stores located inside. My favorite has to be Carmen's cheesesteaks and hoagies!! Amazing taste!

Fantastic grocery and take-away selection. Definitely recommend heading here for meals if you're attending a conference at the convention center across the street. You can easily get a huge lunch to split with a friend for under 10$.

While a cheesesteak from By George! is the obvious choice, try out the schnitzel sandwich at Wursthaus, a pork sandwich with hot peppers from DiNic's, or a handmade kinish from Hershel's. 

Head's up that this place is CROWDED, so try to go a bit before the lunch rush if you want to get in and out quickly. Otherwise plan a 20 minute wait on line for the more popular restaurants.

WOW! Where to start? First, I've been coming here my whole life and it never lets me down. You want it, they have it. Bakeries, dairies, butchers, specialty grocers, seafood, restaurants...it goes on. You need to just go. There's nothing anyone can say here that will truly prepare you if you've never been. I never go without hitting DiNic's for THE best pork sammie in the world. Bassetts ice cream is always worth a stop. And I'm always sure to get a little something at Termini's bakery. A must see during the holidays. Be sure to take advantage of the $4 parking (with $10 purchase) if you drive.
I love taking out of town guests here--they love it and so do I. We've eaten at various spots over the years, bought fabulous meats and produce there, and picked up really special gifts.

HOPES COOKIES. Enough said. These are the best cookies in the market-- hidden in a little corner, but they are always soft, always rich, and always a winner. Don't miss this in the chaos of the market!

They have it all!!!! It's a one place stop and it is different.
Visit around any holiday and you will fall in love with this place
Favorite place to grab a quick lunch while in Philadelphia!  Live the Amish food and so many choices.   Tried the Peking Duck today with pork and bok choy and it was delicious!

As I was walking through the market, I had a permanent grin on my face.

So much of this reminded me of Chinese market stalls back in...China. The way each different stalls were separated. I absolutely loved it for nostalgic reasons as well as what was offered in the market.

Places I remember stopping in: the jerky place, the donut place, one of the places that offered pull pork. My stomach and cholesterol levels begged for mercy for as my 5 senses danced in delight.

My trip to Philly with friends was supposed to stop me at a few other places, but that idea went out the window when one of my friends said lets just stay here for the duration!

Terminal market, I'll be back with some milk pills to eat that ice cream. Soon. Real soon.

Excellent place for some excellent authentic Philadelphia anything! Lots of different choice goods food, drinks, and old school vibe. A little hard to get around in because it's easy to get lost. Other than that, great a place to visit! Also, it's very difficult to find from the convention center. There should be more signs.
Enjoyed the atmosphere, variety of vendors, selection of eateries, etc. Friendly place to visit and get a taste of the diverse culinary influences in Philly. Wish I had more time to explore.

I love going to this place.  Lots of variety in food and a good experience to treat visitors to.  But be aware that many of the stalls are closed on Sunday, so if you want the complete experience, with lots foods beyond the norm - like pickles, Pennsylvania Dutch Treats, etc., get there between Monday through Saturday.

I could not stop saying "wow" and "oh my gosh" to everything!! From the AMAZINGGG food/desserts to the various other vendors including candles, jams, cheeses and fresh produce- this place is AWESOME. I can't recommend it enough. So many places to eat and see!! I can't remember the names of these restaurants/vendors but you GOTTA Try the trainwreck sandwich- and the 3 meat platter (brisket, pastrami and corned beef). I could see myself visiting here very often if I lived here!! A must see in Philly!!!

A recommended must for visitors of Philly that like food. A big market, full of surprises and locations serving good food, as well as fresh produce and groceries, flower shops, bakeries, you name it...

I lived in Philadelphia for two years and this is by far my favorite part of the city. The market is extensive with dozens of food vendors and some craft items. My favorites include Beck's for their po boys, By Geroge for cheesesteaks, Sang Kee Peking Duck for peking duck spring rolls, and Beiler's for their apple fritters. You can spend hours in the market and find everything your stomach desires. I always brought visitors there and everyone loves it! I wish there was a reading terminal market in every city!
From the most delicious tender steamed dumplings to the roast pork and roast beef sandwiches the Reading Terminal Market has it all!!

Without a doubt my favorite spot in all of Philly (parking is meh, tho). But, the Dutch Eating Place (the apple dumpling is super cheap & tasty), coffee, oldie ice cream, and the old school oyster counter were my top spots. The next time I am in Philly, I will be making my way straight to this place!

I had a great time walking around the market with my friends! I'm originally from DC and frequent Union Market which is half the size of the RTM and I absolutely enjoyed all the food stalls! 
Also, as a chocolate lover it was really exciting to see all of the sweet and savory stalls with chocolates, cake, cookies and many more!
I truly enjoyed my time here and will definitely visit again in the future!
Nice place to walk around, great food selection. I thought prices were really good.

Things to know about the Reading Terminal: It is REAL, not some food mall or superstore. You may well see the business' owner or kids bagging up your turkey, or making your sandwich, or filleting your fish. You should go expecting to talk to strangers, to the people working the stalls and so on. It's no grab-and-go thing, it's an experience that is part of living and cooking.

It is sometimes really crowded, especially when big events are at the Convention Center, go early or late.  Don't drive if you can help it... bike, or use transit - SEPTA's Market East Station PATCO, and NJT will get you from nearly anywhere to the RTM. Bring your own tote bags or even a backpack! Granny carts can be tough, especially on the weekend. You might stash yours, then return to load it.

When you go, keep track of what merchants you visited... and always seek out new ones... if you don't you can end up not seeing the whole Reading Terminal Market.

Finally, before you go to Whole Foods, or some other mega market, make a shopping list and see how much you can get from this wonderful place... like Barcelona's famous Boqueria, the RTM is a treasure and we are lucky to live near it.

-- Michael McGettigan, director, Trophy Bikes PHL
I love the Reading Terminal for pretty much everything. I get most of my veggies from here. The $1 Grab bags are the best.

Lots and lots of options for good food. Wish I could have tried them all! I will say the mixture of smells from all the different restaurants and meat counters made me nauseous at times. The smells make it hard for me to want to go back.

Pros: The Reading Terminal Market, literally, has something for EVERYONE! RTM is like Cleveland's West Side Market on steroids. What I like the most about RTM is that, if you only have limited time in Philadelphia, you can get pretty much whatever you're looking for here. I very much enjoyed the concept that you can walk in any direction and find a dozen different fresh and prepared food options, chatchkes to buy, fresh fruit and vegetable vendors, and just a huge variety of general stuff to ogle. And, in case you don't have enough cash, there's plenty of ATMs around.

Cons: The low ceilings and over-abundance of hanging signs (with few way-finding signs) can make it difficult to navigate. I visited on a weekend day during the holiday season, so it was pretty chaotic anyway. This place can be packed - I mean body-to-body. You may have to wait in line no matter what you choose; and, you'll definitely have to stand around and wait for somewhere to sit and eat.

I look forward to visiting the RTM again, during the week and not during the holiday season!

Loved my experience at the RTM this past weekend! Visited for the first time with bunch of girlfriends in a quest to try and eat as much as we could and I think we did pretty well lol. It was a Sunday afternoon. There was live music and good amount of crowd. I immediately felt overwhelmed with all the food and people around me but the handy dandy map came to the rescue and we were able to navigate our way through. 
I have been to Dutch markets in Maryland areas with Amish booths and was hoping to experience it here since their food and products are AMAZING but we unfortunately came on a Sunday :(
Other downside was that Beilers bakery was closed as well. Not sure why but we couldn't try some of their pastries that they are known for. It was overall a good experience and I will definitely back again to try more things!

This place could use a good clean. There's an underlying bad scent in the place. Been here many times for lunch and have seen roaches in the seating area.
Also lose the tough attitude  - it's really off putting.
The best for everything!!  Highly recommend for a quick bite, grocery shopping or indulging in a sweet treat. This market will not disappoint.
The one place that looks a proper market. The city needs more of this kind.

I love reading terminal market! I've been going there for a while to get lunch on the weekends and it's always the first place I want to take guests who are visiting Philly. Lately, I've started buying more and more of my groceries - produce and meat mainly - there as it's super affordable and very convenient.

Various markets. Go for the steak sandwich at Carmen's. They're delicious and, personally, I think better than Pat's or Geno's. Also try a pork hoagie at DiNic's. Very unusual and, if you like roast pork, a definite treat.

Otherwise the place is very touristy and crowded compared to Washington's Eastern Market or Cleveland's West Side Market.

Always a great place to go for some good food! I always enjoy bringing tourists there for lunch, with all the different choices available. It can be hard to find seating, but with so many great choices, including DiNic's pork sandwiches and Sang Kee, it's hard to go wrong!
I love Reading Terminal market. They have great one off restaurants. You can always find something amazing there. They even have great chocolate at the Pennsylvanian market.

For a farmer's market in an urban location, it can't be beat.  A few boutique shoppes with unusual food related ingredients and gifts are fun to shop.  Overall, the Reading Terminal Market has what seems like over 100 fantastic stands to visit, from butchers shops to flower stands to coffee stands!  It is Philadelphia's most unusual grocery store!
LOVE. Get the Di Nic's Roast Pork "Italian Style" which is chopped fine with seasoning. No cheese. Amazing.

Spectacular. One of the best places to visit in philadelphia. You can get anything you could possibly imagine. Delicious prepared food for a quick lunch, or all the ingredients to cook the most elaborate thanksgiving mean.
They have it all from chicken wings to exotic fish. Great place to people watch taste test and enjoy the local fare. I stopped into the Cajun restaurant to have breakfast and it was really tasty.

If you visit Philly this place is a must see stop! This indoor food market has everything imaginable. There are tons and tons of food choices everywhere you turn. So much so that it is a bit overwhelming! 

Boyfriend and I stopped here to get a Philly Cheesesteak. The line was long but moved rather quickly.

If you come please don't expect to find seating. All the seats were completely hogged and one lady was saving 3 seats for herself yet we never saw anyone sit down next to her. That's the only downside of this place. They really should create more seating for customers!

This really is one of Philadelphia's greatest treasures, enjoyed by locals and tourists alike. Be sure to stop by DeNick's for the best sandwich you will ever have in your life, and then go across the market to the PA General Store. They will set you up with some treats at every price point. 

All the stores in between are a treat as well.

My friend and I love to treat ourselves to lunch at the Couch Tomato!  The food is always great and so is the friendly service.  The soup was amazing and the salad was scrumptious.  I honestly recommend it and look forward to my next meal there.
A lot of good places to check out. I also like to do my grocery shopping here. I try to avoid weekends because lines can get crazy and hard to move navigate around.

This is an amazing place- definitely a must-go-to when visiting Philly! It's basically one huge market with everything and anything you can think of. From their freshly baked donuts to seafood, this place is a foodie's dream come true at a reasonable cost too! 

Theres also street side parking available right next to the market, usually free if not then one or two blocks down... super convenient!

Really enjoyed experiencing this area of Philadelphia!

The food was amazing, the store fronts clean, the staff of each booth knowledgable. 

Since we visited on a slow day, we could get around easily. I've heard it gets so crowded you can't move around. We were very lucky to be there on a day we could really experience this wonder. 

I highly recommend putting this on your list for Philadelphia.
Good food at almost every store, not cheap though and avoid the lunch hour very busy but overall great experience

This is the most hectic place I've been to by far. Reading Terminal Market offers a wide selection of various foods ranging from ice cream, crepes, roast beef sandwiches, salads, and more. There are MULTIPLE restaurants and eateries inside the market itself, and it's impossible to try them all in one day. If you're ever visiting Philly, this is probably one of the most important foods spots to check out.

Local eats and fantastic quality all around. The RTM is very community-oriented and tons of shops and boutiques to select from. Dozens of favorites from DiNics to The Herbiary to Old City Coffee! Tons of history and within walking distance to most things

There are a few markets similar to this one in Southern California, but none of them compare to the bustle and variety of Reading Terminal Market! Parking can be a bit of a challenge in this area, so you might be better off taking public transportation, depending on how much you plan on buying.

There's vendors selling meat, bread, pies, coffee, candy, and so much more. If you're overwhelmed by crowds, you could probably spend hours here. I know I could! I was here more for sightseeing than running errands, but I enjoyed myself all the same. There are a few common seating tables if you're having a meal or just hanging out. Great place to feel the vibe of the Philadelphia community!

This massive food market is a must-visit for everyone!  With such a wide selection of foods, there is surely something for everyone.  There are so many stalls bustling with visitors, it's easy to get lost!  

Quick run down on the things I tried:
Beck's Cajun Café - fried mac and cheese: deliciously gooey onomnom
Tommy DiNic's - roast pork sandwich: line moves fast and worth the wait
Flying Monkey - butter cake: pure sugar bomb, don't get this

This is as Philly as it gets. To go to Reading Terminal is not a visit, it is an experience. I frequent this place and always take anyone who visits Philly to this unique Philly destination. Be it any weather it is always a hit. My fav restaurants are Kamal's, Beck's Cajun, the fish and chips place (I forget its name) and the ice cream place. I have also purchase fresh meat from there and it is darn good. Be careful not to get lost (I still get lost in that place after more than 10 visits) and make sure you check out the train exhibit.
Love Beiler's donuts and butter cake from Flying Monkey bakery. Also place with lobster mac and cheese is amazing. Always buy my cheese and crackers here too.

One of my all time favorite places to visit in Philadelphia.  When I lived there, I didn't realize what an awesome place Reading Terminal is.  All of the food places are great!  Their offerings are unique and I love the set up of the terminal as well.

Before I even get to the food I must say that this is a very interesting place to visit. Not only is there a smorgasbord of places to eat, but there are groceries and markets. You can get burgers, German food, Chinese food, Amish donuts and more. If you want variety in your food shopping this is a fun place to go.

I will say that this market can get uncomfortably crowded-especially on weekends. the hallways barely have enough space for all of the people trying to buy items and people shove into you. I would recommend going on a weekday or making your way over early.

I have yet to try all that they offer since it is much! The Amish donuts are excellent. Sometimes they come out tasting a bit like old fryer oil, but they are usually quite good. They offer an interesting and fun variety of flavors like creme brulee. 

The burger place in the main seating area is quite good as well. The fries are cooked and seasoned well. They make a thinner style burger patty that is juicy and also seasoned well. My husband and I din't have to wait long!

There is a large bakery area with excellent and reasonably priced bread. I decided to give their cupcakes a go. My husband and I shared basic vanilla and chocolate cupcakes. They were not very good and I wouldn't recommend them. They mainly tasted like shortening with a vague flavor of anything else, but were very dry. The bread items and chocolate are quite good however.

The groceries and the meat markets are good quality and local. The prices are decent and they serve the throngs of customers fairly quickly.

Next time I have to try a BBQ duck or a roast beef sandwich! There are so many new things to try in that one space.

This is the number one visited tourist spot in Philadelphia. Please do not let the word "tourist" deter you. There is every kind of food you can think of here and some you didn't. A few of my favorite spots:
-Hershel's, (or Uncle Hershel's as me and my siblings like to call it) stop here for the best reuben of your life.
-Beiler's donuts will make you a believer.
-Kamal's has the absolute best falafel I've ever tasted and amazing fresh juices and smoothies.
-a trip to reading terminal is not complete without a stop to Bassett's for some Philadelphia-style ice cream.

I could seriously write about this place all day. Take the train or bus if you don't want to deal with traffic and parking. If you park in the garage directly across the street with the big sign that tells you it's discounted if you get it validated inside, it's not lying. If you have a few people with you and don't mind driving in city traffic, it is definitely a bargain.

Another tip is on Sundays some of the vendors are closed due to religious beliefs, but a lot of the other good spots are opened and it is usually not quite as crowded as a Saturday.

I really enjoyed the atmosphere at this market. I can see why so many people rave about it. I think the range of food items here is good, but I've been to better markets in New York and Seattle that have outstanding food diversity. I went to this market hoping to be tantalized, but that wasn't the case. Some of the food options looked super dodgy, some some overpriced, and some just seemed so-so. I ended up leaving the market with some bananas and carrots. Maybe it was me, but given how much I love, love, love to eat food I surprised myself with my final food purchase. My one piece of advice for people going to the market for the first time would be to walk through the entire market first before selecting your food. Prices range wildly in there as does the quality. For example, my carrots and bananas would have cost over $3 at the vendor right next to the entryway, while another vendor only charged me $1.50. It pays to shop around in this market. Regardless of whether you love markets or not I would recommend entering the gauntlet and enjoying the experience. :)

Wow what an awesome place! My husband and our parents spent the better part of a cold afternoon hanging out inside the market. 2 of them staked a table while the rest of us wandered and brought back random philly treats. 
Shoofly pie, juices, pretzels, cranberry pecan chicken salad, turkey sandwich, you name it we had it. Also my dad had the best espresso he's had in a long time- and he is very picky about his espressos. 

I wish we weren't just visiting and could take home some fish or meats from one of the amazing fresh butchers. 

It's a great place to satisfy all tastes in your family and enjoy something so unique to Philadelphia!

Seriously one of the best places I visited while in Philly. It is truly a foodie's paradise. I can't really comment on the parking situation because thankfully we were staying at a hotel around the corner. The market is hectic in all the best ways yet efficient at the same time. Lines everywhere, but to my amazement they always went quickly. Food is literally in every corner. I had trouble narrowing my lunch destination to just one place. There was good food everywhere. My favorite had to have been Hershel's Deli. Every tourist needs to try that place.

Wish we had time to try Meltkraft!

Food choices are endless!!!  We spent time here wandering around on NYE.  Ended up having a great piece of pizza, but you name it, they have it.  Pastry, Greek, Chinese, German, PA Dutch, seafood, meat counters, the list goes on and on.  Easy parking across 12th Street.  Super close to Chinatown and a close walk to Liberty Bell.

Where do I even begin. This place is massive and packed. Brace yourself as you walk through the doors. 

The market has a lot to offer so you can grab a map when you walk in or wander and see where the road takes you. We stopped and tried a few stands as we were visiting and wanted to try everything. There's a polish stand inside that offered amazing head cheese. It's towards the 'picnic area' seating. I ordered a pork chop from this vendor as well. Delicious!

Make sure to try all the Dutch goods available. It's out of this world, the jerky vendor has some of the best jerky I've had in a while.

All in all, I loved it. Hopefully next time I stop by I won't be packed in like a sardine.
I enjoy coming to Reading Terminal Market.  Always nice people and fresh food.

One of the true gems of the city--my family has loved this mecca for generations.  What do you want, chocolate?  Cheese more your thing?  Oh, fresh produce? Artisanal culinary goods?  Shrimp the size of your hand?  Well, whatever you're searching for, they've got it...and it'll be the best you've ever had!
Variety of food, donuts hyped, I really did not like it that much. Try out the chicken, it's soft and tender.

I never thought I would see a place like that here in the U.S, it's amazing! However I have to consider a few things, first is the time they close, it's just ridiculous! I went there for dinner at 7pm expecting I would find it full of people and the doors were closed already! Also on Sunday only about half of the stores are opened (I believe many of the owners come from traditional places around PA) which I understand, but if they want to develop tourism they should really reconsider about all these things.

I love Reading terminal.  
There is a farmers Market as well as various cultural foods and vendor.
 Consider it a shopping paradise under one roof.

Parking is discounted with a receipt across the street on 12th street.

This is everything. 

This is Philadelphia.

Love it, you can find anything you want in here , my favorite corners are the chocolate stores , yummy 
Good for raining days , some places are over charging so keep your eyes open ;-)

I am not a tourist.... I grew up in Philly so Reading Terminal is apart of everything I love about this City.  It is one of the few places that has kept a good chunk of its traditions and maintained an artisan feel.

It is loud and ALWAYS busy!  There are so many delicious food smells that even if you just ate, it makes you hungry.  You can walk every aisle, then immediately walk it again and realize you missed something.  You cannot walk through without accidentally browsing. So this is definitely a multi-visit sort of place.  

And you do not and should not worry about parking.  No matter where you are staying in the city, there is a public transportation route that will get you to the Terminal for a minimal cost.  Trust that SEPTA (in this instance) is your friend... don't drive your gas guzzling SUV to buy Artisan breads made by the Amish.... that's just wrong on multiple levels.

Enjoy, enjoy , enjoy!

A plethora of food items to choose from in this food hall. You can have your dinner and dessert all in one place which I find very convenient. It's a very big touristy place to go to (which a tourist like me) had a good time at. I didn't get to try one of the vendors which had 'worlds oldest ice cream' but I'll make sure to go back and try it one day.
great place great food just not a fan of the location with so many homeless people and pissy smells.

What a great "food court" for the Convention Center!  I was here for WE16, and I ate at the RTM next door every chance I could get.  It's easy to find something delicious here, particularly with the information desk!  There's a map by the desk in case you're confused as to which door you came in and where the stall your searching for can be found.  There's a diverse mix of cuisines represented, so you're sure to find something for everyone.
The best market around fresh meats some reasonable prices etc.I love this market. Great place to shop.

Grew up in Philly, and nothing compares! As a little girl I frequented this place if we were around that part of town for a cheaper, and more diverse range of foods. Anyone can find something here!!! Well... maybe, it might be harder if you're vegan or allergy sensitive. Otherwise, I've gone into this place with groups of 15, to groups of 2, to only me! It's an adventure for the larger groups, and sometimes a hassle to find seating, but it's worth it. 

If you're on a date, both of you can decide whatever you want to eat. Finding a seat will be easier. Plus, it adds a little adventure into the date. Perfect for showing off the town, if you're into that sort of thing. It's a great pit stop for after ice skating at City Hall, or shopping.

If you're going solo then it's the time to explore. You can easily spend 30mins-1hour in there and not get bored. I usually do grocery shopping in here because their produce isn't outrageously priced, and they have a wide range because the vendors are from all over. I love getting "exotic" fruits. ("Exotic" meaning, not exotic to me but to the average American). On occasions they have dragonfruit, starfruit, lychee, rambutan, and even Asian mangos which I think are much better than the species common to the Americas. 

I love being in an atmosphere where there's a food craze! This is a great spot for shopping, gifts, flowers, honey, and lunch.

I like Reading Terminal Market every now and then.  It's a bit overwhelming the first visit and you tend to buy everything in sight.  After that, you know what you want--get in and get out.   It is a great place to take relatives for a visit in the city but if a local, I probably would never go there.   Good for the experience, you definitely want to go there at least once in your life.  Bucket list.

Come on man??  Really - we need a review of the Reading Terminal??  
Its one of the greatest places you can go on the planet.  PERIOD.  It is Philly and has the tastes of the surrounding countryside.  There is a cool little bar in there too.  Just love it.  need something for dinner, for lunch - You want great fishmongers?  You want great meat and sausage?  You want something Amish?  You want chocolates, fruit, a gift ??  
DONE, DONE, DONE.

For what it's worth, you can get absolutely delicious home-made style food from a variety of different vendors. 

I will say, I wish I would have known that some of the most renowned shops are closed on Sunday as per their religious tradition. If they kept open availability, I would probably give this 5 stars.
SO FUN!!! Perfect place to keep your eye busy with all the cool things, it's indoors, and no matter what your party size - you'll enjoy it!! Even by yourself

Reading market is a must see - but be prepared for crowds, a little chaos, and some long queues. The variety is great, but I'm not sure the many 'best in America' claims are really on the money. Highlights for me were the donuts, the grilled cheese, and the chocolates.

When I planned my weekend trip to Philly, I knew I had to go somewhere that was going to satisfy my foodie soul. I did some researching and came across this place. After reading reviews, I knew I just HAD to visit and laid out a list of all of the shops I was going to stop at. We came by on a Friday afternoon, around 1:00 pm and it was PACKED. It was insanely crowded. It was loud, crazy, busy, crowded and frankly, quite overwhelming. My boyfriend hated it- it was just so busy. And there wasn't a method to the madness, you just kind of had to walk into the crowd and try to figure out where to go from there. The complete and utter madness of the joint is why I deducted a star. I knew ahead of time that if you spent over $10 in the market and you saved your receipts, you could get parking for $4. Pretty awesome deal!

Here are the vendors that I purchased items from:

Termini Bros- Their cannolis are to die for. This is the second time that I've had them in my lifetime and I've never been able to find cannolis that I like better than these. What a delight. I HIGHLY recommend stopping here. 

Miller's Twist- After reading countless reviews raving about their pretzels with honey mustard- I had to try some. I am honestly not a big pretzel person (I know.. I'm a crazy person). I never order them at restaurants, never buy them for my house.. maybe it has something to do with the fact that I used to work at a german restaurant and ate them a lot there.. I don't know. Even though I don't love pretzels, I just HAD to try these ones after reading all of the reviews. WOW. They were literally, unbelievable. So tasty, so different, so fresh.. the best pretzel I have ever had. The honey mustard was so good and was the perfect pairing with the pretzel. I was blown away. 

Fair Food Farmstand- When I came across this adorable farm stand in the midst of the insanely busy reading terminal market, I was super excited. They had fresh & locally grown produce among other local goodies. I went for a Baba's pink lemonade kombucha, which I loved! I never saw that flavor before and it was really tasty and refreshing.

Bassetts Ice Cream-  I heard this place was a must try, so I headed here to try some yummy ice cream after devouring so many savory items at the market. I wanted to try a blackberry cheesecake but when I was informed they were out I went with the classic moose tracks, which is always a good choice. It was super good and hit the spot. 

By George! Pizza- YUM. They had sooo many yummy food items to choose from but I decided to try the eggplant pizza- a slice of it. Red sauce, cheesy with roasted eggplant - yummmm. It hit the spot after a long day of walking around the market.

Herbiary- What an awesome little shop! There were so many things to look at, lots of holistic oils and lotions and herbs among other things. I purchased two "dream balms" , one for me and one for my sister. I love it, it smells wonderful and is very relaxing. 

Overall-- I had a great time. Yes, it was insanely busy.. but for a foodie like me, it was totally worth it.

I do love this place.  I'm sure most will find it to be an expensive tourist trap but that's why I go.   The selection of food offered is insane.  No matter what you're in the mood for, you'll probably find it.  Everything from Mediterranean to Cajun to Italian to your classic Philly Cheesesteak.  
Lots of Amish food items, jams, jellies, honey etc.  not sure how authentic it is though.  I'm no expert on the Amish but the guy who sold me honey was in traditional Amish garb but was listening to music via iPhone with Bluetooth headphones.  You be the judge on that.  
Crowds can be overwhelming sometimes so be prepared for that.

A fabulous place with a lot of personality.  I have been to similar markets in major cities around the world.  Although I would not regard Reading Terminal as the BEST of these markets, it is still fabulous in its' own right.

I love this place! Their fresh produce is dirt cheap and super clean. I buy the majority of my groceries from the Reading Terminal on Sunday's and if you come with a student ID, you get an additional 10% off! They have the BEST olive oil with a zillion different flavors in a store called Tubby Olive; I'm obsessed. There's an old country diner that sells the best breakfast (catfish platter recommended) and the wait time isn't too bad. There's a delicious Cajun eatery called Beck's Cajun Cafe and their New Orleans themed food is to die for! I'm a huge fan of their fried oyster and shrimp poboys! You can even make them do 1/2 and 1/2, but be sure to ask for extra remoulade and hot sauce. I'm also a fan of the ice cream parlor near the entrance and the grilled cheese joint in the back will make you slap YO MAMA!

Great open air market with a multitude of shops and places to eat. If you are looking to buy food or food related items, this is a fun place in town. Can get crowded try to go during an off time. Sunday's the Amish places are closed (roughly 1/4 of the market)

Try- Dinic's pork sandwich. Get a chocolate organ (you can choose a heart, liver, etc.). Coffee place has so many options. Bieler's donuts are a must!

So many good options. I always go to Shanghai Kitchen for the best and most fresh Chinese food. My order is always done in 5 minutes or less and I have yet to find anything nearly as good anywhere else in the city

Wow... This place is amazing!!!  I was visiting Philly and I came here on a Saturday afternoon with a friend.  It was completely packed! So many choices for food and desserts.  I enjoyed visiting the market to grab a quick bite,  but it was hard maneuvering through this crowded place.
I love this place. Lots of specialized foodie shops, great produce; fun and interesting shops that sell books, textiles, flowers, etc. Go any day except Sunday, when the Amish vendors are in church.
Always busy. Good selections and variety. A favorite of mine for people who are visiting Philadelphia.

This is a Philly institution, and for good reason.  The variety of foods, the busy atmosphere, the history--definitely worth a visit.  My favorites include the Amish pretzels and cheesecake, sweet Lebanon bologna sandwiches, and the cinnamon ice cream at Bassett's!
My favorite place in Philly! There is nothing like it outside of Europe. Wonderful places to eat and buy groceries. It's a foodie's paradise.

What an amazing place. Reading Terminal Market is similar to Atlanta's Sweet Auburn Curb Market (which I adore) but on steroids. I'm not as well-traveled as some of my fellow Yelpers, who have compared RTM to other big cities' markets, but of those that I have experienced, I am just head-over-heels for Philly's huge market, full of incredible food stalls and shops.

AT and I came here with Min Y. during our visit of that crazy dude (who gifted me a book for Christmas called "Womanskills: Everything You Need to Know to Impress Everyone" [dude, I know that books shouldn't be wrapped in quotations, but should be bolded or underlined, both of which I cannot do in a Yelp review]). I knew I wanted to hit up Termini Brothers for some cannoli but as AT and I wandered around, our eyes just grew and grew. Yeah, I'm Vietnamese and my eyes probably can't grow much bigger than they are, but you know what the hell I mean. Anyway, we grabbed some coffee from Old City Coffee and hovered in the Beiler's Bakery/Beiler's Donuts and Salads corner, where the lines were massive. I just enjoyed watching the Pennsylvania Dutch bakery folks doing their magic but Min is impatient as a mofo, we figured the wait wasn't worth raising his blood pressure (hahaha, if you're reading this, Min!!).

I grabbed my cannoli and we mostly just looked around. Next time we are in the City of Brotherly Love, when Min will lovingly take us to see Liberty Bell, his absolute favorite landmark in Philadelphia, I'll make him take me back to Reading Terminal Market for some grub. Not because I'm not capable of finding my own way but because I enjoy pestering the hell out of him. Because he gave me Womanskills.

[#Yelp365: 24/365)

How can you go wrong with like 100 places to eat from? Ice cream, fresh doughnuts, Philly cheesesteak sandwiches, gyros, it's all here. Only bad thing is that they close at like 6pm.
