Must run here after work! This is a definite must-do while in town. You could spend a few hours shopping for soaps and flowers, or bellying up to a variety of food counters. Love this place.

What a zoo!  But I loved it!  Mostly... I wish we had had a chance to spend more time there because we came around lunchtime and there were hordes of people everywhere.  It would have been nice to check it out when it wasn't so crazy.  Similar to the Chicago French Market (on claustrophobia-inducing steroids), there were a variety of stalls with miscellaneous tantalizing food options.

We of course had to try the cheesesteaks, which I have to admit were subpar.  Maybe I just don't understand the Philly way, but I have had significantly better sandwiches called a cheesesteak outside of Philadelphia.  And the workers at the stall were about as friendly as robots... who hate you.  But that's okay, it's just a sandwich.  

Because it was lunchtime it was almost impossible to find a seat, but we finally found a table squashed uncomfortably between two other tables.  The whole place also could use a good scrubbing.

My biggest regret is not indulging in the drool worthy desserts at the Flying Monkey Bakery, but at least now I have a good reason to go back!
Reading terminal is always crowded. The food is fresh, the people are from different places. The environment is awesome.
Great place to check out if your visiting the Philly area.  Lots to explore and great fun to try.  Will definitely come again.

Philadelphia always offers exceptional experiences. 
I love going to farmer market, so there is no way that I could miss my chance to visit the renown Reading Terminal Market. It turned out to be one of the most lovable place I've been to in Philly. I went "wow" when I stepped inside because how large and crowded it was. I am a small town girl, so it was the biggest market I've been to. 
They have so much delicious food and beautiful crafts and arts. The vendors are incredibly approachable; I still regret to not having tried the famous donuts place because they had a long waiting line. Anyhow, I enjoy some beef jerky and delicious meal (at a vendor I can't remember). I also got some fresh vegetable and grapes to go. I wish I could spend more time there.
Best place for food in Philadelphia!   Whatever u want it's here.  Always get gluten free things to take to wife when here

This place is a must for visitors.   The perfect Philly spot.

You can get everything you can imagine (except furniture..lol).   Ice cream, jams, honey, jelly, cheesecakes, gazillion bakery items, pastrami, donuts, chocolate...list goes on and on.

There is no way you can say you are hungry if you're in this place.  So many choices.

Prepared foods and fresh food is all over this market.

It gets packed on a Saturday and hard to walk.... They are open on Sundays but many of the vendors are not.  

I love coming here.  The only draw back is seating is at a premium and the restrooms are blah.

Will I be back?   Definitely.
I came here before moving to Philly and loved the place. Every restaurant is good, some are great, like Hershel's. In my opinion the best option in Redding terminal.
This place is legendary and one of a kind. For those of you visiting Philadelphia, I highly recommend visiting this Philly landmark, which is walking distance from our beautiful city hall building.

First time at the Reading Terminal Market. It was soooo crowded yesterday afternoon! Not sure if Sunday afternoons are always like that or if it was just because there was an event at the convention center across the street. Lots of stores seemed to be closed and it was partially under construction. The market is basically Pittsburgh's entire Strip District compiled in one room in the same building. Upside: don't have to walk far to get everything you want. Downside: limited space, crowds, long lines, slightly hard to navigate.

I had pre-picked a few options to try. Unfortunately, most of them had such long lines, it would have taken 20 minutes just to order. I ended up going to Beck's Cajun and The Thai Market. Both had relatively short lines and were very tasty. After ordering, finding a table proved to be the most difficult part. There is limited seating and it seemed most were being occupied by people who weren't even eating (irritating). We tried to eat at a small vacant counter near a bakery and they asked us to move for sanitation reasons. We eventually found a seat, but it was not an easy task.

It's a really cool market. I've been to some similar set-ups that aren't as crowded and really love them. I definitely want to come back at a time when it's less crowded to get the full Reading Terminal Market experience.

What's not to love about Reading Terminal!? All the major food groups in one place: cheesesteaks/hoagies/all other sandwiches, rotisserie chicken, pizza, salads, Asian, baked goods, beer, candy and ice cream! Of course it's ridiculously crowded, what of the greatest eateries in the country isn't? RT is a mainstay of locals, and an absolute necessity for visitors.

Organized very intelligently. There are obvious sections throughout the entire market making it a joy to stroll through. You will suddenly find yourself in the honey and handcrafted soaps section, or the eye poppingly fresh produce section. Everything here seems fresh and local. The prices are affordable and each vendor is willing to tell you about their wares. I saw the coolest mushroom stand here, with more species than I've ever seen in my life. My friend and I bought some gifts for our friends back home since we were travelling in Philly.
One of my favorite places to go in the city! Plus I do my grocery shopping here. Great prices on Meat and Produce

A thorough review of reading terminal would probably take ages. So Im going to keep it brief on this one. Reading Terminal is a Philadelphia landmark, if you eat food, you should definitely check it out. You will be entranced by the plethora of produce, shops, mini-restaurants and general awesome ambiance. This place is pure joy.

If you are sight seeing in Philly this is a must go to!! It is huge and has everything from fresh produce to buy and cook yourself to tons of different places to get cooked meals. My boyfriend and I ate at a small place with Philly cheesesteaks! It was so good!! There is every type of food joint there you can think of though so the whole family or group can enjoy something different. There are plenty of places to pick up dessert as well!

A must go to when in downtown Philadelphia. DiNics has a special place in my heart here however why stop there? So many varieties for made to order food and grocery stores for any taste. Whether you crazing seafood, pastries, a sandwich, or just a quick snack you'll be sure to find it here.

It was not the best butternut squash soup I've ever had, HOWEVER; it IS the best grilled cheese I've ever had!!! The grilled cheese, the draft beer selection, the service and the location are enough to overcome the average, but still good soup for a rare five star rating from uppity me!!
One of those great spots frequented by locals and tourists.   Not a tourist trap. The locals eat and shop here!!

Definitely a staple of philly. In prime location and has a little bit of everything to try. It's really busy and you're going to be bumping into people but that just comes with the territory. A must go if you're visiting philly.
ex, c xccxx xczcxc crevices x cXXxx,cxxxcxxfccxcxzcxcxx xsx,xzxxvxczcZxzczxxdcxxccxxccSCvfx cx c c
PHENOMENAL!!! You can spend days in there. Buy the best and fresh products. Eat delicious EVERYTHING.

The equivalent of walking down fifth avenue for my wife. Or is it park avenue. Whichever one it is with all the ships in nyc. 
This place is a foodies paradise. Especially go for the Amish bakeries along the north and northwestern parts of the market. Beilers bakery and adjacent Amish stores are the gems of this place. But they're only open certain days of the week so check beforehand. 
Other shops are good to and you can certainly spend half a day in here without exploring everything. 
There are also non food markets here. 
Tourists flock here by the droves so be prepared. But well worth it!

Not much to add about the Reading Terminal Market with over 3,000 Yelp reviews but it still is a must stop for anyone visiting Philadelphia. My father used to bring my brother and myself there when we were kids in the late 60's and early 70's. I remember all the butchers and only a few restaurants and saw dust on the floors.  He would treat us to Bassets ice cream. We used to always get our turkeys from Moyers and once borrowed their large Phillies banner to take to Shea stadium when the Phillies played the Mets (my Uncle lived in Queens). The building's history can be felt when walking around.

The Reading Terminal Market has evolved and now has a lot more eating establishments. Yes it is touristy, but it still remains a really cool place. It does get crowded but that is part of the charm. There is something to eat for everyone and deciding what to choose or finding seating might be difficult, but the experience and diversity of food is worth it. Tommy DeNic's and Beiler's Bakery are probably the most popular and naturally the most crowded. There are so many other establishments worth trying and the market is something that is uniquely Philadelphia. I just wish I could go back in time and be there again with my parents.

I love eating at the Reading Terminal Market. I usually go here on Sundays when friends come to visit. Worth noting that it does close pretty early on Sundays, around 5PM, so don't plan on dinner here. It's open later most other days. It's a good lunch spot.
Best place for lunch and shopping in Philly hands down! I especially love the Amish bakery and butcher stalls.
Amazing market, anything you would like under one giant roof.  Quality goods and a real Philly gem.  A must see!

I LOVE THIS PLACE!!! A must-see/visit when in Philly!! Countless options for food, shopping and drinks. I could have stayed in here for hours just looking at all the different stands, seeing the people and deciding what to eat next.

My friend and I stopped at a Greek place, and got the gyro. Such a classic and they did not disappoint, the staff was very authentic and friendly. The food came out fast and you could see & taste how fresh it was.

I could come back here everyday and try something new!!

I go to Philly just so I can spend everyday eating at The Redding Terminal Market.  The place is huge and offers everything your stomach may fancy.  From succulent duck to ribs to the best pork sandwich ever, the (must get the)cheese sandwich to fresh fruits and veggies to desserts.  You want Italian? You got it! You want to gorge on fresh just made doughnuts? absolutely!  You're craving Indian or how about some turkey for lunch? Gobble Gobble, Nom Nom! Having a dinner party and you need some fresh seafood and quality meats?  Don't fret.  Want to have the fluffiest pancakes and omelettes? The Dutch Eating is a must!  Green juices galore! Thai noodle heaven! Deli delights! Desserts! Candy! Even skincare.  It's awesome and cheap!  Did I mention AWESOME and CHEAP?

This is Reading Market...doesn't get better than this historic place. Choices, choices, choices...all tasty, and I have never had anything but great service from all vendors. 
A must when in Philadelphia. I am lucky to live close by....and shop here frequently.

I think that everybody should visit this place. Great food, beer, etc.Great prices too.
I am always amazed when I visit this place. Additionally there are tons of other places to visit nearby such as Chinatown. If visiting from out of town, there is a huge Marriott across the street from the market.

Bottom Line:  A clean market that offeres a variety of foods and a great experience. 

If you've played Monopoly you've probably heard of the Reading Railroad.  In the late 1890s the Reading Terminal was built and used as a passenger train station and train depot.  But by the 1980s the building was no longer effective as a train terminal so the site was eventually repurposed, in part for the well-liked foodie market.  

Reading Terminal Market has over 100 vendors.  Some vendors are selling prepared foods while other are selling groceries, specialty items and gifts.  Meat, seafood, cheese, vegetables, chocolate and other goodies are plentiful here.  This place is a cacophony of sights, sounds and smells.  As a first timer I enjoyed methodically weaving my way through the market checking out all of the stalls.  Unfortunately I was there on a Sunday, a day that the Amish vendors do not participate in the market.  Other than grabbing some lunch I didn't buy anything but I would love to come back to try Bassett's Ice Cream, DiNic's and Molly Malloy's.

Wonderful adventure with my daughter. 

I highly recommend experiencing the sights, sounds, and foods
Whether you live in or around the city or you're just visiting, reading terminal is for all and is always great. Numerous markets and countless food options. Almost always packed but worth the wait.

Great fun place with lots to see, buy and eat.  Just love the atmosphere and always take friends from out-of-town.  Some decent Thai for lunch, Mexican, and good variety of cheeses at various vendors (Downtown Cheese, if they are still around).  Can be a bit overwhelming on a Saturday with little elbow-room to maneuver.  Some pretty good deals on produce if you shop carefully and look for the deals.  Some overpriced stuff, too.  Nice potpourri of many of Philadelphia's small food vendors all under one roof!  If I ever moved away from Philadelphia, this is something I would always remember and definitely miss.
Seriously, if you can't find something amazing to eat here, your tastebuds are broken. And the apple dumplings at the Amish place? Get out of town.

Beyond obsessed with this place. Whatever taste or kind of food you're looking for, you can definitely find it here. It is not only all affordable but also all incredibly delicious. I've never had a bad meal here ever and I've been eating and shopping here for years!
I like a lot of the things here but hate being surrounded by disoriented families from the suburbs.

Reading Terminal is a Quincy Market that had a thousand babies for those Bostonians out there.  There are butchers, bakers, specialty foods and international delicatessens.  The entire bazaar is indoors and would take a couple of hours if one were to appreciate all it had to offer.  There is at least one dining area in the terminal for shoppers.  A great place for people watching, grocery shopping or going for a meal.  Definitely worth the time if you are visiting the area.

It's a good thing I don't live in Philly. The intense Mets fandom might not help, but what I'm really talking about is the Reading Terminal Market. If I lived within a reasonable distance there's no telling how much I might weigh. Basically, what I'm trying to say is go to the Reading Terminal and try not to eat yourself silly.

It's right there in the middle of the city and has been for quite some time. Last Sunday showed some construction being done to the exterior so the classic blue and red lit up sign was a little covered. No worries, the food is still flowing inside.

Now don't get me wrong, I'm from New York and we have our own food-filled market in Chelsea. And when thinking of markets, Quincy up in Boston deserves a mention as well. There's plenty all over that do. But the variety of edible amazingness at RTM is almost unparalleled. 

Enter and pick a direction to go. Some might stumble upon original and old school spots like Bassett's Ice Cream and Godshall's Poultry, or perhaps DiNic's (personal favorite) and Spataro's which have your beefy Philly staples ready to go. I seriously can't dive into everything in this market, but here's a quick food-type list of what you'll find just by walking around: Delis, coffee, BBQ, ethnic food, cheeses, condiments, chocolate, bakeries, seafood, wine, donuts, burgers, salads, teas, a buffet, plenty of fresh produce, and dodo bird eggs (okay maybe not that last one). Don't forget to stop in the PA general store or one of the book spots for something to remember your experience (besides your food baby). 

Once you make your mostly edible purchases, if you'll be eating them immediately, there's plenty of seating areas scattered throughout. It's easy to stay and explore, but leave within two hours and you can get your parking ticket validated (as long as you spend 10 bucks in RTM, an easy feat). You'll then pay a great price of only $4. They want your business, and you should give it to them!

Overall, the Reading Terminal Market is worthy of a visit in Philly just as much if not more than the Liberty Bell. Yep, I went there. So go forth and eat something! You won't be disappointed, because the Terminal will grab hold of your senses and you'll see, hear, smell, touch, and definitely taste exactly what I'm talking about. Thanks for the food, Philly.
Food selection is bountiful. Gets a bit crowded which sorta adds to its appeal. All casual selections
This is a great place to explore all things tasty. It felt welcoming and appetizing. There's so many places to check out. I enjoyed my experience here.

This is a foodie's HEAVEN! I repeat HEAVEN!
Fresh ingredients all around making everything taste a 100 times more delicious.

If you're not carb cutting, I say got get yourself a pork sandwich with broccoli rabe and extra sharp provolone from DINICS! This way, while you're waiting on line for BEILLER'S doughnuts, you have something to munch on! Their line can get pretty long, so avoid the crankiness and get yourself a sandwich! By the time you get to the front of their line you'll be in better shape to start pointing your fingers at all the yummy-goodness! I personally enjoyed the maple-bacon, apple fritter, and the cinnamon roll. IF YOU'RE GOING TO LISTEN TO ANYTHING ON THIS REVIEW... LISTEN TO THIS... Get yourself a DOZEN!

Love this place! There's a donut shop there that makes the best donuts. You'll know it from the mile long line if you go on a Saturday.  I highly recommend visiting on a weekday, if you have the option.

Reading Terminal Market is amazing. You can enjoy any food imaginable. From a greasy hometown cheesestake to a cleansing fruit smoothie. Don't take a loaded wallet because you'll end up spending it all. There is so much to experience at reading terminal and I'll be back soon enough.
You can practically move in here and not want for anything. This is a lively market and wonderful place to eat. Tons of choices. Great ice cream. Ambience is crowded and busy. Go!

Reading Terminal market has the best value for quick food in Philly.  There are so many options from grilled cheeses and cheese steaks, to ice cream and smoothies.  It is the perfect location for a large group that cannot decide on what they are in the mood for. 

The deli's make fantastic sandwiches, Meltkraft has the best grilled cheeses around, and there a handful of ice cream and fruit smoothie joints to choose from.  Not only do they have classic American food, but they have restaurants providing dishes from around the world.  Indian, German, Greek, and several Asian cuisines are all represented; just to name a few.  

The only thing that's a little tricky and can be a pain is the limited amount of seating. It is set up in a fashion with vendors down a line and winding all over the area, with the tables all clustered in the middle.  Usually there is a wait for seating, so I would advise standing if it is at all possible.  Besides this I love the variety and the option to chow down on whatever I'm in the mood for!

A little touristy, but plenty of gems in this market. I highly recommend the roast beef with sharp provolone & broccoli rabe. The roast beef was juicier, more flavorful & cheaper than the brisket. We were really excited to try the Italian sausage, but we went late (2pm) to avoid the madness at lunch time & they'd run out of meatballs & sausage, so it may be a little tricky to find the sweet spot between wading through the market chaos & being able to order whatever you want. 
We had breakfast at Pearl's one day- great waffles & a good value for breakfast.
We sampled 6 different doughnuts from Beiler's one afternoon when the line was reasonable. They were all good, the texture & flavor were excellent, but a bit sweet for my taste. Next time I think I'll go to their bakery right across the aisle & get a piece of mega-crumb cake or pecan sticky bun.

OMG this was one of the highlights of our quick getaway to Philly. We ate at Becks and scarfed down a fried oyster platter that had delusions fried potatoes with jalapeños and cornbread. Then my husband got something called the heartbreaker? Or something?? Or maybe that's what it DOEs to your heart - it was pastrami, salami and cheese god knows what on a roll. Tasty but greasy as hell Next we topped it all off at Bassett's Ice Cream which was soooo good- creamy and not too sweet.

We decided to come here because the Mr. just had to try the roast pork sandwhich from dinic's he saw on the food channel man vs. Food. One word.... heavenly!! The roast pork with provolone and broccoli rabe had my taste buds doing a dance!! A 100% must try wheb you are there. There is so much different places to eat with many varieties for any kinda food lover. From coffee to an oyster bar to halal food and steaks! Beer and ice creams! Chocolate and cannolis. Seriously a foodie heaven!! Plus the different types of mini shops you can find some cool and quirky finds. For our first time there we loved it. Dont be alarmed if you have to walk a bit to find a ppace to sit. But trust me ypu will find a place and many more cool thibhs in literally every corner! And there is a parking garage across the street. I do recommend taking your ticket and getting it validated! You will save about $20 on parking if you eat somewhere there and spend $10+. Other than that I highly recommend this is a must when visiting Philadelphia!!
Great place with so many little hidden gems! There is a huge selections of different foods to try and everything is pretty reasonably priced.

Almost a year later, we came back.  During lunch found duck lo mein at one of the chinese restaurants which was tasty. Considered coming here for dinner as well, but even on a friday they close early. Good thing Chinatown is just a couple of blocks away. But definitely still love the variety of options. We love our food halls in NYC, so not hard to love this place.

The place is a heaven for the food tasting. So many vendors and so much food! Love it! I tried only the smoothie because everywhere were long lines (Sunday afternoon), I wanna definitely to come back !
Great place to get meat, lunch, ice cream, coffee, fresh juice, flowers ... And very crowded on weekends lol

Favorite lunch spot in Philly. Bueller's donuts are AMAZING. Love Hunger Burger. So many different vendors, I never get the same thing twice. Seats at the tables in the middle can be hard to snag. Tend to bring any out of Towner's through here for greasy hangover food.
Super crowded on the weekends, but still a wonderful place. Great for locals and tourists alike. Ive been in philly 10 years and shop here for meat, produce, spices, and tea regularly.

This is a tourist destination that everyone visiting Philadelphia should go to. 

This is an affordable and diverse market that everyone living in Philadelphia should at least visit once.

This is one of the best collections of small casual restaurants I have ever seen. I sometimes feel sad when I visit that I can only eat one lunch per day.

This is as it appears on TV. Everything is true.

FOOD! Any place that has a variety of foods to eat is 5 stars for me. This was the last stop for us on our mini road trip. Shout out to the lovely gentleman that gave me his parking ticket with 25 mins left on it. Since we weren't sure what to expect we just walked around and looked at all the delicious food. There is something for everyone with so many different types of foods and goods to buy. We weren't really hungry so we just got smoothies at the juice bar and they were delicious. I could see us driving 2 hours on a Saturday to come back and get some. I can't wait to come back with an appetite and try some other things.

This is a must stop on any trip to Philly. More food options than you can eat. We chose DiNic's. We chose wisely. So good. 

It's almost overwhelming how many options there are. We had an awesome cannoli as well. There was a huge line for donuts which we opted not to get in. But I kind of regret. Something for everyone.

My favorite place to visit when in Philly! Such a diverse market with tons of great finds! Not to mention a great selection of food joints! 

Upon entering, the aroma of different foods instantly strikes up your appetite! 

The market is conveniently located in city center near the convention center! 

Definitely on my top list of favorite places!

First time going and it was a pleasant surprise. The sheer amount of choices should be enough to keep anyone happy. My group had Chicken Curry, Pickles, Pretzels, and Gyro as well as farm fresh honey in the comb and everything was delicious. Excellent taxi coverage in the area too.

This is an indoor food market with tons of great food options. This was our second time here. Both times we had great food. The place is small and the lines can get long. Go hungry, but give yourself time to walk around and decide what you want to eat. The aisles are small so walking is tight. There is a parking garage across the street on the north side that if you spend $10 at a vendor they can validate your parking and it's only $4 for two hours. Everything looks so good it's hard to choose what to eat.

I find Reading terminal to be a crowded trap that sees you wait in line most of the time. 

Lots of options but the crowds make it a no go for me. No sense in waiting in line for 30 minutes thee are plenty of city restaurants better than wasting time in reading terminal.

What a great place for locals and tourists alike. The sheer amount of food options you have will leave you astounded. There are a bunch of different gems you have to try - Beck's Cajun, Hershel's Deli, Beiller's Donuts, freshly squeezed OJ from Iovine Bros... those are my personal favorites. It's definitely a spot to hit if you're indecisive (like me!).

We try to stop at the local downtown markets when traveling. It is one of our favorite things to do. This particular market was very busy and filled with a variety of local favorites to enjoy We enjoyed walking around and sampling some of the foods. There is a large seating area in the center of the marketplace.; good luck getting a seat.  DiNics was very tasty and Termini bakery was fabulous! The Almond pastry and Pecan Caramel Bar were incredible. Both could be addicting, so I'm glad we don't live close enough to indulge frequently, but I will be dreaming about both of those for awhile! The only disappointment was that we visited on a Sunday and many booths were closed. I would think weekends would be one of the busier times for them.

Also,we encountered several beggars both inside and outside of the market. Then we later saw them on cell phones eating at the food court with others. There should be some added security to prevent this from happening to patrons shopping. 

TIP -  the parking lot across the street offered a discounted parking pass for $4 for 2 hours with a validated purchase from the market.

They make their own nutella syrup here folks. HELLO? Bomb. I go there everyday during my lunch break, and they know my drink. No fuss. La Colombe coffee and cool staff, but not like the whole hipster thing, just nice, nice people. Smoothies, food, baked food excellent and they have gluten-free stuff for those of you who partake.  I am not a big studier with Wifi (never, at all, not in my stage of my career) so if you are concerned, I just don't know. Ambience is not a concern for me, but it's modern, clean but groovy. Suits my needs, good peeps and products, and 5 stars all the way if you are in the the drexel/west philly/near the bridge area

Well, I'm probably digging myself a hole straight to the depths of Yelp hell, but the Reading Terminal Market is overrated. Maybe I don't appreciate what RTM has to offer... maybe I had this grandiose idea of what the place would be like in my head... maybe I just suck. Who knows. 

Too many people. Tight walkways. Lines wrapped around booths so you have know no idea where they start and where they end. No concept of walking on the right. Dirty bathrooms. Rude bathroom attendant. Eating areas are cramped. Meh. 

Hate all you want on the city of Cleveland, but they have the West Side Market. I imagined that the RTM would be similar, but man was I wrong. The West Side Market has high ceilings and a more open feel to it. Feels less congested and easier to navigate. Sorry Reading, but I'll take the West Side Market any day over your hot mess.

I can say that this place is cheap in regards to produce, has great random products throughout, and has really delicious food items available for purchase. This is the perfect tourist place to take any visitor from outside the city. I once even saw Patti LaBelle there!!! 

My only negative is that it becomes so ridiculously crowded that it is almost impossible to walk around. In those situations I become claustrophobic and can't breath, let alone enjoy my stroll through the market. 

However, with all that aside I would highly recommend going here and I would also highly recommend going during an off time like during business hours during the week.
Awesome space. Get the Dinics roast pork sandwich, 4th street cookie, bissets ice cream and a flying monkey whoopie.

The Market is awesome.  Going there is an event, an experience--more than just shopping.  It is a feast for the eyes, the nose and the brain.  The variety of really good food is beyond measure.  For example, there is a cheese shop where one can buy cheeses from around the world as well as goat cheese and other varieties, many of which are new to me.  Go to the butcher and choose the cut of meat you want and at the fish market you can stare back at the fish lying on ice.  Of the Market also offers live lobsters.  For people like me with a sweet tooth, there are a few bakeries and pastry shops.  The variety is endless.  The produce shops are amazing.  I can buy a box of blackberries for one-third or less of what I pay at the supermarket.  Same with many other fruits and vegetables.  Another treat lies in the various Amish shops that provide some wonder food and bakery items, as well as a variety of other things.  Go on a day other than Sunday, though, if you want to catch all the shops including the Amish ones.  Bulk spices and bulk tea is another welcome addition--it reminds me of being in places like the UAE.  Reading Terminal Market truly is a gem--the greatest challenge is resisting buying a little of everything with excellent quality and reasonable prices, one can quickly buy a bit too much of one thing or another.
This place has everything! It's not open very late at night though. They have groceries but the prepared foods is really where it's at. It gets super crowded on the weekend!
So much variety in one place!!  One of my favorite places to go when in philly.  Several different places to get a cheese steak and all quite decent.  Be prepared for long lines on the weekends!

While there are certainly cons (quite a couple actually) the Reading Terminal Market is an experience that overwhelms any minor annoyances such as limited seating, crowded pathways, and terrible layouts.

The solidarity you feel when you are in a line with a group of strangers and you all order the exact same menu items. The focus it takes to duck hoards of families and tourists all milling around, staring up at oversized menu boards. 

Everything I tried out has been incredibly delicious but there are so many other, equally but differently delicious options that I've never ordered the same thing twice.

Do you ever just walk into a place and in every direction you look in, you see food?  I'm not talking like a basic grocery store, but like gourmet food that you can smell just by looking in its direction.  If you are a foodie, this place has everything.  EVERYTHING!!!  It is especially convenient if you are staying at a nearby hotel like the Marriott Downtown since the market is not even a block away.  

So this market is a giant warehouse, and there are vendors literally everywhere.  It has many entrances, one of them being for a diner that is the only thing open 24/7... everything else closes at 6:00.  The food isn't just limited to grocery shopping - aside from the diner, there are plenty of sit-in restaurants too (and some have happy hour!).  There are bakeries and ice cream parlors too.  This place isn't just limited to food, either - there were a few vendors for gifts and for African wear and decor as well.  

The only food I got to try was from a taco place.  It was a chicken taco with very generous portions of everything.... the sauces, the meat, the guacamole, all of it.  How did it taste?  INCREDIBLE.  If I really had money to spend, I would sample various things to take home.  It is a great market and absolutely must be checked out if you are in town.

We usually go to RTM in Philly only when we have company from out of town. So, despite the sporadic visits - it never disappoints. Weekends are crowded but lively and friendly. It is great to be able to buy some fresh fish or meat, sample a few cheeses, and have a cheese steak there - all in the same stop. This is one place that most folks WISH they had near their home!

Looooove this place!!! I've been coming here for years and the food here never fails. You can get all kind of food here from all over the world. My favorite stand are Franks I love their chicken, hands down the best!!! If you have a picky friend who only wants to eat a specific kind of food I guarantee you find that specific food here! Super diverse and everything is really affordable. The best eats in philly. If you are looking for a fun, diverse and super cool eats this place is it foodies.

Go for the red curry chicken at the Thai restaurant in the center.

Donna Wolfe

A wonderful variety of local food! 
I personally love Terminis bakery for their chocolate bananas and cannolis. 
It does get extremely crowded during peak hours so I usually like to go on sundays.

Just point me in the direction of the food. And I mean ALL OF THE FOOD. Reading Terminal Market was destination number one for me on my first trip to Philly. I love public market houses and this had a little bit of everything. Reminiscent of Granville Island in Vancouver, you can explore plenty of fresh produce, much of which is locally produced by farmers in PA! Be sure to check our Fair Food's stall. Gorgeous, locally grown produce and value added products made with love. Not to mention, you can use Philly Food Bucks and double up dollars if you're on SNAP! Whoo! 

There were multiple large produce stands, Amish cheese makers, fresh fish and poultry stands, and all the prepared foods of your dreams. If I hadn't been financially fit an eaten breakfast at home I could've had more than a delicious iced chai from Old City Coffee. I circled the building a couple of times and I believe this was the only coffee station. (Thumbs down) but my drink was tasty!

The market is a great place to go if you're with a group and everybody is wanting something different. Go international or keep it strictly American, you're sure to find something to satisfy those taste buds. Next time i'a in town, I'll have to hit up the oyster bar and try some cheese and sweet treats! Put this place on your list!
This place is simply amazing! Everytime iam here isee something new. Such a magical place.
Can get a little touristy so best to go on the weekdays if dealing with crowds is not your thing. Great produce section and love the new resturant Fox and Son...amazing corndogs and funnel cakes!

Every time I come here I am always torn & not 100% decided. Obviously there's several offerings and choices (sometimes the atmosphere after dark is a little bit questionable i.e., sketchy) overall though, I'm pleased the food is good the service is good great place to walk around and check things out! Especially during the daylight hours and when the weathers nice! I will definitely be coming back, a solid 4.25 stars!

Awesome experience. Everything going is here. Good food. Good produce. Good beer. Good desert. This is a must experience. Parked right across from the Reading Terminal. I suggest you get your parking validated there when you purchase something. Suggest you try the Roast Pork sandwich with Broccoli Rabe at DINICS. A competitor to the Philly cheese steak.

We came here so many times during our short trip in Philadelphia. We came around 5pm and were surprised to learn that the place closed at 6pm - which was so early! If you plan on doing dinner, be aware of those times.

Dutch eating place = AMAZING breakfast! 

Dinics = amazing pork sandwich!

Miller's twist = life changing pretzels.

So many other places for delicious baked goods, chocolates and so forth. I cannot recommend it enough as a tourist for something fast and easy peasy.

This place was great!! So much to choose from. Everyone raved about the pork sandwich from Dinics but I found it meh, I wish I could have tried something from every vendor but the lines were very long.
So much to see, eat, and smell! I want to try it all. I love browsing the aisles and checking out all the vendors. A nice respite from the city - I could spend a whole day here!

Came into town for an extensive work project and stayed at the hotel directly across from Reading. I was shoo excited and blown away when I walked in and saw the busy extensive options. I compared Reading to the Cleveland West side market and thought reading was winning....however... Shopping here is limited to a small amount of produce and vast amount of food stands selling overpriced food lacking flavor. I tried at least 7 different restaurants and was completely underwhelmed. Its seems quantity over quality is the trend here.

I get the Spanikopita from the Greeks, the Pizza from the Italians, The Sushi from the Japanese, the Chicken from the Amish and the fruit from the Koreans.  It's like taking a trip around thew world all under one roof!  A must visit if you are visiting Philly!

Lots of great food at the reading terminal makert. Make sure to go early to get all the goods, I know I've went close to closing before and the Millers pretzels were all sold out and the Beillers donuts didn't have to many options left. Parking can be difficult on the street at times, but usually not to hard to find a spot. There is also parking garages located close by.

Very fun spot, and one of the few sight seeing places in Philly I enjoy going over and over when new visitors come. Avoid lunch hour tho! The lines wrap around corners and its hard to walk between 12-2. But if you go in the morning you might be lucky enough to get one of "the best donuts in Philadelphia" at Beiler's. ( I AGREE ) If you come in the afternoon, many places are doing happy hour. But don't go too late, this place closes promptly at 5 pm and stalls start shutting down before that. Fun ambiance, locally grown food and products. You can see the whole thing in a 30 minute walk, or you can enjoy hours in here eating and shopping.

I've been there a few times, since I'm from Philly  We tend to walk around to see all the different vendors first.
Then we sit down to order at a counter or table (depends on what we have a taste for)  They have the best fresh fried fish plates  
I'm looking forward to eating there again when I visit

First place I stopped in Philly and still the place I go to very often after my move here. It's a place that also sells cheap fruit and veggies. I have tried almost everything and I have usual now like the Italian pulled pork cheesesteak in the middle of the market, the donut joint that everyone waits in line for, the salmon curry at the thai place, and the turkey place towards the center as well. They have quite an eclectic variety and highly recommend going here.

I'm visiting from out of town and decided to take a look at Reading Terminal since my hotel was close by. 

After walking in, I decided that this was my happy place. If you love supporting local food, then this is a place you need to visit. Be sure to have plenty of time on your hands when visiting so that you can check out all of the options and because many of the vendors have lines. 

I plan on going go back at lest once a day to see what I can eat.

A giant, gourmet food court is basically every foodie's dream and that is essentially what you'll find at Reading Terminal Market. Right across the street from the convention center, it certainly gets packed when there is an event going on but most of the lines move quick. I guess the only issue would be finding seating to eat your food. Some of the restaurants have their own seating and waiter service, some just have a bar area, and some have nothing at all.

I ended up trying a cheesesteak from By George followed by waiting 45 minutes in line for Amish donuts at Beiler's. Aside from that, they have pretty much any cuisine you'd like as well as fresh groceries (fruits/veggies, meat, fish, seafood, etc). I would definitely like to come back one day when it isn't as crazy to try out more things!
tootsies salad bar and the amish cheese market are the greatest. i love everything about them! the produce places are super cheap and good quality

Very interesting foodery/indoor market. There's a variety of stands that serve food (crepes, doughnuts, jerky, and more) and some even have seating too!

Some of the shops are kind of boutique-y in nature, but it's still worth the visit. If you have out-of-towners who have never been, this is definitely a spot at which to stop!

The reading terminal market has a little bit of something for everyone. They have a variety of cuisines, great food options - Greek, Mediterranian, Indian, Asian, American, etc. You can shop for knick-knacks, keepsakes, jewelry, groceries, etc. Have a drink. I like this place a lot. The only reason I am not giving it a 5star is because it closes too soon 6:00PM? Wish it was open for dinner.

I wish we had a place like this in Portland Oregon!  Honestly hard to venture out when you have different foods from all over in one place.  This is a must go to and eat!  Unfortunately they close early, so get there with enough time to walk around and get something to eat!

It's the 2nd time I've been here and it's still crowded, still smells delicious and still awakens all of my senses! I love it here, even though I feel like a sardine packed in a metro cart but it's definitely worth the experience and the food here you can't go wrong. They have live music playing from time to time as well as booths set up for gift shopping. Also, it's within walking distance from China town and a good option for when you're in town and you're caught in a downpour (speaking from experience). :)

Loved Reading Terminal Market. Has literally been my go to place when I come to Philadelphia. Their produce is remarkable. I love that I can do my grocery shopping and grab a bite to eat while I'm there. So many choices and they are all great - you cannot go wrong with the food choices. This is a great place to visit on your tourist stop. You can spend hours at Reading Terminal if your heart desires. Its basically an indoor grocery shopping/restaurant/dessert cuisine stop.

I'm writing this review as a student who lives nearby. I feel so lucky to live so close to a place that fulfills (almost) all of my foodie needs! 

I come here 2-4 times a week for groceries. My go-to places are Godshall's for poultry and Iovine Bros for produce. I also love the fish shop near the seating area in the middle (I can't remember the name!) because it's always fresh and the prices are ok for the area. The cheese shops are a bit overpriced, but there's nowhere else nearby to get good cheese for cheaper. 

I also frequently stop by to grab a bite to eat. I've eaten at almost every place here and I've yet to be disappointed! There's a great variety of different cuisines to choose from, but if you're looking for anything Asian, walk the couple blocks over to Chinatown. 

If you can, avoid coming on Friday afternoons or Saturdays because it gets so crowded that it's hard to move. Unless that's the environment you're looking for, in which case it's exciting and bustling with people, both local and tourists. 

A lot of places are closed on Sundays and the Amish places are closed on wednesdays too, so keep that in mind. 

RTM is going to be one of the things I miss the most when I move out of Philly!

This is what every city should have. This market has a great selection of all types of foods. It's fun and engaging. Prices are also below what one usually pays at grocery stores. It's worth a trip for shopping or to just look and have a coffee or snack. Go Philly

Have loved this place since first coming to Philadelphia almost 40 years ago.  It's titled a bit away from a true food market and caters a bit more to tourists and the lunch crowd, but the mix is a healthy one, and real Philadelphians still come here to do their food shopping.
Fun place to check out with lots of good food and interesting people watching.  Some of the best places are Amish-run; be aware that those shops are closed on Sundays.

Best place for anything you could ever possibly want food wise.  We always plan to stop here when ever we go to the city.  Have a delicious breakfast or lunch and pick up something special for dinner.

Has absolutely every type of food you would be in the mood for! Ate at George's and it was delicious! Best cheesesteak I've had! They were very accommodating since I am gluten intolerant - very very crowded on a Saturday, but totally worth it!

Loved our visit to Philadelphia, and really loved Reading Terminal Market which was just a few blocks from our hotel.  Every kind of food that you can think of is represented in RTM. Over the 3 day visit, we stopped by here 4 times! Love the food - love the atmosphere!

Great place to take visitors or stop in through the week for lunch. They have a huge selection of different food places, limited seating though and the close at like 5pm so its not a Dinner spot. Also when anything is at the Convention Center this place is packed and hard to walk around. But the food is good you can always take it to go.

Pretty much the best spot in Philadelphia! It's the place you can find everything you want and things you didn't know you wanted. So many great spots to eat and even grab a cold beer to go! If you go during lunch time you must like small spaces because it gets extremely crowded!!

We try the various restaurants at the market and are constantly amazed at the quality and diversity of the market. I get there by PATCO, at few blocks away because parking is expensive, and a problem if a large convention is in town. There is no lack of business,though.
 Philly may have a nice convention center, but is lacking parking.

Great place with a bunch of places. The donuts from beilers bakery is to die for. The line can get long, especially on weekends...but totally worth it. So far I've been on Saturday afternoons twice. Definitely less crowded when the weather is colder. Parking is not the greatest, however if you can't find a place to sit down they have some tables near the bathrooms. They don't have chairs back there, but eat your food and get in line for another item! :)
so many choices! i love the food selections and its a great atmosphere other than all the homeless people taking over the place and panhandling

This place has no words to describe other than "food heaven"! Everywhere you turn every corner and crevais has a grocery store, deli, ice cream shop, Chinese, you name it it's in there. It's like the flea market of all food sources. 

I went for two days- my first day I ate at HERSELS EAST SIDE DELI- and ate a brisket sandwich that was out of this world!!! It literally blew my mind. I sat across from the deli and the person who made my sandwich exchanged a look of agreement after my first bite. The brisket is soft tender juicy, the mayo was light, the toast was toasted and hugged the meat so gently. The spicy mustard was just the perfect amount of tang And i love white American and the fact that I asked what kind of American cheese do ou have my server answered white like "would you really even dare disrespect with ANY other kind of cheese". I could kiss the cook 

The second day since it being my first day in philly ever I had to eat a Philly cheesesteak so went back and ate at SPARATOS CHEESESTEAK DELI I believe it was called. And again. Another great call. 
White American cheese- steak- hoagie (sooo gooddtomatoe lettuce and mushroom peppers )

Amazing!!! Please please visit this place when you come to Center City, Philly. They have everything from a deli, fish market, Pennsylvania Dutch Foods to soul food. You must try some cookies from the Pennsylvania General Store.
So many choices it was difficult to decide where and what to eat but that's a great problem to have

Very interesting place. Food of ALL types - from seafood, to a grocery area, to cookies, amish donuts, thai food, gumbo...it goes on and on. It is crazy busy here at all times, tight quarters, limited seating to eat, prices slightly overpriced throughout but makes up for it in variety and accessibility. Cool place to go with people.
I LOVE visiting this place when I'm back home in Philly.  Make sure to try locally produced yummies you haven't tried before.  I've never been disappointed!

Love the Reading terminal! Hersels deli is the best! Try the corned beef special. It is out of this world. Worth the wait in line. Corned beef was so fresh it was still warm ,cut to order and placed on the freshest Rye bread.

Reading Terminal is the place to go for fresh and delicious items. I love Basset's Ice Cream, it's my top favorite ice cream ever. Alot of the other stalls have fresh Amish items, Italian specialties and seafood. Like the tastiest Po' Boy sandwich I've ever had. Can't wait til' my next visit!

I like to get my vegetables from Fair Food Farmstand when I have money (they have the freshest tastiest veggie selections and carry specialty vegan items) and when I don't have money I go to Iovine Bros. If you know you're going to use the veggies right away you can go to OK Produce, but ... just be weary and make sure to inspect every inch. I love Flying Monkey bakery, they make some delicious treats when you are feeling bad. Also don't go here on weekends unless it is very early. The tourists will drive you insane. Think; flea market but with food.

There's a reason the paper guide for the market marks the seating areas with an icon of a pig. You will not leave here without eating like one.  You will not leave here without feeling like one.  Carnivores and vegetarians alike.  

You don't eat meat, you come to Philly and you want to experience the classic Cheesesteak? No problem! Head over to Carmen's Famous Cheesesteaks and get in line! Vegetarian cheesesteak is on the menu and seitan is the steak! I got mine with provolone, sweet peppers and onions and if that's what a Philly Cheesesteak is close to tasting like - then no wonder it's such a "thing" here.  It was pretty damn tasty.  

The bf had a pastrami from Hershel's East Side Deli and simultaneously wished he had room for the pulled pork from DiNic's right next door.  Next time.

I've also eaten at the Dutch Eating Place and loved the whole Pennsylvania Dutch vibe that I missed from when I visited Lancaster a few years back.  Just note: not much to choose from if you're a vegetarian.  Also, their famous apple dumplings were sold out on my last visit.  Boo!

Four Seasons Juice and Smoothies Bar is AMAZING.  The ladies are so clean about everything and the menu changes somewhat seasonally.  They have the best looking wheatgrass, too!  A must after indulging too much, leaving and walking around, then coming back for a nice tall fresh squeezed juice or smoothie.

Don't leave here without having a donut (or 3) from Beiler's Donuts....my personal favorites are the fritters.  Apple or blueberry.  Blueberry fritters, people! But the plain, sour cream or glazed are also good.  Everything else is too cloying with the goopy creams all over them.   Long line? No worries.  It moves really fast.

This was my third time here and I have ruined all my other plans for eating in the city by coming here first.  So.... Vedge, Blackbird Pizza, Dottie's Donuts, V Street, Mama's Vegetarian....please wait for me next time I'm in Philly.  I swear I won't go to the Reading so that I have room to visit all of you :)

This might be a bit unfair to have a single review, as each stall has very different fare with a variety of qualities. It can definitely be considered food heaven, but on the contrary on a Saturday morning can be Philadelphia hell. The produce at Iovines is very good and fresh, and very very reasonably priced. It can be hectic but the lines go extremely quickly. The rest of the market tends to have very long lines - but the lines can be an indication of the HAVE TO eat. The Original Turkeys turkey sandwhich with cranberry and stuffing. The Cannolis at Termini Bros (best I've ever had), Becks Cajun Hurricane Sandwhich, Anything at Beilers, but especially their Donuts and their pecan cinnamon rolls, The Reuban or Rachel from Hershels, DiNicks Roast Pork, Dienner's chicken, but most importantly Millers Twist!
Its definitely an experience you dont want to miss as a tourist, and if your a local you already go there regularly!
Great place to get a variety of good food. The juice bar is my go to each time I visit. Any visitor coming to Philadelphia has to visit this great market.
Yes! As good as everyone says. Lines are long at the hot spots but they move fast. Whoopie pies at the Flying Monkey are incredible- get one!

Calling this a "grocery" is a bit misleading.  They do sell groceries, in that there are some stands selling fresh produce or meat - I seem to recall that having a few of these to serve local buyers who live nearby is a condition of the market continuing to operate.  But mostly, the Reading Terminal Market is a big noisy crowded bunch of prepared food stands, with a couple sit-down restaurants thrown in. 

The food served here varies from Chinese to cheesesteaks to seafood to diner fare, and it all ranges from good to very good (though I think Philly has several better places to get a cheesesteak if you're spending more than a day or two in town). I especially like the pizza sold by the large Italian stand,  and on certain days of the week there is an Amish shop inside that serves good breakfast.  There's also a historic ice cream shop that has been selling ice cream longer than any place else in USA and has sold to Presidents, etc.  The market building itself is historic and it's good to see an old building being put to a creative re-use, particularly in this part of the city where chain stores and blight need to be fended off.  If you are staying or working within walking distance, the Market is definitely worth a stop for lunch or snacks. 

Having said all that, given that to go to this market I have to drive in or take public transportation in from Chesco, which has its own awesome food places and Amish markets, the Reading Terminal Market has been kind of a three-star experience for me over multiple visits. The biggest problem with the place is parking. If you come by car, be aware there is little or no street parking and you will have to park in a garage.  There are a couple of garages that will give you a couple hours of deeply discounted parking with a ticket validated by a market vendor, but finding the garage entrances in busy traffic can be tricky, the time you are allotted to park is cutting it close if you wanted to see the whole market or eat at several places, and you really have to watch the time because if you go over your time limit at all then the price goes way up to over 20 dollars.  Also, the last time I drove down there, I had an argument with the parking cashier who tried to charge me 27 dollars although I had a properly validated ticket and was not over my time limit (way under).  She was on the phone and just couldn't be bothered.  I wondered how many tourists would not have realized she made a mistake and just paid the grossly inflated fee for under 2 hours of time.  I recommend walking or taking public transportation here if you possibly can.

Next issue is that the entrances and exits of this market often have aggressive panhandlers who harass shoppers for a handout.  I've had the experience of saying no or trying to walk away and having one of these street people chasing after me shrieking and verbally harassing me because I somehow "disrespected" her by not responding to her demands for money. No security or police presence in sight once you get outside the doors of the market. 

Finally, this place gets very crowded on weekends, so if you are coming to eat, plan on fighting the crowds and standing in a long line to get your food.  Many of the people visiting are tourists and as such hold up the line further by asking questions, asking for special orders, not being totally familiar with payment methods, and/or blocking traffic in the aisles before or after they get their food.  This is a "kid friendly" place which means that there are a lot of families with kids dodging about, strollers, etc. creating more congestion. It can also be hard to find a place to sit down with your food and many of the tables and chairs are the uncomfortable sort that you find in high school cafeterias. I'd really rather take my food home to eat it, but given that I live some distance away, taking home melty ice cream or pizza that will get cold is not a good option. The earlier you can go and beat the crowd on the weekend, the better.  

You can also tell this place was not originally constructed as a market or food court because, unlike some other cities where the markets have higher ceilings and an open-air feel, this place has a pretty low ceiling and little air circulation, and when crowded it gets hot and feels cramped. If you come in colder weather, be sure to dress in layers you can easily shed, or you'll be roasting to death by the time you've made it up and down the aisles. 

Bottom line:  good place to go if you can walk or bike there or you're visiting and want a taste of Philly all in one place.  If you live in the burbs and can more easily drive, walk or bike to other markets and restaurants in your own area, then maybe worth doing once or twice but not on a regular basis, in my opinion.
Wow- what a great place for food from everywhere. Awesome selection and a unique experience in the heart of the city

What a place, the ultimate food court! Actually food court is such a backhanded compliment, Reading Terminal is so much more than that. It's a conglomoration of cultures and foods that have been blended together to create a high energy atmosphere! I really enjoyed the different sites and sounds you'd see around every corner. From cajun, to chinese, delis, BBQ, or Amish markets, Reading has got it all!

Just a sampling of the places I went included:

Dutch Eating Place
Sweet as Fudge Candy Shoppe
Golden Bowl
Sang Kee Peking Duck
Beck's Cajun Cafe
Hunger Burger

I'd recommend all of these, however don't get the chicken pot pie at Dutch Eating Place becuase it's not chicken pot pie and really some weird Amish concoction that's posing as it. Otherwise, this place has so much to offer!

A good option to get a taste of Philly all in one place. 

Molly Malloy's is a great place to grab breakfast. 

Beiler's Bakery has good handmade donuts, but beware they are very sweet

Spataro's has really good cheesesteaks. Always ask for whiz!

Bassett' Ice Cream is amazing!

What a wonderful and fabulous place. They have everything you could possibly want to eat. From soup to nuts. Every best of in Philadelphia is in this place. You will simply love it. You can even walk out with flowers and food to go.
I always go for The Original Turkey!!! It's like Thanksgiving all year round!!!

I'm sure this place is fun ... when it's not overcrowded like crazy. I guess it was bad timing for out-of-towners to check it out on Saturday morning but WOW. You can barely move around and lines at every booth. If you're claustrophobic or have anger issues, do not come here during busy hours. My family and I split up to check out different places to eat but once we got our food, we were standing around looking for a place to sit. People are like black friday best buy shoppers, they will elbow and shove their way to an open spot. I wouldn't be surprised if there are fights here all the time. It also took an hour for my cousin to get his philly cheese steak, which was pretty good but no food is worth that wait, especially when you're hangry and have no place to sit.
Cool place , good food & many selections. Try Molly Malloy's , Chef Bob Fischer is a food icon .

Avoid the weekends if you want to browse. Weekends are great if you know exactly what you need.
Weekdays outside of lunchtime are perfect to walk around and enjoy the people and the delicious  food. 
Go with friends and each pick one thing and share. 
Everything I had was excellent. 
Friendly employees. 
Busy. 
Have patience.
The cannoli was wonderful!!! The Easter treats, breads, and pastries looked phenomenal. Very friendly staff working at this location.....
Mom and I had the Kasha and bowties the other day......best I've had since Coney Island in the early nineties !!   Will definitely go back for these !

Crowded all times of day. If I lived in downtown Philly, I'd shop here all the time. Great for tourists to get ice cream, desert or a full meal on the way to or from hotels in the downtown area. At the end of the day, bakery items were half price.  Workers are friendly and patient.
Love this place and a must visit in Philly. We visited DiNic for their sandwiches: Italian pull pork and brisket. The place was crowded but it is such a great environment with courteous folks.

I love Reading Terminal Market! A great blend of ethnicities, great foods and produce! The place is quite big and it's very easy to get lost, but no matter what corner you turn there is absolutely amazing food

Amazing.  Philly's finest.  Everything here is good.  Donuts, Cajun, all amazing!!!  Definitely stop here for some food if you're hunan.  This place is huge, has great variety, and some amazing, fresh food.
Fantastic variety of food!  Make sure that you stop by Termini Bros to get a canoli!  I always try a new place each time that I come in.

I've been to Reading Terminal Market a few years back and to be honest, nothing was really memorable because I don't remember what I ate there. I think I faintly remember trying the roast pork sammie from Tommy DeNic's but even if I did, I can't remember what it tastes like. So this time around, I decided to document everything, so that if I do visit Philly again, I'll know what to get (or what not to). Here is everything we ate:

Tommy DeNic's: Roast Pork with Provolone and Broccoli Rabe - this was a nice break from the cheesesteaks that we've been eating. The pork was cooked perfectly, and there was a good amount of provolone and broccoli rabe. It does get messy though, so it's not really a sammie that you could eat on the go.

MeltKraft : Melter Skelter ('Melter Skelter' Raclette 3 Month, pickled green tomatoes, jalapeño, BBQ potato chips, and watercress) - this was good, but not worth $9. I don't know what it is about grilled cheese, but I just can't find a grilled cheese anywhere that's worth paying $10 for.

Beiler's Doughnuts - bought a few doughnuts from here - one crumb, the second cinnamon, and the third I can't remember. This had the longest line. The line wraps around other stands. People seem to buy these doughnuts up by the dozen. My boyfriend really enjoyed the doughnuts but to be, they were just doughnuts. But then again, maybe it's just because I'm not a huge fan.

Herschel's: Corned Beef Sandwich - although I only tried a few bites, the corned beef was pretty good. It wasn't overly salty, like corned beef tends to be. The pickles are great.

Overall, the market is a great place to try out a bunch of different foods. But it'll cost you.
Great venue. Worth the trip.Tremendous number of food choices. ALL are good! Worthwhile!

This place is cool, I don't think we have this at New York or New Jersey. So many choices to eat around here, it took my family a long time to decide. It's a busy place, I noticed alot of FiveO's around here, I counted at least 12, when we were there. I don't know if its a good thing that they have so much security in there or a bad thing that they need so much security in there. It's my first time here so I may be over thinking the situation, maybe all those FiveO's were just there for lunch or something. Anyways, this place was very interesting, people need to come here when they visit Philly, I recommend it.

Was definitely a zoo, but if I lived in Philly, I would come here all the time. I had a delicious chicken cheese steak sandwich from By George, and friendly service. We magically found seating and were able to settle in for lunch. Hubby got a sandwich from DeNic's that was great. He wished he had an extra stomach so that he could eat the whole thing. 

It's a little too crowded to make walking around enjoyable at all, but that's not the fault of the market.  If I was there during a less crowded time, I would have enjoyed spending more time there looking/walking around.  

There definitely seemed to be something for everyone there.
Are you looking for a one-stop-shop that's packed nuts to butts?  Well, you found the place. Avoid between 11 AM-1 PM or you'll feel like cattle trying to traverse the place.

Super busy place even on a Monday when I went. But what an assortment of different foods and homemade goods! I went to the Candy store and got a huge pack of Blue Raspberry Gummy Bears for less than $3, went to the small buffet in the market which had a great selection and it was all tasty for about $10 including a can of soda. I would love to go back here and explore more. Unfortunately, I wasn't able to stay long but it was great looking around and finally seeing this place.

As expected, crowded with lots of good food and reasonable prices. Cheesesteaks from the place next to Termini Bros. bakery (forgot their name) were very good and the bakery was outstanding - cannolis were some of the best we've had, including NE Pa., NYC and upstate NY. Filling did not turn watery even on the second day. Limoncello cake, chocolate mousse cake and tieramasu cake were loved by our group. No one wanted to share. Will try more shops on our next trip.

Walking into Reading Terminal Market is great for when there are many options and there are plenty of places to satisfy everyone's palate. Upon walking in here, it very much reminded me of the Essex Market in NYC but bigger and a little bit better. From smoked meats, local goods and sweet delectables, there is so much to choose from. Although it can be quite confusing which direction to go, there are maps that are on the wall to help guide you to the vendor you would like to visit.
The location of the market is conveniently close to popular parts of the city. It is a short walk to the old city where you can visit and tour the liberty bell and independence hall. Also close by is philly's Chinatown. 
A good tip to keep in mind if you have a car to park is that the Reading Market has two parking lots on 12th and the other on 11th that offer discounted parking. You just need to take your parking ticket, spend at least $10 in the market at one of the vendors, ask the vendor to validate your ticket and you are set. It will give you two hours of parking for $4. After that the rates increase, but still a pretty good discount.

Impression:They always list this place as a top 10 thing to do in Philly and it's a no wonder! If you've been to Seattle's Pike Market, then this is a more urban and New England version of it. It has produce from farms, heritage varieties, fresh eggs, cheddars, deli, meats, and bakeries that offer mouth watering pastries. There's also a large variety of food stands and stalls that offer a very impressive variety of foods from barbecue, to breakfast, desserts, Indian, African, and Hillel foods. 

Prices- That's what everyone always wants to know especially if it's a tourist attraction. So in terms of produce, it's not bad priced. Not as high as whole foods, but certainly not your Italian Marketplace where you can haggle your way down to pennies. One can probably get some quality farmer produce for a reasonable price of like 1.99$/lb for apples or 2 for 1$ corn to give an idea of the ballpark range. The food is also pretty reasonable priced. You can get a whole lunch set for less than 10$ and the portions are large. You can order most foods for less than 10$ here. 

Hours- so this place is open until 6 pm on most days, so if you're going to go, do not bank on this place on being your dinner place, because chances are most of the produce will have been sold off, stalls are closing, and you may be left with whatever is leftover (meaning smaller selection). I recommend hitting this place for lunch or even late afternoon stop as you wrap up your activities. 

Food: What to try- there are a few places that have their original site outside the marketplace. Meltykraft and Metropolitan Bakery have their own stand alone branches outside of this marketplace for example, so I recommend trying places that cannot be found outside- this may require a little more research, but the Indian food place for 9.99$ lunch set looked amazing and line moved fast. The Amish desserts are also a hit here as well. 

Amount of time recommended- you can probably spend a couple of hours in this establishment. It is massive and overwhelming. It has almost everything, so don't go in starving because you'll probably just wind up sitting at the first place you see and stuffing your face and then be sad you can't put down the amazing looking treats ahead.

Usually crowded but worth the wait. Lots of variety. Seating area in the middle. Parking nearby is ok. Always tried something new each time and always a good experience. Always get the fresh baked cookies from the cookie company at the end of one of the corner aisles near an entrance. Great cookies.

Loved the concept, however the market needs an upgrade! You get a ton of options: cheesesteaks, burgers, donuts, candy stores, butter specialities, ice cream, groceries, and so much more. I was actually visiting from Virginia for the day and only had time to do one thing - and I don't regret my decision.

Of all the places we could have visited for lunch, we of course chose Carmen's for their classic cheesesteaks. I've made it a tradition to try a different cheesesteak every time I visit philly, and this was probably one of the best thus far (second to Barclay Prime's if you count that)! The classic I got had mushrooms, onions, and sweet peppers, with the iconic cheese whiz on the bread. Full of flavor, however a little on the salty side with the cheese they used. The bread was my least favorite part, as I have definitely had better. It was kind of rubbery to me, but I did buy a few more for home and retoasting them made a huge difference. 

If people were to ask me what my favorite Philly cheesesteak is, I would refer them to Carmen's! (Also, Obama has been here too!)
Oh so yummy berry rolls at Metropolitan Bakery!  Crazy good sticky buns at Beiler's bakery!  Best duck in the city at Sang Kee!  I love my kitchen fish towels from Amy's Place!  And so much more...

Alot of great places to eat at and purchase foods. I have been to a few of the places in here. We eat here every year when the flower show is in town. 
There is currently some construction around the outside of the building. Other than that. It's easy access.

This place was really packed the Saturday we came. Our hotel was 9 mins away so we decided to uber to avoid parking. We got there around 3pm. I tried the sausage and peppers, pierogis and cornbread from Famous Franks A lot..the cornbread was da bomb! Beware of the long line!. I also wanted to try the hot apple dumpling from the Dutch eating place but they ran out, so I got a grilled sticky bun which was pretty good. We sat in the general area, it started to clear out a bit so we were lucky enough to get a seat. I'll be back when next I come to Philly just to try that famous apple dumpling and I'll be sure to come early.

Fantastic market!! An absolute must when in Philly. I couldn't think of a comparison because it's got it's own feel. It was my first time here and I didn't have a list of what stands I wanted to try. It's fun that way because you get to explore more and surprise yourself with the different foods you find.

For the meat-eaters DEF try the fried chicken over at Keren Parker's friend chicken stand. It's the best fried chicken I ever had. And it's voted as the number one fried chicken by the Food Network. It's def true!

For dessert I stopped by Profis creperie and had the strawberry, blackberry cheesecake crepe with raspberry syrup. It was delicious! 

I didn't get to stop by Beilers Donuts. The line  is extremely long but apparently it moves quickly. You'll notice throughout the market everyone carrying boxes from this place. I am coming here the next time I am in Philly no matter what. You can smell the donuts from a distance.

I don't know what to add to hundreds of Reading Terminal Reviews other than it's a must for any Philly trip. The blend of both market and food service businesses combined with the size of the space and the people makes for a high quality, uniquely Philadelphia experience. There is a lot going on so bring an appetite and energy. I've had some really good crepes, tacos and backed goods at Reading (pronounced Redding) Terminal.  Every trip to Philly includes a stop in, so I think it's definitely worth a visit.

A must see for anyone visiting or living in Philadelphia. It represents all that is good in America, abundance of fresh food, knowledgeable vendors and a sense that you're at the right place. Bring a hearty appetite.
Love this place. Unique spot with great history, and the food selections and tastes are phenomenal!

Fantastic market!! An absolute must when in Philly. This spot was recommended by my wife's boss. A great recommendation I just wish they were open beyond 6PM. Every delicacy you have a taste for you will find at Reading (Pronounced "Red-ing"):  Philly food, Check.  Italian Food, Check.  Soul Food, Check. Asian Food, Check. Indian Food, Check.  Seafood, Check. The list goes on and on.  We spent at least everyday enjoying the various meals.  Highly recommended when in Philly.  Cheers!
Best bacon ever!!!!! Great food everywhere! Great place to go on a Sunday morning.  I love this place!!!

Don't go on a weekend as it's chaotic with foot traffic. You can barely walk a foot without stepping on someone else. The claustrophobic need wait for a weekday. But the wait is worth it. This is a true Philadelphia staple to visit. Hundreds of unique vendors all in one stop. My favorite is the spice shop that offers everything I could want.

I don't understand what the big draw here is!  I guess if you live IN the city, it's has many merchants in one place.  However, it's very crowded of course because it's in center city. 
 It is filthy.  The tables and chairs where you eat were disgusting.  The bathroom wasn't very clean either.  And these were only the areas you can SEE!  It's so busy and congested taht it makes me wonder about everything behind the counters.  Yikes!  The prices are extremely high.  If you live in an outlying county, there is absolutely no reason to go here.  There wasn't one thing in this place that I couldn't get in normal errands in Chester Co. and the places I would go would be clean.

I don't even know where to begin. Let's just say that I hate crowded places but even I will brave RTM on a Saturday for a turkey sandwich or some amazing cheese and meat. Or a cannoli, whatever. I could go on and on. If you are visiting Philly, this MUST be a stop for you and give yourself a few hours to wander around and eat your way through. I love love love RTM and can't wait to go back soon.

Rating: 3.5/5.

Food network's advertisements of "Tommy Dinic's" brought me there. The roasted pork broccoli sandwich was more tender and enjoyable than the beef brisket one. 

The highlight of the crowded and touristic Reading terminal market was the honey sampling at "Bee natural". Their raw honey was so delicious and came in so many unusual and interesting flavors! I ended buying a big container, which lasted me years.

The market had a miniature train track, which was a hit with children.

While it was a fine place to get your steps in, nothing was outstanding. I may have been spoiled by places such as the Boston Public Market or Eataly. Those luxuous markets offered more samples and surprising products.

If I were to have lunch there again, I would try the Carmen's shop selling cheese steack sandwiches.

This is definitely a tourist spot, but I come here anyway. The Elvis Cake at Flying Monkey is to die for. Also, the pastrami and the brisket at Hershels is delicious. I always end my trip with fruit from Iona Bros. and hit the butcher across from them.
The only place I can get hard to find spices and a variety of coffee flavors ice cream hot donuts Bassett ice cream platter sandwiches and the list goes on my favorite place to shop

A Philly Best!! The Reading Market is my jam!! Always packed, but damn that food and shopping is amazing!! The The roasted pork broccoli sandwich was more tender and enjoyable than the beef brisket one.
One of the best historical food market on earth . You will find most amazing shops, every type of food. They have shops like 150 years old ..

The Holy Grail of food in Philadelphia.  If you can't find it here, you ain't looking hard enough. 
I have been coming here for far longer than I care to admit.  My mother used to drag me around the market back when it was the old Reading Terminal,  complete with the leaky roof and the floor was coated with sawdust.  There were carcasses hanging on hooks of every edible animal imaginable, some animals wtere still alive,  waiting for the axe.
It was unbelievable!  My mom made me sit with her and drink buttermilk at Spataro's, we ate with the Amish and had ice cream at Bassett's. 
Later in life,  I worked near the RTM and if I didn't visit there everyday,  I got a bad case of the shakes. I was there so much,  some of the vendors thought I had an apartment upstairs. They called me KYW because I was there two, three, four times a day. 
The RTM is different now, it's a kinder,  gentler market, shinier,  brighter and much more diverse. I still love the RTM very much,  and watching it grow has been like watching a family member mature over the years.
