This place is outstanding!!! Our hotel (home2suite by Hilton) is right across the street. We walked around a bit but we were starving so we chose Pearl's Oyster bar. I left a review for it. Anyhow, you can find such a variety of food -- fresh seafood if you want to cook yourself, desserts and little shops. I'd love to have this back home. Our hotel has a refrigerator so this would be great if we had the inclination to cook but we're doing too much sightseeing for that. This is definitely a place to check out!!!

What an awesome place! Reading Terminal Market reminded me a lot of the Seattle Fish Market, with an abundance of diverse stalls selling prepared food, market ingredients, and other generally handmade products. While it can be a little overwhelming at times it's definitely a must see on the list of things to do in Philly.
The only place I can get hard to find spices and a variety of coffee flavors ice cream hot donuts Bassett ice cream platter sandwiches and the list goes on my favorite place to shop

Wow, where to start. I grew up going to the Terminal and frequent it now with my family. It is perhaps the most fun place in the city to grab lunch or breakfast. You can get anything you want to eat -- our favorites are the huge blueberry pancakes at the Amish counter in the back, the Mexican foot at the Cantina, and the new grilled cheese stand. The Terminal is such a Philly experience that it shouldn't be missed by residents or visitors to Philly. 

A visit wouldn't be complete without dessert from either Fourth Street Cookies, a hand thrown soft pretzel dipped in butter from another Amish stand, or Bassetts Ice Cream. 

This place is Philly's own slice of heaven.

Chaos and fantastic food at every turn. Yes, it is a crazy place, but it has anything and everything you could possible want in the realm of food. Prices are average, but across the board, the quality is excellent. 

It is an experience everyone visiting Philly should have.

"Tourist trap"
"Waaaayyyy overrated"
"Waste of time"
"Yada, yada, yada"

That's what I heard from Debbie Downer and Negative Nancy who were having a threesome with Pessimistic Pete.  They can keep those experiences because I loved my time here.

It's market paradise for those who love food and homemade goods.   The most popular ones are Bassett's (ice cream), Tommy DiNic's (cheesesteaks/roast pork hoagies), George's (pizza), Beilers (baked goods), whichever place has the Peking duck, and the fried chicken spot with the food network sign.  You could spend the whole day here getting fat and happy unlike the three bumbles I mentioned earlier.

The thing to do is order your drinks/food from wherever, sit at one of the tables and munch while you people watch.  Strike a conversation with those next to you as they're likely a tourist or a local.  If it's a local, they'll tell you where to go for fun and what to look for (unless your a Giants, Cowboys, or Redskins fan; they'll likely give you the finger).

It reminds me of those night markets when I was in Taiwan but with Philly flare.  Lines get long depending where you're at but move quickly so you better know what you want to order or they'll let you have it.  It is Philly after all!

I'll be back with a bigger appetite and with my friends Hungry Hunter and Eating Earl!
Always crazy packed with people, but they have some of the best food options and prices you can find around. I highly recommend this location for visitors of philly and just PA residents in general!

You just can't argue with a crowd.  This place is amazing, but friggin crowded.  Very hard to get something to eat here in the early afternoon due to crowds of people in line for lunches, unless you don't mind waiting in line.  I Pass when it comes to lines.  Seating is very limited for the number of very successful food venders.  You name it, they have it.  Chinese, Polish, Amish, Fish, BBQ, Deli and just about any other ethnic or local food restaurant you may want to try.

We have only been successful at scoring a lunch at one of the Chinese food venders on several of our walks through and it was amazingly good.  There is no problem when it comes to getting you cakes, cookies or ice creams since the shops are less crowded.

It is a great place to walk around and smell the smells of all the food.  Plenty of fresh meats, fish, cheeses and produce, in addition to cookies candies and most anything else you're looking for in food.  I think they are on the pricy side of meats and seafood, but I'm not living in the City where their are very few grocery stores.  Maybe that's what they pay.

Down sides the lack of table space and very crowded isles.  Additionally, if you're a tourist and looking to walk around for the remainder of the day it's hard to pick up any fresh produce.

Everything is here, all the great spots. Busy and high turnover of people on weekends. Packed seating area but people are always coming and going so you'll find a spot. One of the best markets I've been to.
One of my favorite things about Philly. Open everyday get any everything you need to cook to eat
Love going here to get food. Haven had a bad experience yet. Plus they have fresh produce and meats and best of all Blue Mountain Winery.
Great food, great variety. Don't go during rush times, and there are so many good vendors, I've never found it was worth standing in those with the longest lines. s
Some good shops, some mediocre.  One of the things you must see when you are in downtown Philadelphia.

Wow. Wow. Wow. I am not from the area but I would sooooooo love to have this in my hometown. I would probably visit everyday and be the size of a house. Talk about variety - it is here. If you are from out of town you must visit. Choose from candy, crepes, pretzels, seafood, fresh produce, meat sandwiches and aoooooo much more. There were so many places to choice from. I would definitely return!!

Absolutely no complaints. Fun place to go and see a variety of food and grab things to eat.

Very similar to Boston food market and DC union market with the design of a large number of places to eat on a small space.

No complaints.
This is probably one of my favorite bazaar. I think there are more than 70 shops side by side . Many organic food and fruits,chocolate shops,souvenir stores .

It's an unavoidable institution with such fantastic variety of markets, vendors, and restaurant/drink options.

Don't be deterred by those who say it's a tourist trap!  It IS a tourist-heavy area, but that doesn't mean it's undeserving or fails to deliver genuine quality and uniqueness.  Tourists go there BECAUSE it does not cater to them...plenty of locals are there far more often than the tourists.  Many of the vendors have been operating there for 40+ years, so consider what that means.

Just go! Old city coffee best in the city.   Get a pound of old city blend you won't regret it. And of course a hot apple fritter on the Amish people are  in town. The first place you should bring any visiting tourist to. Just go and enjoy everything it has to offer. If you can go during the off hours that's a very good idea because it can get very busy.

This place gets crowded, but this place is awesome. I love the fact that even during a large conference across the street I was able to get something fairly quickly because all the great options. I enjoyed a turkey stand that had this amazing fresh turkey sandwiches! Forgive me as I don't remember the name as I was so busy with work I just when in and out, but I REMEMBER THAT TURKEY!! :)

I've given it a lot of thought, and if I had one day left to live, I'd probably spend at least half of it in Reading Terminal Market. Not on the beaches of Hawaii, not amidst the lights of Paris, but in a crowded aisle in a market in Philly that smells of donuts and sausage and curry, passing by busy stands of fresh fish, colorful candies, and sandwiches. 

Yes. Give me 4:30 PM on a Sunday afternoon, with clerks calling out that the cookies at the Famous Fourth Street Cookie Stand are now just one dollar. Give me authentic bratwurst. Give me tourist-y souvenirs that are themed with Philadelphia landmarks and Pennsylvania Dutch kitsch. I *love* this place. 

If you think I'm being hyperbolic, please consider the fact that I once traveled two hours via public transportation while in kidney failure just to eat gumbo from Beck's Cajun Café. Seriously. The gumbo (and Reading Terminal Market, in general) is that amazing. As far as food goes, this place has everything you could ever want. Cuisines from diverse regions of the United States as well as the globe. Also importantly, most stands (except some of the gift shops) are reasonably-priced.
Great variety and a lot of fun.  You can pretty much find anything you are looking for here.
Great touristy place with no complaints simply amazing. Great ice cream, they have everything groceries fresh fruits, every type of food.

Lots of reviews here so no to belabor the point, this is a must see. If you are stuck at the convention center, skip the crap food choices there and head to Reading Market. For me, Hershel's Deli was the bomb. The brisket sandwich and turkey sandwiches were to die for. I joking said "it was so tender, it was like eating meat butter". Get it grilled for sure!!

That said, it is delicious and HUGE. It's not for those who are looking for small portions. I will be there next year again for sure.

LOVE THE READING TERMINAL MARKET!!!! We take the greyhound bus to Phily...takes a little over an hour and the bus stop is right by the Market. Pop in....and start with Miller's Twist, the most delicious little hot dog wrapped in a buttery pretzel...they are worth the trip alone! Then you need donuts and cheese steaks and beef jerky! Oh and don't forget the chocolate chip cookies and the deli meats sliced so perfectly thin. Best food market I've ever been too!!!

One of Philly's best attractions. Super crowded on the weekend and closes a bit too early on week nights are my only two complaints. They have so many amazing food options, you really can't go wrong. Get a roast pork from DiNics. Really worth checking out if you are in the area.
Enjoyed my visit to the market. Visited Philly for the first time a few weeks ago and glad I did. The parking special was awesome and super convenient.

After eating breakfast at Pearl's we walked around RTM. OMG food to the left...food to the right! This place is massive. It's like an indoor food flea market. I did visit the restroom and they were very well kept. There were a few restaurants that weren't open but the place was crowded with restaurant goers, sweet tooth satisfiers, and vendor shoppers.

This is one of my favorite places to eat.  It's a melting pot of culinary delights from every corner on the map. The Amish breakfast amongst their many other offerings is superbly fresh. This morning alone I hand fresh Apple cinnamon French toast, turkey bacon, and a freshly squeezed cup of Oj. There's no other place in Philadelphia that brings together so many delicacies under one roof. And that reason i give it five stars.

Ok guys, sorry I couldn't give a 5 because this place is amazing but simultaneously overwhelming!!! Like whoa overwhelming. Anything your heart desires to eat is here, at various places, and based on the ones I've tried they're all top notch. It's also a great place to go in groups because everyone can get what they want! The lines are typically super long (at least at lunchtime when I go) and not always fast moving. But everyone who is in philly should go at least once!

There is something for everyone. The atmosphere is a bit from crowded but for a big city that's a bit slower in pace, I think Reading gives the affect some tourists are looking for. Lots of dessert options too. If you're there for brunch (and not on a sunday) go to the Dutch Eating Place and get a hot apple dumpling with heavy cream. You won't regret it!

Fun, but....almost no gluten free food (except a small selection in the bakery) and very little vegetarian stuff to take out or eat in (except the Indian stand) - the produce areas have little or no organic...so, if you have a dietary restriction or like to eat organic go elsewhere....the little kitchen store is very overpriced too....but it is a fun place to visit once or twice every year or 6.

Such a fun trip to take -- we always take the train and head down for cannolis at Termani's and the best brisket sandwiches at Nick's.  It's a bit touristy, but there are more people there doing their weekly shopping than tourists.  It's always crowded and very hard to find a seat, but there's a reason for that -- the food is great at so many of the places!

Hands down the best thing to do in Philly if you love food. This place is crazy, so many shops and restaurants. Everything from spices, to candles, to fresh produce, pastries, to donuts made right on the line in front of you. I love DiNic's pulled pork sandwich with rabe.

We love the Reading Terminal Market! Tons of different food and store options. We have brought visiting family here as well and they loved it! It is such a cool thing to have offered to us right in the city of Philadelphia. Too many places to list but def. go check out the Reading Terminal Market and give yourself a few hours and some patience. Some of the Philly City Food Tours also give tours of the market which is pretty cool! Cheers!
Love this place! If you're there hour-30 mins before you can get cookies for half price! Yum
I love the market and frequent it on my lunch break since I work in Chinatown. Definitely a special staple of Philly!

This really is the quintessential Philly must-see. Really fun on a crowded Saturday afternoon with dozens of food stalls, mostly manned by genuine Pennsylvania Dutch shopkeepers with great foods from probably the best doughnuts you can get (get in the looooong line and wait!) to made to order gourmet corn dogs, DiNics Philly roast pork sandwiches and even a fully stocked Irish Pub with attached seating where you can bring your food and grab a beer to wash it down. Packed with tourists for a reason, so enjoy!

No matter what your heart desires, you're sure to find it at the terminal. I go for Carmine's and eat while browsing. The Amish section is closed Sundays, so if you crave their pretzels or ice cream (or both!) don't come on Sunday. ALSO, not many people know this, but the terminal validates parking! Park in any nearby garage and bring your ticket so it can be stamped. You can get a stamp at virtually any place where a good or food can be purchased. You need to purchase something for a validation. You can stay in the terminal all day or just 10 mins and it will only cost you $4.00 to park with a validated ticket. Sometimes I park, run errands, hop in the terminal for some grub, validate my ticket and then go get my car. It's a cheap way to park in the city most of the day in a garage.

I love Reading Terminal Market. It has such a wonderful sampling of so many different types of fresh foods and restaurants. The market is located in an area where parking is very difficult. If I want to catch a lunch with a business colleague, I'll just take an Uber down there.

This place is Food Channel Fantasy Heaven. Bakeries galore. Hot sandwiches. Green drinks. Salads. Fresh fruit. Chocolates everywhere. Just chocolate heaven. Similar to Chelsea Market in NYC but with a much homier, friendlier vibe. 

Do yourselves a favor and check it out!

We Love Reading Terminal Market Especially The Omnish Everything Be So Fresh And Good They Cooked Food Is Very Good To We Love Their Fruit And Vegetables We Rather Spend Our Money There Then The Super Markets Cause Nothing At Reading Terminal Never Got Any Of Us Sick Love It There And Will Definitely Be Going Back Real Soon......
Amazing place.. anything you could want to eat is here .. very busy .. very fun.. would highly record a visit if your in the area

Organized very intelligently. There are obvious sections throughout the entire market making it a joy to stroll through. You will suddenly find yourself in the honey and handcrafted soaps section, or the eye popping fresh produce section. Everything here seems fresh and local. The prices are affordable and each vendor is willing to tell you about their wares. I saw the coolest mushroom stand here, with more species than I've ever seen in my life. My friend and I bought some gifts for our friends back home since we were travelling in Philly.
Fantastic food everywhere you turn!  It's a must see, go check it out.  They have such diversity in the food that it offered and you can even find beeswax, candles and unique bar soap.

Well it is an interesting place and the hot pork sandwiches were yummy but it clearly lacked the flair of many urban regional markets as well as the variety of food stuffs. I would rate this as a good place for lunch but otherwise a tourist trap.

This place was packed! You may feel like sardines at times as you maneuver around. The locals said that during lunch hours, this place gets super busy, and of course we were there during the lunch rush. 

Reading has a wide selection of foods and local products (artisan items and fresh produce). If you're wanting a smoothie then check. If sandwiches are more your thing then there are a couple of spots. Needing dessert? Check!

Our friend said there's a Dutch area where you can grab breakfast and see the staff in their traditional attire (at times). It was closed when we ventured here, but he said it was something worth checking out. 

Reading is a good spot for food. If this is on your list as you're visiting Philly, it's not a shopping market or anything that will take too much of your day. If you're there to look then it takes about 10 to 15 mins.

This review is solely for the Gorgonzola cheese bought to me as a gift from my darling brother and his lovely gf.

Jesus, Joseph and Mary (in an Irish brogue)!!
This cheese transported me to an out of this world experience. After the initial bite, I left the planet, flew to the moon, danced and wined with aliens then landed back to Earth. Holy cow! It literally melted in my mouth, there's no chewing required whatsoever. I already had my crackers out to elevate the cheese, but after that bite, I put them away. It's so smooth, has the perfect texture (not too firm or too soft) and has the perfect amount of buttery creaminess, that it totally stands well on its own. The taste is so subtle but flavorful where nothing else is required besides a beautiful glass of wine to accentuate that wonderful aftertaste. I'm not a fan of blue cheese but this one, won me over.

If you're looking for a gift or souvenir, look no further, this is you're wining ticket.

This place was recommended by a colleague and I went while walking around Philly with a friend. So many choices and the movement of people during lunch was impressive. There are bakeries, coffee shops, ethnic markets, restaurants, and more! We went at Pearl's Oyster Bar because they had seating. I had a kale salad and the fish tacos. The salad had a delicious flavor combination while the tacos were hearty and delightful. The waiter tried to discourage me from over ordering but it was all well worth the filling! I can't wait to go back to Philadelphia to try another one of the eating choices here!

So many options! No matter what kind of food you like this place will not disappoint. There is carry with you beer with endless food options. We love a roast pork sandwich, falafel, or fresh cookies. No matter what you eat it's a great experience and even better food!

I loved our visit to Reading Terminal Market! There is no shortage of things you *want* to try so it's just a matter of figuring out how to try the most of everything. It's concept is very similar to places like Pike Place (Seattle), Grand Central Market (Los Angeles), etc...

Lines for some vendors were certainly much longer than others, but most still moved fairly quickly. Staff at most food stands were also incredibly friendly and willing to chat up locals and tourists alike. Most visitors to Reading Terminal Market are also very friendly - I really only had one passing negative incident where a man pushed me out of his way and into one of the display cases at the Pennsylvania General Store. 

Of all the things we tried, my favorites were easily:

1. Beiler's Donuts: the fritters are a must. We even flew some back across the country to the Bay Area. A little reheating and they were just as fluffy and springy as bought fresh!

2. Herschel's Deli: while the pastrami was good, the corned beef was the real winner. Excellent flavor, stacked nice and high, good slaw. Yum.

3. Carmen's Famous Cheesesteaks: wiz is cool, but I like my real cheese. Their provo sauce is made with a mixture of provolone and cream cheese. Their steak was also of a much better quality than that of Pat's/Geno's.

We also tried:

1. Dutch Eating Place: probably should have gotten something sweet as it seemed like this is what they are really known for but the chicken pot pie was still pretty good.

2. Hunger Burger: fresh lobster mac and cheese came our when we passed by...it was a non-negotiable order at that point.

3. Miller's Twist: I don't know of a baked pretzel I've adored more as of recently...

4. DiNic's: The roast pork was okay, definitely not the best sandwich I've had

I love food markets and food stalls, so it's no wonder I love this place. The last time I was in Philly, Mr. Joy and I visited RTM every single day, sometimes, multiple times a day.
I appreciate that the market is set up like a grid. Navigating can be a little confusing if you've never been here, but you're sure to find something good to munch on, especially in the baked goods category.

Bassett's Ice Cream - oldest ice cream shop
Beiler's Doughnuts - freshly baked doughnuts & delicious fritters
Famous 4th Street Cookie Co. - classic cookies
Meltkraft - cheesiest grilled cheese sandwiches
Miller's Twist - freshly baked pretzels, and pretzel rolls
Tommy DiNic's - roast pork sandwiches
Termini Bros - great cannolis

What should I try next?
my favorite part is the fair food stand for my weekly produce. great local veggies and fruit at reasonable prices.

Loved this market, it was so wonderful! The Amish soofly pies, Philly cheese steaks, fresh produces and more.

I could spend couple hours easily just looking around and eat good food.

I wish they have samples that we can taste of those sweets, savory and fresh fruits like in Europe.
Thank you Philly!

One of the best food markets I've been to. Love the variety, and seems like you can't go wrong with whatever you decide to eat here.

Tommy DiNic's: Roast Pork w/ Broccoli Rabe & Provolone Cheese. Super delicious meat, but cheese too strong for me. Very large sammich cannot fit into little girl's stomach.

Bassetts Ice Cream:  Salted Caramel Pretzel (vanilla ice cream with salted caramel swirls &  chocolate covered pretzel nibs). Loved the flavor and the way the pretzels and caramel were incorporated. Very American ice cream. Creamy, heavy, and sweet.

Molly Malloy's: Golden Monkey. Very tasty beer. Found myself tasting something different with each sip. Crisp, sweet, bitter- idk there's a lot going on here.

Take public transportation or walk here
Parking is terrible..
Crazy busy lots of crowds..
So plan that with little ones when visiting.. strollers are not so good in the crammed crowds..
Tons of food...
Fun atmosphere...

If you've been to Boston Quincy market..this is similar..but 1000 times larger

Cool place to go especially if you are new to or visiting Philly. Can be very overstimulating. Beilers Douts is a must try. Herschel's is good for a breakfast sandwich with pastrami. You can get fresh seafood.. not sure how great it is. Many other new places I have yet to try. Fun just to walk around and take it all in.
Really great place to get food.  My favorite is the Amish doughnut place and the Roast pork sandwich with sharp provolone with broccoli rabe.  Its the best trust me.

This is definitely the place to be if you're visiting Philadelphia.  It is pretty similar to the Grand Central Market in LA, but there are a lot more stores/vendors/restaurants.  There is a pretty large seating area and plenty of stuff to try.  I specifically tried Beiler's donuts because that was one of the donut place I wanted to try the most.  I think no matter what you're craving for, Reading Terminal Market will have it.  Stop by and check it out when you're in philly!
One should see this market. It has lots of options for tasty eats. Be prepared for crowded space. Other shops besides food, but mostly a food oriented place.

Listen, anything and everything you could ever want is to be found here!
Food beyond the mind's eye! Galore!
Exotic fruits and veggies as well as the norm.
Cheeses and meats of all kind. Beverages, jams, sandwiches, candies, handmade household items, and more.

Tends to be crowded, be forwarned. It is great for all sorts of things. Highly recommend the Grilled cheese place. Nice people and excellent food. Get you meats and veggies here. Fresher and a better deal than the grocery store.

During our visit we stopped here for lunch. It was not what I expected, to be honest I think it is a bit overrated. Many people recommended Tito make sure I visited this place and it was ok. The lunch options were plentiful and plenty of small shops with interesting items to purchase but it really did not catch my attention. I guess my mistake was comparing it to Faneuil Hall and Quincy Market in Boston. If I return to Philly i don't think this would be on my list to re-visit. Philly has so many dining opportunities, i think I would try something else.
Great selection of food to choose from.  The burgers from Hunger Burger were amazing!  I'd almost have to say better than In n' Out Burger!  Needed more seating though!
Must go place. From donuts to funnel cake, BBQ to pizza this place was amazing. PS you can eat anything for breakfast.

Boyfriend and I were catching a wrestling show up in Philly and we decided to come here before the show. It's amazing and there's so much to take in, truly it's incredible. I recommend trying the ice cream place, the southern cooking place (with their watermelon iced tea!!!) And Fox something for corndogs, my apologies for not remembering their names!

Good food. Very crowded but a lot of choices. 
Great way to enjoy Philadelphia food.  Try Molly Mallow's cheesesteak sandwich.

One of the best there is!  Great choices.  Fresh produce.  Select cut meats.  Always bustling.  Always busy.  Great shops/stands/restaurants.  My favorite place is the Thai place located mid center.  Try the salmon curry w/broccoli and rice and you won't be disappointed.

This place is great, it's a must stop for me when I'm passing through Philly. Dicnics as well as many other eateries are worth the calories. Oh least I forget, I always buy a couple dozen from Wursthaus Schmitz!!!!!
Absolutely amazing!!  You can find almost anything you are looking for all under one roof.   Seating can be tough to find, but DiNic's and all of the other great merchants make it worth it!!

What can you write or say about the RTM that hasn't been said or written? Once you visit our historical treasures head over to RTM. Fresh produce and food from all over the globe. Take your high blood pressure and/or your diabetes medicine and ENJOY!!
This place is amazing. I love the different variety of foods and products. They need more seating options and the place needs to be bigger.

This is definitely my must visited spot in Philly. I stopped by here during my every single visit. There are a lot of vendors and restaurants to meet everyone's needs. 

My favorite places are Beck's Cajun Cafe, Miller's Twist, The Rib Stand, and Beiler's Donuts and Salads. And I loved how new places were opening up, restrooms were renovated and seating areas were rearranged throughout the years.

The parking deal is definitely a plus for this place.

The Reading (pronounced Redding) Terminal Market is a large indoor market that features restaurants, bakeries, food shops and delis. You have food options from a multitude of cultures and countries from locally grown, organic produce and diary to cheesesteaks, Indian dishes and soul food. It's very crowded and busy for most of the day and the only other downside is that it usually closes by 6 PM so you should make sure you go early if you are planning to eat your dinner in the market. I have stopped by quite a few times now while on vacation and I have still only tried a small portion of all the products available.

Came to philly this weekend and heard so many amazing things about the reading terminal market. There were so many choices to choose for food, desserts and goodies. Me and my boyfriend ate at Dinicos pulled pork. But they ran out of pulled pork so we opted for roast beef. SUPER YUMMY. 

For DESSERT we got Bassetts. We got the two scoop, cookies and cream with coffee. I'm not gonna lie but the scoops were hugeeeeee. They were so creamy and delicious.

LOVE THIS PLACE. Doesn't matter if you're a tourist or a local. I've come by here to get produce and lunch on several different occasions. I take the trolley into town from University City and shop. So many great places to grab food from. You will get a little lost inside, but there are maps to guide you. I had Nanee's and Kamal's and they were great. Pretty low prices as well. Bought fruits and vegetables from the produce shops and they were fresh.

Visiting Philly from California. This is our first time staying at the Residence Inn Marriott which is two blocks away from Reading Terminal Market. 

The Market closes at 6:00pm which we thought was unusual. We would have loved for it to stay open until at least 8:00pm, preferably 10:00pm. At 4:00pm the Amish bakery in the back of the Market offers many baked goods for $2.00. We bought half of a pumpkin cheesecake pie for $2.00, simply amazing. The pie was delicious! The sweet girl behind the counter would not accept a tip.

So many choices So little time. We walked around the marketplace and sampled different flavors of hummus, cheese, curd, and more. We were tempted by the many wonderful smells wafting through the market. 

Apparently the Bieler's Bakery is a popular place for donuts and people were standing in a long line to purchase. 

When you enter the Market, there is a welcome/information desk which was manned both times were there. People were stopping by to ask for directions or other questions.

The Market is a stop on the Big Bus tour.
Dinics, Old City Coffee, Terminis in that order on rotation.... simply the best.

A bustling market in the midst of a historical city is exactly what this is. My jaw was on the floor with alll the smells and options from hot sauces, breakfast options, BBQ, coffee, bake shops etc. I'm
From New York so it's hard to get me to like anything that isn't from here. But it's a must go to especially for the Dutch breakfast (which we missed) to the sandwiches and local delicacies that tingle the sense and boggle your tastebuds. I would go to philly again just to visit the reading market and try the Dutch breakfast which has a line you would not believe

I always always always love going here. It's a Philly experience that needs to be had. The atmostphere, the people, the food and different vendors. It's a must for visitors and locals alike. I have been many times and have eaten my way around that place. Miller's has the best pretzels and lemonade. Dinic's sandwiches are to die for. The Dutch stall has some delicious take home desserts. There are also some great cuts of meat for good prices. Basically everything you want is here.

This is a great old school market. It's not full of those hipster type stalls many markets have these days, but it does not need to be.  I was walking around here with my wife and I kept saying how if I lived here I would come here all the time to try all the delicious looking food from the wide variety of stalls.  The choices seem endless and that makes it very hard to choose. I ultimately chose a cheesesteak from By Georges, but I could have easily have been swayed in a number of different directions. Next time in Philly I will definitely be back to try something else.

This place is overwhelming. There are too many good choices! Not that it's a bad thing but WOW. Lol. Food was amazing though. Ended up sharing w/ my daughter because she couldn't finish her food. Fried rice was firrreeeeeeee.

Reading Terminal Market is a foodie adventure and a must visit for out of towners. Its crowded and chaotic here, but with so many delicious items to try and see, browsing can feel like a culinary safari. It gets very tight along the stalls, so do have patience as you go through. There are two large seating areas which are sufficient unless you're here at peak hours. Everything is well ventilated and lit, with ample air conditioning. Plan to spend about 2 hours here if you're from out of town, and try to visit at an off hour.

The food choices are epic. I enjoyed cajun, cheese steaks, italian sandwiches, hand made chocolates, pastries, and I made eyes at the fresh seafood stands and barbecue. There are also several stores to get specialty honey, produce, fresh meat or seafood, and bakeries. The cannolis at Termini Bros were a big favorite. I liked the Becks Cajun and DiNic's Roast Pork sandwich too. 

Bathrooms are well maintained. Parking is nearby in a deck, keep your ticket to get validated so you get a discount.

We arrived at the last hour and missed out on quite a bit. We knew that going in but it was the only free time we had where we could make it work. The interior of this huge building is filled with stall after stall of every kind of food imaginable... from roast pork sandwiches with rabe to chicken tikka masala to fresh filled cannoli! This places has got it all. 

There is also a fairly large produce mart right inside offering all kinds of fresh produce. If cheese is more your thing, or seafood or even meat, there are numerous stalls offering just what you need! 

Sit and eat or take home and create! I wish I had 3 more hours, an empty stomach and a much larger fridge the next time I visit!

Environment: Extremely busy, extremely culturally diverse, this is as good as it gets in regards to culture-shock. They have everything from groceries, to legitimate Amish places, to eating German food.

Service: Most shops are on par with the quickness and attentiveness to the service they provide.

Food: Food here is absolutely amazing. My favorite is finding Beck's Cajun and Beiler's doughnuts. These places offer some excellent homey food at an incredibly affordable price with excellent taste.

Restrooms: It's a public restroom, don't have the highest expectations.

Price: Great price from all the stores here! Nothing here is outrageously expensive and I wouldn't say I've walked in disgusted with the amount I've paid.
This is a great spot if you want to visit Philly and get a lil bit of everything. The combination of different food with the lil shops , deli it was a great mixture and cultural melting pot.

What more could one ask for?  Every kind of food purveyor under one roof centrally located in the middle of Center City .  Was probably ore of a kick before the fixed the place up and tourists make it a stop but its still a great place to eat and shop.  You have to have a smile on your face when you come out.

If you don't know where to eat in philly, this is the place for you!
This place is super cool. You can literally get everything and anything here. From desserts to produce to breakfast! 
It is overwhelming if you don't know what you want. I just searched for the most popular thing to get here which was Tommy Dinic's! My boyfriend and I shared a roast pork sandwich. While it was good, it wasn't amazing IMO but this place sure is.
If i'm ever in philly again, this is the first place that I would stop by!
A must see!!! We went multiple times just to eat various foods!!!  Finding a place to sit is difficult and tables were dirty so bring your own wet wipes to clean. The crepes place was to die for!!!

There are tons of things to do in Philly. Philly is known for having some of the best sandwiches in the country. So great that we are imitated all over the world.

The best place to get some of the best food and sandwiches is in the Reading  Terminal Market. There is literally nothing that you can't find in this place. They have hoagies, baked goods, Chinese Food, sea food, burgers, buffets, and a diner. They also have butcher shops and produce stands to get great fresh meats and produce from. This is one of my favorite places to go due to the variety of product selection that is available.

It does get kind of busy but that just ads to the atmosphere.

It is a place that everyone needs to visit when they are in Philadelphia.

If you park, park at the garage across the street. Most places in the market will validate your parking and it will only cost $4.00.

ALL THE HEART DESIRES IN ONE PLACE. The Reading Terminal Market is a staple for citizens and tourists in Philly. You can go grocery shopping for some fresh produce- then go around the whole place to try everything that stands out- donuts, seafood, burgers, wraps, fries, grilled cheese! There are multiple food courts spread around for people to sit down and enjoy their food!
An incredible sensory experience. Dinics pork and rabe was simple, delicious, and worth the trip. The crepes and doughnuts were equally perfect.
The reading. Market. Is a okay place. Food is excellent but service sucks people are ignorant they don't help u and the clients or customers are the worst
Love this place, I buy all my vegetables here. They have great food with good price as well. I only wish they would close later in the evenings.

This place is fantastic!  They have everything you want or need. Two cheesesteak places, multipolar sweet shops, Icecream, seafood. Even jewelry and fresh produce. They have seats that you can sit down and eat or get it to go. Great for lunch. Close to hotels and shopping.
So freaking cool , first time here and the food selection was incredible , not to mention all of the delicious deserts ! One of a kind market place !! Will be going back !

Reading Terminal Market is pretty big and it kinda feels like walking around in a big maze. You'll see some places selling Philly cheesesteak (obviously), fresh seafood, homemade pastries, homemade chocolates, and many more!!! I recommend walking around the market first before deciding on what to eat and also having a friend to help reserve a table since this place is a tourist spot and it can get very crowded.

The places that I tried so-far:
1) Tommy DiNic's- I had the roast pork with broccoli rabe. It was OK, but nothing memorable.
2) Spataro's Cheesesteaks- I had cheesesteak with mushrooms. I also ordered the tater tots. Both were good.
3) Carmen's Famous Italian Hoagies- I had the classic cheesesteak. There's saute onions, mushrooms, cheese wiz, and peppers (i.e. sweet or hot). I really like the sandwich and it's so flavorful! I also got the coleslaw. It was good but there was too much mayo. I'll comeback here again for sure.

Be sure to put Reading Terminal Market on your list when visiting Philly. Come here for breakfast, lunch, or an early dinner.

Wish I would have come to this place first instead of wasting my time and money going to Geno's (yuck). The Reading Market had everything and then some. The sub sandwiches were super yummy, I think I ate two within an hour (don't tell my wife she thinks that I only ate one, lol) 
The bakeries were yes, yes, and yes. I had some kind of Carmel pecan cheesecake that was so good that I almost called home to Houston and told my boss that I quit cause I am moving to philly!
I will for sure be eating at this place a few more times before we head back to Houston.

This place has ANY type of food you could want. After attending a conference in Philly for several days, I had no desire to venture too far from the area. I purchased a grilled cheese sandwich with chicken, roasted tomato and three different cheeses from a place that makes their own cheese. It was the best food I've had in a while. I also purchased the best Carmel chocolate chip cookie from one of the places. I will be going back to try something different today. This place is heaven on earth.
Love the variety.  Many delicious choices.  Just a bit crowded and difficult to find a seat.

What an experience to come to this place. If you like to eat and sightseeing, it is a good place. There are a lot of varieties food from multi countries. The only negative is the parking space and expensive parking fee.

I was in from out of town, and once I saw the reviews on yelp, I knew I had to check this place out. Reading Terminal Market did not disappoint! There is something here for everyone. We were able to try multiple restaurants within the market. I was a little upset that the line for the donut shop was going around the whole market, but that just goes to tell you how good it must be! I was able to try the ice cream, which was amazing! Overall, i would say checking this place out is a must!
Hope it never leaves! All kinds of goodies! I love the fresh meats and the fact that it was actually a train terminal in the eighteenth century

Reading Terminal allows only certain people to become vendors in there market. While the Dutch are millionaires they wont allow other vendors to come in. I really hate the underground politics going there. More Philadelphia small business owners need to have a chance to showcase there goods.The place could be remodeled to have more vendor space. Most of the stores dont need that much space. Also the upstairs should open for people to eat and vendors are only down stairs.. Check the dates on food before you buy. If you buy a cake from the dutch make sure its not frozen that means its not as fresh. Ask for a thawed cake. Would reccomemed for tourist especially .They will enjoy.

Great spot - super busy, which I found exciting and an experience enhancer. Definitely recommend the roast pork sandwich at Dinic's. Beiler's donuts, while special, are overrated in my opinion. Overall, the kind of place that you can get lost in and just enjoy. Make sure you give yourself enough time to see everything if you're visiting for the first time (2-3 hours is probably sufficient).
This place makes me wish that I lived in a Philadelphia so that I can try all the amazing food stands inside.
Just can't miss this place.  Outstanding experience just to walk around and see all of the choices...but great food options as well.  Had a Philly cheesesteak today.  Choices are endless.

We were in Philadelphia staying at the Hilton Garden Hotel and asked the front desk if there was someplace good to eat within walking distance.  They recommended the Reading Terminal Market and said it was just around the corner.
We had no idea what this was but took the walk and was pleasantly surprised to find everything inside. Tons of places to eat about anything anyone could want, a market, bakery, etc.....
We chose the deli and opted for the corned beef sandwich.  It was huge and tasted fantastic.  There are so many choices that you could go there every day and have something totally different each day.  
The Reading Terminal Market is certainly a place to stop, especially if you have a group of folks with different tastes.  
It is a bit hectic inside and not easy to maneuver around the place but there is no shortage of interesting things to find inside.
We would definitely go there again the next time we are in Philadelphia.

The Reading Terminal Market (RTM) is a foodie haven! It's one of the most well-known indoor markets in the country, so stopping by is a must if you're in Philadelphia.

PROS:
- Multiple dining options! From Cajun dishes to homey soul food and delicious breakfast and brunch items, there is a little bit of everything for everyone.
- Moreover, there is always something new during your next visit! With all of the vendors inside, it is difficult to eat everything you see in one visit.
- $4 parking at 2 different garages for 2 hours! All you need to do is take your parking ticket, spend $10 at ONE vendor and have that place validate it for you before you return to your vehicle and pay.
- The vendors are all friendly. Smiles were abound and enticing dishes were everywhere to be found!

CONS:
- Crowded and touristy. I accidentally "shouldered" a high schooler (or middle schooler?) from out of town because of how crowded this place gets (and because he was hogging the aisle).
- The open seating area is limited. You have two options: Wait for a table to open up OR you could join one. Some vendors, like Molly Malloys, have their own seating area. My family and I were fortunate enough to grab a table after a few minutes of waiting and, seconds later, two people joined us at the table. I'm totally fine with this, but hopefully part of the ongoing construction includes additional seating areas.
- Lines, lines, lines! Everyone wants a taste of the delicious doughnuts at Beiler's or the famous Roast Pork Sandwich from DiNic's, so expect to wait awhile at the popular vendors/stalls.

All things considered, RTM is a great place to grab a bite or even shop for a few groceries! I love the idea of indoor markets and food halls, so visiting this place was a great experience. I'm looking forward to my next visit.
Do not miss the opportunity to visit the Reading Terminal Market!

This market is awesome! They offer a wide variety of food for such a small establishment. My only complaints are the prices, which can be understandable for some of the places depending on what they offer, and the lack of air conditioning. If you go to this place during their peak hours, aka weekends, it gets hot and packed very easily. My personal favorites are Martin's Specialty Sausages and Famous 4th St Cookie Co.

I absolutely love this place. 

I've tried soul foods, cheesesteak sandwiches, and more and they were all delicious!

It's not super clean, it's always very busy, and people aren't too friendly but I think that's what gives character to this spot.  And I'm okay with it. Lol

Btw...don't forget to have one of the merchant validate your parking ticket if you park across the market. It's $10 off (more money to buy foods with...haha!)

Great market!!! Would definitely visit again. We stopped by dinics and got amazing pork sandwiches with provolone make sure to get brocolli with it. I also stopped by a candy shop and got dark chocolate covered candied ginger that was amazing.

Alright, I remember the first time I went to the reading terminal and being overwhelmed by the barrage of smells, noise, and people walking back and forth experiencing this massive food/dining market all at the same time. In order to save you, my readers from doing the same research I did to find the 'best of the best,' 

Here is a list of my suggestions (you can view my personal reviews as needed)

1. Any pretzels from Miller's twist - $2.5 (soooo delicious)
2. Roast pork sandwich from DiNic's - $8-10 (very intense provolone taste, voted best in many food magazines)
3. Gumbo at Beck's Cajun Cafe - $10 (lots of flavors, big bowel, a little bit salty)

Additional things to try (from other viewers)
1. Beiler's doughnuts
2. Roast duck noodle platter at Sang Kee Peking Duck House
3. Apple dumplings at Dutch Eating Place

If you want to explore, I'd recommend going aisle by aisle first to see what's available before you settle down. Here's my recs:

Step 1 - walk and explore
Step 2 - choose where you want food(s) from
Step 3 - find a table (hardest part)
Step 4 - have one person sit there and then get food.
Step 5 - don't forget to get napkins and utensils
Step 6 - eat and repeat

My favorite market I've been to thus far ever, even including markets in Europe! This is a must visit spot when you are in Philly and it's pretty much about killing all your food spots in one hit...if your stomach has space for it!

Come hungry and come alert. If you can, tag team with someone to try multiple vendors and also have someone to save seats if possible!

This place is so awesome! There are so many choices for food; including ready to eat and markets to pick up for home. It's great that everything is indoors and together under one building so you can experience all the flavors at once. Will definitely return! Loved it!
Awesome place, loved all of the food options and freshness of everything. A little crowded during lunch, but was still a pleasant experience.

Over the years I have naturally enjoyed the market to get a quick bite, grab some produce, or feed my sweet tooth. There are days where I walk in and can freely roam exploring what new items are in. Other days I get to see the excitement of tourist and locals "excusing" their way to a vendor in order to feed their bellies. I personally like the quieter times which is after lunch. 
Lines move quickly although and all the vendors have great service. The downside is that some vendors are overpriced but, overall it's the place to go. 

My favorite spot is the Dutch Eating Place. Great food and great service. When I worked down the street, their Turkey sandwich with gravy was my go to! Walk a little further and you can pick up Delish Hope's cookies at the Pennsylvania General Store.

I just returned from Seattle and their mighty Pike Market, therefore I couldn't help but compare. Bottom line, this market has nothing on Pike. It's a place for locals and probably tourists. But when I return to Philly, this will not need a revisit. 

Soap Lady is the coolest spot. Everything else can easily be obtained from other locations.
great place - good selection of eats, interesting mix of  people (Amish servers, office crews, and wide eyed jurors), great CC respite.

Chances are, if you're visiting Philly, you're gonna check this place out. If not, you need to. The legendary Reading Terminal Market lives up to its legendary status. You can find literally anything here. Exciting, bustling atmosphere, and even better smells. You don't want to pass up a trip to this place. The parking garage across the street is the easiest way to park. $4 for 2 hours. You can't beat that. Make sure you come hungry.
Love love!  Buy groceries here once a week.  Two hours free parking in the structure.  Nice local grocery items.  Cheaper than Whole Foods.  As a local I recommend.

All I can say is WOW!  The Reading Terminal Market is the best I have ever been to.  This is a foodie's dream come true.  So many choices that it will send an indecisive person into a tailspin.  Trying to determine what to eat for lunch has got to be a difficult decision because everything looks delicious and exciting.  We arrived looking for breakfast and since it was late, we happened upon Smuckers which made a hearty and tasty bacon, egg, and cheese on a roll.  Tons of produce and fresh meat selections that the locals tend to take advantage of.  This is an absolute must for all tourists.  I would recommend using transportation to and from because it can be a bit of a hike.

I love this market and visited almost a year ago. My rating still remains five stars due to its wonderful epicurean nature. This market is huge: 78000 square feet with 800 spaces for different vendors.
There is an eclectic variety to choose from: bakeries, dairy and cheese, seafood(lobster!), produce and specialty foods.
There are also House ware and book vendors who sell wonderful cookbooks. There are 24 restaurants that can satisfy every craving from the classic Philly cheese steaks to New Orleans Cajun style fare.
Here are a few of my favorites:
Meltkraft: delicious  artisanal cheese sandwiches that do melt in your mouth.
The Flying Monkey Bakery: cupcakes from Spinoni to red velvet and my fave lemon. The buttercream frosting is so rich and delicious. When you fellow Yelpers check in you get a free truffle, we got a chocolate mint. The clerk was so nice and let me keep my check in redeem offer for next visit!
TerraLynn Soaps: where else are you going to find a Shalom soap bar( citronella and lemon). Also coconut oil toothpaste!
La Divisa Meats: allowed my friend to sample the pastrami( she loved it 2 big slices to sample!)
I love the vibe of this place. There are seating interspersed throughout where you sit and mingle: we met someone from Ottawa who recommended a Cuban restaurant to eat at.
The Reading Terminal Market is a virtual feast for eyes, ears and definitely palate!

LOVELOVELOVE Reading Terminal Market (which is apparently pronounced like "Redding"? according to my philly friends). So many choices that we couldn't decide on just one. I shared Keven Parker Soul Food Cafe (leg and thigh w/ one side - mac&cheese), Sang Kee Peking Duck (peking duck roll), Kamal's Middle Eastern Specialties (lemonana - mint, rosewater, and lemon juice/smoothie), and Beiler's Donuts (coconut custard). Everything was amazing and I wish I had more room in my stomach for everything (and maybe money). It was slightly crowded but it was lunch time and a very popular tourist location. There were numerous seating areas in the middle of market and other seating at certain merchants. I would definitely come again and try different places!

So living in Philly u try to avoid some of the more tourist filled areas but RTM is one of those places NOT to avoid. I swear there is magic in that building. It's almost like the entire energy of our amazing city culminates in this one place and I love that.
Whether it's the sites, the smells, the cultures, or the languages all around you, it's like a sensory overload in the best of ways.  It's the one place in the city where you can dive into the Indian culture with the best samosas and curries in town, or take a trip to Germany and taste some of their delectable sausages, or stay right in the USA and be smack in the middle of creole country with some Cajun crocodile on a plate...it's amazing all the culinary experiences you can have in one place. I guess that's why it is truly my favorite place in the city, it's always where I tell tourists to go should they ask, and it's always a place I take friends and family when they visit. 
I never leave without a Millers Twist salted pretzel and I always have to stop in the little Pennsylvania Dutch candy shop for some sweet treats, it's become a ritual that I enjoy more and more every time. 
Some days I just want to find a spot to sit in RTM and watch the city go by, it's a magical place.

I love this market!!  Drove to Philly for the day with some friends and when I tell you that RTM is a - MUST GO TO spot!  If you're a foodie then go RTM - make sure to stop at Beiler's Doughnuts.  They are delicious (definitely try the apple fritters one)!

This is my favorite place to visit in all of Philadelphia.  I come frequently for business and am disappointed if I cannot swing by at least once per visit.  I am a foodie and this place is nirvana.  Words cannot adequately describe the hustle and bustle or the mind boggling selections there.  It needs to be experienced.  On my first visit, it was almost too much to take in at once.  Sensory overload, and I am a New Yorker!  Whatever you have a hankering for will be there.  Just be patient and you'll stumble on it.
This place has individual restaurant stalls with every kind of food you can imagine in a very cool bustling high energy setting. That is all you need to know. Go there.
WOW! There is a lot going on here.  If you're in Philly be sure to check this place out.  They have just about something for everyone's taste here.....

It is definitely a mass of humanity, but if you can navigate a crowd, this place is a must. Great place for a foodie to grab a bite. Everything you can impossibly imagine and then some. Different types of foods, baked goods, florists, books, wine...you name, it's there. Some of the lines can be long, but if you're in a hurry to grab a bite, there are plenty of just as tasty options that you can get your food incredibly quick. Everyone I've encountered that works there is great, as well.

Definitely a must-go if you are in Philly! I try to go somewhere new each time and I'm blown away each and every time. Tommy Dinic's and Hershel's are probably my favorites. There are some really great places for sweets and desserts. To top it all of there is a nice bar you can grab a drink at. Check it out you won't be disappointed!

Best in Philly. If you're ever shopping in center City you must go there for a bite to eat. Enjoyable time.

John H
I have had some bad experiences there. It's good to see or to stop by during jury duty. Great for tourist to see.
Crazy crazy place, I love it! Such an electric mix of food, culture,  and people. I saw people from all over the word exploring without fear or prejudice. It is an amazing experience l

The Reading terminal is a place that you could find yourself lost four hours. If you walk you will find something new at every turn. It would take hours to visit every shop, you will have to be there from the time it opens until the time it closes. While shopping at the Reading terminal you will find tourists well as regulars. There are families that have been shopping for generations at The Reading Terminal, my grandmother. my aunt, now me. There's something family and familiar like about the Reading Terminal. You can shop for meat, vegetables, coffee, tea, candy, pastries breads and smokes. There are also deli's and restaurants, stop and have lunch or purchase a souvenir.

Many small businesses got their start here. Some have moved onto bigger and  better things. But it is a place where all can come to find something that they need in their day or in their life. It is a fast-paced environment for most of the stores that  handle a high-volume. Please be prepared to know what you want to order. Most of the stores will walk you through the process or give you some pointers as to the best buy or the most popular item. I say grab a friend and have lunch!

If you can make it at a not-super crowded time, it'll be much easier to move around. Even if it's crowded, take in the sites and smells of this place cause there's no other place like it in Philly! Don't forget to get some ice cream on the way out, too!
The go to spot for everything food. Always keep an eye on the unique hours, but make sure you stop in if you're new to Philly or here for the day. You won't leave disappointed.

One of the best places on earth.  Tons of variety and choices.  From take home groceries and prepared foods to fruits and veggies this place has it all.  Make sure you have cash before you arrive.  Most places are cash only.  And parking can be a bit tough.

We stayed in the hotel across the street and this was a very exciting surprise. We knew the city market was here, but we were still overwhelmed by the size and diversity of it. It had so many different things to eat and try -not as many places to sit.

We went at lunch time so the place was a buzz with life. We stopped by again later for dessert. Love this place. If you want to experience the culmination of a city, the city market is the place to go and Philly does it right.

My nephew went here on a field trip and asked to be taken there again. We made a whole trip around it and actually went twice. It's very overwhelming and crowded with very little seating but that would be the only negative things I could say. This place is LOADED with great little shops and so many varieties of things! We had food, and milkshakes and smoothies. We bought cookie cutters and passion fruit curd and spice rubs. I wish there was something like this everywhere! Parking is expensive but that is everywhere in Philadelphia and if you spend 10.00 at any merchant inside they validate your parking and it's half price!
Always a fun time to go to reading terminal. They have great food and you can find decently priced fruit at some of the various stands.

Best place to try local Philly cuisine. I live nearby and shop here regularly for my food. You can buy pretty much anything at fair prices. The quality is very good. 

I always bring out of town guests here and they absolutely love it. It's a fun place, the excitement of a town market is something that is lost in American Culture. 

My only qualm is that it is not open later in the evening for dinner.
Great place to eat and people-watch. Reminds me of the grand central market in downtown Los Angeles, but bigger. great atmosphere and fair prices. Lines weren't too long either.
Really cool place - an all indoor market with great food options. Love stopping in for cheesesteaks and cannolis!!

I adore RTM. I shop here every single weekend for the local produce and for meat from the butchers. Really, anything you can think of, they have it. Local honey, cook books, cookies, sweets, herbs, etc. 

It does get REALLY crowded later in the day so I recommend going first thing in the morning. Not all of the shops are open on Sundays, so if you want to see everything, make it a Saturday!
Love it! It's indoors, nicely air-conditioned. There is a great selection of food, and specialty items.  Come hungry, walk around first, then decide what to eat.
A nice place to surf or walk around. Find music art and mostly food. Nice bunch of people around from painter to piano players.I have fun every time I come and go somewhere different.

One of my favorite places in Philadelphia. A large variety of almost anything. I try to stop here every time I am in Philly, just to see what's new, find some things I don't need, but can't live without, and stop at some of the delectable food places. I cannot go home without having at least one or two of the turkey sandwiches, stop by the coffee store, butcher and German deli. And that's just for starters.
The farmers market, ice cream, and cheesesteaks are also worth a stop.
There are usually some minor changes with new vendors, etc. There is ample parking that is reasonable close by.

If you can't find something to please your palate here, I pity you. I love the Mexican cantina, the fresh vegetables, the unfrozen poultry, the german hot dogs, and the fact that just about everyone there appreciates good food.
This place is my second home. I love the fish and fruits aisle. Definitely a place to check out !

What can I say? I love this place. From the lattes and coffee at old city coffee, to the gift shops, countless food counters which I've never eaten anything I didn't like from... it's all great. The only bad thing about it is that it does get really crowded at peak times and I tried two of their bottled wines from the store that sells them with reading terminal market labels and they were horrible. Definitely check this place out if you are in philly!

This place was heaven. So many variety of food in such a compact area. The only problem is that there are so many people here during lunch hours. That and the fact that it closes early than I'm used to. There is such a diverse range of food that I'm pretty sure you can find what you want just by walking around for 15 minutes. Chinese, cajun, soul food, BBQ, dessert, breakfast, candy, groceries, there is just so much to this little terminal. There is also a seating area that had a piano and live music. It was very cute.

The pretzels at this amish looking section was so incredible. Buttery goodness with mustard dipping. This was definitely the most memorable thing after eating some ice cream and jambalaya and trying out gator meat gumbo.

I truly loved this place so much! I've been to many major cities that have markets like this, and I have got to say that the variety of stalls at this place was amazing! Everything from ice cream stores to flower shops to little trinkets...definitely a must visit, especially if it is your first time in Philly like it was mine! 

I would personally suggest to make a lap around the place maybe once or even twice (I did twice) only because there is so much to choose from and you can't obviously eat so much. 

I started with Bassett's which by the way is so amazing! The salted caramel swirl is an absolute must, I paired it with a mint chocolate chip. 

Then I went to Wan's seafood for some amazing friend seafood! The scallops were 85 cents a piece and the jumbo shrimp was $2.75. 

The ambiance was that of a typical market. Very loud and a lot going on. I wouldn't suggest coming here with a lot of little kids, especially if you are afraid of losing them because this place can get pretty crowded! 

Only quirk about this place is that seating is incredibly hard to find, so don't bank on it! But for a place this great I'm not surprised!
An iconic place. Awesome food, traditionally Philly favs, vendors and just plain awesomeness. When coming to Center City you have to stop by here to eat...period!

Very nice indoor public market. Reminded me of Grand Central Market in LA, but this public market is so much better. The grocer and restaurant stalls in this store are all real nice.  I stopped by the Dutch Eating Place and had an excellent breakfast. This is a really nice place to visit, even to just walk through and be tempted by the delicious looking items. I saw many real good items, especially from bakery and grocer stores, that looked real good. 

If you're coming from the airport, this is just a short walk from the Suburban Station that you can reach by taking the train. The train is real convenient here, very easy to take from the airport and only $6.75 for anone way trip.

What can I say?      From Famous 4th street cookies to Hershels East side Deli........Whatever you're hungry for, you can eat there or find all the ingredients necessary to prepare a great meal at home.
great food. 10/10 would recommend. very crowded so it's a great spot to people watch.. if ya know what i mean
Come hungry!  Wide variety and it's all good.

A must see when visiting Philly.. It has everything from wood earrings to kitchen seasonings. Its a good mixture of vendors with all the foods you can think of. I was able to have coffee, a rib lunch and take home a bag of loose tea leaves and seasonings.. I could have also picked up my fresh fruits, meats and breads if i wanted. Be sure to stop in take a walk around and see what you can discover.

A must-visit when in Philly! Eat breakfast at one of the many spots for farm fresh foods! Anything your heart desires you can find there. The chocolates are made in all shapes, and if it's seafood you want, cheese you need....it is here! Breads, desserts, cut flowers, and even artwork is displayed proudly. This is a heady experience and a treat for all ages....what w wonderful place!
Really large food market. Don't expect "cool" and "unique" foods that you wouldn't find at normal take out type places except for the donuts .  Most of the stands were typical fast food type places.

I have traveled to Philly for over 10 years for work and this is hands down the best place to go for lunch.

There are so many choices that it can be overwhelming if you are not sure what you want to eat, but there is something for everyone.

It can be very busy at lunchtime especially if there is a convention going on and it can be hard to find a seat.  Your best bet is to try and go after 1pm it seems to thin out a bit.

I definitely have my favorite places but I always try to go somewhere new on each visit.

Stop in you won't be disappointed!

There's no question that I love Reading Terminal Market.  So much that I actually went twice during my last visit to Philadelphia even though it wasn't planned.  In reality though, if you're visiting from out-of-town, you'll definitely need more than one day to try a good amount of the many food vendors it has to offer.

I covered a lot during those two days:  Beiler's Bakery, Dutch Eating Place, Tommy DiNic's, Keven Parker Soul Food Cafe, and Beck's Cajun Cafe.  All good eats and I highly recommend trying them all if you have a chance.  And even though that may seem a lot, there's still a multitude of over vendors I still have yet to try.  Maybe next time I'll try more of them, but it might be hard to sway from my favorites above, especially Dutch Eating Place and Tommy DiNic's, both which I already tried from my last Philly visit 4 years ago.

Like I stated in my previous review, Reading Terminal Market is truly a great sampling of what Philadelphia has to offer in terms of food.  And I don't think I can ever get tired of the place!

No food courts (God, how I hate that term!) in the United States quite compare to Reading Terminal Market, IMHO. I mean it.

Not Pike Place in Seattle, nor even one of the many comparable markets in New York is quite the same.

The variety really makes it great, as does the quality of the average restaurant here.

For example, this Southern boy loves to grab a soul food meal, but my traveling buds often prefer to wander some distance away and grab bagels elsewhere, or seafood, or Creole, or a cheesesteak at Carmen's, or, well, you get the general picture here.

Prices are generally quite modest, as these eateries are serving masses of hungry people who demand good food at reasonable prices.

Not a good choice, though, if hustle and bustle freak you out.

In Philly? You really MUST stop here for an hour or two. (Take my word for this. It's a very important part of any good Philadelphia visit itinerary.)

Awesome indoor market place with all sorts of goodies from southern comforts, randomly shaped chocolate dipped stuff, Amish donuts and baked goods, unique deli sandwiches, fresh produce, to local butcher shops. I used to be able to throw down 3,4,5 plates at any buffet, now I'm tapping out after half a sandwich and a cup of coffee  I'm in town for the weekend, we'll get in some other goods before we head back home.

Love this place.. soooo
Many food and very affordable. From seafood to burger to Mediterranean to Asian and desserts.. can't beat that cuz it's all under one roof.. one days isn't enough for a visit. Because my stomach can't hold everything I want to try.. lol..
GREAT FOOD SELECTION !!! most places do cash though so that's a drawback, but such a philly gem !

If your coming to philly make sure you stop at Reading Terminal Market. This place is amazing. There is a vast variety of food, fresh fruits, veggies, chocolates, ice cream, and plenty of other things. You name it it's here. Check out Blue Mountain winery the selection is great I loved all of the wines I tried.
So cool! Couldn't make up my mind what I wanted! It was great just walking around and seeing all of the different restaurants and stores.
If you come to Philly this is a must do! You will be overwhelmed by choices and fresh food and produce to offer! Go to franks try the pineapple cornbread and the bakeries are all very good!!

Pure fabulousness. They have everything from cheese, seafood, fruit, donuts, chocolate, cake candy, donuts and seafood. Super busy and super crowded but worth the visit.

I see where people are coming from, calling it a tourist trap, but I don't think that's completely accurate as I know many locals including myself who enjoy stopping by. At times it can get overwhelmingly crowded with people squeezing and shoving in the narrower halls, so I try to come at off times. 

It's like LA's Grand Central Market, a massive building filled with all kinds of vendors. There's fresh produce, every cuisine ranging from Indian to Cajun, kitchenware, spices, butchers, and bakeries. Now that's not to say that all of the vendors are good. Honestly, I've found the food to be pretty hit or miss, and the vast majority to be average. Maybe I'm missing the good places, but I still like this place for its vibe even if not for its food.

Wish I had more time to explore this market and try more foods/drinks here. You can tell just by walking through that they have a lot of delicious foods from different parts of the world and that people are enjoying themselves.

From D.C to Reading Terminal is worth the drive, this place is huge and has so many options. There's speciality grocery stores within the market, that's how everybody gets the produce to cook and make their own stuff in their restaurants. Went to the famous donut shop and the Phili cheese steak oh yes everything in their is good
Overwhelming ! So many different types of food and places to eat. Must see for yourself. There has to be a food for everyone's liking here.

This place is amazing! It was listed as one of the places to check out in Philly. It was right around the corner of my hotel so this was my first stop in Philadelphia. The atmosphere is crazy but everyone is very nice and helpful. If you don't quite know what you want to eat and need options this is somewhere you should be. We saw everything from pizza to donuts, vegetarian to Asian. The market has dozens of shops, most selling fresh food or produce. It definitely can be a little overwhelming if you aren't ready for the amount of noise and people but it is definitely worth the trip. With so many choices you may find yourself going round and round seeing where your taste buds lead you.

You can easily get lost in unique balsamic vinegars and olive oils while also tasting great chocolates or even food showcased on cooking channels. It is also indoors which is a plus to escape hot or cold days in the city. The diverse little markets and restaurants make the Reading Terminal Market a Philly a must see!

What is there to say about the Reading Terminal Market?  They have everything.  It is a true gem in Philly.  Our favorites include Beiler's for donuts, Olympia Gyro, The Tubby Olive and the Hatville Deli.  Singling out merchants here is tough though.  There are so many great places.  The market is a great for breakfast and lunch.  Highly recommend visiting when you're in town!

This is the daily Philadelphia food festival! There's always something good to choose from and so many options that you can literally play roulette with the vendors here and never lose! Highly recommended and perfect for a lunch break!
My favorite place to eat in Philly! You can find anything you want and the atmosphere is great for tourists and newcomers. If you touristy is what you want, they serve great cheesesteaks!

A wonderful timeless Philadelphia tradition.  I have been going her for more than 45 years.  It has evolved and changed over the years, but always a great place to eat, and people watch.  Wonderful food options be sure you don't choose the first one you see or you will be frustrated.  A sampling of the finest foods from all over the Philadelphia area and surrounding counties.

Great spot to go for food! There are many different options for food, along with small shops. Definitely one of the top places to stop by if you're visiting the city. There are also a variety of bars close. Chinatown is also within walking distance.

Whatever food you're in the mood for, you'll probably find it a reading terminal. There is also a great bakery and butcher shop! Amish goodies and fresh made baked goods. The prices here are fair and there is usually plenty of space to sit and enjoy. My favorite place here always was the jewish deli, they have LEGIT pastrami sandwiches!!!

Really fun market with a variety of food! Range of seafood to Asian food and lots of baked goods as well... my friend and I ran out of time to try the Peking duck but we managed to take beilers donuts to go and they are some of the tastiest donuts I've had!
Love the atmosphere! Always glad to be here. Great seafood/sandwiches/and of course yummy desserts

Absolutely obsessed with Reading Terminal Market. The made to order food is, of course, phenomenal but it's also an amazing (and affordable!) place to do my grocery shopping. The merchants are friendly and helpful and are always open to letting you try things, giving you advice, or offering great meal pairings. It's also a great place for Philly-themed gifts and one-of-a-kind items.

The food choices is amazing. I hate the long lines and it is hard for me to find a seat to eat. I use to go the gallery to sit down but it is under construction. The energy is like no other but those improvement would make it so much better.
They have the best donuts especially the glazed strawberry filled donut ( recommended)

Love all that the terminal has to offer... except I can't stand the crowds of tourists and convention center patrons on certain occasions. Also, I wish some of the vendors were open a little later past 5PM..

Coming to Philly for the first time, tons of my friends suggested me to check out Reading Terminal Market. It literally is a one stop market that has literally everything from groceries, desserts, and different food stalls. Walking into the Market was so overwhelming. It was a Sunday afternoon and it was so packed. However, the AC was on high and there was still a lot of tables available for seating.

If you are looking to try different things, this is the place for you.

The food ordered:
1. Beck's Cajun 
-Mac and cheese balls with BACON. Yes, with bacon.
-Chicken gumbo
The seasoning was so rich in this gumbo. I couldn't put my spoon down.

2. Carmen's Philly cheesesteak and Hoagies
I waited 20 minutes on line to order 2 cheese steaks. Yes, it's a long wait but it was totally worth it
-Classic cheesesteak
-Kamikaze cheesesteak (side note: it wasn't really spicy at all unfortunately

3. Hershel's East Side Deli
-3 meats platter
You are in for a real treat, 3 treats actually.

4. Flying Monkey
-Krispi Treat
Expensive, but good! LOTS of choices!! Pay your parking tho, so you don't get a ticket!! Lol..

Reading terminal is like an Amish market in the middle of the city. You can get just about anything here. Donuts, seafood, Asian fusion, cheese steak sandwiches, Even produce!! If have been here quite a few time while passing and I look forward to coming back again.

Lots to see and eat. There is a sit down diner, wine, and a produce market to boot. Many choices for cheesesteaks, Asian cuisine, and dessert. Ice cream at Bassets, Amish breakfast, and Dinic's are good choices.

Food halls are on trend right now, but Reading Terminal Market has been ahead of the game for years. Being in Pennsylvania, a large part of the market is made up of Amish businesses such as Beiler's (one word - donuts), Smucker's (great breakfast sandwiches), Dutch Eating Place (order the hot apple dumpling), and more. There are also sandwich shops like Tommy Dinic's, Carmen's, Beck's Cajun Cafe (order the mac n cheese balls), ethnic food stalls serving Chinese, Indian, and Thai cuisine, and bakeries such as Termini Bros, Flying Monkey Bakery (get some whoopie pies). Not to mention great ice cream, cookies, fresh smoothies and juices...all this and so much more, in addition to fresh product, deli meats, and cookware. I'm not exaggerating with I say Reading Terminal Market is one of my favorite places - period. It's a Philadelphia institution and food lover's heaven, and a must visit when in town. I haven't been anywhere comparable in the country, and there is a charming and welcoming feeling about Reading that newer, more modern food halls lack. I always make a stop here when in Philly, and hope it's not too long before I visit again.

So many good eats in one place!

It's super packed in here on weekends. There is a parking lot nearby the market. You can get your parking ticket validated for a discounted price if you eat somewhere inside the Reading Terminal.
