There are so many food options in here, so come hungry. They sell fresh fish, fruits, veggies, baked goods, meats, flowers, etc. Employees around the market are so friendly and helpful. Restrooms are in the back and clean. There is a lot of seating around the market but they all get taken during weekends. I'm sure if you come here on a weekday, you will have an easier time finding a seat. There is just so much to see in here, we had to walk around a bunch of times to make sure we didn't miss anything. Everywhere you look there is something yummy calling your name. 

A food lovers paradise.
Love spending time here and seeing what the myriad of vendors have to offer.  Sundays the Amish area is closed so go a different day unless you don't care about some delicious baked goods
Great experience, Great food. Four of us went for lunch we all ordered something different, from different shops and enjoyed all of it. I wish I had more time to spend there!

Overcrowded market with nothing fancy. Just a tourist trap and living in Philadelphia I say please don't fall for this trap. There are far better markets than this one. It's a waste of time and the food is nothing amazing. Just over hyped and cashing in on the tourists. Produce is also overly priced. I would rather go to other supermarkets. But trust me you won't miss anything besides the crowd in this so called hyped up market

This is the best food hall I've ever been to (granted I haven't been to many, but this one is a must do in Philly). Was very crowded on a Saturday at 4:30pm. 

The building is right downtown - an old train terminal converted to a huge, open area absolutely packed with local purveyors. It seemed like there were close to 100 sellers, offering meats, fresh veggies, baked goods, ice cream, coffee,  flowers, tons of international cuisine, and more. There are atms, a small seating area and bathrooms. 

I only had the time and appetite for the ice cream from Bassetts (which was great) but I definitely want to go back to try others. If long lines are any fair judgment of how good a place is, then I need to try the donuts from Beiler's - the line wrapped around half the market. 

I could totally spend a couple hours here at least. Check it out if you're in town.
Must visit if you come to Philly. A real, Culture, as well as, Culinary experience, in the Heart of the City. It has everything that typifies the City.

Holy agoraphobia Batman, there are too many people here! But that means it's good right? Yasss.

Reading Terminal Market (pronounced Redding, according to locals) is downtown, was walking distance from our hotel, is always busy, and is full of diverse delicious options (tho you may not have a place to sit when you get your food).  

If you ever go out to eat with me, you know my first 5 or 6 orders are just practice...even worse in a location like this with tons of vendors...

Oooh, I want apple turnovers made by Amish chicks!
Wait, I want a pork sandwich!
German food, that's it!
OMG fresh oysters!
Mmmmmm crepes!
Lobster, definitely lobster! Wait no, they're too cute swimming around in that tank.

Nah, I'm just gonna eat healthy I said. Cut to us standing in line for fried chicken and waffles at Keven Parker Soul Food. 

As I'm eating my delicious meal I'm considering my many dessert options - 
Cookies/Cupcakes/Crepes/Ice cream/Fresh fruit/Fudge 

But, after waiting so long for lunch and eating every last bit of food (5 fluffy little waffles, 3 pcs of fried chicken, and the bestest cheesiest gooeyest mac n cheese I have ever had and this watermelon sweet tea I sucked down way too fast) we were full and tired and done squeezing though people and waiting in line. 

I would totally recommend this chaos to anyone visiting the area, just be ready for the crowd and get there before the hangry sets in.

A fun place to explore. This place has everything from fresh produces to cookies chocolate ice cream and more.  Park across the parking deck and bring your ticket with you and ask for a validation with any purchase for 10$ or more and your two hours parking is only cost you $5 and with out the validation cost 16$ for an hour.

Reading Terminal Market is an absolute must for a first-time Philly visitor! It is enormous, so utilize the maps and signs scattered around the sprawling building. Come hungry, too, because they have every single kind of food from every corner of the map in this place. A quick google search will tell you where to get that perfect Philly cheesesteak, and there's a fair few dessert places as well. Have fun, don't get lost, and plan to walk back to your Airbnb to help digest all that food!
Basically Philly's version of Chelsea Market. I came here on a very crowded day (Thursday around 12-1) worth trying out for good food, but we had to find a place to sit outside.

The perfect venue to experience Philly's diverse food selection and community. Come with an appetite and you'll leave with a full belly and a appetite to try more. Only downside, the place gets packed! If you're not into large crowds open to close then this might not be the venue for you. But if you want to see one of Philly gems, head on over!

What an amazing place. Every kind of food (cooked and grocery) that you could imagine. Fresh food, butchers, specialty items and more FOOD! We tried to eat our way through but alas we could not. We did manage to eat awesome roast pork sandwiches at DiNics, cookies from 3 different bakeries, cheese, ice cream and smoothies. Can you say oink? We already have our list of what we're eating next time. Definitely having a brisket sandwich at DiNics.

If you are looking for a  Gastronomic Adventure You have come to the right place, desserts, breads, Italian, Asian, and  seafood just to name a few , The terminal  also allow you to experience the beautiful sides of our creative and unique crafters.

I salivate just thinking about this place! Some of the finest take out cuisine all in one place!
Will review individual businesses as I endulge.

How LUCKY I was to have this gem just across the street from my hotel. The weather was absolutely terrible the weekend I went but I still ventured out (a tad bit hungover might I add) but the puncturing smells of SUCH GOOD FOOD woke me right up. My first stop? 
1) Beck's cajun (came straight here on my second day as well). The Mac & cheese balls were absolutely delightful. Fried, crunchy and absolutely delicious. Each bite oozed a perfect portion of Mac and cheese into my mouth. Each order comes with two pieces (and I most definitely did opt for additional orders my second visit here). Also, the jambalaya topped with gumbo?!?! Ugh, where else can I get something that rich in flavor here in NYC. I definitely miss that the most. Although two completely different dishes, they didn't contrast each other but instead, complemented each other very nicely. Also, I tried the sandwich that they display in the glass (seasoned ground beef sandwiched in the middle) and WHAT. THE. HECK. How can something be so simple yet be forever engraved in my taste buds?! You ruined me. 
2) the oh so famous DiVi (?? I'm so sorry- my mind was completely boggled I couldn't really remember the names). Not a huge roast beef fan- or so I thought... the portion is big. I shared one with my boyfriend and we weren't able to finish (but maybe it's because we ordered way too much elsewhere)
3) the cured meat/ deli meat stand- I haven't been to Barcelona but my boyfriend has and he was immediately reminded of his food experience there one bite into the prosciutto. We were shamelessly grabbing at the prepackaged back and ripping it apart like complete savages while walking around
4) there's a corn dog stand- the chili fries!! Don't knock it till you try it. I've had fries EVERYWHERE. Literally. I always make an excuse to order fries with every single one of my meals. How fries manage to stay crispy under the layers of chili? I'll never know

I just moved to PHL for school and was recommended this place by my sister-n-law who is from here. It just so happens to only be 0.3 miles from me which means I am able to walk which is such a blessing because this place is awesome! I get all my fruits and vegetables from here, my lunch meat and my sweet treats. It's all CHEAP (I'm a graduate student on a serious budget). This place is a gem and I'm so happy to have it.
Underwhelming. Honestly this is somewhere you visit once. I've been to bigger, better organized markets. We won't even get into the whole parking situation.

RTM as a whole is a great place and a Philadelphia landmark. If you visit Philly, DEFINITELY stop in here, even if you don't buy anything, it's worth a visit. Be warned though, on weekends it can get extremely crowded. My personal favorites:

- Boneless Rib Sandwich with cheese from The Rib Stand
- Apple fritter (or any donut) from Beiler's (the line moves quickly)
- Cheesesteak Italian style (with sharp provolone, long hots, and broccoli rabe) from Carmen's
- Chicken shawarma from Kamal's

In my opinion, DiNic's is extremely overrated. If you want a better roast pork, try Paesanos, Chick's, John's Roast Pork, or Tony Lukes.

This bustling market is a must see for anyone visiting Philadelphia! Lots of amazing food, desserts, and shops, ranging from Mexican food to cheesesteaks to incredible bakeries. Not much inside seating, it can get quite crowded, and it closes before dinner time. But it is worth the trip - so may great options!

A tourist favorite as there's always something new to discover at the Reading Terminal Market. You'd find something from every cuisine including American barbeque, Chinese, Mediterranean, Indian and Italian. We usually go there to pick up fresh produce and enjoy fresh donuts at Beiler's - one of the handful staples of the market. Old City coffee is a must to end your trip after a sinful portion of Dinic's, Sang kee pecking duck house and the 'scrapple' at the Down home diner.

This is my go to place for some fresh fruit and vegetables shopping and to get fresh meat.  There are bunch of restaurants and the place is always packed. The place is very touristy. They have discounted parking near by. Whenever we have any out of town guests,  we always bring them here for some Amish food and cheese.

Maybe I hyped this place up in my mind, but this place was a definite let down. I absolutely love markets, indoor, outdoor, I love them all; but this one had no special spark or experience. I love markets because they are full of the hustle and bustle of locals going about their regular day; however, this one was just okay. We tried pork hoagies here that were downright awful. I couldn't finish mine even though we had been travelling all day without lunch. The seating areas could use a good cleaning. The bathrooms had some not so friendly people outside "guarding" them. I really wanted to like this place but I don't have much else to say about it.

This place is a Philadelphia staple. You can find everything you're looking for here, from vegan cupcakes to hand made jewelry. As a local, navigating all the tourists isn't my favorite thing but I still stop in to pick up inexpensive produce regularly.

First time here! Was told by the locals to come and I wish I would have been here sooner. We did get some dessert, but it has a FAZILLION restaurants, candy shops, market, etc. Great idea! Great ambience.  Definitely worth a shot!

Definitely a cool place to stop if you are in the area. Its an indoor building where you can walk around and choose from many places to eat. I chose crepes and really enjoyed it. They also have a variety of shops inside too. I bought some candles.
Its a cool place to walk around. There is a main area to sit down and eat as well.
Killer market in downtown Philly! Lots of food and market options. Reasonable pricing. Come hungry.

Where else can you buy fruits and vegetables, prepared foods, baked goods, and grab a brewski at the beer garden ? very cool place, always bustling with activity, very fresh seafood, very friendly people. Look if you have never been you gotta try it. Awesome lil gem in the city with something for everyone, however if your a " I hate crowds" kinda miserable person, well this is probably not for you. Happy exploring!

Holy cow!
My buddy's build-up of the Terminal didn't even come close to doing justice to this place. The massive former train terminal packed full of any kind of foods, deli's, desserts you can imagine. Indian to Amish. Beef jerky to gourmet chocolates. Deli meats, and lunch counters. It was packed during lunchtime but it was worth the experience. 
Very very cool

This is one of my favorite places in Philadelphia! The prices are reasonable, the selection is wide, and the competition is tough so places are challenged to keep it tasting great. If you're going to the convention center it would be stupid to eat the overpriced convention center food when this is right next door. If I lived in philly I imagine I would do some of my grocery shopping here too as the produce and meat and seafood were so fresh.

Reading Terminal Market is a fabulous place to ramble around shopping and sampling so many types of ethnic foods, drinks, spices and confections.  The market is large and bustling.  It always seems to be crowded but lines move fast and it is worth the wait in my experience.  Come hungry and with a pal so you can split portions and sample more delicious dishes.  You will find everything from fresh fruits and vegetables to fish, shrimp and oysters.

Every time I come here I get so overwhelmed. There is so much to choose from. This really is a unique place in Philadelphia that I recommend any tourist or local visit.  I have eaten at several locations inside and my favorite is Pearls Oyster House. They have the best chowder and fried flounder. I would frequent this place if it were in walking distance.

Tourist, tourists, and more tourists. I usually avoid weekends and holidays. Produce is cheap at Iovine brothers, lovely Dinic's sandwich, solid fishmongers, and great apple dumplings at Dutch eating place. You'll find what you need in one stop; it'll just take a while to find the most efficient route through this maze.

All I can say about this place is HOLY #$)(#*&!!!!  This has to be the food mecca of the East Coast.  This reminds me of El Centro Market in Mazatlan, Sinaloa MX except everyone hear speaks english.  Picture walking into a Costco where every few feet is a food stand, deli counter, cup cake and pasitisere, ice cream, a stand with only bacon, and the list goes on an on.

You have to stop and eat here, especially Tommy Dinic's which is iconic for their pork sandwhich (which I had) and their brisket sandwich with brocolli rabe (which I had). Portions are massive, could not eat a full sandwiched so I split it with my wife and we also gave some to her friend.  

Not much to say other than this is 5 stars of a place to vist and every food imaginable under the sun.

Go there!

5 stars
Cheesesteaks. Over priced. Bland. Junk. Don't waste your time and money

Amazing place, for visitors and locals alike. You can get pretty much any kind of food, fresh groceries, artisan cheese, even Amish specialties if it's not a Sunday. The market is always bustling and right in the center of everything. My favorite spots are Iovine Bros, the falafel place, and By George. I also understand that DiNic's has some great pulled pork sandwiches for you meat-eaters out there!

2.5 Stars.

These reviews are probably written by tourists or out-of-towners, but here is the inside scoop from a local:

It's overcrowded and thrives on its history. Does it have the best food? No. Does it have the best grocery market? No. Does it have the best bar? No. It's all mediocre, at best.

Locals go to local farmers markets that are full of local farms. Check out the Food Trust for a listing of when and where! Google 'Food Trust Philadelphia'.

The meat places are hit or miss in the RTM. What irks me is some advertise grass fed, but the animals are grain finished. They're salespeople. Snakes in the grass.

The seafood markets, well, again, look what you're buying. Most of the time the fish is dry looking and fishy smelling. No bueno.

The bar is meh. Philly has too many great bars to deal with the crowds of RTM.

Ok, Beilers....well, they're a game changer, and the only reason I visit. They have the best baked goods. Period. 

Dinics, too. They're also great.

So, there you have it. Go at your own risk!

Every time we visit Philly we come here for lunch! We usually go to Hershel's and get the Rueben, it's delicious and so fresh! There's so many different places to eat that everyone in the group will find something to get. Last time we went there was a little table for Birdie's biscuits, and it was the most amazing biscuit we've ever had. I hope next time we go he's there again! Totally recommend people going to get some quick food!

Something fantastic for everyone 
I wanted a Gyro and my wife Salad - simple - Olympia.  But my wife wanted ribs too so she picked up a pound of spare ribs at The Rib Stand and met me back at Olympia.  Ribs were good with the Pita bread and salad.  For dessert ice cream from Bassett's.  Must be 50 other places to try here.   I will read all the other reviews and plan out attack for tomorrow
A heritage spot with amazing food, drinks, and atmosphere. There's nothing you can't find here and I've loved everything I've ever had here. Love the honey/beeswax shop, too!

Awesome place. Went to Beck's for breakfast and had Po sandwich, they're homemade Cajun mayo was the tits. Ivones produce has the freshest fruits and vegetables at a great price will def be back to both and more.

Still catching up on reviews and thought about this place while on a business trip in Philadelphia last year.
Reading Terminal Market was directly across the street from the hotel we were staying at (Home2 Suites). This place has everything!! I even tried out a Chinese restaurant here (the name in question is Golden Bowl). It was the best Chinese food I've ever had besides PF Changs, but that's still good too. :)
My dad tried out a Greek restaurant called Olympic Gyro. It was packed but we managed to find a place to sit to enjoy the food.
It's worth coming back!

If we were in Philadelphia for a week, I'd gain 50 pounds, because I would eat here for lunch every day and then stock up on sweets.  If I lived close by, I'd come all the time for the marketfresh items I saw but couldn't consider because I'm not checking a bag when we fly out.  There are so many amazing places to choose from.  We tried many items and were not displeased with anything we consumed, but I'd highly (as in it is a MUST) recommend the rib sandwich from Glick's Rib Shack and the Corned Beef sandwich special from Hatville Deli.  Go here early in your Philadelphia visit because you'll want to go back.  And if you decide to get some ice cream from Bassett's (which you should), listen to your husband when he says you should get it in a cup and share as two scoops is too much in a sugar cone!!!
Loved it!! Be prepare for the crowd! Loved the food! Tons of choices and one place thats a must visit.

Convenient.  Crowded.  Rodent infested.  Cash only.  Did I mention convenient?

To be fair.  Good, bad, and mediocre vendors must coexist.  Did I mention convenient?
Amazing selection and really fast service (depending on the line of course) I highly recommend the Four Seasons Juice bar for a refreshing and healthy drink.

So many food places under one roof! Anything you have a taste for, it's probably here. A foodie's dream. There is also fresh fruits, fresh vegetables, baked goods, cheese, meat, ice cream and more. I came on a Saturday and it was very crowded. Some of the food places have their own seating areas while others do not. However there are general seating areas in various areas but it still may take you time to find a seat. I was lucky enough to find one in about 5 minutes. I would recommend to come with an empty stomach so you can try as much as you can. 

Best place to park
There is a public parking right across the street. If you spend $10 or more here, you can get a validation. 
Rates:
Up to 2 hours $5
Up to 2 1/2 hours $11
Up to 3 hours $17
*discount expires after 3 hours and fees are like $8 for 30 minutes alone 

There are restrooms here just in case you need one.
Philly classic, always great for breakfast or lunch. Check out the Amish stand, ribs and apple dumplings are some of my favorites.
food everywhere for big eaters.  fresh produce on the go. pastries are very filling, plus enough options to keep you walking around for hours.
the best market around:  has everything you could want to eat from veggies to dinner
Overwhelming amount of foods to choose from but a definite must! Being your fat pants and eat as much as you can! I can't recommend any particular place but only that you try as much as you can.
So many stores and a huge variety of different types of food.  Beiler's, Dinic's and Bassett's are just some of the great shops here.  I only wish it was open later, normally closes at 6pm.

A huge variety of food places, basically a giant food court. It can get annoying on busy days since it's sometimes hard to walk around when there's a lot of people there, but the wait and bustle is worth the different cuisines they have to offer here. Love stopping by Beillers on the way out for some donuts.

Yelp keeps telling me I need to review.... okkkkk here it is. Short and sweet.

* Its crowed except after 4
* Locals are irked by tourist who just stop in the middle of the isle when we are trying to get our lunch and you are on vacation.
* You will get lost (Local and Tourist)
* Have cash, many places don't take cards, there are numerous ATM located around. 
* Its delicious you can get a cake, smoothie, ham hocks, chitterlings, flowers, fish, cannolis, oils, Thai, spaghetti, ice cream , Shea butter, preservatives, donuts and a book under one roof.

Enjoy!

NATIONAL TREASURE STOP #3

Yes, this is the place where Diane Kruger got her cinematic start as she courageously hid behind the counter from Sean Bean and the bad guys. Yeah, I made that up, but I didn't make up all of the many unique items that you can get at Reading (pronounced 'redding') Terminal Market like:
- Pickles by the barrel
- Donuts
- Freshly baked sticky buns
- Huge breakfasts at the Dutch Eating Place
- Cheeses
- Groceries
- Bassett's Ice Cream for the country's oldest ice cream shop
- Roast pork sandwiches at DiNic's
- Cajun food at Beck's

This market is old and charming. Plenty of seating throughout the market so a great place to get some food before you head out to Independence Hall. Bring cash.

Great diversity in terms of food choices - anywhere from authentic Mexican, Italian, Asian to American. Also a lot of dessert and coffee shops! It gets really crowded during lunch time but it's prime location. Amazing grilled cheese and a donut shop.

Best place to go explore, take your kids your date your friends here it's always an adventure..I must've go here at least once a week it's addicting. Iovine, meats at Guinta's Prime Shop, $1 cookies after 530 at 4th Street cookies, Dinics is the best pork sandwich, soft pretzels from Millers, Beilers donuts and the coconut creme pie damn is good, the ribs also across are amazing can't say enough good things about Reading Terminal. It's one of the best reasons to check out Philly!

Anything and everything you could want to eat under one roof, and almost everything is good to excellent. Great coffee and pastries for breakfast, lunches, etc. One of the great places in Philly whether you're a tourist or live here.

OMG! This really should be the last place you visit in Philadelphia before you head home. Keep in mind that a quarter of the businesses will be closed on Sunday. We grabbed roast pork, broccoli rabe and provolone sandwiches from DiNic's. They survived the ride, even with the terrible George Washington Bridge traffic, and were immediately devoured by family member's who expressed their foodie satisfaction. Multiple items were purchased from Condiment's, who mentioned they ship packages frequently. 
Expect crowds, noise, and all the other wonderful things this glorious Market has to offer.

Great experience for Incredible food options.  Very busy and you may have to stand to eat, but the selection of food is well worth it.  Pricing varies by each venue, but the prices overall seemed very reasonable for the amount of food that you got.

What an awesome place!

Me and my wife just stopped here for about 30 minutes before we went to an appointment and we were amazed with how much food there was to pick from. We had some of the Rotisserie chicken from I think Dienner's and it was awesome. There is Greek food, Halal food, burgers, bakery, bread and bagels, ribs, fudge, chocolate, ice cream, etc. It is a cool place to check out with your spouse or to take your kids. Your looking at needing about 2 hours to check out the place and all the cool things they have there. Parking can be a challenge though and definitely avoid this place around lunch time.
Fun foodie palace! Like a flea market of quality food.

Fun place to spend a few hours especially if you have a group with different tastes! Lots of really great choices for breakfast or lunch! Lots of hustle and bustle! Vendors punch your Parking garage ticket for discounted parking. Just put the validated ticket in the machine on the ground floor lobby and it recognizes the discount

One of Philadelphia's gems, Reading Terminal Market boasts something for everyone. A foodie's paradise!  This is a must visit if not once but several times if ever in the area.  From sweet treats to raw oysters, all the way to fresh produce and some of the best prepared foods you can find.  The cuisine ranges from BBQ, Dutch breakfast, to cajun all the way to Asian.  

One of our favorite finds in the market includes stocking up on fresh jerky and meat sticks (sounds weird but dont knock it til you try it!), which you can buy by the pound and take back with you for a great road trip snack.  

A thing to note: Try to come on any day but Sunday, Monday and Tuesday, as there a lot of Dutch/Amish that close on those days with goodies you don't want to miss.  Also, although it is crowded, it is all very much worth it.  My only regret is not finding Reading Terminal sooner!  Wish we had something like it in Boston!  Truly a gem!

I've been coming here my whole life, and I'm old. In some ways I liked it better in the old days. Pre convention center. It's still amazing but it's mostly lunch places and I always like it for my daily shopping. If you don't got at 8:00 am on the weekends don't bother . It's a nut house after 10:00. If you have out of town guests this is a must stop. And I do like lunch. It overwhelms me with so many great choices. I miss the old butcher shops like Harry Ochk's . It's Philly at it's goody best.
My favorite place to go for food since moving to the area...I feel like I'll never eat everything they offer...but I'll try haha

If you like farmer markets.......on acid...this is the place!  A diverse array of food and items to purchase at a decent price!  A lot of diverse people frequent this place and the variety of food is mind blowing!  I highly recommend the experience.  Be aware that it closes early during the week.  The lunch crowd can be overwhelming but the people navigate the hustle and bustle pretty well.  Of course being in an urban environment, you get the occasional crazy look but nonetheless, it's worth experiencing.

Whether your a meatlover or a hardcore vegan they got something to delight everyone. The Amish food stands are open Wednesday thru Saturday. Great eats from east to west, and north to south in this foodie heavenly delight.... I can tell you there are at least Five big cookie bakeries or combo coffee shops. They all are mouth watering hide them b4 you walk in the door at home cookies. You'd do better to find out about all the different choices you have b4 you arrive bc there are so many to choose from it's mind blowing.  Nerve racking if you're attacked to a large group. A must to check out on your visit here. Just don't stand in the middle of the isle making Philadelphians crazy. You have to be good at weaving and dodging thru the crowds during the week. Well pretty much until closing..... Enjoy

Absolutely one of Philly's best attractions and lunch spots!
Shop there for dinner parties.
Love Hirschel's Deli counter for lunch!
Of course it gets 5-stars.  Visiting from San Francisco, it is such a great experience to see local vendors offer wonderful food under one fun roof.  You have to have this checked-off on your list.

SO fantastic. It was chock full of food heaven. Very very crowded but I can see why- there were so many good food stalls. We tried a cajun place and of course the famous pork sandwich. Would have gone for dessert if not so full!

Easily a great location for locals and out of towners alike.

Where else can you get market staples, gourmet foods, candy, fresh seafood, artisanal cheese, Peking duck, hot gumbo, a cheesesteak, and an ice cream all within a few steps of each other? (And that's not all!). 

Definitely check out Bassett's and splurge with a big cone of two of their fresh flavors. Did you know that they are the first ice cream parlor in America?  Their ice creams still hold up and are some of the finest. 

Great people watching, shopping and eating.

Clean bathrooms too!  Definitely park in a garage. Street parking can be difficult with the ever changing temporary rules. You don't wanna get towed.
I'd say it's a "must do."

The Reading Terminal Market reminded me of a grungier, darker Saint John City Market in New Brunswick whose motto is "an original experience every time." I can see that being true of RTM as well! The first time I came I was overwhelmed in the best way possible: there was so much to look at, smell, and taste that I didn't know where to start. It's an enormous, chaotic, loud, very busy maze that's easy to get lost in... which I did repeatedly in my attempt to visit every single stall.

Not sure about something? Ask for a sample! I can't believe how generous and friendly just about every vendor was. From wine to cheeses to potato salads (yes, plural) to chocolates, I got to engage with local purveyors who were very passionate about their goods. 

There really is so much going on that I imagine the next time I come, I'll see, smell, and taste things I didn't even realize were there previously. If I lived in Philly, I'd absolutely make shopping here a regular event... and if you're visiting the city, I encourage checking it out for a quick dose of local flavor (literally and metaphorically), but be sure to give yourself plenty of time to explore every nook and cranny!

If you are in Philly this is a must do! Amazing places to eat and so many choices you could come there everyday for something different! Reminds me of a place I went to in Copenhagen. I wish we had one of these in Orlando!

Go here. Honestly no better advice for to do's in Philly than to visit this place. There is something here for everyone! Luckily for us we stayed right next door so we could come here multiple times. Want breakfast? They have a diner and breakfast sandwiches. Want a hoagie? They have them. Need fresh meats? They got them! Want a philly cheese steak; hell yeah they have amazing ones here! It can get quite crowded but no lie, it's worth the crowds.

If you're a local you know to avoid this place at all costs. It takes a long time to get subpar tourist trap food and then you have to wait to find a seat at a table of which there are few. I'll never understand why this place is packed every weekend with tourists waiting to spend their money. Do yourself a favor and pick another local restaurant. Don't eat at the equivalent of a historical mall food court.

I would say hands down the best place to do a lot of your grocery shopping. Produce is amazing  fresh and less expensive than other grocery stores around. Of course this is it the only reason to go here. So many cute boutiques that have such a variety of things to offer. Always find something new. Love love love it.

Great mix of vendors, amazing breakfast where I had an accidental egg yolk break last second in my omelet (it was the greatest delicious I have ever tasted) at Molly Malloy's; goat cheese, spinach and tomato omelet BTW...  Other than the grilled cheese place, bread spot, cheese spot, and MM's, I find the produce (especially mushrooms at some fancy place that I don't know) completely overpriced.... Molly's is worth it on it's own
Always crowded. But l have to stop in anytime I'm in the area. They have everything !

Upon entering I had instant deja vu recalling that I last visited here when I came to Philadelphia in 2003.    It really hadn't changed that much (save possibly different vendors).    I arrived in Philly just around a quarter to one on Saturday.   After trekking it to La Reserve B&B to check in, I made my way back in search of a place called By George that had gotten rave reviews for their cheesesteaks.   Little did I know that they were located inside of Reading.

So I got there around 2:30 and it was quite the madhouse.   It took a long time to figure out where By George was but I eventually found it.   Of course there was a long line but it actually moved relatively fast.   The next challenge was finding an open spot in their food court area to devour the cheesesteak.    I eventually did find a place and as I finished I scanned the crowded area and saw Flying Monkey which looked to have some interesting desserts.

After my lunch I went to Flying Monkey.   I was checking out the desserts near the line.  The one dessert that caught my eye was their butter cake.   I was about to turn towards the line when I encountered a rude grandma who sternly told me to move out of the way so she can get in line.   I told her I was in line and she was ready to fight me.   When she realized I wasn't going to move, she bitched and moaned the whole time.  I looked away from her but could feel her steely eyes staring me down.    I eventually got my order of butter cake and left.   I imagine with the crowds there are probably a few fights that break out.

I found the cake so delicious I made a return trip to Reading the next morning on route to heading to the airport.    It was a lot less crazy and if I were living in Philly, I'd definitely opt for going in the morning to avoid the crazy grandmas and the large crowds.   With that said this is definitely a great place to visit while in town.

Nothing to say that hasn't already been said about the famous Reading Terminal Market. The vibe is awesome - its like a food flea market. Theres so many great food choices, no matter what you pick you'll love it. My faves are the Dutch Eating Place foe breakfast and DiNic's for the roast pork and broccoli rabe sandwich.  If you've never been, make plans to go. If you've already been, go again. This is an absolute must for any visit the Philly.

OMG!!!!! i love this place. There is so much that goes on & for you to try & sample that if you are on a lunch break or you go before you get to work prepare yourself to arrive or return late. There is no way unless you actually what you are looking for & want to get. Every time I go I am always late to work. This is one of Philly's best place for tourist to go visit while they are here.

Great addition of little stands and hawker stalls in Philadelphia. A walk through the market and one can experience cuisines and dishes from all over the world including the local favorite Philly Cheesesteak. 

When I came here with my friends, we had gator jambalaya, gumbo, Philly cheesesteaks, mango lassis, Indian iced tea and cookies from the local stands. The market is generally packed with customers and tourists so navigating through the narrow corridors is often hard. There is often long lines at the more popular stands. 

One complaint I did have however, was for the cleanliness of the dining tables and seating areas. When my friends and I went, we sat at a table that was oily and littered with crumbs. At least they provide sanitizing wipes, so I guess that makes up for that? 

Overall, I have a decent experience at Reading Terminal Market. They do close at 6 P.M. so get your grub-run in before then!
Awesome place food from all over and not from a can... mostly Italians and middle eastern great place to find gourmet items not to be missed while in philly
Always a fun spot to get ANY food craving. Dessert selections are great, and lots of unique gift ideas at the Herbiary or Amish/farm shops.

The donuts at Belier's here is amazing. They are ranked top five in the country. There is always a large selection of fresh produce. Carmen's cheesesteaks taste even better than the famous Pat's and Genos. If you like Cajun food check it Beck's Cajun they have amazing food and also sell gator gumbo.

When you walk in to this Mecca of a market , you are overwhelmed with choices, Everything  for everybody . Wanna cook your own stuff, butchers and fish mongers abound. Amish farmers with Hugh produce and farm vegetables. Cant wait to eat , the list is endless, from Philly cheesesteak to roastpork and broccoli rabe , Deli style pastrami and corned beef, to greek gyros and pizza, I Scream, You Scream , candy counters , bakeries, Breakfast lunch & dinner ..Just Pick 
Some very interesting choices , some very good , some a waste of money .
Choose wisely , There is a reason some vendors are busier then others . 
I tried the overpriced pastrami on rye with Cole slaw. If you ever had Real NYC Deli. Give this a rest. Cheesesteak sandwich is better in some kioks, then others ... look for longer lines with locals . 
There is a seating area, however based on what time of day , Good luck grabbing a seat . Some vendors offer counter seating ( Limited ) . The best time to go is about 10:30 AM. Fresh prep of food for vendors, Breakfast specials and Hardhats chowing down , the quiet before  the storm. By noon the place is crazy.  Its a good place to site see & munch
Reading Terminal Market has everything that you need everything is fresh good or good for you

Went here with my father.  We tried various vegetarian items from them plethora of vendors that are available here.  

Forget the food (which was delicious btw), if you are in Philly check this place out- even just for people watching lol.  We had a great time and felt good to check off visiting such a historical place.
This place has an overwhelming selection of products. Lots of fresh cheeses and desserts. I recommend a visit if you like markets. Definitely a cool place to visit if you're in Philly.

Stayed across the street at the Marriott and was told by the employees that this was as must go to place. At first I was hesitant but I am glad I made the decision to go. It was amazing in there. Food from everywhere, all cultures. The facility was also very clean which was amazing for how many people they have going through there. They have everything you would want to try. I had gator gumbo which was amazing, also some crepes that were amazing. Everything else I didn't eat looked amazing also. I suggest if your in Philly and hungry stop by here. Guarantee you will not be disappointed. Based on all the great reviews you can't go wrong here. I'll be back!!!

The Reading Terminal is a wonderful place to eat, a lot to choose from, a variety of. Food and drinks and. Very tasteful desserts!! 
It's a must try..

Simply Magical...

This indoor market is remarkable. There are endless aisles lined with everything from baked goods, confections, restaurants and shops. There is truly something for everyone here.

Been to Philly several times and never visited this gem. Most certainly worthy of a day trip. Be sure to visit on a very empty stomach. Do note that the market is mainly comprised of foods. 

Don't make the mistake we made and pay major for parking. Find the lot just across the street and pay for four to five bucks with ten dollar purchase.

I love coming to the Reading Terminal Market because they have a wide variety of food! If you never been here before, it may be overwhelming. Make sure you walk around the entire market so you can get a feel for all the different types of food.
If you want something sweet they have multiple different bakeries you can chose from. If you wanted to get fresh meat and/or fish they have that as well! While you are at the market, you have to get out Dinics! They have an amazing roast pork sandwich, but you have to get there early because they will run out. Another on of my favorite places to eat is Beck's. They have multiple different Po Boys to chose from, but you have to order the Train wreck. It is amazing and it will satisfy any craving you have. 
If you have not been to the Reading Terminal Market then you have to get there ASAP!

This place is amazing! It's an absolute must if you're in Philly. I went to Beiler's to get doughnuts all 3 days I was in town. Their apple and blueberry fritters were fantastic. I also tried the Shawarma at Kamal's which was delicious and the Thanksgiving sandwich at Original Turkey was also solid.

My beau and I stayed in a nearby hotel for a great weekend. The terminal was next door to our hotel. We decided to go in and grab some breakfast before the game. We ran into Pearl's Oyster Bar. Two seats were readily available at the counter. I like the feel of an old school diner in the middle of a bustling market. The waiter was cool. We both decided on excellent choices. He got the crab cake and eggs benedict and I got the oatmeal and egg w/cheese sandwich. All good choices and quick. The service was great as was the food.

Later after the game, we decided to stop in for a cookie and ice cream at Bassett's Ice Cream and Famous 4th Street Cookie Company. The ice cream is super fresh and definitely homemade. The cookies are $1 if you make it in 15 mins before closing.

I would definitely go back on my next trip to Philly.
This market has something for everyone!!  Superb selection and everything I've had from here has been excellent.

Wow what can I say Everything Under One Roof all you can eat in some places many selections, ice cream to steak, soups Two Nuts always a great place to go to lunch a lot of good visitors and travelers passed through here wonderful atmosphere friendly services.

Reminds me of markets in Spain, very crowded very busy place but was really nice. Went there as a tourist hop and the experience was so good. Lots of food to chose from but I tried Beiler's Bakery which had a long long line, took me 30 mins to get to buy pastries and donuts. A little extra sweet but liked them still
Also got some ice cream at Bassetts it was awesome!!
Come here, but be ready to be in a very crowded place specially on Saturday

This is one of the must stops when in Philly.  It has everything one could wish in a market: vendors selling fresh produce, meats, seafood, poultry, coffee shops, bakeries including several Amish and numerous dining establishments.  It can be a wee bit overwhelming when you first walk in.   We  brought a map of the market and it assisted us in getting around.  It is next door to the Convention Center and close to the historical district so we were by a few times.  As I was at a conference at the Convention Center with thousands of attendees, there were often line ups over the lunch hour with many of the dining establishments.

Loved the variety of vendors and the smell of the baked good and food cooking.

Happy to recommend Reading Terminal Market when in Philly.
The Terminal is a bit of heaven for Foodies, the atmosphere is lively and extremely friendly and helpful, you could spend a day wandering from stall to stall sampling out of this world foods.

Reading Terminal is a Foodie Mecca. The market hosts vendors selling everything from seafood and meat, to fresh produce, to sit-down meals. It can definitely be overwhelming, but worth taking your time and wandering around. You could spend hours visiting every stall and trying samples. While the Market is very busy and loud, it's a great place to grab some food and people-watch. Reading Terminal Market is a must stop when in Philly.

Pro-tip: Visit on an empty stomach!
I loooove this place!!! Haven't been in a while and have been trying to get back.. eventually I will:-)

OMG!!! That's what I thought when I walked in here. It's a market indoors. There are many vendors here, ranging from crepes to meats to flowers. It's almost overwhelming the amount of choices you have when going here. The only thing I didn't like was the lack of seating. You have to look up the vendors before you go  or you'll be walking aimlessly forever.

I came here on my latest trip to Philadelphia for breakfast. I did not know what I was getting myself into! I thought that as a market, it was going to be like an indoor farmer's market. I was so happily wrong! While there is an area where fresh produce is sold, there are an assortment of different vendors and restaurants selling just about any type of food product imaginable. While I did select a spot to eat breakfast and get a coffee, it was a very difficult decision to make! I honestly am looking forward to coming back to Philadelphia solely to spend a day in the market and eat. If you are in the city, do not miss this spot!
Man I Looove The Reading Terminal Market The Dutch Bakery's Are My Favorite And I Brought Beef Jerky Out Of There And man it's so good
Great variety of food! Even for people w/food allergies. Gluten free, Dairy Free, Egg Free, Nut Free, Soy Free, Vegan, & Vegetarian!

This is a fun place to go when you're not sure what kind of food you're in the mood for, and you want a little of this and a little of that. It also works great for groups of people who all have different tastes. I love the smoothies, the coffee, and the burgers, personally. The market itself has great energy. It could use more/better seating, and the tables are not very clean. Otherwise, it would have been 5 stars.
Needed some coffee before my bus ride from Philly to NYC. Stopped by this terminal, so many options. At the end I went with a regular cup from the Amish diner, thanks!

I'm a fan! My friends and I were were looking for a place to grab something quick to eat when we ran into this place. 

FOOD: Reading Terminal has it all; bagels, breakfast sandwiches, coffee, tea, and freshly-squeezed juice. I tried them all :) 

LOCATION: We came at a good time (early morning) so it wasn't hard to find a place to sit. There are tables available for you to enjoy your feast. 

*TIP* I recommend grabbing a freshly squeezed juice from one of the stands. I don't remember what this place is called but it's towards the back where the produce is. 

Will I come back? Well, I'm not from around here but yes! I'll make my way back if I'm around.

When in Philly, this is a MUST! I'm so sad that today was my first time coming here after being in Philly multiple times. What was I doing with my life??

This place has everything you could want (and more). And that could even be a problem for people like me, who are bad at making decisions. I think I walked around the whole place twice before deciding on somewhere to eat.

Everything, everywhere looks so good! I honestly can't even remember the place I ended up eating, but I had lobster mac and cheese and a cob kind of salad. SO. GOOD. I also got some coffee from the coffee place near main, front entrance. Also SO GOOD. They had handcrafted syrups!!

I wish I had more time in Philly or lived somewhere close because besides places to eat, the reading terminal also has lots of produce, delis, and other local/homemade things.

I stopped at a couple of the sellers and purchased some candles and honey! 

Really great place. The only bad thing is obviously it does get crowded and I imagine at certain days and times, it's hard to find somewhere to sit so you can eat.

Amazing food & amazing selection. We went on a Saturday mid-day so it was packed. If you're okay with people, the no problem! I read the visitphilly.com article on the top ten places and I hit three. 

Flying Monkeys had great whoopie pies! November seasonal pies were lots of pumpkin combos. 

Tommy DiNic's had great sandwiches but wasn't the best I've had this trip. Plus they were out of Italian Sausage! 

Finally, Beck's Cajun Cafe was said to have good Po' Boys, but I HAD to try the Gater Gumbo! I was not disappointed!!! Yum! 

I could go to the market everyday until I tried something at each stand. 

This is definitely a spot to try even if not for a meal, but for the experience.
This place is so much fun with so much variety of food!!!!!!!!!! Lot go the stuff and homemade, freshly made. My old high school reunion from C. High was thrown here. Oh boy did we have a blast

Fun place to try some of Phillys food options. Every time i visit, I always leave with a dozen Beilers donuts, the blueberry fritter is a MUST. So far as far as food, it has been a bit underwhelming. I tried the infamous Tommy's Roast pork sandwich, which was massively underwhelming and coming from someone who lives for garlic, had much too much. The bee candles are AMAZING, affordable, burn so cleanly, and make great gifts. Overall this is a place meant for exploration. I am always finding something new and delish. If you are new to Philly or just have a day to spend Reading is a must do.

I love this place... too many choices though!  All are top notch and legit.  DiNic's Brisket is an incredible sandwich.  Bring back the beer garden vibe.  The restaurant is ok, but I loved the fact that I used to be able to have a beer with whatever food I brought in with me.  I took away a star because that change spoiled (but didn't ruin) the spirit of the RTM.
Reading Terminal Market is a Philadelphia institution.  Meat, produce, baked goods and every cuisine under the sun is available.

CALLING ALL FOODIES!!!! This place is HEAVEN on Earth for food lovers!! I can't believe this past weekend was my first time here after being to Philly a few times!! Anything you could possibly want to eat in one place!! I did my homework beforehand since our time was limited and I wanted to make sure I tried nothing but the best!!

-Beck's Cajun Cafe: Hands down my favorite!! They were serving bright and early...couldn't pass up on trying the award winning Trainwreck sandwich...WOW!! My mouth is salivating as I type! I also tried their fried mac & cheese balls which were delish!! Staff was friendly and helpful!! 
- By George!: BEST Stromboli I've ever had!! We shared the Italian, phenomenal! 
-Valley Shepard Creamery & Meltkraft: shared the Somerset Grilled cheese which was good. Awesome for cheese and olive lovers!
-Old City Coffee: much needed booster after feasting!! 
-Flying Monkey Bakery: AMAZING SERVICE!! So friendly and sweet!! We actually came here Saturday and Sunday! Not a dessert person but my daughter loved their whoopies! 

Sadly, I could've done without :
-Sang Kee Peking Duck's shrimp dumplings...sauce was great, but wasn't a fan! 
-Fox and Son Fancy Corn dogs was terrible!! I went with the cheese and jalapeno corn dog...really wish I hadn't...sauce was gross and jalapenos were dried up and tasteless. 

But hey you live and you learn!   

TIPS:
-COME EARLY!! Some places don't start serving their heavier foods till 10:30-11am...I still recommend you get here as early as possible to avoid the lines. I got to the terminal at 8:30am and was able to grab some food, eat at a table with no wait, digest, and repeat once the the other places started serving. 
-Crowd starts coming in around by 11am, making the table seating limited.
-Come with a friend(s)!! It's so much more fun when you can try out a bunch of spots and just split it with friends. 
-A lot of the merchants are closed on Sundays (Amish thing) so if you're coming on the weekend, Saturdays is your day!

Reading terminal,  until we meet again!
Love the market! So many delicious food spots to try, while also carrying an array of unique gifts.

Love zany, crowded, food marketplaces that capture the heart, soul, and passion of a city? I do. Reading Terminal at lunch time on a Thursday is packed, energetic, and fun.

Oh wow the sandwich places, Italian joints, Jewish bagels, Amish pretzels, fresh seafood, produce, and meats, meats, meats. Tables jammed with folks in food heaven, eating everything from cheesesteaks to pulled pork to Indian veggie options and chocolate dipped cookies.

I got some baked goods from Metropolitan Bakers on the far edge. The market has many Amish stalls with Amish workers including one featuring pop corn, honey, jarred goods--picked up some gifts there. Picked up chocolate gifts from Mueller's. 

I didn't have time for a big messy lunch sandwich then but later enjoyed my pretzel and gruyere ham croissant. Want to go back soon.

Gem of Philly, a must for locals AND tourists! Filled with local produce, Amish farmers/Pennsylvania Dutch, freshly baked goods, hand churned ice creams, a small chocolate and candy factory showing their mold making techniques, artisan cheeses, fresh fish & meat, book vendors, spice shops, and soooooooo much more. Two of the merchants are even descendants of original vendors from the 1800's, how cool is that??!! Reading Terminal is great for grocery shopping, and lunch.. although it does get quite overwhelming with crowds at lunch. During the holidays they have a giant train display complete with tracks and train cars whistling and zooming around, RT also has lots of festivals and fun events for both adults and kids. I'm not going to list my fave food and market vendors because I love so much that is here and they would all be on the list. An awesome market, highly recommend!! Ah yes, I can't forget to tell you about Philbert! Philbert is the lovely 3' plump bronze piggy bank sculpture in the center of the terminal, he collects coins for charity. Eric Berg is a VERY special local Philadelphia sculptor, whose work is all over the city in major parks, the bear in Fitler Square, the dragon at Drexel, the vine covered cottage gate in Rittenhouse square, the sphere at Pennsylvania hospital and so much more. Reading Terminal is a gem, go!

This place was amazing. Had everything I could ask for in what I wanted to be offered when it came to food products or items in Philly. If I were to be introduced to one place for all kind of foods, it would be this place. The assortment of fresh fruits and produce to different assortment of foods makes this place the ideal candidate to be on my top 5 go-to place for this city. A must go-to for any out of towner for sure!

Definitely would go back on a weekday if I'm back in the area. 
The Melter Skelter grilled cheese at Meltkraft was phenomenal. The hot apple dumpling at the Dutch Eating Place was awesome. And duck fried rice from Sang Kee Peking Duck was great. Would love to go back to try some more food here!

I am a bit biased as I live in the Philadelphia Metro area.  I always enjoy a trip here.  A good choice of foods and merchandise , plus the people watching is fun.  Down Home Diner is a must as is the Amish market and a treat from Termini's as well as a roast pork sandwich.  If you are in Philly it is a great way to spend some time.

I love the Reading Terminal!  I can go shop, eat, and take people from out of town-it's a standard for us to take people there when visiting- I  meet people for coffee there or at brunch. It has everything! the best fish the best meats, the best coffee -the absolutely best coffee- chocolates, flowers, and a wonderful fruit juice smoothie place we always go to. A great Thai take out -long lines!- I buy my spices there, cheese, freshest eggs and also seasonal stuff! A historic place, authentic, a must when one visits Philly but also great for us who live here. Easy to park across the street.

A fantastically popular place where there is lots of good food.  I made the mistake of going at a peak tourist time on a Saturday afternoon.

Seats were full, walked around carrying food shoulder to shoulder, ended up leaving due to hunger.

The Boyfriend Review - Had to leave and find a restaurant in the area, or else have a Hangry girlfriend.

i loved it  alot   alot of  nice  restaurants  and   shops   and   got   a great  meal willl for sure  go    again   this   place  has a  nice  selection  of  shops  and  restaurants  wow   this  place is huge

If you're a foodie, YOU HAVE TO VISIT Reading Terminal Market! Options, upon options, upon more options! I loved visiting Reading Terminal Market for the first time on my trip to Philly. I wish my stomach was big enough to visit every place, maybe one day right? This is for sure a staple in Philly. I will be back very soon to try more FOOD!

Tonight after a seminar in the city I walked to the market. I was disappointed that Dinic's was closed because their roast pork sandwich w/provolone and long hots is one of the best things i have ever eaten. I got some jerky at the store i cant remember the name of that is awesome.  I got dinner to bring home for the fam from a place that i havent tried before. Glick's rib shack is AMAZING!!! The baby back ribs and the spicy sauce are delish!!! Surprisingly, the green beans are so so good!! Highly recommend Glick's!

I've been coming to the Reading Terminal since I was a youngbull. Literally anything you have a taste for, you will find here. Now on to my FAVES!!!! The gyro place is so so so soooo good. Get the classic gyro (with lamb and their special sauce) and you will not regret it, I promise. Then, right next to it you have 12th st Cantina, it's a Mexican restaurant. Their servings are huge so make sure you go when you are really hungry, I recommend the nachos with all of the fixings, yum! And I cannot forget about the cookie place (can't remember the name) they have a variety to choose from (they're better than Insomnia Cookies, shhhh lol.) They have Chinese, soul food, seafood, Amish (rotisserie chicken so good), BBQ, vegetarian, literally anything you can think of. YOU WILL NOT REGRET IT!

Nothing negative will ever arise in my visits to Reading Terminal Market.  There is something for everyone! Yes you'll stand in lines but they owners know this and have food ready for you and you will be satisfied in no time!  Frequently visit Flying Monkey Bakery, Dinics, Crepes, the oyster Bar, Soul Food, and Beilers Donuts.  Food is reasonably priced and prepared in front of you!

As seen on TV Reading Terminal Market is home to all different kinds of foods for all kinds of people.  Craving ribs? There's a place for that!  craving grilled cheese? yup!  Need to pick up some fruits and veggies for the dinner at home? groceries are in the back!  Got in trouble and want to bring the girlfriend some flowers?  They have it!

Great location, just a short walk away from Jefferson Station, short walk away from china town, and literally across the street from the convention center!

An absolute must when visiting Philadelphia.  
Last weekend we held a small conference at the Hotel next door.  I didn't have much time to visit the local restaurants but don't feel left out as the market had just about every taste I needed.  
From Breakfast  at Down Home Diner to wrapping I the weekend with Cookies and ice cream everything was delicious.  Just walking in the door you are is a treat as you take on all the wonderful smells.  
Each stall is something different.  If in a group it's easy to please everyone and meet in the middle to eat together.  Other options are several sit down restaurants or counter style seating. 
I had Beck's Cajun, The Rib Stand, Spataro's Cheesesteaks and a few more.  No disappointments.
I won't kid you the crowds are relentless.  I saw folks standing in  30 min lines for doughnuts.  Some stalls you could only see from a distance.  Most times after I had my order I escaped out a door even if it meant walking outside all the way around this huge building.  There was no leisurely shopping through the cookbook or honey stores like I wanted.  
Another down side was it closed at 6pm nightly and some places at 5pm.  A lot of places were closed on Sunday as well. 
Overall well worth the crowd!
This place is amazing with lots of food and choices. From sweet to salty, you'll find something you like for sure. The best market I've been to so far. Definitely a must stop!!!
There are a few stands that accept SNAP (food stamps)  and all employees are always nice

Tourist trap for sure, but wonderful all the same. Reading Terminal Market is the go-to place if either you're not sure what you want to eat or if your party members all want something different. This is basically an open-air market, just inside. The bulk of the vendors are street-food style, fast-casual restaurants. So many sandwich options!

There are a couple neat gems amid the sandwiches, such as the used book store. It had great hard-covers, many of which were vintage printings. I thought about buying a new book to enjoy on the train or airplane, but like everything else they were overpriced. 

Don't come in expecting immaculate resort amenities or to be waited on, hand and food. The Market is all about its gritty, Old-Town Philly charm. One piece of advice: don't look up.
OMG, they have everything! Love the food so much, they have a wide variety of all sorts of wonderful delights, that you can not find anywhere and everywhere. . I Love It. . .
Great food at every turn. My favorite was the Soul Food! Macncheese with fried chicken. Green beans looked so good too but I was kind of out of money to get them:(
Everything a good foodie wants to eat all under one roof!! Each time I visit, I discover another wonderful vendor...my favorite place in Philly!

I love Reading Term. I've been going since I was a little girl. One of the best historical places, especially food places to go in Philadelphia. Try Tootsies, George's, the soul food place, Carmen's steaks, and the Amish bakery!

Very busy but I love the variety. There is something for everyone. This includes vegans and vegetarians. I also like the mixture of food, salads, desserts and fresh produce and meats. I think this is a good option if you are with a group and people and no one is clear about what they have a taste for. The only issue is the long line you might have to stand in.

I love the Reading Terminal Market! There vendors have exceptional service and the quality of the food is unmatched for the Philadelphia area! 

You can get fresh meat, homemade grains, and basically whatever else you want for a reasonable price.

I've been going here since I was a child. There's great food and a variety of people. Beilers, and all the fresh produce stands make it worth it. On top of that there's delicious food stands and places to eat inside such as the Dutch eating place that is always attentive with a great selection of food. Their turkey melt, burgers, and chili are my favorite items on the menu!

I love it here. I love the diversity of people, food, and coffees. It gets a bit too packed and so it's that weird "new kid in the cafeteria" feeling of staring folks down for a table. I hate that feeling - so I never eat in the terminal. That said, every time I go - I enjoy my experience. The last time, I had a veggie gyro (pretty good), snagged a delicious blue mountain coffee, a few beaded bracelets,  and got a little bag of handpicked assorted chocolates and candies as a sweet finish. I really like taking my son here - we love munching on our bag of goodies as we look at all the cool foods. I just make sure that I hold him SUPER tightly - the crazy crowds give it a kid losing Lifetime movie affect.
Great shopping and great vendors. Can get busy so if you're local and plan to do your grocery shopping here, go during the week.

Personally I think RTM is overrated. Yes, you can theoretically buy some of Philly's best food here; if you can actually get it, that is. Most of the vendors here are textbook examples of how not to set up businesses: inefficient food preparation, messy serving, slow check-out, etc. Combine this with the fact that there's so many people that you can't move 5 feet without being jostled by someone. So, so, so many tourists all the time. You couldn't feasibly shop here with any frequency; RTM is a place to go for a one-time novelty and then go get your actual food someplace else.

You can't beat this place. I look forward to coming here every year at Thanksgiving. You do yourself a disservice if you don't show up with an appetite. One of the things about Philadelphia that I miss the most.
Wasn't enough time or stomach space to sample all they had to offer. Italian hero's, pastrami, desserts ....

This is one of the coolest markets ever! I love the wide range of things I can buy here. It's like Wegmans on steroids. Haha! I would recommend visiting this place, especially if you're just visiting Philly.
The market is wonderful! So many great options for eating and drinking. It can get a bit crowded though hence the 4 stars instead of 5.

Always a great spot for food and grocery shopping. We go every weekend and stop to get a donut first then walk around to grab things for the week. 
Can get busy around lunch on the weekends.

Wow I wish my stomach had more space for food! There's so many great vendors to try! 

I came on a Saturday afternoon and it was packed! I got to try 2 different vendors, but wasn't my first picks, because of the lines. Our tactic was to try 1 thing at as many vendors as we could. Sadly, we tapped out at 2 + coffee. 

A lot of the places don't have a seating area so that was a little hassle. Still a great place to visit. If I had time, I would go back and try a few more places there! Probably need to go back at least 5 times using the same tactic to make some damage. Have fun!

Reading Terminal Market is a collection of stalls, mostly restaurants, selling every food related thing you could possible imagine.

Whether you want awesome donuts, an authentic Philly Chessesteak, European pastries, Cajun gumbo, Italian subs, Chinese takeout, Indian Curries, Vietnamese soups, breakfast to go, a casual sit-down experience or anything else, you are going to find it here.

Raw fish and meat to take home?  Sure!
Cooked right here and served to  you on a bun? Absolutely!
Sauces, spices, jerkys?  Of course!

Really, if you are in the area for lunch YOU WANT TO GO HERE!  

Popular with tourists and locals, people who are not comfortable in crowds might want to stay away on the weekends but in the middle of the week you cannot go wrong.

If you hit the donuts shop, you want to try the fritters (apple and blueberry are both great),
The Cajun place has an alligator sausage sub that is divine (though their claim to fame is a sub called the "trainwreck!")
And if you go to the Ducth Eating Place, the dumplings are to die for.

You can get a cheese-steak at several places and I don't think you can go wrong.

You could eat here every day for a month and not hit the same place twice.

Why are you still reading this? Just go. Wander. And try whatever suits your fancy.

I've been going to the Reading Terminal Market for years now and I love it. I love that I can get just about any kind of fresh meats, seafood and cheeses you could ever want. There are things I'd never thought I'd try but after going for so long you start to get an idea of what's good and decide to try it. I love the people and going on a rainy Saturday is the best. To have lunch and get all of your fresh foods and produce for dinner. And the candy, that is just indescribable as it's freshly made and so good. I would highly recommend that if you've never been, it's worth a visit whether you are local or visiting from another place. It's just as much a landmark as the Liberty Bell in my opinion. Totally worth the trip. If you plan on spending the day, I do suggest bringing a cooler so you can get your food to bring home since I believe it closes rather early.

Love this place! Great market with lots of stores and vendors -- you can buy almost anything here: cookies, pastries, desserts, sandwiches, meats, deli meat, candles, mugs, coffee, etc. 

I love the candles from the Bee Natural candle shop -- they're reasonably priced hand poured candles in a variety of amazing scents. 

Only reason for the four stars is that it's always packeddd, which isn't really a knock on the market itself, but I just had to throw that in there. Would definitely stop by if you're visiting the Philly area!
Love everything about Reading but I extra love Pearl's Oyster bar! Best variety of oysters on the half shell and their "oyster Sommelier" is the reason I keep going back.
Very cool I visited with friends while interviewing in Philly, now that I live here need to go back...

What a great spot. I'd come back here in a minute! The sights sounds and smells are all fantastic. This is everything amazing about Philadelphia under one roof. This was on our list of things to do in Philly but it should have been first on the list!

Reading terminal is a must for both tourists and locals alike. It's one of my favorite places in the city. So many awesome food vendors, led by the Amish merchants you won't find anywhere else. Let me list the vendors that make Reading Terminal so awesome:
1. Beiler's Bakery - Best Bakery in the city
2. Beiler's Donuts - Best donuts in the city
3. Smuckers - Best Roast beef sandwich in the city
4. Dutch Eating Place - Best diner in the city, featuring the apple dumpling
5. Dienner's BBQ chicken - Best Rotisserie & BBQ chicken in the city
6. Bassets Ice Cream - Best ice cream in the city
7. Beck's Cajun - One of the best places for New Orleans food in the city
8. The Rib Stand - One of the best places for ribs in the city
9. Kevin Parker's Soul Food Café - One of the best places for soul food in the city
10. Carmen's - One of the best places for cheesesteaks &  hoagies in the city
11. Pearl's Oyster Bar - One of the best old school seafood spots in the city

I also get my meats, fish and cheeses from Reading Terminal. High quality at some of the lowest prices in the city. My favorites are:
1. Riehl Deli & Cheese shop
2. L. Halteman Family Country Foods
3. Martin's Quality Meats & Sausages
4. Iovine Brothers Produce

I can go on and on. There are candy shops, pretzels, wine, and more... It does get extremely crowded at times, but wading through the crowd is always worth it. No matter what you have a taste for you can find it at Reading Terminal.

What's not to love? One stop shopping for everything great! Almost all that Philly has to offer (and then some) under one roof, open year round! 
Too many great eats to mention... 

I suggest walking or taking the subway since traffic and parking can get a little hairy and expensive if you don't know where you're going. They do have a parking garage though if you insist on driving.

The sights, sounds, and smells of this downtown market are intoxicating! It was across the street from our hotel so we ate breakfast there every morning and lunch once too. Many different cuisines offered plus a produce market. This place can get extremely busy (Saturday afternoons) and that can take away from the enjoyment. You pretty much have to hover around the tables and pounce when someone looks like they are about to finish. It was much more enjoyable weekday mornings after everyone is at work. Recently became open seven days a week, 9-6. However, because each stall is operated individually, you can't be guaranteed every stall will be open the entire time. Had hoped to pick up some energy soup and veggie burger mix at a natural foods stall on Monday before leaving town but at 10:45am, there was still no sign that the stall would open that day.

Oh my gosh. The selections. This place is very very packed on the weekends. If you have kids, it might be a little troublesome getting everyone corralled together. Seating is really limited, but that goes with the atmosphere of the place. So many little food places. Almost any type of food is there. I've been a couple of times now and it's all delicious. Just don't be in a hurry.

This is a must see/stop by to experience! I adore the Reading Terminal Market. They have so many different things to offer thanks to all of their amazing vendors. If able to stop by, make sure to try a freshly made grilled cheese with farm fresh cheese, as well as some freshly baked donuts and whoopie pies from the local Amish people. The flying money has great cookies, and there is also a local honey/bee stand that sells great candles! There are so many other things to eat and try but those are my favorites. You will even find their infamous chocolate covered onion which is made at their local chocolate shop, Mueller Chocolate Co. This is a gag gift which visitors get a real kick out of!
Fun place to walk around and find treats and goodies! There are vendors for snacks, drinks, food, candy, gifts, and restaurants. So much to do and see inside!

I have been going to the Reading Terminal Market for at least 25 years.   The market has changed over the year with more vendors and various upgrades but the quality of every vendor and every selection has always been above 100%.   This place has it all.  From fresh meats and vegetables to fresh food foods that you can't believe.   

You must go hungry or won't appreciate all it has to offer.  
The roast pork is awesome, the Amish fresh cooked chickens and pretzels are to die for.   The fresh meats are like my local South Philly Butcher.  

I grew up in this neighborhood and the Reading
terminals was always a treat to go and shop.  From candy to unusual meats, there is a lot to choose. 
Highly recommend.

All I can say is WOW! What an authentic experience. It's overwhelming in a good way. If you time. There are so many food vendors and varieties. Amish selections, Philly Cheese stakes, and really so many fresh produce and local food selections here. A ton of great restaurants. I ate at Molly's and it was so good. I also purchased some holiday items like dented beeswax candles, local honey and some local wine. A couple of sheen wine coasters too. This is an amazing place to experience if you are visiting Philidelphia

An philly institution.  There is every kind of food you could possibly want.  But it is really crowded too especially around lunch.  Nice place to go an visit when in philly but not sure I would go all the time.

Stopped here while out for the day in Philadelphia as per the suggestion of a friend who is a Philadelphia local. I had the Italian pulled pork sandwich and it was exceptional. There really is something for everyone in here, the perfect spot to stop with all of your indecisive friends and at an affordable price too!
Don't eat here at noon the cops all eat here and they gonna find ya stash stay away at all costs

You MUST visit Reading Terminal Market when visiting philadelphia! There's so many vendors to see, the food is great to sample, and the vibe is so fun. Definitely get an Amish donut while you're there. The vegetables are super fresh as are the meats for a great take away to them prepare your meals at home. Not terribly pricey.

Awesome food market- you can find anything and everything you're looking for under one roof. I've never seen RTM in a state other than bustling, and it usually take a little hunting to find a table to sit down and enjoy your food. Be prepared for it to be pretty crowded, but its all part of the experience.
Reading terminal market is so much fun! I picked up cannoli sat termini and then had lunch with a friend over in the Amish diner area.

I love this place, Old City Coffee (one of the best), the juice bar, the chocolate, the options for fresh vegetables and meats and prepared foods. The bakeries, the amish, the cheese, lol. I could go on and on but its girl's dream, the reading terminal market.

This place is a foodie heaven. So far we ate an Amish made open faced turkey sandwich with mashed potatoes and gravy, bought some Amish pepper jelly, ate cheese steaks, donuts, icecream, roast pork and broccoli rabe sandwiches, & chocolate chip cookies. All in a days work.

This place is the Mecca of food. You can find all types of assorted foods and goods. The place is bussling with people from all walks of life. It's hard to just pick one spot. A great place for tourists.
Delicious delicacies. We are from the north but have lived in the south for 5 years and have missed so many foods. This was a place for us to hit all of our food memories. Highly recommended.

Best place I have been in a long time . Being from Boston which doesn't have a place like this I was so happy to be in this place . Love love love it . If you like to cook and love food. This is heaven in one place

If you are visiting Philadelphia you NEED to stop by this place! There is a lot of history housed here and you can find yourself lost a bit in the maze of this indoor farmer's market. It's a tourist spot so it's going to feel overwhelming from the crowd but it's worth checking out to shop, eat, and just look around.
Very good donuts and very good sandwich,I could say top 10 in United States, the liberty donuts and the slow cook sandwich with lots of meat

This place is a Philly staple. If you are from out of town it is a must. I have been here so many times. From the Dinics Roast Pork sandwiches to the Beilers Donuts, you can't go wrong.
It is huge and so many options. Deserts to oysters. They have it all. You won't be disappointed.
It is also across from the Philly Convention Center.
It is a must, stop in for your meal. Hint of advice, don't come between 11:45-2:00pm. Packed for lunch.

A trip to Philly isn't complete without a visit to RTM. It's like an indoor bazaar in Morocco, vibrant, bustling, and filled with exotic (and familiar) sights and sounds and smells of Philly's best eats. Hot pork sandwiches, cold fresh oysters, raw Penna Dutch cow's milk, all available for reasonable prices. Visitors that I bring here are always jelly that we have such an amazing market in the heart of the city. Parking across the street is convenient and reasonably priced. Awesome-sauce!

Lots of people for good reason: the food is great! We purchased some donuts from Beiler's and some banana pudding from Sweet Nina's. I love that banana pudding. It's run by a husband and wife I think and they are super sweet. I barely shared any of that pudding with my husband it is that good.
Enjoyed the air of energy and happy people who enjoy the coming together in this warm city.
Very cool place to go for a variety of food and drinks. Love these types of markets. It gets packed so be sure to expect a lot of people on weekends and better to on a weekday.
A must-visit at least once in your life...and will return because you didn't experience everything this amazing market has to offer.

If you are in Philadelphia, the Reading Terminal Market is a must visit spot. Every taste of Philadelphia, and really the world can be found here. The smells, the shops, the people, it's always such an amazing experience. 

You want an amazing roast pork sandwich, it's there (DiNic's). You want a delicious Jewish deli, it's there (Hershel's). Chocolates and candy, it's there. Amazing Amish food, yup. Delicious soft pretzels, pastries, small vendors, meats, fish, fruits, veggies, you can find it all in the market. 

There are also parking garages that give you discounted parking with a validated ticket. If you spend $10 in the market, which is easy to do, that vendor will validate the ticket for you!
