A must stop when in Philly. Crepes, beef jerky, tea, ice cream, donuts, Indian, fresh meats & produce and these were just the places we tried. Great atmosphere and all the vendors were very nice and helpful too.

Butterfly in the sky, I can go twice as high. Take a look it's in a book, it's a Reading Rainbow?!?....No No No you're uterrly confused my friends, this is the Reading Terminal not Reading Rainbow you won't find Levar Burton here either :(

Reading Terminal was the one of the many highlights of my trip to Philly. We ended up having a hotel nearby so we were about 5 mins within walking distance of the terminal.  The Reading Terminal is an indoor public market and a historic landmark building for Philly.  There's tons of merchants and vendors inside the terminal to choose from, too many I can't even count so I will list my favorites:

Beiler's Donuts - OMGOODNESS, the east coast knows how to make dounuts and this place is no different.  Make sure you stock up on Saturday because they are closed on Sundays.

Valley Shepherd Creamery - this cheeseshop is known for it's grilled cheese sandwiches.  The Somerset is a must!

Four Seasons - if you're looking for a health kick this is the spot for you.  An assortment of fruit smoothies to choose from.

Keven Parker's Soul Food Cafe - Food Network Rated Best Fried Chicken, this is a must stop at the terminal.

The Reading Terminal has it all, a wide variety of food to choose from, sit down restaurants, you can even do a little produce shopping for the house.  If visiting Philly try to get a hotel near the terminal as it will be your one stop for a quick and delicious bite.

I definitely should come here more often especially because I live so close by.  I really enjoyed Iovine Brothers Produce, very affordable and fresh!  I've also eaten at a few of the restaurants here and for the most part, the food is flavorful, tasty and affordable.  I enjoy browsing the food vendors, I've had good ice cream by Bassets and good sandwiches at Hatfield Deli.  I also enjoyed Godshall's Poultry, very affordable, fresh and tasty chicken.  I've browsed John Yi's fish market too and things looked good there but I'm still not the biggest fan of fish, so I passed on it.  I think the catch with this market is to check the prices.  I thought that by going here everything would be cheaper, not necessarily, sometimes things are more expensive than one would think, so buyer beware.  For the most part though, I'm glad that Reading Terminal Market is around and I'd love to check them out again.  They remind me of Pike Place Market in Seattle, in a way except for the fish throwing, lol!

I don't have enough proper adjectives to describe my deep and unabashed love for all that is Reading Terminal Market. 

It holds some of my favorite booths and most delicious eats. Whenever we are within a five mile radius my husband suddenly gets hungry and has an urge to "just pop in and look around". 

Basically, if you have not had breakfast from the Dutch Eating Place, you are not really living your best life. Now get to it!

Famous as it is, the market is nevertheless a rather overpriced tourist trap yet good for a walk through and finding little snacks and food items for everyone. Everything from pastries to honey and hoagies and crafts are present, including those provided by the foodsellers from the Amish countryside. As a prominent Philly establishment, it's strategically placed right by next to the Convention Center and Chinatown, and a short walk away from the City Hall. A bit crowded but fun to visit in the morning and brunch hours.

fun atmosphere at this market

can be quite expensive, but it is part of the experience

a must visit in the city of brotherly love
Very fun! Loved the people and the shops.  It is crowded though, and I do not recommend bringing a stroller.
The market was excellent with many local shops and restaurants. We ate Tommy Dinics sandwiches and toke apple pie with us. The fried chicken was also tasty.
Great assembly of just about any type of food you could want! You could eat here three times a day for weeks and never get bored! Don't miss this wonderful place when your in town!
Market is HUGE and has a great variety of foods. Definitely a must when visiting Philly!
Nice variety of stores and outlets, tons of amazing food and experiences for you and our family.

This is a foodie's HEAVEN! I repeat HEAVEN!
Fresh ingredients all around, making everything taste a 100 times more delicious.

If you're not carb cutting, I say go get yourself a pork sandwich with broccoli rabe and extra sharp provolone from DI NICS! This way, while you're waiting on line for BEILLER'S doughnuts, you have something to munch on! Their line can get pretty long, so avoid the crankiness and get yourself a sandwich! By the time you get to the front of their line you'll be in better shape to start pointing your fingers at all the yummy-goodness! I personally enjoyed the maple-bacon, apple fritter, and the cinnamon roll. IF YOU'RE GOING TO LISTEN TO ANYTHING ON THIS REVIEW... LISTEN TO THIS... Get yourself a DOZEN!
Some of the best seafood, fresh Vegetables, dutch country milk juice, cheeses. Some of the very best salads, ribs and chicken wings.
This place is a goldmine! Has everything from fresh cut fruit to baked goods to specialty grilled cheese sandwiches. Options for everybody, and many a food occasions!
An absolute must visit if you are in Philly!! There's truly nothing else like it! Tons of vendors in one location. You can find any tasty treat your heart desires!
WOW!!!!  Thats all I can say.  If you want to go to food heaven this place is very close to it.  There are lots of choices to choose from.   Go and have fun.  There are almost too many choices.
Great tourist spot with a large variety of foods and small businesses to see. It gets super crowded on weekends but is well worth a walk around. Pretty much everything here is good :)

Lots of options to choose from, whether it's to catch a bite to eat, purchase some groceries or meats for a meal at home, satisfy your sweet tooth or other. Depending, there are also special attractions like a moving train exhibit for certain holidays. Both private and street parking available. The only downside is that it gets really crowded and finding a place to sit and eat can be challenging.

Absolutely love reading terminal! It's one of the greatest spots in Philly! The meat vendors are great, as are the cheese vendors. Check out flying monkey for a delicious woopie pie. This place is a must see if you're visiting.
One of my favorite places in Philadelphia. You can get so many different things here. Defiantly worth checking out.
Love it.. Everything you might want to eat , you can find it there . The Terminal is a Mall of Small restaurants ,Breakfast , Lunch or Dinner  Junk Food , all Day Long...

What can you say about Reading Terminal Market? It's the #1 spot for me in terms of taking friends from out of town. You can spend 1.5-2 hours in here easily, eating a nice meal, doing a little shopping (food or otherwise), and it's right near the Convention Center & Chinatown so it really is a great jumping off spot for a touristy weekend day. You can't leave without eating some Beiler's. The hype is real!

Very interesting. Various food, fresh made donuts and cake. The donuts place is not open on Sunday. The phili cheese steak is ok. Tommy dinic's brisket beef is pretty good and special because they use a whole skinny pepper for spice not regular green pepper you would think.  The fresh make donut is a must have!

When going to Philly, my dad kept saying "Go to the Reading Terminal! I've seen it on tv!". I didn't know what he was talking about. Why did I want to go somewhere where people read? Then the hotel manager told us to go there for lunch. I then text my dad and told him where I was going and he said, "well, you don't listen to me". 

When we went inside, I was amazing. There was so much going on! There would food spots, markets, and little shops. It reminded me a flea market, BUT WITH FOOD. I had so many choices in where to get food. I ended up going to a sandwich spot that was well known that had "the best sandwich" in America from DiNic's Roast Pork and Beef. Thaaaaaat was okay, however the Reading Terminal was over all great and now I know where to go for a variety of food.
Reading terminal is a great one stop shop for fresh goods and locally sourced fruit and vegetables. Take a look at the massive market.

Jealous this doesn't exist in Chicago!  Such a cool place to visit for food & people watching. Pretty sure you can find any type of food you desire at this Market (including yummy Philly Cheesesteaks). There are also a few different places to buy fresh fruits & veggies as well as meat & cheese (indoor farmers markets). The market is huge and was such a fun place to explore while we were in Philly.

Great location and options. This is a HUGE market. Be ready to ask for a map to acclimate yourself. My review may be a bit premature as I need several visits to properly rate the quality of vendors and food options. I wish the market stayed open later in the workday.

I wish I was there now!  This was one of our favorite stops on our trip to Philly.  I think we ate here like 3 times in 3 days.  Huge selection of food types.  Everyone will find something they like.
Find the cannolis.  The best I've ever had BY FAR!

This was my first time going to the East Coast so I did not know what to expect. I did my research of things to do around the area and found this market. The atmosphere was very welcoming as soon as you walk in. Tons of desert areas around as well as comfort food. We stopped by for breakfast at the seafood place recommended by one of the advisors. It was a twist on breakfast (sea food ) but definitely good. If I had a reason to go back I definitely would but maybe on an empty stomach.

I am obsessed with this place.  Did you know there is discount parking nearby???  Too many excellent options to list.  Walk around.  Enjoy the amazing foods.  Enjoy the chaos.  Enjoy everything about this place.
Amazing everything! but wildly crowded, you really have to spend a lot of time fighting through the crowds.

I love coming here. There are lots of vendors with fresh produce and fresh homemade juices, pastries, and other foods. I don't think I could ever get bored coming here. It does get very busy on the weekends, which makes it a bit tough walking through the market. I can't wait to go back!
i went to by georges for my first meal in philly! i was looking for a good vegetarian cheesesteak and this was the perfect place. so flavorful and totally delicious!

Omg, one guess where I'm HEADING
To the Terminal Market known as READING
I feel like Starlight when she's SHEDDING
I feel like a salon that does THREADING
I feel like Billy Idol singing White WEDDING
I feel like my girlfriend when she's SPREADING
I feel like a happy form of Otis REDDING
Cuz the Reading Market is a BLESSING

But let me tell you what I've been DREADING
Other than any more ISIS BEHEADING
It's being walked in on while UNDRESSING
Having somebody notice my SWELLING
Being accused of some mad bed WETTING
Having everyone in the market STARING
This market gets me going and keeps me SWEATING
And necessitates some brand new BEDDING

WHAT.

If you only go to one place in Philly, go here, and get these items:

What to get: Hot Pretzel, Lemonade, Shake from Miller's Twist.
What else: Pot Roast Sandwich from Smucker's.
And what else: Roast Pork Sandwich w/ Broccoli Rabe from Tommy DiNic's.
Any more: Beiler's Donuts and anything from Dutch Eating Place.
What not to get: Caught at Reading reading Penthouse by an Amish security guard.

But: While you're in Philly, you must also try John's Roast Pork, Nick's Roast Beef, and a bubble tea at Mr. Wish.

This is the quintessential Market for the East Coast. Every other City along the Eastern Seaboard wishes it had a market as lavish and spectacular. Basically it is food Paradise with all kinds of deliciousness inside. A lot of it is overpriced and touristy, but there are also some amazing hidden gems lurking within the walls, particularly those which are owned and operated by the Amish, who have a very large presence within this Market.

Speaking of very large presents... (pulls down pants)... happy Amishmas.

The number one highlight is Miller's Twist which is where you will get the best hot gooey pretzel you've ever had , which will make you never want to eat a pretzel from anywhere else, and will make you speak in very long sentences, and I mean very very long sentences. 

Also try their lemonade and chocolate milkshakes which are amazing. Make sure you get the plain pretzel. Or if it's a flying pretzel, the plane pretzel. The only other pretzel that I've had which compares is down at Sadie Anne's at the Dutch Village Market in Upper Marlboro Maryland. 

Next on the agenda you have to go to Smuckers Grill and get a Pot Roast Sandwich. The breakfast there is ok but the pot roast is otherworldly and sensational. Truly one of the best sandwiches in the world. You do not come to Philadelphia for cheesesteak sandwiches. You come here for other sandwiches such as John's Roast Pork and Nick's Roast Beef and this gem here in the Market at Smuckers.

The Dutch eating place is also very good as are many of the other stands in here like Beiler's donuts. But the next top highlight belongs to Tommy Dinic's. Roast pork is the sandwich that Philly should be famous for, and the only place that makes it better than Tommy is John's which is the ultimate pork destination. Tommy does a wonderful if overpriced roast pork with broccoli rabe. And I highly recommend asking for extra broccoli rabe. Once again skip the cheesesteak. If you must get one, try one when you go to John's, or grab one at Joe's Steaks & Soda Shop, along with some shakes.

Parking here is an absolute nightmare and they give tickets out the way molesters give candy out to children while hanging out of dark unmarked vans. I highly recommend using the parking deck and just paying the lofty prices to avoid the drama. Alternatively, park somewhere cheap far away, and walk into the center so that you aren't paying for every minute you're here. The parking meters and garages here are almost as much of a rip off as your Aunt was last night.

And if your friend Adel is hungry, I'll take him to the market, and will duly Fill Adel For Ya.

Love Love Love This Place!!! I love try all kinds of foods.This Place has it all from soul to junk food.Want to try different cheese or excellent pastries Try out Termini Bros now That's a piece of heaven!
Nice place with feeling, commerse and want to spend money feeling! Go here and get hungry, as I did!
We all love it right? What can't you get here? You can't get bored here. Yeah it's touristy but it's fun especially for the kids

So many options of food, bar in the back at Molly's, fresh food markets and a definite tourist must. We ate at Dinics and he sandwhich was huge with enough toppings and meat to go with the large fresh buns and friendly service! A definite do if you've never been tourist or not.
Wonderful endless selections! And all delicious. Highly recommend to both locals and visitors.

Reading Terminal Market is a hectic place with a ton fantastic food of all varieties. My go to place for a lunch here is the gourmet grilled cheese from Melt Craft. Any of the grilled cheeses with a cup of the incredible tomato soup and the chips it comes with are the perfect lunch. I highly recommend trying a variety of places and grabbing a cookie or cake for dessert before you go.

If you like to eat and sample different things, you need to check this place out.  It's open everyday starting at 8am.  Some of my favorite spots are Hershel's deli for the pastrami sandwich, salmon curry at Little Thai Market, breakfast with freshly squeezed OJ at Dutch eating place, Beiler's donuts, pretzels at Miller's twist.  You can easily spend a couple hours just walking and eating here so worth a visit.

The place has everything you want under one roof. What more can you ask for? Most of the time I come here it's to pick up Produce from Iovine Brothers, Lapsang Souchong at Tea Leaf or a Smoothie from Four Seasons. It's hard to only hit one merchant while you're here. Even your pockets want to keep spending. 

I will admit I try to find any excuse to just be in the heart of this hustle and bustle. Some people just using the Terminal as a walk through, while others doing there Daily or Weekly grocery shopping. From the vibes to the smells, the Terminal has got it going on.

Reading Terminal is home to a diverse and delicious set of Philadelphia eateries, butchers, bakers, produce growers, and speciality shops where you can find anything your heart could possibly desire. 

I'll reserve my shop-specific reviews for their individual yelp pages but I highly recommend taking an afternoon to shop at reading terminal market for your normal groceries. You'll be so impressed at the quality and price difference in things like meats and produce. 

Also - take a minute and grab lunch at one of the delicious restaruants. 

Note: The market can get crazy on weekend afternoons so be prepared to take your time.

I am a frequent visitor to the terminal as I work right next door to it. The terminal offers a lot of options for foodies. The most busiest spot is usually little thai market( the salmon platter is delicious). If you come early morning between 9 and 10 am the terminal is less busy and you are least likely to be in a line.
Definitely a fun place to visit. And a great place to keep returning to. So many good choices for food. Lots of bustle and energy.

So much fun to visit! A great place to have a meal if you're just visiting. Favorites were Old City Coffee and the flower market. We had drinks at Mollys, which were good. If I were in PA any longer, I would have been back for several meals.

This wonderful indoor farmers market is in the original Reading Railroad Terminal, a historic landmark. 

With purveyors of every possible food, it's fun to wander around gathering ingredients for whatever feast to come. I also enjoy having lunch or taking prepared food out from a number of restaurant stalls. 

Among my favorites are: 

Diener's chicken. The Amish do chicken right. I love their classic whole chicken and wings. They've recently added a few nice varieties of chicken, and 
roasted vegetables. 

Dinics for roasted pork with sharp provolone, onions and peppers. 

Hershel's - pastrami is worth dying for. I like the Reuben with Cole slaw. A half is enough for me for months.  

Sang Kee - duck noodle soup. 

Pearl's - snapper soup, breakfast burrito. 

Old city coffee

Famous 4th Street cookies

This is the Chelsea Market of Philly. So many random food stalls and markets that were cool! They even had Amish choices, which isn't something we get a lot around me. It was definitely more old school, but was really nice. I found a great coffee company here and bought the most delicious coffee (besides my top favorite Jamaican Blue Mountain coffee). There are really great vendors and good products, so definitely check this place out!

This is definitely one of my favorite spots in the whole city! It's a concentration of all the yummiest restaurants and food stands in the city in one place. I have tried Beilers Donuts (ask for a fresh made hot donut!) and the Dutch Food Place (bang for your buck and delicious!) the Creperie and the little farmers market in the back to get cheap and fresh produce. I bring people here when they're visiting from out of town and they always leave happy. 

Think of it as Philly's version of Grand Central Market in LA or Pike Place in Seattle with an east coast twist. Definitely a go to spot if you're a local wanting to grab a bite or a tourist wanting a taste of Philly.

Awesome place with lots of food options. Farmers market is really good, you can get variety of fruits which may not be available everywhere, like shaved fresh coconut. 

Great options for desserts, there's a nice crepery, really good ice cream place and a place which sells fresh baked cookies and other goodies. Highly recommended if you are in center City Philly. Only downside is it is not open late in the evening.
Lot of options and great local flavors. Avoid 12 to 1 that being busiest time of the day. My favorite is fresh local produce at decent prices.

Very diverse and interesting place, every time I visit Philly I discover something new here. My favorite stand is Meuller Chocolate Co, which has a variety of fine chocolates, including different body parts and organs packaged with clever little sayings!
Gotta go here for Chocolate Covered Potato Chips - I think they're at Mueller's!

LOVE the Terminal!! Use to work across the street so was there all the time. Worst thing to deal with is tourists who stand in the middle of the isle trying to figure out where they're going, while us working stiffs are trying to get in & out for lunch. The Metropolitan Bakery has the most fabulous sour cherry and sea salt cookie EVER!!! Lovine Produce & Johnathan's Grocer are always a stop and the Little Thai Market is always worth the wait. The Salmon house specialty is spectacular. With live 70+ vendors there is always something for everyone. Sure miss it!!

Love Reading Terminal! Best food stands. If you haven't been you must go. Favs are Guintas meats, diNicks, cheese shops, fresh honey, fantastic produce, pizza, great diners, fantastic breads and baked goods, restaurants, bar, diners. The best stuff!

You can always find something good to eat here. I've loved every restaurant I ordered from. It's counter style so not many formal sit down restaurants. I like that there are so many on one place but I hate that there's never any place to sit. Another thing is that there's never any parking (because it's downtown) so beware. Overall, you can't go wrong. My favorites include an Amish counter with Amish rotisserie chicken and smackaroni salad, the soul food restaurant towards the middle (they have amazing collard greens and sweet potatoes) and fourth street bakery (huge cookies).
The French toast at The Oyster Bar was great! The entire Market is a cool and historic place to eat and shop.

it is a delicious mad house here. be prepared for lines. get there early as they will and do run out of items. so many merchants to visit. insist they were open later so I can eat my way through the whole place. have great merchants for jewelry, health and wellness, produce and take home items. definitely a must visit on any trip to Philly

Calling this place a market is a tad of an exaggeration.
While produce, butcher and shop stalls exist. Reading market really is just a giant indoor food court.  I've been to many of these so call markets and many of them do have tons of shopping. However, here, it's primarily the sale of cooked food for immediate consumption.

That being said, WHAT an indoor food court this is!  With rows and rows of food stalls, you can spend hours easily looking around and trying out different types of food. From Chinese food to the Pennsylvanian Dutch, there is something for everyone! If you look closely, you could find some neat stuff too like draft birch beer. mmmm. The stalls were also a visual treat. I enjoyed watching the cooks stuff meat into the cheesesteaks/roast pork sandwiches. Overall, i felt like the market was a stimuli overload!

I came during the auto show. bad idea. it was insanly crowded. You know that black friday or a full rush hour tokyo/nyc subway form of croweded.

Oh I'm speechless in a good way! Reading Terminal oh how I love you! This is a place I could literally stay in all day long IF they had a gym inside hahaa ! All the vendors from deli's, fresh seafood markets, produce stands, Amish bread! Yum!! 
Not only that but all the places to eat from American to overseas! It's like once you walk in you can tour the world by eating! How awesome is that?! 
I have never been in anything like this before so I was fascinated by the vast food choices as I walked around.
If you are visiting the area this is absolutely one place you need to come. I cannot stress enough how awesome this place is heck I'm getting excited about going again as I write this review!
It's an experience I will never forget and each place I ate was delicious! One thing to note though it gets really crowded! So, when you do get something to eat seating is rare haha, but don't lose faith people are very nice and will make room for you! I call this type of eating family style! Great meeting new people while experiencing fabulous foods!
I'll be back!

Monopoly fans may recognize the Reading Terminal Market as part of the now famous Reading Railroad in the game, but Philadelphians may now associate good food with the Reading Railroad. This historic market outlasted the railroad, but kept the name. It is located in downtown Philadelphia with entrances on North 12th Street close to SEPTA and the subway.

The market has evolved mostly into a large food court, like most other public markets throughout the United States. There are still a good number of fresh food suppliers including butcher counters and produce stands, but most people head here for prepared goods and meals. Most of the individual businesses have separate reviews on Yelp.

Inside, the atmosphere is fun and crazy. There are lots of people and few directional signs making for a lot of confused people. This is not usually a problem since there are so many choices and unique options. The market opens early, but also closes early. This makes breakfast and lunch easy, but not so much for dinner. You can grab some raw meat for a long train ride home!

Anyone who enjoys food should visit Philadelphia. Anyone visiting Philadelphia will probably find something to enjoy at the Reading Terminal Market. It is still a bit rough around the edges, especially for suburban folks, but this is a fun and cool place to get your grub on.
Gets crowded but the food in here during lunch is awesome.  There are so many choices in and you can get pretty much anything you want!  Very cool place if your downtown philly and in a  hurry
I work across from the Reading Terminal.  Dinic's is a fave, HungerBurgers Mediterranean salad is so good, ummmm artichokes.

Great place to stop for quick shop and very close to the Jefferson station for those who use public transportation! The fresh produce are pretty nice and prices are very good! There is a good variety of products for everyone! It could be a little too busy in rush hours in the afternoon so try to avoid being there by then! A tip for students! they have about 20% discount for students on Wednesdays! Have your school ID with you

Everything yiu might be interested to eat and more, it can provide many people  will  a god healthy choice for a down right moan fest of delight.  From Asain  to Amish,  seafood to pizza.  Also you can pu c k up an old fashioned and good book to read while you dine. There are many fin place's to eat and drink as well.
What can I say? This place deserves six stars. It's a Philadelphia icon that never disappoints. We shop here for produce on a weekly basis. They're prepared foods are equally amazing.

It's hard to write a review for an entire market, but I can tell you that everything I ate here was exceptional! We stayed nearby for a weekend and ate there four times! The fried chicken at the soul food place was some of the best I've ever had; their mac and cheese was also wonderful. Get a breakfast sandwich on rye at Herschels. I got it with brisket and oh my wow, best breakfast! I also had the Italian pork sandwich with greens and provolone. Maybe my least favorite meal but totally delicious and filling. Also had the gumbo and eggs for breakfast, and it was spicy and yummy. Only issue was I got spice bread instead of cornbread. Not a huge deal. The cookies and the candy place were also great. Would go back a million more times!
This place is amazing. Really glad I checked it out while in the city. I recommend it to anyone and everyone!

Whether you're a local, born and raised Philadelphian or someone visiting from out of town, Reading Terminal is a MUST. 

If food is your thing, there's something for you here. Indian, Greek, Cajun, you name it, it's at Reading Terminal. Get yourself a Philly Cheesesteak from the same place as Obama or have a roast pork sandwich from DiNic's. If you have more of a sweet tooth then The Flying Monkey bakery whoopie pies are hard to beat. Beiler's donuts are also tough to beat. Maple bacon is my personal fave!

Keeping with Pennsylvania tradition, there are the Amish food stalls and also PA Dutch Eating Place with their apple dumplings will have you heading home happy.

If you're not hungry, then take some time to browse the different stalls for what you can take home. Flowers, loose tea, beeswax products are just a few of my favorite places to stop. 

Either way, you can't lose coming to Reading Terminal and you definitely will be back again!
Great times here and a very broad assortment of cuisines. Definitely a must see if you've never been. Beware it's always packed so don't take it personally if you get bumped into.

TLDR: Reading Terminal Market is probably the best food hall I've ever been to and the selection of food here is amazing.

Food halls are quickly becoming a thing in bigger cities and Philly has their own with Reading Terminal Market. After visiting here for the first time not too long ago, I would have to agree with many other people are saying, and that is Reading Terminal Market is as much as a Philly staple as the Philly cheesesteak itself.

Reading has a pretty rich history and it's been around since the late 1800s. It has had its shares of ups and downs, but it seems to be going on stronger than ever now. It's not just all restaurants here either, you could skip out on going to a grocery store and get all of your produce, meat, poultry, flowers, alcohol, and much more all here.

Obviously with it being a market, you need to come in here absolutely starving to make the most of the selections at Reading. There are foods of all types and you will get stuffed by the time you leave. 

If you do end up driving to Reading, there are two main garages that you can park at, and make sure you bring your ticket with you. If you spend ten or more dollars at one place, a merchant can validate your ticket for a discount on parking.

While there are so many options here, I can recommend:

- Miller's Twist for pretzels (Seriously the best pretzel ever)
- Tommy DeNic's for a roast pork sandwich 
- Beiler's for just about any donut you can think of
- Little Thai Market for chicken red curry
- 4th Street Cookie Company for what else, cookies

I suppose the only downside to this place is that it's only open until 6 pm. If it was open late, I don't think I could eat anywhere else. 

If you've never been here, do yourself a favor and go here now.
Readin terminal is a must. The food here is by yet the best. They have a wide varity of food to eat. Every place I tried at this location has been awsome.

This is a great place to go and grab lunch.  There are a large variety of options and most of the food there is very good.  Prices are also reasonable.  The downside is that everyone knows this is a great place to grab lunch so it can be uncomfortably crowded and it may be hard to get a seat to eat.
Essential Philadelphia culture and a good place to buy a Philadelphia-made gift to take home if you are visiting the city. Do not miss.

Saturday's are the best at Reading Terminal Market, great good variety, great energy and a ton of happy people....basically it's good food, family, fun vibe, even though it's with people you've never met.

Amazing! So many options!
No matter what you are in the mood for, Reading Terminal has it!
Desserts, lunches, snacks!
Great for a group who have very different tastes.
Lot of variety of food. Just some of these people have eye ball problems by whatever Im just going to avoid the issue and walk by all the clutter mess.‍

One of the most magical places I have ever been. Fresh fish counter, meats, sausages etc. as far as your eyes can see. A ton of different food choices from Mexican tacos to ice cream to Indian to donuts and chew steaks. Definitely something for everyone and an awesome experience. Super crowded during the lunch rush but hey that's part of the philly experience!

Great place to grab fresh food or prepared food.  Great location next to the Philadelphia Conference overwhelming number of places to choose from. Easy to get lost inside. Center. Lines can vary depending on spot and time of day but staff all do a great job of getting everyone taken care of quickly.  Everything from fresh fruit to deli meat or prepared cheesesteaks to Peking duck. Great sweets too fudge, cookies, and arrays opetite desserts. Yummy salmon bisque and fresh bread. Only open to 6 on Sundays and some of the stalls don't open (Amish and others). Some places that don't open on Sunday lease out their space other vendors.
Best of the best!!!! Love you, RTM!!!! Top 1st Philadelphian snack and food spot. It's like a food 'hole' for me... if you are here, please check it out

This is the hottest spot in Center City to visit.  You must try 2-3 of the sandwich places, the best is Dinic's, with a great roasted pork.  From one end to the other they have everything that Philadelphia is famous for.  Be prepared for lines and massive crowds.

Talk about sensory overload! Reading terminal has just about anything you could possibly think of. On a snowy day, I took the train into central city and had myself a grand o' time! One stop you could get oysters, then jump to another vendor for roasted Chinese duck. From there I moved onto a cookie and then a donut and then and then! Yes, that was all consumed by one person(me) in about a 4 hour period. This is an awesome place to stop for locals and tourists alike. Tip- the produce/farmers market has very reasonable prices.

Wonderful bazar of various food vendors. Nearly something for everyone. From a market fresh produce, vendors selling honey and cheeses, burgers and gyros, salad bar, to southern BBQ, wonderful pastries, and delicious chocolates. If you're hungry and looking for options right downtown, with a full compliment of visuals and smells, this place delivers.

Recently went on vacation to Philadelphia.  My cousin took us here for the first time and was overwhelmed by all the food vendors they had and fresh  produce section.
If youre ever in Philly, go here and stop by Beilers bakery. Baked goods are made fresh daily and one of the best pastries/doughnuts we ever had!

I shop here when I want to cook the freshest food for dinner. Fresh food with great prices. If you want cheaper seafood go around the corner to Chinatown and bring a translator.  NOT enough actual markets like this around. Second only to the Italian Market.
Great place with many options. Unfortunately, it's a tourist trap and it's always packed with people who have no idea where they're going. I suggest going early in the morning.
An amazing experience from a to Z. I love this place. Always fun, great food, new experiences. Its a must.

I LOVE THIS PLACE!!!!! They have basically anything you want to eat including desserts!!! Plus, there's a fish market, meat market and even a vegan booth....EVERYTHING!!!! Even with the long lines and mobs of ppl....This market is absolutely & simply AMAZING!!!!

Lots of options here! Donuts, Indian, Chinese, Thai, Greek, sandwiches, crepes, meats, cheese.. I could go on and on. 

There's an amazingly cheap grocery with tons of fresh veggies, a flower stall for fresh bouquets.

Tried the Greek place with a fresh gyro. Their meats are sliced fresh off of the heat spinner, and the lamb was super flavorful. 

Super crowded though, be prepared to lose someone.. we did.
not bad for a market type. some good food ,not gourmet but passable!
What's not to love about this place???!!! Some stands can be a little pricey for what they're serving, and the crowds can be overwhelming, but even when it's crowded, it's still worth the trip.

A unique food hall in Philadelphia, the Reading Terminal Market provided an abundance of food options with a dearth of time available to try it all. The options available range from the Philly Cheesesteak to Mediterranean cuisine and everything in between. I ate at the 12th Street Cantina, and the food there was particularly good. The atmosphere at the Reading Terminal Market makes it a necessary tourist attraction, and the only downside to it is the 6pm close time. Overall, I would recommend the Reading Terminal Market to anyone looking for a unique food hall with an abundance of options.
Vary overwhelming with all the people but never disappointed in the food. My kids having a great time on their day off.

Cool place to look around and worth a visit but not many good food options. The only thing that looked worth buying were local products like honey, and flowers or the Thai food place (which had a super long line). There was also a store in the back with lots of seasonings to buy in bulk and lots of options for hot sauce. I had a great juice at a juice stand but the whole place only had 1 vegetarian/vegan food store, and it didn't sell any hot foods- only cold refrigerated soup. 
Disappointing, found another place nearby to eat.

For a taste of Philly, visit Reading Terminal Market. From the small value and premium grocers to butchers, restaurants, and craft stores there isn't a lot to go wrong with here. The sheer scale of options here makes it easy for everybody... the potential lines can make it a bit more difficult, so get there early.

Good places all around.  I personally go to Hershel's East Side Deli for the corn beef sandwich.  Absolutely a must have if you're ever in the area.  Only problem is it's very crowded due to being a big food hot spot.

This place is a gem that so many Philadelphians overlook. I got ribs, chicken wings, and produce here the other day, and all of it was great. For whatever reason, the quality of food from these vendors is quite a bit higher than the rest of the city. My top three: the thai place (salmon), the ice  cream place, and the ribs place.

What cant you say about this place. They have everything!!!! Cookies, Cakes, Coffees, Honey, Cheesesteaks, gifts, fresh fish, raw meats, veggies, etc. They have it all in one location. We love getting items from here. Try to avoid lunch time as they are really busy.

Often too crowded and has trouble-making crazy people inside.  I become impatient with things there like: this place made a tasty hamburger but they put salt on it plus the order taker talked crude.  Food would have tasted better without salt.

It's hard to vote for an entire food market, but I'm going to anyways. Fabulous place to go to if you're in the city, visiting or living here. You can find a meal for all budgets. I highly suggest Beiler's Donuts but get there early if you are going on a weekend! Termini Bros is also a local favorite for fresh cannolis.

They do need more seating options, which is why I'm marking this down.
love this place! there is so much food variety here. It is my go-to spot on Fridays after class. I highly recommend going to beilers and east-hershel (order the pastrami).

This place is amazing!! So many different food options! Everything I have tried here was delicious I love all the little different stands they had and a very cool place as it used to be an old train terminal
I miss working downtown and being able to go here all the time. Th terminal has such an amazing variety of food you can't find many other places! A must-go.

As a multi-cultural experience, it definitely earns high marks. I've been to nYC so I get the crowds and the bumping/pushing to get around. That said, it would be tough to get around with Kids during peak times or impossible with a wheelchair. 

It makes up for it with the unique  food vendors (Thai, Dutch, Chinese, ice cream, etc) as well as shops (delis, soaps, jewelry, etc).
Way too crowded for me. I wouldn't say I hate crowds but when people are up your ass every time you turn around it's hard to shop. I'll never go back

I have only been here a few times and tried a few of the vendors but I don't think it's possible to not find what you're looking for here. There's choices ranging from gourmet grilled cheese to middle Eastern cusine to Italian or german and on and on. Hard to rate the establishment as a whole because it respresents so many different foods but I highly recommend trying it out.

I go to the RT for that Amish chicken place. 
The smoked wings are ridiculous.

Reading Terminal Market walks a fine line between being a top 5 tourist destination in Philadelphia, but also still serving as a utility for local Philadelphians looking to grab a bite to eat or maybe even groceries on the way home. With so many specialty food vendors selling everything from specialty meats to donuts to fresh produce, there is something for everyone. 

Reading Terminal Market is an absolute must-have on any "to-do" list for anyone visiting the city. Every time I have had a guest in town, I have made a point to make a stop at RTM.

Love this place! So many food options. One of my favourites is Dutch Eating Place for breakfast - you'll want to get there for 8am otherwise you'll be waiting in line. The whole place gets really busy around peak hours but there's something for everyone. There's limited seating - it's more set up for takeout or grabbing a quick bite to eat

Massive selection of various foods to eat and all pretty low priced.  Its a bit of a weird mix of local market meats and then clearly touristy attractions.  
That said there is just no seating, so I don't suggest really coming here if you have any kids.  Its just not an option to stand when you have a kid or more with you.

Fun food market around center city Philadelphia. If you are a tourist you should definitely stop by. Try the coffee places, walk around the flower vendors, buy honey from the honey man, and try the Pearl Oyster bar for some sit down brunch.

Great place to go, very much like a European Market. Much to see. Much to eat.  

The parking lot across the way in incredibly expensive. $32 for two hours. Search for another parking lot a few blocks away.
I really miss Terminal Market. Been everywhere in the states and nothing comes close to it.

First- Parking- We parked in the 11th & Arch Street- it was $4.00 for 2 hrs of parking with validation from a vendor that you spend you spend $10.00- easy and - ya I almost forgot, but at the last minute when buying blueberries at .99¢ a pint and other fruity/ veggie stuff I remembered. So it was $4.00

We got there about 12:30 pm-- so obviously smack dab at lunch time, but after walking around a bit and doing my shopping, we decided on lunch- because at the rate of shopping I was doing while hungry....I was gonna buy everything.

Reading Market reminds me of a little bit of Pikes Place market (minus the tossing of fish- if you have been to Pikes you know what I am talking about). Reading has plenty of produce stands, fish and meats counters, nuts, soaps, grocery, pantry staples that are hard to find and olive oil stands and the endless options of foods to choose from at lunch rush or for the sweet tooth in all of us, pastries, cakes, cookies and candies. There are gelato vendors, shakes and of course flowers for your home to make it all springy and pretty or just buy a bunch and give to someone you love, just because.

They have an amazing oyster bar if you love oysters, Greek Food, Italian, Middle Eastern, Soul Food, Thai, you can literally choose anything and be happy-happy-happy with it. I personally enjoy the roast pork sandwich,  the pork is tender, flavorful and so juicy the broccoli rabe is bitter-garlicky-spicy goodness with the melty provolone cheese YES!! I ate half and brought the other half home for the MR. (cuz he had to work and couldn't come with us. 

So my purchases were cheese, pate, pastries, candy (of course), fresh veggies, fruit, a huge cow bone cut in half for Kona & Luna at a reasonable $2.50 lb or something like that. Anyway- I loved my visit and shopping time, if I lived in Philly I would literally do all my grocery shopping here.

Wow, Philadelphia's Reading Terminal Market is like Seattle's Pike Place or Los Angeles' Grand Central Market. Not only is it filled with tons of vendors with delicious food, it's a treat for your eyes!

Definitely come hungry so you can try out all the different foods. So many varieties - Chinese, hamburgers, meats, beers, and more. Since we ate already, we were only able to get some donuts and try some ice cream. Definitely get some donuts from Beiler's Bakery as that is one of the most popular vendors... as proven by the long line!

I find that whenever I come into this place I get what I need as well as a bunch of things I didn't know I wanted :). I decided to stop in for lunch and today's pick was MeltKraft (grilled cheese awesomeness), and Iovine produce. 
I do hope one day the Reading Terminal gets a map but I can't think of anyplace else is rather get lost in.

The Redding Terminal rules. It's best to go outside of the 12-1 hour if you don't like crowds. The businesses are used to being busy so they're efficient, it just gets packed. 

Sometimes on the last Tuesday of the month, one of the vendors hires a small, green leprechaun to run around and hand out gold coins. When he runs out of gold coins, he gets pissed. His real name is Stuart Lu Jennings, but when he's mad he prefers to be called Harry McBillingsworth. If you don't call him by his preferred name he can react poorly and scare small children. He prefers to hang around dessert food establishment and call people, "his beautiful little Irish potatoes". He's strange.

I have lived in Philly my whole life and I regret never going here sooner. There's so much going on, so many stores, and it feels like a little town that's filled with so much life. I'd recommend it very much to those new and old to Philly because being there is a real experience. My only warning is if you have high anxiety like me just be forewarned it can be very overwhelming.

This place is easily one of the wonder's of the east coast.

From food to goods, to skin and hair care, the market yields natural care inside and out of all kinds. My personal favorite of the market, is food of course, but the legendary roast pork sandwich, to the rib sandwich I swear my father and law drove down for. We even had our fair share of garlic bacon we had the opportunity to taste many times before walking away with a whole pound of it and an amish butter.

This place overall is amazing, and we need more places like it EVERYWHERE!
One of my favorite place to shop! Another place to get fresh variety of foods! And they have everything Your heart desires!!
So much variety and a must see when you are in Philly. Be careful if you are short on time around lunch because it's very busy then, but they have the lunch crowd down to a fine science
Nothing to say but I go once a month. It is fun, delicious and, reasonable don't deny yourself the experience if you are close to it.
This is my favorite place me and my 8 yrs old son was taken pictures we ate and played all night well from 12to 4 best day ever

Crazy fun place to go again and again while you are in Philadelphia. Great breakfast, lunch and dinner options. Go where the lines are-that's where the best stuff is! Fresh baked goods, cheese, chocolate and flowers...it's all there. Oh, and ice cream.
You can find everything under the sun here. It's a wonderful place full of great places to eat, fresh produce, fish and meat. Specialty shops, and anything else you can imagine. Love!

I can only base this review on the cannoli I ate from Termini  Brothers. It was everything I hoped, for filled right before eating. Super crunchy shell and sweet and creamy on the inside. Don't forget to get a number just like a deli counter.

Literally something for everyone. If you can't find something here... then I don't even know who you are. 

I was attending an event at the convention center, located adjacent to the Reading Terminal Market, and found myself visiting RTM multiple times per day. And why wouldn't you? You can get hot food, cold food, sandwiches, pizza slices, stromboli, produce, fresh meat, dried fruit and nuts, grilled cheese, baked goods, coffee, smoothies -- the list goes on and on and on. Before coming to Philadelphia, someone told me, "The Market is what lots of cities think they have -- but in reality is 10x better." I didn't know what he meant then but totally get it now.

The only downside is the limited amount of seating. Not that you should compromise the variety and assortment of vendors just for seating -- but it seems easier to grab takeout than to try and find a table here, especially if you're with a group. 

So far my favorite items/spots have been the grilled cheese at Valley Shepherd Creamery & Meltkraft and the chocolate chip walnut cookies at Famous 4th St Cookie Company. I'm planning to go back for a Beiler's donut before I leave.

Pro tip: Some vendors are cash only, so plan accordingly!
Lots of cool food and shops to explore. Super crowded on the weekends though. Definitely try out the Philly cheesesteak and cheese fries when in Philadelphia!

Great variety of food. 
Must visit for first time Philly fans!
Canolis are great!
Try Asian food too!

Nice place with a whole bunch of eateries and restaurants to choose from. It was actually my first time here and it's a bit overwhelming as I didn't know which or what to choose from but it did have a lot of options. The place is crowded as massive amount of tourists and Philadelphians combined meet in this massive market.

Only complaint I had it that it was difficult to find anything that was in the healthier side and which they were more or if any option to get either a salad or wrap at the least. I know this isn't the place to look for when wanting to eat healthy but at least give me that option. Anyway I still recommend in coming here. I had a po' boy with blackened chicken which was pretty good.

Oh my, this is heaven on earth right here, I dont know if words can even describe. You to experience everything here personally, especially beck's Cajun, the gator gumbo is to die for. I'm starving for this place writing this oh my.

One of my favorite solo activities is to wander around Reading Terminal for an hour or 2. I grab a to-go beer from Molly Malloy's and then just ROAM. My favorite spots are Little Thai market and Hunger Burger. Also Martin's quality meats really hook it up and the Dutch beef jerky spot. Great spot for people watching and introspection while being surrounded by all sorts of characters.

Reading Terminal Market is a must-see in Philly, though I found myself a bit overwhelmed by crowds and options on a weekend afternoon. I like that there are a lot of grocery vendors, like seafood, produce, and tea, and not just food stalls. The offerings lean classic and fast food-y rather than super millennial or artisanal.

Lines for Philly cheese steaks are long but move quick; I don't think this is the place to try it unless you're on a speed-tour like I was, as I thought it was pretty average and the experience getting it was stressful. The donut place is a cool stop to see them making different pastries, though I thought the one we had was meh. An unexpected highlight was the infused olive oil and vinegar spot-- you have to try everything.

I do appreciate that prices aren't overly inflated, but for me the crowds just made this too hectic. We really had to fight for seats, like looking around at multiple locations for over ten minutes. Try to hit it on a weekday if possible.

With so many choices and so many varieties, how does a person just pick one? I explored Reading Terminal Market for hours and love this type of setting, where I can get small snacks and meals from a bunch of different places and wander for hours checking out various stalls and what they offer. This is a must go in Philly, especially for out of towners. I have to say, I'm glad I don't live too close or I could definitely see my packing on major pounds from this market alone. Excellent concept and place!

As an actual Philadelphian, I try to avoid Reading Terminal because it is SO crowded and touristy.  However, whenever I have a conference at the convention center or jury duty or am just in Center City, I'm drawn to this mecca of amazing local food.  My personal favorite is the creperie and Greek food.  I was on a 13 day jury trial, and I alternated between those two each day.  I also love the Iovine Produce place.  During my first six months in Philly, I didn't have a car.  I lived near Whole Foods and would often go there with a backpack and two reusable grocery bags, but it was expensive.  I started going once a week on the subway to pick up my fresh produce.  The quality was evident and the price was great.  The market also has a great bar with a good beer selection.  I used to really dig the winery but now find the wines too sweet.  There are also some great speciality shops, including one next to the wine tasting shop that sells Philly/PA gifts.  My parents beeline there every time they visit.  If this place keeps drawing in a local, clearly it is worth a tourist seeing!

It's really hard to complain about Reading Terminal. There are so many options for us foodies. I say try and get there early as it gets crowded as the day goes on. The best spots are The Thai Kitchen and Terminy cookies (in my opinion). But I've heard the pork roast sandwich is yummy. Sometimes they have live music playing and I love the community feel of the eating areas. A must try for anyone visiting Philly.

I almost hesitated to write a review about the Reading Terminal Market because there are just so many written already, and what else can be said.  But when I have told people in my area of New Jersey about it, most don't know how good it is.  So, I feel it is my duty, in a way, to get the word out.

The selection of food items is really one of the very best of any market in our country.  They have so many things that you just can't get outside of PA, such as Amish cheeses made from unpasteurized dairy.

The two negatives are that there really isn't a convenient parking lot because it is located right in the middle of Center City.  That makes it harder to buy a lot of products because you can't just wheel your cart out to your car.  The crowds can also be intimidating.

Still, this market deserves 5 stars because the selection and the overall experience are rare and hard to find anywhere else.
I love it hear so many to choose from alligator gumbo to sweets and delicious Amish breakfast

Reading terminal has always been a cool place to visit when in old city philadelphia. There's so many food places to choose from while inside. This place can get very crowed and it's easy to get lost in here. If you do come to philly, definitely check it out.
Great food and so many options!  Great crowds too, though.  Otherwise it would be a 5 star.  Try Hershel's Deli for the absolute best pastrami and corned beef!!!!
A must in Philadelphia.  Make sure to take some time and stop in here for lunch.  Many different options.  Enjoy a cheese steak!
Everything and anything. Satisfy your every craving but be ready to sacrifice your time, sanity and life to this place. Worse than time square on a hot summer day kinda crowded!
This place is not for a person that doesn't like crowds. It's packed, fun and all Philly. I love the freshness of the food and all the choices.

I love bazaars like this, but this because of some reason seem more chaotic then fun weather you are trying to shop or eat. I have been several times but there have never been a time where there is less of a crowd. I must also say that they have great finds here, but you kindda need to know where to go and how to navigate without getting into the crowd which is difficult.I also want to say that I usually love the crowd, but this crowd I don't know.

Authentic cuisine from all over the world!
This is one of my favorite spots in Philly.

A must see when coming to Philadelphia! There are so many places to choose from to eat that it can be overwhelming. They have a lot of stores that sell fresh foods and meats. It can be busy and a bit crowded on the weekends. The food is reasonably priced. You won't go wrong by visiting this place. I'll be back on my next trip.

When I worked as a travel nurse in 
Wilmington, DE a few years ago, I loved going into Philly to eat. The Reading Terminal Market is a DO NOT MISS for any foodie in City of Brotherly Love. Amazing choice of cuisines, and the caliber of the food is nothing short of amazing. .
Tiny bit small, horribly crowded, and not the cleanest. But it's a real, living market, not some showcase. Philly, this is your gem. Keep loving it to death.

Fun to come on a day when the weather sucks and you need some excitement. Food is everywhere in this place, which would make anyone happy. Fresh fish, fresh meat, and many gift shops in between. This place is like a mini indoor flea market. You'd enjoy it!
Such a cool experience. Put this on your list whenever you visit Philadelphia. So many places to eat it will overwhelm you.
A tourist must see! Such a cool place to visit when coming to Philly. Come hungry and ready!

I was in town for an event at the convention center and ate at Reading Terminal Market for almost every meal. The two meals I had elsewhere were mediocre and just reminded me how much I enjoy the food at the market. You have just about any type of cuisine you can imagine available to you in a very compact space. If I have any complaint at all, it is that the crowds make the place almost unmanageable at meal times. Still, though, it is worth it. Try Spataro's for a cheesesteak, Dinic's for the roast pork, or Bieler's for a donut. Even the hot-dogs at Miller's Twist were amazing. The only place I had that was below my every-rising expectations was Nanee's Indian Palace. The naan there had been sitting around in the hot box all day and was delivered to me stiff as a brick. I even saw the owner check it for softness before he gave it to me, so he knows it is a problem and he gave it to me anyway. But, I digress. Go to the market and pick a place at random. You will probably get a great meal.

ALWAYS something to get here. Great place to take someone when you can't decide on what to eat in Philly because of everything they offer. Usually pretty crowded and difficult to find somewhere to sit and eat, but everything is worth it.

My all time place to go when I'm in center city . Reading Terminal have a variety of foods to choose from and also they have fresh fruits, vegetables, flowers and other scrumptious things you can't help to buy when you are at the Terminal !
Great place to go and grab lunch or baked goods, must try the Amish pretzel it's so good!!!

Visiting Philly for the first time, I was brought to the Reading Terminal marketplace. I was blown away! There's so much going on! In a good way. It felt like a busy outdoor food market, but inside! 

First things I immediately noticed were the variety of vegan options from many of the different vendors. I had some great vegan muffins, cookies, and treats. Very easy to get some much needed coffee. There was something for everyone.

I saw that they had a Filipino market event the weekend before. Too bad I missed it, but it's cool to see they host cultural events like that. I would guess it's a regular type of thing.

Definitely a must see if visiting from out of town. This place is on the top things to do in Philly and now I know why.
The Reading Terminal Market is my absolute favorite place to shop! They have a wide variety of items and the food is to die for!

I've only visited Philadelphia once but I could happily spend all day at Reading Terminal Market. I love Dutch Eating Place for their counter breakfast. But there are amazing stalls all over, from bakeries and cake stalls to butchers and wine bars.

I love this place. We found it was within walking distance of our hotel and didn't know what to expect until we ventured into it. It really feels like an old historic city inside complete with street names.

You won't have any trouble finding food here for just about every taste.

What don't they have here?! Food galore, cooked and uncooked. I came here on a Saturday and we got parking for $4 at the Hilton Garden Inn parking deck, you have to spend at least $10 total at the Reading Terminal and one of the cashiers will validate your parking ticket... otherwise expect to pay at least $6 every 30 min..  There's a doughnut place here they make the doughnuts by hand daily.. line can get rather long on the weekend... I had one of the doughnuts it was okay... We also went to this Grilled cheese place they make the cheese by hand and some they store in a cave for a year! (Off site, of course) Enjoy, this place was epic!
The food was awesome at tootsies but unfortunately it was so crowded I could barely move through the crowd and I couldn't try food from anywhere else

Really close to my area, a good enough drive to almost feel like a trip. Easy location. There are tons of places to eat, there are produce stands, pretzels, sweets and treats, delis. You could easily spend quite some time here. Cheap affordable. We really like the gyros and the Cajun place there!

A great food market both for eating and shopping. For eating, I suggest you walk around once to scope out your choices. Then with food in hand go towards the back to eat for a more comfortable experience.

Amazing spot to get a meal with a group of divergent eaters because I'm pretty sure they actually have every style of food here. I had Thai, Indian, Mexican and seafood on varying days during my week long conference stay. Prices are super reasonable. I would recommend going to at kindergarten lunch time or senior special dinner times because it gets absolutely packed at peak hours and it would be tough to navigate if you don't know where you're headed.
Lots to choose from. Favorites include coffee & cannoli from termini bros & any gyro from olympia gyro!

Came to reading terminal on my visit to Philly. This place was really big and I liked how much food options they had, but it was way too over crowded. You could barely find seats here. There were options from asian to southern to indian. My girlfriend and I got the gumbo, the gumbo was actually really good. We only got one to share to try it at first and we wanted to go get it for the second time but the line grew to about 45 minutes. We ended up trying this indian food spot, but it wasn't as good. Apparently they have really good donuts here but never got a chance to try it.

I come to Philly about once or twice a year just to get away from NYC. Philly has really good food and this place is a big highlight too. Reading Terminal is really fun to explore at if youre in the area. I came here a few times with friends and its typiclaly really packed. It's basically a giagantic food court with different cultures of food everywhere. I loved the gumbo they had at the gumbo vendor. At first me and my boyfriend got one to share but after we finished our first we wanted another but the line was like another 45 minute so we just got Indian food at a stand instead. The indian food there wasn't as good as the places I regularly eat at. I also got a fruit juice. It was super fresh and tasted refreshing. They also have a donut and cheese vendor.

I love market places such as this one, as there aren't many in the states. Definitely worth checking out but be aware that this place is always packed and busy. We went Saturday morning and you're basically shoulder to shoulder with people the entire time. There is very limited seating so expect to order food and eat later or eat while you walk around. Many long lines for all restaurants, so settle on the one you think is worth it. I love that there is produce and other grocery items here as well. 

There's an Amish pickle stand located near the center. They let you sample items and sell pickles individually or by quart (I think). There's also a cute candy store and I was able to buy just watermelon gummy bears. They "don't take card for less than $5," which in fact violates their credit card agreement but WHATEVER. 

This place is located across from the convenient center and it was quite easy to Uber there, since we didn't have to worry about parking. Although this place is pronounced "Redding" and not "reading" so that might be a distinction needed if you cab it.

When I travel to any city in the world, going to the local market or a festive market is always at the top of my list. It's the place to go in Philly. Make sure you make your way through the maze of vendors before deciding on your samplings of the day. For those who seek out the famous names, head to Dinic's for their pork sandwich (choose this over a cheesesteak any day) and grab an assortment of $1 Beiler donuts. From Dutch Eating Place, Hershel's East Side Jewish Deli to Nanee's Indian Kitchen there is something for everyone.
Hands down, the best spot to go while in Philly! The food is incredible and the shops are fun!
love this place! there is so much food variety here. It is my go-to spot on Fridays after class. I highly recommend going to beilers and east-hershel (order the pastrami)

A great selection of good eats! I love the Creole restaurant. I was pleasantly surprised at how well seasoned the food was. This place has everything from healthy juices to cupcakes and banana pudding.

This is such an amazing place. I was so overwhelmed but in a good way. Im a huge foodie and wanted to try every place in the terminal. Its a total day of fun for sure. Great eats!!! Its a must try when in Philly

Perfect place for tourists and locals. Affordable produce, specialty bakeries such as Terminini's, Cheesesteak, chocolate, meat, fish, diner, and  the amazing donuts. This review is for the Riehl's deli. Very friendly staff you can try it first. They have cheese too. You have to take a number. Accept card payment.

Tons to choose from! Lines are crazy so don't go there starving because you will have to wait but definitely bring your appetite. Stop and get a map so you can navigate easier through the shops. Bathrooms are clean.

Absolutely love reading terminal, absolutely hate the crowds. If your visiting don't go on the weekend if you can avoid it, it's way better off weekend and not during peak lunch time. An incredible amount of food vendors serving up some of the best food philly has to offer.
Has everything you want in food. All varieties, quick, and the price is not expensive.
Favorite stop in Philly for fresh vegetables and any variety of food. Would recommend one of the many deli counters.

Incredible mix of cultures and food.  We loved the fresh produce, flowers, eating places, and the atmosphere.  It was amazing everything that we got to see the food was delicious the Greek stand was amazing the selection of cheeses was incredible
Great food, too crowded at times but if that does not bother you,The grill cheese place towards the back is the best!
I'm vegan.  There's like 3 things to eat there.  It's OK if you are starving, but mostly a GAG-FEST if you don't want to eat body parts of excretions.

A have-to-go place in Philadelphia. They have all kinds of food and I personally really love the Dutch breakfast and donuts . It is always crowded and you may need to wait in line for a long time sometimes.

We loved this place. We visited two days in a row. 
We had coffees, breakfast and a lunch. 

Everything is set up so well, clean and everyone was very friendly. 

One of, maybe the best food market I've been to in the world that has plentiful of seating, food and easy to walk around, especially with a pram. 

A must visit when in Phili.

Has a little bit of everything -- go wild and try it all!!!

You really can not go wrong with a lot of the places. The only con is that it does get very crowded and thus seating may be a little hard to come by. 

If you are visiting the city - this is a MUST visit
Loved it. Lots and lots of great food! Something for everyone. Make sure you get your parking validated so that it's only $5 for 90 minutes.

Love this market! This is a popular destination for both locals and tourists alike and with good reason - there is a abundance of culinary options from Peking Duck, ice cream, burgers, soul food and of course cheese steaks. I enjoyed meals from By George (cheese steak with grilled onions and American cheese), Hunger burger (single cheese burger with a side of scalloped potatoes), and from Hershel's (Reuben sandwich on rye with a knish). Dessert highlights are 4th street cookies which does a chocolate chip dipped in chocolate and serves coffee for $1 and Beiler's Sweet as Fudge where you can get donuts for $1.15! Come hungry and leave satisfied!

If you're a foodie, you will absolutely fall in love with this place.  Come here for a stroll - as quick as 15 minutes or as long as a couple hours.  This place is food heaven with a little bit of every cuisine (American, Thai, Greek, Mexican, etc.), butchers, cheeses, seafood, Dutch Goods, homemade goods, and much more!

We came here on a Saturday morning and loved the hustle and bustle of it all (tourists and locals).  A good amount of the prepared food stands were still not open and prepping for the day.  I didn't check out the pricing for a lot of the food stands, but I'm going to say its not going to be the complete cheapest place to buy stuff, but it also won't be the most expensive.  

*Restrooms, ATMs & seating available.
*If you have little ones, the stroller will be ok, but a tight squeeze in some areas.

I feel bad, I really do, giving an average rating just because of how crowded it is. It means it must be popular! Still, it was crowded to the point of frustration.

The lines seemed to stretch forever. And even when you got food (or if), there was barely any room to sit down and eat. The place overall felt dirty and shabby. I expected something like I saw at Chelsea Market in New York, but this was disappointing.

I did find a nice lotion/soap stall that sold me a chai spiced chapstick though :)
I absolutely love Reading Terminal. They have everything for your needs whether it's grocery shopping, a bite to eat, having dessert or looking for something unique.
Love it! Soooo many options! We had great turkey sandwiches and gyros! Cookies and donuts are delicious

The Best must visit food stops in Philly. I won't say every vendor is top notch but if you browse enough you'll find the best vendors. A little something for everyone. I go every time I visit definitely a scene: Oysters, Cheesesteaks, cheese, jerky, corn dogs, Cajun, lobsters, butchers, a BAR!

Love everything that this place has to offer, from inexpensive produce to many different types of eateries and finally you get to top it off with many different dessert options! 

This place is always packed on the weekends, so I try to avoid it, because its just overcrowded. I definitely recommend this place for tourists, as its one of my main shopping location!

My favorite place to go grab a good sandwich before I walk around the city. Always a huge crowd but I love going there. I'm a Philadelphian now so it's even better to go for a walk and go there as well.

Amazing place!!! Almost as good as Seattle's pike marketplace. I love all the food I've tried at the market. The place is very clean for a farmers market and smells fantastic! If only I had a bigger stomach, would love to try everything! My favorite was actually the freshly made donuts which came in tons of interesting flavors (including matcha cream and bacon).
Best pastrami sandwich ever at Herschel's Deli.  Headed straight from the airport to the deli to have the hot pastrami sandwich....yum!

This review is for Wursthaus Schmitz. You can get German sausage, potato salad,  cucumber salad, spatzle, red cabbage which is awesome, sauerkraut (regular or with bacon). All of them are very authentic and can satisfy your craving for real German food. It sell imported German candies such as Kinder. At Christmas time they sell stolen, ginger bread cookies from Germany. They have shelves filled with German grocery items. Don't forget to stop by here when you are at Reading.
Amazing place and amazing food.  Really cool environment that the entire family can enjoy.  I would highly recommend!!!

This place doesn't really need any more 5 star reviews but I love the place so here goes another one.  If you're visiting Philadelphia and you love to eat food then you have to visit.  Huge place filled with every type of food imaginable with a large amount of Amish restaurants and shops featuring the best that PA has to offer!  Tons of amazing cheese shops, fresh produce, bakeries everywhere, fresh pretzels, Philly cheesesteaks, fresh meats, the list goes on and on!  Open 7 days but Sundays the Amish businesses are closed so about 30% of the place isn't open that day.  Give yourself amble time to browse as the amount of places to choose from is staggering.  A must stop on any trip to Philadelphia.  Enjoy!!
Almost too many incredible choices. Minus one for the absolute mad house that it always is. If you're visiting Philly and don't mind crowded places, this is a must-go.

There is definitely something for everyone and for every meal here. It is busy and some of the lines are long, but that just tells you how great all of the food is. Two of my favorite staples are DiNic's, Miller's Twist pretzels, and Termini Brothers Bakery. All delicious and reasonably priced! I love coming here whenever I come into Philly and it's a great place to explore and try out different foods!

I love Reading Terminal market because there are so many options in one place. It's a great convenience for me and I enjoy everything I ever purchased from the multiple shops and stores. Certain hours are better to go than others.

This place is great! So much variety! The only bad thing is that the tables aren't cleaned after every use. Some places offer seating but many don't. Hershel's was a big hit for us. The pastrami panini was meat filled, moist and delicious! Doughnuts at the terminal are so fresh and scrumptious. Forget the name of the place but it's right by one of the entrances and directly across from a bbq spot, which we've tried too and it was good. Only bad place I've tried there out of the 50 they have was sung kee's duck lo mien. The guy didn't use gloves when serving and cutting up my duck with his hands. The duck was cold too and lo mien warm so it wasn't great. I'm pretty sure I got sick from it too

One of the greatest indoor markets in the USA. It's truly hard to find a place that could even come close to the reading terminal market. The food is delicious and the store owners are friendly and knowledgeable on their products. I recommend you try everything you can't go wrong on anything here.

Just an awesome place. Definitely recommend this place when you come to Philly. Place closes at 6pm so get there early. Lots of sweets, fresh meat, great spot for lunch and drinks. The terminal itself is a great part of history.
Whatever it is your looking for, odds are you can find it here. Food, groceries and gifts. It's all here and all great quality.
Awesome place for special treats that you won't find around town in addition to favorite Philadelphia fare

Reading Terminal Market is a fantastic location for if you're a foodie! There are many options of places to eat at, all of which serve food fresh and ready to order. The snack stores inside of the Market serve snacks that are made by hand on location. While there are often crowds, this is a good thing. The crowds are explained by the amazing food in every corner of the market. It's totally worth the trip!

I absolutely love Reading. You will never ever be disappointed in your visit. Granted, weekends can be quite crowded and hectic, but it is a fun time to people watch. 

The best part is, there is something for everybody, every time you visit. Food, flowers, ice cream, chocolate, baked goods, smoothies, shopping...you name it, and it's probably at Reading.  I've tried quite a few places inside, but two I need to highlight. First, (I'm sorry but I don't know the name of it) the place right across from Bassett's ice cream is a little food place that has phenomenal smoothies. It isn't a generic smoothie that you get from a frozen packet or machine. Nope, real, tasty pure fresh fruit smooth. So good. Second. Beiler's bakery. Woah. I don't even like donuts. This place has thee best donuts and much much more. I recommend the blueberry fritter. No joke they are probably the size of my head and are only $1. More importantly they are beyond addicting. They practically melt in your mouth. 

I love you Reading but you sure can ruin a girl's healthy eating kick.
So many places to eat and so much shopping to do!  We popped in to escape the rain and ended up staying for most of the day. If you're in the Philly area I recommend stopping by!

I love everything about this market but wanted to give a shout out to the Pennsylvania General Store. They have THE BEST cookies in the entire place. Not that flying monkey crap stand or the one at the main entrance which sells the black and white cookies (which are decent).  Do yourself a favor and get cookies from this stand. You'll thank me.

What's not to love?

It doesn't matter what you eat, they have it.

Carnivore, omnivore, vegetarian, vegan. They have something for you.

Indian, Mexican, Middle Eastern, Chinese. You are covered.

It almost feels like you are in another country. Or several other countries at once.

And there's more there than just lunch. Used books. Spices. Crafts. 

But it's mostly about the food. Mmmmm.

The Reading Terminal Market is like an indoor flea market of food...forget food halls...this place is huge.  You can find fresh meat and seafood as well as hot meals and packaged specialty items.  Unfortunately it was very crowded on an early Friday afternoon...but it opens at 8 a.m. on Saturday.

Just stay here for a three course meal with lots of options! Crepes, sandwiches, cheesesteaks, chocolates, donuts, ice cream, cupcakes and more! 

Parking is validated and lots of seating around.

Stay away if there is a huge convention because it will be too congested.
Sooo much variety of great food it's amazing! Donuts, bakery, bbq ribs, Indian, Chinese, gyros, amazing ice cream! It's never ending deliciousness...left in a food como...lol
This is a Philadelphia staple. If crowds stress you, wait until non-peak hours. The market is a sea of humanity and good food. Prepare for sensory overload.
Had pulled pork, ribs, amish sticky buns, molly beer!! There is so much to have that you can have a brain burst with so many flavors and food to choose!! A definite place to go!!

Such a cool place with so many options. Could definitely walk around for a couple hours and not get bored or even see the same thing twice. Overwhelming for me as an introvert but if you try to think of what type of food you want to eat before going it'll make the experience much easier and better
