I love RTM!! I love that there are so many choices and that there are plentiful seating areas. But if you plan on going during lunch hours, be prepared to have a crowded experience and some difficulty finding seats. But really, I think that is a testament to how great RTM is!

Huge market! Honestly the biggest I've seen compared to some in LA and Toronto I've been to this one beats them all. Lots of all sorts of options to choose from and each of them are equally tasty.  I had a full meal for only 7 dollars so honestly you can find some great food at a low price or you could go for other pricer options but definitely tons to choose from.

Something for everyone!  Fantastic place to eat and buy food to take away.  From home style goods to food for all tastes.  We stayed close by during our visit to Philly and ended up at the market multiple times for food and snacks.  Loved this place!
Love this place. Came with a large group and everyone was able to find something they wanted. Service is quick even during busy periods.

I love this place for all the amazing stuff to eat, but also for the incredible diversity. All classes, so many ethnicities...in terms of customers and businesses. So many new things to see/eat -- maybe a different version of an old favorite, or something totally new. Spent many hours there, but also have stopped in and been able to get out pretty quickly. Yum!

This place is food heaven!  So many choices to choose from...chicken, fish, beef, pork, veggies, etc. 

They also have other shopping available..clothes, accessories, jewelry, etc!   

If you have a hard time making up your mind...this may not be the place for you! 

Great place to grab lunch or hangout with friends and not have to get the same thing.

A must see if you're in the Philadelphia area! It's a large indoor market with limited seating. It is usually crowded due to its popularity. There is a variety of locals vendors from meats, crepes to ice cream and pretzels. I love the market style and you can pick up a few grocery items when you're there as well. There are often Amish based restaurants coming all the way from Lancaster with the most amazing homemade goods. There is definitely something for everyone here. I would recommend going for lunch or a snack!

Sure, this place is fun to walk through.  But the tourists who think this is a key food place to visit in Philly are seriously missing out.  Philly is a foodie paradise with INCREDIBLE restaurants!  Venture to 13th Street to try Lolita, Barbuzzo, or Jamonera, and to see all the gorgeous little shops on the street, including the artisanal chocolates made fresh at Verde; or go to Bareburger, Bluestone Lane, PS & Co, Buena Onda Tacos, V Street, Dizengoff, etc., for casual but DELICIOUS fresh food. Go to Cafe Karma (four locations) and sit in the beautiful gardens at their locations on 22nd/Pine or 10th/Pine.  Go to Whole Foods Center City and check out the delicious food hall!  For high-end restaurants, go to Talula's Garden, Zahav, Vedge, Res Ipsa, Suraya, and more!  To explore food heaven in West Philly, go to Kilimandjaro or Manakeesh restaurants, or try Chez Yasmine food truck.  For Vietnamese, go to Nam Phong or Vietnam Restaurant on Washington.  For pizza, go to Mama Palma's, Stella's, or Giorgio's on Pine.  Go to the fabulous Saturday Farmer's Market at Rittenhouse Square or the equally fabulous Sunday Farmer's Market at Headhouse Square. In South Philly, go to any of the treasures on Passyunk Avenue or to Stargazy for British pies. You get the idea...
This is a well-known treasure but a treasure nonetheless. I enjoyed this a lot better than Chelsea market. Such a variety of food. Prices are totally reasonable, which I did not expect.

Live everything about this place. A couple of places to not miss are Olympia gyro, beilers pickle patch, becks Cajun kitchen, Miller's twist, and fourth street cookie just to name a few of my favorites. The vibe is super crazy but totally something to see!

Stopped in here one morning while I was in Philly. If there's one thing I love it's food halls and markets like this. There's such a conglomeration of delicious food sights and smells and although it can be overwhelming to make a decision, you're almost never going to regret it. 

My theory still held true here when we stopped at The Fox & Son booth to order lamb fries. Not only were these visually appealing but the taste was beyond description. The best way to put it would be "explosion of flavor". They were just amazing. The lamb, the cucumber, tomatoes, feta, dressing - it all married perfectly. 

There were several other booths to stop at but we were short on time. 

My boyfriend and a friend of his went back a few weeks after and stopped at the donut place (when we were the line was incredibly long) and brought some back so I can attest that the long line is worth the wait. They were light, but dense and flavor packed. 

This place is an absolute must!
First time visiting from New York and it was good. Very crowded and noisy but lots of food for whatever your in the mood for.
Everything you want is here! I've been to similar places in other states, but none do it as well as the RTM. The lines can get crazy, so definitely go during off times.
So many great places, from seafood and steaks to desserts, you gotta go! Dinic's roast pork, beef and brisket is not to be missed!

So many choices!  All excellent.  If you're in the mood for baked goods, you have to go to Beiler's - they have the absolute best fritters and donuts and all kinds of wonderful, delicious baked goods.  THE BEST!

Paradise for foodies. Everything literally everything we had a bite of food from here is delicious and the taste and memories of those still linger on my mind. Will be visiting again when I'm in philly.

We had our wedding 3 weeks ago here at the market and it could not have gone better. We worked with the team at All About Events, who were not only professional, competent, efficient, and organized - but their care for us as bride and groom was evident every step of the way. We felt they were as invested in our wedding being amazing as we were. Everything they orchestrated in the months leading up to our wedding went off without a hitch. 

We wanted a wedding where we could have different kinds of food (instead of just your typical wedding food) - and we got exactly what we wanted, with Philadelphia charm and style to spare! The atmosphere at Reading Terminal Market is energetic, but classy. We sprung for the market string lights and with the vendor signs and decor already in the market, it provided the perfect ambiance. There was plenty of space for a dance floor and Molly Malloy's did a fantastic job with the drink service. We were so in love with the whole evening. Would DEFINITELY recommend this as a unique and flexible wedding spot (we had 250 guests and they can accommodate even more than that!)

We would absolutely recommend events at Reading Terminal Market!

SIDE NOTE: Coming here for lunch, produce, meat, sweets and other food is absolutely recommended TOO!! It is a Philly institution and one of the best places to experience the food the city has to offer in an energetic, affordable and fun setting.

I went here first as a part of the Philadelphia gourmet food tour. The donuts here are the best I've ever had. It's such a unique place where you can walk around and try different food. My favorite savory food was these cheese curds I had. This place is not something you would expect in the city. This is must go place for any tourist or Philadelphia residents

Reading Terminal Market is both a great place to get lunch and a historic tourist attraction in the heart of Philadelphia. There's dozens of places to eat and many are truly amazing. My recommendations are the pork sandwich at Tommy Dinic's with ice-cream at Bassetts for dessert - but it's hard to go wrong anywhere here. Seating is limited, but you can generally get a table if you keep your eyes open. Discounted parking is available nearby - check the website.

Ok, so if you are in Philly you have to stop here. Not only do they validate your parking pass for across the street (brings the price down to about $5), you have so many options to chose from it hurts. I can never make up my mind. They have the best donut place as soon as you walk in over to the left, there is always a line you can't miss it! There are various seating areas, but I suggest you take a quick (as quick as you can with so many options), scan what you think you may want and have someone or multiple people you are with wait at an empty table so you have somewhere to eat after you grab your food! A lot of the vendors are Amish therefore if you go on a Sunday most places are closed (and then those that are just closed on Sunday), but there is less of a crowd and still enough options to choose from:
I have nothing bad to say about this place all the food in this place is bangin and the customer service is good. I love the Reading Terminal

I would go back to Philly just to visit the market again. It's an absolute East Coast must-do. I tried Old City Coffee, Meltkraft, Birdies Biscuits, DiNic's meats, Bassett's Ice Cream, Beck's Cajun Cafe, and Loco Lucho's Puerto Rican, plus bought [super affordable and fresh!] grapes at one of the two produce stands and specialty chocolates at the Pennsylvania General Store. Everything was absolutely delicious and the energy is amazing. I cannot wait to go back.
Great selection of a variety of foods. Wish there were some more fusion offerings, but this was incredible!
Great place if you are in Philly!  Great way to sample local food from many different vendors.

600th review!

I have experienced food markets before in Baltimore and DC, but boy is Reading Terminal Market is on a whole other level.  I would describe it as a cross between a food court, a carnival, and Grand Central Station. Given the many options and people watching opportunities, I can see why it's an iconic Philly attraction that everybody talks about. Come for the food, brave the crowds, and have fun exploring!

There is literally every type of food here you could ever want. Cheesesteaks, baked goods, deli sandwiches, Chinese, Pakistani food, Indian Food, fresh ground coffee, grilled cheese, pizza, Mexican food..you name it this place has it! There are also places for fresh produce, cheese and meats. 
It can get very crowded during lunch. So much so that we actually skipped eating here because we would have had no place to sit. If you can, grab something and go somewhere else to eat it if you know your way around. 
The next day we stopped by again before the lunch crowd and had some old city coffee and a donut...oh my goodness it was wonderful. 
What a fun and interesting place to visit. Dont miss it!

Don't know where to start, I'm in love with this market. I'm personally a big fan of markets with all the new and old school vendors and this market is ddefinitely one of my best places in Philly.

During our recent visit to Philly, we came here multiple and tried out a couple of different vendors. We liked how there are so many options to choose from and there is something for everybody. We loved the Cajun Spot(Beck Cajun) and the cookie spot. Overall definitely a must visit spot, and I'll be back very soon.

I love coming here when I am in the area. There are so many food options and you could probably eat here everyday for a whole year and order something different. There is seating inside if you prefer to eat there or you can take your food with you. They have everything from Termini Bros cannolis to the Flying Monkey bakery, Beilers donuts and so much more. It's a great place to try something new as there are so many ethnic food options! It can get extremely crowded around meal times but that's to be expected! This is a cant miss if you are in Philly.

Wow, while in a family visit to Philadelphia we read about the Reading terminal market. As a Cleveland girl I know firsthand how crazy busy and fun these types of food markets can be as we have our own beloved West Side Market. 
The reading market couldn't be more unique. A cross between foodie heaven boutique stands and small food related retail booths. 
While my town market is more of s grocery store experience where most foods are purchased to take home  and prepare. The seating areas at the reading terminal along with the larger proportion of pre made delights are more suggestive of buy and try now.
Which we did with great glee.
We started with breakfast at the Dutch eating place. The bagel sandwiches my family had could have been better had the bagels been toasted but my blueberry pancake breakfast was delicious.
My son preferred his 1. ham egg and cheese pretzel and his 2. Bacon egg and cheese pretzel from millers twist. 
My daughter lived the pickle assortment at Beilers. While we didn't buy any the donut line and boxes being carried out suggest Beilers is also the place to go for crazy good donuts.
Temporary stand offerings of gin and vodka tastings at boardroom liquor and banana pudding tastings at Nina's topped off our treats. 
Can't wait to visit family again next year to return.

Visiting Philadelphia for my family reunion, the Big Bus rolled past Reading Terminal Market and displayed the incredible array of foods. I walked in and was so overwhelmed. I wanted some of everything!  I didn't buy any food because I had just eaten. But I made a note to return on another visit. I would recommend Reading Terminal Market.

RTM is a must do experience while in Philly. Pearl's Oyster Bar is the best brunch in Philly IMO. Famous 4th Street is a must for delicious, warm cookies. Great chocolate choices at Muller's, Termini's, and the PA General Store. Fantastic local choices for groceries in meat, cheese, milk, and sides of any dish you may desire. Old City Coffee is a must as well for a fresh cup or bag of beans to take home. There are also fresh veggie & fruit stands. RTM for the win!

TEN stars if I could!!! GREAT food of ALL kinds! Gets crowded-- are you surprised? Little shops abound within this crowded huge place -- walking into them is like being in another world. Not enough lifetimes to sample all the goodies, but you can try!! Prices are reasonable -- food is GREAT-- ambience is more than enough to revive a tired person. And their "themed" days are also alot of fun.
I love so many of the vendors here. Was in town for 4 days and we ate here at least once a day. Great variety of restaurants. Just wish it was open a bit later!

Tons of choices!  My turkey hoagie with everything was delicious and reasonable. Hubby went with cheesesteak of course, but it was disappointing and dry. Fries were $3.69 and plain even though it said sea salt. Wanted to try funnel cake as it looked delicious, but was trying to be healthy.
Wow! Just walking in and smelling all of the delicious foods is well worth it! They have everything you could possibly be looking for food wise!
We always go to the market when we are in Philadelphia , if you can't get it there you won't find it, I love the the diversity of things and people.

Love Reading Terminal Market!
So much to choose from.
A great spot for folks visiting Philadelphia or Philadelphia residents.

I get it.. it's a busy spot with a whole range of things to catch your eye. I did find however that my experience in there was a bit lackluster. Lunch time is a very very busy thoroughfare so I recommend going a bit before/after to avoid the local traffic.

Awesome place to visit if you have time to browse. A lot to see and can get incredibly crowded. NEVER go peak times (lunch and weekends) because you will not be able to move. VERY touristy so have to deal with tons of looky loos taking selfies and blocking the aisles.

I liked it to be honest but do not for the love of God bring your car into this city. The parking for 1 hour was like $30 almost. Like I understand the location but for the love of everything holy in this universe take uber. Any ways the terminal is great there is a lot of people and shops to go to its amazing but for the most part half of the crap there is mediocre and nothing to special. I like the fudge place that is run by those Amish people. I gained like 20 pounds just by walking into their shop but it is worth it because it tastes great. Although all the tourists are crap and some of the employees can also be rude. Other than that ... mehh 7/10
This is a must see stop for any visitor to Philadelphia! Great food around every corner. Pastries, New Orleans food, Italian, and of course great beef and pork sandwiches!

Love the reading terminal true Philly girl so much to choose from I came here today with intention on getting some pecan Carmel Cookie s from the Pennsylvania bake shop located on arch street side of the market. Best cookies hands down soft and chewy
So much to do! Place is awesome, but super crowded everytime I go. Not easy to find seating if you are in a group of more than 4 people.
Because of the Amish this place is amazing. Great job hard workers! Great food wonderful
Patience needed during peek hours!!  It gets crowded real quick!  Otherwise, a great and diverse selection of food and desserts.
Great place to grab a fast lunch or to entertain out of town guests.  From cheesesteaks and roast pork sandwiches to out-of-this-world donuts and Asian food, the market has it all!

Great food market ! Mix of everything ....

Few things that they need: 

1) more tables - please 
2) a limit to how long one stays at the table 
3) security to regulate crowds 
4) renovation upgrade

Enjoyed walking around and seeing all the different vendors. Don't recommend going
On the weekend but will try to go back doing the week.

Reading Terminal Market is the obvious place to go if you're a tourist to Philly. You've never been to Philly if you haven't gotten a meal here. There are countless places to eat, grab coffee, drink a brew, or just chill and maybe catch a special event. Don't miss out on the Dutch Eating Place for breakfast or Beiler's Bakery for donuts.

Absolutely LOVE this place!!!  I actually get all of my produce here weekly - high quality & great prices.  There's also a ton of different places for getting unique gifts & of course amazing restaurants & bakeries

Place is amazeballs!!!   You can get anything under the sun--all well prepared.  Be sure to hit the cookie stores around closing time for discounted cookies!  

Must visit if in center city!
This is my fav place for fresh fruit and seafood. Everyone is nice. Try the Amish bakery and tbe chivken wings by far tbe best in tbe city
Love bringing friends and family here to show them all of the cool shops, it is very packed tho I wish it was a little bigger.

The only way to get out of here alive is if you go early in the day. It's otherwise crowded and full of tourists and chaos. Be prepared to be elbow to elbow with everyone and to fight off complete strangers to get anywhere.

Yes a must visit! so many options to choose from. It is packed with a lot of visitors and prices are a bit high however it's a nice place to grab food and find a table to have lunch. Good option if your here with a party so everyone can get what they want. 

The tables are cafeteria style and they have disinfectant for you to clean your area. It does get busy so when you find a table take it.

I LOVE the Reading terminal and it's a must that I get there every year before Christmas, but after Thanksgiving. There's such an old world feel with the open markets, great restaurants and one of a kind gifts. A must do if you're in the Philly area.

I was here on a weekday afternoon and it was absolutely packed with people.  Lots of different shops to look at and lots of places to eat.  I can't imagine what it would have been like on a weekend day.  

The only reason why I'm not giving it less than 5 stars is because it's in sore need of places to sit down and eat.  Lots of places to eat but then you have to stand up and eat if you can't find a rare place to sit.
Fun place to wander, something for everyone.  From fruits and veggies to meats and breads, and every sort of cuisine imaginable,  A feast for the senses!

I love anything food hall. Seriously. There are so much options at the Reading Terminal, and honestly it can be overwhelming. Absolutely come HUNGRY, and make sure to have space to buy things to take home. The donut place is inside, as well as anything Amish. Next time I have to save space for the Amish diner, it looked amazing. There is plenty of space to sit. Park at the lot across the street and make sure to get validated to save $ on parking.

Amazing selection of food, you can pick up prepared food, or take it home and cook it. Lots of other items, too, though the variety of food is enough for all in your party to find something they like. Fun to just stroll.

There's something for everyone at Reading Terminal. Cheesesteaks, hoagies, gyros, cookies, pretzels, doughnuts, crepes, bakey items, teas, coffee, fresh cut flowers, Mexican, German, Indian, Halal, Asian, Mediterranean, a juice bar & smoothies, fresh cut meats, oysters, seafood, Amish cheeses & jerkey, hot dogs & corn dogs, fresh fruits and vegetables, wines, chocolate, fudge, ice cream, linens, mushrooms, cajun, pizza, ribs, fresh poultry, herbs, honey, olive oil, books, soap, skincare, and so much more that I know I'm missing. It seems e.n.d.l.e.s.s. 

If you need it, a map (in various languages) is available at one of the entrances to help you navigate your way around. 

I purposely booked my hotel for work near here so that I could easily walk here to get a few bites. My intent is to change it up with each visit and so that I'm always trying something different. 

Location: Its adjacent to Chinatown and about a 10 minute walk from Independence Hall & Liberty Bell 

The only con is that seating can be a challenge. Some food stalls have some seats available and there's some tables outside but my advice is to before the lunch rush (if you can) especially if you have a larger group.
Awesome!!! Whatever you are looking for and whatever food you desire is here!! PERIOD

There are so many options to eat in reading terminal market. I always get confused as to what I want to eat but one thing I am always certain of is the Lancaster juice store. I have dreams about that delicious orange strawberry lemonade. Just know that they aren't open on Sundays.

Wow- must see if visiting Philly. Large farmers market, lots of variety with food vendors. Something for everyone from breakfast, snack, lunch or dinner. If you leave hungry, that is your own doing. Eclectic shops as well.

A must visit when in Philly. You can essentially get any food you're craving. I go pretty often, and the place is almost always jam-packed. Can definitely be overwhelming, but totally worth it. Beiler's donuts is my favorite spot!

Reading Terminal Market is wonderland of food, smells and traditions that reflect the diverse population of Philly. 

You want a cheesesteak? No problem - there's at least 3 places to have one (but maybe consider roast park with broccoli rave and sharp provolone instead). Traditional east coast deli? They've got it. Authentic eats from all comers of the globe including Peking Duck, Thai, Indian, Greek, Puerto Rican and so many more? Most definitely. 

And of course don't forget poles of produce, fresh meats, whole fish, freshly ground spices and to-die-for cheese counters. Add in freshly pressed juices, local coffee and even a tea stand. It's honestly overwhelming and if I had the proverbial three wishes one of them would be to eat here on demand. 

One of the highlights for many people (myself included) are the Amish vendors who serve up the BEST baked goods, home cooked meals and delicious farm fresh offerings. I couldn't resist donuts from Beilers and you shouldn't either! 

I found the vendors to be friendly without exception and happy to suggest what's best from their offering. Take their recommends and try things you can't get at home. 

I've been to a lot of markets both in the US and abroad and Reading ranks up with the very best. It's well worth a visit. My only regret has to do with being a visitor and not being able to take many things home with me!

Lovely place to come for a quick bite to eat, tons of options to choose from. I especially recommend the Puerto Rican food, the tostones are incredible. Also, ice cream! The place is visually really interesting as well, so it's worth even just walking around and taking it all in.
I love this place, it's filled with tiny little stores inside and there's always something for everyone there. I love this place. If you come to Philadelphia this is a place you should visit.
Everyone should enjoy all the different types of food this place has to offer. Even if your out of state or the country stop by for a visit
I love this place! A little bit of everything for everyone, always!! Great environment and I don't mind the crowds either.
Awesome place to visit!  Crepes at Profi's were the best!  We got pizza crepe and a pesto chicken and tomato.  Some many restaurants to pick from!!!

This place is not how I remember it. 

You can't pause for a half of a second without someone banging into you or being irritated with your presence being in their way. I felt like I was completely surrounded by people at all times without being able to take a breath. 

There were lines everywhere. People everywhere. *Questionable* people everywhere. 

I didn't even want to eat anything because the sheer volume of people made me feel like it can't possibly be clean. 

They have produce stands, bakeries, hot and cold food stands, people selling soap, jewelry, etc. You have to really pay attention because some things seem like great deals and others seem like total ripoffs. 

We did return at the very end of the day to get some cookies and it was much calmer and tolerable at that time. If I were to return here, it would definitely be towards the end of the day when the experience is better. If you like the hustle and bustle of crowds up your @$$ you will enjoy it no matter what. If you are not in the mood for crowds or aren't a crowd person at all, you can come in for the experience but you probably won't last long. 

if you've never been here at all and you are visiting Philly, go for the experience at least once. I personally will have to weigh the options before deciding if I want to go in again and I would never make a special trip to go there, that's for sure.
So many options! We were here to eat at Carmen's. However, we wandered the whole place and thoroughly enjoyed ourselves. A must see if you come to Philly!

If I lived anywhere near this place I'd be here all the effin' time.  This is a food lover's paradise!  Any time I visit my folks (who live about 45 minutes away from this market) this is a definite destination for me.  The last time I was here (May 2018), me and The Hubs shared pizza from By George and a pork sandwich from Di Nics.  We also bought Italian sausages from Martin's Quality Meats and pasta salads (again from By George), as well as some amazing-looking asparagus from one of the green grocers to take to my folk's house for dinner the next night.  Oh yea, let's not forget some amazing cannolis from a vendor whose name I didn't record (but I know where you are!).  Oh yes, I will be back...

I love reading Terminal for grocery shopping. Just know you won't find soy milk at any of the vendors. Love buying meat from an actual butcher and Iovines has a great selection of produce. Spices abound at the Head Nut hiding in a back corner. Stop for a beer at Molly Malloy's if the crowds around the Flower Show and Thanksgiving stress you out. Some of the food vendors are meh - like the Indian place that wraps samosas in pie dough. Thai is way too salty. Instead get a sandwich at DiNicks or pretzel wrapped treat at Miller's Twist.

Love love love it here ! 

Cheesesteaks were amazing here but you gotta make sure you go to the right one.  BY GEORGE ! We got way overpriced but delicious chocolate covered strawberries and breakfast at a cute sit down place across from the cheese place. 

For all my foodies, you will love it too!
My wife worked in the city for many years, and we shopped often at this great market and eatery.  Highly recommended!

So, how do you review an entire market!? I'll try.

First off, if you haven't been to similar markets in other cities, let me warn you that much like other ones, this place is packed. People that live here often visit it in addition to out-of-towners.

Unlike markets in other towns, many of the prices can't be beat. Grocery shopping and butchers sell at below market value a good amount of the time so it's hard to avoid going for fresh food. Grab some muffalata or alligator sausage. Also, unlike other markets, it can be hard to walk around at times. I've pushed a stroller through the past couple years without issue (despite my phobias), but unless you're used to all the people, it can be overwhelming.

Nonetheless, the smells and sights are more overwhelming, in a good way. When family comes to visit, they always want to hit Reading Terminal, which should tell you something.

Let it be known first off that is extremely difficult to review an entire market with countless shops and stores, but I will do my best!

Overall, this market is absolutely phenomenal. If you are looking for an experience that is revolutionary and one of Philadelphia's best attractions, than look no further! Inside of this wonderland, you will find plenty of shops that sell perishable items, meats, cheeses, candy, breakfast/lunch/dinner, and many more. One of my favorite things to do is to check out of the different venues that sell cookbooks and foreign spices and herbs to make your own meal.
It's got everything you need and more great place for lunch people watching coffee fresh everything and Amish what a place

I'm not sure how I can rate this entire market, but this place is great and has something for everybody. It's my go-to when someone comes to visit because the possibilities are endless. I come here on my off-days just so I can try out some new restaurants. My personal recommendations are going to DiNic's for a sandwich and then getting dessert at Beiler's Donuts. I always go by Beiler's - they are absolutely delicious and easy on the budget. Be warned though - it gets busy, and the best place to enjoy your food after a well-earned hunt is actually in the back of the market.

An action packed venue with so much to choose from. The pretzels were delicious. Lots of fresh produce, cheeses, meats, seafood to take home and cook. Also a great variety of cuisines to try and explore. Share dishes w others to get the most exposure to the different offerings.

Always a fun food excursion. Very very busy today but it was Saturday and  filled with too many foodie thrill seekers. I ate at Dinics's and ordered the roast pork with rapieni. It was a perfect balance of cheese to meat to bread and i was very happy with this classics sandwich. The place was mobbed and I'd like to go back again when it wasn't so crazy

This is by far the largest most overcrowded market I have been to thus far. I love places like this but on a Saturday morning/early afternoon, it was hard to get through the blobs of people and the endlessly long lines. We had already eaten before coming here-do not make that same mistake! There is something for every taste here and plenty of dessert options too so my advice would be to come hungry! If I was local I would definitely come here to buy all my vegetables, meats, and cheeses! The grilled cheese booth looked particularly interesting as did the number of Pennsylvania Dutch booths in the market. I also noticed a single spot that serves as a bar, which is nice to have so your whole group can get drinks and then choose separately where you want to dine. The only purchase we made here was at Old City Coffee for my husband. They forgot his order so not a great experience. I would definitely return the next time I'm in Philly but I would change one thing: I'd come hungry so I can eat my way through the market as one should!
Amazing... always fun to walk around and get a bite to eat. And if you have family from out of town, obviously a go to spot.

Fucking awesome!!! *drops mic* 
Best place to get everything under the sun and they never disappoint!!
So sick and tired of being touched inappropriately while shopping there! There isn't even security around!

The choices are myriad.  My brother and I wandered down many aisles before I settled on an Indian restaurant and he decided to test the Cajun restaurant (we are both originally from Louisiana).  I found the chicken Marsala to be a bit bland.  As to be expected at a tourist place, I guess. The naan, however, was wonderful.  My brother said the red beans and rice were not Louisiana style but acceptable.  I missed out on Apple dumpling! I went back for that treat and found that the vendor had left for the day. It was around 4, so plan ahead.

If it's food you want, they'll have it.  Seriously, whatever it is, it will be here.  Fresh raw seafood, fresh raw meat, produce, cheesesteaks, bratwursts, greek food, thai food, a pub, an oyster bar, Amish goods, etc etc.  They have one of the best(and oldest) ice cream spots that I have ever been to in Bassett's.  Hell my ladyfriend even found a cart selling vegan tuna salad.  Don't get me started on what exactly that is but she loved it.  I've eaten in here 3 times and everything I ate was great, but.....

...It is always super crowded.  It's hard to find a place to sit and eat your meal.  If you do find a place to sit inside and eat, the table is usually pretty dirty.  You can't sit outside because the large homeless population in Philly hangs out just outside the building so it's hard to enjoy eating while being asked for money with every bite.  Maybe during the weekdays, it's less busy and easier to navigate through the market.  

I have I lived near here, I'd definitely drop in for meals to go or to pick up ingredients to cook at home.  As a tourist, it's definitely worht checking out but try coming during an off period not Saturday at noon.
Love this place. Bassetts ice cream is the best ice cream i'v ever had! Lunch time is crazy busy.

I love this place! I always take the train and get off at Jefferson station right next to it. So many different types of foods to try. Whether you want a cheesesteak at Carmen's or a cannoli at Termini. The donuts at Beilers and pretzels at Millers are amazing too. You can't go wrong here! It's always packed inside even when I went early but it's always worth it!

This place is crazy! I mean there's restaurants and stations of practically anything you want. From meats to desserts to diners to knick knacks, there's literally anything you're looking for. It's such a huge space that we barely made our way through it all. There's people everywhere so make sure you can tolerate crowds. Have patience since it's very cluttered and congested. It's a really cool concept for a market though.

Fantastic market with many vendors inside where anyone can find something for them to enjoy. During lunch hours and the holiday season, this place can get packed, but not enough for me to lower the rating. It is crowded for a reason and a wonderful spot to visit.

Spent a week out in Philly last November and came here for breakfast 3 times. The food is delicious and the crowd isn't too bad but to put that in perspective I'd be one of the first people in there because I'm an early riser I went another time later in the day for a late lunch and it was much more crowded but to me the the food was definitely worth the wait. There are so many options to choose from and I enjoyed it all from the donuts, pretzels, the Amish restaurant, chocolate store, and the sandwiches. If you are in Philly and want to stop some place with a lot of good food options this is it.

The market is so fun! I was in Philadelphia working at a conference and we went to the market for lunches and sometimes to pick up a snack or dinner on the way back to the hotel. Crazy busy and crowded, but huge variety. Everything I tried was delish.
Great place here a good bang for your buck I love getting simple things like lunch meat and Wings/burgers from here !!
Oh my goodness, who doesn't love Reading Terminal Market? This place is fantastic. All the food vendors you could possibly ever ask for.
Crazy environment with crazy good finds. Worth the chaos.
Great place for produce!  Awesome prices in center city.  I live near city hall so i somt have many places to get healthy food.  I go to while foods for rest of my groceries and Moma organic
So much fun to explore.  Go with a good appetite and at least twenty bucks to get the most out of the experience.

Stone cold classic. Whether you're from Philadelphia or are just here on a short visit, you've got to pick up something to eat at Reading Terminal. Just strolling through it is a feast for the eyes and nose. Coffee, tea, books, fresh produce, fresh-baked breads, goods from Amish farms, cut flowers, herbal remedies ... it's all here!

One of my favorite places to shop. I get my fresh vegetables from Iovine. Meats from  Martin's(spicy Italian chicken sausage is the best!)  I try new cheeses at Valley Sheppard. Spices from the Head Nut. Local raw honey at Bee Natural and I almost always stop by  Nanee's Kitchen for dinner on the way out the door.

Most overlooked place in philly for locals and tourists alike. Do not get a Philly cheesesteak here too many better option here and for cheesesteaks elsewhere. If you come with someone else or a group, go 'halvsies' as we call it so you sample as much as possible. Get stuff cut in quarters, lots of spoons/forks etc.  Get a donut. And walk here bc you best be hungry when you show up, and avoid lunch hour.

This was a great find! There are so many amazing vendors in this market. You definitely need to take a walk through before determining what tasty things you will sample.  My husband and I visited Miller's Twists. Their original pretzel was probably the best I've ever had and I have eaten a ton of soft pretzels.  My husband had the cinnamon sugar sticks and let me try one and they were also amazing. We also stopped by Beiler's Bakery and got a couple of donuts for a late night snack. The maple bacon and apple fritter were amazing. Our last stop was Pearl's Oyster Bar. We shared some clams and oysters and they were great. The staff helped us choose some good ones. All in all, this was a treasure and I hope to visit again one day.

Whether you're a local or visiting Philly for the first time, Reading Terminal is a must! With a vast variety of spots to eat, a fresh produce market, meats, and dessert spots, this place has it all. Most vendors are from Lancaster and have the ability to share with you the exact source of what you're purchasing. Homemade jams, soaps, and trinkets can be found around the market as well. The best doughnuts can be found in Beilers! I recommend harvest apple. This spot is nice due to being indoors and getting a typical "packed market/city vibe" experience. With so many choices of places to eat, you can find something for anyone to eat here.
Best lunch in the city!  Best selection, most authentic food in Philly.
This place is a head turner. Full of culture and diversity. I ate so much from so many different places. Hands down my favorite stop in philly.

It's always a great time at RTM, I would like to see a stronger effort to alert customers to gluten free and veg options (maybe a star on the map?) . Sometimes it's hard to find a clean table, but busy is good! Great people watching.

We ate at the Reading Terminal Market twice while we were in Philly. There's definitely something for everyone, but I'm not a huge fan of crowds and it was packed in there. They have all kinds of food, deli, pastries, chocolates, flowers and good people watching.

Was excited to go here and first impressions were good. After more exploring it became apparent that the choice and quality of most of the food was limited, with one or two exceptions. The prices are high.

This is definitely a place to come to if you are from out of town but also if you are local and want great food. You can pretty much find anything you desire to eat. From chocolates to seafood to Asian cuisine, the choices are limitless.

Great market in Central City Philly. So much food so little time. They have everything and then some. The food and goods is all fresh and local. Great spot for lunch if you can pick just one. The Amish kitchen is great for breakfast and the Amish fresh presses juice was fantastic and reasonably priced. Can't wait to go back and try something new.

Still one of my favorite places in Philadelphia.   My husband and I had grilled cheese sandwiches from Valley Shepherd Creamery and Meltkraft Grilled Cheese.  They were delicious!!  The sodas were also really good.  Different flavors and made from sugar cane (no refills).
I had the 'VALLEY THUNDER', which is (12 month) cheddar, BUBBE'S BRISKET and baked macaroni & (our) cheese.  Absolutely phenomenal.   Great bread and cheese makes all of the difference.   My husband had a mozzarella grilled cheese with spinach and tomatoes.   He really enjoyed it.  
We also got some donuts from Beiler's Bakery.  Again, really good.  I love their bacon caramel donuts.  We bought 4 different flavors.  The donuts are always fresh and the line is long, but moves quickly.   I love this market.  There is always something for everyone.

I know why you are reading this section, you want to answer the foodie question to eat here or not to eat here. In short, yes, but keep this in mind:

DECOR:
Plaza/ food court style. Most places have their own energy and vibe some have seating. The main area for sitting is pretty spacious, and gets full pretty quickly so send a scout ahead of you eating or be prepared to have a mobile meal.

FOOD: 
The food is amazing at several vendors in this Market, but my fav all time food to grab is Beilers the doughnuts are melt in your mouth good, they are freshly made right in front of you annnnnnd you can grab on in a batch that you see being made.

WAITSTAFF: 
There really isn't much in the way of waitstaff. There is a team that prepares the various foods and then those that are selling it to you. I haven't had more than a diner experience to yo, but it is expected so I just roll with it.  

WHAT TO WEAR:
The crowd is pretty diverse and so are the clothing choices, or not. I have seen suits or blatant tourist gear in here. So I would say anything goes here.

CROWD: 
The crowd is massive from all walks of life it's like New York only indoors and less the constant yet surprising whiffs of pee every so often.

*TIPS*:
I would recommend that you not  drive to this location there really isn't a really viable place to park. Unless you want to park in a parking garage.

I am in philly for 2 days for a work conference and was walking around with a coworker when we stumbled upon this gem. It may not look at big from the outside but once you walk in..it's like a whole different world. There are over 70+ vendors and they have everything between deli meats, steak cuts (like a million kinds), fish market, every kind of food place you can think of and even little shops that sell just about anything! Love this place!

My all time favorite spot to take people visiting the city for the first time. Great location within walking distance of many great Philadelphia features, and offering so many different (and delicious) food choices, you really can't go wrong. 

I do wish that their seating area was a little larger to accommodate people. It can be very difficult to find a space to sit down, especially if there are more than 2-3 people in your party.

This is a foodie dream. I've never been anywhere like it before (the closest I could say is Pike Place Market in Seattle), and I was in awe the entire time. We started at one corner and weaved our way up and down every aisle, stopping for roast pork sandwiches at Tommy Dinic's, whoopie pies at Flying Monkey, and donuts at Beiler's. I can't wait to go back (we're VA residents) and try more vendors!
Love RTM.  Went here with my family while doing sight seeing in Philly.  Forgot how great it was.  We all had something great to eat and just loved it.

This place is great for tourists and locals alike! You can find almost anything food-related and other knick knacks too. It can get a bit crowded on weekends so definitely try to visit on a weekday if possible.

Tourists NEED to check out the various Amish stands (for honey, jams, pastries, etc), Bassetts Ice Cream, and Meltkraft if you're into grilled cheese.

This is a great place for locals to get produce, meat, and fish! Don't expect to find frozen dinners here - this is not the place. Also, come prepared to know your prices! Some things are cheaper than others here. But if you want high quality stuff, this is as good as it gets (other than a farmers market of course). If you're a student, go to Iovine Brothers (produce) for 10% on Wednesdays and Sundays!

Absolutely everything you could ever imagine inside! If you're not quite sure what to eat, after a stroll through here, you'll then be confused which place to choose...and then still return for your next meal to try something else! The options are endless. I promise you'll find something you like!

Great spot where you can find food for the whole family. The pork at DiNic's is unbeatable. If you are looking for PA specific items and really good desserts, check out the PA General Store. A great place to grab food or for a family day out.

Where can I begin with this place? 

It was the first place that I worked and called home in my early 20's .... if you want variety on food/goods/groceries/gifts it's a one stop shop. 

In a crew with picky eaters or people with different taste buds? They have a food court and various other no mans land seating separate from individual businesses. Everyone can go off on their own and meet back up to eat together. 

It's open early so it's a great stop for breakfast and a staple for bringing out of towners. 

A little hectic during conventions (car show/flower show/tattoo convention ) but other than that it's one of my favorite places to go. 

Becks Cajun Cafe has the most unique Cheesesteak in the entire market, it's a Cajun spin off and will change your life. Dinic'd roast beef obviously a must... Carmen's is my favorite for your typical lunch sandwich and they have an awesome cheesesteak. Flying monkey is a bakery..their Whoopie Pies are amazing and they make rose cupcakes that will make you come back. 

All and all I love the RTM and I always bring people here because it's a great representation of how diverse Philly is. All they need is an Ethiopian spot and I'm moving in.

Love the market! I could write about all the things offered but I would be writing all day. So many options of food and products like clothes, and jewelry. Everything is fairly priced and there is something for everyone. They also have the best treats like cannolis and cappuccino flavored cupcakes.
Very cool place. So many choices. Noisy but that gives it the feel of a market. I loved it!
This is a must go for every tourist who loves food like me!! Such a huge variety of food. Yummy

Wandered through this amazing place very late in their day after arriving by train from DC. Purposely stayed in a hotel close by so we could scope this very famous market that opened originally in 1893. 

What a place. If you want anything food related they have it. We walked every aisle, pleased that it was near closing and we had plenty of room to roam. Bought a Tropical smoothly for $5.25 which took the edge off our hunger gathered up in the nearly two hour trip from DC. 

We will be checking it out again during the busy time and look forward to seeing the place humming with people.
We absolutely love this place. There is all kids of fun things to do, all kids of shopping and fun things to do. We wanted to go every day.
This place is the best. Whatever you're in the mood for you'll find it.  Been coming here for years. If you can't get it here, you can't get it

A must for anyone visiting Philadelphia.  Something for everyone. Carmen's has a vegan cheesesteak which is really good and you can load it up with all kinds of toppings which makes it even better.  Love the mint lemonade from the middle eastern deli, the Amish bakeries are amazing and it's so cool watching their old world traditions. Also the pickle stand (also Amish) is so good!  Duck noodle soup at Sang Key with their homemade chili oil is BOMB. The salads at the Greek deli (next to Carmen's) are delish. Seriously it is all so good.

Honestly there are too many places to call out as favs so just go and see for yourself. You won't be disappointed!! I've been here 50+ times and I always try and hit up RTM when I'm philly. So many choices it never gets old and never disappoints!
Cannot be overstated. If you do one thing in Philly, make it a visit to Reading. Food, culture, history; all are concentrated here.  A wow on every level.
Really fun place to visit. Lots to see. Food! Food! Food! Great place to get gifts for any holiday or special occasion. Lots to try. Seating can be a bit of a search but worth the effort.

Every time we have out of town guests, we take them here. There is nothing else like it! The produce is also incredibly affordable that we tend to do our shopping here as well. Special and unique place. Beware though...it gets very crowded and hard to navigate through the aisles.

Verdict: I could go here every day.

I went for Tommy Dinc's Roast Pork and Beef on my first sandwich. Philly knows how to do a good roast pork and Tommy Dinc's didn't let me down. I suppose that's why the line wrapped around their stand. Carmen's cheese steaks had quite the line and fan base too. Like other places here, they have their system down and food comes out fast.

The real star of the show was The Original Turkey. Go here for the Turkey Steak and be amazed. My family and I were deciding where to go. They offered a sample of their turkey and it was an instant decision. The meat was more tender and juicy than possibly any turkey I'd had before. I've had some good ones too.

Bassets Ice Cream small is actually rather large. Be warned and be prepared for some good eating if you go here. Don't miss Beiler's Donuts for another favorite. Their apple fritter is fantastic.
Great place for tourists even locals. If you want fresh poultry, try Godshalls meat market.

Visited here for lunch! This place is massive!!! We ended up walking around before deciding what we wanted and it was so overwhelming with all of the options! I highly recommend getting cookies from the 4th Street cookie company. Hands down the best cookie I've ever had!! There's something for everyone here!

My go to place for just about everything foodie!   Desserts, lunches and dinners are within walking distance inside the market. Amish delights, fresh seafood and meats, Down Home Diner, Pizza and Snapper soup... just to name a few.  Also a fresh vegetable market!
No need to shop anywhere else
Downside is parking you car.  Take ride share or public transportation
iko8i8i o9ikooo989oii o.o9888o99i908 initiooo9 0o. 8oooo9 oii0oooout u polloi Kim u8i9in9o oop09i

One of the coolest places I've ever been!  Online, this place looks like somewhere you can order a variety of food from.  In person, this place is sensory overload!

The variety of retail options boggled my mind!  I still can't fathom the food options.  I could have eaten cheesesteaks, Mexican food, Cajun food, bbq, steak sandwiches, crepes, classic American comfort food, and even multiple types of ice cream. Besides a meal, you can buy candy, fresh fish, fresh meat, and just about any souvenir you want.  

I'd almost consider moving to Philadelphia purely to shop here over and over again.  "SHUT UP AND TAKE MY MONEY!"

I love this place so much. They have all sorts of food options and I love just walking around and browsing. It can get crowded at times but it's such a fun experience. I definitely recommend it for people as a fun to-do in philly. I spent a good 1-2 hours just walking around and browsing. My favorite place is the ice cream by the exit/entrance right now but there's just so much good stuff to try in there!

I have so much good eats here:

1) Beck's Cajun Cafe - jambalaya for breakfast
2) Old City Coffee - strong but smooth coffee
3) Termini  Brothers - best Cannoli ever 
4) Hatville Deli - perfect Pastrami on Rye
5) Metropolitan Bakery - flourless chocolate cake
 
Must come and try everything, you would love it!!
Great vendors, fresh food, a lively scene - what else needs to be said? I'm there 2-3 times a week.
A classic place to find any type of food you're looking for!  I highly recommend the Old City Coffee as well! Oh and don't forget about Beilers Donuts.  Ah now I need to go get some!

There are tons of great options here, by my personal favorite is Beck's Cajun Cafe. Alligator gumbo is spicy and so delicious. The servers are great at upselling -- I just can't resist the jambalaya rice & cornbread.

Super cool place. Reminds me of the Westside Market in Cleveland, Ohio. I wish we would've had a longer stay in Philly so we could have had more opportunities to go back and check out the other dining options. I will definitely return when we are back.
It's a foodie paradise for Philly, a lot like Pike Street Market in Seattle except food focused. Excellent lunch spot

One of the best places on Earth, IMHO.

With fresh produce, amazing food, a bar, coffee spots, and every flavor of chapstick you could imagine, what more do you need?

Love, love, love.
All there food is great. I like there seafood and the amish food .
Omg what fun.  Had falafel, tabouli, hummus, pita and juice. Perfect lunch. Was going to try another place for dinner but they were closed. Darn!  Will be back for lunch tomorrow
I go to the place when I'm in the city. Great food , comfortable to get around. Not to busy. The BBQ is to die for !!

What a fun place!! I wish we had something like this in ATL. Wasn't as expensive as I thought/had much more than the eye can see on the outside. Ponce City Market (something as close to this in ATL) should take notes. 

Inside there are restaurants where you can eat via bar space (utilized pretty well for space), buy produce, and buy random items. The restaurants are very diverse. We ate here once a day during our trip. The price tag to eat here is affordable. I really thought it'd be much more expensive since it's in the DT area. Awesome place to come for any reason: wanting a snack, a meal, coffee, desert, quick bite to eat, etc. Honestly think you can come here for everything, haha. If I was a permanent Philly gal, I'd come here daily or probably every weekend. 

Seating wise - not as bad as I thought. Space is available around the market AND some restaurants have bar areas to eat, so that helps with the craziness. 

But beware: if you come at rush time - you may have to wait some time to eat. There was a popular Philly Cheesesteak place that had a line at least 10-15 people deep during lunch. 

I high recommend people to come here... especially folks from out of town.
Fun but very crowded and it can be hard to find a seat.  The large number of vendors is great since it has something for everyone and there are some excellent food choices (Beiler's, DiNic's).

So much fun to frequent, especially during the holidays!!! It can get busy so be prepared. There are some great finds here and I love buying cooking gifts for my FIL here. Definitely a must if you're new to Philly or haven't been yet!

Love the market.  Clean.  Has parking and restroom!  Great selection of shoppes and eateries - bring back memories of my time at la boqueria in Spain and Borough Market in London.  Has one of a kind shop that sell artisanal items such as beeswax candles, hand painted ceramics, fresh baked pastries, abundant selections of meats and charcuteries.  I find the locals to be friendly and ready to help.  Highly recommend this for anyone visiting Philly to add this on their itinerary.

Second visit to this wonderful toursit destination..My mom had never been decided on a mini road trip, located in the heart of downtown area.

Well recommended Spatros Philly Cheesesteak  since 1947....along with PA General Store, defintly a place to go for new experiences, and create a memory.

Reading Terminal Market is like a massive Pennsylvania food court with something local for any Yelper to try ... and 2-3 things for me. 

Coming here has been a Philadelphia tradition since 1893 and it still ranks as an obligatory tourist attraction for city visitors. We came a couple times (over a week) to try different foods and shop a little in the other stalls. 

Recommendations include:
 * Beiler's Doughnuts (underrated donuts)
 * Miller's Twist (Warm Amish pretzels!)
 * Sang Kee Peking Duck (Beijing-style duck)
 * DiNic's Sandwiches (ok, yet overrated)
 * Spataro's Cheesesteaks (average, but historic)
 * Downtown Cheese (say Cheese!!)
 * Valley Shepherd Creamery (Grilled cheese please)
 * Bee Natural (Local honey)
 * Fox & Son ("If" you like corndogs)
 * Dutch Eating Place (Apple dumplings)
 * Flying Monkey Bakery (Red velvet whoopie pies)

Note that the Reading Terminal Market is open 7 days a week from 8:00 am to 6:00 pm (except major holidays), so, plan accordingly with your meal schedule.
This place has all types of restaurants and local vendors available. If i lived nearby can see that being an everyday place.

The best place to go if you want to eat anything and everything in Philly. Personal favorites: DiNic's Roast Pork, Termini Bro's Cannolis, Beck's Jumbalaya with Chicken Andouille Gumbo, and anything from Beiler's Donuts. Goooood luck finding a seat at lunch on a weekday!

Variety is the spice of life here at Reading terminal.  Live Pianist serenaded us at breakfast.  Loads of good choices.  DiNics pork, broccoli rabe with hot peppers on perfect crusty rolls.  Large and generous for the heartiest appetites.  You'll need extra napkins for this savory juicy treat.  Several shops have long lines that move fast.  Service is warm and efficient.  Try several stalls to get the produce, meats, fish, bakery specials and ice cream.  Even a pickle shop.  Cajun, Mexican, huge Salad bar, burger, Hoagies and donuts.  Something for everyone.  Bee wax shop, gifts and all kinds of fun shops to explore while you are at Reading terminal.  Early Dinner is perfect for a quick Greek, Italian or Chinese meal too.  Take family and friends to Reading.

Always fun to browse this market. Brought home to NYC wonderful pastrami and corned beef sandwiches. Highly recommend this market.
Wanted to buy some meat but the buther I stopped at had no ice for my 3 hour trip home.

My all time favorite market and must see in Philadelphia. So many delicious options for food and treats. Any food you can imagine under one roof. 

Perfect if everyone in your party likes different foods there are tables and chairs to sit and eat after picking which vendor you will be dining with.
Running way from a coldest place to touch the local fresh popularity...everything is fresh to me!

Love Reading Terminal!  Always something new to try, meats and ingredients are fresh.  Always have that hard to find item or spice.  

Old City Coffee.....best bar none!!!!
Grilled cheese stand and diniks pork is awesome. Also go to where they sell the donuts, the ones with the m and m's are the best

A fun market to hang out at and try awesome food!! Love everything about it. My top favs in there is Termini Bros Bakery for cannoli or cheesecake, By George for a cheese steak, Fox and Son for there funnel cake or cheese curds, Peking Duck has the best duck in the city! Beilers Doughnuts
What a fun place full of choices.  You can go everyday and not have the same thing twice.  The people there are friendly and fast.  Great place for lunch and shopping for dinner and gifts.
The omish breakfast spot is awsome big portions and great tasting! If u need meat the venders have fresh meat amd seafood and the seasoning store is the best! Have to try it if in center city philly!

The indoor market is always busy with stalls that line every inch of the place. You can find bakeries, donut shops, butcheries, flower shops, and small restaurants all around you. Come ready with cash and be ready to Wade through crowds of people.

A place for tourists and locals. Filled with whimsical products like chocolates in the shape of organs and  everyday necessities like fresh meat, cheese, and vegetables at very reasonable prices. 

Tourist highlights and some of my favorite places to take visitors:
Beiler's Bakery - blueberry fritters and apple fritters are out of this world
Termini Brothers - cannoli are freshly filled and delicious 
Kitchen supplies store (I forgot the name) but there are cute and useful supplies inside 
Herbiary - beautiful herb products that smell great and organic soaps/lotions 

I love buying produce from OK produce (.99$ blueberries?! $1 pepper grab bags). You really have to pick and choose, but you can't beat the price. Iovine Brothers has a larger selection of provide and is great as well. 

For meats, I like Godshall's for poultry and Martin's for other meats.
I love this place! It's an indoor farmers market with access to many vendors. Come hungry if you're looking for a quick bite, or sit down to eat at the diner. They also have lots of shopping.

This place was just so amazing, diverse, and fun. This was my first time here but now I know that every time I visit the city I would like to visit the market because there are so many things to try! It's a little overwhelming but it just makes you want to come back and try a little bit of everything.

Delicious finger foods and meals from all around. It was such a great atmosphere and there was music which made it even more fun. We ate mini corn dogs, bacon on a stick, ribs falling off the bone, philly cheese steak sandwiches and then there was a full market of foods, cheeses, hummus, soaps, raw meat and seafood fresh vegetables it was such an experience
Awesome food! Hayride! Vodka cocktail. Great time!! Came back with lots of bags lol!!

I came to the Reading Terminal Market due to a recommendation from a friend, as he told me to check out DiNics for their famous Roast Pork, & Roast Beef sandwiches.
Upon seeing DiNics on a T.V. food channel, I made it a point to check out the Reading Terminal Market over the weekend. 

What can I say about the Reading Terminal Market?

Well, the best way to describe this place is - it's like a GIANT mega food court & store!!! 
You name it, they probably have it here...........all kinds of ethnic foods can be found here, as well as fresh farm produce, meats & poultry, finest seafood items, baked goods & confections.

My mission when I had visited the Reading Terminal Market was to try the sandwich from DiNics (which I accomplished), as I ended up eating both the roast pork, & roast beef sandwiches.............I really enjoyed both sandwiches, but between the two...........I gave the thumbs up to the roast pork!

While walking around the mall, I ran into another sandwich shop called - Carmen's Famous Italian Hoagie & Cheesesteaks. 
The time when I was there, I saw our island son - Barack Obama come to Carmen's to eat a cheese steak, so I figured if it was good enough for President Obama, it was a must for this island son to also give it a try too! Lol!

There is a very long history about the Reading Terminal Market, as I read a brochure about this place.............let me share a little of what I read.

Apparently back in 1892 the Reading Railroad opened the Reading Terminal Market below the tracks of their massive new train shed. The 78,000 sq. foot market held nearly 800 spaces for vendors & was touted as the "greatest food market" in the world!
By 1971, the Reading Railroad went bankrupt & the Reading Terminal Market started to decline & be in disrepair. 
Beginning in the 1980's, the Reading Company renewed attention to the market & began a turnaround of the facilities, and by 1984 trains stopped running to the station above the market and the city's commuter rail system was re-routed to bypass the old Reading Terminal. 
By 1990 the historic building was sold to the Pennsylvania Convention Center Authority, who rebuilt the market to strict historic preservation standards, and also set up a non-profit management company to run the market and maintain the historical integrity of this place.

I must say, if you're ever in Philadelphia, take sometime to check out the  Reading Terminal Market, as you should put it in your "must" list of things to do! 
Visiting the market has a lot of very cool historical value, as well coming here to try the various types of food...........it's basically a foodie lovers paradise!!!
Great place to grab cheap and fresh veggies! Love how long the vegetables last! The stands are also amazing! I wish a majority of the stands didn't only take cash.
Such a fabulous foodie and shopping experience!  The butter cake from Flying Monkey will literally change your life.
Love it at the market! You can find anything you need or want! Food is fresh- especially enjoyed Pearls Oyster Bar and the crepery!

When it's not packed it's simply amazing for any culinary desire. Obviously the PA Dutch food is sublime, ice cream, produce, luxury baked goods, etc etc etc. Just good luck getting a seat to dine-in on the weekends!

I absolutely fell in love with this place! Wish other cities would have something similar. I stopped by during my business trip. I was unable to get through the whole market. But I plan to return!
I did stop to get hot green tea at Old City Coffee one morning and for lunch, I had duck with rice and veggies at Sang Kee Peking Duck. It was yummy. The next day, I went with a colleague to the Oyster Bar. He had fish tacos with salad (very good, and a good size serving, he said) and I had a bowl of oyster stew. That was very good. The market was clean, vibrant, just bustling with energy. I highly recommend this place.

Reading terminal market is amazing!! Good food, cheap food, exotic, local food, Amish food, Philly local food....... you can find anything you want here. Be careful, it's always crowded here. There isn't a day it's not busy. If you don't like people, this isn't your place. But if you want to explore different kinds of food Philly has to offer, this is it!!!! Can't express how much I love this place enough!
This is a great place to find a variety of great produce, farm fresh items, or just a quick lunch. Lots of variety. This is a Philadelphia mainstay that makes this city what it is.
One of must-go-to place in Philly. There're many interesting shops here, including one of the best ice cream places in town. It's great even just for sightseeing.
Very busy. Some food choices are a disappointment after waiting in line for extended periods of times. Everything is fresh however.

Busy, prepared food and meals. A grocery store, meat markets, and bakeries round out this must go if you're in Philadelphia. Careful where you walk outside as it is close to the convention center, you could step on the many homeless who camp out on the sidewalks unfortunately in the middle of the day.

Always a solid spot if you are a tourist or a local bringing out of town friends. Lots to choose from. A fun 30 minute walk through the 10 or so aisle of the market is super fun and also include a stop anywhere that peaks your interest for breakfast or lunch!
One of my favorite spot in the city ! Such a great place to get any type of food you want. The only downside is that it is always crowded

A historic treasure! I love that it provides food variety and even fresh groceries you won't get at a supermarket. It's very different from any other place to get food in Philly. Every time I have a visitor, Reading Terminal Market is a must. Try pearls oyster bar breakfast special! Amazing!

I love the addition of the Kennett Square Mushroom Company. Great spot for vegetarians and shroom-lovers! They always have a varied selection of fresh farmed mushrooms and seasonal foraged shrooms like chicken of the woods, chanterelles, morels. 
Great place for those interested in the abundant variety of mushrooms!
Love reading terminal. So many different places to choose from and you can even grocery shop!

This. Place. Rules. They have literally everything you could think of. The best and most unique food options. Philly in general probably has the best food of anywhere I have lived... and I have really moved around a bunch! I seriously think of moving back sometimes just because I miss this place, and Ralphs Italian! :'(

The Terminal Market is a fascinating place offering virtually every type of food and beverage one can imagine pus many other items.  It is only open until 6:00 p. m. each day, which is a drawback.  Many of the items are expensive, but they are generally top notch.  The problem is the atmosphere: it is extremely busy, loud, and it is frequented by panhandlers who operate within the facility despite signs prohibiting the conduct.  It is no wonder that there seems to always be a large police presence in the market and not only for the officers to dine. Seating for diners is not comfortable and one is likely to be seated very close to others.  There are few sit-down restaurants; the diner generally orders at the counter and waits for their food to be served.  At By George, a fine Italian restaurant at the market, I was not permitted to buy a pizza that was on display.  I had to wait for a new one to be prepared.

Was an awesome place to wander around. So many stalls and interesting things - fresh produce and meat, handmade items and chocolate. Everywhere you turn there's something to see. I found an Indian food stall and had a tasty samosa. Easy to get turned around if you have no sense of direction like myself but it was fun.
One of my favorite places to eat and grocery shop in the city. So much variety. Sometimes after work, I'll pick up a quick bite before heading home.

How can you not give this place 5 stars?! This a MUST place to visit and walk around in when visiting Philly. They have a ton of food venders, deli's and little markets. When I first walked in, I felt a little overwhelmed with everything there is to see. I could not get over all of the fresh meats, cheeses, and seafood there was to buy. Wowza! I would come here to do my shopping for sure...my time would be spent at the deli with the many amounts and flavors of just the bacon and sausages alone. It's a meat and cheese heaven. 
The food venders have everything fresh including your sweets. There is a bar/restaurant towards the back to grab a refreshing beverage. Your only problem in this place will be which shop to stop at for lunch.
I don't understand what all the fuss is about. It's a tourist trap.  They have decent options but I live here. It's a mall of food.
Hectic. Everyone freaks out about how great this place is but personally I have always found it chaotic and confusing.

I've been going to reading terminal since i was a kid. After i moved into the city i found myself going grocery shopping here and meeting with people for coffee and bumble dates! There's so much variety which allows me and my friends to try different things every time. My go to favorite is the metropolitan bakery or the Amish market

This is a really neat place. I'd heard about it before coming to Philadelphia for a conference so I was excited to check it out. It can be a little overwhelming as there's A LOT of options and people. I recommend doing a lap around all of it before deciding what you want.

There's several little eateries to get juices, sandwiches, a hot and cold food bar, a coffee shop, bakeries, fresh meat and seafood, a philly cheesesteak spot, a diner, an oyster bar, a cajun spot, a greek one and several others!

Definitely check it out if you're nearby! Didn't have a lot of spots open to sit and eat so we brought our food back to the hotel.

Food, smells, hustle, bustle,  people and choices.  The terminal market is a home run for the hungry person. From breakfast to dessert it's all here. If you can't find what you want then look for  the ingredients and go home and make it. The Market is popular lunch spot for tourists, shoppers and workings in the city.  It can get very crowded and timing is everything.

Great choice of food and products from all around many states and countries and all in one place. Nice vibe with the produce market with excellent quality produce with great price. I will have to get back to this place in the future. There are many things I want to try and I can't just do it in one day visit only. The other thing that I would like to get next time is the pastries. There are donuts, pretzels, cakes but I didn't have enough room in my stomach for all of them. What a great place in the middle of the busy downtown area. This place is packed during the week specially during the lunch time. Sometimes it takes time to get a table to eat the food that is eager to be eaten.
WOW!  Tons to see buy and eat.  Really nice to get a feel for the past.  The worn out marble tables etc.
Have you had their cake!? The slices are as big as a whole cake! Looking to impress someone on their bday with just one piece go here the funfetti is

Uncomfortably crowded with oblivious and rude tourists.  They're qued up like lambs to the slaughter for cheesesteak.  I'm baffled by the directive that a cheesesteak sandwich is a mandatory ritual when in Philadelphia.  However, great food, pastry and ice cream selections abound.  Crafts are pricey and not fashionably relevant which explains the non-existent crowd at the register.  T-shirt and souvenirs of that ilk are top dollar and low quality. Epic visual, auditory and claustrophobic experience.  You might like it and I don't judge. Just watching out for those who may go fetal just inside the door.  Love to all.

This is a market and food hall in the heart of downtown Philadelphia. If you are in the neighborhood, be sure to come by and walk through the stalls and stop for breakfast, lunch, dinner and everything in between. Many of the stalls have diner-style seating or take away options. 

What I love about this place is coming early in the morning and seeing the locals eat here. Many of Philadelphia's finest officers begin their days here with a hearty breakfast. I also love that the restaurants have come up with creative ways to serve breakfast like a cheesesteak breakfast, an oyster scramble breakfast. Love, love, love!

I went to Molly Malloy's twice while visiting for breakfast. They have a wonderful avocado toast. Just when you think you had it with the boring same old avocado toast, Molly's will surprise you with their version topped with a fried egg over easy. The avocado is spiced wit pepper flakes and a dash of vinegar. Very very tasty and will keep you fulfilled for those long morning walks in the chilly weather. Service is great and attentive. 

I tried Pearl's oyster as well. Belly up to the diner and be greeted by the waitstaff. Did you say fried oysters for breakfast?  Yes, please!!! I had mine with egg white scramble. It was unusually delicious! 

Turnaround from Pearl's and you will see the Famous 4th Street Cookie Co. Get a cookie for the road. You will need it to top off this amazing experience!
I shop here every Monday morning for my weekly produce & meats. I avoid it at all costs during tourist trap Saturdays

This place is Amazing!!! Such good food and super nice people!  I could walk around and eat my way through this place. There is lots of fun things to try from Oysters to cheesesteaks to pickles to donuts to tea to James and jelly's. I've tried some of the best donuts at a place that starts with a "B" sorry can't remember the name and the best cheesesteak at Carmen's. Will be back to try more food and some fresh produce!

This place is super cool. So many choices in one convenient area and safe from the real weather outside. Closest thing in California is the Anaheim Packing District but there's a special charm that I like here. Maybe it's the efficiency and gruff customer service or that the food isn't frilly hipster food but authentic. Prices are more reasonable too.

Anyway, I kept going back during my stay in Philadelphia and didn't eat anywhere else really.
This place has everything and I mean everything foods and vegetables from all over the world, if u can't find it here it can't b found !!so get on over there u won't b sorry

How could you don't give something so all encompassing 5 stars? Everything under one roof. And everything I've had here over the years has been excellent. 
You can get produce here too ya know?!?
Very overwhelming but a great place to find anything you are craving! Loved the gluten free options and anything from dessert to breakfast to dinner, all day!

Been eating and shopping here 25+ years! Still the best place in Philadelphia for day feasting and shopping. So much culture, so much history, so much Food! Eat all the classics from roast pork to Amish burgers. Shop for top quality meat and produce along with exceptional cheese and dairy. Support local farms and local Philadelphians!
Just go. Get a beeswax candle, some greek food. Theres 80 vendors, eldest and largest farmers market of anywhere in the area. Be aware they close at 5, but it is the best spot for lunch. Just go

Long lines in an extremely congested environment.  Yes there's a variety of choices.  But no I don't think any of them are super great.  I will commend the market for having lots of vegetarian and vegan options.  But I don't think it's the kind of place that you can gracefully explore - you really have to go in with an agenda.  

If you are considering taking your child here for trick-or-treating I would suggest against it.  While the vendors who did participate in the trick-or-treating were very helpful, generous and accommodating, there were not many of them that participated.

This place has everything! Sandwiches. Pizza. The best Philly Cheesesteaks. Homemade desserts galore. Local products and crafts for sale. Farmers market. Butcher. Ice cream. If you're touristing around, this is a definite go to for your group. Everyone can find something they love.

This place is a little too overwhelming for me. I'm like an ADHD kid in 3rd grade when I come in here. I can't make an actual choice on what or where to eat. I just can't. 

You need to either have a solid plan on what you want to eat or plan on being here for a couple hours to really check the entire place out. 

We found street parking right down the block.

This place is AWESOME!  

I highly recommend coming on a Saturday because all the Amish stores (some of the best) are closed on Sunday. 

Some of my favorites are Beiler's Donuts, Dinic's and Downtown Cheese. 

It can get very crowded at lunch time so if you don't like crowds, this isn't for you but navigating through the market is what makes it so much fun. 

There are tons of different types of foods, produce and some stores in here and it's a great experience for anyone coming to Philly!
During lunch hour, it's too crowded and hard to navigate.  But around 5pm...amazing!!

I love eating at every booth in here! Haven't been to all of them yet, but it feels like it's on my bucket list now.
