My favorite's include: the grilled cheese place,"Meltkraft" and "Molly Malloy's" Brussels sprouts (and I usually despise Brussels sprouts.) They also have Philly's signature "Black & White" cookies  and cute little décor vendors who sell all the touristy stuff. How cute :)
I loved this place. There are so many options and everything was delicious. Make sure you are hungry when you go because you will want to try everything.

Excellent selection and quality! You can find a ton of different cuisines alongside classic American fare. A lot of high quality meats, cheeses, and other ingredients. Pretty reasonable prices too! Was really impressed, wish we had something like this near where I live.

What an awesome location in the heart of Philadelphia for awesome food! Reading Terminal Market has a variety of vendors - from home and garden to sandwiches to ice creams to Chinese food to Philly Cheesesteaks to desserts, and MORE! However, there is an extreme lack of seating areas to actually sit down and eat!

P.S. The Flying Monkey has the best desserts!

We came on a Sunday.   Parking on 12th in the garage horribly tight and scary driving up the ramp barely made it by the concrete side by and inch.  People so packed and shoving each other so very very bad place to bring young children.   Would have given less stars except for the historical aspect.  They really need to make it more family friendly.  Will not be back anytime soon .   Most other families looked harried.  Bottled juice 3.50 so twice price of regular items.
It's an entire square block closed off to different markets, music and food.  If you're a foodie and love to try different things I highly recommend spotting here and enjoying some different foods.
So crowded and smelled like trash. But a cool place and I get the idea. On our way out we picked up pastries at Termini Bros. The lady was super nice and it was quick considering the crowd.
Fun place to visit. It's like a huge food court. It was very crowded and no where to sit. We took a lap around and left but enjoyed the atmosphere.

The breakfast counter served some of the most delicious original recipes ever. The staff was attentive and made excellent recommendations based on our needs. Spotless.. one of the cleanest establishments I have ever had the pleasure of dining at and I can't wait to go back!

I love this place! I get groceries weekly and they are fresher and less expensive than supermarkets. Also, I go for lunch sometimes. They have everything from seafood, soul food, Italian, Vietnamese, chinese, Greek, Indian.. cookies, cakes, cupcakes, chocolates!! Everything!! They even have a bar, you can get a drink and walk around the whole Terminal with it but you can't take it outside. The only downside is it's always crowded and the isles aren't big enough, but keep in mind this place is old so.. I love this place and recommend it to residents of the city and tourists alike.

Everything about this place is awesome. Good food and diversity amongst the people. A nice place for tourists and for people who want to grab a good bite to eat if working in the downtown center city area.
Seemed like a standard tourist market in a city that people claim to be better than they are.

From fresh ingredients to fully cooked food, this is the place you get it all. You have all the options in the world to pick from. Be advised that the popular joints have a line and its going to be a wait, but so totally worth it.
The something for everyone! Prices are reasonable. Recommend Herschel's pastrami sandwiches and builer donuts

A visual spectacle that offers a variety of food options to satisfy all palates. While the crowds can be overwhelming to some, its a rite of passage to enjoy some of the best treasures that Philly has to offer. Beiler's has become a staple for fresh doughnuts. DiNic's keeps accumulating awards for their excellent roast pork sandwiches. The one caveat would be to avoid the Chinese food options since you can go a couple of blocks away to Chinatown to get better (and cheaper) fare.

Enjoy!

Lots of options to eat here and everything we tried was good, especially the ice cream. 

Super busy at lunch. Elbow to elbow.

The best places to eat. Food from all different cultures and experience down folk real philly types of local die heart philly fans.  Lots of philly locals like myself have being coming to Reading Terminal for two generations. People sitting around hanging out meeting family, friends and co- workers plus cool  tourist from all over the world on vacation in our great Philadelphia town. And yes you can find vegan and vegetarian food there while listening to some nice jazz and panio sounds.

I love this place. Every time I visit I have to go and try a different spot to eat, I want to try them all!  The diversity and culture is incredible. I try to eat at different places each time and haven't had any complaints. The Amish donuts are incredible. The crepes, chicken, icecream. I feel like I'm walking back in history.
Sooo many options!!! Not enough seating but would definitely take guests visiting the city here. I'll be back (maybe not on a Saturday)
Great variety and local foods and veggies. The ice cream and coffee are also very good. One icon place in philly that no one should miss when they are in town.

Lots of good eats, all in one place. There's a place there where President Obama had a meal. It's a nice hidden gem, where everyone in your family or group can have a meal of their choice, and still eat together as a group.

This is a really nice market.  Lots of places to get yummy food (raw and cooked food). I like the many options, but it was so crowded you can barely move.  I doubt I would return if I visited the city again though.

Absolutely no visit to Philadelphia is complete without a visit to the Reading Terminal.  You will have wasted your entire trip if you do not visit this place. It's a Philly Landmark;  A Philly Institution.  It would be like going to Italy, and never eat a slice of authentic pizza.  Anything your "foodie" mind want to eat, you will find it here.  Yes, the crowds can be massive, especially during lunch hour and on the weekend, but that's the beauty of it. I've mastered how to get around in here, but the smells of the different flavors of food, will certainly pull you in all directions, so indulge yourself and go where the aroma takes you. Bring a shopping bag too!

Reading Terminal Market is an amazing indoor marketplace chock full of grocers, bakeries, delis, and other ready-to-eat restaurants. I came on a Saturday and the place was packed. It's a bit gritty - not very polished or cozy - but I suppose that's part of the charm. There are countless options for a little snack, a sweet treat, or an entire meal, so you're sure to find something to satisfy. Definitely give it a visit if you're in the neighborhood and have the hangries - or just want to check out a very cool Philly institution.

If you don't mind fighting the crowds, this place is a gem! You can find just about any cuisine you could want. A must see if you're visiting Philly. If you're gluten free, be sure to check out Fox and Sons- they are a completely gluten free stand serving delicious corndogs, funnel cakes, and fries!

Pandemonium.  You should be able to find any food that you want here.  But, the place is bedlam.  Crowded, jockeying for seats, and billions of people.  The epitome of urban cacophony.  Go if you like character, activity, and bustling.  Stay away if you are looking for a relaxing place to eat.

Originally from the area and had to try out the revamped Reading Terminal Market. It's a must go to for lunch, a fun afternoon of trying new foods or just being a straight out foodie for a day. The assorted venues offer a wide range of food options and fun trinkets.  We walked away stuffed from burgers and shakes from Hungry Burger, delicious coffee and a cute tote from the coffee shop, a great assortment of jams from the Amish shop, and the most amazing fudge and dark chocolate peanut butter cups from Meiler chocolates.   My older kids loved citing all the movies they could think of that were filmed here, I wish I'd googled that prior to heading there.  Took the train in to the city and  had a blast!
The best local market in the city with both local fresh food grocers and great food restaurants.

I can't say I'm that big of a fan because the place is always too jam packed and not enough places to sit and eat in comfort without elbowing someone on accident. Other than that, the quality of food served at the various restaurants and other eateries is typically pretty good.
This place has everything you could never imagine in your wildest dreams. There is no point in trying to describe this wondrous marvel. It must be experienced

This place is alway a gem, no matter which restaurant you stop in you can not go wrong. My recent visit I brought my friend who was visiting to DiNic's roast pork. Being a Philly native I am picky and I can say this is my favorite roast pork across the area. But like I mentioned earlier, you can't go wrong!
Obviously a staple to Philadelphia. A must go and also a locals gem. The juice stand is the best! Can't go wrong eating anything here. Also great for fresh shopping

Food! Food! And More Fun!!! Seriously, its a place you must visit while in Philly! You name it they have it cooked and raw LOL! There are also lots of deserts (cheesecakes, cookies, banana pudding, etc.)

This place is awesome. Celebrating its 125th anniversary, the market is home to over 100 venders of meat, fish, poultry, cheese, baked goods by local artesans, as well as Amish bakers and prepared to take out. There are fresh produce vendors, Famous Deli cookies, Termini's Italian bakery with canoli stuffed to order, pizzelles, as well as cakes for a party or individual celebrations. Thete are many eateries: Pennsylvania Dutch, Asian, Middle Eastern, vegan, as well as the ubiquitous pizza and famous Philly cheesestake stsnds. Several homemade candy stores including Mueller's home of the anatomically correct body parts. Fresh herbs as well as essential oils and other specialties at the Herbiary shop, fresh brewed coffee, Bassett's ice cream, and eateries too numerous to list. There is seating throughout the market, as well as seating at individual stands. Try it, you won't regret it.

We came here around 10am on Sunday morning and it was bustling but there were plenty of seats in the open areas as well as open stools at most of the vendors. 

Imagine all of the foods you could ever want to eat, you'll find them all here. There's a mix of (almost) everything, and enough to keep everyone in the group happy. From cheesesteaks to ice cream, to gyros and Thai food, each vendor adds to the delicious smells and excitement of the market. 

I bought a turkey & red roasted pepper panini from Market Bakery as well as a buttery chocolate chip cookie. Both the sandwich and the cookie cost under $10, I found this whole place to be pretty affordable for a tourist hotspot. The food was great overall, fresh bread and savory flavors. My partner got a meat lover's cheesesteak from Carmen's and was very happy with his purchase. I wish we had more time to wander around.

I would recommend this for anyone who's with a group that might be interested in eating different things and certainly for the exciting atmosphere of an indoor farmer's market with plenty of fun foods and people watching!

I think an update is in order because the market has changed a lot and I don't think for the better.My perspective may  be skewed by the fact that the place was incredibly crowded on that wonderful semi holiday Black Friday but what I noticed is the market is much less a market and much more a food court.I used to buy things here and look at things.Now there isn't as  much to buy or look at.You can eat but then again you always could .So I think it's beginning to get a bit boring.
Very busy food place. A lot of choices. But as a real Chinese food lover, will go to Chinatown for better Chinese food. But the place is worth to try out.

My family is from the Philly area and I always have to make a stop here during my visits. For me, it's more for people watching and picking up sweet treats, although Glasers Black and white cookies aren't sold here any more (the store closed in NYC). 

Pros:
1). Lots of food options, even for the pickiest eaters. 
2).  Historically interesting
3).  Grocery shopping and specialty foods
4).  Close to Jefferson Septa stop
5).  Restrooms

Cons:
1).  Although there are tons of food options here, it's not the best available in Philly. They have mediocre cheesesteaks and Asian foods that you can get better in one of the cheesesteak places (Jim's, Genos, Sonny's, etc) or in Chinatown. 
2).  Super crowded!  If you can avoid bringing a stroller, do it!  Wait times for food can be almost an hour during peak times. 
3).  Not a lot of places to sit and eat. You have to stalk the tables and wait for someone to leave. 
4).  You're paying for the touristy aspect, so prices are higher for everything. 
5).  The fish markets can ruin your appetite with the stench of fish. 

Go ahead and fall for this tourist trap at least once. It's definitely worth visiting and probably my favorite market.

This is my happy place!!! What's not to love? The absolute BEST food...whatever it is you're in the mood for, its here & it's amazing!!!! I'm seriously wondering if the vendors are required to pass a taste test to be permitted in this place

This probably the best place in philly. You can get a plethora of food choices and do your grocery shopping at the same time. My favorite place to shop is OK produce if you want vegetables or fruit that you can eat and cook NOW!  Hershel is the best place to grab a sandwich. This place by far is the best place on Philly!
My wife buys our veggies, lunch meats and meats there every week. It is so affordable and she loves the atmosphere. There are a lot of shops to choose from and lots of  delicious bakeries too.

A must see in Philly! The variety is incredible. Breakfast, lunch, dinner, dessert, tea, or even just shopping for soaps or spices. Definitely don't miss the reading terminal market if you're visiting or even if you live here. Great place for getting groceries too

Pretty Cool place! We have one of these in our city but not nearly as large. This market was primarily food and produce based but there were some other stalls as well. 

We stopped to get a cheesesteak at By George, which had a very large and good looking array of food. I would like to be able to stop in here on the regular but sadly my time in Philly is limited. 

Definitely stop in here if you are looking for some lunch, meat, produce the selection looked amazing.

Excellent. Have been a patron of Reading Terminal for years. Have visited most stands. Poultry, meats, vegetables, cheese, candy and most especially Beilers and restaurants. Anything you want is here and I personally have not encountered a problem. Love it.
Such a cool place to eat. So many quality choices. I wish that I lived nearby. Tons of fresh baked goods along with great ethnic options.
I am recently employed in the terminal. Everything is amazing but sometimes it is hard to walk because it gets so insanely crowded.

We have been coming to the Reading Terminal Market for as long as we can remember. Place is always packed with workers nearby grabbing a bite to eat and tourists. I warn you, it is really crowded here all the time. Here are some of the food stalls worth stopping for:

Bassetts Ice Cream -
The first merchant to sign a lease at the Reading Terminal Market in 1892. This place is still owned and run by the same family. With more than 40 flavors, you can have your pick. The cone comes with a generous scoop(s).

Beiler's Bakery -
One of the best donuts. If this is your first time here, don't be deterred by the long line. You often hear people giving up when they see how long the line is. It moves pretty fast  and the best part, you get to see first hand how they make it in front of you. By the time you're midway through, grab a menu, choose your donuts so you don't hold up the line. My son who doesn't like sweets love Beilers'. Note: Not open on Sundays.

Flying Monkey -
The owner with the love of the movie, "The Wizard of Oz", named her bakery Flying Monkey. When I first discovered this place, they were famous for their amazing cupcakes but nowadays, it's more on their award winning Whoopie pies. The Whoopie pies were named the best in the world and it comes in many flavors. Another must try is their Elvis cake. We usually buy a huge slice home. Every item is made from scratch.

Dutch Eating Place -
The only item we have tried here is their amazing warm apple dumpling with cinnamon which is served with a dollop of cool heavy cream. It is to die for.

The Original Turkey -
I don't like eating turkey and the only turkey I will eat from is "The Original Turkey". You can see how juicy it is when they carve it right in front of you! Served with all your typical Thanksgiving fixings, you can have this all year round. You can also order it sandwich style. Don't forget to ask for extra gravy. 

Bee Natural -
I love to make my famous French toast at home. Instead of using syrup I prefer to use honey. I'm always pleased with the quality of their honey here. When I run low, I make sure to grab a bottle or two.

These are just a handful of stalls we frequent. The list goes on. There are also lots of counter lunch spots, food stalls and fresh produce. A must visit in the heart of Philly. 

If you park at the Reading Terminal, you can get a discounted parking for $4 if you buy $10 and over at any one of the merchants at the Reading Terminal. Just have them validate your parking ticket. Remember, it is only good for 2 hours. Otherwise it will be $10 for 2 1/2 hours.

If I had to pick one and only one place to take an out-of-town friend to experience Philly, it would be here. The Reading Terminal Market is a bustling indoor marketplace filled with an assortment of the best of what the city has to offer, from its Old City Coffee to Italian pastries and fluffy donuts to Amish breakfasts and cheap locally grown produce. 

It's a busy place so it can be easy to get disoriented. The whole place is laid out in a grid format, so when you enter, pause for a moment to get your bearings on what entrance you came from (or what the nearest shop is). Inside, hanging from the ceilings, you can see the signs for the different aisles/avenues, but they're not always visible. 

Tip: Bring cash! A lot of places take credit cards, but some places require cash only.

I can never get in line for the donuts at this place because this is my third time here and the line was beyond crazy! Are those donuts that good?!

We came here on a Saturday afternoon and as we were walking in through the entrance where the donut shop is the place was packed! Packed like sardines in a can! I don't really buy much when I come here because it seems like there's always a line. There are so many vendors so it's a good place to visit if you don't mind the crowd and the wait.

The selection of local cheese, fish, meat, sweet, and vegetable shops is astounding!  Everything you find there is of quality and Prices are fair.  I wish I lived closer so I could shop here everyday.
The best spot to go in Philly for any number of cuisines, desserts, and groceries. I'd be lost without this place.

I love love this market. It was my go to place to purchase my weekly groceries during my college days in Philadelphia. It is so nice to come back when visiting.
Still extremely visit during the weekends, but weekdays crowd tend to be less. It is the best place for a quick bite or just stroll around and to see the variety of shops.  My favorite place still the Dutch Eating Place - awesome for breakfast - people tend to order their pancakes (which is a generous portion) - I go for the typical egg breakfast with one of Pennsylvania staples the scrapple. Lunch is not bad - my favorite is the open-faced turkey sandwich that comes with mashed potatoes and cranberry sauce.  DiNicks (I know I spelled it wrong) is another favorite for the pork sandwich. Old City Coffee - best coffee in town at least for me.  Always bring a couple of pounds of coffee back home.

Endless array of awesome food to choose from. You can get cooked, made to order, fresh from the seafood or butcher counter, and produce. Tons of great sweets and desserts. Also great Amish stores for goods and foods.

The best place ro go for lunch when you're not sure what  you want to eat. Something will surely capture attention and stimulate your appetite.  While you are there you can grab some ingredients for dinner. The food there is all good because they are all competing for your return visit. This place is great for tourists and locals alike. !

Yes the food here is amazing with plentiful choices.  However, it is ridiculously crowded. Be prepared to wait a half hour to an hour in some places.  Just walking through the place is an adventure.  It's so congested that you can hardly move. Good luck finding an open table to actually sit and enjoy your overpriced meal.  The place is a tourist trap.  

Go there once, just to say you've been there.  Before you do, maybe consider eating in neighboring Chinatown.

Still a top destination for me, but definitely something to check out if you are an out-of-town visitor.  Sometimes you're able to catch some live music while chowing down.  I particularly love the Herbiary for loose teas and other healthy gifts during the holiday seasons (or whenever, really) and the Thai kitchen is still the best for curry salmon with broccoli and rice (this is a cash only joint).  If you aren't shy, ask the people working the cheese counters for samples of the most expensive stuff they've got.  They can't say no.  Don't forget the dollar bags of produce at Iovines before you leave for home.
Love this place.  Lots to see and taste. Fun to wander round and look at even if you are just visiting so cant take it all home. Try the ice cream stand...raspberry and chocolate truffle is devine.

There is a lot to do here. There are a wide variety of food options and some home goods. There are plenty of food booths and options. I tried a cheesesteak which was good, but not spectacular. I also had a double chocolate chip cookie which was enjoyable. Overall worth checking out but not necessarily worth a special trip if you're not in the area.

Fun place to walk around and see all the fresh meats, fish and produce. 
We ate breakfast at the Dutch Eating Place. I had mushroom omelette which was very good. Really creamy American cheese. Then had side of blueberry pancake. It was unfortunate that it was luke warm,  but still tasty. A little floury taste was evident. 
Husband had eggs over easy with bacon, which was plentiful and quite salty. 
We ended up speaking to both couples on either side of us, which was really nice. They said chipped beef good as was the apple dumpling dessert. 
Always find it fascinating the people that come across your path. 
This is a must go to place when in Philly!!  
Within walking distance to ALoft downtown where we were staying. See my review...

Great place for the whole family. Closes a bit early so it's more of a day trip. Take the bus it's significantly easier than finding parking. There's a grocery store inside, some clothes, and plenty of specialty foods to ensure everyone gets what they want.

A Philadelphia staple that everyone must visit at least once. With that being said, I am a fairly devout foodie and still manage to get by without coming here very often. But every time I drop by, I'm pleasantly surprised by the selection, service, and art that is hand made food and fresh ingredients.

I can't believe I've never reviewed Reading terminal market. It's one of my favorite places in Philadelphia. One stop shop for all your food needs. Now every city should have a food market like this where you can eat local food from local vendors. I've been going here for years. They have plenty of fun eat in or carry out places. Most of the restaurants do not have their dedicated seating area. There's a common area which can get packed over the weekends. There's plenty of food options like Greek, Mediterranean, Cajun, Italian or even Philly local roast pork sandwich. Eat at the Amish places to discover local food culture. You can even buy fresh produce, meat and seafood, bread and cheese here. 

If you live in Philly, I'm sure you've been here. If you're visiting, make sure you add this as a must visit spot during your time here.
Weather is a steak switch or chocolate this place has everything. I spend hours here looking and things and checking out and trying all the food. Also a funny ad tasty experience.

Love this place. Give yourself and empty stomach and
Some time to get through it. Bet you can't go without getting a beer, pretzel, doughnut or your favorite Philly Cheese steak or Italian sub.

A perfect way to spend a weekends day. You may loose track of time walking from booth to booth but it's certainly time well spent. The vendors goods are everything and anything you could ever imagine, from handmade soaps to absolutely delicious lunch. There is something for everybody when spending your time at the market.
I could spend a day here just walking around -- the hustle bustle of Christmas is amazing and the smells and sights are worth all the crowds you encounter.
I'm in love with this Market, they have many unique and cool vendors. Many different options for ready to eat foods, fresh produce, cheeses, and sweets! Can't wait to return!
Always fresh food I love their coffees as well. Been there to eat with my fiancé and is a lovely setting and very clean.
Amish Doughnuts. Get the Amish Doughnuts. They're life-changing. They're the best I've ever had.

Love the Reading Terminal Market! A must stop for all tourist. I always want something from the Pennsylvania Dutch countertop restaurant. Also, the soft pretzels, freshly made with butter brushed on top! Add some cheese ,....wow! Absolutely delicious!

You can't come here and have the traditional complaints of "not enough seating" or "too long of a wait" because that is all part of the charm here. I love that every time I visit though, I go in thinking I want X for lunch but end up wandering around for half an hour before I actually settle on X. Too many amazing options.

Highlights for me:

1) Cheesesteak sandwiches (I down one every year during jury duty)
2) Amish pies (got two for Thanksgiving this year and felt blessed)
3) Produce market (well priced)
4) Nice place to get fudge

Love this place; this market has every food you can think of. Fresh food, prepared food & restaurants inside the market. It's very busy on Saturdays & Sunday so just be prepared. It does seem a little pricey but worth it.

It is a beautiful place to hang out and grab something to eat. Unfortunately it was very dirty, smelled really bad. I believe it us a place that you must visit in Philadelphia. But still not more than 3 stars because of the ambience.

Great indoor market. Very similar to the markets in Los Angeles and Seattle. A large variety of different cuisines and shops! Everything I've eaten during my many visits have been perfect experiences!

A must for any foodie visiting Philadelphia or for anyone in general. The market is full of culinary delights, local favorites, every possible grocery ingredient and international bites. It's often very busy and crowded and it's easy to get turned around, but just let go and enjoy. I go town for lunch since I work close by. Or I stop by on my way home to pick up ingredients for dinner.

Vibrant city market with delectable items at every turn. I'm originally from Buffalo, and this is what I wish the Broadway Market could be. We loved the breakfast at Down Home Diner and brought home cookies from Famous 4th Street  Cookies. Do not miss if you are in Philly! 

PS. If you give this place anything less than 5 stars because it's "crowded " and you had to "wait in line" , I feel sorry for your heart of stone.

Located in downtown Philly this is more than a farmers market.  Yes there are fruit and vegetables but so much more.  There is a wide variety of food choices from cajun to crepes to sandwiches to oysters. Almost any food you could desire can be found here.  So many choices it requires more than one visit.  It can get crowded and seating can become an issue but still well worth it.

Amazing historic philly staple
A must see if in Philadelphia amazing veggies fish beef poultry artisan cheeses any food to satisfy u
Love this market.  Lots of delicious food options for breakfast and lunch.  And great place to get all the cooking ingredients you need.  Wonderful place.  Wish NYC had a market like this.
Lots of food - everything you could want. Check to make sure there is nothing happening at the Convention Center though. It can get SO crowded.  I would bring anyone visiting Philly here.

It's overrated but it has some good eats. The fruit and veggies in the back are ok I've had much better. Plus it's too expensive. I don't take time out to go but if I'm in Center City Philadelphia and I happen to drive by I'm willing to stop in. But I don't make special effort to go to Reading Terminal

You know that scene where Belle walks into the library in Beauty and the Beast and it's the most awe inspiring moment ever?  That's this place, but with food.  Go.  You will never be the same again.  

This place is perfect for a Sun-date, to snag your weekly groceries and produce, and to get a fantastic lunch.  We like to get there, get some lunch, then grab some groceries and walk around before settling for a mid-shop beer at the bar.  My favorite spots are the numerous seafood places, all of the cheeses, the Tubby Olive - you can do some shots of delicious and fancy balsamic and olive oil fo free! - and the general bustling atmosphere.

I love markets so of course I had to put this on my list of things to do. No matter how big of a group you have everyone can find a spot to satisfy their craving. They have clothing, sweets, foods and many other items.

The market is an experience that anyone traveling to philadelphia should try. The lines for more popular places can get a bit long so be prepared to wait. But the market has everything you can think of, it's a great place to try new things or try traditional Philadelphia staples.

Looked like fun eating there... many great places for people who ate meat. I'm a vegan and I didn't find anything I could eat on my first time there. My daughter goes to college nearby and she recommends this place but during off-peak hours to get seats.

There is so much crammed into this space it is a bit overwhelming. You can find any time of food you could want. Space and tables are somewhat limited, but even as busy as they were, we were able to find a clean table.

I pretend like I'm not a crier, but let's face it - I very much am. I cried when I found sashimi grade salmon in a Cincinnati seafood market. I cried when my boss told me that about how her dog trots and meets new dogs. Hell, I cried when Jordan Staal was traded from the Pittsburgh Penguins in 2012. I have never met Jordan Staal. I have absolutely no ties to his life.

Why am I telling you this? If I tell you this, you will know exactly what my reaction was when I walked into Reading Terminal Market.

I cried. I bawled like a baby right next to Bassett's Ice Cream.

They were joyous tears, of course, but that doesn't take away from the fact that my over emotional self doused the baked goods at Beiler's with my waterworks. I may have been so overwhelmed that Valley Shepard may now be selling a variety of pickles featuring my tears. The waterfall of emotion perfectly showcased reason #3162 why I can't have children - I certainly wouldn't make it through nine months of this kind of overreaction.

But, guys. Everything was just so damn beautiful.

By the end of my time in Philadelphia, I had eaten at 3/4 of the entire market. The stalls are plentiful but the aisles are cramped because I am clearly not the only person that appreciates the perfection that is Reading Terminal. I ate my weight in ice cream, I stood in line waiting for a subpar Philly cheesesteak whilst complaining in a faux New Jersey accent, I ... I may have even scarfed down a 4th street cookie while hiding in Jonathan Best's grocery so that when I emerged from the abyss I could pretend to be famished and hit up another stall. (If you ever ask me again whether or not this is true I will look you in the eye and swear on my grave it is not. I'd rather go die harboring a secret large enough to make me a Hogwarts ghost than shamefully admit on multiple occasions that I am enough of a fatass to eat two meals in the same hour in the same place.)

This is, by far, the best indoor food market I've ever visited. I still dream about Carmen's Franklin cheesesteak (they add cream cheese to it! Smart people) and I've recklessly attempted to recreate DiNic's iconic roast pork sandwiches at home. (Broccoli rabe is difficult to cook y'all.) I am currently attempting every which way into visiting Philadelphia again so I can skip and dance my way through this amazing food mecca. In the meantime, I will cry - because apparently I do that for everything.

This is a must for tourists. So many great places to check out. I love the Greek place with the blue and white bar(it's the best gyro in the city). DiNicks is awesome, I get the pork sammy with sharp provolone and broccoli rabe. Try the trainwreck sandwich.. you may have a heart attack after but it's worth  a try.

A must-see if you're in Philly. You could find anything you want here! A little bit of everything. I'm gluten free and dairy free and we ate at a shop called Molly Malloy's with lots of options. Remember this place is veryyy busy and it can get a little overwhelming. Parking on the same block.
Love this place! So much selection, and it's a Philly staple. I recommend the fresh produce and seafood.

This is the best place ever. If you come here you will be amazed by what you see and taste. 
Mitchell Thomas Wesby
8 years old 
P.S. Best place ever!

One of my favorite places in all of Philadelphia. It's best to avoid it during lunch hours and weekends unless you like crowds. The produce stands are very affordable and most of the shops are delicious. My favorite places are Hershel's (Jewish deli), Dinics (must get the roast pork, broccoli rabe and sharp provolone) and Beilers (donuts). Whenever I'm downtown, I always stop in

What can I say that hasn't already been said? This is a wonderful market with so many independent retailers and shops that is any small-business-shopper's dream. There are vendors who sell sandwiches and pastries, meats and seafood, jewelry and watches, fine chocolate and exquisite cordials, fresh donuts and baked goods, and lots, lots more!

It was very busy when we visited, on a Tuesday morning, so I don't even want to imagine what it is like during the weekends! We mostly window-shopped and ultimately bought a maple donut for about a buck and which tasted phenomenal. I really love places like these that could be overpriced but choose not to.

Absolutely a must-visit place when visiting Philadelphia!

Reading terminal market is a foodies home away from home. So many choices with so little time. 

I could live there. It's so busy and so big. Love this place because of the variety of delicious options you have. theres everything you can think of. But be ready to fight for a table to sit down and eat. I guess that adds to the reading experience. 

I can't get enough of it. I will probably be having lunch there for the next few days I'm in philly. The good thing is the people working and providing the service there are so nice and polite. 

We will meet again reading we will!

An authentic Philadelphia experience. Some of the city's best food is located in this big indoor market. The environment is very casual in here, but you can find a mix of markers, diners, bars and specialty food and product shops.

Showed up here once absolutely blazzzed out of my mind. Literally riding a 9 or 10,,,, at LEAST!!! Anyways, that was NOT a mistake. This place is actually like High Wonderland (not in the sense that they sell bud-that would be tough tho, make it happen Tommy the Wolf!) they've got tons of stuff in here, flying Monkey is absolut a HIGHlight. those butter bars are Tea Leaf is a must see, truly a wide variety of strains for different drinking occasions, really nice Oolong. This is a HOT take i know but-- Beiler's is only good fresh! Now this is absolutely NOT to hate on them, those crullers are tough as hell fresh, but when even a couple hours old they don't old up, so eat em fresh! Overall some of the stuff here is overpriced, but thats a common knock on food markets like this. It's def a tourist trap, so make sure to go in off peak hours, like 9;30 am on a tuesday, but it def has charms.
Make sure to feed tha pig! 
Regards,
Rollin up a fatty J-ason Felton
Mid-State '06
Awesome!!!!  Everything you could want in one place.  So many markets and food!!!   Dinic's is awesome and there are some great dessert/ice cream places.

Fun, food, full of energy! I went crazy could not make up my mind where to eat!  Philly Steaks, Pork Sanwhiches, peking Ducks, cajun cuisine, best juices and smoothies!! Have mercy! I would come back each day for lunch for a month!! Try just about anything at Beck's Cajun Cafe. Amazing Creole and Canjun comfort food! The pork sandwich with provolone at Dinic's. Juices at Four Seasons juice bar! Hard to find a spot to sit but i am good walking and eating..helps getvready for next tasting!

This place was crazy on New Year's Eve. I highly recommend you not bringing your stroller here. Use a baby/toddler carrier if you can. 

I don't remember the name of the place but the beef jerky spot is hands down my favorite place to stop by.

Foodie heaven.  This is my crews go to after a fun night out on the town.  Sometimes the hours seem to be a little funky but it's worth the wait.  My fav is all the dessert spots.  4 stars because it's so damn crowded though.

AWESOME spot. So many food places along with a few alcohol spots.
Only complaint was the amount of people. This place was a zoo and was almost near impossible to walk. However, once you made your way through, it was fine. I had Tommy DiNic's and it's safe to say it was one of the best sandwiches from 2018.
It was Italian Style pulled pork, long hots, and provolone. The sandwich had so much flavor. I would absolutely get again and if I head back to the market, I would probably STILL order Tommy DiNic's!
Its alright, way too packed for me though. My office is nearby so i go for lunch every now and then. Don't come around then or the weekends unless you want to feel cramped in. Leave the room for me

I've visited this Philly icon a handful of times over the years.  This time around, I broke the most essential cardinal rule:  'Come hungry.'  Indeed.  You see, a couple hours before, I'd stopped with hubby and kid at John's Roast Pork.  A meal I'd ultimately regret, but that's for another review.  Point is, I was still so f***ing full, the mere sight of all the food here made me feel a wee bit queasy.  I tried to power through, though. I really did:

Miller's Twist:  I've eaten Pretzels from an Amish Market before, but not this particular one.  Happily, the classic Pretzel we chose did not disappoint. I have a secret (well, maybe not so much now) thing for Auntie Ann's Pretzels and this was an elevated, buttery, soft, warm version of that.  Even in my semi-nauseous state, that was clear.  We'd ordered some cheese sauce for dipping and both hubby and kid declared, "This tastes just like butter and not in a good way!" I'll concede they were right.  It was more fatty tasting than cheesy. I'd go with Mustard next time.

Smucker's Grill:  Since I knew from previous disappointment that the Amish stands tend to close earlier than many of the others here, I'd made a point of looking up the hours.  According to the official Reading Terminal site, on Thursdays, this stand closes at 5pm.  So imagine my chagrin when we were told at 4:30 ish that they were no longer serving.  After explaining that the stated hours indicated otherwise, they were very accommodating about whipping up a Pot Roast Sandwich for us.  I asked them to add horseradish cheese, sauteed onion, and horseradish.  We wound up eating this after our two hour drive back home to Brooklyn and were shocked at how delicious it was!  I can only imagine how good this is freshly made and warm.  

This was all we could um... stomach on this visit...  But fwiw, have tried the famed donuts from Beiler's and while they're fun to experience once, I'd say there are way better ways to spend your dessert calories in Philly.  DiNic's on the other hand...  That Roast Pork Sandwich is worth everything.

Random Thoughts:  At 3pm, this place was bordering on annoyingly crowded, but by 4pm, it was downright pleasant.  This also happens to be when three hour street parking kicks in v. one hour. We were able to find a spot on N. 12th. Street, right near the entrance.   I believe there are also a couple nearby lots, including at the Hilton Garden Hotel, that with a validated minimum purchase, only charge a few bucks for two hours.

Bottom line:  If you don't like this Market, which is the soul of Philly in so many ways, then you're just not doing it right.  Go at a less crowded off time.  And since all the various options can feel overwhelming, read through some reviews to help narrow down your picks.  In this particular case, at least, Yelp is your friend.:)

Awesome place, so much variety!! Reminds me of the markets in Italy
I buy all my groceries from here but also bring my family and friends for brunch when they're visiting from out of town.
The only con I have about the place is that it's super crowded sometimes, especially on Sundays.

This Market is a must when you are in Philly. Come hungry- you will want to try everything. I suggest sharing with friends- that way you can try more of the amazing food offerings. This place is often very crowded- be ready for crowds. Come early. Many places run out of their most popular items. 
I always head to the melt craft sandwich shop in the back. My friend and I shared the special Fig-goat about it- fresh goat cheese, Granny Smith apples, and fig jam. As well as the Brielle- made with Brie, cranberry chutney, caramelized onions, and pine nuts. Sandwiches are served with homemade potato chips. 
We also filled up on yummy donuts and fresh, strong coffee. 
We were staying in the hotel across the street- so not sure how parking is. So convenient for us- as soon as we were the least bit hungry again- we could run across the street to eat more yummy food. 
We will be back. 
Loved the live Christmas  music while we shopped and dined.

First stop in Philly. Right next to the Greyhound station.

Very old traditional American feel kind of market.
Deli shops, bakery, dinner etc.

Crowd looks older and I guess locals eat here too?

Quick stop for a quick bite, got an apple pie kind of thing from one of the Amish place.

The dish was ok, but guess it's good to try something traditional when in Philly.

Love this place ! Great food shopping and restaurant ! Its right in the middle of Philly. Theres certain things in philly that are musts to do. The zoo , the museums , Penn's landing, and the Reading terminal market ! Weve always had great food there. The cheesesteaks are so delicious. Awesome !

Love come here every time I visit my brother. 

You can find any type of food you like, sweet or savory. Even buy your grocery from here. Some stalls are cash only, while others takes card. 

It is street parking.

There is a cheese shop that I love to get my cheese at and the famous 4th street cookie was delicious! I want to try the gumbo at this cajun stall and another that sells duck.
This is the coolest place! Basically an indoor farmers market. We had an amazing Philly cheesesteak with a pretzel bun. So good!

The only thing I would buy here is flowers.  
No way would I buy food or eat here.
Look around; you'll see why.

One of the most amazing place in Philadelphia. The globally inspired food -- available for breakfast, lunch, dinner and dessert as well as for snacking -- is the main draw, while butchers, bakers, chocolatiers, cheesemongers and produce vendors offer food, ingredients and goods for sale.

From scrapple and samosas to soul food and smoothies, Reading Terminal Market is such a fantastic place to eat that it can be tough to choose what to get. So here are 10 of our favorite things to eat at Reading Terminal Market, the nation's oldest continuously operating farmers' market.

Really not impressed. 
Being new to the city, I had heard this was a place to see. I've lived near and frequented many places like this: SF Ferry Terminal, Pike's Place in Seattle, Cleveland's West Side Market, Denver's The Source. This is like any of those, but with less diversity, dirtier, and with lower quality offerings. 

We came on a Friday morning so the crowds were not terrible. The Lancaster vendors looked to have the tastiest things in the whole place, and they weren't so concerned with everything looking absolutely perfect, like so many other booths. To me, perfection is not appetizing, it just looks like cardboard. As other reviewers have said, the feel of the place as a whole was not clean. We saw a mouse run in front of us while browsing in the bulk/spice store. Sadly I do not think this is rare in the Philadelphia area, but I will not help normalize that poorly managed behavior by patronizing a dirty business. Needless to say we skedaddled.

Last up, we went looking for produce. I had heard that this was one of the best "farmers markets" in the country. I think people who say that are confused. There were two produce vendors, one much larger than the other. One of them was offering disgusting, old, very VERY wilted leaf lettuces, a clue that they either don't understand their offerings or that they just don't care. The other had a much larger selection, but nothing unique. Bell peppers, citrus fruits, etc. Nothing you wouldn't find at a regular grocery store.

I came to this place hoping for new and interesting. I left disappointed and thoroughly disgusted.

A must see if you are in this part of Philadelphia.    Right across the street from the convention center has what seems like hundreds of different vendors of every kind of food you can think of.  I could eat in there every day for a year and still not try everything.  I only wish it was open for dinner.
Best place to get what ever u want, you don't need any other store besides this place, food, groceries, did I say food !!!
Great place to go for any visitor to the city. Lots of food options and very nice shops. You can find anything here! A great mix of the culture Philadelphia has to offer.
I love Reading Terminal . The food is fresh and delicious. Just hate the parking lots.

Wonderful place! The atmosphere is very enthralling. 
Foods and smells are everywhere. I love the Dutch corner place, it's really good. They have some sandwiches and desserts you should try. I tried the pretzel shop and it was awesome as well.

Food markets are like heart beat of a city and if you want to understand the pulse of a city, visit to food markets should be a must. This was one of my favorite places in Philadelphia. Only only complain is that is closed at 6 in the vending which is too early. MArket has its roots from 1800s and there are few merchants whose 3rd or 4th generation is running the place. That only happens when you are passionate about what you do. There are about 80 vendors and each and every vendor has something different to offer. One gets so much variety under one roof. There are about 11 Amish eating places which should definitely not be missed. Few vendors are cash only, so come prepared.

The hot apple dumpling from Dutch Eating Place. The best meal in Reading Market. That's it. Skip the mediocre cheesesteaks and the overhyped donuts and come straight here. 

Order at Dutch Eating Place's register and grab a table elsewhere to skip their line. The dough surrounding the smooth apple is the softest dough I've ever had, so buttery and thick and delicious, dipping in their divine, sweet applesauce. 

5 stars!!!!!!!

Whenever friends visit from out of town, I take them here. If you live in Philly and haven't been, you're a fool. There are so many options for food and much more. Reading Terminal is great for eating and for shopping and wandering. Some standouts are the Dutch Eating Place and Hershel's Deli, though you really can't go wrong.

Foodie heaven!!! If you live nearby or just visiting the Philly area... definitely a great place to check out! Give yourself a few hours so you can walk around and check out all the vendors. Definitely come hungry, as you will have soooo many options for food. They have lots of produce, meats and dairy to do your grocery shopping too. I always try to shop local to support the small local businesses!

Be prepared to be elbow to elbow with people if you go during the weekend hours. But other than that, be patient because it's worth it! 

With the food placard, they have a select number of seats either at the counter or a few tables and chairs. But if you walk in more towards the back middle of the market, there is open seating like a cafeteria style place to sit! 

Have fun and try lots of foods!

Such an awesome market.  I currently live in Seattle but am contemplating a move to Philadelphia and am so happy I checked Reading Terminal out on a recent visit.  We are so spoiled to have Pike Place Market here, but knowing that Philly has such a great market - which is easily on par with Pike Place - is reassuring.  The farmer's produce section is sort of small, but the staggering variety of hot food/meal vendors more than makes up for it.  The wife and I will certainly enjoy Reading Terminal as much as we enjoy Pike Place now.
Great place to check out if you're new to the city. Also a good place to bring visitors. Lots of food options and a bar inside.

An absolute must for anyone (foodie) who loves to eat! An institution in Center City Philadelphia it has an absurd variety of merchants with a wonderful ambiance. You will not be disappointed really - there is something for everyone! I have many favorite vendors there! I no longer work near there and I miss it terribly; however, I try to get there at least once a month.

Reading terminal market is a fun time for philly locals and tourists alike! The prepared food is great and they have a market for locals! They have everything from poultry marts, to world wide cuisine to bakeries!

This place is foodie heaven, if that's what you're looking for. So many different stalls offering a wide array of cuisines are available, but stay away or have a flexible schedule if you want to avoid crowds. I've never tried as soon as they open, but I know that midday is not too terrible, but I've only been on the weekend. I suspect it's not as bad during the week. If you're trying to get something specific though I would probably avoid going closer to closing (5 or 6PM) because they could run out of whatever you're going for. This place is just jam packed with people and for good reason! Most people have already done their research of places to hit up while visiting so if you haven't you'll know what you have to get by looking at the lines near these places.
The places that I have tried are Beiler's, Bassetts, Sang Kee, Shanghai Gourmet and Dinic's (of course). Haven't regretted anything here, so far! 

It can get a little stressful trying to navigate through the aisles with hoards of people walking every which way.
They have a great selection of foods ranging from savory to sweet and from chinese food to Amish. I would probably just take cash here to be safe seeing as a lot of the stalls could be cash only or have a card minimum. There also isn't that much seating compared to the amount of people there are. If it's nice outside, looking for a park bench or eating outside somewhere isn't a bad idea, but for the colder or rainy times hovering around the tables looking for parties that are almost done may be your best option. Just keep in mind that there may be 3-5 other groups of people doing the same thing.

All in all, this is a great place to check out if you're in Philly either for the first time or revisting. There are so many options of great food in one hub. Just be prepared to wait, a lot of crowds and limited seating.
We had the rib place which was pretty solid. Donut place was pretty good,lots of options.  Some other spots looked appetizing as well
This is my favorite place for fruits vegetables an hot roast beef and pork sandwiches
Good variety of food and shops.  Parking is a bear most of the time but great place to head while in philly

When I lived in Phillie, this was my go-to spot for fresh, homegrown veggies, local poultry, meats and fish.  In 30 years, the farmers market movement has caught up!  Now, its my go-to meeting spot for friends visiting the city, or lunch stop when I am working downtown.
The best way, bar none, to sample the tastes of the Philadelphia region and Pennsylvania, and be sure you are supporting local farmers and cooks.

Great place for food. Good people everywhere.  Homeless do come in and beg but not as bad as other places in the area.  Will be very crowded during peak times (lunch). A lot of people familiar with the area use it
OMG! Choices galore. If you don't find something you like, shame on you. I enjoyed the Indian restaurant Nanees Kitchen - Salmon and Curried cabbage.

You could go there a million times and always have something new to eat. Never disappoints and besides lunch time it's pretty relaxing to sit and enjoy your food. The donut place is my favorite and the roast beef place is my second. Really easy access from suburban station.
Wide variety of food to choose from! Got some gumbo at the cajun place to die for. Pies from the Dutch, olives from the creamery, duck, gyros excellent.

One of the best places in Philly! So much to choose from, so much to see. I love the fact that you can buy a beer and walk around. 
Weekdays are obviously less crowded than weekends, but any day is a good day. Choose from an array of different cuisines (I recommend the burgers and tacos) or if head over to the bakery for some awesome sweet treats. 
I love the fact that there are fresh fruits and veggies at a VERY favorable price. Also, a sweet german lady sells some beautiful artwork of Philly landmarks. I got some beautiful coasters of the area. 
AMAZING PLACE! 10/10 recommend.
GO. Eat. Repeat. Buy stuff to take home. Eat. Repeat. Food the way it was when this world was young; fresh, vibrant & diverse.

The last time I visited Reading Terminal Market was over 10 years ago, when I was in middle school. Even at such a young age, I knew this place was special. The thing I remember most from that time was an ice cream cone that was bigger than my head at the time, but you better believe I polished off that entire thing! Now, coming back as an adult, I was able to appreciate Reading Terminal Market in all of its full glory. Over the past few years, fancy, often overpriced food halls have become more popular, but Reading Terminal Market embraced that concept years ago, and is quite reasonably priced. There are upwards of 30 vendors offering everything from meals to dessert to groceries and various Amish delicacies. It is always extremely crowded on weekends and at lunchtime on weekdays, so if you can go during off-peak times, you will have the best experience! Keep in mind that this is not a fancy restaurant, and not necessarily the cleanest, most modern interior, but the food is great and the prices can't be beat!
Great market place always busy if you're in that. I am not, which is why I gave four stars. Enjoy!
My favorite place to lunch in the city. Its just so hard to decide what to eat! I always take people from out of town, its always a big hit. I always get a warm soft pretzel brushed with butter!

I come here often, especially for the Beilers Donuts! They're made fresh daily, have endless amounts of flavor, and will leave you wanting to come back.

Pro tip - buy a 6 or more and they'll cost $1 per donut! That's less than Dunkin for much higher quality.

Lesson learned. 
Never go on a Sunday.
Many stands were closed. 
The crowds were over the top and the baby stroller crews were rude. 
I may update at a later time when I've visited without the raging hordes. 

Having said that, we did find several stands open without the above mentioned issues. A nice Cheese stand, a bakery and Condiment where the clerk was actually helpful and not preoccupied with his Saturday night date recap (cheese place) or too busy to make any suggestions (bakery) - maybe she thought we were to fat already. 

Im leaving a separate review for the diner we tried. 

I get that people working there are probably over worked & under paid but IF I was a tourist instead of a new local I'd not be inclined to return. 

We are planning to go on a weekday soon & hope we have better results.

Too crowded. Dirty. Meh vendors (tried four of them.. Terminis was the best of the lot) Everything is ridculously overpriced. Two burgers, two drinks.. $33. Only to take the greasy, mediocre burgers to filthy tables you have to wlak in circles to find empty. Pass.

Love, love love it! There was so much to offer, including cheese-steaks of course! There was a performance of  a DJ with a dance battle. Little girls were rapping! It was so great! We didn't wait long for any lines or for seating. I tried both a Philly cheese-steak and the Cajun restaurant--both delicious. I wish I could have spent more time in there, but I did not have the time.
Something for everyone here. Southern fried chicken, breakfast bagels, crepes, smoothies, Italian pastries, so much to choose from. Fantastic experience.

A big girl's paradise. Food galore.  Weekend adventure. Sweet tooth island.  Everything you've read about how awesome this place is- its true!

Tip for parents- leave the bulky strollers at home. It can get very crowded and a headache to maneuver a big stroller or jogger

It's hard to give Reading Terminal Market a solid review because of all of the variety. Variety is the best word to describe everything about the market. There is all kinds of things, all kinds of quality, all kinds of people. You can get Chinese food, cookies, cheese, BBQ, salad, bagels, produce, and basically anything else you want there.

Sometimes on the weekends the crowd is a lot to handle. It is sometimes shoulder to shoulder, violating fire codes kind of crowded. Other times it isn't quite as bad. There is one cookie place - I forget what it is called - it always has a line that goes all the way through the market on the weekends. If your intention is to go to a famous cookie place, that's probably it. You should get there early.  

The crowd is as diverse as the food. The destination is one of the biggest tourist attractions in Philadelphia. You see people from all over the world coming to try the food. I think the diversity is one element of it that makes it really special. 

The best part of the market is the quality of food. Some of it is just really really good. I definitely recommend coming hungry and trying a few different places. My favorite is downtown cheese. They have great cheeses and let you try before you buy.

There's so much variety, if you can't find something, it's just due to your own indecisiveness or because it all looks pretty good. It's a market, so expect what you would at Chelsea Market or another big vendor emporium. The middle eastern and greek food spots are my favorite here, and the ice cream/chocolate vendors are a great way to finish off the lunch stop!

If you don't like crowds or pushing around like you're in Manhattan, you probably won't want to spend much time in here. It's worth a couple laps to decide what you want to get, so if you can handle it, I recommend you take your time and get adventurous.

This review has nothing to do with the food there and is solely about a WONDERFUL employee, Cheron Henson. It was my parents first time visiting here and it was quite crowded. We finally found a high table to stand at while we ate our lunch. Cheron was sitting nearby and we struck up a conversation with her and it lead to the most fun personal tour ever! She brought us around to all the stations of a free alcohol tasting with vodkas, ciders, limoncellos, and more, which we never would have found tucked in the corner of the market if it wasn't for her. While she couldn't drink herself as she was on the job, she took the time to make sure we were all having fun! And it lead to my dad buying a delicious chocolate caramel beverage from the limoncello place. Cheron even made sure we were entered into the free raffle giveaway. She was so sweet and when we were about to leave we had a group hug!

READING TERMINAL MARKET IS A MUST!!! My first time in philly I was eager to go to the market. When I finally arrived I was pleasantly overwhelmed. They have every kind of food you could imagine. As well as other products. In the two days we were there we went four times. So much good food!!

I come here often, especially for the Beilers Donuts! They're made fresh daily, have endless amounts of flavor, and will leave you wanting to come back.

Pro tip - buy a 6 or more and they'll cost $1 per donut! That's less than Dunkin for much higher quality!

Always a winner for a quick bite to eat we're sit down at the bar and have a good beer never a bad moment of any terminal. This trip around all I had was a smoothie but it was well worth the wait in line excellent quality excellent service. I will be returning to the wedding party tomorrow Market whenever I am downtown Philadelphia

This place has a magical place within my heart, it has all the amazing options, if not more, of Chelsea Market in NYC but with spirit and old age feeling. 

Cheese sandwich to die for, yep! Authentic Indian with a twist, you bet! Cajun food that will leave you bewildered and grabbing for water, definitely! This place has it all and with a group of people that can't agree, it's better than the UN at bringing you together. 

When my group of 12 ran off, we all ended up at the same three tables, sharing, laughing, and drinking a few good beers and mixes.

If you haven't been, go! If you have, revisit! You'll create a few good memories and have a fantastic and delicious time.

Having lived in Philly and then moved many times for work, I appreciate this market more than you know.   Lots of choices for breakfast, lunch and dinner.  You can walk aimlessly around with a cup of fresh made coffee and take in the multi-cultural possibilities.  Looking to cook?  You can pick from any beef, pork, poultry, or lamb cut you can imagine.  Need produce, bread, and desserts?  No problem, because this market has it all.  Wish I could transport this gem to Nashville!  They even have a bar inside.

Meh. We went at 1pm on a Sunday. It was so crowded it was hard to walk anywhere without losing each other. People were lined up 15+ people deep at each cash register to order food. If you love shiny objects, over crowding, and under performing this is the place for you. If you like out of the way, hidden gems, then walk past and go to ANY of the empty restaurants in the adjacent blocks.
It has amazing ice cream! Definitely worth try if u love ice cream as well as chocolate. Ez to buy seafood in large size(literally), too.

No Philly food experience is complete without the Reading Terminal. Whether you're foraging ingredients to make a great meal or you're grabbing some eats, the Terminal will set you right. 
All of the meat stands are great particularly La Divisa. Great raw fish is available as well. The produce from Iovine's is fresh, varied and affordable. 
Termini brothers, Bassets Ice cream, Beiler's donuts and the apple dumpling from the Amish counter will all satisfy your sweet tooth. 
For savory eats I love the oysters and soups from Pearl's, the roast pork from Dinic's (as much a Philly sandwich as a cheese steak) Sang Kee's duck/ wonton noodle soup, Cajun food from Beck's, ribs and wings from Diener's. Really, you can't go wrong and there are a ton of options. Amazing place. A must see and feel if you're visiting.

I am a huge fan of the Reading Terminal Market and frequent this spot whenever I am in the area. I always bring guests visiting from out of town for a meal and to gander at all the local goods. It's a great spot for people who are in the mood for different foods, since there are so many amazing options. I would definitely recommend this spot to anyone who hasn't been before!

This place was PACKED on a Saturday afternoon. I will never return with that many people coming and going. I was unable to take my time and check everything out because I couldn't stand being around that many people. Not all places take credit you must have cash to make some purchases. I have been here many years ago and it was very cool. Just a little too populated for me. Maybe it would be better to go during the week.
Best in the Nation if not the world.  And you can there which helps you avoid over shopping.
A wide, delicious variety of food. Not just restaurants, but shops too! I feel engulfed in culture whenever I'm there. Stop by if you can!
A staple in Philadelphia food culture. You must eat here when visiting. If you don't you never really visited Philadelphia.

Theres such a large variety inside. You have more than enough options for food, beverage, and miscellaneous. I normally go for food and/or beverage and have not been disappointed yet. This is a must go to.
Beck seafood and gumbo, AMAZING. Busy place, but a lot to see. If you find a seat, I suggest you take it.
What's not to love, it's a Philadelphia institution. Whether you're shopping for your groceries or just stopping in for a quick bite, you'll find exactly what you need. Lunch time is very busy.

This place is a foodie  mega pick it has from Peking duck 2 beef and cheese just some of the best cheesesteaks you can ask for has a farmers market inside and a meat market tomahawk steaks are humongoustook half a day just to see all the stuff I gained 15 pounds every time I visit

Really cool place that exhibits both a touristy and local feel. If you're looking for any kind of unusual or exotic meats or produce that your local grocery store doesn't carry, you're sure to find it here. Went during Presidents' weekend, and this place was packed. It was very difficult to find seating. And for the most part, you are walking shoulder-to-shoulder with other people. A great location to find artisan-made, locally grown, family recipe goods. The terminal also has a rich history that you can learn more about by reading the walls. Personally, we came for ice cream, and it did not disappoint. You could easily spend hours walking around and looking at all the shops. From exquisite chocolate and desserts to chicken hearts, you'll find whatever you're looking for here. As long as you don't mind being part of a massive crowd, you'll enjoy your visit because there is something for everyone.

I love Reading Terminal, it's obviously a Philly classic and everyone needs to go at least once. (Just make sure you're able to handle tight spaces and crowds!) There is so much to look at and eat, you almost don't know where to start. I also think it's kind of charming how easy it is to get lost, it adds to the character, that's for sure! I definitely want the tradition to be preserved, but it would be great to strike a balance between the historic authenticity and more contemporary innovative food options. You're surrounded by animal products there, and I think it could be awesome to update some more for the growing plant-based population. I think there might be one vegan stand occasionally but that's all I've seen so far. You can find vegan options, but it's not as easy as it could be with a few alterations or new vendors. That said, there are terrific whole food options for good prices at Iovine's and OK Produce!

MUST SEE!  You are a fool to come to Philadelphia and not stop here.   Seriously!  
Nuff said. That is all. Trust me. I have great taste.

Brought a group of 23 high school students here for lunch one day and dinner the next. What an amazing place. There is literally something for everyone. Ethnic food galore and something for any food allergy. Tons of food and drink options and so many privately owned restaurants with specialty homemade food items.  During busier times, seating gets very limited and lines can get pretty long but it's worth the wait. Some of the prices are inflated but it's what you'd expect for a prime tourist attraction, staple of Philly history and so many (not all) homemade food items.  Perfect place to bring a large group or a solo meal. I will definately be back!!

They have it all.  You can find literally anything here.  Good location to meet friends, everyone gets to order their favorite items from the various vendors, grab a seat and take in the atmosphere of the history of bygone days.   Fun, crowded, noisy, but always satisfying.

I visited the reading terminal market first on my trip to philly. THIS IS A MUST GO TO SPOT! Such a huge variety of different smells, foods and experiences! Definitely recommend grabbing yourself a map (look closely on the walls around the terminal). Downside is its PACKED! so many people! But there is open seating and bathrooms! (also little gift shops and lots of pamphlets around for the touristy types). Did notice some people playing live music outside!

Why in the world does Vegas not have a market like this!? 

When visiting Philly a trip to the Reading Terminal Market is an absolute necessity. Perusing all the aisles will make you hungry so be sure to bring your appetite. 

There are too many great food stalls to name but just know that whichever ones you choose will leave you feeling happy. I tried a number of different spots and each one was better than the one before it. 

It gets crowded on weekends, so plan accordingly.

So yea, go here!

The Reading Terminal Market (Pronounced as 'red', not 'reed') is a collection of restaurants, shops and stores that really could soak up an entire day here if you wanted it to.  Sadly we didn't have all day, and just a few hours, but I think we sampled a fair amount of what the Redding Terminal had to offer.  

Rather than list every store that's found at the market, i'll just list the locations we visited.  Those places were we visited were:

DiNic's Roast Pork and Beef
Flying Monkey
Old City Coffee inc
Termini Brother's Bakery
Beiler's pickle patch
Glick's rib shack

Again, by no way is my very small sample of the market a real representation of the market, but my tastebuds were happy and if/when I return to Philadelphia, i'll be back to the Reading Terminal Market to sample more of what this place has to offer.  

100% pay this place a visit, and bring your appetite!!

Reading Terminal Market deserves every 5 star review it gets as it has everything you need. It has a large selection of restaurants, cafes and delis and some of the best food you can get in the area, including DiNic's Roast Pork.

If you need good coffee, you'll find a place in the market. If you need a quality breakfast sandwich, you'll easily find a bakery or cafe that has one. Deli sandwich. Thai food. Pretzels. Donuts. So many good options in Reading Terminal Market.

Overall: This is a must visit place in Philadelphia and it never disappoints. Just be prepared for busy lines, especially during the weekends.
How can you not love this place.  There is something for everyone, I always try to make a visit and bring home food for my friends/family.  Delicious

One of the touristy place to visit in Philadelphia. I still haven't been able to thoroughly explore this place, which shows that this place has much to offer. They have variety of stores ranging from souvenir gift shops to chocolatiers to food. It's fun just to walk around.

This is a foodie's dream. So many vendors and food options. From cheesesteaks to bakeries, there are options for everyone. The prices at most of the vendors are super affordable considering its a hot location/tourist attraction. Try to visit during the week as the weekends can get mobbed and it's hard to check out the vendors without being pushed. Seating is not ample so make sure to scope out a table in the center before getting food!
A conglomerate of all foods from all cultures. If you are a foodie, you can't visit Philly and not come to Reading Terminal.

What is there not to love about this magical place?!?! It is one of the best places in philly to grocery shop, so many incredible vendors. Everything is extremely well priced. I am always amazed at how much I save shopping there verses Whole Foods. Also, they have some of the best prepared food stands anywhere!! Whatever you want, you can have. From Peking duck to creole, to brisket sandwiches piled 8 inches high. I love love love it there.

Benefit for the Market: this is an annual event to benefit this wonderful Philadelphia tradition. Although pricey, the food is amazing (don't eat for like 3 days before) and the drinks plentiful. As this has progressed, they have gotten wiser to having more water and seltzer on hand - smart. So the evening; the libations: good with a superior assortment of beers, sad assortment of wind and even a coffee roaster....noice!

Music: jazz and cool not too loud
Dancing: till late and amazing
Food: wonderful

Bottom line: maybe not an every year thing but certainly worth a 'go'
Food delicious always crowded but well worth it. Love the meat market section and the soup food is to die for. The bakery is my fav as well

If you have out-of-town visitors and you want to show them "Philadelphia", take them to the Reading Terminal for coffee and lunch, then walk over to City Hall and then down the Parkway towards the Art Museum. There, I just planned every single out-of-town, show-the-parents-where-you-live visit you'll ever have.

If they come back and insist on doing something different, fine. Take them to the Reading Terminal for coffee and lunch, then walk over to Independence Mall and do whatever it is that people do over there. Bam! I just planned every repeat, you-did-such-a-good-job-showing-us-around-the-first-time visit you'll ever have.

Damn!? They're back again? Fine. Take them to dinner anywhere near 13th and Walnut on Friday before going to a show somewhere on Broad Street (google: Wilma Theater). The next morning, take them out for coffee and brunch at the Reading Terminal Market.

If, at this point, you haven't figured out what is going on here: move to Camden.

Absolutely LOVE this place! If you come on the weekend mid-day, be prepared to battle the masses, as so many others apparently love this place as well. Excellent variety of food choices and markets (meats, produce, sweets, condiments). My favorite two places are Dinics for roast pork sandwiches (Amazing!) and Iovines produce (grab an apple, wash In their customer sink, and enjoy on your walk. A must stop when in the city.
Amazing time at the market, awesome experience but it was packed. Enjoyed my time!! Great place to go if you are with a large group of people and they are not all sure what they want to eat.
I looooooove this place , will miss it once I move but till then I'm just going to enjoy it every day

There are two reasons to visit. One is the history of the building. Two is the FOOD. You can enjoy both at the same time! The only downside is that you're not going to be able to try everything you want to try in one visit. Here's my suggestion, if you have an Amish Market near your home, pass over the Amish food for other traditional Philly favorites. I found I liked the goods my Amish Market sells better than what I found here. BUT Dinic's roasted pork sandwich was something I'll never forget! (I'd also pass on Basset's for Franklin's Fountain or Scoop Devilles.) My next visit, I want to try the grilled cheese place and maybe get some oysters!

You can really never go wrong with Reading Terminal.  A particularly favorable option if you have a group of people with different palettes - there's something for everyone! My most recent try was Becks Cajun kitchen, which was pretty good (a little overpriced) - but other favorites include Keven Parker's Soul Food Cafe and Beilers Doughnuts. I'm not sure of what healthy/vegetarian/vegan food options are available - there seems to be a lot of fast/gluttonous food. To me, produce is overpriced too, but a convenient offering of fresh fruits & veggies for those living in the city. 

It can be overwhelming, especially if you're a bit indecisive and on an empty stomach. For that reason, if possible, I would avoid peak lunch hours because of the heavy crowds. 

It seems like they're constantly under construction here. The building is historic, but it's nice to see some updating  taking place where necessary and improvement of the facilities (bathrooms, ect...) Park at the garage across the street next to Panera and get your ticket validated!

Am I there only person from Philly who just started coming here about 2 years ago?
Everything looks and smells amazing. The lines are very long around lunch time (which is to be expected).
I really want to give RTM a solid try! When I worked in the area I went to Kevin Parkers for lunch a few times and it was good. Ive had Bassetts Ice cream and that was YUM! I've yet to give the Amish Bakery donuts a try. I have to come back with plenty of time and a pair of Yoga pants.

During my most recent visit to Reading Terminal Market, I heard a gentleman say "everything here smells so good" and that's when I realized that's just how I wanted to start this review - everything here really DOES smell so good. 

This market is a Philadelphia staple. Whether you're a local or a visitor, this is one of those places you just have to stop in to at least once. Whether you want to actually grab a meal, just take a walk around to see what all they have, or are looking to stock up on vegetables, fruits, meats, breads, or sweets, this is a great place to go to. Besides the delicious food, they also have some wonderful stands set up to buy great souvenirs and gifts. 

No matter what time of day you're visiting Reading Terminal, be prepared for a large crowd and lines. This is not the place to go to if you're crunched for time. I would recommend stopping in when you have time to spare. If this is your first time visiting, my other recommendation is to walk around the entire premise to see what all there is before you make any purchases. There are ample food options so it's nice to see what all they have to offer before making your decision. Just a few places that stand out to me include Meltkraft, Tommy DiNic's, Beiler's Bakery, Famous 4th Street Cookie Company, and Termini Bros Bakery. :)

If you're in or near Philadelphia, be sure to put Reading Terminal on your list of places to go to so you can take in just some of the greatness our city has to offer. Lastly, be sure to bring your camera/phone to take some photos and don't forget to bring along your appetite!
