Incredible food in a crammed location.

I am so torn about this review.  This market is iconic.  A part of me feels like everyone should go.  Another part of me feels like it was just too packed and you may be able to eat these foods with a well-curated Yelp list.  Thus my conflicted rating. 

We walked to Reading Terminal from our hotel near Independence Hall.  It was about a 20 minute walk.  We went on a Friday and arrived about 11.  The market had narrow aisles.  You regularly have to stand in line.  There are also many shops you will want to go and try their delicious foods.  You will be jostled around as you walk around.  The food goes from good to great.  

If you aren't in to huge crowds, this may not be the place for you.  If you are in to huge food markets and have a huge appetite, then belly on up.  You'll be in heaven.  We were both glad we went but aren't going to rush back.  It was just a little too much for us.

It's a really nice find in the city. Lots of Philly- style food here. Great for tourists. Hard to find seats anytime of the market hours. Located in the heart of Philadelphia. Would like to come here again.

We stopped in to have lunch on the recommendation of a few people.  There were a lot of food options, so many that it was difficult to decide what to eat.  There were 2 of us together and we each chose a different place to get our lunch.  Neither of us was disappointed with our choices.  That said, I don't know that this place would come to mind if people asked me for a recommendation on what to do in Philadelphia.  It was crowded and out of the way for us.  While our lunch was good, I'm sure we could have found a good lunch that was more convenient for us.  So I guess my recommendation would be to stop in if you're in the area, but don't go out of your way.

One of my absolute favorite places to go in the city! When my family comes to town for the holidays we always go there for lunch. The terminal holds a special place in my heart because my uncle and his father owned and worked at a butcher in the terminal, most of my older cousins worked in the terminal in the summers whether at the butcher shop, or another stall. My uncle died when I was very young, and soon after that the butcher closed. 

Another great place at the terminal is termini's bros bakery. The turkey place is a family fav. And there is a beer garden in there now and in front of the bar stools are name plates w the original merchants family names on them. Highly recommend
A huge place for different restaurants. Great for people that can't make up their mind on what cusine to eat. They have alot of different cusines and alot of outlets to satisfy your sweet tooth also.

Pretty much must stop for all foodies visiting Philly. There is a big lunch rush and then a lot of places close down so plan accordingly. Absolutely hit the Amish booths, both for pastries and hearty breakfast sammiches in the AM. From there just wonder around and try whatever looks good.
Love the atmosphere and the awesome food this place reminds me of the marketplace my grandfather and I visited so often in Puerto Rico

The Reading Terminal Market is one of America's largest and oldest public markets, housed since 1893 in a National Historic Landmark building.  The RTM offers the widest variety of restaurants under one roof, which includes a diverse variety of locally grown & exotic produce, locally sourced meats and poultry, plus some of the best seafood, cheeses, baked goods, ice cream and confections to be had on the East Coast!

If you are a foodie, then you can't miss a visit to the infamous Reading Terminal Market. I've been here numerous times over the years and I have yet to be disappointed. Don't miss the Amish Bakery, Beiler's, where at least the very least, you will experience some of the best PA Dutch home-style food in all of Pennsylvania!  I never visit Philly without taking advantage of an opportunity to snag a few Harvest Apple donuts from Beiler's! Best donut I've ever tasted!

My second favorite spot at RTM's has to be "The Original Turkey". It's like having Thanksgiving dinner every day! There are so many choices, you won't go home hungry! 

If you get a chance to buy a ticket to "Taste of Philly", you'll get your fill of cheese-steak, donuts, crepes, ethnic foods from all over the world, as well as some of the best desserts and confections to be found in the massive state of Pennsylvania!

The Reading Terminal Market is a favorite among locals and tourists with over 80 food vendors offering delicious eats that is perfect for lunch or dinner and even dessert. A foodie's paradise. 

The Reading Terminal Market is similar to the Grand Central Market in Los Angeles and The Pike Market Place in Seattle. But a little different in which all food vendors are inside, in an air conditioned place (which is a nice way to stay cool during the summer months). 

Although there are tables and chairs, I feel that there just isn't enough, especially if you come during peak time. My husband and I came on a Thursday, right before noon and as the time progressed, it was getting busier and busier. 

One major negative that I would have to say about this food market is that they close early, at 6 pm every day. If only they stayed open later so that you could grab a later dinner. But now that you know this, just make sure to plan your visit accordingly so that you don't miss out if you are visiting Philly for the first time. 

Please note that a lot of the vendors here do take credit card and there are clean restrooms available.

Reading Terminal Market is a must visit when in Philly. It's a market with tons of options ranging from diner food to groceries to sweets! Inside is where Beiler's donuts and Tommy DiNic's is located but there's definitely more things you can go and try out as well like the Cajun food! There's also a honey shop that has cheap honey sticks. It's definitely crowded inside but there are also tables inside.
A must see if you are visiting Philly. Great selection of food and places to eat.

At the time of writing this review, Reading Terminal Market (pronounced "Redding"), has over 5,100 Yelp reviews. That's a lot. It's easily one of the most-reviewed places I've visited. It's one of those popular "public" markets with a food hall and a bevy of vendors selling everything from fresh produce and flowers to handmade crafts and jewelry. A lot of big cities have them. Comparable markets include Chelsea Market in New York, the Ferry Building in San Francisco, and Pike Place Market in Seattle. In Atlanta, where I'm from, Reading Terminal Market ("RTM") reminds me most of Sweet Auburn Curb Market. New developments have popped up around the country in recent years that try to emulate a sort of old-school municipal market feel.

RTM is different because, unlike its newer counterparts, its atmosphere is genuine and not manufactured. The market opened in 1893, making it one of the country's oldest. Some of the market's vendors have been around since the very beginning, over 100 years, like Bassetts Ice Cream. You can find them just inside one of the 12th Street entrances on the west side of the market. This is where we entered.

This is a Philadelphia hot spot and one of the most recommended places for out-of-towners to go. We visited over the weekend and the market was crowded with tourists and locals alike. It should definitely be high on any foodie's Philly to-do list. There are so many food stalls here and the selection is eclectic, from Amish-style rotisserie chicken, sourced regionally, from Dienner's Bar-B-Q Chicken to Peking duck from Sang Kee Peking Duck (an RTM outpost of a Philly Chinatown favorite).

In all, there are over 80 vendors packed onto one floor. They're classified into the following categories: bakeries, beverages, dairy & cheese; housewares, books, crafts, etc; meats & poultry, Pennsylvania Dutch (note the PA Dutch vendors are closed every Sunday), produce, restaurants, seafood, and specialty foods. The market is laid out in a grid with four large aisles going north-south, and 11 smaller aisles going east-west. There are a handful of communal seating areas (almost all seats were taken during our visit), restrooms (clean enough), and an attended welcome booth if you'd like to pick up a map and/or ask for recommendations. Some of the vendors also have their own dedicated seating.

A few recommendations:

1. Roast pork sandwich at Tommy DiNic's Pork & Beef. Perhaps the most popular vendor here. They offer wraparound counter service.

2. Pretzel from Miller's Twist. These are fresh-made, Amish-style pretzels. They're also known for their cheddar-jalapeno pretzel dog and breakfast foods. (Note: Miller's Twist is a PA Dutch vendor and is closed on Sundays.)

3. Scrapple from Down Home Diner. Also known as Pannhaas by the PA Dutch, this is basically pork scraps made into a savory pate. Reminds me of the Neese's liver pudding (livermush) I ate growing up in North Carolina.

Surprisingly, there's not really a well-known or recommended vendor for cheesesteaks here though there are some who sell them (e.g. Carmen's Famous Italian Hoagies & Cheesesteaks). Bring cash because some vendors, like Carmen's, are cash-only. A couple places that caught our eye that we didn't get to try were Pearl's Oyster Bar and Mueller Chocolate Co. (featured on Food Network).

There are two parking garages, one at 12th and Filbert (Parkway Garage) and the other at 11th and Arch (Hilton Garage). Signs posted at each entrance to the market advertised 2-hour discount parking with $10 market purchase and validation at the vendor.

If you're pressed for time in Philly, Reading Terminal Market is a great place to visit since there are so many vendors all in one place. If you're from out of town, be sure to visit the northwest corner of the market where all the PA Dutch vendors are located. They're unique.

Definitely a must see when you visit Philly. Very busy and something for everyone. From places with seating to takeout to vendors with merchandise. Will take awhile to snake through and see everything!

Unique in it's age and building, which is pretty cool. If you are a local a place to frequent and be proud of. As a visitor it was worthwhile and I'd stop again, but the variety and prices aren't much different from similar markets in DC, Lancaster, Chelsea in Nee York, etc.

Definitely a must see when you visit Philly. Very busy and something for everyone. From places with seating to takeout to vendors with merchandise. Will take awhile to snake through and see everything!

Unique in it's age and building, which is pretty cool. If you are a local a place to frequent and be proud of. As a visitor it was worthwhile and I'd stop again, but the variety and prices aren't much different from similar markets in DC, Lancaster, Chelsea in Nee York, etc.
Great place to go for lunch or breakfast and get a flair for Philly Foods. Best Grilled Cheese sandwiches. Also if a local and need to shop, some good choices for poultry, fish, meats, cheeses, etc.

I wish I could go there everyday so many things to choose from fresh meats and the chicken is so fresh you can see the difference the it looks. I love the Jamaican restaurant there food is delicious and the produce place is so cheap

If I had to live in Philly I would do most of my shopping here probably as they do have some great selections for meats, cheeses, pickles, deli items, seasonings, specialty items.  I enjoyed the Amish selections on sweets and would have eaten here too but needed to move along.  The crowd is off-putting to me but that is what it is there.  parking cost a ton so we walked from our hotel.  I made a poor selection on a philly cheesesteak stand and it wasn't anything special and there was no place to actually sit and eat.  I won't ever go back but it was worth a look-see.

Favorite place of all time!! Crazy chaotic but FULL of amazing variety!! Literally every type of cuisine you can think of, including an all natural beeswax stand AND a whole flower shop, grocery store and several breweries. By far the most memorable spot in Philly!

All I can say is Reading Terminal is just A1 as far as in anything regarding what you have a taste for. You want sweets like desserts it's a lot of shops that a satisfy your sweet tooth. You want food it's too many places for me to name. Just know you won't be disappointed.

My go to lunch place in Philly when I am in a dilemma as to what to eat for lunch! They have a variety of options from house made bread to Philly famous cheesesteaks to mouth watering vegetable lomein. It also allows you to buy groceries while you are waiting for you lunch to be prepared !

This place a must visit when in Philly! It's an indoor food market and has anything and everything you could want! Cajun, Chinese, American, Indian, Thai, bake shops - everything!!!! 

Some of my favorite places - Beiler's donuts (coconut custard donut is to die for), Becks Cajun (gumbo is great), Miller's Twist (jumbo pretzel dog with cheese), Sangkee (roasted duck with lo mein), crepes (forgot the name of the place.

WOW! there is something to be said about a place that has been open since 1893! Incredible. So many vendors, so many delicious choices. Many classics are there. Many of these vendors have been featured on many travel and food networks. Not one vendor disappoints. beiler's bakery and donuts are both a must! Their donuts are delicious, we bought a half dozen and we devoured them (what diet, am i right?! Haha).  Spatro's who has been there for 72yrs, is delicious as well, i had a steak egg and cheese sandwich, it was like a breakfast version of a NY chopped cheese. There's just so much see and taste. Take your time, and arrive with empty stomachs!

Unbelievable good food. Virtually anything you could want to eat.  Hershel's has THE BEST PASTRAMI IN PHILLY.  Probably a line up but that's why. It's sooo good.  Really great alternatives to chose from even if your not a pastrami lover like me!

Love coming here, but it makes me feel like a tourist. But other than that, there's so much of a variety. and there's also a mini farmers market to get fresh veggies and fruit. there's always something new to try but the con is there rarely anywhere to sit and don't go on a weekend. you'll get too annoyed with how crowded it is, where you barely have room to walk

Great stop if your traveling through Philly. I warn you be prepared for the hustle and bustke of the lunch hour and after work shop. Hut there are many jewels within the reading terminal market you can find everything from artisan wears from across the world to Amish pastries and Philly cheesesteaks.

A wonderful place to spend a few hours. (And if you love food, you'll definitely be spending a few hours.) Beware though, as it tends to get extremely crowded. There is such a great variety of food here and so much of it is so delicious! From a variety of ice creams to Indian food to classic gumbo to fancy corndogs with toppings to Puerto Rican food to banana pudding with special flavors... the list just goes on and on. You can even get fresh, smoked bones and pig ears for your dog here. This is a definite must-visit if you're anywhere within a 20 mile radius of Philadelphia. You'll find yourself coming back quite often, as I do. The only bad thing is that it's often incredibly crowded, and because you're in such a crowded place, the seating area where you can eat food at the tables is usually extremely dirty from people leaving behind trash and crumbs and messes constantly.

This place is crowded as hell. I got some expensive shrimp raw shrimps but they were jumbo and 2lbs ribs cooked. All in all the food was good just the crowd is a lot this is not a place for one who doesn't do well with crowds.
We are from Baltimore and our own Lexington Market just doesn't compare.  Fantastic variety, service, cleanliness.

An incredible selection of food available! The workers kept everything very clean so me and my friends had many clean options to eat on. Would recommend this place to anyone who loves to have a wide variety of food options!

One of the worlds greatest markets! This is the kind of space that alters your home purchases because you don't want to be too far away. If I lived closer it would be a daily stop. If you have never been, you can't even imagine the level of awesome you are missing.

Reading Terminal Market far exceeded my expectations! You can find anything you could ever need- from baked goods to fresh produce to tasty meats. I went to Reading Terminal in search of kabobs to grill for dinner. After walking around the entire market, I was unable to find them on display. I inquired with the staff at Giunta's Prime Shop. They offered to make them fresh-specifically for me! The staff truly went above and beyond! The kabobs included chicken, red onion, green peppers, red peppers, and mushrooms. They were absolutely delicious and made for the perfect weekday meal. I will definitely make a meal from Reading Terminal Market again!

Love the Terminal Market. Whenever I come to Philly on the weekend, I make sure to stop buy for a sandwich or some sweets. Great options for food- read to eat or buy to prepare at home. It is a must do in Philly.
Best lunch spot in Philly! There is something for everyone and a great fresh seafood market.
They have a little of everything. If they don't have it there guaranteed you probably didn't need it anyway!
Huge selection of high quality food! Love each place in here. Very fresh food that's the best philly can offer. Also a tourist attraction in itself

This is the best tourist spot in Philadelphia! You will have plenty of options for food, delicacies, and other merchandise. The products are a little pricey likely from the rent of the stores but rest assured, they have quality products. They have a wide variety of food ranging from Thai, Greek, American, Chinese, Italian, etc. The list goes on and on. I recommend you come early as it gets very crowded during lunch time. They close also early at 6pm. Tables and chairs may be difficult during lunch time so better get your food to go. Restrooms are also clean at the corner of the market. Read through the history of the place near the restrooms - pretty interesting.

If you can't find it here, you ain't looking! From fresh foods to baked to ready to eat. And let's not forget the spirit tastings!!! Lemon cello is everything...even the beet vodka is interesting. I have been told the best Philly Cheesesteaks live here. If I lived here... Where I would shop
simply the best cannoli you'll ever have! i never bother with a box either because i always end up eating it immediately. delicious!
Have never seen SO many choices of foods in my life. You could spend weeks trying different things at one vendor. And there were SO many vendors!
The best food market on the East coast. Jeep up the great food .. especially the Meat counters!
So many things to try, so much good food. I highly recommend a visit there no matter where you are in the city!

They have pretty much any food here that you could imagine, and with a fun and energetic atmosphere. Great place to get groceries for home, a dine in meal, or delicious dessert! Plus some cool other shops selling some non-food items. Would highly recommend for both tourists and locals.

If you aren't sure what to eat, then stop by Reading Terminal Market. They have a great selection of various foods all in one location. From burgers to sushi to donuts,  cupcakes,  etc.  Everyone will be able to find something they like. They have seating scattered throughout the market but you have to act fast as the seats get taken pretty quickly.
Best location for meat in Philadelphia = Giunta's. Ask for Brazilian-style steak and you will be happy. Super trust-worthy.

I LOVE THIS PLACE. It's one of the best markets I've been to. You can't really go wrong with anything you get here although you could look on Yelp for recommendations. In LA, we have the Grand Central Market which is similar but smaller. The food and variety here is much better though. It can get pretty crowded especially during lunch hour. As for parking, there's parking structures that has validation but you still pay about $5 for 2-hour parking (validation comes with minimum $10 purchase).
Crazy place like something out of Harry Potter but you're gonna find something good to eat

I didn't actually get a chance to eat anything here because I was busy stuffing myself with pizza and Philly cheesesteak elsewhere, BUT I loved this place and would absolutely want to return. There are so many different places to eat here and it's both overwhelming and invigorating. Really an emotional rollercoaster as I wandered through the aisles - I was simply bewildered at how many delicious places there were to eat. The whole atmosphere is warm and lively, and this would be a really fun place to go with a group of people and try as much stuff as you can. They have literally every food type here and even a grocery store with extremely fresh looking meat and produce. Truly a foodie heaven and I really want to go back.

Awesome huge market with a lot of food options. Don't come here looking for healthy choices, though. It's comfort food. The Amish fare is extra tasty and fresh. Whoopi pies and soft buttery pretzels were my favorite. Locals, tourists and conventioneers all converge here.

Holy macaroni and everything else they sell there. Fresh scratch food it's like parking in front of 100 food trucks and having your choice of every type of Philadelphia fare you could imagine. Breakfast lunch and dinner every day if I could...

There's so many choices here! The aroma of the desserts and coffee is everywhere in this place. The grilled cheese is great and definitely need to come back again to try the other installments. Only down side is not enough seating
A great taste of everything that's good about food in Philadelphia.From soul food to fresh meats to sweets to vegan to the best Jewish deli I never get bored I discover something new every day

Love it here!

Everyone has to visit here even for one day!

Amish Pancakes, Beilers Donuts, Bassett's Ice Cream, to many to mention
If you can't find something to eat here... you are not hungry. Don't forget to tip the poor chap opening the door for you!

What. A. Market!

There are cuisines from all over the U.S. and the world.

Fresh, delicious desserts and baked goods.

Vegan and gluten-free options.

So many vendors packed into a fairly small space, yet despite the crowds it doesn't feel overly packed.  Yes, some places will get a line, but it moves along quickly enough.

Not only are their cuisines-a-plenty to be had at the various restaurants, there are also places to buy fresh meat, seafood, produce and groceries.

Restrooms are pretty clean and don't get obnoxiously crowded.

Plenty of nearby lots for parking, and yes, it's above a train terminal, so it's easily reached by public transportation.

One thing to note:  The Amish take their Sundays seriously.  Hence the booths run by Amish will be closed on Sunday.

This is a place you simply must hit when you visit Philly.

I love this place.  This was my second visit.  I thought the first visit in the summer of 2018 was really crowded because it was summer and there was an ice cream festival.  Nope, apparently it's like this all the time.  Nevertheless, it was an enjoyable visit.  I highly recommend to anyone who's in the area.  There are all types of edibles and beverages.  I stocked up on adult beverages and chocolate and had a wonderful lunch.

Overall a fun place to browse for food, drink, and local products. We ate roast pork at Tommy Dinic's, got some flavored banana puddings, and a cheesesteak stuffed pretzel from Miller's Twist. There's everything from baked goods, seafood, beeswax products, chocolates, cheesesteaks, meats and produce..
The list goes on. I've been here twice (weekends) and it's always packed. Even on the off hours (3pm). If you want to make a trip here make sure you do it before 6pm as they close early!

Reading Terminal is such a staple place to visit while in the city of Philadelphia.  They have tons of shops inside, mostly food.  Some of the shops inside are great!!!!  It is slightly pricey.   Parking is a nightmare if your driving. I wish they had discount parking or something.   Not enough seating to eat your food. But I know it's a lot of people who visit so I understand. It's definitely worth visiting and trying out some food.  I recommend catching a uber there!

Brand new to Philly, I hadn't a clue where I was nor what I was to do while the Mr. was at a conference?  Our hotel was RIGHT ACROSS the street from the Reading Market so we wandered over for lunch - and never left  I was there every day, sometimes for every meal! Read the Yelp reviews for the major stars like Pearl's Diner for fresh yummy seafood, DiNic's roasted pork sandwich rated BEST SANDWICH IN THE US by Food Network, Little Thai Markets curried salmon ($8 people -crazy!?) Carmen's Philly cheese steak, the Crepes - oh my, HUGE and delightful!! Bassett's ice cream - same location since the 1800s and DELICIOUS!! I could go on & on - fresh meats & seafood, produce, SO.MANY. Bakeries  Stop by - it will be a highlight of your trip!! AMAZING!!!!

This is the best market in town. The place offers cheapest items, fresh and baked goods. I come here quite often, the place is close and offers variety. The meat over here is always fresh.
It can be really crowded at times, however the wait is worth the quality. The breakfast over here is another plus. Good location, excellent variety.

I wish I could just take a larger shopping cart into this place and wheel everything home!  There is something for everyone here, all fresh made!  I have such a hard time deciding what to get every time we go!
I only wish there was a place like this closer to home!
I wish they hadn't built a convention center around it. But still a gem. Maybe Philly's greatest attraction.

Reading Terminal Market is a staple in Philadelphia with a 126 year history to boot. It's the nation's oldest outdoor market, though I'd consider it an indoor/outdoor market since it's enclosed in the infrastructure of the Philadelphia Convention Center. However when Reading Terminal opened in 1893 it most likely was outdoors, very much like local Farmers Markets which are set up throughout the Philly area, between April and September yearly.

What makes Reading Terminal special is it's  eclectic feel. There is something for everyone's taste, diet, preference. 

My fondest memories of Reading Terminal was of my 80 year old grandmother ( she lived to be 91!) catching the train from Media into Center City regularly to get her fresh fish. She only bought it from Reading Terminal.
So fun and versatile, many wonderful people who are happy to point you toward the dinner/lunch of your dreams. The best part of Philly
Love it. A must for visitors from out of town . Right across from Jefferson Station go out the Western end.

Awesome place to visit. Lots of great things to eat. I love the Cajun place, Becks. 

This "Terminal" gets bee crowded on Saturday.

Need produce? RTM gotchu. Need meats/seafood? RTM gotchu. Need artisan cheeses? RTM gotchu. Need baked goods? RTM gotchu. Need to eat? RTM gotchu. An indoor market with a variety of merchants to check out for your grocery needs, grabbing a bite/drink, or specialty gifts. A Philly staple!

Iconic tourist location for all food that represents Philly. There are many vendors and a wide variety of food to choose from. Quantity sometime does not equal quality. Seating space is another drawback. It's ok if there one or two but when you are with bigger group it can get difficult to seating.

Destination numeral uno in Philadelphia.  Eclectic nirvana.  Sensory overload!  Definitely a must see place if you're in Philadelphia. Luckily a friend of a friend told us about this place and we took the opportunity to visit.  Fun evening!  Way too much to see or eat in one evening.   Hope to have a chance to come back to Philly again!

Essentially the Chelsea Market of Philadelphia. Such a great place to come to for all foodies. It gets super crowded through as it is the most touristy spot in the city.

Wished this place would be more friendly for people coming in later in the afternoon/evening as they close around 6pm. Some of the stands even close earlier around 3pm which is a letdown to me.
This is a must stop! So much selection to choose from. Dutch Eating Place has the longest line, and great service. Great coffee, juice & food. How does anyone decide with so much here?

Good place to get fresh food at a fairly reasonable price. The "Salmon Spot" as us locals affectionately call it is very popular and usually identified by the lines wrapped around the corner. It goes fast though because everyone typically orders the same thing so they make them really fast. They also have produce stores there (Iovine) that sell fruits and veg for good prices, plenty of specialty stores and culture specific boutiques and markets to keep you busy. Great place to walk around too.

I love the market! There are so many different shops/restaurants to browse around and find exactly what you are searching for. Expect crowds when visiting the terminal as it is the place to be. Come hungry and eat you way around the market! Once you have eaten all the savory meats leave the market with a desert in hand. You won't be disappointed!

I'm gonna warn you, Holy mother of Jesus it's crowded. Beyond crowded, like fire department looks at this as a lost cause crowded. But if you can't come in there and find something delicious to cook at home, eat there, drink, or flowers for the spouse you got some damned issues. I don't want to know people like that! Don't go to philly and miss this.

I really don't know how people decide on just one thing at terminal market.  There are so many great food options.  My first experience my friends brought me here and I didn't know what to expect, didn't know much about Reading Terminal Market but quickly learned.

Note that I've had some experience I would say be prepared for tons of walking and tight spaces due to the crowds in each isle.  Also it can be a bit difficult to find a spot to sit and eat again because it is generally crowded.

Selecting the right meal can be assisted because most venues are really good about giving samples to try.  I usually have one meal and another meal to go for future meals.

The market is in the middle of the city, therefore driving to terminal market and finding parking is not for the faint of heart.  I usually Uber there and have no issues.

A really cool place full of culture. So many options. You can really take your time and browse or run in and grab what you like. Some of the restaurants have small seating areas and there is a few other sections you can stand or sit and eat.

Fun place to meet up with friends and eat till you pass out! I've been here a handful of times before and generally don't get disappointed with the food. 
Since it is a tourist trap expect to pay more then you generally would for the same food elsewhere. 
My friends and I were there for harvest fest where they close down filbert street for some fall activities and vendors. We got some food there and some food inside the market. Overall what we got was pretty good!
Got some seafood paella which has more rice and not that much seafood but still pretty good. Got some pizza that was great!
My husband and our friend split a cheese steak form one place and then a roast pork sandwich from another. Both were great! I got a fruity pebbles donut which was amazeballs. My favorite ice cream place is there and I got a salted caramel pretzel ice cream  delicious !! Def. Want to come back and try other things.
This place is magical. Sensory overload but such a cool collection of foodies. From grocers to restaurants, must stop here for the experience AND food

You can find cuisines from all over the world in this covered market. If you have dietary restrictions you can easily find some gluten free, vegan or dairy free options. The place was really packed when we visited on a Saturday in the middle of October at around 1:30 PM, but it was mostly people waiting in line for their food, not people walking around the market. It is a nice place to buy souvenirs from your visit in Philly, and these sections are by far not as crowded. Definitely worth a visit especially if it is cold outside or a rainy day.

Wow, this is my new favorite place to go shopping.  Unfortunately, it's thousands of miles away from me since I live in California but my sister who lives here recommended that I visit and that I would love it; she was right.  I definitely have to come back for one more shopping trip before I fly back home.  Reading Terminal Market is an indoor market (perfect for a rainy day) and has many places to visit, eat and shop at.  The Market features bakeries (as pictured below), a mini meat and cheese market, a small scaled market that sells a variety of pastas, canned and dried fruits,  a whole produce section with fresh flowers, vegetables and fruits, a gigantic food court (I recommend getting the raspberry banana smoothie at the juice bar yum), and specialty stores too that are from around the world like the Holland shop (all items are designed and made in Holland) and feature some of the most beautiful ornaments and kitchen items I have ever seen!  And not to mention to satisfy your sweet tooth, there are many places to buy fudge, chocolate, cake slices and cupcakes too (oh my goodness)!  The Market can be a little crowded and a little overwhelming at times but this is a must see if you are ever in the area.

This place is so much fun!

So many food vendors and markets that you could literally spend all day and not try everything there is to offer! It can definitely get crowded, especially on the weekends so highly recommend going early.

Love Miller's Pretzels, Dinic's Roast Pork, and Beiler's Doughnuts, just to name a few.

Parking is available across the street at the parking garage. Take your ticket - not credit card - to get it validated for a discount parking price when you purchase something within the market. Ask the vendor to validate your ticket.

Enjoy!

Go there. It's great tourist spot there. A variety of good 
Would suggest the following. 
Produce- Ivoine brothers
Breakfast- Amish 
Ice cream - Bassetts

When in Philly you need to stop by and take a look around. They have tons and tons of different types of foods. The donut shop inside isn't bad at all with tons of different toppings. The cheesesteak shop inside is also very good.
When visiting Philly, Reading Terminal is a must see. Arrive earlier in day to beat some crowds however, various shops, eateries and attractions for every one to enjoy!

Anything and everything you want to eat in one awesome place. Well maintained and very clean. This is an indoor cafeteria. I highly recommend Carmen's cheesesteaks. The donuts are made fresh everyday and melt in your mouth. I wasn't able to try everything but I look forward to visiting again in the future!
This is a foodie's paradise.  I highly recommend this for a full meal or even just a snack.  So many different varieties of food and sweets to choose from.  My advice, go hungry!

This gets 5 stars for the crazy loud fun place.  My husband I split something at about 5 different food places so we could  try more... ribs,  pastrami sandwich, philly cheese steak.   Oh the doughnuts.... and all the beer.  Fun fun fun.  It was Oktoberfest which made it even  more crowded and loud.  A must go in Philly for the atmosphere alone.

We come here very often and it's a must see for people visiting the city. All of the food options are so great and the lines aren't usually too bad. We get vegetables here quite often and have always been satisfied with the food. Would recommend.

So if you are undecided on what to eat... just go to the Reading Terminal Market by the Conventional Center.
We had already ate so we got an Amish Donut that was highly recommend by several people.
We could walk around for hours.
The Sample of Chicken and Shrimp Gumbo from Becks Cajun Cafe was amazing.  I am gonna see if they ship.
The amount of Amish products was amazing.  If we weren't traveling with limited suitcase space I would of bought everything!!!
We settled on some Amish Donuts from Beilers.  Very good and rich!!!!
This is a must when in Philly!!!

Who doesn't give Reading Terminal 5 stars?  Really?  This is Philadelphia's farmer's market and examples of some of the best food we have to offer.  If you are a tourist, you can stop here to get some of everything.  I've also been to 2 Gala events here which were great.

LOVE LOVE LOVE the reading terminal market.   The sights, sounds, food and people make it a wonderful way to spend a few hours.   Met a group of friends which adds to the fun as we all ordered something different and then sat together sharing everything: duck wonton soup, cheesesteak, muffuletta, jambalaya and more.  So many wonderful flavors and spices.     The unique shops, the cooked food, desserts, produce and  they even have a corner with samples of liquor.   Unfortunately I didn't take pictures today but I'll be back again and again.  So next time for the pictures.

This place is by far the pride of Philadelphia when it comes to food. You can find just about everything here and it is all fresh. We went there twice in the last few weeks and each time it was a new adventure.

I love this place so much. If I lived or worked in center city I doubt if I'd eat anywhere else. The selection is just awesome. There are cold and hot sandwich places, buffet style, Cajun, Asian, Indian , Mediterranean, soul food, Italian, pastas, bakeries, seafood and market, coffee shops and butcher shops.

Can't say enough...you just have to go and see for yourself.

This place is great. There's lot of yummy foods to choose from here. There's a grab and go bar for beer and wine and all sorts of foods and sweets. There's also a fresh produce and meats section.
Something for everyone.

Visited for the first time over the weekend. The crowds are crazy and it feels really claustrophobic. We waited in line to eat breakfast at the Dutch Eating Place and grabbed cookies at the 4th Street Bakery. We will definitely be back to try the sandwiches, ice cream, bbq and donuts.

I never want to leave this place. I visited it twice in two days. With tons of stores, markets, places to eat, souvenirs for days, and clean bathrooms, what more do you need. There's not many places to sit, but who cares?! 

Philly Cheesesteak-I went to Carmen's, it was okay, but next time I'll try somewhere better

First Ice cream shop in America, Basset's--a must go!

Don't be overwhelmed by the crowds, you'll get through it. Just enjoy it and have fun.
Lots to of places to eat.  The place just does not seem too clean to me.  It is very popular.  Anything you feel like eating is here.
Love this place! It's always crowded thou. So many different types of foods in this one place.

This was A-day and an adventure I got to come to Philadelphia for 5 hours and I took did the most  I could in a short amount of time. The Reading Market  Is an adventure in itself there is so much to choose from every food group to choose from.  When you walk in it is an amazing treasure hunt if you want something sweet to eat something with fish something with philly cheese steak, chicken, soups, chocolate whoa did I say chocolate oh my goodness everything.  If you ever come to Philadelphia walk to the market street and 12Th and go visit this adventure you  Will not be disappointed eat to your heart's content.

This was my first visit, and let me say, WOW! There is something for everyone, and the quality is outstanding.  This place can be packed and overwhelming, but don't let that get you.  Staff handles the crowds well, so there is no need to worry about long waits. We went to Dinic's (pork sandwich), The Original Turkey (thanksgiving sandwich), and Sweet Nina's (nutter butter banana pudding).  Everything waa flavorful and tasty.  Hope to come back soon!

We had such a fun time here. We were visiting from out of town and wanted cheesesteaks. Of course we were on a time crunch so the traditional Pat/Gino's weren't an option so we decided on Reading. It was perfect! I had been here a few years ago and went again on this trip. They have everything from cheesesteaks to fresh fish to butchers to Amish baked goods. Something for everyone!

We had a wonderful time coming here and enjoying shopping and lunch. Specifically, we fell in love with Fox and sons fancy corn dogs. We eat gluten free and we were able to eat a corndog as well as a funnel cake! Oh, and fried cookies! That never happens for us! It was incredible and you could not tell that it was gluten-free at all! I can't say enough good things about this vendor! 
It is a little crowded in the market and there is a lot of vendors packed in there, I would recommend going down each row one at a time otherwise, you may miss a lot and you get turned around.

THIS is a place where literally everyone is at. The choices of places to eat in here is endless and theres so many things to look at. Just to name a few, you've huge cuts of BBQ meats, sausages, sandwiches, flowers... ice cream, a grocery store, candy shop and much more. Everything related to food and drink can be found in here. Literally any ethnicity, from asian food to mediterranean food, they got it. From coffee to candy, they got it. 

This place is a foodie's paradise. I was in town for a convention and Reading Terminal was within walking distance. Unfortunately, the big downside of this place is that its entirely too crowded during the rush. Shoulder to shoulder and human body traffic on the grid layout of the shops reminds me of downtown traffic. 

Will comeback next time I'm around. Really cool place.
A great historical market with tons of good food! Loved visiting it and enjoyed everything we had there!

Redding Terminal has everything! Its usually very crowded but worth the trip! They also have lots of homemade items that are great for gifts! The fudge booth is amazing! And they have lots of fresh fruit and veggies!
So many options that it is going to take weeks to try all of them. Only tried Dutch eating place so far and that was delicious!

This Location has always been my favorite, for many years! Sooooo... many " stops " with red n' green, with many selections and varieties all around!!!! 
I just simply love the Reading Terminal Market. 
They have all that you expect!

This place was packed when I went, I don't like crowed areas but why not give it a try, they had a lot of small restaurants, bakeries, groceries, and convinced stores u name it, we decided to try a philly cheesesteak because why not we are at philly and must give it a try. While my husband made the line I looked for seat u really have to wait for people to finish eating to be seated, if not you won find a sit, the Philly cheesesteak was delicious and mouth watering, there's other places to try but we really went with that. And left too crowed and I could not hold up a table while others are waiting, not very nice eat and leave. enjoy !

This is probably one of the best tourist spots in Philadelphia. There is such a huge variety of vendors offering different foods including sandwiches, salads, coffee, desserts, and even a butcher section to buy fresh cut meat. It was honestly so hard to choose what food I wanted to eat because there was so much I wanted to try!! Additionally, the prices are all very reasonable for the portions too so it was so worth it!! I tried the philly cheesesteaks on one day and the second day I went back and got a coffee and a breakfast bagel sandwich that I still think about all the time. 

Yes, it can get quite crowded with all the towards and the narrow hallways, but the experience is all so worth it. All the staff is incredibly friendly and patient even with the high capacity of people waiting to eat the yummy foods.

I have to say I'm jealous that I don't live in Philadelphia so I can visit this place more often. Or maybe that's good for my wallet. From groceries, to restaurants, snacks to crafts you can find it here. It's a little confusing to navigate if you're new to the place. It's almost like a maze and it can be overwhelming. I got some really delicious cookies from the 4th street cookie company. I'll definitely come back here when I'm in town again.

I was recently in Philadelphia and was staying not far from here. This is what an urban market is all about. There are numerous stalls with foods of all different types. Worth spending the time walking around to take it all in - some places have counter seating and there are also tables in key places throughout the market. You can also take a number of items to go. It will get crowded during lunch hours, so plan accordingly. I was grateful for having something this close by with a good variety of food since I was eating in between meetings. I will review a couple of the stalls I ate from as well - but this is definitely a place not to be missed in Philadelphia!

Very cool! Tons of sandwich shops, BBQ, Amish restaurants. All this while there are seafood markets, meat markets and a grocery store sprinkled about. Such a cool experience, if you want it, it's here.
This place is unbelievable.  They have everything.  Whether you actually buy anything or not, it's worth spending some time here.

Sooo much to experience here! For me, it's like the taste of Philly! I found a variety of local foods that were all amazing! We had dinner at Molly Murray's and enjoyed some fantastic beers, chili fries, beet salad and empanadas! The service was fast, friendly and professional! They had a very interesting menu with something special for everyone!

We also enjoyed some delicious coffee at Old City Coffee!

Reading Terminal is always my favorite place to head to when I'm in Chinatown or at work. Great vendors and stands with wonderful food! Also love the groceries you can buy at OK Produce and Iovine Produce. The weekends can be very crowded, especially during the holidays! But during the morning on weekdays, it's not so bad. I do recommend getting a roast pork sandwich at Dinic's and a few donuts at Beiler's! Great ice cream at Miller's Twist, as well as their pretzels.

Probably my favorite place in all of Philly despite the fact it's almost always crowded to some extent. I work right down the street and Beck's and Keven Parker are two spots I frequently visit while there. A definite must for anyone in Philadelphia.

This is a great marketplace. There is a great variety of restaurants and shops. I spent a lot of money here. Watch out for the crowds. Lines can get very long at peak hours, it can be difficult and frustrating to navigate. I was with someone who gets anxiety in crowds and we had to leave, so take note of that. Come outside of peak lunch times if crowds are an issue for you. Some of us returned later to eat and I went back later to do some shopping. I found great gifts for my family, instead of the usual souvenir shops. I wish there was more seating and it would be nice if some of the food stalls stayed open a little later at night to accommodate people coming from the Convention Center later in the evening. That said, if I'm back in Philly, I will return.

The Reading Terminal Market is by far my favorite place to go.  Yes, it get's busy....very busy with tourist that don't understand our "keep on moving" attitude.  There are almost always line at every vendor stall.  But I can't think of many places with a better cross section of not only locals but tourists.  

Start on the outside and you'll undoubtedly see some entertainment, some that is from a performer and some that is from just a normal person that keeps this city colorful!  The second you step inside your senses are immediately inundated with beautiful smells, sights of almost every type of food/cuisine imaginable and the sound of commerce and excitement.  

Some of my favorites are DiNic's, get a pork sandwich with broccoli rabe and provolone.  Swing by Martin's Sausages and grab some of the best chorizo I've ever had (my wife loves the chicken sausages).  Molly Malloy's is always available if you need some libation to take the edge off. 

No matter where you go you will love it!

All Different selections of food. We tried Bassetts Ice cream and it was delicious. But three kids cones for $15! Wow! But they gave you a lot of ice cream and it was great. We also went to Kamals spot that had a refreshing drink the lemonana for $5. We had scallops from UMI a 1/2 pound for $13. Amazing. It was a cool spot overall with a variety of food, but make sure you have your money ready! It was our first time, and we will be back.

The Reading Terminal Market is the first spot I went to on my first Philly trip. It was a short walk from my hotel and really gave you a sense of what to expect from Philly. The amazing smelling coffee from Old City Coffee and the delicious looking baked goods as far as the eye can see. Plenty of options for food from burgers, to cheese steaks to fish. There's also a fresh produce section as well a a few gift shops. I came here twice during my stay and it definitely has a little something for everyone.

It's just a tourist trap. I can never find a good place to eat. Food is mediocre at best. Ive tried burgers, burritos, pretzels, breakfast. But the desserts are excellent. Oh and the grilled cheese place is .  But the building is always insanely packed. I'd rather go to the Bourse food court. A little bougier

Every time we come to Philly the Terminal Market is a must stop for us. The entire family looks forward to the amazing Pork sandwich from Tommy Dinic's. They are delicious. There is always a line but it moves fast. There are so many food options on the market. There is definitely something for everyone

RTM is a philadelphia staple. You can find all types of cuisine, bakeries/coffee shops, grocery, small shops, and even a diner. Whatever you are in the mood for you can find it here. If you are lost go to their 12th and Filbert entrance and speak to the front desk staff. There are also copies of the RTM map. Take the map and explore the whole place. You can easily spend all day here just eating your way through Philadelphia. 

Keep in mind lunch hours here are insane. You have people coming here during their work lunch and then the hundreds of thousands of tourists who are in town as well. It is busy busy BUSY. Plan accordingly. 

The entire front left side of the market (the side along 12th and Arch) is closed on Mondays. Welcome to the city!

If you are dieting, not the place for you!!! Love the specialty donuts, great places for dining for breakfast, lunch or dinner. The Amish sells their wares and baked/cooked foods. Great place to purchase meats, fresh seafood, deli meats and fresh produce.
Obsessed lol it was food heaven for me I was like a kid in a candy store lol can't wait to come back my friends are going to love all the food and dessert options

Love Reading Market. Lots of different foods to choose from but DiNics is one of the best sandwiches in the city. Make a stop for dessert as well with lots of different choices. Great to visit on a Saturday if you can avoid the lines and busyness.
Pretty much everything you could want in one place. Tons of energy, awesome food, gift shops, restaurants, produce; it has it all. Must stop when in Philly.

Do you have a full afternoon to do nothing? Are you hungry while doing that nothing? Whether you are with a group of friends or by yourself you could easily get lost for hours in the many treasures of Reading Terminal. There's so much to explore; food, produce, crafts, jewelry, cheese, chocolate, pastries. You want take out...or dine in? From Chinese to Dutch cuisine, they are ready to tap dance all over your taste buds(depending on where you go). Make sure you have nothing to do because you're only gonna kick yourself if you try coming on your cute little 30 minute lunch or right before something you need to be on time for...lol it's like a rabbit hole....you just keep falling to goodness. If you've never been be prepared for crowds and long lines. But the wait is worth. There's metered/street parking and the train, both regional and the MFL are across the street. So GO!! Discover for yourself. No sense in me telling you when you can experience this wonder for yourself!
Awesome place! There is a reason that this also a Tourist Attraction. The quality food places speak for themselves! 5 Stars.
Doesn't get better than this people. If you go to philly, you must go here. Haven't hit a spot here yet that isn't amazing!

Love coming here :) so many goodies. It is very bustling so if you're one who doesn't like waiting in lines, you'll have to suck it up! It's definitely worth it! All the baked goods, cute crafts, food, snacks, fresh produce, and service are great! Definitely an awesome market to bring the family to and enjoy your time together. The choices here are endless! Definitely need to go back and try them all.
I really enjoyed this place lots of great eats within the same building. It's not overtly large which makes it overwhelming. There is a wide variety of places to eat here.

Great local spot for tourists and people who live here. Bunch of mom and pop spots clustered in one tight space. There are so many different spots to eat. You could literally go restaurant hopping to each one. The place is packeD all the time and I only wish the place was bigger and opened for longer hours!

Lots of variety & options in one place, but can become extremely crowded which is not really conducive to eating a nice and relaxing meal...often have to wait/hunt for a seat/table. Many of the places are over-priced, but it's one of those experiences when exploring Center City to do at least once. The produce markets do have good prices/deals and can find good deal at some of the seafood merchants. Parking offered at a discount or free at nearby garage...gotta check w them...I forget exact terms. At the end of the day the Dutch merchant puts many if the bakery items for sale. People literally wait in LONG lines for many if the merchants soooo something to be said for the demand...especially for the Amish Dutch food and Bieler's doughnuts.
There are so many things to choose from here! But make sure you get some of Sweet Ninas banana pudding. You won't regret it!

Awesome place to visit when in Philly!! There is a huge variety of vendors here serving all types of things from gyros, to cheesesteaks, to burgers to Chinese food. Fresh made donuts and chocolates are here to satisfy any sweet tooth. While each place has reasonably priced items, you can find yourself running up quite a tab because you will want to sample everything there is to offer here!

This is the perfect place to take visiting friends and family members for a lively meal/activity and a taste of Philadelphia's unique foodie cuisine. It's chaotic and introverts need to take deep breaths.  But it's worth it.

There are deep fried cheese curds for sale at one of the vendors; I don't remember the name, but they're a central PA-based company. It is one of the most delicious things I've ever eaten.

One of the city's highlights!   Great wide variety of everything on can think of.   Lots of food places to eat, vendors to choose from for retail products as well. 

Highly recommend:

Carmens cheesesteak 
The cookie place (forgot name) but so darn delicious 
The Dutch sweet shop 
By George (great pizza and sandwiches) 


Honestly it just really depends on what you're in the mood for.  Warning! You will be overwhelmed your first visit here.

The place is have breakfast before going sightseeing in Philly.
You can spend the day here.
We ordered breakfast from the Dutch place. Blueberries pancakes ( large stack) the serving is large enough for two. We also ordered a western omelet it came with some buttery rye bread. Our bill was less than $20.
You must visit this market when you come to Philadelphia.
Love this place, although if you don't like crowds don't go here on the weekend. Great lunch spot when on Jury Duty or if you want to try some Philly staples. Great place to find fresh meats.

I love it here! There's always something to see or take in and it's great for people watching. The best time to visit is during the week, as it's less crowded and you have more of a chance of getting a table. Some of my favorite counters are Old City Coffee, Beilers donuts, and Four Seasons juice bar. If you park in any of the garages that offer discounted parking near by, bring your ticket in to be validated for a parking discount.  

The only downside is that it gets so crowded on the weekends you can barely move around and it closes at 6 pm. Also, many of the Amish counters are not open on Sunday.
Such a fun and interesting place! Lots of neat finds in this market. I bought a few souvenirs as well as some food. I highly recommend checking it out if you're in town!
One of my favorite places to eat in the city. If you are a foodie this is a must!! Great place to get fresh produce, seafood and meats as well

By far one of the coolest places in all of Philly! It was so good I went there twice in my few day visit! I wish I had gotten the names of the two places I went to as they were fabulous! I got a bagel sandwich that was a BLT with cream cheese on an everything bagel and I'm still craving another one ever since. 

The second meal was at the classic looking diner. We sat at the bar and I had a sausage egg and cheese sandwich that hit the spot perfectly!

This market is like sense overload. Being from Seattle and used to Pike's Place I was so happy to find this place. There's rows and rows of various vendors where you can find any food you may be craving! There's also fresh produce and a ton of fresh desserts that will for sure make your mouth water. I definitely recommend  walking all the rows before making a decision of where you may want to eat!

I could spend hours in here! It is so easy to find and you're in for a treat that will appeal to all of your senses. Inside you'll find endless cuisine options, handmade goods, cheese shops, butchers, local spirit tasting, a sports bar, and sweets. 

My suggested plan of attack is to start at Molly Malloy's where you can grab a local brew then sip, shop, and eat your way through it all! I loved our my meal at Pearl's. My boo and I shared a seafood platter and it was one of the best meals I've had this year. All of the seafood was perfectly cooked and tender, not too salty and super fresh. We also did some major damage at Downtown Cheese Shop.  And yes you can sample anything you want to buy. We even sampled some truffle cheeses before purchasing. They were very generous and attentive. 

Plan on spending a good bit of time here if you've never been. You will not be disappointed. Everyone I dealt with was incredibly friendly and helpful! It was the highlight of my visit!

European market - lite. Has a similar style and feel to some of the great European markets, in the sense that there's a good mixture of grocery and prepared food stands. However, it's smaller than some of those markets. For instance when I comes to either meat, fish, poultry, vegetables etc. there aren't a ton of a options per category.

I always bring family and friends to this place when they visit!! So many delicious food options, including local favorites like Beiler's donuts. A fun experience to get a taste of Philadelphia food and culture!

I could stay a whole weekend in just this market!! WHOA. How cool of a place, with so many little amazing shops to walk around in, I can't tell you how much time I wish I had! Ended up stopping by a few shops to get some yummy treats, but I wish I hadn't have eaten for a week so I could eat everything in sight!! I do wish there was a little bit of an organization of where places were inside and that was coordinated a little better; for example: meat places in one corner, bakery in another, etc. but overall I had a wonderful time here and I wish I never would have left. 

Honestly told my best friend that I am coming back to Philly just to eat here again... among other things, but yes it was AMAZING.

This place is amazing.  It reminds me of a similar place we have in LA called "The Farmers Market".  It is an indoor, covered collection of mostly eateries and some stalls that sell gifts and other items.  I think you can pretty much find anything you want to eat here, from every type of cuisine, to dessert, to a smoothie, etc.  They also have a market where you can buy fresh produce and some groceries, as well as several meat markets, delis, and more.  I was honestly overwhelmed with the selection here.  Since I came here after eating lunch, I only grabbed a juice to sip on, but they also have many vendors that provide samples of their dishes.  I would highly recommend checking this place out if you are a foodie!

This place is one of my favorite foodie spots! I've been here numerous times and this place is still one of favorite places to go while in Philly!  The variety of shops and food options are so vast that you could spend hours there. Shops ranging from homemade goods, souvenirs, candy, bakeries, donuts, cookies, fresh vegetable and fruits, cheeses, meats...I could go on forever. And also a variety of food places so everyone's tastes buds will be fulfilled even the pickiest of eaters. The only unfortunate thing is that a lot of the Amish owned shops aren't open on Sundays. So a lot of those sections are blocked off since they are closed. We had gotten there a little later in the day so the cookie shop had a sale on their cookies for $1 each! It was def a steal. Also stopped by Termini Bros. and got some freshly filled cannolis! 

Reading Terminal is def a great stop if you're going to Philly! Though we didn't get to eat there--there is a seated food court section for everyone to enjoy your meal. This place is also perfect one stop grocery shopping!

I was not so sure what I wanted to eat that day and so I was looking for a place with a wide variety of food to choose from. Walking into rtm I felt like I was emerging myself into a dark whole of culture, every stand offering a unique experience and great quality! Seafood, cheese, marmalades, sandwiches, donuts, etc. Great food and ambiance.
A little over hyped place. It's a regular market in a closed fitting with a couple good eating options!

Just grazed my way through the Reading Market if you are from out of town it is a must stop for your time in Philly.  We had breakfast in the Dutch Eating Place again and if you don't know what scrapple is have some with an egg or the Apple Dumpling the place is the best.  If you miss breakfast try a roast pork sandwich from De nici's another city favorite plus the hundred of other food and merchants spellings their wears at the market.  I am gladI live here in Philly.

This place reminded me of the grand central market in L.A. so it's most def a must stop here either for shopping, drinking and definitely eating! Or take some food so you can take a stroll down to Love park which is only a few blocks away. This place was hella crowded but I see why. For sure a busy place not only for tourists  for locals as well.

Love this wonderful conglomerate of eateries and shops! Quite literally, there's something for everyone here-lunch, dinner, dessert, coffee, shopping and socializing-you simply cannot ask for more in a market such as this. In all my travels, by far, the best indoor market  anywhere.

Reading Terminal Market is a Mecca for foodies and shoppers alike.

This place has everything, from butchers to bakeries, to olive oil emporiums, to bars, to gifts and cookbooks, to prepared foods and farmers markets....you cannot go wrong when coming here.  There is something for everyone!  

When I come to Reading Terminal, I usually need a game plan, otherwise I will spend hours walking around and exploring everything they have.  I certainly have my favorite spots, but I like to try something new or something different every time I come as well.

If you haven't had a Sandwich from DiNic's, make sure you stop by.  I also love a good corndog from Fox and Son's Fancy Corn Dogs.  My favorite butcher is Giunta's Prime Shop, and I can never go without grabbing some ice cream or a Beiler's Donut. 

I would also highly suggest checking out the cheese vendors and chocolate/candy vendors!  

Honestly, you cannot go wrong here, I could easily go on and on about each vendor I have tried, but frankly, this review would be way too long if I did that!

I personally like to come at off times to avoid the lunch rush, it can get very crowded and overwhelming.  But coming on an off time during the week helps with that.

The best thing to do if you have never come before is make sure you have lots of time to spare.  I suggest walking around and trying a bunch of different things.  I also suggest coming with an idea of what you need and then trying something new each time you come.  The possibilities  are practically endless!  A Philadelphia staple, make sure to check our Reading Terminal Market if you can!

Tons of options to pick the food anything you can think of if you can even go grocery shopping inside get out of the weather horrible parking good seating just in case you want to sit down and eat your food I enjoy people watching here

Amazing location with options for days!

DiNic's is my personal favorite, always providing freshly made food!

"If you love it so much, why don't you marry it" Got married in it, close enough!

One of my favorite places in the world. 

Favorites to take home: sausages from Martin', burgers from Haltemann's, cleaned whole fish from Golden Fish market, fresh pasta from By George, Amish jerky, Victory Thirst Quencher from Lancaster Dairy

Favorites to eat: DiNic's sandwiches, Hershel's sandwiches, Dutch Eating Place apple dumplings, Rib Stands boneless rib sandwich,

This is always one of the first places I bring friends and family who visit my boyfriend and me in Philly.  Whether you want to go for ice cream, cookies, Chinese Food, Italian, whatever your craving is, Reading Terminal Market has it.  You won't be disappointed.  It's usually pretty crowded, so expect not a lot of room around you when exploring the market.  

In terms of food, I've tried peking duck rolls from one of the Chinese stands, they're fantastic & affordable.  The ice cream parlor is great too.  I enjoy going to the stores in the back corner where there are a bunch of kitchen gadgets.  I have yet to try the famous donuts that there's always a line for, but I will one of these days!  I highly recommend.  Tons of food options, perfect place to buy a gift for the holidays.

The best food options in one place ever. Best farmers market. I honestly love the market. Find something new every time I go inside and I'm there often. Great atmosphere. Definitely a hot spot and always busy.

I super duper love this place, you can find whatever you have the taste for here! Amazing cheese steaks, carved turkey, fresh meat and veggies, ice cream....you name it! This is my absolute favorite place to go to when I am downto

Interesting market that seems like a tourist-trap feat. the requisite higher than normal  prices - but that doesn't mean the food isn't still good! I've come back multiple times and each vendor I've visited has been a positive experience.

Very cool spot, reminds me of any other open market I've been to similar in New York & Chicago. Everything you can buy you didn't think you'd need, haha. From sushi, to barbecue, vegan places and candy shoppes galore. Don't forget the cheesesteaks- this is Philly after all! Expect to pay between $15-17 for a fully loaded sandwich.
OMG, so many amazing places to eat.  The donuts, cakes, sandwiches, omelets are amazing anywhere you choose to eat.  If you are in Downtown Philly, this place is worth visiting.

A friend visited me from New Hampshire wanting you see landmarks in Philadelphia. I took her to the Reading terminal and it did not disappoint. We bought cookies and cheese steaks. I showed her where I regularly buy vegetables and meats. These are always well priced and fresh. The variety of foods and merchandise bring me back again and again
Extremely busy but a nice place to play tourist in. Lost of good options and I'm really big on organic food so I'm glad they have a few options here like that.

Went to the Dutch Counter. Not sure that is the actual name but it is an Amish place that makes fresh homemade foods. We had breakfast and they had the most amazing homemade strawberry jam. So delicious.

This is a fun place if you are a foodie and need to buy supplies, at the same time its full of shops and Kiosks where you can eat and drink while you shop. If you are visiting Philly its a must, perfect day to spend an afternoon.

If it wasn't for my friend dragging me out, I think I would have spent my whole time in Philly at this market. Whether you want breakfast, lunch, dessert - this is the place! The place gets super crowded, but there are so many vendors that even with the dozen amount of people in there you don't have to wait as long in line. My favorite thing from the market was the espresso shot in a chocolate waffle cone and tomato basil cheesesteak. The only think I disliked is that it closes so early :(

NOT SAFE FOR PERSONS ON THE SPECTRUM 
Sensory OVERLOAD no place to be quiet 
THIS PLACE WILL CAUSE MELTDOWNS!!!!!

As a professional chef I seek places to acquire the necessary ingredients.
This place would be great IF THE TOURISTS were not there. OVER CROWDED 
Reading terminal was the central hub for decades NOW Meh.
I only go If I can not find my ingredients elsewhere
Did I mention all the TOURISTS!!!!!
my god! they are there wandering like lost sheep stopping midway gawking and pointing.
Heres a thought GET THE HELL OUTTA OUR WAY WERE SHOPPING HERE!!!
It needs more space for people to actually walk
claustrophobia warning!!!!
Not a place for young children or NEURO Sensitive persons IT IS A SENSORY NIGHTMARE
Very packed every time I've been there and that wasn't just weekend days. I'd recommend coming during the week and at times where people don't have to work.

My favorite place to go to eat in Philadelphia. Individual vendors sell every style of food and I spend half my time exploring what interests me that day.
Furthermore, you can find local flavors to taste or give to others. A one stop shop and historic.

One of my favorite places in Philly! This Farmer's market provides a wide range of options inside, and is a place where locals can get groceries, meat and seafood, but also where everyone can have a meal. There are lots of choices of restaurants and cuisines, including Philly cheesesteaks, Chinese food, burgers, ice cream, smoothies, Middle Eastern food, and many others. This is a great place to visit when in Philly's centre.
Place is a foodies dream come true! Lots of variety and the people who work their are really nice... I LOVE THIS PLACE!!!!

SUPER busy inside always but a Philadelphia staple. A diverse array of food and desserts. I sometimes even go grocery shopping there to get produce, spices, and meats. My favorite place in reading terminal is definitely Beiler's Donuts. Their blueberry fritters are the bees knees! Always a long line but one of my favorite desserts in the city.

This place is overwhelming with so many places to eat, so there are so many smells. Some of my favorites there are Beiler's (amazing donuts!!) and Meltkraft (delicious grilled cheese!!). It's a cool experience to check out, but not my favorite place to go for a bite. I like showing people around as it is a staple for Philly. Definitely worth it to check it out once and see if it's for you! It has food to eat from all different cuisines, something for everyone.
I just love the crazy crowds and circling the market trying to decide on what to eat.

If you only have time to see one place in Philly, this is it. Almost everything here is absolutely delicious. Ice cream, donuts, pretzels, chocolate body parts, cheesesteaks, all of the Philly classics and then some. 

Everything here is fabulous - I only wish it stayed open later. Make sure to get there early if you're planning to go for dinner since they usually close at 6:00 pm. If you are on a limited timeline, I would highly recommend stopping by for breakfast to get crepes, donuts, and coffee. The lunch and snack options are really good too, but the donuts are just a must try. I even prefer them over Federal Donuts. They stuff and ice them fresh on an assembly line for you to watch while you wait to order. 

The best approach to managing the chaos of this place is to just get something from everywhere and split it with other people. Every vendor is there for a reason - because people love them! You truly can't go wrong with anything you pick.

Reading Terminal Market is a great place to eat and see, the only cons were, it is always very very packed, and another is, people, (not the employees), are very rude!! 


    Besides that it is a great place to eat and see!
It's an interesting place, lots to eat. If we didn't have similar at home, it would have been 5 stars :)

What a unique place with some truly great places to eat. Every time we go we find something new and interesting from the local counties peddling their products to the staple restaurants representing themselves. This place is definitely a hustle and Bustle place we you have to be patient when its busy as there are lines but always worth the wait. I have never had a bad or negative experience at the terminal.

If you are in the area and have the time, go at least once. There is always a large selection of high quality food of all types. If it was 25 years ago, I would also say that the prices were low, but that is not the case now. The market has been discovered by high income people, who live nearby in the city. They are willing to pay high prices for the convenience and selection. I was there a few days ago, buying cannolis at Termini's. I passed by one of the butcher stalls, where the meats cost twice the price I have paid elsewhere.

What a gem of a place to be lost in, there are so many choices and finds here and I tried walking the entire block to find one good eats and realized there are too many places I want to try but with so little time. I ended up with fried chicken and snacks along the way put of the terminal. 

There are over 50 unique eats here and the best place to be stranded while missing a train. There were not too many tables to sit at, you have to be lucky and grab a seat. I would recommend this place to everyone who can't decide what you want to eat but have time on your hand to find a gem.

Very traditional place, everyone advised me to visit it for food. It's not like as I expected. However, some places do have great good. I will advise to pass by but not like to drive and spent time trying to find the unlimited meal. Overpriced in general.

The market is about 5 mins away from our hotel and it just makes everything so convenient. We tried the the roast pork sandwiches from DiNic's , it's good, but I'd enjoy it more if it's with roast beef. There's a long line there but moves pretty fast. We had juice at the Four Seasons Juice Bar, it's very delicious and the girls there are very friendly as well. We also got to try some donuts from Beiler'a Donuts, the price is so reasonable and the donut itself is very tasty. There are so much to try at the market, hopefully we will come back another time to try more food.

I really liked this place! Besides the lack of seating available - it gets pretty packed and it's hard to find a seat - there's really nothing to complain about!

There's a wide range of food and goods available to buy. I was able to buy a lot of things for my friends' birthdays who are coming up. They sell many different things - clothes, bags, candles/bees wax products, cooking utensils, books - and have food from different global cultures. I tried a vegan chocolate chip cookie from the Flying Monkey (I think?) and it was pretty good! This is a good place to come on a cold or rainy day.

Sssooooo busy!!! But so
Many different food vendors. The line for the donuts was long but went fast.( BEILERS). They had pickles on the other side too!!! Now those were great. We chose the kosher ones and they were prefect in taste and crunch!! The line for sandwiches @ DiNiCi's wrapped around the corner, so we had to see what the hype was about. We ordered roast beef it was ok, but guy in front of me swore by the brisket sandwich. He had ordered 3 of them. Our sandwich was just ok. Flavor wasn't fantastic. But the line went fast. Lastly we visited HATVILLE deli shop for meat and that was great. Got roasted turkey, apple smoked bacon and chipped beef( taste almost like pastrami, but leaner in my opinion)

I wanted to like this place but it was so ridiculously crowded, with barely any space to move, and most stores having lines that were way to long. Siting is very very limited. Unless you're going during less busy times, I'm not sure it's worth it.

Best Place to Visit in Philadelphia! So many vendors to explore and enjoy their offerings. Great for breakfast, brunch, lunch or happy hour! My favorite places are the Amish Market, Cookie Company and Gastropub for bites. Also, they do events on occasion so definitely check out their events calendar when you are in the area.

So many options that I can never decide what to eat.  Both times I've walked around completely overwhelmed, and left empty handed.  I'll try again someday, but I will research particular places so I know exactly where to go, and what to get.
Fabulous food!  Quite a variety.  The pastries are delicious.

This is foodie heaven!  Was amazed at the vast food variety and aroma - every corner is just brimming with something new and delicious.  Its arranged like a grid - but if you are a foodie, you can easily spend lots of time in here.  Has every type of food / cuisine you can imagine.  Wish they had more of these places in each state - really gives you a good taste of the city of Philadelphia under one roof.

Pros - too much to list : lots of variety, every type of cuisine, aroma, decor, seating : just amazing!

Cons - parking ( you have to pay for parking : park in deck because street parking is near impossible )

Overall - MUST see / thing to do when you come to Philly ( especially if you are a foodie )

Tip - park in the parking deck ( located near by ), street parking is extremely difficult as it is in the heart of downtown Philly.  Lots of things to see & do around the area ( lots of stores, chinatown, etc.)

I like this place they have a famous donut place and ribs but oh my how dirty the whole building is. Super hard to find available tables and chairs. Especially clean once. Bathrooms, don't even ask. Wish they had more staff available at each designated area for Quick cleanups!
Busy at peak times but often cheaper than the local Chinese grocery, and more exciting too

I LOVE a great food hall, and this was one. So many vendors and some much to choose from. I can't get enough of this place. There is a very large amishcommunity with fresh goods. I suggest you walk the whole things before deciding what to eat.
